headline: World’s Most Expensive Mint Julep Cup
text: If you watched the Kentucky Derby post position draw Wednesday on ESPN2, perhaps you caught a glimpse of the internationally famous sports artist LeRoy Neiman — how could you miss his mustache? — scribbling away in the crowd.

headline: Jagr’s Last Stand?
text: Aside from the injury to Sean Avery and the steep odds against a comeback from a 3-0 series deficit to the Penguins, the biggest issue hovering over the Rangers in Thursday night’s Game 4 is whether or not it is Jaromir Jagr’s last stand in New York.

headline: Auction Season’s Highs and Lows
text: Carol Vogel picks the best and worst of the season.

headline: Winding Up as a Season Winds Down
text: O.K., the first all-English Champions League final is less than three weeks away. It will be played in Moscow’s Luzhniki Stadium on May 21. (Note that the stadium’s artificial turf, which was used for last year’s Euro 2008 qualifier between Russia and England, has been covered with the real thing for the match.) But there are some other loose ends around the globe, some that do not necessarily show the game at its best.

headline: The End of the Gate, Not the End of the World
text: The fact that Big Brown will break from Post 20 doesn’t change my perception of his chances in the Derby. Richard Dutrow Jr. is putting his colt out there for all to see. No excuses now; he can’t get pinched between horses coming out of the gate, and chances are quite good that he won’t get touched at all with the speedy Gayego, who breaks just inside, figuring to go quickly forward rather than sideways.

headline: Into the Amazon
text: In the Amazon jungle in Ecuador, Nicholas D. Kristof encounters an unusual pair of activists who are fighting to preserve the rainforest.

headline: Regent’s Park building getting luxury residential makeover
text: >Cornwall Terrace

headline: Your Comments on Thursday’s Amazon Column
text: My Thursday column (accompanied by this video) is the second part from the Ecuadorian Amazon, about the work of a remarkable American businessman and a former Amazonian hunter in promoting education in the region, as a way to raise living standards and preserve the rain forest. You can find more about their work — everything from their eco-lodge to their chocolate company — at the Yachana website.

headline: More Workplace Lessons From the Canine Set
text: A few weeks ago, when I blogged about working alongside my new puppy, Sinatra, I asked readers to tell me about their experiences of working with dogs. (Please excuse my unintentional discrimination; I should have been more inclusive of the array of furry, and probably nonfurry, workplace companions out there.) I received many photos of pets engaged in adorable (or just lazy) antics around the office. But the most productive pet I heard about was Bella, the boxer, who is listed as director of goodwill at the public relations firm, Galvin Communications, in Portland, Ore.

headline: Justice Dept. Will Share Interrogation Opinions
text: WASHINGTON  In a partial concession to Congressional pressure, the Bush administration agreed on Wednesday to show the Senate and House Intelligence Committees secret Justice Department legal opinions justifying harsh interrogation techniques that critics call torture.

headline: Lacerated Spleen Sidelines Avery
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The news that Rangers forward Sean Avery had sustained a lacerated spleen and was hospitalized rippled through the Rangers practice Wednesday morning, another hurdle thrown in front of a team facing elimination in its playoff series against Pittsburgh.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,046 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: CURRENTS | A Chance to Shop Till You Help
text: Design on a Dime, the annual sale to benefit Housing Works thrift shops, which raise money for poor New Yorkers with H.I.V. or AIDS, begins next Thursday evening. All furnishings will be sold at 60 to 80 percent off retail, and vignettes will be created by 30 designers, including Jamie Drake, Thom Filicia and James Huniford. An opening-night cocktail party ($200 a ticket) will be an early opportunity to shop and to take part in a silent auction of photographs. Admission to the rest of the sale, on May 9 and 10, is free. At the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, housingworksauctions.com or (212) 645-8111.

headline: The B.C.S. Takes a Pass, Again
text: For a system originally designed to produce a definitive winner, the Bowl Championship Series can't win.

headline: Arizona Adds Digit to License Plates to Keep Up With Growth
text: As people have rushed to Arizona in the past decade like water to a drain, the state has faced problems familiar to bigger states  crowded schools, urban sprawl and jammed freeways.

headline: Open-Toed Fetishes (and More)
text: ON the subway ride to Christian Louboutin, so far up the Upper East Side as to be in what I call “Canada,” I was getting my mind blown by Guy Debord’s “Society of the Spectacle”:

headline: Step Right Up, Kids (and Thank the Dance Gods You’re Not Elephants)
text: With Jerome Robbins’s death in 1998, roles in his ballets and shows began to be taken by performers who had never met him. Ten years later, we’ve already entered the era when his ballets are danced by those born after his lifetime. Enter the School of American Ballet.

headline: Reprise: The Fifth Avenue Ballad of Pale Male and Lola
text: April is the cruelest month.

headline: Door Keeper on 79th St. Keeps Stories of Queens
text: Daytime and evening shifts are busy ones for an Upper East Side doorman  hailing cabs, helping with luggage  but how does the late-night doorman pass the wee hours, once quiet descends upon the lobby?

headline: A Beach Where Discretion Is More Than Just Advised
text: LONG BEACH TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The New Jersey surfer defies stereotype. He may work as a carpenter or as an eye surgeon. Could be in his 20s or late 50s. He’s able to “rip the swell” in water temperatures of 50 degrees for up to six hours, then hop on a one-speed bicycle with a board and steer one-handed. Or no-handed, while doing that signature thumb-and-pinky sign.

headline: Pellicano on Pellicano: He Was No Mastermind
text: LOS ANGELES  Defiant and colorful to the end, the accused Hollywood wiretapper Anthony Pellicano told jurors in his racketeering trial Wednesday that he was no criminal mastermind but a diligent private eye and a “lone ranger” who deliberately kept his accomplices in the dark.

headline: IPod Quandary: Fix or Replace?
text: Q. Is it possible to get a cracked iPod screen repaired for significantly less than what it would cost to just buy a new iPod? Are there other repair options besides Apple?

headline: F.B.I. Questions Clemens Associate
text: The owner of a weight-loss center told a Houston television station that he was questioned on Monday by federal authorities investigating Roger Clemens for perjury.

headline: No. 20 Post? Derby Favorite’s Handlers Say Sure
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The confidence the connections to Big Brown have in their colt knows no bounds. Faced with making a choice from five remaining post positions, Big Brown’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, and the co-owner Mike Iavarone, chose what most would consider the worst slot of all: the one farthest outside, No. 20.

headline: Returning to the Past and Finding the Bogeyman Is Still There
text: When Augusten Burroughs wrote “Running With Scissors,” he regaled readers with hilarious tales of the domestic craziness he endured while growing up. Now in another family memoir Mr. Burroughs makes a crazy move of his own. “A Wolf at the Table” is a portrait of the author’s apparently maniacal and Augusten-hating father. Determinedly unfunny, awkwardly histrionic and sometimes anything but credible, it repudiates everything that put Mr. Burroughs on the map.

headline: Gambling Back at WOR
text: John R. Gambling, who left WOR radio in New York in 2000, will return to the station with a morning show beginning at 5:30 on Monday, The Associated Press reported. His grandfather John B. Gambling began morning broadcasts on WOR shortly after the station went on the air in 1922, and his father, John A. Gambling, hosted the morning program until 1985, when John R. succeeded him before moving to WABC. WOR said the current morning hosts, Joe Bartlett and Donna Hanover, would remain at the station. Mr. Bartlett, as news director, will deliver the news on weekday mornings; and Ms. Hanover will serve as a film critic and substitute host. ... Randi Rhodes will now host the “Randi Rhodes Show,” to be broadcast weekdays, beginning on Monday, from 3 to 6 p.m. on XM 167. Ms. Rhodes ended her employment with Air America radio network last month after she was suspended when a video of her making disparaging remarks about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton surfaced on YouTube. In other radio news the Internet blogger and television personality Perez Hilton will deliver celebrity gossip when he joins “Miss Jones in the Morning” next week on the hip-hop radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM in New York), AllHipHop.com reported. The one-minute segments will be heard at 8.

headline: Starbucks Reports 28% Drop in Profit and Trims Store Openings
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing an increasingly stingy consumer, Starbucks is tightening its belt.

headline: Canada: Grocer’s Profit Climbs 15%
text: The Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest supermarket chain, reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores. Net income climbed 15 percent, to 62 million Canadian dollars ($61.2 million), or 23 cents a share, from 54 million Canadian dollars, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, when it recorded costs for cutting jobs. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to 6.53 billion Canadian dollars. The executive chairman, Galen G. Weston, said price cuts would continue this year as Loblaw tries to blunt Wal-Mart’s expansion into fresh foods across Canada.

headline: Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island
text: Home and garden tours in the city, around the region and across the country.

headline: Opening a Window on a Forgotten Work and Feeling That Fresh Air Rush In
text: Certain revolutions speak in small voices yet describe profound and sudden change. “L’Histoire du Soldat,” Stravinsky’s traveling music-theater show, was one of them, saying  in few words and not that many notes  what music in 1918 no longer was and at the same time offering an alternative for what music might become.

headline: It’s Not Easy to Stick to Principles Devised for Farmers 141 Years Ago
text: STANFORD, N.Y.

headline: Loss and Furor Take Toll on Obama, Poll Finds
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama’s aura of inevitability in the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination has diminished after his loss in the Pennsylvania primary and amid the furor over his former pastor, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: The F.D.A. and Heparin
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trials and Triumphs on the Road to Justice
text: It’s a safe bet that “Thurgood” is the only play on Broadway at which the announcement of a famous legal verdict is greeted by a burst of heartfelt applause.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: Man Threatens to Shoot Student
text: A distraught man held a pellet pistol to the head of a student on City College’s campus in Harlem and threatened to shoot her and himself on Wednesday before the police persuaded him to drop the gun, the authorities said.

headline: New York City
text: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

headline: How Will It Play in Apex?
text: You have to give Bill Clinton credit. Sure we think he’s self-involved. But on Wednesday the former president of the United States was campaigning for his wife in North Carolina, making appearances at Apex, Sanford, Lillington, Dunn, Hope Mills, Lumberton and Whiteville. Following a 7:45 a.m. event in Apex, he was scheduled to discuss “Solutions for America” on “the lawn in front of McSwain Extension Education and Agriculture Center.”

headline: Fed Cuts Rate but Hints About a Pause
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, mixing concern about the feeble economy with worries about rising inflation, reduced short-term interest rates Wednesday for the seventh time since September, while signaling a pause in any additional rate cuts for now.

headline: Federal Contracting Chief Is Forced Out
text: WASHINGTON  Lurita A. Doan has been forced out as head of the General Services Administration, the federal agency that oversees billions of dollars in contracts and manages thousands of government-owned buildings.

headline: Closing Arguments in Suit on Veterans’ Mental Care
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The issue of whether veterans with mental health problems are neglected or whether their sheer numbers are overwhelming the system divided closing arguments on Wednesday in a class-action lawsuit in federal court here.

headline: Boot Up for the Big Easy
text: The bipartisan group of bigwigs who choose the sites for presidential debates made the wrong choice when they rejected New Orleans’ bid. Now Google and YouTube are hoping to hold a forum, with questions zapped in over the Internet, and the sparring candidates seated proudly in New Orleans.

headline: Reshaping Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloomberg Back on Radio
text: Listeners who had grown wistful for the cozy banter, consumer-friendly news announcements and occasional gaffes and malapropisms of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on his Friday call-in radio program with John Gambling have reason to celebrate. They will be able to tune in again starting next week, the mayor said Wednesday, though they will have to get up earlier to catch it.

headline: Carey Holds at No. 1
text: Mariah Carey’s new “E=MC2” (Island Def Jam), lost 61 percent of its sales in its second week out, but it’s still the No. 1 album in the country. It moved 182,000 copes, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its two-week total to 645,000. Leona Lewis’s “Spirit” (Syco/J) holds at No. 2 with 96,000, and the next three spot holders on the Billboard chart are new. The New Zealand musical-comedy duo Flight of the Conchords is No. 3 with its self-titled album on Sub Pop, which sold 52,000; Ashlee Simpson’s third record, “Bittersweet World” (Geffen), is fourth with 47,000; and the alternative hip-hop duo Atmosphere had the best sales week of its more than decade-long career, reaching No. 5 with 36,000 sales of “When Life Gives You Lemons ...” (Rhymesayers). Down the chart, the country singer Phil Vassar bowed at No. 10 with 27,000 sales of “Prayer of a Common Man” (Universal South).

headline: Law Professor Accuses Students of Defamation
text: For some law students, brass-knuckled litigation starts before they even finish school.

headline: Whale Protection Caught in Agency Rivalry, Files Show
text: A federal plan to protect endangered whales along the East Coast has been caught in interagency warfare and held in limbo by the White House, according to documents made public on Wednesday by a Democratic congressman and an environmental group.

headline: Is This the World’s Cheapest Dress?
text: IF rock purists were unsettled last month by the opening of a designer boutique on the site of what once was CBGB, the hard-core Bowery nightclub, imagine how they will feel reading the next sentence: The old Tower Records space a few blocks away on Broadway, for two decades the spot for adolescent reveries of dance, pop and punk, has been leased by Steve & Barry’s, a clothing chain where everything costs less than $10.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. I want to paint a room red. How can I make sure it will feel livable?

headline: Features of Smartphone Without Smartphone Costs
text: If you are looking for many of the features of a smartphone but without the smartphone price, you might consider the Motorola Moto Z9. In addition to its phone functions, it makes digital photos, shoots video, has G.P.S. navigation, plays music and can have access to the Internet.

headline: Six Votes, Then and Now
text: When the Senate passed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, only six Republicans voted with obstructionist Southern Democrats against the historic measure, which outlawed discrimination across a broad swath of American life.

headline: ‘Idol’ Judge Admits Rehearsal Guided Her
text: LOS ANGELES  Paula Abdul acknowledged on Wednesday what some “American Idol” viewers have long suspected: The show’s judges sometimes see portions of the dress rehearsal for the show and use that to help formulate their comments on the evening’s live performance.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about World Wrestling Entertainment’s comeback efforts misidentified the employer of Chris McCumber, who commented on the company’s cable show “W.W.E. Raw,” and a correction in this space on Wednesday misstated his title. He works for USA Network, not World Wrestling Entertainment, and he is executive vice president  not senior vice president  for marketing, digital and brand strategy.

headline: G.M. Invests in Second Ethanol Process
text: WASHINGTON  The General Motors Corporation announced on Thursday that it was hedging its bets on how best to make ethanol from non-grain sources, and making an investment in a second company with technology that might do that job cost-effectively.

headline: CURRENTS | An Encore, Even Without Nine High C’s
text: Opera, Saul Steinberg’s 1950s fabric, has just been reproduced by F. Schumacher & Company, the textiles manufacturer. Steinberg, best known for his New Yorker cartoons, was an opera buff who designed numerous stage sets, and this charming fabric was a favorite of both devotees of his cartoons and opera lovers. The new 68.5-inch-wide cotton fabric has a slightly larger printed pattern than the original version and is available with two background colors, aqua or natural, above. It is $94 a yard to the trade. Information and showroom locations: (800) 523-1200 or fschumacher.com.

headline: Footnote
text: The 12-day Cannes Film Festival will open on May 14 with “Blindness.” Directed by the Brazilian Fernando Meirelles (“City of God,” “The Constant Gardener”), the film stars Julianne Moore as the only sighted person in a town where everyone else is mysteriously struck blind.

headline: For Europe’s Middle-Class, Stagnant Wages Stunt Lifestyle
text: LES ULIS, France  When their local bakery in this town south of Paris raised the price of a baguette for the third time in six months, Anne-Laure Renard and Guy Talpot bought a bread maker. When gasoline became their biggest single expense, they sold one of their two cars.

headline: CURRENTS | What Could Be Happier Than a Pig in Ceramic?
text: What do a foldable cutting board, plates resembling conversation bubbles and a soy sauce dispenser with a duck bill have in common? All are part of Destination: Japan, a new collection at the MoMA Design Stores that highlights the quirkier side of Japanese design. Many items are intended to elicit a laugh, like the silicone lid with a pig face ($18): put it over a pot while cooking, and steam comes out the snout. But they are also highly functional: the bottle opener in the shape of a pincer ($18) is Nambu cast iron; the spoon-fork ($12) is perfect for eating ramen noodles (and was originally designed for the popular Sugakiya restaurant chain). Available starting Thursday at momastore.org and, next week, in the stores, 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (646) 613-1367, and 44 West 53rd Street, (212) 767-1050.

headline: CURRENTS | Not the Poster to Nail Up Over a Crack in the Plaster
text: Some 600 rare posters will be put on the block Sunday by Poster Auctions International. Jack Rennert, the company’s president and the author of several books on poster art, predicted that some of the highest bidding will be inspired by an 1895 poster of Sarah Bernhardt, right, by Alphonse Mucha. He expects it to bring $25,000 to $30,000.

headline: The Ore of Youth, Under Refinement
text: To see young dancers perform at the start of their careers is to see dance in a poignantly pure or raw state. They have not developed star personas or the practiced look of longtime corps dancers. The world is theirs, or so they hope. And the 123 Festival, which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, offers a chance to see gifted youngsters on the brink of careers. All three participating companies  Taylor 2, Ailey II and ABT II  performed together on opening night but will have their own individual programs through May 11.

headline: Live Bacteria to Keep the Cold Away
text: Athletes are often stricken by colds, due in part to the stress of hard training. But a recent study published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine suggests that high doses of probiotics, the "good bacteria" found in yogurt and some supplements, may protect against these annoying infections.

headline: Microsoft Chief Set to Narrow Pursuit of Yahoo
text: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, told employees on Thursday that the company would announce “in very short order” which of three paths it would choose in its three-month-old pursuit of Yahoo.

headline: For Exxon Mobil, $10.9 Billion Profit Disappoints
text: Exxon Mobil, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, said Thursday that its first-quarter net income rose 17 percent, boosted by surging oil prices.

headline: An Oldies Marathon Runs a Few Extra Miles
text: NEW ORLEANS  Men whooped and hollered, rasped and preached. Women sassed, strutted, hurled accusations and wailed away tears. Guitars twanged and cackled, horns laughed, and drums pounded backbeats and chattered with funk. Tuesday was the first of two nights of the seventh annual Ponderosa Stomp, a party on its way to becoming an institution. The Ponderosa Stomp is an oldies marathon as dreamed up by record collectors: the kind of music fans who prize soul veterans’ rare B-sides and limited-edition garage-rock singles, the wilder the better.

headline: A Rescued Goat Gets a Chance for a Normal Life
text: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — They are both amputees: She lost part of her right leg to bone cancer at the age of 10, and he lost part of his left leg four months ago because of an injury he most likely suffered at a Brooklyn slaughterhouse.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 30, 2008

headline: It Was a Dark Afternoon for the Daydreaming Mets
text: There was a man standing in shallow left field when a ball that had zipped down the third-base line toward the corner was retrieved and tossed back into the infield. This man was slim, and he was wearing a No. 7 jersey. That is the corporeal evidence that José Reyes was playing shortstop for the Mets against Pittsburgh during the second inning of their game Wednesday.

headline: A Classroom Path to Entrepreneurship
text: The college campus, it turns out, can be an ideal incubator for hatching small businesses.

headline: Prominent Green Group to Help Buyout Firm
text: Is private equity going green?

headline: Starbucks Earnings Sink 21%
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Starbucks, faced with a sharp drop-off in customers, reported on Wednesday that earnings declined 21 percent during the second quarter.

headline: Former D.N.C. Chairman Backs Obama
text: Joe Andrew, a superdelegate who was the Democratic National Committee chairman under President Bill Clinton, announced Thursday that he had switched his allegiance from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to Senator Barack Obama in the race for the presidential nomination.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a genetic drug doping study in Sweden misspelled the surname of one of the researchers. He is Dr. Anders Rane, not Rhane.

headline: Cycling Success Measured in Frequent-Flier Miles
text: EARLY last year, Dr. Jason Newland, a 34-year-old pediatric infectious disease physician from Stilwell, Kan., decided he would upgrade his Cannondale road bike to something more aerodynamically suited for triathlons, where riders must fight the wind on their own, without the pack shielding them. But instead of ambling into a local sports shop, Mr. Newland flew nearly 1,400 miles from Kansas City, Mo., to Waitsfield, Vt., where he bought a custom titanium and carbon Serotta Legend Ti from a specialty-fit studio called Fit Werx. The price: about $7,000, not including travel.

headline: More Mothers Breast-Feed, in First Months at Least
text: About 77 percent of new mothers breast-feed their infants at least briefly, the highest rate seen in the United States in more than a decade, according to a government survey released on Wednesday.

headline: Yossi Harel, Who, Defying British, Brought Jews to Palestine, Is Dead at 90
text: Yossi Harel, who renamed the rickety ship he commanded Exodus 1947 and sailed it to legend as a symbol of the righteousness of the mission by Jews to settle Palestine in the face of British opposition, died Saturday at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 90.

headline: No Change Imminent for B.C.S. Format
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  After years of research and discussion, major college football’s top executives gathered here to finally have a formal discussion about changing the sport’s controversial and polarizing postseason format.

headline: James Day, Public Television Host, Dies at 89
text: James Day, a former president of Channel 13 in New York, an early executive of public television station KQED in San Francisco and an on-air interviewer for many years, died last Thursday in Manhattan. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: New York, True to Mayor’s Promise, Slashes City Parking Permits
text: The Police Department gave up about 20,000 of the city’s coveted parking placards. The Fire Department lost more than 2,000. The mayor’s office gave up 163.

headline: Today in Business
text: THE ECONOMY STAGNATES ...Consumer spending advanced by only 1 percent in the first quarter, as Americans cut back on a wide variety of discretionary purchases.

headline: Status: Looking for Work on Facebook
text: AS anyone who has ever received a virtual Jagerbomb or fought off intergalactic cyber chickens knows, social-networking sites are designed to be entertaining. If there wasn’t so much fun to be had, there wouldn’t be so many articles warning that what you post on your profile  i.e., photos of you in a beer helmet and a tequila bandolier  could one day cost you a job.

headline: Fund Set for Minneapolis Bridge Collapse Victims
text: Minnesota legislators announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement on a $38 million plan to compensate victims of the highway bridge that collapsed last August in Minneapolis, killing 13 people and injuring 145.

headline: Hoosier Time
text: With just days to go before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here are their first dispatches.

headline: Sharing Your iPod Tunes Without Those Tangled Earbuds
text: Since the iPod has no built-in speaker, sharing a song or video with a friend can often mean becomong tangled up in swapped headphones. If snarled earbud cords are cutting into your communal listening pleasure, there’s the iFrogz Audiowrapz silicone case for the third-generation iPod Nano. It has a set of speakers right on the front.

headline: In a New Climate Model, Short-Term Cooling in a Warmer World
text: After decades of research that sought, and found, evidence of a human influence on the earth’s climate, climatologists are beginning to shift to a new and similarly daunting enterprise: creating decade-long forecasts for climate, just as meteorologists routinely generate weeklong forecasts for weather.

headline: A Run on Rice in Asian Communities
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Along Stockton Street, the bustling heart of Chinatown, there is no lack of eye-popping products and equally eye-popping prices paid for them. Dried toad goes for $42 a ounce, deer tail about $350 apiece, and abalone $428 a pound, a Mother’s Day special.

headline: Pizza and Pop Lift Fox
text: Pizza night on “Hell’s Kitchen” and the start of Neil Diamond week on “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. Nielsen estimated that 24.4 million viewers tuned in to watch the five remaining “Idol” contestants square off at 8 p.m. After “Idol,” Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” delivered 12.3 million viewers, the largest audience ever in the series’ three-year history. The cooking competition led the 9 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” in total viewers in the hour (16.7 million). Despite its edge at 9, ABC ranked third over all, struggling early in the night with two episodes of “According to Jim,” each averaging around 4 million viewers. CBS won second place, thanks to “NCIS” at 8 (14.6 million) and “Shark” at 9 (10.3 million). NBC was fourth for the night, despite leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (12.1 million), which easily outpaced both ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” on ABC (8.1 million) and a rerun of “CSI” on CBS (7.6 million).

headline: The Pentagon’s Message, and Ours: 5 Analysts Reply
text: To the Editor:

headline: White House Forces Out G.S.A. Chief
text: WASHINGTON  Lurita A. Doan has been forced out as head of the General Services Administration, the federal agency that oversees billions of dollars in contracts and manages thousands of government-owned buildings.

headline: Pakistani Parties Weigh Reinstating Judges
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Leaders of Pakistan’s governing coalition are holding crucial talks in Dubai over whether to restore the high court judges ousted by President Pervez Musharraf in November, an issue that had badly strained relations between the coalition partners and even threatens to break them apart.

headline: Hard Times, but Your Lips Look Great
text: LAST month, Betsy Stein made a beeline for Bloomingdale’s to buy a shirt, but the Nanette Lepore top she found was $280. Ms. Stein, 33, a business manager for a classical music composer in Manhattan, told herself that in the current economic climate, she shouldn’t charge it.

headline: France: Drug Maker Posts a Decline
text: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, said first-quarter profit fell 12 percent, hurt by generic competition to the Ambien sleeping pill and by the decline of the dollar. Net income dropped to 1.86 billion euros ($2.9 billion), or 1.41 euros a share, from 2.12 billion euros, or 1.57 euros a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 3.3 percent, to 6.94 billion euros. Sales of Ambien, which lost patent protection a year ago, fell 65 percent, countering higher revenue from the Lantus diabetes medicine and the Lovenox anticlotting drug.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Schedule information on Friday with a film review of “Standard Operating Procedure,” using information from a publicist, misstated the date the film opens in Los Angeles. It is this Friday; it did not open last Friday. (That is when it opened in New York.)

headline: Attacks in Pakistan Rising, State Department Reports
text: WASHINGTON  Terrorist attacks against noncombatants more than doubled in Pakistan from 2006 to 2007, reflecting the growing violence in the country’s turbulent tribal areas and new bombings against Pakistani government officials and security services, according to a report released Wednesday by the State Department.

headline: After Break With Ex-Pastor, Obama Tries to Move On
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Senator Barack Obama sought on Wednesday to set aside the controversy over his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright Jr., and steer the conversation in the Democratic presidential campaign back to the economy.

headline: New Jersey
text: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

headline: Venerable Classical-Music Magazine Plans to Add Online Sales to Its Reviews
text: Gramophone  the leading classical music magazine in the world, 85 years old and based in London  plans to allow readers to buy CDs and downloads from its Web site. This means that it may profit from recordings on which it is passing critical judgment.

headline: Afghans See Link to Qaeda in Plot to Shoot Karzai
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai on Sunday was the work of militants who had infiltrated Afghanistan’s security forces and had ties to groups linked to Al Qaeda in Pakistan’s tribal areas, the Afghan intelligence chief said Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review on Monday about “The Country Girl,” at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, misidentified the singer in one of the recordings played between scenes. The singer is Perry Como  not Bing Crosby, who starred in a film version of the play.

headline: Free Madonna Show? Only for Die-Hard Fans
text: The first ones lined up at 10 a.m. Monday. They brought Madonna memorabilia and warm clothes. Some had candy earrings in tribute to their heroine’s new album, “Hard Candy” (Warner Brothers), which went on sale Tuesday. They were outside the Roseland Ballroom on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and the lucky ones would get free tickets to Madonna’s promotional show there. For this event Roseland had a capacity of 2,200, which by Madonna’s standards is as intimate as a basement club. At 6 a.m. on Wednesday 750 fans received wristbands entitling them to free tickets that night. But by noon a hundred or so still had not left; they just had to be the first to walk inside. “I told my bosses I was going to take four days off,” said Juan Romani, 34, of Pawcatuck, Conn., who was near the front of the line. “When I told them what I was doing, they thought I was crazy. But it’s Madonna.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on April 22 about the rising financial risks facing farmers misstated the length of time that certain futures contracts have been available on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn futures contracts were first listed in 1877 and soybean futures in 1936; the futures contracts were not introduced in 1959 .

headline: The Heisman Trophy Moves Into Its New Home
text: The 80-pound statue was lugged a short distance Wednesday from a safe at its temporary home on Battery Place to its permanent dwelling. The original, nearly 73-year-old Heisman Trophy, tarnished by time and reverent rubbing, was then hoisted upon a wooden pedestal by two of its past winners  Pete Dawkins and Mike Rozier  at the $93 million Sports Museum of America, which will open next week in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Los Angeles Police Expect Calm at Immigration Rally
text: LOS ANGELES  A day before thousands are expected to converge here as part of the annual May Day pro-immigration rallies nationwide, police officials said Wednesday that new technology, training for officers and better communication would prevent a repeat of the melee that concluded demonstrations in Los Angeles last year.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about a football scheduling dispute between Rutgers and Notre Dame, referred incorrectly to Air Force and Navy, which joined Rutgers and some private universities among the football leaders in a recent N.C.A.A. academic report. They are public institutions, not private.

headline: Iraq Team to Discuss Militias With Iran
text: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi prime minister is sending several senior Shiite leaders to Tehran to discuss their concerns that Iran is arming and financing militias in Iraq, senior Iraqi and American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Fewer Latino Immigrants Sending Money Home
text: In a sign that the economic downturn is hitting hard among Latino immigrants, more than three million of them stopped sending money to families in their home countries during the last two years, the Inter-American Development Bank said on Wednesday.

headline: Cablevision Set to Raise the Stakes in Newsday Bidding
text: Cablevision is preparing a $650 million offer for Newsday, $70 million more than bids by Rupert Murdoch and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, while the owners of The New York Observer have dropped out of the bidding, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Fewer Latino Immigrants Send Money Home
text: More than three million Latin American immigrants in the United States, responding to the economic downturn and new uncertainties about their future, have stopped sending money home to their families in the last two years, according to a survey released on Wednesday by the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington.

headline: Operation ‘Went Great,’ and Woods Expects Quick Recovery
text: After a two-week checkup on his surgically repaired left knee, Tiger Woods said Wednesday that his doctors believed the arthroscopic surgery was successful and he should be able to return to competition within the four-to-six-week timetable that was set immediately after the April 15 operation.

headline: The Yanks Add Hughes to the Disabled List
text: By Wednesday, it was obvious to the Yankees that Phil Hughes needed something to change. He is 0-4 with a 9.00 earned run average, a discouraging showing for the youngest pitcher in the majors.

headline: Race Is No Longer Off the Beaten Track
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  When Smarty Jones showed up at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark., to prepare for the 2004 Kentucky Derby, some people might have wondered what he was doing there. Hot Springs was known for its mineral baths, for its barbecue joints, for being the former home of Bill Clinton, and also as the place where 3-year-olds started on the road to obscurity.

headline: British Bank Offers an Optimistic Outlook
text: LONDON  The British central bank suggested Thursday that the credit crisis was easing, saying markets have taken an unnecessarily pessimistic view about losses that will ultimately be felt by banks and the wider economy.

headline: What Would You Drive, if the Taxpayers Paid?
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, drives a 2008 Chevrolet Impala, leased for $219 a month. Representative Michael R. McNulty, a Democrat from the Albany area, gets around in a 2007 Mercury Mariner hybrid, a sport utility vehicle, for $816 a month.

headline: Slower Consumer Spending Hits Home Depot
text: Home Depot, the nation’s largest home improvement chain, said Thursday in a statement that it was dropping plans to open 50 stores and would close 15 poorly performing locations, becoming the latest retail victim of the slowdown in consumer spending.

headline: Microsoft’s Board Meets on Yahoo Bid
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft’s directors met Wednesday to discuss how to proceed with the company’s attempted takeover of Yahoo, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

headline: Palestinians Agree to Plan for Truce With Israel
text: Palestinian groups agreed in Cairo to an Egyptian proposal for a truce with Israel, the official Egyptian news agency MENA reported. The truce would apply first to Gaza and later to the West Bank, the agency said. Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, has already agreed to the proposal. Its rival, Fatah, has given its support. Egypt is expected to seek Israel’s response next week. Israeli officials are wary, saying that Hamas will use any truce period to build up its strength. But they also say Israel will have no reason to act in Gaza if the groups cease their fire.

headline: Turnaround Under Way, G.M. Is Still Bleeding Cash
text: DETROIT  Three years into its turnaround plan, General Motors has greatly improved its primary business  selling cars  yet money keeps flowing out of the company by the billions.

headline: Quintet of Calming Strings and a Rumbling Clarinet
text: Too much time and ink have been spent talking about how challenging, rigorous and difficult Elliott Carter’s music is, and not nearly enough on how lively, vigorous and even funny it can be. The playful qualities outnumbered potential hazards on Tuesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School, when the Juilliard String Quartet and the clarinetist Charles Neidich offered the premiere of Mr. Carter’s “Clarinet Quintet.”

headline: Even Less Help in Hard Times
text: The troubled economy could soon create a major fiscal crisis for the state-run Medicaid and children’s health programs that would only be exacerbated by the Bush administration’s efforts to cut these programs back. Congress must provide temporary aid to the most beleaguered states and find a permanent way to protect Medicaid and children’s health programs from wrenching cuts every time a recession hits.

headline: Despite Some Bumps, Snedeker Enjoys Ride
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Brandt Snedeker stands out in a crowd with no apparent effort. He has a shock of blond curls that spills out from beneath his visor, and a whimsical smile that constantly tugs at the corners of his mouth. He moves with a brisk pace that is somehow unhurried, with an upright bearing free of posturing.

headline: Brooklyn Councilman’s Funds for a Group He Founded Were Blocked
text: The first chance he had to spend the discretionary funds that City Council members control, Mathieu Eugene directed $45,000 last year to a nonprofit Brooklyn group that was close to his heart: a youth sports and mentoring program he had founded and headed until his election.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about criticism of West Virginia University for awarding the daughter of the state’s governor a master’s degree she did not earn misattributed quotations suggesting that the university’s president “accept responsibility for errors in judgment” and inform the governor’s daughter “of the panel’s recommendation and of the decision that her degree was inappropriately granted.” The quotations were from a statement by the university’s board of governors, not from a report by an independent panel investigating the incident.

headline: Firing Puts New Coach in Crowded Marketplace
text: Avery Johnson was fired by the Dallas Mavericks on Wednesday, and Mike D’Antoni clung loosely to his job in Phoenix  their fates underscoring that success is no guarantee of security for N.B.A. head coaches.

headline: Can We Be as Smart as Bats?
text: IN THE AMAZON JUNGLE, Ecuador

headline: Belarus Expels 10 U.S. Diplomats
text: WASHINGTON  The State Department reacted angrily on Thursday to the expulsion of 10 American diplomats by Belarus, a former Soviet Republic widely regarded as having one of the world’s most repressive governments.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, also known as Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Senate Says McCain Is Qualified
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday delivered its judgment on a constitutional question involving one of its own and formally declared that Senator John McCain is eligible to be president  at least from a citizenship perspective.

headline: Statement on Rate Cut by the Federal Reserve
text: Following is the full text of the statement released Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: Gordon Bradley, Who Nurtured U.S. Soccer, Dies at 74
text: Gordon Bradley, a native of England who was a pioneering figure in American soccer and the first to sign with the New York Cosmos, as a player and as a coach, died Tuesday in Manassas, Va. He was 74.

headline: For a Day, the Giants Are Washington’s Favorite Team
text: WASHINGTON  The Giants had one more play to run to complete their championship season. When the band outside the White House started “New York, New York,” players and coaches filed out of a door in two lines, then down opposite curving stairways, pageantlike, toward the South Lawn, where President Bush awaited.

headline: U.S. Sues Alabama Mayor in Bond Deals
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  An Alabama investment banker gave more than $156,000 to Mayor Larry P. Langford in undisclosed payments while Mr. Langford was arranging millions of dollars in fees for the banker’s firm, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit on Wednesday.

headline: H.P. Unveils New Memory Technology
text: A team of Hewlett-Packard scientists reported Wednesday in the science journal Nature that they have designed a simple circuit element they believe will enable tiny powerful computers that could imitate biological functions.

headline: How to Amplify Those Fading Bars
text: WHAT’S the hottest amenity in high-rise apartments these days? Five bars on your cellphone.

headline: TV Dramas Feel Brunt of Strike Fallout
text: The writers’ strike is over, but the damage apparently is not.

headline: Adopting Meters, Washington Ends Taxi Zone System
text: WASHINGTON  Over the objections of cabdrivers, the District of Columbia is set on Thursday to scrap its seven-decade-old method of calculating taxi fares. Conventional time-and-distance meters will replace a system based on geographic zones.

headline: In Inner Mongolia, Pushing Architecture’s Outer Limits
text: Ordos, China

headline: Home and Garden Calendar
text: Images, New York City

headline: Sickened by the Office (Really)
text: FOR Patty Mulcahy, it began with itchy eyes. They started to water two years ago when renovation began on the Midtown office building where she was working as an assistant at a television network. By the fifth day, after 30,000 square feet of new carpeting had been glued in place, the redness and swelling became unbearable. She ended up in the emergency room.

headline: Pittsburgh’s Dynastic Duo
text: Is this the next great dynasty? That is the only logical reaction after seeing the brilliance of Sidney Crosby, 20, and Evgeni Malkin, 21, in the same uniform or, good grief, on the same power-play unit.

headline: A Strained Wright-Obama Bond Finally Snaps
text: Late Monday night, in the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C., Barack Obama’s long, slow fuse burned to an end. Earlier that day he had thumbed through his BlackBerry, reading accounts of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.’s latest explosive comments on race and America. But his remarks to the press this day had amounted to a shrug of frustration.

headline: Of Affirmed and Other Homestretch Heroes
text: Saturday's Kentucky Derby launches this year's Triple Crown series, with a reputedly weak field and no credible candidate to sweep all three races. That leaves us to fall back on memory, to 30 years ago, when Affirmed became the last horse to accomplish racing's greatest feat. He did it in breathtaking fashion, outdueling his great rival Alydar by the thinnest of margins in all three races. None of the victories was more exciting than the final leg at the Belmont Stakes, a race that, as Steve Cady reported for The Times, was "the kind of close-combat struggle that demonstrated why humans have been so fascinated by thoroughbred race horses for centuries."

headline: Tip of the Week: Searching for Text in Firefox
text: Want an even faster way than pressing Control-F to search for text on a Web page in the Firefox browser? Just tap the forward-slash key (the same key as the question mark) to open the Quick Find box at the bottom of the browser window, then type in your search terms.

headline: Moss Makes a Lush, No-Care Lawn
text: Solebury, Pa.

headline: Whitney’s Downtown Sanctuary
text: Optimism is in the air again at the Whitney Museum of American Art, which has just released a preliminary design by the Italian architect Renzo Piano for its proposed satellite museum downtown.

headline: With Two Aces Against a Slam, What to Lead?
text: Look at the West hand in the diagram and at the auction. What would you lead against six hearts?

headline: Three Young Performers, Showing Their Skills
text: The estimable Young Concert Artists series has been providing talented young musicians with the chance to perform on notable stages since 1961, when it was founded by the energetic Susan Wadsworth. The association has a gilded track record, having promoted artists like Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Emanuel Ax, Richard Goode and Dawn Upshaw. Many more recent discoveries have also proved worthy.

headline: Politics and the Economy Occupy Ad Agencies
text: DANA POINT, Calif.

headline: Yanks Finish April Under .500 and Under Siege From Injuries
text: There are 25 players on a major league roster, and at this rate, the Yankees will be all out by Memorial Day. They have placed a prominent player on the disabled list in each of the last three days, ending a difficult month with a thud.

headline: Council Approves Rezoning of 125th Street, Over Loud Protests of Some Spectators
text: The boos and cries of “sellout” and “liar” came so loudly and persistently that the entire audience was removed. But in the end, the City Council overwhelmingly approved a plan on Wednesday to rezone 125th Street in Harlem.

headline: Reading Program Is Called Ineffective
text: President Bush’s $1 billion a year initiative to teach reading to low-income children has not helped improve their reading comprehension, according to a Department of Education report released on Thursday.

headline: As Euro Nears 10, Cracks Emerge in Fiscal Union
text: FRANKFURT  The euro turns 10 next January, a milestone that will be marked with celebratory speeches, inch-thick scholarly papers and a commemorative 2-euro coin, designed by a Greek sculptor. It was chosen from five candidates in an online poll of European residents.

headline: Delays in $4 Billion Brooklyn Development Are Challenged in Tenants’ Lawsuit
text: The ever-lengthening timeline for completing the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn is not just bad news for those who hoped to see the project’s basketball arena, office towers and apartment blocks completed quickly.

headline: Pennsylvania, Delaware and Maryland
text: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

headline: McCain Health Plan Could Mean Higher Tax
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  Though Senator John McCain has promised to not raise taxes, his campaign acknowledged Wednesday that the health plan he outlined this week would have the effect of increasing tax payments for some workers, primarily those with high incomes and expensive health plans.

headline: Corzine Aide Resigns After Testifying in the Corruption Trial of a Hudson County Mayor
text: A top aide to Gov. Jon S. Corzine who had testified he passed a questionable payment from a bar owner to a mayor in Hudson County resigned on Wednesday, the governor’s office said.

headline: First Tibetan Death in Unrest Reported by China
text: BEIJING  A gun battle in a rural area of northwest China this week left a police officer and a Tibetan dead, according to state-run news media.

headline: Germany: Catch the Next Iceberg Out of Town
text: Knut, the Berlin Zoo polar bear cub abandoned by his mother, was a sensation a year ago, a ball of white fluff who seduced the world. Now, as he has grown into a 350-pound adolescent, too big and strong to play with his handler, newspapers have taken issue with everything from Knut’s weight to his sexuality, with one newspaper asking if the bear is gay. But the most enduring question is the one posed from the beginning: how would being hand-raised by humans affect him? “With Knut, it’s clear that he has imprinted on humans, and when neither his keeper nor visitors are there, he cries out,” said Thomas Pietsch, a biologist. Peter H. Arras, a zoologist, put it more succinctly: “He’s a psychopath addicted to human attention.” That attention has fallen off significantly. On a recent afternoon, the fading star lay with his head on his paws, his fur stained from rolling around in sand and dirt. “Is that Knut?” a group of teenagers asked. Told that it was, they looked disappointed. “Oh,” one said, and barely a minute later, they were gone.

headline: While Clinton Focuses, Obama Is Distracted
text: LAFAYETTE, Ind.  Pumped up and focused, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is putting in 16-hour days in Indiana this week as if she  and not her embattled rival, Senator Barack Obama  needs a campaign-changing moment in Tuesday’s primary here.

headline: Producers’ Group Pessimistic on Labor Talks With Actors
text: LOS ANGELES  A bargaining group for Hollywood’s largest movie and television companies on Wednesday told its members, in effect, not to expect a breakthrough in stalled talks with the Screen Actors Guild before their scheduled end on Friday.

headline: States Limit Costly Sites for Cancer Radiation
text: Seeking to rein in medical costs, a commission in Michigan on Wednesday moved to prevent hospitals in the state from each spending $100 million or more to provide a new form of radiation treatment for cancer.

headline: Canadians Investigate Death of Ducks at Oil-Sands Project
text: OTTAWA  Canadian federal and provincial government officials were conducting an investigation Wednesday into Syncrude Canada, a large oil-sands project operator, after hundreds of migrating ducks that landed in a company tailings pond died.

headline: Dressing Up, Win, Place or Show
text: “THERE are no rules here,” Cathy Miller said from her home in Lexington, Ky., where on Tuesday she was wrapping up a two-week trunk show of designer clothes for the wealthy owners of horse farms in anticipation of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in Louisville.

headline: Protecting Alaska
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Tuesday about a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which included three works by the composer Joan Tower, misstated the name of the town where she lives and was recuperating from an injury instead of taking part in a preconcert conversation. It is Red Hook, N.Y., not Red Bank.

headline: Wright Remains a Concern for Some Democrats
text: Senator Barack Obama picked up several endorsements by Democratic superdelegates on Wednesday in his presidential campaign, as some party leaders tried to assess the damage done to his candidacy by the controversy over his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.

headline: A Student of Kicking Passes a Test and Lands in the N.F.L.
text: Like a lot of football kickers, Benjamin Dato’s journey to the sport began on a soccer field.

headline: Hey, Kids, Free Comics!
text: Saturday is Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion that allows visitors at participating stores to pick up a variety of comic books at no cost. The titles run from “Jughead” and “All-Star Superman” to “X-Men” and “Sonic the Hedgehog.” Dark Horse Comics is offering “Hellboy/B.P.R.D.,” which looks into the nightmares of the title hero as well as the background of the Bureau for Paranormal Research and Defense. Virgin Comics, in collaboration with the Sci Fi Channel, is giving away “The Stranded,” about aliens secretly embedded with human families. It is being developed into a pilot for the network. Information is available at freecomicbookday.com, which gives a store locater, a list of free titles and a schedule of appearances by creators. In other comic book news, the Flash, who died in 1985, is alive again. He was resurrected on Wednesday in DC Universe No. 0, a 50-cent comic, which is a primer for “Final Crisis”  the latest big story line that will affect Superman, Wonder Woman, Batman and other DC heroes.

headline: An Ambulatory Arbor
text: Q. I want a flowering arbor for a mid-October wedding on the southern coast of Maine, but can’t erect a permanent structure. Could I grow Sweet Autumn clematis in large pots next to a lightweight arbor at home and then move everything? Or would you recommend some other flowering focus?

headline: China Says Abusive Child Labor Ring Is Exposed
text: SHANGHAI  China said Wednesday that it had broken up a child labor ring that forced children from poor, inland areas to work in booming coastal cities, acknowledging that severe labor abuses extended into the heart of its export economy.

headline: The Gas-Guzzler Gambit
text: Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton have hit on a new way to pander to American voters: a temporary suspension of the federal gasoline tax between Memorial Day and Labor Day. The proposal may draw applause and votes from Americans feeling the pain of nearly $4-a-gallon gasoline. But it is an expensive and environmentally unsound policy that would do nothing to help American drivers.

headline: Immigrants Challenge U.S. System of Detention
text: Immigrants who spent time in detention while fighting deportation filed a federal suit on Wednesday against Michael Chertoff, secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, demanding that the agency issue legally enforceable regulations for its detention centers.

headline: TV Images to Dazzle the Jaded
text: Modern tech life teems with longstanding quandaries, questions that never seem to go away. Mac or Windows? Turn off the computer every night or let it sleep? Plasma or L.C.D.?

headline: New York State
text: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

headline: Texas Reports Added Signs of Abuse at Sect’s Ranch
text: At least 41 children seized from a polygamist ranch in West Texas in April have had broken bones, and some young boys may have been sexually abused, Texas officials said Wednesday.

headline: Carolina, Out of Its Mind
text: With just days to go before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here are their first dispatches.

headline: Obama and Wright: The Uproar
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects City’s Suit to Curb Guns
text: A federal appeals court threw out New York City’s longstanding lawsuit against the gun industry on Wednesday, ruling that a relatively new federal law protects gun makers against such suits.

headline: Yale Students' New Art
text: Aliza Shvarts, the Yale University student whose senior art project created a frenzy last month has submitted a different work to the senior thesis exhibition, The Yale Daily News reported. Ms. Shvarts’s original work supposedly included documentation of repeated artificial inseminations and induced miscarriages. The university has said that it found no evidence to back up Ms. Shvarts’s story. It also would not allow her to show that work in a campus art exhibition unless she admitted that it was a fiction, which she did not do.

headline: French Premier to Seek Common Fiscal Policy in U.S.
text: PARIS  The French prime minister, François Fillon, is using his May 1 holiday to travel to Washington, where he will try to decipher American economic policy and build a common approach to meet growing concerns in both countries about market instability and the weak dollar.

headline: A Mailbox Full of Paper Clips
text: Q. Since I got my PC repaired, all of my e-mail messages show a paper-clip icon, indicating an attachment  even when there isn’t one. Is there any way I can fix this, so that only messages with actual attachments will show the paper clip?

headline: For Madonna Fans, the Wait Is Worth It
text: Halfway through her 32-minute set on Wednesday night at the Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, Madonna offered a message of sympathy.

headline: Agency Floats a Proposal to Help With Home Loans
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Congress reacted coolly to a new $50 billion proposal by the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to permit the Treasury Department to lend directly to as many as a million homeowners to help ease the housing crisis.

headline: H.P. Reports Big Advance in Memory Chip Design
text: Hewlett-Packard scientists reported Wednesday in the science journal Nature that they have designed a simple circuit element that they believe will make it possible to build tiny powerful computers that could imitate biological functions.

headline: Consumer Spending Stagnates as Prices Rise
text: Consumer spending barely budged in March, the fourth lackluster month as Americans grappled with higher food and energy prices amid an economic downturn.

headline: NATO Accuses Russia of Stirring Tensions in Rebel Georgia Areas
text: BRUSSELS  NATO escalated its protests on Wednesday over Russian policy toward Georgia’s breakaway Abkhazia region, accusing Moscow of stirring tensions by announcing plans to increase the number of Russian soldiers there.

headline: Rise in Minorities Is Led by Children, Census Finds
text: Since 2000, members of racial and ethnic minorities have become a majority of youngsters under 15 in two of the nation’s fastest-growing states, Florida and Nevada, with Georgia, Maryland and New York poised to follow, according to census data released on Wednesday.

headline: Rome’s Mayor Plans to Raze Meier Museum
text: In his first news conference as Rome’s newly elected mayor, Gianni Alemanno announced on Wednesday that he would tear down a museum designed by Richard Meier. Built to showcase a first century B.C. altar that honored the military triumphs of the Roman emperor Augustus, the Ara Pacis Museum opened in 2006 to considerable criticism. (The New York Times’s architecture critic, Nicolai Ouroussoff, called the building a “flop” and a “major disappointment.”) Mr. Alemanno said that getting rid of the large structure “was not a top priority,” but that his administration would review all the recent architectural projects in Rome. Built mostly in glass and travertine, the museum was the first important civic building completed in central Rome since Mussolini’s time. Mr. Alemanno had promised to dismantle the imposing structure if elected.

headline: Zimbabwe: Army Accused of Terror Campaign
text: Human Rights Watch accused the army of providing supporters of ZANU-PF, the governing party, with arms and trucks for a campaign of violence against the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. The group’s researchers said witnesses and others had told them that party agents had set up camp at an army barracks in Manicaland Province and were mounting raids on the homes of the opposition riding in army trucks and armed with guns supplied by the army. A spokesman for the Movement for Democratic Change said that 20 of its members had been killed by pro-government militias since the election on March 29. The authorities have yet to announce who won the presidential election. Independent monitors say it was won by the opposition. The opposition and civic groups have charged that the military has taken a leading role in seeking to ensure that ZANU-PF remain in power and have described events since the election as a slow-motion military coup. Western diplomats have openly questioned whether President Robert Mugabe, in power for 28 years, is still in charge.

headline: CURRENTS | Richard Neutra’s Home Seeks a Down Payment on Its Future
text: Richard Neutra’s residence in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles was given to California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, by the Neutra family in 1990. But recently the university, which is financially pressed, announced that unless private financing is found to sustain the house, it may have to be sold.

headline: A Confrontation on ‘Costas Now’ Worthy of a Blog
text: If the sports blogosphere needed someone to symbolize the mainstream media’s fear and suspicion of its influence, it found him in Buzz Bissinger on Tuesday night on a live, 90-minute edition of “Costas Now” on HBO. Bissinger, the author of “Friday Night Lights” and other bestsellers, stepped forward fulminating during a 16-minute discussion with Will Leitch of Deadspin.com and Braylon Edwards of the Cleveland Browns.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Apr. 25 through Apr. 29 with 1,065 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Custom Fitting Just a Flight Away
text: Paying $2,000 to $20,000 for custom-fit bikes is no longer enough for dedicated amateur cyclists. As The Times reports today, these enthusiasts are traveling hundreds or thousands of miles to find a specialty-fit shop. "Now, to fully appreciate the magnificence of their new toys, those athletes must also be able to tell of flight miles logged and far-off bicycle gurus consulted," The Times says. "Feeding the fire is the fact that high-end bike shops like Fit Werx and Wheat Ridge are courting buyers, not just with travel discounts and refunds but with more personal touches like dinner reservations."

headline: Time Warner Refocusing With Move to Spin Off Cable
text: In another era at Time Warner, before a star-crossed Internet merger, the hard-held belief of Gerald M. Levin, then the chief executive, was that “content is and will remain king, but distribution is the power behind the throne.”

headline: Joba Rules?
text: The Yankees struggles have continued the debate about whether Joba Chamberlain should start now, or if the team should keep him in the bullpen and minimize his innings. How should the Yankees handle Chamberlain, and are major league teams in general being overprotective of their young pitchers?

headline: For Eyes That Have Seen It All, There’s a Way to Prove It
text: How often have you found yourself saying, “If your eyes had only seen what I’ve seen”? Slip on a pair of $100 sunglasses from ThinkGeek.com, and you’ll never have to utter those words again.

headline: 5 Asian Nations Are Weighing a Rice Cartel
text: BANGKOK  The prime minister of Thailand, Samak Sundaravej, said Wednesday that his government would try to create a cartel of rice-producing countries in partnership with Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos.

headline: Long Island
text: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

headline: After Troubled Tour, Torch Arrives in China
text: The Olympic torch returned to China on Wednesday in preparation for its first relay on Chinese soil after a troubled worldwide tour.

headline: Low Spending Is Taking Toll on Economy
text: For months, beleaguered American consumers have defied expert forecasts that they would soon succumb to the pressures of falling home prices, fewer jobs and shrinking paychecks. Now, they appear to have given in.

headline: Automakers’ April Sales Reflect Shift to Smaller Cars
text: DETROIT  Automakers reported higher sales of small cars as oil and gasoline prices climbed to record highs in April, but said Thursday that overall vehicle sales in the United States plummeted during the month.

headline: In Wyoming, the Dark Side of America’s Thirst for Energy
text: Pinedale, Wyo.

headline: Corrections: For the Record

headline: Correction: Little Hedge Fund on the Prairie

headline: London Mayoral Election Seen as Close

Meanwhile, seats on 159 local councils across England and Wales were up for grabs in elections widely seen as a referendum on the popularity of Prime Minister Gordon Brown's floundering Labor government.

headline: AT&T Launches TV Service on Cell Phones, Rivaling Verizon
text: Associated Press: “AT&T Inc. is launching its new video service for cell phones Sunday on two phones, and will charge $15 per month for 10 channels. AT&T Mobile TV is almost identical to Verizon Wireless’ V Cast Mobile TV, and is operated by the same company, Qualcomm Inc.”

text: Time Warner’s decision to spin off its cable company “spotlighted the company’s future as a pure content provider,” Tim Arango reports. “From now on the media company will revolve around two core content businesses that have been out of the limelight in recent years: the Warner Brothers movie studio and Turner Networks, which includes the television channels TNT, TBS, HBO and CNN.”

headline: Former Monster Executive Is Indicted
text: A former chief operating officer at Monster Worldwide, the job recruitment Web site, was indicted Wednesday on charges of securities fraud and conspiracy in connection with what prosecutors said was a scheme to backdate millions of dollars in employee stock option grants.

text: Wachovia expects to take a charge of $800 million to $1 billion in the second quarter because of a federal appeals court decision over the taxation of leveraged lease transactions, the bank said on Wednesday.

headline: Time Warner Spin-Off Puts Spotlight Back on Content

headline: Data Centers Are Becoming Big Polluters, Study Finds
text: The world’s data centers are projected to surpass the airline industry as a greenhouse gas polluter by 2020, according to a new study by McKinsey & Co.

headline: What Does Your Car Say About You?
text: The use of a car — gas and insurance included — is one of the benefits of being a member of the House of Representatives. In a front-page story, Ray Rivera notes that 42 representatives from New York and New Jersey, at least a dozen lease cars on taxpayer money, and their choices run the gamut.Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, drives a 2008 Chevrolet Impala, leased for $219 a month. Representative Michael R. McNulty, a Democrat from the Albany area, gets around in a 2007 Mercury Mariner hybrid, a sport -utility vehicle, for $816 a month. Jim Saxton, a Republican of New Jersey, leases a 2004 Chevy TrailBlazer at $310 a month. Gregory W. Meeks, a Queens Democrat, leases a 2007 Lexus LS 460 at $998 a month. And Charles B. Rangel, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, leases a 2004 Cadillac DeVille for $777.54 a month. The car is 17 feet long with a 300-horsepower engine and seats five comfortably. “It’s one of the bigger Cadillacs,” Mr. Rangel, of Harlem, said cheerfully this week. “I’ve got a desk in it. It’s like an airplane.” (See related graphic.)There are few restrictions on what kind of car the members can choose, and there is no limit on how much they can spend. But the benefit can be politically sensitive, given the growing concerns about automobile emissions and an economy that has left many people struggling to pay for the rapidly rising cost of gas, which was averaging $3.63 a gallon nationwide this week.

headline: Demolition to Resume at Building Where Firefighters Died
text: More decontamination and abatement workers will be reporting for duty at the ravaged former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said, after the city Department of Buildings lifted a prohibition on Wednesday that had been in force since a deadly fire in the tower last summer.

headline: Lonely Planet Answers More Criticism
text: BRIEFS For the second time this month, Lonely Planet is addressing criticism of its guidebooks. First, it was faced with a former author’s admissions about sex, drugs and tips-he-stole. Now, the company is defending a volume on Myanmar, the site a brutal crackdown last year. “I am not going to be an ad agency for Burma, but going there is doing more good than bad,” Tony Wheeler, the travel publisher’s founder, told the Associated Press. [Newsvine]

headline: Can Climate Campaigns Withstand a Cooling Test?
text: If the new forecast of a decade of cooler temperatures in North America and Europe pans out, it will pose a substantial challenge to climate campaigners, politicians, and citizens: Can they produce meaningful action to limit the long-term warming that scientists still say is clearly ahead under a building greenhouse blanket even when it’s cooling outside?

headline: John McCain, the Pro-Restructuring Candidate?

headline: Plans to Raze a Building Elsewhere
text: BRIEFS Northern Illinois University decided against bulldozing the building that was attacked by a gunman earlier this year after a public outcry, but Rome’s new right-wing mayor is not exhibiting the same kind of attachment towards a museum designed by Richard Meier. Mayor Gianni Alemanno plans to remove the contemporary structure, which critics fault for clashing with the city’s ancient beauty. [New York Times]

headline: How Much Do You Make? The Nation Already Knows
text: How much do you make? How surprised would you be to learn that your magic number had been posted on the Internet by the government? And that it was not by mistake, as in other recent breaches of privacy.

headline: Milton Gendel: The Fine Print
text: Milton Gendel, born in New York City in 1918, has his first photographic exhibit in the United States, at Verdura on Fifth Avenue. There are, perhaps, several reasons for this delayed happening. Gendel is primarily a writer; living in Rome since 1950, he has been a correspondent for Art News and a consulting editor for Art in America, as well as the editor of the “Illustrated History of Italy.” Photography is essentially a pastime, in spite of producing many, many albums and a dozen or so exhibits in Europe. Gendel’s friendships span the worlds of artists, writers, and aristocrats, and they are the subjects of his candid, unaffected photographs, taken over the last half century.

Ten Years Later, Harry Potter
Vanishes From the Best-Seller List
text: It had to happen sometime — and, lo, an era has ended. After a 10-year run, and less than a year after the seventh and final book in J. K. Rowling’s series was published, the Harry Potter books have fallen — as of the May 11 issue of the Book Review, which went to press last night — off The Times’s best-seller list.

headline: On Sexlessness and Intimacy
text: Yesterday afternoon I finished rereading “Housekeeping” on the subway — a real train would obviously have been more appropriate — and after I had read and gazed at the last poignant sentences I looked around the car, it was 5 p.m. and filled with commuters and young people, and wondered how many of them had or would read the book. And if so what their reaction would be to the almost utter absence of sex.

headline: Six Degrees of Dubai in Union Chief’s Speech
text: Somehow we don’t think that Andrew Stern, the president of the Service Employee International Union, is planning his next vacation amid the soulless skyscrapers and palm-shaped artificial islands of Dubai. After all, Mr. Stern’s union, which represents 1.9 million workers, has been a harsh critic of the human rights record of the United Arab Emirates, of which Dubai is one. In fact, his union has highlighted connections between the emirates and firms such as Carlyle Group as part of its very public critique of the private equity business.

A classic dish for this time of year is a simple combination of pork and turnips in which both are browned for perfect color and simmered in a little liquid until tender.

headline: First, Kill All the Editors!
text: Kingsley Amis liked to drink, and knew how. In the introduction to “Everyday Drinking: The Distilled Kingsley Amis,” a collection of his writings on the hard stuff, Christopher Hitchens (who else?) notes that “the plain fact is that” alcohol “makes other people, and indeed life itself, a good deal less boring. Kingsley grasped this essential fact very early in life, and (so to speak) never let go of the insight.” But for Amis some of those “other people” were editors, and there isn’t much doubt what he thought of them:

headline: ‘More Bad Trips Than …’
text: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Here’s sad news from the world of science, ladies and gentlemen. Albert Hofman, sadly, passed away. You probably remember Albert Hofman was the man who discovered LSD. Yes, that’s right. Albert Hofman was responsible for more bad trips than American Airlines.

headline: The Quad Countdown Begins With Western Kentucky
text: Major League Baseball has just finished the first month of the season, the Kentucky Derby is days away and the N.H.L. and the N.B.A. are in full playoff mode. All of that can only mean one thing: It’s time to start talking college football! The season begins on Aug. 28 and to get you ready for that momentous date, The Quad is ranking all 120 Football Bowl Subdivision teams. We’ll begin today with No. 120 and reveal one each day until we get to No. 1. In addition to ranking the teams, we’ll provide plenty of relevant on-the-field facts as well as some fun off-the-field tidbits that you can use to impress your friends. Feel free to disagree with our rankings. As we all know, the great thing about college football is that it all gets settled on the field. Oh, wait … In any case, here to kick the festivities off is No. 120.

headline: The Morning Skate: Coming Back with Al Arbour, Hap Day and Eddie Floyd
text: Here are the today’s out-of-town stories on the Rangers-Penguins series.

headline: ‘The World Record for Holding His Breath’
text: Aired Wednesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: David Blaine today broke the world record for holding his breath, on “Oprah” — 17 minutes, four seconds. Blaine has now frozen himself, he’s starved himself, he’s gone without sleep for weeks, and deprived himself of oxygen. Today, Dick Cheney said, “See, it’s not torture. It’s magic.”

headline: The B.C.S. Mess of a Different Color

headline: C.I.A. Chief Lists Population as a Top Concern
text: Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, yesterday described three troublesome trends that distinguish this century from the last, and the exploding populations of poor places topped his list. Interestingly, energy shortages (and climate change) were not on his list. (The other trends were growing divisions between the United States and Europe and China’s emergence.) I’ve sent a query to the agency’s press office to find earlier statements on fossil fuels and security.

headline: Bringing the World Together Through Film
text: I’ve written several times about the annual conference known as TED, which stands for Technology, Entertainment and Design. It’s 50 talks over four days, each 18 minutes long. The talks range from hysterically funny to deeply moving.

headline: Scent Notes | Red Roses Cologne by Jo Malone
text: The personality of the man or woman whose name is on a perfume bottle is rarely captured in the personality of the liquid inside. Red Roses Cologne by Jo Malone is an exception. In person, Malone is a crisp, practical, straightforward, delightful Englishwoman, and when she was directing her perfumers in the creation of her scents — she left her eponymous house in 2006; Jo Malone Ltd. is now owned by the Estée Lauder Companies — she established an artistic olfactory style that was, at its best, equally direct and delightfully English (the latter a relative rarity quality in a business dominated by the French and the Americans).

headline: What Explains The Post-Strike Ratings Slump?
