headline: Finding a Quick Jolt in Airports’ Terminal Deserts
text: It is a sorry sight: passengers desperately hunting for airport outlets like dusty travelers in search of oases in a sandy desert. They then cluster, savoring the dribbles of electricity to charge and use their cellphones, laptops and iPods.

headline: Pain Relief Without the Heart Risks
text: To many graying baby boomers coping with joint or muscle pain, painkillers like rofecoxib (Vioxx) and celecoxib (Celebrex) once seemed a godsend. The advent of these inhibitors of the COX-2 enzyme held the hope of pain relief with less damage to the stomach than aspirin can cause, a possibility borne out to some extent by clinical studies. Many patients found them more effective than traditional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or NSAIDs.

text: — Mark Landler in the April 29, 2008 New York Times, reminding us all that clothes do not always make the man.

text: In theory, the gush of political ads should be a bonanza for television stations around the country, especially in this troubled economic climate.

headline: The Mayor’s New Budget, Flat After Years of Growth
text: Facing a worsening fiscal picture, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today finished presenting his executive budget that preserves a popular $400 property tax rebate as well as a 7 percent reduction in the overall property tax rate, but only for the fiscal year that ends on June 30, 2009. Mr. Bloomberg leaves office at the end of 2009.

headline: Saving Harry Reid?
text: It is not just that Democrats sensed that a chance to pick up a vulnerable House seat in Nevada could be slipping through their fingers. And it’s not just that they couldn’t bear to have a little-known openly gay accountant who moved to Nevada just three years ago as their standard bearer in a heavily Mormon district.

headline: Making Cars Smarter, Greener, Safer … and Better Listeners
text: Telematics, the marriage of telecommunications and computer technology, was supposed to be a godsend for increasingly complex cars. In theory, a single telematics system could coordinate G.P.S. navigation, and control electronic systems and hands-free cellphone communications, while checking the status of your air bags. But today most of these technologies are still controlled by separate systems.

headline: Alcoa to Hire Citi Banker as Its Top Deal-Maker
text: Amid recent commodities boom that has fueled a surged in consolidation within the industry, Alcoa announced Thursday that it has hired a longtime outside adviser to head up its mergers and acquisitions efforts.

headline: Jazzfest: A Tradition of its Own
text: In “Faubourg Treme: The Untold Story of Black New Orleans,” a new documentary about a historic New Orleans neighborhood by the journalist Lolis Eric Elie and the filmmaker Dawn Logsdon, the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis talks about the city’s improvisational traditions. Improvising musicians and dancers, he says, “have the feeling not only is this moment here something that’s never happened, it’s a moment that’s always happened.

headline: Neglected Youth Turn to Horse Racing
text: Boys’ Haven is a nonprofit home for neglected and abused youth that races thoroughbreds as part of an equine job-training program.

headline: Be the Book
text: On my train ride home one evening last week, I sat across from a woman whose young daughter was dressed all in pink. The girl — she looked about 6 or 7 — had a leotard and a tulle skirt and sparkly rhinestone shoes, and might have been on her way home from ballet class. But I had a hunch. “Fancy Nancy?” I asked the mother before I exited at my station. She smiled and held up the latest book in Jane O’Connor’s best-selling series. “Launch party,” she said.

headline: Sami al-Hajj Reported Freed
text: I’ve heard that Sami al-Hajj, a journalist who has been held — and mistreated — for six years in Guantanamo is now in a plane en route back to his native Sudan. His plane is supposed to arrive this evening.

headline: Uma Thurman Tells Jury of Menacing Notes From a Fan
text: Updated, 10:37 p.m. | Uma Thurman gave a harrowing reading to a Manhattan jury of cards and e-mail messages sent to her by an obsessive fan who sneaked onto the set of a movie she was filming in New York City in 2005.In her testimony on Thursday morning, she told how Jack Jordan, who is on trial for stalking the actress on and off over a period of two years, came to the door of her trailer on Prince Street in SoHo on Nov. 8, 2005, when she was making the movie “My Super Ex-Girlfriend.” He identified himself to one of Ms. Thurman’s assistants as a friend of her parents.

headline: Jury Duty, Now More Tech-Friendly
text: Most people dread being called for jury duty. It is hard to get excited about the prospect of being trapped at a trial for weeks while work, family and sunshine outside beckon.

headline: Wednesday’s ‘Idol’ Is Again a Ratings Breakout
text: Fox claimed victory in the ratings on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, as 22.1 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. to watch Brooke White be eliminated from “American Idol,” leaving four remaining contestants.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | The Milton Gendel Exhibition at Verdura
text: T Magazine’s Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

headline: Jazzfest: Green Fuz at the Ponderosa Stomp
text: Tucked between the two weekends of the festival was the Ponderosa Stomp, the roots-rock extravaganza with the record-collector’s love of the obscure, and I was in town to hear it.

headline: Bringing Back the Roto-Broil
text: Rachel Felder is a New York-based style writer, self-described as “obsessed with everything vintage, from Emilio Pucci dresses to vinyl Tim Buckley albums to FireKing dishware.” When she saw a reference to my mother using a rotisserie back in the ’50s and ’60s, she immediately sent me an e-mail saying she owned six. Here’s her story. –MB

headline: Paterson’s Wife Stays on Mrs. Spitzer’s Environmental Course
text: Michelle Paige Paterson stepped into the New York’s first lady role with her first press event at the New York State Executive Mansion on Thursday morning. The wife of Gov. David A. Paterson told the audience of schoolchildren, environmental professionals and reporters that she would carry out an initiative started by the former first lady, Silda Wall Spitzer: The drafty old governor’s mansion would be outfitted with solar panels and equipped with other energy saving technology to make the place more environmentally friendly.As substantive as Mrs. Paterson’s talk was, one couldn’t help but notice beneath her well-polished exterior — she was wearing leopard print high heels and matching trim on her cream-colored jacket, and a string of pearls around her neck — a bit of nervousness was spotted.

headline: Marilynne Robinson, Buster Keaton
text: It’s easy to miss the brilliant understated comedy of Robinson’s Keaton-like deadpan. I admire how only three objects float to the surface after the train wreck. One of them? “A lettuce.” The singular usage makes this very funny. So does the fact that, when we so want hard metallic evidence of whatever crashed the conveyance and killed so many, we instead receive on the surface an item itself mostly water and worse, as the writer herself jokes, “perishable.”

headline: Remembering Gordon Bradley
text: A pioneer of American soccer, Gordon Bradley, died Tuesday. He was 74. As Jack Bell writes in Bradley’s obituary, “Bradley is perhaps best remembered as the first to sign with the Cosmos in 1971, their first year in the North American Soccer League, joining the team as player-coach.”

headline: Gonna Make You Sweat | Madonna at the Roseland Ballroom

headline: Kleiner Perkins Goes Late on Energy
text: When it comes to investing in alternative energy companies, things are getting a little later for the Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Iron Man'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "Iron Man," based on the Marvel comic about a man who protects the world in an iron armor suit.

headline: How to Pick a Derby Horse if You Are a Newbie
text: First, a blog is always about helping people and a “n00b” is slang for newbie, or rookie. You’re welcome. So, you’re also new to the Kentucky Derby, and you’re looking to make your first pick and not look too foolish. Have no fear; I’m here to help you.

headline: How Clear Are Your Last Wishes?
text: When my grandfather was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer last year, his health deteriorated far more quickly than expected. Fortunately, he had left very clear instructions about his wishes for care.

headline: Seeking Cures With No Prescription
text: Undocumented immigrants, afraid to use the mainstream health care system, are turning to traditional healers for their health care needs.

headline: How Did the Cougar Get to Chicago?
text: After Chicagoans got over being stunned over a cougar’s arrival and subsequent death last month, there were several basic questions, starting with: How did it get there?

headline: Troy Percival’s Shout Out to Frank Tanana
text: Troy Percival is 38, but, on the young Tampa Bay Rays, he sometimes feels as if he is 58. The closer said he is amazed how often he mentions a prominent retired player and some teammates will stare at him blankly.

headline: Answers About Alternative Energy in the City, Part 2
text: Following is a second set of answers from Carol E. Murphy, who is taking questions from City Room readers about alternative energy choices for consumers, what New York City is doing to decrease its reliance on fossil fuels and how city dwellers can decrease their “carbon footprint.”

headline: Celebrities! They’re Just Like Us! They Have Jury Duty!
text: Not only do celebrities get called to jury duty like everyone else, but every November the court also invites a few of them back for Juror Appreciation Day. (They usually don’t get selected because lawyers fear they will have undue influence, though that didn’t stop Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani from being impaneled when he was mayor.)Vincent J. Homenick, the chatty chief clerk of the jury division for New York County, mentioned this after pointing out that the New York State Supreme Court in Lower Manhattan celebrated its 80th anniversary last year. He then noted that last year was also the 50th anniversary of the classic movie about jury deliberations starring Henry Fonda, “Twelve Angry Men.”

headline: An Analyst Shows Blackstone a Little Less Love
text: Merrill Lynch has had a change of heart about the Blackstone Group.

headline: Love in Saudi Arabia
text: In the desert outside of the Saudi Arabian capital, Riyadh, two young men debate the notion of romantic love in their nation.

headline: The New York Times Close Up
text: In his weekly show on NY1, Sam Roberts interviews guests including Michael Powell.

headline: Now Online | Design & Living Spring 2008
text: Spring fever strikes at home in the new issue of T Design & Living, from a tipsy fashion dinner in London with the designer Christopher Kane to the ultimate in urban al fresco. “Interview” honcho Glenn O’Brien opens the doors (and windows) to his modern-rustic Connecticut home. The polyhyphenate star Maira Kalman sketches the blooms before her. And the fancy-pants event designer David Monn shops CB2 in style. Read up, then get outside.

headline: Weekend Explorer: Queens
text: John Strausbaugh tours the diverse religious sites of Flushing, Queens.

headline: Fossella Faces Drunken Driving Charge
text: Updated, 9:05 p.m. | Representative Vito J. Fossella, Republican of Staten Island, was arrested overnight in Alexandria, Va., and charged with driving while intoxicated, The Washington Post reported.Mr. Fossella is scheduled to appear in Alexandria General District Court on May 12 for a hearing. Mr. Fossella’s office released a statement late this afternoon:

headline: Jazzfest: More from The Stomp
text: But there was another nine hours of music at Wednesday’s Ponderosa Stomp. One remarkable set was by the gospel pianist and singer Davell Crawford–celebrated in New Orleans for his untrammeled virtuosity–backing up his grandfather, James (Sugar Boy) Crawford, who had a career singing secular music decades ago. Not now: James Crawford was singing gospel. He was giving thanks for his recovery from a police beating years ago that fractured his skull and initially left him paralyzed and blind, in long lines that rose from humility to joyful affirmation. All around his steadfast melodies, Davell Crawford was a tsunami of improvisation: surging ostinatos and florid filigree, tremolo chords and keyboard-spanning glissandos, excess as exaltation.

headline: Big Brown Sizzles; Smooth Air Is Slow
text: It’s two days before the Derby, and the one-two finishers of the Florida Derby “blew out” three-eighths of a mile this morning at Churchill Downs. Big Brown accomplished this in a dazzling 35.4 while Smooth Air went in a more pedestrian 38.2.

headline: Strengthening Ties with Southeast Asia
text: Far too often, the Bush administration has ceded diplomatic ground in Asia to China.

headline: Last-Minute Options for an Olympics fan
text: I am a college student planning a trip to Beijing for the Olympics in August. Do you have any recommendations for safe, budget accommodations?

text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

text: A. O. Scott reviews "Mister Lonely," about celebrity impersonators who live together in a commune.

headline: Amazon Sues New York State to Void Sales Tax Rules
text: Before the ink on the bill has even dried, Amazon.com has filed a suit challenging New York State’s new law that forces online retailers to collect sales taxes on shipments to state residents.

headline: The Story Ends for the ‘D.C. Madam’
text: Deborah Jeane Palfrey took extreme measures, even by Washington standards, when it came to defending herself against charges of running a high-priced call girl ring under the guise of an escort service. Standing before the nation’s news media last year, the woman who became known as the D.C. Madam at once denied any involvement in illegal prostitution and threatened to make public her client list — to sell it, in fact, as a way of financing her legal bills.

headline: All the Subway’s a Stage, for a Lucky Few
text: Balla Tounkara, a player of traditional music from the West African nation Mali, came to New York several years back to spread his country’s sound to the world. He had been taught as a boy by his grandfather, who lived to age 117, how to make, then play, the kora, a 21-string instrument fashioned from a giant gourd wrapped in cowhide, with a wooden neck and handles. He has recorded several CDs, teaches kora to a diverse range of young people, and plays concerts across the country.

headline: Democrats Abroad Say, ‘Yes We Span’
text: As she kept up to date about the presidential race back home, Meredith Wheeler noticed a recurring theme in the press coverage of Barack Obama, her favorite candidate.

headline: Iran Protests to U.N. About Clinton Comments
text: TEHRAN — Iran has lodged a formal protest at the United Nations about comments by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that the United States would “totally obliterate” Iran if it attacked Israel with nuclear weapons, the state-run news agency, IRNA, reported Thursday.

headline: Rangers’ Pregame: The Final Scramble
text: The Rangers face their elimination game Thursday night without forward Sean Avery, who is still in the hospital with a lacerated spleen, and center Blair Betts, who will need surgery to repair facial fractures he sustained in Game 3.

headline: Horses Running for More
text: There is no doubt success in the Derby brings riches to the horse’s connections that extend much further than the winning share of the purse. It is nice to see that some owners are committing some of their prize money on Saturday to important causes. The following may well not be an exhaustive list.

text: Labels can be tricky things, and not just for people struggling with their own identity.

text: Joe Taylor is auditioning for a coveted spot as a New York City subway performer.

headline: Subway Idol
text: Joe Taylor is auditioning for a coveted spot as a New York City subway performer.

headline: Does Money Follow Passion? Top Bloggers Weigh In
text: If there is one question that plagues so many of us in our career choices, it is whether it is wise — or even possible — to build careers out of our passions. And there’s a corollary question that often goes along with it: Will financial success necessarily come to those who follow their passions? I’ve covered this before, but I just discovered an excellent post on Chris Guillebeau’s blog, The Art of Non-Conformity, in which several of my favorite bloggers chime in on this subject. (Thanks to Gretchen Rubin, of The Happiness Project, for bringing it to my attention.)

headline: GTA IV Sales Up, Stock Down
text: Herewith, a brief addendum to a post a few days ago about Electronic Arts’ effort to acquire Take-Two Interactive, the distributor of Grand Theft Auto IV:

headline: In the Redesign, the Lollipops Have Stuck Around
text: New York may not be able yet to place the name, but the lollipops will certainly be familiar. So will the shape and the pale color of Edward Durell Stone’s Gallery of Modern Art, built at 2 Columbus Circle in 1964 to house Huntington Hartford’s art collection.

headline: Rubin Called Upon to Help Avert Another Crisis
text: Not too long ago, Robert E. Rubin took part in dealing with a stunning catastrophe, one with ramifications that spread far across the globe.

headline: Hillary Clinton Makes Her Pick
text: Even professional handicappers admit to having a hard time picking the Derby winner.

headline: Goya in Madrid, to Remember a Spanish Uprising
text: If you are in Madrid this weekend you will certainly become familiar with a defining event in Spanish history, that — if you live outside of Spain — you’ve probably overlooked before: the 1808 popular Spanish uprising against Napoleon Bonaparte’s occupying forces. On May 2 that year, the people of Madrid rebelled against the French, sparking fighting in which hundreds of people were killed. The next day, in a harsh backlash against the revolt, the French forces executed hundreds of suspected Spanish rebels.

headline: Jazzfest: A Treasure Hunt
text: For some loyal patrons, Jazzfest can present something like a pioneer land-grab. They show up, the earlier the better, and stake their claims. Sometimes the effort involves chairs, a banner and a pole. Sometimes it’s just a blanket on the ground. Whatever the case, these are the festivalgoers who figure out their plan and stick to it, venturing out for provisions only as the need arises.

headline: The world is lumpy
text: We had a nice event at Princeton yesterday — the Graham lecture, given this year by Jon Eaton — and later, over drinks, Jim Harrigan pointed me to an interesting paper by David Hummels and co-authors about international transportation. The interesting point is that for many countries/routes, there isn’t a lot of competition: modern ships are big, and many countries are small.

headline: May Day Immigration Rallies
text: Supporters of immigration rights gathered in more than a dozen U.S. cities.

headline: The Oud: An Iraqi Lute
text: Dhia Jabbar plays a song in Baghdad as a helicopter flies overhed.

headline: Jazzfest: Wild Magnolias and Tower of Power
text: Two awards for the late slot on Thursday:

headline: Rating the Red Bulls vs. Toronto F.C.
text: The Red Bulls (2-1-2, 8 points) were back on the field only four days after their 2-0 victory against the expansion San Jose Earthquakes last Sunday. On Wednesday, the Red Bulls traveled north to Canada for a match against Toronto F.C. (3-2-1, 10 points), which had won three straight games after starting its second season in Major League Soccer with consecutive losses.

headline: Q & A: Joe Drape From Churchill Downs
text: The Rail invited readers Thursday to submit questions online for Joe Drape, The Times’s Eclipse Award-winning horse racing writer.

headline: Jazzfest: ‘Things Are Gonna Get Brighter’
text: The trumpeter Kermit Ruffins is one epitome of the New Orleans musician: skillful, versatile and no less serious just because he’s happy to entertain. At Jazzfest, taking a cue from Louis Armstrong, he sang “What a Wonderful World.” He also played one piece on a modern-jazz vamp, another on a bright Caribbean beat. He even did some rapping, interspersing the 5 Stairsteps hit “O-o-h Child,” with a rhymed interlude, a chronicle that spanned growing up in the Lower Ninth Ward, the neighborhood still devastated by Katrina, and New Orleans’ situation now: “Clean up this mess.” But that song’s chorus is “Things are gonna get brighter” — a wish easily granted in an optimistic song.

headline: Silverman’s Vision of Broadcast’s Future
text: TVWeek: “In 15 years, broadcast television will only be useful for high-profile live events like the Super Bowl, awards shows and programs like ‘American Idol,’ Ben Silverman, co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, said during a keynote interview at the TelevisionWeek Upfront Summit in New York. Other shows will have to live on multiple platforms to survive.”

headline: Al Jazeera Cameraman Released From Guantanamo
text: “An Al Jazeera cameraman held at the U.S. military prison in Guantanamo Bay for six years without charge has been released, the network said on Thursday,” Reuters reports.

headline: Two-Year-Old Sales Can Now Lead to Derby
text: Not so long ago, auctions for two-year-olds in training were a way for breeders to dispose of the horses they’d been unable to sell as yearlings and that they thought weren’t good enough to take to the races themselves. Today, those sales are a legitimate source of Derby contenders.

headline: Rangers Postgame: Two Heroes, One Victory
text: At one point this season, the Madison Square Garden fans were busy chanting for the team to re-sign forward Sean Avery. But now, with Avery out for the season with a lacerated spleen and the Rangers’ playoff lives seemingly resting on the shoulders of captain Jaromir Jagr and goalie Henrik Lundqvist, the free agent the Garden fans are showering with attention is Jagr.

headline: Seminal example of modernist design will go to highest bidder
Zimbabwe: Officials Begin Verifying Election Results
text: A month after Zimbabwe’s disputed election, representatives of the presidential candidates finally met to begin verifying an outcome that has yet to be announced. Ministers in the government of President Robert Mugabe, left, have maintained for weeks that a runoff will be necessary with his chief rival, Morgan Tsvangirai. The verification process, which allows candidates to challenge what they think are erroneous or fraudulent tallies, could take days or longer.

headline: Union’s War Protest Shuts West Coast Ports
text: SEATTLE  West Coast ports were shut down on Thursday as thousands of longshoremen failed to report for work, part of what their union leaders said was a one-day, one-shift protest against the war in Iraq.

headline: Iran Protests to U.N. About Clinton Comments
text: TEHRAN  Iran has lodged a formal protest at the United Nations about comments by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that the United States would “totally obliterate” Iran if it attacked Israel with nuclear weapons, the state-run news agency, IRNA, reported Thursday.

headline: Cameraman Is Released From Guantánamo
text: A former cameraman for Al Jazeera who was believed to be the only journalist held at Guantánamo Bay was released on Thursday, after more than six years of detention that made him one of the best known Guantánamo detainees in the Arab world, his lawyers said.

headline: Dungeons & Austrians
text: AUSTRIA, that lovely little Alpine republic on the banks of the Danube, has a new and deeply lamentable claim to international notoriety: As of this past weekend, we officially lead the free world in the abduction and confinement of young girls in soundproof, subterranean apartments.

headline: Iran Protests Clinton Words
text: TEHRAN  Iran has lodged a formal protest at the United Nations about comments by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that the United States would “totally obliterate” Iran if it attacked Israel with nuclear weapons, the state-run news agency, IRNA, reported Thursday.

headline: Economic Clouds? Wall Street Sees Signs of Sunshine
text: Main Street may be struggling, but Wall Street is on a bit of a roll.

headline: Stores Hint at Change Under New Castro
text: HAVANA  Can a rice maker possibly be revolutionary?

headline: Card Readers in Cabs, and the Battle Behind the Scenes
text: They clashed over tips.

headline: First Thing, Muzzle the Clergy?
text: Wouldn’t it be nice if, in the name of ecumenism, certain clergymen could reach an understanding about why 3,000 people died on Sept. 11, 2001? Most New Yorkers probably never thought that the victims had it coming. But some gentlemen of the cloth seem to know better.

headline: A Photographer of Pets and Perps
text: “The Favor,” a dreary, interminable drama written and directed by Eva Aridjis, is exactly one-third of a good movie. That third is Frank Wood’s beautifully modulated and modest central performance as Lawrence, a lonely bachelor with a beloved pooch and a washed-out life. Overwhelming it, however, are a limp story line and Ryan Donowho’s callow portrayal of Johnny, the orphaned teenager whom Lawrence inadvisedly fosters.

headline: Jury Gets Hollywood Wiretap Case
text: LOS ANGELES  The six-year-old Hollywood wiretapping case went to the jury Thursday after a federal prosecutor urged the panel members to look past the celebrities and entertainment moguls involved.

headline: Punishing Pierce May Have Done More Harm Than Good
text: In a heated moment of a tight playoff series, Paul Pierce made a hand gesture that closely mimicked a known gang sign and walked threateningly toward his opponent’s bench. The N.B.A. called it a “menacing gesture” and fined Pierce, the Boston Celtics star, $25,000.

headline: Clinton May Be Hopeful, but Obama Rolls On
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Have Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s chances of winning the Democratic presidential nomination improved as Senator Barack Obama has struggled through his toughest month of this campaign?

headline: Steroid Maker Says He Taught About N.F.L. Loopholes
text: PLANO, Tex.  One day last week, David Jacobs took out two measuring cups, put a pot on the stove at his home here and demonstrated how he used to turn raw powder into steroids.

headline: Santa Barbara on the Cheap
text: SANTA BARBARA is a fabled, verdant oasis, renowned for its opulence. Could this magnet to the rich and famous also be a bargain hunter’s paradise?

headline: Germany: Mayhem on May Day
text: Left-wing protesters erected barricades in the streets of Hamburg and burned police cars as part of a demonstration against a march by neo-Nazis that the counter-demonstrators said was intended as a provocation on May Day. In the confusion of smoke and smashed windshields, the counter-demonstrators attacked the police, stormed a cafe and set fires, a police spokesman said. The police said they had arrested 56 people and detained 227 others. They estimated that 1,500 people had participated in the right-wing march and 6,600 in the left-wing response.

headline: Are Men Overlooked at Fertility Centers?
text: But for a semen specimen, most men are practically ignored when couples go to fertility centers. And depending on the infertility specialist offering treatment, that is either a good thing or a bad thing.

headline: For Diamondbacks, Winning Is Child’s Play
text: PHOENIX  The tension was thicker than the Sunday paper as Diamondbacks pitcher Brandon Lyon tried to close out the game. For several seconds Lyon stared at his target, presumably visualizing not only his next play, but also the two or three after that.

headline: Home Care Company’s Chief Is Accused of Grand Larceny
text: ALBANY  The president of a Brooklyn-based home health care company was indicted Thursday on charges that his company employed more than 1,000 aides who lacked proper training. The case is the most significant brought by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo in his investigation of the home health care industry.

headline: The Hard Hat Passes to a New Commissioner
text: IS that much-heralded, and some cynics might say sadly belated, crane safety seminar (don’t even try leaving the Department of Buildings on Lower Broadway without a full-page, freebie invitation) today or is today the excavation site lecture at 7 World Trade? And what day is this, anyway?

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture in some editions on Saturday with an article about reaction from supporters of Sean Bell to the acquittal of three New York police detectives charged in his death carried an erroneous credit in some copies for the pool photographer. She is Julia Xanthos, not Xanthos Julia.

headline: Party of Denial
text: During Barack Obama’s Sunday appearance on Fox News, the interviewer asked him for an example of “a hot-button issue where you would be willing to buck the Democratic Party line” and say that Republicans have the better idea.

headline: Dockworkers Protest Iraq War
text: Thousands of dockworkers at West Coast ports stayed off the job on Thursday in what their union said was a call for an end to the war in Iraq.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: From Making the Cases to Challenging Them
text: For the last 10 years, Ronnie Abrams lived a real-life version of “Law & Order.”

headline: In Subway Platform, These Musicians See Their Stage
text: Balla Tounkara, a player of traditional music from the West African nation of Mali, came to New York several years back to spread his country’s sound to the world.

headline: The Cognitive Age
text: If you go into a good library, you will find thousands of books on globalization. Some will laud it. Some will warn about its dangers. But they’ll agree that globalization is the chief process driving our age. Our lives are being transformed by the increasing movement of goods, people and capital across borders.

headline: Spidey at the Library
text: The Library of Congress is now home to the original artwork, above, by Steve Ditko for Marvel Comics’ Amazing Fantasy No. 15, the comic book that introduced Spider-Man in 1962. The library announced on Wednesday that the comic book was the gift of someone who asked to remain anonymous. Sara W. Duke, curator of popular and applied graphic art in the prints and photographs division of the library, said, “Looking at the drawings inspires a new appreciation for the artist’s skill and design choices and also deepens our understanding of how a superhero created to attract a teenage audience became a cultural icon with mass appeal.” The black-and-white drawings conclude with the lines: “With great power there must also come great responsibility ... and so a legend is born and a new name is added to the roster of those who make the world of fantasy the most exciting realm of all.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Beyond the Porsches and the Jaguars, a Homey Feeling
text: ALONG skinny two-lane country roads, behind well-maintained stone walls, padlocked gates and trees that loom like sentries, the part-time residents of Bedford, harried hedge fund managers and entrepreneurs from Manhattan among them  can kick off their shiny wingtips and shut out the hubbub of modern life.

headline: National Geographic Wins 3 Awards, Honored Beyond Photography
text: National Geographic won three National Magazine Awards on Thursday night, more than it had ever captured in a single year, including a prestigious award for general excellence the second year in a row.

headline: On Throne, Onstage, Online and on Cellphone
text: HALFWAY through her 32-minute set on Wednesday night at the Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan  a promotional show for her new album, “Hard Candy,” that was attended by 2,200 lucky, screamy fans  Madonna offered a message of sympathy. “All you people I saw sleeping in the street last night,” she announced, holding a jet-black electric guitar, “this song is for you.”

headline: Democrats and Fox News Make Friends
text: Standing in front of a television camera last week, the chairman of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, Terry McAuliffe, uttered four words that the Fox News Channel would not soon forget.

headline: Spinsterhood Is Powerful (Until a Catch Shows Up)
text: This year, in an effort to forge an image that seemed a little more with it, the producers of “Masterpiece Theater” installed the actress Gillian Anderson as host and shed the stodgiest half of the title, making it simply “Masterpiece.” There is certainly a hint of sexiness in this linguistic divorce. The word masterpiece on its own sounds racier. It connotes something bought rather than merely endured, and it shares the same syllabic beat as MasterCard, with all the potential to capitalize subliminally on its advertising. One month of Showtime: $16. Nine hundred and six hours of “Bleak House”: Priceless.

headline: Exit Is in With Viewers
text: Fox claimed victory in the ratings on Wednesday night, with Nielsen estimating that 22.1 million viewers tuned in at 9 o’clock to watch Brooke White, below, eliminated from “American Idol,” leaving four contestants. CBS ranked second for the night as "Criminal Minds" at 9 p.m. (12.9 million) and "CSI:NY" at 10 (11.4 million) were the only other shows to crack double-digit audience figures over all. CBS’s prime-time edition of “The Price is Right" with Drew Carey, formerly on Fridays, attracted 7.3 million viewers in its new 8 p.m. Wednesday slot, outpacing Fox’s comedies in the hour, “ ’Til Death” (5.5 million) and “Back to You” (7 million). NBC ranked third for the night, broadcasting a two-hour “Deal or No Deal” at 8 (8 million) followed by “Law & Order” at 10 (9.6 million). ABC was fourth, earning its largest audience of the night at 10 for “Boston Legal” (7.3 million).

headline: House Panel Approves Bill to Assist Borrowers
text: WASHINGTON  The House Financial Services Committee pushed forward on Thursday with an aggressive effort to help troubled homeowners, approving legislation that would make up to $300 billion in federally insured loans available to refinance the mortgages of borrowers in danger of foreclosure.

headline: Myanmar: Sanctions on 3 Companies
text: The United States broadened financial sanctions against Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, to include three prominent state-owned companies. The United States already restricts most trade with Myanmar but says these sanctions would prevent even indirect dealings with the companies  Myanmar Gem, Myanmar Timber and Myanmar Pearl  on international markets.

headline: Going Through Intersection of Fate
text: Rod Thorn called from New Jersey. Pat Riley left a voice message from Miami. One by one, the guys checked in, telling Byron Scott how happy they were for him, how much he deserved the N.B.A. coach of the year award and the taste of Western Conference playoff success after New Orleans’s five-game brush-off of Avery Johnson and Dallas.

headline: Koreans Recall an Era of Propaganda Battles
text: CHONGSON, South Korea  In early April, when North Korea called President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea an “impostor,” a “traitor” and an “American running dog,” the verbal barbs sounded all too familiar to Jin Yong-seon. He has a museum filled with them.

headline: London Is Counting the Votes in Its Tight Mayoral Contest
text: LONDON  Mayor Ken Livingstone campaigned hard across London on Thursday as voters went to the polls to decide whether to let him stay in office for another four years. Meanwhile, seats on 159 local councils across England and Wales were up for grabs in elections widely seen as a referendum on the popularity of Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s floundering Labor government.

headline: Agency Seeks New Credit Card Rules
text: The federal agency that oversees savings associations is proposing new rules that would prohibit several practices of the credit card industry that consumer groups have long called unfair and deceptive.

headline: Confronting the Perils of Puberty Squared
text: How must the world appear to someone who has been treated as an exotic clinical specimen from birth? The moody, surreal “XXY” explores the world of Alex (Inés Efron), an intersex teenager  born with both male and female sex organs  navigating the treacherous emotional and hormonal rapids of uncertain gender.

headline: Shame in Calais
text: For Americans, what is happening each night in the French channel port of Calais is poignantly and shamefully familiar. As Caroline Brothers reported in The Times recently, clusters of poor people wait for darkness and a high-risk chance to crawl inside or beneath a truck to cross to a country that needs and welcomes their labor but refuses to legally recognize their presence.

headline: What Lurks Beneath the Ruffles
text: Hedonism becomes a gravitational force in Ben Daniels’s compelling turn as an 18th-century libertine in “Les Liaisons Dangereuses,” which opened Thursday night in an eye-filling, very imbalanced revival at the American Airlines Theater. Making a sensational Broadway debut in Rufus Norris’s production, which also stars an uncomfortably cast Laura Linney, this London actor seems at all times pulled, pummeled and shaped by the prospect of physical pleasure.

headline: Spices and Spires
text: Reading

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Out-Of-Towners Make Mark on Broadway
text: Broadway theater contributed $5.1 billion to the economy of New York City in the 2006-7 season, according to the Broadway League, a trade association for the theater industry. The total included the spending by visitors, the costs to produce and run shows and the expenses incurred to maintain and renovate theaters. Out-of-towners bought the bulk of the 12.3 million tickets. Of all the tickets 65 percent went to tourists, and 18 percent to surburbanites. Of the 10.3 million tickets sold to out-of-towners, 4.69 million went to 3.16 million people who said they came to New York expressly for Broadway. These visitors contributed $2.23 billion to the city’s economy, the report said.

headline: At TriBeCa Film Festival, Winners Dot the Map
text: Films from Sweden, Turkey, the Netherlands, Britain, the United States and Spain captured the top awards Thursday in juried competitions at the Tribeca Film Festival. “Let the Right One In,” directed by Tomas Alfredson of Sweden and cited for its “exploration of loneliness and alienation through masterly re-examination of the vampire myth,” won the $25,000 Founders Award for Best Narrative Feature. It stars Kare Hedebrant, above. Huseyin Karabey, who directed the Turkish-Dutch-British production “My Marlon and Brando,”  cited for “its skillful blending of documentary style with a classic love story,” won the $25,000 prize for Best New Narrative Filmmaker. Directed by Gini Reticker of the United States, “Pray the Devil Back to Hell,” about peace-seeking Liberian women, won $25,000 as Best Documentary Feature. The $25,000 Best New Documentary Filmmaker prize went to Carlos Carcas of Spain for “Old Man Bebo,” cited for showing “that if you truly have art in your body and soul, it will find its way out into the world.” The winners were chosen from 12 narrative and 12 documentary features from 18 countries.

headline: Crowds Smaller at Immigrant Rallies
text: Thousands of supporters of immigrant rights gathered in more than a dozen cities on Thursday afternoon. But the crowds seemed smaller than at comparable events in past years, with the turnout apparently depressed by fear of arrest.

headline: A Pulpit-and-Pews Gulf on Obama’s Ex-Pastor
text: LUMBERTON, N.C.  The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., under fire for statements that have embarrassed Senator Barack Obama’s campaign, has found staunch support in the pulpits of black churches around North Carolina. The people in the pews, however, are far less accepting.

headline: Fed Takes Steps to Add Liquidity
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced new steps on Friday to help ease tight global credit markets by increasing the size of its cash auctions to banks and allowing financial institutions to put up credit card debt, student loans and car loans as collateral for Fed loans.

headline: ‘Faster, Better, Cheaper’
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Getaway in Belize, Roads Optional
text: AMBERGRIS CAYE was a sleepy destination for divers and fishermen 15 years ago, when the singer and songwriter Jerry Jeff Walker and his wife, Susan, built their house on the Caribbean waterfront.

headline: Corrections
text: Sports

headline: Art in Review
text: MARY CASSATT

headline: From France Avec Style, a Mingling of Generations
text: Last Thursday, after an impressive concert in Paris, the musicians of the Orchestre National de France and their conductor, Kurt Masur, headed to the airport to embark on an American tour. In Paris at the time, I heard that concert at the orchestra’s home, the Art Deco-styled Théâtre des Champs-Élysées.

headline: Diplomats’ Expulsion Angers U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  The State Department reacted angrily on Thursday to the expulsion of 10 American diplomats by Belarus, a former Soviet republic widely regarded as having one of the world’s most repressive governments.

headline: Evaluating the Risks for Male Infertility
text: Here are five tips if you are facing male infertility.

headline: Pakistan: Doctor Released After 2 Years
text: A Pakistani-American doctor has been released after being held by the authorities for more than two years, the local news media reported. Dr. Safdar Sarki, an advocate for greater autonomy for Sindh Province, was taken to a hospital in Quetta after the provincial government of Baluchistan withdrew weapons charges against him. Dr. Sarki, who lives in Texas, was arrested during a visit to Karachi in February 2006. The police in Baluchistan did not announce his arrest or any charges until last October. Pakistan’s Supreme Court identified him as one of the people held in a secret detention system.

headline: Wiggle Room for Summer Rentals
text: THE faintest glimmer of an economic slowdown is on the horizon this summer in some of the most popular vacation spots within a two-hour drive of New York. Rental agents from the Jersey Shore to the Hamptons to the Hudson Valley report that prices for summer rentals have remained about the same as last year but that many people are booking late, hoping for bargains to materialize.

headline: Special House Elections Could Reflect on Obama
text: WASHINGTON  Most Americans have never heard of Don Cazayoux or Travis Childers, two Southern politicians with names that could have been lifted from a John Grisham novel. But the electoral fate of those two gentlemen could be of some consequence in the ongoing presidential race.

headline: Trump International Residences & Golf Club and the Villas at Miraval
text: Trump International Residences & Golf Club

headline: Four Decades of Music That Redefined Free
text: “First of all, No. 1, there’s original music, only.”

headline: Bloomberg Proposes Lean Budget
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, warning that the boom in real estate and on Wall Street has come to an end, unveiled a $59.1 billion budget Thursday that would virtually halt the growth in city spending for the first time since the economic downturn following 9/11.

headline: Primal Instincts Hooked to an Art Against Artifice
text: Philip Guston, the Abstract Expressionist who late in life became a painter of dark, comic images, was a great as-if artist. He wanted, he said, “to paint things as if one had never seen them before, as if one had come from another planet.” He aspired “to paint as a cave man would.”

headline: Saxophone With Subtext
text: Through their sound, some jazz players connote more than what is on the surface. They have a subtext. When Frank Wess plays tenor saxophone his sound can have a delicate, almost courtly veneer. But there’s another player underneath that sound with an almost opposite disposition, brawny and bullish.

headline: New Policy on Security Clearances
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said service members would no longer have to disclose treatment for combat-related mental-health problems when they applied for security clearances. The change is intended to remove the stigma that some members of the military fear when they seek mental-health counseling, Mr. Gates said, and is meant to encourage those suffering from problems like post-traumatic stress disorder to seek help. “Part of the issue of removing the stigma is making it clear that you can be tough and seek help for dealing with these problems,” Mr. Gates said. “After all, you’re tough and you go into the hospital when you receive a physical wound.” The policy will allow members of the military seeking or renewing a security clearance to avoid disclosing treatment for a mental-health problem related to deployment in a combat zone, according to a memorandum issued by the Defense Department.

headline: Rivalry Played Out on Canvas and Page
text: Art is long, art criticism is often very, very brief, its Internet afterlife notwithstanding. Its viability relies on a mixture of prose style, sound-bite concepts, timing and its ability to clarify visual experience. Naming a major art movement can also help embed a critic in a period’s cultural achievement or its mythology.

headline: E.P.A. Proposes New Limits on Lead in the Air, the First Revision in 30 Years
text: WASHINGTON  For the first time in 30 years, the Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a new limit for lead concentrations in the air.

headline: Beijing Air Terminal Goes All Out for the Games
text: BEIJING  Beijing airport’s new Terminal 3  twice the size of the Pentagon  is the largest building in the world.

headline: Foundations Set Record for Giving in ’07
text: Giving by foundations set a record last year, hitting almost $43 billion, compared with $39 billion in 2006, according to estimates by the Foundation Center.

headline: Heavy Suit, Light Touches
text: The world at the moment does not suffer from a shortage of superheroes. And yet in some ways the glut of anti-evil crusaders with cool costumes and troubled souls takes the pressure off of “Iron Man,” which clanks into theaters today ahead of Hellboy, Batman and the Incredible Hulk. This summer those guys are all in sequels or redos, so Iron Man (a Marvel property not to be confused with the Man of Steel, who belongs to DC and who’s taking a break this year) has the advantage of novelty in addition to a seasonal head start.

headline: Recalling the Standard-Setter of Symphonic Ballet
text: As New York City Ballet’s ballet master in chief, Peter Martins, reminded the audience at the New York State Theater, Wednesday was the 25th anniversary of George Balanchine’s death. In these years Balanchine has become a growth industry, even more central to the art of ballet than during his lifetime.

headline: Marilyn Monroe Returns Home to Her Husband, Charlie Chaplin
text: It’s with some reluctance that I describe “Mister Lonely,” the new film by Harmony Korine, as dreamlike. Dreams are often vague, chaotic and dull, and other people’s dreams are notoriously uninteresting. “Mister Lonely” is enigmatic, its moods and meanings sometimes elusive in the way that dreams can be, but nearly every frame is an image of arresting clarity and beauty. And even when it strays beyond the border of sense, you can’t help accepting its logic and its truth, much as you do when your unconscious spools pictures in your sleep.

headline: Amid the Baroque and the Bluster, Love Blossoms
text: WASHINGTON  You don’t usually think of Plácido Domingo as a singer with a passion for Baroque opera, but having left his mark on virtually everything else in the repertory, he is giving it a look. In November he sang Oreste in Gluck’s “Iphigénie en Tauride” at the Met. Now he has taken up Bajazet, the central tenor role in Handel’s “Tamerlano.” After a run at the Teatro Real in Madrid this season, he sang his first American Bajazet on Wednesday evening in a new Washington National Opera production of “Tamerlano” at the Kennedy Center.

headline: Jones’s Teammates Appeal
text: Marion Jones’s former relay teammates have appealed a decision by the International Olympic Committee to strip them of their gold medals with the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland, their lawyer, Mark Levinstein, said. The International Olympic Committee ruled in April that the teammates who won gold in the 4x400 meter and bronze in the 4x100 meter for the United States at the 2000 Sydney Games were disqualified because Jones admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs during that period.

headline: South Africa: 9 Killed in Mine Accident
text: Eight miners and an elevator operator died when an elevator in a mine about 31 miles west of Johannesburg plunged almost 200 feet to the bottom of the shaft. Andrew Davidson, a spokesman for the mine owner, Gold Fields, said the rope bearing the elevator broke. Government regulators and the company are investigating the accident. Five other mine workers died at Gold Fields mines in two rock falls on Tuesday. “We’ve had a very bad week,” Mr. Davidson said.

headline: Loads of Grim Laughs Among the Garbage Cans
text: “Me to play,” the first words spoken by the blind and immobile, the irascible and imperious Hamm in Samuel Beckett’s “Endgame,” can be either threatening or misleading.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about legal maneuvering before the trial of the track coach Trevor Graham stemming from a doping investigation failed to give the context in some editions for comments by the Olympic sprinter Maurice Greene, who has been accused of cheating by a drug adviser expected to be a main prosecution witness.

headline: Determining Who Rides the Lifeboat
text: “I ask you, what am I? I’m one of the undeserving poor. That’s what I am. Think of what that means to a man. It means that he’s up agen middle class morality all the time ... I don’t need less than a deserving man; I need more. I don’t eat less hearty than him, and I drink a lot more.”

headline: Measles in U.S. at Highest Level Since 2001
text: Measles outbreaks in at least seven states are expected to produce more cases in 2008 than in any other recent year, federal health officials said Thursday, warning that measles is highly contagious and can cause severe illness and even death.

headline: In Battle With Malkin, Lundqvist Holds Ground
text: For the first time in the series, Pittsburgh center Evgeni Malkin was out of options. He had launched his approach toward the Rangers’ goal on a penalty shot by charging hard to his right, but as he cut back toward goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, Malkin curiously slowed down.

headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Are Said to Step Up Talks
text: After a months-long standoff, Microsoft and Yahoo are now engaged in active merger talks, people involved in the discussions said Friday.

headline: Officer’s Son, 18, Stabbed to Death
text: A teenaged son of a New York City police officer was stabbed to death on Thursday night at the entrance of an apartment building in Brooklyn, according to the police and relatives.

headline: A Driver, a Truck or a Train?
text: NO question about it, it’s great to have a second home. The rest, the relaxation  but, yikes, the transportation! Whether you fly, take a boat or a train to your vacation haven, once you arrive, you’ll probably need a car. So how do you get it there?

headline: The Miley Cyrus Message, in the Eyes of Schoolgirls
text: On sunny weekdays just before 1 o’clock, the corner of 61st Street and Amsterdam is a study in transition, as clusters of 15-year-old girls  giggling, calling out to the girls ahead of them, some half-running  head back from lunch to afternoon classes at the Beacon School, an alternative public high school with an emphasis on the arts and technology.

headline: Paddling, Wining and Dining on the Other Eastern Shore
text: NORTH, out of Virginia Beach, it was just water and sky, sea gulls and salt air.

headline: Qaeda Leader Reported Killed in Somalia
text: WASHINGTON  An American missile strike in Somalia apparently killed a militant long identified as one of Al Qaeda’s top operatives in East Africa on Thursday, but while Bush administration officials claimed success they also acknowledged facing an uphill battle to score lasting blows in their final months against the terrorist group around the world.

headline: An Architect’s Eye Reflected in Silver
text: AN ARCHITECT’S EYE

headline: Oakland Teach-In Looks at Budget Cuts and the War
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Third period at Paul Robeson High School in East Oakland was pretty much what you might expect on a sunny Thursday afternoon at the end of the term: distracted students, talk of graduation and nearly silent response to teachers’ questions.

headline: David Rockefeller’s $100 Million Gift to Harvard
text: To the Editor:

headline: Struck by Love in a Moody Underworld
text: “As Tears Go By” convulses to the rhythms of mah-jongg parlor brawls, back-alley beat downs and semiautomatic flares in the neon nights, but it’s the rapt little interludes that arrest attention: an aspirin tablet dissolving in a bottle of water, a woman lingering in the fluorescent shadows of a ferry terminal, a mysterious cut away from lovers in bed to a pair of street lamps curving over an empty country road, a modest tracking shot along a row of drinking glasses set upon a Formica tabletop.

headline: Notes From the War on Terror
text: For more than a year, President Bush has refused to honor legitimate requests from the Democratic majority in Congress for legal documents that he used to justify ordering the abuse, humiliation and torture of prisoners. This week, the Justice Department finally agreed to show some papers to members of the House and Senate.

headline: The Lurita Doan Story
text: It has been 11 months since investigators found that Lurita Doan, chief of the General Services Administration, violated the Hatch Act’s ban on politicking on the job, asking her staff how they could “help our candidates.” This week, the White House finally got around to ousting Ms. Doan from the government’s principal agency for awarding rich contracts in goods and services.

headline: Cubans Urged to Work Toward Change
text: HAVANA  The leader of Cuba’s labor union told tens of thousands of workers gathered in Havana’s Revolution Plaza on Thursday morning that they must get to work to build a better country.

headline: Gaza: Militant Tied to 2006 Raid Dies
text: A Hamas militant was killed in an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, the Israeli military and Hamas said. The military said the man, Nafiz Mansur, 40, had been involved in many attacks, including the capture of an Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, in a raid in 2006. Fighters in Gaza also launched more than 30 rockets and mortar shells at Israel, causing some damage, the military said.

headline: Uma Thurman Tells of Odd Card Left by Pursuer
text: In a harrowing account, the actress Uma Thurman described for a Manhattan jury on Thursday the cards and e-mail messages sent to her by an obsessive fan who sneaked onto the set of a movie she was filming in New York City in 2005.

headline: The Biological Clock, Ticking for Men Too
text: Dr. Harry Fisch is director of the Male Reproductive Center and a professor of clinical urology at Columbia University Medical Center's New York-Presbyterian Hospital, and the author of “The Male Biological Clock.”

headline: Those Who Live Longer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Swinging Suburbia and the Sensual City
text: A waggish conceptual venture, “Viva” is a startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution. Written and directed by Anna Biller, who also stars as the title character  a doll of a 1972 housewife first known as Barbi  the film unwinds as a series of adventures that take Barbi from swinging suburbia and backyard bacchanalias into the city and depravity. Despite the parallels with Sade’s “Justine” and the occasional lurid flourish, the depravity never becomes remotely depraved because Ms. Biller, despite her commitment to verisimilitude, maintains an ironic detachment throughout  because she’s a Brechtian or a bad actress, or perhaps both.

headline: Charles Tilly, 78, Writer and a Social Scientist, Is Dead
text: Charles Tilly, a social scientist who combined historical interpretation and quantitative analysis in a voluminous outpouring of work to forge often novel intellectual interpretations  as when he compared nation states to protection rackets  died on Tuesday in the Bronx. He was 78.

headline: 54 More Women Accuse Bloomberg Firm of Bias
text: At least 54 more women are accusing Bloomberg L.P., the financial-services and media company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, of discriminating against pregnant employees, a lawyer for the federal government said on Thursday.

headline: Big Retailers Scaling Back Expansion Plans and Shutting Stores
text: After a decade of breakneck expansion, big retail chains are slamming on the brakes  hard.

headline: Diversity of Talent and Spirit
text: A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, “Hollywood Chinese” surveys a century’s worth of Chinese-American actors and filmmakers, visionaries and dragon ladies, kung fu excellence and Fu Manchu insult, Oscar winners and cliché mongers. Assembled by the filmmaker Arthur Dong, it opens at the turn of the last century, when nickelodeon titles like “Beheading of the Chinese Prisoner” (1900) exploited stereotypes of the violent, inscrutable East, and closes by congratulating Justin Lin for directing “The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift” (2006).

headline: Family Feud Over Brooch
text: The older sister of the jeweler Ralph O. Esmerian is claiming that the 19th-century diamond brooch, above left, recently bought by the Louvre for $10.7 million wasn’t his to sell, Bloomberg News reported. The sister, Jacqueline Esmerian King, and her four adult children said in a motion filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan that the brooch and other jewelry belong to a family trust “and/or were purchased with money improperly diverted from the trust.” The brooch was created by François Kramer for the Empress Eugénie, wife of Napoleon III. Mr. Esmerian filed for bankruptcy on April 15 on behalf of the retailer he owns, Fred Leighton Inc. He did not return calls for comment.

headline: Buzzie Bavasi, a Dodgers Innovator, Dies at 93
text: Buzzie Bavasi, the general manager of the Dodgers during their glory years in Brooklyn and their first decade in Los Angeles, and a baseball executive for nearly a half-century, died Thursday in San Diego, where he lived. He was 93.

headline: The Gas Tax: Out for Summer?
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Backs to Wall, Rangers Fight Back
text: At the biggest moment of his season, Jaromir Jagr was facedown on the ice. He had just scored what would be a season-saving goal in the win-or-go-home game against Pittsburgh on Thursday night, and an opponent’s shoulder nearly knocked him cold.

headline: In the First Round, Mickelson Makes a Stretch Run
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  A national advertising campaign once played off Phil Mickelson’s impulsive shot selections by posing the question, “What will Phil do next?”

headline: Unlikely Allies Campaign for a Gas-Tax Holiday
text: DES MOINES  Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton found themselves taking a lonely stand on the campaign trail Thursday, defending the proposed gasoline-tax holiday while critics from both parties lined up against it.

headline: Lonely Boy’s ‘First Blood’ and First Pal
text: The spiritual godfather, as it were, of the comic British charmer “Son of Rambow” is Sylvester Stallone at his fiercest and certainly his gruntiest. Slathered in sweat and wearing a rag that circles his head like a tourniquet, Mr. Stallone is instantly recognizable as the Reagan-era avenger who first materialized in the instantaneous 1982 camp classic “First Blood.” He rises from the screen like a phoenix from the ashes, even if for the two boys at the center of “Son of Rambow,” who savor his every ponderous, violent move, he’s more of a muscle-bound Tinkerbell ushering them into a new world.

headline: 50-Shot Case May Affect Kelly’s Chances in a Mayoral Race
text: The not guilty verdict in the Sean Bell shooting last week was welcome news to three New York City police detectives charged in the case; one even wept as a judge in Queens read the ruling. But Justice Arthur J. Cooperman’s verdict also created some new challenges in the life of their boss, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: Fossella Is Charged With Drunken Driving
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Vito J. Fossella of New York was arrested early Thursday morning in a Washington suburb and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

headline: An Initiative on Reading Is Rated Ineffective
text: President Bush’s $1 billion a year initiative to teach reading to low-income children has not helped improve their reading comprehension, according to a Department of Education report released on Thursday.

headline: My Best Friend’s Big Fat (Shouldn’t Happen) Scottish Wedding
text: The romantic comedy “Made of Honor” adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush. Directed by Paul Weiland (“City Slickers II”), it begins on a nasty note when Tom (Patrick Dempsey), the putative Mr. Right in this taming-of-the-rogue fable, is introduced as a college boy wearing a hideous Bill Clinton mask and drunkenly bellowing for his Monica at a Halloween bacchanal.

headline: The Mayor’s Responsible Budget
text: Hard economic times are the real test of a mayor’s budgetary skills, and New Yorkers appear to be in luck. With the economy on the skids and Wall Street revenue weak, Mayor Michael Bloomberg unveiled a budget on Thursday that should keep the city on a healthy fiscal course  if everyone shows proper discipline.

headline: Sun Microsytems Reports Loss in Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Sun Microsystems, the maker of server computers, swung to a loss in the third quarter as economic challenges overshadowed its gains in overseas markets.

headline: A Taste of the Vast A.A.C.M. Legacy
text: The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians has issued a staggering amount of music in its four decades of existence. Here is a sampling: a dozen vital works, drawn from both the recent and more distant pasts. Most are still in print; all are available through online retailers like amazon.com, though in a few cases you might have to settle for a used copy or a digital-only release.

headline: Congress Passes Bill to Bar Bias Based on Genes
text: A bill that would prohibit discrimination by health insurers and employers based on the information that people carry in their genes won final approval in Congress on Thursday by an overwhelming vote.

headline: Exxon Posts Its 2nd-Best Quarter, but It’s Not Enough for Wall St.
text: Exxon Mobil reported the second-best quarterly profit in its history on Thursday  and investors could barely hide their disappointment.

headline: In Tougher Times, Carlyle Looks Abroad
text: It’s been a rough few months for David M. Rubenstein, co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘STRETCH (A FANTASIA)’ It was a most implausible explanation. Rose Mary Woods, President Richard M. Nixon’s secretary, made the cover of Time magazine in 1973 after claiming that she had inadvertently pressed the wrong button on a tape recorder and then simultaneously kept her foot on a pedal control for the device while making an impossibly long stretch across her desk to answer a telephone. This gymnastic accident, she said, caused her to erase part of a tape famous for having an 18 ½-minute gap: a crucial conversation between her boss and his chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman. In the June 20, 1972, conversation, the men were thought to have discussed the Watergate break-in, which occurred three days earlier, so theirs was a chat that the special counsel was eager to hear.

headline: Sun Microsystems Posts Loss and Plans to Reduce Jobs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Sun Microsystems just took a big step backward.

headline: The Pulpit Wouldn’t Be So Bully Without Them
text: The man behind the president’s speeches was called his “thinking machine and his writing machine,” and not least of all “his lying machine.” That criticism might have come yesterday  or almost any time in the last 175 years, because the president was Andrew Jackson, whose aide Amos Kendall sometimes polished his words. Jackson’s name-calling political opponent couldn’t have guessed how much our awareness and suspicion of people putting words in presidents’ mouths would grow.

headline: Sampling a Lifetime of Eclectic Collecting
text: Gustav Rau may not be a familiar name to the general public, but to old-timers in the auction world, it summons up the image of an eccentric collector who for nearly 40 years could be found in the London sales rooms of Sotheby’s and Christie’s. Often looking scruffy in hiking boots and rolled-up khaki pants, Mr. Rau trusted only his instinct and his eye, rather than the advice of professionals. He was a frequent bidder for  and buyer of  a wide range of art, including Rembrandts and Monets.

headline: Microsoft Outlines Its Yahoo Strategies
text: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, told employees on Thursday that the company would announce in “short order” which of three paths it would choose in its pursuit of Yahoo.

headline: State Officials Predict a Deep Recession
text: ALBANY  State budget officials said on Thursday that New York’s economy was slipping into a recession that could last through early next year and prove worse than the recession looming before the country as a whole.

headline: Agency Pays $12 Million to Settle Accounting Case
text: THE Interpublic Group of Companies, the large advertising concern, agreed on Thursday to pay a $12 million fine to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into its accounting practices.

headline: Do the Rich Pay Taxes? Italy Tells All
text: ROME  Many Italians’ attitude toward taxes runs something like this: Why should I pay if no one else does? Evasion is so common that landlords often demand two leases: one private with the actual amount expected, the other far lower and submitted to the authorities. Both, bafflingly, are vetted by lawyers.

headline: In a Chokehold, on the Mat and in Life
text: In “Redbelt,” David Mamet has taken a sturdy B-movie conceit  a good man versus the bad world, plus blood  tricked it out with his rhythms, his corrosive words and misanthropy, and come up with a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy. That may sound like a perilous combination, but the film’s visual moderation, contained scale and ambition keep it well tethered. It’s a fight film, purely if not simply, which of course also means it’s about the struggle to live.

headline: Louisiana Democrat Holds His Party at Bay for a Chance at Victory
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  A Democrat stands a serious chance of taking a seat in the House of Representatives from Republicans in a special election here on Saturday. But to achieve that chance of victory in this Republican fortress, the candidate has labored to dissociate himself from the Democratic Party’s national leaders.

headline: Massachusetts Museums That Speak to Children
text: THE Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams is a cavernous temple of modern art, with exceptionally big and provocative works in a variety of media. The Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., by contrast, serves up a whole different aesthetic, one filled with soda fountains, family dinners and sweetly nostalgic takes on small-town life.

headline: Lessons From Big Leagues Guide a Bassmaster Rookie
text: APPLING, Ga.  Bass were busting up the water 60 yards away, feeding on bait fish. A fisherman trolled toward the melee to throw his bait and see if they were tournament-ready bass. After he flipped his bait, there was no movement, and no bass.

headline: Selected Studies: Male Infertility
text: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: For a 4th Month, Shoppers Curtail the Desire to Spend
text: Consumer spending barely budged in March, the fourth month in a row that Americans eschewed the shopping mall, seeking to conserve cash in an economic downturn.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,054 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Voting Rights Are Too Important to Leave to the States
text: It would be hard for Florida to surpass its disastrous performance in the 2000 election, but give the Sunshine State credit for trying. Its latest assault on democracy: a law threatening volunteer groups with crippling fines if they make small mistakes in registering voters. The law seems clearly aimed at keeping new voters  especially minorities and the poor  off the rolls. And it is working. The League of Women Voters, which has registered Florida voters since 1939, has called off its registration drive this year.

headline: Amazon Sues Over State Law on Collection of Sales Tax
text: Amazon.com has filed a lawsuit challenging New York State’s new law forcing online retailers to collect sales tax on shipments to state residents.

headline: Anti-French Boycott Falters in China
text: BEIJING  They came. They expressed patriotic fervor. Then they shopped.

headline: Minister’s Comments Hold Little Sway in Indianapolis Enclave
text: INDIANAPOLIS  In the cafes, gift stores and the gourmet dog biscuit shop in this city’s neighborhood of Broad Ripple Village, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.’s name draws all sorts of responses  sighs, rolling eyes, laughter, grim silence.

headline: U.S. Shed Fewer Jobs Than Expected in April
text: The American economy shed 20,000 jobs in April, the Labor Department said on Friday in a report that many economists took as powerful evidence that the United States is ensnared in a recession.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Wednesday about a news conference at which Senator Barack Obama renounced ties to his former pastor referred incorrectly in some copies to Mr. Obama’s relationship with his father. The assertion that Mr. Obama had “never known” his Kenyan father should have been that he had “barely known” him.

headline: Young Rays Give Yanks a Model to Envy
text: BALTIMORE  The Tampa Bay Rays edited their team name, they changed some players, they say they adjusted their attitude and now they are trying to alter a losing culture that has been their birthmark. That final chore, the challenge of transforming helplessness to hopefulness, will not be accomplished in weeks.

headline: Hughes Out With Fracture in His Rib
text: The injury to the Yankees right-hander Phil Hughes is worse than first thought. Hughes has a stress fracture in a rib on his right side, just under his pitching arm, and he will miss at least four weeks and probably more.

headline: Book Asserts Black Reporter Didn’t Kill White Officer in ’81

headline: Dark Memories Abound
text: For a tale spiked with so much torment, “Fugitive Pieces” feels remarkably soothing. In images rose-tinted and golden-toned, this dreamy adaptation of Ann Michaels’s acclaimed novel transforms a wrenching Holocaust-survival drama into the cinematic equivalent of warm milk and honey.

headline: As Handicapping Gets Less Common, It Also Gets Harder

headline: Holtz Leads Hall of Fame Inductees
text: Lou Holtz, the only coach to lead six programs to bowl games, was named to the National Football Foundation and College Hall of Fame. Holtz coached 36 seasons (1969-2004) at William and Mary, North Carolina State, Arkansas, Minnesota, Notre Dame and South Carolina. The only other coach selected was John Cooper, who spent 24 seasons (1977-2000) at Tulsa, Arizona State and Ohio State.

headline: Pakistan Talks End on Positive Note
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Leaders of Pakistan’s governing coalition concluded talks in Dubai on Thursday over how to restore the high court judges ousted by President Pervez Musharraf without saying whether they had reached an agreement. But they promised good news and fears of a breakup of their month-long coalition subsided, the local news media reported.

headline: The Melting Pot on a High Boil in Flushing
text: IT was slow going on the thronged sidewalks of downtown Flushing, Queens, one recent spring afternoon, in the heart of its huge and bustling Asian community. Along Main and Union Streets many of the signs and the conversations are in Chinese, Korean or Vietnamese. A street vendor blasted Chinese pop music. At a sidewalk counter you can buy Peking duck to go. I passed under the wide window of a tea shop where high school kids sat people-watching and text-messaging as they sipped bubble tea, the sweet Chinese tea with pearls of tapioca in it. At a Chinese grocery tiny grandmas elbowed me aside, the better to haggle with the grocers over vegetables and fruit.

headline: Hendrix Company Disputes Sex Video
text: Experience Hendrix, the Seattle-based company that manages the music and merchandise of the legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix, said in a statement that “we strongly dispute the claimed authenticity” of a newly released sex video purporting to feature him. Posted on its Web site (experiencehendrix.com) on Wednesday night, the statement called the film  being released by Vivid Entertainment, a Los Angeles company that is one of the biggest players in the porn-film business  “a callous attempt to trade on the image and reputation of a deceased artist who is unable to defend himself against such an outrageous and baseless assertion.” The video by Vivid, which said it conducted extensive research to prove the film’s veracity, shows the face of a man who resembles Hendrix, but it does not incorporate any of his music. On Thursday Steven Hirsch, Vivid’s co-chairman, stood by the film’s authenticity and said, “Anyone who believes it is not Jimi Hendrix in this video should come forward and prove it, rather than rely on their emotions to make baseless claims.” He said that since the film’s release his company has been approached by unidentified people who “may want to step forward to verify” that the man in the film is Hendrix, adding that “if they do, we will release their opinions in due course.”

headline: Jazzfest: Local and Proud of It
text: New Orleanians have long been advising me to see Johnny Sketch and the Dirty Notes, which plays the city’s clubs often and had an early-afternoon set on Thursday. No wonder they’re fond of the band. Its lyrics are local and proud of it, jokey with a hard-headed undertone. In “Trouble,” Johnny Sketch rhymed over a swinging vamp: “Sometimes you think you know what livin’ uptown is like, I’ll tell you one thing for sure, y’all, they’re gonna steal your new bike.”

headline: Jazzfest: Randy Newman, From Cakewalks to Fats Domino
text: Randy Newman, who is not the most prolific songwriter, sprinkled his Jazzfest set with new songs: easy-rolling, ragtimey piano parts carrying lyrics that often drifted toward patter: sometimes political, sometimes personal. One song counseled immigrants turned away at the border to “Smile right in their face/Pretty soon you’re gonna take their place.” The chorus of another song, about the relief of forgetting unhappy times, was “God bless the potholes down onMemory Lane.”

headline: The Spinning Wheel of Justice
text: I’m back in court today. The process of actually selecting a jury is pretty arcane. Every once in a while in Room 452 at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a clerk put the names of the entire pool in a wheel and spins it around, then chooses 40 randomly. I was among the ones called late Thursday morning, my second day of jury duty.We marched downstairs. The judge went over some of the basics of the case: the names of the defendant and plaintiffs, the witnesses to be called in case any of us knew any of them. Eight of the 40 raised their hands to claim some sort of conflict. After meeting one by one with the lawyers and the judge in the judge’s chambers, all eight were dismissed while the rest of us wondered why.

I stumbled on a new collection of climate poems (and scientific statements), available as a pdf download online from the British Council, an international organization devoted to promoting British culture and ideas around the world. More accurately, could it continue.

headline: Jazzfest: Mardi Gras Indian Chants
text: There are suits, and then there are suits. When the saxophonist Donald Harrison started his long, last-slot set on Thursday afternoon, he and his band were wearing business suits and playing musicianly small-group jazz: tricky tunes in odd meters–I counted a section in 7/4 time–with the extended harmonies and dissonances of 1960s hard-bop. Mr. Harrison and his band are more than adept in that idiom, but it was too cerebral for me after a long afternoon, so I wandered out.

headline: Jazzfest: Where’s the Jazz?
text: Where’s the jazz at Jazzfest? This facetious question has a few different answers. There’s always a steady allowance of modern jazz at the WWOZ Jazz Tent, which on Friday will feature Terence Blanchard and the Bad Plus, and the Economy Hall Tent, which can be counted on for hourly renditions of “When the Saints Go Marching In.” But because these tents lie on the periphery of the fairgrounds, they require some seeking out.

headline: Paterson Explains Why He Revealed Affairs
text: Gov. David A. Paterson shed some new light this morning on why he disclosed his marital infidelity only a day after he took over for a governor who resigned amid his own sex scandal. During an interview on the sports radio station WFAN-AM (660), the governor said that as he was preparing to replace Eliot Spitzer, he was already aware that many rumors were circulating about his personal life. Knowing some of those rumors to be untrue, Mr. Paterson said he decided he wanted to get out ahead of the story as quickly as possible.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Beet Rosti With Rosemary
text: This thick beet pancake — which I learned 20 years ago from Michael Romano — is cooked slowly until the beet sugars caramelize and a crunchy, sweet crust forms. It’s a lovely, unusual and versatile side dish, good with braised meats or grilled food. Served with a salad, it can even be a light dinner.
