headline: Digging Into the Numbers in a Mining Deal
text: Investors are clearly skittish about BHP Billiton‘s $162 billion hostile bid for rival mining monster Rio Tinto. Rio Tinto’s market value has sunk relative to BHP’s in recent days, giving back much of the premium investors had originally pumped into Rio Tinto’s shares. Regulatory concerns are a major issue. But a growing valuation gap may also be working against this deal, which, if completed, would rank among the largest takeovers in history.

headline: A Dead Composer’s Words, and Now His Music, Circle Ground Zero
text: In his life, the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen often stirred strong feelings with his avant-garde works. After 9/11, he stirred outrage by calling the attack on the World Trade Center “the greatest work of art that is possible in the whole cosmos.” Now one of his pieces is being performed near the very scene of that catastrophe. The new-music group Bang on a Can has programmed his “Stimmung” as the culminating piece of a 12-hour marathon ending early on the morning of June 1 at the World Financial Center Winter Garden.

headline: Coming Soon To Your PC: More Commercial Breaks
text: One of the most appealing attributes of online television viewing is the advertisements — actually, the lack of them. On the Web, commercial breaks usually last for 30 seconds, compared to two minutes or more on TV.

headline: The New York Times Close Up
text: In his weekly show on NY1, Sam Roberts interviews guests including Matt Gross.

headline: Enjoying Long Island
text: One of my favorite evenings of the year is when I finally get around to opening the bottle or two of the latest vintage of chenin blanc from Paumanok Vineyards that I’ve managed to accumulate. Year in and year out, this is one of the best American chenin blancs around. Of course, there aren’t that many good American chenin blancs — Heller Estate and a few other places in California come to mind. But Paumanok’s from the North Fork of Long Island stands out as delicious on almost any scale you choose.

headline: Blog Roll: More Picks

headline: Special House Elections Could Reflect on Obama
text: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that the outcome of two upcoming special House elections in the South could have implications for Barack Obama’s presidential campaign, as Republicans have tried to tie the local candidates to the Illinois senator. Go to column

headline: Bayh’s Capital Spending
text: Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama aren’t the only politicians with a whole lot on the line in Indiana next Tuesday: Senator Evan Bayh — Democratic moderate, Hillary supporter, vice-presidential aspirant and Hoosier-state powerbroker — also has a future hanging in the balance. So, how’s it going? According to The Indianapolis Star’s political ace Matthew Tulley, not so well:

headline: A.L. Leaders Showdown in Beantown
text: The Tampa Bay Rays (16-12) and the Boston Red Sox (17-13) are in a virtual tie for first place in the American League East, with the Rays (.571) edging the Sox out by a few percentage points (.567). Repeat, the Rays and the Red Sox, the defending World Series champions, are sitting atop the division.

headline: Warren Buffett, Heavy Hitter
text: Warren Buffett and baseball go way back. When he was 8 years old, in 1939, his grandfather took him from Omaha to Chicago to see the Cubs play the Brooklyn Dodgers. He has owned a quarter-share of the Kansas City Royals’ Pacific Coast League affiliate for 10 years. He says he has even been approached about buying the Cubs — but apparently he didn’t bite.

headline: Broncos Quarterback Joins Roster of Athletes With Diabetes
text: Denver Broncos quarterback Jay Cutler has been diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes, news that will likely raise awareness about the unique challenges faced by athletes with the disease.

headline: Clinton Touts Support From Former D.N.C. Chiefs
text: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C. –- One day after a former Democratic National Committee chairman switched his endorsement from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to Senator Barack Obama, the Clinton campaign sought to reclaim ground Friday afternoon by releasing a letter from seven former D.N.C. chairs –- and the family of an eighth -– making the case for Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy to Democratic Party leaders.

headline: A bit more about lumps
text: I realized that my previous post didn’t explain why we were talking about shipping and all that. Our conversation concerned an empirical problem with the Eaton-Kortum model of international trade, which was the basis of the big lecture.

headline: Jail Day for Altomare
text: Richard Altomare, the former chief executive of Universal Express must report to jail today, a federal judge ruled this afternoon. He said a warrant would be issued for Mr. Altomare’s arrest if he does not show up.

headline: Clinton Dishes to People Magazine
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton is still eating jalapenos, she follows the practical advice given by ladies’ magazines, and she’d hang out with Abraham Lincoln if she could go on a date with any famous person, alive or dead.

headline: Uma Thurman Fan Testifies He Meant No Harm
text: The man accused of stalking Uma Thurman took the witness stand this morning to say that he had thought of himself as playing a flirtatious “cat and mouse game” with the actress, whom he said he loved, admired and respected, but never intended to “alarm, harass, threaten or annoy.”

headline: Answers About Alternative Energy in the City, Part 3
text: Following is a third and final set of answers from Carol E. Murphy, who is taking questions from City Room readers about alternative energy choices for consumers, what New York City is doing to decrease its reliance on fossil fuels and how city dwellers can decrease their “carbon footprint.” We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline: Schools Sow Seeds of a Moderate Islam
text: A group of Turks is promoting a moderate and flexible vision of Islam by establishing schools in more than 80 countries, including Pakistan.

headline: Skepticism and Sadness After Death of ‘D.C. Madam’
text: Reactions to the cable-TV-eating news that Deborah Jeane Palfrey had been found dead in the shed of her mother’s home in Tarpon Springs, Fla., have been varied and plentiful, but two undercurrents seem to run through many: Rueful sadness about what we know so far, and deep distrust that we’ve heard the whole story.

headline: Car & Writer
text: In advance of summer road trip season, Lexus Magazine has launched a collaborative novel, “In the Belly of the Beast,” which seems to be about a young-ish new hire at Google who prepares for the move out West by buying herself a “sweet Lexus sedan” and hitting the highway with her morose anthropologist fiancé. She has doubts about the relationship; he has doubts about the car.

headline: Jazzfest: Terence Blanchard vs. Stevie Wonder
text: The crowded blocks of programming at Jazzfest can make for some toughcalls. Tonight, for instance, Stevie Wonder occupies the same slot asJohn Prine, Marva Wright, Michael Franti and Terence Blanchard with theLouisiana Philharmonic.

headline: Congress Ventures Down the ‘Slippery, Slippery Road’
text: Congress is in the business of making rules to live by, but things always get tense when it has to start applying rules to itself. Congress’s usual response to an ethical scandal has been to hope that it blows over.

headline: Frank Whiteley Jr. Dies
text: Frank Y. Whiteley Jr., who trained Ruffian and Forego, died Friday in Camden, S.C., where he had recently been hospitalized with pneumonia. Ginny Watts, his friend and companion for almost 20 years, said she was with him, as was his son Allan, who had come from Maryland, and his friend and former exercise rider, Jackie Peacock. His other son, David, who trained thoroughbreds for a number of years, also lives in Camden. Frank was 93.

headline: Clinton: I’m an Economic Engine!
text: Presidential candidates get hundreds, maybe thousands of requests for their autograph in a given day on the stump. Inevitably, they are asked to sign items bearing their names or likeness. Yet none more so than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has inspired all manner of posters, night gowns, T-shirts, bibs and whatnot over the years.

headline: Jazzfest: A Female Brass Band
text: The Pinettes bill themselves as the world’s only all-female brassband. At the Jazz & Heritage stage Friday afternoon, clad in lime-greenT-shirts, they had the crowd on its feet.

text: Here are the alphabetical rosters for the top teams at the IIHF World Championship that starts today in Halifax and Quebec City. The names in bold are those we thought you’d take particular interest in seeing.

text: A lot of elected officials say they want to see Roe v. Wade repealed, clearing the way for abortion to be made illegal. But few of them go the extra step and say what they would like to see done to women who have abortions. Throw a scared 17-year-old woman in jail? For how long?

Subjects include protests over the Sean Bell shooting trial verdict, a tribute to the 93rd anniversary of the Armenian genocide, a Mass mourning of construction-accident victims, auditions for Metropolitan Transportation Authority Arts for Transit’s Music Under New York program, and more.

headline: After Throwing Rider, Police Horse Returns Home Alone
text: Aldo, a police horse on routine patrol in one of Manhattan’s busiest sections, may have lost his cool on Friday afternoon  but he didn’t lose his sense of direction.

headline: Pursuing the Next Level of Artificial Intelligence
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Like a good gambler, Daphne Koller, a researcher at Stanford whose work has led to advances in artificial intelligence, sees the world as a web of probabilities.

headline: Rewarding Suspense
text: The 62nd annual Edgar Awards, held in New York on Thursday, awarded “Down River” (St. Martin’s Minotaur) by John Hart, the Edgar for best novel, Publisher’s Weekly reported. Among the other winners were “In the Woods” (Penguin Group-Viking) by Tana French for best first novel by an American author; “Queenpin” (Simon & Schuster) by Megan Abbott for best paperback original; “Reclaiming History: The Assassination of John F. Kennedy” (W. W. Norton) by Vincent Bugliosi for best nonfiction crime book; and “Michael Clayton” (Warner Brothers Pictures) by Tony Gilroy for best motion-picture screenplay.

headline: Yankees Get Some Help in Stopping a Streak
text: The Yankees faced one of the best pitchers in baseball Friday night, and they really had no answer for him. They used their 28th different lineup, the most in the majors this season, and their final 14 hitters made outs against Érik Bédard of the Seattle Mariners.

headline: Jessye Norman Returns, Serenading the Seasons
text: Jessye Norman, a busy and faithful participant in New York’s vocal world for so many years, has not been around much in recent seasons. She returned to Carnegie Hall on Thursday in a recital titled “The Five Seasons.” It consisted, she explained, of the usual four, and she added “The Eternal Season of Love.”

headline: Exercise Your Brain, or Else You’ll ... Uh ...
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When David Bunnell, a magazine publisher who lives in Berkeley, Calif., went to a FedEx store to send a package a few years ago, he suddenly drew a blank as he was filling out the forms.

headline: Mortgage-Free, but Not Free From the Temptation to Borrow
text: This is a story about the other homeowners. Not the ones who are having trouble making their mortgage payments and getting all the attention lately. No, this is about the homeowners who do not owe any money on their primary residences because they have paid off their loans.

headline: Bankruptcy Protection for Retailer
text: The recent wave of bankruptcies in American retailing widened on Friday as Linens ’n Things, the big seller of beddings and home furnishings, filed for protection from its creditors.

headline: Higher Offer by Microsoft Brings Yahoo to Table
text: After a three-month standoff, Microsoft was in active merger talks with Yahoo on Friday, several people involved in the discussions said.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of a transcription error, a film review on Friday about “Redbelt” referred incorrectly to the character Sondra, played by Alice Braga. She is mouthy, not mousy.

headline: Turning Energy Uncertainty Into Opportunity
text: HIGH energy prices, the search for new power sources and uncertainties over future national policies offer power companies challenges as well as opportunities.

headline: Weill’s Operatic Impression of New York City Life, From the Stoop Up
text: The themes of regret, jealousy, immigration and domestic violence central to “Street Scene,” Kurt Weill’s 1947 opera about life in a New York tenement on a sweltering summer day, are still relevant, although city dwellers are now more likely to be texting on cellphones or huddling inside over a computer than actually talking to one another.

headline: Israel Clears Army in 5 Gaza Deaths
text: JERUSALEM The Israeli military on Friday presented the findings of its inquiry in the deaths of a Palestinian mother and her four children during an army operation in northern Gaza on Monday, suggesting they were killed by explosions caused by Palestinian ammunition.

headline: The Fed Aims at Credit Cards
text: After growing consumer complaints about hidden fees and other tricks of the credit card trade, the rules proposed by the Federal Reserve on Friday to deal with unfair or deceptive practices are a modest step forward. But the final versions of these rules will probably not go into effect until next year, and the nation’s bankers are already mounting a strong opposition to any changes in the rough ways they are allowed to do business.

headline: Tuning In on Thursday
text: CBS delivered more viewers on Thursday, but ABC fared better among adults 18 to 49, with “Grey’s Anatomy,” with Ellen Pompeo and Patrick Dempsey and “Lost” putting it on top in that demographic in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, the ABC shows trailed their competitors on CBS, drawing 15.1 million and 11.1 million viewers, compared with 17.8 million for “CSI” at 9 and 12.9 million for “Without a Trace” at 10. CBS also let in the 8 o’clock hour with “Survivor” (12.5 million), which easily outperformed ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (7.9 million) and NBC’s comedies in that hour, “My Name is Earl” (6.8 million) and “Scrubs” (5.9 million). NBC and Fox shared third and fourth place. Fox had more viewers; NBC more of the 18-to-49 set, thanks to “The Office” at 9 and “ER” at 10. NBC’s “30 Rock” continued to struggle at 9:30 (5.4 million).

headline: A Clinton Religion Aide Is Careful Not to Preach
text: DUNN, N.C.  For Burns Strider, this was something close to heaven on earth. The smoke from the roasting pig was wafting over him, the Carolina sunshine was pouring down and he had a small-town preacher in his grasp.

headline: After Hiatus, States Set Wave of Executions
text: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  Here in the nation’s leading death-penalty state, and some of the 35 others with capital punishment, execution dockets are quickly filling up.

headline: Occupation of Palace Area Invigorates Native Hawaiian Movement
text: HONOLULU  A Native Hawaiian independence group laid claim this week to the nation’s only royal palace and the state land surrounding it, raising anew the issue of self-determination for the islands’ native people.

text: In the vast swath of the New York region that is not New Jersey, gas stations are trying not to break “the Four.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: Judge Says Reggie Bush Must Testify
text: Reggie Bush will testify June 23 about whether he took cash and gifts while attending Southern California on an athletic scholarship, a San Diego Superior Court judge ruled. Bush, a running back for the New Orleans Saints, is being sued by Lloyd Lake, who says he lent Bush and his family nearly $300,000 in a business deal that fell apart. Bush has denied the charges. The judge, Joan B. Lewis, set the trial for March 13, 2009.

headline: Actors Extend Their Contract Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said on Friday that they would extend their current round of contract talks through Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A listing of medications on April 22 with the Personal Health column about hypertension misstated the chemical in the blood whose production is affected by the medications known as ACE inhibitors and ARBs. It is angiotensin II, not acetylcholine esterase.

headline: Paterson Says He Feared Exposure by State Police
text: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Friday that he decided in March to admit publicly to an extramarital affair because he feared that a rogue unit of the New York State Police would disclose the information to embarrass him.

headline: Lincoln Center Summer
text: Midsummer Night Swing and Lincoln Center Out of Doors, those hardy perennials of summer in Manhattan, have announced their schedules. The 20th season of Midsummer Night Swing, featuring the first appearance of Nellie McKay & the Aristocrats Swing Band and a range of ensembles offering music including hot jazz and funk, tango, salsa, electro, Cuban son, samba and rumba, will run from July 8 to 26. The attractions of Lincoln Center Out of Doors comprise flamenco, gypsy guitar, the 25th annual Roots of American Music Festival, “Wordless Music” (a program of minimalist works), rock versions of opera arias and the New York premiere of “Still Black, Still Proud: An African Tribute to James Brown.” That festival begins on Aug. 7 and runs through Aug. 24.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about higher retail rents on the Lower East Side of Manhattan gave an incorrect name for one of the new hotels that is helping to improve the neighborhood’s image. An 18-story hotel where rooms will start at $375 a night is to be called Thompson LES, not the Allen Hotel. The article also misstated the name for retail space at Avalon Bowery Place. It is Extra Place, not Exit Place.

headline: A Tribute to Robbins and His Artistic Partners, Past and Present
text: A nice touch to the current New York City Ballet season  observing the 10th anniversary of Jerome Robbins’s death  is its inclusion of guest artists. At Tuesday’s gala the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham sang “Somewhere” during “West Side Story Suite”: crossover at its best (and far more idiomatic than Leonard Bernstein’s own infelicitous recording with Kiri Te Kanawa and José Carreras).

headline: Papers Filed for Judicial Hearing on City Council Spending
text: Relying on an antiquated provision of the New York City Charter, a civil rights lawyer filed papers in State Supreme Court on Friday requesting a judicial hearing on City Council spending practices that have recently come under intense scrutiny. The hearing, known as a summary inquiry, would not determine guilt or innocence, but would merely lay out the facts surrounding the case for public review.

headline: Injured Posada Hopes to Come Back Within 6 Weeks
text: Jorge Posada’s first experience with the disabled list has been miserable  “Not good at all,” he said  and he does not want to be there very long. So Posada, the Yankees catcher, has decided to spend the next several weeks resting and strengthening his damaged right shoulder in hopes of a comeback within six weeks.

headline: An Overdue Honor for a Pioneer Sportswriter
text: Mary Garber is a legend. On Monday, she will be inducted into the Hall of Fame of the National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association, as a pioneer among female sportswriters, among all of us.

headline: New Jersey Lawmakers Get a Harsh Ethics Primer
text: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J.  It was, in a way, the fox delivering a message to anyone in the henhouse who cared to listen.

headline: Big Powers Agree on New Bid for Iranian Nuclear Freeze
text: PARIS  The world’s major powers agreed in London on Friday to offer Iran modest new incentives to coax it to freeze important nuclear activities.

headline: Zimbabwe Calls for Runoff, but Opposition Challenges Vote Count
text: JOHANNESBURG  After more than a month’s delay, the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission on Friday officially announced the results of the disputed March 29 presidential election, saying that the opposition candidate, Morgan Tsvangirai, had won more votes than the incumbent, Robert Mugabe, but not enough to avoid a runoff.

headline: Religious Persecution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Philipp von Boeselager, Who Attempted an Assassination of Hitler, Dies at 90
text: Philipp Freiherr von Boeselager, believed to be the last surviving member of the inner circle of German Army officers who attempted to assassinate Adolf Hitler with a briefcase bomb on July 20, 1944, died on Thursday. He was 90 and lived in Altenahr, in the Rhineland-Palatinate.

headline: New Recordings of Legendary Pianist
text: This Tuesday privately made recordings of the American pianist William Kapell’s last concerts will finally be available. Sony/BMG is releasing this two-disc set, right, which has works by Chopin, Rachmaninoff, Bach, Mozart, Mussorgsky, Debussy and Prokofiev. Kapell was one of the great pianists of the mid-20th century when he died at 31 in a plane crash in 1953 while on his way home from a concert tour in Australia. A music lover in Melbourne had recorded radio broadcasts of several of his concerts on acetate discs, some of which made their way in 2004 through an intermediary to Kapell’s widow, Anna Lou Kapell-Dehavenon. Several of the works had never been recorded for commercial release by Kapell, and others represent new interpretations. “That last playing is a step beyond anything that we’ve had before,” Ms. Kapell-Dehavenon said. “Can you imagine how it feels? It’s really extraordinary.”

headline: For a Dancer in the Moment, the Past and Future Converge
text: I MARCHED into the dining room of the Greens at Cannondale, an assisted-living community in Wilton, Conn., decked out in the finery of an 18th-century Colonial gentleman. It was an unseasonably warm spring afternoon, and a rather incongruous situation. I was perspiring inside my black tricorn hat and my matching green breeches, waistcoat and frock coat. But my nerves calmed when the four-piece band played the opening notes of a dance number called “Fantocini.”

headline: About Mr. B.: A Compact Guide to a Master’s Works
text: When people find that their dancegoing is getting to be a habit, they often ask, “How can I find out more about this?” The answers are endless and usually too complicated to be of much practical help. But now at last we can say, “If you like Balanchine, you must read Nancy Goldner’s ‘Balanchine Variations.’ ” Slim enough to fit into a jacket pocket, it surveys 22 of Balanchine’s most popular ballets; it’s good-humored, enthusiastic and undictatorial; it gives you numerous things to look out for in any performance; and it abounds with insights.

headline: Don’t Rush to Praise Sugar-Cane Biofuels
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A theater review on Friday about a revival of “Les Liaisons Dangereuses” by Christopher Hampton, at the American Airlines Theater, misstated the year that the play, Mr. Hampton’s adaptation of the novel of the same title, was first produced. It was 1985, not 1986.

headline: Viacom’s Profit Increases 33% With Help From a Video Game
text: Viacom, the media company controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, said on Friday that its first-quarter profit rose 33 percent on sales of the video game Rock Band and higher ratings at its cable channels.

headline: Tax Bill Fuels a Canadian Debate on Film Censorship
text: OTTAWA  Debate over arcane tax law rarely provides much in the way of drama. But in Canada, a single sentence in a 560-page tax bill has brought a procession of film stars and directors to the Senate, has started a national debate about censorship, and may even provoke a federal election.

headline: 20,000 Jobs Lost in 4th Month of Decline
text: The American economy lost 20,000 jobs in April, the fourth consecutive month of decline, in what many economists took as powerful evidence that the United States is almost certainly now ensnared in a recession.

headline: A Clinton Aide at Home in Small Towns and Churches
text: DUNN, N.C.  For Burns Strider, this is something close to heaven on earth. The smoke from the roasting pig is wafting over him, the Carolina sunshine is pouring down and he’s got a small-town preacher in his grasp.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: Fading Sounds of an Elegant Manhattan
text: For the last 14 years, some of the most welcoming sounds in Midtown Manhattan have been the voice and piano of Daryl Sherman, heard as you enter the Waldorf-Astoria hotel at Park Avenue and 49th Street. As you ascend the green carpeted stairs to the lobby, her music invites you into a world of elegance where the spirit of Cole Porter, a longtime resident of the Waldorf, still hovers.

headline: Ailey Fledglings Show How Far They Can Fly
text: Is it quibbling to say that the Ailey II dancers look way too professional to be members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s junior troupe? Or to be participating in an event, the Joyce Theater’s “1 2 3 Festival,” that showcases dancers at the start of their careers? Or that the emotional and physical intensity of the four works they performed on Wednesday night was almost too much? (Quite a few fans in New York City must have been hoarse the next day, to judge by the hoots and hollers that greeted each piece.)

headline: Nevada to Ask Fossett Widow to Reimburse It
text: LAS VEGAS  The State of Nevada, facing budget woes, will ask the widow of the millionaire adventurer Steve Fossett to reimburse it about $487,000 toward the cost of the monthlong search for him last fall.

headline: His Fortune Made, De La Hoya Brings Fight to the People
text: If you absolutely had to watch Oscar De La Hoya’s eight fights since June 2001, it cost you about $400 in pay-per-view fees, enough to fill up your S.U.V.

headline: Dolly Parton’s Subversive Message
text: It’s a good thing that Dolly Parton has written songs about her Smoky Mountain homeland, and that she can flash pictures of the house and the landscape in her shows. It gave a pleasant frame to her show at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday. Love your home, love your country.

headline: On Staten Island, More Deer and Few Solutions
text: There will be no deer hunting on Staten Island. Not anytime soon, probably not ever.

headline: No Budging Is Detected in Bidding for Newsday
text: Rupert Murdoch does not plan to raise his bid for Newsday in an attempt to match a higher offer from Cablevision, while Mortimer B. Zuckerman has not signaled whether he will increase his offer, people involved in the talks said on Friday.

headline: At Least 12 Killed in Bombing at Yemeni Mosque
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A bomb rigged to a motorcycle detonated outside a mosque in northern Yemen on Friday, killing at least 12 worshipers, wounding dozens and threatening to rekindle an intermittent war between northern rebels and government forces.

headline: On Broadway, Revivals Aren’t Only for Shows
text: As Christine Baranski, Mark Rylance, Bradley Whitford and the other cast members of the 1960s farce “Boeing-Boeing” face a house full of first-nighters on Sunday, one concern may be whether the play will be upstaged by the theater’s new ceilings, new seats, new carpets and  not inconsequentially  new restrooms.

headline: An Upstart Up Against a Jewel
text: Just before 6 a.m. on Tuesday, in a spacious but dilapidated studio belonging to WNYC in New York, a veteran public radio broadcaster named John Hockenberry put down his pages of notes, raised two fists to the sky, and shouted something that only he and his co-host, Adaora Udoji, could hear.

headline: Boardroom Types
text: IT takes all types to run a successful business.

headline: Overkill and Short Shrift
text: The Rev. Jeremiah Wright is no doubt (and regrettably) a big issue in the presidential campaign. But what we’ve seen over the past week is major media overkill  Jeremiah Wright all day and all night. It’s like watching the clips of a car wreck again and again.

headline: Fed Moves to Loosen Tight Credit
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced new steps on Friday to help ease tight global credit markets by increasing the size of its cash auctions to banks and allowing financial institutions to put up credit card debt, student loans and car loans as collateral for Fed loans.

headline: Barbaro’s Trainer Endures More Pain
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Michael Matz cannot seem to escape horse racing’s sometimes cruel, sometimes exhilarating twists of fate. On the eve of his return to the Kentucky Derby, Matz, the trainer of Barbaro, watched as one of the current stars of his stable, Chelokee, apparently sustained a condylar fracture of the cannon bone in his right front leg during the running of the Alysheba Stakes at Churchill Downs on Friday.

headline: Congressman May Face Jail in D.W.I. Case
text: Representative Vito J. Fossella was driving with a blood-alcohol level more than twice the legal limit when he was pulled over and faces a mandatory five days in jail if convicted, a Virginia prosecutor said on Friday.

headline: Suddenly, North Carolina Is Facing Tighter Race
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  Just days before the North Carolina primary, the Democratic presidential contest in this state is suddenly alive with a fresh air of competition, as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton seeks to capitalize on a controversy that polls suggest has whittled away some of Senator Barack Obama’s support among white voters.

headline: The No-Tasting Taste Test
text: IN a multilayered bit of twisted grammar, a young woman in a television commercial tells viewers, “So I go on vehix.com and you can literally take a test drive.”

headline: A Player Emerges from the Shadows to Claim the Lead
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Jason Bohn is not leading the Wachovia Championship in any statistical category. He was not among the 14 of the top 20 players in the World Golf Rankings who headlined the pretournament promotions. He is, in fact, barely among the top 200 players in the world, ranked No. 196.

headline: One Country, Two Systems in Hong Kong Press
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese concept of “one country, two systems” is most obviously played out in Hong Kong’s boisterous media. Daily newspapers and local television reports here regularly carry photos and reports that would be banned on the mainland.

headline: Wagner’s Public Scolding Earns Him a Private One
text: PHOENIX  Carrying a football, Manager Willie Randolph walked into his office here Friday afternoon with Billy Wagner a step behind. When Wagner entered, the pitching coach Rick Peterson gently closed the door from the outside. It was safe to say that Randolph and Wagner were not going to play catch.

headline: Batter Up in Encores!
text: Cheyenne Jackson, who stars on Broadway as Sonny in “Xanadu,” will be Joe Hardy in the Encores! Summer Stars production of the musical “Damn Yankees” at City Center from July 5 to 27. Also joining the cast are Randy Graff as Meg Hardy, and Ana Gasteyer as Gloria. They will join cast members already announced: Sean Hayes as the devilish Mr. Applegate, and Jane Krakowski as the seductive Lola. ... Mandy Patinkin will star as Prospero when the Classic Stage Company opens its 2008-9 season with Shakespeare’s “Tempest.” Directed by Brian Kulick, the company’s artistic director, the performances will run Sept. 3 to Oct. 12. ... The Paris production of “The Lion King” (“Le Roi Lion”) won three Molière Awards, France’s version of the Tonys, on Monday night in Paris, Variety reported. Honors went to the show for best musical, costumes (by Julie Taymor, who also directed the production) and lights (by Donald Holder). John Malkovich was also honored for his direction of the French production of “Good Canary,” written by Zach Helm, the American screenwriter of “Stranger Than Fiction.” ... “How Theater Failed America,” Mike Daisey’s monologue, will move from a sold-out run at Joe’s Pub to a six-week engagement at the Barrow Street Theater. The final show at Joe’s Pub is on May 11; performances begin at the Barrow Street on May 16.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A chart with an article on Wednesday about legislation to overhaul federal patent laws omitted a unit of measurement. The figures for the number of patent applications for the last 20 years were in thousands. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the passage of a bill to prohibit genetic discrimination by health insurers gave an incorrect vote count for the Senate in some editions. It passed by 95 to 0, not 95 to 5.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from April 25 through May 2:

headline: Pentagon Considers Adding Forces in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is considering sending as many as 7,000 more American troops to Afghanistan next year to make up for a shortfall in contributions from NATO allies, senior Bush administration officials said.

headline: 5 Arrested in Newark Raids Against Large Drug Ring
text: NEWARK  His gun at his side, a helmet pulled low over his head, Police Officer Carlos Orbe wrestled a drug suspect to the floor of a darkened apartment in this city’s East Ward on Friday morning and felt something being driven into his stomach repeatedly.

headline: Agreement Will Restore Court Judges in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s governing coalition has agreed to reinstate the Supreme Court judges ousted by President Pervez Musharraf by offering a resolution in Parliament, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said Friday.

headline: Forever Dolly: Unbowed, Unsinkable
text: It’s a good thing that Dolly Parton has written songs about her Smoky Mountain homeland, and that she can flash pictures of the house and the landscape in her shows. It gave a pleasant frame to her show at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. Love your home, love your country.

headline: 7 Are Killed as Storms and Tornadoes Sweep Across Arkansas
text: CENTER RIDGE, Ark.  At least seven people were killed and 13 were injured in storms that swept across Arkansas early Friday, state emergency management officials said.

headline: Developers Picked for 2 Closed Brooklyn Firehouses
text: In something of a split decision, the city selected developers to remake two closed firehouses in Brooklyn on Friday, giving one to a firefighter advocacy group in Williamsburg but overlooking a similar group and choosing instead the Brooklyn Philharmonic to redevelop a firehouse in Cobble Hill.

headline: Pfizer Begins Settling Painkiller Cases
text: Pfizer has started settling cases over its Celebrex and Bextra painkillers, a New York lawyer said on Friday.

headline: A Journalist in Zimbabwe
text: To the Editor:

headline: Indiana Holiday
text: Our question for today is: What does the debate over that cheesy plan for a gas tax holiday mean to the American voting public?

headline: Rapper Creates Trust for Sean Bell’s Children
text: The rapper Jay-Z has established an educational trust for the two children of Sean Bell, the unarmed man shot and killed by the police in November 2006 on the day he was to be married, allhiphop.com reported. Last month the three policemen tried for Mr. Bell’s death were acquitted of all charges by a New York judge. Mr. Bell’s fiancée, Nicole Paultre Bell, has been appearing in “I Will Not Lose,” an advertising campaign for Rocawear, a clothing company founded by Jay-Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter.

headline: Hong Kong Embraces Olympic Torch
text: HONG KONG  Thousands of mainland Chinese and Hong Kong residents cheered the Olympic torch through the streets of Hong Kong on Friday during the largely peaceful first leg of its three-month trip through China.

headline: Creating Sounds for a Nonsensical World
text: During an interview segment in the concert devoted to Frederic Rzewski at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening in Carnegie Hall’s Making Music series, the moderator, Ara Guzelimian, asked Mr. Rzewski about his reputation as a political composer. Mr. Rzewski’s “Attica” (1972) and “War Songs” (2008) had just been performed, and ahead were “Natural Things” (2007), a work commemorating the Haymarket massacre of striking workers in 1886, and “Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues” (1980), a thundering arrangement of a 1930s protest song.

headline: ‘Rough’ ‘Tough’ Times, but Still No ‘Recession’
text: MARYLAND HEIGHTS, Mo.  President Bush has no shortage of words to describe the ailing economy.

headline: Derby May Have a Sprint at Start and the Finish
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  When the starting gates open Saturday for the 134th running of the Kentucky Derby, five front-running horses, all stuck in outside posts, will angle sideways and race one another to the rail. Big Brown, the morning-line favorite in the No. 20 post, must run the farthest and fastest of all if he is to gain the all-important position on the rail.

headline: Virus Kills 22 Children in Eastern China
text: BEIJING  A fast-spreading viral outbreak in China has killed 22 children, sickened nearly 3,600 others and caused panic among parents in an impoverished corner of Anhui Province, government health officials said Friday.

headline: Paterson Nominates Executive Director for Port Authority
text: Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Friday that he had nominated Christopher O. Ward, a former executive with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to be the authority’s executive director. Mr. Ward, 53, would succeed Anthony E. Shorris, who was appointed to the job last year by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Convention Preparations Prompt Suit by A.C.L.U.
text: DENVER  Groups planning parades or protests at the Democratic National Convention filed a lawsuit here on Friday charging that the Secret Service and the City of Denver are threatening free speech  not because of tight security rules, but by the very lack of them.

headline: Gold Medalist Listed as Banned-Drug User
text: A government witness list filed Friday publicly identified Antonio Pettigrew, winner of a gold medal in the 4x400-meter relay at the 2000 Olympics, as a user of banned performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: A Sweet-Toothed Queen’s New Royal Edict: Let Them Eat Cake, on Toe Shoes
text: Ballet companies of America, take note: it is possible to create new story ballets and not just retool the existing war horses. And it can be done without byzantine sets, two-intermission marathons or huge casts.

headline: Thurman Fan, Affable on Stand, Admits He Was Possibly ‘Foolish’
text: The man accused of stalking Uma Thurman testified on Friday that he thought he had played a flirtatious “cat and mouse game” with her, but that he had never meant to scare her.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Page 3 of the Travel section this weekend about lighthouses on Croatian islands that take guests gives an outdated name for the home country of some visitors to one lighthouse. It is the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.

headline: Population Dynamics
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Blacklash?
text: Since January, the Clintons have pummeled Barack Obama with racially tinged comments and questions about his character.

headline: Among Orthodox Jews, More Openness on Sexuality
text: Shortly before Toby Goldfisher Kaplowitz married two years ago, she went to a kallah teacher  a woman who prepares Orthodox Jewish brides to be intimate with their husbands.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Republicans Crossing Over to Vote in Democratic Contests
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Until now, Shirley Morgan had always been the kind of voter the Republican Party thought it could count on. She comes from a family of staunch Republicans, has a son in the military and has supported Republican presidential candidates ever since she cast her first ballot, for Richard M. Nixon in 1972.

headline: Parmalat Settles U.S. Shareholder Suit
text: The Italian dairy company Parmalat, which collapsed in December 2003 in the country’s largest bankruptcy, agreed to settle a shareholder lawsuit in the United States by paying investors stock with a market value of almost 24 million euros ($37 million). “The removal of the class action as an issue in return for a nominal payment removes a cloud that has been hanging over the stock,” said Richard Holloway, an outside spokesman for Parmalat. The settlement is subject to court approval.

headline: What a Difference a Year Makes
text: It was a year ago Tuesday that Roger Clemens interrupted a Sunday afternoon game in the Bronx between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners to announce that he was coming back in pinstripes. A lot has happened since then for Clemens, little of it good.

headline: A Last Vanishing Act for Robert Vesco, Fugitive
text: HAVANA  Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier who spent most of his life eluding American justice, might even have managed to die on the sly.

headline: Sometimes a Little Psychology Helps Bring a Contract Home
text: How would you compare the bridge-playing abilities of humans and computer programs?

headline: Rangers Find Way to Impede the Penguins’ Advance
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  As the end of Game 4 between the Rangers and the Penguins devolved into something between a scuffle and a brawl, the Rangers had, at the very least, thrown the first piece of drama into the Penguins’ playoff march.

headline: Parsing McCain on the Democrats’ Health Plans
text: Senator John McCain has been repeatedly suggesting that his Democratic rivals are proposing a single-payer, or even a nationalized health care system along the lines of those in countries like Canada and Britain.

headline: Derby Side Bet: U.P.S. vs. KFC
text: There is a lot riding on the Kentucky Derby for two charities in Louisville. Two corporations have bet on different horses, and if either of those wins, the charity chosen by the victorious bettor will be $10,000 richer.

headline: The Anguish of War, Expressed in Movement
text: Nora Chipaumire’s “Chimurenga (struggle, cry, revolution)” demands close attention, even though she doesn’t always make it easy. But it’s no easy thing Ms. Chipaumire is trying to do in translating her youth during Zimbabwe’s second war of liberation into a 60-minute dance-theater work.

headline: As Gasoline Prices Soar, Politicians Fall Back on Familiar Solutions
text: WASHINGTON  When President Bush called on Congress this week to address soaring gasoline prices by allowing drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and by expanding nuclear power, Democrats on Capitol Hill quickly pummeled him as falling back on tired ideas.

headline: Listen to Your Statement
text: PEOPLE loathe keeping track of expenses, and I am no exception. Few chores manage to combine anxiety and tedium in such high doses.

headline: Police Question Olmert in Possible New Criminal Inquiry
text: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, was questioned by police investigators on Friday in connection with what appeared to be a new criminal inquiry.

headline: Arab and Israeli Peace, at Least for Children
text: “Bridge Over the Wadi” begins with the small and familiar to examine the big and complex. The first scene in this documentary, scheduled to have its television premiere in this country Sunday night on the PBS World channel, shows two sleepy-eyed little boys and their morning routine.

headline: Tom Cruise on ‘Oprah,’ Without Gymnastics
text: “This is so normal!” Oprah Winfrey exclaimed as Tom Cruise took her through the vast, pristine, wood-paneled kitchen in his mountaintop estate in Telluride, Colo. Ms. Winfrey sounded relieved, almost as if she were half expecting to find space helmets and a teleporting station wedged next to the stove.

headline: Britain: 2 Convicted of Trying to Extort a Royal
text: A judge sentenced two men to five years in prison after they were convicted of demanding nearly $100,000 from a member of the royal family in exchange for audio and video tapes featuring accusations that the royal, who is married, participated in a sex act with a male employee at a party. A court order in Britain has prevented publication of the identity of the extortion target. Scotland Yard’s counterterrorism squad arrested the suspects, Ian Strachan, 31, and Sean McGuigan, 41, in a sting operation. The court was told that the royal, known in court as Witness A, contacted the police after a man claiming to have the tapes contacted one of his assistants and demanded that the royal contact him “if he knows what’s good for him.”

headline: A Swallow in the Hand
text: A couple of times in the past few weeks, I’ve stopped by a local swamp where the peepers live. It’s hard to believe that the high-pitched chorus of such small frogs could amount to a roar, but it does. It rises into the night sky and swallows the listener. My internal compass seems to go awry in the midst of such an outcry. In the darkness, there is no horizon except a silence somewhere on the far edge of that cacophony. To the extent that any one peeper has a sense of identity, it must dissolve completely in that night song, because I certainly feel myself dissolving when I hear it.

headline: Israel’s Tactics Thwart Attacks, With Trade-Off
text: NETANYA, Israel  Suicide bombings in Israel have dropped off so significantly that the nation’s security officials now dare to speak openly of success. But the very steps they are taking to thwart bombers appear to collide head-on with the government’s agenda of achieving peace with the Palestinians.

headline: U.S. Seeks New Curbs on Credit-Card Practices
text: WASHINGTON  Federal bank regulators on Friday proposed a new set of rules to make it more difficult for credit card companies to raise rates arbitrarily, conceal high penalty fees or engage in other practices that consumer groups say are abusive.

headline: Tibetan Envoys Head to China for Informal Talks
text: NEW DELHI  A week after the Chinese government offered to meet with representatives of the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan government in exile in India announced Friday that two envoys were on their way to an undisclosed location in China for “informal” discussions. But in a signal of low expectations, the announcement predicted that the visit would be “brief.”

headline: Bids for Botox? Auctions Go Deep to Aid Schools
text: The auctioneer came on with a bold pitch, trying to get the bidders to open their wallets as wide as possible.

headline: William Frankel, Who Edited Jewish Chronicle, Dies at 91
text: LONDON  William Frankel, who reinvigorated the venerable London-based newspaper The Jewish Chronicle as its editor for two decades, broadening its coverage of world affairs to include the Vietnam War and the American civil rights movement, died on April 18 in Washington, where he had a home. He was 91.

headline: It’s Newer Homes That Stand Empty as Vacancies Rise
text: THERE are a record number of vacant homes in America, the government reported this week, and the vacancies are concentrated in the newest part of America’s housing stock.

headline: A Day in May to Celebrate, for Mexicans and the City
text: Phone rings.

headline: Jason Shinder, 52, Poet and Founder of Arts Program, Dies
text: Jason Shinder, a poet, anthologist and teacher who founded the Y.M.C.A. National Writer’s Voice program, one of the country’s largest networks of literary-arts centers, died on April 25 at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 and also lived in Provincetown, Mass.

headline: Kennedy’s Near Future Could Be in the Minors
text: The Yankees have not lost faith in the promise of Ian Kennedy, but they are reluctant to devote more regular starts to him now. Kennedy has not won a game in five starts, and Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged he could be sent to the minor leagues because the Yankees do not need a fifth starter until May 10.

headline: Composer’s Work to Play Where Words Stirred Ire
text: In his life, the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen often stirred strong feelings with his avant-garde works. After 9/11, he stirred outrage by calling the attack on the World Trade Center “the greatest work of art that is possible in the whole cosmos.” Now one of his pieces is being performed near the very scene of that event.

headline: Chevron Profit Rises Even as Production Falls
text: Chevron said first-quarter profit rose 9.5 percent, beating Wall Street estimates. Net income climbed to $5.17 billion, or $2.48 a share, from $4.72 billion, or $2.18, a year earlier, the company said. Petroleum output dropped 1.7 percent, however, to the equivalent of 2.6 million barrels of crude a day. Chevron’s chief executive, David J. O’Reilly, plans to spend more than $400 million a week this year in the company’s costliest push ever to find new reserves, tap discoveries and expand refineries.

headline: Plans for a Cross-Border Peace Park in the Mideast
text: This month faculty members and students from the Yale School of Architecture will join counterparts from Jordan, the Palestinian territories and Israel to design the first cross-border peace park in the Middle East, Yale announced. On May 12 the design teams will begin a visit to the proposed park site, south of the Sea of Galilee at the confluence of the Yarmouk and Jordan Rivers. The park area includes the “Three Bridges” site, where a Roman bridge, an Ottoman railway bridge and a British Mandate road bridge still span the Jordan. No person, train or vehicle has crossed the river at this site since the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. “The goal of the event is to develop ideas on how to recreate a wetland from the dry lake bed into a bird sanctuary, convert the old power station into a visitors’ center, the old workers’ homes into eco-lodges and renovate the bridges so they can be used again,” said Munqeth Mehyar, the Jordanian director of Friends of the Earth Middle East, a Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian organization that developed the idea for the park, which has the support of the local Jordanian and Israeli authorities.

headline: A Divorce Is Sought by Governor of Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS  Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada, whose marital problems have been a titillating sideshow to the state’s more serious budget problems, filed for divorce on Friday, starting a legal battle to force his wife of 24 years to vacate the governor’s mansion.

headline: Footnote
text: The Mystic Seaport maritime museum in Connecticut has announced the retirement of Douglas H. Teeson, its president and director since 2001.

headline: Spinning Iraq
text: President Bush will never live down “Mission Accomplished”  and should not. When the White House’s spinners spun that claim five years ago (remember the aircraft carrier?), it seemed cocky and premature. As Mr. Bush continues his $526 billion war-without-end in Iraq, it seems stunningly deceitful.

headline: New Jersey’s Timid Legislature
text: Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey has thrown in the towel in his four-month effort to persuade the State Legislature to reduce his state’s colossal debt by sharply raising turnpike and parkway tolls. The Legislature, which does not share his sense of urgency, gave him no choice. Despite its merits, the plan had little support from Republicans or the Democrats, who control both legislative houses.

headline: Alou Sparks the Mets to a Welcome Victory
text: PHOENIX — As a few teammates lounged on plush leather couches, one eye on the movie "Old School" on the clubhouse television, Moises Alou, all 41 years of him, came bounding around a corner. This is his time of year – Kentucky Derby time – and Alou, a horse racing aficionado, wanted everyone, even those who could not tell a gelding from a filly, to share his passion.

headline: Flying? Less Is Better
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Orleans Native Sons in Musical Return
text: NEW ORLEANS  At every New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival from 1990 to 2005, the closing set belonged to the Neville Brothers, the band that is led by Art, Aaron, Charles and Cyril Neville and that often includes a member of the family’s next generation. Hurricane Katrina broke that streak, but on Sunday the Nevilles plan to play their first hometown concert after the storm.

headline: No Milosevic, He Says, but Serbia’s ‘Undertaker’ Worries the West
text: BELGRADE, Serbia

headline: Denomination Wrestles With Pastor’s Statements
text: Just as Senator Barack Obama has spent this week trying to stem the damage to his campaign from statements by his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., the small, theologically liberal Protestant denomination both men belong to, the United Church of Christ, has been grappling with the impact of the controversy upon its members.

headline: On Sunday TV, One Hot Race Fuels Another
text: WASHINGTON  It will be a generational battle royal, the younger upstart against the more seasoned warrior who resents the challenge.

headline: Investors Flee Chief’s Fund at Citigroup
text: Only a year ago Citigroup paid $800 million for Old Lane, the hedge fund of which Vikram S. Pandit was a co-founder.

headline: In Taco Truck Battle, Mild Angelenos Turn Hot
text: LOS ANGELES  Los Angeles, loath to rally cohesively around a local cause, has joined hands around tortillas.

headline: Colorful Tory Beats Laborite to Become Mayor of London
text: LONDON  Boris Johnson, the floppy-haired media celebrity and Conservative member of Parliament who transformed himself from a shambling, amusing-aphorism-uttering figure of fun into a plausible political force, was elected mayor of London on Friday.

headline: When New York Teachers Don’t Teach
text: To the Editor:

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Holiday Time in Indiana
text: Straight talk and gas tax holidays. Just in time for Indiana and North Carolina on Tuesday, how voters might distinguish between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

headline: Ichiro Being Ichiro, and Mo Being Mo
text: What is it like to be 22 years old, nearly unhittable, and facing Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners for the first time? Chamberlain –- who has still not allowed an earned run at Yankee Stadium in the regular season –- allowed a single to center by Suzuki in Friday’s 5-1 Yankees victory. Here’s Joba Chamberlain to explain, word for word.

headline: Q&A: Landon Donovan of the Los Angeles Galaxy
text: It was late in 1999 when Landon Donovan helped the United States under-17 national team to its best showing in the FIFA U17 World Cup — a fourth-place finish in New Zealand.

headline: Jazzfest: Stevie Rumor Packs Club for Trombone Shorty
text: In a city where oral traditions thrive, so do rumors. Like the one that Stevie Wonder, the night before his headlining set Friday at Jazzfest, would show up for the 2 a.m. set at Tipitina’s by Trombone Shorty and Orleans Avenue. He has dropped by clubs before previous New Orleans gigs, so the rumor was plausible. And it reached enough people to pack the club, and then some, with people talking about Stevie.

headline: Two Worthy Causes
text: If the Tampa Bay Derby winner Big Truck finishes in the money today in the Kentucky Derby, a portion of his earnings will be donated to ReRun, a nonprofit that helps former racehorses find second careers.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 118 Florida International
text: Location: Miami

headline: Restoring the Longacre
text: After a two-year, $12 million reconstruction, the historic Longacre Theater has been completely redone.

headline: Kentucky Derby Turn by Turn
Take the Wonderlic Test
text: We’ve all heard about it, especially around draft time.

headline: Breakfast Links
text: Here are this morning’s out-of-town stories on the Rangers-Penguins series.

headline: Mr. McDerby
text: Mister McDerby – I finally found him.

headline: Getting a Horse Ready on Derby Day
text: How your Derby pick will be spending his day before the race:

headline: Jazzfest: Stevie Wonder, In the Rain
text: Every great city is swathed in memories. New Orleans openly clings to them: its peculiar habits, celebrations, foods, rituals and syncopations. The Jazz and Heritage Festival is one of the few big popular music festivals that promises not the newest, hippest or most popular acts, but the “heritage” that’s part of its name. And I’ve been running into a retrospective impulse in many sets I’ve heard.

headline: Thursday Ratings: ABC On Top Among Young Viewers
text: CBS delivered more viewers on Thursday, but ABC fared better among adults 18 to 49, with “Grey’s Anatomy,” with Ellen Pompeo and Patrick Dempsey, and “Lost” putting it on top in that demographic in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours, Nielsen estimated.

headline: Jazzfest: Coming Back for More
text: In a conversation with Quint Davis, the producer and director of Jazzfest, he mentioned a startling statistic. One of the festival’s marketing surveys found that people who visit Jazzfest for the first time return as regulars for the next five years. That’s serious recidivism.

headline: Contract Talks: SAG Extends, AFTRA Delays
text: “Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said on Friday that they would extend their current round of contract talks through Tuesday,” The New York Times reports.

headline: Revisiting Dancer’s Image
text: T. D. Thornton writes from Massachusetts. He is the author of Not by a Long Shot—A Season at a Hard-Luck Horse Track, which was recently named the winner of the Castleton-Lyons-Thoroughbred Times best book of the year about horse racing. During the summer, he calls races as the track announcer at Suffolk Downs in Boston. He looks back on Dancer’s Image and the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

headline: Germany, Congo, Darfur, Rwanda
text: Germany and Rwanda — two countries whose names are associated with genocide in the 20th century — are cooperating to figure out how to halt the first genocide of the 21st century, in Darfur.
From the Borowitz Report:

headline: ‘Putting a Spin on It’
text: Aired Friday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: A new poll shows that George W. Bush is the most unpopular president in American history. I know! Now I was on TV with that President just last weekend. Coincidence? I hope so.

headline: Slow in suburbia
text: There’s a new report out from the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation on broadband. It confirms the fact that the United States is lagging in broadband adoption, both in overall penetration and in other aspects including speed and price. Part, but only part, of this may be due to bad policy — basically, the United States failed to enforce effective competition.

headline: A New Moment for Aquarius
text: Senator John McCain described it as “a cultural and pharmaceutical event.” He was not there, of course; as he pointed out in a Republican debate last October in Florida, he was “tied up at the time,” a sly reference to his time as prisoner of war in North Vietnam.

headline: Gas Tax Cut Is No Holiday
text: Senators John McCain and Hillary Clinton both propose to suspend the 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal excise tax on gasoline between Memorial Day and Labor Day this year. For a moment, forget about whether encouraging fossil fuel burning makes sense during a time of global warming, whether we should raid the highway trust fund when bridges are collapsing for lack of maintenance, or the disconnect between the proposal to cut gasoline taxes and all three candidates’ endorsement of “cap-and-trade” pollution limits that would raise gasoline prices.

headline: Gas Tax Holiday: Why It Makes Sense
text: To hear critics tell it, proposals from John McCain and Hillary Clinton to declare a federal “tax holiday” on gasoline and diesel fuel during the summer driving season will, simultaneously, bring no relief to consumers while bringing doomsday to government. A gas tax holiday is not a fantastic idea, but it doesn’t deserve such controversy either.

headline: Love Story at the Track Is Still Aglow
text: After Leo and Sadie Buse married in 1971, they were looking for an activity to bring their families together. Leo, who had five children from a previous marriage and loved horses, had the idea of going to Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., an easy drive from their home in Cincinnati, for the spring meet. Sadie, who had three children, was hesitant.

headline: The Morning Skate: The Sharks Swim with Madonna
text: A couple of days ago, the Morning Skate took a stroll down memory lane to look at the two playoff teams who rallied from 0-3 to win a series.

headline: Yes Way, Jose
text: The equation for Mets success is as simple as this: Jose Reyes hits = Mets win. Doesn’t take Einstein to figure that out, but we all saw during last night’s 7-2 victory against the Diamondbacks how scary this team looks when Reyes is wreaking havoc at the top of the order. Four hits, including two triples, three runs, a stolen base. Reyes has had nine multihit games this season. Care to guess how many of them the Mets have won? I’ll make it easy for you: eight. That’s a pretty good ratio.

headline: Jazzfest: Going Crazy With John Boutté
text: John Boutté is one of those New Orleans entertainers who can seem like a force just barely contained. He’s a jazz singer and a soul singer, though sometimes not in that order, and a wickedly effective communicator. He works hard to connect with his audiences, and more often than not he succeeds mightily. Yesterday he had the jazz tent packed, and going crazy.

headline: Jazzfest: Ellis Marsalis Brings the Monk
text: Out in the world, Ellis Marsalis is best known as a jazz patriarch: father to Wynton and Branford, and to the less-heralded Delfeayo and Jason. Here in New Orleans, he has always been known chiefly as a first-call pianist conversant in the full scope of the jazz tradition, and capable of great things on the bandstand.

headline: Tiviakov, Lahno Are European Champions
text: Going into the last round of the European individual championships, eight players were tied for first, but only Sergei Tiviakov of the Netherlands won, so he is the 2008 European champion. In the women’s section, Kateryna Lahno of the Ukraine, the leader before the last round, drew her final game against Anna Ushenina of the Ukraine while her rivals also only drew, allowing Lahno to hold on and claim the women’s title.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 3:

headline: Oil conservation: getting over the hump
text: Trade in your SUV — the answer to high oil prices is here!

headline: Avery Improves; Rangers Still Kicking
text: The Rangers announced Saturday afternoon that forward Sean Avery had been moved out of intensive care at St. Vincent’s Hospital, his lacerated spleen improved enough to place him in a regular room. He is expected to remain in the hospital for several days.

headline: ‘Grand Theft’ as It Oughto Be
text: “Grand Theft Auto” spoofs found here.

headline: Weekend Interlude
text: We’ll take a weekend break to catch our breath and let everyone catch up on what we’ve covered so far: Landscape! Sex! (Or not.) Comedy! Feminism! (Or not.) If you haven’t been following along, this is your chance to get up to speed — and if you have been following along, but haven’t posted a comment yet, this is your chance, too.

headline: ‘They’re Closing 15 Stores …’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Yesterday was the five-year anniversary of President Bush’s speech in front of the “Mission Accomplished” banner. Yeah, to celebrate, today, President Bush gave a speech in front of a banner that said “Economic Recession Over.”

headline: The Democrats on the Economy
text: The economic policies of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have many similarities, but there is a difference in their instincts.

headline: Obama’s 2-Minute Closers in N. Carolina and Indiana
text: Senator Barack Obama has two-minute spots out in Indiana and North Carolina as the primary campaigns in those states wind down.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, May 4
text: It’s the battle of the titans on this last Sunday before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries. And we’re not just talking about Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. The Times’s Jim Rutenberg looks at the competition between the venerable Tim Russert of NBC’s “Meet the Press” (which has Mr. Obama) and the younger hotshot, George Stephanopoulos of ABC’s “This Week” (on which Mrs. Clinton will appear).

headline: ‘We Lost a Terrific Horse’
text: Eight Belles ran a terrific race to finish second to Big Brown. She beat the third horse, Denis of Cork, handily. She encountered traffic trouble but nothing got in her way. Galloping out she went down quickly. It was over. Two fractured ankles, likely one fractured and the other followed with a shift in weight. Speculation. But the reality is, we lost a terrific horse doing what we wanted her to do, run in the biggest race of the year.

headline: Obama Wins Guam
text: Update | 7:15 p.m.The Associated Press calls Guam for Obama.

headline: Microsoft Withdraws Bid for Yahoo
text: Microsoft said Saturday that it was abandoning its blockbuster bid to acquire Yahoo after the two companies could not agree on a price. (Read Microsoft’s letter here.)

headline: Auctions Help Schools When Budgets Fall Short
text: The auctioneer came on with a bold pitch, trying to get the bidders to open up their wallets. The cause: making up the budget deficit at a city school.

headline: Microsoft’s Letter to Yahoo
text: Talk about a Saturday night special. Microsoft said tonight that it is withdrawing its offer to buy Yahoo, one it had only recently raised.

headline: It Takes Two, Baby
text: I love people. I could not even begin to count how many times my dear friends have tortured me — lovingly, of course — about my unlimited affection for any and every stranger who comes my way. I have made myself late to many a movie or dinner engagement by getting into impromptu conversations with the valet, the police officer, the mailman, the crossing guard, the paperboy, the street vendor, the truck driver. They could be 4 years old, 98 years old, it doesn’t matter. I have gotten lost in conversations with them. I can’t help it. I just love people.

headline: Will Microsoft Really Walk?
text: Microsoft insisted that it would acquire Yahoo only on its own terms. Now it said that it will withdraw its offer, after the Internet giant rebuffed a sweetened $33-a-share bid.

headline: A Take on a Filly’s Courage
text: Jane Smiley is a Pulitzer-prize winning author whose work is included in “To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory” (St. Martin’s Press), edited by Joe Drape.

headline: Guessing Yahoo’s Opening Stock Price
text: Update: We’ve added more predictions below. Well, Yahoo seems to have gotten what it wanted.

headline: Your Comments on my Guantanamo Column
text: My Sunday column is about the remaining 270 prisoners at Guantanamo, which is a national disgrace. One reason is simply the injustice of keeping innocent people in abusive conditions — a far harsher regime than that faced by convicted murderers in the United States. The inmates at Guantanamo haven’t had visits or phone calls with family members for more than six years of confinement, and the authorities constantly play games with them. For example, one of those I mention in the column is al-Ghizzawi, a Libyan who is suffering from extreme health problems. The authorities boasted of giving him glasses. But, according to his lawyer, the glasses are distance glasses, when he is in confined to a tiny cell. What he desperately wants is reading glasses.

headline: Horse Lover’s View From Inside the Industry
text: If human athletes were euthanized on television every time one broke a leg or a neck in an accident, the National Football League, Nascar and Olympic skiing would be out of business.

headline: Jazzfest: Drum Battles and a Tribute to Max Roach
text: There’s ample precedent for the festival-enabled drum battle: at the early Newport Jazz Festivals, for instance, where Buddy Rich duked it out with Philly Joe Jones and others. Here at the jazz tent Saturday afternoon, a tribute to Max Roach featured three drumsets onstage, manned by Jason Marsalis, Herlin Riley and Shannon Powell. But the exchange had more to do with camaraderie than competition.

headline: Jazzfest: Ludacris Goes Green
text: The Ludacris guest spot with the Roots on Saturday afternoon was short but sweet, and pointed: he stalked onstage for a quick jaunt of “Stand Up,” and then preached for a moment about green activism. Then he was off.

headline: Gangster Love: Mob Movies Are a Hit at a Manhattan Barber Shop
text: Mike Welsh walked into Larry’s Barber Shop one afternoon and witnessed two men getting clipped, one in a barber’s chair, the other on a small television screen.

headline: Endless War
text: It was not one of the celebrated moments of what the Israelis call the War of Independence and the Palestinians call Al Nakba, the Catastrophe. But it is one of the more arresting ones.

headline: Wendy Szymanski, Cassel Kroll
text: Wendy Kay Szymanski and Mark Cassel Kroll were married on Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. James R. Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Jennifer Benedict, Scott Goodwin
text: Jennifer Christine Benedict and Scott Alexander Goodwin were married on Saturday evening at the James Burden Mansion at the Convent of the Sacred Heart School in Manhattan. Dr. Robert L. Berson, the leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated.

headline: Commissioner Takes His Cuts
text: Bud Selig has been the commissioner of Major League Baseball since 1992. A former owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, Selig, 73, has presided over the game during a period of tremendous growth. But he may ultimately be remembered for his handling of baseball’s so-called steroids era. This year, team owners extended his contract by three years, through 2012. MIKE ABRAMS

headline: Born Again
text: In the summer of 1976, as Chairman Mao lay on his deathbed in Beijing, the pigs at the Ximen Village Production Brigade Apricot Garden Pig Farm in Gaomi County, Shandong Province, also began to die. The first batch of five were found with “their skin dotted with purple splotches the size of bronze coins, their eyes open, as if they’d died with unresolved grievances.” The commune vet declared they had succumbed to “what we call the Red Death” and ordered them to be cremated and buried immediately. But it had been raining for weeks and the ground was too waterlogged. Dousing the carcasses with kerosene and trying to set them alight simply filled the farm with vile-smelling smoke. Soon 800 more pigs were infected. A fresh team of vets arrived by motorboat with more sophisticated medicines, but their ministrations were of little help. Dead pigs were piled up throughout the farm, their bloated forms expanding and exploding in the heat.

headline: Terrifying, Not Unlike Your Real Life
text: ASIDE from some of the more banal horrors of reality programming, “Medium” has nothing to rival it as the most frightful hour on television. The series, which stars Patricia Arquette as an earnest telepath (Allison Dubois) who lends her powers of premonition to Phoenix law enforcement, has been a quiet success on NBC for four seasons, receiving some of its highest ratings in recent months as the show has delved further into the human capacity for selfishness and intimate depravities.

headline: The Coming of Age of Copenhagen’s Nordic Cuisine
text: THE waiter wore the kind of mad grin normally seen on movie villains as they unleash mayhem on an unsuspecting city. A silvery industrial canister dangled from his hand. It looked like something for transporting dangerous radioactive isotopes. More alarming, it was emitting thick clouds of cold white smoke through the lid.

headline: What Not to Wear to a Cocktail Party
text: HERE’S one way to introduce a new cocktail: hire a stripper to take a bath in a giant replica of it.

headline: Enterprise Going Green in Atlanta
text: Visitors to Atlanta who are sensitive to carbon emissions might want to check out Enterprise Rent-A-Car’s four new Green Branches. The branches  in the Buckhead, Emory, Downtown and Dunwoody areas  have reconfigured their fleets to feature 30 percent hybrids and 30 percent fuel-efficient cars (those that get at least 28 miles per gallon). Hybrids rent for the same price as a premium car (about $45 a day), and fuel-efficient cars rent for about $35.

headline: Correction
text: A review on April 20 about Elizabeth Strout’s “Olive Kitteridge,” using information provided by the publisher, carried an incorrect picture credit. The author photograph was by Andrea Sperling, not Jerry Bauer.

headline: Yes, Manhattan’s Over There. What of It?
text: AS small-town upbringings go, Robert Holden’s is a classic. He grew up in a small house on 74th Street, across the street from the house where his mother was born in 1924. His siblings came to view their neighborhood as a place to leave. For Mr. Holden, it was a place to stay, and in 1978 he bought a house around the corner, within sight of his boyhood home. He and his wife, Amy, reared three children in the house, and when his father died in 1993, his mother moved in upstairs.

headline: Prepping Robots to Perform Surgery
text: WHAT do you call a surgeon who operates without scalpels, stitching tools or a powerful headlamp to light the patient’s insides? A better doctor, according to a growing number of surgeons who prefer to hand over much of the blood-and-guts portion of their work to medical robots controlled from computer consoles.

headline: A $31 Million Wallflower, Languishing Amid Luxury
text: TROPHY houses have a strange way of sitting empty long after the giga-bucks have passed across the table. So it is with the magnificent Ziegler house, at 2 East 63rd Street, bought by a billionaire entrepreneur in 2005 but still dark and silent.

headline: Radio Nowhere
text: To the Editor:

headline: Four to Watch
text: James Franco: 'Pineapple Express'

headline: Betty Tong and Suhail Mithani
text: Dr. Betty C. Tong, a daughter of Ai-Chuan Tong and Yung L. Tong of Atlanta, was married there on Saturday evening to Dr. Suhail K. Mithani, the son of Dr. Kamrudin Mithani of Havre de Grace, Md., and the late Yasmin Sani Mithani. The Rev. Antone Melton-Meaux, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Atlanta Botanical Garden.

headline: 36 Hours in Athens, Greece
text: FOR years, Athens was little more than a one-night stand on the way to the Greek isles. Concretized and crowded, it lived off its archaeological sites and dirty-dancing-on-tables night life. But now a visit has become more than just a quickie for the sake of the Parthenon. Athens is reinventing itself as a city where antiquity meets edginess. Museums and galleries abound, and new ones are in the works. Late this year, the New Acropolis Museum, designed by the New York-based architect Bernard Tschumi, is scheduled to open at the foot of the ancient citadel. Not a bad warm-up for Mykonos.

headline: Deborah Adler, Brian Sutherland
text: Deborah Adler and Brian Sutherland are to be married on Sunday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan. Cantor Steven S. Sher will officiate. Judge Susan M. Breall of the Superior Court of California in San Francisco is to take part in the ceremony.

headline: Brearley Rauch, Ali Khan
text: Mary Brearley Rauch and Ali Alexander Khan were married on Saturday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Wesley D. Avram performed the ceremony at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

headline: Cold-Comfort Farming
text: My parents are organic farmers, but springtime makes my mother sad and anxious. In the winter, the duties are reasonable: the barn cats need Kibble, and the eggs have to be collected. But the first sprouts are needy and will only increase their demands as the season wears on. Farming asks everything of you eventually. But first it gives you plenty of time to fall in love.

text: HIT THE ROOF: Previous spread: Table grill by eva solo, $320. go to unica home.com. Melamine spatula by Zak Designs, $5. AT Broadway panhandler. Bocca sofa by studio 65 from heller, $975. headline: Frenchwoman Wins Attention at an Event Dominated by Men
text: At the European Championships, which ended on Friday, there were two sections. In one, 159 competitors vied to be the women’s champion. In the other, 336 men and 1 woman, Marie Sebag of France, battled for the overall title.

headline: Back to the City, for More Than Just Sex
text: LAST year, around St. Patrick’s Day, as auspicious a time as any for a writer with Irish blood to start telling a story, Michael Patrick King left his house in the Hollywood Hills and drove to a motel in Palm Desert, Calif., where he spent 16 days thinking about four women whose approach to love, friendship and money defined the manners and folkways of affluent single life at the turn of the new century.
