headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the perks and powers enjoyed by the majority party in the New York Senate referred incorrectly to the rules regarding constituent newsletters distributed by Senate Democrats, who are in the minority. The Democrats are allowed to use one color in addition to black and white; they are not limited to black and white alone. (Republicans are allowed to use multiple colors.)

headline: A Georgia Community With an African Feel Fights a Wave of Change
text: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga.  When Wevonneda Minis first came to this marshy barrier island where her ancestors had been rice-cultivating slaves, she learned of the dream her great-great-grandfather, Liberty Handy, had the night before he died. In the dream, people told her, a black cat scratched him.

headline: Understanding the Temporary Insanity of Adolescence
text: MAMARONECK

headline: Bigger Condos, North of Littler Italy
text: IN the last 80 years, Little Italy in Lower Manhattan has lost more than 90 percent of its Italian-American population, according to community leaders, and shrunk by two-thirds.

headline: Palestinians Seek Support on Borders
text: JERUSALEM  Seeking a more active American role in talks with Israel, the Palestinians say they hope that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will “take a stand” on the borders of a future Palestinian state and define them as corresponding with the 1967 lines, a senior Palestinian official said Saturday.

headline: A Pianist Who Balances Acclaim and Assists
text: THE 59-year-old pianist Mitsuko Uchida  born near Tokyo, trained in Vienna and long resident in London  is, in more ways than one, a musician’s musician. Her performances and Philips recordings of Classical and Romantic standards  especially works by Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert  have consistently fed a reputation for elegant and profound musicianship.

headline: Charming Classic Rock Fans With Something New
text: White Plains

headline: Inside the List
text: WEB OF FEAR: Harlan Coben’s “Hold Tight,” a thriller for the Google era, is new at No. 1 on the fiction list.

headline: Riding the Waves of Peru
text: IT was high tide on a scorching Tuesday, and the choppy beaches around Lima, Peru, were crawling with surfers. There were teenagers in ratty flip-flops carrying short boards patched with duct tape, and bronzed women in wet suits paddling out into the shimmering blue waves. There was even a businessman in his 30s, who climbed out of a black-tinted S.U.V. in nothing but shorts, as a muscular chauffeur handed him a freshly waxed board, a bottle of water and a dab of sunscreen.

headline: As You Exit J.F.K., a Chilling Memory Below
text: FROM inside the AirTrain terminal in Jamaica, Queens, against the hum of trains and climate control, the residential swath of neighborhood just to the south looks peaceful, even idyllic. Sidewalks are clean and straight, the rooftops form tidy rows, and especially as winter fades, the backyards look inviting.

text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A Salute to Softball Players

headline: Heard Is Chasing Lost Time After Hard Time
text: ATLANTA  Bennie Heard is on all fours, butt raised, at the foot of a steep hill suitable for sleigh riding. It is another quirky regimen for Heard, boxing’s Ripped Van Winkle, this one in a midtown park sprinkled with lunchtime sunbathers and bicyclists, homeless snoozers and smitten couples strolling hand in hand.

headline: On the Verge of Victory With Newfound Serenity
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Playing with the calm assurance of a veteran and the fiery passion of a rookie, 22-year-old Anthony Kim served notice at the Wachovia Championship on Saturday that his game had matured and so had he. Two strokes behind when the third round began, Kim turned the $6.4-million tournament upside down, fashioning a bogey-free round of six-under-par 66 that propelled him into a four-stroke lead over Jason Bohn, the second-round leader, and Heath Slocum.

headline: A Fiery Theology Under Fire
text: Black liberation theology was a radical movement born of a competitive time.

headline: Up Front
text: Jonathan Spence has been a familiar figure on the Yale campus since the university granted his doctoral degree in 1965. He began teaching there the following year and still offers one of the most popular undergraduate courses, on the history of modern China.

headline: China’s Unfair Trade
text: To the Editor:

headline: Piece(s) Of Cake
text: When a skinny woman with a big appetite and a hefty man on a diet are seated among the guests at your table, the S-XL Cake pan saves them from asking for a slice “just a little bit bigger/smaller.” Designed by Ding3000 and produced by Konstantin Slawinski (both based in Germany), the flexible silicone mold features built-in portions of varying sizes. S-XL’s one setback: limited small

headline: Correction: Trippy Rock, Relaxed Jazz and Other Delights
text: A review of Michael Doucet last Sunday in the Playlist column misstated the name of his new album. It is “From Now On,” not “Solo Gombo.”

headline: Judith Nelson, Thomas Mitz
text: Judith Gael Nelson and Thomas Wayne Mitz are to be married on Sunday in New York. Joan Cleveland, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, will officiate.

headline: Empty Nest Egg
text: The future of Americans’ pensions has not become a serious campaign issue so far this election season. It’s hard to get retirement issues to the front of the line when the nation faces soaring health care costs, global warming, $100-a-barrel oil, a likely recession and collapsing housing prices. There is also the little matter of the worst credit crisis since the 1930s.

headline: Study, but Have Fun, Too
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reuse, Recycle, Reheat
text: Matthijs Vogels was frustrated by the amount of food people throw away after meals. So, for part of his masters thesis at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, the 27-year-old designer put his frustrations to work: he created a zero-waste restaurant installation. The temporary, small-scale project espoused the “cradle to cradle” philosophy, which embraces ecologically intelligent design as a means of turning waste into new products. “I did several crazy experiments,” Vogels says, and not everything worked out. But he did succeed in creating a series of bowls and plates called Waste-Ware that were hand-pressed out of left-over coffee grounds and herbs. Each biodegradable set doubles as a container; the coffee version is perfect for storing chocolates. To purchase, go to studiohergebruik.nl. S. KIRK WALSH

headline: I Take This Cyberpal to Be My Bridesmaid
text: WHEN the time came to pare down her guest list to 50 people, Brigitte Aleman had firm instructions.

headline: On Gossamer Wings
text: In 1882, Mabel Loomis Todd sent Emily Dickinson a little picture she’d painted of a woodland plant called Indian pipe. Dickinson thanked Todd with a poem, eight lines about a hummingbird, that would one day be among her best known, “A Route of Evanescence.” That summer, Todd had begun to fall in love with Dickinson’s brother, Austin (adulterously  both parties were already married), but not before she received a visit from another admirer, the artist Martin Johnson Heade, known for his paintings of hummingbirds. Henry Ward Beecher, the Brooklyn preacher who had been sued for adultery by his best friend a decade earlier, had bought one of Heade’s landscapes in 1859; among the many other things that Beecher collected were stuffed hummingbirds. Beecher’s sister, the novelist Harriet Beecher Stowe, once rescued and tamed an injured hummingbird, teaching it to drink sugar syrup from a silver spoon.

headline: Bedtime Stories | Lee Friedlander
text: With the opening of the Thompson LES hotel next month, Lee Friedlander will bring new meaning to the term “artist in residence.” Over each of the 141 beds in this downtown Manhattan hotel, a wall-mounted light box will illuminate black-and-white photographs from Friedlander’s apple and olive tree series, seven variants in all (including the one above). “Our approach was to integrate the work in an architectural context rather than treat it as an applied afterthought,” says the hotel’s interior designer, Jim Walrod. The photographer is in good company: the lobby features a giant color-field painting by Peter Halley, and at the bottom of the outdoor pool, Andy Warhol gazes up from a Gerard Malanga filmstrip that has been acid-etched into the tiles. So, while a handful of locals might bemoan the continuing gentrification of the Lower East Side, few can complain about the hotel’s artistic pedigree. BILL POWERS

headline: For Sale: Art and Optimism
text: YOU can’t help but wonder just how many of the smartly dressed people sitting night after night at Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips de Pury over the next two weeks will be serious bidders and how many will be voyeurs hoping to witness an implosion of the multibillion dollar art market.

headline: An Invitation to Child’s Play: Big Blocks and Wheelbarrows
text: It is the playground of the future, already in beta mode in New York City and coming soon to empty lots, day care centers and even suburban backyards across the country.

headline: The Case for a Newer Deal
text: PART of the New Deal was a new financial deal. The shameful shenanigans leading up to the 1929 stock market crash and the frightening wave of bank failures during the Depression led directly to the creation of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

headline: A Bordeaux, Blended Well
text: Year after year, Lamothe de Haux, a minor château, produces enticing Bordeaux blanc blends. The succulent 2007 shows why they have become a cult white in New York.

headline: Exotic Destinations for Mother’s Day
text: One hundred years ago, a church in West Virginia dedicated a service to motherhood for the first time. Mother’s Day is now an annual event, and resorts in exotic destinations are honoring the holiday (May 11 this year) with special packages.

headline: Brenda Haendler, William Plishker
text: Brenda Elizabeth Haendler and William Lester Plishker were married on Saturday evening at Grace Church in Washington. The Rev. John M. Graham, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony, with R. Alan Plishker, a minister of the Reformed Church in America and an uncle of the bridegroom, taking part.

headline: Despite Alert, Flawed Wiring Still Kills G.I.’s
text: WASHINGTON  In October 2004, the United States Army issued an urgent bulletin to commanders across Iraq, warning them of a deadly new threat to American soldiers. Because of flawed electrical work by contractors, the bulletin stated, soldiers at American bases in Iraq had received severe electrical shocks, and some had even been electrocuted.

headline: Corrections: Where Many Ended Their Search for Paradise
text: An article on April 13 about the Marquesas in the South Pacific misidentified one of the countries that make up the so-called Polynesian Triangle and the Polynesian island that is the farthest from Tahiti. In addition to Hawaii and Easter Island, the triangle includes New Zealand, not Tahiti. And Easter Island, not the Marquesas, is the farthest from Tahiti.

headline: Melissa Torres, Peter Toomey
text: Melissa Ann Torres, a daughter of Janette S. Laurita of Whitestone, Queens, and Gilberto L. Torres of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Peter Hugh Toomey, the son of Lauretta A. Toomey and Peter T. Toomey Jr. of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Bill Sangiovanni performed the ceremony at St. Augustine Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

headline: Jane Ringer, James Gregoire
text: Jane Kathryn Ringer and James Albert Gregoire were married on Saturday at St. Peter’s Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Christopher Thomforde, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: The Wrong Friends
text: It is remarkable how many people are willing to help illegal gun sellers. Congress all too often takes the side of the gun lobby over victims of gun violence. Last week, in a particularly wrongheaded ruling, a federal appeals court threw out New York City’s longstanding lawsuit intended to rein in illegal gun sellers.

headline: Sadaharu Oh Still Feels and Thinks the Game
text: MIYAZAKI, Japan  After a 22-year playing career in which he became Nippon Professional Baseball’s home run king, Sadaharu Oh is in his 44th season in uniform, now as manager of the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks.

headline: Indiana Jones and the Savior of a Lost Art
text: “THIS is a recreational activity for me” is surely among the last things you’d expect to hear from the director of a huge, costly, dauntingly complex summer action movie as it nears completion, with its release date just a few weeks away.

headline: Déjà Vu Dining
text: “HELLO, your name is familiar  and so is your food.”

headline: The Wheels on the Bus Go Here and There
text: SOME 200 times a day, the M96 bus wheezes westward. As its name suggests, its route is mostly a straight shot across 96th Street. But around Broadway, the bus takes on acrobatic airs: it lunges up the avenue, turns laboriously onto 97th Street while dickering with Broadway traffic, pushes a block westward, and then executes two more lefts, finally swinging east onto 96th Street at West End Avenue.

headline: They Keep the Light on for Visitors in Croatia
text: ISLANDS  some 1,200 of them  dot the Adriatic coast of Croatia like a long line of bread crumbs, ranging from two-acre specks to 35-mile-long spines of rock and scrub. Beautiful and remote, the labyrinth stretches for several hundred miles, from the northern coastal town of Rijeka past the walled city of Dubrovnik.

headline: Live at the Garden
text: How did an English garden center become a social hub and foodie destination? At Petersham Nurseries near Richmond, Surrey, a 15-minute train ride from central London, city folks longing for a country home  or perhaps a glimpse of Stella McCartney  roam the grounds while posh suburbanites from nearby Kew shop for garden supplies and make impromptu play dates around the communal table in a teahouse. The setting is quintessential shabby chic, with rambling greenhouses filled year-round with lush plants, garden antiques and design objects both exotic and familiar. In the main greenhouse, rickety tables hidden among plants form the setting for the chef Skye Gyngell’s lunch-only cafe, with an inspired menu featuring local and seasonal ingredients. (Reservations are mandatory.) A nearby toolshed has been converted into the teahouse, an inviting space for a cup of coffee, tea cakes or a bowl of soup served with Poilâne bread and farmhouse butter  the best way to battle the perpetually damp London air. Church Lane, off Petersham Road, Petersham, Surrey; 011-44-20-8940-5230; petershamnurseries.com. PIM TECHAMUANVIVIT

headline: Forging Ahead With Sewers in Suffolk
text: AFTER obtaining the fire marshal’s approval in January for a 157-seat restaurant in Southaven, Jim McGuckin learned not long before he opened three months ago that Suffolk County health officials had cut his seating capacity by more than half.

headline: Bend Me, Misshape Me
text: Last summer in a quiet suburb of Vail, Colo., Kent Logan showed off his private gallery to a group of visitors. Around the building were paintings by Andy Warhol and sculpture by Jeff Koons, along with flat files filled with hundreds of precious drawings and works on paper. Mr. Logan said he owned about 1,000 works of art and then politely announced that he had promised much of it to museums.

headline: A Rare Shop-and-Stroll Area
text: IN much of São Paulo, window-shopping is simply not practical: the concrete city is too vast for sidewalk strolling. Instead, residents who can afford higher-end merchandise drive to centers of consumption known in Brazil as “shoppings”; in the United States, they are called malls.

headline: Of Locks, Beauty and Driveways
text: The Security of a Lock, the Invincibility of Youth

headline: Turkish Schools Offer Pakistan a Gentler Vision of Islam
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  Praying in Pakistan has not been easy for Mesut Kacmaz, a Muslim teacher from Turkey.

headline: ‘The Lost Dog’
text: TUESDAY

headline: In Bleak Days for Builders, Lessons in Saving Your Life
text: MANUEL ARRANGO, a construction mechanic, works high above the pavement, toiling over masonry, brickwork, and waterproofing. On Monday night, at a training session for scaffold workers held in a church in Westchester Square in the northeast Bronx, Mr. Arrango also did a turn  literally  as a fashion model.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions on Monday, about a bill that would give the New York State Board of Elections the ability to overrule decisions by New York City’s Campaign Finance Board, misstated the surname of a spokesman for the city board. He is Eric Friedman, not Feldman.

headline: Filly’s Death Casts Shadow Over Big Brown’s Derby Victory
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Both came here chasing history and hinting at greatness. Big Brown was unbeaten and trying to become the first horse in 93 years to win the Kentucky Derby after three lifetime races. Eight Belles, a filly, had ticked off four victories, emboldening her owner to run her against the boys in America’s greatest horse race.

headline: Peter Howard, 80, Dies; Put Music on Broadway
text: Peter Howard, who arranged the dance music, composed the incidental music or conducted the orchestra for many of Broadway’s biggest hits of the last half-century, and who sometimes did all three of those underappreciated jobs, died on April 18 in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 and had lived in recent years at the Lillian Booth Actors’ Home in Englewood.

headline: Triumph, and Then Tears, at the Derby
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — After running the race of her life, the filly Eight Belles finished second behind Big Brown in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, then collapsed after the finish line and had to be euthanized.

headline: His Father’s Siren, Still Singing
text: BEFORE Vladimir Nabokov, the author of “Lolita,” “Pale Fire,” “Speak, Memory” and other masterworks, died in Lausanne, Switzerland, in July 1977, he had been hard at work on another novel. The previous December, he told The New York Times that the “not quite finished manuscript” was called “The Original of Laura,” that it had already been “completed in my mind” and that during a recent hospital stay, “in my diurnal delirium,” he had “kept reading it aloud to a small dream audience in a walled garden.” Shortly afterward, Nabokov’s editor at McGraw-Hill revealed that the author was about to do the actual writing, in pencil on 3-by-5-inch index cards (Nabokov never worked with a typewriter). Then, in words parroted by the editor, Nabokov would “deal himself a novel.”

headline: Here Comes Everyboy, Again
text: ON June 6 a new Adam Sandler comedy  its pseudomysterious, catchphrase-ready title is “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan”  will open across the country. This is hardly a surprising piece of news, since a new Adam Sandler comedy comes around just about every spring or summer. Last year was “I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry,” before that was “Click,” and so on, for as far back as most of Mr. Sandler’s audience can remember.

headline: Misspeaking Too Soon
text: As Wordwatchers Watch

headline: Dana Weisberg, Steven Zeller
text: Dana Meredith Weisberg, a daughter of Helaine R. Weisberg and Allan L. Weisberg of Warren, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Steven Lee Zeller, the son of Dana Zeller-Alexis and Mark Zeller of Middlefield, Mass. Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Dropout Prevention
text: To the Editor:

headline: She’ll Get It for You: Retail
text: HER name may have the ring of heavenly virtue, but Faith Hope Consolo’s stock in trade is earthly luxury. Ms. Consolo is the chairwoman for retail real estate at Prudential Douglas Elliman, and the city’s highest-profile practitioner of the art of matching stores with storefronts.

headline: Low Expectations Made for a Good Week
text: The stock market rose last week on news that generally wasn’t very good but was still better than expected.

headline: Breathing Light Into Ballet
text: IT was another evening at the ballet three weeks ago when the Kirov presented an evening of works by William Forsythe. As the audience members settled into their seats and looked at their programs before the first piece, a dancer appeared on the stage. His presence and his cryptic, telegraphic gestures seemed to indicate the start of Mr. Forsythe’s “Steptext,” but as the house lights remained on, the audience only gradually quieted its chatter, a little unsure about exactly what was happening.

headline: A Love Story at the Track Is Still Aglow
text: After Leo and Sadie Buse married in 1971, they were looking for an activity to bring their families together. Leo, who had five children from a previous marriage and loved horses, had the idea of going to Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., an easy drive from their home in Cincinnati, for the spring meet. Sadie, who had three children, was hesitant.

headline: Julianne Fisher, Robert Breitbeil Jr.
text: Julianne Kate Fisher and Robert George Breitbeil Jr. were married on Saturday at St. Charles Borromeo Catholic Church in Arlington, Va. The Rev. Clement M. Aapengnuo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Vog
text: Vog closed in over Oahu last weekend, a thick haze that flattened the landscape and drained it of color. Sky and ocean bled to gray. The mighty, mossy-green Koolau mountains blurred, then vanished. A warm tropical morning in Honolulu had the ashy pallor of winter in upstate New York.

headline: All Over the Dial, and Under One Roof
text: WHEN Clear Channel Radio started consolidating its five New York-area music stations, its online operation and its traffic-information network under one roof, it was a little like creating a multicultural blended family. The company wanted to put the corporate family first but to allow siblings as stylistically diverse as the adult contemporary 106.7 LiteFM and the hip-hop Power 105.1 FM to maintain their artistic identities.

headline: Adrienne Lee, Zealous Wiley III
text: Adrienne Yvonne Lee and Zealous Darrell Wiley III are to be married on Sunday at the Biltmore in Atlanta. The Rev. Joseph Barta, a member of the Society of Christ’s Priesthood, will officiate.

headline: A Revival in a Run-Down Part of Town
text: WEST HARTFORD

headline: Paperback Row
text: SUPREME DISCOMFORT: The Divided Soul of Clarence Thomas, by Kevin Merida and Michael A. Fletcher. (Broadway, $15.95.) Thomas, the most controversial figure on the Supreme Court, is a man of contradictions. A beneficiary of affirmative action, he opposes it; the author of sometimes unfeeling legal opinions, he is compassionate in his personal relations. Merida and Fletcher, journalists at The Washington Post, conducted hundreds of interviews with Thomas’s friends, relatives and colleagues; they focus most successfully on his upbringing and early experience. “The problem of color is a mantle” Thomas “yearns to shed, even as he clings to it,” they write.

headline: The Trouble With Harry
text: Harry Rent, the hero of Mark Sarvas’s first novel, is a Prufrock in his mid-40s. His arms and legs are thin, as is his courage, and the author writes most persuasively in a handful of early passages dramatizing Harry’s zoned-out self-consciousness, his crippling awkwardness and his anxiety about what to do with his hands while standing by his wife’s casket.

headline: Cheating Hearts
text: I’m not sure if it’s irony or good luck that landed Isabel Fonseca’s swirling examination of midlife crises on my desk just as the Eliot Spitzer mess broke (infidelity being a  duh  major wind force), but the coincidence sure made reading this clever, well-observed novel that much more compelling. What happens when the spouse you’ve leaned on and trusted for decades turns out to have a secret life? And what do you do with this potentially explosive information if the story is breaking not under the klieg lights of The New York Times, but rather in the relative privacy of a cybercafe on a tropical island in the Indian Ocean?

headline: Baghdad Must Pay Its Way
text: THE success of the coalition’s counterinsurgency strategy has opened new, and under-reported, opportunities for Iraq’s economy. Per capita income is more than four times 2003 levels. Inflation is coming down. Polls show that Iraqi businessmen are overwhelmingly optimistic about the country’s future and new enterprises are being opened every day. With oil production running at prewar levels, it is time for America to insist that Iraq make fuller use of its oil revenues for equipping and training its security forces and for economic reconstruction.

headline: Voilà (Sort Of)!
text: So what’s on the block at the upfronts this month? Could it be the future of television?

headline: Songs of Eloquence and Experience
text: With just days to go before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here is Allan Gurganus's latest dispatch.

headline: Entitled to What?
text: Virtually unnoticed during the primary season, the baby boom generation turned 62 this year and began to draw Social Security benefits. This heralded a milestone in America’s aging, and depending on which of the candidates you ask, it spells a budgetary straitjacket or possibly a looming social crisis. Over the next generation, the population of seniors will practically double, to 72 million. With more people retiring and a smaller share of people working, the strains on Social Security and especially Medicare will become evident. Over the very long term, the two programs combined are projected to consume virtually the entire federal budget. A portion of Medicare (the part that pays hospital bills) faces insolvency much sooner than that  in 2019. “The entitlement problem is here and now,” says Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow of the Urban Institute. “It is so big and overwhelming, none of the candidates feel they can tackle it.”

headline: For Democrats, Instincts Differ on Economics
text: As they traveled across Indiana and North Carolina over the last few days, trading charges and countercharges about the wisdom of suspending the federal gas tax for the summer, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama were really having a larger fight.

headline: Study Finds Number of Fat Cells Doesn’t Change
text: Every year, whether you are fat or thin, whether you lose weight or gain, 10 percent of your fat cells die. And every year, those cells that die are replaced with new fat cells, researchers in Sweden reported Sunday.

headline: Letters: A Love Song to Rome
text: To the Editor: Grazie to Ian Fisher for his poetic ode to the most fascinating of cities, Rome, in his “Rome at Night” (April 20). The article lovingly evokes the enchantment of Rome on a grand but human scale. Strolling through Trastevere, the Tiber Island, the magnificent Campidoglio, and the cobblestoned streets, with both Romans and non-Romans, to soak in the eternal treasures of the city is the pinnacle of pleasure.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Don’t Drain Iraq’s Cash
text: THE way forward in Iraq must proceed from the recognition that the surge, of which I was an early proponent, has stabilized central Iraq, reduced violence overall and provided space for the Iraqi government to undertake important reconciliation efforts.

headline: Zimbabwe Party Seeks to Verify Vote
text: JOHANNESBURG  Claiming that their presidential candidate was robbed of victory in long-delayed official election results, leaders of Zimbabwe’s opposition party were making a last-ditch diplomatic push on Saturday to persuade the African Union and a bloc of southern African nations to insist on a verifiable vote count.

headline: Before Hours in the City That Always Sleeps In
text: THIS whole city-that-never-sleeps thing  on target when you’re looking for a place to dance at 3 a.m. on a Tuesday, eat at 4 a.m. on a Wednesday or do yoga at 5 a.m. on a Thursday  can get a little dicey come 6 or 7 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday.

headline: China’s Pop Fiction
text: The most successful writer in China today isn’t Gao Xingjian, the winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize, or even Jiang Rong, the author of the best-selling novel “Wolf Totem,” just released in the United States. It’s 24-year-old Guo Jingming, a pop idol whose cross-dressing, image-obsessed persona has made him a sensation in a country where the Communist dictatorship advocates prudery and heterosexuality. Thousands of teenagers  his readers are rarely over 20  flock to Guo’s signing sessions. Some post frenzied declarations of love on his blog: “Little Four, I will always be with you!” (Guo’s nickname comes from “fourth dimension war,” a random quotation he found in a magazine.) Alongside adoring letters addressed to “Big Brother Guo,” the author posts pictures of himself half-naked in the shower, in his underwear or swathed in Dolce & Gabbana accessories and Louis XIV-style shirts.

headline: Danielle Teisch and Andrew Greenberg
text: Danielle Lynn Teisch, a daughter of Allison Teisch and Evan Teisch of Cooper City, Fla., was married on Saturday evening to Dr. Andrew Scott Greenberg, the son of Stephanie Greenberg of Congers, N.Y., and Michael Greenberg of Monroe, N.Y. Rabbi Gayle Pomerantz officiated at the Marriott Delray Beach in Florida.

headline: Dressed for a Meeting, Ready for Mayhem
text: From his precinct on the fringes of Hell’s Kitchen, Detective Kevin P. Schroeder has cracked the case of a corpse in a Dumpster, wrestled a man into handcuffs on the sidewalk, and chased suspects across rooftops and down fire escapes.

headline: To Sorrow and Back
text: IN 1990, I rewrote my will for my son Jonathan to move into my shoes if something were to happen. I knew if he replaced me he would be fair to everyone. I had eight children. He looked out for his brothers and sisters.

headline: Datebook
text: LONDON

headline: Pathway to a Secret Garden
text: “DID I miss something?” asked Carl D’Aquino, the interior designer, as he and his business partner, Francine Monaco, an architect, took a quick trip through the one-bedroom basement apartment for sale at 28 East 21st Street in the Flatiron district. “Is this a vault?” he asked, puckishly. “Or a catacomb?”

headline: 1969: Chicken Canzanese
text: Any food historian will tell you that trying to track down the origin of a recipe is like chasing tadpoles. There are so many and they all look alike. Even when you find what seems to be the original source, you can’t necessarily believe it because the adapting of recipes is an age-old industry. Nonetheless, I thought I’d give the hunt a try with chicken Canzanese, an unusual recipe that ran in The Times in 1969.

headline: Can Rockefeller Heirs Turn Exxon Greener?
text: It has become a habit when Exxon Mobil has a blockbuster quarter, as it did last week, for the company to come under fire for driving up gasoline prices. But attacks from the heirs of John D. Rockefeller, the indomitable capitalist who formed the Standard Oil Trust, which eventually became Exxon?

headline: The Gainful Way to Use a Sabbatical
text: Q. You like your job and want to keep it, but you could use a break that’s longer than a vacation. In academia, professors routinely take sabbaticals in order to recharge. Could that be an option for you in the corporate world?

headline: Kentucky Program Puts Youth on the Right Track
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  On April 26, opening day at Churchill Downs, the team from Boys’ Haven leapt from their seats, screaming encouragement as their horse in the fifth race, Stanton, swung wide on the second turn and gained the lead approaching the stretch.

headline: Stopping Traffic in the People’s Republic
text: WERE people gawking at my children? I wasn’t sure.

headline: Cat Gets New Life
text: JAGUAR CARS LTD., which began in 1922 as a motorcycle sidecar manufacturer, is being bought by Tata Motors of India from the Ford Motor Company. The $2.3 billion deal, which also includes Ford’s interest in Land Rover, was announced in March and is expected to be completed in June.

text: Food and Free Trade

headline: Susanna Sorrentino, Adam Garth
text: Dr. Susanna Sorrentino and Adam Garth were married on Saturday evening at the home of the bridegroom’s parents in Egremont, Mass. Justice Lewis J. Lubell of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated, with permission from the State of Massachusetts.

headline: The Talk
text: assemblage / (ä´ sem bläzh’) / n. / a group of persons or things gathered together; a posh, Frenchified word for assembly, e.g., “Christopher Kane put together quite an assemblage for his little hoedown at Shoreditch House”; a form of art involving the assembly and arrangement of unrelated objects and materials, as in, “Their bookshelves were such a breathtaking assemblage that they looked like a Joseph Cornell.”

headline: Figurative Works That Reveal a Landscapist’s Little-Known Side
text: “Stan Brodsky, the Figure: 1951-2006,” at the Hofstra University Museum, comes as a bit of a surprise. As beautiful and accomplished as Mr. Brodsky’s landscape paintings are  they have been shown in the past at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington  they can be monotonous. With this show we learn that he has also been painting figurative works, largely in private.

headline: A Career Born of a Love for Guitars
text: Copiague

headline: Of Musical Import
text: In Stockholm last fall, walking past a McDonald’s, Tan Dun turned to me and said: “Some 20 years ago, I was still planting rice in China. And now I’m conducting orchestras in all the great concert houses of the world: La Scala, the Met, the Berlin Philharmonic. I still can’t believe it.”

headline: Green Anchors
text: How does your garden grow? These days it’s up: green walls are all the rage. The Belgian fashion designer Ann Demeulemeester recently opened a store in Seoul, South Korea, whose inner stairway and outer walls are covered in mossy Pachysandra terminalis. Broadway East, an edgy organic restaurant on the border of New York’s Chinatown, has a garden wall in its dining room  the perfect backdrop for eating shojin salad. And a 30-foot-high wall of Dryopteris dilatata and Polystichum polyblepharum (ferns) provided a foil for the floral frocks in Stella McCartney’s spring show. For this verdant backstop, McCartney turned to the man who started the green-wall craze, the French landscape designer and botanist Patrick Blanc.

headline: Bike Lanes, Intended for Safety, Become Traffic Battlegrounds
text: James Frederick was in Manhattan cycling west in the Prince Street bike lane on a recent morning when a green Ford parked in the lane forced him to swerve into the narrow roadway where cars and vans were rushing past.

headline: A Haiku to Synthetics
text: Just one word: plastics. The Japanese industrial-design star Tokujin Yoshioka was born in 1967, the year “The Graduate” had its premiere. The movie must have been an omen for him. After working with Shiro Kuramata and Issey Miyake, Yoshioka became strongly influenced by structure, transparency and the use of synthetics. His origami-like Honey-Pop chair from 2001, made for the Italian company Driade, is composed of 120 sheets of glassine paper that are compressed, cut and then spread open. His 2006 limited-edition Pane chair is made of polyester fibers baked like Italian bread. This month, the Museum of Modern Art Design Store is presenting “Destination: Japan,” a retail exhibition that includes home accessories. Slit Bag (above), a woven vinyl bag that has the illusion of depth even when flat, was originally designed by Yoshioka for the cover of a monograph of his work, which was published by Phaidon. MoMA decided it would be the perfect tote for the design-obsessed shopper  and, at $33, a bargain. MELISSA FELDMAN

headline: So It Goes
text: The best thing in this posthumous collection of previously unpublished odds and ends by Kurt Vonnegut is a great piece of writing, the strongest thing by him that I have read. It relates an experience  his experience during the firebombing of Dresden  that after years of frustration he finally dealt with in a best-selling novel. Turns out he had already told the story, better, before he found his distinctive style.

headline: Adventure Vacations That Reach the Extreme
text: Some people want a little more out of their vacation than a fruity drink served poolside. Diving with sharks in South Africa, for example. Or living among penguins for five days in Antarctica. Or paddling in a canoe down a crocodile- and hippopotamus-infested river in Zambia.

headline: The Rebates Might Not Go to the Mall
text: Go ahead and spend  it’s your patriotic duty. That’s one way to look at the government rebates that are just starting to arrive in taxpayers’ bank accounts and mailboxes.

headline: The Queen of the New Age
text: LOUISE HAY IS ONE OF THE BEST-SELLING AUTHORS IN HISTORY, and none of the women who have sold more  like J. K. Rowling, Danielle Steel and Barbara Cartland  owned a publishing empire. They did not change the spiritual landscape of America and several of its Western allies. They were not pregnant at 15 and they did not lack high-school diplomas. Finer writers they may have been (depending on your taste), and wealthier women, but it would be hard to argue that any was more interesting than Louise Hay.

headline: Lights Out
text: Environmentalists hate them. Other folks do, too. They’re soon to be banned from sale in the United States, as well as Canada and Australia. What is this scourge?

headline: Indiana Poses a Puzzle in the Primary Race
text: SALEM, Ind.  It is hard to run for office across this state, mostly because there is no single Indiana.

headline: The Kibitzer of Cobblers’ Row
text: An article on April 20 about a shoe repair shop operated by a Bukharan Jew in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to a book kept under the shop’s cash register. It was a siddur, or daily prayer book  not a Torah, which is a scroll inscribed with the first five books of the Bible and which is traditionally kept in the ark of a synagogue.

headline: Blame the Messager
text: Not too long ago, Jeff Ryan, the managing editor of Contemporary Pediatrics, a medical journal, received an invitation to a naming ceremony for the baby of two friends, Tristan and Marla. “It was a paper invitation, not just an Evite,” said Ryan, 32, referring to the cyber-summons that is both de rigueur among and despised by his generation. “Which should have been my clue that this was an actual event.”

headline: Friends May Be the Best Guide Through the Noise
text: CATHY BROOKS is a typically unapologetic Silicon Valley Web addict. Last week alone, she produced more than 40 pithy updates on the text messaging service Twitter, uploaded two dozen videos to various video sharing sites, posted seven photographs on the Yahoo image service Flickr and one item to the online community calendar Upcoming.

headline: How to See This Mission Accomplished
text: For the fifth anniversary of President Bush’s declaration of the end of “major combat operations” in Iraq, the Op-Ed page asked nine experts on military affairs to identify a significant challenge facing the American and Iraqi leadership today and to propose one specific step to help overcome that challenge.

headline: Narrow Victory for Obama in the Caucuses in Guam
text: Senator Barack Obama appeared to win the Democratic caucuses in Guam on Saturday, defeating Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton by seven votes.

headline: The Camera That Wears a Badge
text: THESE days, the police are much less likely to be hiding behind a billboard waiting to nab someone going over the speed limit. Technology has gone far beyond that.

text: Longtang

headline: Bringing a Smile (Well, a Shine) to a Burdened Statue of Atlas

headline: Missiles Strike Sadr City, Damaging Hospital
text: BAGHDAD  The ugly daily fight for ground in the poor Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City unfolded Saturday at a small mosque next door to a hospital, damaging the hospital and a number of its ambulances, and near a group of children who were wounded as they gathered tin cans to sell for salvage.

headline: Make an Orderly Exit
text: IF the United States is to succeed in Iraq, if the Bush administration is to manage a credible transition to the next president and if there is to be any hope of a bipartisan approach to the war there, we need a clear plan to move forward. Good plans cannot guarantee the future, but they can provide good options.

headline: An Animated Life
text: Morning routine: I get up at 6:30. I shower and make sure I’m in front of the TV for “The Today Show” at 7. Then I make breakfast for my son and daughter, because it’s my only chance to see them during the day. Everybody is out the door by 8.

headline: A Fault Line That Haunts Democrats
text: AS this historic Democratic primary season enters its next grueling phase, the party has become embroiled in a conflict between antagonists who would seem better cast as allies. Senator Barack Obama is a black candidate who has built his career on de-emphasizing race, while Senator Hillary Clinton is a white liberal who has been sensitive to minorities, and the issues facing them, during her long years of political activism.

headline: Race Illustrates Brutal Side of Sport
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: Carole Fakhry, Ali Bydon
text: Dr. Carole Fakhry, the daughter of Nada Fakhry and Dr. Ahmad Fakhry of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married on Friday to Dr. Ali Bydon, a son of Najwa Bydon and Hussein Bydon of Dearborn, Mich. Imam Abdul-Latif Berry, a Muslim cleric, officiated at the home of the bridegroom’s parents.

headline: This Is His Life: A Blue Whale and Hello Kitty
text: THE artist Tom Sachs has a bad-boy reputation and a long track record of provocation, including when he substituted a Hello Kitty character for the baby Jesus in a 1994 Barneys Christmas window, and when he used Prada packaging to build a model of a German death camp shown in a 2002 exhibition at the Jewish Museum.

headline: Jean-Luc Le Dû | Oenophile
text: As the former sommelier at Daniel and the current owner of Le Dû’s Wines in the West Village, Jean-Luc Le Dû has sipped, swirled and spat some of the most coveted hooch in the world. So please excuse him if he appears something of a perfectionist. “There are two things that always make me cringe: a bottle being stored standing up, or a bottle stored in too warm of a temperature,” says the Brittany-born New Yorker. When it comes to his own wood-paneled, climate-controlled booze boutique (above), Le Dû doesn’t mind raising a glass to himself: “It is as close to a perfect wine shop as possible.” Or it will be when he finally hunts down a one-of-a-kind eau de vie. “I’m trying to find the absolute best bottle to import,” he says. “I’m not giving up.” We’ll drink to that. ALEX HAWGOOD

headline: Susan Cohn and David Rockefeller Jr.
text: Susan Cohn, a daughter of Barbara B. Cohn and Bertram J. Cohn of New York, was married on Saturday afternoon to David Rockefeller Jr., a son of David Rockefeller of New York and the late Peggy Rockefeller. The Rev. Dr. F. Paul DeHoff, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in Tarrytown, N.Y., with the Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian Universalist minister, taking part.

headline: A More Permanent Crash Pad
text: THEY know they are fortunate. And they know it might not last. But for now, George Alan Bender and Robin Scott are grateful for the circumstances they find themselves in, a consequence of their luck (genetic and otherwise) and their good sense not to squander it.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,058 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Saturday:

headline: Damon Gets Ball Rolling for Yankees
text: For the second straight game, the Seattle Mariners threw a stingy pitcher at the Yankees. For the second straight game, the Yankees paid no mind, and in turn put their demanding fans’ minds a little more at ease.

headline: A Psychedelic ‘Problem Child’ Comes Full Circle
text: ON the afternoon of Jan. 11, Albert Hofmann, the chemist who discovered LSD, had about a dozen friends and family up to his glass-walled home in the mountains near Basel, Switzerland, for a party. It was his 102nd birthday and, in an important sense, also a homecoming.

headline: Ideas for Bell Labs’ Future
text: LIKE the unsung hero who is paid tribute only upon retirement or imminent demise, the historic Bell Labs building in Holmdel has generated a loud, protective chorus of huzzahs since its demolition was proposed nearly two years ago.

headline: A Man of Steel With Feet of Clay
text: CULVER CITY, Calif.

headline: Lisa Knappen, Sebastian Ridd
text: Lisa Diane Knappen and Sebastian Louis Ridd were married on Saturday at St. Aloysius Church in Washington. The Rev. Thomas Clifford, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Nicaraguan Councils Stir Fear of Dictatorship
text: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  The government billboards and graffiti in this sultry city tell a visitor a lot about the ideological battle racking Nicaragua.

headline: Tournament Quickly Reached a Lofty Goal
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Even in this era of the instant, tradition is not immediate. It still takes time for a sporting event to achieve status, to establish history, to rise to significance. Take the Wachovia Championship, for example.

headline: ‘Mrs. Corbett’s Request’
text: Chapter 1: An Unexpected Call

headline: Report Earnings, and Watch the Stock Fall
text: MOMENTUM investing  a bet that what has gone up will keep going up  is risky at any time. But it is especially so during earnings season, when stocks often move up and down very abruptly; in fact, the top-performing stocks are particularly vulnerable during these periods. And a new study has found that these highfliers tend to fall immediately after their companies announce their earnings  whether those earnings are good or bad.

headline: Up in the Air, but Never Confused
text: I HAVE a full-time job at American Airlines as a pilot, and I run a balloon ride business, Skyblue Ballooning, on the side with my husband, a pilot who works for AirTran Airways. I’m also the mother of two girls, Lauren, 5, and Danielle, 3. My friends say they don’t know how I do it all. You could say I’m a master juggler.

headline: A Latter-Day Gehrig Survives, and He Demands to Be Heard
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y.

headline: A Tour of Go-Kart Nation
text: FROM coast to coast, drivers race for glory in gasoline-powered karts. Here are indoor tracks where they can live fast:

headline: The Birthday Cake as a Milepost
text: SAMUEL, my 10-year-old, told me recently that one of his earliest memories was the birthday cake I made when he was 3. It was a snowman cake, for his snow-theme party. Three single layers cut into proportionate circles and frosted in stiff, white fondant icing; black gumdrop eyes and mouth; a striped scarf made by twisting together red and black shoestring licorice and a traditional carrot nose. It was quite a cake  especially for me, an advanced-beginner baker at best. So when Samuel told me he remembered it, I was proud  for the three seconds before he explained, "I remember it was scary."

headline: Praxis Makes Perfect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Smaller Raises Advised for Board Leaders
text: WESTCHESTER residents are increasingly worried about the growth and cost of government, said a report issued Wednesday by the Compensation Advisory Panel, and therefore hefty raises proposed last December by the County Board of Legislators for its leadership are ill advised, especially given the uncertain state of the economy.

headline: At College, a High Standard on Divorce
text: WHEATON, Ill.  Of all the reasons a beloved professor could be leaving the college where he has taught for the last 20 years, the one for Kent Gramm’s departure is peculiar: He is getting divorced, the college demands an explanation, and he refuses to give one.

headline: A Room With a View (Maybe) in Gotham
text: TOP reader suggestions on visiting New York, compiled from user comments on the Travel section’s Web site. You can read more comments, as well as post your own, on this and other cities, at nytimes.com/travel.

headline: Hawks See an Opening, the Celtics a Lifeline
text: ATLANTA  For five years, ever since a rebuilding project started with General Manager Billy Knight in 2003, Atlanta Hawks fans have resented failed draft picks (Shelden Williams), the refusal to draft a top-shelf point guard (Chris Paul, Deron Williams), the signing of the swingman Joe Johnson to a five-year, $70 million contract, and the squabbling over finances by a cadre of 10 owners.

headline: Even the Insured Feel Strain of Health Costs
text: The economic slowdown has swelled the ranks of people without health insurance. But now it is also threatening millions of people who have insurance but find that the coverage is too limited or that they cannot afford their own share of medical costs.

headline: Ann Abel, Andy Omel
text: Ann Abel and Andy Omel were married on Saturday at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth N. Purdum, an Evangelical Lutheran minister, officiated.

headline: Working to Restore Help for AIDS Patients
text: NOW that Nassau and Suffolk Counties have won their lawsuit to restore full federal financing for helping those with AIDS and the H.I.V. infection, health and social service officials say they hope to boost medical and support services to Long Island patients.

headline: Westchester Can Wait
text: FOR their first home together, Kerrie McHugh and David Hayes assumed that they would buy a starter house. It would be in Westchester County, near her parents.

headline: Loving the Drive, Even After 5
text: “I guess my dream job would be a test engineer,” says Wayne DaCosta, “where you get to drive  maybe even for Ferrari  and your job is basically to dissect the car and tell the weaknesses and strong points.”

headline: Ireland, Then and Now
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: Rome at Night
text: An article on April 20 about Rome at night misidentified the figure from mythology represented in the centerpiece sculpture of the Trevi Fountain. It is Oceanus, the Titan who the ancient Greeks believed ruled the watery elements  not Neptune, the Roman god of the sea. (The error has appeared for years in travel guides about Rome, is found extensively in Internet references, and has infiltrated at least five other articles in The Times since 1981.)

headline: Time to Cut the Cord
text: THE most important thing we can do to help the Iraqis and ourselves is to recognize  and reverse  the seminal mistake that followed the quick destruction of Saddam Hussein’s murderous regime: the foolish (however well-meaning) and arrogant belief that we know better than the Iraqis how to rebuild their devastated society.

headline: The Man in the Blue Pajamas
text: MY parents were volunteer emergency medical technicians for two decades, so I expected I would be great at the job. I certainly had parental support. When I mentioned to my mom in 1996 that I was thinking of becoming an E.M.T., she all but picked me up and carried me into the training hall, right down the block from our house on Eaton Court in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn.

headline: Letters: The Green Issue
text: Kudos on a job well done informing readers of any number of ways to reduce their carbon footprint (April 20). The behavior-oriented suggestions were cleverly organized and easy to navigate. After reading your magazine, I thought, What would it have been like if the “green” issue were printed on postconsumer recycled fiber paper?

headline: Hoop Data Dreams
text: The True Value of Rajon Rondo

headline: Old Hallway Vents Can Pose Dangers
text: Q I live in a high-rise apartment house built in the 1920s. All the apartment lines have kitchens with windows, except for the line I’m in, which has a kitchenette that is mechanically vented. The hallway outside the apartment also has a vent, which does not seem to draw any air. Instead, my apartment is drawing in air and smells from the hallway and from other apartments. I am concerned that in a fire, smoke could be sucked into my apartment in a similar manner. Is my building in violation of high-rise building codes? What might be a potential solution?

headline: Louisiana Democrat Takes House Seat
text: NEW ORLEANS  A Democrat took an open Congressional seat long held by Republicans in the conservative district around Baton Rouge in a special election Saturday, giving the party an early boost in its quest for an increased majority in the House of Representatives.

headline: A Writer’s New Liaison With Broadway
text: AT first Christopher Hampton seems like a scribe from an earlier era: elegantly soft-spoken, with a mane of long gray hair; he writes his first drafts with a fountain pen.

headline: ’88 Campaign Offers a Lesson in Using Symbols as Bludgeons
text: WASHINGTON  Sometimes, as Senator Barack Obama seemed to argue earlier this year, a flag pin is just a flag pin.

headline: How Hard Should It Be to Vote?
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Serve the People!’
text: The novel is the only place for a great many of life's truths. Because it is only in fiction that certain facts can be held up to the light.

headline: Writer Turns Creativity to Shaping Storytellers
text: NEWARK

headline: Music of the Boroughs
text: LAST Saturday afternoon at 3, a Binghamton, N.Y., couple named Halsey and Jo-Anne Bagg were sitting on a bench at 86th Street and Fifth Avenue waiting to meet their son when a fashionably dressed woman carrying a red-dyed antelope bag unzipped the suitcase she had been wheeling along, removed what appeared to be an ordinary Chinese takeout container, and introduced herself.

headline: Questioning a Filly’s Death and Looking for Solutions
text: What readers on The Rail, The Times’s Triple Crown blog, are saying about the death of Eight Belles.

headline: How Murdoch Got Lost in China
text: RUPERT MURDOCH seems to have become a 24/7 story  even, or especially, in media he does not own. He is often portrayed as either a master Machiavellian who always gets his way or a money-grubbing lowbrow impresario. He may be neither.

headline: Weighing the Wisdom of Battling an Invader
text: Maurice River Township

headline: Removing Head Lice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parceling Out Power to the People
text: WITH energy prices rising, many co-op and condominium buildings are looking for ways to cut energy costs. In buildings that have not acted yet, there are basically two ways of doing that.

headline: I Know What You Did Last Math Class
text: ON school days at 2 p.m., Nicole Dobbins walks into her home office in Alpharetta, Ga., logs on to ParentConnect, and reads updated reports on her three children. Then she rushes up the block to meet the fourth and sixth graders’ buses.

headline: Can You Become a Creature of New Habits?
text: HABITS are a funny thing. We reach for them mindlessly, setting our brains on auto-pilot and relaxing into the unconscious comfort of familiar routine. “Not choice, but habit rules the unreflecting herd,” William Wordsworth said in the 19th century. In the ever-changing 21st century, even the word “habit” carries a negative connotation.

headline: Looser Rules for Federal Help
text: PRESIDENT BUSH predicted last August that a new plan introduced by the administration to assist borrowers trying to cope with adjustable-rate mortgages would help tens of thousands of people.

headline: Scoring Erupts in the Playoffs
text: The new N.H.L. may still have its problems with constricted play and low scoring during the regular season, but not during this year’s playoffs. Postseason play has been open and creative, with a number of exciting comebacks and beautiful goals.

headline: Cuisines in Bloom
text: Sooner or later the weather will turn warm and sunny, making it easier to enjoy the full New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. For now, consider a visit to the garden’s current exhibition, “Darwin’s Garden: An Evolutionary Adventure,” which explores Charles Darwin’s research with the world of plants outside his window. Outside the garden is a diverse selection of restaurants.

headline: Lisa Stenson and Antonio Desamours
text: WHEN Lisa Stenson, 43, and Antonio Desamours, 41, met two years ago at a Valentine’s Day event at a church in Atlanta, his first words to her were not, “My name is Antonio,” or “Hello, how are you?” or even “You have beautiful eyes.”

headline: When to Drop Charges
text: I work as a consultant out of my home, doing a variety of research, writing and editing tasks for five or six clients at a time. Much of what I do for one client also helps me with others, since the topics are in the same domain. If I spend a day researching something for Client A and can use the same information for Client B, may I charge both of them the consulting fee? NANCY V. YINGER, OAKTON, VA.

headline: New Jersey Man Is Held in Boy’s Death
text: The male companion of a Linden, N.J., woman has been arrested and charged with the murder of her 2-year-old son, the authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Kissing the Cook
text: You can’t get better publicity for a book than “Banned in Boston.” But as product endorsements go, “Banned in China” sends a more mixed message, even if it still wins points for piquancy. Seeing this legend on the dust jacket of Yan Lianke’s faux-naif novel, “Serve the People!”  the first of his books to be translated into English  you have to wonder what Chinese officials are banning books for these days. Publishing overly frank air pollution charts? Leaking hints on Olympic gymnasts’ floor routines? Indulging in too much of the wrong kind of self-criticism? Too much lead in the ink or too much lead in the pencil  that is, excessive lewdness?

headline: Now Viewing | John Lautner
text: John Lautner apprenticed with Frank Lloyd Wright, designed Bob Hope’s Palm Springs mansion and unwittingly spawned Googie, the futuristic style of Left Coast architecture based on a coffee shop of the same name. For more than 55 years, the architect created dwellings so site-specific they seemed to spring from the Los Angeles hills (the Sheats/Goldstein house) or touch down from a distant galaxy (the Marbrisa house, seen at right, or the Chemosphere house). His glass-and-poured-concrete masterpieces have co-starred in films, TV shows and even a video game. This summer, Lautner’s cult status gets an institutional imprimatur with the opening of the exhibition “Between Earth and Heaven: The Architecture of John Lautner” at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, from July 13 to Oct. 12. (The accompanying catalog, from Rizzoli, is available for $60.) Meanwhile, make like Vincent Gallo and Kelly Lynch and buy a Lautner original at architectureforsale.com. The 1949 Schaffer residence in Glendale, Calif., is on the market for just under $2 million. SARAH VERDONE

headline: Taking the Temperature of Brownstone Brooklyn
text: A DIZZYING variety of sources feed weather information to the federal government: ships at sea, sensors on planes, instruments on balloons  and the whirligig on the roof of Bradley Feldman’s brownstone in Park Slope.

headline: Can the South Stand Strong?
text: THE surge and the new American counterinsurgency strategy have improved the situation remarkably in the northern half of Iraq. This progress could serve as the eventual basis for sustainable stability across Iraq. However, as countless people  starting with Gen. David Petraeus, the top United States commander in Iraq  have rightly noted, that progress is fragile.

headline: Coveting Thy Neighbor’s Condo
text: BOTOX. The iPod. Arugula. Each in its own way ushered in an era of heightened expectations  for brow lines, personal music players and salad courses, respectively.

text: Comedy

headline: Elizabeth Martin, Christopher Coakley
text: Elizabeth Lauren Martin, a daughter of Virginia B. Martin and Dick Martin of Summit, N.J., was married on Saturday to Christopher Augustin Coakley, a son of Joan H. Coakley and Gerald M. Coakley of Westwood, Mass. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph’s on Capitol Hill in Washington.
