headline: In Ballot on a Public Pool, a Village Divided
text: ROWAYTON

headline: Ohio Celebrates a Game of Foot Ball
text: On May 3, 1890, a group of Ohio State students rose early, boarded their horse-drawn wagons and made the 20-mile trip along the Olentangy River from Columbus to Delaware, the home of Ohio Wesleyan University, to play what that day’s Delaware Gazette described as “the first game of Rugby foot ball.”

headline: Cycles Reach for Pebble Beach Cachet
text: ONE day in 1906, in Springfield, Mass., Oscar Hedstrom presented a gift to Harmon Elliott, the 16-year-old son of his friend (and fellow inventor) Sterling Elliott. The gift was a shiny black Indian motorcycle produced by the Hendee Manufacturing Company, which Hedstrom had co-founded.

headline: The Preacher’s New Pulpit
text: THE biggest news in the presidential campaign over the past 10 days was the unapologetic re-emergence of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., whose incendiary statements threatened serious harm to his former parishioner Barack Obama.

headline: Songwriting Sisters and the Universe of What They Like
text: SINCE first gaining attention four years ago with “So Jealous,” the 27-year-old twins Tegan and Sara have been known for playing driving rock with straightforward lyrics. “The Con” (Vapor/Sire), the fifth studio album from these singer-songwriters, was no exception when it was released last year. On Tuesday they released a follow-up called “Live Session EP: Tegan and Sara,” available on iTunes, with four songs from “The Con.” They’ve amassed three nominations for Junos (Canada’s equivalent of the Grammys) and are on tour through December, with stops at Bonnaroo and the recent Coachella festival along the way, as well as select dates with Cyndi Lauper and others on the True Colors tour. Off the road the sisters live in separate cities: Tegan Quin in Vancouver and Sara Quin in Montreal. On a recent afternoon in Portland, Ore., before heading out to an impromptu street hockey game, they spoke to Winter Miller by phone about what they’re listening to.

headline: Two Dead in Newark After Fistfight Escalates to Gunfight
text: A teenager and a man fatally shot each other on a Newark street on Saturday, a few blocks from Mayor Cory A. Booker’s house, the police said.

headline: Remember the Refugees
text: RECOMMENDATIONS for how to ensure the best outcome in Iraq are politically easy  and thus plentiful. Our moral responsibility as a nation, however, requires that we prepare for the worst even as we work and hope for the best.

headline: Is There a Real Woman in This Multiplex?
text: IRON MAN, Batman, Big Angry Green Man  to judge from the new popcorn season it seems as if Hollywood has realized that the best way to deal with its female troubles is to not have any, women, that is.

headline: Buyers’ Guide to a Soft Market
text: THESE days, every source, be it a county housing group or a consumer-oriented real estate Web site, is offering its own specialized kind of help to any buyer interested in taking advantage of the softened housing market.

headline: Yearning to Breathe Free
text: In the tradition of “Mommie Dearest,” which recounted a terrorized daughter’s childhood and escape from the brutal Joan Crawford, “Who Do You Think You Are?” is the moving story of Alyse Myers’s struggle with a cruel if far less glamorous mother, and of the author’s fight to break free.

headline: Dharma Bum
text: In this memoir of a musical prodigy’s avatar as a Buddhist monk, Nikolai Grozni, the author of three novels published in his native Bulgaria, dwells on the “overriding, blissfully benumbing feeling of resignation to the moment” that keeps him in the Indian town of Dharamsala.

headline: A Bit More Room on Delta
text: Delta (www.delta.com) has come up with a new look and feel for its international coach seating. Called Cozy Suite, the seating is staggered, allowing for increased arm and knee space. It also has a contoured shoulder area and a tip-up seat base for a more comfortable passage between aisle and window positions. The design, pending regulatory agency approval, is scheduled to be used on Delta 767ER and 777 international aircraft beginning in 2010.

headline: Letters: Prague is Middle Europe
text: To the Editor: The Check In/ Check Out column (April 13) about Prague twice referred to Prague as being in Eastern Europe.” The countries of the old Austrian Empire  the former Czechoslovakia, along with Hungary, Poland and Austria itself  make up Central Europe. They use a Western alphabet; if Catholic, they are Roman rather than Orthodox; and they looked west for cultural leadership instead of east to Moscow.

headline: Correction: Securing the Homeland
text: A brief item on April 13 about developments in homeland security gave a misleading figure for the number of Americans who subscribe to a mobile phone service. The number of subscribers was recently estimated by M:Metrics, a research firm, at about 226 million, not more than 255 million. The higher figure is used by the International Association for the Wireless Telecommunications Industry to estimate the number of subscriptions. A subscriber can have more than one subscription.

headline: Ritzy Organic
text: The Hotel Ritz in Paris has cleaned up its act. From locally sourced wild game (watch out for buckshot in the duck!) and line-caught

headline: The New Collectibles
text: PHOTOS

headline: Earmarks in Form, if Not Process, Are an Issue for McCain
text: The campaign trail has recently taken Senator John McCain  the scourge of earmarked, pork-barrel spending in Congress  across the Alabama River on the Gee’s Bend ferry, to one of his old Navy posts at Cecil Field in Jacksonville, Fla., and to the Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, Pa., where he marveled at the new technology.

headline: Believe It or Not
text: To the Editor:

headline: Young Man, Old Man
text: “The Mayor’s Tongue” begins when two guys who work for a moving company in New York form an unlikely friendship. Alvaro is from the Cibao Valley in the Dominican Republic, uneducated, living in Washington Heights with his wife and children, keeping a filthy studio in Inwood where he sleeps with mistresses and whores. Eugene is from an Italian-American family, well born, college educated, estranged from his father. Alvaro speaks only Cibaeño, “virtually incomprehensible to natives of the other Spanish-speaking countries in the Caribbean”; Eugene speaks English and Italian. The friends are unable to communicate, and yet they converse feelingly, or at least they think they do. Alvaro is writing a novel that he asks Eugene to translate, and Eugene believes that he is able to capture the essence of the story, even without knowing the language.

headline: The New Staples
text: Smoke Apple- or cherry-wood chunks are $3 a pound at the Woodman, Brooklyn; (718) 554-3251; thewoodman.com. Apple- or cherry-wood chips are $4 for 2 pounds at amazon.com.

headline: Blocking the Transmission of Violence
text: LAST SUMMER, MARTIN TORRES WAS WORKING AS A COOK IN AUSTIN, Tex., when, on the morning of Aug. 23, he received a call from a relative. His 17-year-old nephew, Emilio, had been murdered. According to the police, Emilio was walking down a street on Chicago’s South Side when someone shot him in the chest, possibly the culmination of an ongoing dispute. Like many killings, Emilio’s received just a few sentences in the local newspapers. Torres, who was especially close to his nephew, got on the first Greyhound bus to Chicago. He was grieving and plotting retribution. “I thought, Man, I’m going to take care of business,” he told me recently. “That’s how I live. I was going hunting. This is my own blood, my nephew.”

headline: Pen and Sickle
text: On March 2, Russians went to the polls and dutifully voted for Dmitri Medvedev, the presidential candidate handpicked by Vladimir Putin, just as they’d once voted for the handpicked Putin. Three days later, it was reported that the F.S.B., itself a handpicked successor to the K.G.B., was holding a contest to find “the best artistic portrayal of its work.” And the next day, the American publisher Alfred A. Knopf released Solomon Volkov’s “Magical Chorus,” a history of 20th-century Russian culture.

headline: Proposed Train Station Is No Sure Thing
text: Stamford

headline: Attractive Candidate, Great Debate
text: So here I am, subjecting myself to yet another night of Clinton-versus-Obama coverage on CNN, when my mind drifts away from matters of war, health care and the economy. Who can concentrate on the loss of American jobs when Joba Chamberlain’s job remains up in the air? Talk about a hot-button kitchen-table issue!

headline: Some (Real) Letters From Buzzie
text: Every so often, a letter  not an e-mail message, a real letter with a postmarked stamp on the envelope  would arrive from Buzzie Bavasi, who often chastised himself in it as “this old goat.”

headline: Soccer Star’s Misadventure Leaves His Fans Smirking
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  In a city famed for sexual tolerance, the men who shine on the soccer field are held to a different, more macho standard.

headline: Call of the Wild
text: Lu Xun, China’s most revered modern writer, was a student of medicine in 1906 when he saw a lantern slide of Japanese soldiers decapitating a Chinese prisoner. It was a particularly low moment in China’s national self-esteem, and what appalled Lu Xun most was the passivity of the Chinese spectators. “The people,” he later wrote, “of a weak, backward country, even though they may enjoy sturdy health, can only serve as the senseless material of and audience for public executions.” Convinced that art could goad his compatriots toward “spiritual transformation,” he presented them in his first story, “The Diary of a Madman,” as hypocritical cannibals. His later work abounded in such pitiless depictions, inaugurating a modern Chinese literature marked by what the critic C. T. Hsia called “an obsessive concern with China as a nation afflicted with a spiritual disease and therefore unable to strengthen itself or change its set ways of inhumanity.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FANON, by John Edgar Wideman. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Wideman’s novel — raw and astringent, yet with a high literary polish — explores the life of the psychiatrist and revolutionary Frantz Fanon, who treated victims of French torture in Algeria.

headline: Samantha Rosenberg, Jonathan Darche
text: Samantha Meredith Rosenberg and Jonathan Abraham Darche, both assistant district attorneys in Kew Gardens, Queens, were married on Saturday in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. Justice Arthur J. Cooperman of State Supreme Court in Queens officiated at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel and Marina.

headline: So Young, So Strong, So Fast and Oh So Very Sad
text: Anyone who watched the Kentucky Derby on Saturday had to feel saddened and amazed  saddened, of course, by the death of the filly Eight Belles and amazed by the power of the winner, Big Brown. As a longtime very ambivalent fan of horse racing and a lover of thoroughbreds, I can’t help seeing what happened as a kind of paradigm of Thoroughbredness, if you want to call it that.

headline: When Spring Cleaning Includes a Power Plant
text: THE gigantic old power plant at 500 Kent Avenue, next to the Brooklyn Navy Yard in South Williamsburg, has stood on the waterfront since 1905, generating power for the trains and streetcars of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company.

headline: Upstate, Where It Was First Made, Unwavering Devotion to Jell-O
text: Le ROY, N.Y.  Jell-O is as American as, well, Jell-O, a staple at generations of potluck dinners and fodder for students in cafeteria food fights. For some immigrants at Ellis Island, where it was served, it was their first taste of their new home. Carolyn Wyman, author of “Jell-O: A Biography,” sees it as nothing less than a metaphor for the national character.

headline: Jagr Has Even Higher Hopes for the Rangers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  His Rangers teammates fell neatly in line after Saturday’s practice, expressing the conventional wisdom about never looking past the next game. With the one-game-at-a-time cliché seemingly written in professional athletes’ DNA, Jaromir Jagr was willing to take on all the demons at once.

headline: Mixing Metaphors
text: The old adage that beauty plainly in sight is the most difficult to see came home to me one Sunday morning in Williamsburg. I had wandered into the restaurant Moto, where, front and center on the brunch menu, was the Black Velvet, that oddball combination of stout and Champagne. Friends of discriminating palate had long raved about it, usually as a morning-after recuperative, but I couldn’t get around my purist’s snobbery: stout is heavenly and Champagne marvelous, but the thought of mixing them made me wince — until that morning. The creamy, dark grab of the brew was given a tart goose by the bubbly, the two of them buffing each other’s rougher edges to make something entirely, wonderfully other.

headline: How to Clear a Road to Redemption
text: IT is Day 79 in the hostage crisis otherwise known as the auction-rate securities market. Some $300 billion worth of investors’ funds  advertised as being easy as pie to cash in  are still locked up. And the brokerage firms that got investors into this mess are doing little to help.

headline: A New Jet Will Try to Outrun His Height
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  No matter how many touchdowns he scores, no matter how many yards he picks up and no matter how fast he runs, Danny Woodhead cannot escape one statistic. Woodhead, the running back who signed with the Jets last week as an undrafted free agent, is 5 feet 7 inches.

headline: In-Store: One of a Kind
text: 1. You’d have to search far and wide to find another shop like Few and Far, Priscilla Carluccio’s new concept emporium in London’s Knightsbridge area. (Go to fewandfar.net.) Carluccio, the sister and sometime collaborator of Sir Terence Conran, scans the world for eclectic objects for the home and wardrobe that range from classic to cutting-edge. “In addition to unique, inspiring goods, I wanted to return to traditional shopkeeping, where service matters more than spreadsheets. I want to surprise, delight and really look after my customers.”

headline: Right the Wrong
text: WITH eight months left in office, President Bush has the power to shape his successor’s inheritance in Iraq. And the over-arching imperative right now, as articulated by Gen. David Petraeus and others, is to build on the reduction in violence that the surge has achieved by encouraging political reconciliation among the various factions in Iraq.

headline: This Bud’s for You
text: Barack Obama is going to get down if it kills him.

headline: A Song’s Forgotten History, Complete With Cracker Jack
text: They call it baseball’s greatest hit.

headline: Fighting to Save the Planet, at School
text: CHAPPAQUA

headline: The Whinnying’s Welcome, but Wariness Greets a Stable
text: THE closing of the Claremont Riding Academy in April of last year did not bode well for the future of horseback riding in Central Park. But a lesser-known effect has been the strain on the parks department, which for years kept horses at the stables, on West 89th Street near Amsterdam Avenue. Since the closing, the department has had to haul horses in a trailer from a stable at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

headline: A Prison of Shame, and It’s Ours
text: My Times colleague Barry Bearak was imprisoned by the brutal regime in Zimbabwe last month. Barry was not beaten, but he was infected with scabies while in a bug-infested jail. He was finally brought before a court after four nights in jail and then released.

headline: A Northeast Movement to Cut Emissions
text: AT a conference at Yale University last month, officials from New Jersey, New York and Connecticut were among leaders from 18 states who signed a declaration urging the federal government to take action on climate change.

headline: A Strange City Called Home
text: IN the opening moments of Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest chapter of the cinematically styled video game franchise, two men are standing at the side of a boat, watching a familiar sight drift into view. Through their eyes, we see a digitized, 21st-century retelling of a scene that greeted numerous generations of new arrivals to an unknown country: the eastern end of a long, narrow island, with a towering metal spire emerging from its belly, and a diminutive green statue beckoning from a tiny point off the island’s southern tip.

headline: Microsoft Withdraws Bid for Yahoo
text: Microsoft said Saturday that it was abandoning its blockbuster bid to acquire Yahoo after it raised its offer by $5 billion but Yahoo rejected it as still too low.

headline: The All-White Elephant in the Room
text: BORED by those endless replays of the Rev. Jeremiah Wright? If so, go directly to YouTube, search for “John Hagee Roman Church Hitler,” and be recharged by a fresh jolt of clerical jive.

headline: Nothing ‘Sacred’: Young Hotshot Artist Tries to Make It Big
text: Ah, youth. Imagine being an art student in Paris in the 1880s  a flight of fancy made easier by a small but absolutely fascinating exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum. “Invoking the Comic Muse: Toulouse-Lautrec’s Parody of ‘The Sacred Grove’ ” looks at the role of caricature and pastiche in Henri Toulouse-Lautrec’s early art.

headline: Intellectual Property
text: For Glenn O’Brien and Gina Nanni, weekend life in the Hamptons had become too stressful. So the couple sold their Bridgehampton, N.Y., farmhouse in 2003 and set their sights on the more laid-back Litchfield County, in Connecticut. A vintage Modernist stone-and-glass structure caught their attention online. But when they drove up from the city to look at it, what they found was a scene straight out of “Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House”  the “before” scene. “It looked great on the outside,” says Nanni, a partner in the New York public relations firm Company Agenda, but “the inside was a horrible disappointment.”

headline: Film Crew Rights
text: Film Crew Rights

headline: Alone Home
text: Part treehouse, part oversize closet, the lollipop studios for one, known as Single Hauz, was dreamed up by Pawel Kobrynski, Wojciech Krawczuk and Marcin Sakson, a trio of Polish architects. Each elevated prefab is 6 feet by 20 feet; sliding French doors open into the main living area, with a kitchenette and enough room for a bed and a single chair; and a tiny bathroom is shoehorned into a windowless nook. It can be erected on almost any terrain, even on a lake. “The Single Hauz is a kind of architectural-social manifesto about single people,” Kobrynski says. But it can also provide a refuge even for the happily married, “because every one of us sometimes needs a place where we can be alone.” The Single Hauz has not yet found a manufacturer; for more information, go to frontarchitects.pl. MARK ELLWOOD

headline: Giants’ Zito Offers Help and Is Looking for Hope
text: PHILADELPHIA  Staff Sgt. Christopher Hill was fighting in Iraq when a rocket attack broke his back in June 2004. A few weeks ago, Hill and about 20 other injured Marines were treated to three days of spring training in Arizona by an organization founded by Barry Zito, a pitcher for the San Francisco Giants.

headline: Trying to Put a Name to the Face of Evil
text: “HITLER is alive in Burma” reads the words scrawled on a cardboard sign, held aloft by a sweet-faced Ellen Page, the “Juno” star, in a 90-second human-rights public awareness message that began showing on video-sharing Web sites last week.

headline: Correction: The Spirit of ’68
text: An article last Sunday about the impact of the political upheavals of 1968 on world cinema gave an incorrect courtesy title for the filmmaker Rosa von Praunheim on second reference. He is Mr. von Praunheim, not Ms. The article also misidentified the season during which the Soviet Union sent its forces into Prague that year. It was in the summer  on Aug. 21  not fall.

headline: Kristina Napolitano, Christopher Bauer
text: Kristina Maria Napolitano, a daughter of Maria C. Napolitano and Dr. Raffaele A. Napolitano of North Caldwell, N.J., was married on Saturday to Christopher Charles Bauer, a son of Jean D. Bauer and Eugene Bauer of Washingtonville, N.Y. Bishop Nicholas DiMarzio of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn performed the ceremony in Manhattan at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Don’t Know Much About History
text: Never mind his Pulitzer, the best-selling books, the writing jobs at The Wall Street Journal and The New Yorker: Tony Horwitz is a dope. Really, he’ll tell you so himself, and often does, though not in so many words, in his funny and lively new travelogue, “A Voyage Long and Strange.” Horwitz is probably best known as the author of “Confederates in the Attic,” an exploration of how the American Civil War and its cultural backwash still move otherwise semi-normal Americans to do crazy things, like sleep outdoors in 19th-century-style long johns while pretending to be Abner Doubleday. In that book as in this one, Horwitz assumes the pose of a baby-boomer Everyman, overschooled but undereducated. He is chagrined at the basic historical facts he was once taught but can no longer remember or, worse, never knew to begin with. Like so many of us, he is the incarnation of Father Guido Sarducci’s Five Minute University, where degrees are awarded for reciting the two or three things the average liberal-arts graduate remembers from four years of college.

headline: New Recall at Queens Food Company
text: A Queens food company is recalling about 286,000 pounds of fresh and frozen beef, pork and poultry products that may be contaminated with listeria, a type of bacteria, a federal agency said on Saturday.

headline: When a Landlord Sells the Property
text: Q We rent a house in Westchester County, which the landlord has decided to sell. If we have a signed lease through August 2009, can it be terminated before that date by the new owner?

headline: Correction: Claudia Drummond and Raymond Acciardo Sr.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 3 of the Travel section this weekend about lighthouses on Croatian islands that take guests gives an outdated name for the home country of some visitors to one lighthouse. It is the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.

headline: Mandatory AP Exams Stir Student and Parent Outcry
text: STUDENTS enrolled in Advanced Placement classes at two schools in the Northern Valley Regional High School District in Bergen County are now required to take the AP exams this month  or receive a failing grade in the courses under a new school policy being questioned by some parents and students.

headline: A Lender Gets Caught in the Currents
text: WALKING across his sun-drenched office overlooking Fifth Avenue and the New York Public Library, Jeffrey M. Peek points to a picture on his desk. It is a perfect family portrait, filled with smiling, happy faces on a mountain summit. Perfect, except for one detail: there’s a problem with the guy in the far left corner.

headline: New Album, New Fears, Same Old Attitude
text: AHMIR Thompson was sitting in the back of a town car inching through Midtown when he received a vexing call from management, not entirely unlike the one that opens “Rising Down” (Def Jam), the new album by the Roots. One month before its release there were problems with a hidden track, and Mr. Thompson, better known as ?uestlove, the Roots’ drummer and bandleader, made no attempt to hide his frustration, raising his voice in protest.

headline: If the Fish Liver Can’t Kill, Is It Really a Delicacy?
text: SHIMONOSEKI, Japan  Poison has been as integral to fugu, the funny-looking, potentially deadly puffer fish prized by Japanese gourmands, as the savor of its pricey meat. So consider fugu, but poison-free.

headline: ‘Who Do You Think You Are?’
text: Prologue

headline: Chow, Darling
text: When the 25-year-old fashion designer Christopher Kane first considered giving a dinner party for a few of his friends, he knew, without question, that it was not going to be at home. Kane spends most of his time working with his older sister, Tammy  who is also his accomplice, business partner and fit model  in a spacious but grungy East London loft that is best suited for sandwich deliveries. “My studio is so messy,” said Kane, rolling his eyes. “I have magazines and piles of stuff everywhere because I often start working on projects and don’t finish them. We would have had to eat on the floor.”

headline: Stray Thoughts
text: Michelle de KretSer’s new novel is filled with aphorisms. “The past is not what is over but what we wish to have done with.” “Reality is an effect produced by the accrual of detail.” “Euphemisms are symptomatic of shame.” To which I’d add, aphorisms enlighten  except when they don’t.

headline: INSTANT DECORATOR: Gala Force Entertaining
text: For the Manhattan event planner David Monn, organizing a dinner party on the beach usually involves a tent, sofas and a dance floor. When entertaining in his own Sag Harbor, N.Y., backyard, however, things get a little less complicated. “For me, it’s the opposite of a large production,” says the man who’s orchestrated everything from the Met’s Costume Institute gala to the Plaza Hotel’s coming Grand Reopening Celebration and other intimate soirees. In either case, he first creates what he calls “imaginary architecture,” using torches, hurricane lanterns on pillars or lights strung in trees to make guests feel safe. Next he chooses one color element. “Constancy is where we derive our power image,” he notes. Can Monn purchase power among the offerings of CB2, Crate and Barrel’s cheap-and-cheerful offshoot? No problem. He quickly struck upon his color: “Live chartreuse green”  or Olivine, in CB2-speak  which works outdoors as a “continuation of what the eyes are already seeing.” In fact, he liked the textures and ease offered by CB2 so much, guests at one of the three beach weddings he’s organizing this summer should keep a (green) eye out. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

headline: Want to Be My Boyfriend? Please Define

headline: Works by the Masters in a Celebration of Drawing
text: What a pity it would be if the many big touring exhibitions at Yale managed to deflect attention from “Master Drawings,” a new, quieter show at the Yale University Art Gallery. The European old master drawings shown here are from the 15th to 19th centuries. They are part of the permanent collection, but together form an exhibition no less compelling than the imported works.

headline: Turning Japanese
text: In 2003, after a celebrated and controversial career as the manager of the Mets, you left Major League Baseball and moved to a suburb of Tokyo to manage the Chiba Lotte Marines. These days you speak Japanese and ride your bicycle to work, as we learn in the new ESPN documentary, “The Zen of Bobby V.” What do you think of the film? I think I was a lucky guy to have three special young guys sharing my life for seven months.

headline: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
text: IN February, on a chilly, clear Sunday morning, Sir Richard Branson, president of Virgin Atlantic, along with the co-sponsors Boeing and GE Aviation, lured more than 200 journalists to a hangar at Heathrow Airport near London to witness what they said was airline history. Over flutes of Champagne and plates of mini-bagels filled with salmon, everyone’s eyes were fixed on a 747 as it took off on the world’s first biofuel demonstration flight.

headline: A Phone Call, Then a Man Is Shot Dead
text: A neighbor of a Brooklyn man who was fatally shot in his apartment building said on Saturday that the victim had received a cellphone call just before the shooting, and the police said that robbery did not appear to have been a motive.

headline: Miss Shanghai
text: Midway through Wang Anyi’s extraordinary novel “The Song of Everlasting Sorrow,” its heroine, Wang Qiyao, is on her way to a pawn shop when she runs into Mr. Cheng, a friend she hasn’t seen in 12 years. A portrait photographer, Mr. Cheng had taken Wang Qiyao’s photo in the late 1940s; the picture appeared in a magazine, and she went on to win third place in the Miss Shanghai beauty contest, the pinnacle of her career. By the time they meet again, it is 1960. Tragedy and ill-starred romance have ruined Wang Qiyao’s reputation; she is pregnant with the child of a lover whose identity she refuses to reveal. Food shortages have pushed China to the brink of famine, so Mr. Cheng, taking pity on her, invites Wang Qiyao to share his modest lunch of rice and salt pork. At his apartment, “after her eyes had adjusted to the darkness, she saw that the little world inside had barely changed; it was as if the little room had been encased in a time capsule. ... Wang Qiyao failed to understand that it is precisely this myriad of unchanging little worlds that serves as a counterfoil to the tumultuous changes taking place in the outside world.”

headline: As Tuesday Votes Loom, Obama Seeks Lift and Clinton Pushes Gas-Tax Plan
text: INDIANAPOLIS  After the most trying week of his presidential bid, Senator Barack Obama sought to reframe and reinvigorate his candidacy on Saturday by asking Democrats to disregard “phony ideas, calculated to win elections instead of actually solving problems” and to seize an opportunity to change Washington.

headline: Who Will Tell the People?
text: Traveling the country these past five months while writing a book, I’ve had my own opportunity to take the pulse, far from the campaign crowds. My own totally unscientific polling has left me feeling that if there is one overwhelming hunger in our country today it’s this: People want to do nation-building. They really do. But they want to do nation-building in America.

text: Senator John McCain is 71 years old, a survivor of an aggressive form of skin cancer. If elected, he would be the oldest man to become president.

headline: I’m a Campaign Worker. Can I Sleep Here?
text: SEAN SMITH, a 37-year-old spokesman for Senator Barack Obama, has just landed in Louisville, Ky., where he’s staying with a family with two young children. He’s sharing a guest room with twin beds with another Obama staff member. (His roommate, he reports happily, doesn’t snore.) He expects to live in this borrowed way until May 20, when Kentucky has its Democratic primary.

headline: Forbidden Questions
text: The serial killers who romp through thrillers are supposed to be, among other things, symbols of childhood fears grown to adult paranoia, but what if the bogeyman under the bed was real all along? That’s the premise behind CHILD 44 (Grand Central, $24.99), Tom Rob Smith’s first novel, about a serial killer in Stalinist Russia who can’t be caught because he doesn’t officially exist  otherwise, the totalitarian government wouldn’t be able to blame political undesirables for his crimes.

headline: Pavlov Was Right
text: Hungry? Good. The dinner bell is ringing for you and your pals. A Japanese tapered brass beckoner has a certain Brancusi-esque appeal ($75 at Turpan, Santa Monica, Calif.; 310-451-9500). Olof Kolte’s Ring My Bell, with its lacquered handle and silver-plated clapper, is a sweet example of Salvation Army chic (from $103 at Vessel, London; vesselgallery.com). And the brothers Campana (the Italian word for “bell”) have teamed up with Venini to create a series of limited-edition mouth-blown campane for Moss. N° 1956 has a branch handle and a metal hook for sound ($1,900 at Moss; mossonline.com). CHARLOTTE DRUCKMAN

headline: Stem Sell
text: Design Research was having a sale. It was 1978 or so. “Buy this,” my sister said. “It is a must.” So I listened to my sister, and have not been without one (or a number) ever since. If it chips or breaks (not easily), you buy another. It has a life of its own, so it takes a while to get the flowers to fall into place. But once they do, it is a perfect thing. Lyrical and simple. This vase of flowers, joined with a Friday afternoon spent listening to “St. Matthew Passion,” meditating over a slice of lemon pound cake  it is a must. MAIRA KALMAN

headline: Webb Is the Model, and Pelfrey Learns a Lesson About His Craft
text: PHOENIX  Brandon Webb was two weeks shy of his 24th birthday when he made his major league debut in 2003 and, for these purposes, a bit younger than Mike Pelfrey, his counterpart on the mound Saturday, is now. That frame of reference is instructive when wondering whether Pelfrey could come close to following Webb’s career trajectory, nasty sinker and all, but it also accentuates the current gulf between them.

headline: Packing A Wallop
text: One reason to move to the Bay Area: the Boccalone Salumi Society. Twice a month, members pick up Happy Meal-style boxes of Boccalone meats, made by the Incanto chef Chris Cosentino and his team. The week’s haul might include fresh breakfast sausage, mortadella, orange and wild fennel salame, lardo and other porky items, with prices starting at $174 for three months. It’s like a charcuterie C.S.A. (community-supported agriculture) box, except you won’t have to worry about what to do with all that soppressata. The rest of us can order à la carte at boccalone.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

headline: Jazzfest: Tubas Outnumber Rappers
text: This must be one of the few places the Roots ever play where their sousaphone player, Tuba Gooding Jr., isn’t an unusual sight. In fact, tubas outnumber rappers decisively at Jazzfest; hip-hop generally has a token presence here. That said, the Roots sounded right at home during their explosive set on Saturday, charging through tunes with practiced abandon. And when Ludacris sauntered out to join them, for a brief but potent moment — rapping his 2003 hit “Stand Up” — the vibe was strong.

headline: Jazzfest: A Closer Look at the Costumes
text: When a Mardi Gras Indian parade goes by at Jazzfest, hourly in the early afternoon, the first impression is the sheer joyous ostentation of those outsize feathers and the propulsion of the beat. It’s usually worth taking a longer, closer look. The Indians sew their own costumes anew each year, and the feathers may be the easy part. The costumes also include large panels, called patches, made of painstaking, intricate beadwork — a confluence of African and Native American traditions. So much fine handwork wouldn’t be wasted on mere decoration; the patches often involve symbols and stories. Many show battles between cowboys and Indians, complete with dead cowboys. But there are more contemporary ones as well.

headline: Sorrow at the Derby
text: Welcome to our coverage of the 134th Kentucky Derby. We’ll be getting updates from Joe Drape and our other contributors throughout the day. I’ll be “live” blogging the entire spectacle. I use live lightly because I am not in Louisville. Instead, I am at the Times’s headquarters in New York. But I will be here with you until we have a winner. So while I wish I was sipping a mint julep underneath a wide-brimmed hat at Churchill Downs, I’m happy to be here with you. Send in some questions. Add your comments.

headline: Jean-Luc Le Dû | Oenophile
text: As the former sommelier at Daniel and the current owner of Le Dû’s Wines in the West Village, Jean-Luc Le Dû has sipped, swirled and spat some of the most coveted hooch in the world. So please excuse him if he appears something of a perfectionist. ‘‘There are two things that always make me cringe: a bottle being stored standing up, or a bottle stored in too warm of a temperature,’’ says the Brittany-born New Yorker. When it comes to his own wood-paneled, climate-controlled booze boutique, Le Dû doesn’t mind raising a glass to himself: ‘‘It is as close to a perfect wine shop as possible.’’ Or it will be when he finally hunts down a one-of-a- kind eau de vie. ‘‘I’m trying to find the absolute best bottle to import,’’ he says. ‘‘I’m not giving up.’’ We’ll drink to that.

headline: Rangers Pregame: Avery Released, Lineup Shuffled

He had been released from intensive care only Saturday. No word on whether he annoyed hospital personnel in lieu of being able to annoy the Penguins.

headline: One of These Things Is Not Like the Others
text: One thought that I could not get into today’s article: I’d say that, by this point, Nelson Figueroa has supplanted Mike Pelfrey as the Mets’ No. 4 starter. Right now, Pelfrey’s spot in the rotation is safe as long as Orlando Hernandez and Pedro Martinez are non-entities and Claudio Vargas is gaining arm strength at Class AAA New Orleans. But Willie Randolph loves Figueroa’s rubber arm, and if Pelfrey continues to struggle in his next few starts, the Mets may have to start exploring internal options. I could also see a situation in which Figueroa moves to the bullpen as the long man, replacing Jorge Sosa (who has options), but that’s a little further down the road.

headline: Economic science fiction
text: I’m startled at Brad DeLong’s ignorance: he thinks there’s something new about science fiction novels where the science in question is economics.

headline: MicroHoo: The End of the Beginning

headline: A Man Who Understands Challenges Helps Others Face Death
text: Making the rounds at Montefiore Medical Center with John C. Welton, a physician assistant who is severely disabled from childhood polio.

headline: The Other Car
text: Six years ago my wife and I traded in two cars for two new-used ones. Twice in a few weeks, one of us drove an old car up a ramp to the cavernous second floor of the dealership and just left it there. Well, not quite, for later we reported to each other the same experience. Each of us walked away, but then looked back, realizing that this familiar friend would be gone from our lives forever and, more poignantly, that we were abandoning a faithful, if increasingly troublesome, retainer.

headline: New From Bravo: Cruise, Calendar, Cooking Classes

headline: New Episode of ‘Hannah Montana’ Sunday; First Since Vanity Fair Photo Emerged

headline: Parallel Paths for Two Sunday Morning Hosts

headline: From Mousepads to Piggy Banks
text: This primary season campaign souvenirs are cropping up like kudzu. Retail stores on each of the candidates’ official Web sites offer copious merchandise from lapel pins and mousepads to hoodies and onesies alongside the requisite buttons and bumper stickers. Given the ease with which a logo or slogan can be stamped on any product, the sheer quantity of retail campaign stuff is possibly greater than at any other time in history, albeit a lot less campy than during other elections.

headline: Jazzfest: Preservation at Midnight
text: For well over 40 years, Preservation Hall has been a bastion of traditional jazz, and a magnet for tourists seeking a taste of the old-fashioned New Orleans experience. Housed in a building that dates to the mid-1700s (and sometimes seems to have gone without much upgrading since), the hall has always stood as a stubborn throwback in the rowdy, gaudy heart of the French Quarter.

headline: Jazzfest: For the Kids
text: Plenty of festivals toss around the phrase “family friendly,” but Jazzfest does more than most to deserve the designation.

headline: Legends of the Motorcycle

headline: Jazzfest: Two Kinds of Rebirth
text: It’s one thing — a total joy — to see the Rebirth Brass Band play a club date in or out of New Orleans. It’s another to see the kinds of shows that Rebirth and other bands bring to Jazzfest.

headline: Rangers’ Postgame: The End Comes Hard
text: It is almost impossible to describe the feeling of a losing locker room when a hockey season ends. A place once so filled with laughter and tension and the shared experience of a playoff fight is instantly drained, filled instead with a palpable heartbreak.

text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The day after the Derby is usually for joining all the high spirits in the winner’s barn, and starting the dissection of his strengths and weaknesses. What we all want to know now is does Big Brown possess Triple Crown mettle? The backside was more subdued, however, because of the tragedy that befell Eight Belles.

The move was partly a practical matter, but also a symbolic gesture, announced as the signal gesture of a “Commitment to New Orleans” initiative. It may have been one of the happiest cultural developments in this city over the past year.

Guards had put him in solitary confinement, and late that night, an ambulance had taken him away more dead than alive.

text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama pushed their final appeals on Sunday before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, with Mrs. Clinton sounding like a full-throated populist in highlighting her stance on the gasoline tax and Mr. Obama seizing on the issue to cast his opponent as a political opportunist.

headline: In Matchup of Top Arms, Throw From Right Is Pivotal
text: PHOENIX  It is impossible to know what would have happened had Ryan Church not thrown out an aggressive runner at third base Sunday. But it is quite possible to imagine, and all signs were pointing toward a swift resolution  one favoring the Arizona Diamondbacks, not the Mets  when in one motion Church picked up the ball and fired a perfect one-hopper to nail Chris Burke and preserve a tie score in the eighth inning.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the Charles M. Bair Family Museum in Martinsdale, Mont., may have left an incorrect impression about the amount of time the museum had been closed. The museum, which is open only during the summer, was closed from 2002 through 2005 and was open in the summer of 2006 and 2007. The article may have implied it had been closed entirely since 2002.

headline: Utah’s Brawn Is No Match for Bryant

headline: Corrections: For the Record

She is Ellen Chapnick, not Chapin.

text: You’ve been there. You can hear and see the splash before you even grip the club. And we all know what happens next.

headline: Alan Seiden, a Key to a St. John’s N.I.T. Title, Is Dead at 71
text: Alan Seiden, an all-American guard who helped lead the St. John’s basketball team to the 1959 National Invitation Tournament title, died Saturday at his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens. He was 71.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 1 through May 3 with 671 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 601 said they were registered to vote.

headline: A Turkmen Dismantles Reminders of Old Ruler
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  A 246-foot tall, rocket ship-like monument to the late ruler of Turkmenistan, topped with a golden statue of himself that rotates to always face the sun, will be removed from the center of the Turkmen capital, state news media there have reported.

headline: A Mind-Altering Drug Altered a Culture as Well
text: When it comes to LSD, I have to confess: I inhaled. But I inhaled like so many other denizens of the 1960s and early ’70s, whether they actually took the drug or not. I inhaled because you couldn’t fail to inhale. LSD  its aura if not its substance  was a component of the air we breathed. This hallucinogen infused the exhalations of musicians, philosophers, advertisers and activists.

headline: Police and Army Officers Tied to Attempt on Karzai’s Life
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s defense minister confirmed Sunday that a police captain was connected with the group behind the assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai a week earlier and that an army officer supplied the weapons and ammunition used in the attack.

headline: Hard Lessons for Mother After School-Trip Accident
text: Wearing a baggy cardigan, with dishrag hair and no makeup, Jan Maxwell can go from a calm expression of deepest pain to sudden fury as the mother of a 16-year-old killed in an accident with the rest of his class on what should have been an ordinary school trip. Speaking directly to the audience, she nearly howls in rage at the idiotic phrases of comfort offered to her. (“Everything happens for a reason.”) Ms. Maxwell’s compelling, unsentimental performance is the centerpiece of Anton Dudley’s “Substitution,” but its strength is matched by Kieran Campion’s portrayal of Paul, a young substitute teacher who knew the mother’s son, Calvin.

headline: How Much for Those Baby Photos?
text: Not long ago, when a magazine paid a celebrity more than a person might earn in a lifetime in return for a set of pictures, media critics questioned the ethics of both the publication and the star.

headline: Clashes in Bolivia on Vote Over More Autonomy

headline: McCain-Jindal?
text: Barack Obama said Friday, “We’ve had a rough couple of weeks.” Actually, he’s had a rough couple of months. He’s lost three big primaries to Hillary Clinton. And, should he hold on to win the nomination, he can no longer be considered a clear favorite over John McCain in the general election.

text: Federal agencies are intensifying a criminal investigation of the mortgage industry and focusing on whether some lenders turned a blind eye to inflated income figures provided by borrowers.

headline: Why Leisure Matters in a Busy World
text: A few months ago, I spoke with a Canadian economist, Linda Nazareth, about her prediction that we are entering an age governed by changes in leisure patterns. We talked then about the ways that workplaces and businesses will evolve to accommodate and capitalize on the 77 million baby boomers who will, in increasing numbers, have excess time on their hands.

headline: Judgment Sought for Umpire Art
text: A Norman Rockwell painting depicting three umpires looking skyward as raindrops begin to fall has sent the Curtis Publishing Company in search of a favorable call from the United States District Court in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported. The company has filed suit against ESPN, seeking to bar it from rebroadcasting its television series “The Bronx Is Burning,” about the 1977 New York Yankees, until it withdraws its use of the painting, “Bottom of the Sixth.” In an e-mail message Curtis notified lawyers that ESPN did not have a license to use the painting and was committing willful copyright infringement, the lawsuit said. Court documents said that the painting was shown full screen in the second episode, “Team in Turmoil,” and that the series had since been sold in DVD and VHS format. Lawyers for ESPN did not immediately return calls seeking comment. The painting, one of more than 300 created by Rockwell for The Saturday Evening Post, first appeared in the April 23, 1949, issue and was donated to the National Baseball Hall of Fame & Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Frustration at Shootout on Streets of Newark
text: The details of the shootout were chilling. A man and a teenager argued, both pulled out guns, and they shot each other repeatedly until both ended up dead, witnesses said. The teenager fired a 9-millimeter assault weapon, the police said, and the man used a silver revolver. The gun battle occurred on a busy street, three blocks from the mayor’s home.

headline: Rangers’ Season Ends With More Disappointment
text: PITTSBURGH  After the final shot eluded him, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist stood alone in his crease Sunday afternoon, pain radiating from his blue eyes. His teammates had skated back to their bench, and the Penguins celebrated in a giant mob to his right. For what seemed like minutes, Lundqvist bore his agony alone.

headline: How Bill Clinton Got His Campaign Groove Back
text: BEECH GROVE, Ind.  For anyone who has observed Bill Clinton over the past 20 years  witnessed his intuitive command of his audiences, his keen ability to frame an issue, the heads nodding in agreement whether he is speaking to a gymnasium crammed with voters or a newspaper editorial board his performance this year on his wife’s behalf has been startling.

headline: Special Graduation Guest in Storm Zone
text: GREENSBURG, Kan.  A year to the day after a deadly tornado nearly wiped this western Kansas prairie town off the map, Sunday’s high school graduation ceremony was conducted with a bit more pomp and circumstance than usual. The graduates, all 18 of them, had an out-of-town commencement speaker: President Bush.

headline: Have a Happy Fiesta
text: What would holidays be without commerce? Hallmark turned Mother’s Day from a call for peace into the day of the greeting card. De Beers turned Valentine’s Day into a reason to buy diamonds. On this day, Cinco de Mayo, we celebrate Corona’s prowess in helping craft the nation’s most famous Latino fiesta out of a battle in a Mexican city many Latinos have never heard of.

headline: States Look to Rein In Private Medicare Plans
text: WASHINGTON  State officials say they will soon ask Congress for more power to regulate the marketing of private Medicare insurance plans to older Americans because they are still receiving complaints of high-pressure sales tactics that have led some beneficiaries to sign up for unsuitable policies.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about radio programs, including the new “Randi Rhodes Show” on XM Radio, referred incorrectly to Ms. Rhodes’s employment. The new show, syndicated by Nova M Radio, will be on XM’s Air America channel. While that channel broadcasts some programs from Ms. Rhodes’s former employer, the liberal radio network Air America, the XM channel is a separate entity from the Air America network. Ms. Rhodes is not returning to that network.

text: NEW ORLEANS  Like the city it celebrates, the annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival is steeped in local memory.

headline: Where's Schiller?
text: Question: If Ulysses S. Grant is buried in Grant’s Tomb, who is buried in Friedrich Schiller’s tomb? Answer: Not Friedrich Schiller. Two years of DNA research has determined that none of the remains billed as those of the poet and playwright were actually his, The Associated Press reported, citing MDR television. In 1826, 21 years after Schiller died in Weimar, Germany, and was buried in a common grave in Jacobs Cemetery, it was decided that he needed a new resting place, Fürstengruft Cemetery. The mayor, Carl Leberecht Schwabe, a Schiller fan, decided that of the 23 skulls exhumed from the common grave, the biggest must have been Schiller’s. A skeleton believed to be a match was put together with the skull, and everything was buried anew in 1827, to be joined in 1832 by Schiller’s friend Goethe, who was interred alongside him, above. About 60,000 people visit the site annually. Researchers later unearthed two other skulls said to be Schiller’s. But none of them were supported by DNA from the remains of two Schiller sisters and two sons. Hellmut Seemann, president of the Foundation of Weimar Classics, which oversees the Schiller archives and exhibitions, said he believed the remains were probably still in the Jacobs Cemetery.

headline: Begging Encouragement as They Pose and Eat
text: The month of May brings La MaMa Moves!, a festival of dance at three different spaces at La MaMa E.T.C. Eleven programs will feature a spectrum of dance performers, sometimes with four or more well-known dancer-choreographers sharing the same bill. I wish I could catch them all. I wish in particular I could see those artists whose work I have not yet encountered. But I also wish the festival had begun with something less baffling than Ivy Baldwin’s “Could be nice ...”

headline: After Deal Dies, Yahoo Weighs Its Next Move
text: SAN FRANCISCO  How low will Yahoo’s stock go on Monday? And how long will it stay there?

headline: Britain vs. Snoop Dogg: Now the Rematch
text: The British border agency is appealing for a second time to keep the rapper Snoop Dogg, below, out of the country, the BBC reported. The agency maintains that “a material error in law” was made at Snoop Dogg’s hearing in January, when he was cleared to enter Britain by an immigration judge who said he found no evidence that Snoop Dogg was responsible for any public disorder. Last month the agency lost its appeal of that ruling. In announcing its decision to appeal once more, a representative said, “We will continue to oppose the entry to the U.K. of individuals where we believe there may be a risk to the public.” The case began when Snoop Dogg, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was refused a visa for a tour after he and five members of his entourage were arrested during a reported melee at Heathrow Airport in 2006.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Short on Cash, State Hastens Plan for Casino in City
text: For New Yorkers, a casino will soon be a mere subway ride away.

headline: Confusion and Sorrow for Trainer of Filly
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Larry Jones has watched the replay dozens of times. He has examined photographs of Eight Belles, and he still cannot fathom how the filly he trained was at one moment crossing the finish line in second place in the 134th running of the Kentucky Derby, and then in the next, she was gone.

headline: Microsoft’s Failed Yahoo Bid Risks Online Growth
text: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, walked away from a Yahoo deal on Saturday still looking for an answer to his company’s fundamental problem: its time-tested recipe for success isn’t working against Google, the leader in the current wave of Internet computing.

text: PULI, Taiwan  At his hotel here, a short drive from scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan, Chang Tse-yen is already making plans for a possible boom in tourism from mainland China.

text: Dr. Giuseppe Attardi, a molecular biologist whose penetrating studies of mitochondria, the energy-producing bodies in living cells, helped explain how cells grow and deteriorate with age, died on April 5 at his home in Altadena, Calif. He was 84.

text: There is no such thing as a lull for catchers, as proved Sunday when Seattle’s Kenji Johjima took incoming fire off his bare hand and stoically waited for any feeling to return  the history of that position, in one miserable tableau.

text: On the same page in Barbara Walters’s big, bean-spilling memoir there are photographs of Ms. Walters, the undisputed queen of the television interview, and Cha Cha Walters, her dog. One of them looks businesslike. She wears glasses and sits perched at a computer keyboard. The other is perfectly groomed, coiffed and fluffed. She looks ready for her blue ribbon as best in show.

text: Nancy Weiser, a small woman with a very small backpack, addressed the four women standing before her with the kind of grave urgency that coaches rely on when they’re down in the fourth quarter. “I’m going to permanently change your relationship to the food supply,” she told them. “I want you to be here like your life depends on it, because it does.”

headline: A First-Time Winner Flattens a Tough Field
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  During a stroll on a sunny Carolina afternoon, Anthony Kim came out of the woods Sunday. He won his first PGA Tour event, the Wachovia Championship, by five strokes, grabbing victory by the throat, shaking it for 18 holes and never looking back.

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: Listen to almost any politician, President Bush included, and you’ll hear that the fight against global warming cannot be won without cleaner technologies that will ease dependence on fossil fuels. Yeltsin was dedicated late last month in a central spot in Russia’s most illustrious cemetery, a landscape of earnest tributes to generals and composers, mathematicians and diplomats. text: The Icelandic Team Championship took place April 24 to 27. For the first three days 12 teams played a 16-board round robin. Four teams qualified for the final day, which consisted of a second round robin of 16-board matches.

text: On Dec. 11, the Web site for the band Panic at the Disco turned completely white, with no explanation. Before long, curious fans noticed that the source code for the page contained a clue that hinted at the release of the band’s new album, “Pretty. Odd.”

headline: Helping the Unemployed
text: Americans don’t have to wait for the statistics to know these are very hard times. For the fourth month in a row, the economy lost jobs in April. The economists said the contraction was not as bad as expected  20,000 jobs were shed versus an anticipated loss of 75,000. Not as bad as expected is cold comfort.

headline: Clinton Steals One Show, While Obama Endures Another
text: Senator Barack Obama sat hunched on Sunday across the desk from Tim Russert on “Meet The Press” on NBC and wearily endured question after question about his relationship with the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.

headline: Quick Turnaround as Hopes Build for Big Brown
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  His customary bravado nowhere to be found Sunday morning, a subdued Richard Dutrow Jr. looked ahead to the May 17 Preakness Stakes and did not necessarily like what he saw.

headline: Footnotes
text: Amy Winehouse has abandoned work on the theme song for the forthcoming James Bond film, “Quantum of Solace,” The Associated Press reported. Mark Ronson, her producer, said Ms. Winehouse, whose troubles with drugs and law enforcement have been well documented, is “not ready to record any music.” ... Nicole Kidman will star in and produce a film based on the life of Dusty Springfield, the English pop singer who died in 1999; her success masked mental and physical illness and problems with drugs and alcohol, Variety reported. ... The singer-songwriter Tina Turner plans to embark on her first tour in eight years when she performs on Oct. 1 at the Sprint Center in Kansas City, Mo., Reuters reported. ... Filming of “High School Musical 3: Senior Year” has begun in Salt Lake City, The Associated Press reported. The basketball star Troy and his friends Gabriella, Sharpay, Ryan, Chad and Taylor are facing graduation and choices about the future. The film is to open on Oct. 24. ... Lex Luthor is leaving Smallville, which is another way of saying that Michael Rosenbaum, who plays that nemesis of the young Superman on the CW series “Smallville,” is leaving after seven seasons, Reuters reported. He is to be replaced by two new villains. But the producers hinted that Mr. Rosenbaum might appear as a guest during the eighth season.

headline: Mexico Cites Reprisals in Killings of 9 Officers
text: MEXICO CITY  In what appears to be a bloody counteroffensive by drug cartels responding to a government crackdown, nine federal police officers, including the chief of the organized crime division, have been killed in the past three weeks.

headline: Mobile TV Spreading in Europe and to the U.S.
text: BERLIN  Every day in Switzerland, 40,000 people watch a 100-second television news broadcast on their cellphones. In Italy, a million people pay as much as 19 euros each ($29) a month to watch up to a dozen mobile TV channels.

headline: Rule of the Week: A Shot Interrupted
text: Dave and Steve arrive at the famed 17th hole at the T.P.C. at Sawgrass. They bet that the loser of the hole will buy the other player his favorite adult beverage. Dave’s tee shot stops three feet from the hole. While Steve’s tee shot is in flight, Sammy, the resident seagull, lands on the green. Steve’s ball lands on the green and while rolling away from the hole strikes Sammy and is deflected into the hole. Sammy the seagull then walks to Dave’s ball, picks it up and drops it 10 feet from the hole. How do Dave and Steve proceed?

headline: Celtics Finish Off an Upstart With a Game-Long Victory Party
text: BOSTON  Kevin Garnett’s first priority Sunday, after laying waste to the Atlanta Hawks’ self-worth and whipping a packed arena into a deafening frenzy, was to go to sleep. It figured to be a very long nap.

headline: Education Fund for Latin Players Quietly Changes Lives
text: As major league baseball pulses to an ever stronger salsa beat, most fans see only the rising number of Latin Americans among the batting leaders and in All-Star Games. They do not see the other 95 percent  the anonymous Caribbean teenagers who sign professional contracts, spend years languishing in the minor leagues and return to their homelands without an education.

headline: Aflac Shareholders Vote to Back Chief’s Pay
text: Aflac, the big insurer, has become the first American company to give shareholders a say on pay  a vote on top management’s compensation. And in their first advisory vote on Monday, they signaled that the compensation committee is doing a fine job.

headline: Seeing Grit and Ruthlessness in Clinton’s Love of the Fight
text: JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is waving her fists across Indiana, signing autographs on boxing gloves.

headline: Partial Derailment Disrupts Subway
text: Two cars on an N subway train partly derailed in Midtown Manhattan on Sunday afternoon, city and transit officials said. They said that no one was hurt.

headline: Success Breeds Failure
text: Cross your fingers, knock on wood: it’s possible, though by no means certain, that the worst of the financial crisis is over. That’s the good news.

headline: Hezbollah Trains Iraqis in Iran, Officials Say
text: BAGHDAD  Militants from the Lebanese group Hezbollah have been training Iraqi militia fighters at a camp near Tehran, according to American interrogation reports that the United States has supplied to the Iraqi government.

headline: Jets Rookie Is Undeterred by the Crowd at Tight End
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Around a corner and through another doorway, the Jets’ draft choices and undrafted free agents were holed up in the back of the practice facility locker room. The small lockers are squeezed together and miscellaneous gear  gloves, knee braces, helmets  lined the tops. And, for Dustin Keller, there was a container of pretzels.

headline: Steve Jobs Stakes Out the TV Den
text: I don’t own my iPod. It owns me.

headline: Study Finds That Fat Cells Die and Are Replaced
text: Every year, whether you are fat or thin, whether you lose weight or gain, 10 percent of your fat cells die. And every year, those cells that die are replaced with new fat cells, researchers in Sweden reported Sunday.

headline: Iraqi President’s Wife Not Hurt by a Roadside Bomb
text: BAGHDAD  Four marines were killed in Anbar Province by a roadside bomb, and in Baghdad, the Iraqi president’s wife narrowly escaped an attack on her motorcade, officials said Sunday.

headline: A Skeptical Eye on Auction Surcharges
text: A study recently published in the Journal of Consumer Research finds that eBay bidders react in profound ways to a seller’s numerical “reputation” on the site.

headline: Nuns Face the Guillotine, Each on Her Own Terms
text: In the 10 years that Joseph Colaneri has been artistic director of the Mannes Opera at Mannes College the New School for Music, the program has earned a stellar reputation for the quality of its presentations and the excellence of its student singers. On Saturday evening in the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College the company presented Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites” in a production that lived up to the expected high standard. A second performance with a different cast was scheduled for Sunday.

headline: Our School’s Ideals
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Investigates Yonkers Development After Official’s Surprising ‘Yes’ Vote
text: YONKERS  For years, City Councilwoman Sandy Annabi of Yonkers was among the most vigorous critics of an enormous $600 million development proposal that called for 1,000 housing units, shops and a movie multiplex in the cliffs here over Sprain Lake.

headline: Iran Seems to Reject West’s Offer
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s supreme religious leader said Sunday that his nation would not bow to pressure after Western powers announced Friday that they would offer a new package of incentives to coax Iran to give up its nuclear program.

headline: Chinese Officials Meet With Dalai Lama’s Representatives
text: BEIJING  In their first direct talks since the outbreak of violence in Tibet in March, Chinese officials met with representatives of the Dalai Lama on Sunday, although it was unclear whether there was any progress in easing tensions between Beijing and the exiled Tibetan leader.

headline: For Physician Assistant, Empathy Goes Two Ways
text: This is a story about health care that is not universal. There is a name attached: John C. Welton, from the Bronx, father of two and husband to Vivian.

headline: For the Elderly, Being Heard About Life’s End
text: HANOVER, N.H.  Edie Gieg, 85, strides ahead of people half her age and plays a fast-paced game of tennis. But when it comes to health care, she is a champion of “slow medicine,” an approach that encourages less aggressive  and less costly  care at the end of life.

headline: Critics See Symbols of Islam in Flight 93 Memorial Design
text: SOMERSET, Pa.  As envisioned by its designer, the memorial to the victims who died on Sept. 11, 2001, when United Flight 93 crashed into a field near Shanksville, Pa., would follow the topography of the bowl-shaped land, creating a circular pathway ringed by trees, all focused on the “sacred ground” of the crash site near the bottom of the circle.

headline: Tokyo Police Guard Film
text: Tight security was imposed in Tokyo on Saturday when a Chinese director’s documentary about a Japanese shrine to its war dead opened amid threats from nationalists outraged at its content, Agence France-Presse reported. Police patrolled the entrance to the theater and were posted in screening rooms after reports of plans to disrupt the sold-out showings. But Yutaka Okada, president of Argo Pictures, distributor of the documentary, “Yasukuni,” said, “We have been able to screen the film safely and smoothly.” The film, directed by Li Ying, was to have had its premiere last month but was withdrawn after noisy protests. The documentary, recipient of a grant from the Japanese government, examines the controversy surrounding the Yasukuni Shrine, a Shinto shrine in Tokyo that honors 2.5 million war dead, including convicted war criminals from World War II. Critics said it fed anti-Japanese sentiment by, for example, superimposing images of Emperor Hirohito on atrocities by Japanese troops. The film will be shown eight times a day for a week.

headline: Unusual Concert for Saudi Arabia
text: In a groundbreaking concert in Saudi Arabia, a German-based quartet played European classical music in a public setting for a mixed-gender audience, right, The Associated Press reported. Public concerts are virtually unheard of in this strict Muslim kingdom, and the sexes are segregated even in lines at fast-food outlets. The concert  with the Artis Piano Quartet performing works by Mozart, Brahms and Paul Juon  took place in a 500-seat government-run cultural center in Riyadh on Friday night and touched off speculation that Saudi Arabia was seeking greater openness. “The concert is a sign that things are changing rapidly here,” said the German ambassador, Jürgen Krieghoff, whose embassy sponsored the concert as part of the inaugural German Cultural Weeks in Saudi Arabia. “Evidently the government has decided that a minimum of openness in our new world economy and in our information-based world is necessary for us and also for good understanding among cultures.” The quartet’s Japanese pianist, Hiroko Atsumi, said there had been some discussion about whether she should perform in an abaya, the enveloping black cloak women must wear in public. She wore a long green top and black trousers.

headline: In Poll, Obama Survives Furor, but Fall Is the Test
text: WASHINGTON  A majority of American voters say that the furor over the relationship between Senator Barack Obama and his former pastor has not affected their opinion of Mr. Obama, but a substantial number say that it could influence voters this fall should he be the Democratic presidential nominee, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

text: TiVo has made watching commercials unnecessary. Is it now trying to make watching reality shows a thing of the past, too?

headline: Man Is Fatally Shot With His Own Gun in Scuffle, Police Say
text: A man believed to be a burglar who entered a Midtown office building early Sunday was shot and killed with his own gun as he scuffled with the police, the authorities said.

headline: Zigzagging Toward November
text: As the Democratic presidential contest slouches forward, the Republicans are wise to look ahead to 2012 and try to invent a better mousetrap than the jumbled primary system that they find occupying, if not entombing, the Democrats. The G.O.P.’s rules committee has offered a plan that attempts to find a better balance between “retail” politicking in smaller states and the inevitable big-money, heavy media campaigning in larger states.

headline: Immigration Agency’s List of Deaths in Custody
text: The document that follows, “Detainee Deaths 2004-November 2007,” is the government’s fullest account to date of deaths in immigration detention. Compiled by Immigration and Customs Enforcement and obtained by The New York Times under the Freedom of Information Act, it lists the names of 66 people who died, their dates of birth and death, where they were last held, where they died and the cause of death.

text: Democrats may be about to discover whether campaigning can in fact move the Democratic primary campaign.

headline: In Pellicano Case, Lessons in Wiretapping Skills
text: LOS ANGELES  The wiretapping trial of Anthony Pellicano, the accused sleuth to the stars and irrepressible eavesdropper, has offered much fodder for celebrity watchers over its two-month run, including courtroom cameos by the comedians Chris Rock and Garry Shandling.

headline: A Dream Landscape Littered With the Poet-Hero’s Memories
text: When Jerome Robbins returned to ballet in 1969, he seemed determined to prove he was a grand master and no longer the charming laugh-monger of old. Several of the works he choreographed in the following years  “Dances at a Gathering” (1969), “The Goldberg Variations” (1971), “Watermill” (1972), “Dybbuk” (1974)  were surely aimed at the “magnum opus” category.

headline: G.M. Workers Strike Malibu Plant in Kansas
text: DETROIT  General Motors workers who build Chevrolet Malibu, one of G.M.’s most popular and important new vehicles, went on strike Monday at a plant in Kansas after they were unable to reach an agreement on local work rules.

headline: Democrats Call Victory a Sign G.O.P. Tactic Failed
text: WASHINGTON  The Democratic victory in a special House election in Louisiana this weekend was interpreted by leading Democrats on Sunday as a sign that Republicans would fail in their efforts to damage Congressional candidates by tying them to national figures and presidential contenders.

headline: After a Lost Season, Syracuse Returns to Prominence
text: Before this season, a group of Syracuse lacrosse players asked Coach John Desko if they could borrow his old game tapes. The footage from last year, when the Orange went 5-8 and missed the postseason for the first time since 1982, could pass for a horror film.

headline: Pacman Jones Moves Out, and Emmitt Smith Weighs In
text: Now that he has been traded to the Dallas Cowboys, the former Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones has put his house in Franklin, Tenn., on the market. According to this Associated Press report and this story on a Nashville television station’s Web site, the 30-acre property has a 3,000-square-foot home, a two-acre lake stocked with fish, two barns and a garage.

headline: A Lower Profile for Rick Peterson
text: Perhaps you may have noticed that the thoughts, observations and quotations of Rick Peterson, the Mets’ pitching coach, have been appearing less frequently in articles, both in The Times and in other publications. He has always been a reliable source of information – on the art of pitching and in general – but Peterson is the only uniformed member who does not directly grant interviews. All requests must go through Jay Horwitz, the Mets’ PR honcho.

headline: Jazzfest: A Neville Family Homecoming
text: The finale of Jazzfest was piled with symbolism: the return of the Neville Brothers to their old headlining slot and, more important, to New Orleans itself. It was a family of siblings (and two of their sons, Ivan and Ian) reuniting with their family of listeners, fellow New Orleanians and fans.

headline: Jazzfest: The Last Word
text: Something odd happens over a full weekend of Jazzfest. Between performances and parades, and the geography of where stages are situated, it’s virtually impossible not to run into a brass band, Mardi Gras Indians or both. I assume that’s by design; those traditions infuse all sorts of other New Orleans music and they are the main heritage in “Jazz and Heritage.” To see so many groups maintaining their street-level music after Katrina is heartening, and their tunes are incorrigibly upbeat. Yet after a few days the novelty wears off: oh, yeah, here come more Indians. And then Jazzfest is over and I’m headed back to New York, where Indian gangs don’t vow to “set your flag on fire” over a tambourine beat and there’s not a brass-band gig somewhere every night of the week. There’s not even one a month. Like other things that make New Orleans so utterly singular, what’s commonplace within that one city should never be taken for granted.

headline: Rethinking the Oil Curse
text: I’ve been skeptical of some of the alleged evils of petroleum, but I bought into the recently popular idea among development experts that reserves of oil and other natural resources are a curse to many countries. What I saw while reporting in Iraq jibed with academic studies concluding that a wealth of natural resources did a country more harm than good. It was an appealing and clever counterintuitive idea — but perhaps too clever by half.

headline: Cold, Cold Heart
text: One of the great things about this novel is that it matters so little whether or not one recognizes a “parturition theme” near the end of Chapter 8, or cares to examine correspondences between Ruth and Melville’s Ishmael as narrators. Such insights, and the wonderful “allusions” to 19th-century writers provided by Steve, do enhance my enjoyment of the book. But as slight as it is, this book seems inexhaustible, always welcoming further exploration. Robinson is a hospitable writer, even if her work demands an attentiveness that is increasingly hard to come by, not only for the iPod kids but for older adults who are often too harried and distracted to sit and read. Turning off the television can help, but it’s not enough. C.S. Lewis discouraged even the reading of periodicals, as he felt that they had a bad effect on our capacity to pay attention, to take the long view.

headline: Tim (Stuck) On His Mind
text: There are few public affairs programs on television that require guests to be intensively prepared as does “Meet the Press” with Tim Russert on NBC. And it is a regular ritual for campaigns to take their candidates through mock sessions with an imaginary Mr. Russert before an appearance. An hourlong session like the one Senator Barack Obama sat through yesterday can require that much more rehearsal.

headline: A Mariachi Tale

headline: Trapped Sea Lions Shot Dead in Oregon
text: For years, the Bonneville Dam on the Oregon-Washington border has made life all too easy for the sea lions that congregate in the Columbia River just outside of Portland. Fish ladders in the dam create a bottleneck for salmon swimming upriver to spawning grounds, which allows sea lions to easily swoop in and dine on endangered salmon.

headline: How Bill Clinton Got His Groove Back
text: In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes that after a few very bad months, Bill Clinton seems to have adapted to his self-described role as the “designated ambassador to the smaller parts of the country” as he campaigned for his wife in preparation for Tuesday’s votes in Indiana and North Carolina. Go to the column …

headline: Help Us Report on the Cyclone in Myanmar
text: With reports that nearly 4,000 people may have died in Myanmar as a result of the cyclone that struck the country over the weekend, NYTimes.com is asking readers inside Myanmar to help us report on the disaster by sending in photographs, video or written accounts of the storm and its aftermath.

headline: Amsterdam, Part One: I’ll Have These 25 Dishes, Thanks
text: Dan Saltzstein is Arts editor at the The Times on the Web, and one of the driving forces behind the launch of Bitten. He’s also an avid traveler, eater and cook. This is the first of a three-part mini-series about his recent trip to Amsterdam. –MB

headline: Sprint and T-Mobile? Hold the Phone
text: Sprint Nextel‘s stock rose more than 6 percent Monday morning following reports that Deutsche Telekom was considering buying it — but investors might want to be wary.

headline: ‘CSI,’ ‘Two and a Half Men’ Swap Writers
text: USA Today: The writers of the CBS series “CSI” and “Two and a Half Men,” “which have little in common except high ratings, have written an episode of each other’s show. The results are on display tonight on ‘Men’ (9 ET/PT) and Thursday on ‘CSI’ (9 ET/PT).”

headline: Aflac Chief Discusses "Say on Pay"
text: CNBC interviews Daniel P. Amos, chief executive of Aflac, the first company to give shareholders a vote on top executives' compensation.

headline: Some Roses for Big Brown
text: “A superstar, a horse for the ages, a Triple Crown immortal — or a one-day Kentucky Derby flash? That’s the question exciting the racing world in the aftermath of Big Brown’s stunningly easy Derby victory, accomplished with such panache that everyone is asking: Is this the horse who, finally, is going to end the 30-year Triple Crown drought?”

headline: Buying Art on Credit
text: Art is the ultimate income-free asset. If you buy it as an investment, there is a possibility of capital gains, but no income along the way. You don’t rent out Picassos. (Come to think of it, maybe there could be a market there. Impress people with your Renoir, even if you only have it for the weekend of your birthday party.)

headline: Parallel Stories During NBC’s Derby Coverage
text: In Monday’s Times, Richard Sandomir writes: “Eight Belles’s death shortly after finishing second in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday raised anew a major question about how to cover parallel stories of elation and heartbreak: which one takes precedence when an athlete, human or equine, is seriously injured?”

headline: Tools Tutorial | Fiesta-Ready Finds from Mexico
text: Clockwise, from left: A tortilla press; a Oaxacan rug; a Bebol cup set; a gourd bowl from the town of Olinalà; tortilla baskets from Chilapa.

We are no longer taking questions on this feature.
