headline: Former President Clinton on the Trail
text: After a very bad few months, Bill Clinton seems to have gotten his groove back as he barrels his way through small towns.

headline: ‘Fancy’ Egg Salad a Mother Would Love
text: You can see why I love David Latt’s cooking; his mother and mine attended the same non-trendy cooking school. (For more of his recipes, see www.menwholiketocook.com.) One note: David cooks his eggs on a low boil for 30 minutes and finds they come out perfectly done, with the yolk flaky. –MB

headline: Revisiting Barbara Walters’s Television Tenure
text: In Monday’s Times, Janet Maslin reviews Barbara Walters’ new autobiography “Audition” and Bill Carter interviews the longtime television figure. In an interview with Mr. Carter, she discussed her move from NBC’s “Today” show to ABC’s evening newscast in the mid 1970s:

headline: Maybe This ‘Sweeps’ Month Should Go Under the Rug
text: Five million fewer viewers are watching “sweeps” programming on the big four broadcast networks this year than last year, according to Nielsen Media Research. Was the writers’ strike to blame?

headline: Clinton’s Closing Pitches in N.Carolina and Indiana
text: In her last TV pitches to Indiana and North Carolina voters, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is playing up her image as a friend to the middle class and the candidate who is most in touch with voters’ concerns.

headline: Ferry Service, for $6, From Rockaway
text: A subsidized ferry route from Rockaway to Lower Manhattan, via Brooklyn, will begin next week as part of the city’s plan to expand water service, the mayor and City Council announced this afternoon.While tourist service has been profitable, the companies have long struggled with the economics of commuter ferry service, especially with the escalating cost of fuel. Ferry companies have long complained that despite the number of the city’s waterways, intracity water services — with the exception of the Staten Island ferry — gets nowhere near the level of city subsidies that the subway and bus systems receive.

headline: Yargh! Cuomo Takes Aim at Movie Pirates
text: New York likes to bill itself as the entertainment capital of the world. But it apparently has a more nefarious distinction among people in the film industry: the piracy capital of the world. To fight the flourishing underground movie-counterfeiting operations in the state, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has proposed stiffening the penalties for illegally recording a movie. He is also adding a special assistant attorney general to coordinate antipiracy law enforcement. The proposal would also broaden the current law to include recordings of concerts and Broadway shows. (See Mr. Cuomo’s news release.)

headline: Child Seat Recall Raises More Questions
text: Given a recent recall of one million Evenflo Discovery child restraints because of “catastrophic” failure in a crash test, I find it puzzling that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration doesn’t want to reopen its 2004 investigation into an earlier Discovery model that may have a similar failing.

headline: Risk and the Running Mate
text: In his column today in The New York Times, William Kristol (with the assistance of “no fewer than four McCain staffers”) floats the name of Bobby Jindal, the 36-year-old governor of Louisiana, as a promising running mate for John McCain.

headline: A Second Leader for Second Life
text: Second Life? Wasn’t that last year’s fad?

headline: Measuring the Club-Deal Discount
text: When private equity firms go clubbing, it could be bad for investors’ financial health. At least, that is the implication of a recent study on club deals, or those in which two or more private equity firms join together to sponsor a leveraged buyout.

headline: ‘The Quality of the Bile’
text: Last week, as part of the fourth annual PEN World Voices festival, a panel discussion on the great Austrian writer Thomas Bernhard (1931-89) was held at the Austrian Cultural Forum in New York. It was a packed house, if by “house” we mean a room the size of a typical Manhattan apartment, and everyone there seemed to agree that Bernhard himself would have found such a gathering odious.

headline: How to Buy an Avocado
text: The other day I was talking to Nick Fox, the deputy editor of the Dining section, about avocados. (We have a lovely little avocado soup on the Minimalist schedule for a few weeks down the road.) And I said, “The odd thing is, whenever I buy semi-ripe or ripe avocados, they’re awful — banged up and overripe, and often mealy.” His response, which jived with my experience but I have never been quite savvy enough to verbalize, was simply “You should buy them rock hard.”

headline: ‘Ugly Betty’s’ New Guest Star: Lindsay Lohan
text: The Associated Press: “Lindsay Lohan will make a guest appearance on the season finale of ABC’s ‘Ugly Betty.'” She is also expected to appear in five episodes of the show next season.

headline: What Don’t They Make in China?
text: China has been recently been the subject of withering international media coverage for its repression of demonstrators in Tibet and their allies who want more self-determination for the Himalayan province.

headline: Outside the Lines
text: ESPN’s “Outside the Lines: First Report,” which aired today at 3:30 p.m. Eastern and will be repeated at 5 p.m. Eastern on ESPN2, is taking a look at the question: Why are horses more fragile than ever before?

headline: A Lesson on How to Say Goodbye
text: By now, many people have heard about Randy Pausch, the Carnegie Mellon professor dying of pancreatic cancer who became a media sensation after delivering a final lecture about how to achieve childhood dreams.

text: 1800 Essential with limited editionartwork by Jorge Alderete.

headline: 8 Cramped (Not So Much Angry) Jurors
text: It took the government 43 years to call me for jury duty (25 if you subtract the years before I became eligible at 18). To my surprise, I was seated on a civil case last week, despite my suspicion that lawyers prefer not to pick journalists to serve on juries. So I spent many hours since Thursday afternoon cooped up in a small jury room at the Manhattan Supreme Court with five other jurors and two alternates.

headline: Obama Strikes Back With Negative Advertisement
text: As the campaigning for the Indiana and North Carolina primaries comes to a close, the Democratic presidential candidates are letting loose on one another over the TV airwaves.

headline: Regulated Rents Could Rise 3.5 to 9.5 Percent
text: Updated, 10:45 p.m. | At the first of its meetings on rent increases for the city’s one million rent-stabilized apartments, the city’s Rent Guidelines Board recommended increases ranging from 3.5 percent to 7 percent for one-year leases and 5.5 percent to 9.5 percent for two-year leases.The board’s actions do not cover rent-controlled apartments, a separate and shrinking category of low-cost housing, or the increasing number of luxury apartments not subject to rent regulations, although the board’s ranges can be influential in the market. (For details, see the Times Topics page on rent stabilization and rent control.)

headline: We’ll Miss Him When He Gets Here
Once Again, the ‘Housewives’ Pretty Up ABC’s Ratings
text: “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday, with 16.6 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show delivered the night’s largest audience overall and the top ratings among adults 18 to 49 by a wide margin.

text: Today’s press release from NBC had a headline that made us look twice: “NBC Universal Announces Exclusive Deal With Magical Elves.”

headline: Return of the Cellphones-in-Class Question
text: Today’s mailbag brings a question that was on every teacher’s lips a few years ago. I haven’t heard much talk about it recently. Is that because teachers have solved this problem on their own? If so, I’d like to hear your suggestions…

headline: A Baseball Writer on the Run
text: If you write about baseball for a living, you had better love the sport. And I do. But I also love some moments of solitude where I don’t have to worry about every pitch and every managerial decision. I find those peaceful moments when I run. Just me, my iPod and whatever course is in front of me.

headline: In Summation, Two Portrayals of Uma Thurman’s Pursuer

headline: Thousands Gather to Make Their Own Fair
text: I knew we that we were in for something unusual when the traffic on Highway 101 came to a dead standstill a mile before the turnoff to the San Mateo County Fairgrounds. Last weekend was the third annual Maker Faire, an eclectic gathering spun off from Make magazine, the voice of the so-called Do It Yourself or DIY movement.

headline: On the Street: Shorts
text: This afternoon, following my wig wash for the Costume Institute party, I saw a twentysomething woman on Fifth Avenue wearing a black knit top and boxy red hotpants, perhaps in a cotton sateen. Her look was not entirely successful (the conventional black pumps?), but an hour earlier, near Times Square, I happened to see a young Asian woman wearing a similar pair of hotpants in a stiff white fabric (with platforms). The effect was more flattering on her. I was intrigued on this warmish spring day: Will we see more of the look on the streets?

headline: Tropicana Files for Bankruptcy
text: Tropicana Entertainment, the privately held casino operator, filed for bankruptcy protection Monday night, becoming the largest company to do so as the twin problems of a slumping economy and seized-up credit markets spread across the market.

headline: Is Obama misrepresenting what I said?
text: I don’t have a link to the ad itself, but apparently there’s an Obama ad citing something I said about McCain’s gas tax holiday as a way to attack Hillary Clinton.

headline: The Winner (at Least on TV)

headline: The Magic of Flight Insurance
text: Thanks to Orit Tykocinski, one of the psychologists quoted in my Findings column on tempting fate, I’m starting to understand why American Express is trying to sell me flight insurance by advertising it along with a photograph of an apparently blissful couple on a faraway beach.

headline: Live From the Met!
text: OMG, have suddenly seen just about everybody. Tom Ford, Richard Buckley, Valentino, Daphne Guinness (in a twilight sequined L’Wren Scott), Ed Burns talking with Jerry Seinfeld, lots of models. A pretty glamorous, not sci-fi, night.

headline: Late New York socialite’s legendary duplex hits the market

headline: Another Season Ends Early for Rangers
text: For the Rangers, it came far too soon. They entered the season with high hopes, but they ended up just where they did last year, knocked out in the second round.

headline: A Lighter Melky Leads the Way
text: It was so easy to frame the Yankees’ winter around Phil Hughes and Johan Santana. They kept Hughes instead of trading for Santana – that’s where the narrative often ends.

headline: Jeanine Pirro’s Next Act: TV Judge
text: “A former district attorney is parlaying her experience as a legal commentator on television into becoming a judge on a TV show,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Statement From Eight Belles’s Jockey
text: Gabriel Saez, a 20-year-old Panamanian jockey, is just starting his career and had a weekend no one will soon forget. He won the Kentucky Oaks aboard the filly Proud Spell for the trainer Larry Jones, and then was atop the filly Eight Belles — also a Jones trainee — when she finished second in the Derby, and then was fatally injured on the gallop out.

headline: With Indiana Polls Closing, Heavy Turnout
text: Voters in North Carolina and Indiana turned out in droves on Tuesday to vote on a potentially decisive day in the Democratic primary fight, as Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton made a last-minute round of pitches in the delegate-rich states.

headline: Random House Chief to Step Down, Executives Say
text: FRANKFURT  Peter W. Olson, the chief executive of Random House and one of the most powerful figures in American book publishing, will step down in the next few weeks, according to two executives at Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate that owns the division.

headline: His Average Down, Canó Tries to Keep His Chin Up
text: The Yankees were rolling in the bottom of the third inning Sunday. It was already their biggest inning of the season, with five runs across, and Melky Cabrera had just homered into the right-field seats. The bases were empty for Robinson Canó, and the count quickly fell to 0-2.

headline: I’m Not Lying, I’m Telling a Future Truth. Really.
text: Some tales are so tall that they trip over their own improbable feats, narrative cracks and melodrama. That one-on-one playground victory over Kobe Bryant back in the day; the 34 hours in labor without painkillers; the former girlfriend or boyfriend who spoke eight languages and was a secret agent besides.

headline: Home Remedies (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Data Shows Increase in Street Stops
text: Despite criticism about aggressive policing, New York City police officers stopped more people on the streets during the first three months of 2008 than during any quarter in the six years the Police Department has reported the data.

headline: 'Runway' Producers Run Away
text: NBC Universal has signed Magical Elves, the producers of “Project Runway,” to an exclusive production deal, one month after the Weinstein Company, the show’s distributor, said it was moving “Runway” from Bravo, an NBC subsidiary, to another cable channel, Lifetime. (NBC sued the Weinstein Company after it announced the move to Lifetime.) That means Lifetime and the Weinstein Company now have a show but not a producing team. The “first look deal” means that Magical Elves’ Dan Cutforth and Jane Lipsitz, who produce “Top Chef” as well as “Runway,” consistently one of the most popular programs on cable, will give NBC Universal the first opportunity to distribute projects they develop. The duo are also creating a new dance competition for Bravo and will look to produce other series for NBC’s broadcast, cable and digital properties.

headline: Death by Detention
text: A chilling article by Nina Bernstein in The Times on Monday recounted the secrecy, neglect and lack of oversight that are a few of the shameful symptoms of the booming sector of the nation’s prison industry  the detention of undocumented foreigners.

headline: Combat and Composure
text: Life is short, but campaigns are long. And during the course of them, each candidate will have impressive and pathetic moments. But underlying the highs and lows, there are the fundamentals. The fundamentals of the Obama-Clinton race were on display Sunday morning.

headline: Bomb Kills at Least 5 Police Officers in Chechnya
text: MOSCOW  At least five police officers were killed in Chechnya on Sunday when a makeshift remote-controlled bomb exploded in Grozny, the capital, the authorities and local news services said. A separate ambush Sunday killed a police officer riding in a convoy in the mountainous district of Vedeno.

headline: Panel Subpoenas Close Cheney Aide
text: WASHINGTON  A House subcommittee investigating the Bush administration’s approval for harsh interrogation methods voted on Tuesday to issue a subpoena to David S. Addington, chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and a major proponent of the methods, which some legal experts have condemned as illegal torture.

headline: Filly’s Owner Stands by His Decision
text: Still saddened by the death of his filly Eight Belles, the owner Rick Porter said Monday that he had no regrets about running her in the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Ted Key, 95, Creator of ‘Hazel’ Cartoon, Is Dead
text: Ted Key, whose cartoon creation, an independent-minded and impertinent maid who came to be known as Hazel, a name that became synonymous with live-in housekeepers as American suburbs flowered after World War II, died on Saturday at his home in Tredyffrin Township, near Philadelphia. He was 95.

headline: Patterns: Serious Message in a Seductive Voice
text: A come-hither sound in a woman’s voice may carry a message about her readiness to conceive.

headline: In Dublin, Seeing Irish Dance of a Different Sort
text: DUBLIN — As the Dublin Dance Festival came to an end last weekend after 16 days packed with local and international work, two audience members weighed in. “It’s O.K., this stuff — different,” one said, after a performance featuring Irish choreographers.

headline: With Right Props and Stops, Clinton Transforms Into Working-Class Hero
text: All over North Carolina and Indiana, crowds of teachers and truckers, salespeople and small business owners, have been hailing Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as one of their own.

headline: Soccer Thaws British-Russian Relations, at Least Temporarily
text: MOSCOW  As if Russia and Britain have not had enough to wrangle over  what with the spy scandals, accusations of political assassination and even a crackdown on English language lessons in Russia  now comes a new challenge: nearly 50,000 British soccer fans.

headline: New Titans of Las Vegas Reinvent Old Formula
text: LAS VEGAS  A few Fridays ago, George Maloof Jr. was driving out of town when he stopped to look back down at the mammoth bowl of glittering lights.

headline: Reports Find Racial Gap in Drug Arrests
text: More than two decades after President Ronald Reagan escalated the war on drugs, arrests for drug sales or, more often, drug possession are still rising. And despite public debate and limited efforts to reduce them, large disparities persist in the rate at which blacks and whites are arrested and imprisoned for drug offenses, even though the two races use illegal drugs at roughly equal rates.

headline: Attack and Counterattack
text: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York on Monday engaged in a rapid-fire exchange of confrontational advertisements on television stations in Indiana and North Carolina. Here are two from the barrage.

headline: Dozens of Arrests in University Drug Sting
text: SAN DIEGO  A drug ring operating out of San Diego State University was broken up today after a five-month sting operation, resulting in the arrests of nearly 100 people, many of them college students accused of selling drugs to fellow classmates, the Drug Enforcement Administration said.

headline: In a Faded City, Plans to Build a Hotel Build Hope
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  The old Plaza Hotel downtown is a tomb, sealed shut for more than 20 years now, its windows shattered and its green marquee worn and stripped of letters.

headline: Microsoft to Put Voice-Activation Software in Hyundais
text: Microsoft is expected to announce Tuesday in Seoul, South Korea, that it will develop a version of its Microsoft Auto software for the Hyundai Kia Automotive Group, the world’s fifth-largest automaker.

headline: Another Horse-Racing Horror
text: There is no reason why a race of one-and-a-quarter miles should be a death sentence for a horse, as it was on Saturday for the 3-year-old filly, Eight Belles. She was euthanized after breaking both front ankles immediately after coming in second in the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Georgia, NATO and Mr. Medvedev
text: Russia is playing a game of cat-and-mouse with neighboring Georgia that, if everyone is not a lot more careful, could quickly turn deadly.

headline: Stalker or Harmless Eccentric? Jury Deliberates on Fan’s Uma Thurman Obsession
text: To the defense, the man accused of stalking the actress Uma Thurman is a social misfit with a strange sense of humor who is being prosecuted because he had the ill fortune to become fixated on a celebrity.

headline: Doubts Raised on Big Backers of Mortgages
text: As home prices continue their free fall and banks shy away from lending, Washington officials have increasingly relied on two giant mortgage companies  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac  to keep the housing market afloat.

headline: Bird-Babble to Song Takes Surprising Route
text: Songbirds have long been studied for insight into how the brain learns motor tasks  in a bird’s case, singing its characteristic song. Juvenile birds babble in screechy random bursts before they eventually develop a tonally and rhythmically precise song.

headline: Tagged as Elitist, Obama Shifts Campaign From High-Flown to Folksy
text: EVANSVILLE, Ind.  With sleeves rolled up and folksy on his mind, Barack Obama stepped into the Evansville Labor Temple  a highbrow name for a barlike haunt where the walls are adorned with photos of Nascar drivers, basketball schedules and a poster celebrating the 75th anniversary of the end of Prohibition. Mr. Obama slapped backs and ambled over to a mountainous breakfast buffet long on grease.

headline: Stars and Superheroes Sparkle at Museum Gala
text: One could probably read as many metaphors about the transformative power of fashion in the silver-sequined, elaborately padded Chanel gown that Anna Wintour wore to the Costume Institute gala on Monday night as one could in Superman’s cape, which happened to be hanging in a gallery down the hall.

headline: Teamsters Union Defends Its Endorsement of Obama
text: The Teamsters union vigorously denied on Monday that its decision to endorse Senator Barack Obama in the presidential race was in any way tied to Mr. Obama’s statement that federal supervision of the union had run its course.

headline: In Democracy Kuwait Trusts, but Not Much
text: KUWAIT  In a vast, high-ceilinged tent, Ali al-Rashed sounded an anguished note as he delivered the first speech of his campaign for Parliament.

headline: What Do We Want in a Leader?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Looking for a Train Bound for Oblivion
text: Theater pieces billed as multimedia often turn out to be regular plays with a couple of video projections tossed in. The Triple Shadow company’s “Alice: End of Daze,” which takes its inspiration from Lewis Carroll’s “Through the Looking Glass,” is a true and often graceful blend of forms.

headline: ‘Housewives’ Delivers for ABC
text: “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday, as 16.6 million viewers tuned in to the 9 p.m. drama, Nielsen reported. The show delivered the night’s largest audience over all and the top ratings among adults 18 to 49, by a wide margin. ABC led the night in that demographic during every hour of prime time, starting with the 400th episode of “America’s Funniest Home Videos” at 7 (7.3 million) and “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (11.5 million). In total viewers, however, those two shows trailed their time slot competitors on CBS, “60 Minutes” at 7 (10.5 million) and “Cold Case” at 8 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers, falling behind from 9 to 11 with two hours of “Dexter” (6.4 million). ABC’s “Brothers & Sisters” remained dominant at 10 (10.8 million), ahead of “Dexter” and a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (6.3 million). Fox and NBC were third and fourth over all, although Fox finished second among the 18-to-49 set, ahead of CBS, thanks to the strength of its comedy lineup among younger viewers.

headline: This One’s on Trent Reznor
text: In an unusual nod to the popularity of free music online, the rock act Nine Inch Nails is offering its new studio album, “The Slip,” through its Web site, nin.com, for nothing. In a post on the site, the band’s leader, Trent Reznor, said, “Thank you for your continued and loyal support over the years  this one’s on me.” The album, which became available for download early Monday morning, seems to be the first time a superstar act has distributed an entire album free, without an option for fans to pay. Two months ago the band issued the instrumental album “Ghosts I-IV,” allowing fans to obtain a portion of it free or the entire recording for $5. Before that the British rock act Radiohead offered its 2007 album, “In Rainbows,” online with a tip-jar-style setup in which buyers could name their price, including nothing. “The Slip” could serve as a test of how the easy availability of free music online affects later CD sales and other money-making opportunities. “The Slip” will not be sold on CD or vinyl until at least July. But the free digital version could stoke interest for Nine Inch Nails’ recently announced concert tour. Not everyone seems convinced that such giveaways will be more than a promotional gimmick. But Jim Guerinot, the talent manager who represents Nine Inch Nails  which is now without a record contract and controls its own recordings  said: “Free exists whether you want to acknowledge it or not. Let’s acknowledge that, use it and do something with it.”

headline: Lots of Animals Learn, but Smarter Isn’t Better
text: “Why are humans so smart?” is a question that fascinates scientists. Tadeusz Kawecki, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Fribourg, likes to turn around the question.

headline: Board’s Proposal for Rent Increases Disappoints Landlords and Tenants Alike
text: The board that regulates rents for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments proposed a tentative range of increases Monday night that could lead to larger increases than last year’s.

headline: Democrats Battle Over Gas Tax and Iran
text: GREENVILLE, N.C.  Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton bickered over the airwaves on gasoline taxes, foreign policy and the state of the race for the Democratic nomination Monday morning as they began their final furious day of campaigning before the North Carolina and Indiana primaries set for Tuesday.

headline: Pakistan: Elections Postponed
text: Elections to fill vacant legislative seats will be delayed by two months, to Aug. 18 from June 18, the Election Commission announced. Election officials said the postponement was necessary because of security concerns in North-West Frontier Province and the presentation of the federal budget in June. Members of the governing coalition of political parties, who were harshly critical of the decision, vowed to challenge it in the Supreme Court. Siddiqul Farooq of the Pakistan Muslim League-N, part of the coalition, called the delay a conspiracy by President Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Run a Red Light, It Goes on the Tab
text: WHEN I got around to reading the fine print on my most recent car rental contract, I saw that I had given my rental company the right to plead guilty to any traffic ticket I might receive, and to bill me for the cost later  without my having any say in the matter.

headline: Fatal Accidents Erode Perk of Off-Campus Lunches
text: SMITHTOWN, N.Y.  The students used to overflow the wooden booths and green tables at Don Jono’s Pizzeria, racing through pepperoni slices and large sodas before driving the quarter-mile back to Smithtown High School West in time for their next class.

headline: China: Shanghai Bus Fire Kills 3
text: Three people were killed and 12 injured when a fire broke out on a municipal bus during morning rush hour in Shanghai. The bus exploded after catching fire. Police officials said the fire was under investigation.

headline: Undefeated in the Ring, a Boxer Shifts to Politics
text: BUFFALO  The punch came late in the ninth round, crashing into the back of the boxer’s head like a snap of thunder. Dazed, he crumbled to a knee. Twice more he would hit the canvas.

headline: Ending Housing Disparities
text: To the Editor:

headline: 50 Cent Show Disrupted in Angola
text: Chaos erupted at a performance by 50 Cent in Angola last week after a man jumped onstage and snatched 50 Cent’s neck chain. The scene, captured on video and circulated on YouTube, above, shows a man rushing 50 Cent, interrupting his performance and quickly dashing off. A spokeswoman for 50 Cent at Interscope Records, the label that distributes his music, said the interloper had been prevented from leaving, and that 50 Cent’s chain had been recovered. In the video the scuffle appears to have set off a scramble of fans. It was not clear if anyone was hurt.

headline: Stuck Between Capitalist Comfort and Castro’s Communism
text: Carmen, the former seamstress at the center of Rogelio Martinez’s interesting but overstuffed new play, “All Eyes and Ears,” seems to be playing at revolution.

headline: Baltic Pipeline Stalls 3 Years After Deal
text: BERLIN  A pipeline that Russia and Germany want to build under the Baltic Sea is facing so much opposition and scrutiny that the pipeline company, Nord Stream, has yet to obtain a single construction permit from any of the countries surrounding the sea, according to government officials.

headline: New Singapore Service
text: NEW SINGAPORE SERVICE Singapore Airlines is starting a new all-business-class service between Newark and Singapore on May 15, using Airbus A340-500 ultra-long-haul airliners configured with 100 flat-bed business-class seats. James Boyd, a Singapore Airlines spokesman, said demand for all-business-class service on the 18 ½-hour nonstop flight to Singapore has been “very strong.” Singapore Airlines also plans to begin all-business-class service between Los Angeles and Singapore in September, making it the first airline to offer this service across the Pacific, he said. The airline is converting cabins on five of its A340-500s  which it normally flies configured with 181 seats in two classes  for use in the new service.

headline: Iran Halts Talks With U.S. on Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  As American strikes on Shiite fighters in Baghdad have widened, Iran has suspended talks with the United States on Iraqi security, with the Iranian Foreign Ministry on Monday citing the continued offensive as the reason.

headline: Blood Pressure Is Most Lethal in Poor and Middle-Income Countries
text: Defying popular wisdom about wealthy countries and coronary disease, a new study has found that about 80 percent of the world’s deaths from high blood pressure occur in poor and middle-income countries.

headline: Redefining Disease, Genes and All
text: Duchenne muscular dystrophy may not seem to have much in common with heart attacks. One is a rare inherited disease that primarily strikes boys. The other is a common cause of death in both men and women. To Atul J. Butte, they are surprisingly similar.

headline: Mildred Loving, Who Battled Ban on Mixed-Race Marriage, Dies at 68
text: Mildred Loving, a black woman whose anger over being banished from Virginia for marrying a white man led to a landmark Supreme Court ruling overturning state miscegenation laws, died on May 2 at her home in Central Point, Va. She was 68.

headline: Moving Out of the Ivy Halls to Perform at Carnegie
text: “Yale at Carnegie” offered different come-ons to different constituencies on Sunday night. The concert, the fifth in a series bringing the university’s school of music to Carnegie Hall, appealed first to the curious. Prokofiev’s B flat Piano Concerto for the left hand is not exactly a repertory item, and Boris Berman was there to play the solos, joined by the Philharmonia Orchestra of Yale, led by Shinik Hahm.

headline: Food Emergency
text: As soaring food prices threaten to unleash widespread hunger across Africa and other poor countries, President Bush is right to press Congress for more food assistance. He is also right to insist that some of that aid be given in cash to purchase food from local farmers. Unfortunately, the American farm lobby, which supports food aid as long as it gets the profit, is fighting any change to the system.

headline: ‘The Post-American World’
text: The Rise of the Rest

headline: In Politics Today, Bribery Just Seems So Old-School
text: Crime in New York, as everyone knows, is way down from where it was years ago. Thank goodness, we have the political class to take up the slack.

headline: Region Poses Challenge for Aid Delivery
text: The area worst affected by the cyclone that struck Myanmar on Saturday is a vast and populous delta crisscrossed by canals and inlets, qualities that are likely to make the damage extensive and delivering aid extraordinarily difficult.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the country’s last maker of washboards misstated the company’s name. As the article correctly reported, it is the Columbus Washboard Company, not Columbia.

headline: Appeasing the Gods, With Insurance
text: Suppose you’re preparing to travel by air. Which of these precautions do you think is most likely to prevent your plane from crashing?

headline: Finding Inner Strength
text: SUMNER, Wash.  Melanie Roach is a former gymnast who owns a gymnastics facility. Her husband is a state legislator. At 33, she is the mother of three young children, including 5-year-old Drew, who is autistic. And she can lift 238 pounds over her head.

headline: At Every Level, Appreciating a Veteran Voice
text: Baseball players everywhere should have given their caps a heartfelt tip over the weekend when they learned that Julio Franco had stepped to the plate for the last time.

headline: New Ferry Service Will Begin Next Week
text: A subsidized ferry route between southern Queens and Lower Manhattan, via Brooklyn, will begin next week to give commuters another option, the mayor and the City Council announced on Monday.

headline: Tough Love
text: In the days before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here are their final dispatches.

headline: Family Science Project Yields Surprising Data About a Siberian Lake
text: In 1945, when Stalin ruled the Soviet Union, Mikhail M. Kozhov began keeping track of what was happening under the surface of Lake Baikal, the ancient Siberian lake that is the deepest and largest body of fresh water on earth.

headline: ’70s Quartet Reunites to Celebrate Messiaen
text: It may not have generated pop-culture buzz the way the reunion of the Police did last year. But Tashi, the contemporary-music quartet, which during the mid-1970s was classical music’s answer to a cutting-edge rock band, played Town Hall on Sunday afternoon. The musicians are on their first tour together in 30 years.

headline: The Virtue of Term Limits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: The Arts

headline: It’s Florida. It’s Hiaasen. It’s Golf?
text: VERO BEACH, Fla.  Quail Valley, the Florida golf club where Carl Hiaasen plays, looks like the kind of place where some of the creeps who populate his novels  the environmental despoilers, glad-handing lobbyists and politicians on the take  might belong.

headline: Body Is Found in S.U.V.
text: City sanitation agents made a gruesome discovery on Monday morning while issuing summonses in Queens. As they approached a sport-utility vehicle, they saw a human foot protruding from a black plastic bag in the back seat.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear ‘Enigma’ (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Challenge for the U.S.: Sun Rising on the East
text: What a difference five years  and one war  make!

headline: Google Ends Microsoft’s Yahoo Search
text: Microsoft and Yahoo were pushed to the brink of a multibillion-dollar marriage and then to a sudden breakup this weekend by the same player.

headline: The Growing Wave of Teenage Self-Injury
text: “I feel relieved and less anxious after I cut. The emotional pain slowly slips away into the physical pain.”

headline: August Said to Be Target for New iPhone in Europe
text: BERLIN  Apple plans to begin selling the long-awaited, faster 3G version of its best-selling iPhone by the August summer holidays in some European countries, a person close to the situation said, as part of an expanded introduction of the device to 10 countries that was announced Tuesday.

headline: Nine Inch Nails Album Is Free Online
text: In an unusual nod to the popularity of free music online, the rock act Nine Inch Nails is offering its new album, “The Slip,” through its Web site  for nothing.

headline: Perceptions: Whom to Believe? Children Find Out Early
text: Beware a puppet who tells you that a ball is a book, or that you tie your shoe with a spoon. That, at any rate, is the message of a study that looked at how 3- and 4-year-olds evaluate the trustworthiness of others.

headline: New DVDs: ‘La Roue’
text: LA ROUE

headline: For Primaries in 2 States, a Variety of Scenarios
text: It’s almost over.Well, not quite. But the Democratic presidential primaries taking place on Tuesday in North Carolina and Indiana have more delegates up for grabs than any of the remaining contests. For political, demographic and mathematical reasons, those states have the potential to reshape the competition between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.

headline: Corrections
text: Schedule information on Friday with an art review about “Action/Abstraction: Pollock, De Kooning and American Art, 1940-1976,” at the Jewish Museum, misstated the telephone number for information. It is (212) 423-3200.

headline: D’Antoni May Be in Running for  Knicks' Job
text: The innovative coach Mike D’Antoni and the Phoenix Suns appear to be moving toward a swift divorce, and it could be only a matter of days before he lands in New York or Chicago.

headline: After Repairs to Building, Artists Return to Their Lofts
text: More than 100 artists have begun to return to their loft spaces in a building in Brooklyn, about three months after the Fire Department cited their landlord for a flurry of code violations and forced the residents out.

headline: The Claim: Running Outdoors Burns More Calories
text: THE FACTS

headline: Economic Troubles Affect the Vegas Strip
text: LAS VEGAS  For decades, this gambling center seemed nearly immune to the economic swings of the rest of the country. But these days, the city built on excess is seeing a troubling sign: moderation.

headline: Record Price for Monet at Auction
text: An 1873 canvas by Monet of a riverbank landscape with two trains atop a railway bridge sold for $41.4 million Tuesday night at Christie’s. It was a record price for the artist.

headline: Celtics Focus on James After First-Round Test
text: WALTHAM, Mass.  On a pleasant Monday afternoon, in the calm between playoff series, Boston exhaled and tried to reassure itself. The surprisingly pesky Atlanta Hawks had been vanquished. The battle-tested Cleveland Cavaliers had not yet arrived. There were precious few hours to consider where the Celtics stood.

headline: Teamsters Defend Endorsement of Obama
text: The Teamsters union vigorously denied on Monday that its decision to endorse Senator Barack Obama in the presidential race was in any way tied to Mr. Obama’s statement that federal supervision of the union had run its course.

headline: Marvel Strikes While 'Iron' Is Hot
text: Ant-Man? As a summer box office titan? With “Iron Man” proving that even a B-list superhero can sizzle at the multiplex, Marvel Studios on Monday placed big-screen bets on three of his fellows. “Thor,” the story of a partly disabled medical student whose alter ego is the Norse god of thunder and lightning, is scheduled for a June 2010 release. A tentatively titled “The First Avenger: Captain America” will follow, in May 2011. (Captain America, left.) And then there’s “Ant-Man,” about a scientist who can control insects. It has a writer and director but no release date. Along the way, Marvel will serve up “Iron Man 2” in April 2010 and “The Avengers,” a team that includes Iron Man and the Incredible Hulk, in July 2011. Marvel used to license its characters (Spider-Man, the X-Men) to other studios but began making its own pictures to retain the bulk of the profits. “Iron Man,” the studio’s first solo effort, sold more than $100 million in tickets over the weekend.

headline: In One Flaw, Questions on Validity of 46 Judges
text: Law professors are sometimes influential, but in a general way. Their insights can help shape the law, over time and at the margins.

headline: Illinois: No Defense Witnesses for Rezko
text: Both the prosecution and the defense rested in the trial of Antoin Rezko, a businessman and former political fund-raiser who was an adviser to Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois. While federal prosecutors spent about eight weeks building their case, the defense declined to call any witnesses. “We do not believe the government has met their burden of proving the charges against Mr. Rezko, plain and simple,” Joseph J. Duffy, Mr. Rezko’s chief lawyer, said outside the courtroom. Among the government’s final witnesses was Ali Ata, a former high-ranking state official who provided testimony after pleading guilty to lying to the F.B.I. in another case. Closing arguments in Mr. Rezko’s trial are scheduled for next Monday.

headline: G.E. Medical Device Plant Cleared
text: The Food and Drug Administration, which more than a year ago forced General Electric to close a surgical equipment plant in Salt Lake City because of manufacturing quality problems, gave the plant official approval to restart on Monday.

headline: The S.E.C. of the Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strike Hits G.M. Plant That Makes a Big Seller
text: DETROIT  General Motors workers who build the Chevrolet Malibu, one of G.M.’s most popular and important new vehicles, went on strike Monday at a plant in Kansas after they were unable to reach an agreement with the company on local work rules.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Federal Reserve’s decision to lower a key interest rate known as the federal funds rate described it incorrectly. It is the rate at which banks lend to each other, not the rate at which the Fed lends to banks on overnight loans. (When the Fed lends to banks overnight, it uses what is called the discount rate.)

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “As Tears Go By,” directed by Wong Kar-wai, misidentified the film by Mr. Wong in which the main character is seen eating expired tins of pineapple. It is “Chungking Express,” not “Fallen Angels.” (A character with the same name in “Fallen Angels” refers to having been made mute by eating expired pineapple.)

headline: Harmful Rays? For Some Spiders, a Mating Signal
text: The ultraviolet portion of the sun’s rays has a bad reputation, and among the different types of ultraviolet, UVB has about the worst. These shorter-wavelength rays cause sunburn and cancer and can harm the retinas of humans and other mammals.

headline: Leading Indian Telecom Seeking Deal in South Africa
text: Bharti Airtel, India’s largest telecommunications company, said Monday that it was in discussions with the MTN Group of Johannesburg. MTN, which operates cellphone systems in Africa and the Middle East, could be worth more than $40 billion in its entirety, according to bankers and analysts.

headline: Racial Disparities Found to Persist as Drug Arrests Rise
text: More than two decades after President Ronald Reagan escalated the war on drugs, arrests for drug sales or, more often, drug possession are still rising. And despite public debate and limited efforts to reduce them, large disparities persist in the rate at which blacks and whites are arrested and imprisoned for drug offenses, even though the two races use illegal drugs at roughly equal rates.

headline: The College Pressure Cooker (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Price Drop Could Imperil Mortgage Agencies
text: As home prices continue their free fall and banks shy away from lending, Washington officials have increasingly relied on two giant mortgage companies  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac  to keep the housing market afloat.

headline: Clemens Acknowledges Mistakes in Personal Life
text: After a week when he was repeatedly linked in published reports to women other than his wife, Roger Clemens acknowledged Monday that he had “made mistakes” in his personal life but maintained that it did not mean he had ever used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Ethiopian Exodus, Told on a Human Scale
text: Israel has no shortage of immigration stories, but many Americans are unaware of the Ethiopian Jews who in the late 1970s and 1980s braved a trek through the Sudanese desert to reach it. Yossi Vassa, an actor-playwright who survived that journey, has written, with Shai Ben Attar (who directs), a semiautobiographical account, “One of a Kind,” now at the New Victory Theater. The 65-minute production, for audiences 10 and older, manages to infuse its potentially harrowing tale with a childlike vigor, wonder and sense of humor, spiced with exuberant African music and dance.

headline: Evidence a High-Fat Diet Works to Treat Epilepsy
text: A formerly controversial high-fat diet has proved highly effective in reducing seizures in children whose epilepsy does not respond to medication, British researchers are reporting.

headline: At a Festival of New Plays, Money Makes Two Plots Go Round
text: COSTA MESA, Calif.  With the possible exception of a few hedge fund billionaires, is anyone in America not worried about money, as the stock market settles into a state of permanent hysteria, the economy lumbers, and the cost of living leaps?

headline: Scarred by Strife After Election, Kenya Begins to Heal
text: MOLO, Kenya  The bus was full. Expectant faces pressed against the windows. Soldiers stood guard with their guns.

headline: Presidential Primary Is Casting a Long Shadow in Indiana
text: ANDERSON, Ind.  Inside Eva’s Pancake House in this central Indiana town, it had been a slow morning for Jill Long Thompson, one of two Democratic candidates for governor. The diners she approached were polite enough, but the table set aside for local supporters who had been invited to drop by was, so far, empty.

headline: Art and Mental Illness (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Votes Near, a Fast Pace for Bill Clinton
text: NEW BERN, N.C.  Former President Bill Clinton had no time on Monday for his usual leisurely hourlong sessions pressing the flesh on the rope line, or for a meandering speech that could run on just as long.

headline: Lasers May Treat Cancers of the Larynx
text: For people with early cancer of the larynx, the standard treatment can be grueling: a biopsy in an operating room followed by a six-week course of radiation that may lead to permanent hoarseness or speech impairment.

headline: In China City, Protesters See Pollution Risk of New Plant
text: BEIJING  Residents took to the streets of a provincial capital over the weekend to protest a multibillion-dollar petrochemical plant backed by China’s leading state-run oil company, in the latest instance of popular discontent over an environmental threat in a major city.

headline: And the Brass Ring Goes to Chicago Symphony: Riccardo Muti Says Yes
text: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra snagged the prize.

headline: Calling on Tourists to Come for New York City, but Stay for the State
text: NEW YORK STATE is asking tourists to fall in ♥ all over again.

headline: Honoring Survival, and Gifts to a Nation
text: JERUSALEM  The gray walls of Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial here, have long documented the horrors perpetrated by the Nazis against Europe’s Jews. Now, an oddly vibrant exhibition at the memorial is telling a less known story of the renaissance of the survivors in Israel and the extraordinary role they played in shaping the character of the new state.

headline: Corrections
text: An article and headline on Wednesday, about a construction accident in Manhattan in which a worker was critically injured after falling 25 feet from a building, misstated the profession of the worker, Christopher Gunn. He is an iron worker, not a steel worker.

headline: Rockettes to Roam
text: A new, touring version of the Radio City Christmas Spectacular will hit the road in November in a production designed to play arenas with a capacity of 7,000 to 12,000 in 18 cities across the Midwest and South, Reuters reported. “We’re big believers in the big spectacle,” said Jay Marciano, the president of Madison Square Garden Entertainment, a division of Cablevision that owns and operates Radio City Music Hall, the Beacon Theater, Madison Square Garden and the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden. The touring show will incorporate elements of the 75th edition of the spectacular, which opened last year at the 6,000-seat Radio City Musical Hall. The touring show will involve 30 trucks and 16 buses, a huge screen and a cast of 56, including, of course, Rockettes. The show will open with an engagement on Nov. 8 and 9 in the Brown County Arena in Green Bay, Wis.; there are plans to play more than 60 markets in the next three years before repeating the cycle. “If we’re successful in the U.S., we’ll start to think about it in the context of international opportunities,” Mr. Marciano said. (Tickets for the 2008 Radio City Christmas Spectacular at Radio City Music Hall went on sale last week. The show will run from Nov. 7 through Dec. 30.)

headline: The In-Flight Movie Is Always Better When It’s Your Son’s
text: WHEN I was a little boy, my mother wanted to take my sister and me to Florida. Unfortunately, we missed our plane. It was one of those profound psychological moments that followed me into adulthood.

headline: Myanmar Reels as Cyclone Toll Hits Thousands
text: Myanmar struggled Monday to recover from a cyclone that killed more than 3,900 people and perhaps as many as 15,000.

headline: E.R.’s Are Busy, but Fewer Patients Are Uninsured
text: It is often said that emergency rooms are crowded because of the disproportionate number of uninsured people using them. But data based on telephone surveys and in-person interviews, published on April 14 in The Annals of Emergency Medicine, tell a different story. The number of uninsured people nationwide rose to 15.7 percent in 2004 from 15.4 percent in 1995. Yet in that period, the proportion of uninsured people using emergency rooms declined.

headline: Service Sector Improved Its Hiring in April, a Survey Finds
text: Service companies added jobs last month for the first time this year, according to a private survey released Monday. But the survey, from the Institute for Supply Management, also showed that activity slowed down at the nation’s service industries as inflation further squeezed businesses already pressured by falling demand.

headline: Giveaways to Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Rangers May Pursue the Player Who Ended Their Season
text: For all of the talk during the Rangers’ second-round playoff series about the Penguins’ young superstars, Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin, it is significant that neither one scored the series-winning goal in overtime in Game 5. Instead, Marian Hossa ended up being the star.

headline: Coughlin’s Playful Side Has Deep Roots in Florida
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Tom Coughlin stood behind the ninth green at Marsh Landing Country Club on Monday, telling the story about the golf cart that rolled into the lake at No. 2 a few years ago. He provided his own sound effects.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on April 26 about an acknowledgment by the documentary filmmaker Errol Morris that he had paid some interview subjects in his new film, “Standard Operating Procedure,” about the Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal, misstated the address of a Web site that had noted Mr. Morris’s acknowledgment at an early screening of the film. It is andthewinneris.blog.com, not andthewinneris.com.

headline: Torre Says Wins Will Help Mets Win Back Fans
text: LOS ANGELES  Joe Torre is gone from New York, but he has a pretty good idea of what it will take for fans at Shea Stadium to stop raining boos on the Mets at the drop of a bat. Winning games in October should do.

headline: Long Live the Amaryllis!
text: Q. When my nephew was born 16 years ago, his mother received a white amaryllis, which is about to bloom once again. How long does an amaryllis live?

headline: Can M-U-D Really Spell M-O-N-E-Y?
text: LOWER WATERFORD, Vt.  In Vermont, mud season is the limbo between winter and spring, when the snow melts, the crocuses start peeking through and rubber boots and low gears are needed to navigate the mess that takes over many roads and fields.

headline: Theme Parks Help Disney’s Quarter
text: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse, so far at least, is not a discretionary expense.

headline: Acquisition of Lender Is Possibly in Jeopardy
text: Is Kenneth D. Lewis getting cold feet?

headline: Bernanke Urges Flexibility in Mortgage Regulation
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urged Congress on Monday to allow federal agencies more leeway in overseeing the ailing mortgage industry, emphasizing that the causes of the current foreclosure crisis were more difficult to address than those in the past.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the young stars of the Pittsburgh Penguins, gave the wrong nationality for Marian Hossa. He is Slovak, not Czech.

headline: Prognosis: Kidney Decline Difficult to Stop
text: High blood pressure can often lead to chronic kidney disease, which is especially prevalent among African-Americans.

headline: Tully Hall to Reopen in 2009 With Eclectic Music Festival
text: When Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center reopens in February after a $159 million, 22-month renovation, it will have a gleaming, three-story glass lobby; custom-made seats; and a mechanized stage extension that will allow musicians to get closer to the audience.

headline: For Donovan and Galaxy, Changes for the Better
text: It was late 1999 when Landon Donovan helped the United States under-17 national team to its best showing in the FIFA U-17 World Cup, a fourth-place finish in New Zealand.

headline: The Downside of Exercise (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Forcing Sobriety, However Imperfectly
text: Like most patients assigned to my substance abuse clinic these days, John, a stylish 22-year-old cosmetology student, did not arrive voluntarily.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and article on Saturday about “Bridge Over the Wadi,” a documentary about a school for Jewish and Arab pupils shown on the PBS World channel on Sunday, misidentified the school’s location. It is in northern Israel, not on the West Bank. The article also referred incorrectly to the West Bank. While it is occupied by Israel, it does not belong to Israel.

headline: Some Diabetics Don’t Have What They Thought They Had
text: Ryan Collins of Aldie, Va., was only 10 weeks old when doctors made the diagnosis: Type 1 diabetes. That meant up to eight insulin shots per day, a big burden on him and his family.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,061 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

headline: China: Virus Death Toll Climbs
text: The death toll from the spread of an intestinal virus rose to 26, and all of the dead were children younger than 6, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency. The virus, known as hand, foot and mouth disease, has also infected nearly 12,000 others, more than triple the number reported Friday, the news agency said. Health officials have recorded cases far beyond the central province of Anhui, where the outbreak began, with infections as far south as Guangzhou and as far north as Beijing. The virus is not usually fatal, and health officials are at a loss to explain why so many children have died. The outbreak began in early April, but was not reported by health officials until last week, provoking accusations of a cover-up. On Monday, the government in Anhui Province punished 10 health officials for inadequate medical care or for mishandling the outbreak.

headline: 5 Restaurants in Manhattan Get Citations Over Calories
text: City health inspectors began issuing violation notices on Monday to restaurants that did not have calorie counts posted beside the prices on their menu boards.

headline: Zimbabwe: Opposition Party Isn’t Ready to Commit to Runoff
text: The opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, will not say whether its candidate, Morgan Tsvangirai, will take part in a presidential runoff election until the authorities announce the date for the runoff, said a party spokesman, George Sibotshiwe. The official results, released Friday, showed that Mr. Tsvangirai had received more votes than President Robert Mugabe, but did not win by an outright majority. The runoff is supposed to be held within three weeks, but Mr. Mugabe can postpone the date by decree, buying more time for the repression of opposition supporters in areas that used to be his party’s unquestioned strongholds, political analysts said. The opposition says the governing party, ZANU-PF, stole its presidential victory and has pursued a campaign of terror against its workers.

headline: 16 Are Killed as Gunmen Seek Rancher in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Gunmen killed 17 people over the weekend in the southern coastal state of Guerrero in a wild hunt for the head of the state cattlemen’s association, who has gone into hiding, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Scientists Finally See Sugar Chains in Action
text: Glycans don’t get a lot of publicity compared with DNA and RNA, but they play important roles in the life of the cell. These sugar chains, also known as oligosaccharides, are often found on cell surfaces, where they are involved in cell-to-cell interactions, both healthy (like embryonic growth) and unhealthy (like viral infection).

headline: Corrections

The university said Mr. Feeney was a student there in the early 1950s but did not play for its football team and was not a starting quarterback, as his son had told The A.P.

headline: Championing Luminaries of Chamber Music’s Past, and Visionaries of Its Future
text: For the finale of his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, the pianist Yefim Bronfman assembled a group of his colleagues  the violinist Gil Shaham, the cellist Lynn Harrell and the Emerson String Quartet  for an afternoon of unusually vigorous and engaging chamber playing. The program’s comfortably familiar pillars were the Shostakovich Piano Quintet (Op. 57) and the Tchaikovsky Trio (Op. 50). But Mr. Bronfman also devoted a significant part of the program to premieres by Marc-André Dalbavie and Jörg Widmann.

text: When humans engage in highly strenuous exercise day after day, they start to metabolize the body’s reserves, depleting glycogen and fat stores. When cells run out of energy, a result is fatigue, and exercise grinds to a halt until those sources are replenished.

headline: Police Stop-and-Frisk Encounters Soar
text: Despite criticism about aggressive policing, New York City police officers stopped more people on the streets during the first three months of 2008 than during any quarter in the six years the Police Department has reported the data, Al Baker reports. The 145,098 stops from January through March — up from 134,029 during the same quarter a year earlier — led to 8,711 arrests and put the Bloomberg administration on course for the highest annual total. The numbers also reflect an increased reliance on a practice that has become an emotional flashpoint, particularly after the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell in 2006.

headline: McCain Criticizes Democratic Rivals on ‘Activist’ Judges

headline: The Beauty of Clarified Butter
text: Recipe writers sometimes tell you to add oil to butter when sautéing to “keep the butter from burning.” I never quite understood how the addition of oil would prevent the milk solids in the butter (which are what burn at low temperatures) from blackening and tasting nasty; it certainly never worked for me, and I abandoned the practice years ago. I finally looked this up in Harold McGee’s “On Food and Cooking” and, well, it doesn’t work: whatever is going to burn at about 250 degrees will still burn at about 250 degrees. McGee also tells us that clarified butter –- butter without the milk solids or water, hence more or less pure fat –- doesn’t burn until a good 400 degrees, a far more useful temperature for frying.

headline: Flagstaff, Ariz., or Salt Lake City, as a Mountain Retreat
text: My cousin and I are planning a three-day weekend in late June where we will meet somewhere between San Francisco (where I live) and New York (where she lives). We mainly want to hike and we’d love to be in a nice mountain town or some other place with a bit of culture or some kind of interesting vibe. We want to go somewhere we can both take a direct flight and then not have to travel too far.

headline: The Morning Skate: Versus vs. Fans, Garbage Bags and Fabian
text: The Rangers have their final physicals and exit interviews and then will say goodbye today. As we all know, breaking up is hard to do, but while the dying coals of the playoff fires smolder, you can still sound off on our post of yesterday. Tell us what you think about the Rangers’ season and what they have to do to move forward in 2008-09.

headline: Ruth, Unbuttoned
text: I’ve been following our discussion with great interest — I was fascinated by what Kathleen said about coldness and Allan’s analysis of the lake — but what I want to respond to today is Greg’s comment about Ruth’s voice.

headline: TV Guide Names New Top Editor After Sale Closes
text: “TV Guide promoted two executives to top editorial roles Tuesday, days after the previous leadership departed amid the acquisition of the magazine’s parent company,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo: Not Dead Yet?
text: It’s not over until… well, when is it really over?

headline: A-Rod Goes Deep on the YES Network
text: The Yankees will pay Alex Rodriguez about $300 million over the next 10 years in part because of his value to their cable network, YES. So it is no surprise that the feature subject for the next episode of a new show, “YESterdays,” is A-Rod.

headline: Spring “Housekeeping”
text: In its second week, the discussion about Marilynne Robinson’s 1980 novel “Housekeeping” is still going strong over in our Reading Room blog. The conversation so far has touched on eccentricity, sex (or not), comedy, feminism (or not) — rich topics for a rich novel. And readers have pointed us in interesting new directions: Robinson’s view of childhood, the coded symbolism of the characters’ names, the book’s interest in fiction itself as a theme.

headline: Super Bowl Starting Line: $3 Million for a 30-Second Spot
text: NBC plans to sell commercial time on next January’s Super Bowl for $3 million per 30 seconds, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: What the N.T.R.A. President Is Saying
text: Alex Waldrop is president and chief executive officer of the National Thoroughbred Racing Association. He shares his thoughts on the death of Eight Belles.

headline: In Brooklyn, Haitians Protest as Ex-Paramilitary Leader Faces Trial
text: Inside the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn early Tuesday morning, he was just another defendant in a list on the computer screens on the first floor: Constant, Emmanuel, set for trial on grand larceny charges. The printed calendar in the court clerk’s office said the same. Only prosecutors and Mr. Emmanuel’s lawyer, it seemed, knew that the case had been put off until the summer.

headline: Obama Grassroots Ops in Indiana
text: As the voting got under way in Muncie, Ind., the Obama campaign was facing a demographic landscape that had thwarted it in the past.

headline: Primary Voting in North Carolina and Indiana
text: With Barack Obama ahead in the delegate count, Hillary Rodham Clinton sorely needs a victory in Indiana to counter pressure on her from within the party to end her candidacy.

headline: End of the Road for Super Aguri
text: It was short run, but the team that was cobbled out of desperation (Honda’s desire to keep Takuma Sato in Formula One) eventually ran out of money and time.

headline: He’s No Marcus Welby, But Viewers Like Him Anyway
text: Fox claimed a share of first place in the ratings on Monday, thanks largely to the strength of its medical drama, “House,” about a cantankerous doctor. Despite a modest audience of 13.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, the 9 p.m. show delivered the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, enough to lift Fox into a tie with CBS for first in that demographic even though Fox’s “Bones” earned relatively mediocre results at 8 p.m. (8.1 million).

headline: Think Again, Landmarks Panel Tells St. Vincent’s
text: Updated, 3:01 p.m. | St. Vincent’s Hospital, which had pushed for a $1.6 billion development proposal within the Greenwich Village Historic District, was sent back to the drawing board today by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. All 10 commissioners who spoke at a public hearing this morning opposed the plan, which would have demolished nine existing buildings to permit the construction of a towering new hospital and an enormous luxury condominium in conjunction with the Rudin Management Company.

headline: Strahan Making Friends With Fox
text: Michael Strahan says he knows which way he’s “leaning” on whether to retire.

headline: Microwave Popcorn, Minus the Ripoff
text: Somehow, I’ve managed to write about popcorn at least three times in the last year or so without hitting on the key issue: The Great Ripoff that is microwave popcorn. And that’s because somehow, I appear to have come late to the realization party, the one in which we all recognize that popcorn can be microwaved in an ordinary paper bag (or similar container; see photo).

headline: Indiana and North Carolina Primaries
text: John Harwood of The New York Times talks to The Times's John Broder about today's primary elections.

headline: Another Google Executive Leaves for Facebook
text: Every time a Google executive leaves, the company says that it is not facing a brain drain and that it has deep bench of talent. That’s true. Far more people still want to work at Google than want to leave.

headline: Wright Dominated News Coverage
text: Now it’s been quantified. If you thought the news media had been giving lopsided coverage to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Senator Barack Obama’s former pastor, you would be correct.

headline: Breakdowns and Dollars
text: It’s the economy, stupid.

headline: Finally, Some Good News for Katie
text: After writing the same headline two weeks in a row — “A Record Low For ‘CBS Evening News'” — it is worth noting that Katie Couric’s nightly newscast posted some gains last week.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, May 6:

headline: Sect Leader Arrested on Child-Sex Charges
text: Law enforcement officials in the Southwest are once more on the offensive against a leader of a fringe religious group accused of sex with children.

headline: Q and A: Johnny Iuzzini
text: Johnny Iuzzini has been the executive pastry chef for the restaurant Jean Georges for more than five years.

headline: Is Clinton Biting Wall Street’s Hand?
text: As the Democratic presidential primary drags on, Hillary Rodham Clinton has fired warning shots across Wall Street’s bow.

headline: Trailer: Swingtown
text: A trailer for Swingtown, CBS's new one-hour drama about life in the '70s.

headline: Fighters Press Albany to Lift Ban on Mixed Martial Arts
text: ALBANY — Matt Serra is a tough guy. He’s short and stocky and has been pummeling men with his bare fists — O.K., he wears an open-fingered glove — for years as a fighter with the Ultimate Fighting Championship.

headline: Captain of the Titanic Does Some Yard Work
Reader Photographs From Myanmar
text: Our thanks to two readers, Jay Saxon and Henry Webb, who sent us photographs of some of the damage caused by the cyclone in Myanmar.

headline: Booker Bookies
text: To mark its 40th anniversary, the Man Booker Prize is running a contest this spring to determine the best Booker-winning title of the past four decades. (The annual award goes to one original, full-length, non-self-published novel written by a citizen of the British Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.)

headline: Broadcast, Cable Profits Grow At Disney
text: The Walt Disney Co., the owner of ABC, ESPN and the Disney Channel, reported second-quarter profit that exceeded analysts’ estimates on Tuesday. Bloomberg reports:

headline: Bowery Bay Team Wins City’s ‘Sludge Olympics’
text: The 21st annual Operator’s Challenge — a competition affectionately known as the Sludge Olympics — was held today. The Bowery Bay team — three workers, and an alternate, who work at the city’s giant sewage treatment plant in western Queens — were the undisputed winners, sweeping all five events to take the championship and a chance to move on to the statewide competition.

headline: ‘A Lincoln-Douglas Debate’
text: President George W. Bush is now officially less popular than his father, although Laura is neck-and-pearls with Barbara.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Flashing Lights, Pull Over Sir
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week.

headline: Voting Rights? Nun for You!
text: The Supreme Court last month upheld Indiana’s harsh voter ID law (pdf), which requires voters to present government-issued photo ID — something many registered voters don’t have.

headline: No Silver Bullets
text: No one ever said suing the federal government was a quick way to get policies changed, but if you are very, very patient, it sometimes gets results before everyone involved has retired.

headline: Crustless Quiche
text: Mark Bittman deconstructs quiche for a delicious breakfast treat.

headline: Rangers: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
text: As the Rangers went through the season’s final motions, doing their exit interviews with coaches and management as well as their physicals, they dealt with the disappointing end to their season and faced the questions ahead.

headline: The Supers
text: The trouble with last night’s party at the Met, if I may speak frankly, is that it was a little like being sucked into a sequined wind tunnel. It started with a little breeziness before the superhero displays—Oh, hey, Narciso and Claire! Hi Liya! Alessandra! Isaac! Diane! Tom!—and then, suddenly, people seemed to be flying around the room. Oh, it was fun. In the crush and cocktail chatter, you don’t really see the clothes.

headline: Sabres Add (That’s Right, Add) Talented Forward
text: Boston College’s Nathan Gerbe is riding his NCAA tournament success right into the pros. The forward signed with the Buffalo Sabres, choosing to forgo his senior season with the national champion Eagles.

headline: Raise a Glass to the Tired Campaigners …
text: In the last hours of yet another election day — the 42nd? The 44th? Did I miss the trip to American Samoa? The Obama campaign turned to drink in North Carolina.

headline: Cyclone Aid and China’s Role
text: David I. Steinberg, the author, most recently, of “Turmoil in Burma” (2006) and a professor of Asian studies at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown, was asked if the United States should be worried that its $3 million in assistance to victims of the cyclone in Myanmar will be siphoned off by the country’s military government.

headline: When Genes Go Retro
text: Pssst! I’m going on a tour of the genome — want to come?

headline: Behind the Bouquet
text: Nicholas D. Kristof examines the impact of free trade on Colombia's economy with a flower industry worker and President Alvaro Uribe.

headline: Beekeeper’s Journal
text: When I wrote earlier about my travails of trying to drive the queen down to the bottom of the stack of hive boxes so she could lay her eggs in the “proper” spot, I heard the voice of my mentor: “Oh, come on! Find the queen, brush her in to the lowest box, slap a queen excluder on, and be done with it!” Besides a lifetime of experience handling bees, my mentor, who retired and moved from New Jersey to North Carolina a couple of years ago, has two things that I don’t have: fearlessness when handling his hives and an ability to find the queen. Look as I might, even with my 1.50 magnifying glasses on under my bee veil, I cannot find the queen.

headline: No-Win Situation
text: No matter who wins Indiana tonight, Democrats are the losers, suggests The Atlantic’s Marc Ambinder. “Forget the horse race numbers for a moment: if the surveys are accurate, the polarization within the Democratic Party has reached critical levels,” he writes at A Reported Blog on Politics (yes, that really is its name). He continues:

headline: Upside for McCain
text: The Weekly Standard’s Michael Goldfarb reads Marc Ambinder’s analysis of the exit polls from North Carolina and Indiana and calls the results “a best case scenario for McCain.” One number in particular jumps at at Goldfarb, writing at his magazine’s blog: “Indiana seniors favor Clinton by 78-21. McCain’s age is going to be an issue, but the Dems may overplay their hand and spark a backlash among a group that is already disinclined to Obama. McFogey Democrats!”

headline: Rush to Judgment
text: A reader at The Plank, The New Republic’s staff blog, has done some interesting figuring from the exit polls to come up with a plausible measure of the “Limbaugh effect” (the number of Republican voters who are strategically voting for either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama as part of Rush Limbaugh’s “Operation Chaos”) in Indiana. Relying on data from CNN.com, “Sdemuth” writes:

headline: Rider Remembers Fusaichi Pegasus
text: Big Brown will be the heavy favorite for the Preakness. I caught up with Andy Durnin, who galloped Fusaichi Pegasus during the 2000 Triple Crown. Fusaichi Pegasus was also a heavy favorite for the Preakness, only to lose to Red Bullet.

headline: Experts say buyers in Spain ‘waiting’ for more bad news
After the Vote, There’s the Spin
text: Partisans for Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton furiously debated last night’s results live on television, and sometimes on-line, in opposing efforts to sway a tiny subset of the audience: The Democratic superdelegates who become more important with each successive Tuesday night.

headline: Live Blogging the Indiana-North Carolina Primaries
text: 1:34 a.m. | The Wrap: After a grueling and unexpectedly dramatic night, Senator Clinton at last pulls out a win in Indiana, but by a bare 22,000 votes, or 50.9 percent to 49.1 percent. But her “win” almost doesn’t matter. That Mr. Obama came so close is bad news for her.

headline: Oxygen Ends ‘Talk Sex’ After Six Seasons
text: The Associated Press: “Sunday night is getting less steamy. Oxygen’s ‘Talk Sex’ call-in show with colorful septugenarian educator Sue Johanson is ending its run after six seasons, the network announced Tuesday. The final show airs at midnight Sunday.”

headline: Shrinking Audiences For ‘Sweeps’
text: The Associated Press summarizes the low ratings during the first week of May “sweeps:”

headline: Not Yet
text: At the time of the writing of this post, 14 percent of the vote in Indiana has yet to come in. The Atlantic’s Matthew Yglesias, however, makes the valid point that the outcome of the race is already clear. “As we wait to hear from Indiana, it’s always worth recalling that there’s no real substantial difference between a narrow win in Indiana and a narrow loss in Indiana,” Yglesias writes on his blog for the magazine. “A lot of our primary punditry has proceeded as if this is the electoral college and there’s a huge difference, but the Democrats’ rules for delegate allocation assures at this point that Indiana’s going to be a push while Obama picks up a nice parcel of delegates out of North Carolina.”

headline: Primaries: Swaying with the Spinners
text: “Partisans for Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton furiously debated last night’s results live on television, and sometimes on-line, in opposing efforts to sway a tiny subset of the audience: The Democratic superdelegates who become more important with each successive Tuesday night,” Jim Rutenberg writes.

headline: Primaries: Postponing Projections, TV Networks (Except For CBS) Wait For Vote Tallies
text: Update: 1:15 a.m.: All the major television networks called Indiana for Clinton around 1:10 a.m.

headline: Barack Obama in North Carolina
text: Barack Obama comments on the results from the May 6 primaries. (Video: NBC)

headline: Better Health Care Sought for Detained Immigrants
text: The head of a Congressional subcommittee looking into complaints of inadequate medical care in immigration detention announced on Tuesday that she had introduced legislation to set mandatory standards for care and to require that all deaths be reported to the Justice Department and Congress.

headline: Uncertainties Mark Next Steps
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is bracing for one of the most difficult days of her presidential race on Wednesday, anticipating new pressure to quit the race and facing a set of financial and logistical decisions that will determine just how robust a campaign she can continue to wage against Senator Barack Obama, according to several advisers and political allies.

headline: Bryant Lands M.V.P. With Off-Court Assists
text: There were four words more than any others that Kobe Bryant needed to say Tuesday as he accepted his first N.B.A. Most Valuable Player award after waiting a dozen years to fulfill his destiny of being like Mike.

headline: Ilyas Malayev, 72, Uzbek Musician and Poet, Dies
text: Ilyas Malayev, a musician and poet renowned in Uzbekistan and transplanted to Queens, where he was a legend among fellow Bukharan Jews, died on Friday in Flushing. He was 72 and lived in Forest Hills.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about using a Tivo service called StopWatch to predict the loser on “American Idol” referred incorrectly to the genesis of the service. While engineers who are fans of the reality show decided to use the service to try to predict the outcome, they did not come up with the idea for StopWatch.

headline: Building Proposal by Greenwich Village Hospital Is Rejected
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday sent St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, which had pushed for a $1.6 billion development proposal within the Greenwich Village Historic District, back to the drawing board.

headline: Many Propose Ways to Make Construction Sites Safer
text: Proposals for improving safety at construction sites in New York City after a rash of fatal accidents stacked up like high-rise scaffolding at a City Council hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Revenue Up, but Income Falls at Cisco
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems reported Tuesday that its sales grew in the third quarter despite continued concerns about an economic slowdown. Company earnings topped Wall Street’s forecasts and shares rose in after-market trading.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,062 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: For the Republicans, It’s McCain (and Others)
text: Amid the chatter about whether the Democrats would be able to unite around one of their candidates was an interesting nugget. Incomplete returns on Tuesday night showed that more than 20 percent of those who voted in the Republican primary in Indiana voted for someone other than Senator John McCain, the party’s presumptive nominee.

headline: Four Chums Grow Up but Still Meet in the Bleachers
text: The new musical “Glory Days” may be the youngest-feeling show about being young ever to land on Broadway.
