Granted, this callow portrait of four friends on the cusp of manhood, which opened on Tuesday night at the Circle in the Square Theater, doesn’t have the raging hormonal current or electrified anguish that made teenage cult favorites out of “Spring Awakening,” “Rent” and, four long decades ago, “Hair.”

headline: Judge Blocks Two Athletes’ Testimony for Coach’s Trial
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Two world-class athletes and leading prosecution witnesses will not be allowed to testify in the trial against the track coach Trevor Graham, a United States District judge said Tuesday.

headline: Lawyers for Guantánamo Inmates Accuse U.S. of Eavesdropping
text: One lawyer for Guantánamo detainees said he replaced his office telephone in Washington because of sounds that convinced him it had been bugged. Another lawyer who represents detainees said he sometimes had other lawyers call his corporate clients to foil any government eavesdroppers.

headline: Let’s Take a Closer Look at That Study on Yak Cheese
text: WITH the possible exception of high-fructose corn syrup, is there a food left on the planet that hasn’t had its health benefits touted in a scientific study and a press release? These days it seems that analyses of food composition are automatically served up with a side of hype. Take, for example, two recent reports, one on organic produce and the other on a slightly less mainstream ingredient, yak cheese.

headline: Come for the Clothes, Stay for the Sweets
text: You might choose pants in a size 4 instead of a size 2 once you see the new Tisserie cafe on the Thompson Street side of the DKNY store in SoHo. Ronald and Morris Harrar, who own a pastry shop in Caracas, Venezuela, opened Tisserie in Union Square two years ago. This cafe, an offshoot, offers croissants and other morning temptations ($2 to $2.50), starting at 7:30 a.m., before the store opens. Later there are quiches ($5.99), brownies ($2.50), tiny fruit tarts ($1.50), above, Argentine alfajores cookies filled with dulce de leche (6 for $8), sandwiches ($8 to $12) and salads. A custard layered pudding topped with dulce de leche ($5.50) might mean size 6: 420 West Broadway (Spring Street), (646) 613-1100.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A profile on April 29 about Francisco J. Ayala, a professor who speaks often in defense of the theory of evolution, misstated the location of McGill University, where he gave a recent talk. It is Montreal, not Toronto.

headline: A Thoroughly Modern Oscar and Algernon
text: Deep in the third act of the Pearl Theater Company’s entertaining production of “The Importance of Being Earnest,” I realized how much the sitcom “Frasier” owes to Oscar Wilde. Jack Worthing, this play’s proper, endearingly puffed-up gentleman, is echoed in Frasier; Jack’s more foppish, droll brother (as it turns out), Algernon Moncrieff, is Niles. And their swift, sardonic repartee in Wilde’s masterpiece ripples through the ages, surfacing  with conscious influence or not  in the most surprising places.

headline: Some Signs of an Upturn for the Dollar
text: WASHINGTON  After six years of stumbling against the euro, the dollar may be showing signs of getting back on its feet.

headline: UBS Announces $10.9 Billion Loss, Job Cuts, and Tax Probe
text: LONDON  The Swiss banking giant UBS, the European bank hit hardest by the tight credit market, said Tuesday that it had sold $15 billion of subprime mortgage debt and would cut 5,500 jobs as part of its cleanup, news that some investors saw as an indication that the bank was dealing with its problems.

headline: Executions Resume, as Do Questions of Fairness
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  The release of the third death row inmate in six months in North Carolina last week is raising fresh questions about whether states are supplying capital-murder defendants with adequate counsel, even as an execution on Tuesday night in Georgia ended a seven-month national suspension.

headline: In Battle of Aquariums, Big Gets Bigger
text: ATLANTA  Apparently eight million gallons of water and 80,000 animals were not enough for the Georgia Aquarium, which already claims to be the world’s largest. It did not have dolphins.

headline: House Panel Backs a Subpoena for Cheney’s Chief of Staff
text: WASHINGTON  A House panel investigating the Bush administration’s approval for harsh interrogation methods voted Tuesday to issue a subpoena to David S. Addington, chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and a primary proponent of the methods, which some legal experts have condemned as illegal torture.

headline: Clinton Vows to Continue Her Run
text: INDIANAPOLIS  With a sizable share of votes yet to be counted and the outcome in the balance, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton claimed victory Tuesday night in the Indiana primary and vowed to push on to the remaining contests on the nearly finished Democratic presidential nominating calendar.

headline: Clinton Takes Indiana by Slim Margin; Obama Wins North Carolina Decisively
text: Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory in the North Carolina primary on Tuesday, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton very narrowly won Indiana, an outcome that injected a boost of momentum to Mr. Obama’s candidacy as the Democratic nominating contest entered its final month.

headline: Japan Fights Crowds of Crows
text: KAGOSHIMA, Japan  Fanning out in small teams, the men in gray jumpsuits scour the streets and rooftops with binoculars, seeking to guard this city from a growing menace. They look for telltale signs: a torn garbage bag, a pile of twigs atop an electric pole or one of the black, winged culprits themselves.

headline: Europe Delays Decision on Growing of Modified Crops
text: The European Union authorities delayed decisions on Wednesday on whether to allow European farmers to grow types of genetically modified crops, heightening tensions with agro-science companies and risking further friction with trading partners like the United States.

headline: World Wrestling Entertainment’s Earnings Rise 29%
text: World Wrestling Entertainment, the producer of the television show “Friday Night SmackDown,” said first-quarter profit rose 29 percent on increases in films and live events.

headline: Companies Improve Scores in Climate-Change Ranking
text: This just in from Climate Counts, the nonprofit group that scores consumer products companies on their green track records: consumer companies are getting greener, but they are still a pretty carbon-intensive lot.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about electrocutions of American soldiers in Iraq because of flawed wiring misstated, on second reference, the surname of a victim shown with his mother, Cheryl Harris. He was Staff Sgt. Ryan D. Maseth, not Sergeant Harris.

headline: State Watch for 2 Percent of Doctors
text: ALBANY  More than 2 percent of all doctors practicing in New York last year landed on the state medical board’s watch list because of problems including substance abuse, mental health concerns or their professional conduct.

headline: A Challenge Getting Relief to Myanmar’s Remote Areas
text: BANGKOK  International aid agencies began distributing food in Myanmar’s commercial capital and main city, Yangon, on Tuesday but there was uncertainty that the assistance would reach people stranded without shelter in the remoter reaches of the country’s vast Irrawaddy Delta.

headline: Monet and Rodin Set Price Records at Christie’s
text: Fears that the Christie’s sale of Impressionist and modern art would usher in a market meltdown were assuaged early Tuesday evening when everything from a Monet landscape to a monumental sculpture by Rodin brought record prices.

headline: Iran: What Does ‘Exporting the Revolution’ Mean?
text: A former president has come under attack by Tehran’s leading conservative newspaper for comments that appeared to suggest that Iran was supporting insurgents in other countries. On Monday, the newspaper, Kayhan, accused Mohammad Khatami, the former president, of making remarks that were against Iran’s national interests. Mr. Khatami said in a speech on Friday that when the founder of the 1979 revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, talked about “exporting the revolution,” he meant making Iran a role model for other countries, not supporting sabotage operations in other countries.

headline: After Fossella’s D.W.I. Arrest, District Is Puzzled and Torn
text: He has become the talk of his own Congressional district, and not always in the most flattering of tones. Across Staten Island on Tuesday, voters were wondering what Representative Vito J. Fossella was thinking when, the police say, he drove into a Washington suburb while severely intoxicated early one morning last week.

headline: Wine’s Pleasures: Are They All in Your Head?
text: THE mind of the wine consumer is a woolly place, packed with odd and arcane information fascinating to few. Like the pants pocket of a 7-year-old boy, it’s full of bits of string, bottle caps and shiny rocks collected while making the daily rounds of wine shops, restaurants, periodicals and the wine-soaked back alleys of the Internet. It’s harmless stuff, really, except to those within earshot when a wine lover finds it necessary to elaborate on the nose, legs and body of a new infatuation.

headline: Guatemala: Hiatus in Foreign Adoptions Is Ordered
text: Guatemala has ordered a one-month hiatus in foreign adoptions, to investigate potential fraud. A law that took effect in January created a government adoption authority to replace an adoption system handled by private lawyers. The suspension affects 2,300 adoptions that began earlier. The attorney general, Baudilio Portillo, said the cases, most of them involving American parents, will be individually reviewed, according to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: California Awards $271 Million for Stem Cell Research
text: LOS ANGELES  California has awarded $271 million in grants to build 12 new stem cell research centers in the state, even as one of the political rationales for the building program might soon disappear.

headline: Fire Dept. to Send Units First, Save the Questions for Later
text: A pilot program for Fire Department dispatchers in Queens was so successful in improving response times that it will be extended across the city next month, the department said on Tuesday.

headline: Patents Need Protection
text: To the Editor:

headline: Young Artists Find a Private Space, Only Without the Privacy
text: One “room” is a cramped cubby that measures, in all, perhaps 25 square feet, just enough for a full-size mattress and whatever can be stashed beneath. The first-floor rooms, in the basement, are musty and windowless, like caves. The second-floor rooms have plywood walls but no doors, only cut-out windows that overlook a kitchen cluttered with day-old dishes, a chore wheel and the odd paintbrush.

headline: Filly’s Death Brings Issues to Fore, but Where Is the Accountability?
text: For the last several days, the death of Eight Belles at the Kentucky Derby has become the talk of the nation. The filly’s demise was especially sobering for casual fans, whose only contact with horse racing is through one of the Triple Crown races.

headline: At the Airport, Training for Heightened Diplomacy
text: At Fordham University, students can take courses in “personal branding” and “sales management.”

headline: Telescoping 4,000 Years of Talmud and Tradition
text: It is easy to see why someone might approach “The Jewish People: A Story of Survival” with a certain reservation. The documentary, to be shown on Wednesday on WLIW and on other PBS stations in June, condenses four millenniums of atrocity into 60 minutes, allotting the pogroms the amount of time it takes to dust a coffee table.

headline: The Foreclosure Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Serra’s Monumental Vision, Vertical Edition
text: PARIS  France is making a fuss this week over Richard Serra, the 68-year-old American bantamweight who fashions elegant, gargantuan art out of steel.

headline: South Africa: Cabinet Appointment Requested
text: The governing African National Congress has asked South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, to appoint the party’s deputy president, Kgalema Motlanthe, to serve in Parliament and in Mr. Mbeki’s cabinet. Mr. Motlanthe is an ally of the party’s president, Jacob G. Zuma, a keen rival of Mr. Mbeki’s. Mr. Motlanthe has often been mentioned as a possible heir to Mr. Zuma, whose trial on corruption charges is scheduled to begin in August. The party’s secretary general, Gwede Mantashe, made the party’s request for Mr. Motlanthe’s appointment public at a news conference.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on April 25 about new federal measures that offer a path to legal status for illegal immigrants whose close relatives died in the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the position of a Republican congressman, Dan Lungren of California, on a proposed House bill that would grant the immigrants permanent resident visas. He supported it when it went before the House Judiciary Committee but said he wanted to know how many immigrants would be affected before supporting it in a final vote on the floor. He did not oppose the bill.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Friday about the early success of the Tampa Bay Rays this season misstated the year that Troy Percival, a pitcher, won a World Series title with the Angels. It was 2002, not 2004.

headline: Cisco Sales Top Lowered Forecast, and Profit Declines
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems to Wall Street: It’s not so bad.

headline: Urban Farmers’ Crops Go From Vacant Lot to Market
text: IN the shadows of the elevated tracks toward the end of the No. 3 line in East New York, Brooklyn, with an April chill still in the air, Denniston and Marlene Wilks gently pulled clusters of slender green shoots from the earth, revealing a blush of tiny red shallots at the base.

headline: Lost Opportunities Plague Mets
text: LOS ANGELES  It was a game the Dodgers appeared to be willing to concede to the Mets. Shortstop Rafael Furcal, their offensive catalyst, sat out with back stiffness on Tuesday night and many of the rest of the Dodgers seemed to have checked out mentally.

headline: Lost and Found in New York Taxicabs
text: MIDTOWN, FEBRUARY 2007 A woman from Dallas left a suitcase in Osman Chowdhury’s taxi, which she took from the Hilton Hotel to East 35th Street between Second and Third Avenues. She gave Mr. Chowdhury a 30-cent tip on a $10.70 fare  and a $100 reward when he returned the suitcase, which had been left in the trunk and which held, in addition to clothing, 31 diamond rings and a laptop computer.

headline: Officials’ Memory an Issue When Time Stands Still
text: The officials huddled on the court, armed with nothing but their memories of a few fleeting seconds of action. They were trying to determine the length of time it took to run a play, which is nearly impossible to determine without a clock.

headline: Attempted Killings Incite Violence in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Scattered violence struck areas of Baghdad as well as parts of central and northern Iraq on Tuesday, as a trickle of families began to leave Sadr City to escape bombings, and Iraqi security forces raided a hospital suspected of treating militia forces.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with a report in some editions on Saturday about the N.B.A. playoffs misidentified the player shown dunking for Atlanta. He was Al Horford, not his teammate Josh Smith.

headline: Butter-Braised Asparagus and Oyster Mushrooms With Peas and Tarragon
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: Thom Yorke and Company, Kicking Off a Tour With a Lush Miasma
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Radiohead played the first concert of its North American tour here at the Cruzan Amphitheater on Monday night, and nobody onstage was tan. “We’ve just spent the last three days in Miami Beach,” said Thom Yorke, the band’s lead singer, looking incredulous. “What’s going on there? Some kind of reconstruction. For once I was proud to be white, pale and English.”

headline: Medical Drama Pays Off for Fox
text: Fox claimed a share of first place in the ratings on Monday, largely because of its medical drama, “House,” starring Hugh Laurie, above with Jennifer Morrison. Despite a modest audience of 13.3 million viewers reported by Nielsen, “House,” at 9 p.m., delivered the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49. That was enough to lift Fox into a tie with CBS for first in that demographic even though Fox’s “Bones” earned relatively mediocre results at 8 p.m. (8.1 million). CBS was solid during both hours with its regular comedy lineup and led the 10 p.m. time slot by a wide margin with “CSI: Miami” (13.9 million). ABC finished third among the 18-to-49 set, but outperformed Fox and CBS in total viewers, as “Dancing With the Stars” averaged 17.9 million total viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. ABC’s “Bachelor” (7 million), however, remained mired in third place at 10 behind “CSI: Miami” and NBC’s “Medium” (9.5 million). NBC finished fourth overall, broadcasting “Deal or No Deal” from 8 to 10 (8.4 million).

headline: The Death Penalty Returns
text: Roughly 15 death row prisoners are scheduled to be put to death between now and October, according to the Death Penalty Information Center. This flood of executions is the result of the Supreme Court’s ruling that upheld the constitutionality of a troubling form of lethal injection. The next few months, as states put their machinery of death into overdrive, are an ideal time for the nation to rethink its commitment to capital punishment.

headline: Burger With a Side of Spies
text: Monterey, Calif.

headline: White House Vows to Veto Housing Measure
text: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a House floor debate on a plan to help homeowners in danger of foreclosure, the Bush administration said on Tuesday that it opposed the measure and that White House advisers would urge the president to veto it.

headline: Protégé in Russia Is Sworn In
text: MOSCOW — Dmitri A. Medvedev, a soft-spoken lawyer and Kremlin insider who had never held elected office before, was sworn in as Russia’s president at noon Wednesday inside the Grand Kremlin Palace.

headline: Jagr Will Take Some Time to Decide Future
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jaromir Jagr walked into his future on Tuesday and sounded a little more encouraging about returning to New York.

headline: Bush Advisers Oppose Housing Measure, and Vow a Veto
text: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a House floor debate on a plan to help homeowners in danger of foreclosure, the Bush administration said on Tuesday that it opposed the measure and that White House advisers would urge the president to veto it.

headline: Wishing Happy Birthday to a Place Where Art Is Made
text: The Joyce Theater, now a Chelsea institution, gave itself a 25th-birthday party on Monday night: a couple of choreographic appetizers, followed by dinner and dancing of the social sort. Mercifully, the speeches were short.

headline: 3 Taiwan Officials Quit in Diplomatic Furor
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The foreign minister of Taiwan and two other top officials resigned on Tuesday over a botched attempt to win diplomatic recognition from Papua New Guinea, a scandal that has stirred public outrage against the departing government just two weeks before it is to step down.

headline: Focus Turns to Long Island Philanthropist as Israeli Prime Minister Is Investigated
text: A Long Island philanthropist and fund-raiser for Israeli charities is at the center of a growing storm surrounding Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, that has riveted and agitated Israel despite a veil of secrecy over the continuing investigation.

headline: Clinton’s Options Seem to Dwindle
text: In this case, a split was not a draw.

headline: Irvine Robbins, Ice Cream Entrepreneur and a Maestro of 31 Flavors, Dies at 90
text: Irvine Robbins, who with his brother-in-law, Burton Baskin, started the Baskin-Robbins chain of ice cream stores  together concocting quirky flavor combinations with names like Daiquiri Ice, Pink Bubblegum and Here Comes the Fudge  died on Monday near his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Removing the Crust for a Savory Custard
text: I SUPPOSE crustless quiche is a contradiction in terms, like seared ceviche. But if, like me, you sometimes crave what amounts to savory pie filling without the hassle of making an actual crust, this is the way to go. (The other option is to buy a crust and fill it, but if you can find a good pre-made crust you’re a better shopper than I am.)

headline: A New Governor, Yes, but an Old Port Authority
text: For all the drama of the coup d’escort that brought down Eliot Spitzer and delivered David A. Paterson into the governor’s office, any shifts of power in the state since then have been as noiseless as a fog.

headline: Simmering Anti-Semitism Mars a Vibrant Hungary
text: BUDAPEST  Ostensibly, a rock concert sparked it, reminding us that culture is not the exclusive province of liberals, certainly not here in Europe. A young woman (who knows whether she was just intending to make trouble) walked into a ticket office in the traditionally Jewish 13th District in this Hungarian capital several weeks ago and asked about Hungarica, an obscure extremist far-right band.

headline: Kennedy Makes Most of His Trip to Minors
text: By the time he met with reporters a few minutes after the Yankees’ 5-3 loss to Cleveland on Tuesday night, Joe Girardi had already heard the happier news from Moosic, Pa. Ian Kennedy, the rookie starter the Yankees demoted to Class AAA on Sunday, had thrown seven and a third shutout innings, allowing just one hit.

headline: Gas Prices Expected to Peak in June
text: Oil jumped to another record on Tuesday, and the government said it expected gasoline prices to peak at a national average of $3.73 a gallon in June, just as the summer driving season kicks off.

headline: Alvin Colt, Broadway Costume Designer, Dies at 91
text: Alvin Colt, a Tony Award-winning costume designer who draped actors in everything from gamblers’ pinstripes for “Guys and Dolls” to flowing robes for classic Shakespearean productions to vacuum cleaner hoses and Coca-Cola cans for recent spoofs of Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Butterflies Aren’t Free
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Turqua Grill and The JakeWalk
text: NEW PLACES

headline: F.B.I. Raids Office of Special Counsel
text: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. agents on Tuesday raided and temporarily shut down the offices of a small federal watchdog agency that is charged with protecting the rights of government whistle-blowers but has been accused of retaliating against whistle-blowers in its own ranks.

headline: New Mexico Compound’s Enraptured Believers
text: There is much to make the jaw drop in “Inside a Cult,” a timely documentary about the Strong City sect in New Mexico being shown on Wednesday on the National Geographic Channel. But by its end you may feel that the most stunning thing is that this film exists at all. Why would these people have let a documentarian get so close to their exceedingly eccentric world?

headline: Construction Worker Is Killed in Fall From a Scaffold
text: A construction worker fell about 30 feet to his death from a scaffold on the Triborough Bridge in Queens on Tuesday afternoon, officials said.

headline: ‘Yeltsin: A Life’
text: At twelve noon, Friday, December 31, 1999, Moscow time, on the cusp of the new year, the new century, and the new millennium, a surprise announcement from the president’s office was televised across Russia from the Baltic Sea, where the sun had crept above the horizon, to the Bering Strait, where it had just dipped below. Boris Yeltsin, attired in a charcoal-gray suit and silver tie, with a tinseled holiday tree in the background, had videotaped it that morning. He was retiring seven months before the expiration of his mandate, he said hoarsely, and was handing over power to the prime minister and now acting president, Vladimir Putin, pending confirmation by the electorate. As the terse clip rolled, the presidential suite, paraphernalia, and “nuclear briefcase” were already in Putin’s hands and Yeltsin was clinking glasses at a leave-taking luncheon.

headline: The Police Bow Out in New York
text: The Police said on Tuesday that it would play its final concert this summer in New York. A statement posted on the Web site of the frontman, Sting  (sting.com), said, “We kicked off our very first American tour at CBGB’s in 1978 and this summer, 30 years later, our journey will come full circle as we play our final show here in New York City.” The concert will be a fund-raiser to benefit arts programming for Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York. Tickets will be available nationally online through those stations. The date and site of the performance are to be announced. At a news conference in Times Square with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Sting, joined by the guitarist Andy Summers and the drummer Stewart Copeland, said the band, which split up in 1984 and reunited for a 30th anniversary world tour last year, was also pledging $1 million to the Mayor’s Fund to Advance New York City in support of MillionTreesNYC. The donation, matched by the city, will provide $2 million to help implement the reforestation component of MillionTreesNYC, which plans to plant 10,000 trees and reforest 2,000 acres of parkland across the five boroughs. Reforestation improves air and water quality, reduces greenhouse gases and lowers energy costs.

headline: I.O.C. Rules Will Limit Protests by Athletes
text: Athletes who compete in the Beijing Olympics will not be allowed to wave flags, make gestures or alter their external appearance to make a political statement, according to guidelines issued in April by the International Olympic Committee.

headline: At the Philharmonic, Musings About Muti
text: The announced union of Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra left 100 jilted suitors at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday.

headline: An Improvised Asparagus Dish Is a Happy Accident
text: WHEN it came to cooking asparagus, I thought my skill set was complete.

headline: The Risks of Brand-Building in the Winner’s Circle
text: MINUTES before he was to appear live on NBC on Saturday as the presenting sponsor of the Kentucky Derby, David C. Novak, the chief executive of Yum Brands, says he was in the dark.

headline: New Rules, Different Chamberlain
text: Last season, it was the Joba Rules, the wordplay that referred to the Yankees’ careful use of Joba Chamberlain and his utter dominance of the opposition. This season, the term does not quite apply.

headline: Revenue Rises 16 Percent at News Corporation
text: The News Corporation, the global media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a 16 percent gain in revenue in the third quarter on Thursday, mainly from growth in the company’s television and cable networks businesses.

headline: Amid Partisan Standoff, Bush Submits 3 Nominees to Election Commission
text: President Bush on Tuesday submitted three new nominees to the Federal Election Commission, a move that could help end a political impasse that has left the agency paralyzed in the midst of a heated presidential campaign.

headline: An Auction of New Chinese Art Leaves Disjointed Noses in Its Wake
text: SHANGHAI  Sotheby’s auction house called it the “most important collection of contemporary Chinese art to ever come to market”  some 200 works by some of China’s hottest names.

headline: A Culinary School’s Changes Are Met With Unrest
text: ON the campus of the Culinary Institute of America, the New York culinary school whose alumni include many of the biggest names in cooking, the mood is as tense as a Gordon Ramsay kitchen.

headline: Tapping Into a Clean Alternative
text: Though it will occupy a square foot of counter space and stands 16 inches tall, the new Cuisinart countertop water filtration unit can process 80 gallons of water before the filter needs replacing.

headline: A $500 Million Week for Grand Theft Auto
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest iteration of the hit video game franchise, racked up first-week sales of $500 million, Take-Two Interactive, the game’s publisher, plans to announce on Wednesday. The report exceeded the sales expectations of analysts.

headline: New Musical for Harry Connick Jr.
text: Harry Connick Jr., in the role of a Long Island playboy, will return to Broadway in March as the star of “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” a new musical comedy with songs by George and Ira Gershwin. Joe DiPietro, whose credits include “I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change” and “All Shook Up,” will provide the book. Kathleen Marshall, who directed Mr. Connick in the 2006 revival of “The Pajama Game” and won a Tony Award for her choreography, will direct and choreograph the new show, at a theater to be announced.

headline: Obama Wins North Carolina Decisively; Clinton Takes Indiana by Slim Margin
text: Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory in the North Carolina primary on Tuesday and lost narrowly to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Indiana, an outcome that injected a boost of momentum to Mr. Obama’s candidacy as the Democratic nominating contest entered its final month.

headline: F.B.I. Raids Office of Special Counsel
text: WASHINGTON  The office of the official responsible for protecting federal workers from political interference was raided by F.B.I. agents on Tuesday as part of an investigation into whether he himself mixed politics with official business.

headline: Film Says Franco Rigged Eurovision Contest
text: The Spanish dictator Francisco Franco rigged the vote in the 1968 Eurovision Song Contest, cheating the British entertainer Cliff Richard, below, of victory, according to a documentary to be televised on Thursday in Spain, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Richard’s song “Congratulations” was the favorite in the competition, held that year in London, but it was beaten by a single point by “La La La,” sung by a Spanish contestant, Massiel. The film contends that Franco (that’s his statue below, in Santander, Spain), bought votes by dispatching music and television executives to other countries in Europe to purchase the rights to series that were never broadcast and to sign obscure acts. José María Iñigo, a Spanish public television journalist, told the documentary that the Franco regime “had a great need to win recognition, even if it was only in one area.” In 1968 the winner of the Eurovision contest was determined by a jury from each participating country. The winner is now chosen by votes cast by telephone and text message from television viewers. Informed of the content of the documentary, Mr. Richard told The Guardian of London, “I’ve lived with this No. 2 thing for so many years, it would be wonderful if someone official from the contest turned around and said, ‘Cliff, you won that darn thing after all.’ ”

headline: Dancing Around Town
text: The Joyce Theater’s celebration of its 25th anniversary will continue with a free festival of 25 outdoor performances spread throughout New York’s five boroughs over five days, from July 16 to 20. A presentation with the City Parks Foundation, the festival, Dance Out!, features three international works: “Dans le Jardin,” an improvised piece created and performed by the Dutch choreographer Michael Schumacher and set to live music by the cellist Alex Waterman; Compagnie Beau Geste’s “Transports Exceptionnels,” a duet by Dominique Boivin for a man and an excavator, accompanied by the voice of Maria Callas; and “Contigo,” a solo by the Portuguese choreographer Rui Horta for the acrobat and the Chinese-pole master João P. Pereira Dos Santos. Dance Out! opens with all three works being performed at the East River Park on July 16 at 7 p.m. From there it spreads to locations including the parachute jump at Coney Island, the Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens and the South Beach boardwalk in Staten Island. Information: Joyce.org or cityparksfoundation.org.

headline: Truffles? Call It Fudge With Class
text: Truffles, the chocolate kind, usually have creamy ganache centers. But John Kelly Chocolates in Los Angeles has made the truffle homy by using old-fashioned fudge instead of ganache. An old-fashioned chocolate-loving mom might appreciate them on Sunday.

headline: In England, at Home in a Railroad Station
text: LENWADE, England

headline: After 60 Years, Arabs in Israel Are Outsiders
text: JERUSALEM  As Israel toasts its 60th anniversary in the coming weeks, rejoicing in Jewish national rebirth and democratic values, the Arabs who make up 20 percent of its citizens will not be celebrating. Better off and better integrated than ever in their history, freer than a vast majority of other Arabs, Israel’s 1.3 million Arab citizens are still far less well off than Israeli Jews and feel increasingly unwanted.

headline: After Making an Early Call, CBS Keeps a Lonely Stand
text: At 8:09 p.m. on Tuesday, Katie Couric broke into the procedural crime drama “NCIS” to tell her viewers: “A split decision tonight in the latest primary showdown: Hillary Clinton needed to win Indiana; CBS News estimates she did. Meanwhile, we’re projecting Barack Obama the winner in North Carolina.”

headline: Write-Down at Wachovia Nearly Doubles Its Loss
text: Wachovia reported on Tuesday that its previously reported first-quarter loss nearly doubled to $708 million because of a write-down tied to life insurance policies.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “A Wolf at the Table,” referred incorrectly to another book by Augusten Burroughs, “Sellevision.” It is a satirical novel about a television home-shopping network; it is not about Mr. Burroughs’s experiences in the advertising business.

headline: Gingrich Warns G.O.P. Swift Change Is Needed
text: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrich, the man who engineered the Republican takeover of the House in 1994, warned his fellow Republicans on Tuesday that they faced disastrous losses in November without a quick change in political course.

headline: The Cost of Smarts
text: Research on animal intelligence always makes me wonder just how smart humans are. Consider the fruit-fly experiments described in Carl Zimmer’s piece in the Science Times on Tuesday. Fruit flies who were taught to be smarter than the average fruit fly tended to live shorter lives. This suggests that dimmer bulbs burn longer, that there is an advantage in not being too terrifically bright.

headline: Garnett Comes Up as Big One for Celtics
text: BOSTON  LeBron James sank behind a wall of bodies, barely visible or audible from even a few feet away, his usual regal presence muted by the crowd and the din that surrounded him.

headline: Aid to Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: 8 Men Are Accused of Abducting, Torturing and Robbing Dozens of Drug Dealers
text: A gang of robbers used fake police lights, sirens and badges  and real handcuffs and guns  to pull over and rob more than 100 drug dealers of cash and cocaine in New York and elsewhere up and down the East Coast, federal prosecutors charged in an indictment unsealed on Tuesday.

headline: Trainer Recalls One That Got Away
text: Pat Reynolds watched the Kentucky Derby on Saturday and did not know if he should laugh, cry, cheer, feel sorry for himself or just enjoy the spectacular performance of a horse he knows intimately. For Reynolds, Big Brown’s first trainer, it was a bittersweet time.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Rosés, Head to Head

headline: Thurman’s Pursuer Is Found Guilty
text: Jack Jordan, a University of Chicago graduate turned drifter who lived in his car, was found guilty on Tuesday of stalking the actress Uma Thurman, the star of edgy, violent movies like “Kill Bill” and “Pulp Fiction.”

headline: The Making of Yeltsin, His Boldness and Flaws
text: In the introduction to his biography of Boris N. Yeltsin, Timothy J. Colton lists more than 100 of the similes and analogies that have been applied over the years to Yeltsin, among them martyr and jester, Lincoln and Nixon, Alexander the Great and Ivan the Terrible, Hamlet and Hercules, bear, bulldog and boa constrictor. The wry list is an early signal that Mr. Colton knows he is treading into a subject that has inspired rival mythologies.

headline: Fannie Mae Wins Cheers Despite Loss
text: Fannie Mae, the nation’s largest buyer of home loans, gave investors little reason to cheer Tuesday, announcing a $2.2 billion quarterly loss and a dividend cut, and warning of steeper losses ahead.

headline: Bright Lights and Big Money in India’s New Cricket League
text: NAVI MUMBAI, India  With an infusion of bling, Bollywood and go-go boots, a new cricket league is trying to spin off India’s colonial inheritance into a money-making symbol of a brash, emerging nation.

headline: China-India Rivalry Possible in African Telecom Deal
text: NEW DELHI  A battle for the MTN Group, a leading South African telecommunications company, could come down to a clash between the world’s largest and fastest-growing emerging markets.

headline: British Contractor Told to Strengthen Ethical Standards
text: LONDON  BAE Systems, the British military contractor accused of paying bribes to win contracts, must improve its ethical standards or risk more damage to its reputation, a panel reviewing its business ethics concluded on Tuesday.

headline: Changes at New Orleans Schools Bring Gains in Test Scores
text: NEW ORLEANS  A broad education overhaul under way here has produced improvement in test scores, results released Tuesday showed, though many students are still struggling.

headline: European Commission Sues to Force Italy to Take Out the Garbage
text: After years of warnings, and a spell of hot weather that did nothing to improve the stink of tons of uncollected trash around Naples, the European Commission filed suit against Italy on Tuesday, charging that it had failed to meet its obligation to collect and dispose of its rubbish.

headline: Benefits
text: Stepping Up to the Plate

headline: Quarrel Erupts Between Bear’s Elder Statesmen
text: After 59 years, Alan C. Greenberg is still trading away at Bear Stearns, the troubled Wall Street bank that is about to disappear. Ask about his retirement plans, and he lets out a belly-jiggling laugh.

headline: The Pursuer of Thurman Is Convicted
text: A jury in Manhattan decided Tuesday that Jack Jordan had tried too hard to meet Uma Thurman and sent her one too many love letters.

headline: Actors Guild and Producers End Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  Representatives of the Screen Actors Guild and Hollywood’s production companies ended their contract talks after three fruitless weeks.

headline: Jane Jacobs Honorees Are Chosen
text: Jane Jacobs Medals and $100,000 each will be awarded to Peggy Shepard and Alexie Torres-Fleming by the Rockefeller Foundation in a ceremony on Sept. 8 at the Morgan Library & Museum. The Jane Jacobs Medal was created last year by the foundation to honor Ms. Jacobs, the urban design author and activist who died at 89 in 2006. Ms. Shepard, 61, is the executive director and a founder of West Harlem Environmental Action, a leader in publicizing and combating the practice of situating environmentally harmful facilities in working-class neighborhoods with minority residents. Ms. Torres-Fleming, 43, is the founder of Youth Ministries for Peace and Justice in the South Bronx and a founder of the Southern Bronx River Watershed Alliance, a coalition of local groups campaigning to replace the Sheridan Expressway with affordable housing and green spaces.

headline: It’s About the White House
text: Like many Americans, we have been intrigued and often exasperated by the long-running Democratic primary and the ever smaller-bore spats between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. So we are thankful to Senator John McCain for reminding us Tuesday what this year’s presidential race really is about.

headline: 75 Students Arrested in Drug Raid
text: SAN DIEGO  Seventy-five students at San Diego State University have been arrested on drug and weapons charges in an undercover operation that grew out of a student’s death from a cocaine overdose last year, law enforcement authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: What You Get for ... $3 Million
text: Honolulu

headline: Cabdriver Thanked for Returning a Stradivarius
text: NEWARK  The violinist stood on a makeshift stage between two lampposts crowned with a patina of bird droppings, under a weathered vinyl canopy hastily erected outside Newark Liberty International Airport in the taxicab holding area. The audience watched him in awe, about 50 drivers in three rows, their yellow cabs a few feet behind, some lined up neatly, others askew.

headline: Paying for Doctors’ Classes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeing Inflation Only in the Prices That Go Up
text: Next week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will release its monthly report on inflation, and it sure is going to sound strange. Wall Street is expecting the bureau to announce that the Consumer Price Index rose just three-tenths of a percentage point in April. Over the last year, the index has risen only about 4 percent.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on April 26 about the acquittal of three New York City police detectives in the shooting death of Sean Bell misstated the date of his death in some copies. It was Nov. 25, 2006, not Nov. 26.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Friday about the quarterly earnings for Sun Microsystems misstated the given name of the company’s chief financial officer. He is Michael Lehman, not Mark.

headline: In Europe, New Scrutiny of Ethical Standards
text: PARIS  A series of bribery investigations at leading European companies has helped to accelerate compliance with global anticorruption standards as managers recognize the risk to their brands and reputations, legal analysts and international regulators say.

headline: A City Committed to Recycling Is Ready for More
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Mayor Gavin Newsom is competitive about many things, garbage included. When the city found out a few weeks ago that it was keeping 70 percent of its disposable waste out of local landfills, he embraced the statistic the way other mayors embrace winning sports teams, improved test scores or declining crime rates.

headline: Lazard Profit Off 71% on Problems in Corporate Holdings
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that its first-quarter profit plunged 71 percent, hurt largely by a $28.5 million write-down in its holdings of corporate debt and losses in its corporate equity portfolio.

headline: Crustless ‘Quiche’
text: Time: 30 to 40 minutes

headline: Lottery Numbers
UBS Banker Detained in Tax Inquiry
text: A top-ranking UBS executive was briefly detained by federal authorities in the United States in connection with a widening investigation into the Swiss bank’s work with questionable tax transactions, the bank said Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article in some editions on April 15 about a plan by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to install solar panels at its facilities misidentified the entity from which it buys electricity. It is the New York Power Authority, not Consolidated Edison.

headline: A Technology Consortium Plans a Wireless Network
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A who’s who of technology and telecommunications companies plans to announce on Wednesday that it intends to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks, according to several people briefed on the deal.

headline: No Signs of a Slowdown in Traffic at Disney’s Parks
text: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse, so far at least, is not a discretionary expense.

headline: Evacuation Ordered as Chilean Volcano Begins to Spew Ash
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Chaitén volcano in southern Chile blasted ash and what appeared to be lava a dozen miles into the air on Tuesday, leading the government to order the immediate and complete evacuation of everyone living within a 30-mile radius of it.

headline: A Win for Clemens’s Lawyer
text: A federal judge Tuesday ruled that Roger Clemens’s lead lawyer, Rusty Hardin, could continue to represent Clemens in a defamation lawsuit he filed against his former personal trainer Brian McNamee.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on April 24 about Augusten Burroughs, who has published a new memoir, “A Wolf at the Table,” referred incompletely to the settlement of a lawsuit over another book by Mr. Burroughs, “Running With Scissors,” that was filed by the children of a psychiatrist he lived with as a teenager. In addition to changes in some language on the acknowledgments page, there was a financial settlement of an undisclosed amount, and Mr. Burroughs and his publisher, St. Martin’s Press, agreed to call the work a “book” instead of a “memoir” in the author’s note.

headline: Quinn Plans More Changes in Council’s Budget Process
text: Speaker Christine C. Quinn plans to announce more changes to the City Council’s budget process, possibly as early as Wednesday, amid growing controversy over how council members spend the millions in discretionary money they control.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Suburban Office Market Uneasy but Holding Up
text: To gauge the direction of the commercial real estate market these days, John P. Hannigan, a co-owner of Choyce Peterson, a brokerage firm in Westchester and Fairfield Counties that specializes in representing tenants, relies on his own economic weather vane.

headline: The Democratic Recession
text: There are two important recessions going on in the world today. One has gotten enormous attention. It’s the economic recession in America. But it will eventually pass, and the world will not be much worse for the wear. The other has gotten no attention. It’s called “the democratic recession,” and if it isn’t reversed, it will change the world for a long time.

headline: Footnotes
text: “Betrayed” was honored as outstanding play and “The Adding Machine” as outstanding musical when the 23rd annual Lucille Lortel Awards for outstanding achievement Off Broadway were presented on Monday by the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers at the Union Square Theater. Among other honorees were Theodore Mann, given the Edith Oliver Award for Sustained Excellence; and Primary Stages, for Outstanding Body of Work. ...Garth Drabinsky and Myron Gottlieb, the founders of Livent, the Broadway theater company that produced “Ragtime” and “Showboat,” pleaded not guilty to large-scale accounting fraud as their trial began on Monday in Ontario Superior Court in Toronto, The Associated Press reported. ... The Babyshambles frontman Pete Doherty was released from Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London yesterday after serving 29 days of a 14-week sentenced for breaking probation imposed for drug and driving offenses, the BBC reported. ... The police in Angola arrested Bruno Carvalho, the man accused of jumping onstage and snatching a neck chain off the rapper 50 Cent during a concert last week in Luanda, AllHipHop.com reported. Mr. Carvalho was turned in by his parents.

headline: Injured Racehorses You Didn’t See
text: Will the death of the Kentucky Derby runner-up spur any real, meaningful change within the thoroughbred racing industry? Does it take a nationally televised catastrophe to bring about significant, long-term betterment to racehorse safety?

headline: Guantánamo, Defended
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Killing of Innocents Faces a Dry-Eyed Dissection
text: In “Battle for Haditha,” the British filmmaker Nick Broomfield revisits a wretched chapter of the war in Iraq. On Nov. 19, 2005, marines stationed in Haditha, a Euphrates River valley city northwest of Baghdad, killed 24 Iraqi civilians, including at least 10 women and children, from toddler age up, who were in their homes. The reasons for the killings remain in dispute, though not this evidence: most victims died from close-range gunfire and at least five were shot in the head. After various investigations, murder charges against four marines were dropped; one still faces reduced charges.

headline: Disaster in Myanmar
text: By all accounts, Cyclone Nargis has devastated Myanmar  a 12-foot wall of water sweeping away entire villages, leaving the coastal plain under water, thousands dead, missing or homeless and much of the capital city of Yangon without electricity or water. It is the sort of disaster that brings the world together in a desire to help, and the reaction of governments, the United Nations and international humanitarian organizations has been swift and noble. There is no time to waste.

headline: Technology Group Plans Wireless Network
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A who’s who of technology and telecommunications companies announced Wednesday that it intended to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

headline: When the Elderly Get to Choose Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Front Page

headline: McCain Assures Conservatives of His Stance on Judges
text: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  Senator John McCain reached out to conservatives on Tuesday by vowing to appoint judges he characterized as strictly faithful to the Constitution and who did not engage in what Mr. McCain condemned as “the common and systemic abuse of our federal courts.”

headline: Give the Lower East Side Some Respect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tight Credit Worries for a Hotel and Mall Operator
text: David Lichtenstein was new to the hotel business when he made one of the last big highly leveraged real estate deals before the credit squeeze, acquiring Extended Stay Hotels, a chain of 687 no-frills hotels, last June for $8.1 billion.

headline: Further Travails of Scarlett and Rhett
text: Pummeled by the critics, the London production of “Gone With the Wind” will have its running time trimmed by 15 minutes to three and a quarter hours, the lead producer told The Independent, adding that he was committed to continuing the run of the $9.5 million show that bills itself as “a play with music.” Aldo Scrofani, the lead producer, said: “Even the people who love the show have said it’s a bit long. It is long  and it’s going to be cut.” Once that is accomplished, he said, the “story itself will be more highlighted.” He denied that Trevor Nunn, the director, was forced to shrink the show, and denied rumors that management had planned to post a closing notice at the New London Theater over the weekend. “We’ve never posted a closure notice, nor discussed it,” he said, adding that “Gone With the Wind,” starring Jill Paice as Scarlett O’Hara and Darius Danesh as Rhett Butler, would continue through the traditionally slack months of May and June.

headline: Failings of One Brooklyn High School May Threaten a Neighbor’s Success
text: Set just a few subway stops apart in blue-collar Brooklyn, drawing from a similar pool of new immigrants and American-born blacks, two high schools spent the past decade careering toward opposite destinies. The question now is whether the failure of one will destroy the success of the other.

headline: John Jay Iselin, Public TV Innovator, Dies at 74
text: John Jay Iselin, who led WNET, also known as Channel 13, the nation’s largest public television station, through a period of innovative programming, great popularity and wide influence, died early Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: To Dine at Momofuku Ko, First You Need Nimble Fingers
text: WHAT you’re about to read may prod you to try for a reservation at Momofuku Ko, so it’s incumbent on me to say this right off the bat:

headline: Congress Weighs Veterans’ Adjustment Aid
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, badly wounded in World War II, reflects on the help he received in readjusting to civilian life after intense combat in Europe and finds today’s government support for returning troops impersonal and inadequate.

headline: Stocks Take a Fall Late in the Day
text: A late Wednesday afternoon tumble sent the stock markets to their worst session in nearly a month, as a swirl of unsettling financial and economic news unnerved investors who had enjoyed several weeks of relative calm after the winter’s tumult.

headline: After Promise of Reform, Ohio Democrats Face Test
text: CINCINNATI  Eighteen months after scandals helped Democrats in Ohio break a Republican monopoly on top state offices, a Democratic official has found himself enmeshed in one of his own.

headline: Flood of Attack Ads on Final Day
text: In these closing hours of the North Carolina and Indiana primaries, voters in the two states have been witness to a cacophony of attack ads the likes of which had not yet been seen in this protracted and already hard-hitting Democratic race.

headline: Aid for Myanmar Mobilizes, Mixed With Criticism
text: BANGKOK  A powerful cyclone that destroyed a vast swath of coastal Myanmar and left many thousands of people dead prompted the country’s military leaders to allow some foreign aid groups to deliver relief supplies on Tuesday. But the ruling junta came under increasing pressure to further open its doors  and even relax its tight political grip  to grapple with the growing disaster.

headline: Greek Islands, Overwhelmed by Refugees, Seek Help
text: ATHENS  A rash of refugees from Africa, southern Asia and the Middle East has been crossing the Aegean Sea and besieging a cluster of craggy Greek islands.

headline: Randolph Preaches Patience While Rotation Tests His
text: LOS ANGELES  It is not even mid-May, and the Mets, despite their faults and foibles, are a mere game and a half out of first place. But the lack of reliable depth in the rotation is starting to cause some anxiety.

headline: Washington: Mystery Men Identified
text: Two men whose behavior on a ferry last July prompted the F.B.I. to release their photographs in an effort to determine who they were have been identified, and “it appears that they were in the area for legitimate reasons,” the bureau said. The men were photographed by a ferry worker after they entered restricted areas and asked detailed questions about the boat’s structure, the bureau said. Robbie Burroughs, an F.B.I. spokeswoman, said the men were software consultants from Europe who were in Seattle for a conference. After learning of the search for them, they eventually went to a United States embassy and showed proof of their identity and their reason for traveling to Seattle. The F.B.I. has not released their names or nationalities. The men had dark hair and olive skin, and the release of the photographs prompted accusations that the F.B.I. was profiling passengers.

headline: An Afternoon at the (New Sports) Museum
text: It is a near certainty that no museum has ever celebrated its creation by enlisting 30 renowned painters, musicians or scientists to wave foam fingers at a lunchtime crowd while cheerleaders tumbled in a park next door. But that was the endearing if goofy sight at the end of a news conference Tuesday when Carl Lewis, Billie Jean King, Walt Frazier, Martina Navratilova, Eli Manning and others waggled those red appendages on a stage in Lower Manhattan to herald Wednesday’s opening of the Sports Museum of America.

headline: Colombia: U.S. Accuses Russian of Arms Smuggling
text: Viktor Bout, a Russian businessman described by the United States as one of the world’s most prolific arms traffickers, has been accused in New York of conspiring to smuggle missiles and rocket launchers to rebels in Colombia, the Justice Department said. His indictment on federal terrorism charges was unsealed on Tuesday. Mr. Bout, above, was arrested in Bangkok in March following an international sting operation in which undercover investigators posed as rebels from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia seeking to purchase millions of dollars in arms, according to the Justice Department, which says the weapons would have been used to kill Americans in Colombia. Mr. Bout, 41, is opposing extradition.

headline: Smaller Programs Are Among Hardest Hit in N.C.A.A. Academic Report
text: When Dick Tomey took over as coach of the San Jose State football team three years ago, he bluntly assessed the lack of programs available to help his players’ schoolwork.

headline: King-Mellencamp Musical Postponed
text: The Stephen King-John Mellencamp musical planned for next season in Atlanta in preparation for a Broadway run has run into an obstacle, The Associated Press reported. Having announced in February an April 2009 opening, the Alliance Theater in Atlanta notified subscribers that the show, “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” described as “a sultry Southern Gothic mystery with a blues-tinged, guitar-driven score,” had been delayed because members of the creative team “realized the script would not be ready by spring 2009.” The plot deals with a legend that grows from the deaths in 1957 of two brothers and a young girl. The Alliance said it hoped to produce the show in its 2009-10 season.

headline: Results From an Indiana County Kept Democrats Waiting
text: Early this morning, all eyes were on Lake County in far northwest Indiana, which is, in essence, a suburb of Chicago, Senator Barack Obama’s hometown. Results from the county, one of the state’s most populous with 494,000 people, were dribbling in late into the night. Results there tightened margin between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Obama, raising the specter of a possible recount in the state.

headline: A Lesson Before Writing, Courtesy of Idi Amin’s Ghost
text: The premise of “Steve & Idi” may be enough to make you laugh. Steve, a playwright who has been dropped by his agent and dumped by his boyfriend, becomes despondent enough to swallow a handful of pills. Instead of dying, he is visited by the ghost (or dream) of Idi Amin.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Charles Tilly, a prolific theorist of social science, misstated his relationship to three survivors  Kit Tilly, Laura Tilly and Sarah Tilly. They are his daughters, not his sisters. Because of an editing error, the name of his former wife and sometime collaborator was rendered incompletely. She is Louise Audino Tilly, not Louise Audino.

headline: Rings Welcomes You
text: We start Rings, the Times Olympics blog, in an appropriately friendly way: with 福娃. That’s “fuwa,” which means “friendlies,” the Mandarin term for dolls, stuffed animals, etc. The five fuwa above are the official mascots of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, and you will no doubt be seeing a lot of them between now and the closing ceremonies on Aug. 24.

headline: The Nominees Emerge, Hobbled
text: Here are two things we learned tonight. First, Barack Obama is going to almost certainly be the Democratic nominee. He’s withstood seven weeks of bad news and he still exceeded expectations.

headline: Hillary Clinton in Indiana
text: Hillary Clinton comments on the results from the May 6 primaries. (Video: NBC)

headline: Analyzing the Results
text: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, analyzes the results of the May 6 primaries and looks ahead to what's next.

headline: An Official-Looking Co-op Document
text: Q. I have heard that a number of co-ops have received a notice from a "Corporate Records Compliance Office" in Albany, stating that under New York law, corporations must hold annual meetings of shareholders to elect directors and conduct other business.

headline: Taxing the Gas in Them Thar Hills
text: Q. I read in a recent article in The New York Times ("There's Gas in Those Hills," April 8, 2008) that landowners in Pennsylvania (and potentially upstate New York) are being paid large sums of money as "sign-on bonuses" to lease the rights to explore and drill for gas under their property. The article also says that if gas is found, the landowner gets a monthly "royalty" check, which in one case cited amounted to $20,000.

headline: Producers Suspend Talks with Actors Guild
text: “Hollywood producers on Tuesday temporarily broke off contract talks with the Screen Actors Guild, calling its demands regarding DVD sales and online content ‘unreasonable,'” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Israel's Arabs
text: As Israel prepares to celebrate its 60th anniversary, the Arabs who make up 20 percent of its citizens will not be celebrating. Far less well off and integrated than Israeli Jews, they are feeling increasingly unwanted.

headline: Victory Speeches in Two States
text: Barack Obama won in North Carolina, while Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged to keep going full throttle for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: What In God’s Name Is That? Part 2: Hong Kong Roast Meat Shops
text: While larger restaurants often have a bewildering array of dishes, small traditional shops usually have only one or two specialties. A roast meat place will have just that on rice, so don’t expect dim sum, tofu, wine, dessert or anything else. Similarly, don’t go to a dumpling, soup and noodle shop (to be covered in my next installment) and ask for roast meat.At the roast meat shop, your basic choices are:“char siu”  – honey-roasted BBQ pork which you can identify by its red-tinted skin“siu yuk” – roast pork with a thick, brown-tinted crackling skin, which you can identify by the fact that it’s usually displayed as a large, curved slab of meat“see yeow gai” – soy sauce chicken, which (rather obviously) is the color of something that has been boiled in soy sauce“bak cheet gai” or “yeow gai” – like soy sauce chicken, but with plain or bright yellow skinSome of the more upscale places may also have:“siu ngap” – roast duck“siu ngoh” – roast gooseI mean “upscale” in a relative sense. A “rice box” with roast meat will go for U.S. $3-5, or H.K. $25-40. Don’t expect much in terms of presentation or service.Poultry will usually be served with minced raw ginger and scallion. Pork will usually be drizzled with soy-infused drippings. “Siu yuk” may come with a dab of mustard. A limp stalk of “gai lan” (Chinese brocolli) will probably be thrown in.

headline: Tropicana Bondholders Ask for Trustee Control
text: Some creditors of Tropicana Entertainment, which has filed for bankruptcy, asked for it to be placed under a court-appointed trustee’s control, saying the company’s chief executive, William Yung, had come close to destroying the casino operator’s prospects, according to court filings.

headline: Glaxo Raise $9 Billion in Bond Sale
text: GlaxoSmithKline, the drugmaker with a U.S. headquarters in Philadelphia, has raised $9 billion in the largest U.S. corporate-bond sale in six years.

headline: Spot Runner Said to Snag Another $51 Million
text: Spot Runner, an Internet-based advertising network that puts local business pitches on TV and radio, expects to announce Wednesday that it has landed another $51 million from investors including British media company Daily Mail and General Trust, Spanish media group Grupo Televisa, institutional investor Legg Mason Capital Management, and the luxury conglomerate Groupe Arnault/LVMH, CNet News.com reported.

headline: Wilfried Romoli and the Paris Opera Ballet
text: A look at Mr. Romoli’s final performance with the Paris Opera Ballet.

headline: ArvinMeritor to Spin Off Car Parts Unit
text: ArvinMeritor said on Tuesday it plans to spin off its automotive parts business from its larger trucking group in a move it hopes will improve the focus of each unit, sending its shares up 6 percent.

headline: Former Bear Broker Is Sentenced for Insider Trading
text: A former broker at Bear Stearns was sentenced on Tuesday to three years of probation and a year of home confinement and fined $300,000 for his part in an insider trading case.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Former Goldman Banker for Asia Post
text: JPMorgan Chase said on Wednesday it had hired former Goldman Sachs  banker Oral Dawe as managing director and chief executive of its Asia Pacific Commodities group.

headline: Fannie Mae Wins Cheers Despite Loss
text: Fannie Mae, the nation’s largest buyer of home loans, gave investors little reason to cheer Tuesday, announcing a $2.2 billion quarterly loss and a dividend cut, and warning of steeper losses ahead.

headline: Countrywide Admits Errors at Senate Hearing
text: The mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, which is accused of inflating certain borrowers’ fees, acknowledged on Tuesday that it had made errors and pledged to take steps to improve its operations.

headline: Write-Down at Wachovia Nearly Doubles Its Loss
text: Wachovia reported on Tuesday that its previously reported first-quarter loss nearly doubled to $708 million because of a write-down tied to life insurance policies.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Reject Retailer’s Settlement Offer
text: With a shareholder showdown just days away, Charming Shoppes said Monday that dissident investors, seeking to oust the chief executive officer and two other members from the board, had rejected its offer to settle a proxy fight.

headline: Will WPP’s Sorrell Take TNS Bid Hostile?
text: British advertising impresario Martin Sorrell may soon go hostile in his latest takeover tussle, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Silver Lake Closes $1.1 Billion Sumeru Fund
text: Silver Lake, a technology-focused private equity firm, said Tuesday that its first middle-market fund, Silver Lake Sumeru, would close with $1.1 billion, significantly higher than the original $750 million target the firm had set.

headline: Cablevision’s Newsday Bid Would Face Few Regulatory Hurdles
text: If Cablevision Systems manages to wrest the Tribune Company‘s Long Island, N.Y., newspaper Newsday away from other interested bidders, the transaction would raise the ire of consumer groups, but regulators in Washington won’t have much to say, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Andreessen to Join Facebook’s Board?
text: Veteran Silicon Valley entrepreneur Marc Andreessen has been asked to join the board of Facebook, according to All Things Digital.

headline: Investors Expect to Pour $200 Billion into Hedge Funds This Year
text: Hedge fund investors expect to put $200 billion into such funds in the next year, in spite of an overwhelmingly bearish view on the economy.

headline: Legg Mason Posts First Loss in Its History
text: Legg Mason posted on Tuesday a wider-than-expected quarterly loss — the U.S. money manager’s first loss ever — as it took a big charge related to a bail-out of money market funds exposed to risky securities and suffered outflows from its poorly performing funds.

headline: As Video Game Succeeds, How Much for Take-Two?
text: Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest iteration of the hit video game franchise, racked up first-week sales of $500 million, Take-Two Interactive, the game’s publisher, plans to announce on Wednesday. The report exceeded the sales expectations of analysts.

headline: Deal Chatter Swirls Around LinkedIn
text: Fresh rumors are popping up about LinkedIn, the online social network that has, at various times in the past year, been thought to be preparing an initial public offering or drawing interest from potential acquirers.

headline: A Feud in the Bear Stearns Family
text: After 59 years, Alan C. Greenberg is still trading away at Bear Stearns, the troubled Wall Street bank that is about to disappear. Asked about his retirement plans, and he apparently let out a belly-jiggling laugh.

headline: HK Energy Partners Pulls I.P.O.
text: HK Energy Partners, formed by Petrohawk Energy to acquire, develop and exploit oil and natural-gas properties, has canceled its plans for an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Tuesday.

headline: Tight Credit Worries for a Hotel and Mall Operator
text: David Lichtenstein was new to the hotel business when he made one of the last big highly leveraged real estate deals before the credit squeeze, acquiring Extended Stay Hotels, a chain of 687 no-frills hotels, last June for $8.1 billion.

headline: UBS Faces Tax Probe, Amid Other Woes
text: When Swiss banking giant UBS, the European bank hit hardest by the tight credit market, said Tuesday that it had sold $15 billion of subprime mortgage debt and would cut 5,500 jobs as part of its cleanup, some investors saw as an indication that the bank was dealing with its problems.

headline: Talleyrand and the gas tax holiday
text: I’m on record as saying that Hillary Clinton’s advocacy of a gas-tax holiday, while it wasn’t good policy, didn’t rise to the level of a crime.

headline: Buyout Firms to Trim Burger King Stake
text: TPG Capital, Bain Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs plan to sell 15 million shares of Burger King, reducing their combined stake in the fast-food chain from 43 percent to 32 percent.

headline: Citigroup Forms Alternative-Asset Group
text: Citigroup has formed a new unit within its investment bank that will bring together groups servicing private equity and infrastructure funds, according to an internal memorandum sent to employees on Tuesday.

headline: The Creator of Mr. Peabody, Sherman and the Wayback Machine
text: Ted Key, the cartoonist who created the impertinent maid “Hazel” in the 1940s — later played by Shirley Booth in the 1960s sitcom — died last weekend at 95. But did you know he also created Mr. Peabody and Sherman — the time-traveling professor (who also happened to be a dog) and his little boy sidekick? They were regulars on “Rocky and His Friends,” starring Rocky the squirrel and Bullwinkle J. Moose. Here’s a clip in which professor and boy go back to help Marconi invent the radio:

headline: ‘Party Could Be Over …’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: The Democrats had two important primaries today in North Carolina and Indiana. And the party could be over for Hillary Clinton. She might have won Indiana, but she lost North Carolina, which is bigger. They’re saying now the only way that Obama could possibly lose would be for him to marry Bill Clinton.

headline: Big Names Hook Up for Wireless Venture
text: A who’s who of technology and telecommunications companies announced Wednesday that it intends to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

headline: Against the grain
text: From the annals of unusual political action (via Felix Salmon):

headline: GLG’s Profits Rise Despite Market Turmoil
text: GLG Partners, the publicly traded British hedge fund, said on Wednesday that it earned $33.8 million for the first quarter, a 142 percent jump over last year even as the firm’s industry continues to struggle with the choppy markets.

headline: Where Are They Now?
text: On Tuesday, Harman International Industries finally reconfigured its management team and appointed a new chief financial officer. According to a news release, the former chief financial officer:

headline: Kennedy Dominant in Class AAA
text: If you want to know what’s happening with the Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Yankees, you should read Chad Jennings’s coverage in the Times-Tribune. Jennings was there for Ian Kennedy’s Class AAA debut Tuesday, when he completely overwhelmed the Charlotte Knights.

headline: Early Season Trade Rumors
text: It’s early in the season, but some names are already being thrown around in trade talks, most notably, Ken Griffey Jr.

headline: Great Color TVs Depend on Black and White
text: Creating the sharpest television images depends on more than just having a lot of pixels. Video engineers agree that contrast — the ratio between the blackest black and the whitest white — is just as critical. Other things being equal, the higher the contrast ratio, the sharper the image.

headline: Myanmar Disaster Relief: How to Contribute
text: For readers interested in contributing to help victims of the cyclone in Myanmar, here is a list of contact information and links for some agencies that plan to provide relief. The New York Times does not certify the charities’ fund allocations or administrative costs. More information about giving, for this and other causes, is available online from the GuideStar database on nonprofit agencies.

headline: La Vie Bohème, in East Williamsburg
text: In an evocative front-page article, Cara Buckley examines life at two sprawling, almost identical five-story former factories that face each other and sit at 248 and 255 McKibbin Street. Perhaps 300 people — mostly young, white, and hip — live in each building, from one to eight people to each loft. Few were born before the mid-1980s. Rents can range from $375 for one person to roughly $800 for a space. “To spend a few days at the McKibbin lofts is to experience what it is to be young, hungry for acceptance, and willing to put up with just about anything in order to gain a foothold in the city’s competitive, and thriving, underground art and music scenes,” Ms. Buckley writes. “This could have been Greenwich Village 60 years ago, or SoHo 30 years ago, or the East Village in the 1990s.”

headline: Ace’s Revenge
text: Landon Thomas has a fascinating article in today’s Times about the feud between Alan (Ace) Greenberg, the legendary former boss of Bear Stearns, and James (Jimmy) Cayne, who was chairman when the firm collapsed.

headline: If Dreams Were a Movie
text: I often awake from nonsensical dreams wondering to myself, “What was that about?” So I was particularly interested in a new video that attempts to capture the look and feel of dreams.

headline: ‘Jenna Getting Married This Weekend …’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Here’s something frightening. Oil has now passed $120 a barrel. That’s a new high. Yeah. You thought the Mexicans were celebrating yesterday, you should have seen the Saudi Arabians today.

headline: Richard Serra’s Paris Moment
text: A look at two of Richard Serra’s works on display in Paris.

headline: The Early Word: Race Shifts to Superdelegates
text: With the Indiana and North Carolina primaries behind us, we’ve crossed an interesting threshold: there are now more uncommitted superdelegates (231, according to The New York Times’s count) than pledged delegates (217) remaining to be won.

headline: A Holiday at the Bird’s Nest
text: BEIJING — May 1 is International Labor Day, and China is still, at least in name, a Communist nation, which meant many Chinese enjoyed an official holiday last Thursday and Friday. They traveled all over the place — to national parks in the west, to beaches in the south, to villages in the countryside. Some, though, gave in to Olympic fever and made a pilgrimage here to the capital to visit the Olympic Park.

headline: Obama Memo to Superdelegates
text: In the coming hours – or days or weeks? – the Democratic Party’s superdelegates will receive a flood of information about The State of The Presidential Race. Today’s first memorandum comes from David Plouffe, campaign manager for Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Reviews of a Slo-Mo Political Campaign?
text: From College Humor (which should go back to class on the spelling of raspberry):

headline: Medvedev Speaks
text: Viewers outside Russia who tuned in this morning to watch the inauguration of Russia’s new president, Dmitri Medvedev, on the Kremlin-backed, English-language, 24-hour television news channel Russia Today heard a man recite the oath of office in deep, rich tones that evoke power and authority, but it wasn’t the new president — it was a voice-over artist, dubbing Mr. Medvedev’s remarks into English.

headline: Clinton Lends Campaign $6 Million
text: Highlighting the financial woes of Clinton campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has lent her campaign more than $6 million over the last month, campaign officials said.

headline: Delta Blues
text: UPDATE 5/10, 10:30 p.m.: An op-ed piece by Amitav Gosh and my Week in Review story on the dangers of deltas both explore how some countries, in particular Mauritius and Bangladesh, have found ways to greatly cut vulnerability from cyclone storm surges.UPDATE, 5/9, 11:45 p.m.: On revelations that Al Gore radio comments on Cyclone Nargis and global warming were edited deceptively by Gore critics (see update at end of this post).

headline: The Horse That Changed the Crown
text: Reading Richard Dutrow’s comments on running Big Brown in the Preakness, you get the sense he’d rather just skip the race rather than run the horse back on two weeks of rest. But opting out of the second leg of the Triple Crown is just not done for the Derby winner, unless he’s been injured, like Grindstone in 1996. It’s been as unfashionable as a toupee at least since 1985 — the last time a healthy Derby winner took his tack elsewhere.

headline: Keeping the Bloom on a Rose of Many Other Colors
text: It’s a horticultural combination of “Project Runway” meets “American Idol,” and it’s supposed to transform a New York brand from “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” into “Sex and the City.”

headline: Geometries | The ‘Eggs’ in Brooklyn
text: The “eggs,” or digesters, at the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Brooklyn are going into operation. Each tank is 140 high and 80 feet wide. The eight steel eggs weigh about two million pounds apiece when empty, and it has been calculated that one may weigh up to 32 million pounds when it is processing waste. Two began running late last week; the remainder are expected to be at work by year’s end.

headline: Disney Posts Higher Earnings
text: CNBC interviews Robert A. Iger, Disney's chief executive, about the entertainment giant's better-than-expected earnings report.

headline: Microsoft May Build a Copyright Cop Into Every Zune
text: UPDATED | 10:25 PM Microsoft has posted an item on its Zune Insder blog related to this. See the end of this post.

headline: Cisco Beats the Street
text: Earnings results and a company outlook with John Chambers, Cisco chairman and C.E.O.

headline: UBS Banker Detained in Tax Inquiry
text: A top-ranking UBS executive was briefly detained by federal authorities in the United States in connection with a widening investigation into the Swiss bank’s work with questionable tax transactions, the bank said Wednesday.

headline: The I.O.C. Memo Prohibiting Political Displays by Athletes
text: Athletes who compete in the Beijing Olympics will not be allowed to wave flags, make gestures or even alter their “external appearance” to make a political statement, according to guidelines made public Tuesday by the International Olympic Committee.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Roasted Asparagus With Parmesan
text: Fat asparagus spears have their charms, but pencil-thin spears have two distinct advantages in a time-sensitive kitchen. They can be cooked without peeling, because their outer sheaths are so tender, and they cook so much faster, which is an asset for roasting.

headline: Because ‘the Big Apple’ Was Taken
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: ‘Whoa, Are You Kidding Me?’
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: How about the presidential Democratic campaign, the primaries? Whoa, are you kidding me? Today they’re in Indiana. My home state. And also North Carolina. And then, after that, they go to Canada. And then after the Canadian primaries, they go to Europe; they do the European primaries, and the election is still three years away.

headline: Disney Sees Healthy Spot Ad Market
