text: Associated Press: The writers’ strike “raised prices in the spot ad market as the lull in network shows shrunk available ad time. That bodes well for the upcoming upfront sales presentation to advertising agencies in New York, which will affect pricing for the coming fall TV season, Disney Chief Executive Robert Iger said” on a conference call with analysts Tuesday.

headline: Primaries: Analysts Assert The ‘Race Is Over’
text: Jim Rutenberg reports:

headline: A Homeless Life
text: Men who live underneath the Major Deegan Expressway talk about getting by. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Just Call Him Jesus
text: Locals muse about a neighborhood man they know as Jesus. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Reading the Signals at Sprint Nextel
text: Sprint Nextel has generated a lot of deal buzz this week. The wireless carrier just signed an agreement with Clearwire and a consortium of other companies to build a high-speed wireless Internet service. The deal came as two rumors were making the rounds: that Sprint might spin off or sell its beleaguered Nextel unit, or be bought by Deutsche Telekom, which operates the rival mobile service T-Mobile USA.

headline: Sundance Is Sold to Cablevision for $496 Million
text: Rainbow Media, the cable programming subsidiary of Cablevision, said Wednesday that it was purchasing the Sundance Channel, which shows independent films and other programming, for $496 million in stock and cash.

headline: Obama’s Gas Tax Benefit

headline: Scariest Place in the World to Buy a Car

Still warm from the photocopier, the single sheet of paper listed the usual items you’d expect to find on any economy car: good fuel economy figures, air-conditioning, automatic transmission, antilock brakes. But I couldn’t find a sticker price anywhere.

headline: Made in Africa
text: Children in a sunflower field in Lira, Uganda. The sunflower plant is used as a natural way to control pests on the cotton farms instead of using pesticides. The pests are attracted to and eat the sunflowers instead of the cotton plants nearby. (Photo: Nicole Mackinlay Hahn)Africa may be the second largest continent, but in the fashion world, it can be pretty darned difficult to find on the map. “Most American don’t know where Tunisia is,” exclaims Leslie Hoffman, the executive director of the environmental organization Earth Pledge. The could soon change. “Reap What You Sew,” a new interactive video installation at Barneys New York by the artist and filmmaker Nicole Mackinlay Hahn aims to connect items like Christian Louboutin pumps and Phillip B. beauty products (not to mention consumers) to their place in the African supply chain. No mean feat according to Julie Gilhart, Barneys Fashion Director. “We asked all of the buyers where their products were made, and a lot of them didn’t even know,” she says. Hahn spent several years traveling all over Africa, documenting people at work and at play. Some 200 clips — from the enlightening (factory workers dying fabric) to the entertaining (a group of men practicing their dance moves set to multiple versions of Toto’s “Africa”) — are on view on the ninth floor at Barneys through the end of May. Hahn predicts that the RFID technology she used to make her art piece (the same used to create E-Z Pass) will soon be the norm in the retail world, ushering in a new age of accountability for producers and consumers alike. And she has a point: If you could click on an image of the sweatshop where your sneakers were constructed by 11-year-olds, would you still buy them?

headline: Greinke’s Royals Comeback
text: In 2004, Zach Greinke made his major league debut at the age of 20, becoming one of the youngest players in Royals history. Selected sixth overall in the 2002 draft, he was considered a can’t-miss prospect, but he never quite fit in. He soon became withdrawn and unhappy. It all came to a head in 2006 during spring training when Greinke decided to walk away from baseball.

headline: Putting a Merger in Reverse
text: When auto parts suppliers Arvin Industries and Meritor Automotive came together as and ArvinMeritor back in 2000, the merger was heralded as “a perfect fit” by Larry Yost, chairman and chief executive of Meritor. headline: The Morning Skate: Coaches in the Crosshairs and Bob Dylan
text: The guys were all in the room this morning, lacing up their skates and getting ready. The jokes were flying and then someone said, “Are the playoffs over? Who won?” It wasn’t a ha-ha funny kind of joke, yet it was weird funny because after a month of great games almost every night, there’s been nothing since Sunday (well, early Monday morning) and there won’t be anything until tomorrow night.

headline: Why Superstition Is Logical
text: Are you superstitious? I like to think I’m not, but I’m reconsidering after seeing the research of Jane Risen and the other psychologists mentioned in my Findings column. Dr. Risen, a professor at the University of Chicago, knows better than anyone how irrational superstition is. But consider what she does on plane trips.

headline: Amsterdam, Part Two: Localism Can Be Global
text: With all the recent talk (and writing and blogging and sermonizing) about localism — generally speaking, an emphasis on fresh, local ingredients in cooking with an eye toward environmental conscientiousness — it’s nice to know that it’s not all just chatter. And though spots like Blue Hill at Stone Barns in New York and, more famously, Chez Panisse in northern California, have cult localist followings, it’s not just being preached and practiced in the coastal states. In Amsterdam, a restaurant called De Kas, in its eighth year, is turning out quality food using herbs, fruits and vegetables from its on-site nursery; meat from a local purveyor; and fresh fish caught in the nearby Wadden and North Seas.

headline: Gilding the Flute
text: My column in today’s newspaper is a bit of a rant, to use a bloggish word, which is only a appropriate since it stems from the trio of posts concerning “The Wine Trials,’’ a new book by Robin Goldstein. I don’t want to rehash the discussion here, except to say that the column takes off from those posts to ask both whether anybody can really know what goes on in the minds of wine consumers, and whether it’s really beneficial to try to strip away the context so that wine can be judged solely by what’s in the glass. I’ll say no more – for now – except that I welcome any comments on the column right here, although in this post I want to head in an altogether different direction.

In this first installment, Danny gives us a running diary, beginning with the tournament selection show and encompassing topics as varied as a team dinner at Chili’s and the sexual shenanigans of the ancient Greeks. Bad news is — Kristof just got shot in the head with a blowgun. Good news is — we got it on video.”

headline: Working — or Not — After a Death in the  Family
text: It has been quiet at Shifting Careers this week because I took an unexpected trip to Florida for a death in my family. I was only gone three days. But because I left suddenly, I have returned to a personal and work life in chaos. Meetings and appointments missed need to be rescheduled. Deadlines that were comfortably far away are now looming. E-mail and phone messages have piled up. And since I left Florida long before processing the loss, I am trying to get back into work when my mind is still down there with my mourning relatives.

headline: These Lofts Have a Downside
text: The living spaces are cramped at the McKibbin, a Brooklyn landing pad for hundreds of post-collegiate creative types.

headline: Your Comments on my Election Column
text: My Thursday column argues that Senator Clinton has virtually no chance of winning the Democratic nomination if she stays in the race, but a significant chance of helping Senator McCain. I’m particularly troubled by the latest exit polls in which a majority of her supporters say they will not vote for Senator Obama in the fall if he is the nominee. How seriously should we take that? Any of you Clinton fans out there who are so angry at Obama fans that you would vote for McCain — and if so, you want to explain why?

headline: Turkey acts swiftly to lift restriction on sales to foreigners
text: Investors and agents in Turkey are certainly breathing a sigh of relief after the government moved quickly to reinstate the ability of foreigners to buy property. Sales to foreigners were temporarily suspended last month, in order to give the Turkish legislature a chance to rework regulations.

headline: MTV Promoting Its ‘Podbusting’ Techniques
