headline: Returning to the Track
text: Giant Moon completed his last major work for the Preakness this morning at Belmont Park. He went five-eighths in 1:01.04. He worked in company, and it was the sixth-fastest work of 26 at the same distance. He will have one more, lighter work at Belmont before shipping to Pimlico.

headline: Eddy Arnold, Country Singer, Is Dead
text: NASHVILLE  Eddy Arnold, the gentleman crooner who took country music uptown and sold more than 85 million recordings over seven decades, died Thursday. He was 89.

headline: Cablevision Unit Buys Sundance Channel
text: Rainbow Media, the cable programming subsidiary of Cablevision, said Wednesday that it was purchasing the Sundance Channel, which shows independent films and other programming, for $496 million in stock and cash.

headline: Another Casualty of Digital TV
text: Q. For years, I’ve used the TV band on portable radios for listening to the audio portion of talking-head programs. Will I still be able to do this next year after the switch to digital transmissions?

headline: Bush’s Threat Provokes House Skirmish on Housing Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Emboldened by President Bush’s threat to veto a Democratic plan to help homeowners in danger of foreclosure, House Republicans threw up repeated roadblocks to delay debate of the legislation on Wednesday, prompting an angry argument between party leaders over procedural tactics.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Tuesday about an agreement between Microsoft and the Hyundai Kia Automotive Group to develop software for voice control over cellphones and entertainment systems in automobiles misstated the name of the software. It is Microsoft Auto  not Microsoft Automotive or Windows Automotive, which is a separate platform for use in vehicles.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on April 18 about the Senate’s vote to direct the Justice Department to investigate how a change was made in a 2005 transportation bill misstated the location where Senator Barbara Boxer spoke against having a bicameral investigative committee. It was on the Senate floor, not the House floor.

headline: Peak Health, Maybe, but Not Peak Times
text: It's a question that crosses the mind of many triathletes: Is it possible to peak in more than one sport at once? As Gina Kolata reports today in The Times, the training necessary to excel in one sport will likely counteract what's necessary to be good in another. But that simple fact doesn't stop many athletes from complaining about their times, saying, for example, that they aren't running as fast as they think they should be. "I have conversations with them," said Joel Friel, a coach and author of 10 books, including "The Triathlete's Training Bible" (VeloPress, 2004). "Do you really want to be a triathlete? If you want to run faster you have to give up swimming and cycling."

headline: 216 Held in Protests of Police Acquittals
text: In the largest public protest against the acquittal of three detectives in the shooting death of Sean Bell, 216 people were arrested on Wednesday in carefully orchestrated demonstrations that halted traffic at busy intersections in Manhattan and Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A theater review last Thursday about “Thurgood,” a one-man show about Thurgood Marshall at the Booth Theater, referred incorrectly, at one point, to the Supreme Court’s 1896 ruling in Plessy v. Ferguson in citing Marshall’s efforts to end segregation while chief counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. As noted elsewhere in the review, the ruling enshrined de jure segregation (segregation by law), not simply de facto segregation (segregation in fact).

headline: Support for Clinton Wanes as Obama Sees Finish Line
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture on Wednesday about continuing her presidential bid despite waning support from Democratic officials and donors. Some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.

headline: Meadowlands Commission Cuts Ties With Developer
text: After years of legal and political wrangling and hundreds of millions of dollars in public money, the New Jersey Meadowlands Commission voted Wednesday to end its relationship with a developer that wanted to build thousands of homes and a golf course atop several landfills.

headline: Americans Are Heaviest Bidders on Impressionist and Modern Art at Sotheby’s
text: Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday proved to be a solid if unexciting evening. Experts there, however, pronounced it “fantastic,” as if to again reassure buyers and sellers that the art market was alive and well despite setbacks in the financial and real estate markets.

headline: Britain: Last Call on the London Tube
text: London’s new mayor, Boris Johnson, left, said that he was banning alcohol on the city’s public transportation system, effective next month, in an effort to “end the problem of drunken and intimidating behavior on the Tube.” Some subway workers said they welcomed the move as a way to change the unpleasant late-night atmosphere in the subways. But Bob Crow, general secretary of the union representing transportation employees, said the plan had been put into place too hastily and would be difficult to enforce. “Perhaps the mayor will come out with his underpants on over his trousers like Superman one Saturday to show us how it should be done,” he told Agence France-Presse.

headline: Letters
text: Kiss and Tell

headline: Would-Be Rescuers Can’t Save Jersey City Woman From Fire
text: JERSEY CITY  First, a police officer and a firefighter who happened to be nearby tried unsuccessfully to make their way into the burning apartment here on Wednesday morning, but smoke drove them back. Then a Hudson County freeholder tried to make his way in, but somehow cut his hands in the effort before smoke pushed him back, too.

headline: Gadget Fanatics, Take Note
text: Sooner or later, almost everything goes digital: cameras, camcorders, music players, TV, books, you name it.

headline: The Energy Battles
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Uneven Playing Field
text: Janelle Pierson, a high school senior in Florida, has traveled like a professional athlete since her early teens, flying around the country to play in soccer tournaments. She has also suffered ruptures of the anterior cruciate ligament, or A.C.L., in both knees. In this week's New York Times Magazine, Michael Sokolove, a regular contributor to Play, describes Pierson's singular dedication to soccer, and how she, like so many other young female athletes and several of her teammates, has endured serious injuries. The article is adapted from Sokolove's new book, "Warrior Girls: Protecting Our Daughters Against the Injury Epidemic in Women's Sports," which will be published in June.

headline: This Taste of the Big Top Has a Big Board Flavor
text: For its first season with theater as a permanent component of its arts programming, the World Financial Center has commissioned “Corporate Carnival,” a premiere by the Women’s Project that weaves sideshow and circus shenanigans into a narrative about the financial world.

headline: Transformation Includes Sacrifice
text: Hillsborough, N.J.

headline: Jefferson Charged With Assault
text: Nets forward Richard Jefferson was charged in a Minneapolis court Wednesday with choking a man who said Jefferson crashed his private birthday party in January.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Foreign

headline: After Indiana and North Carolina
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Welfare of Racehorses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A picture caption on April 29 with the continuation of a music column about the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif., omitted the name of the large sculpture shown in a photograph of fans and the name of its creator. The sculpture is by Mike Ross and is called “Big Rig Jig.”

headline: China Orchestra Plays for Pope for First Time, Hinting at Thaw
text: VATICAN CITY  The China Philharmonic Orchestra performed Mozart’s Requiem with the Shanghai Opera House Chorus for Pope Benedict XVI on Wednesday, an unprecedented concert that could signal a thaw in the historically chilly relations between the Vatican and the Chinese government.

headline: New Vision for Catskill Development, Without Cards
text: THOMPSON, N.Y.  This once-prosperous resort town, where the ghosts of bustling hotels loom from wooded roadsides, was dealt a serious blow earlier this year when the federal government quashed a decades-long effort to bring casino gambling to the Catskills.

headline: Claude Rosenberg, Advocate for Philanthropy, Is Dead at 80
text: Claude Rosenberg, who made a fortune managing other people’s money and then began persuading the rich that they could significantly increase their charitable giving while also shrinking their tax bill, died Saturday near his home in San Francisco. He was 80.

headline: In His Visit to Japan, China Leader Seeks Amity
text: TOKYO  The leaders of China and Japan pledged Wednesday to make their nations partners instead of rivals as the Chinese president, Hu Jintao, began a good-will mission to Tokyo aimed at improving often tense relations between the Asian powers.

headline: Cuomo Accuses Power Authority Officials of Erasing E-Mail of Investigation Target
text: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo accused officials at the New York Power Authority on Wednesday of erasing e-mail messages kept by Daniel Wiese, the authority’s inspector general and a key figure facing scrutiny in Mr. Cuomo’s wide-ranging investigation of the State Police.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the Flushing area of Queens, included a quotation from City Councilman John C. Liu, whose district includes Flushing, that referred incorrectly to Main Street there. There are Main Streets in the Bronx and Brooklyn, and on Roosevelt Island and Staten Island; the Main Street in Flushing is not the only one in New York City.

headline: Amy Winehouse Arrested Again
text: The Grammy Award-winning soul singer Amy Winehouse was arrested on Wednesday in London on suspicion of drug offenses and held after she turned herself in at a police station, Reuters reported, citing the police. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was released less than two weeks ago with a caution after accusations of assault. The police declined to give further details.

headline: Clashes in General Strike in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Supporters of the Iranian-backed group Hezbollah, trying to enforce a general strike called by labor unions, clashed with government supporters and blocked roads in Beirut on Wednesday, escalating tensions as the country remained mired in its worst political crisis since the 1975-1990 civil war.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article in some editions on Friday about the fatal stabbing of a Brooklyn teenager gave an erroneous surname from a relative for the victim. He was Renato Scantlebury, not Rowe.

headline: Argentina: Ash Cloud Grounds Flights as It Spreads
text: Major Argentine airlines suspended flights to some cities in Patagonia as the huge ash cloud from the Chaitén volcano in Chile blew east into Argentina. Although people in Argentina have not been evacuated, the authorities in affected areas have suspended classes and distributed face masks and drinking water. At least 8,000 have been evacuated in Chile since the volcano’s eruption on Friday.

headline: MTV Plans to Increase Its Blending of Ads and Shows
text: Every year at this time, networks pitch advertisers on their programs for the coming year in previews called the upfronts. On Thursday, MTV Networks will sell not only the appeal of its programs but of its commercials as well.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Thursday about David Benner, a Pennsylvania gardener who gives tours of his moss garden in the first two weeks of May, gave an incorrect e-mail address for him. The correct address is bigdavebigsue@hotmail.com.

headline: Madonna Is No. 1
text: As expected, the new Madonna album, “Hard Candy” (Warner Brothers), has opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, selling 280,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The only surprise is that a relatively high 26 percent of its sales were digital downloads. “Hard Candy” bumped the chart-topper for the last two weeks, Mariah Carey’s “E=MC2” (Island), to second place with sales of 95,000; Leona Lewis’s “Spirit” (Syco/J) falls one to No. 3 with 84,000. This week’s chart is busy with new releases, though sales were unexceptional. Lyfe Jennings’s “Lyfe Change” (Columbia) opens at No. 4 with 80,000; Def Leppard is No. 5 with “Songs of the Sparkle Lounge” (Island), moving 55,000; the Roots open at No. 6 with 54,000 sales of “Rising Down” (Def Jam); and Portishead’s first new album in 11 years, “Third” (Mercury/Island), bows at No. 7 with 53,000. Tom Petty’s project Mudcrutch is No. 8 with its self-titled album on Reprise Records, and Tim McGraw’s “Greatest Hits” Limited Edition” (Curb) is No. 10.

headline: As News Corporation Posts Wide Gains, Murdoch Keeps His Sights on Newsday
text: In the News Corporation’s earnings conference call on Wednesday, Rupert Murdoch voiced skepticism that Cablevision can succeed in its bid for Newsday, which is now at the center of a tussle among three New York moguls, even as he vowed not to get into a bidding war for the newspaper.

headline: U.S. Detains Executive, Deepening UBS Inquiry
text: A top-ranking UBS executive was briefly detained by federal authorities in the United States in connection with a widening investigation into the Swiss bank’s work with questionable tax transactions, the bank said Wednesday.

headline: A Pioneering Driver Spins Tales, Not Wheels
text: FREWSBURG, N.Y.  There was a faraway look in Lloyd Moore’s eyes as he recalled racing against a Nascar legend.

headline: White House and Democrats Move on Ohio Court Plan
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats and the White House moved ahead Wednesday with a compromise to break a years-long impasse over approving judges for the federal appeals court based in Ohio.

headline: A World Beyond Comprehension (but You Know You Love to Hate It)
text: Neku Sakuraba hates his life. The 15-year-old hates the crowded city, hates people, and in the beginning of The World Ends with You finds something new to hate: a cell phone text message telling him to complete a mysterious task or face “erasure.” He also hates the countdown timer that suddenly appears on the palm of his hand, the bizarre frogs that attack him and the spunky girl named Shiki who insists on following him around.

headline: N.F.L. Is Taking Cable Fight to the F.C.C.
text: Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, said this week in a Federal Communications Commission filing that Comcast removed the NFL Network from a broadly available digital tier as retaliation for the league’s not selling eight regular-season games each season to Comcast’s Versus channel. The games went to the NFL Network.

headline: Mural Tests Vermont Law That Forbids Billboards
text: BELLOWS FALLS, Vt.  It was meant to be a throwback to the days of romantic Sunday drives  a mural painted on the side of a red barn urging passing drivers to “See Bellows Falls,” a town whose Main Street conjures up bygone days.

headline: Medvedev Takes Oath in Russia, but Putin Dominates Much of Day
text: MOSCOW  Dmitri A. Medvedev, the Kremlin insider and unprepossessing lawyer who had never held elected office before, was sworn in as Russia’s president on Wednesday inside the Grand Kremlin Palace.

headline: Tape Time
text: The Patriot Tapes live on. The Times reported today that the league received eight tapes showing that the Patriots recorded the play-calling signals in six games between 2000 and 2002. Not all details are known, but the question can be raised: Will the additional taping revelations affect the way people regard the accomplishments of Bill Belichick and his recent teams?

headline: The Torch en Route
text: It’s been a while since we last gave thought to the Olympic torch. Where is the little guy these days, anyway? Still getting good hotel rooms?

headline: Former Guantánamo Detainee Tied to Attack
text: BAGHDAD  A former Kuwaiti detainee at the United States prison camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was one of the bombers in a string of deadly suicide attacks in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul last month, the American military said Wednesday.

headline: Morgan Sparks, Bell Scientist, Dies at 91
text: Morgan Sparks, who made critical contributions to developing the second-generation transistor, which became a building block of modern electronic devices, died on Saturday at his daughter’s home in Fullerton, Calif. He was 91.

headline: All That Jazz in Montreal
text: The 29th Festival International de Jazz de Montréal, which is being dedicated to Oscar Peterson, will run from June 26 to July 6 and present more than 3,000 musicians from Aretha Franklin to Woody Allen, as well as Leonard Cohen, Abbey Lincoln, Dianne Reeves, James Taylor, the Wailers, Ravi Coltrane and Steely Dan. In tribute to Peterson, the piano virtuoso who died at 82 last winter, a series within the festival will feature pianists including Hank Jones, McCoy Tyner and Dave Brubeck, according to a statement. The Georgian-born British singer Katie Melua will perform at the opening concert. ... The saxophonist Sonny Rollins will headline the JVC Jazz Festival Newport, held from Aug. 8 through 10 at Fort Adams State Park and the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I., The Associated Press reported. More than two dozen acts, including the pianist-composer Herbie Hancock and the trumpeter Chris Botti, will be among the performers. ... Queen, Leona Lewis, Annie Lennox, Shirley Bassey and the Soweto Gospel Choir will be among the performers on June 27 at a concert in London to celebrate the 90th birthday of former South African President Nelson Mandela and to benefit his AIDS charity, the BBC reported. The number of tickets for the event in Hyde Park will be 46,664, Mr. Mandela’s old prison number.

headline: Hitting the Wall and the Ball, the Mets Lack for Nothing
text: LOS ANGELES  When outfielder Ángel Pagán went tumbling headfirst into the seats along the left-field line to make a daring catch of a pop fly in the first inning, it was a sign that Wednesday might be different for the Mets.

headline: At Rail Hub, Bird Will Still Soar, but With a Bit Less Polish
text: They have not clipped the wings of the birdlike structure that is to be the aesthetic centerpiece of the World Trade Center transportation hub and PATH terminal, but Port Authority officials now plan to shrink it as they search for ways to keep the project within a $2.5 billion budget.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Art on Park Avenue

headline: Tip of the Week: Saving a Little Bit of the Earth
text: If you’re not eating lunch at your desk or working all night, you can save electricity  and maybe even a little bit of the earth  by setting your computer’s monitor to turn off automatically after a few minutes of inactivity. This advice may seem rather basic, but about half of Americans don’t do this, according to a Harris poll last year.

headline: With Divorce Almost Complete, a Happy Collaboration (With Lots of Help)
text: Though the relationship between the conductor Christoph Eschenbach and the players of the Philadelphia Orchestra clearly did not work out, the reasons are still being debated. Even critics in Philadelphia cannot seem to agree. Whatever the case, Mr. Eschenbach, who became the orchestra’s music director in 2003, will leave at the end of this season.

headline: Acquittal in Nun’s Killing Provokes Outcry in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Human rights advocates and the Brazilian government on Wednesday sharply criticized the acquittal of a man accused of being behind the murder of an American Roman Catholic nun in the Brazilian Amazon forest.

headline: Airbus Suffers Setback to Recovery Plans
text: In the latest setback to its recovery program, Airbus, the airplane manufacturer, said Wednesday that tighter credit and the weakening dollar had forced it to break off talks with a second supplier over the sale of European factories.

headline: TV Guide, Having Just Been Bought, Is Bracing to Be Sold
text: Days after getting new owners and new editors, the long-troubled TV Guide is back on the block.

headline: A Son’s Death, a Mother’s Agony, a Country’s Shame
text: There is no trace of football on the cover of Mary Tillman’s book about her son, Pat. In the early pages, he is a rambunctious child, climbing out of his crib, speaking his first words, slipping out the bedroom window into an adjacent tree.

headline: In Women, Natural Testosterone
text: Do some elite female athletes get an advantage from having abnormal ovaries? That's the intriguing question raised by work recently completed by scientists in Sweden. During their extensive study of all the athletes who competed for Sweden in the 2002 or 2004 Olympic Games, an anomaly emerged among the female team members that researchers believe may have improved their athleticism.

headline: CURRENTS | A Folding Desk by Poggenpohl Lets You Work While Dining
text: Most people do far more than just eat at the dining table: it has become a place to work, pay bills and read the newspaper. With that in mind, Poggenpohl is introducing the Dining Desk, a table that slides open to reveal a panel down the center with functional inserts like cutlery trays, chopping boards, stainless-steel compartments for putting beverages on ice, and trolleys with nonstick thermal tableware and grill plates. The desk comes in two lengths (79 and 99 inches) and various materials. Prices range from about $7,000 for a basic version in marsh-oak veneer to $47,000 for the Statuario marble version with all the extras, seen here. Information is at (973) 812-8900 or poggenpohl-usa.com.

headline: Disney’s Newly Crowned Prince, Plucked From a London Stage
text: LOS ANGELES  As jarring moments go, the action figure in his likeness was nothing compared to the billboard on the Sunset Strip. There he was, towering eight stories above the boutiques and rock clubs, with sword brandished, lips pursed and “The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian” emblazoned across his legs. “This has to be one of the weirdest moments of my life,” said Ben Barnes, the young British actor who plays the title role in the coming movie. He backed up to take in the advertisement’s full effect. “I have no comprehension of what’s about to happen to me, do I?”

headline: Frances Yeend, Soprano at City Opera and the Met, Dies at 95
text: Frances Yeend, an internationally known soprano who appeared regularly with the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera in the decades after World War II, died on April 27 in Morgantown, W.Va. She was 95 and lived in Morgantown.

headline: Dharma in the Dirt
text: MUIR BEACH, Calif.

headline: Citi to Send a Top Banker to Dubai
text: Citigroup announced late Wednesday that it was moving one of its most senior investment bankers to the Middle East, hoping to establish a stronger foothold in the oil-rich region.

headline: Generic Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An Inside The Times capsule summary on Sunday of an article about the birthplace of Jell-O misidentified the state in some editions. It is Le Roy, N.Y.  not N.J.

headline: CIRCUITS | Timekeeper for Techies Turns 25 in Style
text: Next to the plastic pocket protector, there is probably no better-known artifact of the nerd than the Casio G-Shock watch. But the chunky digital watch, created in 1983, has become a fashion item on the wrists of those who aren’t necessarily technologically inclined.

headline: New Math for Men: Subtract Just a Little Gray
text: TRIPS to the colorist every six weeks are not a matter of ego or vanity for Tony Hayman, a film editor living in Burbank, Calif.

headline: For the Democrats, Signs of a Possible Changing of the Guard
text: After 16 years, the Clinton era may be coming to an end, presenting Democrats with a historic but potentially wrenching transition and a challenge to Senator Barack Obama as he seeks to reconcile a deeply divided party.

headline: Berlusconi Chooses Cabinet, Reuniting a Familiar Cast
text: Silvio Berlusconi prepared on Wednesday to take power for the third time as Italy’s prime minister, announcing a slimmed-down cabinet of familiar faces aimed at overcoming an immobile economy and years of political paralysis. He is expected to be sworn in on Thursday.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article in some editions on April 22 about customer reaction to calorie counts posted in some coffee shops and fast-food restaurants in New York City misspelled the surname of a Starbucks customer who said posting the numbers would not be good for business. He is Bruno Mastropasqua, not Mastropasqui.

headline: Iranian Exiles Aren’t Terrorist Group, British Court Says
text: LONDON  After a seven-year legal battle, Britain’s Court of Appeal ruled Wednesday that the British government was wrong to include an Iranian resistance group, the People’s Mujahedeen of Iran, on its list of banned terrorist groups.

headline: A Treasure Is Restored, With Culture Its Bounty
text: MOSCOW  The program of Bach and Mozart, featuring Pinchas Zukerman accompanied by the Bolshoi Theater Orchestra, was not the usual fare for a Moscow night spot. Then again, this was not the usual night spot.

headline: At Tammany ... Err ... City Hall
text: The legendary George Washington Plunkitt, who proudly labeled his brand of politics “honest graft” almost a century ago, would certainly recognize the scene these days in New York City Hall. City Council members have been in revolt, aghast that Speaker Christine Quinn dared to try to make them account for the way they toss around public money. Some were so angry that they wanted to toss Ms. Quinn out of the top council job.

headline: Italian Sculptor Attuned to the Harmonic Occupation of Space
text: Moving freely among plaster, ceramics and metal, the Italian artist Fausto Melotti (1901-1986) defied the convention of the sculptor invested in a single medium. His work has been linked to the cagelike Surrealist constructions of Alberto Giacometti, the early wire sculptures of Lucio Fontana, the paintings of Giorgio de Chirico and even the playful mobiles of Alexander Calder.

headline: Correction: A Blacklash?
text: A graphic accompanying Charles Blow’s column on Saturday, about polling results for Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, misstated the date of the start of data for Mr. Obama. It was Jan. 21, 2007, not 2008.

headline: City Council in Bay Area Declares Bankruptcy
text: VALLEJO, Calif.  In a potentially ominous harbinger for some cities in California and elsewhere, the Vallejo City Council voted to declare bankruptcy Tuesday night in the face of dwindling tax revenues, the housing market meltdown and a faltering economy.

headline: New Hope for Old Chestnuts
text: New Hope for Old Chestnuts

headline: Toyota Feels Slowdown in U.S.
text: TOKYO  Toyota Motor said Thursday that the slowdown in the United States economy would probably cause its first annual profit drop in nine years, accelerating a shift by it and other Asian car manufacturers into emerging markets like China, Latin America and the Middle East.

headline: A Casting Call for Sexy Cars (Hybrids Need Not Apply)
text: LOS ANGELES  It is cleaner than a smoking Beetle. Quieter than a roaring Mini. Able to leap through car pool lanes with a single occupant. But the Prius, car du jour among Hollywood insiders, is not looking much like movie star.

headline: CURRENTS | A New Book Looks Inside 20 Greenwich Village Houses
text: More than a century and a half before Greenwich Village became one of New York’s most desirable neighborhoods, the architectural bones were laid by the newly prosperous merchant class. “The Houses of Greenwich Village” (Abrams, $45), a new book by Kevin D. Murphy, takes readers inside 20 homes to show how the interiors evolved over time with the residents’ needs. A modest row house from 1827, for example, was renovated in 1893 to transform it into a space appropriate for Robert Blum, a celebrated artist interested in “Japonisme.” And in 2003, an 1801 town house was renovated by Ben Cherner and Emma O’Neill, architects who turned it into four Modernist apartments with a penthouse that blurs the boundaries between indoor and outdoor space. Don’t look for celebrity homes; Mr. Murphy omitted homeowners’ names to protect their privacy. But photographs by Paul Rocheleau provide plenty of insider access.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: The Critics’ Choice column on Monday about new CDs misidentified the composer of “King Korn,” a song on the new album “January” by the Marcin Wasilewski Trio. It is by Carla Bley  not Paul Bley, her former husband.

headline: After All This Time, Rivera Is Keeping It Simply Unhittable
text: Mariano Rivera does not overanalyze the incredible success he has had as a closer. Not now, not ever. He prefers to view his exploits in a simple way. He throws one pitch and he expects to get batters out. No overanalyzing needed.

headline: Myanmar Faces Pressure to Allow Major Aid Effort
text: BANGKOK  As hungry, shivering survivors waited among the dead for help after a huge cyclone in Myanmar, aid agencies and diplomats said Wednesday that the delivery of relief supplies was being slowed by the reluctance of the country’s secretive military leaders to allow an influx of outsiders.

headline: India: Trading in Food Futures Suspended
text: India has expanded bans on trading of food futures as the government intensifies efforts to cool inflation that is at the highest level in more than three years. Trading in soybean oil, potatoes and chick peas will be suspended on exchanges including the Multi Commodity Exchange of India, said Anupam Mishra, a director at the Forward Markets Commission, an industry regulator. Trading in rubber futures will also be suspended. “We have written to the exchanges asking them to ban trading in these four commodities with immediate effect,” Mr. Mishra said Wednesday night in a telephone interview. “This ban will remain for at least for four months.”

headline: Colorado: Lesbian Couple Guilty of Trespassing for Sit-In
text: A lesbian couple from Englewood was found guilty of trespassing by a Denver jury, in a case stemming from a brief sit-in they staged on Sept. 24, when the Denver Clerk and Recorder’s Office refused to grant them a marriage license. The couple, Sheila Schroeder and Kate Burns, had sought to overturn Colorado’s ban on same-sex marriage, contending that it violated their right to equal protection, but Judge James B. Breese of Denver County Court told the six-woman jury to focus on the trespassing charge. The women will each have to pay $41 in court fines and serve 28 hours of community service. “This was an excellent opportunity for them to stand proudly as Americans and exercise their First Amendment rights to protest what they believe was an unfair law that treated people unequally,” said Mari Newman, a lawyer for the couple.

headline: An Event That Doesn't Necessarily Need Woods
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  If it is a measure of a golf event’s stature that the absence of Tiger Woods is causing no cold sweats, either at the network broadcasting it or the governing body organizing it, then the Players Championship is really breathing in some of the rarefied air reserved for golf’s four major championships.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about Lightstone Group, a New York real estate company facing challenges in paying its debt, misstated the name of a research company that tracks commercial mortgage-backed securities and gave an outdated description of its ownership. It is Realpoint L.L.C.  not Realpoint Research  and it is now an independent company, no longer a division of Capmark.

headline: Police Beating of Suspects Is Taped by TV Station in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA  About 12 police officers were videotaped on Monday beating three men stopped in response to a drug-related shooting, and six of the officers have been removed from patrols, Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey said Wednesday.

headline: The Tax Trickery Spreads
text: It was bad enough when Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain decided to engage in some petty pandering by calling for a suspension of the federal gas tax over the summer. What they suggested would reduce needed tax revenues and hamper efforts to combat global warming. And it would fail to deliver lower prices while giving oil companies more money. But neither senator is actually running the country, so it might be tempting to chalk it all up to campaign pandering.

headline: European Bank Stays Course on Rates
text: ATHENS  The European Central Bank on Thursday said that Europe’s economy remained resilient despite nearly nine months of financial turmoil and it left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent. The bank gave no sign that it was in a hurry to raise or lower borrowing costs.

headline: Raid on Sect in Texas Rattles Other Polygamists
text: COLORADO CITY, Ariz.  As the supper dishes were being cleared away and the rice pudding brought out for dessert, Marvin Wyler’s two wives, along with some of their children and a group of friends, began poring over the list.

headline: Oil Giants to Settle Water Suit
text: Some of the nation’s largest oil companies have agreed to pay about $423 million in cash to settle a lawsuit brought by more than a hundred public water providers, claiming water contamination from a popular gasoline additive.

headline: On the Web
text: IN THE LATEST setback to its recovery program, Airbus, the airplane manufacturer, said tighter credit and the weakening dollar had forced it to break off talks over the sale of European factories. NICOLA CLARK

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about television appearances on Sunday by Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated the channel for “Fox News Sunday.” It is Fox Broadcasting, the over-the-air network  not Fox News Channel, a cable channel. (Both are part of the Fox Entertainment Group.)

headline: $271 Million for Research on Stem Cells in California
text: LOS ANGELES  California has awarded $271 million in grants to build 12 stem cell research centers in the state, even as one of the political rationales for the building program might soon disappear.

headline: Goats Eat Free at the Getty
text: The Getty Center in Los Angeles has contracted about 60 goats, including the one shown above, to eat the brush on its 110 acres. If left unmanaged, the brush could serve as fuel for wildfires.

headline: Correction: Dungeons & Austrians
text: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about a woman kept in a dungeon in Austria, misstated the native country of Sigmund Freud. His birthplace, Freiberg, once part of the Austrian Empire, is now known as Pribor, Czech Republic. It is not in Austria.

headline: Confrontation in Lebanon Appears to Escalate
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The decision by the Lebanese government to shut down a private telephone network operated by the Iranian-backed group Hezbollah was an act of war and Hezbollah would defend itself, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, said on Thursday.

headline: Bush Vows to Veto Housing-Relief Bill in House
text: WASHINGTON  As the House prepared to vote on a housing-relief bill offered by Democratic leaders, President Bush on Wednesday told the lawmakers, in effect, not to bother.

headline: BlackRock Is Fix-It Firm to Manage Risky Assets of Others in Distress
text: One Saturday morning in March, Laurence D. Fink got some urgent news: Wall Street needed his help.

headline: A Long List of Big Issues for F.A.A.
text: WASHINGTON  With its more rigorous oversight of airplane maintenance having led to the recent grounding of thousands of flights, the Federal Aviation Administration is confronting long-term questions about whether it should act more like a tough regulator, rather than a partner, of the airlines.

headline: Hit by Fire, a Texas University Looks to Rebuild
text: SAN ANTONIO  Officials of a Roman Catholic university here vowed on Wednesday to rebuild after a fire on Tuesday night substantially damaged the Gothic-style Main Building, which serves as both its administrative offices and its signature on the city’s skyline.

headline: The Too-Long Goodbye
text: After the Tuesday primaries, Hillary Rodham Clinton now has maybe a 2 percent chance of winning the Democratic nomination. But if she pursues her losing battle, she has perhaps a 20 percent chance of costing the Democrats the presidency in the fall.

headline: Players From Smaller Colleges Honored
text: The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame, which chose 13 players and 2 coaches from major colleges last week, added 4 players and 2 coaches from smaller colleges. The players were defensive end John Randle of Texas A&M-Kingsville (1988-89), quarterback Jim Ballard of Mount Union (1991-93), linebacker Ronald McKinnon of North Alabama (1992-95) and halfback Brad Rowland of McMurry (1947-50). The coaches were W. C. Gorden of Jackson State (1976-91) and Doug Porter of Mississippi Valley State (1961-65), Howard (1974-78) and Fort Valley State (1979-96).

headline: Ground Zero’s Train in a Box, Above a Forest of Steel
text: The people don’t always ride in a hole in the ground. Those aboard the No. 1 train in Lower Manhattan are now riding part of the way through the air.

headline: The 18-Cent Solution
text: Fairfax, Va.

headline: Platypus Looks Strange on the Inside, Too
text: If it has a bill and webbed feet like a duck, lays eggs like a bird or a reptile but also produces milk and has a coat of fur like a mammal, what could the genetics of the duck-billed platypus possibly be like? Well, just as peculiar: an amalgam of genes reflecting significant branching and transitions in evolution.

headline: City Officials on Investment Trip
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  City Hall is headed to Belfast.

headline: Sex? Yawn. Politics? That’s Hot!
text: A FORMER editor of People magazine had some hard-and-fast rules: young is better than old, pretty is better than ugly, television is better than music, music is better than movies, movies are better than sports.

headline: When Web Time Is Playtime
text: IF you’ve been noticing an increase in the number of smudgy fingerprints on your computer screen, it may be because your young children are spending more time online. With new services coming from companies like Lego and Disney that are aimed right at them, it might be wise to keep some glass cleaner nearby.

headline: Amid Talk of the End and Boos From the Crowd, Clinton Carries On
text: SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s greatest gift may be her ability to remain upright and smiling as chaos and chagrin surround her.

headline: Stripes That Are Seen, Not Heard
text: JUST as Nostradamus predicted, dress shirt mania has spread mightily in this millennium. Just look at how the top-drawer British shirting firm Thomas Pink has grown in the last decade, adding 54 stores worldwide to the 18 it operated in 1998. If this success rankles Brooks Brothers, whose shirts were for decades a kind of oxford standard, at least Brooks can gloat that a signature look from its archives is having a comeback. The stripped-down striped shirt, in simple oxford or broadcloth, is looking sharp again.

headline: D’Antoni Awaits Offers From Knicks and Bulls
text: Rick Carlisle is nearly off the market, and Mike D’Antoni  who never officially hit the market  could be the next top-tier N.B.A. coach to land a new job.

headline: A Reclusive Government, Forced to Ask for Help
text: BANGKOK  In opening its doors to international disaster relief, Myanmar’s military government is breaching a wall of isolation it has built around itself over nearly half a century.

headline: Today in Business
text: OIL SETTLEMENT About a dozen oil companies agreed to pay $423 million in cash plus clean-up costs to settle litigation over groundwater contamination from a gasoline additive.

headline: China: Rushing to Track Children’s Disease
text: Health officials in China, responding to the continued spread of hand, foot and mouth disease, a dangerous intestinal virus, issued new regulations requiring all health care providers to report new cases of the disease, which has killed 28 children in the past two months, most of them in central Anhui Province. Several new cases were reported in Beijing this week.

headline: Wave of Lawsuits Over Losses Could Hit a Wall
text: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.

headline: Betty Comes Home
text: After two years in Los Angeles production of the popular ABC drama “Ugly Betty” may move to the city in which it is set: New York. A spokeswoman for ABC Studios said no final decision had been made, but media reports said “Ugly Betty” staff members were informed of the move on Tuesday. According to Variety, the producers would save money thanks to tax breaks signed into law last month by Gov. David A. Paterson of New York. Under the provision 30 percent of film production costs now qualify for tax credits. “Ugly Betty” would join “Law & Order,” “30 Rock” and “Gossip Girl,” which are also filmed in New York. The series, starring America Ferrera, above, as an employee at a Manhattan fashion magazine, has drawn an average of 7.8 million viewers in its second season.

headline: Forget It, Comrade. This Is Moscow.
text: On Page 275 of his tightly woven debut novel, “Child 44,” Tom Rob Smith reveals what the title means. The moment is a shocker  but its full effects can be felt only if you’ve read the 274 pages that precede it. This book is much too densely, ingeniously plotted for its secrets to be accessible via shortcut.

headline: NBC to Start News Channel in New York
text: NBC Universal plans to announce Wednesday that it will start a 24-hour local news channel along the lines of cable’s New York One. It will de-emphasize the identity of the NBC network’s flagship station, WNBC, Channel 4 in New York, rechristening it a “content center,” and making it one part of a larger local media effort.

headline: Where a Little Awkward Whimsy Can Take You
text: As if by decree, the fans who came to Town Hall in Manhattan Tuesday night to see the comedy-music duo Flight of the Conchords arrived in pairs, one with glasses and one without. Among them were two sisters, Janice and Erica Jim. Seated in a front row, Erica (with glasses) was holding a hand-painted sign, shaped like a hot dog, bearing the band’s name, while Janice (without) toted a bag of tacky sweatshirts. (Both items were elaborately specific references to the “Flight of the Conchords” television show.)

headline: One Killing Lead, and Several Examples for the Textbook
text: The diagramed deal occurred during the first qualifying round of the Iceland Team Championship last month. The layout features textbook declarer play and textbook defense, depending upon West’s lead against four spades. What would you pick?

headline: CURRENTS | Let the Interpreting Begin: Cooper-Hewitt Hands Out Prizes
text: Every year for the last nine years, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum has chosen a slate of design-world worthies to receive its National Design Award. And every year at the time of the announcement (this year it is Thursday), some in that same design world scratch their heads, wondering if this is an awards program meant to reward the young and innovative, to celebrate the reigning masters or to give thanks to the greats as they exit the stage.

headline: Cowen Elected Prime Minister of Ireland
text: LONDON  Brian Cowen was elected Ireland’s new prime minister by an 88-to-76 vote in the parliament on Wednesday, and he announced a major cabinet shuffle.

headline: Rodriguez on Target to Return Next Week
text: Alex Rodriguez performed baseball drills for the first time in more than a week Wednesday, and said he could rejoin the Yankees on May 14, the first day he is eligible.

headline: Post Reporter Files Lawsuit Over Frisking by Police
text: A freelance reporter for The New York Post sued the city on Wednesday, claiming that his civil rights were violated when he was stopped, frisked and arrested in the Bronx last year.

headline: Victor Christ-Janer, Modernist Architect, Dies at 92
text: Victor F. Christ-Janer, a member of a group of influential architects who built Modernist homes and offices in New Canaan, Conn., died on March 24 at the home he designed for himself there. He was 92.

headline: France: Sales Increase at Luxury Retailer
text: Hermès International, a maker of luxury apparel and accessories, said first-quarter revenue rose 13 percent, helped by store openings and sales of leather goods. Sales climbed to 415.1 million euros ($643 million) from 366.1 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Hermès, based in Paris, enlarged its original Paris store last year, opened on Wall Street in New York and said it planned to open or renovate about 20 outlets in 2008.

headline: Republicans Focus on Obama as Fall Opponent
text: At least one political party is acting like it knows who the Democratic nominee will be: the Republicans, who have greatly stepped up their criticisms of Senator Barack Obama in recent weeks while practically ignoring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Pianist of Apollonian Finesse Finds His Inner Dionysus
text: The Austrian pianist Till Fellner is turning out to be one of the great musical chameleons. At one of his first New York performances, in 1995, he played a Mozart concerto with a style-conscious fastidiousness and refinement of tone. He approached his 2004 recording of Bach’s “Well-Tempered Clavier,” Book I, with a similar refinement, but greater tensile strength, and other performances have shown him to be more interested in probing, sensitive phrasing than in virtuosic display, even in big Romantic showpieces.

headline: Staging Their Happenings in an Art-Punk Mode, Embracing the Threat of Chaos
text: Not three songs into No Age’s set at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night Dean Spunt noticed a problem. A rigorous and straightforward drummer, Mr. Spunt  who wore a Ramones T-shirt, in pink, with Arabic lettering  paused, leaned into his microphone and said, “I rocked that song so hard, I broke my hi-hat cymbal.”

headline: Crippled Election Commission
text: The White House is removing a member of the Federal Election Commission for standing up for clean elections, while trying to install another member whose specialty is keeping eligible voters from casting ballots. The Senate, which must confirm nominees, should insist that President Bush appoint commissioners with a proven record of supporting voting rights and fair elections.

headline: ‘Glory Days’ to Close
text: “Glory Days,” the new musical written by a 23-year-old and a 24-year-old that transferred to Broadway from the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., announced its immediate closing on Wednesday, just a day after it opened to a raft of bad reviews.

headline: CIRCUITS | From Japan, a Tiny Laptop That Stands Out in a Crowd
text: Fancy laptops are becoming fashion statements because of sleek models like the MacBook Air. But if you really wanted to stand out from the crowd, you could get the Vye Mini-v S41, a tiny laptop that is available only in Japan  or through Dynamism.com, which imports high-tech gadgets to the United States from Asia.

headline: Pundits Declare the Race Over
text: Very early this morning, after many voters had already gone to sleep, the conventional wisdom of the elite political pundit class that resides on television shifted hard, and possibly irretrievably, against Senator Hillary Clinton’s continued viability as a presidential candidate.

headline: Technical Factors Cited in Slow Results
text: CROWN POINT, Ind.  For hours, as the tallies in the Democratic presidential primary rolled in all over Indiana on Tuesday night, the announced count from Lake County sat puzzlingly at zero.

headline: TV’s Pundits Pronounce Judgment: It’s Over
text: Starting early Wednesday morning and continuing through the evening news, the conventional wisdom of television’s political pundit class shifted hard against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s continued viability as a presidential candidate.

headline: Trying to Flesh Out the History of a Family That Was Minus One
text: More than 40 years ago, when she was a teenager, Jean Moore learned something quite by accident that haunts her still.

headline: Young Video Makers Try to Alter Islam’s Face
text: LOS ANGELES  When Ali Ardekani started fishing around on the Internet a couple of years ago for video blogs about Muslims, he did not like what he found: either the world’s 1.3 billion Muslims were depicted as bloodthirsty zealots, or they were offering defensive explanations as to why they were not.

headline: Four Players Who Came Out of Africa Return to Help
text: The trip home to Nigeria had been planned for months, every detail considered to prevent a hitch in their good intentions. On the first day of their charity mission, four N.F.L. players riding a bus on the way to meet Nigerian President Umaru Yar’Adua, were  bang!  broadsided by a truck.

headline: CURRENTS | Glass Can Improve the Look of Cabinets
text: New glass inserts can change the look of old cabinets or enhance the style of new ones.

headline: A Plunge Disrupts the Recent Calm
text: Wall Street markets tumbled the most in nearly a month late Wednesday afternoon, casting some doubt on the staying power of the calm that has settled over investors recently after the winter’s tumult.

headline: New Orleans Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Company Ahead of Its Time
text: HAD you caught “Big Ideas for a Small Planet” on the Sundance Channel on Tuesday night, or read last week’s issue of Fortune, you might have been intrigued by reports about the environmentally conscious philosophy of a Portland, Ore., fashion company called Nau. But if you had then visited the company’s Web site, you would have discovered a notice that Nau is going out of business.

headline: 11 Years of Police Gunfire, in Painstaking Detail
text: New York City police officers fire their weapons far less often than they did a decade ago, a statistic that has dropped along with the crime rate. But when they do fire, even at an armed suspect, there is often no one returning fire at the officers. Officers hit their targets roughly 34 percent of the time.

headline: Steampunk Moves Between 2 Worlds
text: “MEET Showtime,” said Giovanni James, a musician, magician and inventor of sorts, introducing his prized dove, who occupies a spacious cage in Mr. James’s apartment in Midtown Manhattan. Showtime is integral to Mr. James’s magic act and to his décor, a sepia-tone universe straight out of the gaslight era.

headline: Stalker's Mother Recalls His Early Days of Promise
text: Jack Jordan was, by all accounts, an exemplary child.

headline: Biodegradable Home Product Lines, Ready to Rot
text: THE other day, Cody Anderson, an earnest young salesman at Montauk Sofa on Mercer Street, was extolling the many, many virtues of the furniture there while leading me to a buff-colored, chenille-covered, down-filled chaise longue called Stanley. “You want to get right onto it,” he said, taking my bag. “Isn’t that amazing?”

headline: Criticized in U.S., the F.A.A. Is Seen in Many Regions as a First-Rate Regulator
text: Despite the heightened scrutiny of the Federal Aviation Administration, regulators elsewhere say they still view the American agency as a model for safety and regulatory compliance.

headline: Bringing Balanchine’s ‘Four Temperaments’ to a Fevered Pitch
text: PARIS  It’s not often that the vast stage of the Bastille Opera House is the setting for the Paris Opera Ballet’s mixed bills, which are usually shown within the more intimate, gilded confines of the Palais Garnier. But the huge contemporary space of the Bastille proves a spectacular setting for the current program of works by Balanchine, Nureyev and William Forsythe.

headline: NBC Plans 24-Hour News for the New York Region
text: NBC Universal announced on Wednesday plans to start a 24-hour local cable news channel similar to New York 1. It will de-emphasize the identity of NBC’s flagship station, WNBC, Channel 4, rechristening it a “content center” and making it one part of a larger media presence.

headline: Delta and Northwest Defend a Merger
text: WASHINGTON  The chief executives of Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines defended on Wednesday their plans to merge, telling a Senate subcommittee that the consolidation was essential to preserve jobs and service to small cities, and to compete with foreign-flag carriers. They also insisted that consumers would not suffer.

headline: Idolatry Outdraws Terpsichore
text: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” celebrated its 100th episode on Tuesday, drawing solid ratings for the night but not enough to overcome Fox’s advantage with “American Idol.” Nielsen estimated that 21.2 million viewers tuned in to Fox at 8 p.m. for the singing competition, while 10.5 million watched a “Dancing With the Stars” special in the hour commemorating the judges’ favorite performances over the years. At 9 p.m., ABC’s regularly scheduled “Dancing With the Stars” results episode earned the night’s second largest audience, 18.1 million, but it trailed well behind Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” in the time slot among adults 18 to 49. “Hell’s Kitchen” did attract far fewer total viewers, 11.2 million. CBS ranked third for the night behind both networks, faring well at 8 with “NCIS” (13.8 million) but drawing smaller audiences later in the night for “Shark” at 9 (10.4 million) and a rerun of “CSI: Miami” at 10 (7.6 million). NBC won the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (10.4 million) but finished fourth overall.

headline: Lottery Numbers
R. Kelly Trial to Start
text: After six years of repeated delays, the R&B star R. Kelly is to stand trial on child pornography charges; jury selection will begin on Friday in Chicago, The Associated Press reported. Contributing to the delays were more than 30 pretrial motions, the multiple fractures suffered by Judge Vincent Gaughan in a fall from a ladder at home and Mr. Kelly’s emergency surgery for a ruptured appendix. Mr. Kelly, 41, was indicted on June 5, 2002, after the appearance of a videotape police and prosecutors say shows him having sex with a girl as young as 13. But the woman identified as the victim says she is not the one in the video. Mr. Kelly, a Grammy Award winner who has settled three lawsuits accusing him of having sex with under-age girls, faces as many as 15 years in prison if convicted. The judge has ruled that the videotape may be shown in open court.

headline: Yemen: Japanese Tourists Briefly Taken Hostage
text: Armed men kidnapped two female Japanese tourists near the town of Marib in Yemen, but released them hours later, local officials said. The kidnappers had been demanding the release of a comrade from jail in return for the women’s release, the officials said. But it was unclear whether the demand was met.

headline: In a Sleek Package, a Home Theater System to Rock Your World
text: Sometimes true surround sound is overkill. While chair-bouncing sound pumping out of a phalanx of speakers in the living room intensifies movie viewing in the living room, it’s often easier just to set up a smaller home theater system  like the Sony DAV-F200  and call it a day.

headline: For Peak Performance, 3 Is Not Better Than 1
text: WHEN Jenny Higgins started doing triathlons, she discovered something peculiar. She had been on her high school cross country and swim teams and her college swim team. But in 2003 she started running, swimming and cycling, and tried to excel in all three at once.

headline: Support for Clinton Wanes as Obama Sees Finish Line
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture on Wednesday about continuing her presidential bid despite waning support from Democratic officials and donors, while some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.

headline: Germany: 2 Groups Banned for Neo-Nazism
text: The German government shut down two groups, Collegium Humanum and the Association for the Rehabilitation of People Persecuted for Denying the Holocaust, accusing them of spreading anti-Semitic propaganda and glorifying the Nazis. The bans came after the authorities conducted a series of early morning raids in North Rhine-Westphalia, Lower Saxony and Hesse.

headline: Backstage All-Access Passwear
text: LAST Friday I walked down to the Bowery to visit the new John Varvatos store. As you probably know, Mr. Varvatos took over the legendary and recently defunct music site CBGB and turned it into a stylish space to sell his superior and expensive clothing.

headline: Ladies Who Lunch? No, Here’s to the Power Players
text: It seems safe to say that no New York restaurant, not even Michael’s or the Four Seasons, has seen a power meal to match the one that so exhilaratingly begins Caryl Churchill’s “Top Girls,” which opened last night in a well-acted revival at the Biltmore Theater.

headline: A New Opening in Cuba
text: To the Editor:

headline: CIRCUITS | The Robotic Lawn Mower Will Take Your Call Now
text: Using your cellphone ... to mow your lawn?

headline: Your Chance to Finish a Movie Microsoft Started
text: CALLING all would-be Judd Apatows, Martin Scorseses and Coen brothers. Your cinematic ambitions may be supported by an unlikely patron, based not in Hollywood but more than a thousand miles to the north in Redmond, Wash.

headline: Violence in Zimbabwe Disrupts Schools and Aid
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s ruling party, bent on retaining control after 28 years in power, has broadened its campaign of intimidation and violence to include teachers and even aid workers, disrupting education and basic care for tens of thousands of children across the country, according to humanitarian groups, union officials and the teachers themselves.

headline: For Boomers, It’s Time to Go to the (Brain) Gym
text: To the Editor:

headline: CURRENTS | Paul Kohn, a New Home-Décor Store, Opens in TriBeCa
text: Paul Kohn, a new store in TriBeCa, carries several collections of furniture, including one line made of mesquite, a rarity in Manhattan. But don’t expect rough-hewn Southwestern style. Pieces like the daybed ($19,200) and dresser ($19,500) have a spare, refined look that can “work with different kinds of interiors,” said Elaine Paul, an interior designer and one of the store’s owners. Ms. Paul designed most of the furniture with Barbara Shattuck Kohn, an investment banker who owns the store with her.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. Where can I find a comfortable, attractive chair for a small bedroom?

headline: Questions May Follow Clemens’s Apology
text: When Roger Clemens tacitly acknowledged on Monday that he had engaged in extramarital relations, and apologized, he was seen as perhaps undermining the defamation lawsuit he filed in January against his former personal trainer Brian McNamee.

headline: Architects in Glass Houses
text: LONDON

headline: Giuliani Weighs In on Distant Mayoral Race
text: Who would have guessed that the next chapter in Rudolph W. Giuliani’s life would involve political consulting for an election in Eastern Europe?

headline: A New Council Spending Inquiry
text: This article is by William K. Rashbaum, Ray Rivera and Russ Buettner.

headline: Indians’ Lee Puts the Yankees Under His Spell
text: The last hitter to face the Cleveland Indians’ Cliff Lee on Wednesday was José Molina, who slammed his bat to the dirt after whiffing on a fastball. It was that kind of night for the Yankees, whose depleted lineup was no match for a pitcher on a joyride.

headline: Extended Visits for Britney Spears
text: Britney Spears, below, was awarded extended visits with her sons after a child custody hearing in Los Angeles Superior County Court on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. Mark Vincent Kaplan, a lawyer for Kevin Federline, her former husband, said the extended visits with the children, Sean Preston, 2, and Jayden James, 1, were “recognition of the progress that has been made, a progress of structure and stability.” Mr. Federline has had full custody of the children since January, when the police were summoned to Ms. Spears’s home, and she was taken by ambulance to a medical center after refusing to surrender the boys to Mr. Federline’s bodyguard. In a statement read by a court spokesman, Ms. Spears’s parents said, “We are so pleased with Britney’s progress and we are very appreciative of the court’s recognition of this progress.” A report on the new arrangement was scheduled for July 15.

headline: Tales of the Big City
text: In case you need reminding, and it never hurts, the gap between your life and that of a Major League Baseball player is immeasurably vast. Here are two case studies, both from this beautiful, vivid sports city we call home.

headline: Today, I Think I’ll Be Hippohead
text: LAST week, I got a call from Scott Arpajian, who wanted to tell me about his new Web site.

headline: McCain Pushes Priorities That Resonate on the Right
text: ROCHESTER, Mich.  Senator John McCain appealed to religious conservatives on Wednesday with pledges to prosecute sex traffickers, fight Internet child pornography and make religious freedom a priority in American diplomacy.

headline: Georgia’s Offer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Patriots Assistant Sends the N.F.L. Eight Tapes
text: A former New England Patriots employee has sent the N.F.L. eight videotapes showing the team recorded play-calling signals by coaches of five opponents in six games between the 2000 and 2002 seasons, in violation of league rules.

headline: At 60, Israel Redefines Roles for Itself and for Jews Elsewhere
text: JERUSALEM  The Jewish people are marking the 60th anniversary of their national rebirth, the founding of Israel, on Thursday with the usual military flyovers, flag buntings and televised reminiscences of aging pioneers.

headline: Student Consultants Supply Fresh Insights to Businesses
text: FOR the last four months, nine students at Stetson University’s business school have been putting together a marketing plan for a maker of parachutes and related equipment, Complete Parachute Solutions Inc., not far from the school’s campus in central Florida.

headline: CIRCUITS | Simulating Vinyl With D.J. Gear for the PC
text: Amateur D.J.-ing on a PC can often sound, to use the vernacular, kind of whack. Hercules hopes to improve the chances of pumping out a great mix with the Mobile DJ MP3.

headline: How to Convert Uppercase Text
text: Q. I have text in an e-mail message that was typed in capital letters, and I’d like to convert it to standard uppercase and lowercase letters. Is there a way to do this, or am I stuck retyping?

headline: Toward Better Student Lending
text: President Bush showed good sense on Wednesday when he signed legislation to ensure an uninterrupted flow of federal student loans during the credit crunch. Now comes the test of leadership.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: The Torch en Route
text: The question on everyone’s lips today is whether Hillary will quit now that her chances of winning the nomination are extremely remote. She is strong. She is invincible. Or, at minimum, extremely hard to discourage.

headline: Born a Day Late, Not a Year Too Early
text: Vic Zast is thoroughbred racing’s only travel critic — with a “Destinations” column in The Blood-Horse that features a five-star rating for international events. He has written about horse racing for ESPN.com, MSNBC.com and National Public Radio. He has been a participant in the sport for over 45 years and was president of Finger Lakes Racetrack and Turfway Park.

headline: Taking a Pass On Gas
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Iraq Briefing: Hometown Baghdad
text: Hometown Baghdad, a series of videos documenting the lives of three young people in Iraq, was among the many winners at the Webby Awards announced on Tuesday. [chattheplanet.com]

headline: The New World Mapped
Ralph Wiggum, Pitchman
text: “Simpsons” character stumbles onto the truth of many iPods:

headline: Sprott I.P.O. Expected to Price
text: The initial public offering of Sprott Asset Management is expected to be priced early Thursday, with underwriters likely to put in the pin at 10 Canadian dollars a share, valuing the Canadian hedge fund at 1.5 billion Canadian dollars, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: UBS to Pay $37 Million in Settlement With Massachusetts A.G.
text: Massachusetts Attorney General Martha Coakley’s office reached a $37 million agreement with UBS  Wednesday, requiring the bank to return funds to the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority and 17 municipalities that it allegedly misled into buying auction-rate securities.

headline: Truths of Urban Warfare
text: The American military is fighting daily battles for the control of Baghdad’s Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City. On May 3, the Americans fired at least three missiles at a small building next door to the Sadr General Hospital. The building was identified by the U.S. military as a command center for the militia.

headline: Illinois Tool Works to Add Enodis to its Belt
text: Illinois Tool Works, the manufacturer of Duo-Fast nail guns and Wilsonart countertops, agreed to buy Enodis for $2.1 billion, trumping a rival offer for the British catering-gear maker from Manitowoc.

headline: Germany’s United Internet Moves to Halt Freenet Deal
text: Germany’s United Internet on Wednesday ratcheted up its opposition to a 1.63 billion euro ($2.53 billion) purchase of mobile-services group Debitel by Freenet, an Internet and cellular-service provider that United wants to buy.

headline: Posting Loss, Marsh to Sell Kroll Units
text: Marsh & McLennan, which runs one of the world’s largest insurance brokerage companies, posted a first-quarter loss on Wednesday after it wrote down the value of its Kroll corporate security unit by $425 million.

headline: Dr Pepper Snapple Bows to Lukewarm Reception
text: Dr Pepper Snapple Group shares began trading in New York on Wednesday at a lower-than-expected $25, indicating that U.S. investors aren’t that thirsty for the country’s third-largest soft drink maker.

headline: Carlyle and JMI Team Up to Take Gemcom Private
text: The Carlyle Group and JMI Equity have agreed to buy Gemcom Software International , the largest global supplier of specialized mining technology and software, in a cash deal valued at about 180 million Canadian dollars ($178 million).

headline: BofA’s Selig on the Merger Market
text: The merger advisory business is in a downturn, and Stefan Selig may know this as well as anyone. Mr. Selig, the global head of mergers and acquisitions at Bank of America, talked about the state of the market in an interview with Investment Dealers’ Digest, telling the publication that 2008 might look more like 2003 in terms of announced deal volume.

headline: Markets Plunge, as S.E.C. Calls for More Oversight of Banks
text: Wall Street markets tumbled the most in nearly a month late Wednesday afternoon, casting some doubt on the staying power of the calm that has settled over investors recently after the winter’s tumult. Perhaps further adding to the jittery market, Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, called for stricter oversight of investment banks.

headline: Will May Be a Merry Month for I.P.O.’s?
text: A nervous Wall Street scorned initial public offerings for months, but suddenly I.P.O.s are popular again, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: Clear Channel Case to Proceed in N.Y.
text: It looks like Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital, which are suing a group of banks over the buyout of Clear Channel Communications, will have their day in court.

headline: Protestor at ‘Generations of Women for Hillary’ Event
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke to about 1,500 supporters Wednesday night at a “Generations of Women for Hillary” fund-raiser at the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington. The campaign said the event brought in close to $1 million, although the crowd was not without agitators.

headline: Colfax Prices I.P.O. at $18 a Share
text: Colfax, a maker of industrial pumps and valves, said Wednesday that it has priced its initial public offering at $18 a share, giving the stock offering a total value of $337.5 million.

headline: Private Equity Firms Take More, Give Less, Report Says
text: Private equity firms are charging investors more for managing their investments and giving them back less of the fees they charge to their portfolio companies, according to a new report.

headline: TV Guide, Just Bought, Is Bracing to Be Sold
text: Days after getting new owners and new editors, the long-troubled TV Guide is back on the block.

headline: GLG Hopes to Keep at Least $2 Billion in Coffey Funds
text: GLG Partners, the British hedge fund manager that on Wednesday announced losses of more than $200 million for the first three months of the year, said it hoped to retain $2 billion of the once $7 billion of assets in the emerging markets funds run by star manager Greg Coffey, who resigned last month.

headline: Wave of Lawsuits Over Losses Could Hit a Wall
text: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.

headline: Icahn Raises Stake in Motorola
text: Carl C. Icahn is adding to his foothold in Motorola, now that he’s won seats on the board and is getting his way.

headline: Bear Investors Drop Suit to Block JPMorgan Deal
text: Bear Stearns shareholders suing over the planned JPMorgan Chase takeover are dropping efforts to block the deal but will seek damages of at least $2.8 billion, an attorney for the plaintiffs said on Wednesday.

headline: Albireo Swallows Addition Cash from TPG
text: Albireo has closed its Series A round at $40 million.

headline: Giant Realm Takes $2 Million for Softbank Capital
text: Giant Realm, the entertainment portal geared towards men, has received $2 million in funding from SoftBank Capital.

headline: Steaz Gets $11 Million for Organic Drinks
text: The Healthy Beverage Company, which operates under the trade name Steaz, has raised $11 million for fairly traded, organic teas, VentureBeat reported. The funding was provided by Inventages Venture Capital and Whitefish Group, the publication said.

headline: JPMorgan Sees Bear Clients Returning
text: JPMorgan Chase, which is buying Bear Stearns, expects to regain business from Bear clients who stopped doing business with the troubled investment bank, JPMorgan’s co-chief executive of investment banking said on Wednesday.

headline: Carphone and Best Buy Strike $2.2 Billion Deal
text: Britain’s Carphone Warehouse will sell a 50 percent stake in its retail unit to U.S. electronics chain Best Buy for 1.1 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) and they will launch a new company to expand across Europe.

headline: Murdoch Keeps His Sights on Newsday
text: In the News Corporation‘s earnings conference call on Wednesday, Rupert Murdoch voiced skepticism that Cablevision can succeed in its bid for Newsday, which is now at the center of a tussle among three New York moguls, even as he vowed not to get into a bidding war for the newspaper.

headline: Looking for a Deal, Microsoft Said to Feel Out Facebook
text: In the wake of its failed $47.5 billion takeover bid for Yahoo, Microsoft apparently sent a calling card to Facebook, the social networking site, to see if it might be up for a deal.

headline: Delta and Northwest Defend a Merger
text: The chief executives of Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines defended on Wednesday their plans to merge, telling a Senate subcommittee that the consolidation was essential to preserve jobs and service to small cities, and to compete with foreign-flag carriers. They also insisted that consumers would not suffer.

headline: Northern Rock Shareholders Challenge Lender’s Nationalization
text: Some Northern Rock shareholders are planning to challenge the British mortgage lender’s nationalization by filing a request for judicial review, The Times of London reported. If successful, they could claim 2.1 billion pounds ($4.1 billion) in compensation.

headline: The New Hacker Economics
text: To make money, you have to move up the economic food chain into higher-value, more profitable work and markets. That economic fact of life applies to nations, companies and individuals.

headline: Huawei Said to Consider Stake Sale

headline: When Police Officers Open Fire
text: The New York Police Department has turned over 11 years of annual firearms-discharge reports to the City Council and to the New York Civil Liberties Union, and Al Baker has set about poring through the voluminous records. In a front-page article, he highlights several of the most intriguing findings. New York City police officers fire their weapons far less often than they did a decade ago, a statistic that has dropped along with the crime rate. But when they do fire, even at an armed suspect, there is often no one returning fire at the officers. Officers hit their targets roughly 34 percent of the time.

headline: Wish You’d Held On to That ’75 Ducati?
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. – There were plenty of winners at last weekend’s Legend of the Motorcycle concours event and accompanying bike auction. The biggest winner, however, was Vince Martinico, an admitted pack rat, and his 1908 Indian Torpedo Tank Racer.

headline: Top Edwards Adviser Endorses Obama

headline: After Great Pain
text: My dim recollection of the “Housekeeping” I read in 1980 was of a wonderful saga, a comic novel about an eccentric family and a group of unforgettable woman characters. Nowadays I come away from multiple re-readings of the novel with a heavy heart. For all its pleasures, the novel is so suffused with loneliness and grief that the more I read, the sadder I get.

headline: A Gated Community for Ron Paul Supporters?
text: A group of ardent backers of Ron Paul, the maverick congressman and Republican presidential candidate, are flocking to Paulville.org, a Web site that promises to help them set up exclusive residential enclaves open only to the like-minded — presumably to help them replicate in the physical world the comfortable feeling they’ve experienced online, of being fenced-off from the rest of us.

headline: Another Happy Day!
text: This has been a great Beckett season in New York. In January, the fab Fiona Shaw was terrific in Deborah Warner’s production of “Happy Days” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. And now John Turturro is strutting his stuff — albeit from a wheelchair — as Hamm in “Endgame,” directed by Andrei Belgrader. Although Turturro has touches of Dr. Strangelove and the old guy in the orchid hothouse at the beginning of “The Big Sleep,” he makes the role his own, with just the right combination of kookiness, cruelty and pathos. Max Casella excels as Clov, Hamm’s co-dependent manservant, and Elaine Stritch and Alvin Epstein are quite wonderful as Nell and Nagg, popping up from their garbage cans. (“Endgame” runs through May 18 at BAM.)

headline: Analysts Grill Cablevision on Deal Agenda

It is reportedly bidding against Rupert Murdoch for Newsday, a newspaper owned by Tribune. And Cablevision recently considered buying a stake in AEG Live, the concert promoter.

We took the question to Dr. Larry Bramlage, who is a partner in Rood and Riddle Equine Hospital in Lexington, Ky. He is past president of the American Association of Equine Practitioners.

headline: A Brief History of the Stirrup
text: Last Sunday the A’s and Rangers played in throwback uniforms and baseball purists (at least those that obsess over fashion) rejoiced. It was not the sight of Oakland players wearing vests or even butter cream yellow batting helmets that caused the celebration. Rather, it was the sight of seeing two teams of major leaguers wearing classic stirrup socks.

headline: Jockey Club to Study Safety
text: The Jockey Club formed a Thoroughbred Safety Committee today and commissioned seven of its members to review every facet of equine health, including breeding practices, medication, the rules of racing and track surfaces. It intends to issue recommendations to be adopted by the industry to insure safety.

headline: A Vanderbilt Remembers Native Dancer
text: Alfred G. Vanderbilt is a writer and public relations consultant based in Norwalk, Conn. His father owned and bred Native Dancer, whose bloodline is now reported to be in 75 percent of all thoroughbreds. He also contributed to “To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory.” He shares with the Rail memories of Native Dancer.

headline: Cold Turkey
text: Leaving Paris yesterday for my trip to Turkey I decided to lighten the suitcases by not taking coats or heavy sweaters. Fortunately, I decided I’d take one sweater in case it was cold on the airplane. Turkey previously hosted the race in August, remember, and I was under the impression it would be about 80 degrees Celsius in May as well. Dumb. Arriving at the track yesterday under dark, cloudy skies and very cold air temperature, I regretted my lack of winter clothes.
