headline: A Place to Read, and Comment on, Times Articles in Arabic
text: As part of Generation Faithful, our ongoing series examining the lives of young people across the Muslim world at a time of religious revival, The New York Times has established an Arabic-language blog. It’s hosted through the news and blogging site Al Bawaba, and will allow readers in the Middle East to read and comment on articles in our series in Arabic.

headline: A Place to Read and Comment on Times Articles in Arabic
text: As part of Generation Faithful, our ongoing series examining the lives of young people across the Muslim world at a time of religious revival, The New York Times has established an Arabic-language blog. It's hosted through the news and blogging site Al Bawaba, and will allow readers in the Middle East to read and comment on articles in our series in Arabic.  The first article in the series, on marriage in Egypt, has already been posted on the new blog, and the next two articles in the series will be published there soon.   We are hoping to use the blog to expand the English-language discussion we started here in The Majlis section of The Lede, to open up the conversation to non-English-speakers, as we have for our series on Russia, Kremlin Rules, which is being discussed quite actively on our Moscow bureau's LiveJournal blog.  We will translate some of the responses posted on the Arabic blog into English and post them on NYTimes.com in the coming days and weeks.

headline: Facebook Agrees to Protect Young Customers
text: Following MySpace out of the penalty box of 50 state attorneys general, the social network Facebook is agreeing to a broad set of principles to protect young users from predators and inappropriate material.

headline: Three Kitchen Tidbits
text: OlivesI almost always keep a bowl of olives in the fridge; the type varies, and is often a mixture. (These, as it happens, are Portuguese, from My New Favorite Store, Xavier’s in New Bedford, Mass., right down the street from Antonio’s.) Every now and then I add oil to the mix, and every now and then I use the oil for cooking which, needless to say, is wonderful. A little rosemary is good, as are thyme, and sage — alone, together, whatever. Fennel seeds, too. Lemon, orange, tangerine peel. I fish the old spices out when they look tired, and add new ones. (I don’t like chiles in olives, but you could do that too.)

headline: Mission to Myanmar?
text: Is it time for an international coalition to invade Myanmar? “The French foreign minister is making noises that sound curiously close to a humanitarian invasion,” Megan McArdle notes at Asymmetrical Information, her blog for The Atlantic. She cites the report in today’s Times that “the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, suggested that the United Nations should invoke its ‘responsibility to protect’ civilians as the basis for a resolution to allow the delivery of international aid even without the junta’s permission.”

headline: A Bronx Diner Becomes a Teamsters Battleground
text: Business is down at the Celeste Diner, but not because of what’s on the menu. The tacos, eggs and sandwiches are as tasty as ever. The place might be quieter now, because of what’s on top of it: signs urging truckers at a nearby company to join the Teamsters in an election scheduled for May 21. This year, union organizers waging a campaign against Baldor Specialty Foods in Hunts Point, paid $250 a month to perch the bilingual signs declaring “It’s Your Time to Organize — Yes We Can” on the corner diner, right where Baldor’s drivers are sure to see them as they go out to deliver produce to restaurants in the metropolitan region.

Last October, after a vacation in Rome, Mr. Dunlap invited City Room readers to guess which of four chefs was the real Roman, and last month, he pointed out another sighting of the chef, this time on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Scent Notes | Privet Bloom by Hampton Sun
text: There is a class of fragrance that lies somewhere between perfume and scent. On the one hand, there are classical perfumes — multifaceted works of olfactory art, based on ideas and built with complexes of raw materials, in styles as varied and intellectualized as pointillism and expressionism. On the other, aromatherapy — mono-themed smells, generally built in minimalist (if not inchoate) style and structure, meant simply to hypnotize like the single, pulsing tone of a Buddhist bowl, lulling into a state of non-thought. Where perfumes seek to convey ideas, aromas are designed to produce the opposite outcome, intentionally tamping down thought: the scent concept of being free of scent concepts.

headline: Russia Plans Near-Quarantine for English Soccer Fans

headline: A Photographer and Her Subject, Reunited Decades Later
text: In 1979, the photographer Jill Freedman was walking through the flower district when a young couple, leaning against a storefront’s riot grating, caught her attention. The emblem of a gun on the man’s shirt pointed menacingly at the woman’s head. Ms. Freedman aimed her Leica M4 and captured the moment.Almost 30 years later, Mario Pesa, 55, unexpectedly discovered the black and white image of himself, entitled “Love Kills,” which appeared with an April 27 article on the cover of The City section about Ms. Freedman. Mr. Pesa, who lives with a 17-year-old daughter in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, is a mail handler for the postal service. He was handed the article by a co-worker. Unaware before last week that there even was a photograph, he said, “I recognize the shirt, but I’m not sure who took this picture.”

headline: Inflation Warning

headline: Farewell, My Lovely Pork Buns
text: I’m very sad to report that the venerable, wonderful Mei Lai Wah Coffee House in Chinatown appears to have closed for good. At least that was the report at Eater.com last week, which I have no reason to doubt. Rumors that Mei Lai Wah would close have floated for more than a few years now, but apparently the continuing clampdown by the Department of Health over the last year and a half was the last straw. This is a great loss both to the Chinatown community and to occasional visitors like me.

headline: Your Photos Here
text: The results keep coming in. Since we began asking for your photos back in February, hundreds of readers from San Diego to Strasbourg, Jakarta to Jersey City, have submitted images to the Polling Place Photo Project, our joint effort with the AIGA, the national association for design. The Polling Place Photo Project was created in 2006 by William Drenttel and AIGA during the midterm elections.The photos range from the quirky to the mundane – a bevy of ballot boxes, curtains, and levers – representing the far-flung corners of the nation. Often the images stray yards, perhaps miles, from the polling sites themselves, spilling out onto streets, walkways, and even cemeteries. Together they form a “voter-generated” portrait of the election season.

headline: A Flood of Allusions?
text: I had to laugh when I was awakened in my apartment yesterday to a bathroom flood. It was clean water (unlike the heavy-laden waters of Lake Fingerbone) overflowing the toilet tank, and it was a relatively simple matter to turn off the valve and use every towel I own to mop up the mess. But few things make a person feel so helpless as water that won’t stop running over things one takes for granted, like floors. I wondered at the time if this was punishment for messing with Marilynne Robinson’s fine novel.

headline: Queens Market Cheated Grocery Baggers, State Says
text: Once again, several New York supermarkets have been accused of not paying any wages to those friendly baggers who help shoppers pack up groceries. In years past, many city teenagers would bag groceries just for tips after school or during the summer. But supermarkets are increasingly using immigrant workers — who often receive $1 to $4 an hour in tips — and state officials say the law requires that these workers receive wages and not just tips. Some store owners say that the baggers are independent contractors who work for themselves. But state officials insist that they are employees who follow management’s orders.

headline: Gotbaums Sue Phoenix Over Airport Death

headline: Preakness Updates: Thursday
text: Kentucky Bear jogged two miles this morning at Pimlico, the home of the second leg of the Triple Crown. This Canadian challenger is the only horse on the grounds at Pimlico.

headline: Paterson Meets With Bell’s Family and Sharpton
text: Updated, 7:04 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson met Thursday afternoon with the parents and fiancée of Sean Bell and with the Rev. Al Sharpton, saying afterward that he understood and respected the large-scale protests that occurred on Wednesday, resulting in 216 arrests, and also that he accepted a Queens judge’s decision to acquit three New York City police detectives charged in Mr. Bell’s shooting. Mr. Paterson said he would review proposals to require alcohol testing for police officers who fire their weapons and to review protocols governing undercover police work.

headline: More Reader Photographs From Myanmar
text: [ Update, May 15 — A visitor to Myanmar who posted comments and submitted photos of the cyclone and its aftermath to The Lede, including the photos above and below, has asked us, out of concern for his security, to remove his name from the blog, and we have done so. – Ed.  ]

text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Clinton’s Fund-Raising Online: $1 Million
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised more than $1 million over the Internet in the 24-hours after the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, according to Hassan Nemazee, a national finance chairman for her campaign.

headline: Military Junta Portrays Control
text: The military junta portrays its control over the massive devastation in Myanmar by broadcasting its relief efforts.

headline: Military Junta Portrays Control
text: The military junta portrays its control over the massive devastation in Myanmar by broadcasting its relief efforts.

headline: MySpace Turns Social Network Sharing in the Right Direction
text: Amid all the initiatives in which Internet companies are supposed to make friends with one another — like Facebook’s Platform and Google’s rival OpenSocial initiative — the announcement Thursday by MySpace may well be the most useful to ordinary people and thus the most important.

text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Confirmed: Wilmington To Make Early Switch to Digital TV
text: It’s official: “Any glitches in the nationwide switch to digital television will be felt first in Wilmington, N.C.,” the AP reports.

headline: Pelosi Pressured?
text: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, would not disclose today the details of a phone conversation she had with the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein, who CNN has been reporting pressured her about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy a few weeks ago.

headline: The Torch Atop Everest
text: The Olympic torch achieved the remarkable feat of reaching the summit of Mount Everest earlier today, but as the Times’ Edward Wong reports, overseas groups opposed to Chinese rule in Tibet “quickly denounced the event, saying the Chinese government was simply using the torch relay to bolster claims of sovereignty over what should be an independent country.”

headline: The Widening Gap
text: The phrase “generation gap” came into vogue in the 1960s as a way of describing the wide gulf in values, beliefs and lifestyles that emerged between baby boomers and their parents and grandparents. Indeed, this difference between younger and older people played out sometimes turbulently in the ’60s in virtually all aspects of life, including the ballot box. Unlike in previous elections, from 1968 to 1980 young voters gave much stronger support to Democratic presidential candidates than did their elders.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Speed Racer'
text: A.O. Scott reviews "Speed Racer," the new film from Andy and Larry Wachowski based on the animated television series.

headline: Google: We Like Yahoo, and We Like It Independent
text: Will you do a search advertising deal with Yahoo? How will you do it in a way that avoids antitrust objections? Are you relieved that Microsoft withdrew its offer for Yahoo?

headline: Turmoil in Student Lending
text: Borrowing for college is confusing enough at the best of times, and these are not the best of times.

headline: UrbanEye: The NY Philharmonic
text: Broadway comes to the  New York Philharmonic in the form of "Camelot."  Melena Ryzik reports from the opening night and gala.

headline: The Well Podcast: Child Care and Outdoor Play
text: Child care has been the hottest topic on the Well blog this week after readers responded to a post about new research into outdoor play among young children.

headline: Hmong Hip-Hop Heritage
text: Tou Saiko Lee, a rapper from Minnesota, keeps his Hmong heritage alive through a mix of hip-hop and ancient traditions.

headline: Why you should hate economists
text: From the WSJ:

headline: Cross Promotion
text: Over on our sister blog, The Pour, Eric Asimov writes a stirring elegy for Chinatown’s great, departed Mei Lai Wah Coffee House and its memorable pork buns.

headline: Reaction Abroad to the U.S. Election
text: A look at this week's news events with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

headline: A McCain Digs In
text: Updated Cindy McCain, the wife of Senator John McCain, said in an interview televised Thursday that she would never release her tax returns, even if her husband was elected president and she became the first lady.

headline: Rocking the Vote and More
text: As the campaigns have rolled through state after state, Democrats picked up new voters almost as easily as a navy-blue jacket picks up lint. So why stop now?

headline: Sharpton to Clinton: ‘It’s Over’
text: He’s not a superdelegate, but the Rev. Al Sharpton’s remarks tonight that “it’s over” for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton could carry some weight among New York City superdelegates backing Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Friday’s Links: Personality Types of Presidential Types
text: Michael Melcher, a frequent guest blogger at Shifting Careers, has been writing an engaging series for The Huffington Post about the probable Myers-Briggs personality types of politicians. The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator assessment is perhaps the most widely used tool to understand personality preferences and differences, and if you’re unfamiliar with it, this detailed Wikipedia entry offers a good primer.

headline: Famed Dutch architect to make his mark on New York City skyline
text: For his first major U.S. building, Dutch architect Ben van Berkel is wrapping a 20-story residential tower in New York City with black ribbons of metal, creating a look that mocks conventional high-rise design.

headline: Picture this in Moscow….
text: Moscow’s endless spate of springtime festivals and arts events must surely have something to do with the end of the dark winter (which was actually quite warm, but nonetheless dark). After all, residents of the Russian capital, which is 24/7 as it is, need more and more entertainment as the days grow longer and longer.

headline: Violence in Beirut
text: Gun battles raged in parts of Beirut on Thursday after the leader of Hezbollah had accused Lebanon's Western-backed government of declaring war on his Shiite militant group.

headline: Rick Ankiel’s Two Great Throws…
text: Rick Ankiel had such trouble throwing strikes from 60-feet six-inches that the Cardinals converted him from a pitcher to an outfielder. Oddly enough he had no trouble throwing strikes from centerfield to third base on Tuesday night as he recorded two put outs in a 6-5 victory in the thin air in Colorado. Richard Justice of The Sporting News (as well as the Houston Chronicle) says that with Ankiel in centerfield, the Cardinals are in contention. He also brings up this intriguing stat:

headline: Art-ful Travel: Fun at the New Eurostar Terminal
text: The chaos that unfolded around the opening of Heathrow’s Terminal 5 over the last few months, prompted me to visit was has proved a far more successful transportation unveiling: the transfer of London’s Eurostar terminus from Waterloo to St. Pancras Station.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Homeowner Rescue Bill Passed Despite Veto Threat
text: WASHINGTON  Hoping to throw a rescue line to at least half a million families in danger of losing their homes, the House on Thursday approved legislation that seeks to broadly expand the availability of mortgages insured by the federal government.

headline: A Decade of Sins Deserves a Year Out
text: What an extensive video library Bill Belichick turns out to have produced. Eight more spy tapes sent to N.F.L. headquarters for Commissioner Roger Goodell’s viewing pleasure by a former student in the New England Patriots’ film noir studies program. Who knows how many more taped over or discarded over the last eight years?

headline: Art in Review
text: ANTON KANNEMEYER

headline: Europeans and British Leave Rates Unchanged
text: ATHENS  The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent on Thursday, saying that the region’s economy remained resilient despite nearly nine months of financial turmoil.

headline: Pushkin Museum Overhaul Planned
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia has announced plans for a $177 million restoration of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts, the largest museum of European art in Moscow, CBC News reported, citing the news agency RIA Novosti. The museum will be closed in 2009 and reopen for its 100th anniversary, in 2012. The museum’s collection includes work by Botticelli, Rembrandt and Rubens, as well as Egyptian antiquities. Its Beaux-Arts building complex is planned to quadruple in size. The British architect Norman Foster has been approached to lead the redesign and restoration of the museum.

headline: Dan Rather Revises Lawsuit Against CBS
text: Less than a month after a New York State judge dismissed large parts of the Dan Rather lawsuit against CBS, his former employer, Mr. Rather has amended his original lawsuit and resubmitted it to the court. He continues to contend that CBS violated his contract by failing to give him sufficient work after removing him as anchor of “CBS Evening News” in March 2005. In the new filing, made in State Supreme Court on Wednesday, Mr. Rather argues that his subsequent efforts to secure a job with ABC, NBC or CNN  he says he met with executives of each in 2006  went nowhere, at least partly because of the damage done to his reputation by CBS. Mr. Rather’s career at CBS was upended after he served as the correspondent on a 2004 report for the weekday edition of “60 Minutes” that purported to raise new questions of favoritism in the Vietnam-era National Guard service of President Bush. The network later said it could not verify the documents on which the report had been based. While the judge, Ira Gammerman, said last month that Mr. Rather could continue to pursue a claim against CBS that his contract was breached, he rebuffed Mr. Rather’s efforts to collect damages from Sumner M. Redstone, the executive chairman of CBS; Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of CBS; and Andrew Heyward, the former president of CBS News.

headline: Supporters Rally in Newark as an Imam’s Trial Opens
text: NEWARK  The 14 charter buses started arriving at the Federal Building at 4:30 and continued throughout Thursday morning. They were filled with men and women who had taken the day off from work. Teenagers in brightly colored headscarves marched off the buses chanting “Allahu akbar”  God is great  and linked hands in a human chain that lined the block.

headline: Utah Mine Disaster Was Preventable, Report Says
text: The general manager and possibly other senior staff at the Crandall Canyon Mine near Huntington, Utah, where 9 miners died in August 2007, hid information from federal mining officials that could have prevented the disaster and should face criminal charges, according to a Congressional investigation whose results were released Thursday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,066 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Market Regulatory Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Advertising column on Wednesday, about the effect of a racehorse’s death at this year’s Kentucky Derby on Yum Brands, one of the race’s sponsors, misidentified the location of the corporate headquarters of United Parcel Service, a sponsor of the winning horse, Big Brown. It is Atlanta  not Louisville, Ky., site of U.P.S.’s air hub.

headline: His Impetuous Investment Races for the Crown
text: Garden City, N.Y.

headline: Nixon’s Secretary on Her Days of Glory and After
text: When an actress is giving as commanding a performance as Kristin Griffith does in “Stretch (a Fantasia),” a new play about Rose Mary Woods, there is a danger that those who share the stage with her will disappear into her shadow.

headline: Italy: Starving the Pigeons of St. Mark’s Square
text: Offering birdseed to the pigeons in St. Mark’s Square in Venice has been a tradition for eons. But after years of debate, the city has banned people from feeding the birds in the square. (It was outlawed in the rest of the city 11 years ago.) The final straw was the skyrocketing number of tourists to the city  about 20 million a year now by official estimates, bringing more birdseed sales, then more pigeons, then more damage to the historic buildings in the square, including the mosaics on the facade of St. Mark’s Basilica. Birdseed sellers are in mourning. “It’s like removing Rialto or the Bridge of Sighs,” one said.

headline: F.B.I. Says the Military Had Bogus Computer Gear
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Counterfeit products are a routine threat for the electronics industry. However, the more sinister specter of an electronic Trojan horse, lurking in the circuitry of a computer or a network router and allowing attackers clandestine access or control, was raised again recently by the F.B.I. and the Pentagon.

headline: Cipriani Empire Charged With Violating State Laws
text: The Ciprianis may have to stop serving their celebrated bellini cocktails and other alcohol at the Rainbow Room, Harry Cipriani, and the rest of the family’s empire of Manhattan restaurants and catering halls that are favored sites for prominent society events.

headline: A Postscript for a Writer, 200 Years in the Works
text: WEIMAR, Germany  A body at rest tends to stay at rest, unless it is suspected of being that of the German writer Friedrich Schiller. For nearly 200 years, the dozens of candidates for that honor have been disinterred and subjected to the cutting-edge forensic science of the era.

headline: On Ireland Visit, Noting That Council Speaker and Belfast Go Back a Long Way
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  At least he got the name of the ship right.

headline: G.M. to Pay $200 Million to Settle Strike
text: General Motors said Thursday that it had agreed to give as much as $200 million to a parts supplier, American Axle and Manufacturing, to help settle a 10-week strike that has reduced or halted production at 32 G.M. factories.

headline: Reprieve for a Struggling Catholic School in Jersey City
text: JERSEY CITY  The Rev. Kevin Hanbury stood under the basket in the school gymnasium and uttered 10 words that would have seemed highly unlikely just weeks ago:

headline: Push to End Europe’s Ban on U.S. Poultry Backfires
text: BRUSSELS  American pressure for a quick end to a decade-long Europe-wide ban on poultry imports from the United States threatened to backfire Thursday after European officials contradicted claims that the dispute was almost resolved.

headline: Iran Says April 12 Blast at Shiraz Mosque Was Terrorism
text: TEHRAN  Authorities said Thursday that a previously reported explosion in the southern city of Shiraz on April 12 that left 14 people dead and more than 200 injured was terrorist sabotage and that the United States and Britain had links to the group responsible.

headline: Hitting Curves (of All Sorts)
text: So you want to learn how to hit a curveball?

headline: In a Changing World, an Ever-Evolving Terrorism
text: When the Barbary pirates were in their prime, they were paid homage and protection money by every major shipping nation. In the 17th and 18th centuries these northern African corsairs, many of whom traced their ancestry to the Muslims expelled from Spain, seized privately owned ships, demanding ransom, selling captives into slavery and compelling conversions to Islam.

headline: Short of Cash, Clinton Is Forced to Cut Spending
text: The once-formidable fund-raising machine of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton has begun to sputter at the worst possible moment for Mrs. Clinton’s presidential campaign, Clinton advisers and donors said Thursday, with spending curtailed on political events and advertising as Mrs. Clinton seeks to compete in the last six nominating contests.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: Mr. Mugabe’s Cynical Plan
text: There is little doubt that Morgan Tsvangirai was elected president of Zimbabwe in March. There is no doubt that President Robert Mugabe’s henchmen have used the weeks since to massage the count and terrorize Mr. Tsvangirai’s supporters and anyone who dares to criticize the government. Now Zimbabweans are being told there will have to be a runoff.

headline: Murcer the Author Tells of His Life and New Yogiism
text: Bobby Murcer did not expect to write his autobiography so soon, but in 11 days, on his 62nd birthday, “Yankee for Life: My 40-Year Journey in Pinstripes” (Harper), will be released. It is funny, wry, lovely  and about having the worst brain cancer possible.

headline: On Becoming an Ex-Smoker
text: Dr. David B. Abrams is executive director of the Steven A. Schroeder National Institute for Tobacco Research and Policy Studies at the American Legacy Foundation, a nonprofit group dedicated to reducing tobacco use. He was formerly director of the Office of Behavioral and Social Sciences Research at the National Institutes of Health. As a researcher and a clinical psychologist, he has studied and treated nicotine addiction for 25 years. He co-wrote an Institute of Medicine report, “Ending the Tobacco Problem: A Blueprint for the Nation,” published in 2007.

headline: Cuomo Sees Fraud in Some Lawyers’ Pensions
text: ALBANY  Hundreds of lawyers across the state have been illegally granted state pension benefits by school districts, towns and other governmental entities, according to Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who has opened an investigation into the abuses.

headline: Lighter Mood as Ford Shareholders Meet
text: WILMINGTON, Del.  It would have been difficult a year ago to find many satisfied shareholders of the Ford Motor Company, much less to assemble them in one room.

headline: Taxes and Oil Companies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Average Teenage Girl, Assembling a Life Without a Set of Instructions
text: “I’m not who you think I am,” says Tracey Berkowitz, the 15-year-old protagonist of “The Tracey Fragments.” Since she has also described herself, with evident irony, as a typical teenage girl, it is not always clear what she thinks of herself. And this confusion is part of the point of this short, powerful feature, directed by Bruce McDonald from a script by Maureen Medved (based on her novel). Tracey (Ellen Page) is a squall of conflicting emotions and perceptions, a volatile compound of anger, vulnerability, curiosity, recklessness and fear.

headline: High Prices for Staple Foods Dip, but Volatile Markets Persist
text: HONG KONG  After months of startling increases, the prices of rice, wheat, soybeans and several other foods have come down recently, a development that could ease some of the panic in global food markets.

headline: Something About Austria?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Pressures Myanmar to Allow Aid
text: UNITED NATIONS  With up to 1.5 million people in Myanmar now believed to be facing the threat of starvation and disease and with relief efforts still largely stymied by the country’s isolationist military rulers, frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded Thursday that the government open its doors to supplies and aid workers.

headline: 'Soul Surfers' Rekindle the Love of the Longboard
text: MATT Micuda was 12 in 1973 when he surfed for the first time. It was on a board that had come from a friend of the family  a Barry Kanaiaupuni model from Rick Surfboards that was made in 1968.

headline: Power Dressing
text: Superheroes exist for many reasons. Certainly in our time they exist to sell movie tickets and plastic action figures. (Somewhere in my basement is a box of X-Men that represents a period of desperate pleadings.) But superheroes, those crusading men and women in tights, allow us to believe that in a cape or magical second skin we can do the impossible. We can transform ourselves.

headline: The Bronx Opera Makes Fun of Itself in a Mozart Adaptation
text: It is a Thursday night at 7:30, and the members of the Bronx Opera, its two designated divas included, have assembled to rehearse.

headline: Major Deal Preserves Ranch Land in California
text: Almost 90 percent of one of Southern California’s best-known ranches  long the property of one of the state’s best-known newspaper families  will be kept permanently free of development under the terms of a deal announced on Thursday between the ranch corporation and five major conservation organizations.

headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Hot-Hued Engines
text: Many of us who grew up watching television in the 1960s and ’70s have fond if vague memories of “Speed Racer.” Those big-eyed characters (Trixie! Speed! Racer X!), their mouths never quite moving in sync with the dialogue; those bright colors and semiabstract backgrounds; those endless, episodic story lines. Whether we knew it or not, the series was a primer in the aesthetics of Japanese animation, the love of which we could later pass along to our children.

headline: Top Colleges Dig Deeper in Wait Lists for Students
text: In what may be a happy surprise for thousands of high school seniors, Harvard plans to offer admission to 150 to 175 students on its waiting list, and Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania each expect to take 90, creating ripples that will send other highly selective colleges deeper into their waiting lists as well.

headline: They Came to New York for the Waters
text: PUNGENTLY sulfurous waters burble up from the ground alongside a concrete 1970s hospital building in Clifton Springs, N.Y., southeast of Rochester, and I’m soaking in them. That is, waters from a mineral spring renowned in the 19th century for healing properties have been pumped from a stream running beneath the hospital lawn into a new spa wing, where I’ve gone more for relaxation than anything curative, and a nurse has prepared a hot bath for me.

headline: Vienna Opera Chooses Female Concertmaster
text: The Vienna State Opera has for the first time named a woman to serve as concertmaster, Agence France-Presse reported. The opera announced Thursday that on Sept. 1 the Bulgarian-born Albena Danailova, who plays first violin, will take on the post. In a statement, the opera said, “After an initial probation period of a maximum two years, a final decision will be made about her definitive appointment.” Most of the orchestra is made up of members of the Vienna Philharmonic, which admitted women little more than a decade ago and in which women remain relatively rare. Ms. Danailova has been concertmaster at the London Philharmonic and plays first violin in the Bavarian State Opera orchestra in Munich.

headline: Youthful Energy and Religious Pain
text: When the Israeli government elected to withdraw from the Gaza Strip in 2005, its citizens responded with everything from unadulterated fury to heartbroken resignation to welcome relief. Capturing the full range of these emotions, Adam Hootnick’s “Unsettled” makes the political personal, drawing a scattershot yet intimate picture of a nation divided.

headline: Facebook Agrees to Devise Tools to Protect Young Users
text: The social network Facebook has reached an agreement with 49 state attorneys general to institute a broad set of principles intended to protect young users from online predators and inappropriate material.

headline: Putin Is Approved as Prime Minister
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s Parliament overwhelmingly confirmed Vladimir V. Putin as prime minister on Thursday, completing his managed departure from the presidency in a manner that left him the country’s dominant politician, with a firm grip on power.

headline: Hard Sell to Medicare Insurance Buyers Would Get Softer Under New Rules
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration proposed on Thursday to crack down on the aggressive marketing of private Medicare insurance plans by outlawing unsolicited visits and telephone calls to beneficiaries, regulating commissions paid to sales agents and increasing the fines that could be imposed on insurers.

headline: Verdi Versus Shakespeare: With ‘Macbeth’ It’s a Draw
text: There are two gripping productions of “Macbeth” in New York right now.

headline: Shiite-Sunni Clashes Intensify in Beirut
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fierce clashes escalated in Beirut on Thursday between Sunni supporters of the government and loyalists of Hezbollah, the Shiite militant group, after Hezbollah’s leader said the government had declared war by threatening to shut down the group’s private telephone network.

headline: New York’s Coveted Public Schools Face Pupil Jam
text: Of all the draws of 200 Chambers Street, a luxury TriBeCa condo with floor-to-ceiling windows and a swimming pool, Sherry Hsiung was particularly attracted by Public School 234, the celebrated elementary school next door.

headline: In Lake, Signs of Slow Shift From Savannah to Sahara
text: Six thousand years ago, northern Africa was a place of trees, grasslands, lakes and people. Today, it is the Sahara  a desolate area larger area than Australia.

headline: Hanon Reznikov, a Force Behind the Living Theater, Dies at 57
text: Hanon Reznikov, an actor, director and writer who helped run the avant-garde Living Theater for 23 years, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 57.

headline: The Filling of an Empty Soul
text: In “The Memory Thief,” a strange and melancholy journey to the heart of madness, a rootless young man finds meaning in the horrors of a stolen past.

headline: Robert Vesco, ’70s Financier, Is Dead at 71
text: MEXICO CITY  The death of the financier Robert L. Vesco, confirmed by documents and interviews, has closed the books on one of Washington’s longest and most prominent fugitive hunts.

headline: Finding Your Bliss? Losing Your Mind
text: Male midlife crisis presents as pathological self-loathing in “Meet Bill,” an imperative to which the only sane response is: No thanks.

headline: Months of Talks End in New Contract for ABC’s President
text: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company signed the president of ABC Entertainment, Stephen McPherson, to a new contract, signaling confidence in the maverick executive’s ability to deliver new hits to succeed workhorses like “Grey’s Anatomy.”

headline: 77 New Cases of Hepatitis Are Identified in Las Vegas
text: Nevada health officials said Thursday that they had identified 77 new cases of hepatitis C among patients treated at a Las Vegas endoscopy practice, in one of the country’s largest outbreaks of the liver disease.

headline: Cuban Defectors Adjust to a New Life
text: LOS ANGELES  Under a sunny sky on a manicured soccer field, the drill was repeated over and over for 15 minutes. Maykel Galindo would settle a cross just outside the top of the penalty area, then try to figure out a way to put the ball past the man in goal.

headline: The Dream House at Last
text: AS Jim Abdo emerged from the 1907 bungalow he has transformed from its humble past into its current double life  period vernacular outside, completely modern inside  Vivaldi strings gushed from exterior speakers, filling the Virginia foothills with music.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on May 1 about allocations by a New York City councilman, Mathieu Eugene, to Youth for Education and Sports, a community organization he once ran, referred incorrectly to the group’s sign on its former headquarters in Brooklyn. The sign does not in fact mention Liberty Multiple Services, an insurance and tax preparation business run by Mr. Eugene’s brother, Maxi. (A separate sign on the building for Liberty Multiple includes the phone numbers of both the youth organization and Maxi Eugene.)

headline: Toyota Expects Decline in Annual Profit
text: TOKYO  The Toyota Motor Corporation said on Thursday that its annual profit would probably drop for the first time in nine years because of the slowdown in the United States economy, accelerating a shift by it and other Asian car manufacturers into emerging markets like China, Latin America and the Middle East.

headline: Reports of Qaeda Arrest
text: BAGHDAD  Officials in Baghdad early on Friday were confronted with conflicting reports about whether the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia had been captured.

headline: Manslaughter Trial Set for British Artist
text: Jan. 26 has been set for the trial of Maurice Agis, the British artist (above with his work) charged with manslaughter by gross negligence after two women were killed when one of his inflatable “Dreamspace” sculptures overturned in July 2006 in Chester-le-Street, England, the BBC reported. Elizabeth Collings and Claire Furmedge died when a gust of wind separated the creation  consisting of inflated rooms connected by tunnels  from its moorings. Another 13 people were injured. Mr. Agis, 76, also faces charges under health and safety laws.

headline: Jack-Rabbit Habits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defying Bush, House Passes Broad Housing Bill
text: WASHINGTON  House Democrats defied a veto threat from President Bush on Thursday as they approved a broad housing bill that would provide up to $300 billion in federally insured loans to refinance the mortgages of debt-strapped homeowners.

headline: Iran: A Hate Note on Israel’s Birthday
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad called Israel a “stinking corpse” that was doomed to fail, and warned countries that they would “burn in the fire of their people’s hatred” if they helped Israel, the news agency IRNA reported. “Today the reason for Zionist regime’s existence is questioned, and this regime is on its way to annihilation,” he said in a speech on the 60th anniversary of the Jewish state.

headline: Pedaling, and Protecting, New Hampshire Trails
text: POLLEN erupted from the trees like smoke from a forest fire. We were resting with our bikes atop granite cliffs, looking out over the Saco River, taking a break from mountain biking in the White Mountains of New Hampshire.

headline: No Sex, Please, We’re British Indians
text: The New Group, a theater company that specializes in up close and personal ensemble work, now invites you to invade the privacy of a pair of newlyweds. But don’t worry. Even if you shudder at the idea of celebrity sex tapes and wedding-theme reality shows, this is one invitation you’ll probably want to accept.

headline: The Conservative Revival
text: For years, American and British politics were in sync. Reagan came in roughly the same time as Thatcher, and Clinton’s Third Way approach mirrored Blair’s. But the British conservatives never had a Gingrich revolution in the 1990s or the Bush victories thereafter. They got their losing in early, and, in the wilderness, they rethought modern conservatism while their American counterparts were clinging to power.

headline: Myanmar’s Biggest City Still Paralyzed After 5 Days
text: YANGON, Myanmar  Five days after the powerful cyclone struck, this city, Myanmar’s commercial capital and until Saturday a verdant oasis of wide avenues, was far from back to normal on Thursday.

headline: Thinking About November
text: The fight for the Democratic nomination seems to be winding down. It’s not completely over, but the odds now overwhelmingly favor Barack Obama.

headline: A Family That Surfs to a Beat: Its Own
text: There are many different ways to drop off the grid, but few dropped off with such style and urgency as Dorian Paskowitz, the paterfamilias of what is lovingly and at times enviably described as the first family of surfing. It was an intensity in part born of his passionately felt engagement with history as a Jew, which took him from Stanford Medical School in the 1940s to button-down respectability in the 1950s and, thereafter, on the road and into the blue yonder with a devoted wife, nine children, a succession of battered campers and the surfboards that were by turns the family’s cradles, playpens, lifelines and shields.

headline: After Them the Monsoon: Two Worlds Collide in India
text: Fatal culture clash, imperialist entitlement, forbidden passion between master and servant: the ingredients of the Indian director Santosh Sivan’s period piece “Before the Rains” may be awfully familiar, but the film lends them the force of tragedy. From the moment Moores (Linus Roache), an arrogant British planter in the southwestern Indian state of Kerala, hands a gun to his loyal manservant T. K. (Rahul Bose), you can be certain that the weapon will be discharged and lives destroyed.

headline: That Congenial Spot Revisited, With a World-Class Orchestra Playing Along
text: The New York Philharmonic calls its charming performance of Lerner and Loewe’s “Camelot,” which opened on Wednesday night before an adoring audience, a semistaged production. Actually the staging is fairly elaborate.

headline: A Mystery With No Resolution
text: “The Da Vinci Code” brought to the masses the theory that there exists a lineage traceable to Jesus and Mary Magdalene. The sensationalistic documentary “Bloodline” further explores this supposition, one that is gospel to some and totally ludicrous to others.

headline: McCain’s Vote in 2000 Is Revived in a Ruckus
text: WASHINGTON  Did Senator John McCain not vote for George W. Bush in 2000?

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Argentine Farmers Cut Off Exports
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Farmers in Argentina began cutting off grain exports on Thursday after the breakdown of talks to resolve a conflict over government agricultural policies.

headline: A Portrait of Perseverance
text: As a portrait of perseverance and hope, “Refusenik,” named after the Soviet Jews who were denied the right to emigrate and persecuted for asking, is tough to beat. Sadly, it falls short as entertainment because of the plodding, overly studious approach of the director, Laura Bialis.

headline: García Plays in Calm Weather, Leaving Others to Twist in the Wind
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  While the hard and fast T.P.C. at Sawgrass twisted some of the world’s best golfers slowly in the hot wind Thursday, Sergio García was applying his newfound old putting stroke to take the lead after the first round of the Players Championship.

headline: Air Travelers Need to Pack More Money
text: Air travel these days is an adventure with many surprises, some of them unpleasant.

headline: Madonna Sets Tour
text: On Aug. 23, a week after she turns 50, Madonna will embark on a tour of Europe and North America, Agence France-Presse reported. Her “Sticky and Sweet Tour,” promoting her new album, “Hard Candy,” will take her to nine European cities, beginning in Cardiff, Wales, before she plays 18 dates in the United States and Canada. The North American leg will begin on Oct. 3 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., and include Madison Square Garden on Oct. 6 and 7.

headline: A Little Pity, Please, for Lenders
text: General Motors thought it had found a safe and profitable business, far away from the ups and downs of the automobile business that was causing so many headaches. Instead, it found an albatross that is now forcing the company to put up billions of dollars just to stay in business and hope for a turnaround.

headline: When Life Gives Lemons, Pick Up a Pool Stick
text: You can almost smell the clammy atmosphere inside the New York pool hall to which Kailey Sullivan (Famke Janssen), a tough cookie from upstate, periodically repairs to regain her bearings in “Turn the River.” Kailey, who has served time in prison, is a card shark and pool hustler who lives by her wits and exists in a state of such high anxiety that stress makes her retch.

headline: In Middle East, Looking Beyond Bush
text: WASHINGTON  The 2008 race for the White House is casting a long shadow over President Bush. So long, in fact, that it may extend all the way to the Middle East.

headline: The Fight Stuff
text: San Francisco

headline: Britain: Best Buy in Venture
text: The Best Buy Company, the electronics retailer, will open its first stores in Europe by investing £1.1 billion ($2.16 billion) in a joint venture with the Carphone Warehouse Group. Best Buy, based in Richfield, Minn., will open stores under its brand name across Europe beginning next year in Britain.

headline: Sen. Clinton and the Campaign
text: There is a lot of talk that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is now fated to lose the Democratic nomination and should pull out of the race. We believe it is her right to stay in the fight and challenge Senator Barack Obama as long as she has the desire and the means to do so. That is the essence of the democratic process.

headline: Ritzenhein Withdraws
text: Dathan Ritzenhein, who set a Central Park record a year ago in the Healthy Kidney 10k, withdrew Thursday from this year’s race on May 17. He said an injury to his left foot had kept him from racing for 13 weeks and had set back his training for the marathon in this summer’s Beijing Olympics.

headline: Footnotes
text: Whoopi Goldberg will host the 62nd annual Tony Awards ceremony, to be broadcast live by CBS from Radio City Music Hall on June 15. Nominations will be announced on Tuesday. ... The Labyrinth Theater Company will present “Bitter Honey,” a benefit evening of readings of underperformed and never performed works by Eric Bogosian, on May 21 and 22 at the Anspacher Theater at the Public Theater. ... Vaclav Havel’s wife, Dagmar, citing reasons of health, has quit her lead role in “Leaving,” the play written for her by Mr. Havel, the former Czech president, Variety reported. The play is to open in Prague on May 22. ... The Nobel winner Gabriel García Márquez, who said two years ago that he was finished with writing, seems to have changed his mind, The Guardian of London reported. A friend, Darío Arizmendi, director of news at Radio Caracol in Colombia, said the author, 81, was finishing an untitled novel that should appear next year.

headline: An ‘Our Town’ Stage for the Creative Set
text: THREE OAKS was once just another small southwestern Michigan farm town burdened by a sluggish local economy. But in recent years, pioneering Chicagoans with a creative bent have transformed Three Oaks, about 70 miles away, into a hot spot for second-home buyers smitten with the arts.

headline: From Japan, With Genes to Capture the Belmont
text: By way of Japan, Casino Drive has the breeding to win the Belmont Stakes, and maybe even the talent. No one else seems capable of stopping Big Brown’s march toward a Triple Crown, but maybe the mystery horse from the Far East can.

headline: Fossella Admits He Had an Extramarital Affair
text: Representative Vito J. Fossella, the Staten Island Republican who was arrested on drunken-driving charges in Virginia last week, acknowledged on Thursday that he had fathered a daughter, now 3, in an extramarital affair. But he declined to address questions about his political future.

headline: A Heroine’s Inner Flame, Fueled by an Excess of Feeling
text: “I am burning!” cries Alma Winemiller one unusually cold New Year’s Eve in Glorious Hill, Miss. Pitched forward with excitement, her hands fluttering and heart palpitating, Alma, the heroine of Tennessee Williams’s “Eccentricities of a Nightingale,” seems animated by some inner flame.

headline: A Cop in a Tailspin
text: Michael Madsen, best known as the sadistic Mr. Blonde in “Reservoir Dogs,” has appeared in his share of B movies, and “Vice” won’t catapult him to the A list. But the film, a muddled, disposable crime thriller, has modest merits.

headline: ‘Idol’ Trounces Barbara Walters
text: Barbara Walters was no match for “American Idol” on Wednesday in the ratings, as a news special devoted to Ms. Walters failed to lift ABC out of fourth place on the night. Nielsen estimated that 7.4 million viewers tuned in at 10 p.m. for “Audition: Barbara Walters’ Journey,” in which Charles Gibson interviewed his colleague about her career and new memoir. The hourlong program fell short of its time-slot competitors, NBC’s “Law & Order” (8.8 million) and CBS’s “CSI: NY” (12.6 million), as well as Fox’s “American Idol,” which dominated the 9 p.m. hour with 22.4 million viewers. Fox led the night over all, followed by CBS, which attracted 12.8 million viewers for “Criminal Minds” at 9. NBC edged past ABC for third place as a two-hour edition of “Deal or No Deal” (7.2 million) outpaced ABC’s “Wife Swap” (7 million) and “Supernanny” (5.1 million) from 8 to 10.

headline: Decades of Rhythms, Tensing and Stretching Still
text: The bassist Charlie Haden and the drummer Paul Motian, both in their 70s, have their methods of mellow provocation. Mr. Haden looks for a kind of simple major-triad vernacular, and an uncomfortably plain-spoken feeling passes through his playing, giving it friction. Mr. Motian sketches rhythm on drums and cymbals, avoiding the usual combinations; a steady pulse is always somewhere inside, but obscured by open space. They have played together a lot in the last 40 years: with Keith Jarrett in the 1960s and ’70s; with Mr. Haden’s Liberation Music Orchestra; with the pianists Geri Allen, Paul Bley and Gonzalo Rubalcaba, among others.

headline: Eddy Arnold, 89, Country Singer With Pop Luster, Dies
text: NASHVILLE  Eddy Arnold, the gentleman crooner who took country music uptown and sold more than 85 million recordings over seven decades, died Thursday. He was 89.

headline: El Banco and Ballyhack Golf Club
text: El Banco

headline: Some Oil Companies Settle Suit Over Chemical Cleanup
text: Several major oil companies have agreed to pay the Suffolk County Water Authority $74 million for the cost of filtering a potentially hazardous additive in gasoline that has leaked from storage tanks into the groundwater, the agency said on Thursday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Thursday about new theater productions at the World Financial Center misstated the schedule for two works. “Giant Place Detail” is to be performed on Saturday night; tonight, is not the final performance. And “Corporate Carnival” opens on Wednesday for a four-day run, not for three days.

headline: A Story Shared by Father and Son, and Now by Audiences
text: When John Lithgow was 5 or 6, he would sit on the nubby burnt-orange couch in his living room each night with his older brother and sister, and their father would read them stories. Theirs being a theatrical, high-minded family  Mr. Lithgow’s father, Arthur, was a director and a producer of Shakespeare festivals  Mother Goose was not involved.

headline: North Korea Gives U.S. Files on Plutonium Efforts
text: WASHINGTON  North Korea has turned over to the United States 18,000 pages of documents related to its plutonium program dating from 1990, in an effort to resolve remaining differences in a pending agreement meant to begin the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, Bush administration officials said Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Morning Hangover, Spouse and Jackpot
text: “What Happens in Vegas,” one of those junky time-wasters that routinely pop up in movie theaters, won’t make you laugh much or at all. (Once was enough for me.) But if you know anything about the art or have ever marveled at how even the most generic of old B movies look pretty good (they were usually in focus, for starters), you may wonder how a major studio like 20th Century Fox could release something this crudely manufactured, with its graceless setups, unstable lensing and ghastly lighting. It also makes you wonder if executives at studios look at dailies, much less can hear the poetry of the English language.

headline: From a Greek Myth, Some Lessons on Crazy Love
text: In Greek mythology, as in life, few situations are more excruciating than being dumped and not knowing why. The newest production by Gotham Chamber Opera, being performed at the Abrons Arts Center, brings just such a distraught heroine to the surface in “Ariadne Unhinged.”

headline: Indian Court Declares Painting Not Obscene
text: A court in India has quashed three obscenity cases against M. F. Husain, one of the country’s most famous contemporary painters, the BBC reported. The charges contended that Mr. Husain, 92, offended Hindus with a work, above, that represented India as a nude goddess. The court in Delhi ruled that the painting was not obscene. Mr. Husain, who has been accused of obscenity in at least seven cases, apologized for the painting, which he declared an “expression of purity.” He has been living in the Middle East because of the lawsuits, but his lawyer, Akhil Sibal, quoted the court as saying Mr. Husain “deserves to be at home, painting his canvases.”

headline: Down and Out in Connecticut
text: Here is a shameful fact that Connecticut’s politicians should ponder: Over the past two decades, of all the 50 states, income inequality increased the most by far in Connecticut  and not only because of the outsize gains of the state’s many hedge fund managers.

headline: A Tale of Two Cities, Only One With Sewers
text: When Gordhandas Soni, the owner of an Indian food company, agreed to relocate his warehouse and factory to Willets Point, Queens, back in 1990, it never occurred to him to ask about some of the more basic amenities  the sewage system, for example. “You never ask, ‘You have sewers here?’ ” said Mr. Soni, whose business is called House of Spices. “In America, right here, in the heart of New York City? No! It never occurred to me to ask. It would be silly to ask.”

headline: Aural Examination
text: Anyone whose blood has boiled after being kept awake by a persistent car alarm can vicariously relish the revenge taken by David Owen (Tim Robbins), a Manhattan lawyer with a short fuse. Rushing into the street one evening, he gleefully vandalizes the offending vehicle.

headline: Finding Food in Brooklyn
text: To the Editor:

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Zimbabwe: Arrests in Government Crackdown
text: The government intensified its crackdown on critics and opponents. Davison Maruziva, editor of the independent newspaper The Standard, was jailed for printing an opinion article by a prominent opposition politician. The police also arrested Lovemore Matombo, president of Zimbabwe’s Congress of Trade Unions, and Wellington Chibebe, its secretary general. They were charged with inciting others to overthrow the government, an official from the group said.

headline: Blue-Light Specials at Citigroup as Its New Chief Plans a Revival
text: Vikram S. Pandit is doing some serious spring cleaning at Citigroup.

headline: Bomber’s Final Messages Exhort Fighters Against U.S.
text: BAGHDAD  The last words of a suicide bomber in Mosul were a rallying cry for Muslims to join the fight against Americans.

headline: Broken Spirits on the Mend
text: Shot piecemeal over the course of four years on locations in 18 countries, and paid for out of the pocket of its co-writer and director, Tarsem Singh, “The Fall” is a genuine labor of love  and a real bore. The story takes place once upon a time in a picturesque Los Angeles hospital, where a pudgy Romanian 5-year-old named Alexandria (Catinca Untaru) convalesces from a broken arm. Befriending her fellow patient Roy Walker (Lee Pace), a movie stuntman with busted legs and a cracked spirit, Alexandra sits enthralled as Roy relates an epic tale of colorful heroes seeking revenge on the nefarious Governor Odious (Daniel Caltagirone). The details of this saga, a threadbare patchwork of postcard exoticism, turgid characterizations, stilted duels and lackluster spectacle, are projected via the imagination of a little girl cognizant, it would seem, of the full repertory of high-gloss, empty-headed pictorialism deployed by corporate advertising.

headline: Jammys’ Next Act: Preaching Beyond the Flock
text: During one of his brief moments onstage at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the guitarist Trey Anastasio likened being in a rock band to performing a sort of community service. “Thank you so much for letting us be part of your experience,” he said, sounding choked up. It was late in the evening at the seventh annual Jammy Awards, and Mr. Anastasio was accepting a lifetime achievement award on behalf of Phish, the group in which he humbly toiled for 21 years.

headline: The Lucrative Art of War
text: Congress is finally moving to shut one of the more egregious forms of Iraq war profiteering: defense contractors using offshore shell companies to avoid paying their fair share of payroll taxes. The practice is widespread and Congressional investigators have been dispatched to one of the prime tax refuges, the Cayman Islands, to seek a firsthand estimate of how much the Treasury is being shorted.

headline: Senator’s Ties to Real Estate Draw Criticism
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  He has made millions as a title insurance executive, landlord and real estate developer in this college town, where the economy, despite trouble nationwide, is still growing nicely. Now, as a United States senator, with the mortgage mess fueling a national economic slowdown, Richard C. Shelby has more say over the revamping of housing finance laws than almost anyone else in Congress.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: National

headline: Dreams of Fields
text: FOR an urban second-home buyer, the allure of a farmhouse in the northern Catskills has much to do with the setting. There, rolling pastures are bordered by blue-green mountains that rise from the edges of patchwork farmland; languid cows graze in meadows bordered by stone walls; and stands of sugar maples line winding roads where silos and red barns are commonplace. There are log homes, chalets and manufactured homes, too, but in Delaware County, it is the indigenous farmhouse that defines the regional aesthetic.

headline: Taming That Overwhelming Urge to Smoke
text: If you smoke, no one needs to tell you how bad it is. So why haven’t you quit? Why hasn’t everyone?

headline: After Making It Out of Paris, Finding There’s No Escape
text: There’s enough blood in the unrated French horror film “Frontier(s)” to satiate even the most ravenous gore hounds. The real surprise here is that this creepy, contemporary gross-out also has some ideas, visual and otherwise, wedged among its sanguineous drips, swaying meat hooks and whirring table saw.

headline: Contemporary May be Hot, but Here the Focus Is on Comfort
text: With its crimson-and-white tent ceiling and booths painted comforting shades of navy, taupe and burgundy, the International Fine Art Fair at the Park Avenue Armory could be mistaken for a posh clubhouse. Many of the booths have been outfitted with antique furniture, plush carpeting and fake fireplaces.

headline: A Call for Criminal Inquiry on Mine Collapse
text: WASHINGTON  The general manager and possibly other senior staff members at the Crandall Canyon Mine near Huntington, Utah, where nine miners died last August, withheld information from federal officials that could have prevented the disaster and should face a criminal inquiry, the chairman of a Congressional investigation said Thursday.

headline: When Immigrants Die in Detention
text: To the Editor:

headline: How’s That ‘Rule of Law’ Work Now?
text: Join us on a journey in the time machine. We’re not going back terribly far, only to December 1998, when the House of Representatives impeached President Bill Clinton for having lied about sex with “that woman.”

headline: Yanks Avoid a Sweep and Exult a Little
text: Jason Giambi stuck out his tongue and kept it at the corner of his mouth as he stared at a ball he had just sent on a parabola. The ball’s flight, which began as a first-pitch fastball from the Cleveland Indians right-hander Paul Byrd, ended in the upper deck, just fair of the right-field pole.

headline: Caught Between Her Passion and Her Pension
text: More tired than the fantasy it promotes, “A Previous Engagement” aims at middle-aged women with the subtlety of a pitch for bladder-control medication. Take a frustrated wife and her sexually inept husband, add a dollop of temptation (a French accent can’t hurt), and plunk it all down in an exotic location. The world may roll on, but the dreams of the everyday housewife are as predictable as the tides.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to Quit
text: Dr. Richard H. Carmona, who was surgeon general of the United States from 2002 to 2006, is a distinguished professor at the Mel and Enid Zuckerman College of Public Health at the University of Arizona and president of the nonprofit Canyon Ranch Institute in Tucson. His advice to smokers: “Stop now. It will improve the quality and quantity of your life, no question.” He says that smokers should know these five things about quitting.

headline: Going for the Finger-Licking Gusto
text: It’s opening day at the new American Chicken Bunker, and, as might be expected of a fast-food restaurant built atop an American Indian burial ground, things are going to hell. Outside, a group of protesters led by the frequently topless Collegiate Lesbians Against Mega-Conglomerations (CLAM) vents its outrage at the perpetuators of the chicken holocaust.

headline: Your House, Their Nest
text: LET’S see what winter has brought us.

headline: Endorsers’ Relationships Tested by Suit Swapping
text: The Speedo representative walked onto a pool deck in South Austin, Tex., a salesman there to try to lead two Nike athletes into temptation. He showed up at a Longhorn Aquatics practice last week with two bags containing an assortment of Speedo swimsuits, including the hotter-than-a-jalapeño LZR Racer, the uniform of choice for swimmers who have accounted for 36 of the 40 world records set this year.

headline: Shift From Savannah to Sahara Was Gradual, Research Suggests
text: Six thousand years ago, northern Africa was a place of trees, grasslands, lakes and people. Today, it is the Sahara  a desolate area larger area than Australia.

headline: Polygamists Are Asked About Fostering Children
text: ST. GEORGE, Utah  Utah’s attorney general, Mark L. Shurtleff, sat before a room of perhaps 400 people, most of them fundamentalist polygamists, at a town hall meeting here on Thursday night. He asked for a show of hands. How many people, he wanted to know, were related to the children who were seized last month in a raid in Texas in an investigation of possible marriage and abuse of child brides?

headline: Austria’s Dungeon Man: ‘I Must Have Been Crazy’
text: FRANKFURT  Josef Fritzl, the 73-year-old Austrian who imprisoned and raped his daughter for nearly a quarter century, said he knew his actions were wrong. But he denied that he was a “beast,” and he said that he thought constantly about freeing her from the underground vault where she was locked up, along with three of her seven children, whom he had fathered.

headline: The Sights and Sounds of Oppression
text: The Danish director Henning Carlsen has Max Roach to thank for the revival of “Dilemma,” his debut feature from 1962. Screening as part of Jazz Score, the Museum of Modern Art’s survey of movies with original jazz compositions, this black-and-white drama gets a blast of vitality from a soundtrack hopped up on Roach’s bebop and the infectious swing of Gideon Nxumalo, a South African composer adept in the style of indigenous jazz known as marabi.

headline: Gunmen Kill Chief of Mexico’s Police
text: MEXICO CITY  Gunmen assassinated the acting chief of Mexico’s federal police early on Thursday morning in the most brazen attack so far in the year-and-a-half-old struggle between the government and organized crime gangs.

headline: Scandal May Hurt Family-Values Image and Hopes for a Sixth Term
text: Representative Vito J. Fossella has left open the door to fighting for a sixth term in Congress, but there is a sense among politicians  both Democratic and Republican  as well as analysts that the embattled congressman’s political prospects are dim at best.

headline: American Rancher Resists Land Reform Plans in Bolivia
text: CARAPARICITO, Bolivia  From the time Ronald Larsen drove his pickup truck here from his native Montana in 1969 and bought a sprawling cattle ranch for a song, he lived a quiet life in remote southeastern Bolivia, farming corn, herding cattle and amassing vast land holdings.

headline: New Direction for Skydiving: From Vertical to Horizontal
text: PALATKA, Fla.  It was a Sunday morning in the South during Lent. As church parking lots filled with cars and pews with people, another group concerned with a different kind of resurrection gathered at a small airport nearby.

headline: McNamee’s Lawyers Preparing to Send Investigators to Houston
text: A day before the Mitchell report was released in December, two retired Houston police officers working as investigators for the lawyer for Roger Clemens interviewed Clemens’s former trainer Brian McNamee in New York.

headline: From Energetic Players, a Mix of Modernism
text: The Argento Chamber Ensemble is devoted mainly to the more abstruse side of the contemporary-music repertory. But at Casa Italiana on the Columbia University campus on Wednesday night, these energetic young players showed how varied that brand of modernism can be. They juxtaposed works exploring harmonic ingenuity, sheer display and continuously morphing timbres that both create and frustrate expectations.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Deal to Build at Railyards on West Side Collapses
text: Six weeks after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority selected Tishman Speyer Properties to build a vast complex of office towers, apartment buildings and parks over the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan, the deal has fallen apart.

headline: To Reduce Costs, Warner Brothers Closing 2 Film Divisions
text: LOS ANGELES  Warner Brothers announced Thursday that it would shut two troubled film divisions, a cost-cutting move rooted in the changing economics of the specialty film business.

headline: Bad Investments and a $7.8 Billion Loss at A.I.G.
text: The fortunes of American International Group, one of the world’s biggest insurance companies, rise and fall on precise calculations of risk. Last quarter, those calculations went seriously awry.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The On Education column on Wednesday, about the impact of the planned closing of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn’s Bath Beach neighborhood, misstated this year’s enrollment in the Lafayette building. It is 1,064, not 720.

headline: Russia Expels U.S. Military Attachés
text: WASHINGTON  Russia has ordered the expulsion of two American military attachés working at the United States embassy in Moscow, the State Department said on Thursday.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Sinkhole and Town: Now You See It ...
text: DAISETTA, Tex.  A huge and ravenous sinkhole that threatened to swallow this little East Texas oil town gobbled more crumbling earth Thursday but spared, at least for now, homes, the high school and the main road, Farm to Market 770.

headline: In a Weak Economy, Quirky Restaurant Ads Yield to Tried and True
text: ONE of latest victims of the sagging economy is a sass-talking “spokes- apple” that briefly starred in a campaign for Applebee’s, the budget restaurant chain.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Two Boys Past Adolescence Still Just Being Boys
text: “Oh, grow up!” would be a reasonable response to “Double Album: Daniel Guzmán and Steven Shearer,” an intermittently interesting but ultimately disappointing exhibition at the New Museum. Organized by Richard Flood, the museum’s chief curator, it introduces two artists in their 40s who not only share a fascination with male adolescence and classic rock but also seem mired in creative adolescence themselves.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on April 14 about the funeral of Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein and his wife, Deborah, who were killed in a fire at their home in New Rochelle, N.Y., misidentified the community where the rabbi’s synagogue is located. Although the synagogue is named Young Israel of Scarsdale, it is actually in New Rochelle.

headline: Olmert ‘Never Took a Bribe,’ He Says
text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said Thursday that he had taken contributions from a Long Island businessman starting in the 1990s but that they were legitimate campaign funds, not bribes, and that he would resign if indicted as a result of a developing investigation into the affair.

headline: Pentagon Drops Post in Pakistan for Top General
text: WASHINGTON  When the Pentagon announced in March that Maj. Gen. Jay W. Hood would become the senior American officer based in Pakistan, it reflected the military’s aim to put a crisis-tested veteran in a critical job at a pivotal time in the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban in Pakistan’s tribal areas.

headline: What to Ask About Quitting
text: Here are some questions you may not think to ask, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about research into how animals learn misspelled the Latin name of a worm used frequently in laboratory experiments. It is Caenorhabditis elegans, not Caenorhadits. The article also misspelled the name of the university where one of the researchers, Reuven Dukas, works as a biologist. It is McMaster University, not McMasters.

headline: Beverlee McKinsey, 72, Actress in Decades of Soap Operas, Is Dead
text: Beverlee McKinsey, a well-known soap opera actress of the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s who played memorably strong women on “Another World” and “Guiding Light,” died on May 2 in Los Angeles. She was 72 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: A Dashing Agent in Egypt
text: The hero of “OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies” might be described as a French equivalent of James Bond. Or even a precursor, since the first novel in which he appears predates Ian Fleming’s “Casino Royale” by a few years. But the template is basically the same: a dashing agent seducing, scheming and shooting his way through cold war trouble spots in the service of a fading imperial power.

headline: Salmon Gone, Fishermen Try to Adapt on a Changing Coast
text: CHARLESTON, Ore.  So long, salmon. Steve Wilson is refitting his 51-foot troller to fish for the future. No longer will he cast for the conflicted symbol of Northwest abundance and bitterness. No more fishing for a myth.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about changes in the way diseases are classified misspelled the university where Dr. Jacalyn Duffin works as a professor of the history of medicine. It is Queen’s University, not Queens.

headline: Letting Loose, Lena Horne Style, but With Original Touches
text: Ferocious. That is the word the pop-jazz singer Jane Scheckter applies to Lena Horne in “From This Moment On,” her tribute to Ms. Horne, who is now 90. Ms. Scheckter recalled at Broadway Baby bistro on Wednesday evening that Ms. Horne, along with Bobby Short and Tony Perkins, was one of her youthful idols. Holding up an old LP of Ms. Horne’s 1957 live album at the Waldorf-Astoria, she credited it with rerouting her girlhood fantasy of movie stardom to nightclub singing.

headline: From High School Student to Ruthless Madam
text: Until it crosses a shadowy line dividing serious comedy from distasteful exploitation, “The Babysitters” has the makings of an incisive satire of greed and lust in suburbia. Katherine Waterston (a daughter of Sam) portrays Shirley Lyner, a cool-headed high school honors student and baby sitter who stumbles into an affair with her employer, Michael Beltran (a miscast John Leguizamo). A middle-aged advertising executive who feels guilty about their first stolen kiss while taking her home, Michael overtips her. When they eventually have sex, he gives her $200. This paves the way for the enterprising Shirley to enlist her best friend, Melissa (Lauren Birkell), as a “baby sitter” for Michael’s pal Jerry (Andy Comeau). Before long Shirley is running a teenage prostitution ring and demanding 20 percent of her girls’ earnings.

headline: In F.E.C. Moves, Some See Effort to Aid McCain
text: For months, the White House and Senate Republicans have been content to let a political impasse over vacancies at the Federal Election Commission persist, sidelining the regulatory agency in the throes of a heated presidential campaign.

headline: Questions of Rent Tactics by Private Equity
text: Private investment firms have been amassing what may seem like unusual stakes in New York real estate: they have bought hundreds of apartment buildings with thousands of rent-regulated units across the city that produce decidedly meager returns.

headline: Retailers’ April Is Mixed, With Discounters Strong
text: Wal-Mart and Costco reported April sales that rose more than analysts estimated as American consumers, contending with record gasoline prices, sought discounts on clothing and food.

headline: Britain: Jihadist Cleric Released on Bail
text: An appeals panel ordered the release on bail of Abu Qatada, a Muslim preacher from Jordan once described by a Spanish judge as Osama bin Laden’s “ambassador to Europe.” He was convicted in two bombings in Jordan in the 1990s but then fled to Britain and has been fighting extradition while in prison there since 2002. Home Secretary Jacqui Smith said she was “extremely disappointed.”

headline: Obama Takes a Victory Lap
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama began trying to rally the Democratic Party around him on Thursday and struck a tougher tone against Senator John McCain, saying Mr. McCain was “losing his bearings” in his pursuit of the White House.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on May 1 about a lawsuit against the Empire State Development Corporation over the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misstated, in some copies, the year in which a financing agreement that prompted the lawsuit was signed by the state agency and the project’s developer, Forest City Ratner. It was 2007, not 2006.

headline: Clinton Aide Says Race May Not Go to Convention
text: As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton rejected calls for her to drop out of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, her campaign signaled Thursday that Mrs. Clinton might not take the battle all the way to the convention at the end of August.

headline: Amy Winehouse Freed
text: After nine hours of questioning, Amy Winehouse was released from police custody in London after her arrest on suspicion of drug offenses, the police said on Thursday, Reuters reported. The arrest related to video images submitted to the police that showed her smoking what appeared to be crack cocaine. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was not charged.

headline: Olympic Torch Reaches Everest Peak
text: BEIJING  A team of climbers trudged through snow and ice to carry the Olympic torch to the summit of Mount Everest on Thursday, fulfilling a long-held goal of the Chinese government to have the Olympic flame lit on top of the world’s highest mountain.

headline: Met’s Nautical Mural Has a Return Voyage
text: For nearly two decades some patrons of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s old first-floor restaurant liked to perch at the bar so they could take in the lustrous splendors of its big Art Deco mural.

headline: Fist Pumps and Roar Draw Ire of Indians
text: Until this week, Joba Chamberlain entered games at Yankee Stadium with an air of invincibility about him  much like the one exuded by closer Mariano Rivera, who is 17 years his senior.

headline: A Fear of Big Demand for Corporate Loans
text: When times were sunny, banks promised scores of companies money for a rainy day. Now that day is here  and the banks, hard pressed themselves, are worried they will have to keep their promises.

headline: Selected Studies: Smoking Cessation
text: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Help for Myanmar
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday Nights With the Siblings
text: For well over a year now, at 10 on Sunday nights, I’ve turned on “Brothers & Sisters” with the pre-emptive regret of someone gustily digging into a second piece of cake.

text: MOVIES
