text: ROCOCO EYE-OPENERS

headline: Somalia: Militiamen Kill U.N. Aid Worker
text: A truck driver working for the United Nations World Food Program was killed while delivering food in central Somalia, the United Nations said. The driver’s convoy was stopped by militiamen who demanded money at an illegal roadblock north of Galkayo. An argument broke out, and a bandit opened fire, officials said.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article last Friday about President Bush’s proposal for $770 million in foreign food aid misidentified the room in the White House where he made the announcement. It was the Diplomatic Reception Room, not the East Room.

headline: An Alien Sighting on Planet Pittsburgh
text: PITTSBURGH  Lately, it seems, biennial exhibitions don’t do much except sit there, looking good and offending no one. Instead of being shows that people “love to hate,” or vice versa, these big, often international affairs now inspire mild interest or resigned indifference. Their underlying message seems to be: Careful now, don’t frighten the trustees.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 112 Baylor
text: Location: Waco, Tex.

headline: The Return of ‘The Gong Show’
text: Variety reports: “Comedy Central is reviving Chuck Barris’ ‘The Gong Show,’ with comedian Dave Attell as host.” The show will premiere July 17. The original “Gong Show” was hosted by Mr. Barris, left, and aired on NBC and in syndication in the late 1970s.

headline: ABC’s McPherson Signs New Contract
text: “The Walt Disney Company signed the president of ABC, Stephen McPherson, to a new contract, signaling confidence in the maverick executive’s ability to deliver new hits to succeed workhorses like ‘Grey’s Anatomy,'” Brooks Barnes reports.

headline: Flip Sal: The Barbaro of 1974
text: This year’s Kentucky Derby returned the horse Flip Sal back into the news. The largely forgotten Flip Sal was the 1974 Kentucky Derby’s answer to Barbaro.

headline: Just Call Him Jesus
text: Locals muse about a neighborhood man they know as Jesus. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Prawns Instead of Salmon
text: With most of Oregon and California’s commercial salmon fishery shut down this year, fishermen like Steve Wilson are looking for alternatives.

headline: When We Think We Know Someone
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Envelopes, Please
text: This year’s National Design Award winners were announced by the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum on May 8, and the winners were a mixed bag. The Lifetime Achievement award went to a refreshing choice: Charles Harrison, an industrial designer at Sears, Roebuck & Company for over three decades and one of the first African-Americans in his field. Other winners, however, made you wonder. Pentagram partner Michael Bierut deserved his Design Mind award, and Tom Kundig his Architecture Design award, but it would have been nice if they had been recognized before they became megastars. And giving awards to mainstream firms, like Rockwell Group for Interior Design, does little to encourage young, edgy designers to submit their work, even if they’re nominated. But maybe the general public will be more adventurous than the NDA jury: The People’s Design Award, in which anyone can vote for their favorite design, will be announced on October 23rd.

headline: ‘A Mysterious Sinkhole Near Houston …’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: That Would Take the Cake
text: Jenna Bush’s wedding in Texas on Saturday is touted as a low-key affair, but it’s a fair bet it won’t be this low-key:

headline: Flomerics Rejects Mentor’s Buyout Bid
text: Shares in British engineering software firm Flomerics Group surged on Friday after rejecting a buyout offer from larger U.S. rival Mentor Graphics, saying it would explore interest from several other parties.

headline: Julius Baer Up on Standard Charter Bid Rumors
text: Shares in Julius Baer Holding rose Thursday amid rumors British bank Standard Chartered is preparing a bid, valuing the Swiss private bank at over 23 billion Swiss francs ($2.2 billion)

headline: Sprott Raises $197 Million in I.P.O.
text: Sprott, a mining and energy hedge fund, raised 200 million Canadian dollars ($197 million) in the biggest Canadian initial public offering in five months.

headline: Sovereign Said to Plan Big Equity Offering
text: Sovereign Bancorp, the second-largest U.S. savings and loan, plans to raise just over $1 billion in an equity offering to help it navigate a difficult economic environment, Reuters reported.

headline: Uncertainty as Deadline for British Energy Bids Approaches
text: Shares in nuclear power generator British Energy fell 2.5 percent on Friday on fading hopes that a bidding war would push up the price for the stake being sold by the British government.

headline: Société Générale Names Chief Financial Officer
text: Société Générale, the French bank hit by a rogue trading scandal, said Didier Valet would become its new chief financial officer.

headline: Lime Rock Raises $1.4 Billion for New Energy Fund
text: Lime Rock , a private equity firm that focuses on the global energy sector announced Thursday that it had closed its fifth Lime Rock Partners fund, Lime Rock Partners V, L.P., with a total $1.4 billion in investor capital commitments.

headline: V.C.s Fund Serious Business
text: Serious Business, a San Francisco-based Internet application start-up, has raised $4 million in Series A funding, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Julius Baer Warns of Headwinds
text: Julius Baer Holding Friday tempered profit expectations as the strong Swiss franc and unpredictable markets ate into managed assets.

headline: SlideShare Scores $3 Million Funding from Cuban and Others
text: SlideShare, the PowerPoint social network backed by Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban and others, has closed on a $3 million A round led by Venrock, the company announced Thursday.

headline: S.E.C. Fines Marvell $10 Million
text: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of semiconductors, agreed on Thursday to pay a $10 million civil fine to settle regulators’ accusations of improper backdating of stock options.

headline: Carlyle to Lead Buyout of Japanese Glass Business
text: The Carlyle Group will lead a 58.1 billion yen ($560 million) management buyout of an LCD glass venture jointly owned by Japan’s Hoya and Nippon Sheet Glass, Hoya said on Friday.

headline: RealNetworks to Spin Off Casual Games Business
text: RealNetworks said Thursday that it plans to spin off its casual games business into a separate company and distribute its shares to RealNetworks stockholders.

headline: Alcoa Names Chief Executive
text: Alcoa named its president, Klaus Kleinfeld, as its new chief executive on Thursday.

headline: Gomez Aims for Nasdaq Listing
text: Gomez, an Internet performance monitoring company, has filed to go public. But is the market ready for this small, unprofitable but fast-growing company?

headline: Charming Shoppes Averts Proxy Fight
text: A dramatic proxy showdown at apparel company Charming Shoppes ended Thursday with an 11th-hour truce that will expand the company’s board to 11 from 10.

headline: Bad Investments and a $7.8 Billion Loss at A.I.G.
text: The fortunes of American International Group, one of the world’s biggest insurance companies, rise and fall on precise calculations of risk. Last quarter, those calculations went seriously awry.

headline: Spying and Specter: The End Is in Sight
text: A links roundup on the seemingly fizzling conclusion to the Patriots’ spying scandal:

headline: For Public Hedge Fund and Private Equity Firms, Where the Upside?
text: Shareholders of publicly-traded hedge fund and buyout firms need to re-check their checklists, says Breakingviews. The downturn is highlighting the disadvantages of public scrutiny, with performance fees evaporating and new investment slowing, the publication said. But the supposed pluses – having a public currency to retain talent and grow – aren’t holding up their end of the bargain, either, it argues.

headline: One Bear Stearns Hedge Fund Seems to be Getting It Right
text: Investment bank Bear Stearns may have hit rough times but at least one of its hedge funds, the $1.2 billion Emerging Markets Macro Fund, is bouncing back from earlier losses this year.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Chief Fuels Sprint Takeover Speculation
text: The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, the largest European telecommunications company, fed speculation Thursday that it was considering a takeover bid for the U.S. mobile operator Sprint Nextel, saying the German company had an obligation to consider all acquisitions that would improve its bottom line.

headline: Microsoft Disbands Yahoo Board Nominees, Report Says
text: Microsoft continued to distance itself from Yahoo on Thursday, telling the people it had lined up to nominate to the board as part of a prospective hostile takeover battle that their services were no longer needed, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: Onex Hunts for Gambling Deals
text: Onex, Canada’s largest investment firm, is looking for deals in the United States gambling industry, and some think it might consider the recently bankrupt Tropicana Entertainment. The Globe and Mail reports that Onex has turned to Alex Yemenidjian, the former president of Kirk Kerkorian’s MGM Grand casino empire, for help in seeking out these kinds of investment opportunities.

headline: U.S. Softballers: Too Good for Their Own Good?
text: The more games the USA Softball team plays, the more impressive the feat of a college pitcher named Angela Tincher. She is the Virginia Tech senior who no-hit the national team in a 1-0 Hokies victory on March 26.

headline: Schwarzman’s Atomic Bomb Comment Sparks Chatter
text: A recent comment by Blackstone Group chieftain Stephen Schwarzman comparing a failed buyout to dropping the atomic bomb on Japan has industry observers chattering that the private equity titan may have put his foot in his mouth.

headline: Wachovia Ousts Chief From Chairman Post
text: Wachovia stripped its chief executive, G. Kennedy Thompson, of his chairman role on Thursday, separating the top management position from the top oversight post.

headline: A Fear of Big Demand for Corporate Loans
text: When times were sunny, banks promised scores of companies money for a rainy day. Now that day is here – and the banks, hard pressed themselves, are worried they will have to keep their promises.

headline: Questions of Rent Tactics by Private Equity
text: Private investment firms have been amassing what may seem like unusual stakes in New York real estate: they have bought hundreds of apartment buildings with thousands of rent-regulated units across the city that produce decidedly meager returns.

headline: The Early Word: Superdelegate Switches
text: Score two more for Barack Obama this morning.

headline: Citigroup’s Big Garage Sale
text: Vikram S. Pandit is doing some serious spring cleaning at Citigroup.

headline: Edwards Still Won’t Endorse
text: Another day, another round of television interviews and another polite refusal from John Edwards to endorse a presidential candidate.

headline: On Bearings and Age
text: The McCain and Obama campaigns, which have both pledged to run high-minded races, got into some of the fiercest sparring of the campaign on Thursday evening.

headline: Betting on Global Warming or Cooling
text: The scientists who maintain the Realclimate.org blog have offered a climate wager to the research team from Germany that recently predicted a short pause in global warming (along with some North American and European cooling).

headline: At the Most Coveted Schools, a Glut of Children
text: Parents consider it a sacred tenet of city life: If you move into a good elementary school’s zone, your children can go to the school, Elissa Gootman writes. But Public Schools 234 and 89, in Battery Park City — part of Lower Manhattan, which has experienced a baby and construction boom — are faced with a glut of children and nowhere to put them. Some three dozen children are already on the waiting lists for these schools, an unusual predicament that has surprised parents, setting off outrage on playgrounds, at meetings and on the Internet.

headline: How to Cook a Wolf
text: Last Sunday’s Book Review featured a bunch of reviews of ambitious new Chinese fiction, including Jiang Rong’s “Wolf Totem,” a sweeping allegorical novel about an intellectual who goes to live among nomadic herders in Inner Mongolia during the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Circuit City Opens Its Books to Blockbuster
text: Circuit City, the electronics chain, said Friday that it would allow the video rental company Blockbuster to examine its books, marking a shift from its initial, highly skeptical stance toward Blockbuster’s unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: G.O.P. Web Site Attacks Obama
text: Updated The Republican National Committee has rolled out a new Web site, “CanWeAsk.com” that takes on Senator Barack Obama as though he were already the Democratic nominee.

headline: Saturn Brings Owners Together
text: Since its debut in 1990, Saturn has promoted itself as the younger, willing-to-experiment counterpart to its traditionalist parent company, General Motors. In an effort to maintain its “different kind of company” heritage and close relationship to its customers, Saturn has created a dedicated social networking Web site ImSaturn.com.

headline: AIG In Denial
text: A.I.G.’s conference call this morning is remarkable. The company is making clear that it does not believe the big losses it reported last night are real. It is just a matter of irrational markets.

headline: Kinder, Gentler?
text: John Heilemann’s latest column for New York magazine isn’t intended as a direct rebuttal to Susan Faludi’s op-ed in today’s Times. But it has that effect anyway. Faludi suggests that Hillary Clinton’s campaign was the most successful by a woman for the American presidency in history because Clinton “stepped across an unstated gender divide,” running as a “brawler” who “got down with the boys.”

headline: Group: Tell Clinton to Stop ‘Race-Baiting’
text: Upated The online grassroots organization, ColorOfChange, today urged its members to begin a phone onslaught of the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee, in a protest against what it views as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “race-baiting” remarks.

headline: Digital TV Poses a Challenge for Some Apartment Buildings
text: For people without cable or satellite television service, the annoyances involved in tuning in to a favorite show or the 6 o’clock news with a signal from a rooftop antenna have always included rainstorms and windy days. For people with set-top “rabbit ears,” there is the matter of getting them into just the right position, keeping them there, and then being careful not to stand near them in a way that causes any mysterious interference.

headline: Pandit’s $500 Billion Diet Plan
text: Citigroup is slimming down in a big way.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Negima (Japanese Beef-Scallion Rolls)
text: I first came across these perfect inside-out beef rolls years ago, at Inagiku in Manhattan, where the chef brushed wafer-thin slices of sirloin with teriyaki sauce before wrapping them around scallion greens and grilling them.

headline: Upfronts: Analysts Warn of Ad Sales Slump
text: TV Week: “Broadcast television networks’ upfront advertising sales will be down this year, posting a drop of between 2 percent and 14 percent, a leading Wall Street analyst said.”

headline: In Middle East, Looking Beyond Bush
text: When Israeli and Palestinian leaders committed themselves to peace talks after meeting in Annapolis, Md., last November, President Bush had hopes of wrapping up his presidency on a foreign policy high note, with a deal for the contours of a Palestinian state. But, as Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes in her column today, with Mr. Bush headed to the region next week for the second time in five months, peace seems more elusive than ever — and some are already looking past him to his successor. Go to Column …

headline: Amsterdam, Part Three: Little Tastes
text: In my previous posts on the appeal of the Indonesian risttafel at Tempo Doeloe and localist cuisine at the lovely De Kas, I focused on two acclaimed Amsterdam restaurants. But Amsterdam has plenty to offer the traveling foodie in between such stops.

headline: Brad Pitt’s Carbon Footprint
text: The Daily Mail has gone after celebrities who preach against greenhouse emissions but travel by private jet, like Brad Pitt, Madonna, Barbra Streisand and Coldplay’s Chris Martin. The British newspaper gives its full five-star “hippy-crite” rating to Mr. Pitt for narrating a documentary, “e2: The Economies of Being Environmentally Conscious,” and also taking dozens of private-jet trips last year, including a quick day-trip from Chicago to Los Angeles and back so he could perform jury duty. This critique raises a couple of questions in my mind:

headline: Istanbul F1 action heats up as temperature drops
text: A day on and off the track that lived up to the expected unexpected. The lower temperature actually dropped lower, to 14 degrees Celsius, and rain arrived before the second practice session. With the resulting wet track and lower temperatures there was a lot of sliding about of cars today, with the most spectacular moment being that of Mark Webber, who touched the grass and lost control of his Red Bull, spun around and ran into a guard rail. No more Red Bull front end. Mark humbly accepted all the blame himself:

headline: Euthanizing Bear
text: On Wednesday, they finally took Bear Stearns out behind the woodshed and ended its lingering misery. On that day, the plaintiffs’ attorneys in the last remaining viable lawsuit in New York against JPMorgan Chase and Bear withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction to halt the JPMorgan acquisition. Instead, the lawyers stated that they will pursue monetary damages. There is one more suit pending in federal court but it does not look significant.

headline: ‘Happier Than Liberals’
text: Aired Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: A new poll came out today. It says conservatives like Rush Limbaugh are happier than liberals. Although it might not be happiness. In Limbaugh’s case, it might just be the OxyContin kicking in.

headline: Only in New York, Kids, Only in New York
‘Eight or Nine Homes’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: A lot of pressure now on Hillary Clinton to drop out of the race. She did not do so well in the primaries the other night, but one of her advisers says that the chance of Hillary conceding the nomination to Barack Obama and dropping out of the race is only about 10 percent. But the adviser admits that if Obama wins the presidency, that number could go as high as 11 percent.

headline: ‘Trying To Evict His Wife’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Nevada Gov. Jim Gibbons has filed for divorce, and he is now trying to evict his wife from the governor’s mansion. Gibbons told the press, “You know what it’s like when a woman just won’t get the hint and leave,” to which Barack Obama said, “Tell me about it.”

headline: Bill Clinton Argues With Voter in W. Va.
text: If you think things aren’t getting tense on the campaign trail, check out this video from CBS News in Fayetteville, W. Va.

headline: ‘I Thought This Was Cute …’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: So here is what happened on Tuesday. Hillary Clinton barely won my home state of Indiana. And she lost in the state of North Carolina. But here is the good news. She has a substantial lead in the state of denial.

headline: Lacrosse: The Bratton Twins Experience Some Growing Pains
text: Other than being the most hyped recruits in the history of college lacrosse, Rhamel and Shamel Bratton really didn’t have any pressure on them heading into their freshman season at the University of Virginia. The twins from Huntington, Long Island, were christened as legends before they even stepped on campus, appearing twice on the cover of Inside Lacrosse magazine. (The Times also checked in, though we will bow down to the guest blogger John Jiloty as the arbiter of all lacrosse judgments.)  The Brattons were an alluring story not only because of their immense talent, but also because they were African-American stars in a sport that Virginia Coach Dom Starisa described as “lily white.”

headline: Fossella’s Hometown Paper Calls for Resignation
text: One of the most notable features in the saga of Representative Vito J. Fossella is the clear reluctance on the part of his fellow politicians, Democrat or Republican, to weigh in on the matter publicly. But his local paper, The Staten Island Advance, showed no such reticence, calling this morning for Mr. Fossella to resign immediately. Mr. Fossella, a Staten Island Republican, was arrested on May 1 in Alexandria, Va., and charged with drunken driving. On Thursday, he issued a statement that he had had an extramarital affair with Laura Fay, a former Air Force lieutenant colonel, and that the two of them have a 3-year-old daughter together.

headline: Clinton’s Endgame Strategy?
text: Let’s throw this into the mix of speculation about what Senator Hillary Clinton is up to with those remarks about whites and a new letter today from 16 House members to superdelegates in the House: maybe they are part of an elaborate bargaining package.

headline: Soft Serve | Chic Dumbbells, EZ Pass for Customs, Intravenous Fountain of Youth
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: A Belmont Prep: Peter Pan
text: A horse can arrive at the Belmont Stakes having competed in the previous two legs of the Triple Crown. Considering this option are two possibilities, Big Brown and Recapturetheglory. Each would need to run well in the Preakness to move forward to the Belmont.

headline: Love Hurts
text: We’ve all loved and lost. When Tony Soprano’s son is distraught over a break-up, Tony tells him to bear up and helpfully explains that such occasions have, in fact, spawned an entire industry — the music business.

headline: Wondrous Dread
text: As its title suggest, “Housekeeping” starts by seeming to engage the niceties of human domestic order; but the word soon hints how hard it is to “keep” much of anything. Not simply our purchase on mere real estate, but our grasp on any assurance that is real, lasting. When Lucille defects, it is natural she would turn to a teacher of Home Economics with its stalwart complacent reassurances.

headline: AT&T’s Wi-Fi Tease for iPhone Users
text: Maybe it’s because I work as a reporter, but it seems to me that secrets are overrated. I suspect that so often the cost of keeping secrets is greater than whatever benefit they bring.

headline: Did Microsoft Overpay for Its Facebook Stake?
text: This week’s chatter that Microsoft may have approached Facebook to discuss a possible takeover has created quite a buzz. But maybe Microsoft should be inquiring about getting a partial rebate on its $240 million investment instead.

headline: The Morning Skate: The Pennsylvania Polka, Chubby Checker and Olie the Goalie
text: There are times in life you must do what you don’t want to do. This is one of them. For as much as we’re not fond of Don King, we need to find him and his flamboyant ‘do right now and ask if he’ll bestow a suitable moniker on Series M of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: For This Treasure, Spain Says, Finders Aren’t Keepers
text: The Spanish government is pressing its claim to a deep-sea treasure that it did not know existed until it was recovered last year by an American exploration company, saying that the gold and silver coins belongs to the state because it came from a Spanish warship sunk by the British in 1804.

headline: Stray Questions for: Alan Dershowitz
text: Alan M. Dershowitz is a professor of law at Harvard. His most recent book is “Is There a Right to Remain Silent? Coercive Interrogation and the Fifth Amendment After9/11.”

headline: Myanmar Faces Aid Delays
text: Nearly one week after a devastating cyclone, supplies into the country were still being delayed and aid experts were being turned back as they arrived at the airport.

headline: Upfronts: MTV Networks Skips A Few Letters, Dubs “Generation P”
text: Whether it’s Sarah Silverman singing about a media buyer or Stephen Colbert breathing deeply from a bag of Doritos, MTV Networks sure knows how to impress advertisers.

headline: The CW: Anybody Want To Buy A Time Slot?
text: The CW is putting a “For Sale” sign on its Sunday night time slots. The network is close to a deal to sell its 7 to 10 p.m. hours to a media buyer, “which would turn around and develop programming and sell ad time,” Variety reports.

headline: Interview With General Vang Pao
text: Excerpts from an interview with General Vang Pao conducted by Times reporter Tim Weiner in late February 2008.

headline: The Post-Materialist | Brutal, Superdense Design Rises Again
text: A report from our Berlin correspondent on design in culture.

headline: Very | Christina Ricci
text: Very is a regular free-association column by Elizabeth Spiridakis, in which she calls it like she sees it.

headline: Mom’s Favorite Banana Cake
text: David Latt’s nice memories of his mother, Mother’s Day, Vietnamese food and banana cake . . . –MB

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Tracey Fragments'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "The Tracey Fragments," a film starring Ellen Page about a girl searching for her missing brother.

headline: Chinese Reversal
text: The most interesting thing in the trade figures today may be the fact that China’s trade balance with the United States is shrinking fast. In March, it came to $16.1 billion, the lowest figure for any month in two years and nearly $10 billion below the peak monthly figure of $25.9 billion, reached in October.

headline: Tensions, Suspensions, and a Police Funeral in Philadelphia
text: Emotions are running high in Philadelphia today as the city’s police bury one of their own and assess the impact of a video clip showing a crowd of police officers beating and kicking three suspects.

headline: What’s Really in That Seat-Back Pocket
text: How is your airplane etiquette?

headline: Con Edison Proposes Another Rate Increase
text: Updated, 3:55 p.m. | Just a few weeks after sending out bills that reflected a $425 million rise in electric rates, Con Edison is asking for an even bigger increase next year.

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Built by Rampant Speculation’
text: Monday, May 5

headline: A Time for Real Science
text: Valerie Grash, an art historian-university professor and a lifelong horse racing fan, writes the blog Foolish Pleasure in honor of her childhood racing idol.

headline: Lacrosse: Scouting the Tournament’s First Weekend
text: So here I was all ready to write my Friday blog about how terrible Cornell is, how their defensive midfield is a bunch of heartless scrubs, how they have the veteran leadership of a second-rate T-ball team and how the No. 8-seeded Big Red are the upset special in this weekend’s N.CA.A. tournament’s first round against unseeded Ohio State.

headline: An Old Web Icon Disappears
text: In today’s mailbag, a sign of the times:Dear David: On the bottom of your webpage (davidpogue.com) is a counter that shows how many miles you’ve driven your Toyota Corolla. Don’t you ever drive it?? I never see the number being updated. Of course I realize this is somewhat trivial, but it’s just one thing I noticed.And my reply:

headline: Have a Cigar, It’s a Red-Tailed Hawk … Make That 3 of ’Em!
text: Updated, May 12 They may not have as swanky an address as their East Side counterparts, Pale Male and Lola, the red-tailed hawks who got evicted from, then invited back, to the building where Mary Tyler Moore lives on Fifth Avenue at 74th Street.

headline: Duking It Out at the Yard
text: Anyone planning to attend railroad giant CSX‘s contentious annual shareholder meeting next month in New Orleans will probably need a good map, sunscreen and a fly swatter. That’s because the meeting is being held not at a posh hotel in the smart part of town, as was the case in past years in other cities, but on the outskirts of the city in a rusty rail yard.

headline: Avs and Coach Q Part Ways
text: The Colorado Avalanche announced today that they and coach Joel Quenneville, a former Devils defenseman, have mutually decided a change would be better for both.

headline: Outtakes From 1958
text: In an essay in this Sunday’s Book Review I look at some of the cultural debates of 1958 — particularly the showdown between the Beats and their New York intellectual critics, and the dissolution of the distinction between highbrow, middlebrow and lowbrow.

headline: Answers About the Health of the Arts, Part 2
text: This week, Randall Bourscheidt, the president of a nonprofit arts organization in New York that conducts research and also runs a cultural guide and calendar, has been answering readers’ questions about the economic health of the arts in the city, and what the city is doing to strengthen its commitment to the vitality of the arts. Following is his second and final set of answers. City Room is no longer taking questions on this feature.

headline: Ratings: If It’s Thursday, It Must Be CBS
text: For the third consecutive week, CBS’s Thursday night line-up earned more viewers than any of its network competitors during every time slot of the night. Beginning with the second to last installment of “Survivor: Micronesia,” CBS drew 12.7 million viewers to lead the 8 p.m. hour, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS then dominated the rest of the night with “CSI” at 9 p.m. (17.8 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 p.m. (14.6 million).

headline: U.S. Softballers: Too Good for Their Own Good?
text: The more games the USA Softball team plays, the more impressive the feat of a college pitcher named Angela Tincher. She is the Virginia Tech senior who no-hit the national team in a 1-0 Hokies victory on March 26.

headline: Where Bedbugs Ride Around, Besides Just Beds
text: Reports that the city’s bedbug epidemic was spreading to subway benches certainly alarmed New Yorkers this week.

headline: Prices and gasoline demand
text: With gasoline prices rising, there’s a lot of speculation about how and whether Americans will change their behavior.

headline: Mothers’ Day
text: There is a dream most mothers have, a nightmare really. It goes like this: you are away somewhere, and you remember you have left your children at home, perhaps for a week, and haven’t fed them. You can’t get back to them. Or it could be a litter of puppies or kittens other stand-ins for children, but you have lost or neglected to feed them, or they are in a storm, or you have rolled over in bed and smothered them. It’s a frantic nightmare and it recurs, for some of us, throughout our lives. My daughter and I laugh at the nightmare together, conceding that it must have something to do with our mothering skills, which we both accept as erratic.

headline: Obama Offers Veep Talk
text: BEAVERTON, Ore. – When Senator Barack Obama arrived at a software and technology plant here today, holding a town meeting with a few dozen Oregon voters, he came armed with a prepared speech about Senator John McCain.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Lexicographical Longing
text: When I was 19, my father gave me an Oxford English Dictionary, the 1971 compact edition with the 1987 supplement. Citations for every English word since the eighth century were crammed into three bulky volumes of minuscule print. I hallucinated before the speckled onion-skin pages until I discovered that the dictionary came with a magnifying glass.

headline: No Chance? No Problem, Says Paul.
text: Ron Paul never could quite claw his way to the top of the Republican presidential pack, but now he’s sitting on the top of several best seller lists with his new book, “The Revolution.”

headline: Rockefeller-Era Drug Laws, 35 Years Later
text: The tough drug laws signed into law by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1973 have long been the target of criminal-justice advocates who called the laws cruel. In 2005, the laws were slightly eased under a reform agreed to by the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki; mandatory sentences under the laws were reduced and prisoners who had been sentenced to the longest terms under the laws could ask to be re-sentenced. Some advocates believe the change did not go far enough, and on Thursday, the 35th anniversary of the day the laws were signed, the State Assembly held a lengthy series of hearings on whether the laws should be further revised.

headline: The Back Story | Asparagus Carbonara
text: (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

headline: Overqualified for This Job
Superdelegate Swish, Swish …
text: Update In case you were away from your e-mail in the last few hours, the superdelegates are lining up rather quickly today behind Senator Barack Obama, so much so that he’s now surpassed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in that category. It started overnight and has just kept rolling along as if someone opened the gates.

headline: Can Facebook Build a Better Passport?
text: It didn’t take long for Facebook to react to the announcement by MySpace Thursday that it would enable other Web sites to tap into information about its users and their friends.

headline: Catching Up With | Harmony Korine
text: (Photo: Ari Marcopoulos)

headline: How Smart Is Smart?
text: Sunday’s Automobiles section will have a pair of reviews of the Smart Fortwo. Eric A.Taub drove a Smart Fortwo Passion in Los Angeles, and Lawrence Ulrich gave the Fortwo a tryout in New York City. Two regular contributors who own Smart cars, Dave Kinney and John Schwartz, also weighed in with their brief takes — “Getting Used to the Quirks” and “Feeling Like a Rock Star.”

headline: Triathlon: The Confusion of the Long-Distance Runners
text: In trying to figure out which three male triathletes to send to Beijing, the Americans are in danger of handing one of their qualification spots to the Russians. And doing so would keep both of the top Americans, Andy Potts and Hunter Kemper, home in August.

headline: Friday Happy Hour: Gravel Woos Obama Girl
text: No.

headline: ‘Four More Superdelegates’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Barack Obama picked up four more superdelegates this week. Those are the party big shots whose votes, for some reason, mean a lot more than our votes mean. Even so, it’s nice to see a politician pick up something other than a prostitute every once in a while.

headline: Obama Won’t Rule Out Easing Clinton Campaign Debt
text: Updated WOODBURN, Ore. – Senator Barack Obama said today that he would not rule out the possibility of helping Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton retire her campaign debt to bring her into the fold and unify Democrats. But he said no discussions have taken place yet.

headline: Windermere Fixes May Be in Sight
text: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction today ordering the owners of the Windermere — the decrepit but once grand seven-story apartment complex of three 1881 Queen Anne-style buildings in Hell’s Kitchen — to halt the deterioration of the structure, which was designated a city landmark in 2005.

headline: The Vatican Tries a Little Web II.0
text: Somehow, Primoris ephemeridis just doesn’t have the same ring.

headline: ABC’s Private Practice Gets A Little TLC
text: “Private Practice,” the “Grey’s Anatomy” spin-off that premiered last year, will have two new show-runners at the helm when it returns this fall, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Diamonds Invade a Jewel of a Public Space
text: Sometimes, I’ve paused at the top of the great ramps at Grand Central Terminal and — as if I were gulping needed oxygen — simply taken in the sight of a pure, cathedral-like public space; architecture untouched by any overlay of modern marketing.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 9
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include Holocaust Remembrance Day, a subway derailment, a record-setting auction at Christie’s, public protests against the acquittal of three detectives in the shooting death of Sean Bell, the deportation trial of a popular New Jersey imam, and more. Here are more recent highlights from City Room.

headline: He Shoots, He Soars!
text: Tomorrow, May 10, is the 38th anniversary of one of the most storied goals in hockey history, Bobby Orr’s flying leap in front of Glenn Hall as he scored the winner 40 seconds into overtime of Game 4 of the 1970 Stanley Cup final, giving the Boston Bruins a sweep of the St. Louis Blues. It was the Bruins’ first Cup since 1941.

headline: The Aid Crisis in Myanmar
text: The military junta continues to refuse some foreign aid and foreign-aid workers into Myanmar.

headline: The Aid Crisis in Myanmar
text: The military junta continues to refuse some foreign aid and foreign-aid workers into Myanmar.

headline: Bloggingheads: McCain's Rev. Wright
text:
Could Rod Parsley, an evangelical minister in Ohio, become a serious political problem for John McCain?
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Avoiding moral hazard
text: I love The New Yorker — for the wonderful writing, the reporting, the poetry — oh, who am I kidding? Like everyone, I start with the cartoons.

headline: Farmland and Shakespeare
text: Chicago artists and other creative types are making Three Oaks, Mich., a hot spot.

headline: The Marketing of Menthol
text: Menthol cigarettes have been on the market for more than 80 years, and for much of that time African-Americans have been a target audience.

headline: Buffett’s Return to Daytime Drama
text: Warren E. Buffett is no stranger to Pine Valley. In 1992, the billionaire investor first visited the town that is the setting for ABC’s “All My Children,” after striking up a friendship with the popular soap opera’s creator.

headline: Justin Timberlake to Produce MTV Reality Show
text: “Youth-oriented cable television network MTV said on Friday it will air a new reality game show called ‘The Phone’ to be executive-produced by pop star Justin Timberlake,” Reuters reports.

headline: Witness to a Suicide Bombing in Afghanistan
text: Two days after the April 27 assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the photojournalist Stephen Dupont and the writer Paul Rafael, both Australian, were traveling with an opium eradication team in eastern Afghanistan’s Nangarhar Province when a suicide bomber attacked their convoy. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 15 and wounded 14. Both journalists were among the injured; Mr. Dupont suffered minor injuries to his head, and Mr. Rafael serious ones.

headline: Witness to an Afghan Suicide Bombing
text: (Photo: Stephen Dupont/Contact Press Images)  See a Slide Show. Warning: Some readers might find the images disturbing.  Two days after the April 27 assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the photojournalist Stephen Dupont and the writer Paul Rafael, both Australian, were traveling with an opium eradication team in eastern Afghanistan’s Nangarhar Province when a suicide bomber attacked their convoy. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 15 and wounded 14. Both journalists were among the injured; Mr. Dupont suffered minor injuries to his head, and Mr. Rafael serious ones.  Afghanistan is again expected to have a bumper poppy crop this year, and Afghan eradication teams like the one they were traveling with have come under increasing attack from the Taliban or other armed groups, who use the profits from the opium trade to fuel the insurgency against American and NATO forces. The following is an account of the attack by Mr. Dupont, who was working for Contact Press Images and on assignment for Smithsonian magazine, at the time. You can view a slide show of images taken by Mr. Dupont before and after the attack.  That morning we set off from Jalalabad in a convoy of about eight vehicles, green Ford pickups and one small truck with 50 to 60 laborers. About 40 minutes later we came to a small town, Khogyani. The truck in front of us pulled up to the gate of a police barracks. We were at the edge of the town, the police buildings facing fields in a desert valley below.   We stopped. The driver and the commanding officer got out, and everyone started jumping off the back of the flatbed, all the police meeting each other. Paul and I waited in the truck. We had the windows down and were smoking, talking, when I heard a huge bang. Then I saw black. I still don’t know if it was smoke or if I actually blacked out.   When I could see again, I got out of the car and I ran. My instinct led me away. I heard gunfire. Some Afghans were running and I ran with them. We took cover behind a mound of dirt 30 or 40 yards away. Blood poured down my face. I didn’t know how badly I was wounded, and I started asking people could they tell me if I was O.K.  Crouched with me was an Afghan cameraman and some police officers. Then I looked toward the vehicles, 20 yards from where the bomb had gone off, and I saw six or seven bodies. That’s the first time I knew that people had been wounded or killed. I started to move toward the bodies, and then after 10 or 20 seconds, I thought, “Where’s Paul?”   I headed back to our vehicle. Paul was still in his seat, his right side completely covered in blood, but he seemed coherent. I spoke to him, saying, “You’re O.K.,” and things like that. He didn’t say anything. All around people were shredded like minced meat, mangled bodies missing heads, legs and arms. I didn’t see many wounded. I remember one guy alive sitting among all these bodies. I think it made an impression just because he was alive in this mess. I started taking pictures. I felt I was taking pictures of evidence.   Eventually, the Americans, who were from the 173rd Airborne Brigade and incredibly hospitable, gave us a medevac flight to Bagram Air Base, outside Kabul. Paul is here, too. He’s got five holes in the back of his head, two the size of golf balls. There’s a bone fragment stuck inside one. They don’t know if it’s his or somebody else’s. They think it may be pushing up against his brain, affecting his vision. I’ve talked to him and he seems O.K., except for the vision and not hearing from his right ear. They think he may have punctured his eardrum.   -- STEPHEN DUPONT

headline: Scenes From Sam Bassett's Film
text: Scenes from Sam Bassett's unfinished documentary about the unlikely relationship with his neighbor, the artist Bettina Grossman.

headline: Polygraphically Perverse
text: Tell me your answer to this question, and I could probably come close to guessing your age: What public figure of an earlier time did you see, live on television, call lie detectors “twentieth century witchcraft”? Want to give your memory a chance to click in? (Answer to be found later.)

headline: Google-Yahoo: Deal or No Deal?
text: Will Google and Yahoo come together on a search advertising partnership? The two companies have been discussing an agreement under which Google would deliver some ads alongside Yahoo’s search results. Since Google on average earns much more than Yahoo for every search, the deal, at least in theory, would bolster Yahoo’s revenue. The two companies conducted a two-week experiment to make sure that was indeed true and both companies have called the test a success.

headline: Clyburn Sees ‘Tipping Point’ to Obama
text: The “tipping point” has been reached, according to Representative James E. Clyburn, a prominent uncommitted superdelegate.

headline: No News Is Bad News
text: Bangkok

headline: Footnotes
text: Jury selection began on Friday in Chicago in the long-delayed trial of the R&B singer R. Kelly, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly, 41, is accused of having sex with a girl as young as 13. ...One of the New York-area tour dates for Madonna’s “Sticky & Sweet” tour has been changed. Live Nation, the promoter, now says the show at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., is set for Oct. 4, not Oct. 3 as first announced. (The dates for the Madison Square Garden shows, on Oct. 6 and 7, are unchanged.)

headline: In the Face of Great Loss, Embracing Innocence
text: The woman was seated just two chairs away at the table, but the man had to speak over music that filled the room.

headline: R. R. Knudson, a Writer Whose Subject Was Sports, Dies at 75
text: R. R. Knudson, an author whose stories about girls and women in sports, particularly her series of “Zan” novels, heralded the lowering of gender barriers on the playing field, died on May 3 at her home in St. Petersburg, Fla. She was 75 and also lived in Sea Cliff, N.Y.

headline: Return Laps for the First Voice of Speed Racer
text: “I keep saying to myself, ‘Of all the things you’ve done in show business, this is the one thing that’s recognized,’ ” Peter Fernandez said. He was talking about his voice work for the hero of “Speed Racer,” the time-honored anime imported from Japan in 1967.

headline: Queens Shooting Case Exposes Rifts in Black Officers’ Groups
text: Detective Marc Cooper spared no gratitude after his acquittal in the Sean Bell shooting, using a news conference to thank the Lord, his lawyers, his family, his union and Victor Swinton, the president of the Guardians Association, a fraternal organization for black police officers formed more than 60 years ago.

headline: Myanmar Proceeds With Vote, Outcome Certain
text: YANGON, Myanmar  Monks in Myanmar have been at the center of major pro-democracy protests against the ruling junta, most notably a large uprising in 1988, and again during huge protests last September. Whenever the generals stage a crackdown, monks are among the first to be hauled off to the notorious Insein Prison.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 54 of The Times Magazine this weekend, about injuries in girls’ sports, misstates the results of an Ohio study of the frequency of injuries sustained by student athletes. The rate of concussions sustained by high school girls who play soccer is 1.5 times the rate for boys who play soccer  not 1.5 percent greater.

headline: Suit Over Death of Rapper Can Proceed
text: A federal district court judge in Los Angeles reinstated a wrongful-death lawsuit brought by the family of the rapper Notorious B.I.G., reversing an earlier decision to dismiss the case, The Associated Press reported. Judge Florence-Marie Cooper threw out the lawsuit on March 21, ruling that the family had missed a California deadline for bringing a claim against the city and two former police officers. The family appealed, and the judge ruled that federal claims in the case can proceed, according to court papers obtained Thursday. The rapper, whose real name was Christopher Wallace, was gunned down in Los Angeles in 1997, at age 24. His killing remains unsolved, and two wrongful-death suits have been filed against the city, claiming that rogue police officers conspired to commit the murder.

headline: Fragrance Market Is Establishing a Foothold in China
text: One of China’s hottest sellers is a nonessential Western luxury product that the Chinese have historically never bought and that has virtually no Chinese cultural roots: perfume.

headline: Argentina: Farmers Revive Blockade to Protest Tax
text: Thousands of farmers have taken to the picket lines, blocking hundreds of roads and impeding exports of grains in a renewed strike against government agricultural policies. The protests in Buenos Aires and at least four other provinces were the latest challenge to President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, who imposed higher export tariffs in March on soybeans and other products. By Friday, there were about 230 road blockades, including in Gualeguaychú, left, according to the Argentine Agrarian Federation.

headline: Hints of a Shift at OPEC About a Rise in Oil Output
text: As prices jumped to another record, a member of OPEC signaled on Friday for the first time in months that the oil cartel might increase its output to prick the price bubble.

headline: Justice in Turkmenistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraq Contractor in Shooting Case Makes Comeback
text: WASHINGTON  Last fall, Blackwater Worldwide was in deep peril.

headline: Citi’s Chief Says Change Will Take Time and Patience
text: Vikram S. Pandit is doing some serious spring cleaning at Citigroup.

headline: The Leader of the Country Is the Father of the Bride
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  Yes, the economy is in the dumps. Yes, the war in Iraq drags on. But it’s hard to imagine even his harshest critics begrudging President Bush the father-of-the-bride grin he has worn around the country lately.

headline: Mortgage Holders Find It Hard to Walk Away From Their Homes
text: As American homeowners fall behind on their mortgages in growing numbers, bankers and policy makers worry that while many of these people cannot pay, some simply will not.

headline: Mystics and Militants: A Look at the Rastafari Kingdom
text: WASHINGTON  Bob Marley, ganja smoking and dreadlocks are here  how could they not be in what is billed as the first exhibition about the Rastafari ever mounted in a major museum? Reggae, the ceremonial smoking of marijuana, and tightly coiled locks of hair could hardly be omitted when the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History devotes a show to this Jamaican-born subculture. Most of us, in fact, know of Rastafari only through these popular manifestations.

headline: Ignoring the Rule of Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A Spare Times listing on Friday about events at the Wave Hill garden and cultural center in the Bronx misstated the days on which two-for-one admissions with vouchers, being offered this month, are available. They are Wednesdays through Fridays, not Wednesdays through Sundays. The listing also included an outdated Web address for in- formation. The new one is nycvisit.com/culturespot.

headline: Correction
text: The column by David Brooks on Tuesday included a widely reported but incorrectly transcribed phrase attributed to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. In discussing the economy during a speech, Mrs. Clinton mentioned “Wall Street money brokers.” She did not use the phrase “money grubbers.”

headline: You’ve Seen the YouTube Video; Now Try the Documentary
text: There is a moment of foreshadowing at the end of “Battle at Kruger,” the eight-minute African safari video that has drawn more than 30 million views on YouTube.

headline: Political Foe of Musharraf Is Released in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A provincial leader who was one of the most prominent politicians jailed by President Pervez Musharraf was freed Friday by the newly elected government, fulfilling one of its major promises to release political detainees.

headline: Design Change Sought for King Memorial
text: The United States Commission of Fine Arts has asked the creators of a sculpture of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for the Washington Mall to change it. In a letter, the commission said that renderings of the sculpture made Dr. King appear stiff and “confrontational,” evoking Socialist Realist statues of political figures recently toppled in other countries. The lead sculptor, Lei Yixin, above with a model of the work, is from China and has made busts of Mao Zedong. Critics had opposed giving him the commission, saying that an African-American sculptor should have been chosen. Supporters said choosing an artist without regard to race or color was in line with Dr. King’s philosophy. The commission, whose approval is necessary for the project to proceed, recommended that the sculpture portray Dr. King as a more sympathetic figure.

headline: From a Bright Past to a Cloudy Future
text: When Vito J. Fossella Jr., the soon-to-be boy congressman, stood beside the young girls of a cheerleading squad at the Excelsior Grand catering hall in 1997, it seemed a particularly vivid version of Staten Island pageantry. Mr. Fossella  32 and with Al Pacino looks  was on his way to becoming the sole Republican in New York City’s Congressional delegation at a spirited party billed as an evening of “pasta and politics.”

headline: Spam Moves to Cellphones and Gets More Invasive
text: If you thought spam on your computer was a bother, brace yourself: spammers want to find you on your cellphone.

headline: On a Windy Day, the Elders Stand Their Ground
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  There was something for everybody Friday at the T.P.C. Sawgrass, where the hot summer winds came early and stayed late, and a few PGA Tour pros were last seen limping into the fitness trailer for chiropractic care.

headline: As Stimulus Rebates Go Out, Stores Want the Whole Check
text: As the government sends out roughly $100 billion in economic stimulus checks to about 130 million American homes, retailers are trying to persuade consumers to spend their windfall at a time of high anxiety about the economy.

headline: Charles R. Ellis, President of John Wiley & Sons, Dies at 72
text: Charles R. Ellis, an executive who led the venerable family-owned publishing house John Wiley & Sons back to fiscal health in the 1990s after a period of misdirected expansion, died on May 4 in Paris. He was 72 and had homes in Paris and Manhattan.

headline: Fears Ease, So It’s Time to Be Fearful
text: NOW that public opinion is solidifying around the idea that the Federal Reserve has made its last rate cut for a while, stocks may be poised atop a slope of complacency.

headline: Lottery Numbers
One Duo Celebrates the Songs of Another
text: What a pleasure to hear a songwriter whisper his own well-known lyrics as if the familiar words were a stream of consciousness spontaneously emanating from a meditative state. That is how Alan Bergman sang “The Windmills of Your Mind” on Thursday at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency in a show celebrating his 50-year collaboration with his wife, Marilyn (who was in the audience). The performance made you realize that quiet understatement often draws you into song lyrics more than florid declamation.

headline: For First Time, More Superdelegates Favor Obama
text: The trump card Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held in her faltering bid for president  her support among the superdelegates who can control the fate of the Democratic nomination  began slipping from her grasp on Friday as Senator Barack Obama moved into the lead on this front, with uncommitted delegates declaring their allegiance to him as others deserted her.

headline: An Eternal Battle, Waged With Vigor
text: It’s easy to forget that ballet can be cool. But many of Twyla Tharp’s strongest forays into this art form are effortlessly so: the dancers may be drenched, but the choreography never breaks a sweat.

headline: Circuit City Opens Its Books to Blockbuster
text: Circuit City, the electronics chain, said Friday that it would allow the video rental company Blockbuster to examine its books, a shift from its initial, highly skeptical stance toward Blockbuster’s unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: Death Comes Ashore
text: THE word “cyclone” was coined in Calcutta (now called Kolkata) in the 1840s by an eccentric Englishman named Henry Piddington. Inspired by the great British meteorologist William Reid, Piddington became one of the earliest storm-chasers, besotted with a phenomenon that he once likened to a “beautiful meteorite.” His elegant coinage was originally intended as a generic name for all revolving weather events, but is now applied mainly to the storms of the Indian Ocean region like Cyclone Nargis, which struck Burma with devastating effect last week.

headline: Mother’s Day Scandal
text: By now we voters are well-versed in how to respond when, say, your law-and-order governor turns out to be a primo patron of the Emperor’s Club V.I.P. Escort Service. But the bar moves ever upward, and this week, New Yorkers are trying to figure out the proper reaction to news that a veteran local congressman, Vito Fossella, is the proud paterfamilias of both a household in Staten Island (wife, three children) and a love nest with mistress and child in Virginia.

headline: Microsoft Appeals $1.4 Billion Fine by Europe
text: Microsoft asked Europe’s second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union. The appeal was filed at the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, a Microsoft spokesman, Jesse Verstraete, said in an e-mailed statement. The European Commission, the E.U.’s antitrust authority, fined the company on Feb. 27 for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order. Under that decision, in which Microsoft was fined 497 million euros, the E.U. ordered the software maker to provide data to rivals to allow servers to connect to the Windows platform.

headline: New Shows at HBO
text: HBO has lined up another big Hollywood name for a new project. Alexander Payne, the director and Oscar-winning co-writer of “Sideways,” will direct and serve as an executive producer of “Hung,” a new dark comedy series about a former basketball coach with a large penis. The series, being created by Dmitry Lipkin, the creator of “The Riches” for FX, and his wife, Colette Burson, was the first project signed by Sue Naegle, who took over as president of HBO’s entertainment division last month. HBO has several other new series in various stages of development, including “True Blood,” a vampire drama scheduled to begin in the fall; “One Percent,” a drama about a motorcycle gang; “Last of the Ninth,” a drama set in the New York Police Department in the 1970s; and “David’s Situation,” a comedy by Bob Odenkirk and David Cross in which Mr. Cross portrays himself living with two roommates, one liberal and one conservative.

headline: Indiana Jones Is Battling the Long Knives of the Internet
text: LOS ANGELES  Now comes the part where Indiana Jones dangles over the snake pit of public opinion.

headline: Columbus Orchestra May Suspend Activities
text: Is it curtains for Columbus? The Columbus Symphony Orchestra, a high-quality regional ensemble in Ohio’s capital, has canceled its outdoor summer concerts and says it will probably call a halt to making music indefinitely.

headline: Times Publisher and His Wife Separate
text: Arthur Sulzberger Jr., chairman of The New York Times Company, and his wife, Gail Gregg, have decided to separate, they said in a statement issued Friday.

headline: The Chief of Barneys Is Expected to Resign
text: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, who restored the company’s stature after it fell into bankruptcy in the 1990s, has told colleagues he intends to resign, according to people knowledgeable about the situation.

headline: Man Is Found Shot to Death in an Elevator
text: A 29-year-old man was found shot to death inside a building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on Friday, the police said.

headline: Mr. Hu’s Peaceable Visit to Tokyo
text: President Hu Jintao’s visit to Japan this week was the first by a Chinese leader in a decade. It was a lot friendlier than the previous one  when President Jiang Zemin publicly chastised his hosts for not showing sufficient contrition over Japan’s brutal occupation of China in 1930s and 1940s. Unlike some of his recent predecessors, Japan’s prime minister, Yasuo Fukuda, has made an effort not to infuriate the Chinese. Notably, he has refused to pander to Japanese nationalists by visiting Tokyo’s tainted Yasukuni war shrine.

headline: Judge Drops General From Trial of Detainee
text: In a new blow to the Bush administration’s troubled military commission system, a military judge has disqualified a Pentagon general who has been centrally involved in overseeing Guantánamo war crimes tribunals from any role in the first case headed for trial.

headline: Blogging Against Barbie
text: MOST of Eco Child’s Play, a blog for environmentally conscious parents, is concerned with tips and advice about products like nontoxic pacifiers and children’s clothing made from bamboo (ecochildsplay.com).

headline: Kenya: World Food Program Worker Is Killed
text: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a logistics officer working for the United Nations World Food Program in northwestern Kenya. The officer, identified as Silence Chirara by The Associated Press, was ambushed late Wednesday by men brandishing assault rifles, United Nations officials said Friday. The killing may have been connected to the reduction of aid efforts in the area, which used to be a hub for relief supplies to Sudan. A driver hauling food for the World Food Program was fatally shot Wednesday in Somalia.

headline: Another Game Goes to the Big Screen
text: The video game “BioShock” is set to become a film. Take-Two Interactive Software said on Friday that Gore Verbinski (“Pirates of the Caribbean”) would make a movie version of its popular game about an underwater utopia gone disastrously wrong, Reuters reported. The film will be released by Universal Pictures, and the screenwriter John Logan (“Gladiator,” “Sweeney Todd”) is in talks to write the script, the company said. Take-Two did not disclose the financial terms of the deal or say when the film would be released. “BioShock” has sold more than two million copies, and Take-Two is working on a sequel.

headline: Close Your Eyes and Smell the Brine
text: In “Moby Dick Rehearsed,” the Orson Welles adaptation of the Melville novel, the audience is implored early on to be prepared for a mental workout, there being no chance of getting a credible whale, ship or sea into the theater. “Think, when we speak of whaleboats, whales and oceans, that you see them,” an actor asks, “for ’tis your thoughts that now must deck our stage.”

headline: Roaring Twenties Speakeasies With Tubs Full of Ginger Ale Fizz
text: Though it is set in an era of speakeasies and bathtub gin, the 1920s musical “No, No, Nanette” makes only fleeting reference to cocktails. Bootleg hooch is clearly not the signature drink of the happy flappers in this show. Nor is tea, though the possibilities of its being served for two are sung about rhapsodically.

headline: Gambling Is Never Enough
text: Like a gambling addict certain that his luck will turn on the next roll of the dice, New York State is betting that vastly expanding gambling at the Aqueduct in Queens is part of the answer to the budget deficit. The state’s overly generous revenue projection is based on the hope that bidders will pay $250 million for development rights from the state-owned racetrack, and with it, the right to add 4,500 video slot machines that would provide the state a worry-free revenue stream.

headline: Kerkorian Moves to Buy a Bigger Stake in Ford
text: DETROIT  The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian started a cash tender offer on Friday to bolster his stake in the Ford Motor Company to 5.6 percent but stopped short of revealing his long-term plans as a major shareholder in the carmaker.

headline: CBS Rules Thursday
text: For the third consecutive week the Thursday night lineup on CBS had more viewers at every time slot than any of its network competitors, according to Nielson estimates. CBS drew 12.7 million viewers for “Survivor: Micronesia” at 8 p.m. and continued to dominate with “CSI” at 9 (17.8 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (14.6 million). Despite CBS’s advantage in total viewers, ABC edged ahead for the night among adults 18 to 49, thanks to “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (with 15.6 million total viewers) and “Lost” at 10 (11.3 million total), which did well in that demographic. Fox and NBC were third and fourth over all, with NBC faring better among the 18-to-49 set. While NBC garnered small audiences for the season finales of “Scrubs” at 8:30 (5.4 million) and “30 Rock” at 9:30 (5.6 million), its ratings perked up at 9 for “The Office” (7.2 million) and at 10 with “ER” (7.6 million).

headline: A Look at War, That Zero-Sum Game
text: Luis Lara Malvacías, a choreographer, dancer and visual artist, has clearly spent a lot of time thinking about the set for his new dance, “Reason Without Meaning.” His installation even spills into the audience at the Kitchen, where the back of every other chair is covered with a slice of bubble wrap. A black piece of cardboard with a message reading “X caution” is placed on the same seats, along with an object wrapped in more bubble packing to resemble a candied apple. Or, judging by the events that follow, a grenade.

headline: St. Vincent’s Pleads Poverty to Evade Landmark Law
text: In the contentious world of New York landmark preservation, it is not always hard to be a hardship case.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on April 27 about Newark’s difficulty in helping ex-convicts get jobs gave an outdated and erroneous name for a New York agency that is conducting a three-year study of employment and recidivism among ex-convicts in four cities. It is MDRC, formerly known as the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation (not Development).

headline: Hezbollah Seizes Swath of Beirut From U.S.-Backed Lebanon Government
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Heavily armed Hezbollah fighters seized control of much of western Beirut on Friday, patrolling the deserted streets in a raw show of force that underscored the militia’s refusal to back down in its escalating confrontation with the American-backed government.

headline: Touring Season
text: Hitting the road in the coming months: Coldplay, My Morning Jacket and Tina Turner. Coldplay’s tour begins June 29 in Philadelphia after a free show at Madison Square Garden on June 23 and runs through Aug. 4 in Chicago before returning for a second leg in October. My Morning Jacket opens its tour on June 20 with a show at Radio City Music Hall and continues on the road through Oct. 10 in Chicago. Ms. Turner, above, will start a tour on Oct. 1 in Kansas City and continue through Dec. 8 in Montreal; she will play the Prudential Center in Newark on Nov. 26 and the Nassau Coliseum on Dec. 3.

headline: Bush and House G.O.P. Team Up to Present Show of Strength
text: WASHINGTON  It was just like the old days. President Bush and House Republican leaders strode purposefully out of the White House to the waiting microphones, where the president celebrated their mutual views on housing, energy, war spending and terrorist surveillance bills taking shape in Congress.

headline: If Your Appliances Are Avocado, They Probably Aren’t Green
text: I DON’T know about you, but I’m a little tired of the whole green thing. Not the idea that Americans need to sharply cut their energy use (the words carbon footprint will not pass my lips). And not the idea that there are some relatively painless actions we can all take that will help  although I know real change will not be made without real sacrifice.

headline: Short of Cash, Fremont May Not Complete a Deal
text: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business. Fremont, based in Brea, Calif., is behind on required filings and does not know when it will be able to provide data needed to finish the sale to CapitalSource, according to a company statement and filing. After agreeing to sell mortgage servicing rights to a Goldman Sachs unit yesterday, Fremont said it had contracted to divest “substantially all” the bank’s remaining assets. “There can be no assurance that there will be any monies” left for Fremont’s shareholders, the company said.

headline: West Side Railyards Project Gets New Push From Mayor
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that he would push to revive a $1 billion deal to develop the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan as he met with the developer whose negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had collapsed.

headline: Marrying at Rikers Island: Few Frills, Many Rules
text: The long walk to the Rose M. Singer chapel on Rikers Island starts after the wedding party passes through metal detectors. When the bride and groom reach the altar, the chapel doors are locked behind them.

headline: New Signs of Zimbabwe Attacks as Mbeki Arrives
text: JOHANNESBURG  President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa held talks in Zimbabwe on Friday with the country’s longtime leader, Robert Mugabe, as fresh evidence emerged that forces sponsored by Mr. Mugabe’s government were accelerating their attacks on the political opposition.

headline: Bloomberg Teaches London’s New Mayor Old Tricks
text: LONDON  They are a study in contrasts, Mayor Mike and Mayor Boris.

headline: Igawa Does Little to Help Himself or the Yankees
text: A three-run rally by the Yankees in the ninth inning made Friday night’s final score look respectable: a 6-5 victory for the Tigers, their fourth triumph in four tries over the Yankees this season.

headline: Illegal Farm Workers Get Health Care in Shadows
text: MADERA, Calif.  The curandera is weary from work. Three, four, five times a day, the immigrant farm workers knock on her apartment door, begging her to cure their ailments.

headline: For Duke, Extra Year of Players’ Eligibility Makes a Difference
text: When Chris Kennedy sat down last spring to write an appeal to the N.C.A.A. for 33 members of the Duke lacrosse team to be granted an extra season, he had no expectations.

headline: Japan: Marine Sentenced in Sexual Misconduct Case
text: A United States marine was sentenced to two years in prison and given a dishonorable discharge for sexual misconduct with a Japanese woman in October in Hiroshima, military officials said Friday. He was cleared of rape and kidnapping charges. The marine, Lance Cpl. Larry A. Dean, 20, was the first serviceman to face court-martial among four accused of rape by a 19-year-old Japanese woman. Japanese authorities investigated the case, but decided not to bring their own charges against the marines.

headline: Rapper Pleads Guilty
text: Less than a month after being released from prison, the rapper Foxy Brown pleaded guilty in a Brooklyn court on Thursday to using her BlackBerry phone to menace a woman, Reuters reported. Foxy Brown, 29, whose real name is Inga Marchand, avoided a felony assault charge, which carries a maximum sentence of seven years in prison, by pleading guilty to menacing, a misdemeanor. She was accused of bruising an eye and chipping a tooth of her longtime neighbor, Arlene Raymond, when she struck the woman with the phone last July. On Thursday, Justice John P. Walsh of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn sentenced the rapper to time already served and ordered her to submit an apology. “I apologize for the incident that occurred on July 31, 2007, in that I attempted to scare Arlene Raymond and place her in harm’s way,” Foxy Brown said in a handwritten note.

headline: Con Ed Seeks Another Rate Increase and Draws Fire
text: Just a few weeks after sending out bills that reflected a $425 million rise in electricity rates, Con Edison is asking for an even bigger increase next year.

headline: Seeds of Destruction
text: The Clintons have never understood how to exit the stage gracefully.

headline: Light Touch in Inventing Chinese Scents
text: Western perfume makers have been selling their scents in China for roughly a decade. But in a few months, Parfums Benetton will introduce two of the first perfumes that have been created especially for Chinese tastes.

headline: Farnsworth’s Appeal Is Heard and Listened To
text: DETROIT  The bullpen dominated much of the discussion Friday when the Yankees opened a three-game series with the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park. The topics included the suspension of Kyle Farnsworth, the antics of Joba Chamberlain, the optioning of Chris Britton to Class AAA and the loss of Sean Henn on waivers to San Diego.

headline: From Places Unexpected, Support for the Press
text: WASHINGTON  An unusual cast of conservatives has added momentum to a bill that would protect the confidentiality of reporters’ sources, even as the Bush administration has lobbied vigorously against the idea.

headline: Slam Bidding Decides Fate of Cavendish Teams
text: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, the planet’s biggest cash tournament of the year, ends on Sunday in Henderson, Nev., on the outskirts of Las Vegas. Play can be watched at bridgebase.com.

headline: A Warm Welcome for an Injured Vendor of Hot Coffee
text: Despite the driving rain, the customers lined up at the coffee wagon in front of State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Friday morning, not so much to get their cup of joe as to see the man they call Joe. They quickly shouted their greetings:

headline: Stolen Laptop Helps Turn Tables on Suspects
text: WHITE PLAINS  The thieves were voracious, filching flat-screen televisions and computer games, purloining iPods and DVDs, even making off with a box of liquor and a set of car rims in a burglary two weeks ago at an apartment three young people shared here. Luckily, they also took two laptop computers.

headline: Israel Readying for a Post-Olmert Era
text: JERUSALEM  The overwhelming view in Israel on Friday, just hours after Prime Minister Ehud Olmert declared his innocence in a bribery investigation involving a Long Island businessman, was that the post-Olmert political era had already begun.

headline: Myanmar Proceeds With Vote, Outcome Certain
text: This article was reported and written by a correspondent of The New York Times. Reporting was contributed by Seth Mydans in Bangkok.

headline: Russia Parades Its Military in an Echo of Soviet Days
text: MOSCOW  Nuclear missile launchers and columns of tanks rolled through Red Square on Friday in a display of martial hardware not seen since the Soviet Union’s waning days.

headline: Home-Grown, Everyday Sadism
text: If Ellen Page ever worried that her roles in “Juno” and “Smart People” would too securely set her image as a feisty know-it-all, she chose well to appear in “An American Crime,” a film that manages to wrench all the placid innocence from her bones. The movie, which appeared at the Sundance Film Festival last year and which makes its debut on Showtime on Saturday, calls for none of her verbal wood chopping. Indeed, it demands a listless opposite, turning Ms. Page’s body into a cadaver long before her character becomes one, speaking to us softly, phlegmatically and from the grave. Ms. Page is all dreamy, spectral passivity; she mesmerizes. But so much is done to her that it is hard to know what she is actually doing.

headline: Ranch to Be Searched for Manson Victims
text: LOS ANGELES  For those who spend a great deal of time mulling the intricacies and unanswered questions of real-life crimes, a remote area in Death Valley has always been fertile ground.

headline: With European Flavor, Galaxy Tries for M.L.S. Success
text: CARSON, Calif.  The name Ruud Gullit still carries great currency in Europe, where Gullit, a two-time world player of the year from the Netherlands, was as distinctive for his flopping dreadlocks and his iconoclastic personality as for what he could do with a soccer ball at his feet.

headline: Stared At in China
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Tuesday about the immigration detention system misstated the level of the charge against those who enter the country without authorization. It is a misdemeanor, not an administrative violation.

headline: Taking Advantage of Previously Issued Credit Lines
text: IT appears to be a conundrum. Banks tell the Federal Reserve that they are tightening loan standards across the board, and that demand for loans is down from consumers as well as businesses. But the amount of money they are lending has been rising at an unusually fast pace.

headline: Museum Plan for Chicago’s Treasured Lakefront Stirs a Fight
text: CHICAGO  A proposal to build a children’s museum in a downtown park here has set off a fierce debate over Chicago’s cherished lakefront.

headline: E-Mail Shows Racial Jokes by Secret Service Supervisors
text: WASHINGTON  Secret Service supervisors shared crude sexual jokes and engaged in racially derogatory banter about blacks, and passed around an anecdote about a possible assassination of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, according to internal e-mail disclosed in a federal court filing on Friday by lawyers for black Secret Service agents.

headline: Edwards Endorses Obama, or Does He?
text: Rewind that tape again.

headline: In Flooded Delta, a Want as Pervasive as Death
text: BOGALE, Myanmar  The water has not receded fully, and few aid trucks have made it here. Only one helicopter, from the Myanmar military, was spotted all Friday, dropping off packages of instant noodles around a devastated delta that needs much more. Win Kyi, a mother looking for a lost son, was crying, her body shaking and her arms outstretched for food, money, water  anything.

headline: Ledger Portrait Wins a Prize
text: A portrait of Heath Ledger that was painted weeks before his death has won an art award in Australia, The Associated Press reported. The painting, by the British-born Australian artist Vincent Fantauzzo, shows three bare-chested images of the actor, one staring out from the canvas as the others whisper in his ears. On Thursday the painting, “Heath,” won the People’s Choice award in the annual national portrait competition at the Art Gallery of New South Wales in Sydney. Mr. Ledger, who plays the Joker in the new Batman movie, “The Dark Knight,” died in New York in January of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs. He was 28.

headline: Castro Back With Mets; Wise Is Soon to Follow
text: Sitting on a clubhouse couch, Matt Wise greeted a visitor Friday afternoon with a happy-to-be-here smile and by saying: “Hi, I’m Matt Wise. Nice to meet you.” No introductions were necessary, but forgive Wise for feeling the need to get reacquainted.

headline: Housing Bailout Bill Seems to Be on Shaky Ground
text: WASHINGTON  Even as the housing foreclosure crisis deepens, legislation to rescue homeowners and their lenders appears to be in significant political jeopardy.

headline: Enemies Face to Face, Exchanging Tales of Loss
text: “The Fever Chart,” a well-made trilogy by Naomi Wallace exploring that cauldron that is the Middle East, has absorbing characters and sharp, evocative dialogue. Just as important, though, is what it doesn’t have: strap-on bombs or heartfelt hugs.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 2 through May 9:

headline: An Identity Crisis? Hirshhorn Embraces It
text: WASHINGTON  “Um, interesting painting, but could you please tell me where all the airplanes are?”

headline: Caught in a Swirl of Drug Violence, Mexico Vows to Fight Back
text: MEXICO CITY  President Felipe Calderón and dozens of federal agents attended the funeral of the chief of the federal police on Friday morning, a day after his assassination, even as investigators focused on the possibility that someone inside the police force had tipped off the killers to his location.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
