text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about airline safety records abroad misstated the timing of the crash of a DC-9 on takeoff from Goma, Congo. The crash was on April 15, not “last week.”

headline: At Daimler, Sales Follow the World’s Oil Riches
text: Daimler AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, will deal with slowing auto sales in the United States in part by shifting sales to Russia, China and the Middle East, says Dieter Zetsche, Daimler’s chief executive. And the company, based in Stuttgart, Germany, expects to be the first to introduce a car with a lithium ion battery, the technology that is seen as crucial to creating all-electric vehicles, he says.

headline: How to Be Smarter
text: WHILE your I.Q. is basically determined at birth, Wired says, “still, there are lots of ways to get smarter  to max out your so-called functional intelligence” at work and elsewhere.

headline: Arizona and Utah Officials Reach Out to Polygamists
text: ST. GEORGE, Utah  Polygamy is probably here to stay. But child abuse in the polygamist world must be eradicated at all costs.

headline: Safety Set to Blaze Path With Familiar Number
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kenny Phillips said he figured all the telephone calls he had made to the Giants paid off when he spotted the blue practice jersey hanging in his locker Friday morning at Giants Stadium, and the No. 21 was on it.

headline: Racial Inequity and Drug Arrests
text: The United States prison system keeps marking shameful milestones. In late February, the Pew Center on the States released a report showing that more than 1 in 100 American adults are presently behind bars  an astonishingly high rate of incarceration notably skewed along racial lines. One in nine black men aged 20 to 34 are serving time, as are 1 in 36 adult Hispanic men.

headline: The Track That Defied the Writing on the Wall
text: DARLINGTON, S.C.  Harold King maneuvered the car onto the track at Darlington Raceway, Nascar’s original superspeedway. He punched the gas and steered the car high around the banked corner.

headline: 40 Years Later, an Uprising in Paris Is Still a Puzzle
text: Even without retrieving that bundle of yellowing French newspapers from the top shelf in a closet, it is easy to remember the night of May 10, 1968, in Paris. It is far less easy, 40 years later, to discern what it was all about. Adolescent hormones, the death of Communism, the death of capitalism or, as Andre Malraux suggested at the time, the death of God?

headline: Child Labor Rings Reach China’s Distant Villages
text: LIANGSHAN, China  The mud and brick schoolhouses in the lush mountain villages of this remote part of southwestern China are dark and barebones in the best of times. These days, they also lack students.

headline: Gas Prices Send Surge of Riders to Mass Transit
text: DENVER  With the price of gas approaching $4 a gallon, more commuters are abandoning their cars and taking the train or bus instead.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: METRO

headline: One Man, Alone Onstage, Displays a Disquieting Family Album
text: The multiple layers of “Far ...”  a personal, poetic and extraordinary hourlong work of multimedia dance theater by Rachid Ouramdane  express aspects of what might be called shared post-invasion, post-traumatic stress syndrome. Political, sociological and psychological, “Far ...” is an engrossing work of art, devoid of any explicit agenda, frequently ambiguous and often touching on the ineffable: a one-man show about the collective unconscious.

headline: China: Officials Fight Opposition to Chengdu Plant
text: Government officials are stepping up a campaign to quiet dissent over construction of a petrochemical plant on the outskirts of Chengdu, a provincial capital in western China. Last Sunday, hundreds of residents marched through downtown Chengdu to express concern about the plant’s environmental impact. This week, several blogs protesting the plant’s construction were blocked. Ran Yunfei, a blogger and journalist, said government officials visited his office to discuss the merits of the project. A state-controlled newspaper, Chengdu Business News, published articles laying out its benefits.

headline: Myanmar Seizes U.N. Food for Cyclone Victims and Blocks Foreign Experts
text: BANGKOK  The military leaders of Myanmar seized a shipment of United Nations food aid on Friday intended for victims of a devastating cyclone, declaring that they would accept donations of food and medicine but not the foreign aid workers international groups say are in equally short supply there.

headline: On McCain, Obama and a Hamas Link
text: In the clearest indication yet of how he intends to confront Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy issues in the general election, Senator John McCain on Friday again portrayed the Democratic contender as being the favorite of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, and implied that he would also be friendly with Iran, a Hamas ally.

headline: D’Antoni Takes His Time Pondering His Future
text: Mike D’Antoni’s teams are all about speed and spontaneity. His career planning strategy appears to be much more methodical.

headline: Obama Pulls Ahead of Clinton in Superdelegates
text: Senator Barack Obama surged ahead of his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the count of superdelegates on Friday, the first time since the outset of the race that Mrs. Clinton has lost the lead in one of her few remaining trump cards.

headline: Keeping ‘Furniture Ransom’ Off Your Moving Bill
text: LEAH MOORE and her husband, Colby Nichols, assumed they would be in their new Chicago home in time for dinner. Why would they think otherwise? All their belongings were in boxes, they had little furniture and they were moving only a few miles away.

headline: 25 Years to Life for Lawyer Guilty in Tycoon’s Murder
text: A Manhattan lawyer convicted of orchestrating the 1990 murder of a real estate tycoon involved in a bitter split from his estranged wife was sentenced on Friday to 25 years to life in prison.

headline: George Cressman Dies at 88; Led Weather Service
text: George Cressman, a pioneer in the use of computers to predict the weather and a former director of the National Weather Service, died on April 19 in Rockville, Md. He was 88 and lived in North Bethesda, Md.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 6 of the Travel section this weekend about music camps for adults misspells the given name of one rock musician who has appeared at a rock ’n’ roll fantasy camp and misspells the surname of another. They are Neal Schon, not Neil, and Roger Daltrey, not Daltry.

headline: Thank Goodness, Dublin Keeps Its Guinness Plant
text: DUBLIN  The owner of Guinness stout, ending widespread media speculation in Ireland that it would shut the 250-year-old St. James’s Gate brewery, said Friday that it was committed to continuing operations at the central Dublin site because of its iconic status.

headline: Elaine Dundy, Author of ‘The Dud Avocado,’ Is Dead at 86
text: Elaine Dundy, the author of the best-selling novel “The Dud Avocado,” whose title came from the theater critic Kenneth Tynan, her husband at the time, died on May 1 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86.

headline: Questions of Freedom, Set in Black and White
text: In his furious satire “The Unconquered,” the British playwright Torben Betts shakes the daylights out of the smarmy idea of freedom, commonly given lip service today in far-flung spots like Iraq, Britain and the United States. Rather like an angry dog with a series of rats in its jaws, Mr. Betts sets himself the task of killing off popular beliefs in the benevolence of Big Brother government, religion, marriage and, of course, capitalism and bourgeois consumerism.

headline: Snapshots of a Frenetic Campaign
text: To the Editor:

headline: With More Videotapes Come More Questions
text: When a former New England Patriots employee sent eight videotapes to the N.F.L. this week that showed the team spying on opponents, the question turned to whether the tapes contained new evidence of cheating, or if the league was already aware of everything on the tapes.

headline: Paris on the Anniversary of the 1968 Protests
text: France puts great stock in anniversaries. On your Paris map, you’ll find streets named “8 Mai 1945” and “4 Septembre” and squares called “8 Novembre 1942,” “18 Juin 1940,” “19 Mars 1962,” and, most recently, “Place du 8 Février 1962”  this one so christened last year on the anniversary of a protest for peace in Algeria. Flags come out, like the mammoth Tricouleur under the Arc de Triomphe for today’s Victory Day; newspapers groan under weighty ruminations; officials don sashes.

headline: Trade Deficit Narrows in March, but Exports Fall
text: Domestic demand for imports fell in March by the most since 2001, the latest indication that the economic slowdown has forced Americans to rein in their spending habits, the government reported Friday.

headline: Imagining a Cipriani Dining Place Without Those Family-Invented Bellinis
text: A Cipriani restaurant without a liquor license: aphorisms about dogs without bones spring to mind. How could it go on? And would it even be possible?

headline: Starting a Party, and Hoping to Crash Singapore’s Parliament Again
text: SINGAPORE

headline: Violence in Beirut
text: Heavily armed Hezbollah fighters seized control of much of western Beirut on Friday, after three days of the worst sectarian clashes Lebanon has seen since its 15-year civil war.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 111 U.N.L.V.
text: Location: Las Vegas

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Mother’s Day Scandal
text: It’s hard to imagine that a love child or two poses any actual threat to a Congressman’s constituents. The same cannot be said about having a local lawmaker who is prepared to get behind the wheel of a car when he’s too drunk to remember the rule about not mentioning the daughter in Alexandria to authority figures brandishing pencil and pad.

headline: Meg and Wes
text: Meg Berte and Wes Owen discuss briefly dating at Harvard and then finding years later that they belonged together.

headline: Meg and Wes
text: Meg Berte and Wes Owen discuss briefly dating at Harvard and then finding years later that they belonged together.

headline: Rastafari Culture at the Smithsonian
text: Images of the exhibition “Discovering Rastafari!” at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History.

headline: Rebranding the Hirshhorn
text: Images from the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, a contemporary art museum in Washington, D.C., which is hoping to distinguish itself through a new ad campaign.

headline: Jason Taylor Dances; The Theme Is Nostalgia
text: Jason Taylor on “Dancing With the Stars”

headline: ‘Pleasingly Plump’
text: More of your “late night jokes” (send via the comment link below):

headline: Free-Fallin’ Pols: The Screen Savers
‘According to the Most Recent Exit Polls …’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: I saw something in the paper today which shows how fat we’re getting in this country. A company has now come out with a bathroom scale that goes to 1,000 pounds. This is probably the worst Mother’s Day gift in history.

headline: Tensions Rise as Polar Bear Decision Looms
text: Steven C. Amstrup, the federal biologist who led an analysis last year concluding that the world’s polar bear population could shrink two thirds by 2050 under moderate projections for retreating summer sea ice, is once again in the field along Alaska’s Arctic coast, studying this year’s brood of cubs, yearlings and mothers.

headline: Stalling exports?
text: Brad Setser tells us that the trade numbers, contrary to just about all reporting, are worrisome: strip out the effects of raw material prices, and it looks as if export growth — the only thing that has kept us from having a much worse slowdown — is stalling out.

headline: Sick transit and all that
text: The Times reports that ridership on mass transit is surging thanks to high gasoline prices. Good.

headline: Where Gymnasts Are Chosen, in the Middle of Nowhere
text: NEW WAVERLY, Texas — This week, a group of Olympic gymnastics hopefuls headed for Bela and Martha Karolyi’s women’s national team training center held about 60 miles north of Houston. The last time I was at this 2,000-acre ranch was four years ago, just before the Athens Games. Since then, I’d forgotten about how far away this training center was from civilization. It’s in the boondocks, or maybe just south of there: about 16 miles away from the Texas State Prison in Huntsville, death row capital of the United States, and smack in the middle of Sam Houston National Forest, where the Karolyis settled in the early 80s.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 10:

headline: Your Comments on my Kids Column
text: My Sunday column is about high school and younger students moving into philanthropy and social action. It’s something that my wife and I noticed in particular in our work on a forthcoming book about women in the developing world. High school students, for example, have done great work on human trafficking, perhaps because it’s kids their age who are being locked up in brothels in India and Cambodia. Among the high school-led groups on that issue are Loosen Change to Loosen Chains and Minga. Minga’s founder was inspired by Free the Children,  a network of children helping other exploited children through education and other means. Girls Learn International is another example of high school kids fighting trafficking and helping kids abroad by keeping them in school.

headline: The Early Word: Delegate Catch-Up to General Match-Up
text: Now that he has caught up with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the superdelegate count, Senator Barack Obama is clashing more directly with Senator John McCain (so is Mrs. Clinton, for that matter).

headline: Blog Roll: Searching for Belmont Winner
text: Our friend Paul Moran appears to be conceding a victory to Big Brown in next Saturday in the Preakness Stakes. He is, however, looking for a Triple Crown upsetter for the Belmont Stakes. His search begins today in the Peter Pan Stakes out at Belmont.

headline: Narrow Escapes for CNN Reporter in Myanmar
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: HBO Signs Writer For ‘Hung’
text: “HBO has lined up another big Hollywood name for a new project,” Edward Wyatt reports. “Alexander Payne, the director and Oscar-winning co-writer of ‘Sideways,’ will direct and serve as an executive producer of ‘Hung,’ a new dark comedy series about a former basketball coach with a large penis.”

headline: Avocado Refrigerators Out, Mass Transit In
text: There are a couple of important stories in The Times worth highlighting today, one on determining when an old appliance should — and should not — get the heave-ho, and one on a burst of interest in mass transit driven by high gas prices.

headline: Three stories behind qualifying in Turkey
text: The top three finishers in today’s qualifying session each had equally interesting stories, although they are not all equally as straightforward.

headline: Retiring Horses
text: While we are in the midst of the Triple Crown, the showcase of our best 3-year-olds, it is important to remain committed to all horses that perform at racetracks up and down North America, and those horses that can no longer perform. Racetracks are now starting to recognize the issue and do something positive for its retired stars.

headline: May’s Poli-Book Best Sellers
text: Cokie Roberts rides in at No. 1 with “Ladies of Liberty,” on the heels of her earlier work, “Founding Mothers.”

headline: McCain Plane Still Flying
text: Cindy McCain said Thursday that she would never release her personal income tax filing even if her husband, Senator John McCain, was elected president. But Federal Aviation Administration records indicate that she appears to be using her personal wealth to help his campaign, through the continued use of her corporate jet.The New York Times reported last month that during a crucial five-month period Mr. McCain’s campaign regularly used a corporate jet owned by the Phoenix-based beer distributor that Mrs. McCain heads, saving the campaign hundreds of thousands of dollars. His campaign pays rates well below market ones for the plane’s use because of an unresolved exemption in a recent campaign finance law that Mr. McCain backed.

headline: Quick Hits: Catching Up With Mauer
text: In 2006, Joe Mauer of the Twins had two hits on the final day of the season that raised his average to .347. In doing so, he became the first catcher since 1930 to lead his league in batting average, and the first ever to lead the majors.

headline: The Morning Skate: Mighty Pens, Mighty Mouth
text: Poor Marty Biron. He’s been the Flyers’ MVP this spring, and deservedly so. But, c’mon without, c’mon within, he’s not see nothin’ like the mighty Pens.

headline: Clouds With No Rain
text: The rain is not coming down horizontally today at Shea Stadium, as it did last night, so everyone’s optimistic that we’ll get in both games of the day-night doubleheader without incident. So much so that Keith Hernandez, the SNY analyst, said (in jest? maybe?) we should cancel tomorrow’s game and play three today. Mmm…

headline: Macho Again In, Recapturetheglory Out
text: The Derby Trial winner Macho Again is back in the Preakness picture and worked a half mile this morning in 49.8 at Churchill Downs.

headline: Lemaire to Return as Wild Coach
text: Following a few weeks of speculation and uncertainty, former Devils coach Jacques Lemaire has announced he will return to the Minnesota Wild as their head coach.

headline: Four More Superdelegates for Obama
text: Updated Senator Barack Obama picked up three more superdelegates today. While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton earned a new one, one of her opponent’s pick-ups was a defector, so, at this point, today is a wash for her.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, May 11
text: Senator Barack Obama appears on CNN’s “Late Edition,” while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top advisers are making the rounds this Sunday, presumably to assure Democrats that she’s still “in it to win it.”

headline: An Urban Patchwork
text: The Brighton Beach neighborhood is a melting pot near the water. Photos and text by Becky Holladay.

headline: McCain Convention Coordinator Resigns
text: The public relations executive that Senator John McCain’s campaign tapped to run the Republican National Convention this summer resigned his post Saturday after a magazine reported that his firm had lobbied for the military junta that runs Myanmar.

headline: Clinton’s Mother’s Day Fund-Raiser
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton shared some advice Saturday that she says she gives her mother these days: “Just turn off the television.”

headline: Game’s On Big Brown
text: In quick succession, I got e-mails from a couple of our Rail regulars, Eric Banks and Alex Brown, about the emphatic victory today by Casino Drive in the Peter Pan Stakes. He is a half brother to 2006 Belmont Stakes winner Jazil and a three-quarters brother to 2007 Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches — all three are out of the dam Better Than Honour. Jazil’s sire is Seeking the Gold. Rags to Riches’ sire is 1992 Horse of the Year and Belmont Stakes winner A.P. Indy. Casino Drive’s sire is 2003 Horse of the Year Mineshaft, a son of A.P. Indy. The 140th Belmont Stakes will be run June 7.

headline: Obama Says McCain’s Keating Five Connection Is Not Off Limits
text: BEND, Ore. – Senator Barack Obama said today that a scandal from Senator John McCain’s past – the Keating Five – was just as relevant to the presidential campaign as questions about who Mr. Obama has associated with over the years.

headline: The eh team
text: OK, I knew that US public transit was pathetic compared with Western Europe; but if you try to talk about Europe, people start going on about population density, as if we all lived in Montana or something.

headline: With Casino Drive in Mix, All Bets Are Off
text: Even if Big Brown wins next Saturday’s running of the Preakness Stakes, the odds against him becoming the first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978 just got a lot longer. In the Grade II Peter Pan Stakes on Saturday at Belmont, Casino Drive proved that the hype surrounding this long-legged colt making his second career start after an 11½-length win in February in Kyoto, Japan, was earned.

headline: Fox, The CW Each Renew One, Cancel One
From YouTube to Documentary
text: There is a moment of foreshadowing at the end of “Battle at Kruger,” the eight-minute African safari video that has drawn more than 30 million views on YouTube.

text: MONTREAL

headline: In Cat and Mouse Game, Patriots Are Central Players
text: Long since the days of leather helmets and the V-formation, the N.F.L. has embraced technological advances that have brought dizzying changes to coaching strategy in the past decade.

headline: A Spring Taste From Italy
text: Alto Adige (a k a South Tyrol), in northern Italy, loves lagrein, a local red grape. Muri-Gries, a Benedictine monastery there, makes a popular lagrein rosato (rosé).

headline: Wackadoodle
text: Let’s begin at the ending.

headline: Mugabe’s Opponent Says He’ll Return for Runoff
text: PRETORIA, South Africa  Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of Zimbabwe’s opposition, announced here on Saturday that despite brutal attacks on hundreds of his party’s workers and fears for his own life, he would soon return home to face President Robert Mugabe in a runoff election.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GRAVEDIGGER’S DAUGHTER, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco/Harper Perennial, $15.95.) The daughter of a Holocaust survivor (the gravedigger of the title) who commits an incredible murder, Oates’s heroine endures enough violence to fill a slasher movie. But she is able to reinvent herself as a peppy salesclerk with a jazz-musician lover and become “a living, breathing, complex presence on the page,” our reviewer, Lee Siegel, wrote. Oates is sometimes compared to Theodore Dreiser, the author of “Sister Carrie,” Siegel continued, “but in the way her novels take off at the moment when her heroines break free, Oates is sometimes more like Carrie herself.”

headline: It’s the End of the World as the Knicks Know It
text: The sentiment was understandably strong for the slick-passing and smooth-talking Mark Jackson, out of Queens, N.Y., and St. John’s University and Madison Square Garden. But here is what Donnie Walsh, himself of the Bronx, had to be thinking once it was apparent that Mike D’Antoni, late of the Phoenix Suns, was also in play, available for hire as the coach of the Knicks:

headline: Chronicle of a Death Foretold
text: One of the wonders of the genome is how it enables us to time-travel, both backward and forward. Scribbled within it are clues to our ancestry, which can give us an emboldening sense of continuity, coherence, place  how marvelous to imagine ourselves the sons of Levi, the daughters of African queens! But scrawled within it, too, are clues about our future, which can be downright terrifying. Rather than expand our sense of possibilities, they foreshorten them. There are dread mutations slumbering in our cells. From our genes, we learn how we may die.

headline: Gunfire in Beirut, and 2 Mourners Become the Mourned
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  On Saturday morning, Ali Masri, 23, and Moussa Zouki, 24, and friends and relatives gathered outside the Gamal Abdel Nasser mosque for the funeral of Muhammad Shamaa, a 22-year-old man killed in a gun battle on Thursday.

headline: A Caramoor Performance Moves Into the Community
text: OVER the last five years, Jamie Bernstein’s family concerts have become a fixture at the Caramoor International Music Festival, held annually in Katonah. But next weekend, for the first time, they will move beyond the festival grounds.

headline: The Suffering of Soldiers
text: Several years into a pair of wars, the Department of Veterans Affairs is struggling to cope with a task for which it was tragically unready: the care of soldiers who left Afghanistan and Iraq with an extra burden of brain injury and psychic anguish. The last thing they need is the toxic blend of secrecy, arrogance and heedlessness that helped to send many of them into harm’s way.

headline: Meredith DePaolo, Hamel Shah
text: Meredith Ellen DePaolo, a daughter of Diane and Frank DePaolo of Landenberg, Pa., was married on Saturday to Hamel Mansukh Shah, the son of Chandri and Mansukh Shah of London. The Rev. Robert O. Davis, a Baptist minister, officiated at Mount Vernon Beach in Cape May, N.J.

headline: Martine Combal, Patrick McDonald
text: Martine Elizabeth Combal, a daughter of Mary Schmid Combal and Pierre H. Combal of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in Washington on Saturday to Patrick Hills McDonald, the son of Melinda Hills McDonald and Patrick O. McDonald of Philadelphia. The Rev. Lydio F. Tomasi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Rosary Church, where he is pastor.

text: Owning Up to Gentrification

headline: Dial M for Mother
text: Los Angeles

headline: Rasner Gives Yanks Some Stability
text: DETROIT  The Yankees’ 5-2 victory over the Tigers on Saturday at Comerica Park raised their record to .500 again and featured the sort of ensemble pitching that may tempt the team’s ownership, management, fans and news media followers to be patient with the staff.

headline: Correction: No Shoes, No Shirt, No Worries
text: An article on April 27 about high-end vacations for nudists referred incorrectly to Larry Massa, a retired Naval commander and computer science engineer from Virginia Beach, and his fellow nudists. They call themselves naturists  not naturalists.

headline: Correction: ‘Shakespeare’s Wife’
text: Because of an editing error, a review on April 27 about “Shakespeare’s Wife,” by Germaine Greer, misstated the nature of a “return” Shakespeare made in 1611, the subject of one of the book’s chapters. It was from London to Stratford-upon-Avon, not “to London.”

headline: Paris Bistro, Minus Paris
text: A PARISIAN dive with a prix-fixe menu heavy on warm beer and mediocre sausages would seem an unlikely source of inspiration for a cozy little bar in Hollywood, but that’s what spurred Steven Arroyo to create his new bistro, Sgt. Recruiter.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on April 6 about proposals to give shareholders of various companies a nonbinding vote on executive compensation referred incorrectly to the precedent set by Aflac, the supplemental insurance company. It is the first publicly traded company to offer such a vote, not the first company over all. (That distinction is held by TIAA-CREF, the big pension fund, which has given policyholders a so-called say on pay since last summer.) The April 6 error was discovered when TIAA-CREF sent an e-mail message on Tuesday pointing out that a headline and an article in Business Day that day contained the error.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: FILM

headline: 36 Hours in Liverpool, England
text: THE word Liverpool invariably evokes two images: the Beatles and soccer. That’s a shame because this industrial city, which celebrated its 800th birthday last year (and is the 2008 European Capital of Culture), moved on a long time ago. Avant-garde architecture and glassy museums share the skyline with redbrick warehouses and foggy quays. Liverpool’s contemporary art scene is no longer overshadowed by London’s but possesses its own roster of Turner Prize winners. And the city’s legendary music scene continues to put together new sounds. Just listen to the recent crop of breakthrough bands like the Wombats, the Zutons and the Coral. Never heard of them? Must be a different generation.

headline: For Students, a Coveted Space for Their Art
text: MORRIS TOWNSHIP

headline: Ballot Box Office
text: Q: As the director of   “Meet the Parents” and other hit comedies, you adopt a surprisingly sober tone in your coming film, “Recount,” which takes us back to the 36 days in the autumn of 2000 when the results of the presidential election remained disputed in Florida. Have you shown the film to   Al Gore? He has not seen the film as far as I know.

headline: Take My Brother, Please
text: Children tend to become what we expect them to be. When we envisioned them as vessels waiting to be filled with virtue, they made like vessels; nowadays we see them as consumers, and they fall into line, getting, spending and demanding designer gear. A couple of new books about brothers and sisters reveal expectations adults currently have of sibling relationships.

headline: Abigail Herron, Donald Fried
text: Dr. Abigail Jane Herron and Donald Stephan Fried were married on Saturday at Loft Eleven, an event space in Manhattan. Franklin Bradley, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Correction: How Murdoch Got Lost in China
text: The Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of “Rupert Murdoch’s China Adventures,” a book by Bruce Dover, referred incorrectly to Mr. Dover’s current employer, the Australia Network, where he is chief executive. It is part of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, not the ABC-TV unit of Disney.

headline: ‘Muqtada’
text: The Fall of Najaf

headline: Time of Her Life
text: Can we talk about the Upper West Side for a second? I know, I know, it’s just not the same these days. The comfy habitat of liberal Manhattan intelligentsia has been dismantled: the hedge funders have colonized the classic sixes, every other storefront’s a bank and Broadway is lousy with Starbucks. But the old neighborhood’s still got some magic, as evidenced by Lily Koppel’s new book, “The Red Leather Diary: Reclaiming a Life Through the Pages of a Lost Journal.” Where else can a young writer inherit a 75-year-old diary, left to rot in the storage room of a prewar building? And in a plastic bag from Zabar’s, yet?

headline: 1958: The War of the Intellectuals
text: Much has been made of 1968  the student uprisings in Paris, the assassinations of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy, the full flowering of youth culture. But what of its more unassuming antecedent, 1958? Fifty years ago, Eisenhower was in the White House, the country was in a recession and the American intellectual scene was crackling with energy.

headline: Call Your Mother
text: The ad popped up in my e-mail the way it always has: “1-800-Flowers: Mother’s Day Madness  30 Tulips + FREE vase for just $39.99!”

headline: Rethinking Ethanol
text: The time has come for Congress to rethink ethanol, an alternative fuel that has lately fallen from favor. Specifically, it is time to end an outdated tax break for corn ethanol and to call a timeout in the fivefold increase in ethanol production mandated in the 2007 energy bill.

headline: Emotional Responses to a Thoroughbred’s Death
text: There was an outpouring of reactions to The Times’s coverage of the May 3 Kentucky Derby, in which Eight Belles finished second to Big Brown, then broke her front ankles and was put down on the track at Churchill Downs. Here are some of the letters.

headline: Cinematic Life in Oslo (Where Else?)
text: “REPRISE,” the first feature by the director Joachim Trier, is set in Norway’s capital, Oslo. It’s not a city that often turns up on American screens, but for some viewers the film will be as familiar as the bedrooms and bull sessions of their formative years. This portrait of the artist as a young man is lovingly bedecked with the accessories of a certain type of intellectual in training: the Bataille and Barthes paperbacks, the punk-rock posters and LPs.

headline: The Car That Made a Brand
text: OF all the vehicles that Nissan has sold in the United States, the 1970 240Z did the most to establish its reputation. Here are highlights of that car’s later generations.

headline: Mount Tremper, N.Y.: Kate’s Lazy Meadow
text: THE BASICS

headline: The Watch List
text: Travis Hafner had improved every season since first coming up in 2002. So it was logical to view his subpar 2007 with the Indians as an anomaly. The problem is, his batting troubles are becoming the norm. Hafner, right, was dropped to sixth in the Indians’ lineup two weeks ago and then sat back-to-back games last week. His .220 average can be partly attributed to a lack a patience  he is seeing fewer pitches per at-bat than in his previous three seasons. If there is an encouraging sign, it is that he is hitting fewer ground balls, which could spark his power numbers.

headline: Saving the World in Study Hall
text: Teenagers are supposed to be sullen and self-absorbed, but Rachel S. Rosenfeld never got the memo.

headline: Gasol Ceding the Spotlight, but Still Shining
text: LOS ANGELES  Pau Gasol, the Lakers center, was explaining the other day why he is highly motivated to finish off the Utah Jazz in the second round of the N.B.A. playoffs. “I’m supposed to go to the opera next week,” he said.

headline: The Play Is Over, but the Party Lingers On
text: ON most nights at 59E59 Theaters, the end of the play is just the beginning of the evening.

headline: Hangers Made to Recycle

headline: Niko Bellic vs. Britney Spears and Indiana Jones
text: How huge is Grand Theft Auto IV, the recently released installment of the guns-ablazing video game franchise?

headline: Map of Dreams
text: Since 1963, Uri Shulevitz has commanded attention. In that year, a refugee in his 20s, he published his first picture book, “The Moon in My Room.” Forty-five years, a Caldecott Medal, numerous honors and more than 40 titles later, Shulevitz now gives us his first explicitly autobiographical story. It is a masterpiece.

headline: A Wedding Invitation for a Mom Long Gone
text: SEVEN months ago, I was married in an ivory lace dress to a man in a gray suit on an island neither of us had ever been to. There was wind and sun and ocean, and 50 of our favorite people squinted up at us as we read our own vows. My mother was not there, as I knew she wouldn’t be, because she has been dead for so long that the scales have recently tipped: I have seen more days without her than with.

headline: Governor Paterson’s Forgotten Agenda
text: Before he suddenly became New York’s governor, David Paterson was a committed reformer. In his years as a state senator (and leader of the Democratic minority), he called for limiting special-interest money, public financing of elections, and sweeping out as much muck as possible from the State Legislature.

headline: Jenna Bush Has Wedding at Ranch in Crawford
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  President Bush’s daughter Jenna Welch Bush on Saturday married Henry Chase Hager, a graduate student and son of a former Virginia lieutenant governor, before 200 relatives and close family friends here, the White House confirmed.

headline: Nellie Stevens, Corey Reed
text: Nellie Kate Stevens, a daughter of Margaret and Jeremy Stevens of Los Angeles, was married on Saturday to Corey Reed, the son of LeeAnn and Charles Reed of Middletown, N.J. Mitchel R. Goldberg, a retired judge of the federal Bankruptcy Court in Riverside, Calif., officiated at Rancho del Cielo, an event space in Malibu, Calif.

headline: D’Antoni Accepts Offer to Coach Knicks
text: Mike D’Antoni likes his basketball to be fast and furious, entertaining and effective  in essence, everything the Knicks are not. In the most counterintuitive move of the year, D’Antoni agreed Saturday to become their new coach.

headline: Nancy White, John Feldtmose
text: Nancy Carolyn White and John Nielsen Feldtmose were married on Saturday evening at their home in Larchmont, N.Y. Valerie M. O’Keeffe, the supervisor of the Town of Mamaroneck, N.Y., officiated.

Tassler and Alan Tassler of Washington, were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Peter H. Schweitzer officiated at the Altman Building in New York, an event space that was once the carriage house of the B. Altman department store.

text: The arrival of the newest and tallest motor homes in the Formula One paddock is an overt statement of intent by the sport’s youngest team, Force India.
