headline: Roaming the World, Detecting Fashion
text: LINDA DeFRANCO recalls a meeting five years ago where her boss, the head of trend forecasting at Cotton Inc., came back from a research trip with some interesting photographs. While strolling the streets of Stockholm, she had seen teenagers wearing their jeans rolled up a few inches to make them tighter around the legs.

headline: Why Garden? Because It’s Spring
text: AH, spring. The sun’s cameo appearance. The first 70-degree day. Nature’s spectacular roll-out, from the first crocus to the regal, shimmering cherry tree.

headline: In Fashion, and Baseball, What’s Old Is Still Old
text: The Athletics and the Rangers played in throwback uniforms last Sunday, and baseball purists (at least those who obsess about fashion) rejoiced. The celebration was not caused by the Oakland players wearing vests or even their butter-cream-yellow batting helmets. Rather, it was the classic stirrup socks.

headline: I, Chihuahua
text: Ten miles from California’s border with Mexico, a new craze is spreading among the students at the Chula Vista Learning Community Charter School. Enthusiasm for Pokémon is fading, and Hello Kitty is also on the wane. Judy Schachner’s “Skippyjon Jones” books  about a Siamese kitten who thinks he’s a Chihuahua  are all the rage.

headline: My Landlord, My Curator
text: TO Adrian Longo, a building is a blank canvas. While not a painter, Mr. Longo has transformed the family business  three five-story yellow brick apartment buildings in Washington Heights  into what he calls living galleries, places that celebrate his love of pictures and, believe it or not, his tenants.

headline: Two New Contenders Emerge for World Championship Slot
text: A tournament that ended last week provided another reminder that the cliché “they don’t play the games on paper” is true.

headline: Breakfast as You Like It
text: With the lush banks of the Housatonic River nearby and the Appalachian Trail just steps away, the Mountainside Cafe, a forest-green roadhouse with a knotty pine interior, is aptly named. Its affiliation with the Mountainside Treatment Center, a drug and alcohol treatment facility in Canaan, makes that doubly true.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about the television show “Medium” misspelled the surname of a composer whose film soundtracks come to mind during the show’s opening credits. He was Bernard Herrmann, not Hermann.

headline: Correction: Rome, Datebook
text: The Datebook column on April 27, about a Carlo Levi exhibit at the Villa Torlonia, a former home of Mussolini, gave an incorrect location for the villa. It is in Rome, on the Via Nomentana; not 15 miles out of the city.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about police detectives’ longstanding tradition of wearing suits and ties on the job referred incorrectly to the coats worn by detectives shown escorting Charles (Lucky) Luciano in 1936. They were topcoats  not trench coats, a type of raincoat that is typically belted and double-breasted.

headline: All the Difference
text: The life of Robert Frost has been autopsied and re-autopsied so many times that, 45 years since his death, the congeries of appraisals can already be measured in layers, like geologic strata. The early biographies  beginning with Gorham B. Munson’s “Robert Frost: A Study in Sensibility and Good Sense,” published less than 15 years after Frost’s first book of poems  tended toward hagiography, portraying Frost as Frost carefully portrayed himself: as a homespun Yankee sage, the L. L. Bean of verse, a swinger of birches and picker of apples whose wisdom and prickly wit were like a potbellied woodstove taking the chill (Eliot, Pound) out of Modernist poetry.

headline: Neetika Prabhakar, Joseph Cox
text: Neetika Prabhakar, the daughter of Saroj Prabhakar and Dr. Shyam Prabhakar of Baldwin Harbor, N.Y, was married on Saturday to Joseph David Cox, the son of Bebe Cox and David Cox of Haleyville, Ala. The Rev. Andrew Cannan, a minister of the International Council of Community Churches, officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York. The Rev. Bret-Ashton G. Gresham, a United Methodist minister, also participated.

headline: The Promise and Perils of Ceramics in Artificial Hips
text: In the past, doctors routinely advised young and active patients to live as long as possible with hip pain before getting their first implant, in hopes of avoiding a second replacement.

headline: Man in a Black Turban
text: When it comes to the cat’s cradle of Iraqi sects, tribes, families, ethnicities, parties, regions and seemingly eternal animosities, there is hardly a better candidate for teasing apart those crisscrossing threads than Patrick Cockburn. The Iraq correspondent for The Independent in London, he has been visiting Iraq since 1977 and has written two previous books on the country. Cockburn lives up to those credentials in his important new book, “Muqtada,” which goes a long way toward helping us understand the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr by following his family through the modern history of Iraq.

headline: Struggling to Prevent Suicides at Tappan Zee
text: TARRYTOWN

headline: Home Again (or Still)
text: AFTER a few years in their cluttered one-bedroom co-op, Francesca Perissinotto DeMartino and David DeMartino were feeling caged.

headline: News Corporation Withdraws Its Bid for Newsday
text: Cablevision on Saturday appeared likely to prevail in the bidding for Newsday, people briefed on the matter said, after the News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, pulled out of the running.

headline: Three Soldiers
text: Of all the grim theaters of conflict in World War II, none were more dismal and murderous than Italy in the winter of 1944. As American forces slogged and scrambled their way north, the Germans gave way with brutal reluctance, while Italian partisans fought Fascists, and others welcomed the “liberators” or just sullenly watched. The war took place in a world of ambush, treachery and uncertainty. This is the setting for Richard Bausch’s 11th novel, a short, bleakly brilliant one-act drama depicting the futility and moral complexity of combat.

headline: Vote Like Thy Neighbor
text: The buzz these days is that American politics may be entering a “postpartisan” era, as a new generation finds the old ideological quarrels among baby boomers to be increasingly irrelevant. In reality, matters are not so simple. Far from being postpartisan, today’s young adults are significantly more likely to identify as Democrats than were their predecessors. Along with colleagues at the Brookings and Hoover institutions, we recently completed a comprehensive study of the nation’s polarization. Our research concludes not only that the ideological differences between the political parties are growing but also that they have become embedded in American society itself.

headline: Is She a Trojan Rabbit?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Public Defender System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time to Tie a String Around That Strad
text: They talk about these bundles of wood and string as if they’re an extra limb, a repository of their DNA, a conduit to the very depths of their soul.

headline: Tabitha Shanies, Keith Hutton
text: Dr. Tabitha Amity Shanies and Keith Aaron Hutton were married on Tuesday in Media, Pa. Judge Nicholas S. Lippincott of the District Court of Upper Providence Township officiated in his chambers.

headline: The Spring Thaw Means a River Rush
text: IT’S time to stash your snowboard and blow up your inner tube. A significant spring thaw is expected to make the boating and rafting season stronger and longer this summer  especially out West.

headline: In Serbian Elections, Voters Face a Choice Between East and West
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  A few weeks ago members of a liberal resistance group here scattered ashes over their heads, an act of penance, they said, for electing Vojislav Kostunica, the prime minister who helped overthrow Slobodan Milosevic but who has since adopted Mr. Milosevic’s harsh nationalist language.

headline: Fifty Years of Memorable Cars
text: THE success of Japanese automakers in the United States, though typically remembered as a story of smooth, steady sales increases, was in fact a road full of bumpy stretches. For Nissan, which can point to a half-century of experience in this country, the time has been more akin to the description of combat flying offered by the World War II ace Col. Gregory Boyington: hours and hours of boredom sprinkled with a few seconds of sheer terror.

headline: Musical Goes Silent, Its Star Felled by Illness
text: RUTH WILLIAMSON could tell something was wrong. On Friday night, May 2, when she went onstage at the Emelin Theater for the second performance of “Pure Heaven: A Party With Kay Thompson,” she said, she felt definite problems with her voice.

headline: Take My Wife. Please. I’ll Take Yours.
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Starwood Is Going Green With a New Hotel Chain
text: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide is introducing a new green hotel chain, called Element (www.elementhotels.com). The first hotel, scheduled to open this July in Lexington, Mass., is serving as a laboratory of sorts to explore the design, construction and operations for all future Element properties (the company plans to open more than 20 hotels by the end of 2009). Each Element hotel will be required to pursue certification from the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design.

headline: Her Brilliant Career
text: ON my 13th birthday, I was discovered at Elaine’s.

headline: In a Reptile Survey, Unexpected Finds
text: MASTIC BEACH

headline: For Rooftop Antennas, It’s Showtime
text: LOOKING east from the roof of the 19-story co-op at 875 Boynton Avenue in Soundview in the Bronx, you can see the Whitestone Bridge. Looking far to the south, off in the distance, past the East River and the Manhattan skyline, you can see the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. If you look straight up, to the very top of a brick shed on the roof that houses the building’s elevator machinery, you can see a bridge to the not-so-distant past, when most people’s television signals came, without charge, out of the big blue sky.

headline: Correction: When Off Meets Off Off, Creative Ferment Is On
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the eroding boundary between Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway productions misidentified the actress pictured with Tobias Segal and Julie White in “From Up Here.” She is Aya Cash, who portrays the sister of Mr. Segal’s character, not Jenni Barber, who portrays his student mentor.

headline: I Had a Funny Farm in Africa
text: The first scene in Robyn Scott’s memoir takes place shortly after her family has arrived in Botswana. Her parents had decided on the spur of the moment to uproot their children from New Zealand and return to the peaceful nation where they had met.

headline: Meg Berté, Wes Owen
text: Meg Bowman Berté and Larry Wesley Owen II were married Wednesday in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Gabriel Gillen, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Catherine of Siena Church in New York. On Saturday, Thomas Berté, a brother of the bride, led a celebration on the beach in Playa del Carmen, Mexico. The couple met at Harvard Business School, from which they both received M.B.A. degrees.

headline: Carrie Fowler, Douglas Stowe
text: Carrie H. Fowler, the daughter of Betsey and Jim Fowler of New Canaan, Conn., was married on Saturday to Douglas Stowe, the son of Virginia K. Stowe and Richard Stowe, both of New York. The Rev. Dr. William D. Coker, a Presbyterian minister and the pastor of the Covenant Presbyterian Church in Albany, Ga., officiated at the bride’s father’s wildlife ranch, also in Albany.

headline: Correction: Terrifying, Not Unlike Your Real Life
text: An article last Sunday about the television show “Medium” misspelled the surname of a composer whose film soundtracks come to mind during the show’s opening credits. He was Bernard Herrmann, not Hermann.

headline: Foraging in the Wilds for Mushrooms
text: Pound Ridge

headline: 2005 Merliance Is New Merlot From Collective
text: When the Long Island Merlot Alliance was formed by five producers in 2005, the local wine industry debated its value. Since merlot had become established as the Island’s signature red  today 38 of 43 producers make it  an organization to promote it and to define quality standards was unnecessary, dissenting producers said.

headline: When Should the Fed Crash the Party?
text: IN the darkest days of the Depression, Treasury Secretary Andrew W. Mellon, one of the richest men in the United States, opposed any government action to stem the tide of plunging business activity and soaring unemployment. Instead, he urged a policy of supreme indifference.

headline: Longtime Practice of City Council Financing Lands on Speaker’s Shoulders
text: In the widening scandal that has revealed the peculiar accounting methods of the New York City Council, a harsh light has been cast on Christine C. Quinn, the Council speaker, who is being asked to answer for a system not of her own making.

headline: A Dance Curriculum That Offers Much More Than the Fox Trot
text: North Babylon

headline: Questions Linger Over Immigrants’ Deaths
text: MOUNT KISCO

headline: The Greatest’s Story, Told Twice
text: Muhammad Ali’s epic journey  from the 12-year-old Cassius Clay who learned to box after his new bike was stolen, to the ’60s icon of defiance, sacrifice and principle, to the first three-time heavyweight champion of the world, to the gallant Parkinson’s patient  is a narrative so dense and complex that it has so far eluded definitive biography.

headline: Pragmatic Politics, Forged on the South Side
text: In August 1999, Barack Obama strolled amid the floats and bands making their way down Martin Luther King Drive on Chicago’s South Side. Billed as the largest African-American parade in the country, the summer rite was a draw over the years to boxing heroes like Muhammad Ali and jazz greats like Duke Ellington. It was also a must-stop for the city’s top politicians.

headline: In Dixie, Signs of a Rising Biracial Politics
text: Across the South, Barack Obama’s smashing primary victory in North Carolina last week reflects a new reality  a half-century of rising Republican red tide has crested, with signs of receding.

headline: Boys to Men
text: A college friend who was struggling in one of his classes went to talk things over with his professor. If he was counting on sympathy, he was in for a surprise: “Get interested in Latin,” the professor advised him. “Latin won’t get interested in you.”

headline: Difficult Truths
text: A young man, heir to a fortune so vast he considers it his “cross of gold,” comes home from Guadalcanal a decorated hero, bearing scars from a bullet that just missed his heart. God has saved him, he believes, for a purpose. The vocation he heard at Yale has grown loud enough to drown out the objections of his family. Ordained an Episcopal priest in 1949, he begins his career in a blighted New Jersey parish, eventually climbing to a position so exalted that at his death in 2003 he is remembered as “a prince of the church,” “a saint.”

headline: Bridal Gown? Caterer? Mortgage?
text: AS they seek ways to offset the downturn in home sales, real estate and mortgage brokers have recently started courting first-time buyers among the newly engaged  at wedding expos and on wedding Web sites.

headline: When We Last Saw Our Heroes ...
text: Unto God is the sequel of all things,” says the Koran, but we’ve never paid much attention to that, have we? America is the land of the sequel, from the founding of the New World to the release of “Spider-Man 3,” and children’s literature is no exception. Perhaps this is because both children and publishers are honest enough to say out loud what the rest of us think when we finish a good book: “More!”

headline: City Opera’s Man in Waiting, Thinking Ahead
text: PARIS

headline: First-Class Privilege
text: Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff went to Baltimore-Washington International Airport two weeks ago to inaugurate a program called Checkpoint Evolution. It introduces 600 “whole-body imagers” that replicate, in schematic 3-D, everything a passenger is hiding under his or her clothing  not only hypothetical daggers, pistols, knuckle dusters and cocaine but also actual moles, scars, sores, nipples and genitalia. And all of it so vividly that the A.C.L.U. calls the imagers “virtual strip-search” machines. But Checkpoint Evolution is about comfort as well as security. Pleasant music, better lighting and open spaces are supposed to change the airport-security experience “in a way that lowers the general stress level,” Chertoff said. He failed, however, to mention a thing about checkpoints that drives stress levels to insurrectionary heights: the segregated security lines that certain airports and airlines permit. Many first- and business-class passengers, as well as frequent fliers, zip right to the metal detectors while coach passengers snake through lines for waits than can exceed half an hour. If Americans will put up with that, they’ll put up with being seen naked.

headline: Pastors and Politics
text: Pastors and Politics

headline: Kitchen So Small, but Taste So Big
text: THE major dissonant note at Harvest Supper, a new restaurant in New Canaan, is the name. On my first visit I expected home-style cooking and a fake Amish atmosphere. What I found was a stylish American menu, sophisticated food to match, beautifully plated on Japanese ceramics of varying shapes. And while the décor is crisply simple, it is artfully so. This is no country kitchen in the Poconos.

headline: Day to Remember, Night to Forget (Except Pelfrey)
text: The opener of their day-night doubleheader Saturday reminded the Mets how simple and enjoyable baseball can be: see the ball, hit the ball. They thrashed the Cincinnati Reds, 12-6, scoring 12 runs for the second straight game, as Carlos Beltrán and Carlos Delgado were front and center in offsetting a merely good outing by their ace, Johan Santana.

headline: A Peek Behind the Price at the Pump
text: FROM Capitol Hill to Wall Street to the campaign trail, the recent surge in oil prices is quickly threatening to supplant the mortgage crisis as the country’s leading economic issue. Last week, prices for crude set another record, finishing at $125.96 a barrel on Friday, while gasoline prices closed in on $4 a gallon.

headline: Taking a Break From Life to Live the Fantasy
text: A LATE-NIGHT jam session in a hotel lobby is what persuaded Tom Stockfisch to take up the cello shortly before his 50th birthday. On a summer night four years ago, he and his wife stumbled upon a Quality Inn where participants were staying for the annual Strings Conference in San Diego, a summer camp of sorts for violinists, cellists, bassists and viola players created by the virtuoso violinist Mark O’Connor.

headline: Station Site Envisioned as Village
text: A TRANSIT village consisting of an estimated 1.2 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail and industrial development, tied together by a new Long Island Rail Road station, is being explored for the Route 110 corridor near Republic Airport.

headline: Back From the ’80s, Eyeing Other People’s Money
text: Would Larry the Liquidator have been able to take over Yahoo?

headline: Over the Bustle of the Everyday Commute, Her Voice Has Guided the Way
text: The voice that launched a thousand trips — on Thursday alone — was about to launch another.

headline: Even Listening Is Dangerous
Humbler, After a Streak of Magic
text: FOR 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller, one of the country’s most closely watched and widely worshiped stockpickers, made investments that handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.

headline: Almighty Dolor
text: Foreign-Currency C.D.’s

headline: New Rules and Economy Strain Adoption Agencies
text: Faced with a tightening of federal regulations governing foreign adoptions, and suffering from a downturn in business, international adoption agencies in the United States are finding themselves in financial straits and closing their doors in unprecedented numbers, experts say.

headline: Katherine Barge, Jeremy Paris
text: Katherine Wright Barge and Jeremy Austin Paris were married on Saturday evening at the Grove Park Inn in Asheville, N.C. Rabbi Harvey J. Winokur officiated, with the Rev. Timothy C. Ahrens, a United Church of Christ minister, taking part.

headline: Ski Portillo in Chile Opens a Spa Hotel
text: Owners of the prestigious Chilean ski resort Ski Portillo recently opened the Tierra Atacama Adventure Spa Hotel (www.tierraatacama.com) in northern Chile, just outside the historic town of San Pedro de Atacama. The 32-room resort, which was built at an elevation of 8,000 feet in the Andes Mountains, below, is surrounded by high-altitude deserts and salt flats. Its spa incorporates local ingredients, like desert herbs and salt from the flats, into treatments like body wraps and massages.

headline: Correction: Evening Hours
text: Two picture captions last Sunday in the Evening Hours column reversed the identities of the couples honored on April 27 at the New Museum anniversary gala. Susan and Leonard Feinstein were at the middle left; Mitzi and Warren Eisenberg were at the top left.

headline: Katharine Carter, Bradford O’Grady
text: Katharine Carter and Bradford O’Grady were married on Saturday at Christ Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Leslie Smith, an Episcopal priest and the church’s interim rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Quiet Jazz, Roaring Noise, Hip-Hop Wizardry
text: Jonah Jones

headline: Hezbollah Begins to Withdraw Gunmen in Beirut
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah and its allies began withdrawing their gunmen from the capital here on Saturday evening, raising hopes for a political settlement after four days of street battles that left at least 29 people dead.

headline: Correction: Inside the List
text: Because of a transcription error, a brief report in the Inside the List column on April 27 about Julie Andrews’s memoir, “Home,” misquoted one word of an interview Andrews had with Terry Gross on NPR. She described being very young with a voice that was able to do cadenzas, not “condensers.”

headline: 50 Years of Dizzy, Courtesy of Hitchcock
text: “I LOOK up, I look down,” says Detective John (Scottie) Ferguson of the San Francisco police, standing nervously on a stepladder in an early scene of Alfred Hitchcock’s “Vertigo.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: LIFE AND DEATH ARE WEARING ME OUT, by Mo Yan. Translated by Howard Goldblatt. (Arcade, $29.95.) This visionary novel tracks China’s revolutionary experience through the eyes of five animal narrators, serial reincarnations of a wealthy landlord.

headline: Criminal Charges Filed in Fuel Spill Aftermath
text: WHEN fuel-pumping equipment at the Croton-Harmon Metro-North rail yard ruptured in late March, about 17,000 gallons of diesel fuel spilled into the ground  a potential environmental hazard.

headline: Von der Lippe Is Still Making a Splash at 42
text: Winning an Olympic medal is supposed to open doors. Isn’t that how it works? Susan von der Lippe, a three-time Olympian who won a silver in 1984, ruminated on the privileges bestowed upon the sport’s ultra-elite from her seat high above the pool deck at the United States swimming trials four years ago.

headline: The Dangers of the Deltas
text: Deltas are disaster zones in waiting. From the Mekong to the Mississippi, the rich soils and strategic positions of river mouths have long lured farmers, fishers and traders. But the same geography also guarantees they will be periodically inundated.

headline: Emily Forland, Mark Abrams
text: Emily Forland and Mark Abrams were married on Saturday evening at the McNay Art Museum in San Antonio. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl officiated.

headline: Lottery Numbers
With Echoes of Their War, Veterans Greet Iraq Soldiers
text: Fort Dix

headline: Bread That’s Flat and Flavorful
text: At restaurants that serve Mediterranean foods, the bread is often a semiflexible scoop for hummus or a bland envelope for a sandwich. So it comes as a surprise when the first impression  a good one  of a falafel sandwich is the pita, fluffy, pliant and even flavorful.

headline: Stocks and Earnings Suffer Together
text: The stock market fell last week, beaten down by grim corporate earnings reports and the burden of record-breaking energy prices.

headline: Going Once, Twice, Sold to the Guy on the Curb
text: BRIAN KEARNEY, an auctioneer wearing a black suit and red tie, stood at the front door of 593 President Street in Park Slope on Tuesday, holding a wooden gavel that proved merely decorative, since there was nothing on which to bang it.

headline: A Funhouse Floating in a Korean Spa
text: “THIS is the best night of my life!” burbled Rory as he was swashed in an inner tube around the whirlpool section of the outdoor hot pools at Inspa World.

headline: Judge’s Guantánamo Ruling Bodes Ill for System
text: A decision by a military judge on Friday to disqualify a top Pentagon official from any further role in a Guantánamo war crimes case was a major new challenge to the Bush administration’s legal approach to the war on terrorism.

headline: One County Away, a Different Care Picture
text: While Suffolk County is considering whether to dispose of its nursing home, Nassau County is making plans to build a $100 million replacement for its 47-year-old A. Holly Patterson Extended Care Facility in Uniondale.

headline: As You Exit J.F.K., a Chilling Memory Below
text: The Dispatches column last Sunday, about an AirTrain station near Kennedy Airport that was struck by a police detective’s bullet during the confrontation that led to the shooting death of Sean Bell in 2006, referred imprecisely to the background of Richard Criscuola, an airport cargo handler who often passes through the station. He moved to Queens about a year ago  but not to Jamaica, Queens, where he moved more recently.

headline: An Indie Scene That Comes With a Texas Twang in Denton
text: WITH its Piggly Wiggly markets and dusty pawnshops, the Texas college town of Denton does not look the part of a Woodstock in waiting. A Romanesque courthouse juts out of the central square, as in that fictional town in “Back to the Future.” And whenever the local college football team plays at Fouts Field, the entire town seems to put on Mean Green T-shirts.

headline: The Mother Hood
text: Suddenly unmoored in her 41st year, Amy Lamb is drifting in a familiar midlife sea of ambivalence and regret. Like many other Manhattan mothers, she left a career to raise her child. But now her son, Mason, is 10 and increasingly independent; Leo, her kindly, overworked husband, is more and more remote, burrowing ever deeper into the files he brings home at night. And as for her long-lost career  she was a corporate lawyer in the middling firm where she’d met Leo  well, it was really never that absorbing. Amy’s circle includes Roberta Sokolov, an artist turned full-time mother whose own career, like Amy’s, never quite blossomed, and Jill Hamlin, her best friend from college, who carries around a whole satchelful of disappointments: a failed dissertation, years of infertility, an inability to connect with her placid, adopted daughter.

headline: Avenues of Change
text: New wrinkles keep coming in the competition between the incumbent Fifth Avenue and the challenger Seventh Avenue as Park Slope’s restaurant row. These additions have arrived in the past year.

headline: Istanbul's Beat Is International
text: TO sample the youthful sounds of Istanbul, snake down a narrow street behind Tunel square until you find Badehane. For years, this one-room corner cafe (General Yazgan Sokak 1D; 90-212-249-0550) in the buzzing night life district of Beyoglu has been a favorite of the bohemian set, which comes on Wednesday nights to listen to the gypsy tunes of a local legend, Selim Sesler.

headline: Information That Doesn’t Come Freely
text: NINA BERNSTEIN, a Times reporter, wrote a front-page article last June about the deaths of prisoners in the fastest-growing form of incarceration in America, immigration detention.

headline: Woodsman, Don’t Spare That Tree
text: ON a sunny afternoon last week, a retired New York firefighter named Bruce Stuart sat on a tree stump overlooking a narrow creek that ran through Udalls Cove Park Preserve in Douglaston, Queens. A tall man with a graying mustache, Mr. Stuart listened as the birds chirped and the water murmured on its way toward Little Neck Bay to the north.

headline: Balcony? Not at These Intimate Listening Spots
text: WHEN it comes to describing places to hear music, here’s an adjective that is tossed around a lot: intimate.

headline: That Isn’t Lint on My Lapel, I’m an Officier
text: AT a recent book party high above Gramercy Park, Brian Gallagher, a young journalist, approached Robert Silvers, the longtime editor of The New York Review of Books. What, Mr. Gallagher asked, was that little red thread sewn onto Mr. Silvers’s suit lapel? “Legion of Honor,” Mr. Silvers answered, with a smile at once proud and slightly bashful. “It was for the paper,” he said, referring to his literary journal.

headline: Fearing for Many at Home, City’s Burmese Unite to Aid Cyclone Victims
text: Linda Wu said that whenever troubles in Myanmar make news in the United States, business spikes at the two Burmese restaurants she owns in Manhattan, with regular patrons coming by daily to check on her and the restaurants’ staff. And once the regulars check in, Ms. Wu said, most of them stay to eat.

headline: Kelly Edwards, Michael Irwin
text: Kelly Elizabeth Edwards, the daughter of Sandra L. Edwards of Madison, Conn., and James R. Edwards of Dallas, was married on Saturday evening to Michael Alan Irwin, the son of LuAnn Irwin and Lee Irwin of Sodus, N.Y. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard.

headline: Already, Obama and McCain Map Fall Strategies
text: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are already drawing up strategies for taking each other on in the general election, focusing on the same groups  including independent voters and Latinos  and about a dozen states where they think the contest is likely to be decided this fall, campaign aides said.

headline: The Trunk Is in Their Yard, the Branches Are in Yours
text: Q I own a home that abuts property, owned by a railroad company, that has trees that are growing over my property and dropping large branches. When I contacted the company, I was told it does not clear branches from trees that grow over other owners’ property, but I could do so at my own risk and cost.

headline: ‘The Red Leather Diary’
text: The Discovery

headline: Hamptons Poll: Take a Sip, Cast Your Vote
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Tiger Stadium Faces Partial Demolition Amid Opposition
text: DETROIT  After the Tigers played on opening day, a pickup truck full of guys drove across Woodward Avenue from Comerica Park on the near East Side to old Tiger Stadium on the near West Side, a mile or so away.

headline: When Health Insurance Is No Comfort
text: To the Editor:

headline: Up Front
text: No conservative writer was tougher on Richard Nixon than George F. Will, the longtime columnist for The Washington Post and Newsweek  particularly on the subject of “the 784-day Watergate debacle,” as he once termed it. “The Nixon White House ran amok as no other has done, and its abuses were uniquely lurid and sinister,” Will wrote on Aug. 8, 1974, the day Nixon announced he would resign from the presidency.

headline: Progress in Promoting Black Officers, but Police Department Faces Hurdles
text: The fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, a black man killed in a hail of 50 bullets on his wedding day, spurred widespread public anger and put the Police Department’s relationship with some black New Yorkers under a microscope.

headline: Jenny Slayton, Justin Green
text: Jenny Anna Slayton, the daughter of Margareta Slayton and Paul Slayton of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Justin Hays Green, the son of Susan Zises Green of New York. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York.

headline: Mike Tyson Film Takes a Swing at His Old Image
text: Henderson, Nev.

headline: A Reprieve for State Parks, but Not a Solution
text: Hopewell Township

headline: Letters: Clothing Optional
text: CLOTHING OPTIONAL

headline: Sarah Myler, Nicholas Ingrassia
text: Sarah Rachel Myler, a daughter of Carol and Colin Myler of London, was married on Saturday to Nicholas Andrew Ingrassia, the son of Vicki and Lawrence Ingrassia of Brooklyn. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.

headline: Spiritual Retreat
text: It was 7:30 p.m., minutes before the 12 diners schmoozing on the opposite side of the kitchen wall would sit down to an elaborate eight-course tasting menu. Chef Bryan Sikora, who was running water through pig intestines for chorizo sausages he’d fill the next day, was meditating absently on the undeveloped potential of hot dogs stuffed in gougères. His wife, Aimee Olexy, uncorked a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc and poured everyone in the kitchen a generous glass. So while most every other restaurant in the country edged toward meltdown getting ready for the onslaught of diners, the staff of Talula’s Table in Kennett Square, Pa.  about 40 miles southwest of Philadelphia  clinked together their handblown glasses and began service.

headline: Suffolk-Run Nursing Home Falls in Budget-Cutters’ Sights
text: YAPHANK

headline: Focused Food, Center Stage
text: THEATER SQUARE GRILL, the 10-year-old restaurant in the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, is impressive on many counts. But the most impressive may be its theatrical sense of pace.

headline: A Hurdle for TV: Wall Street Reality
text: The mortgage crisis hasn’t merely caused millions of home foreclosures, cost big Wall Street firms tens of billions of dollars and forced layoffs. It has also made it harder to find willing participants for “Wall Street Warriors,” a cable television show that documents the lives of traders, brokers, bankers and other financial professionals.

headline: Doubling Up for Shakespeare’s Twin-Laden ‘Comedy of Errors’
text: If one set of identical twins doesn’t generate enough mayhem for a comedy to take flight, the presence of two doppelgänger duos should ensure total bedlam. In his “Comedy of Errors,” Shakespeare not only borrowed twins from “Menaechmi” by Plautus, the play that was his principal source, but tightened the tangle by adding another pair, from “Amphitruo,” by the same author.

headline: Daria Natan and Robert Pahlavan
text: Daria Mia DeLancey Natan and Robert Bardia Pahlavan were married on Saturday evening at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia. The Rev. Alan Neale, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, led a ceremony that included Muslim and Jewish elements.

headline: Lexicographical Longing
text: When I was 19, my father gave me an Oxford English Dictionary, the 1971 compact edition with the 1987 supplement. Citations for every English word since the eighth century were crammed into three bulky volumes of minuscule print. I hallucinated before the speckled onion-skin pages until I discovered that the dictionary came with a magnifying glass.

headline: San Francisco: Yoshi's Jazz Club & Restaurant
text: Jazz and sushi seem at first an unusual combination, but in the San Francisco Bay area they are inextricably linked, thanks to Yoshi’s.

headline: Sadr City Bomb Squad: Looking for Trouble Before It Explodes
text: BAGHDAD  The bland job description is “route clearance,” but it is one of the most unglamorous and dangerous missions in Iraq. Creeping along the scarred streets of Sadr City, the soldiers search for roadside bombs around the clock, using bright spotlights at night that make them a big, bright target.

headline: Adele Morse, William Nevins
text: Adele Forbes Morse and William McCay Nevins were married in Pasadena, Calif., on Saturday at the home of Mary Lois Nevins, the bridegroom’s mother. The Rev. Valerie M. Webster, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Classical Music
text: Arizona

headline: Songwriter’s Open Mic: Something to Sing About
text: MAPLEWOOD

headline: Correction: The Coming of Age of Copenhagen’s Nordic Cuisine
text: A map with an article on May 4 about restaurants in Copenhagen labeled incorrectly a body of water near Nyhavn. It is Copenhagen Harbor, not the Malmo River. The label on the map is by the former dock for ferries to Malmo, Sweden; there is no Malmo River.

headline: Oil Prices Are Up and Politicians Are Angry. Yawn.
text: There is seemingly no more combustible mix than high oil prices and a hotly contested election. With gasoline closing in on $4 a gallon, Washington is awash in proposals to bring down prices  once more turning the energy debate into political football.

headline: Miya Kang and Justin Ko
text: Mi-Hyang Kang and Justin Ko were married on Saturday evening at Viansa Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Christopher M. Jackson, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: ‘The Story of a Marriage’
text: We think we know the ones we love.

headline: In New York, Parking Is Ever So Easy
text: SHOULD Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg be feeling glum over the death of congestion pricing, his plan to divert drivers onto public transit by imposing an $8 surcharge to motor into the heart of Manhattan, he ought to be cheered by the arrival of the Smart car from Europe.

headline: Sudan’s Army Beats Back Rebel Attack on Capital
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Darfurian rebels staged a bold attack on Saturday, advancing to within a few miles of the center of Sudan’s capital, Khartoum.

headline: Feeling Like a Rock Star
text: I’VE been driving my Smart Fortwo since the middle of last month and have been having a great time. It is, simply, a hoot to drive.

headline: ‘Mad Pride’ Fights a Stigma
text: IN the YouTube video, Liz Spikol is smiling and animated, the light glinting off her large hoop earrings. Deadpan, she holds up a diaper. It is not, she explains, a hygienic item for a giantess, but rather a prop to illustrate how much control people lose when they undergo electroconvulsive therapy, or ECT, as she did 12 years ago.

headline: Trajectories
text: TO JUDGE from the news out of NASA these days, you might think we are witnessing the last gasps of the space age. The agency has announced that it will phase out its aging fleet of space shuttles by the year 2010, and the next iteration of the space program, known as Constellation, isn’t likely to be sending people into orbit before 2015. Back in 2004, President Bush exhorted NASA to return humans to the moon (and then continue on to Mars), but precious little has been heard from the White House on the matter since. The American enthusiasm for space travel that accompanied the first footprints on the lunar surface seems less ardent with each year that separates us from that one small step.

headline: Under Analysis: The Psychology of Tudor’s Ballets
text: WHEN the choreographer Antony Tudor, whose centenary is being celebrated this year, moved to America in 1939, the moment could not have been more right. He was known as the psychological choreographer, and he arrived when psychology entered American popular culture. In 1938 Fred Astaire played Ginger Rogers’s psychoanalyst in “Carefree”; in 1942 Claude Rains steered Bette Davis back from a nervous breakdown in “Now, Voyager.” Later Martha Graham would become yet more famous for the Greek myths she turned into modern-dance psychodramas, but that phase  like Hitchcock’s (notably in “Spellbound,” 1945)  had not yet arrived.

headline: Getting Used to the Quirks
text: I don’t drive my Smart much. My office is only about a mile from home, but I still have to drive because the lack of sidewalks makes it dangerous to walk. My Smart, a red Cabriolet, is well-equipped and has been a pleasure to own.

headline: 24-Hour TV News
text: To the Editor:

headline: The New New World
text: Every 20 years or so, the end of America is nigh  ever since the 18th century when, in France, Comte de Buffon fingered the country as a den of degeneracy while Abbé Raynal slammed its cultural poverty: America had not yet produced “one good poet, one able mathematician, one man of genius.” In 1987, in his book “The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,” the Yale historian Paul Kennedy saw the United States on the road to perdition  this, four years before the suicide of the Soviet Union, which left America all alone in the penthouse of global power. Now, two decades on, it is the much-hyped “great power shift” toward Asia that will turn the United States into a has-been.

headline: Living a Charmed Life
text: SOME people say that what’s on television is not an accurate reflection of reality. But look at Joan Collins. She had her ingénue moments in the mid-1950s, yet it was not until 1981 that she truly became the Joan Collins we know, portraying Alexis Carrington Colby, etc., on “Dynasty.” It was this incarnation, brimming with fur hats, Nolan Miller gowns, leg-of-mutton sleeves and shoulder pads out to there, that resonates as one of the most potent of the ’80s.

headline: Earth to Young People: Help!
text: Environmental consciousness-raising is a big thing now in children’s books, and that’s good. But as a genre, it can be kind of a bummer, which may explain why it doesn’t bring in nearly the returns of, say, fantasy novels. DK Publishing’s “Earth Matters” is a perfect example of why.

headline: Change We Can Stomach
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Profit, Ego and Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Breeding for Speed, Ignoring Durability
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Hancocks have been raising racehorses for four generations and not too long ago, Arthur III kept to a rule he learned from his father, Bull Hancock Jr.: Never breed to a stallion with fewer than 25 career starts. That rule was good enough to produce the Kentucky Derby champions Gato Del Sol in 1982 and Sunday Silence in 1989.

headline: Brooklyn Churches Come and Go
text: EVIDENCE suggests that New Yorkers may be more religiously observant now than three decades ago. The number of churches, temples, mosques and other houses of worship  many of them in storefronts  jumped by 37 percent in Manhattan from 1980 to 2000, according to census data. In Brooklyn during the same period, the jump was a whopping 87 percent.

headline: What Could I Get for my House? Please, Don’t Ask
text: It can be so much fun to play the “What’s my home worth?” game, either with your friends and family or inside your own head.

headline: Murdoch Ends Bid to Buy Newsday
text: News Corporation, the global media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is withdrawing its bid to purchase Newsday.

headline: Speaking Loudly to Her New Canaan Peers
text: New Canaan

headline: Dying of Cancer, but Full of Life Lessons
text: Pittsburgh wide receiver Hines Ward arrived for this month’s Steelers minicamp with two books tucked in his duffel bag: the team’s playbook and a copy of “The Last Lecture,” co-written by Randy Pausch, who left his job as a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University last September.

headline: ‘The Second Plane’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Party Like It’s 2008
text: ANOTHER weekly do-or-die primary battle, another round of wildly predicted “game changers” that collapsed in the locker room.

headline: These Daredevils Don’t Dust the Crops. They Plant Them.
text: OLIVEHURST, Calif.  As rice farmers in Northern California plant their flooded fields over the next couple of weeks, most will not head for a tractor or a tiller or any kind of seeder.

headline: Do You Have That Portable in a Midsize?
text: THIRTY-SIX years ago, Alan Kay, a computer scientist, published a rough sketch of his Dynabook portable computer, establishing the ideal of ever more intimate personal computers.

headline: Memoirs of a Girl From the East Country (O.K., Queens)
text: IT is one of the most evocative images of Greenwich Village in the 1960s. An attractive young couple are walking down the middle of a snow-covered street. His head is down and tilted toward her. He’s wearing an artfully half-buttoned brown suede jacket, but his hands are stuffed in his jeans’ pockets against the cold. She is smiling, huddling against him. Shot in February 1963, the photo would come to epitomize the romantic youth culture of the time  its freedom and fragility, its rootlessness and sense of purpose.

headline: Letters: Remembering Ansel Adams
text: To the Editor: I read with delight your story about Ansel Adams and Yosemite National Park (“What Adams Saw Through His Lens,” April 27). I was privileged to work with Mr. Adams in the summer of 1982 as a professional environmentalist to assist him in protecting Big Sur, in California, from development.

headline: Ohio State Tops Cornell for Its First N.C.A.A. Victory
text: ITHACA, N.Y.  Anticipating a rematch with No. 1-ranked Duke, Cornell might have overlooked Ohio State.

headline: For Griffey, the Roads Not Taken
text: Any day now, perhaps this weekend at Shea Stadium, Ken Griffey Jr. will hit his 600th major league home run. It will have been a long time in coming. Griffey, when he was traded to the Cincinnati Reds in February 2000, had hit 398 homers, to that point the largest total ever for a player yet to reach his 30th birthday. (Alex Rodriguez has since broken his record.)

headline: A Buyer’s Guide to Inventions, in Plain English
text: INVENTORS and companies like to court each other. Inventors need companies to move their ideas forward, and companies need inventions to help their businesses grow. But suitors sometimes have trouble finding that perfect partner. Now a Web-based service under development, the USA National Innovation Marketplace, offers a new tool intended to help with the matchmaking.

headline: A Welcome Into Artists’ Creative Spaces
text: The Studio: An Alternative Space for Contemporary Art, in Armonk, closed its gallery last November, but the 10-year-old nonprofit group is still living up to its name by providing opportunities to view contemporary art.

headline: Baseball Legends, and a Beloved Song
text: “ ‘Anatomy of Baseball’ is no medical book  if it was, I’m certain I wouldn’t have read it,” Yogi Berra writes in the foreword.

headline: Bring Us Apart
text: Rick Perlstein’s sprawling, rollicking book arrives hard on the heels of a contest of empathy-exhibitionism in which the two Democratic presidential candidates competed to see who could more ardently adore churchgoing, gun-owning, not-at-all-bitter working-class Pennsylvanians. Perlstein’s readers will learn why this happened. He shrewdly quotes a commentator’s assessment of Richard Nixon’s 1952 Checkers speech with its maudlin reference to his wife’s “Republican cloth coat”: “Dick Nixon has suddenly placed the burden of old-style Republican aloofness on the Democrats.”

headline: As Foreclosures Rise, Towns Take on Storage Role

text: Laura Catherine Campbell, the daughter of Leslie Campbell of Arnold, Md., and Michael Campbell of Potomac, Md., was married on Saturday to Dr. Abe Shahim, the son of Shahla Shahim and Dr. Houshang Shahim of White Plains. Debby Altomonte, a Spiritual Science minister, officiated at the Oaks, an inn in Royal Oak, Md., and Payman Amiri led them in a Persian cultural ceremony.

headline: ‘Mermaid’ Actor Breaks Wrists in Fall From High Over Stage
text: An actor in the Broadway show “The Little Mermaid” fell through a trap door on the deck of a suspended boat and onto the stage just before the start of the Saturday matinee performance, a spokesman for the production company said.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the eroding boundary between Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway productions misidentified the actress pictured with Tobias Segal and Julie White in “From Up Here.” She is Aya Cash, who portrays the sister of Mr. Segal’s character, not Jenni Barber, who portrays his student mentor.

headline: Militants Kill Israeli; Israelis Kill 5 Hamas Policemen
text: JERUSALEM  Five Hamas police officers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on two police posts in southern Gaza late Friday night, Palestinian officials said Saturday. The strikes occurred hours after an Israeli civilian was killed by a mortar round fired into Israel by militants from Gaza.

headline: Youth Lacrosse Program Places Premium on Sportsmanship
text: FRENCHTOWN

headline: In Mali, S.U.V.'s and Camels Deliver the Fans
text: The Festival au Desert, held each January in the remote African city of Essakane, Mali, is a time-shifting experience. This year, as it began to come to life, Tuareg men in billowing clothes and brightly colored turbans ducked in and out of leather and canvas tents. Camels strolled into camp by the hundreds and folded their ungainly legs as vendors prepared their wares for an invasion of foreign travelers.

headline: A Cruise for Jazz Fans With a Soft Side
text: Smooth-jazz enthusiasts who like cruises might want to check out Bob Jamieson’s Smooth Music Cruise series (www.smoothmusiccruise.com). Mr. Jamieson, a former music executive (Sony, CBS, BMG) has assembled a collection of Grammy-, Tony- and Emmy Award-winning musicians to perform night and day on a Caribbean cruise aboard the 1,778-passenger Century, a Celebrity Cruises ship.

headline: Losing a Home, Then Losing All Out of Storage
text: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.  The foreclosure crisis is hitting yet another American locale: the self-storage center.

headline: Because It’s Good for You
text: While a book can lead us to love reading  the one that did it for me was “Little Runner of the Longhouse,” written by Betty Baker and illustrated by Arnold Lobel  can it do so on purpose? Tyrone Brown, “professional student and class clown,” likes a lot about school: math, science, recess. But reading bugs him: “It’s not that I despise books; I just don’t prefer them. I like playing freeze tag with my friends and catch with my dad and helping my mom pull the pesky weeds from the front yard. These things are real.”

headline: Worth the Climb
text: LIVING in a top-floor walk-up in New York City is a mixed blessing.

headline: With Ryan Church
text: The last five months have turned Ryan Church’s life upside down. Church joined the Mets in a November trade with the Washington Nationals. He sustained a concussion in spring training and, two weeks later, became a father for the first time. His wife, Tina, gave birth to their son, Mason Alexander, on March 14. Church, a 29-year-old outfielder, entered Saturday hitting a team-best .328 with 6 homers, 24 runs batted in and 4 outfield assists.

headline: Styron’s Choices
text: There used to be a time when writers, purely on the basis of the books they had published, were invited to eat dinner with presidents. By his own estimation, the novelist William Styron, who died in 2006, was one of the last of his kind to enjoy an honor more likely, “since John F. Kennedy at least,” to be bestowed upon “rock stars, stand-up comedians and golf champions.” “Havanas in Camelot,” his charming collection of essays, recounts two such dinners, one with Kennedy, whose fondness for cigars both impressed and intimidated the cigarette-addicted Styron, and the other with François Mitterand, after which Styron, Arthur Miller, Carlos Fuentes, Elie Wiesel and the Greek politician Andreas Papandreou had to be rescued from an exuberant crowd of Mitterand’s admirers by a resplendent Melina Mercouri: “A heady and thrilling moment indeed, even when  as Fuentes pointed out  the crowd surely thought that the five gentlemen in their raincoats were Mercouri’s bodyguards.”

headline: Selling Isn’t Poetry
text: THERE was one last full-floor condominium lingering on the market in a meticulously restored and expensive prewar Park Avenue building at East 75th Street. So Elliott P. Joseph, the project’s developer, jumped on what he thought was the perfect sales sweetener: two free Lexus hybrids with the purchase.

headline: 32 Gas Stations in Report Show Spillage Signs
text: An article on April 27 about the presence of methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., in soil beneath some gas stations on Long Island misidentified the agency whose study reported the contamination. It was the New York State Department of Conservation, not the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.

headline: The Uneven Playing Field
text: BY THE TIME JANELLE PIERSON SPRINTED ONTO THE FIELD for the start of the Florida high-school soccer playoffs in January, she had competed in hundreds of games since joining her first team at 5. She played soccer year-round  often for two teams at a time when the seasons of her school and club teams overlapped. Like many American children deeply involved in sports, Janelle, a high-school senior, had traveled like a professional athlete since her early teens, routinely flying to out-of-state tournaments. She had given up other sports long ago, quitting basketball and tennis by age 10. There was no time for any of that, and as she put it: “Even if you wanted to keep playing other sports, people would question you. They’d be, like, ‘Why do you want to do that?’ ”

Carmelo Tosado Moya, a minister of the Methodist Church of Puerto Rico, officiated, and the Rev. Jimmy Casellas, a Roman Catholic friar, participated in the ceremony.

headline: Steeped in History, With a Feel of the Brand New

headline: That Must Be Bob. I Hear His New Hip Squeaking.
text: The first time John L. Johnson’s artificial hip squeaked, he was bending down to pick up a pine cone in his yard in Thomasville, Ga. Mr. Johnson looked up, expecting to find an animal nearby.

headline: Letters: Triple-A Failure
text: Congratulations to Roger Lowenstein (April 27) for writing what is perhaps the definitive explanation of the underlying mechanics of the credit-rating agencies as they relate to the causes of the mortgage meltdown. This opens the door to regular folks understanding this mess, and perhaps now we can put pressure on Congress to act forcefully to make necessary regulatory changes.

headline: But the Songs Remain the Same
text: “DO you play piano?” My mother’s question is timed with the precision of a Swiss watch  always after I have slipped out of the left sleeve of my coat, but not quite before breaking free of the right one.

headline: Zoe Segal-Reichlin and Daniel Garodnick
text: Zoe L. Segal-Reichlin, a lawyer, and Daniel R. Garodnick, a New York City councilman, were married Saturday afternoon in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. Judge Colleen McMahon of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Atlantica, a catering business at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel and Marina.

headline: The Dollar: Shrinkable but (So Far) Unsinkable
text: If the United States were any other country, these would surely be days of panic and austerity in Washington. With debts spiraling higher, a trade deficit exceeding $700 billion a year, and its currency plunging for years, the government would be forced to cut spending and jack up interest rates in a frantic bid to attract investment.

headline: Racing Industry Is Stuck in Perpetual Post Time
text: Thoroughbred racing has been too slow to change.

headline: Gut-Wrenching
text: 1. Symptoms

headline: Letters: Young Gay Rites
text: It strikes me that one of the obvious reasons straight people in their 20s get married is because that’s when you pretty much need to start having kids. Gay people are spared that necessity: we get to choose so very much more from the smorgasbord. The chirpy, bright tone of nearly all the 20-somethings, married or affianced, in your article (April 27) was a little scary to me: they sound supercharged  either on too much Starbucks coffee or on some notion that “true love” is something you can trap forever in a legislative cage of marriage. I kept wanting them to take long, long breaths and not feel they had to be “couples” in some institutionalized way so very, very quickly.

headline: How I Met My Mother
text: For much of our life together, my mother and I hated each other. The way I saw it, I spent most of my childhood fighting with her  or trying to get away from her bitterness, her unhappiness and her endless smoking. As a teenager, I learned how to defend myself with words that were designed to hurt and could never be taken back. In return, she vowed that one day I would have a daughter who would feel the way about me that I felt about her.

headline: Grueling Series Put the Stars on Their Heels
text: The Dallas Stars’ path toward the Stanley Cup has wound through the toughest teams in the league, and it may be taking its toll.

Dillon of Hawthorne Woods, Ill. The Rev. Bojan Jancic, a pastor of Revival Ministries International, officiated in a nondenominational service at the Bourne Mansion in Oakdale, N.Y.

headline: Creation of a Bygone Era, Soon to Be Demolished
text: The ramshackle wooden tower has loomed over Avenue B for more than 20 years, drawing curiosity and a range of reviews from tourists and neighbors. Some have declared the colorful structure a masterpiece, and have admired the effort that went into assembling it. Others have complained that it takes up valuable space or just looks weird.

headline: Can the Sponsor Vote for His Ex-Wife?

headline: Matching Newcomer to College, While Both Pay
text: ATHENS, Ohio  When Xiaoxi Li, a 20-year-old from Beijing, decided she should go to college in the United States, she applied only to Ohio University  not that she knew much about it.

headline: Leisure’s Starring Role in a Complete Life
text: LEISURE is not a topic that typically emerges as a workplace concern. But in fact it has a direct effect on how we handle and view our working life, according to Alison Link, who has done research on leisure issues and is a consultant for individuals and organizations through her firm, the Leisure Link (www.theleisurelinkconsulting.com).

headline: As Bush Term Wanes, Mideast Peace Appears as Elusive as Ever
text: WASHINGTON  The 2008 race for the White House is casting a long shadow over President Bush. So long, in fact, that it may extend all the way to the Middle East.

headline: Spring in a Cold Climate
text: THE only way to know when the residential real estate market has “hit bottom” will be with a look in the rear-view mirror, according to Jeffrey G. Otteau, the New Jersey-based real estate analyst.

headline: Cracking the Comics Code
text: Tricking children into reading has a long and mostly honorable history. Key to the con are coupling pictures, which are fascinating and adorable, with letters and words, which are alphanumeric. This duplicity dates back at least to the 17th century and Comenius’ “Orbis Sensualium Pictus,” a primer with woodcuts designed to hoodwink the young into thinking Latin was going to be a treat. Advances in technology and desperation have added color to the ruse, along with pop-ups and pull-tabs, scent strips, sound chips and touch-and-feelies, none of which approach the sensual pleasures of Lego Star Wars or Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock.

headline: Special Effects From the Real World
text: IN this era of digital special effects, we’ve become accustomed to the idea that by manipulating pixels on a computer screen, filmmakers can show us practically anything in a more or less convincing manner.

headline: Stockholm Is More Than Abba's Town
text: STARING out at the azure waters of Saltsjon Bay from a hilltop in the Sodermalm district of Stockholmisland, I stopped for a moment to take in the last glints of a long, Nordic sunset. Behind me, the neighborhood’s clubs and concert venues were starting to get busy. Behind the sound of crowds and shouted hellos came a line of familiar music, filling the crisp air: “Don’t come back to Stockholm.”

headline: Nuala O’Faolain, 68, Irish Memoirist, Is Dead
text: Nuala O’Faolain, an Irish journalist who mined a rich vein of longing and childhood suffering in two midlife memoirs and an acclaimed first novel, “My Dream of You,” died on Friday night in Dublin. She was 68 and lived in Barrtra, County Clare, Ireland, and Manhattan.

headline: Stylish School Expansion
text: WITH its ornate moldings and mahogany paneling, and its links to New York’s high society and old money, the brick and limestone mansion at 17 East 90th Street near Fifth Avenue seemed a perfect refuge for another wealthy family in the heart of the city.

text: IN fits and starts, blue-chip stocks have been climbing higher since mid-March. But many market watchers aren’t convinced that the worst of this market storm, which began in October, is behind us.

headline: Big Rescues Can Work. Just Ask New York.
text: AS the great American credit crash continues to reverberate, we still have nothing that resembles an intelligent and comprehensive plan for dealing with mass foreclosures and the economic consequences associated with the debacle.

text: WASHINGTON — So, now that it might finally be over (or maybe close to it, possibly, perhaps), does Senator Barack Obama come out a bloody mess, or a battle-tested warrior?

headline: Bodies Flow Into Hard-Hit Area of Myanmar
text: THANAP PIN SATE, Myanmar  The bodies come and go with the tides. They wash up onto the riverbanks or float grotesquely downstream, almost always face down. They are all but ignored by the living.

headline: Voices in Concert
text: EXCEPT for five years when I lived in Arizona, from ages 9 to 14, I grew up in Los Angeles. My family lived in a small apartment off Wilshire Boulevard and I went to Beverly Hills High School. There were a lot of children of famous people. Rob Reiner was in the class behind me. Albert Brooks played on the football team with me.

headline: Official Chosen by McCain to Run Convention Resigns
text: The public relations executive whom Senator John McCain’s campaign had chosen to run the Republican National Convention this summer resigned his post on Saturday after a magazine reported that his firm had lobbied for the military junta that runs Myanmar.

headline: Gen. Vang Pao’s Last War
text: The wars of the 20th century destroyed many millions of people who once lived in the hillsides and valleys of remote rural worlds. Few were hit as hard as the Hmong, an ancient tribe whose members hewed out rough lives upcountry in Laos, west of Vietnam. Half a century ago, Laos became a cockpit of the cold war. The Hmong, led by a charismatic soldier named Vang Pao, sided with the United States in the fight against Communism in Southeast Asia. They lost everything  their land, their way of life, their country.

headline: Their Place in the Sun, and on the Court

headline: Not Exactly the Wild West
text: THE Landmarks Preservation Commission is reviewing a proposal from the local chapter of the Victorian Society in America to include the west side of West Broadway in the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District, and it would seem that the east side of that avenue  protected by the designation since 1973  would provide an instructive architectural contrast.

headline: Alexandra Snyder, Elliot Charen
text: Alexandra Elizabeth Snyder and Dr. Elliot Michael Charen were married on Saturday evening at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich officiated.

headline: A 16-Year Tour Veteran Takes an Unlikely Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The Players Championship demolition derby continued Saturday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, with the contestants in the $9.5 million tournament spinning out, hitting spectators and marshals with tee shots, running into railroad ties, and littering the landscape with bogeys, double bogeys and other unmentionables.

headline: Danna Drori, Benjamin Strauss
text: Danna Drori and Benjamin Henry Strauss are to be married on Sunday afternoon at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Cantor Angela Warnick Buchdahl is to officiate.

headline: Like Rainfall, Restored Map Trickles Home
text: Seventy years after it was booted out of the World’s Fair and 60 years after it was last seen by the public, a gorgeously sculptural relief map of the New York City watershed has finally reached its intended destination: the New York City Building, now the Queens Museum of Art, in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

headline: Ready for Its Hollywood Close-Up
text: IF Smart USA, distributor of the Smart microcar, could get every person who shouted, whooped, ran into the street, stopped traffic and corralled me for a chat to actually buy a Fortwo like the one I drove around Los Angeles, Daimler’s factory in France would have to run 24/7.

headline: Foreign Exchanges
text: In responding to readers’ questions, I often discuss why a proposed act is wrong. But it is also incumbent on me to suggest more ethical alternatives. Below, I revisit a few recent answers in which I failed to propose a better course of action when one was available  as many of you pointed out, and quite rightly.

headline: Vendler’s Yeats
text: The critic is the only artist who depends entirely upon another art form, which means that part of his job is to determine the nature of that relationship. Should he be an advocate? A policeman? A curator? A hanging judge? A mostly loyal but occasionally snippy personal assistant? The decision is an unconscious one, perhaps, but once it’s made, the critic’s writing will be colored by his chosen role in the same way that our voices carry the accents of our birthplaces.

headline: Killing Deer in New Jersey

headline: Straightening Out the Northeast Corridor
text: FOR many train riders, the concrete ties that keep the rails in place are about as noteworthy as the electrical power lines above the train.

headline: Letters: Questions for Ted Sorensen
text: Journalism at its best: Deborah Solomon’s interview of Ted Sorensen covers so much in one page (April 27). His 11 years with J.F.K; his forthcoming memoir; the so-called poet of Camelot asking not about “ask not;” the Cuban missile crisis versus World War I; Bill-Hillary and Barack; Ted’s unsuccessful run for the U.S. Senate; his religion and his own obit (many years in the future, one hopes).

headline: Can a Bargain Rent Have Staying Power?
text: FOR landlords and some tenants in rent-stabilized buildings, few issues are more important than “preferential rent”  rent that is lower than the legal regulated rent registered with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

headline: Alison Franklin, Shane Milam
text: Alison Beth Franklin and Shane McGuire Milam, lawyers, were married on Saturday evening in Columbia, Mo. Michael Heath, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Firestone Baars Chapel at Stephens College.

headline: A Deadly Day on the Top of the World
text: STORIES of the catastrophic ascent of Mount Everest on May 10, 1996, which claimed the lives of five climbers, including two top guides, began circulating even before some of those caught on the mountain had returned home.

headline: Sadrists and Iraqi Government Reach Truce Deal
text: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government and leaders of the movement of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr agreed Saturday to a truce, brokered with help from Iran, that would end more than a month of bloody fighting in the vast, crowded Sadr City section of Baghdad.

headline: Shakespeare in England, in Luxury
text: Here’s a luxurious  and cultured  outing if you happen to be in England on July 9. Board one of two Orient-Express Trains  the British Pullman in London or the Northern Belle in Birmingham, Coventry or Milton Keynes  start the voyage off with a Bellini, and then watch the countryside roll by while having brunch.

headline: Taking a Chance on a Second Child
text: HARRISON

headline: Correction: What Adams Saw Through His Lens
text: An article and a map on April 27 about Ansel Adams’s photographs of Yosemite National Park gave an incorrect location of Wawona Tunnel. It is on the western end of Yosemite Valley, in the southern section of the park, not on the park’s southern edge.

headline: If N.F.L. Doesn’t Call, the Army Will
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  No matter how he performed at the Giants’ rookie camp this weekend, Owen Tolson will be issued a uniform. His name will be stitched on it, and he will be assigned a number.

headline: To Smell the Roses, Take the Bus
text: A REGULAR visitor who drove on May 1 to Wave Hill, the pristine, 28-acre public garden in Riverdale, to spend a few hours sitting on a bench and admiring the vivid tulips and the majestic copper beech tree, would have been in for a surprise.

headline: All in Favor, Say ‘Word’
text: IN 1976, a 16-year-old boy from Washington Heights heard a radio announcement from Percy Sutton, then Manhattan borough president, urging that people of all ages be represented on the city’s community boards. When the boy’s mother, a City Council member who represented the neighborhood, heard of her son’s plan to answer the call, she told him, “No way,” setting the stage for a simultaneous act of civic precociousness and teenage rebellion.

headline: Rough Justice
text: You can usually count on three things in a Louise Erdrich novel. One: the tale will be told by many characters, each with his or her own chapter or three. Erdrich established this pass-the-talking-stick style in early novels like “Love Medicine” and “The Beet Queen.” It’s served her well, and she’s staying with it. Two: although these narrators differ in age, perspective, gender and disposition, they will share an uncannily similar voice, hushed and deeply observant. Erdrich’s characters have rich inner lives, expressed in language that’s often achingly poetic but can sometimes resemble a John Mayer lyric. (“I was everything the mountain knew.”) This is Erdrich, take her or leave her. Third: there will be Indians, there will be white folks, and there will be tension between the two.

headline: Jill Furman and Richard Willis
text: JILL FURMAN, a producer of the Broadway musical “In the Heights,” believes in big dreams and bright lights. So when it came to love she refused to settle for less.

headline: A ‘Farmhouse’ Near the L Train
text: KERMIT WESTERGAARD grew up on the Upper East Side, far from hammers and paintbrushes. Yet early on, he was seized by the idea of renovating a historic house for himself. Last year, he got the chance when he and his wife, Azadeh, bought a 1908 row house in Ridgewood, Queens, for $592,000, and turned it into their comfortable fantasy of a simple upstate farmhouse.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Inside the List
text: GOODBYE, HARRY: It had to happen sometime - and, lo, an era has ended. After a 10-year run, and less than a year after the seventh and final book in J. K. Rowling’s series was published, the Harry Potter books have fallen off The Times’s best-seller list.

headline: The Fog of Love
text: We think we know the ones we love, and though we should not be surprised to find that we don’t, it is heartbreak nonetheless. It is the hardest kind of knowledge, not only about another but about ourselves. To see our lives as fiction we have written and believed.” So observes plain, devoted, innocent Pearlie Cook, the narrator of Andrew Sean Greer’s wondrously unsettling new novel and the wife of Holland Cook, a man whose physical beauty creates a force field of strong passions all around him.

headline: Something Wild
text: It’s funny when, as a relatively well-adjusted woman in your 40s, you read two fine novels about intelligent girls who are curious and daring and good-hearted. There is a wrench in your belly  of recognition, or nostalgia. It’s appreciation for careful attention paid to a short, mostly underrated phase in the life of women. Suddenly the body armor you’ve built and polished feels leaden and even cowardly. What seem bold are the characters of Jacqueline Woodson and Pat Murphy, who in their new novels render the knotty friendships of girls with gravity, whimsy, intimacy and melodrama.

headline: Woman Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Companion
text: A Queens woman was arrested and charged with murder on Saturday after the police said she stabbed her live-in companion to death with a steak knife at their home near Rockaway Beach.

headline: In a Fantasy Realm With Joys and Disappointments
text: If, as one of Spain’s classic plays declares, life is a dream, lovers and emigrants must be particularly alive. Being in love is as close as we come to the dream state while awake; and who would ever leave the comfort, or even the discomfort, of home without the insistent prodding of a dream?

headline: Parking Space as Living Space?
text: GENERATING both praise and criticism in a county with plenty of expensive housing but not much of the budget-friendly kind, a Department of Planning report urges towns and villages here to use land in existing office parks as sites for new housing, some of it for moderate-income families.

headline: Letters: Drawing Lessons
text: Until we can agree on standard and objective criteria of what arts in education is, we will never have proof that the arts can build better learners (Ann Hulbert, April 27). That’s a pity. Art education must be described and approached as a discipline like all others.

headline: Belt-Tightening Can Bring Change, or More Misery

headline: Turkish Traffic Stopper
text: Tava in Port Washington is a traffic-stopper. The Turkish restaurant’s snappy red awning stands out against its coal-black walls. There’s even a tree out front wrapped in strings of red mini-lights.

headline: Downtown-Uptown Girl
text: BEFORE heading out of the four-story West Village town house she shares with her husband, the musician Billy Joel, Katie Lee Joel bade goodbye to her makeup artist and one of her two pugs. “Be a good watchdog,” she called to the dog, which was slumbering on a silk-covered armchair in the lavish living room.

headline: A Fixed-Fee Refinancing
text: FOR many borrowers, adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARMs, are too risky, even though the interest on such loans is usually fixed for 5 or 7 years at a rate lower than that offered on 30-year fixed mortgages.

headline: Rockin’ the Casbah
text: FROM his perch on a rooftop terrace near the crenelated western ramparts of the walled city, a visitor from England watched the sun set in spectacular display over the Atlantic Ocean. As it disappeared on the cloudless horizon, the sun’s rays cast a golden glow on a rising crescent moon decorated on the eve of the summer solstice by a silvery alignment of planets and stars.

headline: You Can’t Make This Stuff Up, or Can You?
text: FOR a long time, I spent my days as an independent producer by morning, a law professor by afternoon and a dog fancier by night. I would hatch ideas for television shows and movies, take them to studios and pitch them and, once in a while, some kindly soul would buy one and, even more rarely, one would be made.

headline: Good Times at Sotheby’s

headline: State Agrees on Protocol for Governor and Father
text: ALBANY  The state Ethics Commission has advised Basil A. Paterson, a labor lawyer and the father of the governor, to avoid conflicts of interest by not arranging meetings between his clients and his son or accepting business with the state.

headline: After Hard Pasts, a Sanctuary by the Sea
text: BRIGHTON BEACH conjures plastic swans, women in tight pants, men in small bathing suits, and deep-fried dough with surprise morsels inside. The neighborhood is defined by contradictions: deep shadows and bright light.

headline: ‘Peace’
text: They went on anyway, putting one foot in front of the other, holding their carbines barrel down to keep the water out, trying, in their misery and confusion — and their exhaustion — to remain watchful. This was the fourth straight day of rain — a windless, freezing downpour without any slight variation of itself. Rivulets of ice formed in the muck of the road and made the walking treacherous. The muscles of their legs burned and shuddered, and none of them could get enough air. Robert Marson thought about how they were all witnesses. And nobody could look anybody in the eye. They kept on, and were punished as they went. Ice glazed their helmets, stuck to the collars of their field jackets, and the rain got in everywhere, soaking them to the bone. They were somewhere near Cassino, but it was hard to believe it was even Italy anymore. They had stumbled blind into some province of drenching cold, a berg of death. Everything was in question now.

headline: In Animal Shelters, Reminders of the Economy
text: ON Valentine’s Day, a loved one named Riley found himself being led back into the same noisy institutional building where he was also known as No. 08-447. The floppy-eared 2 ½-year-old Rottweiler-Doberman pinscher mix had been adopted as a puppy a year earlier from the Stamford Animal Care and Control municipal shelter.

The request was denied because the league believed flying in relative comfort would give the Red Bulls a competitive advantage. Such is life in the single-entity Major League Soccer, where equality and mediocrity often share the same toothbrush.

Fortunately for Senna, though, only his car suffered. And he said goodbye to the points he was likely to score in the race, as he could not rejoin.

headline: Big Brown Showed Me
text: I have never really given much thought about state nicknames. The Garden State? Every state has gardens. The Sunshine State? What state doesn’t have sunshine? The Beaver State? I assume Theodore Cleaver was just too long. I hail from the Show Me state. Say what you want, but you have to show me. We are so stubborn that the state animal is a mule. What a majestic beast; goats and skunks must have been taken.

headline: Wally Backman and ‘Playing for Peanuts’

In fact War Pass’s deal was complete before he turned 3. These deals will more than likely mean we won’t see these young stars beyond their 3-year-old career.

headline: The Trunk Is in Their Yard, the Branches Are in Yours

When I contacted the company, I was told it does not clear branches from trees that grow over other owners’ property, but I could do so at my own risk and cost.

headline: Can a Co-op Sponsor Vote for His Ex-Wife in Board Elections?

headline: Cheap Thrills
text: I recently spent four days recording at the Wilco Loft — a gesture, most kind, extended to me by Jeff Tweedy, et al. The Loft is in my neighborhood in Chicago and has been the locus for Wilco’s recording and vintage gear collecting over the last decade. They have a cozy yet massive space with a great MCI sound board and tape machine, plus any guitar, bass, obscure amp or piece of percussion you could imagine (in perfect operating order). With Neal Jensen, our live sound engineer, behind the board, Mark Greenberg handling the digital realm, and Wilco’s loft manager Jason Tobias hosting, I brought Martin Dosh down to play drums on the tracks we recorded in Nashville and Jeremy Ylvisaker to play some bass. We also tracked the final two songs as a band. This was incredibly challenging. It should be simple, right? Put three musicians in a room, put up some microphones and press “record.”
