TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won the most Andys, 18, followed by BBDO Worldwide, also part of Omnicom, with 14, and Leo Burnett, part of the Publicis Groupe, with 10. The Richard T. headline: Little Pieces of Los Angeles, Done His Way

Everybody watched, everybody blamed him. Then it was over. Then he was gone.

headline: DMX Is Arrested

The arrest was his second of the week. On Tuesday state police arrested DMX, left, whose real name is Earl Simmons, for driving as fast as 114 miles an hour on a freeway. His lawyer in New York, Murray Richman, expressed doubt that the animal cruelty charges  relating to possible abuse of pit bulls  could be sustained.

headline: ‘Iron Man’ Shows Muscle
text: “Iron Man” (Paramount) extended its run as the No. 1 box-office attraction by pulling in $50.5 million over the weekend at movie theaters in North America to enlarge its two-week haul to $177.1 million, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported on Sunday. In the No. 2 spot, “Speed Racer” (Warner Brothers), starring Emile Hirsch and Christina Ricci  and based on the 1960s-era cartoon, drew $20.2 million in its debut. That was only $210,000 more than the gross of another newcomer, the uncelebrated comedy “What Happens in Vegas” (Fox), with Ashton Kutcher and Cameron Diaz. Fourth place and $7.6 million went to the romantic comedy “Made of Honor” (Columbia) in its second week. Another comedy, “Baby Mama” (Universal), finished fifth with $5.7 million in its third week.

headline: Snapping Out of a Slump, Beltrán Is Starting to Click

Mr. Tunick said on his Web site, spencertunick.com, that the “ephemeral installation” was “devised to capture and combine the spirit of sports, the grand sweeping waves of stadium architecture and the abstract relation of the human form to modern structures.”

headline: Rescuers Search Wreckage After at Least 23 Are Killed in Storms
text: Emergency crews searched through wreckage on Sunday from violent storms that left a path of destruction from the Midwest to the South and killed more than 20 people in Missouri, Oklahoma and Georgia.

headline: Little League Mother’s Slap Still Stings in a New Jersey Town
text: TENAFLY, N.J.  One June day at a baseball field in this leafy Bergen County borough, one Little League mom slapped another in the face.

headline: Tilt to West Is Seen in Elections in Serbia
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  A pro-Western party declared victory on Sunday night in closely contested parliamentary elections that were widely viewed as a referendum on whether Serbia would turn toward the West or revert to the nationalism and isolation of the Slobodan Milosevic years.

headline: Sudan Breaks Off Ties With Chad After Attack
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Sudan broke off diplomatic relations with Chad on Sunday, accusing its neighbor of backing a rebel force that nearly penetrated the capital on Saturday.

headline: Rescue Crews Search for Survivors After Storms Kill 23 in Three States
text: Emergency crews searched through wreckage on Sunday from violent storms that killed at least 23 people in Missouri, Oklahoma and Georgia.

headline: New Hub for Music: Practice, Practice
text: The Orchestra of St. Luke’s intends to buy half of a building in Clinton to create a permanent home for itself as well as rehearsal space for a dog’s breakfast of local orchestras. If the plan is realized, it could represent a major boon for New York’s classical music scene.

headline: State Programs Add Safety Net for the Poorest
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  For years, state welfare offices like the one alongside Interstate 30 have drawn the unemployed. But these days, the red-brick building here is also attracting poor, working parents with an unexpected offer: $204 a month in cash.

headline: A Knock in the Night in Phoenix
text: On Oct. 18, Jim Larkin and his wife, Molly, were in bed in their home outside Phoenix when a group of men in unmarked cars pulled up and began knocking on the door and shining flashlights in the house, saying, “You know what we want.”

headline: Academic Overtures
text: The folk singer Pete Seeger,  the musician and songwriter Billy Joel and the opera star Susan Graham are to receive honorary degrees of doctor of musical arts when the Manhattan School of Music holds its 82nd commencement ceremony on Friday at Riverside Church in Manhattan. ... Nearly 25 years after Vanessa Williams dropped out of Syracuse University to become the first black Miss America, she received her bachelor of arts degree on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Williams, 45, a Tony Award nominee and a star of “Ugly Betty” on ABC, also delivered the convocation address to graduates of the university’s College of Visual and Performing Arts.

headline: Israel at 60: A Time for Reflection
text: To the Editor:

headline: Footnotes
text: For the World Science Festival, at sites around New York City from May 28 to June 1, Alan Alda has written a play. “Dear Albert,” based on letters written by Albert Einstein, his wife and his friends, will star Anthony LaPaglia. Dan Sullivan will direct the work, which will play on June 1 at the Miller Theater at Columbia University. ... The run of “The Sound and the Fury” has been extended through June 1 at the New York Theater Workshop. ... On July 13 Nathan Lane is scheduled to bow out of David Mamet’s “November” at the Barrymore Theater. ... The Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Tracy Letts, “August: Osage County,” at the Music Box Theater, has recouped its initial $2.56 million investment, the producers announced. ... The Salzburg Marionette Theater in Austria has brought home “The Sound of Music.” After performing the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical on a United States tour, it was presented for the first time on Friday in Salzburg, the Austrian city that was, in part, its setting. The show will be performed three times a week in the company’s Baroque residence before a world tour. ... Mark Wing-Davey, the British actor, director and teacher, has been named chairman of the graduate acting program at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. Mr. Wing-Davey, who will also hold the title of arts professor, will take up his posts on Sept. 1.

headline: A Kosher Soup Kitchen Offers a Dignified Place to Eat, and Steak for One Day
text: The poor and hungry people at the Masbia soup kitchen in Borough Park hardly fit a bums-and-bag ladies stereotype.

headline: Art of Recital, From Serious to Playful
text: Few vocalists approach the song recital with as much thought and inspiration as the soprano Felicity Lott; few pianists accompany with as much insight and sympathy as the pianist Graham Johnson. Encounter them together, as an adoring Zankel Hall audience did on Saturday night, and you come away with renewed admiration for the rich international song repertory as well as an appreciation for the effort that goes into constructing an enticing program.

headline: Nobel Regrets for Doris Lessing
text: Doris Lessing, the 2007 Nobel prize winner in literature, told the BBC that receiving the prize was “a bloody disaster” that brought so much attention from the news media that writing a full-length novel was next to impossible. “All I do is give interviews and spend time being photographed,” Ms. Lessing, 88, complained in a radio broadcast on Sunday. Discussing her writing, she said: “It has stopped; I don’t have any energy anymore. This is why I keep telling anyone younger than me, don’t imagine you’ll have it forever. Use it while you’ve got it, because it’ll go; it’s sliding away like water down a plug hole.”

headline: There’s a New Thane in Town, a New Lady, Too
text: The director Adrian Noble’s bleak and boldly updated production of Verdi’s “Macbeth” made a strong impression when it was unveiled at the Metropolitan Opera in October. The production returned to the Met on Friday night with new singers in the four main roles, and as often happens, the mood and impact of the overall staging seemed to change.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the conviction of a drifter on charges of stalking the actress Uma Thurman misspelled the given name of her spokesman in some editions. He is Beau Benton, not Bo.

headline: The Jewish State at 60
text: This week marks the 60th anniversary of the founding of the state of Israel. There have already been many birthday greetings, some heartfelt, some perfunctory, along with numerous reflections on the meaning of the occasion, some profound, some commonplace. For me, however, a discordant voice broke through.

headline: As Rivals Rest on Mother’s Day, Clinton Pushes On
text: GRAFTON, W.Va.  On Mother’s Day, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was not served breakfast in bed. She did not go to a fancy lunch, or get to be queen for a day.

headline: Venezuela’s President Scorned by Bitter Political Foe: His Ex-Wife
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez is faced with problems like rising inflation, a diplomatic crisis with neighboring Colombia and defections of officials from his Socialist Party to the political opposition.

headline: Ecuador Opposes Outpost in American War on Drugs
text: MANTA, Ecuador  The scene at the Manta Ray Cafe, a mess hall here at the most prominent American military outpost in South America, suggests all is normal.

headline: The United States Open Changes Its Cable Home
text: ESPN and the Tennis Channel will start televising the United States Open starting next year through 2014, ending the USA Network’s reign as the Open’s exclusive cable TV home.

headline: Pro Surfer’s Death Exposes Beach Town’s Violent Side
text: SAN DIEGO  The affluent community of La Jolla has long produced beach cliques, most formed around the inclination of surfers and other beachgoers to guard their local break.

headline: That Pundit on Fox News? An Upstart Named Rove
text: WASHINGTON  Late Thursday night, Karl Rove, the architect of the last two Republican presidential victories, was on his new television perch at Fox News, offering free advice to Senator Barack Obama as he closed in on the Democratic nomination.

headline: Downsizing a Larger-Than-Life Warlord
text: This may seem counterintuitive, but a surefire way to guarantee yourself a portrayal in the modern Western operatic canon is to become a brutal Chinese despot. John Adams turned Mao Zedong into a philosopher king in “Nixon in China” (1987), and Mao turned up again (though seen more critically) in Bright Sheng’s “Madame Mao” (2003). More recently Tan Dun used a Metropolitan Opera commission to resurrect Qin Shi Huang, the emperor who unified China through conquest and the suppression of regional cultures and ruled in the third century B.C.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Chicago Symphony Orchestra’s hiring of Riccardo Muti as its music director referred imprecisely to a role with the New York Philharmonic that Mr. Muti agreed to take last year. It is equivalent to principal guest conductor but does not carry that title.

headline: After a Quixotic Attack in Sudan, a Question Lingers: Why?
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The day after the Sudanese government quickly dispensed with an attack by Darfurian rebels on the capital, Khartoum, the question that many people are asking is, “What were the rebels thinking?”

headline: A Horse Trainer’s Rough Ride
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Big Brown is perfect. The colt’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, admittedly is not. He once was a drug-addled horseman who was ruled off New York racetracks for five years. Since returning, he has earned a rogue reputation for being suspended for everything from medication violations to making up a workout for one of his better horses.

headline: Joseph Egan, Lawyer Who Fought Nuclear Waste Site, Is Dead at 53
text: WASHINGTON  Joseph R. Egan, a nuclear engineer-turned-lawyer who led Nevada’s legal campaign to block a nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain, died Wednesday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 53.

headline: A Lesson for a Price That Cannot Be Beat
text: Whether you know it or not, you probably need a golf lesson. People will go to a driving range 10 times during a season and fork over $100 for range balls.

headline: García Clears Water and Ends a Drought
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  In world-class tournament golf, as in almost every athletic competition at the highest level, superior talent usually prevails. It did again Sunday at The Players Championship, when Sergio García shot a final-round one-under-par 71 to chase down Paul Goydos and win the first sudden-death playoff in 21 years at the T.P.C. Sawgrass.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a new generation of developers leaving their mark on Las Vegas misidentified the university at which Lorenzo Fertitta, a son of the founder of Station Casinos, befriended Thomas C. Breitling, part of a group that bought and later sold the Golden Nugget. It was at the University of San Diego, not the University of Southern California.

headline: Idealism and Bawdiness Under Many Guises
text: Between songs at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night Erykah Badu leaned over a computer and some electronic equipment to set off burbling, swooping noises straight out of sci-fi B movies, as if she were tuning in the concert from another dimension. Maybe she was.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on May 1 about Yossi Harel, captain of the Jewish refugee ship Exodus 1947 that was turned back as it tried to cross the British blockade to deliver Jews to Palestine, included an incorrect figure from a speech in which Mr. Harel estimated the number of Jewish combatants in Israel’s 1948 war of independence. The number is variously estimated at 40,000 to 100,000  not the 600,000 Mr. Harel cited. (That was believed to be the total Jewish population in Palestine at the time.)

headline: Serious-Minded Golfers Tackle a Whimsical Game
text: Peter Gilchrist is a favorite to win this year’s United States Open. He practices his golf game daily, tours the country to play in tournaments and has pocketed his share of prize money. He is the patriarch of a family that includes four national golf champions.

headline: Production of a Movie Stops Over Funds to Pay Its Stars
text: LOS ANGELES  The Screen Actors Guild on Friday pulled its members, including the stars Jake Gyllenhaal and Jessica Biel, from a movie being directed by David O. Russell after producers of the film failed to keep sufficient funds to pay actors in a union-mandated account.

headline: The Oil Nonbubble
text: “The Oil Bubble: Set to Burst?” That was the headline of an October 2004 article in National Review, which argued that oil prices, then $50 a barrel, would soon collapse.

headline: Can Corzine Still Pass as a Liberal? He Thinks So
text: TRENTON  You never know which Gov. Jon S. Corzine is going to show up at the State House these days.

headline: GodTube, Where Networking Is More Spiritual Than Social
text: GodTube.com, a YouTube knockoff for the evangelical set, seems to be one step closer to building a kingdom on earth.

headline: Corrections
text: The Advertising column on Thursday about a film contest to promote Microsoft’s Vista operating system misstated the distance between Hollywood and Microsoft’s headquarters in Redmond, Wash. It is more than a thousand miles, not “several hundred miles.”

headline: In Sadr City, a Cease-Fire Is Put to the Test, and Fails
text: BAGHDAD  A column of Iraqi armor set out on Sunday to test a new truce in the Sadr City area of Baghdad between the militias and the Iraqi government by venturing north on a major thoroughfare that borders the Shiite enclave.

headline: City Ballet’s Itinerary: Robbins and Beyond
text: Those who assemble programs at New York City Ballet have much to learn, but will they learn? The two new ones that the company presented on Friday (“Russian Roots,” a quadruple bill) and Saturday afternoon (“World Tour,” quintuple) were built with quite different objectives, but neither satisfies as a whole.

headline: Citi’s New Slogan Is Said to Be Second Choice
text: Perhaps the next Citigroup tagline should be “Let’s Get It Right.”

headline: One More on the Road
text: Most states do not just outlaw driving while drunk, but also drinking while driving. Not Connecticut.

headline: Rainout Spoils Chance for Jeter to Bat Fourth
text: DETROIT  It has been almost nine years since Derek Jeter batted fourth in the Yankees’ batting order. Who knows how long it will be before he sees his name in the cleanup spot again?

headline: Crandall Canyon’s Shame
text: The six miners and three would-be rescuers killed in last summer’s Crandall Canyon mine disaster might have died needlessly. New evidence suggests that the mining company concealed an earlier collapse, which could have alerted safety regulators and avoided the tragedy. There will be no peace for the dead  and no deterrence of future disasters  until there is a criminal investigation.

headline: Strains of Humor in a Classical Vein
text: Music has a hard time being funny, especially music of the last 100 years. Haydn managed it in the past, and Gyorgy Kurtag’s piano pieces, as played by Mitsuko Uchida at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, come close today.

headline: Encores! for Bernstein
text: Leonard Bernstein is coming back to New York City Center as part of a celebration of what would have been his 90th birthday. For the first time, the City Center Encores! series will begin in the fall, with “On the Town,” the 1944 musical that Bernstein wrote with Betty Comden and Adolph Green. “On the Town” is scheduled to run from Nov. 19 to 23, followed by a production of the 1932 Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein musical “Music in the Air” from Feb. 5 to 8. The season will conclude with “Finian’s Rainbow,” the 1949 musical by Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy about what to do with an Irish pot of gold in the state of Missitucky. That is scheduled to run March 26 to 29.

headline: At the Cavendish Pairs, Six Spades, Much at Stake
text: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which finished Sunday afternoon in Henderson, Nev., was won by Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla. They led before the final session and moved further ahead of Gary Cohler of Miami and Sam Lev of New York City. Third were Bobby Levin of New York City and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., who won last year. A full report will appear in Thursday's column.

headline: Sinew and Blood: Tugging Connections Between America and Africa
text: The dancer and choreographer Reggie Wilson seems to be constantly working to enlarge the meanings of the term African-American. He is the main figure behind and within “Kwenda Vutuka (Come Go Return),” which was presented for two performances at the Florence Gould Hall over the weekend.

headline: Accepting the Costs of a Life in Football
text: Lying in his hospital bed, Reggie Williams watched a flow of blood, four or five inches high, coming from his postsurgical knee.

headline: Crews Search for Storm Survivors
text: Emergency crews searched through wreckage and conducted rescue operations on Monday in areas that were hit by violent storms that killed at least 23 people in Missouri, Oklahoma and Georgia over the weekend.

headline: A Better Immigration Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloomberg Asks Albany to Oppose Union-Backed Retirement Bills
text: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York is appealing to Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders to hold firm against two bills that the city believes would cost as much as $300 million a year.

headline: Once a Hostess, Now a Bar’s Grande Dame
text: Show up at the storied Café des Artistes anytime after 6:30 most evenings, and you might notice an elderly woman nursing a glass of red wine at the bar, her carriage erect, her suit jacket immaculate, her gaze resting nowhere in particular. Her small smile suggests that she’s not waiting for anyone, and that she’s comfortable with that. She’s old enough that even among the restaurant’s graying clientele, she stands out. Maybe you’d even avoid an empty seat next to her, for fear it might open the door to a rambling tirade about some government conspiracy involving vitamins or aluminum foil.

headline: Saying No to Everything
text: Even before the House passed a new plan last week to prevent foreclosures, President Bush threatened to veto the bill, calling it “overly burdensome.” The bill is not burdensome enough.

headline: The Week’s Major Economic Reports
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS The highlight for economic news this week will be the Consumer Price Index for April, on Wednesday.

headline: Strengthening Your Funny Bone
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Joyful Noise From Fans Rouses the Jazz
text: SALT LAKE CITY  The Jazz’s third-year point guard, Deron Williams, showed up Sunday. He was in the starting lineup for Game 4 of Utah’s second-round series against the Los Angeles Lakers despite a bruised right wrist, a remnant from the Jazz’s victory two days earlier.

headline: Today in Business
text: SHRINKING TV AUDIENCE The prime-time broadcast television audience has shrunk by six million viewers in the last year as other sources of entertainment have become more popular.

headline: President Apostate?
text: Chevy Chase, Md.

headline: Mozart and Schubert With Pipe and Slippers
text: Critics trying to deal with the idea of musical interpretation might keep in the back of their minds what Isaac Babel said, that “if the world could write by itself, it would write like Tolstoy.” Something similar drew me admiringly to Paul Lewis’s evening of piano music at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday.

headline: Deutsche Telekom May Gain Control of Greek Company
text: ATHENS  With its sales slipping and fixed-line customers defecting, Deutsche Telekom looked set this week to complete plans to buy a stake worth nearly 3 billion euros ($4.6 billion) in Greece’s former phone monopoly.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Rally at Turin Book Fair
text: Protesters in the thousands, including Dario Fo, the 1997 Nobel laureate in literature, massed on Saturday in Turin, Italy, to demonstrate their opposition to that city’s book fair, which highlights the 60th anniversary of Israeli independence. The fair’s decision to showcase Israeli writers drew a crowd of “Free Palestine” demonstrators  estimated at 3,000 to 4,000 by photographers, at 10,000 by the organizers and at 1,500 by the 1,000 police officers mobilized to shepherd the protesters, Agence France-Presse reported. The Paris book fair in March, also with an Israeli theme, drew similar pro-Palestinian demonstrations.

headline: ‘Little Mermaid’ Actor Has Surgery on Wrists
text: The actor who plummeted through a trapdoor minutes before the Saturday matinee of “The Little Mermaid” remained hospitalized on Sunday, said Chris Boneau, a spokesman for the show.

headline: To Curb Truancy, Dallas Tries Electronic Monitoring
text: DALLAS  Jaime Pacheco rolled out of bed at dawn last week to the blaring chorus of two alarms. Then Jaime, a 15-year-old high school freshman, smoothed his striped comforter, dumped two scoops of kibble for the dogs out back and strapped a G.P.S. monitor to his belt.

headline: What Social Security Isn’t Meant to Do
text: To hear some in Congress tell it, the federal government urgently needs to expand its electronic employment verification system, E-Verify, to all corners of the country and force every business to use it. But a hearing in the House last week raised serious questions about the costs and collateral damage of that expansion, the latest scheme by hard-liners to slam the door shut on unauthorized immigrant workers.

headline: Attack in Kashmir Leaves 7 Dead
text: NEW DELHI  A long lull in violence in the Indian-administered province of Kashmir broke on Sunday as a gun battle between militants and Indian soldiers left seven dead, according to Indian authorities.

headline: Upfronts: NBC To Confirm Jimmy Fallon’s ‘Late Night’ Hire on Monday
text: Jimmy Fallon, the former cast member of “Saturday Night Live,” is to be named the host of NBC’s “Late Night” talk show at a press conference on Monday, Bill Carter reports.

headline: Powerset Debuts With Search of Wikipedia
text: Powerset is undoubtedly among the most ballyhooed start-ups in Silicon Valley. The company’s mission is as improbable as it is daring: just as Google did a decade ago, Powerset wants to come up with a better way to search.

headline: Upfronts: A Season of Time-Shifting
text: This week, the television upfronts — in which the broadcast networks present their schedules to advertisers — will open with a mystery. Who stole six million viewers?

headline: Dutrow’s Long and Bumpy Journey
text: In Monday’s New York Times, Joe Drape tells the story of Rick Dutrow, who was once a drug-addled horseman who was ruled off New York racetracks for five years. He has also been fined and suspended for numerous violations. Even now, as the winning trainer of the Kentucky Derby, he has a redemptive tale with its share of rough edges.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 109 Northern Illinois
text: Location: DeKalb, Ill.

headline: The Quietening of Basra
text: Iraqi troops have largely pacified the city, which only a month ago shuddered under deadly clashes between the government and Shiite militias.

headline: Style Wars
text: At a TriBeCa warehouse, eight fashion design contestants relied on tape, scissors, staples, binder clips and large doses of creativity in the first national Style Wars competition.

headline: Hitting Rewind on Patriots’ Taping
text: A nice summary of where we’ve been — as Matt Walsh prepares to meet Roger Goodell tomorrow morning — begins with the words:How did we get here? (See bottom for companion lyrics)

headline: Pimlico on Monday: Not Much to See
text: During the years when I covered the Preakness Stakes for The Baltimore Sun, one of my jobs was to go to Pimlico Race Course at the beginning of the week and, as one editor told me, “set the scene.”

headline: Sing It: ‘We All Snort in a Cocaine Submarine, Cocaine Submarine, Cocaine Submarine …’
text: The Economist on a trend in cocaine smuggling:

headline: That Hillary Show
text: Better than “Saturday Night Live”? Check out Hillary Clinton impersonator Rosemary Watson (too bad demand for her shtick is fast fading):

headline: ‘His Two Favorite Domestic Programs’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Late-Night Musical Chairs
text: NBC will make it official today: Jimmy Fallon, the former cast member of “Saturday Night Live,” will be named the third host — after David Letterman and Conan O’Brien — of NBC’s “Late Night” talk show. He’ll probably start in mid-2009. Here he is busting some moves in that Pepsi commercial with Parker Posey a few years back:

headline: Podiums in Podunk
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Noble Environment Whips Up I.P.O. Plans
text: Wind energy company Noble Environmental Power has filed to raise as much as $375 million in an initial public offering, according to a document with the Securities and Exchange Commission that was filed Thursday.

headline: Deutsche Telekom May Gain Control of Greek Rival
text: With its sales slipping and fixed-line customers defecting, Deutsche Telekom looked set this week to complete plans to buy a stake worth nearly 3 billion euros ($4.6 billion) in Greece’s former phone monopoly.

headline: Citi May Sell Japanese Consumer Finance Unit
text: Citigroup is considering selling its Japanese consumer finance company CFJ or cutting the unit’s business significantly as part of its plans to shed assets, Japanese daily Nikkei reported on Sunday.

headline: Renault-Nissan and Bajaj Team Up for Low-Cost Car Venture
text: Renault-Nissan and Indian carmaker Bajaj Auto said on Monday they would form a joint venture company to develop a low-cost car model with a wholesale price range starting from $2,500.

headline: H.I.G. Capital to Finance Shapes Bankruptcy
text: The Miami buyout firm H.I.G. Capital Partners has taken over bankruptcy financing for Shapes/Arch Holdings, one of South Jersey’s largest employers, displacing rival Versa Capital Management, of Philadelphia.

headline: U.S. Companies Go North of the Border for I.P.O.’s
text: Companies that are finding it hard to raise money in the United States these days given the faltering economy and weak stock market, increasingly are selling their shares in Canada, according to BusinessWeek.

headline: EnCana to Split in Two
text: EnCana, Canada’s biggest energy company, said on Sunday it plans to split into two separate oil and natural gas firms in an effort to wring out more value with crude prices at record highs.

headline: HSBC Says 1Q Profit Up Despite $3.2 Billion Write-Down
text: HSBC Holdings said Monday that its first-quarter profit was ahead of the equivalent period a year ago as higher profits in Asia, the Middle East and Latin America helped offset rising bad-debt charges in the U.S. and a write-down at its investment banking arm.

headline: Yahoo Snaps Up Inquisitor to Help With Apple Searches
text: Yahoo has acquired Inquisitor in a move to improve how search results appear on Apple computers.

headline: Australia’s Westpac in Talks to Buy Rival St. George
text: Westpac Banking said Monday that it was in talks on an all-share bid for St. George Bank, which has a market value of 15 billion Australian dollars, in a deal that would create Australia’s largest home-lending and wealth-management provider.

headline: Liberty Appeals IAC Break-Up Ruling
text: John C. Malone’s Liberty Media filed an appeal to stop Barry Diller’s IAC/InterActiveCorp from pursuing a plan to break up the Internet conglomerate, although Liberty’s chief executive said it was still exploring a variety of options.

headline: Microsoft Appeals $1.4 Billion Fine by Europe
text: Microsoft asked Europe’s second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union.

headline: I.L.F.C. Considers Split from A.I.G., Report Says
text: International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of American International Group, is worried by the insurer’s financial troubles and mulling a split from it, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Will a Hedge Fund Take Control of TVT Records?
text: D.B. Zwirn & Company is a leading contender to win the upcoming bankruptcy auction of TVT Records, the record label known for its stable of rap and hip-hop artists.

headline: Humbler, After a Streak of Magic
text: For 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller, one of the country’s most closely watched and widely worshiped stockpickers, made investments that handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.

headline: The Chief of Barneys Is Expected to Resign
text: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, who restored the company’s stature after it fell into bankruptcy in the 1990s, has told colleagues he intends to resign amid disagreements with the retailer’s news owners, The New York Times reported.

headline: Fremont May Not Complete a Deal
text: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Planning a Web Site, Publisher Buys a Harvard Alumni Magazine
text: A small New York publisher on Friday bought 02138, a magazine for Harvard alumni, with visions of expanding it into social networking and event sponsorship, and then duplicating the operation for each Ivy League school.

headline: GodTube, Where Networking Is More Spiritual Than Social
text: GodTube.com, a YouTube knockoff for the evangelical set, seems to be one step closer to building a kingdom on earth.

headline: Electronic Arts Arranges Loan for Take-Two Bid
text: Electronic Arts, the video-game company seeking to buy Take-Two Interactive Software, said in a regulatory filing that it arranged $1 billion in loans to help fund its $2 billion offer.

headline: Canada Blocks U.S. Takeover of a Technology Firm
text: Canada confirmed its decision to block an American company’s takeover of the space and satellite division of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates, Canada’s leading space technology firm.

headline: Kerkorian Moves to Buy a Bigger Stake in Ford
text: The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian started a cash tender offer on Friday to bolster his stake in the Ford Motor Company to 5.6 percent but stopped short of revealing his long-term plans as a major shareholder in the carmaker.

headline: With Deal in Limbo, Clear Channel Reports Higher Earnings
text: Clear Channel Communications, a major radio and outdoor advertising company at the center of a heated legal battle, reported higher first-quarter earnings on asset sales, but operating results were flat, reflecting weak demand for radio advertising.

headline: Citi’s New Slogan Is Said to Be Second Choice
text: Perhaps the next Citigroup tagline should be “Let’s Get It Right.”

headline: United and US Airways Said to Be Closer to a Deal
text: United Airlines is closing in on a merger with US Airways, after being spurned by Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Wall Street Layoffs May Be Boon for Boutiques
text: The layoffs at big Wall Street firms will be expensive in dollar terms, but they may turn out to be costly in other ways, too. They may fuel market share opportunities for some of their smaller, more flexible rivals, The New York Sun reported.

headline: R.I.M. to Launch BlackBerry Venture Fund
text: Take that, iPhone.

headline: Bear Bankers May Soon Learn Their Fate
text: Investment bankers at Bear Stearns are expected to learn as early as this week whether they’ll keep their jobs or be axed, The New York Post reported, citing sources who have spoken to Bear’s co-head of investment banking, Jeff Urwin.

headline: Ex-Amaranth Chief Said to Plan New Fund
text: Nicholas Maounis, the hedge-fund manager whose Amaranth Advisors collapsed under a record $6.6 billion loss in 2006, is seeking to start a new firm, Bloomberg News reported, citing a note sent Friday to his former investors.

headline: Private Equity to the Rescue on Alliance Boots Debt?
text: Banks holding billions of pounds worth of debt backing last year’s buyout of Alliance Boots, the British healthcare chain, are set to turn to private equity companies after they failed to sell chunks of the debt last week, according to British press reports.

headline: Sisters
text: Becky Sinkler in her final post wrote in such an eloquent and timely fashion about mothers. Missing mothers abound in “Housekeeping,” but I’ve found myself thinking these last couple of days about siblings.

headline: Paul Weiss Picks Its New Chairman
text: When Alan Schwartz, Bear Stearns‘s chief executive, was called to Capitol Hill in early April to testify about the firm’s stunning collapse, he was flanked by super-lawyers from Washington and Wall Street.

headline: House G.O.P. Adopts Change Theme
text: For House Republicans, this week could be a real political turning point. But will it be a downturn or an upturn?

headline: Facebook Said to Raise $100 Million
text: Facebook, which has raised $360 million in the last seven months, is taking a different tack this time around, using debt instead of equity to bring in an additional $100 million, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: MBIA Posts $2.4 Billion Loss for 1st Quarter
text: MBIA, the biggest player in the troubled bond insurance industry, said Monday that it lost $2.4 billion for its first quarter, as the credit crisis continued to roil the subprime-based instruments that the company had insured.

headline: The Early Word: McCain Addresses Climate Change
text: One of the presidential candidates is off to the Pacific Northwest today to talk up a big campaign pledge to combat climate change — and it’s a Republican.

headline: Cumulus Buyout Is Terminated
text: Cumulus Media, the radio broadcaster, said Monday it terminated its July agreement to be taken private by its chairman and an affiliate of Merrill Lynch, stating the parties were “unable to agree on terms on which they could proceed with the transaction.” Cumulus said it will get a $15 million break-up fee from the investors, who agreed last year to pay $1.3 billion for the company.

headline: Rainout Gives Yanks Options for Rotation
text: The last time I missed a road game for one of my daughters’ christenings, it was Game 7 of the 2001 World Series in Arizona, just before I took the Yankees’ beat. This weekend, it was two games and a rainout in Detroit. I doubt any books will be written about these games.

headline: Complete Energy Sells Itself in $1.3 Billion Spac Deal
text: Complete Energy Holdings said on Monday that it will sell itself to GSC Acquisition, a blank-check company, in deal that values the power company at $1.3 billion.

headline: Cablevision to Buy Newsday (But Why?)
text: Cablevision Systems, the cable giant controlled by the Dolan family, has clinched a $650 million deal for Tribune‘s Newsday newspaper. The much-rumored transaction has had many analysts scratching their heads lately about why Cablevision would do such a deal at that price.

headline: Why oil isn’t gold
text: One reference I didn’t end up using in today’s column was this piece in Reason. It declares that “the oil market is coming to resemble the gold market” where “most gold traders don’t even ask the question of how much gold was mined last year or how much spare gold mining capacity there is. ”

headline: In Gun Cases, Police Testimony Met With Disbelief
text: Over the last six years, the police and prosecutors have cooperated in a broad effort that allows convicted felons found with a firearm to be tried in federal court, where sentences are much harsher than in state court. Officials say the initiative has taken hundreds of armed criminals off the street and turned some into informers who have helped solve more serious crimes. But a closer look at those prosecutions, Benjamin Weiser writes, reveals something that has not been trumpeted: more than 20 cases in which judges found police officers’ testimony to be unreliable, inconsistent, twisting the truth or just plain false. The judges’ language was often withering: “patently incredible,” “riddled with exaggerations,” “unworthy of belief.”

headline: McCain’s TV Preferences Emerge: Office Farce, Not Soap
text: John McCain may not watch “The Hills,” but he seems to sincerely enjoy “The Office.” He seemed slightly star-struck upon meeting B. J. Novak, a writer and actor on the show, at a gala sponsored by Time magazine on Thursday. Mr. McCain started rattling off the details of “Dinner Party,” the April 10 episode. Read more…

headline: Protecting Knees of Young Athletes
text: We’ve been reading a lot lately of the growing problem of serious knee injuries among young athletes, particularly girls. As a parent, I’m left with one question: What can I do to protect my daughter from a serious sports injury?

headline: Frank Whiteley, a True Horseman
text: It’s less than a week before the Preakness, and on this relatively quiet day, as the sport turns its attention from Louisville to Baltimore, my attention turned to a Maryland homebred, the trainer Frank Whiteley, who died a little over a week ago.

headline: Three Baby Hawks Are Most Likely Dead
text: As if this Monday morning weren’t dreary and chilly enough, now comes news that three nestlings born in recent weeks to red-tailed hawks in the south end of Riverside Park are believed to have died.

headline: The Law of Unintended Consequences
text: One of the biggest phenomenon in corporate governance these days is majority voting for directors. But despite the head-long rush to adopt its features, the mechanism is largely untested and its true affect on public company governance unknown.

headline: Alien Native
text: On the periphery of the PEN World Voices Festival the other week, I was glad to meet Rian Malan, a South African journalist whose book “My Traitor’s Heart: A South African Exile Returns to Face His Country, His Tribe, and His Conscience” I highly recommend. The grand-nephew of an architect of apartheid, Malan fled the country to avoid the draft and later returned to write his excellent reckoning with family and national history.

headline: Costs of Text Messaging vs. Space Transmissions
text: Need another reason to get angry at your next cell phone bill? Turn to Nigel Bannister, a space scientist at the University of Leicester in Britain, who has concluded that sending a mundane, ubiquitous text message costs at least four times as much as transmitting scientific data from the Hubble telescope. Here’s his math, from a news release, converted to dollars from British pounds:

headline: Can Actor Sway College Superdelegates?
text: After inching past Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the official tally of superdelegates last week, Senator Barack Obama is looking to extend his lead, and his campaign is hoping a little star power might do the trick.

headline: Evercore’s Lumpiness Problem
text: Evercore Partners reported its first quarterly loss ever as a public company, with both arms of its business — financial advisory and investment management — taking major body blows. The news sent Evercore’s share price to its lowest point since the firm’s 2006 initial public offering; after falling nearly 16 percent soon after the market opened, the stock was down about 7 percent at $13.92 shortly before midday.

headline: About Those Teachers No One Seems to Want . . .
text: The rule in New York City schools used to be that senior teachers could transfer to any school they wished, by bumping younger teachers out of their jobs. The city and the teachers union did the right thing when they abandoned that rule.

text: Mayor Michael R. headline: Hoping the Swedish Meatballs Hold Out in Red Hook
text: So the first thing Ikea wants you to know: Customers will not be allowed to line up outside the new Ikea in Red Hook, Brooklyn, until 48 hours before the grand opening (which is scheduled for 9 a.m. on June 18).That may seem like a bizarre warning, except that a man showed up two and a half weeks before the opening of West Sacramento Ikea store in California in 2006, and another person showed up two weeks early in Tempe, Ariz., in 2004. (In Brooklyn, there will be give-aways to early arrivals on that opening Wednesday, but not to the very first few people.)

headline: Clear Channel: Sketching a Settlement
text: The word is that the parties in the Clear Channel Communications dispute are negotiating a settlement that could involve a reduction of the purchase price from $39.20 to $36 per share. I’m surprised that they are doing so at this point, because of the small reduction in the consideration. It will be interesting to read the background of the settlement in the transactions documents. But in any settlement, here are a few of the issues that the parties need to address:

headline: Commenting on Comments
text: Alex asks which piquillos? I don’t know; they’re all supposed to be from Lodosa in the Navarre, and as long as they are I’ve never had bad ones. He also asks how to store Parmesan rinds; I try to use them as they come, but sometimes I wrap them and keep them in the freezer. It’s true they never taste as good, but it’s better than mold.

headline: ‘Late Night with Jimmy Fallon’ Debuts Next Year

headline: Voters Tuned In to Superdelegate Power
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — In some previous presidential elections, no one much cared about superdelegates or even knew they existed. But with the Democratic nomination likely to be decided by these party leaders and elected officials, voters are taking an extraordinary interest in them this year.

headline: Wachovia Subpoenaed Over Securities Auctions
text: Wachovia, the nation’s fourth-largest bank, said on Monday that it had received inquiries and subpoenas from federal and state regulators related to its auction rate securities, including the failure of the auctions.

headline: Obama Confronts the Israel Issue
text: Questions about Barack Obama’s commitment to Israel have been growing ever since an official of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that the State Department classifies as a terrorist organization, said last month that “we like Mr. Obama and we hope that he will win the election.”

headline: Think Tank Weighs In on ‘Iron Man’
text: BRIEFS The top movie in America rarely earns the attention of the Brookings Institution, one of Washington’s oldest research centers. But here it is: How to Be All That You Can Be: A Look at the Pentagon’s Five Step Plan For Making Iron Man Real.

headline: Field of Weeds

headline: The Top 10 Screw-Ups
text: Regnery, the conservative publishing house, has just brought out a book called “10 Books That Screwed Up the World: And 5 Others That Didn’t Help.” The author, Benjamin Wiker, is a senior fellow at the St. Paul Center for Biblical Theology and co-author of “Answering the New Atheism: Dismantling Richard Dawkins’ Case Against God.” Accordingly, none of the world’s great religious books make the cut in this new volume.

headline: ‘Survivor': Exhausted?
text: “Survivor: Micronesia,” the sixteenth edition of the CBS franchise, ended on Sunday, drawing the lowest ratings ever for a season finale of the 8-year-old series. The episode drew an average of 12.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, coming up just short of the previous lowest rated finale in the franchise, last year’s conclusion of “Survivor: Fiji” in May (13.6 million).

headline: A Mother Dead on a Brooklyn Street
text: The body of a woman who had been slashed to death was discovered on a street in Brooklyn on Monday, about 30 feet from a car where her infant son was found sitting unharmed, the police said. The woman, identified as Iasha Bristol, 27, of Brooklyn, was slashed across her throat, the police said. She was discovered at the corner of Hart Street and Lewis Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.A passer-by made the discovery at about 7 a.m. the police said, and officers who responded found a kitchen knife close by that is believed to be the murder weapon. Inside Ms. Brisol’s car, a dark-colored Hyundai, the officers found the 1-year-old boy sitting in a car seat. He was immediately transported to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.

headline: New Way Into Prison, and Old Way Out
text: In a matter of days, a new way to enter prison gave way to a very old way to break out.

headline: Us and Theme
text: Settling on a “theme” — meaning color, patterns, typeface, vibe, not something literary like “man’s inhumanity to man” — has become part of loading up a new device. My BlackBerry has a speedy and frightening I’m-very-rushed look to it; I uploaded a photo to the home screen but left the default theme.

headline: Q&A: Love in Saudi Arabia
text: As part of our series on young people in the Islamic world, Generation Faithful, this week we have published two articles on love and romance in Saudi Arabia; one about young men, by Michael Slackman and the other about young women, by Katherine Zoepf.

headline: Can New York Close the Video-Game Gap?
text: New York is losing out to rival cities like Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Austin, Boston, Montreal and Vancouver in attracting companies that develop video games, a burgeoning industry that could easily play a larger role in the local economy, according to a new report [pdf] by a research organization that studies city issues.

headline: Bottoms Up | Wine Guru Gary Vaynerchuk
text: There’s nothing posh about Gary Vaynerchuk, and you’ve got to love him for it. Vaynerchuk is the host of the Internet’s zaniest wine-tasting Web cast, “The Thunder Show.” While sniffing and sampling a selection of, say, white Burgundies, he’s likely to be wearing wrist bands, playing with action figures and expectorating into a metal New York Jets bucket. He’s cultivated a sizable fan base by demystifying wine, and this week he has a book coming out, “101 Wines,” a selection of his favorite bottles. (Full disclosure: I’m an occasional viewer, but not one of his hardcore followers, known as Vayniacs.)

headline: The [Annotated] McCain Climate Speech

I’m immersed in unrelated reporting at the moment — on the shape of the next green revolution — but will start annotating the speech shortly (with your help, please) as we did with President Bush’s recent climate speech.

headline: Times Reader Beta for Mac Coming This Month
text: A beta version of Times Reader for Mac users will be released this month. In building Times Reader for the Mac we’ve focused on providing the core set of features that have made the PC version popular. These include the easy-to-read paginated format, the ability to view the paper offline, a seven-day archive, text search, the ability to adjust the font size and access to Premium Crosswords.

headline: On the Eve of West Virginia
text: The rolling hills of West Virginia and its mines are so close to our own home (in southwestern Pennsylvania) that tomorrow’s primary keeps dredging up that John Denver song in our head to the point that it’s an earworm (meaning you can’t get rid of it). For those of you with the same irritant, colleagues have been posting a techno-version; it doesn’t erase all but offers a newer rendition.

headline: A Slower Pace for a Once-Great Race

headline: The Class Isn’t Always Greener (But It Could Be)
text: School design, particularly public school design, is often lumped in with the design of other institutional structures like jails, civic centers and hospitals, to detrimental effect. My high school, for example, had the dubious distinction of having been designed by the architect responsible for San Quentin. (The convicts got the better building.) Schools fulfill a practical function, to be sure, but shouldn’t they be designed to inspire?

headline: Plans for Spain’s version of Las Vegas may be ‘a busted flush’
text: Remember those plans to build a Las Vegas-style gambling city outside Zaragoza in Spain? Last November the regional government in Aragon approved a scheme calling for 32 hotels and five theme parks covering 5,000 acres, according to the London Times.

headline: H.P.’s Bid for E.D.S. Shows That Data Centers Are Sexy

headline: Will Leno Stay at NBC? ‘It’s a Reach’
