We may not have found Grandpa Foster’s derailed train, but I’m pretty sure that’s the only secret the lake didn’t surrender to our close analysis.

headline: Want to Fight a Parking Ticket? Log On First.
text: Glen Bolofsky, who has made a two-and-half-decade-long career of fighting City Hall, or at least the parking tickets it issues, unveiled his latest weapon Tuesday morning: a Web site.Actually, the site, parkingticket.com, which was introduced in the Plaza Hotel in Midtown to a small conference room of reporters, is basically the same one he has offered since 2001, but it now boasts a new feature that assesses users’ chances of successfully challenging a ticket before enlisting Mr. Bolofsky to do it for them.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Ferrari Blow Out Sale
text: Ferrari’s 1961 250 California Spyder. (RM Auctions)

headline: More on oil and speculation
text: One of the things I find puzzling about the whole oil market discussion is how complicated people seem to make it. They get all wrapped up in stuff about forward markets, hedge funds, etc., and lose sight of the fundamental fact that there are only two things you can do with the world’s oil production: consume it, or store it.

headline: Quote Unquote |  Pup Art
text: — WKMG-TV, Denver, reporting on the kind of consciousness-raising strategies that go above and beyond the call of beauty.

headline: McCain’s ‘Eco-Friendly’ Line
text: Just in time for Father’s Day and his speech on curbing emissions, Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign is out with a hot new spring line of “eco-friendly” products.

headline: An Afghan Breadmaker's Struggle
text: Soaring bread prices are leaving Afghans hungry and increasingly desperate.

headline: Watching West Virginia
text: 9:50 p.m. | Wrapup: Well, what is left to say that hasn’t been said? Not only by us and the TV-types, but Mrs. Clinton too. Her campaign has been telegraphing for days that she planned to carry on after tonight, then she came out and said it herself.

headline: An Afghan Breadmaker's Struggle
text: Soaring bread prices are leaving Afghans hungry and increasingly desperate.

headline: Rauschenberg’s Art Car Legacy
text: Robert Rauschenberg, one of the most significant American artists of the latter 20th century, died Monday. His career spanned six decades and many media, as Michael Kimmelman notes in his obituary for Mr. Rauschenberg. One thing not mentioned, though, is the artist’s work for BMW.

headline: SocGen Changes Its Numbers
text: Société Générale, the French bank that lost billions from a rogue trader, disclosed today that it had restated quarterly income figures for last year to account for the unauthorized trades. The audited numbers, which the company admitted violated accounting standards, now turn out to have been wrong. (The violation of accounting standards, as I explained in this column, involved shifting losses taken in 2008 to 2007. The company got its auditors to agree that was fine, despite the rules.)

headline: Stuffed Chicken Breasts
text: Mark Bittman makes a sandwich of two chicken breasts and sauteed greens.

headline: We Like ‘Filthy’ and ‘Rich,’ But…
text: The CW has been developing a series based on the book “How to Teach Filthy Rich Girls” for months. But this week, the name of the show was abruptly changed.

headline: Mean Girls Play Very Nicely for the CW
text: “You’re nobody until you’re talked about,” the commercials for “Gossip Girl” told viewers last fall.

headline: Upfronts: The CW’s Lineup
text: The CW will start its fall season on September 1, weeks before other broadcast networks, in an effort to jump-start its junior year schedule.

headline: A Busy Day at Shea
text: Twelve percent of the Mets’ roster changed Tuesday when, after designating Jorge Sosa and Nelson Figueroa for assignment and putting Angel Pagan on the disabled list, they recalled Claudio Vargas and Fernando Tatis and activated Matt Wise.

headline: A Seedy Rivalry
text: This week, I want to look at recent discoveries in one of my favorite subjects — sex. Discoveries that reveal surprising male subtlety. Discoveries that could, perhaps, have implications for how we approach in vitro fertilization (I.V.F.).

headline: Upfronts: CW’s Mystery Sunday
text: The CW network’s upfront presentation ended early Tuesday evening with a mystery solved, and in true TV cliffhanger fashion, more whodunits still to be unraveled.

headline: The West Virginia Primary
text: Only 39 delegates were at stake in the West Virginia primary on Tuesday, but Hillary Rodham Clinton counted on a big victory there to help rally her bid for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Director Accused at Russian Museum
text: Russian prosecutors charged the director of the Sakharov Museum in Moscow on Tuesday with inciting hatred or offending human dignity with an exhibition titled “Forbidden Art  2006,” Agence France-Presse reported. The March 2007 show, which included an image juxtaposing coarse words with Christ’s crucifixion, offended the Orthodox Church, said Anna Stavitskaya, a lawyer for the accused, Yuri Samodurov. The exhibition comprised works deemed by other museum directors to be too shocking for display during the previous year. The art was visible only to viewers peeping through small holes in a white wall. Ms. Stavitskaya said the case was driven by government displeasure with the museum’s involvement in controversial projects. In 2005 Mr. Samodurov was convicted and fined by a Moscow court for instigating religious and ethnic hatred through “Caution, Religion!,” an exhibition intended to provoke discussion about the role of religion in modern society.

headline: Olive and Almond: Mediterranean Delight
text: I’VE nibbled almonds and olives in the same mouthful dozen of times (Moroccan tagines, Spanish tapas and overlapping bites in hotel bars come to mind). But it wasn’t until I discovered the delights of Fairway’s almond-stuffed green olives that I realized their sublime synergy.

headline: F.D.A. Chief Writes Congress for Money
text: WASHINGTON  After being pummeled for weeks on Capitol Hill over the president’s budget, Food and Drug Commissioner Andrew C. von Eschenbach has written Congress that the agency needs an immediate infusion of $275 million to ensure that imported foods, drugs and medical devices are safe.

headline: Teach for America Sees Surge in Popularity
text: Teach for America, the program that recruits top college graduates to teach for two years in public schools that are difficult to staff, has experienced a year of prodigious growth and will place 3,700 new teachers this fall, up from 2,900 last year, a 28 percent increase.

headline: Relief on Société Générale’s Profit Report
text: Even as investors were sighing with relief on Tuesday over Société Générale’s no-worse-than-expected first-quarter results, the French banking sector was hit with more bad news. Crédit Agricole announced plans to raise 5.9 billion euros, or $9.1 billion, to shore up its capital after further write-downs at its Calyon investment bank.

headline: In the Tracks of Ron Paul, a Candidate Goes Forth
text: Can Bob Barr become the next Ron Paul?

headline: Tax Windfall Could Soften Budget Cuts in New Jersey
text: TRENTON  The state treasurer said Tuesday that New Jersey collected $533 million more than anticipated in 2007 tax revenue, allowing Gov. Jon S. Corzine to soften his proposed budget cuts to small towns and largely spare the state parks from closing this summer and the Department of Agriculture from being dissolved.

headline: When an Anchor Curses on the Air, She Becomes the Night’s Top Story
text: Maybe that will teach Chuck to stop reading things on his computer monitor and start paying attention to Sue.

headline: Education Aid for Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: California: 5 Held in Counterfeit Ring
text: Five men have been arrested in Los Angeles since Thursday in connection with a counterfeit operation that may have produced up to $6 million worth of fake $100 and $20 bills in the past two years in “one of the largest, if not the largest, counterfeit currency rings” ever uncovered in Southern California, said Thomas P. O’Brien, the United States attorney there. Six men were charged with activities related to the ring, including dealing counterfeit securities and printing federal reserve notes on inkjet and laser printers out of the home of Albert E. Talton, 44, in Lawndale. The arrests came after an investigation by multiple law enforcement agencies that began in February. When officers raided Mr. Talton’s home last week, they found almost $250,000 in counterfeit currency and about $825,000 in partially printed bills, officials said.

headline: HBO Film About 2000 Recount Draws Protests From Democrats
text: Wounds from the Florida recount, still healing for many Democrats, are being ripped open again for some prominent former advisers to Al Gore. They say that a coming HBO film dramatizing the ballot battle after the 2000 election unfairly blames them for the Democrats’ failure to secure the White House.

headline: Quick and Tasty, but Hold the Ambiance
text: A PERSON should eat to live, not live to eat. That was Socrates’s take on it anyway. And while I might not see eye to eye with the Greek on that point, I still find the need, between sojourns in search of what’s new or next, for something cheap, quick and utterly delicious, without frippery like seats, credit card acceptance and ambiance.

headline: At Christie’s, Bidding Is Strong for Even a House
text: In an overflowing salesroom at Christie’s, bidders from all parts of the globe were happy to pay top dollar Tuesday night for everything from an abstract canvas by Mark Rothko to a painting of a monumentally fat woman by Lucian Freud.

headline: Earthquake in China Highlights the Vulnerability of Schools in Many Countries
text: The enormous loss of life in collapsed schools around China’s quake-stricken Sichuan Province could have been significantly reduced using known methods for designing or retrofitting structures in earthquake zones, several experts on global hazards said Tuesday.

headline: Barbaro’s Little Brother Nearly Ready to Run
text: ELKTON, Md.  The bay colt Nicanor has never been tested and has never raced, but he is already special. His every start, even his every move, will be followed and scrutinized, and the expectations will be tremendous. Barbaro’s little brother is getting there, nearing a race, ready to answer the tantalizing question of whether he, too, has what it takes to be a star.

headline: Officers Battle Visa Hurdles for Iraq Aides
text: When Lt. Col. Michael Zacchea left Iraq in 2005, he was torn. His yearlong mission to train an Iraqi Army battalion had left him wounded and emotionally drained, and he was eager to go. But leaving Iraq also meant leaving Jack, his Iraqi interpreter, to face an insurgency that has made a point of brutalizing those who help the Americans.

headline: Need a Different Peeler? Turn and Try Again
text: We love multiple-use kitchen gadgets that do not have detachable parts that disappear into the jungle of the kitchen drawer. Take the Trio by Prepara, a peeler with three blades  straight, serrated and julienne  that are stored in its handle and released simply by turning the bottom part of the base.

headline: Roasted Striped Bass With Orange, Olive and Almond Gremolata
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: Shortlist Announced for Turner Prize
text: A mannequin perched on a toilet and a cartoon cat were among the artworks chosen on Tuesday to compete for the Turner Prize, a traditional flash point for controversy about British art, Reuters reported. No painters made the shortlist of four artists. The nominees were sculptors and visual artists: Runa Islam, Goshka Macuga, Cathy Wilkes and Mark Leckey. Mr. Leckey features cartoon characters in his work, Ms. Wilkes uses shop mannequins in many of her installations, Ms. Islam recreates cult movie scenes, and Ms. Macuga draws inspiration from the German horror film “The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari.” Anticipating a hostile or derisive response from critics and newspapers, Stephen Deuchar, director of Tate Britain in London and chairman of this year’s Turner jury, said: “This is art made by people for people. What is vital about the Turner Prize is that it creates informed debate about art. People are not frightened to argue about its merits and demerits.” The Turner Prize, open to British artists under 50, carries a top prize of $49,000. Each runner-up receives $9,740. Work by the shortlisted artists will be exhibited at Tate Britain beginning Sept. 30. The winner will be announced there on Dec. 1.

headline: Welsh Voice Crooning American Soul
text: The debut album by the Welsh soul revivalist Duffy, “Rockferry” (Mercury), is an exercise in control. Her voice is subtle, pristine and evocative  there are shades of Motown, more Mary Wells than Diana Ross  and her songs, of which she is a co-writer, are neatly layered and womblike. At worst, her music is successful mimicry, but much more often Duffy strikes notes of blissful languor. She never tests herself, but she doesn’t have to; she teases, she confesses, and she says goodbye. “Rockferry” is, in every way, smooth.

headline: Veal Just One Way, Please
text: MAYBE it’s an inevitable consequence of so many restaurants vying to be noticed. Maybe it’s an attempt to justify entrees sailing far north of $35. Maybe it’s a reflection of chefs too neurotic or vain to commit to one strategy or to dwell on one note.

headline: Singing for a Poet Offstage
text: The narrator of Nikki Giovanni’s poem “All I Gotta Do” is a sleepless woman repeating to herself in a voice of mounting frustration that all she has to do is sit and wait until an unnamed something (a lover? a political movement?) comes and sweeps her away. But when will that happen?

headline: Ex-Inmate Loses Lawsuit Over Secondhand Smoke
text: A man who was notorious among the city’s law enforcement officials for being a leader in the illegal numbers business has lost a lawsuit against the Department of Correction that blamed the Rikers Island smoking policy for his bladder cancer.

headline: Mets Making Moves and Noise
text: The inspirational story of Nelson Figueroa, the Brooklyn boy made good, took a detour toward New Orleans on Tuesday when the Mets designated him for assignment. But before he left the clubhouse, Figueroa again expressed his irritation at what he believed was childish and unprofessional behavior by some Washington Nationals during Monday’s game.

headline: Democrat Wins House Seat in Mississippi
text: COFFEEVILLE, Miss.  Democrats scored a remarkable upset victory on Tuesday in a special Congressional election in this conservative Southern district, sending a clear signal of national problems ahead for Republicans in the fall.

headline: Delays Stall Delivery of Airbus A380s Again
text: PARIS  Airbus announced another delay in deliveries of the A380 on Tuesday, risking new financial penalties from disappointed airlines as it struggles to increase production of the world’s largest passenger jet.

headline: Clinton Beats Obama Handily in West Virginia
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton arranged to meet with uncommitted superdelegates on Wednesday following her lopsided win in the West Virginia primary, as her supporters argued that her appeal to some traditional Democratic voting blocks may change some opinions despite the continued long odds that she can secure her party’s nomination.

headline: Profit Rises, but Wal-Mart Cautions
text: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest retailer and a bellwether for the economy, said Tuesday that its sales and profit surged in the first quarter, as belt-tightening consumers flocked to its bargain prices.

headline: Getting Better (Can’t Get Worse)
text: The great thing about inheriting an awful situation  and the Knicks are awful  is that it does not take much to please the fans. Especially in New York, where they are desperate for a hint of winning.

headline: A Passion for Beers All Started With Dad
text: So many beers, so little time. If it’s Lion Stout from Ceylon that tempts you, you will find it at Fatty Crab in Greenwich Village. Schneider Weisse from Germany? Take your pick of 42 bars and restaurants.

headline: Knife Skills: Creating Feasts for the Eyes
text: LOOKING at a butternut squash and a fistful of rhubarb, James Parker sees a jellyfish and its tentacles. Show him a carton of pineapples and he will envision stacking them end to end to form the trunk of a palm tree. Pumpkins put him in mind of the sun and red peppers suggest its rays.

headline: Gates Says New Arms Must Play Role Now
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned the military and its contractors on Tuesday that expensive new conventional weapons must prove their value to current conflicts, marked by insurgency and terrorism, if they are to be included in further Pentagon budgets.

headline: Prosecutors Rework Indictment of Bonds
text: Barry Bonds was re-indicted Tuesday by the federal authorities in an effort to fix the original indictment in his perjury case.

headline: France: Bistros to Offer Drinks and Breathalyzers
text: Barely recovered from the imposition of a smoking ban this year, the French are bracing for the next novelty in their favorite bistros: a Breathalyzer. The government submitted a decree to France’s top legal authority to require as many as 44,000 cafes, bars, restaurants and nightclubs to install the alcohol-testing devices by Jan. 1. The use of the Breathalyzers would be voluntary.

headline: Soave Challenges Its Easy Image
text: ON the face of it Soave would seem to be about as controversial as a carrot. It’s a white wine, right? An Italian white, which to many people means a crisp, cold, characterless quaffing wine for knocking back, not for savoring. Yet there we were, the wine panel, completely divided over the merits of the 25 Soaves we had just tasted.

headline: It’s Still Spring, but the Ice Cream Truck War Revs Up
text: The man in the Mister Softee truck stuck his head out the window and glared at the fellow in the white cap and black bow tie.

headline: Footnotes
text: “Jackie Mason: The Ultimate Jew” has been extended for a second time, through Aug. 31 at New World Stages. The show opened what was to have been a 10-week run on March 18. ... Three jurors, including the wife of a Baptist preacher, a business executive and a telecommunications company employee, were chosen on Monday in Chicago for the pornography trial of the R&B star R. Kelly, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly is accused of videotaping himself having sex with a girl as young as 13. The supposed victim, now 23, says she is not the person on the tape. Court officials estimate that questioning and selection from a pool of 150 prospective jurors will take about a week.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the slow counting of votes in Lake County, Ind., for the state’s Democratic primary election misidentified the city where a lawyer for the Lake County Board of Elections, David Saks, was shown talking to reporters. He was in Crown Point, Ind., not Hammond.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,070 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: An Easy Way to Stuff Chicken Breasts
text: IN almost every instance the sole reason to stuff one food with another is appearance. So for me the questions are: Is it easy enough to make it worth the effort? Does the process add or detract from the overall flavor?

headline: Dolan’s Conflict of Coverage
text: When there is news in his Cablevision empire, shouldn’t Jim Dolan be there? He is America’s newest newspaper mogul  Cablevision agreed to buy Newsday on Monday  but he was absent Tuesday when his Knicks introduced Mike D’Antoni as their coach.

headline: A New Wrinkle in College Admissions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fearing Red Herring in the Data
text: Only a month ago, a recession looked inevitable. Job cuts were picking up speed, and stock prices were falling. The Federal Reserve was cutting its benchmark interest rate rapidly, in an effort to keep the downturn from snowballing. But the notion that the economy could avoid a recession altogether seemed fanciful.

headline: Fourth-Line Center Is Flyers’ Voice of Experience
text: VOORHEES, N.J.  The voice that Philadelphia Flyers right wing Steve Downie hears so often on the ice belongs to a wizened man with graying curls and a salt-and-pepper Fu Manchu that ends on both sides of his chin.

headline: Corrections
text: Sports

headline: The New Cold War
text: The next American president will inherit many foreign policy challenges, but surely one of the biggest will be the cold war. Yes, the next president is going to be a cold-war president  but this cold war is with Iran.

headline: The Optimistic (and Long) View of Larry A. Silverstein
text: Larry A. Silverstein, the New York developer, is used to being second-guessed.

headline: Uncertain Futures for Bounty at Cannes
text: CANNES, France  When the 61st Cannes Film Festival opens here on Wednesday, all the customary glamour, spectacle and high Gallic seriousness will be in place: the red carpet, the hatchet-faced guards, the shouting paparazzi, the promenading stars and bleary-eyed journalists. If the Americans look a little more anxious than usual, it’s not just the enfeebled dollar. Everyone may be expecting the bounty of good and even great films from around the world over the next 12 days, but the excitement is tempered by a sense that those films are facing unusually difficult prospects back in the United States.

headline: ‘Almost Nominee’ Status Keeps Obama in Limbo
text: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo.  The contest with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton not quite over and the one with Senator John McCain not quite under way, Senator Barack Obama is floating somewhere between the two major phases of his long campaign  a political limbo that brought him to this Republican hamlet on the night of a West Virginia primary he was expected to lose.

headline: A Second Night for Comedy at CBS
text: CBS will try to expand its growing success with comedy in the new lineup of programs that it will introduce on Wednesday to advertisers in New York.

headline: Detroit City Council Votes to Request Removal of Mayor by Governor
text: DETROIT  The Detroit City Council voted on Tuesday to ask the governor of Michigan to oust the city’s mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who is charged with perjury and obstruction of justice.

headline: School Bus Safety Officials Are Accused of Soliciting Bribes
text: Four City Department of Education employees were charged in a federal indictment on Tuesday with soliciting bribes in exchange for promising preferential treatment, including on safety inspections, to bus companies that serve thousands of special education students.

headline: Spain: Water Shipped to Parched City
text: A boat loaded with drinking water docked in Barcelona on Tuesday, the first in a series of shipments to stave off shortages in the city. The shipments are part of a broad effort to alleviate the impact of the worst drought in the region of Catalonia in decades. Fountains and beach showers have been turned off in Barcelona, and residents have been told not to water their gardens. The government will charter ships through October if the drought does not end, a spokesman for the regional environment department said.

headline: New Problems and Old Friction Put British Premier in Political Jeopardy
text: LONDON  Gordon Brown is still six weeks away from his first anniversary as Britain’s prime minister, a job he hankered after so keenly during much of his 10 years as Tony Blair’s No. 2 that the two men ended up barely able to speak to each other or agree on major policy issues.

headline: Taking Advantage of Slumping Yanks, Rays Move Into First
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Cliff Floyd was due to lead off the bottom of the 11th inning at Tropicana Field on Tuesday, still searching for his first career hit off the Yankees’ Mariano Rivera. This did not seem to be the time.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the actress Vanessa Williams, who received a bachelor’s degree from Syracuse University nearly 25 years after she dropped out, erroneously included an award among her achievements. While she was nominated for a Tony Award for her performance as the Witch in “Into the Woods,” she has not won one.

headline: Michael Moore Versus Bush Again?
text: The next documentary by Michael Moore, below, untitled but described as “a searing and provocative follow-up to his groundbreaking 2004 documentary ‘Fahrenheit 9/11,’ ” will be financed by Paramount Vantage and Overture Films, the two companies announced on Tuesday. “Fahrenheit 9/11” bashed the Bush administration and won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 2004, when Mr. Moore first hinted at more to come.

headline: Ex-Banker From UBS Is Indicted in Tax Case
text: Some of the secrets of Switzerland’s biggest bank were put on display on Tuesday as federal authorities indicted a former UBS banker on charges of helping a wealthy American real estate developer evade taxes.

headline: Woman Wins a Settlement Over Her Bathroom Ouster
text: A West Village restaurant where a woman said she was asked to leave the women’s restroom, and then the premises, because she looked too much like a man will pay her $35,000 and has agreed to change its workplace practices.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Green Fairy

headline: ‘Standard Operating Procedure’
text: McCotter had not known Abu Ghraib's history or its symbolism when he first admired its possibilities. The buildings alone were mute, and the flamboyant murals of Saddam that decked their walls were no different from a thousand others he'd seen in Iraq: a stern Saddam pointing an admonishing finger; a playboy Saddam in shades and a Panama hat; a happy soldier Saddam in epaulets, crowned by crossed swords and circled by fluttering white doves. But he had since heard the harrowing stories of the prison's past: how so many prisoners were kept in some cells that half of them had to stand while the other half slept; how they were fed one meal a day of soup, rice or lentils, and a piece of bread; how guards extorted protection money from prisoners and their families; how Saddam's son Qusay, the secret-police chief, would stop by and order a thousand executions because he felt like it; how prisoners were bolted to the floor and hung from the rafters, subjected to electric shocks, and beaten until they might feel lucky to be killed. McCotter had explored the death house — the torture chambers and cells for the condemned within earshot of the clanging iron trapdoors of the gallows. His interpreters had read to him the last words of prayer and despair scratched into those cell walls, and one day, while inspecting work at the prison, he had been summoned to the gate because an American reporter was there accompanying four Iraqis who had their own desperate plea.

headline: Clear Channel Accepts Smaller Takeover Bid
text: Clear Channel Communications agreed on Tuesday to a revised $17.9 billion takeover by two private equity firms after settling a long and often acrimonious dispute with the six banks that agreed to finance the deal.

headline: Spain: Court Finds G.I.’s Justified in Iraq Killing
text: The National Court dismissed homicide charges against three United States soldiers accused of killing a Spanish television cameraman when they opened fire on a Baghdad hotel in 2003. The National Court ruled that the shooting was an act of war and that the soldiers could have believed they were firing on the enemy.

headline: Colombia Extradites 14 Paramilitary Leaders
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombia extradited 14 jailed paramilitary leaders to the United States on Tuesday, in an effort by President Álvaro Uribe to take a hard line against the warlords and defuse a scandal that has tied them to senior lawmakers in the Colombian Congress and members of his own family.

headline: Even at Home, Flyers Are Unable to Stop Penguins
text: PHILADELPHIA  Ryan Whitney is a defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins, which explains why he had not scored in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

headline: Thursdays Free for Michaels
text: Al Michaels will not spend any of his Thursday nights in November and December working for the NFL Network after all. The channel looked into hiring Michaels, the play-by-play voice of NBC’s “Sunday Night Football,” a few weeks ago.

headline: A Mountain Paradise and Paradox
text: “The Adirondacks,” a two-hour special on most PBS stations on Wednesday night, offers a little history, a little culture and a whole lot of gorgeous, gauzy travelogue: misty mountain lakes, organic arugula at luxury resorts and straight-faced eco-spiritual narration (“the great green empire of leaves that took all spring and summer to build”). Watching it, some city dwellers will want to gag, and quite a few others will want to book a weekend on Saranac Lake.

headline: Dottie Rambo, Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 74
text: Dottie Rambo, a singer and prolific songwriter who was one of the most successful women to write songs in gospel music, died early Sunday when her tour bus ran off a highway near Mount Vernon, Mo. She was 74 and lived in Nashville.

headline: Factory Visit Tied to Ouster of Attachés From Russia
text: MOSCOW  The two American military attachés who were expelled from Russia early this month, days ahead of the Victory Day martial parade on Red Square, had made an uninvited visit to a military aviation factory in Siberia that Russia regards as strategic, several American officials said this week.

headline: Cuts in Medicaid May Mean Billion-Dollar Loss to New York for Training Doctors
text: New York’s public and private hospitals stand to lose more than $1 billion in state and federal funds for the training of doctors because of changes to the Medicaid program backed by the Bush administration, according to an analysis by the city’s Independent Budget Office released on Tuesday.

headline: Société Générale’s First-Quarter Profit Drops 23.4%
text: PARIS  Société Générale, the large French bank pummeled by a rogue trading scandal, reported Tuesday that its net profit fell 23.4 percent in the first quarter, although earnings beat the average market forecast. Net profit fell to 1.096 billion euros ($1.69 billion) mainly because of a 79 percent decline in net profit at its corporate and investment banking division and a loss at its global investment management unit.

headline: Indians Find U.S. at Fault in Food Cost
text: NEW DELHI  Instead of blaming India and other developing nations for the rise in food prices, Americans should rethink their energy policy  and go on a diet.

headline: Larousse Offers Online Encyclopedia
text: Wikipedia got a new rival on Tuesday, when the French publisher Larousse introduced an online French-language encyclopedia inviting users to contribute content and offering free access to its dictionary, Agence France-Presse reported. But larousse.fr said its contributors, unlike Wikipedia’s, would be identified. “People are more and more used to this abundance and are able to distinguish between reference articles and those expressing a point of view,” said Line Karoubi, the assistant director for dictionaries and encyclopedia at Larousse.

headline: North Korea Documents Make Debut, at a Distance
text: WASHINGTON  The State Department, seeking to ward off criticism, kicked off a public-relations offensive on Tuesday by offering reporters a view  from a distance  of nuclear documents that senior officials said appeared to represent a complete accounting of North Korea’s plutonium production.

headline: What You Get for ...$900,000
text: Fernandia Beach, Fla.

headline: Redesigning a Building to Preserve Peace in the Neighborhood
text: You have to pity any architect who appears before the landmarks committee of the Upper East Side’s community board. Packed with amateur preservationists, it is notoriously adverse to anything new.

headline: Ban on U.S. Chicken Imports Might End
text: The end of a decade-long European ban on poultry imports from the United States moved a step closer after the European Commission promised to put forward a formal proposal to lift the embargo. Still, the concession, which was made during talks between the European Union and the United States, is likely to come with conditions and would require the approval of individual European Union governments. The ban was imposed in 1997 because of the common practice in the United States of cleaning chicken carcasses with a chlorine wash. Policy makers in the United States say there is no evidence that the process is harmful to human health.

headline: John Edwards Endorses Barack Obama
text: At a rally in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Wednesday evening, John Edwards endorsed Barack Obama, who was on the stage with him, to be the Democratic nominee for president.

headline: ‘Wanderer’ Has Given Up Wandering
text: An Italian-American bluesman records a song in Florida. An Irish-American disc jockey plays it at a radio station in Woodstock, N.Y. He tells a friend from his old neighborhood in the Bronx about the song. And before you know it, Mexican teenagers whose families replaced the Irish in the tenements and row houses of Mott Haven are tapping their toes to the tune.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: City Revisits Old Bidders After Railyards Deal Fails
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s last-ditch effort to revive his ambitious plans for the West Side railyards ended on Tuesday after Tishman Speyer Properties failed to come to terms with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on a $1 billion deal.

headline: Discounters Fared Well in Quarter
text: It’s bargain time in American retailing.

headline: Italian’s Detention Illustrates Dangers Foreign Visitors Face
text: He was a carefree Italian with a recent law degree from a Roman university. She was “a totally Virginia girl,” as she puts it, raised across the road from George Washington’s home. Their romance, sparked by a 2006 meeting in a supermarket in Rome, soon brought the Italian, Domenico Salerno, on frequent visits to Alexandria, Va., where he was welcomed like a favorite son by the parents and neighbors of his girlfriend, Caitlin Cooper.

headline: Frank Talk About Obama and Islam
text: To the Editor:

headline: Detroit Council Seeks Mayor’s Ouster
text: DETROIT  The Detroit City Council voted on Tuesday to ask the governor of Michigan to remove the city’s mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, from office.

headline: Quirky Top-Floor Spaces in Demand for Offices
text: In their endless search for ways to maximize revenue in office buildings, Manhattan landlords and developers are looking up. They are creating new rentable space from top floors once used for storage or for housing building equipment, and they are figuring out how to use even small quantities of air rights.

headline: Saving Moynihan Station
text: New York City is a glorious place, but there is no glory in New York’s Penn Station. Unfortunately, plans to transform this abysmal place into a grand entryway called Moynihan Station have stalled, most recently because nobody is really in charge of the project. It is time to give the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey the lead role in rebuilding this major gateway.

headline: How Abu Ghraib Became the Anything-Goes Prison
text: A hooded prisoner standing on a box with wires dangling from his outspread arms. A pyramid made of naked human beings, stacked like cordwood, one on top of another. A woman holding what looks like a dog leash attached to a groveling prisoner. A naked prisoner cringing before a snarling police dog. Such heinous pictures of abuse at Abu Ghraib prison have become iconic images of the war in Iraq: gruesome symbols of what went wrong with the war and the occupation.

headline: Seams of Belgium’s Quilt Threaten to Burst
text: LIEDEKERKE, Belgium  If Belgium vanishes one day, it will be because of little towns like this one, where Flemish politicians are riding a new wave of nationalism and pushing for an independent state.

headline: Aid at the Point of a Gun
text: Mae Sot, Thailand

headline: Chaos in Court Hallway After Remy Ma Sentence
text: Remy Smith, the hip-hop artist convicted in March of shooting a friend in an angry tug of war over a purse, was sentenced on Tuesday to eight years in prison at an emotional court hearing that touched off violence moments later outside the court.

headline: Rauschenberg and Dance, Partners for Life
text: Something inherently theatrical about Robert Rauschenberg’s talent  always evident in his radical feeling for color, light, composition and new ingredients and juxtapositions prompted him to his boldest and freshest conceptions when he worked onstage. From the early 1950s until 2007 he designed for dance. And in the late ’50s and early ’60s, when he first came to fame, he was recurrently (at times constantly) occupied in dance theater.

headline: Budget Deal in Congress Tops Request From Bush
text: WASHINGTON  Senate and House Democrats said Tuesday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a budget blueprint that embodies their priorities and sets spending levels somewhat higher than President Bush had requested.

headline: Myanmar Government Still Blocking Relief
text: YANGON, Myanmar  Further deliveries of small-scale aid arrived in Myanmar on Tuesday  a darkly clouded and rainy day in Yangon and in the south  but international aid experts and diplomats here in the main city expressed concern that the government may not be up to delivering it, a task it has claimed almost exclusively as its own.

headline: Raspberry for Barry
text: WASHINGTON

headline: N.F.L. Says Tapes Add Nothing to Inquiry
text: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Tuesday that the former New England Patriots employee Matt Walsh had provided no new information about the team’s illicit videotaping tactics, and that the team and its coach, Bill Belichick, would not be punished further.

headline: The 24-Second Knicks Introduce Their Seven-Seconds-or-Less Coach
text: Donnie Walsh was two weeks into his coaching search when he got a call from Phoenix that changed everything. Steve Kerr, the Suns’ general manager, was on the line. He said that Mike D’Antoni, the Suns’ wildly successful coach, was available. Walsh’s reaction, like a Suns jump shot, came in seven seconds or less.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, the Big City column on Friday, about House of Spices, one of the businesses in Willets Point, Queens, that are suing the city over its failure to provide services like sewers to the neighborhood, misspelled the owner’s surname at one point in some copies. He is Gordhandas Soni, not Somni.

headline: Liberty Media in Accord With Diller’s Company
text: Liberty Media and IAC/InterActiveCorp said on Tuesday that they had settled their differences, paving the way for the division of IAC into five companies.

headline: National Endowment Salutes Opera
text: The United States government is honoring opera. The National Endowment for the Arts announced Tuesday that it was establishing yearly Opera Honors awards and named the first four recipients (right, from top): James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director; the soprano Leontyne Price; the composer Carlisle Floyd; and Richard Gaddes, general director of the Santa Fe Opera. Each receives a $25,000 prize. To put that $100,000 in context, the endowment is giving $2.5 million in direct opera grants this year and $7 million in other classical music grants, according to Dana Gioia, its chairman. Total grants to the arts are $72 million, with another $48 million sent to state arts councils to make their own allocations. Mr. Gioia said the awards have an “enormous symbolic value” and were established in part to stir awareness and appreciation of opera. While $25,000 could mean a lot more to a struggling singer, say, than to Mr. Levine, who may make more than that for a guest conducting engagement, Mr. Gioia called the prize “a lifetime achievement award.” “If the N.E.A. opera award is going to have credibility,” he added, “it has to recognize artists that work at the highest reaches of the art and to create, as it were, a hall of fame of American opera artists. It would be remiss, I think, not to start with the very best.”

headline: A Rescue in China, Uncensored
text: BEIJING  Mothers wailing over the bodies of their children. Emergency workers scrambling across pancaked buildings. And a grim-faced political leader comforting the stricken and reassuring an anguished nation.

headline: Ballet to Blush by (Think Sexy Bikinis, Not Prim Tutus)
text: Ballet insiders often complain that their art form is misunderstood as prissy and old-fashioned when, really, it is all about sexy, young things and sensual feats. Three of the works Configuration Dance presented at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Monday night seemed intended to underline this fact.

headline: For the Disabled, Age 18 Brings Difficult Choices
text: Outside Sam Stabiner’s room pumps the steady drone of ventilators, giving life to his neighbors breath by breath. Most are in their 80s and 90s, in the twilight of their years.

headline: In Paraguay, Time Melts in the Torpid Air
text: If the quality of a nation’s moviemaking trumps its quantity of production, Paraguay may possess one of the most vital cinemas in the world on the basis of a single film. That “Paraguayan Hammock” happens to be one of the few features to emerge from the country in recent decades in no way diminishes its rarity.

headline: Simple Potato Salad
text: Adapted from “Kids’ Kitchen: Good Food Made Easy,” by Amanda Grant (Mitchell Beazley, 2005)

headline: Tagliatelle With Mussels and Peas
text: Adapted from Trestle on Tenth

headline: An Experienced Hand in a Very Familiar Kitchen
text: Jean-Jacques Rachou certainly knows his way around this kitchen. The bustling stainless steel sprawl in the back of 60 West 55th Street was for years his base at La Côte Basque; it is now crammed with cooks working for Benoit, Alain Ducasse’s new restaurant at the same address.

headline: South Africa: Power Losses Trim Ore Output
text: South Africa, the world’s biggest precious metals producer, said mining output fell 17 percent in March because of power shortages. Gold production declined 11 percent from a year earlier, said Statistics South Africa, the national statistics agency. Output of metals other than gold fell 18 percent. Most mines in South Africa were shut for five days from Jan. 25.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bottled Water Paradox: Banned, and Required
text: After two years of extremely heated debate that included references to ecology, history, geography, and the politics of selling or buying mass-produced cupcakes, the Park Slope Food Co-op in Brooklyn voted at the end of last month to discontinue the sale of bottled water. It comes to about 670 gallons of water per week.

headline: Republicans Try to Regroup After Another Setback
text: House Republicans struggled to regroup Wednesday in the aftermath of a devastating election loss in Mississippi, acknowledging that their party faced a significant challenge in November after the loss of three Republican seats in special elections this year.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Weigh a Proxy Fight at Yahoo
text: The Microsoft-Yahoo merger story may not be over yet.

headline: In Paris, Owning an Eleventh of an Apartment
text: PARIS

headline: Blair Unveils Proposals to Improve Life on the West Bank
text: JERUSALEM  Tony Blair, the international envoy for Palestinian development, unveiled a package of West Bank proposals on Tuesday in a bid to show some movement in the faltering Israeli-Palestinian peace effort on the eve of a visit by President Bush.

headline: A City Cooler and Dimmer, and, Oh, Proving a Point
text: JUNEAU, Alaska  Conservationists swoon at the possibility of it all. Here in Alaska, where melting arctic ice and eroding coastlines have made global warming an urgent threat, this little city has cut its electricity use by more than 30 percent in a matter of weeks, instantly establishing itself as a role model for how to go green, and fast.

headline: Annika Sorenstam Announces Retirement
text: CLIFTON, N.J.  For a decade starting in the mid-1990s, Annika Sorenstam was the face of women’s golf: the winner of the most tournaments, the biggest money-winner, a fresh-faced native of Sweden who brought public attention to the L.P.G.A.

headline: Congress Votes to Stop Stockpiling Oil
text: WASHINGTON  Groping for a quick response to rising gas prices, Congress voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to order the Bush administration to stop depositing oil in a national reserve even though lawmakers predicted the impact for consumers would be modest at best.

headline: Bacon Painting Auctioned for Record $86 Million
text: A 1976 triptych painting by Francis Bacon brought a whopping $86.28 million Wednesday night at Sotheby’s big spring contemporary art sale. It was a record for the artist at auction and, seemingly, a retort to doomsayers who had predicted that the art market would falter seriously this season because of broad economic anxieties.

headline: Stuffed Chicken Breasts
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: ‘Gladiators’ Falls Flat
text: “American Gladiators,” NBC’s surprise hit during the writers’ strike, made a disappointing return to network television on Monday after a three-month hiatus, drawing just 4.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen reported. The athletic competition (with Randee Haynes, above left, and Hulk Hogan) showed promise when it made its debut in early January, attracting 12.1 million viewers and particularly high ratings among adults 18 to 49. Six weeks later, the last episode before the show went on hiatus attracted a much smaller audience (7.3 million). NBC finished fourth for the night over all, faring modestly better during the 10 p.m. hour with “Medium” (8.6 million). ABC led the night in total viewers, thanks to “Dancing With the Stars” at 8 (18.3 million) followed by the season finales of “Samantha Who?” at 9:30 (11 million) and “The Bachelor” at 10 (9.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC ranked third behind CBS, with its comedy lineup, and Fox, which eked out a victory in the 18-to-49 set courtesy of “House” at 9 (14.8 million), the night’s top-rated show among that age group. CBS won the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (13.7 million).

headline: ‘SportsCenter’ to Be Shown Live During the Day
text: After years of televising taped versions of “SportsCenter” in the mornings, ESPN announced Tuesday that the studio show would be live starting in August.

headline: Australian Bank Acquires Rival for $17.5 Billion
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Westpac Banking said Tuesday that it would acquire its smaller rival St. George in a takeover worth about 18.5 billion Australian dollars, or about $17.5 billion. The deal will create one of Australia’s largest banks.

headline: The Post-Bush Climate
text: John McCain has been engaged in the fight against global warming for years, even at the expense of breaking with Republican orthodoxy and with President Bush on the issue. But it was still an important moment this week when Mr. McCain, the presumed Republican presidential nominee, decided to raise the profile of climate change in the 2008 campaign. We have clearly entered the post-Bush era of policy and politics on climate change. However this election turns out, the United States will have a president who supports mandatory cuts in greenhouse gases. It is possible to begin to believe in the prospect of serious Congressional action.

headline: Robert Rauschenberg, American Artist, Dies at 82
text: Robert Rauschenberg, the irrepressibly prolific American artist who time and again reshaped art in the 20th century, died on Monday night at his home on Captiva Island, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Loving v. Virginia and the Secret History of Race
text: Americans born in the 21st century will shake their heads in disbelief on learning that 40 states once had laws prohibiting interracial marriage. The Supreme Court struck down the last of these statutes in the 1967 case of Mildred and Richard Loving, a black woman and a white man who were arrested and banished from Virginia for the crime of being married.

headline: Cookbook Publishers Try to Think Small
text: AT a time when 2-year-olds take cooking classes, trick-or-treaters turn up in chef’s whites and a personalized child’s size spatula costs $20, it is no surprise that the children’s cookbook genre is enjoying a new life.

headline: Shame on the Junta
text: After Cyclone Nargis devastated Myanmar, killing tens of thousands of people, the world rushed to offer help. Most governments would be grateful. Not this one. A week and a half later, the country’s ruling generals are still blocking large-scale foreign aid. That negligence could lead to the death of tens of thousands more.

headline: Brooklyn Boy, 9, Is Struck by a Car
text: A 9-year-old boy was critically injured in Brooklyn on Tuesday by a 16-year-old hit-and-run driver who later turned himself in, the police said.

headline: Oil Refiners See Profits Sink as Consumption Falls
text: While drivers are facing sticker shock at the pump these days, here is a bigger shock: high prices are putting a strain on oil refiners.

headline: Shmuel Katz, an Opponent of Begin’s Peace Effort, Dies at 93
text: Shmuel Katz, who was a close adviser to Menachem Begin, Israel’s prime minister in the late 1970s and early 1980s, but who later became a vociferous opponent of Begin’s peace efforts with Egypt and the Palestinians, died on Friday in Tel Aviv. He was 93.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about Bloomberg L.P.’s moves to bolster the journalism side of its business misstated the name of the cable channel introduced last fall by News Corporation as competition in business journalism heats up. It is Fox Business Network, not Fox Business News.

headline: Senate Approves $350 Million in Projects Intended for Economic Development
text: ALBANY  While state analysts are forecasting lean times, lawmakers are bankrolling what some see as a bumper crop of pork.

headline: Series of Blasts Leave 56 Dead in India
text: JAIPUR, India  In the first terrorist attack in many months, seven bombs went off within minutes of one another on Tuesday evening in the crowded lanes of one of India’s main tourist hubs, the historic city of Jaipur, killing 56 and wounding 84, officials said.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Is Facing Skepticism on E.D.S. Deal
text: Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has been a Wall Street darling ever since he joined the giant computer maker three years ago. The company’s profits surged as Mr. Hurd deftly cut costs, increased revenue and successfully integrated several acquisitions, including the $20 billion purchase of Compaq Computer made by his predecessor.

headline: McCain Backer Regrets Comments on Catholics
text: The Rev. John C. Hagee, whose anti-Catholic remarks created a controversy when Senator John McCain received his endorsement for the Republican presidential nomination with fanfare, has issued a letter expressing regret for “any comments that Catholics have found hurtful.”

headline: Quake Toll Rises; China Struggles to Reach Victims
text: YONG’AN, China  The battle for survival here is as stark as anywhere in the earthquake zone.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about a neurosurgeon who came to the United States as an illegal immigrant 21 years ago misstated the doctor’s given name in some copies. He is Alfredo Quiñones-Hinojosa, not Alberto.

headline: Craigslist’s Countersuit Criticizes eBay’s Tactics
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Craigslist, the online classified ad company, filed a countersuit Tuesday against its minority owner eBay, accusing it of unfair competition, false advertising, trademark infringement and diluting the value of the Craigslist trademark.

headline: At Barneys, the Chief Is Leaving After 7 Years
text: Barneys New York, the ultra-chic department store, confirmed on Tuesday that its chief executive, Howard Socol, intended to resign, leaving open a coveted job in the fashion world.

headline: Mayor Controls Smaller Pot for Council Discretionary Funds
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s office on Tuesday detailed a little-known pot of discretionary funds that it distributes to council members for use by community programs they consider worthy and said it would tighten the regulation of the funds.

headline: Stories to Explore Someone Else’s Skin
text: A waiter at Picholine sets down a plate in front of Nam Le: sea urchin panna cotta, a shell-pink colored disk that looks like a powder compact topped with tiny black beads of caviar.

headline: Case Against 9/11 Detainee Is Dismissed
text: The Pentagon official in charge of war crimes cases declined to permit a case to proceed against one of six detainees charged in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, dismissing charges against a Saudi who had been subjected to aggressive interrogation at the United States detention camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: For the Mets, New Faces, Better Result
text: Ryan Church hit the ball well, and he knew it, but that was the only thing he was certain of as he watched it soar toward right field with two outs in the sixth inning Tuesday night. So instead of watching the trajectory, he focused on Austin Kearns, the Nationals’ right fielder. More precisely, he looked at Kearns’s feet.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on May 6 about a new laser treatment for cancers of the larynx omitted the first word in the name of the organization that sponsored the meeting where a scientific report on the findings was presented. It is the American Broncho-Esophagological Association.

headline: This Year’s Tony List Is Filled With Unusual Suspects
text: The Tony nominations are in, and it would be difficult to come up with a season that presented a clearer portrait of where Broadway is headed and where it has been. The creative team behind “In the Heights,” a musical with a hip-hop, rap and salsa-infused score that led the field on Tuesday with 13 Tony nominations (including shots at best musical and best direction), is about as young as you get in a Broadway production: 6 of the show’s 11 individual nominees are under 33.

headline: Stumping on Climate, McCain Faults Bush
text: NORTH BEND, Wash.  Senator John McCain intensified his criticism of President Bush and the administration’s environmental polices on Tuesday, taking a walk in the cold, rain-drenched foothills of the Cascade Mountains and asserting that in the effort to stem climate change, “America can lead and not obstruct.”

headline: Pairings: Tagliatelle with Mussels and Peas
text: The bright minerality and hints of budding blooms and citrus that characterized the best Soaves we tasted made these wines perfect for a springtime palate. They suit tender greens, herbs and vegetables, and might not be daunted by difficult ones like asparagus and artichokes, and salads dressed with vinaigrette.

headline: The Art of Reciting a Tale, Across the Generations
text: Simply put, the triumph of successful acting is the audience’s belief that the falseness onstage is true.

headline: A Is for Amandine: A List for Beginners
text: HAVE children suddenly developed a passionate longing to cook? Or are adults just more determined to shepherd their young into the kitchen?

headline: Chamberlain and Gossage Chat
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain did not know Rich Gossage had a problem with him, but he was happy to take Gossage’s phone call on Tuesday. Gossage is a Hall of Fame reliever, and Chamberlain has a deep respect for baseball history.

headline: Join the Hunt for Super-Rice
text: There is no quick fix to the world food crisis, but a project getting underway Wednesday could make a difference in the long run.

headline: Hillary Clinton in West Virginia
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at a victory party in Charleston, W.Va., after winning the West Virginia primary May 13. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Rays Take Over Best Record in A.L., at the Yankees’ Expense
text: Cliff Floyd started in the major leagues when he was 20 years old, five years before Tampa Bay got a major league team in 1998. The region is still waiting for a winning major league team, and now that Floyd is 35, they have it.

headline: Corporate Express Rebuffs Staples’ Sweetened Offer
text: For the second time in nearly three months, struggling Corporate Express on Tuesday quickly rejected an increased takeover bid from U.S. rival office supplier Staples, saying the new offer still significantly undervalues the Dutch company.

headline: ING Reports Drop in First-Quarter Proift
text: Dutch financial services group ING Groep reported a bigger-than-expected 19 percent drop in quarterly net profit, hit by weaker returns from real estate, private equity and market investments.

headline: Nike May Run Off With an Asian Rival
text: Nike could buy a Chinese or Japanese rival to strengthen its presence in Asia, the brand president of the world’s largest maker of athletic footwear and apparel told a German newspaper.

headline: Relief on Société Générale’s Profit Report
text: Even as investors were sighing with relief on Tuesday over Société Générale‘s no-worse-than-expected first-quarter results, the French banking sector was hit with more bad news. Crédit Agricole announced plans to raise 5.9 billion euros, or $9.1 billion, to shore up its capital after further write-downs at its Calyon investment bank.

headline: Craigslist’s Countersuit Criticizes eBay’s Tactics
text: Craigslist, the online classified ad company, filed a countersuit Tuesday against its minority owner eBay, accusing it of unfair competition, false advertising, trademark infringement and diluting the value of the Craigslist trademark.

headline: Will Yahoo Shareholders Get Behind Icahn?
text: As news surfaced that Carl C. Icahn may go on the warpath at Yahoo, questions turned to what kind of support the billionaire investor and activist shareholder could expect — both from Microsoft and Yahoo shareholders alike.

headline: The Other Auction-Rate Problem
text: The seized-up market for auction-rate securities has caused headaches for the investors who bought them and the banks that sold them. Compliance Week points out another problem: Financial reporting executives need to figure out how to value them.

headline: All Quiet on the Deal Front as Electronic Arts Posts Loss
text: The video game publisher Electronic Arts posted a wider fourth-quarter loss on one-time charges on Tuesday, but its adjusted results fueled by game sales beat Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: BHP Won’t Rule Out Adding Cash to Rio Bid, Chief Says
text: BHP Billiton was not ruling out adding cash to its all-share hostile offer for rival Rio Tinto, BHP’s chief executive, Marius Kloppers, told CNBC.

headline: More Write-Downs Coming, Ex-Fed Official Says
text: Wall Street’s banks and brokers aren’t out of the woods yet, a former director of the Federal Reserve Board told The New York Post.

headline: Bank of America Forecasts Higher Home Equity Losses
text: Bank of America on Tuesday increased its forecast for expected losses from home equity loans, citing the deteriorating U.S. housing market.

headline: At Barneys, the Chief Is Leaving After 7 Years
text: Barneys New York, the ultra-chic department store, confirmed on Tuesday that its chief executive, Howard Socol, intended to resign, leaving open a coveted job in the fashion world.

headline: Harvard: A Tax-Free Hedge Fund?
text: A recent report in The Wall Street Journal that Massachusetts legislators are studying a plan to levy a 2.5 percent annual tax on the portion of college endowments that exceed $1 billion, had The American Scene pulling out its calculator and coming up with this conclusion: All Harvard University is, in fact, a just a tax-exempt hedge fund.

headline: JPMorgan May Cut 4,000 of Its Own
text: JPMorgan Chase could cut as many as 4,000 of its own employees worldwide as the bank prepares to take on staff from Bear Stearns at the same time it deals with turmoil in financial markets, Reuters reported.

headline: In Smart, Wealthy World, Schools Still Fall. Why?
text: I have a story up on the Chinese earthquake that I started reporting, in effect, in October 2005, when 17,000 students, trapped in more than 7,000 crumpled schools, were among the 70,000-plus victims of the extraordinary Kashmir-area earthquake in Pakistan. The potent temblor that hit China’s Sichuan province also exacted an outsize toll on schoolchildren, as several crowded schools pancaked into rubble. In recent years, it has been developing countries that have been most shaken by such events. But experts say there are plenty of schools in western Canada and the United States and other wealthy countries that could similarly tumble someday under assault from known seismic threats.

headline: Blackstone Launches Asia-Focused Hedge Fund Business
text: The Blackstone Group, manager of the world’s biggest leveraged buyout fund, said it had launched an Asian-focused hedge fund business to seek opportunities created by corporate events including mergers and bankruptcies.

headline: Diller and Malone Reach Accord in IAC Spinoff
text: Barry Diller and John C. Malone, it seems, have smoked the peace pipe.

headline: With E.D.S. Deal, Wall Street Turns on H-P’s Chief
text: Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has been a Wall Street darling ever since he joined the giant computer maker three years ago. The company’s profits surged as Mr. Hurd deftly cut costs, increased revenue and successfully integrated several acquisitions, including the $20 billion purchase of Compaq Computer made by his predecessor.

headline: Clear Channel Settlement Gives Hope to BCE Shareholders
text: News that Clear Channel Communications buyout is a go following a settlement with the six banks financing the deal may also be sweet music to shareholders of BCE, the Canadian telecom giant that agreed last year to sell itself to a private equity consortium in a 52 billion Canadian dollar ($51.3 billion) deal.

headline: Clear Channel Accepts Smaller Takeover Bid
text: Clear Channel Communications agreed on Tuesday to a revised $17.9 billion takeover by two private equity firms after settling a long and often acrimonious dispute with the six banks that agreed to finance the deal.

headline: Greentech Media Connects With V.C.’s
text: Venture capitalists, it seems, just can’t get enough of anything green. From alternative energy start-ups to organic beverages, V.C.’s are opening their wallets for environmentally-friendly business.

headline: NYSE Jumps on the Spac Bandwagon
text: NYSE Euronext, challenging the American Stock Exchange‘s historic dominance in listings of special-purpose acquisition companies, plans to list its first Spac later this month. The Spac is Heckmann Corporation, which made its debut on the American Stock Exchange in November but will jump from there to the NYSE Euronext on May 23.

headline: Should Private Equity Firms Double Down on Losing Bets?
text: Few things are more embarrassing for a private equity shop than seeing a portfolio company go toes-up. But, asks Breakingviews, should blushing buyout barons try to save face by doubling down and snapping up the failed company’s distressed debt?

headline: BrightSource Taps $115 Million in Fresh Funding
text: BrightSource Energy, the Oakland, Calif., solar thermal startup, has landed a hefty $115 million funding round to continue developing its solar power tower technology.

headline: Expresso Fitness Bulks Up With $12 Million
text: Expresso Fitness, which has created a more interactive experience for users looking to shed pounds on a stationary bike, such as virtual cycling courses, has raised $12 million in the second part of its third round of funding.
From The Onion:

headline: Banks Said to Prepare Sale of Alliance Boots Debt
text: Investment banks are poised to agree a plan to sell much of the 9 billion pounds ($17 billion) debt in Alliance Boots, the private equity-owned pharmacy chain, providing a crucial test of improving conditions in loan markets, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Uh-oh
text: More tech trouble on the way …

headline: The Dolans’ Conflict of Coverage
text: When there is news in his Cablevision empire, shouldn’t Jim Dolan be there? After all, says The New York Times’ Richard Sandomir, he is America’s newest newspaper mogul – Cablevision agreed to buy Newsday on Monday – but he was absent Tuesday when his Knicks introduced Mike D’Antoni as their coach.

headline: Upfronts: Previewing The CBS Schedule
text: Bill Carter reports:

headline: Charter Will Monitor Customers’ Web Surfing to Target Ads
text: Charter Communications, the fourth-largest cable system in the United States, has started telling its high-speed Internet customers that it is going to keep track of every site they visit on the Web.

headline: The Early Word: Endorsements for Obama as Clinton Touts Win
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton walloped Barack Obama in West Virginia’s Democratic primary Tuesday night, beating him by 41 points.

headline: Under 30, and in Nursing Homes
text: As medical advances have allowed patients who might have died as children to survive into adulthood, the patients are falling into a void in a health care system that has yet to develop institutions for the young and “medically fragile,” Marc Santora reports. Each year 500,000 youths in the United States with special health care needs resulting from ailments like congenital heart disease, cystic fibrosis, diabetes, renal disease and sickle cell turn 18, according to a survey conducted by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. Many of these young people will transition to adulthood smoothly, but for the most seriously disabled, the options for care often prove limited.

headline: Geometries | The Renwick Ruin
text: The former Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island is now known as the Renwick Ruin for its architect, James Renwick Jr., who also designed St. Patrick’s Cathedral. It has been abandoned for about half a century, and is the only ruin in New York City with official landmark status.

headline: Upfronts: Live-blogging CBS’s New Schedule
text: 9:30: “Moonlight,” the freshman vampire drama, is not coming back. Recalling the outcry when “Jericho” was cancelled, prompting tons of peanut deliveries to CBS, a reporter asked: “Are you prepared for whatever the fans of that one are going to send you?”

headline: The Wind From West Virginia
text: What if they held a primary and nobody noticed?

headline: The political scene

headline: The Unsung Royals
text: The most underrated closer in baseball may be Kansas City’s Joakim Soria. While Mariano Rivera, who is arguably the greatest closer in baseball history, gave up his first run of the season Tuesday night, Soria’s scoreless streak continued as he secured the Royals’ 3-2 victory over the Tigers. It was Soria’s ninth save in nine chances.

headline: Our Favorite Horse

headline: Chicken Breasts Get a (Slightly) Fancy Filling
text: My contention in today’s Minimalist column is that, more often than not, stuffing is more for appearance than for flavor. I know that stuffing is a venerable and lovely tradition, and certainly one of the world’s great foods — sausage — wouldn’t exist without it. But is it not true that in most cases the stuffing and the food being stuffed would taste just as good side by side? My recipe — a sandwich of chicken breasts enclosing cooked spinach — might make the flavor of the spinach slightly more complex, but I like the recipe mostly because it’s about the easiest way I know to make boneless chicken breasts look fancy.

headline: How to Beat the Euro
text: Yes, the euro has reached new heights against the once-mighty dollar. But exchange rates aren’t the only things conspiring to shrink our travel budgets; most credit card issuers and banks in the United States levy fees whenever you use their cards abroad.

headline: ’57 States’

Yeah, after hearing this, President Bush said, “Ha-ha, he forgot Alaska and Hawaii.”

headline: Patience Wears Thin as Yankees Slump Continues

headline: The Boris Yeltsin Russians Remember

headline: Misfits: Sprinters in France
text: My friend Jean-Yves and I were commiserating the other day as we walked our horses back from the gallops. We both were sitting on 5-year-old sprinters of rather limited talent, and it was getting harder and harder to find a race where we might have a chance. There are more than 150 tracks across France, and a horse that isn’t making the grade at the big venues around Paris can often run with some success at the smaller country tracks — unless you’re stuck with a sprinter.

headline: Unimaginable Crimes
text: I don’t know about you, but one of the first things I thought of when I heard about Josef Fritzl — the 73-year-old Austrian who held his daughter prisoner for 24 years and fathered seven children with her — was John Fowles’s 1963 novel, “The Collector.” In the book, Frederick drugs a 20-year-old art student, Miranda, and imprisons her in a basement/dungeon. In the real world, Josef drugged his 18-year-old daughter, Elisabeth, and imprisoned her in a basement/dungeon. An article in Der Spiegel even refers to Fritzl as a kind of “collector.”

headline: What is the Grand Tour?
text: To some people, it implies an extended jaunt around Western Europe. To others, it’s simply a long trip taken after college, whether to Southeast Asia, Central America or Southern France. In fact, the Grand Tour is all of these and more. Even though the basic contours of the Grand Tour were established in the 17th century — as a kind of cultural finishing school for affluent young gents — it has mutated to meet the shifting demands of generations of travelers.

headline: The Starting Line: The Aftermath of Disaster in China and Kenya
text: The horrifying aftermath of Monday’s massive earthquake in Sichuan province wears on, with the death toll rising to a reported 15,000. How China can successfully stage the Beijing Olympics in less than three months in an open question, but there have been past instances where countries that have suffered devastating disasters were able to persevere and put on huge world sporting events. Probably the best example was Mexico’s succesful staging of the 1986 World Cup just eight months after an earthquake in the capital killed some 25,000 people.

headline: Who’s on First? A Matter of Albany Protocol
text: Sit through enough of them, and you’ll quickly realize that the news conference is a form of political theater, but one with strict forms to be observed. Among them: The order in which the various politicians in the room get to speak. In Albany, governors go first. Then, usually, goes the Senate majority leader or the Assembly speaker. Then go the minority leaders of the Senate and Assembly, if they get invited.And then — if they’re lucky or influential or there’s enough time — go the individual senators or Assembly members who sponsored the legislation, along with (maybe) some advocacy group leaders.

headline: Zimbabwe: Presidential Runoff Delayed
text: Without giving an exact date for the presidential runoff, the government announced a delay in the election, reporting in a brief published notice that the vote would take place within 90 days of May 2, not in 21 days as the election law stipulates. May 2 was the date official results of the disputed March 29 election were finally released. In that vote, the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, finished ahead of President Robert Mugabe, but without the majority needed for a first-round victory.
