text: JERSEY CITY

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about the discovery of a dead baby red-tailed hawk on the West Side of Manhattan misstated the photographer’s surname. He is D. Bruce Yolton, not Yallon.

headline: House Backs Farm Bill With Numbers to Beat Veto
text: WASHINGTON  The House overwhelmingly approved a $300 billion farm bill on Wednesday afternoon, making it probable that the measure will become law despite President Bush’s anticipated veto.

headline: To End the Death Penalty
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Terrified Monks
text: XIAHE, China

headline: Connecting Game Players to Build a Sense of Loyalty
text: Back in the analog era, delivering mass entertainment meant helping people connect with a character, a brand or a franchise. Few companies were more successful with that approach than Disney, with its stable of pop culture stars.

headline: Alou Loses Cool, Heilman Loses Control and Mets Lose a Game
text: On a chilly night, Moises Alou lost his cool. Normally undemonstrative, Alou was ejected for protesting a called third strike in the fifth inning. It was not the main reason the Mets lost, 5-3, to the Washington Nationals at Shea Stadium on Wednesday night. But it indicated a larger point: The Mets seemed to have things under control, until they did not.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Beverlee McKinsey, a soap opera actress, referred imprecisely to the date of her death. It was Friday, May 2  not the Friday the obituary was published.

headline: Ranked No. 1 in World, Henin Decides to Retire
text: In January, when Justine Henin was riding a 32-match victory streak, retirement seemed as preposterous a thought as a switch to a two-handed backhand.

headline: When Life at the Top Isn’t Enough of a Life
text: Life happens. Sooner or later, that crackling backhand winner is not as thrilling, measured against the exhilaration of impending adulthood.

headline: Persecuted to Powerful: Exhibiting a History of New York’s Catholics
text: Hundreds of years ago, there was a tiny religious minority so despised and persecuted that it was forced to build its own educational, social-welfare and political infrastructure just to survive in the city of New York. Improbably enough, this subculture ultimately seized power from the entrenched majority, became the city’s largest Christian group, created institutions that affected everyone in the five boroughs and permanently changed what it meant to be a New Yorker.

headline: British Bank Chief Expects No Relief From Inflation
text: LONDON  The Bank of England painted a bleak picture of Britain’s economy on Wednesday, saying that it expected inflation to accelerate, making further rate cuts unlikely.

headline: Obama Secret Service Agent Tied to Sex Joke
text: WASHINGTON  A Secret Service supervisor who until recently was a leader of Senator Barack Obama’s security detail sent several colleagues an e-mail message in 2005 that included a crude sexual joke about blacks and American Indians, according to documents disclosed last week as part of a lawsuit by black Secret Service agents.

headline: Improvements in New Orleans Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Castillo Will Probably Go on the D.L.
text: More than two hours before the Mets played the Washington Nationals at Shea Stadium on Wednesday, the injured second baseman Luis Castillo worked out to check his injured left quadriceps.

headline: Ex-Rival Edwards Throws His Support to Obama
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  John Edwards gave his long-awaited endorsement to Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday, bolstering Mr. Obama’s efforts to rally the Democratic Party around his candidacy and offering potential help in his efforts to win over working class white voters in the general election.

headline: Aid Groups Say Myanmar Food Stolen by Military
text: YANGON, Myanmar  The directors of several relief organizations in Myanmar said Wednesday that some of the international aid arriving into the country for the victims of Cyclone Nargis was being stolen, diverted or warehoused by the country’s army.

headline: Chinese Soldiers Rush to Bolster Weakened Dams
text: CHENGDU, China  China mobilized 30,000 additional soldiers to the earthquake-shattered expanses of the nation’s southwestern regions on Wednesday  not just to help victims, but also to shore up weakened dams and other elements of the infrastructure whose failure could compound the disaster.

headline: Tip of the Week: Upload Photos to the Web From Your Cellphone
text: Posting to YouTube, Flickr, Facebook, Twitter or a blog on the go from your mobile phone can be simplified with a little help from ShoZu, a free program at www.shozu.com. ShoZu works with phones from most wireless carriers and lets you quickly upload and tag photos taken with your phone, read and reply to online comments and download your friends’ feeds. There’s a desktop version of ShoZu available as well for one-click uploading from your computer to your favorite social sites.

headline: Hit Man’s Dilemma: Sly Widow, Nasty Boss
text: A third of the way into Thomas Perry’s latest game of strategy, two strangers find themselves at an impasse. They are both in her bedroom. He is a hired killer. She is a recent widow. She has been sleeping; he’s been watching. He wants her dead.

headline: Diversity Isn’t Rocket Science, Is It?
text: BACK in the bad old days, the workplace was a battleground, where sexist jokes and assumptions were the norm.

headline: How to Drive a Contractor Crazy
text: 1. Avoid making decisions.

headline: We’ll Have to Check, Sir
text: Pity the innocent air traveler whose name repeatedly registers as a match on the government’s mammoth terrorist watch list. One major airline registers 9,000 false hits every day, according to Michael Chertoff, the secretary of homeland security. These travelers and thousands more must routinely step aside and provide firmer proof of identity.

headline: War Over Wall Persists in Sadr City Despite Truce
text: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi soldier was watching over the concrete wall on Monday when a .50-caliber round ripped into his head.

headline: Its Roster Is a Bargain, but Florida Is a Handful
text: The Florida Marlins were not supposed to be this good. Not the $22 million Marlins. Not a team that traded its premier position player and its most durable starting pitcher less than six months ago. Not the easy-to-forget Marlins. Not this season, anyway.

headline: Ceramics as Table Art, on Sale
text: Marek Cecula, a designer who formerly headed the ceramics department at Parsons School of Design in New York and now has studios here and in Poland, is selling his discontinued Industrial Line at a 50 percent discount. Dinnerware and tabletop accessories include: a sugar and creamer set ($30); dinner plates ($10 each), salad plates ($7 each) and dessert plates ($5 each); and pitchers in various sizes ($7 to $22). The sale begins Thursday, and continues until the stock is depleted, at Mxyplyzyk, 125 Greenwich Avenue (West 13th Street), (800) 243-9810.

headline: Russia: Clashes Kill 9 Near Chechnya
text: Six insurgents were killed in fighting against government troops this week in Ingushetia, the predominantly Muslim Russian republic adjacent to Chechnya, a Russian general said. Three police officers were later shot dead there by insurgents, who fled. With Chechnya largely under the control of local forces aligned with the Kremlin, many remaining insurgents have moved to Ingushetia. Col. Gen. Sergei Bunin, chief of staff of Russian interior forces, said 50 insurgents had been killed in Ingushetia this year, according to a local report. The tally could not immediately be confirmed.

headline: Shopping for Flowers with De Juan Stroud
text: DE JUAN STROUD loves flowers. He holds them, sniffs them, looks deeply into their petals and studies their shading. Sometimes, if they don’t look quite right, he shakes them vigorously, oblivious to the snow of petals falling to the ground.

headline: Library of Congress Adds to Aural Archive
text: The first trans-Atlantic broadcast, on March 14, 1925; Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia’s reading of the comics in 1945; and Michael Jackson’s 1982 best-seller “Thriller” were among 25 recordings added Wednesday to the Library of Congress’s National Recording Registry, The Associated Press reported. The archive is part of the library’s endeavor to preserve America’s aural history through recordings deemed “culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.” Other selections this year included Harry S. Truman’s speech at the 1948 Democratic National Convention; the original-cast recording of “My Fair Lady” from 1956; and music by Tommy Dorsey, Roy Orbison, Joni Mitchell and Herbie Hancock.

headline: Man Sought in Killing of Estranged Wife
text: A Bronx woman was found dead in a Lower East Side parking garage late on Tuesday, and the police said on Wednesday that her estranged husband was wanted for questioning.

headline: French Court Convicts 7 for Helping to Send Youths to Join Jihadist Fight in Iraq
text: PARIS  A Paris court sentenced seven men to prison terms of up to seven years on Wednesday for helping to send French youths to fight alongside insurgents in Iraq, ending a four-year investigation into a jihadist recruitment ring.

headline: Plea in Case That Toppled Spitzer
text: The woman accused of being the primary booker for the prostitution ring patronized by Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty on Wednesday morning to charges related to her role in the ring.

headline: Collateral Foreclosure Damage for Condo Owners
text: Barbara Sanz has never missed a mortgage payment, but the plunge in real estate is punishing condominium owners like her anyway.

headline: Child Welfare Tightens Law on Removal
text: New York City has enacted a tough new policy that allows the authorities to remove newborns from their parents’ homes in all but an “extraordinary instance” if the parents previously had children taken from their custody and their case is still open.

headline: Cup of Southern Joy (Northern, Too)
text: John Ellis is a North Carolina-born tenor saxophonist with a smart and generous flow who’s spent a lot of time studying and playing in New Orleans. But he’s a New Yorker now, and his new band, Double-Wide, combines musicians of both cities. Gary Versace, who plays Hammond organ, lives here; the sousaphone player Matt Perrine and the drummer Jason Marsalis live in New Orleans.

headline: Green, but Hardly Minimal
text: Riverhouse, a 264-unit condominium in Battery Park City being marketed as the latest in environmental sustainability, has amenities like photovoltaic cells that generate solar power and an ultraviolet light that kills bacteria in the pool, reducing the need for chlorine. It also has a 2,000-square-foot model apartment with an unusually ornate take on green design. Thom Filicia, the designer, who stars in “Dress My Nest,” a show about fashion-inspired interiors, maintains that “the green look doesn’t have to be a green minimalist look.” The space he created for a fictional pair of empty-nesters relocating from the Upper East Side is filled with tribal art objects and patterned textiles  all antiques, recycled materials or sustainable materials, he said. The bedroom has a bamboo mattress, a throw pillow filled with kapok and a bamboo knitted throw that he said feels like cashmere. “When people hear the word kapok or the word bamboo, they don’t think of a luxurious feel, but the way things are woven and spun now, bamboo can go from the floor to the bed,” he said.

headline: Italian Trial of C.I.A. Operatives Begins With Torture Testimony
text: MILAN  A long-delayed trial of C.I.A. operatives and former top Italian intelligence officials moved forward here on Wednesday, as a judge ruled that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi could be called to testify about the abduction of a radical Muslim cleric here in 2003.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Tony nominations misstated the age of Arthur Laurents, who was nominated for his direction of “Gypsy.” He is 90, not 89. (The error also appeared on March 23 in an Arts & Leisure article about Laura Benanti, who stars in “Gypsy” as Louise, who becomes Gypsy Rose Lee.)

headline: Leonard Cohen, Live Again
text: Leonard Cohen received a standing ovation from a sold-out house when he stepped onstage Sunday for his first show in 14 years, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The appearance by the 73-year-old singer and songwriter at the 700-seat Playhouse in Fredericton, New Brunswick, began a 48-date tour that will take him to 14 countries in coming months. He played two sets of eight songs each and four encores. The list included 1960s standards like “Suzanne,” “Bird on the Wire” and “So Long, Marianne.”

headline: What She Saw at 2 Revolutions, and Other Festivities
Taking Control of Repairing Your Computer
text: LEMONADE and computer keyboards do not mix. I learned that the hard way a few weeks ago, when my stepdaughter accidentally spilled some onto her iBook laptop. Over the phone, I told her how to remove the keyboard and blot up the mess.

headline: How to Juggle Windows on Mac
text: Q. What is the easier way to run the Windows operating system on Intel-based Macintosh hardware  Boot Camp or a program like Parallels?

headline: In a Kyrgyz Garden, Unburied Soviet Memories
text: RAZANSAI, Kyrgyzstan  In this remote corner of the former Soviet Union, life has shrunk to the size of the basics: tomatoes; corn; apricot trees; baby goats.

headline: Mexico: Police Chiefs Seek Asylum
text: Attacks on Mexican police officers by drug cartels have escalated so severely that three police chiefs have sought asylum in the United States in recent months, saying their lives are in danger, Customs and Border Protection officials said. The officials did not identify the officers. Since President Felipe Calderón began an offensive against drug cartels a year and a half ago, more than 200 police officers have been killed.

headline: Physical Culture | For Triathletes, How Exact a Fit?
text: LATELY, triathletes have become curious about a new crop of flashy-looking running shoes aimed squarely at them. But the question remains: Do they really need separate running shoes, or is this just another way to get triathletes, who are known for their love of new gear, to spend even more money?

headline: Relying on the Horse, but Not Protecting It
text: One of the most viscerally intimidating moments I have ever had was in Hyde Park in London a few years ago. With the Grateful Dead in my headset, I was stretching for a workout on the lush grass, a few feet away from a tranquil pathway, when I felt the earth shake.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on April 22 about the growing scrutiny faced by Patricia J. Lancaster, then New York City’s buildings commissioner, after a series of fatal construction accidents misstated the location of one accident, in which a window installer fell from a condominium tower when a safety strap failed. The tower is on the East Side of Manhattan, not in Queens.

headline: Newly Released
text: May’s list of new books comes weighted with accolades, from within publishing and without. One of this month’s authors has been declared a genius; another is one of the year’s most influential people, according to Time magazine (for writing, of all things, a series of teen-theme vampire novels). Others have just received very, very good reviews. Will such distinctions sell copies? That remains to be seen.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A photograph on Tuesday with an article about the lead-up to a special Congressional election in Mississippi carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of Greg Davis, the Republican candidate, shown with Vice President Dick Cheney, was by Rogelio V. Solis of The Associated Press  not by Thomas Busler via The Associated Press.

headline: For St. John’s, Home Is Where the Talent Is
text: In a sport dominated by teams based in warmer climates, the St. John’s baseball program is an anomaly. The Red Storm has become a consistent winner in the Northeast by relying largely on local players from what is considered by many scouts to be a shallow talent pool.

headline: A Weapon in the Identity Theft Battle
text: Although I try hard to be careful about personal papers  I recycle generic papers but chuck the parts with my name on them into the trash  someone opened a J. C. Penney account in my name not long ago, charging over $300. So the other day I took home a weapon: a nifty-looking, 9 1/4-inch handheld number called the Ziszor ($39.95 at www.ziszor.com).

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article by The Associated Press on Monday about the crash of a medical helicopter in Wisconsin misstated the make of the helicopter. It was a Eurocopter EC135, not EC13.

headline: Where Parking Rules the Days, a Little Miracle
text: It is a routine so ingrained in the New Yorker’s life that it seems to have always existed: And on the sixth day, God created man. And on the seventh day, while God rested, man had to go move his car because of alternate-side parking rules.

headline: It’s No Hallucination: Polka-Dot Buses Aim to Cut Travel Time
text: No, there are no illegal drugs being handed out as passengers begin their morning commutes: For the past few weeks, those seats on the M23 crosstown bus really have been decorated with light and dark blue bubbles.

headline: Leaping Puffballs, Floating Demons and Lots of Gyrating Whatsits
text: “Passion,” a 75-minute show presented by Momix, strikes me as sensationalist trash so brightly harmless that I wish I could fall in line with those who enjoy it as sheer sensation. Its main genre of movement is a lyrical, musical and theatrical arrangement of acrobatics. Its images evoke flora and fauna selected from various points in the Darwinian chain of evolution, and imaginary species too: centaurs, pushmi-pullyu, spinning puffballs with feet and more.

headline: F.D.A. Delays Clinical Trial of Embryonic Stem Cells
text: The Geron Corporation announced Wednesday that its plans to begin the first clinical trial using embryonic stem cells had been delayed by federal regulators.

headline: House Passes Farm Bill by a Veto-Proof Margin
text: WASHINGTON  Ignoring a veto threat from President Bush, who says he wants to sharply limit government subsidies to farmers at a time of near-record commodity prices and soaring global demand for grain, the House on Wednesday approved a five-year, $307 billion farm bill with a solid bipartisan majority.

headline: No Charges Against Winehouse
text: The Grammy Award-winning singer Amy Winehouse, 24, will not be charged in connection with a video segment that appeared to show her using drugs, The Associated Press reported on Wednesday, citing her spokesman Chris Goodman. The police questioned her about the footage for nine hours last week.

headline: Europe Expanding Inquiry on Availability of Drugs
text: BRUSSELS  European antitrust investigators are expanding their inquiry into the pharmaceutical market to determine whether companies are blocking generic drug makers from getting less-expensive medicines to market quickly.

headline: Historical Tremors
text: San Francisco

headline: Price Data Suggests Slowdown Is Cooling Inflation
text: Consumer prices edged up slightly in April, but far more slowly than many economists had expected, the government reported Wednesday, lending credence to the view that a slowing economy is applying the brakes to inflation.

headline: Alaska: Gasoline Averaging $4 a Gallon
text: Alaska has become the first state with an average gasoline pump price exceeding $4 a gallon, as rising oil costs are passed along to motorists, according to AAA. Regular gasoline averaged $4.006 a gallon in the state Wednesday, up from $3.983 the day before, according to AAA. Gasoline prices have surged this year on rising crude oil and declining supplies. Nationwide, pump prices have risen about 67 cents since the end of December to an average $3.758 a gallon.

headline: Eco-Friendly Paths to Exfoliation
text: AFTER Laura Noss signed up to receive a weekly organic produce box from a farm near her home in Menlo Park, Calif., she decided that fruits and vegetables grown close to home taste better.

headline: Sean Penn’s Fiery Revolt
text: Defying France’s strict new antismoking laws, Sean Penn, right, president of the jury at the 61st Cannes Film Festival, lighted a cigarette at a news conference yesterday, Agence France-Presse reported. After a couple of puffs in defiance of rules that banned smoking in enclosed spaces since January, he put the cigarette aside and returned to answering reporters’ questions. But a jury member, the Iranian writer and director Marjane Satrapi, prompting laughter, then asked if anyone minded if she smoked “for medical reasons.” She lighted a cigarette; Mr. Penn and the French actress Jeanne Balibar joined her.

headline: Telecom Deal by Germans in Greece
text: ATHENS  Greek officials said Wednesday that the government had sold a 3 percent stake in the country’s public telecommunications operator to Deutsche Telekom, the largest telephone company in Europe.

headline: All Over the Map (and Timeline) Seeking Wisdom
text: A strange phenomenon can be observed over at Classic Stage Company, an upending of the natural chronological order of things. A 2,400-year-old play is being staged there by Target Margin Theater but updated with all sorts of 21st-century references. The strange part is that it’s those 21st-century references that feel old.

headline: Republican Election Losses Stir Fall Fears
text: WASHINGTON  The Republican defeat in a special Congressional contest in Mississippi sent waves of apprehension across an already troubled party Wednesday, with some senior Republicans urging Congressional candidates to distance themselves from President Bush to head off what could be heavy losses in the fall.

headline: At the Cavendish, One Card and an Awful Lot of Points
text: The winners of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs on Sunday in Henderson, Nev., were Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

headline: Bacon Triptych Auctioned for Record $86 Million
text: A 1976 triptych by Francis Bacon brought $86.3 million on Wednesday night at Sotheby’s, becoming the most expensive work of contemporary art ever sold at auction and a retort to doomsayers who had predicted that the art market would falter seriously this season because of broad economic anxieties.

headline: Cashman Under Fire as Yankees Struggle
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The top baseball operations executive under Hank and Hal Steinbrenner in the Yankees’ hierarchy is General Manager Brian Cashman, whose contract expires after the season. The more the Yankees lose, and the more impatient Hank Steinbrenner becomes, the more speculation Cashman faces on his future.

headline: Neil Diamond, Chart Topper
text: For Neil Diamond the 46th time is a charm. His new CD, “Home Before Dark” (Columbia), became the first of his 46 charting albums to reach No. 1. His second record with the producer Rick Rubin, it sold 146,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, thanks in part to high-profile promotional appearances. Billboard’s Top 10 this week is packed with new releases, though sales were relatively slow. The country star Toby Keith, No. 2 with his new “35 Biggest Hits” (Show Dog Nashville), sold 103,000 copies; Madonna’s “Hard Candy” (Warner Brothers) fell two to No. 3 in its second week out, with 94,000 in sales; Clay Aiken’s new “On My Way Here” (RCA) sold slightly less to reach No. 4. (The figures are rounded.) Down the chart Gavin DeGraw opened at No. 7 with his self-titled album on J Records; Josh Groban’s new CD/DVD package “Awake Live” (Reprise) is No. 8; Dierks Bentley’s “Greatest Hits: Every Mile a Memory” (Capitol Nashville) bows at No. 9; and Luis Miguel’s new “Complices” (Warner Music Latina) is No. 10.

headline: Underserved Communities and City Council Funds
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Hum of Summer
text: IT’S time to go outside, take a deep breath of fresh air, and . . . mow.

headline: Inside a Case Against 2 Men Who Sold Arms
text: Last spring, while flying in custody from Romania to New York, a Syrian arms dealer named Tareq Mousa al-Ghazi turned to the American agent sitting next to him on the plane and asked why he had just been arrested. The agent told Mr. Ghazi that the United States government was, in fact, interested in one of his business partners, court papers say: a wealthier and much more prolific arms dealer named Monzer al-Kassar.

headline: The Earthquake in China: A Closer Look
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russia: German Foreign Minister Visits
text: The Kremlin rolled out the red carpet for the German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the first foreign official to hold talks with President Dmitri A. Medvedev and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin since they took up their new positions last week. Mr. Steinmeier had hoped to bring to Moscow an agreement from the European Union to begin negotiations on a long-delayed trade and cooperation accord. But European countries failed Tuesday to agree on how to begin despite an agreement reached in Lithuania on Sunday that should have allowed the talks to proceed.

headline: If It’s Eye Care Technology, This Must Be Orange County
text: THAT Orange County, Calif., has become a center of small companies developing devices for eye care is no coincidence.

headline: He-and-She Act, Working on a Cabaret Thing, Baby
text: The husband-and-wife team of Marilyn McCoo and Billy Davis Jr. are a prime illustration of how pop culture, which seems so complex at any given moment, eventually congeals into a nostalgic cavalcade in which distinctions among musical styles and eras begin to dissolve.

headline: O.K., Avatar, Work With Me
text: WHEN Nintendo released the Wii 18 months ago, it upended the notion of what video games could be. Moving beyond the sunlight-deprived young men at gaming’s core, Nintendo appealed to the rest of the world with an intuitive, family-friendly entertainment experience.

headline: No Rebates for You
text: Immigrant restrictionism is stiffing hundreds of thousands of American citizens and legal residents out of their tax-rebate checks.

headline: Lebanon at the Edge
text: President Bush claims Lebanon’s 2005 “Cedar Revolution”  which ended 30 years of Syrian military occupation  as a triumph of his policy of democracy promotion. Given Lebanon’s history, that was always naïve. Lebanon is now in deep trouble, and Mr. Bush, who will be meeting Prime Minister Fouad Siniora in Egypt on Sunday, has no real plan to help overcome the crisis.

headline: Mrs. McCain Sells Funds Tied to Sudan
text: WASHINGTON  Cindy McCain, the wife of the Republican presumptive nominee for president, has sold off at least $2 million she held in funds with investments in Sudan businesses.

headline: Big Brown Weathering Storm (and He Hasn’t Run Yet)
text: BALTIMORE  Big Brown was more or less bronzed as a great horse Wednesday by the Pimlico Race Course oddsmaker Frank Carulli, who made him the 1-to-2 favorite for the 133rd running of the Preakness Stakes. The owners and trainers of his 12 challengers here lavished praise on Big Brown, the Kentucky Derby-winning colt, at the post-position draw Wednesday. The only thing missing from Big Brown’s coronation?

headline: G.E. May Sell Appliance Division
text: General Electric is planning to sell its appliance division, one of the oldest businesses in the conglomerate’s 120-year history, people briefed on the proposal said Wednesday.

headline: It’s a Touch-Screen Phone, but You Can Still Hunt and Peck
text: The invasion of the multimedia touch-screen phones continued last week as the Samsung Glyde landed in Verizon Wireless stores. Although the Glyde’s icon-filled 2.8-inch screen looks familiar, the phone features a slide-out keyboard for people who like the feel of physical buttons when pecking out e-mail and text messages.

headline: A Meeting Is Helpful, but Mussina Helps More
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Hank Steinbrenner visited Tropicana Field on Wednesday to see his team in person. He had criticized the Yankees for two days, questioning their attitude and hunger and bemoaning the lack of offense.

headline: Merrill Tries to Temper the Pollyannas in Its Ranks
text: Sometimes Wall Street seems a bit like the make-believe Lake Wobegon: Most stocks are above average, and it is always a good time to buy.

headline: Sichuan’s Migrant Sprawl Now a Network of Worry
text: SHANGHAI  Li Suyue left Sichuan two years ago and traveled the 1,000 miles here for a job in a small restaurant. Now, days after the earthquake that struck her province, she is distraught, unable to go to work. She constantly tries to call home.

headline: A Victory Plan for Hillary
text: Hillary Clinton scored a whopping victory in West Virginia. Trounced Barack Obama, who is consistently described as the inevitable presidential nominee.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Wednesday about a trip by Senator John McCain to Washington State to talk about climate issues misstated part of the name of a lake that he visited. It is Chester Morse Lake, not Morris.

headline: Out With Vegas, In With Vamp
text: AT 6 p.m. last Tuesday, the elevator doors opened on the eighth floor of Macy’s in Herald Square, exhaling shoppers squished to the shape of sausages and inhaling the echoing sound of a woman’s British-accented voice.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Plan a Proxy Battle at Yahoo
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor and activist shareholder, has decided to move ahead with plans for a proxy fight at Yahoo and will propose a dissident slate of directors, people with knowledge of the plans said Wednesday.

headline: Graduation Day, the Wearable Kind
text: COUNT on the young to carry off the brashness of their convictions. At a reception in Manhattan last week for year-end design awards at Parsons the New School for Design, graduating students did just that, arriving in nervy new turnouts that rated a spin on the runway.

headline: Making Their Own Limits in a Spiritual Partnership
text: Bowie, Ariz.

headline: The Promise of Green Paint
text: WHEN it comes to building, renovating and maintaining a home, paint is a little like milk: it’s a staple, a basic ingredient. And much like milk, a product that helped make the organic food movement a mass-market phenomenon, paint is leading the expansion of the green building movement, as stricter regulations, pressure from environmental groups and increasing consumer demand for eco-friendly products force manufacturers to produce paints with fewer dangerous and smog-producing compounds.

headline: Larry Levine, an Inventor of ‘Wall of Sound,’ Is Dead at 80
text: Larry Levine, the recording engineer who helped create Phil Spector’s groundbreaking “wall of sound” technique on hit records by the Crystals, the Ronettes and the Righteous Brothers, died May 8 at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Schwarzenegger Has Plan to Close State Budget Gap
text: LOS ANGELES  To close California’s huge budget gap, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has a plan: get a Wall Street investment firm to lend the state $15 billion against future proceeds from its rather unsuccessful lottery program, with the lending firm taking large risks for a low-yield return.

headline: Amid Myanmar Secrecy, Tales of Survival
text: BOGALE, Myanmar  It is a disaster still shrouded in secrecy. The world is growing accustomed to seeing images of devastation, from earthquakes or calamitous storms, as they unfold. Here the military dictatorship continues to cordon off the areas worst hit by Cyclone Nargis on May 3, and so little is known about the extent of the devastation, how aid is reaching those in need  or extraordinary stories of survival and death like that of Than Lwin.

headline: Religious Canon for All Generations
text: It’s easy to think of the liturgical repertory as a largely European concern, given the monumental contributions of Josquin, Bach, Handel and Mozart, to say nothing of earlier and later composers. But the program in which John Scott led his choir of men and boys r at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Tuesday was a reminder that American composers have been producing terrific sacred choral works since the early 20th century.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about the quarterly earnings report of HSBC Holdings, Europe’s biggest bank, referred incorrectly to the impact the turmoil in the American subprime mortgage market has had on financial services companies. They have lost more than $320 billion in asset value through write-downs; they have not lost that much in profit.

headline: Backcountry Bonding
text: For parents, signing up the kids for sleep-away camp can cause pangs of envy, thanks to the promises of hiking, fishing, river rafting and hearty mountain meals. Now new family adventure camps from the Appalachian Mountain Club let mom and dad in on the fun for a fraction of the cost of a typical summer vacation.

headline: A Useful Tool to Print Photos or Haul Water
text: What comes in buckets? Rain, fried chicken  even photo printers.

headline: Turner to Offer Marketers Way to Link Ads to Content
text: Ever smile while watching a movie on TV because, say, you just saw the scene from “The Godfather” when Vito Corleone leaves his office at the Genco Olive Oil factory and a commercial comes on for Bertolli olive oil? Turner Entertainment Networks wants to turn those coincidences into sales opportunities.

headline: Benjamin Gaon, Who Aided Israel-Arab Trade, Dies at 73
text: TEL AVIV  Benjamin D. Gaon, an Israeli industrialist who tried to build trade links with the Arab world and who helped the Israeli economy move from its socialist roots toward privatization, died here on Saturday. He was 73.

headline: Sorenstam's Exit Will Create an Opening
text: CLIFTON, N.J.  When her fellow golf professionals heard that Annika Sorenstam would retire after this season, there was sadness over losing the L.P.G.A. Tour’s dominant player over the last decade. There was also agreement that the mantle would pass to Lorena Ochoa, a 26-year-old from Mexico who had become Sorenstam’s main rival.

headline: Polar Bear Is Made a Protected Species
text: The polar bear, whose summertime Arctic hunting grounds have been greatly reduced by a warming climate, will be placed under the protection of the Endangered Species Act, Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne announced on Wednesday.

headline: If They Knew Then ...
text: This Saturday in the Preakness Stakes, a talented thoroughbred named Big Brown will be escorted to the Pimlico wire by a cooperative field of second-rate horses that will look for all the world as if someone had rigged the Washington Generals to run a mile and three-sixteenths. This is virtually a foregone conclusion in a sport that tends to rip up foregone conclusions and leave them in a pile on the OTB parlor floor. And likewise you can be sure of what will happen next: upon winning the Preakness, Big Brown will be subjected to that silly annual rite whereby people who watch horse racing three times a year declare him the potential savior of a sport that in fact doesn't need to be saved.

headline: From Parts to How-To Advice, the Web Is a Fix-It Essential
text: For those who would like to fix their own computers, there are a number of online resources that can help guide you through the process. Here is a list of some of them:

headline: Freddie Mac Posts Quarterly Loss Tempered by Accounting Techniques
text: Freddie Mac, one of the nation’s largest buyers of home loans, announced a fresh wave of bad news Wednesday, disclosing losses that were smaller than expected only because of accounting tactics that minimized the effects of bad loans.

headline: Sony Braces for Letdown After a Year of Gains
text: TOKYO  Income at the consumer electronics giant Sony rebounded in the last quarter as the company was able to hold down chip costs but was hurt by a drop in the value of its financial holdings.

headline: Fox Will Bring Back ‘Idol,’ and Add Sci-Fi
text: FOX BROADCASTING, the most-watched television network this prime-time season, will seek to make further gains with a new science-fiction-oriented drama from J. J. Abrams of “Lost” and a comedy about life at a luxury hotel starring Jerry O’Connell, according to people who have been briefed directly on the lineup that the network is expected to introduce on Thursday.

headline: A Salon With Britten and Mozart as Guests
text: Performances of chamber music and song in concert halls too large for the purpose are a fact of life in New York. As listeners we adapt; great performances happen anyway. Still, one historical aspect of the chamber music experience  the social element, in which performers and audience members do more than share space for a time  falls by the wayside. We shuffle into a hall, sit quietly, then head for the door when the last note is sounded.

headline: Curfew in Indian City After Blasts
text: JAIPUR, India  The authorities imposed a daylong curfew here in this historic western Indian city on Wednesday, the day after serial bombs tore through its pink-walled center, killing 63 people and wounding more than 100.

headline: For Movies, a Summer That’s Shy on Sequels
text: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood’s summer movies promise to be a little fresher, more original and funnier than usual. And that could be a problem for an industry that has done well lately by peddling the familiar.

headline: 2 Baghdad Attacks Attributed to Teenagers Kill 11 Others
text: BAGHDAD  Two suicide bombers described as teenagers carried out attacks Wednesday in suburban Baghdad as the prime minister went to the northern city of Mosul to encourage Iraqi soldiers fighting in a new offensive to rid that area of Sunni Islamic extremists.

headline: Grappling With the Cosmic Questions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sensing the Moment Favors Them, Unions in Albany Push for Gains
text: ALBANY  With the downfall of Gov. Eliot Spitzer and an approaching state election that has senators of both parties desperate for support, labor unions are flexing their muscles in the capital to a degree not seen in years.

headline: Thin and Stylish Reigns in Laptop Couture, Too
text: After Lenovo bought I.B.M.’s laptop division in 2005, everyone expected more of the same: somber ThinkPad laptops with I.B.M.’s signature durability. But now Lenovo is releasing laptops that are more suited to the catwalk than the boardroom.

headline: Spain: Truck Bomb Hits Police Barracks
text: A truck bomb detonated outside a barracks, left, housing police officers and their families in northern Spain, killing an officer. The authorities blamed the Basque militant group ETA, though nobody claimed responsibility. The blast on the outskirts of Legutiano, a small town near the Basque capital, Vitoria, struck the barracks in the middle of the night, as about 30 members of the Spanish civil guard and their families slept.

headline: Brazil: Environmental Official Replaced
text: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva confirmed the appointment of Carlos Minc as environment minister, replacing Marina Silva, left, who resigned, citing a lack of political support for protecting the Amazon rainforest. Ms. Silva stunned the international environmental community when she stepped down Tuesday after five years in the post. She had lost several political battles recently.

headline: As a Lovers’ Kiss Turns a World Around
text: If you are between the ages of 13 and 87, the last time you met anyone who described herself as a loyal viewer of daytime soap operas you were probably still hoarding quarters for pay phones and maintaining a casual position on sunscreen. Soaps have been shedding audiences for years now. The young, especially, have found their absurdities elsewhere; there is almost nothing put forth by the writers of “All My Children” that could, in a stupidity contest, outrank a single moment of “The Hills.”

headline: Building Rage
text: ADMIT it: You do not regard contractors as sensitive creatures. There are times you are not even sure they are quite human. They track all that dirt into your house. They seem unable to clean up after themselves after a day’s work. They are unaware that you have a life, a schedule.

headline: Specter Calls Patriots’ Spying Wider Than Stated
text: WASHINGTON  After meeting with a former New England Patriots employee who helped the team spy on opponents, Senator Arlen Specter on Wednesday described the team’s illicit videotaping tactics as more systematic and deliberate than what the N.F.L. has acknowledged publicly.

headline: Ego-Fueled Hip-Hop Sci-Fi Space Odyssey
text: There is a new yardstick for the size of the universe. It is approximately equal to the size of Kanye West’s ego.

headline: New Kinds of Spiderwort
text: Q. It took me years to eradicate the spiderwort that had become a rampant weed in my garden, and I vowed I’d never plant any again. But the new colors are very tempting. Are they any better behaved than older varieties?

headline: Proletarian Bull’s-Eye at Barneys
text: THE event was invitation only, but staffers blithely looked the other way last week as shoppers at Barneys New York stormed the seventh floor hoping to snag an oversize tank top or wrap dress designed by Rogan Gregory for Target.

headline: Tiny Bodies in a Morgue, and Grief in China
text: JUYUAN, China  The bodies are everywhere. Some are zipped inside white vinyl bags and strewn on the floor. Others have been covered in a favorite blanket or dressed in new clothes. There are so many bodies that undertakers want to cremate them in groups. They are all children.

headline: Going Through the Motions
text: Possibly the leader of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra on Tuesday could be considered a conductor. Definitely the leader was a semiconductor  a whole lot of them, The Associated Press reported. Asimo, a 4-foot-3-inch Honda robot, led the orchestra in a performance of “The Impossible Dream” from “Man of La Mancha.” After greeting the audience in a childlike voice, Asimo mimicked the actions of a conductor, nodding at sections of the ensemble during the performance and gesturing with one or both hands. At the end Asimo  an aconym for Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility  was greeted by the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, above right, and enthusiastic shouts from the audience. Engineers based the robot’s motions on those of Charles Burke, the orchestra’s education director, as he conducted the piece about six months ago.

headline: Immigration and Gang Violence Propel Crusade
text: LOS ANGELES  Jamiel Shaw Sr. never gave much thought to the immigration status of gang members in his South Los Angeles neighborhood. With his military wife deployed to Iraq and two sons to raise, there were football practices to manage, shoes to buy, college applications to consider.

headline: Man Arrested Near Scene of Wildfires in Florida
text: MIAMI  The police arrested a man in connection with a small blaze early Wednesday in central Florida, where wildfires have destroyed at least 22 homes and caused some $10 million in damage.

headline: Kitchen Spices Tuesday
text: Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew its best ratings ever on Tuesday as 12.4 million viewers tuned in to the competitive cooking show at 9 p.m., Nielsen estimated. The series attracted the night’s second highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, trailing only Fox’s “American Idol,” which dominated the 8 p.m. hour with 24 million viewers. Fox easily led the night over all, while CBS took second place thanks largely to “NCIS” at 8 (14.7 million). CBS remained solid the rest of the night with “Shark” at 9 (10.2 million) and a rerun of “Criminal Minds” at 10 (8.3 million). ABC was third. Despite outpacing “Hell’s Kitchen” during the 9 p.m. hour in total viewers with “Dancing With the Stars” (16.6 million), ABC struggled at 8 with two episodes of “According to Jim,” which together averaged 4.4 million viewers. At 10 ABC’s “Women’s Murder Club” garnered 8.5 million viewers, well short of the season finale of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” in the hour (11.3 million). NBC finished fourth for the night over all.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on April 29 about a Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral to mourn the 13 people killed up to that point this year in construction accidents in New York City referred incorrectly to the victims in some copies. Not all were construction workers; one was a tourist. The error also appeared in headlines and picture captions in some copies.

headline: Ban Lifted, Foie Gras Is Back on the Menu in Chicago
text: CHICAGO  Foie gras, run out of town with great fanfare two years ago, is being allowed back.

headline: A Bean Bag That Delivers Web Widgets
text: O.K., first of all, what’s up with the name Chumby?

headline: Attack, Blamed on ETA, Kills 1 in Northern Spain
text: MADRID  A powerful truck bomb detonated outside a barracks housing police officers and their families in northern Spain on Wednesday, tearing through the building and killing a policeman.

headline: Firefighter Who Drove Drunk and Killed Officer Is Found Guilty
text: A volunteer firefighter from New Jersey who struck and killed an off-duty New York City police officer with his sport utility vehicle was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter on Wednesday in State Supreme Court. The firefighter, Robert Derian, 25, of Saddle River, was also found guilty on four lesser charges.

headline: Woman Pleads Guilty in Prostitution Ring Case
text: A former literature major accused of being the primary booker for the prostitution ring patronized by Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty on Wednesday under terms of an agreement with the government that obligates her to testify, if necessary, before a federal grand jury sitting in the case.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Justine Henin
text: Justine Henin is serving. She tosses the ball. Her eyes follow its flight upward, and as they do they reveal what looks like a split-second of fear. This happens on every serve. The ball rises, her eyes flash upward, the point begins, and the illusion of fear is immediately dispelled with a ground stroke that lifts Henin into the air. There is almost no inherent fragility in her game, apart from that passing expression on her face, and when she retired on Wednesday, effective immediately, she retired at No. 1, the winner of seven grand slam titles, and only 25 years old. Anyone who understands the intensity with which she plays understands how hard it must be to sustain.

headline: Attachment and Confusion
text: Q. My Mozilla Thunderbird e-mail program sometimes tries to open file attachments in the wrong program, even when my file associations are set. How can I open the attachments?

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption with the Calendar in the Connecticut weekly section on Sunday about Music for People, a benefit concert on May 17 at 7:30 p.m. at Westport Unitarian Church, gave an incorrect telephone number for ticket information. It is (877) 446-8742.

headline: Medical Journal’s Article Questions TV Ads for Stent
text: A television advertisement for a heart stent that promotes the product’s potential benefits but seems to play down the medical risks may deceive the public and should be reviewed by federal regulators, according to an op-ed article published on Wednesday by a leading medical journal.

headline: A 30,000-Volume Window on the World
text: FOR the last seven years, I’ve lived in an old stone presbytery in France, south of the Loire Valley, in a village of fewer than 10 houses. I chose the place because next to the 15th-century house itself was a barn, partly torn down centuries ago, large enough to accommodate my library of some 30,000 books, assembled over six itinerant decades. I knew that once the books found their place, I would find mine.

headline: The Politics of the Lapel, When It Comes to Obama
text: WARREN, Mich.  It showed up on Monday, right there on his lapel, as he addressed veterans in West Virginia: a flag pin.

headline: ‘Fidelity’
text: Phil Kramer walked down the sidewalk under the big trees toward his car. It was quiet on this street, and the lights in the houses were almost all off. There was a strong, sweet scent of flowering vines that opened their blooms late on hot summer nights like this one — wisteria, he supposed, or some kind of jasmine. There was no way to limit it, because there wasn't anything that wouldn't grow in Southern California. He supposed his senses were attuned to everything tonight. He had trained himself over the past twenty-five years to be intensely aware of his surroundings, particularly when he was alone at night. He knew there was a cat watching him from the safety of the porch railing to his right, and he knew there was a man walking along the sidewalk a half-block behind him. He had seen him as he had turned the corner — not quite as tall as Phil Kramer, but well-built, and wearing a jacket on a night that was too warm for one. He could hear the footsteps just above the level of the cars swishing past on the boulevard.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Monday about the Myanmar military junta’s restrictions on aid distributed to victims of the May 3 cyclone misspelled the name of a well-known Myanmar film star who was prevented by a military patrol from handing out bags of rice. He is Kyaw Thu, not Kyaw Dhyu.

headline: Supernova Remnant Is Young and Quick
text: About a century ago, the light from the explosion of a star within our galaxy swept past Earth.

headline: A Blur of Hands, Spokes and Determination
text: WARM SPRINGS, Ga.  It happened every few miles during Josh George’s 45-minute workout through the hills of middle Georgia. A car or truck driver would slow to a tentative crawl, spend 10 to 20 seconds deciding whether it was rude to pass, and after creeping over the double-yellow would rubberneck at the young man stuffed into a racing wheelchair huffing and puffing his way across the asphalt.

headline: Lebanon Reverses Decisions That Prompted Violence
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanon’s governing coalition on Wednesday night formally reversed two decisions that had provoked the militant group Hezbollah, bringing the country a step closer to resolving the week-old political crisis that set off the worst factional violence since the nation’s 15-year civil war.

headline: Party’s Rules Committee Has a Crucial Role in Clinton’s Hopes
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s hopes for the presidential nomination may in large part rest on an obscure Democratic National Committee panel, a group of several allies, but not enough at this point to achieve her goal of counting the votes or delegates of Florida and Michigan.

headline: Getty Trust Trims Staff
text: The J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles will eliminate 114 jobs and cut programs to marshal resources for the organization’s arts mission, The Associated Press reported. Fewer than 40 people were laid off, and most reductions were accomplished through attrition, a spokesman for the trust, Ron Hartwig, said. James Wood, chief executive of the trust, said, “The whole goal here is to focus the Getty on the core mission of the visual arts.” The cuts were reported Wednesday in The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Hartwig said that many of the positions are staff assistants and jobs in maintenance, communications and management.

headline: California: Logging Banned at 3 Sites
text: A federal appeals court in San Francisco barred logging at three sites in the Plumas National Forest, part of the Sierra Nevada range. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed and remanded a 2007 lower-court decision that allowed logging, saying the federal Forest Service had failed to fully explore ways to pay for fighting forest fires when it approved plans for awarding timber contracts. The Forest Service has argued that the contracts help pay for clearing underbrush and other fire-prevention programs. Environmental groups, backed by Attorney General Jerry Brown, said the approved plans failed to protect the spotted owl and other scarce species. In calling for a temporary halt to logging, the court said cutting timber could “irreparably damage” vital habitat and in turn sensitive species.

headline: Ohio Official Caught Up in Scandal Quits Post
text: Under threat of impeachment, Marc Dann resigned Wednesday as Ohio’s attorney general, a consequence of a sex scandal that has consumed the Statehouse for six weeks.

headline: Footnote
text: “The Real World: Brooklyn” may sound redundant, but MTV has approved plans to start production of a Brooklyn edition of its “Real World” reality series in which seven young strangers live together as the cameras roll. MTV said it had ordered 12 episodes of the show, which is scheduled to run in the first quarter of 2009.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Jack, Being Nimble
text: Jack Black, above, postures amid a small army of faux pandas in an elaborate  what else?  bid for publicity at the Cannes Film Festival. In the animated film “Kung Fu Panda” Mr. Black provides the voice of Po the Panda, a slothful noodle-restaurant waiter called upon to perform heroic feats of martial arts.

headline: Pakistan: Taliban Prisoner Exchange
text: The Pakistan Army released 40 Taliban militants in exchange for 12 members of the army and the paramilitary Frontier Corps before the expected completion of a peace accord with Islamic extremists in the tribal area of South Waziristan, government spokesmen said. The Bush administration has tried to discourage such accords, saying they would allow the militants more freedom to organize attacks against American forces in Afghanistan.

headline: Defying President Bush, Senate Passes Farm Bill
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to approve a five-year, $307 billion farm bill, sending it to President Bush for what is expected to be his futile veto.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Women and Fashion

headline: Canadian Oil Sands Project Is Delayed
text: Work on a large oil sands project was delayed on Wednesday after the Federal Court of Canada rejected an appeal by Imperial Oil to reinstate a permit that was voided in March.

headline: Rejoice!
text: Much has been made lately of Joba Chamberlain's fist-pump celebrations after big strikeouts, putting him among a long list of athletes who rejoice after a big play, whether it be a home run, blocked shot or first-down catch. Manny Ramirez even high-fived a fan in the middle of a play yesterday. Do we care any longer how demonstrative athletes are when they celebrate?

headline: Judge Says Countrywide Officers Must Face Suit by Shareholders
text: Directors and officers of Countrywide Financial, the beleaguered mortgage lender, must answer shareholder accusations of insider trading and an overall failure to monitor lending practices that led to the company’s collapse, a federal judge in California has ruled.

headline: Suggested Reads: Behind the Final Bows
text: Within just 24 hours this week, two of this decade's best female athletes announced their retirements, and as in previous instances where athletes left near the top of their game, questions arose about their motivations. But maybe the departures of Justine Henin and Annika Sorenstam are right in character.

headline: Stained Glass, With Shotguns
text: One night in 2004, Kyle Cassidy, a photographer living in Philadelphia, went to a dinner where he sat next to a presidential campaign staff member who explained that one of his many tasks had been to “wrangle the gun vote.” Mr. Cassidy became curious. Who made up the gun vote, he wondered, and were those voters all the same?

headline: China: Virus Kills 2 Children in Beijing
text: In the first reported deaths in the capital, two children have died of an intestinal virus that has killed 42 children and infected almost 25,000 others, according to Xinhua, the official news agency. The number of those infected has more than doubled in the last week. The virus has been spreading beyond central Anhui Province, where the outbreak began in early March.

headline: Just Two More Reps (Says the Video Game)
text: Could a video game hold the key to getting more Americans in shape? Eighteen months ago, Nintendo upended the notion of what video games could be with the Wii, an intuitive, family-friendly entertainment experience. "Now Nintendo's latest brainchild, Wii Fit, could send similar ripples through the home-fitness market," The Times writes today. An interactive home-fitness system that is used with the Wii console, "Wii Fit is like having a Bob Harper or a Denise Austin who talks back -- gently cajoling you through exercises, praising, nudging, even reminding you to eat a banana once in a while."

headline: Streaming Online Video by Piggybacking on Cable TV
text: Online video is an embarrassment of riches, from reruns of “Lost” to clips of classic weatherman bloopers. It’s little wonder that everyone is trying to get that video from the Internet to the living-room TV. The ZeeVee ZV-100, a $500 kit that connects to your PC, avoids many of the common video pitfalls and streams what’s on your computer screen to an open cable channel on your TV.

headline: D’Antoni Wants to Win, but He’s Also Realistic
text: Hope and renewal at Madison Square Garden now come in many forms and guises: the wizened face of Donnie Walsh, the new president; the fresh ideas of Mike D’Antoni, the bold new coach; and the vague promise of 2010.

headline: Write-Down at Royal Bank of Canada
text: The Royal Bank of Canada said it would take a write down of 855 million Canadian dollars ($846 million) on its second-quarter earnings, largely because of problems in the United States debt market.

headline: I.R.S. Seeks Reports of Foreign Accounts
text: In its hunt for wealthy Americans who have stashed money overseas to evade taxes, the federal government has turned to an obscure law enacted nearly four decades ago.

headline: Rocket Hits City in Israel as Bush Hails Anniversary
text: JERUSALEM  President Bush was hailed as “a great leader” and “a great friend” of Israel at an emotional Academy Awards-style celebration of the country’s 60th birthday here Wednesday night. But his visit, aimed at promoting peace in the Middle East, was instead marred by violence.

headline: Tax Havens Face Pressure From Europe
text: BRUSSELS  Under pressure from Germany, the European Union on Wednesday agreed to consider a new clampdown on tax havens, despite the opposition of one country, Luxembourg, which said it saw no reason to change the existing law.

headline: Rescues Require Skills, Specialists Say
text: Among professional search-and-rescue teams, the first 24 hours after an earthquake or a building collapse are known as “the golden hours,” the time when frantic clawing by neighbors, friends and relatives can pull survivors from the periphery of the rubble.

headline: Dutch Modernist Chairs, Reborn
text: Three chairs from the archives of the Dutch modernist architect Gerrit Rietveld are back in production and available for the first time in the United States. “Most people know the Red Blue Chair and maybe the Zigzag, but few know the rest of the models,” said Ries Seijler, the designer’s great-grandson, who heads Rietveld by Rietveld, the company manufacturing the chairs. The three pieces are the first of several that will be produced from an archive of more than 215 furniture designs, Mr. Seijler said. They include: the 1963 Steltman ($3,950); the child-sized 1934 Crate Chair Junior ($395), originally made out of discarded shipping crates, but now made of beech wood; and the 1957 Mondial (starting at $545), which has a seat and back pressed from a single sheet of aluminum. Information: (800) 319-8222 or www.m2lcollection.com.

headline: House Backs Farm Bill With Numbers to Beat Veto
text: WASHINGTON  The House overwhelmingly approved a $300 billion farm bill on Wednesday afternoon, making it probable that the measure will become law despite President Bush’s anticipated veto.

headline: Colombian Warlord Pleads Not Guilty to Drug Charges
text: A right-wing Colombian paramilitary leader who has been accused of ordering hundreds of political assassinations and smuggling tons of cocaine into the United States  including drugs that were sold from a busy Brooklyn crack house  pleaded not guilty to drug charges Wednesday in federal court in Manhattan.

headline: New World Bank Plan to Fight Aids
text: The World Bank said it was shifting from an emergency approach to a long-term strategy to combat AIDS in Africa, the epicenter of the global epidemic. As new infections outstrip the number of people with AIDS starting treatment with antiretroviral drugs, the bank will focus on helping countries tailor prevention strategies to their needs.

headline: An Antiwar March Through Towns Unused to One
text: CENTRAL SQUARE, N.Y.  On Wednesday, Charlie Price was smoking a cigarette and sitting outside his restaurant, Charlie’s Place, on a two-lane stretch of highway on the outskirts of town.

headline: Insert Tony Stunt Here
text: Who in the world is this Cubby Bernstein, the baby-faced, fast-talking, 9-year-old “Tony Campaign Manager” who has been showing up in YouTube videos, chat rooms and, on Wednesday, an advertisement in The New York Post, claiming, “There’s a broken promise for every light on Broadway” and promising to guide clients “through the treacherous waters of Tony Season”?

headline: Non-Tony Award News
text: The New York Drama Critics’ Circle has named the Tracy Letts melodrama “August: Osage County” the best play of the 2007-8 season. The accolade for best musical went to “Passing Strange,” with book and lyrics by Stew and music by Stew and Heidi Rodewald. The organization of 22 critics from daily newspapers, magazines and news services based in the New York region will present its awards at a reception on Monday at the Algonquin Hotel.

headline: A British Actor’s Seduction of America
text: When Ben Daniels was preparing for his role as the ostentatiously rakish Valmont in the Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of “Les Liaisons Dangereuses,” he did all the research about the demimonde of an 18th-century aristocratic hedonist that you’d expect of a studious, experienced actor. He toured Versailles. He gleaned clues on body language from historical dance and paintings at the Louvre.

headline: Airbus Unit Helps EADS Post Profit
text: PARIS  The European aerospace group EADS bounced back to a quarterly profit Wednesday, reflecting an unexpected turnaround at Airbus, its commercial plane maker, and a hefty early payment for its military transport aircraft.

headline: Corrections
text: Business Day

headline: West Virginia’s Top Judge Loses His Re-election Bid
text: The chief justice of West Virginia’s Supreme Court, Elliott E. Maynard, lost his re-election bid on Tuesday after being dogged for months by a conflict-of-interest scandal stemming from photographs showing him on vacation and dining with the chief executive of a coal company with cases pending before the court.

headline: Harvey Schein, Promoter of Betamax at Sony, Dies at 80
text: Harvey L. Schein, who led the Sony Corporation of America in the 1970s and doubled its size in spite of championing the failed Betamax video recording system and clashing with Sony’s top Japanese executives, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80, and had homes in Manhattan; Washington, Conn.; and Sanibel, Fla.

headline: The Lakers Try to Take Their Focus Off Bryant
text: LOS ANGELES  Anybody who arrived late to the Lakers game Wednesday night missed Kobe Bryant’s statement. In the first minute of Game 5 against the Utah Jazz, Bryant made a 3-pointer and a fall-away jumper. Bryant ran the floor as if he did not have an ache in his body.

headline: Ask.com Tries Again (and Not Just With Women)
text: Ask.com is not giving up on its quest to compete with the big search engines.

headline: Camden High Fashion
text: Students strut at a school fashion show, with clothing provided by a New York company.

headline: Your Comments on my Tibet Column
text: My Thursday column is from the Tibetan areas of Qinghai and Gansu Provinces — the area that used to be the Tibetan region of Amdo. I’d welcome your comments, partly because my Sunday column is also likely to be about the Tibetans. I’m a little vague about my vacation at the moment, since I don’t want my trip cut short….

headline: No Surprise: Big Brown Is Favorite
text: The post positions are set for the Preakness Stakes, and Big Brown (Post 7) was installed as the 1-2 favorite by the Pimlico Race Course oddsmaker Frank Carulli. Joe Drape writes that Big Brown arrived late to Pimlico and barely got to the track at Churchill Downs, galloping only three times since the Derby.

headline: The Rescue Effort Continues
text: In the aftermath of this week’s powerful earthquake, the latest figures put the number of people still buried at 26,000 and the missing at 14,000.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: A Victory Plan for Hillary
text: Hillary Clinton loves impossible obstacles. Ever since the North Carolina primary, the Democratic establishment has been sending out word that Clinton has a perfect right to run through the rest of the election schedule as long as she doesn’t say anything mean about the Chosen One. But is it hopeless? Not entirely.

headline: A Historical Tibet
text: In Gansu and Qinghai Provinces of China, Nicholas D. Kristof met with Tibetans who spoke about the recent Chinese crackdown in the region.

headline: ‘Two Million Depressed Teens’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: When TV Newsmen Get Uptight
text: It’s not Sue Simmons or Bill O’Reilly spewing expletives — both in the news lately. Rather, it’s the MTV sketch troupe Human Giant’s sendup of a short-fused TV news correspondent (some dialogue bleeps):

headline: When TV Newsmen Get Loose
text: Tom Brokaw plays along with Will Ferrell, in character as the anchorman Ron Burgundy, at Radio City Music Hall during Mr. Ferrell’s “Funny or Die” comedy tour.

headline: ‘Netherland’
text: The afternoon before I left London for New York — Rachel had flown out six weeks previously — I was in my cubicle at work, boxing up my possessions, when a senior vice-president at the bank, an Englishman in his fifties, came to wish me well. I was surprised; he worked in another part of the building and in another department, and we were known to each other only by sight. Nevertheless, he asked me in detail about where I intended to live ("Watts? Which block on Watts?") and reminisced for several minutes about his loft on Wooster Street and his outings to the "original" Dean & DeLuca. He was doing nothing to hide his envy.

headline: Italy’s A2A Looks to Mergers to Compete With Enel

headline: Paris Memo | Lindsay Lohan Hangs At The Louvre
text: The annual traveling fashion circus that is the Fornarina Urban Beauty Show touched down at the Carrousel du Louvre on Monday night. Imagine, if you will, the poppy Italian sportswear company setting up an enormous temporary shop, and a series of giant, fantastical installations by artists like Moebius, Glenn Barr, tattooist Angelique Houtkamp and Junko Mizuno, featuring lip-synching models dressed up in bedazzled denim mermaid bikinis, trapeze artists and a winged male dancer in tighty whities trapped in a cage. There were thousands of assembled Euros to take it all in, mostly Fornarina’s best customers and sales associates (ie, more Italians in France since the Italians ceded Sardinia in 1860). They were shopping up a storm, dancing to music by Aurore LeBlanc, and generally making way more noise than a museum-adjunct space should ever be forced to endure. Things got even louder with the appearance of Lindsay Lohan, who let slip that she’s the new face of Fornarina come Spring ’09. (The trendy, clubby label and the clubgoer who never saw a flippy party dress she didn’t like are a good match if you ask us.) For any of you looking for dirt, we hate to disappoint you: Lohan was on time, well-behaved and all in all quite professional — though she was indeed wearing leggings. In fact, she confirmed that she is going ahead with producing her own line, called 6126 after Marilyn Monroe’s birthday, and admitted it was a retort to the many Internet critics who jeer at her for her leggings habit. Intermix has picked 6126 up, and perhaps there will be more design coming from Lohan. “Maybe a handbag,” she said. Let’s see how it goes.

headline: The National League Least

The Marlins, continuing to defy expectations, remain in first place, and no team among the Mets/Phillies/Braves crowd can seem to gain any ground. If you look at the standings, and I did, you may notice that a Mets loss today and a Marlins victory would put New York nearly as far back from first place (three games) as they would be in front of last-place Washington (three and a half).

headline: Go karting in Spain
text: As happens every year, Formula One journalists get together Friday evening at the Spanish Grand Prix to race go karts against each other at the Bridgestone karting race to see just how far off their abilities are from the pros they write about. Although the event is open only to journalists, a number of Formula One drivers have become part time journalists after their F1 career is over. That means that drivers such as Marc Surer and Bas Leinders take part in the event. Surprise, surprise, this year the teams of those two drivers came in first and second place in the race. Oh yes, and Autosport came in third. My team came in a poor ninth.

So while the training goal is simply to keep the horses happy and prepared for their race on Saturday, with light jogs and easy gallops, for those that shipped in it also includes checking their condition after shipping. The two sides parted ways last week after 18 days of talks over a contract that covers both movies and prime-time TV shows. That contract ends June 30.”

headline: CNet: CBS Gives Us Air Cover

At a time when the Internet ad market was growing and changing rapidly, CNet has had to confront investigations into its option granting practices and a group of dissident shareholders (who raised some good questions about the company’s efficiency).

headline: Worries Over the Shad, Tomcod and White Perch

But the Hudson remains an important commercial channel, and as it has been cleaned up, native species of fish have responded positively. A new report out today raises some troubling questions about the Hudson, however. The report by Riverkeeper, an environmental organization, says 10 of 13 key species of fish have declined since the 1980s, despite the river being substantially cleaner today than it was a generation ago.

A ruling by the California Supreme Court could give the constantly simmering culture war new salience, as the state becomes the second to allow full-fledged gay marriage.

headline: Scent Notes | Fracas
text: There are perfume legends, there are perfumer legends, and then there are perfumes that become obsessions. Fracas is all three, which is a hat trick less common that you’d think. Still more extraordinary, Fracas is built on a concept of tuberose, a small white flower (unrelated to rose; the name comes from the Latin word describing the plant’s tuberous root system) that generates an overpowering scent and is notorious among perfumers for being a difficult raw material to master. Which is perhaps why Fracas’s perfumer, Germaine Cellier, managed it.

text: Judi Hoffman admits that making Preakness selections is “way harder than the Derby.” She said she had no concrete picks as of yet, but she does have some hunches.

His show is called “Sports: Now and Then.”

Between blogs, Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Digg, and the next new social networking communication enhancer, suddenly e-mail is just one of the online “mailboxes” we have to tend.

headline: The Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
text: The sun is setting, the cleanup crew is nearly done, and the only other people left in the Shea Stadium press box at 8:07 p.m. are Brian Heyman, the venerable reporter from The Journal News, and a security guard who doesn’t look happy that Brian and I are the only people left in the Shea press box. Today, I feel like Alexander. More accurately, I feel like the Mets are Alexander, the title character from one of my all-time favorite books: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day.

headline: Voices and Visions
text: Last time I blogged, I was about to go into the studio and see what snakes came flying out of my mouth, so to speak. No snakes this time. Just one little verse of the song “Pale Cowboy.” It’s a very restrained verse, kind of formal-feeling, which fits its subject.

headline: Voices and Visions
text: Last time I blogged, I was about to go into the studio and see what snakes came flying out of my mouth, so to speak. No snakes this time. Just one little verse of the song "Pale Cowboy." It's a very restrained verse, kind of formal-feeling, which fits its subject.  If your friend is an orchid then you are a rose. Upright and thorny against your horizon. Still solitary with all petals closed. In the heat when the heart's desert sun is arising.        I wrestled with myself for a while about whether the word "heat" should be "cool." After all, flowers open in the warmth and stay closed in the coolness. And if the sun is arising in this person's heart, then it is morning, and morning tends to be cool, not warm, so that's why the petals are closed. Well, it will be hotter later and that's when the petals will be open, probably. So there is an expectation set up in the song.  When I talk about "morning," I am talking about this person's age and experience — if his lifetime is one day, he would be approaching the noontime of it. Well, now that I think about it he would be approaching the afternoon of it — he is a young man but still past 30. As I said, not someone I know well. So I think "heat" is O.K., and it sounds better next to "heart." Which is important.  The guitar part is tricky and I have to practice it. I had Britt, my engineer, repeat it three times so we could see how long the finished song might be. And so that I could figure out, does it need a bridge? Maybe a section that would become a real chorus? You should know that this clip is not here just for your entertainment but to illustrate the problems I am wrestling with -- that's why I left it as it is, and didn't just fade it out -- so you can hear what I am doing in real time.  (Photo: Suzanne Vega and Britt Myers in the studio recently. (Photo: Brittany Barney))   So the main image in this song is that he is a "rose." Most songs begin for me with an image of some kind in my mind. A man is a flower in this case. If you have an image in your mind, what is another word for that? Some people might call it a vision. It is usually some kind of metaphor, which I feel reveals a deeper truth. You can say a man is just a man, but if you say he is like a rose, that gives you an idea of what kind of man he might be. Thorny and fragile. And the other man, his friend, is an orchid -- open-petaled, exotic, more of a hothouse flower.  I had a cat whose name was Cow. And that gives you an idea of what kind of cat she was — fat with black spots. I had to defend myself once against a couple of Italian journalists who demanded to know, Why do you always lie in your songs? You are not a small blue thing. What is all of this about a queen and a soldier? Why don't you say what you mean? Well, I say what I mean, but sometimes I am attempting to write something that I see in a world beyond this one, and the metaphor is the way to get there.  Many times a song will begin with a clear image in my mind, but sometimes a song can begin with a melody popping into your head. How does it come? On an instrument? With a voice? On something unearthly that is neither, maybe. It could be a clear voice that says, for example, "Men in a war, if they've lost a limb, still feel that limb as they did before." I heard that line clearly in my mind and it sounded like a voice to me.   But voices and visions are scary to admit to. And also you have to make time for them, or they go on to someone else.

headline: Gallup: 38% Support Animal Racing Ban
text: Last week, the public-opinion research company Gallup (aptly named when it comes to horse polls) conducted a poll about Americans’ opinions of animal racing.

text: Several networks stuck to their plans, previously announced, to cut back on the hoopla and hyperbole for the 2008-09 upfront week. Others decided that the assembled advertising agency employees and journalists could use a song, a laugh or a glimpse of a celebrity or two.

headline: Edwards Back in the Spotlight Again
text: Updated On his way into an award ceremony in New York City on Thursday, John Edwards took a few questions from reporters about his endorsement of Senator Barack Obama the day before.
