text: Front Page

headline: Germany Debates Subsidies for Solar Industry
text: THALHEIM, Germany  This sad stretch of eastern Germany, with its deserted coal mines and corroded factories, epitomizes post-industrial gloom. It is a place where even the clouds rarely seem to part.

headline: Post 9/11, a New York of Gatsby-Size Dreams and Loss
text: Driving a rented car up the Saw Mill River and Taconic State Parkways, Hans, a Dutchman displaced in New York, thinks of the Dutch names  Yonkers, Cortlandt, Verplanck and of course Peekskill  that sprout amid places like Mohegan, Chappaqua and Ossining, and finds himself superimposing on the landscape “regressive images of Netherlanders and Indians, images arising not from mature historical reflection but from a child’s irresponsibly cinematic sense of things.” He has a similar sense of America’s vastness and panoramic possibilities when he travels up the Hudson and glimpses spectacular, unspoiled vistas of forests and mountains “canceling out centuries”  vistas unimaginable, he says, to someone who grew up in the congested, overpopulated landscape of the Low Countries.

headline: From Iraq to Disney World: A Military Resort
text: AS they enter through the Magic Kingdom gates, following signs with the familiar mouse ears, past the sighing of the monorail and the distant screams from Space Mountain, a few visitors take an unusual route, up a driveway just off the entrances to the Disney World golf courses.

headline: No Nets Arena Yet, but Suites Are on Sale
text: Construction of the Nets’ proposed arena near downtown Brooklyn is long delayed and financing has not been completed. But the effort to sell the Barclays Center’s luxury suites began Thursday with the opening of a showroom in Manhattan.

headline: Labor Report Shows Gains in City’s Job Picture While Rest of State Weakens
text: For months, economists and city officials have been bracing for signs that the city’s job market is weakening after several of New York’s largest banks recorded huge losses in the mortgage market and said they would eliminate thousands of jobs.

headline: Buffett Increases Stakes in Kraft Foods and Wells Fargo
text: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, added to stakes in Kraft Foods and Wells Fargo in the first quarter, taking advantage of prices driven down by the credit crisis and the slowing American economy.

headline: A Teenager’s Betrayal in Brooklyn
text: The most chilling image in “Sangre de Mi Sangre,” Christopher Zalla’s grim, incompletely realized story of identity theft and betrayal among illegal Mexican immigrants in the shabbier streets of Brooklyn, shows 17-year-old Pedro (Jorge Adrian Espindola) moments after he is booted from the truck that has smuggled him from Puebla to New York City.

headline: Warren Cowan, a Star at Promoting Stars, Dies at 87
text: Warren Cowan, one of Hollywood’s most powerful and innovative publicists and the representative of generations of celebrities  from Doris Day to Bette Midler, Frank Sinatra to Elton John, Ronald Reagan to Arnold Schwarzenegger  died Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 87 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Unbeatable Mountain Views and a Slow-Paced Life
text: BRISTLING with saguaro cactus, Superstition Mountain rises from the desert floor in Arizona, its cliff faces blushing when caught by the sun. The mountain seems to stand sentry over the low-slung, earth-colored houses in Gold Canyon, keeping watch over a daily parade of joggers, golfers and cyclists.

headline: California Court Affirms Right to Gay Marriage
text: The California Supreme Court, striking down two state laws that had limited marriages to unions between a man and a woman, ruled Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.

headline: A Values Debate (Not the Political Kind)
text: WALL STREET is struggling to answer what might seem like a simple question: How much are some investments really worth?

headline: Bush Speech Criticized as Attack on Obama
text: JERUSALEM — President Bush used a speech to the Israeli Parliament on Thursday to denounce those who would negotiate with “terrorists and radicals” — a remark that was widely interpreted as a rebuke to Senator Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential contender, who has argued that the United States should talk directly with countries like Iran and Syria.

headline: In the South, a Force to Challenge the G.O.P.
text: NEW ORLEANS  The sharp surge in black turnout that Senator Barack Obama has helped to generate in recent primaries and Congressional races could signal a threat this fall to the longtime Republican dominance of the South, according to politicians and voting experts.

headline: French Bank to Sell Assets to Offset Subprime Losses
text: LONDON  Just days after announcing plans to raise capital, the French bank Crédit Agricole named a new head for its investment banking unit on Thursday and said it planned to sell 5 billion euros ($7.75 billion) of assets to help pare losses linked to the subprime market downturn.

headline: When Selling a Soul, Consider the Price
text: Christian Petzold’s enigmatic thriller “Yella” offers a surreal X-ray vision of cutthroat capitalism in 21st-century Germany. Yella Fichte (Nina Hoss), a sleek young businesswoman on the make, is an ardent student of that world. One of the first lessons she is taught is how to strike the “broker pose.” The technique, which her instructor says he learned from a John Grisham movie, requires that at the opportune moment during a business negotiation she lean over and whisper something in his ear.

headline: Bernanke Says Banks Need More Capital
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, pushed banks on Thursday to keep raising capital in the aftermath of losses from the credit crisis to avert deeper damage to the economy.

headline: Videotaper’s Inside View of the Patriots’ Spying
text: WASHINGTON  Until the New England Patriots were caught cheating during a game against the Jets last September, Matt Walsh was a largely unknown former staff member who had done his work behind the video camera. Now he finds himself in front of it, the only person who was involved with the Patriots’ illicit videotaping operation who has spoken publicly about how the team skirted league rules for years.

headline: Feuding Political Camps in Lebanon Agree to Talk to End Impasse
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The warring political camps in Lebanon agreed Thursday to hold renewed talks in a deal negotiated by Arab diplomats that reopened the country’s airport and appeared to end a week of bloody political crisis.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Zimbabwe: Opposition Protests Delay in Runoff
text: Tendai Biti, the secretary general of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, protested the government’s decision to delay the presidential runoff up to 90 days. By law, the election  pitting Morgan Tsvangirai, of the opposition, against President Robert Mugabe  was supposed to take place by May 23, or 21 days after results were announced for the first round of voting. The delay, he said, allows the government to continue a campaign of violence that the opposition says has claimed at least 32 lives, including, on Tuesday, two founding members of the party’s youth assembly.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: The Villas at Amangiri and Palmetto Bay Resort
text: The Villas at Amangiri

headline: Gift Aids Struggling Honolulu Symphony
text: An anonymous donor has given $1.175 million to the Honolulu Symphony, helping the financially troubled orchestra to pay seven weeks of back wages to musicians and staff members, The Honolulu Advertiser reported. The orchestra has struggled recently with higher expenses and lower ticket sales after it was forced to move to smaller and often more costly auditoriums, in part because it was displaced from Blaisdell Concert Hall by a tour of “The Lion King.” Revenue fell last month by at least $500,000, and the operating budget, normally $6 million or $7 million, jumped to about $8 million, Tom Gulick, the ensemble’s executive director, said failure to meet bills and save sufficient money by June 30 could jeopardized the state of the next season.

headline: Redgrave’s New Show
text: Lynn Redgrave has written three shows about her acting family: “Mandrake Root,” “Shakespeare for My Father” and “Nightingale” (which is Broadway bound). She now has a solo work in progress, “Rachel and Juliet,” about her mother, Rachel Kempson, and her relationship with Shakespeare and the role of Juliet in particular. On June 2, the one-woman show will be presented by the Shakespeare Society at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College. ...The revival of "Grease," at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, was born from reality talent show and will survive by reality talent show. Taylor Hicks, the 2006 “American Idol” winner and captain of the so-called soul patrol, will step into the role of Teen Angel from June 6 to Sept. 7.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The On Education column on May 7, about the impact of the planned closing of Lafayette High School in Brooklyn’s Bath Beach neighborhood and at John Dewey High School, just to the south at Dewey, misspelled the surname of a student at Dewey who discussed overcrowding at the school. She is Elizabeth Piligromova, not Piligromava.

headline: When We Go, We Always Stop
text: FRIDAY evenings, as families gird themselves for the trip to their weekend homes, they have some certain critical decisions to make.

headline: China: CNN Apologizes Over Tibet Comments
text: CNN apologized to China after the government strongly complained about remarks made on April 9 by the CNN commentator Jack Cafferty. During a broadcast that came after riots in Tibet, Mr. Cafferty said China’s leaders were “basically the same bunch of goons and thugs they’ve been for the last 50 years.” China demanded an apology, and angry Chinese accused CNN of biased news coverage. An earlier apology was rejected. But recently China’s Foreign Ministry highlighted a second apology, saying it came in a letter sent by the CNN president, Jim Walton, to China’s ambassador to the United States.

headline: Injured Actor Files Petition
text: An actor who was injured last Saturday when he fell through a trap door on the set of “Disney’s The Little Mermaid” has asked for a court order to preserve a prop in the show as evidence for a potential lawsuit. In the petition, filed on Wednesday in Manhattan Supreme Court, Adrian Bailey, above, asked that Disney and the Nederlander Organization, which owns the Lunt Fontanne Theater, the show’s home, be ordered to preserve a “certain show prop sailing ship,” as well as the prop’s design and repair records, so they can be inspected. Mr. Bailey, 51, fell through a trap door on the sailing ship and landed on the stage 30 to 40 feet below, according to court papers. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he is being treated for fractured wrists, a broken back, a shattered pelvis, a fractured sternum, several fractured ribs and a fractured foot. He has undergone four surgeries, the court papers said. Officials from the Nederlander Organization declined to comment. Officials from Disney Theatrical Productions said they were investigating the accident.

headline: Sanofi-Aventis Wants F.D.A. to Reconsider Heart Drug
text: Armed with new research data, Sanofi-Aventis, the French pharmaceutical giant, said Thursday that it planned to ask the Food and Drug Administration to reconsider the company’s experimental heart rhythm drug Multaq, which the regulatory agency rejected in 2006.

headline: Big Brown a Big Favorite, but Others Still Want a Shot
text: BALTIMORE  Big Brown has won his four starts by a combined 33 ¾ lengths. He so decimated a full field of 20 at the Kentucky Derby that only one of the vanquished  Gayego  has come to Pimlico Race Course for another shot at him in the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Bacon’s ‘Dyer’ Expected to Attract Big Numbers
text: Bacon’s ‘Dyer’ Expected

headline: Competitor Files a Lawsuit Claiming Speedo Is Attempting a Monopoly
text: The swimsuit war has spilled into the court of law. TYR Sport Inc. filed suit this week against Warnaco Swimwear Inc., the parent company of Speedo and the maker of the LZR Racer high-tech suit, citing unlawful restraint of trade and an attempt to monopolize the competitive swimwear marketplace.

headline: Bad Words, Overused, Can Lose Their Sting
text: The most surprising thing about Sue Simmons’s unbleeped blooper the other night is that anyone in this city even noticed.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,071 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: Rays Provide Yanks Glimpse of What Could Be
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees hope Ian Kennedy one day will be part of a young, revamped pitching staff that can dominate hitters, much like the rotation the Tampa Bay Rays employ.

headline: What to Ask About Epilepsy
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. If you — or your child — have epilepsy, here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

headline: New Parking Rules Receive a Wary Welcome
text: History may recall it as P-A Day as it approaches in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the start of some sort of new world, a place with new laws, new codes of human conduct, as primitive and mysterious as the Planet of the Apes.

headline: See How They Run
text: It should not be an extraordinary moment when a candidate for president declares allegiance to the Constitution, promises to not ignore or flagrantly violate laws, talks about ending a long and draining war and vows transparency in the Oval Office.

headline: Women Are Finding Their Voices Behind the Mike
text: Doris Burke is a rarity in sports television: an analyst (and sideline reporter) at ESPN and ABC for men’s and women’s college basketball, and for the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A.

headline: Discovering Alabama From Its Watery Byway
text: THE Robert F. Henry Dam near Montgomery, Ala., is a sprawling wall of reinforced concrete with 11 spillway gates that holds back approximately 234,200 acre feet of water, creating the lake called Jones Bluff Reservoir. Its lock, a massive concrete-lined chamber 655 feet by 84 feet, was built to raise and lower bulky barges hauling tons of wood and grain some 200 miles downriver to Mobile Bay.

headline: Tasting the Bounty of San Francisco Markets
text: EACH morning, produce floods into San Francisco from some of the nation’s most spectacular farmland  Napa’s hilly vineyards, the sun-baked orchards and green fields of the eastern valleys, the Pacific Coast’s misty pasture lands. San Franciscans scoop it up with barely a thought, as if excellent fresh food were simply a California birthright.

headline: A Brahms Piano Quartet, With No Strings Attached
text: Musicians and composers have long been tempted to transcribe and rearrange each other’s works, like chefs experimenting with a recipe. Sometimes new ingredients are a welcome addition; on other occasions you yearn for the original flavors.

headline: Study Links Rise in Mastectomies to M.R.I. Detection
text: New techniques for detecting breast cancer may be leading more women to have their entire breast removed, researchers said Thursday.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: After a Hectic Week, a Partylike Evening at Phillips de Pury Brings in $59 Million
text: After 48 hours in which more than $800 million in art was snapped up by the world’s super-rich, several hundred collectors, dealers and art advisers went back for more, trekking to Chelsea on Thursday night for the final evening sale in a marathon week of contemporary-art auctions.

headline: District Puts All the World in Classrooms
text: NEW HYDE PARK, N.Y.  For nearly a decade, the lesson that the world is interconnected  call it Globalization 101  has been bandied about as much in education as in economics, spurring a cottage industry of internationally themed schools, feel-good cultural exchanges, model United Nations clubs and heritage festivals.

headline: A Hearing No One Needs
text: With a terrible sense of foreboding, I read the interview with Matt Walsh on The New York Times’s Web site, describing how, earlier in this decade, Walsh was delegated to spy on opposing coaches.

headline: Obama Admires Bush
text: Hezbollah is one of the world’s most radical terrorist organizations. Over the last week or so, it has staged an armed assault on the democratic government of Lebanon.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Footnotes
text: Indiana Jones  oops, make that Harrison Ford   has been elected to the board of the Archaeological Institute of America. Brian Rose, president of the nonprofit organization, said, “Harrison Ford has played a significant role in stimulating the public’s interest in archeological exploration.” ... “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” featuring Duane Chapman, will return to the A&E lineup on June 25. The series, the most successful on A&E in recent years, was suspended last fall after Mr. Chapman made racially charged comments in a private telephone conversation made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapman’s son for the tape. At the time, A&E announced it was stopping production “for the foreseeable future.” ... Yet another reprieve has been granted the Mount, the financially troubled Edith Wharton House in Lenox, Mass. Seeking to avert foreclosure, it has raised more than $875,000 in an emergency campaign and announced on Thursday that its major creditors had agreed to extend the foreclosure deadline for six months, until Oct. 31. Planning a full season of operations, the house opened to the public last Friday and generated $8,000 in revenue in its first three days.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Saturday about Senator John McCain’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama’s Middle East policy incompletely described Mr. Obama’s position on negotiating with the leaders of countries, including Iran, with which the United States currently has little contact. While Mr. Obama and his aides have indeed described various conditions and limitations on such negotiations, Mr. Obama himself, in a Democratic debate in July 2007, also said he would be willing "to meet separately, without precondition" with the leaders of Iran, Syria, Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea.

headline: California Supreme Court Overturns Gay Marriage Ban
text: The California Supreme Court, striking down two state laws that had limited marriages to unions between a man and a woman, ruled on Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.

headline: Farm Bill, Facing Veto, Goes to Bush
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a five-year, $307 billion farm bill with wide bipartisan support, virtually sealing President Bush’s defeat in a battle over agriculture policy.

headline: Those Gas Prices: Think Outside the Tank
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yahoo’s Chairman Disputes Icahn’s Accusations
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo’s chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the company’s board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

headline: Unions Bankrolled Analyst Vetting Pension Bill
text: ALBANY  A bill offering thousands of additional city workers early retirement has been gaining support in the Legislature in recent weeks. New York City officials have protested, saying it would cost the city $200 million annually.

headline: Pakistan: Sharif Cleared to Run for Parliament
text: An election tribunal in Lahore accepted the nomination papers of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, paving the way for him to run in legislative elections on June 18. Mr. Sharif’s papers had been rejected during the general elections in February. His party, Pakistan Muslim League-N, pulled out of cabinet ministries this week over the failure to reinstate the Supreme Court judges dismissed by President Pervez Musharraf last year.

headline: This Is Basketball, Boys; It’s Not Rocket Science
text: Well now, if this isn’t just the cutest thing I don’t know what is. “Quantum Hoops,” a documentary by Rick Greenwald, tells the story of the California Institute of Technology’s men’s basketball team  a topic that in the context of college sports is approximately as farcical as the history of aspiring semioticians among the contestants on “America’s Next Top Model.”

headline: Soon-to-Be Retiree Has a Share of the Lead
text: CLIFTON, N.J.  Annika Sorenstam may be retiring from the L.P.G.A. Tour at the end of the year, but she hardly seemed like a retiree Thursday while grabbing a share of the Sybase Classic’s first-round lead.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a skirmish between rival ice cream truck drivers outside a school building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan referred incorrectly in some copies to the school that shares the building with Public School 9. It is the Anderson School  not the Sarah Anderson School, which is an alternate name for P.S. 9.

headline: 100 Feared Dead in Nigerian Pipeline Fire
text: LAGOS, Nigeria  More than 100 people were feared dead on Thursday after a construction vehicle struck an oil pipeline on the outskirts of Lagos, Nigeria’s biggest city, setting off an oil-fed inferno that spread to surrounding homes and a school.

headline: 'Idol' Semifinals Buoy Fox
text: Fox’s “American Idol” dominated another night of television ratings on Wednesday as the singing competition reduced its cast of would-be pop stars to two, David Archuleta and David Cook, above, who will compete in next week’s finale. Nielsen’s estimated that 24.3 million viewers tuned in to the results show at 9 p.m., during which Syesha Mercado was eliminated. Fox led the night overall despite drawing much more modest ratings during the 8 p.m. hour with its comedies “ ’Til Death” (5.8 million) and “Back to You” (6.9 million). CBS took second place with “Criminal Minds” at 9 (12.7 million) and “CSI: NY” at 10 (11.6 million). NBC and ABC ranked third and fourth, with NBC earning slightly more viewers with “Deal or No Deal” from 8 to 10 (7.1 million) followed by “Law & Order” (8.6 million).

headline: Doherty Performs Again
text: Fresh out of prison after serving 29 days of a 14-week sentenced for breaking probation imposed for drug and driving offenses, the Babyshambles singer Pete Doherty, 29, returned to the stage for the first time, performing with his band in London on Tuesday, the BBC reported. He says he had overcome his drug problems while in Wormwood Scrubs prison. ... Bob Dylan will perform on June 23 at the 2008 World Expo in Zaragoza in northeastern Spain, Agence France-Presse reported on Wednesday, citing organizers of the event, scheduled to run from June 14 through Sept. 14. For the fair, expected to draw 6.5 million visitors, Mr. Dylan has recorded a new version of his classic “A Hard Rain’s A-Gonna Fall,” including his spoken comments on the importance of clean water worldwide. Other performers at the fair, with exhibits from about 100 countries, will be Alanis Morissette, Iggy Pop and Montserrat Caballé.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A film review on May 7 about “Battle for Haditha,” which looks at the killing of 24 Iraqi civilians by United States marines in the city of Haditha in November 2005, referred incorrectly to some of the evidence in the case. According to marines’ testimony in legal proceedings, Iraqi men shot and killed in one house were armed. It has not been established that “no weapons were found in the houses” where Iraqis were killed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Italy Arrests Hundreds of Immigrants
text: ROME  Underscoring the new Italian government’s determination to crack down on illegal immigration and what the government contends is associated crime, Italy’s police arrested hundreds of people this week in a sweep of migrant shantytowns in major urban areas across the country, the police announced Thursday.

headline: What Next for the Democrats?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not Just a Dance, but a Book and a Web Site, Too
text: It is endearing to give the members of your audience a gift. It is smart to butter them up with compliments. And it is dynamite to perform a dance that makes them think. Eleanor Bauer/Good Move manages the trifecta in “At Large,” which opened on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory.

headline: What Wine Goes With Beetle Larvae?
text: The new vogue for survivalist entertainment has had trend watchers citing its roots in rising oil prices, the housing crunch, the credit crisis and other aspects of our economic turmoil, but I’m not so sure that people who enjoy “Man vs. Wild” are getting into it because they are fearing a collapse at Fannie Mae.

headline: Working Toward Total Seizure Control
text: Dr. Patricia Crumrine is a pediatric neurologist and the director of the Pediatric Epilepsy Center and the EEG Laboratory at the Children’s Hospital of Pittsburgh. Dr. Crumrine is as a principal investigator on several clinical studies evaluating the safety and efficacy of antiepileptic drugs for use in the treatment of childhood seizure disorders. Here are five things that she thinks everyone with epilepsy should know.

headline: Selected Studies: Epilepsy
text: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: New Indictment in Police Corruption Inquiry
text: In late 2006, a New York City detective was suspected of being involved with illegal drugs, and an Internal Affairs Bureau sergeant was bluntly advising him on how to avoid investigators, according to new court filings in a continuing federal probe of police corruption.

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Shaking Up the Crowd at Cannes
text: CANNES, France  The apocalypse came early to the Cannes Film Festival this year, filling screening rooms with snarling dogs, bursting bombs, shouting men and screaming women. Midway through Day 2, on Thursday, characters had gone blind, gone to prison, gone to war. One had turned into a piece of furniture, and another had crawled out of a sewer, slimed in waste that the filmmaker threw at the audience with giggles, metaphorically speaking, of course.

headline: Ruling May Revive Gay Marriage as Issue
text: WASHINGTON  Gay marriage is an issue on which the three major presidential candidates  John McCain, Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton  are pretty much in agreement. All oppose it, while saying at the same time that same-sex couples should generally be entitled to the legal protections afforded married couples. All think the decision should be left to the states.

headline: More Progress Asked of Smithsonian
text: The Government Accountability Office recognized the Smithsonian Institution’s progress in improving governance during the past year, but said in a report released on Thursday that there is still some distance to go. Among the initiatives cited in the report were the Smithsonian’s new and clarified policies on senior staff compensation, standardized leave and travel policies, ethical reforms, transparency and improved communications. The Board of Regents, the Smithsonian’s governing body, has also established an executive committee with three voting members, begun posting the minutes of its meetings on the Smithsonian Web site (si.edu) and agreed to hold a public meeting every year. At the same time, the report said, “development of policies and internal controls for broader operational issues such as travel, event expenses and contracting is still underway, and training and establishing accountability remain challenges.”

headline: Concerts Set to Benefit Children
text: Free concerts starring Shakira, Miguel Bose, Los Tigres del Norte and David Bisbal and others are expected to draw 300,000 people in Mexico City and Buenos Aires on Saturday and will issue a call for action to support early childhood development programs in Latin America. The concerts follow an announcement on Thursday by artists, intellectuals, business leaders and philanthropists, including Carlos Slim Helú and Howard Buffett, of the establishment of ALAS (América Latina en Acción Solidaria) to address the needs of an estimated 32 million impoverished children in the area.

headline: Fox Plans to Run Fewer Ads in 2 New Prime-Time Dramas
text: The Fox network announced a new approach Thursday to keep viewers hooked on shows: give them fewer commercials.

headline: From Around the Globe, a Mustering of the Tribes
text: All art fairs are messy, but the New York International Tribal & Textile Arts Show is messier than most. It assembles a ridiculously broad range of tribal art from Africa, Oceania, Asia and North and South America. It is a forceful, entrancing ensemble nonetheless.

headline: Opera Official Quits
text: Peter Mussbach, below, the general manger of the Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, has quit, The Associated Press reported. A statement from the city government on Thursday said that the Staatsoper, which oversees the city’s three opera houses, decided in consultation with Mr. Mussbach to “release him irrevocably with immediate effect” and that “both sides were prompted to take this step because they were unable to reach agreement on the future direction of the overall operation and the artistic programming.” Mr. Mussbach, 59, had been general manager of the Staatsoper since 2002.. Daniel Barenboim is the music director. The two reportedly were at odds over whether more money should go into opera productions or into the house’s Staatskapelle orchestra. At a recent public meeting of the heads of the opera houses and the city’s mayor, Klaus Wowereit, Mr. Mussbach denounced the mayor, who had said he would not renew Mr. Mussbach’s contract when it expired this summer.

headline: Ways to Share, and Save
text: TO own a second home, you need to be rich, right? Wrong. Various options are out there that let even regular folks have a piece of the vacation-home pie. And piece is the key word. You can buy into a second home either by time, by use or as part of a group.

headline: Oakley Hall, 87, Novelist Attuned to the Old West, Is Dead
text: Oakley Hall, the author of the novels “Warlock” and “The Downhill Racers” and a literary heir to fellow California writers like Wallace Stegner, died Monday at his home in Nevada City, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Nevada City, Squaw Valley and San Francisco.

headline: Blackstone Reports a $66.5 Million Quarterly Loss
text: The Blackstone Group, the big private equity firm run by Stephen A. Schwarzman, posted a $66.5 million quarterly loss on Thursday, and its executives warned that the turmoil in the financial markets may not be over.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in the special Well section on Tuesday about foot health described incorrectly peripheral artery disease, which reduces blood circulation to the feet. The disease involves narrowing of arteries in the legs, not veins.

headline: Myanmar Farmers May Miss Harvest
text: YANGON, Myanmar  Normally, at this time of year, Burmese farmers in the southern delta of Myanmar would be draining their rice paddies, plowing their fields with their water buffaloes and preparing to plant new seeds for an autumn harvest.

headline: Shingles Vaccine Recommended
text: People 60 or older should be vaccinated with Zostavax against shingles, a painful disorder related to chickenpox, health officials said. Only 2 percent of the 43 million people at risk for shingles have been immunized since the drug’s maker, Merck, won approval in May 2006 to sell the vaccine, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. A panel of outside advisers to the centers, based in Atlanta, gave a preliminary recommendation in October 2006 for the vaccine. More than one million people each year develop shingles, a recurrence of dormant chickenpox virus. Anyone who had chickenpox can contract shingles. The vaccine is covered by many health insurers.

headline: Deal for Auto Workers
text: The Canadian Auto Workers union reached tentative agreements with General Motors of Canada and Chrysler Canada on Thursday, four months before current contracts expire.

headline: The Table Brought a Whole Lot to D’Antoni
text: On the day Ethel Kennedy arrived for tea, Mike D’Antoni was a 9-year-old blur skittering through the family kitchen. A West Virginia boy had more pressing concerns than who would lead the free world.

headline: Out of the Wardrobe, Into a War Zone
text: Here in the unenchanted world of ordinary moviegoing, it has been about two and a half years since “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,” the first installment in Walt Disney and Walden Media’s mighty “Chronicles of Narnia” franchise. In wartime England, where the Pevensie children live when they’re not consorting with talking lions and battling witches, a year or so has gone by. But in Narnia itself, to which the four plucky Pevensies return in “Prince Caspian,” the second movie in the series, centuries have passed, and everything has changed. The grand hall where Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy were made monarchs of the realm has fallen into ruin, and the friendly woodland creatures with their homey British accents and computer-animated fur seem to have vanished from the scene.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Wednesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory in the West Virginia primary overstated the size of her campaign debt. The total debt is approximately $20 million and includes $11 million in personal loans from Mrs. Clinton; the $20 million is not in addition to those loans.

headline: Easing the Seizures, and Stigma, of Epilepsy
text: The first thing you notice about 13-year-old Nora Leitner is the dark circles under her eyes. They stand in stark contrast to the rest of her appearance. At a glance she might be any petite, pretty tween girl, with her blond ponytail, elfin frame and thousand-watt smile, but the circles tell a different story. Nora looks as if she hasn’t slept in a month.

headline: Spontaneity Was the Medium and the Message
text: Since Polaroid announced in February that it would stop manufacturing instant film and that supplies would run out next year, artists like Chuck Close and Lucas Samaras have been passing through stages of grief. Nothing, they say, can replace the Polaroid  awkward, dated, a little sleazy, but miraculous nonetheless.

headline: Gay Couples Celebrate California Decision; Both Sides See a Fight
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Gay and lesbian couples in San Francisco rejoiced on Thursday over a State Supreme Court decision affirming their right to marry even as political leaders on both sides of the issue girded for an extended fight over the ruling in the courts and at the ballot box.

headline: Oregon: Heat Killed Sea Lions
text: Six sea lions caught in traps at a major dam on the Columbia River died of heat exhaustion, not gunshots, as had earlier been suspected, federal officials said this week. The sea lions, which were found dead on May 4, feed off salmon and other fish making their way past the Bonneville Dam. They were being trapped as part of a federal and state effort to protect endangered Chinook salmon. Wildlife officials are authorized to permanently remove, and in some cases kill, California sea lions that had been previously tagged for feeding at the dam. One of the six that died was a tagged animal. Officials initially believed that the animals had been shot in the cages but later determined that they died from heat exhaustion. For reasons that remain unclear, gates on the cages, shown covered above, had closed unexpectedly, preventing the sea lions from cooling off in the water.

headline: Grand Isolation
text: WHO Denise Travers, 43, her husband, Brian Mills, 52,a lender for commercial real estate, and their children Conor, 14, and Cennedi, 11 WHERE Little Gasparilla Island, Fla. WHAT 4-bedroom house

headline: Eight Belles Did Not Have Heart Attack, Necropsy Report Says
text: Eight Belles, the filly who broke down after the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on May 3, sustained compound fractures of her front legs at the fetlock joints, a necropsy report released Thursday concluded.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a string of weeklong antiwar marches in upstate New York, culminating at Fort Drum on Saturday, misstated, in some copies, the number of years since the war in Iraq began. It started five years ago, in March 2003, not six years ago.

headline: France: Caesar Was Ambitious, and Perhaps Worried
text: An excavation near Arles has found what is thought to be the only surviving bust made of Julius Caesar during his lifetime, the newspaper Le Monde reported. “It is the only known bust of Caesar that was made when the emperor was still alive,” said Luc Long of the French Ministry of Culture, which organized the dig. The bust, which shows Caesar with little hair and a wrinkled forehead, was found in the Rhone River. The ministry said it was created around 46 B.C.

headline: Text of Icahn’s Letter to Yahoo Board
text: Following is the text of a letter sent by the billionaire investor, Carl Icahn, to the chairman of Yahoo, Roy Bostock, on Thursday in which Mr. Icahn announced plans to start a proxy fight for Yahoo. Included with the letter were the biographies of Mr. Icahn’s 10 nominees for the board. (Later in the day, Yahoo issued a response.)

headline: When Artworks Collide
text: “Who’s Afraid of Jasper Johns?,” a group show at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery in Chelsea, is the latest proof that you don’t have to be a museum to shake things up. It was organized by Gavin Brown, who has a downtown gallery of his own, and Urs Fischer, a Swiss artist he represents.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Rulers Unleash Police on Anglicans
text: JOHANNESBURG  The parishioners were lined up for Holy Communion on Sunday when the riot police stormed the stately St. Francis Anglican Church in Harare, Zimbabwe’s capital. Helmeted, black-booted officers banged on the pews with their batons as terrified members of the congregation stampeded for the doors, witnesses said.

headline: Western Experts Monitor China’s Nuclear Sites for Signs of Earthquake Damage
text: China’s main centers for designing, making and storing nuclear arms lie in the shattered earthquake zone, leading Western experts to look for signs of any damage that might allow radioactivity to escape.

headline: A Disgraceful Farm Bill
text: Congress has approved a $307 billion farm bill that rewards rich farmers who do not need the help while doing virtually nothing to help the world’s hungry, who need all the help they can get.

headline: McCain Vision Has Most G.I.’s Out of Iraq by 2013
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Senator John McCain declared on Thursday that most American troops would be home from Iraq by 2013 and that the nation would be a functioning democracy with only “spasmodic” episodes of violence. The comments were a striking departure from his usual refusal to set a date for American withdrawal.

headline: For a Change, N.L. Clubs Are Outscoring A.L. Clubs
text: Johan Santana was focused on finding the right shirt to wear under his Mets jersey. As a conversation started, Santana was more immersed in the shirt than the words. But once Santana heard statistics detailing how National League hitters have been superior to American League hitters this year, he was intrigued.

headline: Safer Building Sites
text: To the Editor:

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Shaping a Work That Has Returned to Fashion
text: Monteverdi’s “Vespro Della Beata Vergine” (1610) seems to be in fashion at the moment. Years go by when performances are few and far between (although recordings are always plentiful), yet over the last five years or so they have been turning up several times a year, sometimes performed by period-instrument bands and Baroque vocal specialists but often by church choirs supported by modern forces.

headline: In Manhattan’s Dominican Areas, a Different Political Campaign Holds the Stage
text: For the past few weeks, the talk of Washington Heights, like most other places in New York, has been of campaigns and elections and a nation’s future. But in Upper Manhattan, the names Hillary Clinton, John McCain and Barack Obama rarely come up.

headline: Of Canadians, Tourism, and Free Parties as Ads
text: With Canada’s dollar on a par with America’s  and having a cuter, Seuss-like nickname: the loonie  New York’s upstairs neighbors need to find better reasons than the exchange rate to lure tourists.

headline: Blackwater’s Impunity
text: After guards from Blackwater Worldwide protecting a State Department convoy killed at least 17 Iraqis in a hail of bullets last September, we hoped the Bush administration would rethink the folly of relying on mercenaries, who have no accountability to Iraqi or American law.

headline: Pakistan Defies U.S. on Halting Afghanistan Raids
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani officials are making it increasingly clear that they have no interest in stopping cross-border attacks by militants into Afghanistan, prompting a new level of frustration from Americans who see the infiltration as a crucial strategic priority in the war in Afghanistan.

headline: The Serene Life of a Fighter for Civil Liberties
text: Kent Lakes, N.Y.

headline: Gay Couples Rejoice at Ruling
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Gay and lesbian couples in San Francisco rejoiced Thursday over a state Supreme Court decision affirming their right to marry even as political leaders on both sides of the issue prepared for an extended fight over the ruling in the courts and at the ballot box.

headline: Editor From Herald Tribune to Run A.P. News in the U.S.
text: PARIS  Michael Oreskes, the executive editor of The International Herald Tribune and a veteran journalist at The New York Times, said on Thursday that he was leaving the paper to take a newly created position as managing editor for United States news at The Associated Press.

headline: Led by Germany, a Strong Quarter for Europe
text: FRANKFURT  Surprising even the most optimistic forecasters, the German economy grew 1.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, delivering its best performance in more than a decade despite the global financial crisis and recessionary fears enveloping the United States.

headline: Man’s Best Friend, Hoofed Department
text: Without horses, where would we be? Trousers might never have become fashionable. The violin might never have come into existence. The Aztecs might have thrived another few centuries. The Industrial Revolution might have sputtered out before its time. No one would have to get off his high horse, and no political race would have a dark horse candidate. And the American Museum of Natural History would have had to find another subject for its sprawling, charming and illuminating exhibition that is opening on Saturday: “The Horse.”

headline: Rescuers Aim for Chinese Villages Yet Unreached
text: WANDENG, China  The People’s Liberation Army marched into this tiny village only to find that Monday’s earthquake had destroyed the road leading deeper into the mountains. Beyond, 20 men were trapped in a distant coal mine. Even farther away, a mining town of 5,000 people was cut off and partly buried beneath fallen rocks and dirt.

headline: Housing Investment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bob the Builder
text: I APPROACHED Bob Rauschenberg in the mid-’80s to design a cover for the Talking Heads record “Speaking in Tongues.” I had recently seen some of his black-and-white photo collages at Leo Castelli’s gallery on West Broadway and thought they were amazing, and I wondered what he would do with an LP cover.

headline: Hunger and Food Prices Push Afghanistan to Brink
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Thieves raided the city flour market in broad daylight a few weeks ago, shooting and wounding two people before escaping with their loot.

headline: The Woes of New York’s Public Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Wall Street Workers, Ax Falls Quietly
text: People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight.

headline: Tending to the Legacy of a Deco Master
text: TENDING TO THE LEGACY

headline: Bush Assails ‘Appeasement,’ Touching Off Storm
text: JERUSALEM  President Bush used a speech to the Israeli Parliament on Thursday to liken those who would negotiate with “terrorists and radicals” to appeasers of the Nazis  a remark widely interpreted as a rebuke to Senator Barack Obama, who has advocated greater engagement with countries like Iran and Syria.

headline: Former Videographer Details Patriots’ Spying
text: Matt Walsh, a former New England Patriots videographer who helped the team spy on opposing teams, met with N.F.L. officials and Senator Arlen Specter on Tuesday for separate interviews about how the Patriots conducted an illicit videotaping program under Coach Bill Belichick.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 105 Temple
text: Location: Philadelphia

headline: LIVE Friday on This Blog: Russia-Finland and Canada-Sweden
text: Stuck in the office, jonesing for hockey? No problem. Join the Times hockey blog on Friday afternoon at 1:00 Eastern Time for our description of the IIHF World Championship semifinal between Russia and Finland, LIVE, as it happens at Le Colisée in Quebec City. Then return to the Slap Shot blog at 5:00 Eastern for our LIVE play-by-play of the Canada-Sweden semifinal, described as it unfolds in Quebec City. Jeff Z. Klein will narrate the Russia-Finland match, Jeff Hale the Canada-Sweden contest.

headline: Herald Reporter Walks Through How He Botched Article
text: In a  lengthy column posted shortly after midnight on The Boston Herald Web site, John Tomase, The Herald’s Patriots beat writer, explained how he blundered in his infamous Super Bowl walk-through article. How much damage did Tomase do? In a radio interview Thursday, the Patriots’ president, Jonathan Kraft, said the article was a significant distraction for the team the day before its Super Bowl loss to the Giants (more on that below).

headline: The New Jersey State Museum
text: The New Jersey State Museum’s main building reopened in Trenton after four years of renovation.

headline: The King and the Pygmy
text: With thoroughbred racing praying for an accident-free Preakness and hoping a Triple Crown winner will take the public’s mind off the industry’s troubles, the time has come to tell the story of “The King and the Pygmy.”

headline: Major art fair this weekend in Hong Kong
text: By Caroline Mok and Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

headline: Now Online / T's New Travel Issue
text: The new issue of T Travel charts the season’s most intriguing spots both near and far, from the Ontario lakes and the beating heart of Provence to a Himalayan wonderland in the north of India and the otherworldly desert of Namibia. (Be sure to check out Norbert Schoerner’s film “Soar,” shot near the Namib-Naukluft National Park, the site of our cover shoot.) We also take a look at how the creative class is shaking up Copenhagen; a new hotel that’s drawing attention to Australia’s Kangaroo Island; and even an unlikely artistic revival in Paducah, Ky. Plus: a guide to Beijing, the laid-back Italian island of Ischia, shopping in Barcelona and more. So come hit the road with us, no passport necessary.

headline: ‘Over 17,000 Boxes of Cookies’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: A Hot Dog Play, Then a Throw With Mustard on It
text: At the end of a running catch on Wednesday, Manny Ramirez of the Red Sox high-fives a fan in the bleachers before doubling-up the runner on first:

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Digs Into Infrastructure Plays
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is strapping on its hard hat.

headline: Morgan Stanley Cuts Staff in London
text: Morgan Stanley has begun a series of job cuts in London that could see at least 350 people let go. The Telegraph reported that the bank began cutting jobs on Wednesday, with the process expected to take some weeks as Morgan Stanley continues to restructure.

headline: Prudential Eyeing Equitable Fund
text: Prudential is among the parties eyeing Equitable Life‘s 7 billion pound with-profit fund, which is up for sale in what is expected to be the final restructuring of the troubled mutual, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Leaves R.B.S. Auction
text: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has pulled out of the bidding in Royal Bank of Scotland‘s $13.6 billion auction for its British insurance business.

headline: Australia’s GrainCorp Offers to Buy Ridley
text: GrainCorp has offered to buy livestock feed maker Ridley for $390.5 million. The deal would allow eastern Australia’s largest grain handler to gain 23 domestic grain mills and sales in North America.

headline: Report Finds Big Health V.C. Industry in Pennsylvania
text: In a study, Pennsylvania ranked sixth in the nation in health care-focused venture-capital firms.

headline: BHP Stock Mines Gold On Report of Partial Stake Buy
text: Shares of BHP Billiton set a record high in Sydney, Australia on Friday, after a local newspaper reported that China has approached an Australian superannuation and investment fund to partner in a multibillion-dollar attempt to buy a 9 percent stake in the mining giant.

headline: Bernanke Says Banks Need More Capital
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, pushed banks on Thursday to keep raising capital in the aftermath of losses from the credit crisis to avert deeper damage to the economy.

headline: Yue Yuen Aims for Retail Spinoff
text: Athletic shoe manufacturer Yue Yuen Industrial will spin-off its retail distribution business in China, assuming that its minority shareholders give it a nod of approval at a special general meeting next Tuesday.

headline: BlackRock’s UBS Portfolio Move: A Good Sign?
text: BlackRock‘s assignment to manage a massive subprime portfolio from UBS is a sign that first buyers are returning to assets long considered too toxic to touch, and more similar deals may follow, Reuters reported.

headline: Evercore Toasts Bollinger
text: Evercore Capital Partners has bought a majority stake in insurance broker Bollinger in a deal valued at $250 million, The Daily Deal reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: As Private Equity Snaps Up Debt, Others Stay Away
text: While Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and other investment banks purge themselves of billions in buyout loans, investors remain skittish about investing in the high-yield debt market, The New York Post reported.

headline: Severstal to Sell $1.5 Billion in Bonds
text: Severstal is planning to sell $1.5 billion of bonds, according to media reports.

headline: An Expensive Stroll Down Old Lane
text: It is far too early to say whether Vikram Pandit will be a success as Citigroup‘s chief executive. But it is already clear that his performance as a hedge-fund manager is nothing to crow about.

headline: CBS-CNet Deal is Good News for Jana
text: Activist hedge fund Jana Partners generated big gains on Thursday after CBS agreed to buy Internet news provider CNet Networks for $1.8 billion.

headline: In Yahoo Fight, It’s Goldman Against Icahn Again
text: Goldman Sachs and Carl C. Icahn, it seems, will square off once more.

headline: Seattle Venture Firm Stays Active
text: OVP Venture Partners is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, but the Seattle venture firm apparently isn’t slowing down as it gets on in years.

headline: For Wall Street Workers, Ax Falls Quietly
text: People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight. Thousands are losing their jobs as hard-pressed banks cut deep. But while layoffs are nothing new in the financial industry, this round seems different: it is eerily quiet.

headline: Yahoo Chairman Fires Back at Icahn
text: Yahoo‘s chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the company’s board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

headline: Attention CNET Shoppers
text: CNET Networks surprised the market, and no doubt Jana Partners, with its announcement Thursday that it would be acquired by CBS. But the merger agreement filed by CNET on Thursday contains its own surprise. CNET has negotiated a rather unique provision that gives it more leeway than usual to find another, higher bidder. If it can.

headline: Verso Shares Fall in Market Debut
text: Shares of Verso Paper, a company backed by private equity firm Apollo Management, fell 17 percent in their market debut Thursday. The company had already cut the number and expected price of shares to be sold.

headline: G.E. Confirms Potential Sale of Appliances Unit
text: General Electric on Friday confirmed that it is exploring a potential sale or spinoff of its appliances business, one of the oldest at the 120-year-old conglomerate.

headline: The Early Word: Conflict Issues for McCain
text: John McCain, the presumptive G.O.P. nominee, is cleaning up some ethical entanglements after news outlets questioned his campaign’s association to some questionable supporters.

headline: Senate Rejects Looser Media Ownership Rules
text: The Senate voted on Thursday to overturn new, looser media ownership restrictions in the 20 biggest U.S. cities, defying a White House threat to veto the measure.

headline: VH1 Acquires ‘Bachelor’ Library
text: The Hollywood Reporter: “‘The Bachelor’ will be looking for love all over again on VH1. The lifestyle cable network said Thursday it acquired the full library of ABC’s reality competition series.” VH1 has set network records with its own dating reality shows.

headline: City’s Employment Rate Holding Steady, for Now
text: The latest labor report indicates that the city’s economy has remained relatively vibrant even as the rest of the state has continued to lose jobs, Patrick McGeehan reports.

headline: Thursday Ratings: ‘Idol’ Nears End
text: Fox’s “American Idol” dominated another night of television ratings on Wednesday as the singing competition reduced its cast of would-be pop stars to two, David Archuleta and David Cook, who will compete in next week’s finale.

headline: In Search of McCain’s Mideast Doctrine
text: James P. Rubin, a former State Department official in the Clinton administration, says John McCain is guilty of hypocrisy when he criticizes Barack Obama for being willing to talk with Hamas. For proof, in a Washington Post op-ed, Rubin brings up some comments McCain made in an interview during the economic forum at Davos, Switzerland, in 2006:

headline: Arbitration Court Rules in Favor of ‘Blade Runner’
text: The Court of Arbitration for Sport has issued a ruling allowing the double-amputee South African sprinter Oscar Pistorius to compete at the Beijing Olmypics, overturning an International Association of Athletics Federations ban that barred him from competing. The IAAF ruled in January that the carbon-fibre “Cheetah” blades he uses give Pistorius, who runs the 400-meter sprint, a technical edge unavailable to other runners.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Pixels at an Exhibition
text: What do video artists make of YouTube? Every minute, 10 hours of video are uploaded to the video-sharing site, which now shows hundreds of millions of videos each day. The place is a mess. Maybe artists should avoid it altogether.

headline: Obesity Promotes Global Warming?
text: As someone who commutes by bicycle into Manhattan, I would normally applaud any scientific rationale for more bike lanes. But some calculations in the new issue of the Lancet make me uncomfortable. The authors argue that policies promoting cycling and walking are good for the planet because they could reduce obesity — and obesity, the authors calculate, contributes to global warming.

headline: Carlyle to Buy Booz Allen’s Government Unit
text: The consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton said early Friday that it would sell a majority stake of its government practice to the private equity firm Carlyle Group for $2.54 billion. The announcement came four months after DealBook reported that a potential deal with Carlyle, run by David Rubenstein, was in the works.

headline: Stray Questions for: Katie Roiphe
text: Katie Roiphe’s most recent book, “Uncommon Arrangements: Seven Portraits of Married Life in London Literary Circles, 1910-1939,” will be out in paperback this month.

headline: Looking Beyond Big Brown
text: Napoleon had Waterloo. Custer had Little Big Horn. I have the Triple Crown races. Nappie and George just had to do it once, I endure it every year. Once again trying to get it right, this time.

headline: Low-Fat Diet May Cut Prostate Cancer Risk
text: Cutting back on fried foods and baked goods may lower a man’s risk for prostate cancer, a new animal study suggests.

headline: Upfront Wrap-Up: Speaking Profanglish
text: Here is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the upfront week, which ended on Thursday.

headline: Moody’s Drops Merrill Deal
text: My column today deals with an amazingly bad mortgage securitization underwritten by Merrill Lynch a year ago.

headline: What’s ‘Even Worse’ About Buying Fake Handbags?
text: New York City is starting an advertising campaign on Monday concentrated on pay phones in Times Square and Chinatown to educate tourists and residents about the social costs of counterfeit and pirated goods.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Fast Pot-Stickers
text: What can make pot-stickers a minimalist dish? One approach is called takeout and is already quite common. The alternative is using the wrappers now sold in just about every supermarket.

headline: Lacrosse: Playing for the Final Four
text: So the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s lacrosse quarterfinals take place this weekend, Saturday at Annapolis, Md., and Sunday at Ithaca, N.Y. All four games can be seen live on ESPNU, and tracked live at InsideLacrosse.com.

headline: Batali, Paltrow, Bassols and Bittman
text: I spent about half of last fall in Spain, taping television with Mario Batali, Gwyneth Paltrow and Claudia Bassols. Here’s a preview of the show, which will air on public television this September.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Summer 2008
text: The new summer issue of T Travel charts the season’s most intriguing spots both near and far, from the Ontario lakes and the beating heart of Provence to a Himalayan wonderland in the north of India and the otherworldly desert of Namibia. (Be sure to check out Norbert Schoerner’s film “Soar,” shot near the Namib-Naukluft National Park, the site of our cover shoot.) We also take a look at how the creative class is shaking up Copenhagen; a new hotel that’s drawing attention to Australia’s Kangaroo Island; and even an unlikely artistic revival in Paducah, Ky. Plus: a guide to Beijing, the laid-back Italian island of Ischia, shopping in Barcelona and more. So come hit the road with us, no passport necessary.

headline: Our Preakness Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors make their Preakness selections.

headline: White House Smacks Democrats Over Bush Remarks
text: Update During the White House press gaggle today in Saudi Arabia, Dana Perino and Ed Gillespie expressed shock (!) over the widespread Democratic outrage toward President Bush’s remarks to the Knesset in Jerusalem yesterday.

headline: The Starting Line: What Is Disability?
text: The Court of Arbitration for Sport’s ruling Fridayclearing the way for Oscar Pistorius to compete for a spot on the South African Olympic team may be the key to a radical re-imagining of what constitutes “disability.” As Pistorius himself told the Times of London last year: “Would I want my legs back? I’d have to sit down and think about it.”

headline: The View From Brooklyn to London
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Unintended Consequences of the House Democrats’ Winning Streak
text: While much of the Congressional political focus has been on the declining fortunes and numbers of House Republicans, House Democrats have their own problem – they are winning too many elections, Carl Hulse writes today in his column.

headline: ‘Calling a Reporter Sweetie’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Barack Obama had to apologize for calling a reporter sweetie. Yeah, meanwhile, Bill Clinton apologized for calling a reporter when her husband was home.

headline: Parking Rule Suspension Starts Monday in Park Slope
text: A reminder for residents of Park Slope, Brooklyn: Starting on Monday, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended indefinitely — well, O.K., it will probably be just a few months.

headline: Bamboo You | Noguchi for Sale
text: Bamboo Basket Chair, 1950. Shioji, bamboo and iron. Designed by Isamu Noguchi in collaboration with Isamu Kenmochi and produced at the Industrial Arts Research Institute. (Courtesy The Noguchi Museum)

headline: ‘Anything She Can To Raise Money’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Hillary thinks there is a chance. She is counting on her stimulus check to keep her going.

headline: Art Happens
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Love of a Sport Is Tested
text: Elizabeth LaBan is a freelance writer who lives in Philadelphia.

headline: New Clinton Ads for Oregon, Kentucky
text: Not only is Hillary Rodham Clinton continuing her push for the White House, but she’s still actively competing on the airwaves.

headline: Job-Hunting in London? Keep Looking
text: From Julia Werdigier, DealBook’s colleague in London:

headline: Chevys in the Guggenheim
text: Last week, I finally made it to the Cai Guo-Qiang retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum. The centerpiece is a spectacular cascade of nine white Chevrolet Metros hung inside Frank Lloyd Wright’s courtyard. It is titled “Inopportune: Stage One” and was shown earlier in two versions, at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art and the Seattle Art Museum, with white Ford Tauruses instead of the Metros.

headline: The Morning Skate: Theory 33 Lives, the NHL Network Vanishes and Senator Blutarsky Speaks
text: Just when we thought we were free, that it was safe to move forward, we have been pulled back by an unknown force. And now, we face an uncertain future — a pair of Game Fives.

headline: Q & A: The Drama of Calcio
text: The race for the scudetto comes down to the final day of the Italian Serie A season: Inter clings to a one point (and tie-breaker) lead over rival AS Roma. When the neroazzuri visit relegation-threatened Parma on Sunday, and Roma travels to Catania, who is one above the drop zone, they’ll do so without their most loyal fans.

headline: Buster Posey Plays All Nine Positions
text: Florida State catcher (and sometimes shortstop and closer) Buster Posey played every position during Monday’s 10-0 victory over Savannah State. Surprisingly enough he is the fourth player to accomplish this feat under manager Mike Martin, who has been on the bench for 29-seasons at Florida State. Oh, and Posey also hit a grand slam in the second inning to give the Seminoles a 6-0 lead.

headline: Stephen King: The College Years
Interleague by the Numbers
text: With interleague play for the 2008 season starting Friday night, it is a good time to look back at some of the numbers from MLB.com dating back to the start of interleague play in 1997.

headline: Tour of Homeless Shelter Does Not Solve Problem
text: The Bedford-Atlantic Armory, at the corner of Bedford and Atlantic Avenues in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, is a massive, turreted structure that takes up a full city block near the center of the neighborhood. It is also a 350-bed men’s homeless shelter and assessment center, though Department of Homeless Services officials said there were only 345 men staying there on Wednesday, when I visited with a contingent from the department.

headline: Who Ya Gonna Believe?
text: As many have noted, including Peter Goodman in yesterday’s Times, the consumer price index figures for gasoline look a little strange these days.

headline: Grief, and Rising Anger, Over Fallen Schools
text: [UPDATE 5/17, 6 p.m.: Some readers, including some in China, have complained about my rush to explore causes and possible lapses related to schools in this, and other, earthquake zones. Here’s one comment, and my response and explanation.]

headline: Behindatthebar Is Scratched
text: Behindatthebar will not run in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday because of a bruised left front foot which was discovered Friday morning at Belmont Park. The scratch leaves a field of 12 for the race.

headline: ‘Hillary Democrats?’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Thank you for coming out on such a hot day — 101 degrees today in Los Angeles. Man. People were sweating like President Bush when he heard gay marriage was legal in California.

headline: Water Woes From Florida to Spain to Orbit
text: You need water more urgently than anything other than breathable air, yet the difficulty of securing a clean, reliable supply seems to be making headlines all over, and not just in desert areas or in the ravaged wake of disasters like the Sichuan earthquake or the Irrawaddy Delta cyclone.

headline: Water Rates Will Rise 14.5 Percent
text: Updated, 3:16 p.m. | The New York City Water Board voted this morning to approve a 14.5 percent increase for water and sewer rates — the largest increase since 1992. When the new rate is in place on July 1, according to the city’s Independent Budget Office, water rates will have risen a cumulative 77 percent [pdf] since 2001, and double digit increases are expected to keep coming for at least a few more years. According to official projections, the average single-family homeowner will pay $800 for water in the fiscal year that starts July 1, up from $700 this fiscal year.

headline: Audio: A Conversation With Dr. Dean Richardson
text: The University of Pennsylvania’s New Bolton Center is a well-known veterinary hospital, but you could argue that one horse truly put it on the map. The 2006 Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro has helped the hospital raise millions of dollars for patient care and laminitis research. Dr. Dean Richardson, the chief of surgery at the center and a horse lover, discusses (below and at left) his most famous patient, his reaction to Eight Belles and the future of horse racing.

headline: Icahn’s Proxy Fights: A Scorecard
text: “I’m the guy in school that the other guys go to and say ‘Beat that guy up.'” — Carl Icahn

headline: Props Dept. | Our Emmy Nominations
text: Here’s what we’ll be toasting to this weekend: T Magazine has been nominated for two daytime Emmy awards. The films are “Circle Squared,” by Todd St. John and “Dinner Plans,” by the Neistat Brothers. We commissioned these shorts for our 2007 holiday series on T’s Web site.

headline: FINAL: Russia 4-0 Finland
text: To follow the description of the Russia-Finland semifinal at the IIHF World Championship, LIVE, as it unfolds at Le Colisée in Quebec City, click on “read more” and then refresh like mad.

headline: Hot Prom Mess
text: Christian Siriano, the winner of Season 4 of Project Runway, has taken on his newest challenge…virtual reality. He has teamed up with Gaia, an online community, to create custom looks for its live prom this weekend. We talked to the catchphrase-loving designer about avatar couture, future projects and hot tranny messes.

headline: Republicans Warm Up at the N.R.A.
text: Kentucky’s senior senator, Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, addressed the gathering of the National Rifle Association earlier today at its convention in Louisville. (Senator John McCain, and his former G.O.P. rivals for the nomination — Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney — are also attending.)

headline: The Upfront Deadpool: Which Network Shows Will Be Killed Off First?
text: The upfronts are over. The broadcasters have laid their cards on the table. Which new shows will survive?

headline: The Yahoo Final Exam
text: From: The Deal ProfessorTo: DealBook Readers

headline: Upfrontology: Which Shows Will Become Hits?
text: Every network has a fall show they place their biggest bet on. Usually the most promising show is apparent from its place on the fall schedule.

headline: About That Foreign Policy ‘Dust Up’ . . .
text: Updated | 5:35 p.m. WATERTOWN, S.D.– Senator Barack Obama responded sharply Friday to recent criticism of his foreign policy by President Bush and Senator John McCain, saying that the Republican leaders were guilty of “dishonest, divisive attacks” and had engaged in “hypocrisy, fear-peddling, fear-mongering” in an effort to continue what Mr. Obama called “the failed policies” of the past seven years.

headline: A Construction Manual for Cupcakes
text: I am about as far from a cake decorator as anyone you’ve ever met — in fact you can count on the fingers of no hands the times I’ve used the small tips on a pastry tube — but I know art when I see it, and Karen Tack and Alan Richardson’s “Hello, Cupcake!” (Houghton Mifflin, out now; www.hellocupcakebook.com) qualifies. These are “recipes” — construction directions is more like it — for the most fanciful and frequently bizarre cupcakes you’ve ever seen, using ingredients that you may not even want to eat. Whatever; I have not had as much fun simply browsing through a book in months.

headline: Sports Activity After a Concussion Slows Recovery
text: Student athletes who return to sports quickly after a concussion appear to have a slower brain recovery than teens who stay off the field longer, a new study shows.

headline: Few Survivors Found in China Quake
text: As the death toll in China’s worst natural disaster in 30 years passed 22,000, the government estimated that the figure could climb to as many as 50,000 people.

headline: Atrocious Victorian Verse Shines at Auction
text: Even the most exceptionally talented among us have a very difficult time securing lasting fame by writing great poetry. From getting published to getting read to getting any sort of critical notice, it’s a low-odds proposition all around, and as for material reward, well, definitely don’t quit your day job.

headline: Q&A: The Earthquake in China
text: This week, a Times correspondent in China and a former Beijing bureau chief answered readers’ questions on the earthquake in Sichuan Province, the aftermath and the Chinese government’s response. The forum is now closed for questions.

headline: Who’ll Stop the Rain?
text: One thing a baseball writer hates is rain. It’s not so much because the game might be rained out; we have to be at the ballpark anyway, and we have to write regardless. It’s because everybody seems to ask us if we think the game will be called. The answer is always the same: I have no idea.

headline: FINAL: Canada 5, Sweden 4

text: ADDED: The video’s gone from YouTube. As commenter Will pointed out, this does not inspire confidence in its authenticity. But the jury  what jury?  is still out.
