headline: The Play’s the Thing, but N.Y.U. Has Some Revisions
text: The walls of the Provincetown Playhouse theater will be preserved under a revised plan from New York University, according to a group that has been fighting the proposed demolition of the building, which is at 133-139 MacDougal Street.Andrew Berman, the executive director of the group, the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, said the new plan calls for keeping the facade and the walls around the theater space, demolishing the rest of the building and building a new structure around it.

headline: The Plutocrats Go Shopping
text: You’d think the meltdown in the credit markets sparked by the housing crisis would be just the sort of economic upheaval that might even touch the checkbooks of the financial plutocracy at the pinnacle of economic power.

headline: Friday Happy Hour: Life in an Obamatopia
text: So, this week we’ve seen John McCain’s vision for the country in 2013, after he’s wrapped up his first term as president. Osama bin Laden will be dead and the American economy will be prosperous, he said.

headline: Robert Mondavi Dies
text: Robert Mondavi, perhaps the most influential American winemaker of the past 50 years, died today at the age of 94.

headline: Minnesota’s Fired Crisis Director Stays Fired
text: When the in Minneapolis collapsed last Aug. 1, Sonia Morphew Pitt was out of town. Then she was out of a job. Now she’s out of luck.

headline: Answers About Cycling in New York, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of answers from Joshua Benson, the bicycle program coordinator for the New York City Department of Transportation, to selected City Room reader questions.

headline: Six Months Since Cyclone Sidr
text: The cyclone disaster in Myanmar is as rife with human error as with elemental force — and this problem is all too common.

headline: TV at 140 Miles an Hour
text: One benefit of the transition to digital broadcasting is that, thanks to compression technologies, multiple channels can be transmitted in the space previously needed for just one.

headline: Leaving for the Land of Euros
text: I’m off on my Grand Tour of Europe. Get a preview of my 12-week journey, watch me scrounge for euros and take the subway (the most frugal way, of course) to the airport.

headline: Protest Stops Traffic in Crown Heights
text: Updated, 7:06 p.m. | A crowd of more than 300 Hasidic Jewish residents began a protest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon to express anger over the assault and robbery of a 16-year-old Jewish man early Friday morning. The protesters marched from the scene of the crime, at Empire Boulevard and Albany Avenue, to the 71st Precinct, and then up New York Avenue to Eastern Parkway, one of the neighborhood’s main corridors, where protesters blocked traffic. They were briefly stopped at Kingston Avenue from going forward by a line of police officers who stood arm-to-arm. After the protesters shouted for a while longer, traffic was reopened on the parkway at 6:10 p.m. and the crowd gradually dispersed around 6:45 p.m.

headline: Some Gas Pumps Can’t Handle the Truth
text: Driving through California last month, I couldn’t believe that gas had passed $4 a gallon. With the price of oil continuing to climb, the rest of the country seems to be heading to $4 as well. But for some gas stations, it’s literally impossible to charge more than $3.99 a gallon.

headline: Speaker Tosses Work of ‘Voodoo’ Actuary
text: Speaker Sheldon Silver’s office said Friday that the Assembly would put all pension bills on hold that rely on financial analyses prepared by Jonathan Schwartz, a consultant paid by labor unions. The Speaker said the bills would need new “fiscal notes,” which are legally required to explain the cost of bills to taxpayers.The move, which would affect scores of current bills, followed a New York Times report revealing that the Legislature has been using Mr. Schwartz, a union consultant, to draft financial analyses of legislation impacting the city’s pension funds.

headline: McCain Criticizes Obama, Clinton on Gun Control
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Senator John McCain reached out to the National Rifle Association on Friday and warned 6,000 people at the group’s annual convention that a President Barack Obama or Hillary Rodham Clinton would put the rights of “law-abiding’’ gun owners at risk.

headline: Our Bloggers’ Picks
text: Patrick Patten of Handride and Alan Mann of Left at the Gate share their picks. View their Derby picks here.

headline: Former Arabic School Principal Faces Defamation Suit
text: Updated, May 17 | Three opponents of a Brooklyn public school that teaches Arabic filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against the school’s founding principal, Debbie Almontaser, claiming that she had defamed them by saying that they stalked her.

headline: Huckabee Jokes About Obama Ducking Gunfire
text: Updated Known for his humor on the campaign trail, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee raised some eyebrows with his latest improvisation, which imagined a gun pointed at Senator Barack Obama of Illinois.

headline: ‘The View’ To Go Backstage For One Show
text: Associated Press: “Daytime’s ‘The View’ will rerun one of its shows in two weeks from an entirely different view that lets fans know a little about what goes on backstage. Producers will attempt the experiment with the Memorial Day episode, which is being taped a week earlier. On Friday, May 30, ‘The View’ will air a version of that show with backstage footage that explains what went into making it. Only about half of the original show will be seen.”

headline: Larry King Squelches Ryan Seacrest Rumors
text: “Larry King, who said last year that he hoped Ryan Seacrest would succeed him on CNN should he ever give up his prime-time show, invited Mr. Seacrest on as a guest Thursday night and then sought to tamp down speculation that any succession was imminent,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: Previewing the 2008 Cable Show
text: “Cable operators are riding high heading into this year’s industry trade show, which kicks off this weekend,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a 93-year-old barfly, spring rainshowers and a record art sale at Christie’s.

headline: Mets-Yankees Rained Out
text: The rain never really stopped Friday and still had not stopped as of 7:30 p.m. So the game between the Yankees and the Mets at Yankee Stadium was postponed. No makeup date has been decided, but the Yankees said it would not be played on Saturday, Sunday or Monday.Anyone with tickets for Friday’s game can use them for the rescheduled game or exchange their tickets for any regular-season game at the stadium for the next 12 months. Because of the limited ticket availability, the Yankees are encouraging fans to use their tickets on the rescheduled date. The Yankees and the Mets are scheduled to play at Shea Stadium on June 27, 28 and 29. Sounds as if another day-nighter between the Queens and the Bronx is possible.

headline: The Reasoning Behind the Pistorius Ruling
text: Many commenters have expressed disbelief in the wake of Friday’s decision to overturn the International Association of Athletics Federations’ ban against the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius. What some of them seem to have missed was the reasoning behind the Court of Arbitration for Sport’s unanimous decision: that the scientific analysis suggesting Pistorius gained an advantage from his prostheses was fundamentally flawed.

headline: Final Preakness Preparations
text: Wet weather at Pimlico Friday morning affected the training of the Preakness contenders on the grounds. Only Icabad Crane, who is not at Pimlico, had a good track to gallop over this morning; the tapeta track at Fair Hill Training Center. With this morning’s defection of Behindatthebar, Icabad Crane is the only Preakness starter not on the grounds at Pimlico. He will ship in early Saturday morning.

headline: Another Poll: At Odds, or Not?
text: One day after Gallup released a poll showing that 38 percent of Americans favor banning animal racing, Rasmussen Reports unveiled a poll Friday showing that only 10 percent of Americans favor banning horse racing.

headline: High-Tech Japan Running Out of Engineers
text: TOKYO  Japan is running out of engineers.

headline: 1 Killed and 7 Hurt as Van Jumps Curb
text: A van jumped a curb on Lexington Avenue in Harlem and crashed into a sidewalk crowd on Friday, killing the driver and injuring seven bystanders, one critically, the authorities said.

headline: Parmalat Had Little Cash Left, Executive Testifies
text: Parmalat, the Italian dairy, had 6.5 million euros ($10 million) in cash left six days after filing for bankruptcy in 2003, rather than the 4 billion euros it claimed to have, Roberto Trovati, a former chief accounting officer, testified at a civil trial in New Jersey. Mr. Trovati was the first witness at a trial where Parmalat’s chief executive, Enrico Bondi, is seeking to prove that the dairy’s former banker, Citigroup, abetted corrupt employees who looted the company. Citigroup has countersued, claiming it was a victim of the fraud that led to the company’s collapse.

headline: Marine Given 4 Years in Sex Case
text: TOKYO  A United States court-martial on Friday sentenced a marine to four years in prison for sexually abusing a 14-year-old Japanese girl, ending a case that deepened anger over the American military presence in Japan.

headline: Kyle Busch Is Being Compared to a Nascar Icon
text: CONCORD, N.C.  When Kyle Busch knocked Dale Earnhardt Jr. out of the lead in the final laps of a Sprint Cup race this month in Richmond, Va., Busch did more than infuriate a legion of fans devoted to Earnhardt, the most popular driver in Nascar. He also drew comparisons to Earnhardt’s father, whose aggressive driving style helped him win seven Cup titles and a following that still exists seven years after he died in a crash at the Daytona 500.

headline: Glimpses of Survivors, Miraculous and Few, in Earthquake’s Ruins
text: YINHUA, China  Four days after a powerful earthquake turned this picturesque mountain town into a jumble of beams and brick and gray roof tiles, villagers stood on a knoll to watch rescue workers pick through the remains of a six-story apartment block. At one point came a hush, and then a burst of applause, as a man emerged from a slit in the rubble, his body draped in a floral blanket.

headline: It’s Not Just Petroleum, All Imports Cost More
text: FOR years, waves of inexpensive imports helped to keep inflation at bay in the United States. But those days are over, and now many imports are bringing inflation with them.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 9 through May 16:

headline: Dominican President Wins a Third Term
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  Dominicans who went to the polls on Friday had been given chickens, poured beer, promised new homes and even handed cash during a spirited frenzy of campaigning. But President Leonel Fernández won a third term in office largely as a result of a campaign gift to the populace that dwarfed those of his six opponents: a shiny new subway system.

headline: Unwrapping the Secrets of Ordinary Objects
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  Almost every day since 1972, the German artist Peter Dreher has painted a small picture of the same simple water glass on a white table in a white room. Two of those exemplary exercises in close observation are included in “Here’s the Thing: The Single Object Still Life,” a visually and philosophically engaging exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art.

headline: Figures on a Stage, Alone, Together
text: Art is a puzzle. How is it that a performer can look mysterious and intriguing  a conduit to a whole other world  while not doing very much? Nina Winthrop’s “Minority,” which opened at the Flea Theater on Thursday night, accomplishes this feat in its first moments with ambient sounds of chattering, a half-lighted stage and one woman who walks on slowly, only to slump forward, gradually straighten and tip her head backward.

headline: A Classroom Where the Teacher Really Wants That Apple
text: THE gelding we nicknamed Big Brown, in honor of the Kentucky Derby winner, loped off to the far corner of the arena as if he were looking for a place to hide. I exchanged frustrated frowns with my teammate, Shanda Steenburn, a tall, curly-haired nurse and hospital pharmacy manager.

headline: Medical Company’s Investors Sue Over Acquisition
text: Shareholders of CryoCor, the maker of a device that freezes heart muscle to correct abnormal rhythms, sued the company to block its acquisition by Boston Scientific. The complaint, filed in California state court in San Diego, requests a court order blocking an April 18 merger agreement. Boston Scientific and CryoCor announced last year that they would work together to develop new treatments for atrial fibrillation using extreme cold.

headline: Sunni Insurgents in Mosul Offered Amnesty and Cash
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki offered amnesty and cash payments to Sunni insurgents in the northern city of Mosul on Friday.

headline: Mr. Bloomberg’s Small Pot of Gold
text: Each day, it seems, there is more news about how New York’s politicians  in the City Council and the State Legislature  hand out taxpayer funds as political sweets to friends and allies. The only one who seemed exempt from the game was Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

headline: Mayoral Hopeful, an Earmark Critic, Has His Own
text: There is no doubt that Anthony D. Weiner wants to be mayor of New York. And there is no doubt, to that end, that he has seen an opening to wound a rival: criticizing Christine C. Quinn and the City Council he once was a member of for doling out money to favored groups in their districts.

headline: In Effort to Avoid Conflicts, McCain Issues New Rules for Staff
text: WASHINGTON  After expelling four advisers in the last week over concerns about their outside entanglements, Senator John McCain said Friday that his presidential campaign was beginning a new “vetting process” intended to end the embarrassments over staff ties to private interests, foreign governments or independent political groups.

headline: Women of Rock, Here’s Your Musical Grandma
text: All those interested in improving their chances of snagging the vice-presidential slot on one of the 2008 tickets should tune in “The Sweet Lady With the Nasty Voice,” on Sunday on the Smithsonian Channel. It has nothing to do with politics, but it’s a virtual clinic in the art of self-promotion.
