text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A chart on Friday sizing up the field for the Preakness Stakes misstated the distance of the race. It is 1 3/16 miles, not 1 3/4.

headline: Rhode Island’s Budget Crisis Deepens
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Darrell West, a political science professor at Brown University, sums up Rhode Island’s budget crisis this way: “It’s a bad situation that keeps getting worse as the economy weakens.”

headline: A Problem of Perception for the Mets
text: Such is the state of the Mets that they make the last-place Yankees, with a blustering owner and a general manager probably dangling again on the big employment hook, appear as placid as Carlos Beltrán on a cloudless day at Coney Island.

headline: Hard Roads Ahead
text: Walt Disney would have been proud of John McCain’s presentation on Thursday of what the world might look like at the end of a first McCain term as president.

headline: Places to Go, but Dreading the Fill-Up
text: SOMETIME in the last couple of months, the price of gasoline crossed a line. It’s not just that gas is now hovering around the dreaded $4 a gallon. It’s that an unconscious expense has become a painfully conscious one.

headline: Stiller Eyes Sequel
text: Ben Stiller has found another hallowed institution to flee. The sequel to “Night at the Museum,” the 2006 hit in which he played a security guard trapped in the American Museum of Natural History when its exhibits come alive, will be shot at the Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum, below. “Night at the Museum II: Escape From the Smithsonian,” scheduled for release in May 2009, is the first commercial film for which the museum has allowed itself to be used. “The popularity of the first movie convinced us that this is an innovative way to capture the imagination and curiosity of a young audience,” Richard Kurin, the museum’s acting under secretary for history, art and culture, wrote in a memo that was posted on the blog Modern Art Notes at ArtsJournal.com. The cast includes Owen Wilson and Amy Adams. On-location shooting was scheduled to be completed next week.

headline: In New York, Debating a Flat Tax on Gasoline
text: With gasoline prices hitting new records daily, oil companies are not the only ones raking it in. New York City is profiting, too.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on Friday about the comedian Mort Sahl was accompanied by an incorrect picture in some copies. The photograph was of the comedian Shelley Berman, not Mr. Sahl.

headline: Paulson Says Economy Is Starting to Rebound
text: The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivered a guardedly optimistic message to business leaders on Friday, saying that the economy was moving toward a rebound after months of malaise.

headline: Soldier’s Ploy Backfires in Bid to Quit War
text: The door to the doughnut shop swung open. For a moment, the tall young man, every bit a soldier in his bearing, stood with the windy rain of Friday afternoon at his back. A wave of coffee and doughnut humidity slapped him in the face.

headline: A Traveling Festival Comes Back to Town, This Time With a New Slate of Works
text: On its home turf, the Jerusalem International Chamber Music Festival takes place at the end of the summer. But during the rest of the year, the pianist Elena Bashkirova, who founded the festival in 1998, tours with some of its players, and on Thursday evening, a representative ensemble performed at the Metropolitan Museum. Ms. Bashkirova’s celebrated husband, the pianist Daniel Barenboim, was not among them, but their son, Michael Barenboim, was the group’s violinist. They were joined by Kyril Zlotnikov, a cellist, and Matthias Glander, a clarinetist, in works by Schumann, Hindemith, Berg and Beethoven.

headline: Obama Says Bush and McCain Are ‘Fear Mongering’ in Attacks
text: WATERTOWN, S.D.  Senator Barack Obama responded sharply on Friday to attacks on his foreign policy, linking President Bush and Senator John McCain as partners in “the failed policies” of the past seven years and criticizing them for “hypocrisy, fear peddling, fear mongering.”

headline: Frustrating the Pirates
text: DISPENSING with the bluster that normally surrounds the issue of pirated movies and music, Anders Bylund of Ars Technica tries to appeal to business sense in arguing that media companies should stop suing their potential customers and instead try to serve them (arstechnica.com).

headline: Saving Horses, One Thoroughbred at a Time
text: COOKSTOWN, N.J.  A thoroughbred named Tchaikovsky, a grandson of Secretariat, was having a tooth pulled in one stall. A horse in another was given a sponge bath. Out the stable door, about a dozen horses shared a sun-lit field.

headline: No Hope for the Defense? Create a Distraction
text: When you are defending and believe that declarer is slated to make his contract, try to find a diversionary tactic.

headline: Smithsonian Director Resigns
text: Sharon F. Patton has resigned after five years as the director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art, effective in December. In a statement, Ms. Patton said she had achieved much of what she set out to accomplish, but she also nodded to the appointment of a new leadership at the Smithsonian. (G. Wayne Clough, the president of Georgia Tech, is to assume the post of Smithsonian secretary, or chief executive, on July 1.) “It seems to be the right time to leave,” Ms. Patton, 64, said. Under her leadership the museum’s collection of more than 9,000 African art objects grew to include the Walt Disney-Tishman collection of 500 pieces from nearly every country in Africa. She also increased programming for children and promoted contemporary artists. The Smithsonian has been through considerable turmoil over the last year and a half. Its previous secretary, Lawrence M. Small, resigned over revelations that he spent the institution’s money on luxuries like private jets. In a report on Thursday, the Government Accountability Office cited recent progress at the institution but said it still needed better internal controls.

headline: Galaxies Twice as Bright as They Seem, Study Finds
text: The universe, it seems, has been operating with a dimmer switch.

headline: Looming Dangers for Orphaned Burmese
text: BANGKOK  While the death toll in Myanmar continues to climb, international aid agencies are warning of a new kind of threat to the most vulnerable survivors, children.

headline: House G.O.P. to Re-evaluate Course
text: WASHINGTON  Still smarting from Tuesday’s special-election loss in Mississippi, House Republicans have set a special meeting for next Tuesday to try to find a way to turn around their political slide.

headline: Airlines Told to Report Tarmac Delays Fully
text: WASHINGTON  The Department of Transportation said on Friday that it would require airlines to give fuller accountings about what has become a bane of modern air travel  delays on the tarmac  and is taking several steps to reduce delays around New York City.

headline: F. A. O. Schwarz Will Sell Toys in Macy’s Stores
text: Two of New York’s most venerable retail brands, Macy’s and F. A. O. Schwarz, are teaming up for a risky experiment: bringing toys back to the department store.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,072 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Laura Veirs and Liam Finn, at the Bowery Ballroom next Thursday, misidentified Mr. Finn’s nationality. He is from New Zealand, not Australia. The entry also referred imprecisely to the record label of his solo debut album, “I’ll Be Lightning.” While Independent Records is the label in Ireland, in the United States the album is on Yep Roc Records.

headline: Report Assesses Blame in Hepatitis Cases
text: Health care workers at a Las Vegas endoscopy clinic linked to more than 80 cases of hepatitis C routinely mishandled injection equipment and medication vials and often failed to perform basic hand hygiene, according to a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released Friday.

headline: This July 4, Fewer Bombs May Burst in Air
text: An explosion that destroyed 20 fireworks warehouses in China three months ago will probably dim night skies in the United States this Fourth of July.

headline: R. Kelly Jury Selected
text: A panel of eight men and four women will decide the fate of R. Kelly, the R&B star whose much-delayed trial on child pornography charges is to begin Tuesday in Chicago. During jury selection, which ended Thursday, the defense accused the prosecution of eliminating some African-Americans from the pool of candidates, while the prosecution countered that it had also eliminated some white males, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The final group of jurors includes an African-American woman married to a Baptist preacher, a young white woman who is an aspiring police officer, a 68-year-old Romanian immigrant and a recent college graduate who was once arrested for marijuana possession. Mr. Kelly was indicted on June 5, 2002, after the appearance of a videotape that prosecutors say shows him having sex with a girl as young as 13. He has pleaded not guilty. On Friday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, rejected a motion that news organizations have access to sealed court transcripts and records of the case.

headline: 3 Nordic Banks Help Iceland Prop Up Currency
text: FRANKFURT  In a show of Nordic solidarity, three central banks in the region have ridden to the rescue of Iceland, lending the island emergency credit of up to 1.5 billion euros ($2.3 billion) to shore up its swooning currency and forestall a broader economic collapse.

headline: Skirting Appalachia
text: As Hillary Clinton's rout in West Virginia underscores, Appalachia is not Obama country. Of 410 counties in the region, which stretches from New York to Mississippi, Barack Obama has won only 48 (12 percent) so far. Of the counties he has lost, nearly 80 percent have been by a margin of more than 2 to 1. The region is whiter, poorer, older, more rural and less educated than the rest of the country, and seems to be voting like a bloc.

headline: Smoothing the Rides on Greyhound
text: AS the summer travel season approaches, oil and gasoline prices continue to rise. Gas cost an average of about $3.75 a gallon nationwide earlier this week. Oil prices are setting records almost daily, passing $125 a barrel.

headline: Chasing Utopia, Family Imagines No Possessions
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Like many other young couples, Aimee and Jeff Harris spent the first years of their marriage eagerly accumulating stuff: cars, furniture, clothes, appliances and, after a son and a daughter came along, toys, toys, toys.

headline: Ex-Speaker Hires Lawyer in Inquiry
text: Gifford Miller, the former City Council speaker, has hired a criminal defense lawyer to represent him in a federal investigation into the Council’s longstanding practice of allocating millions of dollars to phantom nonprofit groups, people involved in the case said on Friday.

headline: Released From Rigors of a Trial, a Nobel Laureate’s Ink Flows Freely
text: TOKYO

headline: Learning Not to Rely on Bryant, Lakers Close Out Utah
text: SALT LAKE CITY  Outside of Hollywood, the perception persists that the Lakers are the N.B.A.’s answer to H.B.O.’s “Entourage,” with the guard Kobe Bryant filling the role played by Adrian Grenier and his teammates playing his cool crew of acolytes.

headline: McCain’s Superfuture
text: John McCain gave a speech this week describing what the world would look like after his first term in office.

headline: Upshaw Expects N.F.L. Owners to Opt Out of Labor Deal
text: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the N.F.L. players union, said Friday that he expected the owners to opt out of the collective bargaining agreement after they meet Tuesday in Atlanta.

headline: A Victory for Equality and Justice
text: The California Supreme Court brought the United States a step closer to fulfilling its ideals of equality and justice with its momentous 4-to-3 ruling upholding the right of same-sex couples to marry.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Thursday about Hollywood’s summer movies, including “Sex and the City,” using information provided by New Line Cinema, which made the movie, misstated its release date. It is May 30, not May 28. (On the Hollywood calendar, “summer” movies include those released in May.)

headline: Water Rates Are to Rise 14.5 Percent on July 1
text: The New York City Water Board voted on Friday morning to approve a 14.5 percent increase for water and sewer rates, the largest increase since 1992.

headline: Congressional Pressure Prevails as U.S. Halts Filling of Oil Reserve
text: Bowing to pressure from Congress, the Energy Department said Friday that it would temporarily suspend a program to fill the nation’s strategic oil stocks.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the surprising early success of the Florida Marlins misstated, in some editions, the scheduled length of their series this week with the Cincinnati Reds. It was four games, not three. (They played only three games because the finale on Thursday was postponed because of rain.)

headline: Famine Looms as Wars Rend Horn of Africa
text: DAGAARI, Somalia — The global food crisis has arrived at Safia Ali’s hut.

headline: Painting Damaged
text: During the removal of an installation at the National Gallery in London, “Marcia,” a 500-year-old painting by the 16th-century master Domenico Beccafumi, slipped out of its frame, causing one of its three large panels to break away from the other two. The Art Newspaper, which reported the incident, called it “one of the most serious handling accidents known to have occurred in a U.K. museum in living memory.” The painting, one of three by Beccafumi depicting classical heroines, was part of the “Renaissance Siena” exhibition, which closed early this year. The damage was not made public until recently, when minutes of a National Gallery trustee meeting on Feb. 8 were posted online. Museum authorities ordered an investigation which is still going on, the publication reported, but the panels were restored immediately and the painting is now on public view. “Under present lighting in the gallery, the vertical strip of damage can hardly be seen when looked at straight on although it is just visible when the painting is viewed from the left side,” Martin Bailey wrote in The Art Newspaper.

headline: Rethinking Locally: New Jersey Opens Big Museum Doors Again
text: TRENTON  The New Jersey State Museum’s main building reopens here on Saturday after four years of renovation, but appeals for celebration are premature. Closed since 2004 for work that expanded in scope, ran two years late and cost $15 million  with at least $12 million more still being sought from private donations  the museum’s main building seems to embody anticipation more than realization.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and Racial Justice Find Common Ground
text: Not long into the oral argument before the California Supreme Court in March over whether gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, Chief Justice Ronald M. George showed his hand.

headline: The President Goes Negative
text: President Bush’s penchant for slash-and-burn politics, learned at the feet of Karl Rove and the late Lee Atwater, is unseemly when practiced at home. It is shameful for the president and damaging for the country when put on display abroad.

headline: Shop Owner Is Charged With Assault
text: A Brooklyn store owner who struck a 15-year-old boy in the head with a hammer was indicted on felony assault charges on Friday, although his lawyer said he acted in self-defense.

headline: Pen in One Hand, Cricket Bat in the Other
text: There are no longer any Staten Islanders in the Staten Island Cricket Club, one of the country’s oldest. The members are from places like Sri Lanka, India, Pakistan, Jamaica, Guyana, Trinidad, St. Vincent and Grenada. There are just two Europeans; one of them, Joseph O’Neill, a 44-year-old Irishman who grew up in the Netherlands, was educated at Cambridge but has lived in New York since 1998.

headline: Robert Mondavi, Napa Wine Champion, Dies at 94
text: Robert Mondavi, the California vintner who set in motion the rebirth of the Napa Valley wine industry and, to a generation of Americans, championed the idea that fine wine was an integral part of the good life, died Friday at his home in Yountville, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New Tack on Straying Parolees Offers a Hand Instead of Cuffs
text: WICHITA, Kan.  Since his release in January after serving time for a 2006 theft conviction, Lonnie Kemp has violated his parole conditions several times, getting drunk and kicked out of a halfway house and showing traces of marijuana in urine tests. If this were a few years ago, he almost certainly would be back in prison.

headline: Talk of Larry King’s Successor Won’t Stop, but Neither Does Larry King
text: Larry King, who said last year that he hoped Ryan Seacrest would succeed him on CNN should he ever give up his prime-time show, invited Mr. Seacrest on as a guest on Thursday night and then sought to tamp down speculation that any succession was imminent.

headline: Passions Run High on Indexing
text: Did you see the latest issue of The Financial Analysts Journal?

headline: France: Warming Imperils Truffles
text: The black truffle is under threat from climate change, with years of bad harvests becoming the norm, according to Jean-Charles Savignac, president of the Fédération Française des Trufficulteurs. The European black truffle, highly aromatic and expensive, is suffering from prolonged drought in traditional growing areas, Reuters reported. Prices have soared, with a kilogram of truffles, about 2.2 pounds, costing roughly $1,550, three times the price eight years ago.

headline: For Officers’ Survivors, a Long Wait for Benefits
text: WASHINGTON  In October 2004, Gary Tilton, the fire chief in Katy, a suburb of Houston, came home and jumped into the shower after directing traffic around an accident in the Texas humidity. Within minutes, he lay dying of a heart attack.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The San Isidro Tilantongo Journal article on Tuesday, about the successful use of old pre-Hispanic farming techniques in the barren Mixteca highlands of Mexico’s Oaxaca State, misstated, in some copies, the three-to-four-fold rise in crop yields in eight villages where the techniques have been applied. The yields have grown to between one and one and a half metric tons per hectare, or 16 to 24 bushels per acre  not 100 to 150 bushels per acre.

headline: Poverty in Connecticut
text: To the Editor:

headline: Finales Boost CBS
text: Finales of “CSI” and “Without a Trace” lifted CBS into first place in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “CSI” attracted 17.7 million viewers to CBS at 9 p.m., the night’s largest audience, while “Without a Trace” won the 10 p.m. hour with 14.5 million viewers. Despite CBS’s edge in total viewers, the network ranked third for the night among adults 18 to 49, just behind NBC, which got a boost from the season finales of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (7.1 million), “The Office” at 9 (8.1 million) and “ER” at 10 (8.4 million). ABC, trailed by both networks in that demographic, broadcast the night’s top two shows among the 18-to-49 set, “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 and “Lost” at 10, which delivered 15.2 million and 11.4 million total viewers respectively. Fox finished fourth overall.

headline: Missouri Legislature Ends Session With Voter ID Amendment Still on Agenda
text: Missouri lawmakers ended their legislative session on Friday without completing action on a proposed constitutional amendment that would have enabled election officials to require proof of citizenship from people registering to vote.

headline: Do the Superfriends Have Library Cards?
text: One of the world’s largest collections of comic art has found a home in Columbus, Ohio. According to The Associated Press, the Cartoon Research Library at Ohio State University will soon exhibit about 200,000 works from the International Museum of Cartoon Art, founded by the cartoonist Mort Walker (“Beetle Bailey”) in Greenwich, Conn., in 1974. The museum, most recently located in a villa in Boca Raton, Fla., was $2 million in debt and closed in 2002. Plans to have its memorabilia  including a Walt Disney storyboard for an early Mickey Mouse cartoon and original drawings for “Dick Tracy,” above  moved to Yale University or be displayed at the Empire State Building fizzled. But Ohio State has plans for the sketches, films, figurines, toys and collectibles, which will double its existing collection, the library’s curator, Lucy Shelton Caswell, told The Associated Press. Ms. Caswell, a former board member of the International Museum of Cartoon Art, said new space was being sought for the collection, expected to go on display in the summer.

headline: Myanmar Raises Cyclone Toll to 78,000
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar’s government almost doubled the official death toll on Friday to 78,000, two weeks after a huge cyclone ravaged much of the Irrawaddy Delta and the main city, Yangon. It also nearly doubled the number of missing to 55,917, and raised the number of injured steeply to 19,359, up from 1,403.

headline: Brooklyn Dry Cleaner Is Found Dead in Her Windsor Terrace Store
text: When her husband became too sick five years ago to tend to the family dry-cleaning business, Kyung-Sook Woo did not hesitate to take over the job, sometimes rising so early to open the shop that customers would find her with a curling iron in her hand and her short hair half-curled.

headline: Networks Anticipate the Fall Cautiously
text: At the party after the Fox network’s presentation of its fall schedule on Thursday, an executive from one of Hollywood’s biggest talent agencies looked around and said, “Finally, we had a real upfront.”

headline: The World Can’t Stand By. Help the Burmese Now.
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Chávez in Check, Talks in Peru Stay Calm
text: LIMA, Peru  To the relief of organizers of a summit meeting here of leaders from Latin America and Europe on Friday, the encounter was notable for being relatively free of insults being flung publicly.

headline: Reducing College Costs
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Siberia, Shopping Malls Are Sprouting All Over
text: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia  In this region of Siberia, long synonymous with gulags and hardship, shoppers mobbed an Ikea store last winter with the vigor of a miners’ riot. They loaded their outsize yellow shopping carts with clothes, housewares, appliances and small furniture.

headline: Tending to a Flock in Hard Hats
text: The Rev. Brian Jordan had just loped to the end of a long run on a Saturday afternoon, savoring one of those rare times a priest could be considered off duty, when he checked the message on his cellphone. The voice belonged to an old contact in Local 14 of the operating engineers’ union. His words were succinct and specific: “There’s been an accident at 51st and Second. Can you help us?”

headline: Detainee’s Trial Delayed Until Justices Rule
text: A military judge delayed the first war crimes trial of a Guantánamo detainee Friday, saying he wanted the opportunity to examine a much-awaited Supreme Court decision on the rights of the detainees.

headline: U.S. Plans Steps to Ease Congestion at Airports
text: WASHINGTON  To hold down ticket prices and ease airplane congestion over the New York region, the Bush administration proposed Friday to auction landing slots at two major airports, Kennedy and Newark, and to impose a limit on airline traffic at Newark.

headline: U.S. Frustrated by Myanmar Junta’s Aid Limits
text: WASHINGTON  Two weeks after a devastating cyclone smashed ashore in Myanmar, the United States is facing the limits of its clout, at least in dealing with a junta that human rights advocates say is putting its own survival before that of a storm-ravaged population.

headline: Zimbabwe Election Runoff Set for June 27
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s delayed runoff election between President Robert Mugabe, who has led the nation for nearly three decades, and the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai has been set for June 27, the country’s election commission said Friday.

headline: Robbins, Served Up in French Style
text: The latest evening in New York City Ballet’s Jerome Robbins Celebration draws on the music of two refined composers: Ravel and Debussy. Despite its painfully cute title, “French Cuisine,” the choreographic treats are of a quiet, understated variety.

headline: Suit Accuses Ex-Principal of Defamation
text: Clarification appended.

headline: Failing to Close Door on Road, Celtics Will Return Home
text: CLEVELAND  LeBron James had to halt his shot in midair, tuck his legs under him and hold the ball an extra count before heaving it. A foul, he said. No call, the referees said. It did not matter. Even when his shot was off kilter, James was the most dominant player in the building Friday night.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: International

headline: Einstein Letter on God Sells for $404,000
text: From the grave, Albert Einstein poured gasoline on the culture wars between science and religion this week.

headline: Citigroup May Sell Its German Banking Business
text: Citigroup may sell Citibank Privatkunden, its consumer-banking unit in Germany, as part of a plan to replenish capital, the unit, based in Düsseldorf, said. The German retail unit could fetch 5 billion euros ($7.8 billion) to 6 billion euros, according to Dirk Becker, an analyst at Landsbanki Kepler in Frankfurt. Citigroup’s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, has said he plans to get rid of about $400 billion in assets over the next three years. Citigroup’s German unit has about 6,800 employees and 3.2 million customers and is one of the country’s largest credit card issuers.

headline: Sri Lanka: Attack on Police Bus Kills 10
text: A suicide bomber rammed a motorcycle into a police bus in Colombo, and military jets continued airstrikes on suspected rebel bases in the island’s north for a second day. The military said 10 people were killed and 86 were wounded in the bombing, for which the military blamed Tamil rebels.

headline: Senator Kennedy Is Hospitalized After a Seizure
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, 76, leader of the nation’s most storied political dynasty, was hospitalized in Boston on Saturday after apparently suffering a seizure.

headline: Lou Reed to Play D.J.
text: Lou Reed will take a break from promoting his forthcoming concert film, “Berlin,” to host a two-hour radio show on the Sirius Satellite Network. Starting Saturday on Channel 70, “Lou Reed’s New York Shuffle” will broadcast a mix of rock, country and jazz, the kind of programming that Mr. Reed said he has enjoyed for years. He will share host duties with the producer Hal Willner, who was the music director of “Berlin.” The staged concert, based on Mr. Reed’s 1973 album of the same name, was taped at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn in December 2006. The film version, directed by Julian Schnabel, is to open in New York and Los Angeles on July 18. Requests for Mr. Reed’s radio show will soon be taken at loureed.com.

headline: Given Second Chance Against Mets, Rasner  Misses Out Again
text: In his start against the Mets last May, Darrell Rasner broke his finger when he was struck by a batted ball. He will never know what would have happened in an encore this May, because his start was wiped out by rain Friday.

headline: Dick Netzer, 79, Municipal Finance Expert, Dies
text: Dick Netzer, an economist who advised mayors of New York City and governors of New York State and served on the first board of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which pried New York City out of bankruptcy in the 1970s, died on May 7 in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Brooklyn and in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: A Fast-Fading Sway: The Nation’s Leader, but Not His Party’s
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush is not irrelevant. Presidents never are. But with eight months left in office, his ability to shape the country’s legislative and political agenda has diminished more quickly than his aides and allies expected  or at least hoped  only weeks ago.

headline: In China, Skittish Pandas, Then Exploding Cliffs
text: CHENGDU, China  The birds suddenly disappeared from the sky. Something also was wrong with the pandas. They were strangely skittish. And then, within minutes, the isolated, verdant mountains above China’s most famous panda reserve exploded as if hit by a megaton bomb.

headline: F.B.I. Gets Mixed Review in Interrogation Report
text: WASHINGTON  A new Justice Department report praises the refusal of F.B.I. agents to take part in the military’s abusive questioning of prisoners in Guantánamo Bay, Iraq and Afghanistan, but it also finds fault with the bureau’s slow response to complaints about the tactics from its own agents, people with knowledge of the still-secret report said.

headline: U.S. Planning Big New Prison in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is moving forward with plans to build a new, 40-acre detention complex on the main American military base in Afghanistan, officials said, in a stark acknowledgment that the United States is likely to continue to hold prisoners overseas for years to come.

headline: The Doctor With a Dark Side Samples Boston
text: Evil is always more compelling than virtue. This axiom of drama gets a workout in “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” which will be shown on the Ion network on Saturday night. It sets Robert Louis Stevenson’s story of dual personality in contemporary Boston; makes Dr. Henry Jekyll a dedicated, hardworking neurologist (or urologist; the sound quality is not perfect); and opens with another staple: the murder of a prostitute.

headline: Another Star Pairing in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES  Kareem and Magic. Shaq and Kobe. Are Lisa and Candace next?

headline: Courting N.R.A., McCain Criticizes Obama and Clinton on Gun Control
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Senator John McCain reached out to the National Rifle Association on Friday and warned 6,000 people at the group’s annual convention that a President Barack Obama or Hillary Rodham Clinton would put the rights of “law-abiding” gun owners at risk.

headline: Afghanistan: Soldier Killed in South
text: A suicide bomber attacked Afghan and Canadian soldiers patrolling a village in the Panjwai district of southern Afghanistan, killing one Afghan soldier and wounding four Canadians, the Afghan military said.

headline: That Fake Gucci: Does It Have Links to Terrorists?
text: New York City is starting an advertising campaign on Monday to educate tourists and residents about the social costs of counterfeit and pirated goods.

headline: A Meeting, an Apology and Support for Randolph
text: Soon after Carlos Delgado strolled into the Mets’ clubhouse on Friday, he said Billy Wagner “intercepted” him. Wagner, who a day earlier complained about some teammates’ accountability, began his damage control by talking to Delgado, then to reporters. It was the beginning of the Mets’ attempt to mitigate a potentially explosive situation.

headline: Booz Allen to Sell Part of Its Government Unit to Carlyle
text: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, said on Friday that it would sell a majority stake in its government practice to the private equity firm Carlyle Group for $2.54 billion.

headline: Saudis Rebuff Bush, Politely, on Pumping More Oil
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Bush used a private visit to King Abdullah’s ranch here on Friday to make another appeal for an increase in oil production that might give American consumers some relief at the gasoline pump. The Saudis responded by announcing they had decided a week ago on a modest increase of 300,000 barrels a day.

headline: Olympic Dream Stays Alive, on Synthetic Legs
text: When an international court ruled Friday that a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa was eligible to compete in this summer’s Olympic Games in Beijing, the stage was set for disabled athletes to meet their own trailblazer.

headline: A Subdued Clinton, and a Subdued Audience
text: JUNCTION CITY, Ore.  On the day Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was endorsed by the governor of North Carolina, a supporter gave her a three-foot-long balloon replica of herself, complete with blond hair, black pantsuit and wide pink smile, which Mrs. Clinton promptly took on her plane and laughingly showed off to reporters.

headline: South Africa: Trial Delay for Zuma
text: The corruption trial of Jacob G. Zuma, the presumptive next president of South Africa, has been delayed yet again. The trial had been scheduled to start Aug. 4, but no new date was set. It is now likely that Mr. Zuma, president of the governing African National Congress, will become president next April with the charges still unresolved.

headline: Crowd Protests an Assault on a Jewish Teenager
text: A crowd of more than 300 Hasidic Jews, some shouting “We want justice!” marched in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon to protest the assault and robbery of a Jewish teenager early that morning.

headline: Air of Confidence for Favorite; Industry Holds Breath
text: BALTIMORE  Rick Dutrow is relaxed and focused. Big Brown, the colt he trains, is the 1-2 favorite to win the Preakness Stakes, and looks miles  not lengths  better than the 11 other horses lining up against him.

headline: Five Basics for Building a Solid Financial Future
text: The stark truth about managing our money these days is that we are mostly on our own.

headline: Assembly Halts Bills With Analysis by Union-Paid Actuary
text: The State Assembly will halt action on all legislation that relied on the financial analyses of an actuary who was being paid by labor unions, and the bills will undergo new reviews, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said on Friday.

headline: The Overpriced Bargain Bin
text: BEDS that cost $60,000; $1.5 million sports cars; $57,000 for a set of golf clubs.

headline: Larry King Squelches Rumors of Shift at CNN
text: Larry King, who said last year that he hoped Ryan Seacrest would succeed him on CNN should he ever give up his prime-time show, invited Mr. Seacrest on as a guest Thursday night and then sought to tamp down speculation that any succession was imminent.

headline: Several Found Dead in New Jersey House
text: Three people were found dead in a Tenafly, N.J., house on Friday, all of them stabbed multiple times, with their bodies decomposing after sitting in the house for about a week, the Bergen County prosecutor said.

headline: Excess Money, Deficits and the High Price of Oil
text: To the Editor:

headline: Former State Police Official, a Guard to Governors, Commits Suicide
text: A former New York State Police inspector who once headed the governor’s personal security detail committed suicide at his home in Orange County on Thursday, a family friend confirmed on Friday. The inspector, Gary A. Berwick, 48, retired from the State Police last month, shortly after the resignation of the acting State Police superintendent, Preston L. Felton.

headline: Revised Plan by N.Y.U. Would Preserve Walls of Provincetown Playhouse
text: The walls of the historic Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village will be preserved under a plan released by New York University on Friday, a move that Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, hailed as “tremendous progress” in the talks between the university and community leaders about the site. Plans had included a proposal to demolish the building.

headline: Scrapping 2 Costly Reactors, Canada Reopens Aging One
text: OTTAWA  Atomic Energy of Canada will continue to rely on a 51-year-old reactor to produce most of the world’s radioactive medical isotopes after deciding Friday to abandon two troubled replacement units.

headline: In Huckabee Joke, Gun Aims at Obama
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, was known for his sense of humor on the presidential campaign trail, but on Friday he startled listeners with his latest improvisation, an imagined gun pointed at Senator Barack Obama.

headline: American Airlines and F.A.A. Differ on Groundings
text: WASHINGTON  American Airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration, endeavoring to explain the biggest disruption to air travel in years, disagreed on the fundamental facts in reports each submitted to the federal transportation secretary.

headline: Cleaner, Gentler Hustings?
text: The presidential campaigns of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain are expressing interest in steering donors away from shadow groups that are planning big-budget, rough-and-tumble attack ads on the opposition this fall. Jaded voters can only hope it’s true.

headline: Jimmy Slyde, Dancer and a Giant of Rhythm Tap, Dies at 80
text: Jimmy Slyde, one of the last great tap dancers of the big-band era, whose smooth moves carried him from swing and bebop to Broadway and the movies, died early on Friday at his home in Hanson, Mass. He was 80.

headline: The ‘Appeasement’ and Iraq Speeches
text: To the Editor:

headline: Middle East Meets West in a Small Syrian Hotel
text: “Damascus,” part of the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, begins with a punchy, comic scene. Paul, a rumpled Scotsman who writes textbooks, arrives at a hotel in the Syrian capital. He’s exhausted. He’s lost his sense of smell. And no, he says into his cellphone, he won’t be watching porn; this is a Muslim country. Beat. “Pay TV?” he asks the receptionist.

headline: Belichick Tries to Discredit Ex-Employee’s Story
text: Patriots Coach Bill Belichick questioned the credibility of the former employee who spoke publicly about the team’s video practices, saying that the taping of opposing teams’ sideline signals was not a clandestine operation.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 104 Rice
text: Location: Houston

headline: Trying to Make a Difference
text: John Branch’s article in Saturday’s Times — including an audio slideshow — highlights horse farms and organizations that are helping rescue and rehabilitate thoroughbreds.

headline: Reaction to Kennedy’s Hospitalization
text: The following is a collection of statements from friends and colleagues of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts in reaction to his hospitalization for stroke-like symptoms.

headline: A Solution Is in the Incentives
text: We can talk all we want about what we want, but things are hard to change. Lip service will be paid to the memory of Eight Belles in a manner that I’m sure everyone will swallow. It’s good that something will be done. But, will it be THE change that will make our sport better? Only one thing can do that, and that’s money.

headline: Test Lesson
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: McCain’s Superfuture
text: John McCain gave a speech this week that was a little like those old Victorian novels in which the hero visits the future and discovers that by the year 2000, America has become perfect. The terrorists are on the run, Iraq is a “functioning democracy,” and back home the economy is terrific. It’s always helpful to hear a candidate’s broad vision, but sweeping plans do pose a problem if you can’t get there from here.

headline: Michael Sokolove on ‘The Uneven Playing Field’
text: Q: Very interesting article. As a (female) former high school and collegiate cross-country and track athlete, I experienced many of the same struggles as the young woman described in this article. In the running world, overuse injuries, such as stress fractures and tendonitis, are more common than ACL ruptures, though the emotional turbulence surrounding injury is devastating to any dedicated athlete.

headline: Night at the Museum — in Moscow this Weekend
text: Have you ever dreamed of spending the night at the Tretyakov Gallery? Here’s your chance: Russian museums swing open their doors after hours and free of charge in celebration of International Museum Day tonight.

headline: Shuvee, a Filly for the Ages
text: Teresa Genaro at Brooklyn Backstretch recalls Shuvee, the filly who won the Triple Tiara and who then beat the boys twice in the Jockey Club Gold Cup twice.

headline: The Early Word: Lessons from ’04
text: During what could be, in the eyes of many, the last weekend of the 2008 primary season, the campaigns of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are moving forward into the general election – but the latter camp is looking backward, as well, for campaign lessons and language.

headline: Lee Finds Location, and Success Follows
text: Location, location, location.

headline: Horse Wisdom
text: BALTIMORE — I ran into one of our more dedicated Railbirds down here — Dan of South Baltimore. Besides being an accomplished horseplayer, a Preakness devotee and funny guy, he’s got a T-shirt and hat business — more like hobby on the sign.

headline: ‘At Least God Tried to Stop Them’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC:The two finalists for “American Idol” were announced this week and they are a high school student and a bartender. When asked about it, Paula Abdul said, “I’m leaning towards the bartender.”

headline: Exit Strategy
text: When your unit finds it’s not in Kansas anymore …

headline: Referendum Race Has Furlongs To Go
text: As the second jewel of the Triple Crown, the Preakness is overshadowed nationally by the Kentucky Derby which precedes it. However, the race is, of course, the highlight of the Maryland racing season; and, in these troubled times for the state’s racing industry, hardly only in terms of pomp and prestige.

headline: The Morning Skate: Marty’s Oh-fer, Kimmo’s Toe and Marvin’s Grapevine
text: There’s a little playoff maxim we have at The Morning Skate: If you have a chance to close out a team on home ice and fail, you’re in trouble. That’s what the Red Wings face today and the Penguins face tomorrow.

headline: The Spirit of Eddie Haskell Lives On
text: From topjokes4u.com:

headline: Senator Kennedy Rushed to Hospital
text: Updated WASHINGTON – Senator Edward M. Kennedy was rushed to a hospital this morning in Cape Cod, where he was treated for a serious – but unknown – illness.

headline: In Uneven Season for Yanks, Bullpen Shines
text: Through Thursday, the Yankees’ bullpen was leading the major leagues in strikeouts, with 127 in 147 1/3 innings. The bullpen E.R.A. is 1.85 over the last 19 games, the lowest mark in the majors in that span.

headline: Voluntary Simplicity
text: Aimee and Jeff Harris spent the first years of their marriage eagerly accumulating stuff. Now, they are frantically trying to get rid of it all.

headline: The Joba Chamberlain Chronicles
text: It is another day in Yankeeland, which means it’s time for another Joba Chamberlain fix. And, on this day, it sounded like he might not be leaving the bullpen after all this season.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 17:

headline: Willie and the Mets
text: Willie Randolph greeted reporters at his news conference this morning by telling them — in jest? — that he had a bodyguard wearing a bulletproof vest stationed toward the back of the room. Randolph chooses to laugh about his job security because, really, what else can he do? This is not the space for me to opine on such matters — objectivity prevails — but we all know how crucial this nine-game stretch is. Two in the Bronx. Four in Atlanta. Three in Colorado.

headline: Final Preparations for the Preakness
text: The Pimlico racetrack opened this morning from 5:30 to 6:00 a.m. to allow the Preakness horses to get some light exercise if necessary. For most races, trainers do not train a horse on race day. Big races are different and it makes sense sometimes to take a little edge off the horses so they don’t get overly excited during the long day waiting for the big race.

headline: N.C.A.A. Quarterfinals: Virginia Wins in Overtime
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — The traffic for today’s N.C.A.A. lacrosse quarterfinals lined up more than 100 cars deep at the exit on U.S. 50. The day couldn’t have been more ideal, as the temperature hovered in the mid-70s and the sky was a spectacular blue.

headline: Psychic’s Prediction: Well, That’s Tough
text: “I woke up as nervous as Big Brown,” said Judi Hoffman, who was dressed head to toe in leopard print — the same outfit (except for the shoes) she wore on Derby day when she correctly packaged Big Brown, Eight Belles and Denis of Cork.

headline: Signals in Obama Return to Iowa?
text: Updated On the day that voters in Kentucky and Oregon choose between the Democratic candidates, Senator Barack Obama will hold a rally in Iowa, his campaign announced today.

headline: Crazy Ex-Boyfriend
text: When a relationship ends, this almost never happens, right?

headline: Woodlawn Vase: Triple Crown Trophy
text: It sometimes seems that there is little that unites the tracks that run the Triple Crown races. Both Churchill Downs and Magna Entertainment, the owner of Pimlico Race Course, were partners in an organization that tried to wrest control of the New York racing franchise from NYRA. Back in 2001, each entity competed on bids for New York City O.T.B. Curently Magna Entertainment and Churchill Downs seem to be allies, but in the fractious world of racing, there are few friends, only enemies we have yet to make.

headline: A Win-Win Deal
text: In the classic baseball film “Bull Durham,” Annie Savoy (played by Susan Sarandon) memorably said, “Bad trades are part of baseball — now who can forget Frank Robinson for Milt Pappas, for God’s sake?”

headline: The Watch List
text: When Kenji Johjima was hitting below .200 last month, the Mariners gave him a three-year, $24 million contract extension. Johjima, a soon-to-be 32-year-old catcher, is showing signs they did not make a mistake. Johjima has raised his batting average 50 points this month and had four extra-base hits, including his first homer, in three games this week.

headline: Another Hall of Fame Induction for Berra
text: Yogi Berra thinks Albert Einstein “is a pretty smart guy.”

headline: Barack Obama on Ted Kennedy
text: At an appearance in Oregon, Barack Obama made mention of the hospitalization of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline: Burlesque Makes a Comeback
text: Burlesque was kicked out of New York in 1942, but the gleefully bad-mannered entertainment has returned.

headline: McCain: Clinton Could Be Feeling Sorry for Herself
text: Senator John McCain thinks Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton might be feeling sorry for herself.

headline: No Worries, No Protesters to Be Seen
text: BALTIMORE — There is a sense that the horse racing industry needs an injury-free Preakness Stakes this evening to avoid more calamity.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, May 18
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appears on CNN’s Late Edition on Sunday, but for the most part, the Sunday talk shows appear to have moved on to the general election – including looks at the battle for Congress.

headline: Block Party!
text: BALTIMORE — The streets surrounding Pimlico Race Course turn into one massive block party on Preakness day.

headline: Clinton Links McCain to Bush
text: FRANKFORT, Ky. – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ignored her Democratic opponent and took on the Republicans at a rally Saturday afternoon, as she promised to fight Senator John McCain over economic policy and called President Bush the worst president in American history.

headline: N.C.A.A. Quarterfinals: Shipping Up To Boston
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — We have two of the Final Four teams in Division I men’s lacrosse, as Johns Hopkins blew out Navy, 10-4, in the second game of Saturday’s quarterfinal doubleheader. Navy jumped out early but went more than 30 minutes without scoring, much to the chagrin of the record crowd of 17,017 at Navy Marine Corps Stadium here.

headline: An Impressive Victory
text: Big Brown absolutely dominated a weak Preakness field. The acceleration he showed when Kent Desormeaux let him loose was something we have not seen in a long time. He won under an easy handride. All this horse has done so far is win, and win easily.

headline: The $50 Million Horse
text: It’s true Big Brown’s stallion rights were sold to Three Chimneys Farm for more than $50 million. Michael Iavarone, the president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings and co-owner of Big Brown, confirmed he signed a deal after a week of negotiations en route to Pimlico today.

headline: Duke’s Ronald McDonald Information
text: Here’s a quick follow up to a story that I wrote for Sunday’s paper regarding the Duke men’s and women’s lacrosse teams blossoming rapport with the Ronald McDonald House on the Duke campus. The relationship began when the new Duke coach John Danowski made community service a mandatory part of his players’ schedules last year. This season, the women’s team joined the men’s team in volunteering there.

headline: Siege at Labrang Monastery
text: Nowhere is the Chinese policy towards Tibet clearer than at this Buddhist Monastery in Gansu Province.

headline: LIVE Sunday: Canada-Russia, for the World Championship
text: Join us on the Times hockey blog at 1 p.m. Eastern Time Sunday for the gold medal match of the 2008 IIHF World Championship: Canada-Russia, LIVE, as it unfolds at Le Colisée in Quebec City. One of us will describe the game in all its apocalyptic portent, we guarantee it, so be here on the Slap Shot blog to follow along as history is made.

headline: Big Brown Rules Preakness
text: We’re back again, blogging the 133rd Preakness Stakes “live” from The Times building in Midtown Manhattan. Can Big Brown claim the second leg of the Triple Crown? Will all of the horses come out of the race unharmed? We sure hope so. As in the Derby, we’ll be getting updates from Joe Drape and our other contributors throughout the day. Send in some questions. Add your comments. Enjoy.

headline: Rating the Red Bulls vs. Kansas City Wizards
text: The Red Bulls (3-1-3, 12 points) entered Saturday night’s game against the Kansas City Wizards (3-3-2, 11 points) on a four-game unbeaten streak, and left with a five-game unbeaten streak. The Red Bulls are one of two teams in Major League Soccer (Columbus is the other) with only one loss. Kansas City came into the game on a two-game losing streak, and left without a victory in its last three.

headline: Fun With Preppy Names
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — Anyone who has followed lacrosse over the years can’t help but have noticed the abundance of uber-preppy names that filter through the sport. (Two that jumped out at me Sunday were Maryland’s Ryder Bohlander and Johns Hopkins Orry Michael.)

headline: Your Comments on Tibet, Part Two
text: My Sunday column is again from the Gansu and Qinghai areas that are mostly Tibetan, as was Thursday’s column. This time I try to focus on the need for a negotiated settlement of the Tibetan question, and the risk that if the stalemate continues Tibetan areas will lose their traditional character and be overwhelmed by Han migration, while Han Chinese areas will face terrorism from Tibetans. I think China, the Dalai Lama and the U.S. are all partly to blame for a failure to pursue serious diplomacy on this issue.

headline: A New Site for Foodies
text: Foodies might be interested in Eats.com, a social network that was started last month. Members may review or request particular dining spots, create restaurant wish lists as part of their profiles and upload photographs of their favorite dishes (some of which might even be selected for Dish of the Day, a rotating image featured on the Web site’s home page).

headline: Sleeping Around
text: New and newly redone hotels are throwing open their doors all over the capital.

headline: Doctors Say ‘I’m Sorry’ Before ‘See You in Court’
text: CHICAGO  In 40 years as a highly regarded cancer surgeon, Dr. Tapas K. Das Gupta had never made a mistake like this.

headline: ‘Likkul’ Bit of Sweden and a Touch of Nigeria, Too
text: Lykke Li

headline: Correction: Supreme Court Inc.
text: An article on March 16 about the Supreme Court and its tilt toward business interests misspelled the surname of a friend whom Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote to before becoming a justice about his view that the American economic system was “under broad attack.” He was Eugene B. Sydnor, not Snydor. (A letter from a reader about the misspelling was overlooked by editors.)

headline: The War of 1948
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Drudgery of Chores, and the Comfort
text: IT’S the pointlessness of it all that gets me first. First thing every morning, I am bound by habit to sweep off the porch  leaves if it is autumn, possibly snow in the winter, muddy footprints in spring, and, whatever time of year, the dust, the dog hair, the debris of daily life. The uselessness of the exercise never escapes me, because it seems to exist only to be done again. And again.

headline: Lisa Pitlor, Ian Abramson
text: Lisa Lynn Pitlor, a daughter of Marcia G. Pitlor and Steve L. Pitlor of Omaha, is to be married on Sunday evening to Ian Thomas Abramson, a son of Ginnie A. Abramson of Ardsley, N.Y., and Ben L. Abramson of Boynton Beach, Fla. Rabbi Mordechai Levin is to perform the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue in Omaha.

headline: Smallish Attackman Gives Virginia a Boost
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Virginia Coach Dom Starsia freely acknowledges that his star attackman, Ben Rubeor, is not a physical specimen.

headline: Correction: ‘The Song of Everlasting Sorrow’
text: A review on May 4 about “The Song of Everlasting Sorrow,” a novel originally written in Chinese by Wang Anyi, misstated the middle name of one of its translators. She is Susan Chan Egan, not Chang.

headline: For Israelis, an Anniversary. For Palestinians, a Nakba.
text: IN 1948, during the war known to the Israelis as the war of independence, the historian Constantine K. Zurayk wrote the book “Ma’na al-Nakba,” later translated as “The Meaning of the Disaster.” The title struck a resounding chord, and nakba (catastrophe) became the term Palestinians used for the cataclysm that befell them that year.

headline: Hezbollah Ignites a Sectarian Fuse in Lebanon
text: MENIEH, Lebanon  For two and a half days, Hussein al-Haj Obaid lay on the floor of a darkened warehouse in west Beirut, blindfolded and terrified. Militiamen loyal to Hezbollah had kidnapped him at a checkpoint after killing his nephew right in front of him.

headline: Poetic Injustice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Larger Than Life, More to Fight Over
text: Twenty-eight feet tall and carved from Chinese granite, the statue of Martin Luther King Jr. planned for the National Mall in Washington could resist almost any attack but the one that came recently from the panel whose approval it needs to proceed.

headline: Up Front
text: Lorraine Adams won a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting of civil rights violations against disadvantaged minorities in Texas, then turned to the plight of North African immigrants to the United States in her acclaimed first novel, “Harbor.” Now finishing her second novel, set in Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan, she has traveled widely, from North Africa to India, while researching her fiction.

headline: May I Have This Dance?
text: I SPENT most of last year and a decent-size chunk of the year before in Iraq. For the last half of that sojourn I was stationed at a combat outpost on the east side of Baghdad.

headline: A Brighter Side of High Prices
text: CORN prices are at record high levels. Costs for other agricultural essentials, from wheat to coffee to rice, have surged, too. And many people are stunned, even frightened, by all the increases.

headline: Sniff, Sniff
text: Sniff, Sniff

headline: Annette Frankel, Michael Schuster
text: Annette Frankel and Michael David Schuster were married on Saturday evening by Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake at the Harmonie Club in New York.

headline: Heaven’s Gate
text: I found myself, on the longest day of last year, in what was billed as “the highest motorable pass in the world,” though “motorable” seemed as open to question as “pass.” Icicles were hanging from the mountainside, and plaques around every hairpin turn recalled those fellow travelers, most of them soldiers, who had “left for their heavenly abode” after plunging over the precipice inches from the loose stones that made up the road. My driver, red-cheeked and indomitable, clambered out of our rickety Toyota to fiddle with a loose starter — not quite what I had ordered at 18,350 feet — and fluid the color of Pepto-Bismol began to leak out of the back of the truck in front of us.

headline: After a Fall, a Landing for Reynolds
text: Harold Reynolds seemed pleased. He was on a studio set, talking baseball, but it was about the Mets and the Yankees, not the full breadth of major league baseball. He was in Manhattan as SportsNet New York’s new analyst, sitting with Darryl Strawberry and Lee Mazzilli, not in Bristol, Conn., where he was a mainstay on ESPN’s “Baseball Tonight.”

headline: Vera Zlatarski, John Henderson
text: Vera Vassileva Zlatarski and John Brien Henderson were married on Saturday at St. Joseph’s Church in New York. The Rev. John J. O’Brien, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom’s uncle, performed the ceremony.

headline: Pragmatic Appeal to Voters to Approve School Budgets
text: THE average proposed school district budget and property tax increase are the lowest on Long Island in a decade, but voters going to the polls on Tuesday will find that school spending plans vary widely by district.

headline: One Rough Inning Darkens Pettitte’s Afternoon
text: Andy Pettitte bent over the ball by the third-base line like a gardener inspecting weeds. He stared for a moment  a long moment  seeming to will it off the infield grass.

headline: Theola Labbé and Brian DeBose
text: Theola Sacha Labbé and Brian Abraham DeBose were married on Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. Msgr. W. Ronald Jameson, the cathedral’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Vicki Lansky, Stephen Schaefer
text: Vicki L. Lansky and Stephen Mark Schaefer were married on Saturday evening at Bet Shalom Congregation in Minnetonka, Minn. Rabbi Norman M. Cohen, the congregation’s leader, performed the ceremony.

headline: The Middle East in the Year 2068? Some Presidential Prognostications
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt  President Bush said not long ago that he did not have a magic wand to bring down gas prices. But when it comes to Middle East peace, he apparently has a crystal ball.

headline: This Time, It All Came Together for NBC
text: Big Brown made NBC’s job easy on Saturday at the Preakness Stakes.

headline: In Latino Enclaves, Less Arroz, More Beans
text: HOW important is rice to Dominicans?

headline: Catch the Drift in Namibia
text: I began perhaps the most fantastic single day in all my years of travel by riding up to a traditional Himba “village” — a small clutch of domed mud-and-thatch huts surrounding a pen for livestock, improbably sited in a wide desert valley — on a Honda A.T.V., pulling off my helmet and questioning a bare-breasted and intricately coiffed octogenarian about the changing nature of her world.

headline: Out of Africa, Passionately Packaged
text: BECAUSE he grew up in Ghana, Ken Braun knew about the Beatles sooner than most American kids.

headline: For Kenyan, It’s a Run in the Park
text: Tourists always remember their first trip to New York  the tall buildings, the swarms of people. Patrick Makau will tell of the tuna fish and the tape.

headline: Whose Sari Now?
text: With a security tape pulled tight around its girth, my travel bag looked uncharacteristically floppy, like an obese figure on a draconian diet.

headline: Fuel From Plants, Not Oil Wells
text: FOR drivers who would rather cover miles without increasing the country’s need to import Middle East oil, biodiesel is an attractive proposition. Ideally, such an alternative for petroleum-based diesel fuel would take full advantage of the diesel engine’s thrifty operation without using nonrenewable resources.

headline: The Lowdown | Salta
text: Salta is Argentina’s hottest hot spot, with a boho, Santa-Fe-Sur vibe and dramatic Andean backdrop.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: COMEDY

headline: Locomotive in Petticoats
text: In 1878, Queen Victoria used a telephone for the first time, after Alexander Graham Bell arranged a demonstration. A phone was placed on a piano and a series of songs played and sung for the curious monarch, who listened intently. In retrospect, this little incident seems charged with symbolism, a marker of the old age touching the new. But who had the honor of performing for the queen, albeit telephonically? Not a famous musician, nor even a Briton, but rather an American journalist named Kate Field who’d been moonlighting for Bell as what we would now call a P.R. flack. With her knack for job-juggling, eye for the main chance and limitless energy, Field (1838-96) was herself a pure product of modernity, a self-invented dynamo chugging across the later 19th century like a locomotive in petticoats.

headline: The Place
text: A Cultural Cheat Sheet

headline: Moving Day
text: IN 1985, when Margaret Morton began teaching photography at Cooper Union in the East Village, she moved into an apartment on nearby Tompkins Square Park. At the time, a number of homeless people were living in the park in shelters built from scavenged materials. Ms. Morton began photographing these makeshift homes and their owners.

headline: A Buyer’s Market, a Seller’s Pain
text: Ridgewood

headline: Beauty and the Beat
text: With her boyish platinum mop and her penchant for wearing leopard-print pants with silver oxford shoes, the model Agyness Deyn is used to stopping people dead in their tracks. But recently it’s her G4530 Wild West Sweethearts guitar, from the Gretsch Americana limited-edition series, that’s been getting all the attention. “I carry it on my back everywhere I go,” she explains. “When I’m wearing it, people just come up to me and start chatting about it. I get to meet some cool people that way.” For Deyn, who is a new face for Shiseido and a Burberry favorite, crisscrossing the globe is all in a day’s work. In fact, she got her acoustic shredder last year in Japan, a surprise gift picked up by her boyfriend Josh Hubbard (of the band the Paddingtons). The guitar’s compact size makes it easy for lugging on the road, and the campy aesthetic perfectly riffs on Deyn’s own Paris-meets-Lower East Side style. “I love the whole Wild West thing. It reminds me of a Sailor Jerry tattoo,” she says. But Deyn’s love for her little red six-string is no passing fancy. “I think I’ll have it forever.”

headline: Correction: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
text: The Green Traveler column on May 4, about the use of biofuels in air travel, gave an incorrect name for an organization that says that more than 2.2 billion people flew last year. It is the International Civil Aviation Organization, not the International Civil Aviation Authority. In addition, the column also misstated the name of an organization that expressed concern about the environmental impact of jet exhaust. It is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, not the International Panel on Climate Change.

headline: Will Elder, Cartoonist of Satiric Gifts and Overpopulated Scenes, Dies at 86
text: Will Elder, whose frantic, gag-filled illustrations helped to define the comic identity of Mad magazine and who was a creator of the Playboy cartoon serial “Little Annie Fanny,” died Wednesday in Rockleigh, N.J. He was 86.

headline: As High Line Park Rises, a Time Capsule Remains
text: THE first section of the new High Line park is moving toward completion, six blocks of hulking elevated rail line along the lower West Side, converted to an urban symphony of walking paths and landscaping  with one exception. Under the artists’ housing complex Westbeth, on Washington between Bank and Bethune Streets, one little section of the old rail line continues in a glorious romantic desuetude.

headline: Letters: Triple-A Failure
text: While Roger Lowenstein admits there is no evidence to suggest ratings firms inflate ratings to please bond issuers (April 27), he nonetheless questioned the independence, integrity and quality of credit ratings.

headline: A Nose for a Business Opportunity
text: Tammi Giesen got a whiff of living with a man who plays hockey on a November morning in 2001.

headline: Does the ‘Real’ Ireland Still Exist?
text: AN August night in the sea-scented village of Kinvara finds us at Connolly’s, a pub so permanent that if some codger were to tell you it was here before Galway Bay, lapping now just outside the door, you’d nod and buy him a pint. My wife and I are hunched at a small table with friends when a smiling woman in a peasant skirt sits beside us, carrying a perfectly appropriate accessory in this corner of Ireland  a button accordion.

headline: Passing the ‘Doorbell Test’
text: WESTCHESTER was a good place for Amanda Allensworth and Sean Cleary to start out. They married two years ago, after meeting while waiting on tables together at a restaurant in Eastchester.

headline: O Canada, Where Have Your Bargains Gone?
text: ONCE upon a time, not all that long ago, there existed a magical country that was a lot like the United States, only less expensive. Its enchanted currency  the other dollar  allowed Americans to indulge as they could not back home. This delightful fantasyland was called Canada, and for centuries it was synonymous with frugality.

headline: The Watch List
text: When Kenji Johjima was hitting below .200 last month, the Mariners gave him a three-year, $24 million contract extension. Johjima, a soon-to-be 32-year-old catcher, is showing signs they did not make a mistake. Johjima has raised his batting average 50 points this month and had four extra-base hits, including his first homer, in three games this week.

headline: O Pioneer!
text: If slavery is America’s original sin, lynching is its capital crime. The historical memory dies hard: only last year, three nooses were hung from a schoolyard tree contested by white and black students in Jena, La.

headline: The Language of Loss for the Jobless
text: THE neighbor, a jovial suit-and-tie presence at the school bus stop in the mornings, disappeared for a while last fall. Nobody saw him for weeks. Finally he began to venture out  at afternoon pickup, in jeans and a T-shirt. A senior manager of a technology department, he had been laid off. Neighbors didn’t know what to say to him.

headline: Diesel Automobiles Clean Up for an Encore
text: AFTER years in the automotive wilderness, largely exiled to the smoky borders of truck stops, diesel is coming home. Americans may not recognize its freshly scrubbed face.

headline: Call Him the Worst Director (Then Duck)
text: UWE BOLL is often referred to as the worst filmmaker in the world.

headline: The Price of Street Justice: A Child Is Gone
text: TRENTON

headline: A Haitian in U.S. Wins Case Over Forced Labor
text: MIAMI  Amid tears, Simone Celestin recalled the repeated beatings she endured at the hands of her adoptive family while working for them as an unpaid servant for six years.

headline: Kahne Proves Fans’ Faith Was Well Placed
text: CONCORD, N.C.  Talk about a million-dollar smile.

headline: Next Stop: A Commuter Village
text: SECAUCUS

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: COMEDY

headline: Correction: What Adams Saw Through His Lens
text: An article and a map on April 27 about Ansel Adams’s photographs of Yosemite National Park misstated the location of a tunnel, and a correction in this space on May 11 misspelled the name of the tunnel. It is the Wawona  not Wauwona  Tunnel and it is on the western end of Yosemite Valley, not on the park’s southern end.

headline: Hungarian Rhapsody
text: For years, the Hungarian menu has stuck to tradition  hearty paprika-accented dishes, tokaji wine and the national brandy known as palinka. But these days there’s bright, creative energy in Budapest, as chefs and bartenders give a new spin to old ideas.

headline: The Birth of a Nation, 1948
text: IT was Friday, May 14, 1948. I was sitting in the press section of the United Nations General Assembly in its temporary quarters at Flushing Meadow in Queens. I felt my heart thumping. We journalists were waiting impatiently to see who would win a tug of war taking place in Washington.

headline: John Cusack Goes to War
text: POLITICAL satire has its work cut out for it in the current environment. An unpopular war, the tortured rhetoric of a government defending its various pratfalls and news media that many see as complicit in the mess have created a burlesque  one that may not require annotation or exaggeration. Not that John Cusack isn’t willing to give it a whirl. His “War, Inc.,” which opens in New York and Los Angeles this weekend, is a satire that goes over the top and stays there.

headline: Lee Finds Location, and Success Follows
text: Cliff Lee, a left-hander who won 18 games in 2005, reached a low point in his career last year when he was left off the Cleveland Indians’ postseason roster. It was an expected move after he produced a 6.29 earned run average in 20 games and was sent down to the minors for 10 starts.

headline: Escape plan
text: A world apart from the seedy foot-rub joints on every Beijing block, Zenspa occupies a hushed courtyard residence in the Chaoyang district. Inside the colorfully lacquered structure, the Hong Kong interior designer David Ng has created a modern retreat where treatments like a fresh milk bath and gold-leaf scrub are administered in suites arranged around a reflecting pool. House 1, 8A Xiaowuji Lu; 011-86-10-8731-2530; www.zenspa.com.cn.

headline: Provence Profound
text: Many travelers to the Vaucluse are like me: they believe that among the joys life can provide, one of the most moving is to plant oneself before the sausage stand in the Place de l’Église, in l’Isle-sur-la-Sorgue, during the Sunday market, and just gawk and taste. Who knew that human ingenuity could craft of simple animal flesh and fat (with some addenda) so many wonders? Let’s enumerate. There’s sausage in the tradition of Arles, sausage with marc brandy, extra-lite sausage (why bother?), sausage with herbs, boar sausage, duck sausage, spicy sausage, Corsican figatelli, pure pork sausage, sausage with wild mushrooms, donkey sausage (!) and at least 40 other kinds. There are French things here that, even given today’s global market, you just aren’t going to find in the United States. The cheese stands and the olive stands are similarly dazzling.

headline: More Than Snappy Comebacks
text: Our elders, who remember American life before World War II, swear that people were nicer to one another then. My father always said that. Neil Simon makes the point convincingly in “Lost in Yonkers,” his Pulitzer Prize-winning 1991 play. And the Schoolhouse Theater is currently demonstrating it with a production that radiates warmth from beginning to end.

headline: No Internship Yet? There’s Still Time
text: Q. You still haven’t found an internship for the summer. Is it too late?

headline: Trenton Tea Party
text: You don’t see a lot of puppets having afternoon tea. But DoDo and DaDa have a standing invitation in “Cecilia’s Last Tea Party,” a modest but ravishing new piece of theater well served by the Passage Theater Company’s production in Trenton.

headline: In-Store: Maine Event
text: 1. His Portland, Me.-based store and fashion label Rogues Gallery may be more stylish than salty, but Alex Carleton’s supercool riffs on sailor and workman’s garb draw heavily from local traditions. “I grew up on Cape Cod and am passionate about the sea and the history of the region,” he says. “I moved to Maine because it reminds me of what New England used to be.” 41 Wharf Street; (207) 553-1999; dandyrogue.com.

headline: In His Former Home, a Spirited Randolph
text: Willie Randolph was pacing as much as he could pace in the narrow, crowded Mets dugout. He moved 15 feet to his left, then 15 feet to his right. It was not the type of manic pacing that happens in a maternity ward, but it was a brief, tense walk.

headline: For Ochoa, No Shortage of Birdies or Confidence
text: CLIFTON, N.J.  It seemed destined. Lorena Ochoa, the 26-year-old Mexican who has dominated the L.P.G.A. Tour the past three years, took the lead Saturday in the $2 million Sybase Classic.

headline: Immigrants’ Children Find Better Lives, Study Shows
text: A decade-long study of adult children of immigrants to the New York region has concluded that they are rapidly entering the mainstream and doing better than their parents in terms of education and earnings  even outperforming native-born Americans in many cases.

headline: Bitter Young Things
text: The Israeli writer Etgar Keret is a genius, although it’s not entirely apparent in “The Girl on the Fridge,” his new story collection. “New” in this case means newly published, not newly written. These stories date from the mid-1980s, when Keret was a young man in the army, just starting to develop the powerful and unsettling voice that would turn him into an acclaimed spokesman for his generation of Israelis  and gain him an enthusiastic foreign audience with the publication of a collection called “The Nimrod Flipout.”

headline: Plane Crash in New Jersey Kills 2
text: A small airplane crashed in a wooded area near an airport in Ocean County, N.J., on Saturday, killing two passengers and critically injuring the plane’s other two occupants, officials said.

headline: Putting Science to Work in the Kitchen
text: HARTFORD

headline: An Alarm Is Blaring: Time to Buy
text: MARKET timing  trying to jump into or out of the stock market just before rallies and declines  is notoriously difficult. Most investors would probably be better off sticking with a buy-and-hold strategy.

headline: Death in Venice
text: Official justice being arbitrary in Donna Leon’s gorgeously written but deeply melancholic Venetian police procedurals, the task of her detective, Commissario Guido Brunetti, isn’t so much to solve a crime as to find a way of bearing the pain and horror of it. THE GIRL OF HIS DREAMS (Atlantic Monthly, $24), the 17th book in this superlative series, restates Leon’s theme with more intensity than usual, opening with the burial of Brunetti’s mother and his sad thoughts about the transitory nature of life.

headline: A New Place Satisfies the Craving for Italian
text: IF I lived near Luciano’s Italian Ristorante and Lounge, my weekends would be calmer. I wouldn’t feel the need to make double batches of marinara, or 96 meatballs at a time, just to freeze some for the hectic weeknights ahead.

headline: The Horse, Familiar and Unfamiliar
text: Perhaps the most interesting thing about “The Horse”  a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History  is how remote its subject seems, how completely the horse has faded from the everyday life of ordinary people.

headline: Ho Hum, It’s Just Another Senate Race

headline: Readers’ Picks: Prague
text: Selected reader suggestions on Prague, compiled from user comments on the Travel section’s Web site, nytimes.com/travel.

headline: Mugabe Opponent Cancels Return to Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, suddenly canceled on Saturday his planned return home, where he would have begun campaigning in the June 27 presidential runoff election, after his party received what his spokesman called credible, specific intelligence about a plot to kill him.

headline: Edifice complex
text: As construction cranes continue to crawl through the city, architecture in Beijing is bound to have its highs and lows. Here, a few top projects.

headline: What a Deal: Trash for Treasuries
text: SAVING the nation’s financial system from reckless banks and brokerage firms is an enormous job, heaven knows. But somebody’s got to do it, so the Federal Reserve Board, with its taxpayer-funded balance sheet, stepped in.

headline: Cold War? What Cold War?
text: If you’re going to make a stage musical out of a television show, “Happy Days” is not a bad choice. All that cheerful white-bread 1950s innocence. All those instant audience associations with beloved characters and the actors who played them. The show won’t ever win a Pulitzer Prize (or the musical-comedy equivalent), but the Goodspeed Opera House’s bouncy new production delivers a pleasant if not transporting evening, and  most important  the Fonz (Joey Sorge) is cool.

headline: Can a Dead Brand Live Again?
text: Do you remember Brim?

headline: Datebook
