headline: The Ashes
text: There have been good novels about living in the post-9/11 world (Ian McEwan’s “Saturday”), pretentious ones (Don DeLillo’s “Falling Man”) and sentimental ones (Jonathan Safran Foer’s “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close”). But sorting through the pile of so-called 9/11 novels is a sad exercise, one that grows more pointless by the day. They’re all 9/11 novels now.

headline: When Shakira Calls, Even the Shy Appear
text: The Mexican telecommunications billionaire Carlos Slim Helú does not seem to like appearing in public, but he apparently could not resist an invitation from the Colombian pop star Shakira and about a dozen other Latin music stars.

headline: In Westchester, Many Seem Able to Wait Out the Storm
text: THE real estate troubles that have been plaguing the rest of the nation are now hitting hard in Westchester, with markedly fewer sales, according to a report released last month by the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service.

headline: Beating the Bushes for a Bargain Ticket
text: IS it still possible to find cheap airfares? With prices rising  the average cost of an airline ticket in the United States was up 10.2 percent in March, compared with a year ago, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics  and with airlines raising fees on everything from ticket changes to checked bags, it’s no wonder that a lot of travelers are talking about just staying home this summer.

headline: In Iran, Debate Over an Article of Faith
text: TEHRAN  In his three years as president of Iran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has been harshly criticized in the West. But he is increasingly drawing fire from Shiite clerics here, who accuse him of using religion to distract attention from his government’s failure to deliver on promises of prosperity and political freedoms.

headline: Past the Sound Barrier, on a Business Jet
text: SPEED sells in the business-jet world, where Gulfstream Aerospace recently announced a hot new heavy-metal model, the G650, due for delivery in 2012.

headline: Street Cred Vienna
text: Trends don’t take hold easily in Vienna. This is a city charmed by its own traditions  a seventh-generation bootmaker, an Adolf Loos-designed haberdashery. Still, hats are suddenly huge in town, most obviously in the Museumsquartier, where the cool kids are all rocking headgear. But this is no passing fancy for trucker caps or a Pete Doherty trilby. Driving the craze is the 105-year-old hatmaker Mühlbauer, which has lately been revitalized by the fourth-generation owner Klaus Mühlbauer’s clever designs and savvy marketing (Elfie Semotan shot his current ad campain). His newsboy caps, perforated leather fedoras and unisex turbans have become hipster staples. Mühlbauer. Seilergasse 10; 011-43-53-352-6912; muehlbauer.at. MARKUS EBNER

headline: Even in the Hamptons, Homes Are Slow to Sell
text: HOME sales on Long Island continued to slide in the first quarter of 2008, with even the usually resilient East End vacation market falling on sluggish times.

headline: The Sophisticated Traveler: Hit The Hay
text: No longer just for beach totes and barnyards, straw has become a summer favorite of designers looking to stay cool. Witness Salvatore Ferragamo’s retro tote ($650; ferragamo.com), Tom Ford’s posh panama hat ($790; tomford.com) and Anya Hindmarch’s oversize clutch adorned with amethyst ($370; anyahindmarch.com). Thinking outside the picnic basket, Lanvin has made a pair of raffia platform sandals with an ostrich heel ($1,435; lanvin.com). And the French designer Alexis Mabille has even raised a crop of

headline: Yes, It’s a Cooperative. But for Whom?
text: THE traditional idea of agricultural cooperatives is that farmers have more muscle to negotiate prices when they band together.

headline: ‘We Are Now Beginning Our Descent’
text: At four a.m., when it was still dark and an hour before the Fajr prayer, Sarina Najafi got up, washed, dressed, ate a hasty breakfast of lavash and cheese and left her family's apartment on the tenth floor of a modern block on the southern outskirts of the Iranian city of Esfehan.

headline: Phillis Levin, Jack Shanewise
text: Phillis Marna Levin and Dr. Jack Stacey Shanewise were married on Saturday evening at the Century Association in New York. Rabbi Richard A. Davis officiated at the ceremony, and the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski, an Episcopal priest, participated.

headline: Blade Runner
text: In the 1980s, the distinguished but now forgotten Paris decorator Christian Badin would pose for design magazines with an old-fashioned watering can, dribbling water on the chunky Elizabethan rush matting in his apartment in an 18th-century hôtel particulier. While connoisseurs of the Rolls-Royce of vegetal floor coverings nodded mischievously, many more shrunk at the thought of spores, mildew and the ravishing parquet de Versailles underneath. Watering your parquet? Quelle horreur.

headline: Yes, Manhattan’s Over There. What of It?
text: The “Living In” column on May 4, about Maspeth, Queens, incorrectly listed a Kiwanis flea market as an upcoming event. There will not be a flea market today.

headline: Park Slope: Where Is the Love?
text: POOR Union Hall. First, there was the tempest in a sippy cup stirred up in Brooklyn last February by this bar-brunch-boccie spot’s ban on children in strollers. And just last week, a subcommittee of the Park Slope community board  swayed by an army of pitchfork-wielding locals  dealt the joint a harsh, if symbolic blow: no liquor license renewal until you do something about the noise. Though the full board overruled the committee within days, the blogosphere’s critics and conspiracy theorists had already drawn their conclusions: “It’s the revenge of the Stroller Moms.”

headline: Stock Gains Defy Reports of Weakness
text: The stock market gained ground last week, despite surging oil prices and sharp declines in consumer confidence and in the construction of single-family homes.

headline: Aria! Action! Making Opera a Director’s Art
text: HERE is a treasure. Opera DVDs tumble out by the dozens nowadays, too often featuring routine performances of recent productions that hardly seem worth preserving. In contrast Arthaus’s scholarly and imposing “Walter Felsenstein Edition” offers a fascinating glimpse of an important moment in operatic history now vanished.

headline: Another Side of Dr. House, in Sitcom Mode
text: HUGH LAURIE has a long résumé in British television comedy, from “Blackadder” to a stint as P. G. Wodehouse’s highborn twit, Bertie Wooster. Fans of Mr. Laurie’s current series, the medical drama “House,” may have a hard time reconciling his sarcastic and saturnine diagnostician with the goggle-eyed goofballs he’s made a career of playing. But there was a transition between the two, now available as a DVD: the six-episode 2003 British comedy “Fortysomething.”

headline: A Rock, a Hard Place and an Exit Strategy
text: DO you feel that you’re working harder and harder to get ahead financially, but can’t even seem to stay in the same place? Do you feel trapped by larger forces that are increasing your cost of living but lowering your income? Do you worry about losing your job or having to change your career, even as news reports say the overall economy is growing and you see a privileged few enjoying unparalleled prosperity?

headline: San Francisco: InterContinental
text: THE BASICS

headline: Garlic Defanged
text: It’s often been said that chefs must be a little crazy. Those who advance this theory usually cite the willful pursuit of long hours and low pay under punishing conditions, the erratic behavior and temperament that tend toward what might generously be described as artistic. This is a lie, a cruel stereotype that I, as a perfectly sane chef, flatly reject. Well, I do have one quirk that might be considered a little eccentric: I don’t like garlic.

headline: Q&A
text: I am taking three teenagers to Paris in June and will be doing day trips from there. I was thinking of taking a trip to Bruges, Belgium, because it sounds cool. Is there enough there to keep the kids interested for a day?  Colleen McCloskey, Catonsville, Md.

headline: Frock Stars
text: A new generation of designers is turning Beijing women into fashionistas and making that Mao jacket ancient history.

headline: The Scene: Copenhagen
text: Denmark may never completely escape the shadow of Arne Jacobsen’s Egg chair, but at street level in Copenhagen today, where the creative energy flows no less freely than it did 50 years ago, young artistic types are hardly hooked on the classics.

text: Claudine Michele Majcher and Buck Wolf were married on Saturday in Hawley, Pa. Mayor Ann Morgan of Hawley officiated at the Settlers Inn.

headline: Conjunction Junction
text: London’s venerable Connaught has snagged Hélène Darroze, the two-Michelin-star chef who’s earned a cult following at her eponymous Paris kitchen. As part of the Mayfair hotel’s $138 million makeover, Darroze will open her first of three dining rooms in June with a restaurant designed by India Mahdavi.

headline: Counting Classroom Seats in a Booming City
text: STEPHANIE PEDERSON, an author of books on beauty and health and the mother of a kindergartner named Leif, first became aware of the problem in September. It was Leif’s first day at Public School 116, on East 33rd Street in Kips Bay, and Ms. Pederson had just arrived to drop him off.

headline: Captain Kangaroo
text: People always tell me, ‘Finally I feel like I’m in Australia,’ even if they’ve been in the country for weeks,” Craig Wickham said as we barreled down a red dirt road on Kangaroo Island. Wickham is tall and graceful, with tan skin and a salt-and-pepper buzz cut. He grew up on a farm on the island’s north coast and now owns the Exceptional Kangaroo Island touring company, which has been taking travelers around this island, 10 miles off the coast of southern Australia, for nearly 20 years. Beyond the dusty windshield of our Land Cruiser scrolled great arcades of silvery gum trees, tossing dappled sunlight onto the road. Every once in a while the greenery dropped away, revealing the island’s famous limestone cliffs and aquamarine water, bright flashes of color amid sedate browns and greens. “K. I. encapsulates everything people were hoping to find here in Australia,” Wickham said. “You can have a lot of people lost in the landscape and you never feel that the land is crowded.”

headline: Ceramic Hip Implants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Image Banks
text: Beijing has emerged as China’s frenzied, money-minting art hub. Sort through the hype at these top museums and galleries.

headline: Changing Configurations Make Up Jazz Collaborative
text: Peekskill

headline: Lottery Numbers
Derby Winner Cruises to Victory at Preakness
text: BALTIMORE  The first time Kent Desormeaux came to this venerable old racetrack, he was a kid from the bayou, barely removed from Louisiana bush track match races where boys like him, as part of their early lessons, rode against horses strapped with bags of rocks, or a rooster, and sometimes a monkey. He was the Cajun Kid, who won nine riding titles in Maryland and still holds a single-season record for victories here  599 of them in 1989.

headline: Drilling for Defeat?
text: Nearly two decades ago, Republicans won the West by linking Democrats to environmentalists, who supposedly cared more for the spotted owl and other favored species than they did for the jobs of loggers or miners. But now, as a boom in natural-gas drilling reshapes the region, Western Democrats have found success recasting environmentalism as a defense of threatened water supplies, fishing spots and hunting grounds. As a result, the party may hold the advantage this fall in the region’s key Congressional races. The simultaneous rise of Western energy production and the Western Democrat is no coincidence.

text: Barcelona on the Brain

text: SEATTLE

headline: Lenders Raise the Bar
text: IF you have a mortgage, consider yourself lucky.

headline: Who Needs to Travel When There’s Home?
text: How much have you really explored your neighborhood? There’s the diner where you’ve never eaten, the store you’ve never bothered to enter, the statue in the park that commemorates something  you’ve never found out what. Who needs London or Paris, with these cultural riches so close at hand?

headline: A Home as Quirky as Life Itself
text: WEI WEI SHANNON and Andrew Gluckman occupy one of the more eccentric spaces in Manhattan.

headline: Militants Free Ambassador of Pakistan in Exchange
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistan’s ambassador to Afghanistan, who was kidnapped three months ago by Taliban militants as he traveled in Pakistan’s tribal area, was released Friday night, the government said.

headline: How to Join
text: Creating an online community is usually a simple process. With an e-mail address, a user can follow easy instructions to register.

text: Tucked away inside the United States attorney’s office in the Northern District of California are documents that link more than 100 major league baseball players to positive tests for steroids conducted in 2003.

headline: Brooklyn Public School Is a Big Winner at National Championships
text: At the elementary school national championships in Pittsburgh last weekend, public schools won many of the top prizes. But there was controversy when one team had to split its squad and when another won a division with players who might have had an unfair advantage.

headline: The Scars of Losing a Home
text: ACROSS the United States, there were 243,353 foreclosure filings in April alone, nearly three times the total in the same month just two years ago, according to RealtyTrac, a company that follows the numbers. The trend is unmistakable, and suggests that, without government intervention, many millions of American families will be losing their homes before long.

headline: Whose Rain Forest Is This, Anyway?
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — For as long as most can remember, Brazil has gazed nervously at maps of the vast, mostly uninhabited territory of the Amazon rain forest.

headline: Not Much Help for the Polar Bear
text: Boxed into a corner by the courts and its own scientists, the Bush administration agreed last week to place the polar bear under the protection of the Endangered Species Act. The decision was the clearest official acknowledgment that the bear, its hunting grounds diminished by shrinking summer ice, is seriously at risk.

headline: Her Goats, Her Cheese
text: Five years ago, with her children grown and her motherly instincts still strong, Lisa Schwartz bought two American Alpine goats. In short order, her herd grew from 2 to 36. Standing in her milking barn on a recent spring day, with nanny goats stuttering and butting heads and their kids bleating incessantly, Ms. Schwartz cradled a newborn in her arms and said, “A psychologist could have a field day with me.”

headline: Thinking About California. Maybe Gonna Get Married.
text: As soon as the California Supreme Court ruled Thursday that gay men and lesbians had a constitutional right to marry, my partner and I started getting the calls: When would we head West to get hitched?

headline: Gotcha!
text: This is the column that the gleeful Gotcha! Gang and its modest affiliate, the Nit-pickers League, live for: abject confession of errors by the professional error-corrector. Let the hooting, stoning and caning begin:

headline: High Rises at Center of Arts District Debate

headline: A Virgin Islands Invitation
text: The United States Virgin Islands Department of Tourism is directing marketing to Caribbean cruisers who would like to stay a little longer after their time at sea has ended. The USVI Six to Six promotion entices travelers who spend about six hours visiting the ports of St. John, St. Croix or St. Thomas on cruises to remain on land six days longer through freebies that include a sixth day of lodging, a bottle of Cruzan rum, a sixth day of car rental, a $60 gift certificate and a coupon book with a value of $626.

headline: Celtics Home, but Not Necessarily Home Free
text: WALTHAM, Mass.  If they need to wrap themselves in a mental security blanket, the Boston Celtics have plenty to choose from: the 66-victory regular season, the 7-0 home record in the playoffs, the friendly sea of green that will greet them Sunday at TD Banknorth Garden.

text: XIAHE, China

headline: A Popular Red for Snacking
text: Hazlitt 1852 Vineyards, on Seneca Lake, hopes to sell 150,000 cases of nonvintage, semisweet Red Cat in 2008. That is an attainable goal.

headline: Over the Years, It Feels Right at Home
text: I MOVED into my apartment, in a six-story red-brick building in Tarrytown, N.Y., with the intention of moving up and out within a few years.

headline: Settlement Will Help Clean Suffolk Water
text: WHEN several major oil companies agreed earlier this month to pay nearly $424 million to settle a federal lawsuit brought by scores of water providers claiming damages from the gasoline additive M.T.B.E., one Long Island provider took the largest share by far.

text: Taser C2 Personal Protector

headline: Party Loyalty
text: Nightclubbing is a relatively new pastime in this otherwise conservative town. And the capital is certainly making up for lost time, with a host of new clubs catering to a range of nocturnal passions.

headline: Born Supremacy
text: Style Map | Barcelona: Once a neglected tangle of narrow streets around the Picasso Museum and the church of Santa Maria del Mar, the Born district has slowly shed its gritty image to become Barcelona’s version of the West Village. The cafe-lined squares and bosky lanes are filled with young local talent offering their own bold, distinctly Spanish take on fashion, design and cuisine. DALE FUCHS

headline: Magicians Ask: What’s Up His Sleeve?
text: Los Angeles

headline: A Win for Eight Belles’s Camp
text: It is true that Big Brown’s stallion rights were sold to Three Chimneys Farm for more than $50 million. Michael Iavarone, the president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings and a co-owner of Big Brown, confirmed he signed a deal Saturday on his way to Pimlico after a week of negotiations.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ASSAULT ON REASON, by Al Gore. (Penguin, $16.) The former vice president pulls out all the stops in this “blistering assessment of the Bush administration and the state of public discourse in America,” as Michiko Kakutani described it in The Times. Gore argues that “reason, logic and truth seem to play a sharply diminished role in the way America now makes important decisions”; one example is the administration’s tendency to ignore expert advice (from generals and scientists) so it can promote its ideological agenda.

headline: Instead of Fistfights, Fashion at a Troubled High School
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  Notable happenings at Camden High School this year included a cafeteria brawl that led to the arrest of 18 teenagers and left a police officer with a bruised face, a 14-year-old boy smuggling a gun loaded with hollow-point bullets into school in his backpack, the replacement of a principal and a hip-hop fashion show that turned the auditorium into a South Jersey version of a Bryant Park tent.

headline: Elena Wechsler and John Simpson
text: IT came as no surprise to anyone who knew her that Dr. Elena Wechsler would find herself with a man who won her heart with ducks. Her childhood home in Glen Mills, Pa., was often referred to as the zoo by friends. Besides caring for the family’s own menagerie, Dr. Wechsler’s mother, a veterinarian, was known to care for an injured flying squirrel in the bathtub or give dialysis to a dog in the kitchen.

headline: No Frills but a Fiesta in Every Kitchen
text: RIVERHEAD

headline: Times Square to Have New Tourist Center
text: Befuddled tourists in Times Square in New York will welcome the Broadway Concierge and Ticket Center (www.broadwayleague.com), scheduled to open next month. The center, in the Times Square Information Center at 1560 Broadway, will provide information on Broadway shows in six languages (English, Japanese, German, Spanish, Portuguese and French); offer ticket sales; make restaurant, hotel and car service reservations; distribute free neighborhood maps; and share parking information. The center will also customize packages, like the Regular Guy’s Guide to Broadway, which might be dinner at ESPN Zone, tickets to “Stomp” and bowling afterward).

headline: Letters: Where Alaa Al Aswany Is Writing From
text: Alaa Al Aswany is grateful for the extensive coverage of his life and work in The New York Times Magazine, but he has asked the American University in Cairo Press, as his principal English-language publisher and international literary agent, to inform your readers of the following crucial clarifications (April 27).

headline: A Masterful Caricaturist and His Lithographs
text: In 1830, newly installed on the throne, King Louis-Philippe boldly declared an end to censorship laws. So began a golden era in the French press, with publishers and editors seizing the opportunity to start political newspapers and journals.

headline: Kimberly Wilson, Michael Portnoy
text: Kimberly Ann Wilson and Michael Steven Portnoy were married on Saturday evening at the Bushnell Center for the Performing Arts in Hartford. Stephen M. Gromko, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Road Scholar
text: The new book “A Road Trip Journal” (Phaidon, $250) documents a 1973 cross-country drive the photographer Stephen Shore made from New York to the West Coast and back, one of many such trips he took during the 1970s. The volume recreates the scrapbook Shore made at the time: what TV shows he watched (the Watergate hearings, “All in the Family”), the mileage he clocked, which locations he shot (“Sha-Mar Beauty Salon, Chestnut St.”). He also included every piece of paper he collected  receipts, parking and movie tickets, and, most important, postcards. “I found them fascinating because they were not trying to be works of art,” he says. “They just show you the main street, the so-and-so motel. I was attracted to that matter-of-factness.” Ultimately, it was that matter-of-factness that had a big influence on his own pictures; although made with a view camera on a tripod, they are printed to look like everyday snapshots.

headline: A Musical Collaboration That’s Making Noise Beyond Bridgeport
text: BRIDGEPORT

headline: Over the Long Haul, Diesels Appeal
text: THE first fuel crisis that followed the Arab oil embargo of 1973 persuaded Americans to give diesel cars a try. These proliferated at first, but quickly faded under a foul-smelling cloud.

headline: Critic Earns ‘I Told You So’ in Meadowlands Project
text: Lyndhurst

headline: Along Cherished Lanes, the Last Strikes and Spares
text: MANY of the gray-haired patrons of Woodhaven Lanes bowling alley in Glendale, Queens, have bowled there since they could barely lift a bowling ball. Romances, friendships and competitive spirits have budded on its 60 lanes, and wedding pictures were once taken on Lanes No. 1 and 2. The bowling alley is a place where it’s not uncommon to hear someone earnestly declare, “Bowling is my life.”

headline: Hedging Their Bets
text: The saying “everything old is new again” came true during the Milan furniture fair last month, when Meta made its debut. The company, which was created by Mallett, the venerable antiques dealer, pairs the fine materials and techniques of the past with contemporary design. Its first collection includes objects like a solid-gold box by Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture and a modern take on the traditional lantern by Matali Crasset. But its showstopper is the Fig Leaf wardrobe by Tord Boontje, who helped make a black-clad design world learn to love flora and fauna some years back. The wardrobe’s hand-forged ironwork structure is adorned with 616 individually attached leaves, each of which is hand-enameled on both the front and back and signed by its respective enameler. Inside is a cast-bronze tree, the branches of which offer a poetic alternative to the conventional hanging rod. Boontje said he could see the wardrobe in a minimalist house as well as “in a palace, next to a Gainsborough.”

headline: Court Without a Quorum
text: Appointment to the United States Supreme Court is an extraordinary honor that conveys the power to influence the course of American law and justice. It does not seem too much to ask that sitting justices order their personal financial affairs to minimize the potential for conflicts of interest requiring them to sit out cases.

headline: In Rhode Island, Deficit Keeps Growing
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Rhode Island officials learned that they faced a budget shortfall this year of $168 million, they began pruning services.

headline: For Senate, Clinton (Bill)
text: Charleston, S.C.

headline: As Prices Rise, Crime Tipsters Work Overtime
text: To gas prices, foreclosure rates and the cost of rice, add this rising economic indicator: the number of tips to the police from people hoping to collect reward money.

headline: Chávez Seizes Greater Economic Power
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Faced with shortages of foods, building materials and other staples, President Hugo Chávez is intensifying state control of the Venezuelan economy through a new wave of takeovers of private companies and the creation of government-controlled ventures with allies like Cuba and Iran.

headline: An E-Commerce Empire, From Porn to Puppies
text: TRIBUTES on the Web site of Richard J. Gordon‘s company strike all of the uplifting chords one would expect of a digital maverick. He is described as a “trailblazing businessman” who is “operating in the front ranks of those transforming the Internet into the global marketplace of the future.”

headline: G.O.P. Eyes Two Westchester Senate Seats
text: EAGER to preserve their majority in the State Senate, Republican leaders are beefing up efforts to capture the two Westchester seats held by Democrats, including that of the longtime Senator Suzi Oppenheimer.

headline: Ink-Stained and Loving It
text: IT’S hard to look authentically rebellious or menacing these days, when even well-behaved businessmen wear earrings and ponytails and college students destined for quiet suburban lives have body piercings and tattoos.

headline: Costs of Living
text: The timing for Jeffrey D. Sachs’s new book on how to avert global economic catastrophe couldn’t be better, with food riots in Haiti, oil topping $120 a barrel and a gnawing sense that there’s just less of everything  rice, fossil fuels, credit  to go around. Of course, we’ve been here before. In the 19th century, Thomas Malthus teased out the implications of humans reproducing more rapidly than the supply of food could grow. In 1972, the Club of Rome published, to much hoopla, a book entitled “Limits to Growth.” The thesis: There are too many people and too few natural resources to go around. In 1978, Mr. Smith, my sixth-grade science teacher, proclaimed that there was sufficient petroleum to last 25 to 30 years. Well, as Yogi Berra once may have said, “It’s hard to make predictions, especially about the future.”

headline: Earthquake Opens Gap in Controls on Media
text: SHANGHAI  Two and a half hours after a huge earthquake struck Sichuan Province on Monday, an order went out from the powerful Central Propaganda Department to newspapers throughout China. “No media is allowed to send reporters to the disaster zone,” it read, according to Chinese journalists who are familiar with it.

headline: Letters: The Queen of the New Age
text: For 20 years, there has been a copy of “Heal Your Body,” by Louise L. Hay, at my bedside, and I subscribe to her descriptions of the mind/body connections, but I was appalled to read Hay’s response to questions about victims of genocide and the Holocaust (April 4). Bad karma? Former lives? What enormities could they possibly have committed to deserve their horrific fates? I’m sorry that Hay thinks human cruelty, or autoimmune disease, for that matter, is a result of karmic transgressions. For a woman with her influence, coyly sidestepping with “That’s just my opinion” doesn’t fly.

headline: Paying Off the Refs
text: I officiate youth hockey. In nonleague games, it is the coaches who pay the two officials. At one game, one team’s coach (whom I knew) paid the other official the normal fee but tucked away extra money for me. When my co-official asked if I had gotten the same wage, I said yes so he would not feel cheated. Was it ethical for this coach to pay me extra when the other official and I are the same age, have the same experience and both did the same amount of work?  A.M., NEW JERSEY

headline: A Thicket of Easy Loans That Entangled One Mortgage Holder
text: Redding

headline: Pixels at an Exhibition
text: What do video artists make of YouTube? Every minute, 10 hours of video are uploaded to the video-sharing site, which now shows hundreds of millions of videos each day. The place is a mess. Maybe artists should avoid it altogether.

headline: California Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage Fuels a Battle, Rather Than Ending It
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Just hours after the California Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry, Mathew D. Staver was already raising money to overturn the decision.

headline: Art Just for the Art’s Sake in Berlin
text: THE Fifth Berlin Biennial for Contemporary Art, which runs through June 15, may well be remembered for signaling the beginning of a new curatorial movement: Slow Art.

headline: Letters
text: ‘Mad Pride’

headline: Table talk
text: The city’s food scene may be getting haute, but for every reimagined egg roll there’s also a triedand-true original worth seeking out. Here, three approaches to high-and-low Beijing eating.

headline: Dreams and Disaster
text: On long bus rides, David Samuels used to fake a Southern accent and tell strangers he was raised on Army bases rather than in the Orthodox Jewish household in Brooklyn where he grew up. “There was something scary about the ease with which I became a new person, a fictional character,” he has written. “I felt cold inside, and detached from my own body.” Eventually he started listening more carefully to the stories of his fellow travelers, spending much of the last 10 years on the road for Harper’s Magazine and The New Yorker, absorbing himself in the lives of a strange cross section of America: con men and fugitives, radicals and rap stars, addicts and politicians. Now we have his first collection of long-form journalism, a tribute to the twin American traditions of self-invention and self-deceit.

headline: Tori Amos | Songbird
text: For the musician Tori Amos, the best way to travel is to step onstage. “Performing is like taking a magic carpet ride,” she says. Her songs cover a wide range of subjects, from sexuality to religion to designer accessories. (Sample lyric: “Somewhere in the hills of Ireland, there’s a Prada bag.”) “Comic Book Tattoo,” an anthology of graphic art inspired by her songs, is due out in July. The book follows last year’s “Legs and Boots,” a series of live “bootlegs” sold through her Web site, and her American Doll Posse World Tour; ever the provocateur, she invited Pope Benedict XVI to her show in Rome. (He never R.S.V.P.’ed.) Despite his absence, Amos still managed to feel a higher power. Of giving a concert, she says: “It’s a legal way to get ecstasy. But there is less of a hangover if you go my way.” ALEX HAWGOOD

headline: A Man Who Loves Big Museums
text: CHICAGO

headline: Senator Kennedy Is Hospitalized After a Seizure
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, leader of the nation’s most storied political dynasty, was airlifted to Boston from Cape Cod on Saturday where he was hospitalized after suffering a seizure.

headline: ‘Wallace Stegner and the American West’
text: Seattle

headline: Politicians Challenge Integrity of N.F.L.
text: We often expect little from politicians; our standards for athletes, whether we admit it or not, are higher.

headline: Art and Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tentative Agreement May End Strike That Disrupted Production at 32 G.M. Plants
text: DETROIT  The auto industry’s longest strike in more than 40 years, a walkout at a parts supplier that disrupted production at 32 General Motors plants, will end within days if the picketing workers ratify a tentative agreement reached late Friday with their employer, American Axle and Manufacturing.

headline: The Ingénue Who Roared
text: AS Nellie Forbush, the sweetheart from Little Rock in the smashing new revival of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s South Pacific,” Kelli O’Hara deserves a medal for single-handedly rescuing the ingénue from extinction.

headline: When the Kremlin Tried a Little Openness
text: A dash of openness can be a dangerous thing in an autocratic state.

headline: Correction
text: A brief report in the Suits column on May 4 about Sheldon Adelson, chief executive of the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, referred imprecisely to his perks at the company. Although he is entitled to free use of dry-cleaning services at the company’s Venetian Resort and of the gym in the resort’s Canyon Ranch Spa, he says he has never used these benefits.

headline: Letters: Blocking the Transmission of Violence
text: Alex Kotlowitz’s insightful piece (May 4) on the cycles of violence that plague many communities makes the points that in matters of health, prevention is more effective than punishment, and that ending any addiction requires us to teach alternatives. Our own experience and a vast body of rigorous research suggest a few simple directives. Support prevention programs that start early, are rooted in community values and resources and are sustained over time. Focus on resources instead of deficits; embrace the hopes, skills and positive values of youth and communities, and build on that foundation. Teach alternatives to violence: anger management, empathy, communication, cooperation, conflict resolution and active community engagement help young people not only avoid violence; they also help inoculate them against the hopelessness that breeds these cycles.

headline: Edging Closer in Cyprus’s Divided Capital
text: LIKE most of Nicosia, the Atolye Cadi Kazani Cafe feels nostalgic. It is awash in jazzy piano music, the scent of cardamom-spiced coffee and an Ottoman ambience that reminds the owner, Nilgun Guney, of her grandmother’s house.

headline: Alley Cats
text: While most of Beijing’s hutongs  narrow lanes snaking around historic courtyard houses  have come under the bulldozer, there’s new life in the old Drum Tower district, where designers have opened hip boutiques.

headline: Fielding Edlow, Larry Clarke
text: Fielding Edlow and Larry Clarke are to be married on Sunday in Santa Barbara, Calif. Rita Rivest, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for the occasion by Santa Barbara County, is to officiate at the Bacara Resort and Spa.

headline: ‘Counselor’
text: Roots

headline: Climbing Everest: The Compulsion to Climb
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Voice of Mother Russia, in English
text: JUDGING from the news lately, Russia is well on its way to restoring that old Evil Empire image. Military parades have returned to Red Square. Key businesses are choked by corruption or are under state control. Journalists who probe too deeply turn up dead. And critics of the Kremlin are jailed, pushed out of elections or, in one instance, mysteriously poisoned.

headline: Penguins Hit Detour on Route to Finals
text: One victory from the Stanley Cup final, the Pittsburgh Penguins had faced little adversity through three rounds of playoffs.

headline: Eastern Star
text: Beijing has been attracting plenty of attention (and controversy) lately. Love it or hate it, the Chinese capital is the boomtown of our times. As architects, chefs, designers and filmmakers  to say nothing of the Olympics  leave their mark, this once buttoned-down metropolis has become a stylish city of the future. BY AMY FABRIS-SHI

headline: As Goes the Rest of the Nation, So Goes Connecticut
text: WINIFRED WILKINS did not need numbers to tell her about the state of real estate in Connecticut.

headline: Subdivided We Fall
text: As catchy pop-social science coinages go, “the Big Sort” may not have quite the pith or resonance of, say, “bobos” or “tipping points.” But in attempting to define and argue the implications of the sweeping social and political balkanization that has swept across America over the last 30 years, Bill Bishop has set his sights ambitiously on David Brooks and Malcolm Gladwell territory: identifying a big, worldview-changing social science phenomenon, and interpreting it for a popular audience.

headline: The Poetry of Barack Obama
text: Following are two poems by Barack Obama that were published in the Spring 1981 issue of “Feast,” a 51-page student literary journal that described itself as "a semi-annual journal of short poetry and fiction collected from the Occidental College community.” The journal is no longer published, according to a college spokesman.

headline: Where the Kids, Not the Stars, Are the Stars
text: ENGRAVED with the name Sopranus and looking not a little like a certain fictional New Jersey mobster, the faux-marble bust suggested a man no longer of this world. But in a Manhattan rehearsal space, Carmela Soprano was alive and kicking  literally  alongside Uncle Junior, Little Paulie and a trio of pint-sized henchmen in “The Mezzo-Sopranos,” a spoof of the HBO series of almost the same name.

headline: Loosen Your Borscht Belt and Raise Your Highbrows
text: JEWISH arts in New York City. What, exactly, does that mean? A 19th-century Austrian menorah? D.J.’s from Tel Aviv playing Prospect Park in Brooklyn? Jackie Mason cracking up an Off Broadway crowd with jokes that would not be funny  and would be offensive  from the mouth of anyone else?

headline: Sealing Victory, Wagner Is Happy to Talk About It
text: Mets closer Billy Wagner, who questioned his teammates’ accountability on Thursday, was relieved to be talking about his pitching instead of his critical remarks on Saturday. Wagner notched the last four outs as the Mets defeated the Yankees, 7-4, at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Democracy, Limited
text: When Bill Clinton was in the twilight months of his presidency, he made a compelling case that by integrating China into the world economy we would gradually undercut the viability of its authoritarian government. It was only a matter of time, he told an audience of American and Chinese students in March 2000, before a Net-savvy, rising middle class would begin to demand its rights, because “when individuals have the power not just to dream, but to realize their dreams, they will demand a greater say.”

headline: Correction: Inside the List
text: A brief report in the Inside the List column on May 4 misstated the title of the Lawrence Durrell novel that was No. 8 on the fiction best-seller list of May 5, 1968. It is “Tunc,” not “Tune.”

headline: Obama to Return to Iowa, Possibly to Claim Victory
text: Senator Barack Obama has chosen to spend Tuesday night not in Kentucky or Oregon, the two states that will be holding their primaries that day, or even at his home in Chicago. Instead, Mr. Obama’s staff announced on Saturday, he will be returning to Iowa, where he won the Democratic caucuses way back in January and has at least two good reasons to revisit now.

headline: Israel at 60
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Story of Obama, Written by Obama
text: Barack Obama was a first-time author and rookie politician embarking upon his first run for public office. Hermene Hartman was the publisher of N’Digo, a magazine in Chicago aimed at upscale black readers. As Ms. Hartman tells it, she got a call from Mr. Obama in the fall of 1995 saying he wanted to come and talk. He wanted her to read his newly published memoir.

headline: Jane Austen Meets Nancy Drew
text: In Karen Joy Fowler’s new novel, “Wit’s End,” set in Santa Cruz on the eve of the 2006 midterm election, a 29-year-old woman named Rima, whose entire nuclear family has died, comes to stay with her “fairy godmother,” the “rich, outrageously successful” mystery writer Addison Early. Sixty-four and unmarried, Addison lives near the beach with her housekeeper and her dachshunds in a sprawling, Hitchcockian mansion called Wit’s End (one, but not the only, justification for the book’s title). The house, which would make a fine up-coast annex to Disneyland, is littered with cutesy-macabre dollhouses  on a bedside table, in a kitchen corner, by the sink, on a shelf  each a “meticulous replica” of a murder scene from one of Addison’s detective novels. Every diorama comes with a miniature corpse, wee props (a toy blue convertible, a cummerbund the size of a twist-tie, a lipstick slightly larger than a grain of rice), “right down to its tiny clues and tiny gore.” Addison likes to entertain her friends or fans (there’s no difference  everyone she knows is obsessed with her genius and possesses an exhaustive mental concordance of her oeuvre) by sharing personal anecdotes; ruminating on admirers of her fictional detective, Maxwell Lane; and fulminating on Bush-era politics.

headline: Trying to Sell Europeans on Connecticut Charm
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: A Bid to Shield a Row of Sturdy Soldiers
text: GENERATIONS come and go on West End Avenue. White-collar types have replaced exiled Viennese Jews, and the Freudians in ground-floor suites have given way to cognitive behaviorists.

headline: Doors Close, Doors Open, and the Homeless Trudge On
text: THE old brick building that sits behind a tall iron fence at East 30th Street and First Avenue has been a haven for the lost since 1931. From that year until 1984 it operated as Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and now its ivy-covered walls house some 600 homeless men, along with the main intake center for homeless men citywide. Soon, the building will provide more luxurious shelter: In March, the city’s Economic Development Corporation announced plans to convert it into a hotel and conference center.

text: Danielle Laura Hersh and Corey David Rudolph were married on Saturday evening  at the Brooklake Country Club in Florham Park, N.J. The Rev. Brian Croak, a Presbyterian minister, officiated and Cantor Elliot Levine participated in the ceremony.

text: South Amityville, N.Y.

headline: André Galerne, 81, an Entrepreneur of the Deep, Is Dead
text: André Galerne, who in the early 1960s brought together a band of rugged divers willing to descend hundreds of feet to repair oil rigs, lay cables or salvage something from a sunken vessel  starting what became the world’s largest privately owned deep-sea construction company  died on May 6 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81, and for more than 30 years had lived by the bay in Larchmont, N.Y.

headline: Abigail Fyten, Johan Aasbo
text: The Rev. Abigail Fagan Fyten, a Disciples of Christ minister, and Dr. Johan David Aasbo, a physician, were married on Saturday at the Quogue Chapel of the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Quogue, N.Y. The Rev. Gretchen Steffenson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated following a nondenominational Christian ceremony led by George Fitchett, a Quaker chaplain.

headline: An Island Scorned
text: If the measure of a writer’s success is the ire he provokes, then V. S. Naipaul is a spectacular success in Trinidad. In this island nation of just over a million people, there is a widespread perception that he has jilted his homeland through unflattering portraits in his books and a string of cutting remarks over the years. “History is built around achievement and creation; and nothing was created in the West Indies,” Naipaul wrote in “The Middle Passage” (1962)  the first sign that he wasn’t going to play the proud native son. A fresher wound came in 2001, when Naipaul omitted any mention of Trinidad from his initial press release after winning the Nobel Prize, which many here saw as a deliberate rebuff. And last year, during a visit sponsored by the University of the West Indies, Naipaul more than lived up to his reputation for cantankerousness, prompting disapproving press coverage after he snapped at a group of students at a Hindu girls’ high school.

headline: Roach Qualifies
text: Melanie Roach, whose road to Beijing has been longer and more winding than many Olympic hopefuls, emerged from the United States weight lifting trials in Atlanta as the nation’s top qualifier.

headline: A More Permanent Crash Pad
text: The Habitats column on May 4, about two friends who pooled their resources to buy a house in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the name of a thoroughfare in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that one of them, Robin Scott, referred to as “sort of a fashion parade.” It is Bedford Avenue, not Bedford Street.

headline: Profile in Courage
text: In 1956, Douglas McKay left the Eisenhower cabinet to go back to Oregon and run against Wayne Morse for the Senate. At the Portland airport, he read a ghostwritten arrival statement, took off his glasses and said, to snickers, “Now I’d like to add a few words of my own.”

headline: From Afterthought to Essential
text: BROADWAY has no shortage of unsung heroes. After actors, playwrights, directors and producers, name recognition drops off steeply. But many who work behind the scenes can take solace that they might win a prominent award or, failing that, at least find a union to represent them.

headline: Letters: Young Gay Rites
text: I was surprised and saddened to note that although some of the couples mentioned (Benoit Denizet-Lewis, April 27) intend to have sex with multiple partners, there was no reference to sexually transmitted diseases, especially AIDS. It doesn’t matter whether a marriage is gay or traditional: there is danger involved in such behavior. As The Times has reported, sexually transmitted diseases are increasing among just about every segment of the population.

headline: Bold, Colorful and Detailed
text: Though he never achieved the fame of Grandma Moses, Ralph Fasanella, who died in 1997 at the age of 83, had a lot in common with her. He, too, was a self-taught, folk-primitive artist who created bold, colorful compositions loaded with minute detail.

headline: At N.Y.U., a Reason for Students to Feel Good About All That Trash
text: By the end of their academic careers, students in the dormitories at New York University acquire a lot of knowledge. They also acquire a lot of stuff.

headline: Letters: Biofuels for Jet Travel
text: To the Editor: The May 4 Green Traveler column (“Trying to Lighten that Carbon Footprint”) cites Friends of the Earth’s negative comments regarding Richard Branson’s biofueled flight and the drawbacks of producing biofuels for air travel. Friends of the Earth is considering only the current state of biofuel technology. Mr. Branson showed a successful “proof of concept” that might have boosted the confidence of consumers, industry, policy makers and investors and catalyzed more biofuel research. Evidence that biofuels work in a high-risk and unforgiving mode of transportation is a major step forward in powering them past the novelty stage.

headline: On The Q.t.: Paul Smith
text: Paul Smith calls London home, but he’s a designer without borders, finding inspiration for clothes and furniture around the globe. His latest project  a travel-themed store in Heathrow’s new Terminal 5  reinvents the airport gift shop. Between takeoffs, Smith took the T Travel Questionnaire.

text: Q Can a co-op shareholder install a satellite dish on the roof of the co-op?

headline: A Family Relic, Thoroughly Modern
text: THERE ought to be a word for it, this propensity to idolize your grandparents’ great style while, at least by omission, dismissing your parents’ style as a poor relation.

headline: Lacrosse Teams Form Bonds in Durham
text: The reverberations from the false accusations against members of the Duke lacrosse team more than two years ago are still felt throughout the campus and the community of Durham, N.C. Lawsuits linger, controversy simmers over Duke players’ being granted an extra season of eligibility, and players say they occasionally detect tension when they wear Duke lacrosse gear around town.

headline: Impressions of 3 Victims Offer Little on Killings
text: Neighbors knew little about the older couple and the younger man who moved into the quiet neighborhood in Tenafly, N.J., last year. Some remembered the older man fastidiously washing his car outside the white, two-story house. One believed the younger man might have owned a string of cellphone stores in Queens and New Jersey.

text: If not her, who?

headline: Aimee Torres, Alejandro Latorre
text: Aimee Elizabeth Torres and Alejandro Alfonso Latorre were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: The McCain Doctrines
text: Whatever their disagreements on policy, United States senators, even in today’s hyperpolitical climate, are reluctant to impugn one another’s motives or integrity.

headline: Fixing the Military
text: The United States’ military is the world’s best. It is also in need of substantial repair. Two wars  the war of necessity in Afghanistan and President Bush’s disastrous war of choice in Iraq  have worn out soldiers and equipment at an unprecedented rate. So alarming is the deterioration that many military commanders say the country is unable to sustain the current operation in Iraq let alone face down future threats.

text: Below are excerpts of e-mail messages to The Times and comments on The Fifth Down blog regarding last week’s news developments about the New England Patriots, who videotaped opponents’ signals; the N.F.L.’s investigation into the matter; Matt Walsh, who spent three seasons with the team’s videotaping operation; and a call for an independent inquiry from Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania.
