text: JONES BEACH

headline: Crash
text: “All is suffering,” say the Buddhists, but all is not tragic. Some is downright comical, as Caroline Adderson demonstrates in her second novel, “Sitting Practice,” in which a good man marries the love of his life and permanently disables her in a dumb automobile accident. His wry and sensible wife, now unable to walk, is game to wheel her way through life’s rich pageant, but self-blame paralyzes the husband and threatens the marriage. None of this should be amusing  except when it’s played out by Adderson’s surprising, generously realized characters.

headline: Traveling Salesman, Nash Pitches Belief in Knicks
text: The Mike D’Antoni Show is coming to New York this fall, with apologies to the Phoenix Suns.

headline: A Drink Puts on the Kid Gloves
text: HERE’S a drink for your inner child. It gets thirsty, too.

headline: Road Rules
text: Mao sneakers may be on every corner of Beijing, but the kitschiest bit of “Maomorabilia” has to be Madame Mao’s limousine. The bulletproof black stretch with red-velvet trim takes you on a 50-minute joy ride accompanied by a bottle of Moët & Chandon, a guide from the Red Detachment of Women and Mao’s voice crackling over the radio. $270; 011-86-10-8403-5308; redcapitalclub.com.cn.

headline: Battlefield Notes
text: James Meek’s fourth novel opens with a scene that seems stolen from a Tom Clancy thriller, albeit one with a sharply anti-American twist. While attacking an Iranian nuclear plant, American soldiers shoot hundreds of young women, one of whom catches the massacre on a video camera even as she is killed: “She recorded it all, under the harsh lights. The American soldiers screaming at each other. ... The moving of the trucks into the mass of schoolgirls. The screams as their bodies went under the wheels.”

headline: Heavy Metal, Light on the Success
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Mekhala Subramanian and James Attonito
text: Mekhala Subramanian, a daughter of Ananthi and Sethuraman Subramanian of Wake Forest, N.C., was married on Saturday evening to James Michael Attonito, the son of Kathleen and Joseph Attonito of East Quogue, N.Y. Pandit Umesh K. Jois, a Hindu priest, officiated at an Indian wedding ceremony at Loft Eleven in Manhattan.

headline: McCain Can Run, but Bush Won’t Hide
text: THE biggest gift President Bush has given his party this year was to keep his daughter’s wedding nearly as private as Connie Corleone’s. Now that his disapproval rating has reached the Nixon nadir of negativity, even a joyous familial ritual isn’t enough to make the country glad to see him. The G.O.P.’s best hope would be for both the president and Dick Cheney to lock themselves in a closet until the morning after Election Day.

headline: Parents Sue Over Equestrian’s Death, Raising Safety Issues
text: The parents of a 17-year-old girl who died in a fall while competing in the Olympic equestrian sport of eventing have sued the sport’s governing body, her former trainer and others in a California court, claiming that the death was caused in part because the course was made more dangerous to make it more “thrilling” to spectators.

headline: End in Sight for Bank Standoff
text: Northport

headline: Katherine Patterson and Michael Gilles
text: Katherine Meghan Patterson, the daughter of the Rev. Caroline Johnson Patterson of Cranston, R.I., and Dr. Robert Bruce Patterson of Warwick, R.I., is to be married on Sunday to Michael James Gilles, the son of Jane Susan Jung and David Joseph Gilles of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Dr. Leslie S. Simonson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Fearrington Village in Pittsboro, N.C.

headline: 36 Hours in Luang Prabang, Laos
text: THE Southeast Asia circuit  Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand  is thick with travelers encountering familiar faces at the next required stop. (If it’s Tuesday, it must be Ho Chi Minh’s Tomb.) The crowds are beginning to head to Laos as well  with both Vientiane and Luang Prabang emerging as the next potential hot spots for globe-trotting tourists. But the beguiling ancient capital of Luang Prabang, nestled between the Mekong and Nam Khan Rivers, is still a place that feels as if it is on the cusp of discovery. It is a town where one minute you are checking your e-mail messages at an Internet cafe next to giggling novices and the next you are walking on a bridge across the Nam Khan with views of farmers silently working in the lettuce fields with nary a tourist bus in sight.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the potential rise of biracial politics in the South referred incorrectly to a young man whom George Allen, a Republican senator seeking re-election in Virginia, called a “macaca,” widely considered to be a racial slur, during a campaign appearance in 2006. The young man, who was of Indian descent, was conducting opposition research for the Democrats; he was not heckling Mr. Allen.

headline: Foreign Intelligence
text: When in Rome, why not eat as the Romans (really) do? One of the surest ways to get off the tourist grid is to read local guidebooks. Never mind if you don’t speak their language  a handful of guides to Italy and France have symbols, numerical ratings and pictures that will steer you toward your next discovery. “Osterie d’Italia,” from Slow Food Italy, recommends restaurants, organized geographically, with a snail icon to indicate that they follow Slow Food principles. If you like nonna-in-the-cucina places, it’s worth the weight. Another Italian bible, “Ristoranti d’Italia del Gambero Rosso,” groups restaurants, trattorias and wine bars regionally. A numerical score is based on a 100-point scale, and a meter indicates value for your money. But the most important symbols are the forks (for restaurants) and shrimps (for wine bars): if you see a place with three, go. In France, “Carnet de Route Omnivore” is for anyone serious about 21st-century French cuisine. The annual book lists 200 experimental restaurants and highlights the best dish at each (under the heading “Le Plat qui Change Tout”). Accompanying recommendations of nearby hotels are a bonus. The same publisher also recently released “Carnet de Vigne Omnivore,” a guide to 200 small, artisanal vineyards, with handy regional maps. And for architecture, art and history lovers, there’s “Ouverts au Public: Le Guide du Patrimoine en France,” which provides visiting information, photos and maps for more than 2,500 state-protected monuments. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

headline: One Country’s Table Scraps, Another Country’s Meal
text: Grocery bills are rising through the roof. Food banks are running short of donations. And food shortages are causing sporadic riots in poor countries through the world.

headline: In Courtroom 102, Focus Is on Sex Offenses
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: President Bush Calls for More Oil Exploration at Home
text: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt  President Bush said Saturday that Saudi Arabia’s decision to boost oil production by 300,000 barrels a day is “something, but it doesn’t solve our problem,” and he called again on Congress to approve legislation allowing more oil exploration at home.

headline: Correction: Where Many Ended Their Search for Paradise
text: A correction on May 4 of an April 13 article about the Marquesas in the South Pacific described two of the points of the so-called Polynesian Triangle incorrectly. Neither Hawaii, a state, nor Easter Island, a Chilean territory, is a country. In addition, Tahiti is included in the triangle, though it is not one of its points.

headline: Correction: Cover Story: The King of Visceral Design
text: An article on April 27 about George Lois misidentified the creators of two advertising campaigns that his firm handled. Julian Koenig and Helmut Krone of Doyle Dane Bernbach created the “Think small” ads for Volkswagen, and John and Faith Hubley worked with Fletcher Richards, Calkins & Holden to produce the “I want my Maypo” ads; Mr. Lois did not create them.

headline: That Stegner Fellow
text: If you were choosing an all-star team of 20th-century American writers to represent the liberal mind  construed expansively, not in narrowly political terms  you might have Lionel Trilling batting cleanup, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. hitting eighth and so on. But you’d have to reserve a spot in the lineup for a non-Mormon graduate of the University of Utah (class of 1930) who spent some of his formative years in a tiny, windblown town in Saskatchewan, just across the border, a dry prairie region that couldn’t support the farmers who had been encouraged by the Canadian government to settle there.

headline: Journalism From the Bottom of the Boat
text: THE front-page articles out of Myanmar last Saturday and Sunday, a week after a cyclone hit the Irrawaddy Delta, told of horrible devastation and suffering  countless bodies floating face down in the river and canals, a landscape of toppled trees, flattened houses and bloated farm animals, and survivors without food, clean water or aid.

headline: The Buck Starts Here
text: With the dollar as anemic as last year’s Brazilian models, even the most fortified travelers are looking for new, less pocket-emptying summer playgrounds. So where to go next? CHARLES RUNNETTE

headline: ‘The Hakawati’
text: Listen. Allow me to be your god. Let me take you on a journey beyond imagining. Let me tell you a story.

headline: Correction: Classical Music
text: A classical listing in the Summer Festivals section last Sunday omitted one of the cities where the Oregon Bach Festival takes place. In addition to Portland, where the festival opens, it takes place in Eugene. Another classical listing misidentified the director of the new chamber version of William Bolcom’s opera “A Wedding,” to be performed at the Music Academy of the West. The director is Chas Rader-Shieber  not Marilyn Horne, director of the voice program at the academy, which is presenting the production.

headline: 30 Seconds With Penny Marshall
text: Jack Nicholson gets most of the attention, but the Bronx-born actress and director Penny Marshall is a regular at Los Angeles Lakers home games, too. Marshall, 64, who played Laverne DeFazio opposite Cindy Williams’s Shirley Feeney in the sitcom “Laverne & Shirley” from 1976 to 1983, has season tickets to the Lakers and the Clippers. Her seat at Staples Center is along the baseline, cater-corner to the visitors’ bench. During halftime of a playoff game against the Jazz, Marshall stood to stretch her legs and, while surveying the Utah bench, answered a few questions. KAREN CROUSE

headline: Despite H.I.V., Fighting to Maintain Health and a Positive Attitude
text: Patricia Clouden dresses in a whirl of color, from her bright African dress to her shiny green toenail polish. She is a grandmother of eight who gets noticed in her Harlem neighborhood and is not afraid to speak her mind.

headline: Removing, Little by Little, a History in Stone
text: SHARON

headline: What Are Friends For? Power and Pain
text: FOR adults, romances are variable, and friendship is the constant. Privileged Youth reverses the equation: Love affairs are constant, and it’s the friendships that vary.

headline: A Honda on a Diesel Diet
text: HONDA has spent decades establishing a reputation for fuel efficiency. But nothing in the company’s current lineup, including its Civic Hybrid, can match the mileage of the diesel Accord that I recently tested in and around New York City.

headline: Gaining Seats, Democrats Find Their House Ideologically Divided
text: While much of the Congressional political focus has been on the declining fortunes and numbers of House Republicans, House Democrats have their own problem: They are winning too many elections.

headline: Bag Man
text: The end of the world just inched a little nearer: an eBay seller has written a memoir. About handbags.

headline: Liquid Assets
text: India. The House of Hermès had declared it its theme of 2008, and silk scarves are vivid with raw pinks and fleshy mangoes, elephants harnessed to carriages and tigers rampant. The company’s resident “nose,” the man hired in 2003 to juice perfume sales, Monsieur Jean-Claude Ellena, is back in the south, in the state of Kerala  cut with canals, the Venice of the subcontinent, the world’s supermarket for spice  where he has been wrestling for some time with how to bottle the fantasy.

headline: Mommy’s Dearest
text: Let us begin by eradicating all suspicion: Julie Klam’s memoir of growing up a coddled daughter of Westchester County bears no sign of narrative inauthenticity. In “Please Excuse My Daughter,” there are no discernable lies masking dark hopes of literary recognition.

headline: A New Stamp on a Vast Space
text: THE historic American Bank Note building in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx is the kind of structure that inspires a second look.

headline: White Terrorists
text: In the middle of the Colfax, La., cemetery stands a 12-foot-high obelisk. It’s weathered now. But in its day it must have been a grand sight, towering over the rows of gravestones, its marble glinting in the Southern sun. The monument was built as a tribute to three local white men, “the heroes,” according to its inscription, “who fell in the Colfax riot fighting for white supremacy” on April 13, 1873  Easter Sunday. There is no mention of the estimated 81 black people who were murdered that day.

headline: Correction: Summer Movies
text: A listing in the Summer Movies section on May 4 misidentified the nationality of the Baekelands, whose family is chronicled in the film “Savage Grace.” They are American, not British. The listing also misstated the relationship between Tony Baekeland and the inventor of the plastic Bakelite. Mr. Baekeland is the great-grandson of the inventor, not his grandson.

headline: Diesel Is Showing Its Racy Side
text: Last week, Jacques Villeneuve, the 1997 Formula One champion, took his first major win in 11 years for the 1,000-kilometer race at Spa-Francorchamps in Belgium, but his mind was already on the next race in June.

headline: Houses Even Bigger, Scores Way Above Average
text: FOR the most part, the imposing Tudors and colonials look as if they had always been here. The only clue that some are no longer originals, dating back to the town’s first building boom in the 1920s, is the presence of large bins in their driveways, overflowing with plasterboard and worn plumbing fixtures.

headline: Katherine Lavin, Scott Phillips
text: Katherine Elizabeth Lavin, a daughter of Elizabeth H. Lavin and Thomas J. A. Lavin of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Scott Young Phillips, a son of Gwendolen M. Phillips and John D. Phillips Jr. of New York. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

headline: As Deaths Outpace Births, Cities Adjust
text: PITTSBURGH  This city has passed a grim demographic milestone: More people are dying here than are being born.

headline: Marisa Fort, Brandon Adams
text: Marisa Rose Fort, the daughter of Laurinda Spear and Bernardo Fort-Brescia of Miami, was married there on Saturday evening to Brandon George Adams, a son of Holly Bryan Adams of New Orleans and Wayne L. Adams of Pensacola, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Niblock performed the ceremony at Plymouth Congregational Church, where he is the senior pastor.

headline: The Almost Naked City
text: Burlesque, that fabled if slightly soiled fantasy realm whose heraldic totem was the twirling pasty and whose undisputed queen was Gypsy Rose Lee, has returned to New York, dripping with rhinestones and trailing clouds of glitter. Under the rubric neo-burlesque, a Depression-era genre whose hallmarks were smut with attitude, bargain-barn glamour, rock-bottom ticket prices and a proudly stuck-out tongue is reasserting itself, flourishing in unexpected corners around the city.

headline: The Computer Industry Comes With Built-In Term Limits
text: MATHEMATICIANS have long tried, and failed, to solve the Riemann Hypothesis, a stubbornly unyielding math problem. Good luck to whoever tries to figure it out. For the first correct proof, a $1 million prize will be awarded by the Clay Mathematics Institute.

headline: G.M.’s Dreadful Engines Gave Diesels a Bad Name
text: WHAT WERE THEY? 1978-85 General Motors full-size diesel sedans.

headline: Just Before Budget Vote, Fingers Are Crossed at School
text: BAND practice at the A. B. Davis Middle School in Mount Vernon takes place in a windowless fourth-floor classroom where students spread out to play their instruments, except on days when it rains. On those occasions, the seventh and eighth graders maneuver into the back of the room, avoiding the half-foot gaping hole in the ceiling.

headline: An Experiment in Endowments at Wesleyan
text: THE good news for students and their parents facing high tuition bills is that the student government at Wesleyan University voted last month to establish an endowment to reduce costs at the liberal arts university in Middletown.

headline: The Talk
text: last great / (last& gra\t&) / commonly used phrase signifying a place that has retained a rare quality, e.g., “I just had the most amazing journey in Namibia, one of Africa’s last great wildernesses.” An erstwhile cliché, it has taken on new significance as travelers become ever more aware of environmental and cultural fragility, as in, “Ladakh is the last great stronghold of Himalayan Buddhism  like an unfallen Tibet.”

headline: Prescription Med
text: Ah, Ischia,” a Neapolitan friend said wistfully when I told him I was headed to the “green island,” as it is known. “I spent every summer there as a kid. You know, those summers where three months last for years and years?” As soon as I made landfall on Capri’s earthier neighbor, 15 miles off the coast of Naples, I knew exactly what he meant. A hard-driving New Yorker, I’d wanted a vacation from a vacation  a simple summer weekend at the beach, without all the glitz and glamour found in most Italian seaside playgrounds.

headline: They’re All Connected
text: WHEN James Keating moved into the Beacon, a 10-tower residential conversion in Jersey City, in August, he found a cascade of e-mail messages circulating among the new residents. Some had questions about amenities, some wondered when construction projects would be completed and others just wanted to get to know their neighbors.

headline: Lauren Gold, Adam Block
text: Lauren Dara Gold, the daughter of Jill Vogel of Long Beach, N.Y., and Fredric Gold of Port Washington, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Adam Eric Block, a son of Rochelle Block and Michael Block, also of Port Washington. Cantor David Katz officiated in Southampton, N.Y.

headline: Chinese Flee Flood Threat From Quake
text: CHENGDU, China  Thousands of earthquake survivors fled tent camps and villages across the ravaged landscape of southwestern China on Saturday after the government warned that several lakes and rivers were getting dangerously close to overflowing because landslides have blocked water flow.

headline: Once Upon Many Times
text: If any work of fiction might be powerful enough to transcend the mountain of polemic, historical inquiry, policy analysis and reportage that stands between the Western reader and the Arab soul, it’s this wonder of a book  a book not about a jihadi but a hakawati (Arabic for storyteller). “Listen,” Rabih Alameddine invites. “Allow me to be your god. Let me take you on a journey beyond imagining. Let me tell you a story.”

headline: Foot Soldiers Can Use the Parkway Now, Too
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Chic by Accident
text: On most Sunday mornings, Emmanuel Picault, a tall, chain-smoking 39-year-old Frenchman, spends a few hours at the weekly Lagunilla flea market in Mexico City, sifting through piles of painted masks and brass candlesticks. Other days, he may call on a private collector in Lomas de Chapultepec, the leafy enclave of the city’s bourgeoisie.

headline: Chinese Soldiers Work to Restore a Winding Lifeline
text: BAIHUATAN, China  It is not a voyage for the faint of heart.

headline: Provence Profound
text: In 1860, two Canadians named James Bain (age 18) and John Campbell (20) made the quite peculiar decision to holiday in the northern wilderness. From Toronto they took the train to the end of the line, caught a steamer up to a town called Orillia, then started rowing. When they finally hit their destination, a giant freshwater lake named after an Ojibwa chief, the only signs of humanity were two wigwams on the beach. Bain and Campbell enjoyed sojourning in the wild and returned the following year, stopping at a tavern along the way. Shocked to find city folk in her establishment, the proprietor asked, “Yez’ll be preachers, then?”

headline: Truce Holds in Sadr City Amid Patrols by Iraqi Army
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi Army troops have encountered little resistance during operations near the fortified front line in Baghdad’s Sadr City district, the American military reported Saturday, signaling that a shaky truce with the cleric Moktada al-Sadr’s Shiite militia was holding.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: COMEDY

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Sports

headline: Ask for a Taco, Not for Lucinda
text: Lucinda Burritos + Tacos in downtown Jersey City is not your typical lunch truck; its logo features a retro pinup girl in short-shorts playing a ukulele.

headline: Correction: Memoirs of a Girl From the East Country (O.K., Queens)
text: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about Suze Rotolo’s memoir of her relationship with Bob Dylan carried an incorrect credit. The picture of Mr. Dylan in glasses being embraced by Ms. Rotolo was taken by Ted Russell, not by Don Hunstein.

headline: A Poisonous Love Affair
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Lost in the Big City
text: IT takes all kinds of people to turn a cold building of marble and brick, even a famous one, into a community.

headline: Alexis Bryan and Spencer Morgan
text: Alexis Bryan and Spencer Morgan were married on Saturday in at the Church of St. John the Divine in Houston. The Rev. Laurens A. Hall, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Philharmonic and the Man Who Got Away
text: TALK about stepping all over your own message.

headline: No Incidents: Race Is a Success
text: Baltimore

headline: When Your Child Has a Genetic Disorder
text: To the Editor:

headline: International Pressure on Myanmar Junta Is Building
text: YANGON, Myanmar  International pressure on the ruling military junta in Myanmar continued to grow over the weekend as a senior United Nations envoy was due to arrive in Yangon on Sunday to talk with government officials about what the United Nations has called a slow response to international aid offers after Cyclone Nargis.

headline: A Rock Star, Finally
text: I WAS born in the city of Sasebo in southern Japan right near a United States naval base. My father, who had been a soldier during World War II, had his own construction company there and some of my mother’s friends married Americans. So we had a lot of connections with American families.

headline: Inside the List
text: OH, DÉSIRÉE: Fifty-five years ago this week, the No. 1 book on the hardcover fiction list was one that is all but forgotten today: Annemarie Selinko’s lusty novel “Désirée.” Based on the life of Désirée Clary (1777-1860), a onetime fiancée of Napoleon Bonaparte, it was later turned into a film starring Marlon Brando as Napoleon. Here are all of the Times best sellers for May 17, 1953 — a group that includes (hard to believe) a best-of collection of Adlai Stevenson’s speeches:

headline: Notes From the Underground
text: Off a cobblestone street in Montparnasse, behind a small courtyard, down a poky alleyway, hides something called the Territory. Two juniper trees cling to the alley wall; a tin roof hangs over an entryway; and the only outward clue of habitation is a “Beware of Dog” sign that, oddly enough, is written in English. The Territory had been described to me variously as a youth hostel, an art studio, a submarine, a dreamscape and a favela  to which one could add, on first impression, a firetrap, a serial-killer lair and Willy Wonka’s chocolate factory.

headline: Parallel Misfortunes
text: Early on in “The Third Angel,” Alice Hoffman’s three-part tale of women falling for impossible men, a kindly doctor tells a woman whose fiancé is dying that “love has nothing to do with the here and now.” A London hotel clerk later expands on this maxim, reassuring a young girl that she did no wrong in abetting an ill-starred lovers’ reunion: “Love is ancient and mysterious and you can’t mess with it. If you do it just backfires and you meet with disaster. That’s a fact.”

headline: ‘Vertigo’: A Brilliant Tragedy
text: To the Editor:

headline: State Development Agency Buffeted by Slowing Economy and Internal Rifts
text: For more than a year, the state’s main economic development agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, has been in disarray, plagued by turf battles, poor management and the political collapse of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, business leaders and state officials say.

headline: A Theatrical Jigsaw Puzzle for All Ages
text: LAST August Mary Rose Lloyd was scouting for the New Victory Theater’s 2008-9 season at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, where she had previously uncovered shows like “Tapeire” and “Life Is Rhythm.” As director of programming, Ms. Lloyd spends half her life on the road and sees more than 250 shows a year, but she says she never knows where the next treasure might be waiting.

headline: India Landrigan, Ryan Bayley
text: Dr. India Fox Landrigan, the daughter of Judith Landrigan and Ward Landrigan of New York, was married on Saturday evening to Dr. Ryan Patrick Bayley, the son of Robin Bayley of Las Vegas and the late Patrick Bayley. Evelyn M. Daly, a probate judge in Farmington, Conn., officiated at a farm owned by the bride’s parents in South Kent, Conn.

headline: Industrial Conversions, Stuck in Gear
text: STONINGTON

headline: Seeking a Few Good Shepherds
text: Children everywhere love prizes and fuzzy animals, right? The North Dakota shepherding industry is counting on it.

headline: When the Hokey-Pokey Isn’t Enough
text: SHOULD you be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park on June 28, you may witness a once-in-a-lifetime site-specific performance. People dressed in strange costumes, wielding various props and accompanied by musicians, will enter Queens Theater in the Park, forming a vibrant, carnival-like parade.

headline: High School Ranks Have Been Infiltrated by Agents
text: A report last week that O. J. Mayo received thousands of dollars in extra benefits while in high school and during his one season at Southern California raised eyebrows but ultimately was not a shock to those in college basketball circles.

headline: Only Connect
text: Many affluent travelers used to consider a private villa and an after-hours museum tour the ultimate vacation  a way to seal oneself off from the world in a bubble of luxury. But as a cult of authenticity has taken hold among global nomads, the impulse to engage has replaced the desire to escape. And they want more than just superficial encounters with “the natives”; they want their culture unfiltered. What the locavore movement did for food  giving the heirloom tomato from down the road more cachet than an ounce of beluga  this new humanism has done for travel.

headline: ‘One or Two Murderers in Any Crowd’
text: To open one of Charles Simic’s collections of poetry  this is, incredibly, his 19th  is to enter with renewed delight an instantly familiar neighborhood. Delight may not be the first word you’d associate with his shabby rooming houses, seedy movie theaters, empty restaurants on lonely side streets, dusty stores about to go out of business, bare trees. But if the scenery comes out of Edward Hopper, complete with the aura of loneliness and of ordinary things made strange by odd slants of light, the people who live there are nothing like Hopper’s doughy American depressives. They’re characters from Eastern European folk tales or Kafka, boiling with energy, nicely poised between the comic and the sinister and prone to metamorphosis: an opera singer keeps “a monkey dressed in baby clothes,” a woman “turned into a black cat / and I ran after you on all fours.” Even Grandmother  and Simic’s poems are full of grandmothers  “knitted / With a ball of black yarn.” The fun  and Simic’s poetry is nothing if not amusing  comes from the way he puts together the whimsical, the earthy, the banal and the transcendent. There are a lot of chickens in his poems and a lot of angels, too.

headline: First W Hotel Opens in Europe
text: The first W Hotel in Europe (www.whotels.com) opened this month in Istanbul. The hotel, among the recently renovated Akaretler Row Houses, a group of historic structures built in the 1870s to house employees of the Dolmabahce Palace, blends the traditional Ottoman design of the row houses with the contemporary feel of the luxury hotel chain. The hotel, which opened May 6, has 134 guest rooms and suites, many with private gardens, terraces and cabanas. Amenities include WiFi and MP3 docking stations; a spa; and a Jean-Georges Vongerichten restaurant, Spice Market, specializing in Southeast Asian street food.

headline: Myanmar’s Children Face New Risks, Aid Groups Say
text: BANGKOK  While the death toll in Myanmar continues to climb, international aid agencies are warning of new threats to the most vulnerable survivors, children.

headline: Mets’ Gain Is Yet Another Yankees Loss
text: The Steinbrennerian overtones at Yankee Stadium pervaded the clubhouse, seeped through an adjacent interview room and trickled into the third-base dugout, where the Mets, not the Yankees, reside. It is the visiting team, for a change, reeling from internal friction and poor play, and whose manager has begun facing a daily barrage of questions about his job security. That man does not wear pinstripes, either, at least not anymore.

headline: As Menus Turn Green
text: Tender and fresh, early spring produce is starting to appear in the city’s Greenmarkets and on the menus of these restaurants near Union Square, home of its own famous Greenmarket.

headline: Sliding Down Memory’s Fire Pole
text: OF all the places where I’ve done my writing, none was more unusual than the office that had a fire pole. The year was 1987, and I had just left an editor’s job in New York to get back to my own writing and teaching.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article last Sunday about changes to the N.F.L.’s game operations manual referred incorrectly in some editions to the way operators of clocks and coach-to-quarterback radio systems were hired before the 2007 season. It was done then, as it is now, by the league  not by individual teams.

headline: Chick Crit
text: “Sex and the City,” the former HBO hit about four single women devoted to designer shoes and other forms of self-gratification, is about to be released as a feature film. But isn’t the film out of sync with the spirit of New York at a time when people are scaling back? But the top are not scaling back. That’s what we keep hearing, right? These girls are doing pretty well. My money and Charlotte’s money  that’s big law-firm money.

headline: Hope Amid the Plantains
text: DURING its heyday in the 1950s and ’60s, La Marqueta was a steaming, fragrant, noisy, tropical bazaar, sheltering 500 mostly Puerto Rican vendors in five buildings under the elevated Metro-North tracks on Park Avenue between East 111th and 116th Streets.

headline: Rough Spots Remain in Nascar’s Safety Road
text: CONCORD, N.C.  After slamming into the wall at about 185 miles an hour at Texas Motor Speedway in April, in a trajectory eerily similar to the wreck that killed Dale Earnhardt in 2001, the rookie Michael McDowell’s No. 00 Toyota barrel-rolled over and over down the track.

headline: After 24 Open Houses ...
text: ON a Wednesday evening nearly three weeks ago, Dawn and Barry Goldstein were surprisingly calm as they sat on their plush brown sofa chatting with a guest, while their son, Jordan, almost 3, fidgeted between them.

headline: The Hillary Lesson
text: Berkeley ’s Fourth Street is my town’s version of a strip mall: there is little you might need there, but much to want: hand-crafted Japanese paper; diaphanous Stevie Nicks-inspired frocks; wooden toys imported from Europe. One recent morning, as my 4-year-old daughter and I strolled to our favorite diner, she pointed to a bumper sticker plastered on a mailbox. A yellow, viraginous caricature of Hillary Clinton leered out from a black background. Big block letters proclaimed, “The wicked witch of the East is alive and living in New York.”

headline: Neighbors Puzzled by New Jersey Deaths
text: Neighbors knew little about the older couple and the younger man who moved into the quiet neighborhood in Tenafly, N.J., last year. One neighbor remembered the younger man tending to the garden outside the white two-story home. Another believed that the young man might have owned a string of cellphone stores in Queens and New Jersey.

headline: Salvation Army
text: Stroll into Cynthia’s Ristorante in downtown Paducah, Ky., on any given Friday night and you’ll likely find a gaggle of artists holding court at the end of the bar, their animated conversations fueled by Finlandia cosmopolitans and Chambord martinis. In the dimly lit dining room toward the back, locals tuck into twice-baked Montrachet goat-cheese soufflés or oak-grilled pork tenderloin wrapped in apple-wood-smoked bacon. The vibe is faintly reminiscent of Elaine’s on a Thursday night, which is a bit of a shock since this Southern town on the western tip of Kentucky is a long way from the Upper East Side.

headline: Under My Skin
text: Not very long ago I was in New York for a few weeks and decided to get a tattoo while I was there. It was a partly impulsive decision. I’d thought of doing it for years, but I think of doing all sorts of relatively exciting and ostensibly transgressive things and never do them, either because I am too lazy or too cowardly or because I come to my senses in time to stop myself.

headline: Lucius Battle, Diplomat and Official, Dies at 89
text: WASHINGTON  Lucius D. Battle, a career diplomat who was special assistant to Secretary of State Dean Acheson in the administration of President Harry S. Truman, led a reorganization of the State Department under President John F. Kennedy and later served as ambassador to Cairo, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 89.

headline: Obama and the Jews
text: Pssst. Have you heard? I have. I heard that Barack Obama once said there has to be “an end” to the Israeli “occupation” of the West Bank “that began in 1967.” Yikes!

headline: Correction: Evening Hours
text: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the guest shown with Senator John McCain at the Time magazine party on May 8. He is Jeff Bewkes, chief executive of Time Warner  not Richard Stengel, the magazine’s managing editor. The column also misstated the given name of the guest shown with Eva Mendes at the Metropolitan Museum party on May 5. He is Francisco Costa, not Francesco.

headline: Soccer as N.B.A. Building Block
text: LOS ANGELES  The Phoenix Suns had just finished a practice earlier this season when Steve Nash, Boris Diaw, Leandro Barbosa and Grant Hill joined a man in jeans and a T-shirt who had arrived carrying a soccer ball. They formed a small circle and with their feet, thighs, chests and foreheads took turns juggling the ball. Each took more than a few touches, some to control the ball, others to show off tricks learned long ago. Then the ball was flicked to someone else in the circle. Rarely did it touch the court.

headline: Train-Hopping Traveler’s Life, Captured on Film
text: For nearly as long as rail lines have crisscrossed the country, there have been stories about wanderers covertly climbing aboard train cars and riding away from problems or speeding toward some glimmering promise on the horizon.

headline: Taste of Italy, Feel of Manhattan
text: WITH its recent face-lift, downtown White Plains is behaving more and more like that other, better known metropolis to its south. And sure enough, in the white-hot dining scene that has erupted here in recent months, Antipasti has some of the gait and polish of a dressy Midtown Manhattan restaurant.

headline: World’s Poor Pay Price as Crop Research Is Cut
text: LOS BAÑOS, Philippines  The brown plant hopper, an insect no bigger than a gnat, is multiplying by the billions and chewing through rice paddies in East Asia, threatening the diets of many poor people.

headline: So You Think Gas Costs a Lot?
text: INCREASING its longstanding appeal to mileage-conscious drivers, diesel fuel has for years cost less than gasoline, and even as recently as last summer the two were no worse than equal in price. Since then, a gallon of diesel has become more expensive than unleaded regular  now 16 percent more and poised to go higher still.

headline: Designers at Cervantes’s Door in Madrid
text: THE Spanish adjective castizo describes something that is quintessentially Castilian and, as far as neighborhoods in Madrid go, few are more castizo than the Barrio de las Letras. Climbing the hill opposite the Prado museum, this district of narrow lanes, brick houses and elaborate ironwork balconies was named after Spain’s men of letters, literary lions from the 17th century like Miguel de Cervantes and Lope de Vega.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: NIXONLAND: The Rise of a President and the Fracturing of America, by Rick Perlstein. (Scribner, $37.50.) Perlstein’s sprawling, compulsively readable study holds that Nixon’s divisive and enduring legacy is the “notion that there are two kinds of Americans.”

headline: U.S. Rowers in Princeton Have Sights on Beijing
text: WEST WINDSOR

headline: The Long Shadow
text: Strange to think that Sean Wilentz, a professor of history at Princeton University, would embrace Ronald Reagan as the historic alpha dog of postmodern American politics. For starters, Wilentz was trained as a Jacksonian-era scholar; the 20th and 21st centuries aren’t his bailiwicks. Then, back in 1998, Wilentz testified before the House Judiciary Committee that the impeachment of Bill Clinton was an abomination. He also endorsed Al Gore in 2000 and Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2008. Considered by some the heir apparent to Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Wilentz is perceived more as an erudite spokesman for the Democratic Party than as a judicious analyst of the Republican agenda. Yet in “The Age of Reagan”  a smart and accessible overview of the long shadow cast by our 40th president  Wilentz largely abandons partisanship in favor of professionalism. Thus, the supposedly inflexible Reagan emerges here as the pragmatic statesman who greatly reduced the world’s nuclear stockpiles.

headline: The Return of the One-Man Band
text: On a rainy afternoon this past December, in his cramped rehearsal studio on Toronto’s southwest side, Owen Pallett  known to his fans as the singer, songwriter, violinist, pianist, bassist, harpsichordist, engineer and everything else that makes up the indie-rock one-man band Final Fantasy  was trying to play his violin through five amplifiers at once. Effects pedals, instrument cables, patch cords and microphone stands took up most of the space, radiating out from the laptop and sound card that Pallett was fussing over, and an ominous hum filled the room. The amps were arranged in a loose semicircle, vaguely reminiscent of Stonehenge: Pallett spent the day before writing a computer program to coordinate the various outputs, and the impression he made now was less that of an up-and-coming rock star than of a crackpot inventor, à la Nikola Tesla, sequestered in his workshop. “Oh! This is exciting,” he whispered at one point, giggling to himself nerdishly. “I’ve never made it this far before.”

headline: Lists of Candidates Running for the Board
text: Q Is there any legal requirement for a co-op in New York to publish a good-faith list of names of people running for the board before the annual meeting? In past years, only a partial list of people who had informed the managing agent they were interested in running was published before the meeting. It seems as though the ones who were published were either a spouse or partner of a current board member; those not published did not have such connections.

headline: Celebrating an Aristocrat
text: WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR. and his wife, Pat, entertained guests  from heads of state to wide-eyed college students  at perhaps a thousand dinner parties over many decades at their maisonette apartment at 778 Park Avenue at East 73rd Street.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 103 Akron
text: Location: Akron, Ohio

headline: The Food and Energy Research Gaps
text: Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin have a sobering story in The Times showing declines in funding for agricultural development assistance and basic research even as the world’s poorest regions face spiking prices and shortages of basic foods.

headline: Live From New York, It’s John McCain
text: Senator John McCain chased after the youth vote in two cameo appearances on Saturday Night Live by joking about his age – he is 71 – and sparing viewers the sound of him crooning a medley of Barbra Streisand songs, as he did when he hosted the comedy show in 2002.

headline: A Veteran of the Swimsuit Wars of 1974 on the Swimsuit Wars of 2008
text: The Olympic champion posed in the revolutionary swimsuit for a full-page ad that appeared in Swimming World magazine. In the copy accompanying the photograph, the swimmer rhapsodizes about the suit’s “minimum water resistance and full body freedom” and how it “moves with you like a second skin.”

headline: Op-Classic, 1996: Gay Marriage, and Beyond
text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Mosley and MI5
text: In the paddock in Turkey journalists were exchanging information about an alleged MI5 involvement in the Mosley sex scandal. One well-informed journalist pointed out that MI5 itself has much more important matters to tend to than trying to help Max Mosley destroy himself. Others said that talk of MI5 made the whole thing look like paranoia was reaching a high at the FIA. It turned out, however, that there were some grounds to this talk, as a story on the Mosley/MI5 affair in The Sunday Times today notes. One of the prostitutes that cavorted with Mosley was the wife of an MI5 officer.

headline: The Week Ahead: May 18-24
text: Film

headline: ‘Squeak By’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: ‘Speed Racer’s’ a Flop …

headline: Live From New York, It’s John McCain

headline: What in God’s Name is That? Part 3 – Hong Kong Noodle Shop
text: Here’s part three of the series on how to order cheap, local Hong Kong food even if you can’t read all those confusing Chinese characters and don’t have a local’s innate ability to identify strange-looking ingredients. As I explained earlier, small traditional shops usually only serve one type of dish, as evidenced in What in God’s Name is That? Part 2: The Roast Meat Shop. Here’s a guide to places that just do wontons, dumplings, noodles and soup.

text: A look at some of Kelli O’Hara’s stage performances.

text: Nicholas D. Kristof observes the way of life of Tibetans in Qinghai and Gansu Provinces of China.

headline: Great Horse?
text: BALTIMORE — It’s hard to find fault in Big Brown’s performance here in the Preakness. He was barely asked to run by the jockey Kent Desormeaux and buried an overmatched field.

headline: Lists of Candidates Running for the Board
text: Is there any legal requirement for a co-op in New York to publish a good-faith list of names of people running for the board before the annual meeting? In past years, only a partial list of people who had informed the managing agent they were interested in running was published before the meeting. It seems as though the ones who were published were either a spouse or partner of a current board member; those not published did not have such connections.

headline: A Satellite Dish on the Roof
text: Can a co-op shareholder install a satellite dish on the roof of the co-op?

text: There are many takes on Big Brown’s victory in the Preakness — here are a few.

text: A family lives and works in an eccentric space that overlooks the lighting fixture stores that dominate a section of the Bowery.

headline: Turkey without tobacco?

headline: Dutrow Sizes Up Casino Drive
text: Big Brown walked the shedrow this morning with the assistant trainer Michelle Nevin. He appears to be fine after his win Saturday in the Preakness. He will ship by van at 10 a.m. Monday to Belmont Park. He will be stabled in the barn of Bobby Frankel. Rick Dutrow’s main New York stable is at Aqueduct.

headline: Early Voting Shows Modest Rise in Oregon and Kentucky
text: Early voting in Kentucky and Oregon, which hold primaries on Tuesday, is up compared to previous years. However, the enthusiasm seems less extreme than it has been in other states, as the Democratic primary season appears to be coming to a close.

headline: The Hunt: May 18, 2008
text: A couple was drawn to Astoria, but irked by its unfriendliness to dogs.

headline: Shrinking Aid, Soaring Prices
text: Spending on agricultural projects in developing nations has declined sharply, hampering the ability to feed the poor as prices rise.

headline: Chugging Along
text: Diesel engines were once a curiosity, but have attracted a dedicated following.

headline: Coming Soon: New Diesels
text: Four foreign manufacturers will bring highly efficient diesel models to market in the United States.

headline: Living in Scarsdale, N.Y.
text: Gut renovations are a common sight in Scarsdale, N.Y., a small town that draws in families with its highly regarded public schools and proximity to Manhattan.

headline: Career Wisdom From Broadway
text: I was speaking with another journalist Katherine Lanpher, about the frenzied pace of our freelance lives. She was in the midst of an especially busy stretch of work, planning a trip to Paris and the Loire Valley for two magazine articles while also preparing for her “Upstairs at the Square” live interview series at Barnes and Noble by furiously reading literature and listening to music. While we were both overwhelmed by deadlines, I couldn’t help noticing that she was consuming art, fine food and wine, whereas my workplace intensity meant I hadn’t been to a museum or seen a new film in months.

headline: Surprise! Microsoft Proposes New Deal to Yahoo
text: Microsoft has proposed a complex new deal with Yahoo that would involve collaboration between their online advertising businesses but would not involve a full takeover, Microsoft said on Sunday.

headline: Obama Draws Record Crowd in Oregon
text: An estimated 75,000 gathered on the banks of the Willamette River in Portland on Sunday to see Barack Obama.

headline: Slightly Smaller Preakness Audience
text: After setting attendance records in 2006 and 2007, the Preakness saw a 7.5 percent decline this year, with 112,222 in attendance, compared with 121,263 last year. This year’s crowd was still the fifth largest ever.

headline: Big Brown Dominates Preakness
text: Big Brown, ridden by Kent Desormeaux, soared to a five-and-a-quarter-length victory in the 133rd running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Upfronts: Judging The Crowd Reactions
text: Are any of the new shows unveiled at the upfronts going to be hits? The CBS comedy “Worst Week” provoked enthusiastic laughter in Carnegie Hall and the Fox drama “Fringe” found instant support from the crowd at City Center, Bill Carter reports. “Neither ABC nor NBC was able to ignite talk about coming series,” he adds. Read more…

headline: Frugal Traveler: Toronto
text: The Frugal Traveler spends a weekend in Canada's most expensive city on $500.

headline: The Friends of ‘Gossip Girl’
text: In Sunday’s New York Times, Alessandra Stanley writes about the relationships on shows like “Gossip Girl,” a “semisatirical portrait of power and privilege in the private schools and penthouses of New York’s ultra rich.” Its first season finale will be shown on Monday.

headline: ‘NewsHour’ Money Woes Reflect Broader Challenge For PBS
text: In its 25 years on the air, “The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer” on PBS “has had fallow budget periods, but none that equal the current one,” Elizabeth Jensen reports in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: On ‘Idol, ‘Good Singers Make For A Dull Season
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Strategy Sessions
text: At a struggling school in Newark, students and staff gear up for an annual test.

headline: Property site names Brazil, U.S. and Canada top investment spots
text: OK, here’s another one of those lists. This one, issued by Propertyshowrooms.com, the real estate investment site, aspires to identify “the most outstanding property hotspots across the world, in terms of investment returns on real estate.”

headline: Victory, and Tension, for Tyson Gay
text: CARSON, Calif. – As the Olympics approach, Tyson Gay, the world champion at 100 and 200 meters, is being projected as the new, unblemished face of American track and field, a sport ravaged by performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: The True Story of a Script, Big Dreams and Vanishing Private Equity
text: LOS ANGELES  Last September, when Sanjay Sanghoee set about turning his first novel into a Hollywood movie, the budding filmmaker had his pick of investors.

headline: U.S. General Apologizes for Desecration of Koran
text: BAGHDAD  The commander of United States troops in Baghdad asked local leaders and tribal sheiks this weekend for their forgiveness after the discovery that a soldier had used a Koran for target practice at a shooting range.

headline: Bats in This Museum Don’t Have Wings
text: Editors’ Note: Because of the Memorial Day holiday, In Advertising will arrive next week on Tues., May 27.

headline: Inspirations by Neruda, the Minutiae in Mahler
text: Peter Lieberson’s “Neruda Songs” puts its trust in the staying power of five consecutive slow movements, in this case five vocal settings of Pablo Neruda’s sonnets. With impregnable dignity and great variety, Haydn succeeded at much the same challenge in his “Seven Last Words of Christ.”

headline: Artists Absorb Israel’s Six Decades, and Move On
text: JERUSALEM  At first glance it seems a straightforward if animated photograph of Israeli soldiers in a mess hall: uniformed young men chatting, pouring, laughing, smoking at a set of utilitarian tables bearing metal bowls and nondescript food. But it doesn’t take long to sense that the scene is spiritually and sexually charged. The men are a little too handsome and draped a little too casually over one another, and their group pose is a little too evocative of a certain iconic meal.

headline: Online Search Ads Faring Better Than Expensive Displays
text: In the past few years, Web publishers have made a big bet on booming online advertising revenues. But the economic slowdown may be throwing a wrench into those plans.

headline: Dancing the Night Away, With a Higher Purpose
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  In their floor-length gowns, up-dos and tiaras, the 70 or so young women swept past two harpists and into a gilt-and-brocade dining room at the lavish Broadmoor Hotel, on the arms of their much older male companions.

headline: After Forays With ABC and HBO, a Video Blogger Returns to Video Blogging
text: “It’s weird,” Amanda Congdon says, looking off-camera, eyeing her own image reflected on the computer screen in her Los Angeles apartment. “It’s just weird when you come back.”

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Senator Barack Obama’s response to remarks by President Bush in which the president likened those who call for talks with “terrorists and radicals” to those who appeased the Nazis referred incompletely to Mr. Obama’s stance on the circumstances under which he and his administration would negotiate with Iran.

headline: Weekend in Bronx Revives Mets
text: The Mets came to Yankee Stadium this weekend with a manager under pressure and tension in the clubhouse. The Yankees could have looked at those problems with a rueful smile.

headline: Arrest in Slaying of Shopkeeper
text: A 22-year-old man was arrested Sunday and charged with killing a shopkeeper who was found dead in her dry cleaning store in Brooklyn last week, the police said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Border Crossings Into Realms of Film and Movement
text: When Yoshiko Chuma, one of the most eccentric dance artists in New York, takes hold of a subject, she generally holds on for dear life. (This is not a criticism.) Using Teinosuke Kinugasa’s 1926 silent film “A Page of Madness” as a guiding spirit, she presents the latest production in her dance-installation series.

headline: Girl Is Killed in Queens as Shots Scatter Dancers
text: The teenagers were dancing before the squat backdrop of a housing project Saturday night in Far Rockaway, Queens, when the gunfire began. They all ran, until someone turned and saw that one girl was not running. She had dropped to the ground without a sound, a bullet hole in her temple.

headline: Trinity’s 41st Straight Victory Sets Record
text: Trinity College set a Division III record with its 41st consecutive victory, beating Southern Maine, 10-3, in a regional title game in Harwich, Mass. Trinity advanced to the national championship tournament next weekend. (NYT)

headline: Posada Tests His Legs but Says He Worries More About His Arm
text: It has been more than three weeks since Jorge Posada played for the Yankees. He is on the disabled list with rotator cuff inflammation, and on Sunday he caught Ian Kennedy in the bullpen to get his legs reaccustomed to the feel of his demanding position.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Monday about the corruption trial in Chicago of the political fund-raiser Antoin Rezko misstated the age of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois, whose administration has been tied repeatedly to Mr. Rezko during testimony in the trial. Governor Blagojevich is 51, not 57.

headline: In a Running Family, Someone Had to Be First
text: KIPSIRWO, Kenya  Each morning around 5, the girl felt her parents shaking her awake.

headline: Koreans Agog as Off-Screen Soap Becomes Courtroom Drama
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The scandal had all the makings of a tabloid blockbuster: a soap opera actor accused his wife, another popular television star, of infidelity with his close friend and an Italian chef who was giving her private cooking lessons.

headline: James Recalls a Shot Not Taken
text: Boston

headline: Uninvited Attachés
text: To the Editor:

headline: New CDs
text: BUN B “II Trill” (Rap-a-Lot)

headline: A Shift in Voters, but Oregon Still Embraces the Unconventional
text: HOOD RIVER, Ore.  The Obama ’08 signs end roughly where the orchards begin. Another reinvented Western town gives way to another valley of calloused hands. Telecommuting gives way to irrigation. New gives way to old.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Friday with coverage of the Nationals’ 1-0 victory over the Mets misidentified, in some copies, the Washington player shown diving for a catch. It was Willie Harris, not his teammate Rob Mackowiak.

headline: McCain Exceptionalism
text: Last Tuesday, Republicans lost another Congressional seat in a special election  their third such defeat in two months. On Wednesday I received an acerbic e-mail message from a disgusted young G.O.P. loyalist: “I just have to say that Republicans are a dumb party that chooses stupid candidates. With the exception of McCain.” Who says the young lack wisdom? In fact, Republican hopes of denying Democrats complete control of the federal government for the next couple of years may rest on the promise of “McCain exceptionalism.”

headline: Irving Rosenthal, 95, Mentor to Journalists, Dies
text: Irving Rosenthal, who taught journalism at the City College of New York for 40 years and seeded the newsrooms and broadcast studios of America with thousands of journeymen reporters and editors and a few of the nation’s most prominent journalists, died Sunday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 95.

headline: McCain to Rely on Party Money Against Obama
text: Pivoting toward the general election, Senator Barack Obama is turning again to his history-making fund-raising machine, which helped to anoint him as a contender against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and then became a potent weapon in their battle for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Finding, and Refining, a Spiritual Calling
text: Angie Hummel craned her neck and beheld a glass-sheathed Upper West Side tower where luxurious studios sell for more than a million dollars. She shifted her gaze ever so slightly downward to the brick building where Mexican immigrant families cram four people into a single room barely big enough for a bed.

headline: Memory Transfigured by Spontaneity
text: LONDON  In “Dances at a Gathering,” Jerome Robbins made a classic of dance and theater, a work that irresistibly invited multiple interpretations that Robbins both planted and discouraged. At New York City Ballet, the company for which he made it in 1969, “Dances” has been performed with a kind of quiet understatement that during the last decade and a half has dimmed the ballet into near-dullness. The Royal Ballet at Covent Garden, by contrast, had not danced it for 32 years  until Saturday.

headline: For Women, Memories of West 78th and Beyond
text: As a young girl growing up on the Upper West Side in the early 1950s, Laurie Burrows Grad, the daughter of the playwright Abe Burrows, had every intention of becoming a Girl Scout until her mother put an end to it. “She let me be a Brownie, but then she found out that the Girl Scouts were segregated, and she couldn’t tolerate that,” Ms. Burrows Grad, a glass of wine in her hand, explained to a roomful of women last week. “But she didn’t think I’d understand that idea at that age. So she just told me that green wasn’t my color.”

headline: Democracy and the Web
text: Users of the Internet take for granted their ability to access all Web sites on an equal basis. That could change, however, if Internet service providers started discriminating among content, to make more money or to suppress ideas they do not like. A new “net neutrality” bill has been introduced in the House, which would prohibit this sort of content discrimination. Congress has delayed on this important issue too long and should pass net neutrality legislation now.

headline: Corrections
text: A film column on Friday about the Cannes festival misidentified the company that will distribute “Blindness,” a film shown at Cannes, in the United States. It is Miramax, not Focus Features. (Focus Features International is distributing the film in other countries.)

headline: Music in Review
text: MOSCOW VIRTUOSI

headline: Gender Issue Lives On as Clinton’s Bid Wanes
text: With each passing day, it seems a little less likely that the next president of the United States will wear a skirt  or a cheerful, no-nonsense pantsuit.

headline: Banks’ Terms Imperil Deal to Buy Out Bell Canada
text: The $51.8 billion takeover of Bell Canada, the largest leveraged buyout ever proposed, appeared to be in trouble over the weekend as the Wall Street banks that committed to finance the deal sought to renegotiate the lending terms, people on both sides of the transaction said on Sunday.

headline: The Mystery Art Buyer
text: Who bought the 1976 Francis Bacon painting “Triptych” for $86.3 million and the 1995 Lucian Freud painting “Benefits Supervisor Sleeping” for $33.6 million last week at, respectively, Sotheby’s and Christie's in New York? The 41-year-old London-based Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, The Art Newspaper reported on its Web site (theartnewspaper.com). The Bacon became the most expensive work of contemporary art ever sold at auction, and the Freud was said to be the most expensive work by a living artist. The Art Newspaper said that Mr. Abramovich apparently intended to display both works in his home. His fortune, from oil and gas, is estimated at more than $22 billion.

headline: Ochoa Holds Off the Field to Win Her Third Straight Sybase Classic
text: CLIFTON, N.J.  Lorena Ochoa played out the drama Sunday to the last shot. And just when it seemed her game might have deserted her, she did what she had to do to win the Sybase Classic by a stroke.

headline: After Rare Restart, Lagat Wins the 1,500
text: CARSON, Calif.  Running his first metric mile of the outdoor season on Sunday, the world champion Bernard Lagat steered clear of trouble at the start of the 1,500 meters, which more closely resembled a Nascar race than a footrace.

headline: ‘Prince Caspian’ Rules at the Box Office
text: Starring Ben Barnes, far right, the film fantasy “The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian” (Disney) generated an estimated $56.5 million in weekend box-office revenue in its debut, ousting the superhero adventure “Iron Man” from the top of the rankings. In its third week “Iron Man” (Paramount) grossed $31.2 million to take second place and bring its total to $222.4 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. The romantic comedy “What Happens in Vegas” (Fox) attracted $13.8 million in its second week, and the disappointing “Speed Racer” (Warner Brothers), also in its second week, occupied fourth place with $7.6 million. Fifth place went to the comedy “Baby Mama” (Universal) on a gross of $4.5 million in its fourth week.

headline: Geeks Crash a House of Fashion
text: Of all the dot-com publishing franchises, Wired seemed the most likely to end up as road kill on a superhighway it helped create.

headline: Investment in Clean Energy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mrs. McCain’s Money
text: Senator John McCain’s wife, Cindy McCain, has decided not to release her tax returns  not now and not in the future. In the interest of transparency and to support her husband’s frequent calls for clean and open government, she should rethink that decision.

headline: HSBC to Buy Majority of Indian Firm
text: HSBC Holdings, the British banking company, said it planned to buy 73.2 percent of IL&FS Investsmart, an Indian brokerage firm, for 10.03 billion rupees ($235 million).

headline: Bush’s Speech Prods Middle East Leaders
text: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt   After basking in a showy celebration of America’s close ties with Israel, President Bush criticized other Middle East leaders on Sunday, prodding them to expand their economies, offer equal opportunity to women and embrace democracy if they want peace to become reality.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Tim Andree, chief executive at Dentsu America, New York, part of Dentsu, is being nominated as an executive officer at Dentsu. The appointment would make Mr. Andree the first non-Japanese to be named an executive officer at Dentsu.

headline: Urban Baby’s Lesson: Don’t Mess With Mom’s Chat
text: How devoted are fans of the Urban Baby Web site?

headline: A Regulatory Agency in Need
text: Prodded by Congress, the Food and Drug Administration has finally acknowledged that it needs a lot more money than the Bush administration has been willing to give it to protect the public from unsafe drug and food imports and other dangerous products.

headline: Arthur W. Burks, 92, Dies; Early Computer Theorist
text: Arthur W. Burks, a member of the team that designed the Eniac computer, a frequent collaborator of John von Neumann and a pioneer in computing education, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 92.

headline: For This Year, Emmy Drama Is Over Money
text: If the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences bestowed an Emmy Award for best behind-the-scenes drama, it might find itself a winner this year.

headline: In Hospitals, Simple Reminders Reduce Deadly Infections
text: Loose strands of sweaty dark hair fell across the woman’s face, but she was too sick to push them back. She was in respiratory failure, and nurses were rushing her to intensive care. They grabbed a sheet under her body and heaved her from the gurney onto a bed as if she were a fish in a net, then attached her to a beeping monitor, hand-pumped oxygen into her lungs and got ready to administer an intravenous sedative.

headline: Pierce Wins Duel; Celtics Take Series
text: BOSTON  Paul Pierce and LeBron James chased each other, harassed each other, traded hip-checks and jump shots and admiring glances for a long, glorious afternoon, while historic comparisons flew and the balance of power in the Eastern Conference shifted hard toward the Northeast.

headline: Queens Senator May Lose Party Support
text: State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat, may find himself in the unusual position of losing the support of the Democratic organization in his borough in his bid for re-election, with leaders of the party likely to back City Councilman Hiram Monserrate instead.

headline: Does ‘Do the Right Drugs’ Give Readers the Wrong Idea?
text: Yes, its name is a double entendre, referring both to technology and to being high. But does Wired magazine really mean to promote drugs?

headline: What Would You Pick if You Could Have Just One Wish?
text: Playing a solitary round on a quiet weekday evening at my home course, I searched for an errant shot in the woods and came upon a stray golf ball.

headline: Send in the Latrines
text: London

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about Senator John McCain’s proposals to combat global warming referred incorrectly to the Washington-based Center for American Progress, whose top official noted that Mr. McCain sometimes voted with Democrats on environmental bills. Although the Center for American Progress often supports policies espoused by the Democratic Party, it is not “a Democratic policy shop” or officially affiliated with the party.

headline: They Had Faces Then, in Silent Movies, and Feet, Too
text: Craft is an underrated virtue. But it’s the resounding element of Susan Stroman’s “Double Feature,” which had its first performance of the New York City Ballet’s spring season at the New York State Theater on Friday night. “The Blue Necklace” and “Makin’ Whoopee”  the two independent ballets, both channeling silent movies  are so beautifully made, so funny, ingenious and charming, that it’s easy to overlook choreography that is often thin and simply serviceable.

headline: 2 Weeks After Cyclone, Burmese Leader Pays First Visit to Refugees
text: YANGON, Myanmar  The leader of Myanmar’s ruling junta, for the first time, on Sunday visited victims of the cyclone that destroyed wide swaths of this country, two weeks after the storm killed at least 78,000 people and left hundreds of thousands homeless.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 11 Near a Pakistani Army Base
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber killed 11 people and wounded 22 at a market close to an army base in the North-West Frontier Province on Sunday, local officials said, just days before the government was expected to complete a peace deal with Taliban militants.

headline: Offenders Return to Society, but Under Her Watchful Eye
text: DICKINSON, N.D.

headline: Fatherly Advice Helps Canó Keep Swinging
text: Robinson Canó dutifully calls his father, José, in the Dominican Republic after almost every game he plays with the Yankees. Sometimes, if it is too late, Canó waits and calls the next morning. The calls are familial, therapeutic and consistent.

headline: An Orchestra’s Woes
text: The financially stricken Columbus Symphony Orchestra has suffered another blow. The grants committee of the Greater Columbus Arts Council, which gave the ensemble $261,417 last year, recommended last week that no more money be given to the orchestra, The Columbus Dispatch reported. The full board of the council will decide the matter on May 27, said a spokeswoman, Emily Swartzlander. Bryan W. Knicely, president of the council, said, “We shouldn’t be giving operational support to an organization that’s not going to be here after June 1.” The orchestra, which had a budget of $13.5 million this season, canceled its outdoor summer concerts, and its board chairman, Buzz Trafford, said it would “be out of money at the end of the month,” adding, “It is likely the C.S.O. will suspend operations effective June 1, 2008.”

headline: Remembering Fleming, Ian Fleming
text: LONDON  Any writer who has struggled to “do the words” would take heart from the self-effacing assessment written for himself by Ian Fleming, the raffish Englishman born 100 years ago this month who became one of the most successful authors of his time through the creation of the world’s best-loved spy, James Bond.

headline: Signs Fossella May Run Again Unnerve G.O.P.
text: There has been nothing but silence coming from the embattled Staten Island congressman, Vito J. Fossella, regarding his plans to run for re-election this year. And that uncertainty has caused waves of concern not only among Republicans in New York City, but in Washington as well.

headline: Playing It Safe in Sun
text: At the L.P.G.A. Tour event that ended Sunday in New Jersey, dermatologists were on hand for free skin-cancer screenings. And for much of the tournament, sun safety remained a frequent topic of conversation among players, especially after doctors examined one of the player caddies and detected what they believed to be a serious skin disorder.

headline: Arrest Could Yield Suspect in Fatal Stabbings
text: A 32-year-old man who was arrested in Los Angeles early on Sunday may be connected to the stabbing deaths of three people found inside a home in Tenafly, N.J., law enforcement officials said.

headline: Cause of Kennedy’s Seizure Is Unclear
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy remained hospitalized in Boston on Sunday, with doctors still uncertain about the cause of a seizure that gripped him on Saturday at his Cape Cod home.

headline: Elite Athletes Fill Prosecution’s Witness List in Trial of Track Coach
text: The track coach Trevor Graham sent a dozen athletes to the Olympics in 2000, when Sprint Capitol USA, his private training camp in Raleigh, N.C., dominated the sport. The most famous, Marion Jones, won five medals. In the following years, two of Graham’s most explosive athletes, Tim Montgomery and Justin Gatlin, set world records in the 100 meters.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills Tuesday.

headline: Obama Draws Huge Crowd in Oregon as Clinton Courts Kentucky
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Senator Barack Obama drew the largest crowd of his campaign so far on Sunday, addressing an estimated 75,000 people who had gathered here on the banks of the Willamette River.

headline: A Pop Formula: The Younger They Are, the Louder the Screams
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Saturday night, for approximately two and a half hours in the middle of Zootopia 2008, several thousand young girls were held hostage at the Izod Center here. They had come to scream for the Jonas Brothers, the preppy New Jersey sibling heartthrobs who opened the show, and for Miley Cyrus, the teen queen who closed it. That there were eight acts in between was a sort of cruel punishment.

headline: Celebrating Undefinable Songwriting
text: “I’m so unfinished,” Arthur Russell sang in the 1982 song “A Little Lost,” and though it goes on to rhyme with “diminished” and take the form of a lover’s plea for a second chance, that line, alone, remains important.

headline: You Can Do the Math, but Sometimes It Pays to Trust Instinct
text: The three-session World Bridge Production Pairs ran concurrently with the five-session Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Henderson, Nev., a week ago.

headline: Reality Rudely Intrudes in the Screening Rooms
text: Toward the end of Brillante Mendoza’s “Serbis,” the patrons of a dilapidated Manila adult-movie palace are surprised to discover that a goat has wandered in from the street, partly obstructing their view of the naked bodies on screen. The animal’s sudden appearance  which sets off one of several chaotic, hilarious chases in this rambunctious, noisy film  might be taken as a symbol. The cinema can be a place of fantasy and sometimes disreputable pleasure, but reality, as stubborn and hard to corral as that goat, has a way of intruding whether we like it or not.

headline: Kennedy Stays in Hospital After Seizure
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, remained hospitalized in Boston on Sunday, with doctors still uncertain about the cause of a seizure that gripped him Saturday at his Cape Cod home.

headline: What Working Women Want
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sluggish Start Dooms  Liberty in  Opener
text: Once the Liberty went to a full-court press, the team appeared to have the Connecticut Sun on the ropes Sunday. The Liberty forced turnovers and fouls at one end of the court while putting together a 21-7 run at the other during a 10-minute stretch between the third and fourth quarters.

headline: Fore! A Writer Tees Off and a Turtle Is Airborne
text: Carl Hiaasen is such an unswervingly funny writer that die-hard readers would follow him anywhere. Or so it always has seemed. Now he tests that blind devotion with a potential deal-breaker: who wants to traipse onto the golf course, even in such witty, good-humored company? Whose affection for Mr. Hiaasen transcends total indifference to golf?

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Sept. 14, 2007, about a photo historian and innovative dealer in photographic equipment misspelled his surname at one point. He was Fred Spira, not Shira. It also misspelled his given name at birth and referred to him incorrectly in recounting how he was barred from attending high school in Austria because his father was a Jew. He was born in Vienna as Siegfried Franz Spira, not Sigfried, and was known in his youth as Siegfried, not Franz. (After emigrating to the United States, he changed his name to S. Franklin Spira but preferred to be called Fred.). Mr. Spira’s son Jonathan brought the errors to the attention of The Times last year and again last month; this correction was delayed because editors and a reporter did not follow through on the complaint.

text: Microsoft has proposed a complex new deal with Yahoo that would involve collaboration between their online advertising businesses but would not involve a full takeover, Microsoft said on Sunday.

headline: Colombia Denies Its Forces Entered Venezuela Illegally
text: LIMA, Peru  Tension between Colombia and Venezuela increased Sunday after Colombia’s defense minister rejected an accusation by Venezuela’s government that 60 Colombian troops had illegally entered a border region of Venezuela known to be a redoubt for Colombian guerrilla groups.

headline: Anti-Immigrant Violence in Johannesburg
text: JOHANNESBURG  Violence against immigrants, like some windswept fire, spread across one neighborhood after another here in one of South Africa’s main cities this weekend, and the police said the mayhem left at least 12 people dead  beaten by mobs, shot, stabbed or burned alive.

headline: Fleeting Stage Glory, Savored and Survived

At the Signature Theater in Arlington, “Glory Days,” the four-man musical about growing up, was a hit this year. The reviews were mixed to positive, but the real story was the show’s creators, Nick Blaemire, 23, and James Gardiner, 24. So young, and to have written a musical!

headline: Al Jazeera English Tries to Extend Its Reach

headline: A Gust of Wind, and a Check of the Rulebook
text: Bob and Jerry are playing the final hole of their club championship, tied for the lead. They each reach the green in two strokes and mark their balls, which rest on a slope about 3 feet above the hole. Bob replaces his ball and lifts his ball marker. He addresses the ball and prepares to make his stroke. He then backs away from his ball, and a gust of wind causes it to roll into the hole. Next, Jerry replaces his ball and leaves his ball marker behind his ball as he walks to the other side of the hole to read his putt. While he is there, a gust of wind blows the ball into the hole.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a dispute between President Bush and Senator Barack Obama over Mr. Bush’s remarks about appeasement in a speech to the Israeli Parliament misstated the connection between Mr. Obama and Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser. Mr. Brzezinski has endorsed Mr. Obama and has met with the senator, but the campaign does not consider him an “adviser.”

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the harsh environment surrounding the Knicks while Isiah Thomas was the coach, erroneously linked Thomas to a racially charged comment about Larry Bird when both men were top N.B.A. players. It was Dennis Rodman  once a teammate of Thomas’s  who famously suggested that Bird would have been regarded as an ordinary player had he been black.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about Senator Barack Obama’s plans to spend primary night on Tuesday in Iowa referred incorrectly to the state of the delegate race for the Democratic nomination. Mr. Obama could amass enough additional pledged delegates on Tuesday from primaries in Oregon and Kentucky to secure a majority of pledged delegates from nominating contests sanctioned by the party. But that alone would not be enough to allow him “to proclaim, without fear of contradiction, that he is now the Democratic nominee.” (To become the presumptive nominee, Mr. Obama would have to win additional support from elected officials and party leaders known as superdelegates. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to have the party recognize results from two disputed contests, in Florida and Michigan, could also affect the status of the delegate race.)

headline: Doings on the Avenue for a Museum Festival
text: The 30th annual Museum Mile Festival on June 3 will feature nine cultural institutions offering admission at no charge from 6 to 9 p.m. along a traffic-free stretch of Fifth Avenue, from 82nd to 105th Streets. Live music, including jazz, Broadway melodies and classics played by string quartets, will be performed in front of participating institutions: El Museo del Barrio; the Museum of the City of New York; the Jewish Museum; Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution; National Academy Museum & School of Fine Arts; Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum; Neue Galerie; Goethe Institut and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
