headline: As the Search for Survivors Scales Back, an Air of Hopelessness Descends
text: BEICHUAN, China  On television, the miraculous survivor stories have begun to fade, replaced with reruns of dramatic rescues. A man who endured entombment for 148 hours in the town of Yingxiu was rescued and celebrated Sunday. Elsewhere, three people beat the odds, being found alive amid the rubble, although one of them later died in a hospital.

headline: IPhone’s Hold on Users Not Exclusive
text: Nearly half of iPhone users changed carriers in order to use the device, according to a survey of 460 iPhone users by Rubicon Consulting, a technology consulting firm. The survey found that the average iPhone user was paying $19 more in phone bills than before.

He worked for Snead for 19 years, absorbing many of Snead’s idiosyncratic golf teachings. One that has stuck with Snyder through more than 50 years of giving lessons is Snead’s conviction that music helps a swing.

headline: Profit Honors Poet in His Own Country
text: William McGonagall (1825-1902) may have gone to his unmarked grave a mocked man, ridiculed as the world’s worst poet, but when a collection of 35 of his poems went up for auction on Friday in his native Edinburgh, they fetched more than $13,000, better than the price (about $12,000) paid for a set of Harry Potter first editions signed by J. K. Rowling, the BBC reported. Known as the Tayside Tragedian, McGonagall, above, who spent much of his life in Dundee as a weaver in the jute mills, did not take up poetry until he was 47. He specialized in subjects like Scottish battles and Queen Victoria’s golden jubilee, as well as death and catastrophe. At his readings in Dundee, he was often scorned, and audiences were fond of throwing eggs and vegetables at him. Perhaps his best-known poem dealt with the Tay Bridge disaster of 1879 and included the lines “So the train mov’d slowly along the Bridge of Tay/Until it was about midway,’/Then the central girders with a crash gave way/And down went the train and passengers into the Tay.” Alex Dove, of the auctioneers Lyon & Turnbull, said: “He was a confident gentleman who thought that his poetry was some of the best. He once walked all the way to Balmoral to try to become poet laureate. Unfortunately, the queen wasn’t in.”

headline: Drama Desk’s Awards
text: With five citations, including the accolade for outstanding musical revival, “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s South Pacific” led the field when the 53rd annual Drama Desk Awards were announced on Sunday at the LaGuardia Concert Hall at Lincoln Center. Three awards each went to the drama “August: Osage County” and the musicals “Gypsy” and “Passing Strange.” “South Pacific” won for actor in a musical (Paulo Szot), director of a musical (Bartlett Sher), set design of a musical (Michael Yeargan) and sound design (Scott Lehrer). “August: Osage County” by Tracy Letts won in the categories of outstanding play, actress in a play (Deanna Dunagan) and director of a play (Anna D. Shapiro). Jule Styne, Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurents’s “Gypsy” was cited for actress in a musical (Patti LuPone) and featured actor and actress in a musical (Boyd Gaines and Laura Benanti). “Passing Strange” by Stew and Heidi Rodewald, took honors for outstanding musical, music (Stew and Ms. Rodewald) and lyrics (Stew). Mark Rylance of “Boeing-Boeing,” which was named outstanding revival of a play, won for lead actor in a drama; and Laurence Fishburne was honored for solo performance for his portrayal of Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall in “Thurgood.” The unique theatrical experience accolade went to “The 39 Steps,” and “Forbidden Broadway: Rude Awakening” was cited as outstanding revue.

headline: $1 Billion Later, New York’s Subway Elevators Still Fail
text: New York City Transit has spent close to $1 billion to install more than 200 new elevators and escalators in the subway system since the early 1990s, and it plans to spend almost that much again for dozens more machines through the end of the next decade. It is an investment of historic dimensions, aimed at better serving millions of riders and opening more of the subway to the disabled.

headline: Filming ‘The Alchemist’
text: After 20 years, the best-selling novel “The Alchemist,” by the Brazilian writer Paulo Coelho, is bound for the screen in a Weinstein Company adaptation directed by and starring Laurence Fishburne in the title role, Reuters reported. In an announcement in Cannes, France, Harvey Weinstein, a co-chairman of the company, said the film, costing “$60 million plus,” would go before the cameras in late spring or early summer. The novel tells of Santiago, an Andalusian shepherd boy who travels to Africa in search of his dream and meets the alchemist along the way.

headline: The Early Word: Obama Holding Off on Declaring Win
text: Barack Obama and his family greeted a record-breaking crowd of 75,000 in Portland, Ore., on Sunday, ahead of that state’s primary this Tuesday. Even if things “go as we hope,” he said, his campaign won’t declare victory in the Democratic primary that night, even though Oregon could tip the majority of pledged delegates his way.

headline: Widespread Breakdowns in Subway Elevators

One of every six elevators and escalators in the subway system was out of service for more than a month last year, according to New York City Transit data.

And Anthony Lake, whom Diehl calls Obama’s “senior foreign policy hand,” endorsed the idea. Diehl explains why:

headline: Greens and Hunger

They explain how the Green Revolution faltered after Western governments and agencies slashed funds for agricultural research, partly to shift money to other areas, like environmental projects, and partly because of opposition to high-yield agriculture from advocacy groups.

headline: A Series of Unfortunate Events

headline: A Taser Duel in Colorado
text: BRIEFS What happens when the man saying “Don’t Tase Me, Bro” has a Taser too? On the weekend police blotter in Boulder, Colorado, a bizarre duel: Casey Dane, a private security guard, “told police he reached for his Taser after [Harvey] Epstein refused to drop the bolt cutters. That, according to Dane, is when Epstein pulled a stun gun out of his pocket and shot him. He fired back, stunning Epstein in return.” Neither was injured. [Daily Camera via The Associated Press]

headline: Developer in Deal With M.T.A. to Develop West Side Railyards
text: In an act that could be described as loser’s remorse, the developer Stephen M. Ross signed the billion-dollar deal he had abandoned only a few months ago to develop the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Homegrown Cubs Winning Over Doubters
text: With most of the baseball world focused on interleague action, the Cubs quietly closed out an 8-2 home stand with a 4-3 victory over the Pirates in the lone intraleague game Sunday.

headline: Viacom Joint Venture Hires Ex-Showtime Executive As CEO
text: “An entertainment joint venture formed by Viacom Inc, its Paramount Pictures unit, and film studios Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios Inc and Lions Gate Entertainment Corp said on Monday that it hired former Showtime cable executive Mark Greenberg as its chief executive,” Reuters reports.

headline: Defending Driving While Distracted
text: In an article on the various ways that drivers become distracted, USA Today cited an interesting finding in a recent survey. “Older drivers were more likely than teens to multitask when driving,” wrote Angela Haupt. Time to celebrate those surprisingly responsible young folks? Not exactly.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Pasta With Leeks and Parsley
text: While there is a lot to be said for a sauce of slow-cooked onions, there is one major disadvantage: it’s slow. Fresher, greener and milder than onions, leeks cook down and become tender quickly enough to make a distinctive, delicious sauce for spaghetti in little more time than it takes to boil the water and cook the pasta.

headline: Mac Clones Are Back (for Now)
text: Apple ended its Mac clone program in 1998, soon after Steven P. Jobs rejoined the company. At the time, there was little reason to suspect that it would ever be revived. Now a Mac clone is back, but this time without Apple’s blessing.

headline: Clinton: ‘This Is Nowhere Near Over’
text: MAYSVILLE, Ky. – Adding a new mathematical twist to her case for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Monday that she had not only won more popular votes than Senator Barack Obama, she had won states totaling far more electoral votes.

headline: Big Brown New York Bound
text: Big Brown boarded a van at 10 a.m. Monday at Pimlico Race Course and is bound for Belmont Park. The colt will take up residence in Bobby Frankel’s barn in the stall that was once occupied by the 2003 Belmont Stakes winner, Empire Maker.

headline: 12 Midtown Buildings Evacuated After Water Main Break
text: Updated, 3:27 p.m. | The authorities evacuated 12 commercial buildings and rerouted three bus lines this morning after a 20-inch water main broke on West 57th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues around 8:10 a.m. The bus lines that were detoured were the M30, M31 and M57, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority warned of extensive service delays.

headline: Paying Attention to the Food We Don’t Eat
text: The health community has long focused on how much Americans eat, but now the world is starting to pay attention to how much we don’t.

headline: Paying Attention to Food We Don’t Eat
text: (Photo: The food we waste. (Jonathan Bloom))   The health community has long focused on how much Americans eat, but now the world is starting to pay attention to how much we don't.  For a detailed look at how much food the typical family wastes each month, check out this great graphic that appeared in The Times this weekend, along with this story on food waste by my colleague Andrew Martin.   I've also started reading WastedFood.com, a great blog by  journalist Jonathan Bloom, who chronicles food waste and efforts to salvage food. Recent blog postings highlight the fact that 60,000 pounds of shrimp are consumed in Las Vegas each day, and how immigration policies can lead to food waste in the field because there aren't enough workers to pick it.  To see a slide show illustrating how much edible food gets wasted every day, click here.

headline: What Does Microsoft Want?
text: Microsoft‘s latest overture to Yahoo has raised a lot of questions about what exactly it wants from the new round of negotiations. What we do know for sure from the statement it issued Sunday is that Microsoft isn’t currently pursuing an acquisition of all of Yahoo. That leaves all kinds of other possibilities, including joint ventures, partnerships or a deal to acquire just a piece of Yahoo.

headline: Bounties: Working at Home, Not Abroad

headline: When Food Releases
text: I figure that when I’m completely mystified about something, plenty of you are too, so maybe this of some interest. I know from experience that if you grill something long enough, or sauté it long enough, or even roast it long enough, eventually a kind of crust will form on its bottom and it will magically release from the cooking surface. (Sometimes by then it will be overcooked, but more often than not, again mysteriously, it releases at just about the “right” moment.)

headline: Belmont Preparations: What to Expect
text: Typically a trainer will give a horse three days off after it races. We will most likely see Big Brown back on the track at Belmont Park on Wednesday or Thursday. Other Preakness contenders, Icabad Crane and Macho Again, who are also considering the Belmont, will follow a similar schedule regarding a return to the track.

headline: McCain and Obama Trade Barbs on Iran
text: CHICAGO — Senator John McCain challenged Senator Barack Obama on his home turf here today, attacking him for comments he made over the weekend downplaying the threat posed by Iran relative to the former Soviet Union.

headline: Architects Selected for New Police Academy
text: City officials have selected Perkins+Will to design the new Police Academy planned for College Point, Queens, the architectural firm announced today. But don’t expect Tackleberry, Hightower and Mahoney to be stumbling out of the building; the aimless recruits from the “Police Academy” movie series would be so lucky to be trained in the new facility, which could cost as much as $1 billion.

headline: Playing the ‘Appeasement’ Card
text: The outlines of the debate over the merits of negotiating with America’s enemies can be seen in dueling articles on the op-ed pages of The Wall Street Journal and The Los Angeles Times, by John Bolton, the former ambassador the to the United Nations under President Bush, and J. Peter Scoblic, the executive editor of The New Republic, respectively.

headline: No Holiday for Shares of Bell Canada
text: Today is Victoria Day in Canada, which marks the unofficial start of that country’s vacation season. But Monday was anything but a day at the beach for the bankers involved in the troubled, $51.8 billion buyout of BCE, the parent of Bell Canada. The New York Times reported Monday that the transaction — the largest leveraged buyout ever proposed — was in danger after the Wall Street banks that committed to finance it sought to renegotiate the lending terms.

headline: Al Jazeera English Still Seeking U.S. Carriage
text: Eric Pfanner reports: “The English-language offshoot of Al Jazeera, the Arabic television news network, is pushing for a ‘breakthrough’ that would make the channel available to American TV viewers and help it move beyond a turbulent start-up phase, according to its new managing director, Tony Burman. The hiring of Mr. Burman, a former editor in chief of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the Canadian public broadcaster, was announced last week.”

headline: ‘Housewives’ Finale Leads Sunday Night Ratings
text: ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” delivered Sunday’s top ratings, as the closing minutes of the plot-twisting series’ fourth season gave viewers a brief flash-forward five years into the future. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour finale attracted 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., in line with its performance this spring but down two million from its third season finale a year ago.

headline: The Starting Line: Where Women Are Still Barred From Olympic Participation
text: The International Herald Tribune revives a largely dormant issue in the Olympics that was once a major source of contention: gender discrimination. In an op-ed piece today in the I.H.T. (which is wholly owned by The New York Times), the director of the Washington-based Institute for Gulf Affairs, Ali Al-Ahmed, cites this year’s Olympic slogan, “One World, One Dream,” and writes, “This dream, however, will not be realized by women in Saudi Arabia and other Muslim countries that ban women from sports domestically and internationally.”

headline: Investors Offer $12.8 Billion to Run Penn. Turnpike
text: A consortium led by Citigroup and Spain’s Abertis Infraestructuras won the bidding war to run the Pennsylvania Turnpike with a $12.8 billion offer, Gov. Edward Rendell said on Monday.

headline: A New Site to Find Sports Buddies
text: I generally define “Web 2.0” as Web sites where the visitors provide the material (YouTube, eBay, Flickr, Craigslist), rather than the Web site owner (CNN, Onion, New York Times). The power of Web 2.0 comes from connecting people who don’t know each other but have similar, often very specific, interests.

headline: Barack Obama’s Post-Racial Campaign
text: It’s taken for granted these days that Barack Obama, the all-but-presumptive-if-only-she’d-go-away Democratic nominee, has a problem with white working-class voters. On the morning after the Pennsylvania primary (let’s not even get into West Virginia), he said, “We have won the white blue-collar vote in a whole bunch of states.” But as Ronald Brownstein explained in National Journal, “That’s not true, no matter how the white blue-collar vote is defined.”

Only time will tell though if the price they paid for Haren was simply too high.

headline: In China, Mourning Period Begins
text: China began a three-day period of national mourning today in memory of the tens of thousands of victims of last Monday’s Sichuan earthquake. The mourning period began at 2:28 p.m., the exact minute one week ago when the quake struck, and covers all areas of life in the country, including the Olympic torch relay, which was suspended for the duration.

headline: Crowding Forces Prisoners Into Makeshift Sleeping Areas
text: New York’s federal prisons are letting inmates sleep in areas not originally designed for inmate beds — such as television rooms — because of overcrowding in excess of 50 percent, according to correspondence with the Federal Bureau of Prisons that was released by Senator Charles E. Schumer today.According to Harley G. Lappin, the director of the Bureau of Prisons, more than 5,700 inmates were in New York federal prisons on an average day in the 2007 fiscal year, far above the recommended population of 3,600.

headline: Lessons From My First Boss
text: Last week, I had lunch with the lawyer I worked with nearly 15 years ago in my first job. As we sat across a table the way we had countless times before, I realized that he was the reason I stayed so long in a career that wasn’t suited to me. I enjoyed working with him so much that I didn’t focus on the fact that I didn’t want to be a lawyer. But it’s a good thing I stayed because he taught me many things that made me successful in my career long after I left his firm and his field.

text: The fast-growing buyout firm that owns the fashion house Bill Blass, the retailer Athlete’s Foot and the ice cream chain MaggieMoo’s appears to be on the verge of collapse.

headline: House Conservatives to Offer Ideas for G.O.P. Message
text: WASHINGTON  Conservative Republicans in the House plan to urge their colleagues to rally behind a new manifesto that mixes antispending initiatives and tighter restrictions on government benefits as the party seeks a fresh message after a string of election defeats.

headline: Yanks May Be Scratching Surface of Sox Items at New Stadium
text: If inexperienced pitchers and key injuries were not enough to explain the Yankees’ struggles, fans may have a new reason.

headline: Picture Columbia as Ivy Champion
text: Before Brett Boretti settled in as the new Columbia baseball coach three years ago, he told his players to think big, to visualize themselves as Ivy League champions. Never mind that the team he inherited after the 2005 season had won only five league games.

headline: Cervical Cancer Could Double by 2030 Where Screening and Vaccine Are Lacking
text: Cervical cancer, which can be prevented by a vaccine or detected early by Pap smears, kills 33,000 women in Latin America and the Caribbean a year, according to a new study.

headline: Britain: Hybrid Embryo Ban Is Defeated
text: The House of Commons has defeated a bill that would have banned the creation of so-called hybrid embryos  part human and part animal  for medical research. That means scientists who obtain proper licenses will be allowed to create hybrid embryos by transferring DNA from human cells into animal eggs that have had most of their genetic information removed. The embryos would then be grown in a laboratory and their stem cells would be harvested for up to 14 days, after which they would be destroyed. Opponents call the process unethical and unnatural; supporters say the embryos could aid the understanding of genetic defects and diseases like Parkinson’s.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A film review on Friday about “My Father My Lord” referred incorrectly to a character in another film about Israeli ultra-Orthodox Jews, “Kadosh.” A childless wife in that film is ostracized by her family because she is believed to be infertile, not because she is indeed infertile (a doctor tells her that she is fertile and that the problem must be with her husband, not her) .

headline: Memo Pad
text: SINGAPORE AIRLINES AND IPOD Passengers on Singapore Airlines new all-business-class flights between Newark and Singapore can now connect personal audio and video on iPods and iPhones to the airline’s high-end KrisWorld in-flight entertainment system, which Singapore said was a first. Each seat has a 15.4-inch L.C.D. screen and an audio system with noise-canceling headphones. The system has a dedicated cable that supports iPods and iPhones. The all-business-class flights on A340-500 aircraft began May 15, and a route connecting Los Angeles and Singapore will be added in August.

headline: Beverly Rae Kimes, Automotive Journalist and Historian, Is Dead at 68
text: Beverly Rae Kimes, who, after failing to find work as a theater writer, parlayed a job as a secretary at a fledgling car magazine into a career as one of the nation’s pre-eminent historians of automobiles, died on May 12 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 68.

headline: Not All Earmarks Are Paid in Full, and a Senator Wants to Know Why
text: In early 2005, the office of Senator Ben Nelson received a curious phone call.

headline: Grisham Football Novel to Become a Movie
text: The John Grisham novel “Playing for Pizza” will have its shot at the big screen. Executives at Phoenix Pictures said Monday that they had acquired rights to develop a feature film based on the book, about a washed-up National Football League quarterback who joins a semiprofessional team playing American football in Italy. Mr. Grisham is best known for legal thrillers, several of which became the basis for hit movies, among them “The Pelican Brief” and “The Firm.” Mike Medavoy and Arnie Messer of Phoenix Pictures expect to join the company’s co-president of production, David Thwaites, in producing the film. Among Phoenix’s credits are “Zodiac” and “All the King’s Men.”

headline: A Living-Room Crusade via Blogging
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Jane Novak, a 46-year-old stay-at-home mother of two in New Jersey, has never been to Yemen. She speaks no Arabic, and freely admits that until a few years ago, she knew nothing about that strife-torn south Arabian country.

headline: The Spurs Get Past a Game 7 Roadblock
text: NEW ORLEANS  The San Antonio Spurs had won four N.B.A. titles, but had never captured a Game 7 on the road, losing all four attempts. In this Western Conference semifinal series against the New Orleans Hornets, they had lost three games here by more than an average of 20 points. Monday night was a reversal of fortune.

headline: Little Orphan Artworks
text: CONGRESS is considering a major reform of copyright law intended to solve the problem of “orphan works”  those works whose owner cannot be found. This “reform” would be an amazingly onerous and inefficient change, which would unfairly and unnecessarily burden copyright holders with little return to the public.

headline: As Time Runs Short, Clinton Claims Lead in Popular Vote
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is entering the Kentucky and Oregon primaries on Tuesday with one of the most pugnacious political messages of her campaign: That she is ahead in the national popular vote when all votes are counted, including from the unsanctioned primaries in Michigan and Florida, and that party leaders who have a vote as super-delegates should reflect this level of appeal.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Child Pornography Law
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld the latest Congressional effort to curb the spread of child pornography on the Internet, a 2003 law that makes it a crime to offer or solicit sexually explicit images of children.

headline: Birds Rely on Surface Tension to Eat Dinner
text: Surface tension can be a wonderful thing. It helps some insects walk on water. It allows the dappling of raindrops on the hood of a car. And, a new study in Science shows, it enables certain birds to eat.

headline: Patterns: Craving Sweets? It May Be in Your Genes
text: Could there be a genetic explanation for the sweet tooth?

headline: Let’s Be Serious
text: The general election is about to unfold and we’ll soon see how smart or how foolish Americans really are. The U.S. may be the richest country on earth, but the economy is tanking, its working families are in trouble, it is bogged down in a multitrillion-dollar war of its own making and the price of gasoline has nitwits siphoning supplies from the cars and trucks of strangers.

headline: Son of a Gun, Hollywood Has Big Fun on the Bayou
text: SHREVEPORT, La.  There is a backlot feel to Shreveport, tucked in “Ark-La-Tex,” the nexus of three states where the piney woods encircle sloughs and bayous. Its post-boom downtown  the oil and gas petered out in the mid-1980s  has plenty of fine old buildings, not many people and, along with a bit of dissipation, an air of expectation, as if the circus might suddenly crest a hill and bring all manner of hoopla.

headline: Ruling on U.S. Currency and the Blind
text: WASHINGTON  In a decision that could drastically change the appearance of American money, a federal appeals court panel ruled on Tuesday that the United States discriminates against the blind because the country’s paper currency is the same size regardless of a bill’s value.

headline: Sailing the Waters of New York Harbor
text: Just above the desk in my office hangs a U.S. Geological Survey map of New York and Vicinity made in 1901. When I sit at my desk, the top of my head is about level with the Narrows between Staten Island and Brooklyn, where the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge later went. I used to admire this map mainly for the vast expanses of swamp and salt meadow it shows and for the still incomplete hatch work of streets. But now I find myself looking at the waterline  especially the waterline of what the map calls the Upper Bay of New York Harbor, north of the Narrows and south of the Hudson River proper.

headline: A Second Chance
text: With prison costs soaring, many states are understandably desperate for ways to cut recidivism and increase the chances that newly released prisoners build viable lives. The Second Chance Act, signed into law by President Bush last month, would galvanize the re-entry effort, providing the states with money and guidance. Now Congress must appropriate the promised dollars.

headline: Housewives Future: Not as Good as Its Past
text: ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” delivered Sunday’s top ratings, as the closing minutes of the show’s fourth season gave viewers a brief flash-forward five years into the future. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour finale attracted 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., in line with its performance earlier this spring but down two million from its third-season finale a year ago. ABC led the night’s ratings over all. The finale of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” from 7 to 9 p.m., attracted a modest 9.4 million viewers, although the show’s second hour averaged 3.5 million more viewers than its first. CBS was runner-up for the night thanks to “60 Minutes” at 7 (10.7 million), followed by the Academy of Country Music Awards, which drew 11.7 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m., an increase of 2.4 million from a year ago. Fox finished third over all, with season finales of “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.1 million), “King of the Hill” at 8:30 (5.4 million) and “American Dad” at 9:30 (5.6 million). NBC was fourth.

headline: Katie Holmes Is Broadway Bound
text: Katie Holmes is about to make her Broadway debut.

headline: Far-Flung Placement of Children in Texas Raid Is Criticized
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Texas policy holds that when children are taken from their parents for investigation of possible abuse, geographic distances should be kept to a minimum to allow supervised visitation.

headline: With Primaries in Two States, Obama Looks to End Race
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama would like to begin shutting down the nominating contest with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday night as two more states  Kentucky and Oregon  hold their primaries. But he wants to do it subtly.

headline: Department Charges in Bell Shooting
text: Facing a legal deadline, the Police Department on Tuesday filed administrative charges against a group of officers involved in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, a black man killed in a hail of 50 bullets on his wedding day.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the sale of Francis Bacon’s “Triptych” (for $86.3 million) and Lucian Freud’s “Benefits Supervisor Sleeping” ($33.6 million) at auctions in New York last week misidentified the auction house that sold the Freud painting. It was Christie’s  not Sotheby’s, which sold the Bacon work.

headline: Arc-Shaped Troughs on Europa May Be Sign of Wandering Poles
text: Europa, that icy moon of Jupiter, is famous for its odd surface features  long lines, pits, domes, spots and the occasional crater.

headline: Huntington Hartford II, A. & P. Heir, Dies at 97
text: Huntington Hartford II, who inherited a fortune from the A. & P. grocery business and lost most of it chasing his dreams as an entrepreneur and arts patron, died Monday at his home in Lyford Cay, Nassau, in the Bahamas, where he had lived since 2004. He was 97.

headline: A Musician Who Performs With a Scalpel
text: For Claudius Conrad, a 30-year-old surgeon who has played the piano seriously since he was 5, music and medicine are entwined  from the academic realm down to the level of the fine-fingered dexterity required at the piano bench and the operating table.

headline: A Resignation Explained
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Arts

headline: Report Urges Tennis Match Fixing Investigation
text: An independent review of possible match fixing in professional tennis recommended that 45 matches played in the last five years be investigated because betting patterns gave a strong indication that gamblers were profiting from inside information. While finding that professional tennis is neither “systematically nor institutionally corrupt,” the report cautioned that the scale of the suspicious matches left no room for “complacency.”

headline: A Psychotic’s Love Affair (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama and McCain Spar Over Iran
text: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain traded blows over foreign policy in separate speeches on Monday in which the two presidential hopefuls clashed over the proper approach to dealing with Iran.

headline: Hospital Infections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bruce Lee, Singing and Dancing
text: Enter the director. Bartlett Sher, currently being feted for his work on “South Pacific,” has agreed to direct the previously announced new musical by David Henry Hwang and David Yazbeck, “Bruce Lee: Journey to the West.” The show, which follows Lee’s path to martial arts superstardom (and involves Chinese mythological figures like the Monkey King along the way), is aiming for a place in the 2010-11 Broadway season.

headline: Upset by Fumes and a Visit by the Biohazard Team
text: I’M one of those guys who are comfortable when flying. But even folks like me have their limits.

headline: Tumor’s Location and Size Determine Treatment
text: The malignant tumor that Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s doctors said he has is known as a glioma, a cancer that arises in the brain.

headline: Adventures in Hands-On Science
text: About five minutes into “Lord of the Ants,” on Tuesday on the PBS “Nova” series, certain preconceptions you may have about ivory-tower types are likely to be exploded. That’s when Edward O. Wilson, the eminent Harvard biologist and the “Lord” of the title, demonstrates a point by plunging his hand into a nest of stinging fire ants. So much for aloof theorizing.

headline: Rising Food Prices Sharpen a European Debate
text: BRUSSELS  The recent sharp rise in global food prices added an element Monday to the long-running debate over farm subsidies in the European Union, with some government ministers seeing a new reason to dismantle the multibillion-euro payouts and defenders countering that the system was needed more than ever.

headline: Dance in Review
text: COMPAGNIE 111

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Child Pornography Law
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld a 2003 federal law aimed at child pornography, concluding in a 7-to-2 opinion that a federal appeals court was wrong to find the law unconstitutionally vague.

headline: As Primaries End, Clinton Appeals Directly to Blogs
text: As Hillary Rodham Clinton decries the mainstream media for diminishing her chances of capturing the Democratic nomination, she is turning more to the Internet to make her increasingly urgent case.

headline: Senate Leaders Agree on Housing Aid
text: WASHINGTON  Senate negotiators on Monday said they had reached a deal on legislation aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure by expanding the availability of government-insured mortgages.

headline: Venezuela Denounces U.S. After an Airspace Violation
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The defense minister said Monday that an American fighter plane violated Venezuelan airspace over the weekend, prompting the government here to summon the United States ambassador to explain the incident and other recent statements about Venezuela by senior American officials.

headline: Regulating Tobacco
text: To the Editor:

headline: Phoenix Lander Is Ready for Risky Descent to Mars
text: To get to the ice, you have to go through the fire.

headline: Access to a New Inhaler (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Girl Wearing Pain Patch Dies; Foster Mother Charged
text: A 6-year-old girl in foster care in Harlem died Sunday after her foster mother placed a powerful medicinal patch on her neck and sent her to bed to treat the child’s complaints of pain, the authorities said.

headline: Who Are These Guys? Mets’ Identity Is in Flux
text: Before a frenzied capacity crowd at Yankee Stadium on Sunday, the Mets throttled the home team for their second consecutive victory. They toppled two elite pitchers, Andy Pettitte and Chien-Ming Wang, over the weekend with equal parts patience and power. They played crisp, fundamentally sound baseball and, when Sunday’s game ended, declared themselves fit to begin a winning streak.

headline: McCain Finds a Thorny Path in Ethics Effort
text: Sorting out the lobbying entanglements of his campaign advisers is proving to be a messy business for Senator John McCain.

headline: One for the Ladies — and Their Friends
text: LOS ANGELES  Fan boys, move over. The girls are back in town.

headline: Iraqi Forces Find Weapons Cache in Baghdad Mosque
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi troops uncovered a large cache of arms in a raid on a Baghdad mosque on Monday amid signs that Shiite militants had stepped up their attacks outside Sadr City.

headline: Screening for Abuse May Be Key to Ending It
text: The silver-haired woman greeted me at the clinic door, one arm suspended in a bright blue sling.

headline: A Series of Unfortunate Events
text: WASHINGTON  When it comes time to recount the story of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s descent from inevitable nominee to defeat at the hands of Senator Barack Obama  assuming that is how this ends up  there is no shortage of mistakes by the Clinton campaign to put on the what-went-wrong list.

headline: Reaching Well Beyond the Farm
text: WASHINGTON  Few pieces of legislation generate the level of public scorn consistently heaped upon the farm bill.

headline: Many Hands, Not Held by China, Aid in Quake
text: LUCHI, China  Hao Lin had already lied to his wife about his destination, hopped a plane to Chengdu, borrowed a bike and pedaled through the countryside in shorts and leather loafers by the time he reached this ravaged farming village. A psychologist, Mr. Hao had come to offer free counseling to earthquake survivors.

headline: Willis Lamb Jr., 94, Dies; Won Nobel for Work on Atom
text: Willis E. Lamb Jr., who shared the 1955 Nobel Prize in Physics for the discovery of a slight and subtle discrepancy in the quantum theory describing how electrons behave in the hydrogen atom, died on Thursday in Tucson. He was 94.

headline: Senator Kennedy Has Malignant Brain Tumor
text: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, has a malignant brain tumor, his doctors said on Tuesday.

headline: Project Digitizes Works From the Golden Age of Timbuktu
text: From Timbuktu to here, to reverse the expression, the written words of the legendary African oasis are being delivered by electronic caravan. A lode of books and manuscripts, some only recently rescued from decay, is being digitized for the Internet and distributed to scholars worldwide.

headline: Court Upholds Tax Exemptions for Municipal Bonds
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld the preferential tax break that nearly all states give their residents who invest in bonds issued by the state and its municipalities.

headline: Israel’s Friends and the Path to Peace
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hazards: Despite Dangers, Hookahs Gain Favor
text: First the casbah, now the campus.

headline: Girls’ Gains Have Not Cost Boys, Report Says
text: The American Association of University Women, whose 1992 report on how girls are shortchanged in the classroom caused a national debate over gender equity, has turned its attention to debunking the idea of a “boys’ crisis.”

headline: A Dark and Stormy Night, Played for All Its Drama
text: James Levine has made the Met Orchestra into a powerful precision instrument that plays Romantic and contemporary works with an uncommon beauty and suppleness. But if you want to hear these players in music that howls, roars and drags you through one or two dark nights of the soul, Valery Gergiev is your man.

headline: Lingerie Stores Enjoyed Heyday, but Now Simply Try to Survive
text: Hidden amid the hip shoe stores, stylish coffee shops and Asian markets on Orchard and Grand Streets are tiny remnants of the Lower East Side of long ago.

headline: Sex, School and Videotape (Hold the Tea and Sympathy, Please)
text: “Good Boys and True,” about a scandal at a prep school, is a standard-issue issue play written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and acted competently by a likable cast. The brouhaha in question, unfortunately, is likely to inspire more stifled yawns than furrowed brows or raised consciousnesses.

headline: France Admits Contacts With Hamas
text: PARIS  France confirmed Monday that it had been engaged in contacts with the leaders of Hamas, the radical Islamic group that is running Gaza, for several months to try to better understand its positions.

headline: Talking Versus Doing
text: In 1965, Mancur Olson wrote a classic book called “The Logic of Collective Action,” which pointed out that large, amorphous groups are often less powerful politically than small, organized ones. He followed it up with “The Rise and Decline of Nations.” In that book, Olson observed that as the number of small, organized factions in a society grows, the political culture becomes more divisive, the economy becomes more rigid and the nation loses vitality.

headline: New Developer Signs $1 Billion Deal to Transform West Side Railyards
text: Less than two weeks after the collapse of a billion-dollar deal to develop the railyards on Manhattan’s Far West Side, a new developer has agreed to salvage the plan and help keep alive the Bloomberg administration’s campaign to transform the area into a major business district.

headline: Odom’s Wait Began Long Before Playoffs Did
text: Forward Lamar Odom could not hide his hunger after the Los Angeles Lakers closed out the Utah Jazz in Game 6 of the Western Conference semifinals. Scooping popcorn out of a bucket the size of a bowler hat, he consumed a couple of mouthfuls and spit out a kernel of truth. “From now on,” he said, “every game is the biggest game of my life.”

headline: Girardi Preaches Amnesia for Woeful Yanks
text: When Manager Joe Girardi discussed the Yankees’ 20-24 record on Sunday night, he seemingly spit out those two numbers, which define his underachievers. Girardi said he was embarrassed, and he acted disgusted. He preached the need for amnesia regarding the previous seven weeks.

headline: Netflix to Sell a Device for Instantly Watching Movies on TV Sets
text: Netflix, which pioneered the business of offering DVD movie rentals by mail, is now offering its 8.2 million subscribers an option to watch movies easily on their televisions without involving the post office.

headline: When He Tried to Vanish, His Sister Wouldn’t Let Him
text: Dying of cancer, terrified of becoming an invalid and reluctant to give up his strenuous life, Carl Brenner  a former trial lawyer turned apple grower  prepared to take his own life in early 2003. He returned home to Texas, took his computer hard drive to a garbage dump on the other side of San Antonio, and filled his car with every piece of paper that might tell anyone anything about his life. He invited friends and cousins over to cart away his possessions  his guns, his fishing tackle, his books and prints. And for good measure, he spent several hours erasing all of his last appointments from his calendar.

headline: Argentine Farms to End Strike
text: BUENOS AIRES  Farm leaders announced on Monday night that they planned to suspend a national strike and resume negotiations with the Argentine government to resolve a dispute over a tax increase on exports. They said they would begin selling grain on Tuesday at midnight.

headline: Water Main Break Brings a Busy Midtown Street to a Gushing Standstill
text: New York’s aging network of subterranean pipes, valves and connectors poked through the surface again on Monday morning when an 85-year-old water main burst beneath West 57th Street, sending torrents of water  some laced with small amounts of asbestos  into one of Manhattan’s busiest commercial districts.

headline: Knee Replacement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Huntington Hartford, A. & P. Heir, Dies at 97
text: Huntington Hartford, who inherited a fortune from the A. & P. grocery business and lost most of it chasing his dreams as an entrepreneur, arts patron and man of leisure, died Monday at his home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. He was 97.

headline: Google Offers Personal Health Records on the Web
text: After a year and half of development, Google began offering online personal health records to the public on Monday.

headline: Aspirin More Beneficial if Taken at Night
text: People who are at risk of developing hypertension may be able to lower their blood pressure by taking a small amount of aspirin daily  but only if they take it at bedtime, a new study suggests.

headline: Where Industry Once Hummed, Urban Garden Finds Success
text: PHILADELPHIA  Amid the tightly packed row houses of North Philadelphia, a pioneering urban farm is providing fresh local food for a community that often lacks it, and making money in the process.

headline: Obama Is Expected to Hit a Milestone in Today’s Votes
text: Senator Barack Obama is poised to reach a milestone in the presidential race on Tuesday by capturing a majority of pledged delegates, but he said he would not declare victory against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton or suggest the Democratic primary should end until the final three contests are finished on June 3.

headline: In Today’s Air Travel, Stress and Comfort Mix
text: THE summer of 2008 looms, and the airlines have shrunk the domestic system to the point where the term “cattle car” is no longer useful, because there are laws about how many cattle can be crammed into a railway car.

headline: Aloft and Close to Nature, Fine-Feathered Birds in Constant Flux
text: BEACON, N.Y.  The glorious expanses of Robert Ryman’s paintings always seduce on a first tour through his galleries at Dia:Beacon. As you get closer, you are taken in anew by the details. Rich edgings of vibrant color appear where there seemed to be only white. Thick ridges of paint complicate not-so-pristine surfaces.

headline: Support for Girardi, a Bit Less for Cashman
text: Not long ago, a humbling weekend for a stumbling Yankees team could have provoked the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, into criticizing the manager. Times have changed, but only to a point.

headline: Newspapers on Upswing in Developing Markets
text: NEW DELHI  While gloom haunts the newspaper industry in the United States and Europe, the business is flourishing in much of the developing world.

headline: Met Director Will Become Professor at N.Y.U. Institute
text: The mellifluous voice of Philippe de Montebello will next be heard in classrooms at New York University’s Institute of Fine Arts, where he will become the first professor to teach the history and culture of museums.

headline: War Takes Toll on Baghdad Psychiatric Hospital
text: BAGHDAD  In a different time, in another country, where violence and terror did not stalk the streets, Dr. Amir Hussain could practice psychiatry the way he once hoped to.

headline: Arbitration Panel Gives Raise to City Police Officers
text: Ending a protracted labor dispute, an arbitration panel on Monday awarded New York City’s roughly 23,000 police officers a retroactive 9.7 percent raise over two years and significantly increased the low starting pay for recruits by $10,781.

headline: Public Theater’s History to Be Published
text: In 1986 Kenneth Turan, then a freelance writer and now a film critic for The Los Angeles Times, collaborated with Joseph Papp on an oral history of Papp’s Public Theater. But after 18 months and interviews with more than 160 people, Papp did not like the first draft and the project was dropped. After Papp’s death in 1991, Mr. Turan brought up the project with Papp’s widow, Gail Merrifield Papp, and they decided to revisit the book, addressing some of Papp’s objections. Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Doubleday (who, as editor in chief at Bantam, originally acquired the rights), has now announced that the book, “Free for All,” is going forward, with a 2009 publication date. Mr. Turan chose not to do any new reporting for it, so the interviews with theater stars are all from the period. Almost a quarter of those interviewed are now dead, among them Bob Fosse, Raul Julia and Madeline Kahn. Other subejcts include David Hare, Larry Kramer, David Rabe and Meryl Streep. “I thought about that a lot,” Mr. Turan said in a telephone interview. “I finally decided we’re all different people 20 years down the road.”

headline: Red Bulls Rookies Earn Praise, but Not Much Money
text: Major League Soccer is trying to make itself more vivid in the hearts and minds of American fans, and one way is by importing big-name and big-salaried stars from abroad like David Beckham, Juan Pablo Ángel, Marcelo Gallardo and Cuauhtémoc Blanco.

headline: Victim’s Journal Leads Investigators to Slaying Suspect
text: TENAFLY, N.J.  Han Il Kim’s journal, written in Korean, included both commonplace entries and crucial clues, leading the police from a house here where he, his mother and an uncle were found stabbed to death to a casino near downtown Los Angeles where, the authorities said, they found a suspect with nearly $90,000.

headline: From Cracks to Falling Cranes, a Big Job for Building Inspectors
text: The crack in the facade of the century-old apartment building looked ominous. Nearly an inch wide and jagged, it ran through the basement and up the front wall, causing the building to list precariously to the right.

headline: Foster Mother’s Pain Patch Is Believed Responsible in 6-Year-Old Girl’s Death
text: A foster mother in Harlem has been arrested and accused of accidentally killing a 6-year-old girl in her care by placing a powerful medicinal patch on the child’s neck as treatment for pain, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Myanmar to Widen Neighbors’ Aid Role
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar agreed Monday to let its Southeast Asian neighbors help coordinate foreign relief assistance for cyclone victims, bending somewhat to international pressure to allow more outside aid, Singapore’s foreign minister, George Yeo, said.

headline: Assertions by Ex-Referee Are Dismissed by N.B.A.
text: A lawyer for the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy suggested in court papers Monday that games had been influenced by relationships among referees, coaches and players, and that other factors had “prevented games from being played on a level playing field.” The league immediately denounced the charges as unfounded.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Chart on Friday was premature in describing the accomplishments of the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. The telescope is not expected to be completed until 2014.

headline: Britain Tries to Lower the Volume on Commercials
text: NO noise please  we’re British.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The continuation of an article on Sunday about Robin Sotire, who faces foreclosure on two homes after obtaining mortgages that did not require proof of income, was omitted.

headline: South Africans Take Out Rage on Immigrants
text: JOHANNESBURG  The man certainly looked dead, lying motionless in the dust of the squatter camp. His body seemed almost like a bottle that had been turned on its side, spilling blood. His pants were red with the moisture.

headline: Finding the Best Way to Cook All Those Vegetables
text: By now, most people know they should be eating more vegetables. But are there ways to get more from the vegetables you already eat?

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A theater review on Friday about “The Bully Pulpit,” at the Beckett Theater, misidentified the sound designer. He is Tom Shread  not Jill Nagle, who designed the lighting.

headline: Index Implies Slowdown May Prove a Short One
text: The index of leading economic indicators rose in April for a second month, the first back-to-back gain since October 2006, suggesting that the current slowdown will be short-lived.

headline: Economic Tide Is Rising for Repo Man
text: HARRISON TOWNSHIP, Mich.  So many people have so many things they can no longer afford. This is an excellent time to be a repo man.

headline: Telltale DNA Bits Give Away Presence of Secretive Invaders
text: In dealing with invasive species, conservationists first have to identify the scope of the problem. But that isn’t always easy. Some animals are so secretive that finding them, to determine how far they have spread, is nearly impossible.

headline: Makeshift Space for Inmates as Prisons Exceed Capacity
text: New York’s federal prisons are letting inmates sleep in areas not originally designed for inmate beds  like television rooms  because of overcrowding in excess of 50 percent, according to correspondence with the Federal Bureau of Prisons released on Monday by Senator Charles E. Schumer.

headline: Trying to Break Nicotine’s Grip
text: Michael Shaw, a 40-year-old from Brooklyn who has smoked cigarettes for 24 years, says he really wants to quit. And I do not doubt his sincerity. He has tried to give up cigarettes many times. But after several days or weeks of not smoking, something happens  an evening out with friends, an emotional upset or just plain boredom  and he relapses.

headline: As Term Wanes, Bloomberg’s Temper Boils Up
text: For more than six years, Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have enjoyed a warm relationship. So when the councilor spotted the mayor outside City Hall on a recent sunny morning, he greeted him amiably, shook his hand, and turned to go on his way.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A film column on Monday about the Cannes festival misstated the surname of the author of “Gomorrah,” the book on which the film of that title is based. He is Roberto Saviano, not Soriano.

headline: Buffett’s Shopping Trip to Europe Draws a Crowd
text: FRANKFURT  Warren E. Buffett may be one of the few Americans who can still afford to come to Europe for a shopping spree.

headline: Call in France to Lengthen Workweek Falls Flat
text: PARIS  The leader of France’s governing party called Monday for a definitive end to France’s 35-hour workweek, but within hours he was contradicted by other party figures and by President Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: 4 Philadelphia Police Officers in Videotaped Beatings Will Be Fired
text: PHILADELPHIA  Four police officers who were caught on video beating three suspects in a drug-related triple shooting will be fired, Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey said Monday.

headline: Comfort Food, for Monkeys
text: The ladies who lunch do not obsess about their weight in the rhesus monkey compound at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center in Atlanta. Food is freely available, and the high-status females do not pride themselves on passing it up. They don’t seem to stigmatize obesity  there is no equivalent of a Kirstie Alley joke  and they certainly don’t turn themselves into Social X-Rays.

headline: The Claim: Smoking Can Cause the Loss of Hair
text: THE FACTS

headline: More Hospital Tests for Kennedy
text: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy underwent further tests Monday that doctors hoped would reveal the cause of seizures he had Saturday morning.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Details of Microsoft Offer to Yahoo
text: Under its latest proposal to Yahoo, Microsoft would buy its search business and take a stake in the company, people briefed on the negotiations said Monday.

headline: No Rescue, Yet, for Airport That Saved Berlin
text: BERLIN  Sometimes you can read a city though a cultural landmark. Tempelhof Airport is Berlin’s open book.

headline: Who Is the Walrus?
text: I was about to meet a walrus for the first time in my life, and I felt fabulous. After all, Ronald J. Schusterman of the University of California, Santa Cruz, who has studied them for years, had assured me over the phone that to meet a walrus was to fall in love with walruses  the mammals were that smart, friendly and playful. “They’re pussycats!” he said.

headline: When the New Kid on the Block Is a Swaggering Cad
text: Reggie Youngblood, lead vocalist of Black Kids, saved his meta-commentary for the very end, biting his tongue until he could bite it no more. He had, somewhat sourly, made it through the band’s set at the Bowery Ballroom on Sunday appearing alternately glib and wary. Mocking his band’s naysayers, he declaimed, “This is going to be the worst encore of all, because we only have four songs.”

headline: Initially Rebuffed, a Greenwich Village Hospital Scales Down Its Redesign Plans
text: St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan returned from the drawing board on Monday with a more modest redesign of its $1.6 billion development proposal that was rejected this month by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

headline: Concerns About BPA Plastic
text: Anybody worried about the potential danger from plastic bottles and cups, especially for the very young, should take note. The Canadian government has announced plans to restrict the use of bisphenol-a, or BPA, a chemical used to make hardened plastics. The government would prohibit the sale of baby bottles made with BPA. (Those are the ones with the numeral 7 in the triangle stamp on the bottom).

headline: McCain Attacks Obama on Cuba
text: MIAMI  Senator John McCain took his sharp criticism of Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy to a new venue on Tuesday, using a speech on Cuba here in a critical swing state to argue again that Mr. Obama is too willing to talk to America’s enemies.

headline: Opening Statements in Trial of Track Coach
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A lawyer for the controversial track coach Trevor Graham said in opening arguments at trial Monday that Graham was “the original Balco whistleblower” and “a convenient scapegoat” for disgruntled former sprinters who used performance-enhancing drugs on their own.

headline: Former AOL Executives Sued in Ad-Revenue Case
text: In a reminder that the wreckage of the disastrous merger between America Online and Time Warner is still being sifted, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed fraud charges against eight former AOL executives, saying they had inflated online advertising revenue by more than $1 billion.

headline: Worker Verification
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Ruling on the Side of Opportunity
text: When Oscar Pistorius was denied a chance to run in the Summer Games last January, the International Association of Athletics Federations cited a scientific study that proved Pistorius had an edge by running on curved artificial feet.

headline: Stay Calm, Breathe Easy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Bush’s Travels
text: President Bush’s visit to the Middle East last week offered a graphic primer on his failed policies  and the many dangers his successor will face.

headline: Giving Pets Long Lives
text: Q. Do dogs and cats that have been spayed or neutered live longer?

headline: Paterson to Undergo Laser Eye Surgery
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson is scheduled to undergo laser eye surgery on Tuesday to relieve the sharp head pain that sent him to the hospital early in the morning.

headline: Iranian Clerics Tell the President to Leave the Theology to Them
text: TEHRAN  In his almost three years as president of Iran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has been harshly criticized in the West. But he is increasingly drawing fire from Shiite clerics here, who accuse him of using religion to distract attention from his government’s failure to deliver on promises of prosperity and political freedoms.

headline: The Smarter Species? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Veteran Knopf Editor Switches Jobs
text: Marty Asher, the editor in chief of the Vintage Anchor paperback imprint of Alfred A. Knopf, is stepping down from his position after 21 years to become an editor at large at the company. In a staff memo, Sonny Mehta, chairman and chief executive of Knopf, said Mr. Asher, 63, wanted to “devote more time to acquiring and editing books.” While he ran the paperback imprint, which largely repackages books already published in hardcover, Mr. Asher’s acquisitions included “Stumbling on Happiness” by Dan Gilbert and “Letter to a Christian Nation” by Sam Harris. He will now spend his time looking for new books and editing them. During his tenure at Vintage Anchor, Mr. Asher, in partnership with Anne Messitte, the imprint’s publisher, helped quadruple gross sales in the last two decades. He also helped shepherd the paperback fortunes of authors including Charles Frazier, David Guterson and Nicholson Baker. Mr. Asher did not return a call seeking comment. Mr. Asher, who reported directly to Mr. Mehta, will be replaced by LuAnn Walther, who is being appointed editorial director of Vintage Anchor, and Edward Kastenmeier, who is being named executive editor of the paperback imprint. Both will report to Ms. Messitte.

headline: Germany: Dalai Lama Ends 5-Day Visit
text: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, ended a five-day visit to Germany during which only one government minister agreed to meet with him. Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, the development minister, met with the Dalai Lama, apparently against the wishes of Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier and the leader of the Social Democrats, Kurt Beck. Both had said that no senior party leaders would meet with him. The Dalai Lama ended his visit with a big rally in Berlin at the Brandenburg Gate, the symbol of Germany’s reunification.

headline: Obama Talk on Iranians Draws Fire From McCain
text: CHICAGO  Senator John McCain put Senator Barack Obama on the foreign policy defensive once again Monday, criticizing him here in his hometown for saying Iran did not pose the serious threat to the United States that the Soviet Union once did.

headline: Mother Has Hearing in Polygamy Case
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Texas policy holds that when children are taken from their parents for investigation of abuse, geographic distances should be kept to a minimum to allow supervised visitation.

headline: Chicago Prepares for Trial of R. Kelly
text: CHICAGO  Al Capone was a murderous gangster, but the only way the authorities here could nail him was on charges of income tax evasion.

headline: Man Jailed for Copying Army Secrets
text: A man whose true identity remained unknown was sentenced to prison on Monday for illegally copying military secrets while working as an Arabic translator for the United States Army in Iraq, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said.

headline: With Lottery, Knicks Hope for an Early Victory
text: Donnie Walsh and Mike D’Antoni bring decades of experience, success and credibility to the Knicks. For one night, simple luck will trump all of it.

headline: Landmark Hotel Among Sites Seen as in Peril
text: WASHINGTON  When it opened in 1956, the Statler Hilton Hotel in Dallas was a marvel of modern architecture, its size a tribute to imagination and a booming economy. Now it stands empty, another white elephant on the American landscape.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Barkley Says Gambling Debt Is Paid
text: Charles Barkley said Monday that he had paid the $400,000 he owed the Wynn Resorts in Las Vegas since October and vowed to stop gambling.

headline: Professional Background Screening a Small Price to Pay
text: The candidate for chief financial officer at a fast-growing computer hardware company was forthright about his own money troubles.

text: To the Editor:
