text: WESTERNS

headline: Russia: Plans for a Car Plant
text: PSA Peugeot Citroën, the European carmaker, and a Japanese rival, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have agreed to build sport utility vehicles and midsize cars in Russia, Europe’s fastest-growing major auto market. Peugeot will invest as much as 350 million euros ($543 million) in a plant near Kaluga, 112 miles southwest of Moscow, Christian Streiff, the chief executive, said. The factory will initially make 160,000 vehicles a year, of which 50,000 will be S.U.V.’s, and eventually increase production to 300,000. The Peugeot-Mitsubishi plant will open in 2011, employing 3,000 people, Mr. Streiff said. Peugeot will hold a 70 percent stake, he said.

headline: Older Brain Really May Be a Wiser Brain
text: When older people can no longer remember names at a cocktail party, they tend to think that their brainpower is declining. But a growing number of studies suggest that this assumption is often wrong.

headline: Fossella Is Said to Be Ending Re-election Bid
text: After more than two weeks of damaging and scandal-filled headlines, Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island has decided not to seek another term in Congress, according to several people close to him.

headline: Pursuing Yahoo, Microsoft Shows Need for Web Franchise
text: Two weeks after walking away from takeover talks with Yahoo, Microsoft has made it clear that it still needs to create an Internet powerhouse that could rival Google  and that its interest in Yahoo has not waned.

headline: Excavating the Past to Set the Record Straight
text: CANNES, France  Memory twists and turns, peering into this and that dark corner in Wong Kar-wai’s “Ashes of Time Redux” and Terence Davies’s “Of Time and the City,” two beautiful entries at this year’s Cannes Film Festival. The selections, both screened out of competition, find each director working through the past, with Mr. Wong revisiting one of his older features, the martial-arts fantasia “Ashes of Time” (originally released in 1994) and Mr. Davies returning to Liverpool, the city of his birth and the backdrop for his earlier autobiographical films, including the haunting and haunted “Distant Voices, Still Lives” (1988).

headline: Shares of Bell Canada Drop as a Buyout Deal Unravels
text: OTTAWA  Shares of Bell Canada fell Monday, reflecting unease about the prospects for a proposed $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company.

headline: Fallibility, Wise Men and Politics
text: If the punditocracy is correct  and isn’t it always, which explains why Rudolph W. Giuliani is the likely Republican presidential nominee, John McCain has a one-way ticket to Palookaville, Fred Thompson is renowned as the Republicans’ Energizer bunny and Barack Obama is an interesting but can’t-do candidate  Tuesday could be D-Day for Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Crunching Data in a Hard-Hitting Sport
text: As an astrophysicist, Chuck Bower is consumed by the tiniest particles crashing in space. But gigantic particles crashing into one another spawned his second passion: building a better pro football team.

headline: A Gamble, but What if He Wins?
text: About a month and a half ago, Carl Icahn and I went to dinner at Tse Yang, an upscale Chinese restaurant in Midtown Manhattan. Mr. Icahn, the corporate raider turned activist investor, came blustering through the dimly lit restaurant about 20 minutes late, grabbed one of the waiters  they all know him  and ordered a martini.

headline: The Clarinet, Speaking in Many Voices and Accents
text: When composers look for important voices among the family of wind instruments, they come away, more often than not, with a clarinet. It has many colors. Its acoustical presence makes it a good public speaker. It can sing simply or be complicated on demand. But there is something else: an ambiguous quality, a hint of delicious sourness that says to the listener, “You think I’m playing flat, but I’m not.”

headline: Air Taxis Fly Into Financial Turbulence
text: With fares rising and commercial air service increasingly unreliable for business travelers, Ed Iacobucci figured his plan for an air taxi service would be a no-lose proposition. So why is Mr. Iacobucci shaking his head in frustration?

headline: One Week Later, a Nation Pauses to Share Its Mourning and Grief
text: MIANYANG, China  In a day of fresh tragedy and continuing fear, the nation observed an official period of silence on Monday to mourn the tens of thousands of earthquake victims.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Friday about habitual stops on people’s drives to their weekend houses referred incorrectly to one popular place, Perry’s Nut House in Belfast, Me. Though it did close in 1997, it has since reopened.

headline: With Eased Parking Rules, New Worries in Park Slope
text: The indefinite suspension of alternate-side parking rules in Park Slope, Brooklyn, took effect on Monday, and residents and drivers greeted the change with a mix of reactions: joy, astonishment, apprehension, confusion and  yes, one has to admit it  a bit of the self-importance for which the neighborhood is sometimes criticized.

headline: Kenny Chesney Honored but Upset
text: No sooner had the Academy of Country Music handed out its awards on Sunday than Kenny Chesney, above, objected to the method that gave him his fourth straight win as entertainer of the year. For the first time in the show’s 43 years, its foremost accolade, traditionally decided by academy members, was determined in an online vote by the public. Backstage on Sunday night, Mr. Chesney said that although he favored the inclusion of fans, he did not think they should determine the academy’s most important award, The Associated Press reported. He emphasized that his criticism was directed at the industry, not the fans, and said that this year’s voting method amounted to “complete disrespect” of the artists, turning the award “into a sweepstakes to see who can push people’s buttons the hardest on the Internet.” The academy did not immediately respond to messages seeking comment. At the ceremony in Las Vegas, Brad Paisley was named top male vocalist and Carrie Underwood top female vocalist, both for the second consecutive time. Honors for vocal group went to Rascal Flatts (six in a row) and for vocal duo to Brooks & Dunn (13 in a row).

headline: Regina Kellerman, 84, Locator of New York’s First City Hall, Dies
text: Regina Kellerman, an architectural historian whose research led to the literal unearthing of New York City’s first City Hall, died on May 13 in Mount Vernon, N.Y. She was 84 and lived in Greenwich Village, the neighborhood in Manhattan where much of her work was focused and about whose buildings she may have known more than anyone else.

headline: Ice Dwellers Are Finding Less Ice to Dwell On
text: Nobody knows how many walruses the world holds. Recent surveys by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and others put the number at roughly 190,000, with the vast majority of walruses in the Pacific half of the Arctic and sub-Arctic Circle and maybe 10 percent in Atlantic waters.

headline: The Eve of Kentucky and Oregon
text: Senator Barack Obama visited Montana on Monday, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton pressed her case in Kentucky.

headline: The Tempelhof Airport
text: Michael Kimmelman writes: Sometimes you can read a city though a cultural landmark. Tempelhof Airport is Berlin's open book.

headline: Colombia: Rebel Commander Surrenders
text: A woman who was a senior commander in the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, has surrendered after almost two decades of guerrilla activity. Nelly Ávila Moreno, who used the nom de guerre Karina, turned herself in to the army in the latest setback for the FARC, Colombia's largest rebel group. Four other senior commanders were killed in the past year. Ms. Ávila had been accused of taking part in the killing of President Álvaro Uribe's father in the early 1980s, a claim she denied at a news conference in Bogotá, the capital. "My hands are not dirty with that crime," she said.

headline: Yemen: Judge Orders Suspect Held
text: A Yemeni judge has ordered the detention of Jaber Elbaneh, a Yemeni- American accused in terrorist plots who had been living free despite a $5 million American bounty on his head. American prosecutors won the indictment of Mr. Elbaneh in 2003, accusing him of being part of a group of young men from Lackawanna, N.Y., who had traveled to Afghanistan to train at a camp of Al Qaeda. Mr. Elbaneh, 41, was convicted last fall of conspiring to blow up oil installations in Yemen. He had been allowed to remain free during his appeal, which angered American authorities. While a judge ordered his detention on Sunday, it was not clear on Monday whether he had in fact been detained.

headline: Nigeria: Senator Faces Graft Charge
text: A Nigerian senator who is the daughter of a former president has turned herself in to authorities to face charges that she accepted a kickback from the government’s Health Ministry. The senator, Iyabo Obasanjo- Bello, had been sought for weeks by investigators who have accused lawmakers of having accepted cash from government officials in exchange for approving inflated budgets, which were then looted. Ms. Obasanjo-Bello is the daughter of Olusegun Obasanjo, who stepped down last year after two terms as Nigeria’s president.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 101 Minnesota
text: Location: Minneapolis

headline: Music and Milan
text: A look at an apartment owned by the opera singer Madelyn Renee.

headline: $5 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in Georgia, Illinois and California.

headline: Game Ball to Gregg Easterbrook
text: Gregg Easterbrook, who writes ESPN’s Tuesday Morning Quarterback, deserves credit for writing presciently about the Patriots’ spying scandal back in September, when it was less clear how far-reaching it would be.It’s worth revisiting two of his early columns:

headline: Getting the Most Out of Vegetables
text: What is the best way to cook vegetables? It’s one of the most common questions asked by readers, so I decided to explore whether boiled, steamed, microwaved or raw is better.

headline: Aquiline to Introduce New Commercial Finance Firm
text: Aquiline Capital Partners, the private equity firm run by former Marsh & McLennan chief Jeffrey Greenberg, will announce Tuesday that it has formed a new commercial finance firm with more than $1.75 billion in equity commitments.

headline: Chongqing Machinery Seeks $200 Million in I.P.O.
text: China’s Chongqing Machinery and Electric has launched pre-marketing for a Hong Kong listing that is expected to raise about $200 million.

headline: Permira Adds Executive
text: Permira Advisers has hired Riccardo Ruggiero, Telecom Italia‘s former chief executive, to help it find technology, media and telecommunications investments.

headline: Central China Real Estate Begins I.P.O. Roadshow
text: Central China Real Estate has kicked off the institutional roadshow for its upcoming I.P.O. The offering could become the first successful Hong Kong listing of a Chinese property company in more than six months, Finance Asia reported.

headline: How Lionel Found Light at Tunnel’s End
text: Lionel LLC, the toy train maker, recently pulled out of a three-and-a-half-year stop in bankruptcy protection. The company’s chief executive tells Investment Dealers’ Digest that, given a few more years and the right conditions, an initial public offering might be in the cards.

headline: Citi Could Slash 650 U.K. Jobs
text: Citigroup will close two of its British personal loan operations and could cut more than 650 jobs, the bank said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Plan Job Cuts in Japan
text: Morgan Stanley is cutting as many as 25 jobs at its Japan real estate securitization unit. This marks the second round of reductions this year, Bloomberg News reported citing two unnamed sources.

headline: Riding the Vespa S
text: I’ve always thought that driving in New York City is a bit like a game of touch football between the Jets and the Giants — you’re always seconds away from a painful collision, but for the most part you don’t get clobbered. Getting through a traffic jam on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is a game of inches. So even though I’m a fan of almost anything with a motor and two wheels, I was a bit skeptical about venturing onto the city streets aboard the Vespa S. After touring through Manhattan and Brooklyn on a group ride for journalists, though, I found myself persuaded that scooters are extremely useful for basic city transport — at least when the weather is cooperative.

headline: Esmark Union Says It Will Fight Essar Deal
text: The United Steelworkers union has announced it will fight Esmark‘s sale to India’s Essar Steel.

headline: Former AOL Executives Sued in Ad-Revenue Case
text: In a reminder that the wreckage of the disastrous merger between America Online and Time Warner is still being sifted, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed fraud charges against eight former AOL executives, saying they had inflated online advertising revenue by more than $1 billion.

headline: Xojet Soars With $2.5 Billion In Fourth Round
text: Private jet operator Xojet has secured $2.5 billion in a fourth round of funding to help expand its fleet of 20 planes to 127 by 2012.

headline: Biotech’s Banner Year
text: Biotechnology firms in the United States drew a record $5.5 billion in venture-capital funding in 2007, according to Ernst & Young’s annual report card on the industry. But the sector may not be immune from broader economic ills.

headline: San Fancisco Seeks Closer V.C. Ties to China
text: San Francisco’s Bay Area Council is forging deeper links with China and billionaire developer Vincent Lo, reported The San Francisco Business Times.

headline: EADS Looking for U.S. Acquisitions, Chief Says
text: European Aeronautic, Defence & Space is seeking acquisitions in the U.S. to increase its presence in the world’s largest military market, its chief executive said according to Bloomberg News.

headline: A.I.G. to Raise $20 Billion Via Various Offerings
text: American International Group will end up raising about $20 billion by selling a variety of securities, much more than the insurer originally planned, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Bidders Said to Circle Huawei’s Handset Unit
text: AT&T and Vodafone may be circling China’s Huawei, according to media reports cited by CNet’s News.com.

headline: Apollo-Backed Metals USA Files for I.P.O.
text: Metals USA Holdings, a metal processing company owned by Apollo Management, filed to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Deutsche Bank Adds Executive to Private Wealth Unit
text: Deutsche Bank‘s private wealth management said Monday that it has appointed Anurag Mahesh as head of global investments and sales for Asia-Pacific, Finance Asia reported.

headline: Carlyle, Blackstone Miffed at Bankrupt Homebuilder
text: Carlyle Group and Blackstone Group‘s GSO Capital hedge fund say they’re being left out in the cold in the case of a bankrupt homebuilder that they claim fraudulently obtained a credit line designed to keep it afloat, The New York Post reported.

headline: Middle East Private Equity Looks to India
text: Middle East investors are increasingly turning their attention to India, drawn by the country’s long-term growth prospects and the belief that is somewhat “decoupled” from the woes of the United States, according to a report in BusinessWeek. Private equity participation is set to come to sectors such as real estate, health care, retailing and education, the article said.

headline: Barclays Is Said to Consider Buying a Rival
text: Barclays is considering a takeover bid for a rival investment bank, The Telegraph reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Bob Diamond, the head of Barclays’ investment bank unit, is thought to have looked at both Lehman Brothers and UBS  in the past few weeks.

headline: Details of Microsoft’s Yahoo Search Offer Emerge
text: Under its latest proposal to Yahoo, Microsoft would buy its search business and take a stake in the company, The New York Times reported Tuesday, citing people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: Midmarket Lender Gets $425 Million
text: American Capital Strategies and Autobahn Funding Company have committed a combined $425 million to Core Business Credit, a new commercial finance firm dedicated to middle-market transactions in the United States.

headline: ’14 Tons of Double-Stuffed Oreo Cookies’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Wachovia Takes Hit in Citi Hedge Fund
text: Wachovia said on Monday it has had significant losses from a Citigroup hedge fund, Reuters reported. The North Carolina bank is one of at least three that has been hit hard by the decline in the Falcon Strategies hedge fund.

headline: Buffett’s Shopping Trip to Europe Draws a Crowd
text: Warren E. Buffett may be one of the few Americans who can still afford to come to Europe for a shopping spree.

headline: Owner of Bill Blass Faces Cash Squeeze After Deal
text: The fast-growing buyout firm that owns the fashion house Bill Blass, the retailer Athlete’s Foot and the ice cream chain MaggieMoo’s appears to be on the verge of collapse, The New York Times reported.

headline: ResCap Says Investors Support Debt Buyback
text: Residential Capital, the distressed mortgage-finance company, said it has enough support from bondholders to proceed with its offer to exchange or buy back $14 billion of debt in an attempt to stave off bankruptcy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Yo, Six-Pack
text: Beer commercial hits the campaign trail:

headline: Carlyle’s Rubenstein Sees Uptick in Buyouts
text: Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein suggested that private equity investment activity has hit a “bottom” and said he expects to see more deals close in the $2 billion to $4 billion range.
From The Onion:

headline: Icahn’s Big Yahoo Wager
text: Carl C. Icahn prides himself on his poker-playing skills. But he may have just made one of the biggest gambles of his career as he tries to shake up Yahoo.

headline: Banks Keep Write-Downs Off Income Statements
text: Wall Street banks and securities firms aren’t owning up to billions of dollars of write-downs on their income statements, instead taking those losses on their balance sheets, Bloomberg News reported. The accounting treatment, used by Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and ING, is perfectly legitimate, but could just be delaying the inevitable.

headline: ‘The Office’ — The Japanese ‘Original’
text: From “Saturday Night Live”:

headline: Troubles Prompt Franklin Bank to Ponder a Sale
text: Franklin Bank, the Texas bank led by mortgage bond pioneer Lewis Ranieri, may seek a buyer after an internal probe of lending practices led to the removal of its chief executive and sparked an inquiry by federal regulators, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Paterson Is Hospitalized for Migraine Symptoms
text: Updated, 2:15 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson checked into a Manhattan hospital this morning — his 54th birthday — after feeling symptoms of a migraine headache. It was at least the third time the governor has been hospitalized in recent years. (Doctors have now given him a diagnosis of acute glaucoma in his left eye, which will require a medical procedure today.)

headline: Parmalat Suit Against Citi to Begin This Week
text: More than four years after the meltdown of Italy’s Parmalat, the food company is set to begin presenting its case to a U.S. jury on Thursday accusing Citigroup of playing a key role in its collapse, Reuters reported.

headline: The Early Word: Pledged Delegates Likely to Tip Obama
text: Voters in Kentucky and Oregon will likely give Barack Obama enough pledged delegates tonight to give him a majority of the delegates awarded through the nominating contests — which could cause more undeclared superdelegates to jump off the fence and support him as well.

headline: Clinton’s Louisville Remarks
text: The following is a transcript of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s remarks to supporters on the night of the Kentucky and Oregon primaries, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

headline: Obama’s Remarks in Des Moines
text: The following is a transcript of Senator Barack Obama’s remarks to supporters on the night of the Kentucky and Oregon primaries, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

headline: White House Complains About NBC’s Edit of Bush Interview
text: An aide to President Bush sent a letter on Monday to the head of NBC News requesting a correction for what he deemed “deceitful editing” of an interview and complaining about the blurring of the lines between news on NBC and opinion on its cable news network MSNBC.

headline: The Irish Priest in the Kenyan Highlands
text: ITEN, Kenya – At 6 each morning, the runners appear in groups, three here, five there, dressed in jackets and tights against the chill at 8,000 feet, as many as 500 of them training along red dirt roads that undulate through the farms of this rural village.

headline: Fossella Won’t Seek Re-election
text: After more than two weeks of damaging and scandal-filled headlines, Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island has decided not to seek another term in Congress, Jonathan P. Hicks reports, citing several people close to the congressman. Mr. Fossella, 43, has been the object of intense scrutiny since he was arrested in a Washington suburb on May 1 and charged with drunken driving. A week after his arrest, Mr. Fossella, the only Republican representing New York City in Congress, disclosed that he had been on the way to visit Laura Fay, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel. (See the text of Mr. Fossella’s letter to his constituents and supporters.)

headline: King As He Was
text: King me: Eugene Robinson, in his column for The Washington Post, says he likes the memorial statue of Martin Luther King Jr. that the United States Commission of Fine Arts wants reworked.

headline: ‘Law & Order’ Finale: From Spitzer Headlines?
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Two Chinese Friends, RIP
text: China is full of mourning these days because of the Sichuan earthquake, generating a civic and philanthropic response that has been stirring to watch.  That’s probably what I’m going to write about for Thursday: Suggestions welcome for what the quake response says about China’s evolution.

headline: Raining on Ranieri
text: There are strange things happening down in Texas, at Franklin Bank, the lender that was started by Lew Ranieri, the man who is credited with starting the mortgage securitization business. It seems that the bank has been, well, ignoring, a lot of losses.

headline: Big Brown Racing Beyond Belmont?
text: Rick Dutrow says he’d like to see Big Brown race beyond the Belmont and in the Travers Stakes, or the Midsummer Derby, and the Breeders’ Cup Classic, where the reigning Horse of the Year Curlin could await.

headline: Text of Fossella’s Letter to Constituents
text: In the end, Representative Vito J. Fossella’s announced his decision to abandon his re-election campaign not at a news conference in his district, but by placing a letter on his Congressional and campaign Web sites. The letters first appeared early this morning.

headline: And That Thing in the Wall Is Called a Phone Jack
text: New York City is lucky that it doesn’t face blackouts with the regularity of India or South Africa. Still we should be prepared. Power failures come and go in New York City. There are solidarity-building blackouts, historically scarring blackouts and blackouts that seem to go on forever (yet the power company only offers a meager $100 per household).

headline: Your Dot: Meet the Neighbors
text: Meet Wang Suya, a Dot Earth comment contributor who is originally from Mongolia but now lives in Japan and has been a frequent and interesting voice here. UPDATE 5/21: Meet Elizabeth Tjader, too. UPDATE 5/22: Meet Robert Verdi. UPDATE 7/2: Meet Jeff Huggins.UPDATE 8/11: Meet Paul Horan. UPDATE 5/17/09, Meet Danny Bloom (below).

headline: Analyst Sees More Pain Ahead for Banks
text: James Dimon, the head of the banking giant JPMorgan Chase, recently estimated that the credit crunch was about 75 percent over. But Meredith Whitney, the head of equity research at Oppenheimer, believes that it will extend well into 2009 and perhaps beyond that.

headline: Reactions: Defusing a Koran Shooting in Iraq
text: By all accounts, the United States military acted with great speed after one of its soldiers used a Koran for target practice in Iraq. But was it the right response?

headline: A Country Voice on Rural Voters
text: With Kentucky in play today, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton likely to win that state with its sizable swath of rural voters, we asked Dave “Mudcat” Saunders, a Democratic strategist from Roanoke, Va., to talk about this segment of the electorate and its importance to the 2008 campaigns.

headline: The Long and Short of Health
text: BRIEFS In a pair of health headlines today, the World Health Organization reiterated that most people die from well-known conditions — heart disease, stroke and diseases from malaria to tuberculosis — while the National Institutes of Health unveiled an effort to ferret out lesser known ones. The Undiagnosed Diseases Program will tackle “the most puzzling medical cases,” according to a news release cited by Wired Science.

headline: Lester’s Story Keeps Getting Better
text: Red Sox fans have to feel good about their young starting pitchers. While the Yankees’ Ian Kennedy (0-3) continues to struggle, and Phil Hughes (0-4) remains on the shelf, the Red Sox’ Jon Lester pitched a no-hitter Monday night against the Kansas City Royals, just eight months after another young Boston starter, Clay Buchholz, no-hit the Baltimore Orioles on September 1, 2007.

headline: Looking Back At TV’s Dead List
text: Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post asks: “Where Are The Shows Of Yesteryear?”

headline: Is MSNBC a Political Liability to NBC?
text: Monday’s letter from the White House aide Ed Gillespie to the NBC News president Steve Capus was a high-profile complaint about NBC News and MSNBC — ­ but it was far from the first.

headline: Oil Tycoon Follows Icahn Into Yahoo
text: Boone Pickens is probably best known for his big bets on oil and gas. But the Texas billionaire, who celebrates his 80th birthday this week, said Tuesday that he has put a few chips down on Yahoo, the Internet company that is the unwilling object of Microsoft‘s affections.

headline: They Eat Horses There, Don’t They?
text: This is a touchy subject, so allow me to start with a disclaimer: I live in France, I love living in France, and I do not eat horse meat — and neither do 82 percent of the people who live here.

headline: Flight of the Phoenix
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Planning a Family Trip to Greece
text: I am planning a visit to Greece with our two boys (14, 10) this summer and would like to visit both cultural and historical sites. Keeping the boys in mind, I would also like to spend several days on the beach for some swimming or snorkeling. Can you recommend an itinerary for a 10 day visit? Should we attempt to visit islands on the Aegean on our own or join a tour?

headline: Recipe of the Day: Sautéed Red Snapper With Rhubarb Sauce
text: Like most people, when I see rhubarb I usually think ”pie” and leave it at that. Which is a shame, because rhubarb can be a truly interesting ingredient — deliciously sour, unexpectedly smooth, beautifully pale pink on the plate, and totally seasonal.

headline: Lacrosse: Four Left Standing
text: Your full-service Quad lacrosse contributor here. Not only do I provide game previews and reviews, flawed predictions and lame cracks about The Quad’s writers and editors, but I also got to drive Mr. Pete Thamel back and forth to the N.C.A.A. quarterfinals last weekend in Annapolis, Md. He even made me fetch him pizza in the press box at Navy Marine Corps Stadium.

headline: Snapper of the Sassy
text: The photographer Nikola Tamindzic is known for capturing images of both the celebrities and mere mortals of New York City night life.

headline: Hitting the Books, Beachside
text: Students at Kingsborough Community College lounge waterside between classes. Video  by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Frankfurt, Wine and the Rheingau
text: If you are anywhere near Frankfurt, be sure to take some time out for the wine in the Rheingau.

headline: ‘Couldn’t Be More Out of Touch’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton still campaigning hard. In a speech this weekend that she just gave, Hillary Clinton said that John McCain “couldn’t be more out of touch.” Yeah. Yeah, then Hillary said, “Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m about to win the Democratic nomination.”

headline: On the Q.T. | Taavo Somer
text: On the QT is a travel questionnaire for stylish globe trotters. Here New York-based restaurateur, nightlife nabob and men’s wear designer Taavo Somer gives us his answers. As the co-owner of Freemans, Freemans Sporting Club and his latest, the Rusty Knot — a down home version of Trader Vic’s — Somer doesn’t get to pencil in too many vacation days. While he’s chowed down on fugu in Tokyo and counts Villa D’Este in Lake Como, Italy as one of his favorite hotels, the king of unkempt cool typically prefers old-school America.

headline: ‘When Will It Be Over?’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: I’m trying not to be too depressed about this, but how about the price of gasoline in this country? You know what they’re saying now? By Labor Day, it will probably be $20 a gallon.

headline: ‘A Gold Lamé Thong’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Thank you for coming out on such a hot day. It was so hot, Hillary Clinton became delusional, began claiming she could win the White House. I’m sorry, that’s the regular Hillary.

headline: The Starting Line: Beware of Greeks Bearing Banned Substances
text: Looks like no medals in store for Greek weightlifters at Beijing this year, given the high unlikeliness that the team will show up there after a Greek prosecutor filed misdemeanor charges today against 11 of the weightlifting team’s 14 athletes, as well as team coaches and doctors.

headline: Retail Shareholders Shun the Ballot Box
text: Voters have turned out in droves this primary season, thanks in part to a hotly contested race between Democratic contenders Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. But the exact opposite trend is being seen among mom-and-pop shareholders, whose already low voting rate has plunged during this spring’s proxy season.

headline: The Morning Skate: I Was Told There Would Be No Math
text: So here are the Pittsburgh Penguins relaxing last night at home. They don’t care much about the upcoming primaries, who’s got how many delegates in which states with what amount of electoral votes or the proportions of committed vs. uncommitted super-delegates. This is no time for numbers.

headline: A-Rod Returns to the Yankees Lineup
text: It will be interesting to see what kind of reception Alex Rodriguez receives when he returns to the lineup for the Yankees at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night. Since the Yankees have struggled mightily to score runs, most fans will surely stand and welcome Rodriguez. Heck, the Yankees offense has been so hollow that some fans might feel compelled to bow.

headline: About Tom Kuntz
text: Tom Kuntz has been a New York Times journalist for more than 20 years. He was a foreign editor during the collapse of communism and the first gulf war. At the Sunday Week in Review, his Word for Word columns of verbatim excerpts led to two books, “The Titanic Disaster Hearings” (Pocket Books, 1998) and “The Sinatra Files” (Three River Press, 2000). After 9/11, he produced Times television documentaries for Discovery about rebuilding ground zero. As a special projects editor, he helped edit “Class Matters,” a series about social class in America. As pop music editor, he started New York Times Popcast, a podcast. After returning to the Week in Review in 2007, he started the Laugh Lines and Idea of the Day blogs.

headline: Kennedy Has Malignant Brain Tumor
text: Tests performed over the weekend at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston indicated that Senator Edward M. Kennedy, 76, has a type of cancer known as a malignant glioma in the left parietal lobe, the upper left portion of his brain.

headline: ‘Endangered’ Lower East Side? What’s New, Some Ask
text: Updated, 3 p.m. | This morning, in a news conference at Seward Park High School, the National Trust for Historic Preservation designated the Lower East Side of Manhattan as one of the 11 most endangered in places in America. But for some people, the designation only makes explicit the obvious: that the wide swath of Manhattan long known for its immigrant communities and counter-cultural vibe has long ago given way to rampant real estate development and gentrification.

headline: McCain Now Hammers Obama on Cuba
text: MIAMI — Senator John McCain used a speech here marking Cuban independence day in a critical swing state to continue to hammer Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy.

headline: Worst-Named Horses
text: A few years back, on a cold November day, a friend and I were negotiating a sloppy Belt Parkway on our way to Aqueduct to test our acumen in a handicapping contest at the Big A, the $25,000 grand prize dangling like a larded leg of prosciutto in front of us. Brom was the designated driver, I the annoying right-side passenger, when I slipped into a familiar routine, doing what I had done any number of times when I took the subway back from the Big A or got on the pokey Long Island Railroad train from Belmont, having forgotten to pack along some “reading material” to kill the time on the journey back: That is, I got my kicks by gleaning the past performances of the horses at tracks we rarely if ever handicapped — Evangeline and Emerald, Fort Erie and Fairmount and Fairplex.

headline: Bill Clinton: ‘Dumb Politics’ to Discount Fla. and Michigan
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. – Bill and Hillary Clinton dropped by Lynn’s Paradise Café, a cutesy diner near downtown, for an election-day photo op Tuesday morning.

headline: Is Sudan Collapsing Into War at Abyei?
text: One of the great foreign policy risks right now is that Sudan’s north-south war will start up again. The last round of that war killed more than 2 million people, and the next round would be just as deadly. My fear is that the Darfur conflict will be remembered just as the prologue to an even bloodier war that engulfs all of Sudan.

headline: Watching a No-No: Reporters Not Allowed
text: When I tell people I cover baseball for a living, they inevitably ask me to name my favorite team. I tell them that I don’t have a favorite team anymore but, as a reporter, I root for great stories and deadline-friendly games.

headline: The Insider | Tim Hamilton
text: The Insider is a profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. In this installment, the men’s wear designer Tim Hamilton shares a few of his stylish essentials with The Moment. Hamilton, a veteran of Ralph Lauren and J.Crew, is a self-proclaimed “one-man show” who is nominated for the Swarovski Award for Men’s wear from the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA). The CFDA winners will be announced June 2nd. Whatever happens, Hamilton’s fans have plenty to look forward to: he’s launching a tailoring line this fall and a range of men’s accessories next year.

headline: Marilyn Einstein
text: Some people look better the farther you get from them (this is also true in watering holes the closer it is to closing time, but that’s another story). Back away from your screen 10 feet or so. See?

headline: Reconsidering Orientalism
text: Robert Irwin’s re-assessment of the legacy of Edward Said, 30 years after the publication of “Orientalism” and five years after Said’s death, is quite interesting — even if it has that very British (or very TLS) tendency to drop very obscure names as if everyone knows what he’s talking about. For instance, in Irwin’s view, “Said was utterly oblivious to the humour and stylishness of Alexander Kinglake’s ‘Eothen.’” Hmmm. Some quick googling shows that Kinglake, an Englishman, traveled to the Levant in the 19th century. And through Project Gutenberg you can even download the entire book. Irwin is the TLS’s Middle East editor, and has also written a cute book on the Alhambra.

headline: Drogba, Full of Love
text: As go Frank Lampard and Didier Drogba, so goes Chelsea. The twosome is responsible for 34 goals this season, almost a third of the Blues’ total. And Drogba, the dynamic Ivorian striker, has been particularly potent in Europe, netting six Champions League goals and persistently threatening Chelsea’s opponents (he has 21 shots on goal).

headline: Making Reading Easier
text: Publishers Weekly has a fascinating article this week about large print books, and it seems that size isn’t all that matters anymore.

headline: 3 Banks Open Up Their ‘Dark Pools’
text: Three major brokerage firms said on Tuesday they will start letting their clients access each other’s “dark pools” — trading systems which keep buyers and sellers anonymous — to increase chances of trading orders being filled.

headline: Smoking on Staten Island Falls, at Last
text: After years as an exception in the citywide smoking decline that began in 2002, Staten Island’s smoking rate is finally falling, officials announced today.The smoking rate on the borough fell by 25 percent, or 22,000 residents, according to the city’s annual Community Health Survey. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Health Commissioner Thomas R. Frieden and the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn announced the decline at a news conference, joined by Borough President James P. Molinaro and representatives of Coalition for a Smoke Free City and the American Cancer Society.

headline: A Beaujolais Maker’s Pain
text: If you have been so unfortunate to have suffered a hangover – and honestly, who hasn’t — then you might enjoy  “A Few Too Many’’ by Joan Acocella in the May 26th issue of The New Yorker.

headline: Why the Roku Netflix Player Is the First Shot of the Revolution
text: In the small, generic plastic box that is the new Netflix Player made by Roku, I think you can see the future of video.

headline: On the Front Lines in Sadr City
text: On May 10, the photographer Robert Nickelsberg embedded with American troops from the Third Brigade Combat Team, Fourth Infantry Division, in Baghdad’s Sadr City, where the American-backed Iraqi Army and the Mahdi Army militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr had been fighting for more than a month. The day his embed started, there was news of progress: The Iraqi government reached a truce with the Mahdi militia in a deal brokered with help from Iran. But the fighting  did not immediately stop.

headline: Microsoft’s Yahoo-less Advertising Conference
text: When Microsoft invited its advertising customers for an annual gathering in Seattle a year ago, one of the main attractions was Terry Semel, who was then the chief executive of Yahoo. News that Microsoft and Yahoo had held discussions about a possible merger leaked before the event, and everyone was hoping to find out more.

headline: In Wreckers’ Wake, a 170-Year-Old Church Re-emerges
text: As the city ceaselessly rebuilds itself for the future, a veil is sometimes lifted on the past. Small artifacts or brawny foundations may be unearthed. Old billboards will come to back to light as buildings are demolished in front of them. Best of all, an entire vista can open on a long-overlooked landmark for the first time in generations.

headline: Hurricanes, Citizenship, and the Makings of an Unnatural Disaster
text: People in the Rio Grande Valley, on the southern tip of Texas, were rattled last week by reports that the federal government was planning to do something very, very stupid the next time a hurricane came bearing down.

headline: UTC Chief Says Diebold Isn’t a ‘Must-Have’
text: United Technologies‘ new chief executive sent what appeared to be a show across Diebold‘s bow: Release your financial information, or the conglomerate will walk away from its $2.6 billion unsolicited offer.

headline: Japan: ‘A Full-Fledged Aged Society’
text: Nearly two years after Japan laid claim to the world’s highest elderly ratio, the country has hit another milestone.

headline: This Year’s Finales Are Drawing Fewer Viewers Than Last Year
text: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted Monday’s largest audience, with 18.8 million viewers tuning in for the show’s final performances of the season, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Like most network television shows this spring, ratings for the final episode were down compared with last year: the same episode of “Dancing” drew 20.2 million viewers in 2007.

headline: Rethinking Video-on-Demand
text: Video-on-demand, which has mostly been associated with movies and premium programming, has been getting a second look.

text: Most of us don’t know Senator Edward M. Kennedy personally. But news that the longtime senator has been diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor has hit many people particularly hard.

text: City officials seem awfully meddlesome with our weight these days. First Philadelphia challenged its residents to lose 76 tons in 76 days. Then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thought it was a good idea to remind us how many calories we consume each time we go to Starbucks.

text: Big Brown is off to Three Chimneys with a $50 million valuation.

headline: Live Blogging the Kentucky, Oregon Races
text: 11:25 p.m. | Wrap Up:  One big message from the night: Senator Clinton is increasingly playing the gender card to make her case. Her speech showed that her message is partly aspirational, that she is fighting to break the highest and hardest glass ceiling. It is also based in sexism, she says, that misogyny is alive and well in 21st Century America.

headline: Tech is Back
text: For the first time since 2002, when technology stocks were descending from the great bubble, tech shares are again the largest group in the Standard & Poor’s 500.

headline: Clinton-Happy in Kentucky
text: Hillary Clinton has been declared the winner of the Democratic presidential primary in Kentucky, and some of her surrogates — including Terry McAuliffe in an interview with MSNBC’s Chris Matthews — are suggesting that the undeclared superdelegates are ready to break in her favor. The Atlantic’s Marc Ambinder doesn’t buy it. He writes at A Reported Blog on Politics, his blog for the magazine:

headline: U.S. Announces Roster for England Game
text: Bob Bradley, the coach of the United States men’s national team, will take only three M.L.S. players — Landon Donovan (Los Angeles), Ricardo Clark (Houston) and Brad Guzan (Chivas USA) — to England for next Wednesday’s international friendly at Wembley Stadium.

headline: The E-Mail That Shouldn’t Have Been Sent
text: We’ve all done it – hit the send button when we shouldn’t have – or cc’ed a person by accident, and there is a terrific post on The Times’s Freakonomics blog inviting readers to share their worst experiences with e-mail that shouldn’t have been sent. A follow-up post directs readers to Think Before You Send, the Web site for the book, “Send,” written by the Times’s Op-ed editor David Shipley and Will Schwalbe, the former editor of Hyperion Books.

headline: X-Rays on Jeter’s Hand Are Negative
text: When Derek Jeter was plunked in the left hand by Daniel Cabrera’s fastball in the third inning, it did not sound good. The sound of the ball colliding with the bones in Jeter’s hands was harsh and had to concern the Yankees.

headline: Hillary Clinton Presses On
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton addresses her supporters after winning the Kentucky primary. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Why Not Closer in Kentucky?
text: Did Barack Obama’s campaign make a mistake by not campaigning in Kentucky? The New Republic’s Noam Scheiber thinks so.

headline: After Oregon, Look Out: Ideology Ahead
text: Barack Obama is cruising to victory in Oregon, and he has secured a majority of the pledged delegates – those delegates who are elected in primaries and caucuses – who will attend the Democratic presidential nominating convention this summer. But Ed Kilgore, the managing editor of The Democratic Strategist, thinks Hillary Clinton’s victories in West Virginia and Kentucky are still something for the Obama campaign to worry about. “Obama’s team would be well advised not to completely dismiss the implications of HRC’s recent wins,” Kilgore concludes.

headline: NBC Limping To The TV Season’s End
text: “NBC is limping to the close of the prime-time TV season,” the AP reports. “Only one of the network’s shows, ‘Law & Order: SVU,’ finished among the 25 most-watched shows last week, ranking No. 16, according to Nielsen Media Research. ‘Shark,’ a drama that CBS is canceling, was seen by more people last week than any other NBC show but ‘SVU.'”

headline: Enter, the Cybrids
text: This week, a complex and controversial piece of legislation began to make its way through the British parliament. One of the provisions of the bill permits the creation of “savior siblings” — children created via in vitro fertilization (I.V.F.) to ensure their tissues will match those of a sick older brother or sister, in order that the new child could provide, say, a bone marrow transplant. (Conceiving a child the old-fashioned way doesn’t guarantee a tissue match.) Another is a reduction of the legal time-limit on abortion, which up to now has been 24 weeks.

text: Reuters reports:

headline: Taiwan: New President Seeks Economic Ties to China
text: Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist, took office as president and used his inaugural speech to repeat campaign promises that he would seek closer economic relations with mainland China and an eventual peace accord. He also reiterated that he would not seek political reunification with the mainland. Prosecutors said they would investigate whether the departing president, Chen Shui-bian, had misappropriated money from his presidential expenses fund. Mr. Chen has denied wrongdoing.

headline: Treats for the Treasure Hunters
text: THE rumors of huaraches were greatly exaggerated (or at least premature), but they lured me to Brownstoner’s Brooklyn Flea as if I were a cartoon hobo drawn to a pie on the windowsill.

headline: Lawyer and N.B.A. Are Trading Insults
text: SECAUCUS, N.J.  While the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy awaits his fate in federal court, his lawyer and league officials are trading insults and accusations through the courts and the news media.

headline: Medicare’s Much-Too-Hard Sell
text: The Bush administration has proposed welcome new regulations to curb the deceptive, hard-sell tactics often used to foist private Medicare policies on unwary consumers. Unfortunately, it has been unwilling to eliminate the root cause of the problem: the high subsidies that prop up these plans and make them so attractive to high-pressure marketers.

headline: Grilled Spring Onions With Romesco Sauce
text: Time: 30 minutes using microwave, about 1 hour if not

headline: ‘Barbecued’ Brisket
text: Time: About 3 hours

headline: Regal Plans to Add 3-D Movie Screens
text: The Regal Entertainment Group, the world’s largest cinema operator, has reached an agreement to equip 1,500 screens to show three-dimensional films.

headline: Obama Says Nomination ‘Within Reach’
text: DES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday, amassing enough additional delegates to claim an all but insurmountable advantage in his race against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Democrats in Florida Amid Delegate Dispute
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama both made campaign stops on Wednesday in Florida, a state whose Democratic delegates have been blocked from the party convention this summer but whose votes could prove critical in the general election in November.

headline: A Diploma’s Worth? Ask Her
text: Kanye West’s debut album, “The College Dropout,” which came out in 2004, was a concept album. The title referred to Mr. West, then 26 years old and already a successful hip-hop producer. The lyrics pointed out that many of his peers who had finished college weren’t doing nearly so well.

headline: Foster Rules on Medicine Are Key in Child’s Death
text: Foster parents are supposed to check with the foster-care agency before administering even routine medication to children in their care, but the Harlem woman charged Monday with criminally negligent homicide of a 6-year-old girl apparently did not do so before placing a strong medicinal patch on her injured neck or giving her Motrin earlier.

headline: A Discomfiting Threat to Free Speech
text: The Supreme Court upheld a law on Monday that sweeps too broadly in its attempt to ban child pornography, which is repellent and illegal. Those who traffic in it must be punished, but this law is drawn in a way that also criminalizes speech that should be protected by the First Amendment.

headline: In Study, Researchers Find Nanotubes May Pose Health Risks Similar to Asbestos
text: Nanotubes, one of the wonder materials of the new age of nanotechnology, may carry a health risk similar to that of asbestos, a wonder material of an earlier age that turned into a scourge after decades of use when its fibers were found to cause lung disease, researchers said Tuesday.

headline: More Shame on the Junta
text: There is no end to the criminal behavior of Myanmar’s generals. Nearly three weeks after Cyclone Nargis killed more than 100,000 people, the junta’s refusal to open the country to international help is condemning many more thousands to malnutrition, disease and, unless something is done quickly, death.

headline: Cabrito and the Redhead
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Suspect’s Delusions Described to Judge
text: To David Tarloff, everyone, from the prisoner sitting next to him to the guard down the hall to the doctors who examined him, is an undercover detective out to get him, his lawyer said on Tuesday. Mr. Tarloff’s belief is so strong that he is refusing to speak with his lawyer, fearing that the conversation would be overheard. Instead, Mr. Tarloff exchanges notes.

headline: Care for the Disabled
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bulls Win Draft Lottery as the Knicks Slip to 6th
text: SECAUCUS, N.J.  The N.B.A. fates showed an odd sense of humor at the draft lottery Tuesday night when the Chicago Bulls, a team without a coach, won the grand prize: the chance to take point guard Derrick Rose or power forward Michael Beasley with the No. 1 pick.

headline: Markets Drop; Oil Continues Its Surge
text: Stocks ended sharply lower Tuesday on Wall Street, in part on retail earnings and new concerns about inflation.

headline: Virginia Law on Abortion Is Struck Down
text: A federal appeals court panel in Richmond, Va., on Tuesday struck down a Virginia law that made it a crime for doctors to perform what the law called “partial birth infanticide.”

headline: You Can Call for I.T. Help Without Hiring a Whole Crew
text: SMALL-BUSINESS owners often juggle tasks from accounting to finding customers to keeping existing ones happy. But the one task many busy managers avoid is taking care of computers, networks and other technology. Installing software, setting up broadband connections and backing up servers can be time-consuming and complicated.

headline: A Busy Year as Tornadoes Wreak Havoc
text: ATLANTA  At least one Arkansas family already knows that 2008 has been a devastating year for tornadoes.

headline: New President Takes Office in Taiwan
text: A Nationalist, Ma Ying-jeou, took office as Taiwan’s new president on Tuesday and used his inaugural speech to repeat campaign promises to seek closer economic relations with mainland China and an eventual peace accord.

headline: Children’s Cookbooks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seizing the Day in Slippery Times
text: FOR inspiration on getting through an economic slump, Steve Walker, chief executive of Walker Information, goes back to his roots. His grandmother started the market research and consulting firm that he now heads as the Depression was ending in 1939. At the time, his grandfather was working as a teller at a bank that sponsored radio programs. To bring in extra money for the family, his grandmother had the idea of going door to door asking people about their listening habits and sold the survey results to advertising agencies.

headline: The Goal Is to Do the Right Thing
text: TERRACYCLE’S fertilizer is priced the same as its competitors’. It is on the same store shelves, from Home Depot to Wal-Mart. But comparisons stop there.

headline: Obama Declares Bid ‘Within Reach’ After 2 Primaries
text: Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday, amassing enough additional delegates to claim an all but insurmountable advantage in his race against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Airlines’ Cuts Making Cities No-Fly Zones
text: Earlier this decade, city officials in Hagerstown, Md., started making the case to build a longer runway at their airport to lure service by regional jets, instead of the turboprop planes that provided its only flights.

headline: Lottery Numbers
An Oracle of Oil Predicts $200-a-Barrel Crude
text: Arjun N. Murti remembers the pain of the oil shocks of the 1970s. But he is bracing for something far worse now: He foresees a “super spike”  a price surge that will soon drive crude oil to $200 a barrel.

headline: Publishing Outsider Picked to Head Random House
text: After weeks of rumor and speculation, Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, appointed Markus Dohle, the head of its printing unit, to run the company’s Random House division. Peter W. Olson, the current chief executive of Random House and one of the country’s most powerful figures in publishing, is stepping down from the post.

headline: Using the Web to Draw in Crowds
text: NIKI RUSS FEDERMAN feels that her 94-year-old family business, Russ & Daughters on the Lower East Side of New York, is fighting for survival in a retail environment under assault by chain stores and generic tastes.

headline: Rescues Continue in China, but Focus Is Shifting to the 5 Million Left Homeless
text: CHENGDU, China  Eight days after a massive earthquake struck southwest China, the government began to grapple Tuesday with what may be its biggest quandary: what to do with what it says are the five million people left homeless by the disaster.

headline: Correction
text: The column by David Brooks on Tuesday said incorrectly that Senator Barack Obama voted last week for the farm bill. Mr. Obama did not cast a vote on the bill; he supported it.

headline: Hussein Aide Faces Accusers in Trial on Mass Execution
text: BAGHDAD  Tariq Aziz, the diplomat who served as the public face of Saddam Hussein’s government, appeared in court on Tuesday accused of being part of a “systematic campaign” to kill Iraqi merchants. The deaths, prosecutors said, amounted to crimes against humanity.

headline: Jesse Edwards, Pathologist, Dies at 96
text: Dr. Jesse E. Edwards, a leading cardiac pathologist, who assembled a formidable collection of human hearts to let doctors study coronary disease, congenital defects and trauma, died on May 18 in Rochester, Minn. He was 96.

headline: A California of Noir Shadows and Blood
text: CANNES, France  Clint Eastwood has wrangled a number of unruly stars in his long directing career, but somehow he hasn’t been able to do the same with  or for  Angelina Jolie. She’s the lustrous centerpiece of his latest endeavor, “Changeling,” which was shown to a respectful if subdued press audience on Tuesday morning at the Cannes Film Festival. A view of the human beast at its worst, the film is a tricky bit of storytelling business, in part because it involves a true crime with no moral gray areas, in part because it takes place in the 1920s, an era so at odds with its modern star that it’s like watching Joan Crawford do Queen Victoria.

headline: In Milan, a Diva Finds a Home
text: MILAN

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Friday about the contemporary art auction at Phillips de Pury & Company in Manhattan misstated the total sales at the Christie’s auction of postwar and contemporary art earlier last week. Sales totaled $348.2 million, not $438.2 million.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A television column on Friday about “Man vs. Wild,” a show on the Discovery Channel starring Bear Grylls, misstated Mr. Grylls’s original name. He was born Edward Michael Grylls, not Mitchell Winston.

headline: Importing a Spanish Spring
text: RECENTLY at a lunch at the Capafons-Ossó winery in the Priorat region of Spain, I sat with wine experts sipping grenache-and-carignan-based blends. Tasting descriptors dominated the conversation  clove and raspberry, vanilla and coffee, my companions suggested.

headline: Rodriguez Returns; Jeter Leaves Early
text: Mike Mussina threw only 41 pitches Tuesday night before Ross Ohlendorf jogged in from the bullpen to take his place. Mussina got only two outs with those 41 pitches, and any game that Ohlendorf enters in the first inning is quickly disintegrating.

headline: Benefits
text: Downtown Sampler

headline: Report Details Dissent on Guantánamo Tactics
text: WASHINGTON  In 2002, as evidence of prisoner mistreatment at Guantánamo Bay began to mount, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at the base created a “war crimes file” to document accusations against American military personnel, but were eventually ordered to close down the file, a Justice Department report revealed Tuesday.

headline: A Video Game Star and His Less-Than-Stellar Pay
text: Michael Hollick never thought his big break would come in a video game.

headline: Florida: 7-Year Sentence for Imposing Forced Labor
text: A former schoolteacher was sentenced in Fort Lauderdale to more than seven years in prison for forcing a Haitian girl to work as a virtual slave in her home. The defendant, Maude Paulin, told the court at her sentencing that she had made some mistakes while raising Simone Celestin, but she would not admit she held the girl as a forced laborer. Ms. Paulin, 52, along with her mother, Evelyn Theodore, 74, were convicted of conspiring to violate Ms. Celestin’s civil rights and compelling her to perform forced labor. Ms. Theodore’s sentencing was postponed because she suffered a stroke shortly after her sentencing in March. Ms. Celestin told jurors in March she worked 15 hours a day, was sometimes beaten by the women and was forced to eat table scraps. “I love Simone with all my heart,” said Ms. Paulin at the sentencing hearing. “I regret it. I blame myself.”

headline: Iceland: Bond Rating Cut by Moody’s
text: The government of Iceland’s bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moody’s Investors Service on growing concern that the country’s banks may face a credit squeeze. The rating on the foreign currency country ceiling for bank deposits was also reduced one rank to Aa1 from the top level, Moody’s said. Iceland’s banks may encounter “liquidity constraints” because their assets are mostly denominated in foreign currency, according to Moody’s. The move comes four days after Iceland was offered an emergency loan by the central banks of Denmark, Sweden and Norway to support the krona and avert an economic collapse. The offer is evidence that Iceland still has access to funds and that liquidity risk should not be overstated, Moody’s said.

headline: Nearly Deaf Professor Teaches English Literacy, One Student at a Time
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  After three degrees, after five universities, after 40,000 pupils, and after 84 years, 10 months and 25 days, John Kuhlman has circumnavigated his way back to the essentials of education: a teacher and a student in a room.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about sculpture carved from produce misstated the date of an exhibition of photographs of such work by Hugh McMahon. The photographs are on display at the James Beard House, 167 West 12th Street, through May 31; they will not be on view “next month.”

headline: Corrections
text: Editors' Note

headline: Slipping the Knife With Care
text: These knife guards are as practical as they are neon-bright. The guards, which protect the blades in a drawer, also prevent cooks from cutting themselves when searching for the right knife. And they are indispensable for transporting knives to a picnic.

headline: Cooking School Tempest
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Sudden Transfer of 40 Priests Brings Egan Unrest From Within
text: Cardinal Edward M. Egan has reassigned almost 10 percent of the active priests in the Archdiocese of New York without adequately consulting the personnel board that has traditionally advised him and his predecessors, according to members of the board and other clergy familiar with the developments.

headline: U.S. Moves to Prohibit Beef From Sick or Injured Cows
text: The Agriculture Department proposed on Tuesday banning from the food supply all cows that are too sick or injured to walk, a long-sought victory for advocates of animal welfare.

headline: No Sex, Please, This Is Jerusalem
text: Jerusalem, the Holy City, has effectively banned sex. No, not the act but the three-letter word that appears elsewhere in billboard advertising for the new film “Sex and the City.” Sex in the city became an issue when the advertising company Maximedia told the news media that it would not post billboards featuring Sarah Jessica Parker, above, one of the stars, in deference to requests from city officials concerned about “offending public sensitivities” by mentioning “sex,” Agence France-Presse reported. Then the distributor, Forum Films, said that without “sex” there would be no billboards in Jerusalem or Petah Tikva, a town near Tel Aviv that has a large ultra-Orthodox Jewish population. But in other Israeli cities, “sex” in advertising is O.K.

headline: Senator Kennedy Has a Malignant Brain Tumor
text: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, has a malignant brain tumor, his doctors said on Tuesday.

headline: Red Wings and Pistons to Split Screens in Detroit
text: Detroit sports fans will face a rare predicament on Saturday and Monday nights: whether to watch Games 1 and 2 of the Stanley Cup finals between the Red Wings and the Penguins, or Games 3 and 4 of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals between the Pistons and the Celtics.

headline: Biotech Company to Auction Chances to Clone a Dog
text: A California company is planning a string of online auctions next month to clone five dogs, with the bidding to start at $100,000.

headline: More Ball Fields Allowed Despite Voiding of Deal
text: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that the Bloomberg administration can continue to build athletic fields on Randalls Island even though a deal in which private schools had agreed to help pay construction costs was voided by the court earlier this year.

headline: Footnotes
text: Rupert Goold, who staged the hit production of “Macbeth” currently on Broadway at the Lyceum Theater, has been named an associate director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, Variety reported. He will join the company on a full-time basis 2010. ...Projected for Broadway in 2010 is a new musical based in part on a forthcoming memoir by Zindzi Mandela, a daughter of Nelson and Winnie Mandela who grew up under apartheid in South Africa. The show will deal with the struggle for freedom and its leaders. “The freedom songs were so important to the morale of the people,” Zindzi Mandela said in a statement, “so it’s natural for the story to be told with music as a cornerstone.” ... The two-time Tony and Emmy Award winner Bebe Neuwirth is making her nightclub debut at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency with “Stories With Piano,” a show emphasizing the works of Kurt Weill and Kander & Ebb but also saluting Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim and Tom Waits. Ms. Neuwirth, appearing through May 31, will be followed from June 3 to 14 by Tony Danza in a new show, “I Could Have Danced All Night,” and from June 17 to 28 by Liz Callaway, whose show “The Beat Goes On” will be devoted to music of the 1960s. ... Keely Smith, whose honorary titles include Queen of Swing and First Lady of Las Vegas, will make her Birdland debut with performances from June 3 through June 8.

headline: Tying Knots That Bind Lives Despite the Divisions of Generation and Nationality
text: There are six principal characters in “The Edge of Heaven”: two mothers, two daughters, a father and a son, all arranged in more or less symmetrical pairs. In the course of this extraordinary film by the German writer-director Fatih Akin (which won the best screenplay award in Cannes last year) children are lost, lost parents are never found, and generational and geographical distances grow wider.

headline: Poison Moonshine Kills 110 of India’s Poor
text: BANGALORE, India  Venkateshwarappa, a shepherd on the edges of the city, found plastic sachets of it tossed in the bushes. It was moonshine. It was Sunday afternoon. He felt lucky and drank it.

headline: Safety at the Stove
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuba Is Topic as McCain Continues Attack on Obama
text: MIAMI  Senator John McCain took his sharp criticism of Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy to a new venue on Tuesday, using a speech on Cuba here in a critical swing state to again argue that Mr. Obama is too willing to talk to America’s enemies.

headline: On the Road Again? Tricks to Logging On
text: THE Internet may be more accessible than ever, but business travelers often need more than one way to log on to get their e-mail, send and receive files and search the Web for maps, restaurants and other information.

headline: Rodriguez, Unlikely Savior, Is Back to Help
text: When Alex Rodriguez reported for work Tuesday at Yankee Stadium, he did not have an S on his chest, he was not wearing a cape and he was not planning to leap any tall buildings. Rodriguez is a super player, but he is not Superman. He is one man, one very important contributor on a stagnant team.

headline: Once More Unto the Breach (It’s a Rambo World Out There)
text: Many a martial march is heard, but not a single flag is waved in “The Great American All-Star Traveling War Machine,” a revue of songs, sketches and speeches focusing on the history of human conflict at the Theater for the New City.

headline: Iraqi Troops Take Charge of Sadr City in Swift Push
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi troops pushed deep into Sadr City on Tuesday as the Iraqi government sought to establish control over the district, a densely populated Shiite enclave in the Iraqi capital.

headline: ABC's Dancers Draw Eyes
text: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted Monday’s largest audience as 18.8 million viewers tuned in for the show’s final performances of the season at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality competition led its time slot but failed to lift ABC to No. 1 for the night overall as the network’s premiere of “The Bachelorette” struggled from 9 to 11 p.m., averaging 8.8 million viewers. CBS eked out a victory as the night’s most watched network thanks to solid ratings for finales of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 p.m. CBS’s “CSI: Miami” also led the 10 p.m. hour with 16.1 million viewers. Fox, meanwhile, despite a third-place finish in total viewers, ranked second among adults 18 to 49 behind CBS but ahead of ABC, earning the night’s top ratings in that demographic with the finale of “House” at 9 p.m. (16.2 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, drawing just 4 million viewers for “American Gladiators” from 8 to 9:30.

headline: Problems in School May Come From Outside
text: To the Editor:

headline: R. Kelly Jurors Hear Opening Statements
text: Jurors in the child pornography trial of the R&B star R. Kelly, right, were warned on Tuesday by a prosecutor that they would be required to watch a videotape of an “under-age child performing sex acts that you have never seen before.” In an opening statement in Cook County Criminal Court in Chicago, the prosecutor, Shauna Boliker, said, “A child doesn’t choose to be violated and placed on a videotape, a videotape that will live on forever  long after this child becomes an adult,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly, 41, a Grammy Award winner, is accused of videotaping himself having sex with an under-age girl. Prosecutors contend that she was as young as 13 when the recording was made, between Jan. 1, 1998 and Nov. 1, 2000. Both Mr. Kelly and the woman, now 23, deny they are the people on the tape, and one of Mr. Kelly’s lawyers, Sam Adam Jr., told the jurors during his opening statement that the videotape is “at best a copy of a copy” and that Mr. Kelly was not the man on the tape. “Not a single witness can tell you that is him on the tape,” he said. If convicted, Mr. Kelly could face as much as 15 years in prison.

headline: For Many Olympic Families, the Dream Is Proving Costly
text: Peter Fekete is about to retire from his job as a maintenance machinist at a General Motors plant in Wilmington, Del. His wife, Irene, is an administrative assistant at a pharmaceutical company.

headline: ‘The Coffee Was Lousy. The Wait Was Long.’
text: THE Rooz Cafe, a restaurant and coffee shop in Oakland, Calif., signals its distaste for patrons who post reviews on Yelp.com with a small sign: No Yelpers.

headline: In Quake, Apotheosis of Premier ‘Grandpa’
text: CHENGDU, China  He is widely known as “the crying prime minister,” although he prefers to be called “Grandpa Wen.” Over the past week, as Wen Jiabao toured earthquake-shattered towns and cities across northern Sichuan, he has hollered out words of encouragement to those trapped beneath fallen buildings and shared tearful moments with newly orphaned children.

headline: To Thwart TiVo, a Nod to Television’s Golden Age
text: TELEVISION may be the ultimate “green” medium, recycling ideas that go in one era and out the other. NBC, for instance, plans to bring back “Knight Rider” in the fall, and CW is scheduling a new version of “Beverly Hills 90210.”

headline: Operation in Sadr City Is an Iraqi Success, So Far
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi forces rolled unopposed through the huge Shiite enclave of Sadr City on Tuesday, a dramatic turnaround from the bitter fighting that has plagued the Baghdad neighborhood for two months, and a qualified success for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: French Cookies, in Vivid Hues
text: Cécile Cannone’s macarons are not shy. She bakes them in bold, improbable tones of turquoise, chartreuse, burgundy and buttercup yellow, and puts them on bright display at Macaron Cafe, which opened several months ago in the garment district.

headline: New Era Brings Buzz (and Big Budgets) to the Met
text: In his mission to reinvigorate the Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb, who completed his second season as general manager on Saturday night, has inaugurated outreach campaigns and digital-media ventures that are the envy of the opera world. There have been the enormously popular live high-definition transmissions of broadcasts to movie theaters worldwide, and the Met’s lively 24-hour station on Sirius satellite radio. Mr. Gelb has proved a master of marketing and drawn high-profile directors from film and theater into the house.

headline: Pondering a Common Word With One Dreaded Meaning
text: Some words are asked to do too much. “Love” is what you feel for ice cream and your life partner. “God” is a multipurpose interjection or the creator of the universe. In “Depression: Out of the Shadows,” a stark documentary on Wednesday on PBS, Andrew Solomon, who won a National Book Award for his book about depression, makes his own nomination for this grouping.

headline: Genre-Bending Hangout Takes Its Final Bows
text: ALMOST 23 years ago a transplanted young Frenchman named Florent Morellet, the youngest son of the conceptual artist François Morellet, took over a diner named the R & L on Gansevoort Street.

headline: Clinton Still Sees Plenty of Reasons to Press Her Campaign
text: Rebuffing associates who have suggested that she end her candidacy, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has made it clear to her camp in recent days that she will stay in the race until June because she believes she can still be the nominee  and, barring that, so she can depart with some final goals accomplished.

headline: A Broken Pipe Is Fixed, and the Good Life Goes On
text: But for a steady drizzle, water was in short supply Tuesday on the north side of 57th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, where a water main break the day before had forced a shutdown.

headline: Actuaries Scrutinized on Pensions
text: By firing its actuarial consultant last week, the New York State Legislature shone a light on one of the public sector’s deepest secrets: All across the country, states and local governments are promising benefits to public workers on the basis of numbers that make little economic sense.

headline: Oven Adds Flavor When the Grill Can’t
text: THIS is a story about hedging bets, about taking advantage of some old-fashioned barbecue techniques, and about the heartbreak of Memorial Day.

headline: Blind Win Court Ruling on U.S. Currency
text: WASHINGTON  In a decision that could radically change the size, the color and even the feel of American money, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the United States discriminates against the blind and those with limited vision because its paper currency is all the same size regardless of a bill’s value.

headline: Simply Irresistible
text: LONG before she became one half of the most knocked-off fashion label you have probably never heard of, Dana Foley was an aspiring playwright on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who used to avoid writing by shopping.

headline: Celtics Remain Perfect at Home in the Postseason
text: BOSTON  The central conflict heading into the Eastern Conference finals has been as much about home court and road performance as it has been about the Detroit Pistons and the Boston Celtics.

headline: Racing the Clock to Bring Back the Intrepid
text: Getting stuck in the mud on its first attempt to leave Manhattan was not the last or the least of the troubles that the aircraft carrier Intrepid has encountered in the past 18 months.

headline: Troopers Honor Inspector Amid Disbelief at Suicide
text: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  There was the familiar long gray line, ranks of troopers gathered in uniform to pay their respects, as they always do for a fallen brother in service. There was ritual and recollection, as hundreds gathered inside a tidy Roman Catholic church here on Tuesday to pay tribute to a loving husband, father and friend.

headline: Bush Team Criticizes New Report About Iran
text: WASHINGTON  The White House sharply criticized a news organization on Tuesday for the second time in two days over reports about administration policy toward Iran, dismissing an Israeli report that President Bush was preparing to order an attack on Iran before leaving office in eight months.

headline: A Young Man’s Passion for Beer Blossoms Along With His Hops
text: Squatting in the cold drizzle Tuesday morning, Dan Suarez fingered a little shoot of a plant that has managed, somehow, to rise for a second season from a tiny green patch of his parents’ backyard in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Haunting Soundtracks: Jazz With a Polish Accent
text: The Polish trumpeter Tomasz Stanko’s records of the last six years, with their elegiac moods and clean, controlled lyricism, have become a primary reference point for current European jazz. So it was curious to see him taking a step back into a woollier past on Monday in a performance at the Museum of Modern Art, part of the museum’s Jazz Score series on jazz and film.

headline: Indulgence, Doubled
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good Wine Reading With Mellow Aftertaste
text: GASOLINE? Shooting past $4 a gallon. Airfare? Similar trajectory. The dollar? Stuck at the bottom. Summer? A shady spot in the park and a good book is sounding awfully attractive.

headline: Mondavi’s Legacy: Reinventing Napa Valley
text: LIKE many great Americans, Robert Mondavi reinvented himself  several times, in fact  and in the process he reinvented Napa Valley and the American wine industry.

headline: Telescope Takes a Long View, to London
text: Before sunrise on Tuesday morning, a strange sight began to appear on Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn: a six-foot-tall metal drill bit seemed to emerge from the wooden pier, covered in genuine East River mud and revolving slowly beneath the glow of the Manhattan skyline. On Wednesday it will grow into a 12-foot-tall industrial-looking behemoth erupting just in front of the quaint Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory. And on Thursday? Imagine an enormous brass and wood telescope, 37 feet long by 11 feet tall, connected to a mirrored dome, like a child’s drawing of something that will see into the future. Voilà: the Telectroscope will have materialized.

headline: A Different Sort of Republican?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Troubles for a Thrift Institution, Despite Warnings of Its Founder
text: Lewis S. Ranieri, a pioneer of the mortgage bond industry, spent the last few years warning anyone who would listen that the housing market was about to collapse.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Election
text: To the Editor:

headline: China’s Class Divide
text: Beijing

headline: South Africa: Anti-Immigrant Mob Kills 2 at Hostel
text: Violent attacks against immigrants, a siege of mayhem that has afflicted the Johannesburg area for more than a week, began to ease, though two more foreigners were killed, bringing the death toll to at least 24 people. The latest victims were killed when a mob raided a hostel. Thousands of immigrants  most of them from Zimbabwe, Malawi and Mozambique  have been chased from their ramshackle homes. The South African Institute of Race Relations blamed the government of President Thabo Mbeki for a “tinderbox of unmet expectations.”

headline: Prognosis Usually Bleak for Condition, a Glioma
text: The statement that Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s doctors issued on Tuesday made clear that his malignant tumor was a glioma, a cancer that arises in the brain and that often carries a bleak prognosis.

headline: Minnesota: Students Vandalize Portraits at Capitol
text: In flesh and blood, former Gov. Jesse Ventura is stubborn and unvarnished. In oil paint, it is a different story, which is good news for the two high school freshmen who are believed to have made marks on his portrait when their United States government class toured the Capitol in St. Paul. “It turns out the ink wasn’t very stubborn and the paintings had enough varnish to keep the ink from seeping below the surface,” Brian Szott, curator of art at the Minnesota Historical Society, said of the vandalism the students are believed to have inflicted on three portraits of governors.
