Marks were also drawn across the mouths of Elmer L. Andersen and Harold LeVander. Initial estimates suggested the vandalism would require restoration, costing several thousand dollars. In fact, the repairs cost $175. It took an hour and a mild solvent to remove the ink from the paintings. An investigation is focusing on students from Eastview High School in Apple Valley. Mr. Ventura, a former professional wrestler, called the act “despicable.” A fine and community service are the likely penalties for a misdemeanor of this type, said James Backstrom, the county attorney for Dakota County.

headline: Officers Face Department Charges in Bell Killing
text: Seven New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, including three detectives who were acquitted in a criminal trial, were formally accused on Tuesday of breaking Police Department rules in the case.

headline: The Last Debate
text: “What do you want? Please, Sweetie, would you just tell me what you want?”

headline: Homeland Security Stands by Its Fence
text: NACO, Ariz.  As the Department of Homeland Security pushes to complete 670 miles of fencing along the Mexican border by the end of this year, it is confronting the sharpest resistance yet while conceding that physical barriers alone do not stop illegal crossings.

headline: Foreign Investors Pull Back, but Not Out of Deals
text: The extraordinarily strong office market in Manhattan in recent years owed its vigor in part to the presence of foreign real estate investors. Now, however, many such investors, even those with deep pockets and a strong currency on their side, are waiting on the sidelines.

headline: Spain’s Defense Minister Becomes a Mother
text: MADRID  Spain’s first female defense minister, whose pregnancy became a symbol of Spain’s new commitment to sexual equality, began maternity leave Tuesday after giving birth to a boy.

headline: While the Economy Struggles, Profits Can Be Made
text: WHILE the slow economy has left many small businesses scraping to get by, some enterprises are finding opportunity in the carnage. They include an entire industry devoted to distressed companies. When things are booming, this sector is like the lonely Maytag repairman, who doesn’t have much work to do.

headline: Limits Weighed for Commodities Investors
text: The chairman of a Senate oversight committee said Tuesday that he was considering legislation limiting large institutional investors in commodities markets.

headline: Braised and Grilled or Broiled Pork Ribs
text: Time: About 2 hours

headline: At Trial, Witnesses Tie Coach to Drugs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Two people pointed at Trevor Graham in a courtroom Tuesday and accused him of lying. One was a federal agent who said Graham misled him about his involvement with performance-enhancing drugs, and the other was a former Mexican athlete who said Graham arranged for him to supply the drugs.

headline: Charity’s Leaders Suspended as Payments Are Reviewed
text: The American Bible Society, the Christian charity based in Manhattan, announced on Tuesday that its president, Paul G. Irwin, and chief financial officer, Richard B. Stewart Jr., had been placed on paid temporary leave at the request of the organization’s board.

headline: China Blocks Thousands of Hindus From Tibet Pilgrimage
text: NEW DELHI  The Chinese government is refusing to issue visas to Hindus trying to make the traditional summer pilgrimage to what they hold to be the home of Lord Shiva in Tibet, forcing thousands to delay or cancel the trip.

headline: Buyout of Penn National May Involve Revised Terms
text: Another private equity deal is feeling pressure this week, as the firms buying Penn National Gaming for $6.1 billion begin to jostle with the banks over the terms for the leveraged buyout, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Giants Face Questions About Two Key Players
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Many people in the Giants’ organization have had to parry questions about the futures of Jeremy Shockey and Michael Strahan. Their position coaches took turns Tuesday answering those persistent questions, and neither provided much clarity.

headline: What You Get for ... $5 Million
text: Clarkesville, Ga.

headline: Report Details Interrogation Debate
text: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. agents complained repeatedly, beginning in 2002, about the harsh interrogation tactics that military and C.I.A. interrogators were using in questioning terrorism suspects, like making them do dog tricks and parade in the nude in front of female soldiers, but their complaints appear to have had little effect, according to an exhaustive report released Tuesday by the Justice Department’s inspector general.

headline: Randolph’s Comments Add Another Distraction
text: ATLANTA, May 20  Willie Randolph finds himself in the spotlight these days, with his job status in question and his demeanor in the dugout under a microscope.

headline: A Warning to Europe From Gazprom
text: BERLIN  Gazprom, the Russian export monopoly, warned the European Union on Tuesday that it was endangering the security of its natural gas supplies by planning to break up the Continent’s energy giants.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the winemaker Robert Mondavi misstated part of the name of an institute established in his name at the University of California, Davis. It is the Robert Mondavi Institute for Wine and Food Science (not Service).

headline: Developer of Affordable Housing Faces New Challenge
text: Among the many programs established to encourage construction of affordable housing in New York in the last few decades, the state’s 421-a negotiable certificate program uses one of the more original approaches.

headline: Estranged Father Testifies in Sect Case
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  In the weeks since the authorities raided a fundamentalist polygamy group here in West Texas in an investigation of possible child marriages and abuse, the sect’s mothers have drawn the most attention.

headline: The Obies Cite ‘Passing Strange’
text: The musical “Passing Strange” was honored as best new theater piece, and its cast (featuring Daniel Breaker, above) was honored as an ensemble when the 53rd annual Village Voice Obie Awards were presented on Monday in a ceremony at Webster Hall in the East Village. Honors in playwriting went to Horton Foote for “Dividing the Estate” and David Henry Hwang for “Yellow Face.” For accomplishments in directing, Krzysztof Warlikowski was cited for “Krum” and David Cromer for “Adding Machine.” ... Not a bad month for Rob Ashford. In addition to winning the Fred & Adele Astaire Award for best choreography on Broadway for his work in “Cry-Baby,” he was cited for outstanding choreography (“Cry-Baby” again) when the Drama Desk Awards were handed out on Sunday. Spencer Liff of “Cry-Baby” also won an Astaire Award as best male dancer on Broadway for his performance in the show. Karen Olivo was honored as Broadway’s best female dancer for “In the Heights.”

headline: Central Figure in State Police Inquiry Strikes Back
text: ALBANY  In his first public response to a widening investigation of the State Police, Daniel Wiese, the former lieutenant colonel at the center of the inquiry, has sought to rebut suggestions that he ran a rogue unit specializing in political favors and dirty tricks.

headline: Keeping Vow on Obama, McCain Adviser Resigns
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s chief advertising strategist, Mark McKinnon, announced Tuesday that he was resigning, following through on a vow he had made months ago not to work against the candidacy of Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Plastic Finds a Second Life and Skirts the Dump
text: WALTHAM, Mass.

headline: Weak Dollar Bolsters H.P. Global Sales in Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The weak dollar has its detractors, but it is working out just fine for Hewlett-Packard.

headline: For $1 Billion, They Should Work
text: Officially, the elevators and escalators in New York’s sprawling subway system are incredibly reliable. In the last quarter alone, New York City Transit reported that they were working more than 98 percent of the time. Tell that to the pregnant woman on the runaway escalator or the passenger whose escalator began to disintegrate beneath her feet as she scrambled to safety. Tell that to all those commuters who have been trapped inside steamy elevators waiting for help.

headline: A Double Standard Over Candidates’ Flag Pins?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wider Antiterror Role for Elite Forces Rejected
text: WASHINGTON  The military’s elite Special Operations Command has quietly stepped back from a controversial plan that gave it the authority to carry out secret counterterrorism missions on its own around the world.

headline: Wall Street Journal Editor Named
text: Rupert Murdoch named Robert J. Thomson as the top editor of The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday, shifting one of his most trusted advisers from the publisher’s chair into one of the most important editorial jobs in American media.

headline: In Netherlands, Soccer Is King, but Baseball Eyes Crown
text: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  Robert Eenhoorn’s cellphone rang to the tinny tune of “Take Me Out to the Ball Game,” interrupting a discussion of the vigorous state of honkbal in his native land. Honkbal is the Dutch word for baseball, and Mr. Eenhoorn, 40, the coach of the Dutch national baseball team, should know something about it.

headline: Clinton Fades Even in a Victory
text: While Senator Barack Obama gingerly commended his rival’s “perseverance,” the shrinking candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton all but vanished from the television set on Tuesday, sidelined by bigger news.

headline: Study Finds High Ground Zero Stress
text: A new study by the Mount Sinai School of Medicine suggests that the percentage of ground zero workers who suffered post-traumatic stress is roughly the same as for airline crash recovery workers and returning Afghanistan war veterans.

headline: Fire Under Control at Home of Berlin Philharmonic
text: BERLIN  Firefighters brought a large fire in the roof of the famed home of the Berlin Philharmonic under control on Tuesday, but the full extent of damage to the building remained unclear.

headline: Senate Panel Backs Housing Compromise
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday approved compromise legislation aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure by expanding the availability of government-insured mortgages.

headline: New Trend in Biofuels Has New Risks
text: ROME  In the past year, as the diversion of food crops like corn and palm to make biofuels has helped to drive up food prices, investors and politicians have begun promoting newer, so-called second-generation biofuels as the next wave of green energy. These, made from non-food crops like reeds and wild grasses, would offer fuel without the risk of taking food off the table, they said.

headline: A Little Breathing Room for a Growing Market
text: The Flatbush Food Coop started with 11 members in 1976 and now has more than 3,000. But unlike many other co-ops, it is open to the public. On Sunday, it had a ribbon-cutting ceremony for its expanded store, which has been open for about a month.

headline: A Developer’s Unusual Plan for Bright Lights, Inspired by a Dark Film
text: LOS ANGELES  The year is 2019. The illuminated windows of the city’s densely packed towers sparkle like stars in the night, and their facades are covered with bright, animated billboards. A flying car glides past the enormous eye of a smiling geisha hundreds of stories above the wet urban streets.

headline: Hamilton Jordan, Carter’s Right Hand, Dies at 63
text: Hamilton Jordan, a self-proclaimed “political animal” and campaign whiz-kid who, at age 26, ran a successful campaign for governor and, at age 31, a successful presidential campaign for Jimmy Carter, eventually becoming the president’s chief of staff and top confidant, died Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 63.

headline: Piazza Calls It Quits After 16 Years and 427 Homers
text: Mike Piazza, who went from a 62nd-round draft pick to the best-hitting catcher in major league history and a near-certain Hall of Famer, announced his retirement from baseball on Tuesday.

headline: Correction
text: In his column on Monday, Bill Kristol said he could not find a recent primary in which the candidate who would go on to win the nomination lost by as big a margin as Barack Obama lost by (41 points) in West Virginia. Mitt Romney won the essentially uncontested Utah primary on Feb. 5 with about 90 percent of the vote.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A subheading on Tuesday with an article about a developer’s agreement to salvage a $1 billion deal for the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan misidentified, in some editions, the agency that owns the railyards. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not the Port Authority.

headline: Pakistan: High-Level Talks With India Resume
text: India and Pakistan held high-level talks in Islamabad, marking the first peace negotiations between the rival nuclear nations after a 15-month lapse. Foreign Secretaries Shivshankar Menon of India and Salman Bashir of Pakistan discussed Islamic terrorism, economic cooperation and the disputed region of Kashmir. Pakistan and India agreed on what they described as a “road map for peace” in 2004, with both sides pledging to curb terrorism and strengthen ties.

headline: Twice-Cooked Mock Tandoori Chicken
text: Time: About 2 hours

headline: Seeking Raise, Firefighters Will Reopen Contract
text: Now the firefighters want their retroactive raise of nearly 10 percent, too.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about Senate legislation to expand the availability of government-insured mortgages misstated the role played by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored financial institutions. They purchase mortgages from lenders; they are not lenders themselves.

headline: Dalai Lama’s Britain Visit Raises Questions of Protocol
text: LONDON  The Dalai Lama arrived in London on Tuesday as part of a protracted foreign tour, highlighting efforts by European governments to balance China’s hostility toward him against their support for human rights in Tibet.

headline: Cyprus: Court Denies Extradition of Russian
text: A court in Cyprus has denied Russia’s request to extradite Vladislav Kartashov, a former executive of Yukos, once Russia’s largest oil company. The court ruled that charges of theft and tax fraud filed against him had been politically motivated. The decision further undermined the legitimacy of a Russian legal challenge to the corporate remnants of Yukos, which had been Russia’s top oil company before the arrest in 2003 of its owner, Mikhail Khodorkovsky. The arrest was widely viewed as an attack by the Kremlin on a political rival.

headline: Bob Schieffer Makes a Golden Years Deal
text: Bob Schieffer has reached agreement with CBS News on a new contract that will probably keep him hosting “Face the Nation” for “several more years.” The deal does not specify how long he will host the Sunday morning public affairs show, Mr. Schieffer, 71, said on Monday. But when his tenure on the program does eventually end, said Mr. Schieffer, above, the new contract ensures that he will stay on at CBS News to provide on-camera analysis, including on election nights. “That’s kind of the way Tom Brokaw works at NBC,” Mr. Schieffer said. “Tom’s kind of my model for how to live out the golden years.” Mr. Schieffer said in January that he planned to leave “Face the Nation” soon after the inauguration of the next president, but he later said he had decided to postpone his retirement at the request of CBS News executives. The network has been unable to identify a successor to Mr. Schieffer, at least one who was available. The Washington Post reported on Monday that Mr. Schieffer and CBS had reached a long-term agreement.

headline: On Back-to-Back Nights, a Homer Is Not a Homer
text: On consecutive nights this week, umpires ruled incorrectly about a batted ball that should have been called a home run.

headline: Bertelsmann Appoints Outsider to Head Random House
text: On the day that Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, quelled weeks of speculation by announcing that Markus Dohle, head of the company’s printing unit, would take over as chief executive of Random House, industry executives were largely reserving judgment on what it would mean to have a relative outsider in charge of the world’s largest publisher of consumer books.

headline: Barbara Sears Rockefeller, Actress With a Famous Divorce Settlement, Dies at 91
text: Barbara Sears Rockefeller, a Pennsylvania coal miner’s daughter who married one of the richest men in America and, after their divorce six years later, won a settlement regarded as a record in its day, died on Monday at her home in Little Rock, Ark. She was 91 and had lived in Arkansas for the last few years.

headline: Excerpts From the Season, and a Return of Old Friends
text: No matter the sense of occasion that a ballet gala affords  the gowns, the celebrity sightings, the air kisses  once the actual dancing gets under way, it’s best to consider the expression “one step forward, two steps back.” If you’re lucky, by the end the steps might more or less equal out, as they did on Monday night, when American Ballet Theater opened its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: More Glory: Talking Baseball, From the ’50s and ’60s
text: Bart Giamatti, the former commissioner of Major League Baseball, was fond of saying that the history of the game was oral. This may sound somewhat counterintuitive, considering how much great literature the national pastime has produced. But there is an essential truth to Giamatti’s words. For baseball lovers nothing is more delicious than the firsthand stories of those who lived the dream and made it to the big leagues.

headline: Obama and Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: McCain to Meet 3 Possible Running Mates
text: Senator John McCain is planning to meet this weekend with at least three potential Republican running mates at a gathering at his ranch in Arizona, suggesting that he is stepping up his search for a vice president now that the Democratic contest appears basically decided, according to Republicans familiar with Mr. McCain’s plans.

headline: Argentina: Farmers Ready to Resume Negotiations
text: Farm leaders said they expected talks with the government to restart as soon as Wednesday, after they suspended a national strike and returned to the negotiating table to try to resolve a dispute over an export tax increase. The strike began in March, initially paralyzing Argentine highways and leading to food shortages.

headline: Auteur Who’s Ripe for French Discovery
text: CANNES, France  On Monday evening, as I emerged from Lisandro Alonso’s “Liverpool,” an Argentine movie that takes place in Tierra del Fuego (as you might have guessed from the title), it occurred to me that I had not seen an English-language film in four days. Not a long time, but in those 96 hours I had watched 12 movies. What’s more, of the 20 or so I had seen since the festival started last Wednesday, only one had come from the United States. (No, it was not “Indiana Jones and the Global Publicity Bonanza,” which I’ll see with my kids when I get home. It was James Toback’s “Tyson.”)

headline: Red Sox’ No-Hitter Puts Varitek in Record Books
text: Upon recording the last out in his no-hitter, the Boston Red Sox left-hander Jon Lester pumped his fist. So did his battery mate, Jason Varitek, who dashed to the mound and hoisted him as their teammates joined them.

headline: Torn by the Contradictions of Being Gay and Muslim
text: Sad to say, “A Jihad for Love” is not a sequel to the pornographic satire “The Raspberry Reich” (2004), in which pseudo-revolutionaries exhort their comely comrades to “join the homosexual intifada!” It is, rather more arduously, a dispatch from the outer limits of marginalization: a documentary on devout Muslims struggling with their homosexuality.

headline: As Expected, N.F.L. Owners Opt Out of Labor Deal
text: ATLANTA  Even for very wealthy N.F.L. owners, difficult economic times can sting.

headline: Airbus Wins Big A350 Contract, but Its Parent Still Struggles
text: PARIS  UBS downgraded shares in the European aerospace group EADS, the parent of the plane maker Airbus, to sell, from neutral on Tuesday despite news that Airbus had won its biggest contract ever for its next-generation A350 business jet.

headline: For Randolph, Winning Will Cure All Woes
text: Willie Randolph is one of the good people in sports.

headline: Injury on Final Play Caps the Mets’ Misery
text: ATLANTA  Carlos Delgado’s blistering line drive was snatched from the air by Atlanta right fielder Jeff Francoeur, and all the resolve and hope the Mets pledged with their weekend sweep of the Yankees started to vanish. Ten and a half hours later, there was nothing left.

headline: Iraqi Refugees
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Movement and a Market Converge at a Bank
text: FOR 14 years, Cowgirl Creamery in San Francisco has been making award-winning organic cheeses and growing  to more than $8 million in sales last year. Yet no bank had ever actively sought its business until New Resource Bank came calling.

headline: Those ’68 Paris Protests
text: To the Editor:

headline: Imbalances of Power
text: There has been much debate in this campaign about which of our enemies the next U.S. president should deign to talk to. The real story, the next president may discover, though, is how few countries are waiting around for us to call. It is hard to remember a time when more shifts in the global balance of power are happening at once  with so few in America’s favor.

headline: Scramble Begins for Staten Island Congressional Seat to Be Vacated by Fossella
text: The decision by Vito J. Fossella not to seek another term in Congress has roiled the political waters of his reliably Republican district, as both parties are searching for consensus candidates to succeed him when his term ends in January.

headline: Obama’s April Fund-Raising Passes $31 Million
text: Aided by his army of small donors, Senator Barack Obama bested Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain in April fund-raising, taking in $31.3 million and ending the month with more cash on hand than either rival.

headline: South Africans Vent Rage at Migrants
text: JOHANNESBURG  The man certainly looked dead, lying motionless in the dust of the squatter camp. His body seemed almost like a bottle that had been turned on its side, spilling blood. His pants were red with the moisture.

headline: Paterson Undergoes Eye Surgery for Glaucoma
text: Gov. David A. Paterson underwent surgery on Tuesday to relieve sharp pain that doctors determined was caused by glaucoma.

headline: Lower East Side Is Given ‘Endangered’ Designation
text: The National Trust for Historic Preservation designated the Lower East Side of Manhattan as one of the 11 most endangered in places in America on Tuesday.

headline: Investors Retreat on Gloomy Forecasts
text: Stocks fell on Tuesday as several reports suggested that the worst may not yet be over in the financial markets or in the broader economy.

headline: Europe Proposes a Farm Subsidy Overhaul That Pleases Few
text: BRUSSELS  The European Commission proposed on Tuesday an overhaul of farm spending that fell far short of the liberal farm policy favored by countries like Britain but sharpened a debate with France, which has sought to preserve generous support for agriculture.

headline: The Risks of Rescuing Borrowers
text: When the Senate Banking Committee approved on Tuesday legislation to help suffering homeowners refinance costly loans, lawmakers said they had found a way to rescue the housing market without requiring taxpayers to foot the bill.

headline: Paterson Undergoes Laser Eye Treatment
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson underwent laser eye treatment on Tuesday to relieve the sharp head pain that sent him to the hospital early in the morning.

headline: A Chronicler of Night-Life Melancholy, Looking for Contradictory Layers
text: Nikola Tamindzic went out late on Friday night to shoot pictures at Trash, a weekly themed party at 40C, an East Village nightclub.

headline: Trump project in Panama goes to court over talk it copied design of famous Dubai hotel
text: The developer of a Trump residential tower in Panama is defending itself against charges it copied the design of the legendary Burj Al Arab hotel in Dubai.

headline: White On White
text: She’s got her white voters. He’s got his. Her whites go to church every week. His whites are more secular. Her whites have dirt under their fingernails. His are more likely to be changing ink cartridges in the office. Her whites like the hard stuff. His whites will choose Oregon pinot.

headline: Obama Says Nomination 'Within Reach'
text: Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Obama Claims Majority of Pledged Delegates
text: Senator Barack Obama declared the nomination “within reach,” while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continued to make a case that she could prevail.

headline: Graduation Day for a War Survivor and Olympian
text: Among the thousands of students gathering for today’s commencement ceremonies at Columbia University on Morningside Heights, there will be one with a remarkable Olympic background.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 100 Eastern Michigan
text: Location: Ypsilanti, Mich.

headline: Patient Voices: A.D.H.D.
text: Taming an overactive brain, succeeding with and without medication, and more from people living with A.D.H.D.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Calais, France
text: Across the English Channel, Matt finds art, beer, fries, but also refugees struggling to survive.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
text: Across the English Channel, Matt finds art, beer, fries, but also refugees struggling to survive.

headline: Blog Roll: Gambatte Kudasai
text: I hope that’s the Japanese sentiment of good luck, as I respectfully wish good things for Casino Drive. Let’s take a look at the big picture and try to figure out what Casino Drive is trying to attain.

headline: Champions League Final
text: Manchester United won its third European title at the expense of English rival Chelsea in a rain-soaked penalty shootout.

headline: ‘He’s Tried To Walk a Straight Line’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Leaving Baghdad
text: Ahmad Fadam was the head of the Iraqi staff in the newsroom of The New York Times in Baghdad. He left Baghdad in May to take up a visiting fellowship at the University of North Carolina. He will continue to contribute to the Baghdad Bureau blog from there.

headline: Jefferies Sees Brighter Forecast for Clean-Tech I.P.O.’s
text: Bankers at Jefferies Group on Wednesday forecast an improved deal pipeline for initial public offerings for companies in the business of reducing the world’s carbon emissions and fossil-fuel consumption, following a dry spell in the first quarter.

headline: Outside.in Pulls in $3 Million
text: Outside.in, a New York-based company that aggregates news and blog discussion around towns and neighborhoods, said Tuesday it has raised $3 million in venture funding and hired a new chief executive, former About.com general manager Mark Josephson.

headline: Russian Internet Firm Said to Eye $2 Billion N.Y. I.P.O.
text: Russian biggest internet firm Yandex plans to raise between $1.5 billion and $2 billion in a New York initial public offering in the fall, according to Reuters.

headline: Clearspring’s Coffers Swell With $18 Million in Fresh Funding
text: Clearspring Technologies, a technology platform for syndicating and tracking widgets, has raised $18 million in a third round of funding from New Enterprise Associates and Novak Biddle Venture Partners, among others.

headline: It Doesn’t Take a Rocket Scientist … Oh, Wait, Apparently It Does
text: For those who enjoyed Judy Battista’s article about how an Indiana University astrophysicist and his partner helped develop a computer program that analyzes strategic decisions by N.F.L. coaches, here is additional reading on the topic from Gelf Magazine:

headline: Russia’s Severstal Makes a Play for Esmark
text: Russian metals and mining company Severstal offered Tuesday to buy Esmark for $17 per share in cash, claiming it has the critical support of the United Steelworkers union.

headline: ICAP Sees Markets Returning to Normal
text: ICAP, the world’s largest broker of transactions between banks, said Tuesday that financial markets were returning to normal, reducing the volatility that drove its earnings to a record.

headline: Imperial Tobacco to Raise $9.6 Billion in Share Sale
text: Imperial Tobacco, seeking to help pay for its recent acquisition of Altadis of Spain, said Tuesday that it plans to raise $9.6 billion by selling shares at a discount. Imperial also reported that its profit fell 45 percent in the first half.

headline: A Warning to Europe From Gazprom
text: Gazprom, the Russian export monopoly, warned the European Union on Tuesday that it was endangering the security of its natural gas supplies by planning to break up the Continent’s energy giants.

headline: Despite Break-Up, Diller Continues Shopping Spree
text: Barry Diller, it seems, just can’t help himself.

headline: A.I.G.’s Raising of Capital Depresses Its Share Price
text: The American International Group‘s recent issue of equity and debt is expected to raise about $20 billion, far more than initially expected, its chief executive, Martin J. Sullivan, confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Dinsey’s Steamboat to Raise $200 Million for New Fund, Report Says
text: Steamboat Ventures, the venture capital arm of The Walt Disney Company, is planning to raise a third fund, worth $200 million from its owner, PE Week reported.

headline: ArcelorMittal Takes Stake in Australian Miner
text: ArcelorMittal has taken a 14.9 percent stake in Macarthur Coal and investors speculated that it might be exploring a takeover bid for the Australian miner.

headline: Lehman to Cut Another 1,300 Jobs, Report Says
text: Lehman Brothers is cutting roughly 1,300 positions globally, or nearly 5 percent of its work force, amid difficult market conditions, Reuters reported.

headline: Take-Two Begins Talks With Suitors
text: Take-Two Interactive Software hinted Monday at the possibility of formal negotiations with its hostile suitor and rival video-game publisher, Electronic Arts.

headline: Bidding War Said to Erupt Over Twitter’s Latest Round
text: Are venture capitalists vying for a piece of Twitter? GigaOm, citing multiple, undisclosed sources, reports that the micro-blogging service is at the center of a bidding war as firms jockey to take part in its latest funding round.

headline: Time Warner Gives Details on Cable Spinoff
text: Time Warner and its cable television arm, Time Warner Cable, said Wednesday their boards have approved the companies’ legal separation, with Time Warner Cable expected to pay a hefty $10.9 billion one-time dividend to shareholders.

headline: Less Emotionally Grounded Than a 5th Grader
text: That would be the comedian Zach Galifianakis, seen here on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” promoting his 2007 DVD:

headline: HBOS Completes First Mortgage Securitization Since Credit Freeze
text: HBOS, Britain’s largest mortgage lender, on Tuesday completed the first mortgage securitization since the credit markets seized up in August last year, The Telegraph reported.

headline: TCI to Lobby Other J-Power Shareholders for Support
text: The Children’s Investment Fund, the $10 billion hedge fund seeking to double its stake in Japan’s biggest power wholesaler, will lobby fellow shareholders to support bigger dividends and limit cross-shareholdings.

headline: Barnes & Noble Said to Study Borders Bid
text: U.S. bookseller Barnes & Noble is looking into a possible bid for competitor Borders Group , The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Former Merrill Executive Delays Launch of Fund, Report Says
text: Former Merrill Lynch executive Dow Kim delayed the launch of his hedge fund recently as financial backing from some large investors, including Credit Suisse, failed to materialize, The New York Post reported.

headline: Foreign Investors Pull Back on N.Y.C. Real Estate
text: The extraordinarily strong office market in Manhattan in recent years owed its vigor in part to the presence of foreign real estate investors. Now, however, many such investors, even those with deep pockets and a strong currency on their side, are waiting on the sidelines.

headline: Zuckerman, Goldman Said to Bid for G.M. Building
text: An investor group including Mortimer B. Zuckerman’s Boston Properties, Goldman Sachs and two Middle Eastern investors is in talks to buy the General Motors Building and up to three other properties for $3.6 billion to $3.9 billion, according to press reports.

headline: Yamaguchi Wins ‘Dancing With the Stars’
text: “After four consecutive male winners on ‘Dancing With the Stars,’ it was finally ladies’ night,” the AP reports.

headline: Citi Said to Offer Compensation to Hedge Fund Investors
text: Citigroup is reportedly coming under pressure to bail out investors in one of its troubled hedge funds, in another embarrassment for a company already among the biggest losers from the credit crisis.

headline: Corporate Express Strikes Deal to Thwart Staples
text: Corporate Express has made it clear exactly how feels about a deal with U.S. rival Staples, which has launched a hostile bid for the Dutch office supplier.

headline: Dimon Confirms More Than Half of Bear Staff to Be Cut
text: JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive confirmed Tuesday that the bank will be keeping nearly half of the employees at Bear Stearns, the struggling investment bank that JPMorgan agreed to buy in March.

headline: New Multi-Year Deal for Bob Schieffer
text: “Bob Schieffer has reached agreement with CBS News on a new contract that will probably keep him hosting ‘Face the Nation’ for ‘several more years,'” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: Troubles for Franklin Bank, Despite Early Warnings
text: Lewis S. Ranieri, a pioneer of the mortgage bond industry, spent the last few years warning anyone who would listen that the housing market was about to collapse.

headline: Start-Up to Auction Chances to Clone a Dog
text: A California company is planning a string of online auctions next month to clone five dogs, with the bidding to start at $100,000.

headline: An Oracle of Oil Predicts $200-a-Barrel Crude
text: Goldman Sachs‘s Arjun N. Murti remembers the pain of the oil shocks of the 1970s. But he is bracing for something far worse now: He foresees a “super spike” – a price surge that will soon drive crude oil to $200 a barrel.

headline: The Early Word: Two More Weeks
text: Another primary night, another split decision. But with Barack Obama capturing the majority of the pledged delegates after the contests in Kentucky and Oregon on Tuesday, there appear to be few sands left in the hourglass for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy.

headline: Greenberg May Face Civil Charges, Report Says
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, may face civil charges for his alleged role in an effort to improperly boost the insurer’s financials, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

headline: Does More Pain Await Macquarie?
text: The Macquarie Group this week showed that it isn’t immune to the global credit squeeze, as the investment bank’s profit growth slowed this past year. But Breakingviews argues that while the firm seems to have been hit only lightly, it’s still vulnerable to prolonged troubles in the debt market.

headline: Banks Said to Balk at Penn National Buyout Terms
text: Another private equity deal is feeling pressure this week, as the firms buying Penn National Gaming for $6.1 billion begin to jostle with the banks over the terms for the leveraged buyout, The New York Times reported.

headline: Remember the Baseball Bunch
text: Baseball fans of a certain age (probably in their 30s) will remember watching the Baseball Bunch on Saturday mornings from 1982-85 while mainlining sugared cereal and either waiting for or recovering from the Smurfs (can’t remember if it was on before or after those little blue ones).

headline: UEFA Champions League A to Z
text: It will not quite be midnight in Moscow when the UEFA Champions League final kicks off Wednesday in Moscow. It will happen at 10:45 p.m. local time to accommodate prime-time TV in Western Europe. The first all-English final, between Manchester United and Chelsea, has been the talk of the soccer world as an estimated 45,000 English fans streamed into the Russian capital for the match.

headline: Banks Said to Prepare Sale of Alliance Boots Loans
text: The banks holding 9 billion pounds of debt tied to the leveraged buyout of Alliance Boots are poised to sell about a third of those loans, in what would be the biggest sale of a hung leveraged loan in Europe, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.

headline: White on White
text: She’s got her white voters. He’s got his. Her whites go to church every week. His whites are more secular. Her whites have dirt under their fingernails. His are more likely to be changing ink cartridges in the office. Her whites like the hard stuff. His whites will choose Oregon pinot.

headline: One Man’s Advice From Four Cancer Battles
text: Hamilton Jordan, the former White House chief of staff for President Jimmy Carter, was a well-known force in the health community. During the past 24 years he battled four different forms of cancer and urged cancer patients to empower themselves with information.

headline: Internal Charges Against Officers in Bell Case
text: Seven New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, including three detectives who were acquitted in a criminal trial, were formally accused on Tuesday of breaking Police Department rules in the case, Al Baker reports.

headline: Feminist Hero or ‘Just a Politician’?
text: Two articles on the nation’s op-ed pages today try to explain to Hillary Clinton’s supporters why losing a presidential campaign is insufficient evidence that the candidate in question has suffered from a misogynistic backlash.

headline: From Sichuan to Oregon: Schools at Risk
text: [UPDATE 5/22: A poem has risen from the wreckage in China.] I’m doing a fresh article examining how to cut the chances that more schools in known earthquake zones will crumble and kill in years to come. Yumei Wang, the geohazards team leader for the state of Oregon, sent me a cautionary note saying it’s important to remember that such risks are not confined to poor countries or emerging powers, but also face parts of the United States and other industrialized nations. She cited a 2007 survey of the vulnerability of schools and emergency-services buildings in Oregon that provides a chilling hint of the dangers. The bottom line? More than a thousand schools in Oregon are ready to fall in a quake that could be 32 times more powerful than the one that shattered eastern Sichuan province.

headline: Deal-Making in a Downturn
text: Attention! Merge now to create value!

headline: Geometries | U.S. Marine Hospital 43
text: At United States Marine Hospital 43, the hospital on Ellis Island, the powerhouse and laundry building housed the mortuary and autopsy room. Bodies were refrigerated in these eight compartments in the wall. The site was used as a teaching area, and was associated with the Long Island College Hospital. More than 12 million immigrants were processed on Ellis Island, and more than 3,500 died, including about 1,400 children.

headline: Reading Children’s Books That Ooze New York
text: Shortly after last week’s unveiling of the portrait of Eloise,  the endearing denizen of the Plaza Hotel, we started thinking about other children’s books set in New York City, and how they caught our imaginations early on. The books helped convince us, back when we were truly the center of the universe, that New York might actually share that honor.

headline: The Final: Players to Watch
text: It will be a clash of familiar teams in Wednesday’s UEFA Champions League title game between Manchester United and Chelsea in Moscow.

headline: What About the Veterinarians?
text: When I was a kid growing up in Wisconsin, my grandmother used to take me to the only dentist in the county for regular checkups. Somehow, despite never having a toothache and never eating sweets or drinking soda, I had a mouth full of cavities that necessitated nearly weekly trips for filling after filling — or so the dentist would have my grandmother believe. That was the era when the authority of doctors and dentists was never questioned. The guys in the white coats were to be respected and their orders followed. It seems as if the American horse racing industry never left that era.

headline: In Italy, a Billionaire Takes Out Trash
text: Update, 1:57 p.m. Scroll for developments from a news conference.

headline: If You Don’t Have Anything Nice to Say …
text: BRIEFS Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende of the Netherlands tried to counter negative public opinion today with a message for his many critics, those cold and timid souls who know neither victory nor defeat: “I am convinced that we have a mission that will advance the Netherlands,” he said. “Cynicism and complaining don’t help us make any progress.” [Reuters]

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Rebecca Walker
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: ‘Visited an Indian Reservation’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Tonight’s, of course, a big night for all the candidates. Let’s get this straight. Hillary Clinton is expected to win in Kentucky. Barack Obama is expected to win in Oregon. And John McCain is expected to win at bingo.

headline: And the Winners of the 2007-2008 Season Are…
text: Both the May sweeps month and the 2007-08 television season end today, and already the broadcast networks are promoting their achievements.

headline: Tank Warfare
text: In today’s political climate, it doesn’t take much for someone to call you a Nazi, an appeaser or a fascist. So, what the hey: This old propaganda poster’s available for the energy debate:

headline: A Study With a Daily $50 Lottery
text: Researchers at Duke University are looking for participants in an online study looking at ideas for improving the world, and they promise to award a $50 gift certificate each day to one randomly chosen participant. The survey takes about 10 minutes. You can participate by clicking here.

headline: Detroit Panic City?
text: When Florida shipped two of their best players, Miguel Cabrera and Dontrelle Willis, to Detroit in the offseason, many thought it would enable the Tigers to run away with the A.L. Central, and possibly more. But it is the Marlins sitting on top of their division with a little less than three-fourths of the season to go and the Tigers are nine games under .500.

headline: Mansion Plan Rejected in Hedge-Fund Haven
text: A Russian millionaire who hoped to build a 27,000-square-foot mansion with 26 toilets and room to park 12 cars will need to go back to the drafting table, now that the Planning and Zoning Commission of Greenwich, Conn., rejected his proposal at a meeting late Tuesday.

headline: In Brooklyn, a College With Its Own Beach
text: Video

headline: Microsoft Searching for Users With Rebates
text: UPDATE | 5/21 3:00 PM Added information from the official introduction and more background.

headline: Monaco
text: What else is there to say. Monaco. The biggest race of the Formula One calendar. And I arrived last night, since Monaco is also the only race where there is a practice session on the Thursday, and therefore a press conference on the Wednesday. The press conference was interesting for the contrasting views of racing in Monaco, from Sebastien Bourdais’ interesting and precise description of what attitude a driver needs to have to go fast here, and why he likes this track, to Felipe Massa’s flat statement of dislike for the track. He prefers tracks like Turkey (surprise, surprise) and even China. See details on the FIA site, when it gets there….

headline: In Case of Rain (But That Won’t Happen)
text: The way I figure it, today’s Minimalist column, about using the broiler as a hedge against bad weather on Memorial Day, should pretty much guarantee a bright and sunny start to the grilling season. (For more about magical thinking, see John Tierney’s recent column about buying flight insurance to “guarantee” that your plane doesn’t crash.) Happy grilling, everyone!

headline: Of Bank Deals and Bookkeeping
text: Are accounting rules keeping American banks from buying each other? Or is the real problem the sorry state of the potential buyers?

headline: Recipe of the Day: Spicy Shrimp Salad With Mint
text: Here’s another dish, like those in today’s Minimalist column, that’s usually grilled but that works just as well, if not better, in the broiler. For years I never realized that one of the greatest assets of my favorite grilled shrimp dish — the juices that the shrimp exude — was just sputtering away on those hot coals. That’s why broiled shrimp are so desirable: you get to savor the juices, the essences, produced by the shrimp itself.

headline: The Morning Skate: Cup Dates and Diving Greats
text: Poor Detroit. The local economy is crumbling, there are no jobs, the mayor — who is accused of perjury, obstruction of justice and misconduct in office charges — spends all his time fighting to save his own job. You know, small stuff. But now, real problems of apocalyptic proportions: the first three games of the Stanley Cup final are going head to head with three Pistons-Celtics NBA semifinal games. On two of those dates, they’ll both be playing home games. The horror. THE HORROR!

headline: Where History Takes Off
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: ‘Delegates, Superdelegates, Pledge Delegates …’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: They held primaries in Oregon and Kentucky. Hillary Clinton won Kentucky, Obama is expected to win Oregon, which would mean that he would clinch a majority of the pledge delegates. There are the delegates, superdelegates, pledge delegates, Lemon Pledge delegates, and the farmer in the delegates, without which you don’t get to the White House.

headline: Dial-up Downloaders Are in the Minority
text: From the mailbag:

headline: Farewell, Patrick Ireland
text: After 36 years, Brian O’Doherty put to rest his alter ego, Patrick Ireland.

headline: Just Asking | When to Pull the Plug?
text: Biba’s full-spectrum fashion, 1967. (David Graves/Rex Features/Everett Collection)

headline: What’s On Your DVR?
text: “Grey’s Anatomy,” “House,” “Lost,” and “American Idol” were the most-played-back shows of the 2007-08 television season.

headline: Trapped in an Elevator, Captured on Video
text: With so much in the news these days about elevator problems, it reminded me of this harrowing video of a man trapped in a New York elevator for 41 hours.

headline: How to Talk About Iraq
text: When it comes to trying to figure out what we should do in Iraq, the presidential campaign debates are close to useless. To appease their parties’ bases, all the candidates articulate oversimplified, emotion-laden positions — Stay in! Get out! — that have little to do with the day-to-day complexities on the ground. Television talk shows, with their ratings-driven shouting matches, are worse. (And even though you’re reading a blog, let’s not talk about what gets said in most of the blogosphere.)

headline: The Starting Line: Dalai Lama Reverses Himself on Attending the Olympics
text: The Dalai Lama said today in London that if he is invited to the Beijing Olympics, he would be “happy” to attend, reversing a statement he made last week in which he said it would be “very hard” for him to attend the Games if invited. The Tibetan leader made the remarks after arriving yesterday for a 12-day visit to the U.K..

headline: What Obama Is Reading
text: So now we know what Barack Obama is reading these days: Fareed Zakaria’s “The Post-American World.” This is, in its way, the most stylish book ad I’ve seen in a while. Looks like Obama is on Page, I dunno, 116.

headline: The Burger Is $175, but the Fries Are Free
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Boosting Japan’s Military
text: BRIEFS A few news items suggesting changes considered unthinkable a few years back: Japanese lawmakers opened the door to expanding military assets into space today, a news cycle after U.S. Ambassador to Japan Thomas Schieffer urged the country to increase its defense budget. As Asian nations spend more on their militaries, Mr. Schieffer said, so should Japan. He even has a shopping tip: buy fighter jets compatible with U.S. forces. “The more joint operational we become, the better off we will be,” he said.

headline: The Post-Materialist | Pedaling Art
text: A report from our Berlin correspondent on design in culture.

headline: ‘Ice or Water?’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Thank you for coming out on another hot day. And it was hot again today, wasn’t it? It was so hot, John McCain narrowed his list of running mates to either Ben or Jerry.

headline: At Media Power Lunches, Joe Armstrong Holds Court
text: Joe Armstrong, who is otherwise known as the Mayor of Michael’s, took his usual perch, Table No. 3, on Tuesday as the suits began filling the room.

headline: Donor Gives $20 Million to Save St. Brigid’s
text: Updated, 5:35 p.m. | An anonymous donor has come to the rescue of St. Brigid’s Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, saving the building — which has presided over Tompkins Square Park since 1848 — from demolition and making it possible for the structure to be reopened as a parish church.

headline: LAX: Hopkins Cast as Unusual Underdog
text: The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team bottomed out in the middle of the season, losing five consecutive games and looking like it may not even make the postseason.

headline: What Women Don’t Want
text: Ivory Tower | Hey Harvard, can Larry Summers have his job back now? New research suggests women really aren’t interested in science and engineering, according to this piece in the Boston Globe. Still, “the researchers are not suggesting that sexism and cultural pressures on women don’t play a role, and they don’t yet know why women choose the way they do.” Read more …

headline: Remain Silent Remain Silent Remain Silent
text: Maybe it was a ’70s thing, but my mom thought it was her duty to prepare her kids for the tricky ways of police interrogators. I don’t know why she was so sure we’d one day need to know how to elude the stock police plays — “your buddy upstairs has confessed,” and of course good cop/bad cop — but she drilled us on cop stuff as if it were multiplication tables.

headline: Mine Workers Union Backs Obama
text: Senator Barack Obama’s efforts to woo working-class voters received a sizable boost today, when he received the endorsement of the United Mine Workers of America.

headline: D.C. Journalist Joins Obama Campaign
text: Linda Douglass, currently at National Journal, will leave the magazine to become a traveling press secretary and adviser to Senator Barack Obama, Ms. Douglass said today, part of an expanding team gearing up for a likely general election battle with Senator John McCain.

headline: Way? No Way? A Request From Herald Square
text: Jerry Orbach had a tough time gaining approval. Now, members of Community Board 5 have to decide whether to O.K. or refuse to put up a street sign for one of the most famous names in New York City history.

headline: Spread ‘Em
text: Over at Print Magazine — it focuses on “Design, Culture, Comment” — the Book Review’s longtime art director Steve Heller has compiled a gallery of spread-leg book jackets (and movie posters and advertisements and comic books and much, much more). These things are wonderfully, irresistibly pulpy, and they’re pretty much everywhere you look: The “A-Frame,” Heller writes, “is the most frequently copied trope ever used.”

headline: The Great Government Sell-Off
text: Is it any wonder that investment banks and private equity firms are hiring infrastructure experts at a rapid clip?

headline: Live In 3, 2, 1: A Commercial
text: Television networks are reusing a popular advertising ploy of the past: the live commercial.

headline: Will Work For Free
text: Politics | “Ask not what your country can do for you—ask what you can do for your country.” It’s back: Youth community service is included in both Obama’s and McCain’s platforms, Reason magazine notes skeptically. “The coming McCain-Obama contest holds great promise for those who hope to see the day when youth are expected to perform nearly free labor as a matter of federal policy.” [Reason]

headline: Obama in Florida
text: TAMPA, Fla. – One day after Senator Barack Obama inched closer toward winning the Democratic presidential nomination, he arrived here in Florida with another problem on his hands: Healing the anger percolating among Democrats who feel they have been excluded in the race for the White House.

headline: Extra Firm Mattress, Comfortably Sleeps Two
text: Technology has made many inroads elsewhere, but a construction site is still a place of heavy manual labor.

headline: A Different Kind of Mattress
text: In Flushing, Queens, patrons shop for stone beds. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Living in the Past
text: With all this talk of a Triple Crown, and with a dominant horse who arguably has the best chance to seal the deal since Affirmed did so in 1978, one might feel as if he/she has been transported back to the 70s.

headline: Fla. Gov. Games the ’08 Race
text: TALLAHASSEE _ With all three presidential candidates in his very important state on Wednesday, Florida’s Republican governor, Charlie Crist, predicted that Floridians would find Senator Barack Obama’s positions on taxes and foreign policy to be out of the mainstream.

headline: Library Looks at Photography and the City
text: In 2005, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority considered, then backed away from, a proposal to ban photography on subways and buses (unless a permit was obtained). In 2007, the Bloomberg administration faced a firestorm from photographers and filmmakers over a proposal to restrict video recording on streets and in other public spaces.

headline: Big Changes Coming to Profile Pages on Facebook
text: Profile pages on Facebook are getting a total makeover.

headline: Notes From Belmont
text: Some quick notes from Belmont Park. Rick Dutrow seems to understand the magnitude of what Big Brown is attempting: to become the first Triple Crown champion since Affirmed in 1978, and the 12th of all time. Some brass came off his prediction this morning.

headline: ‘Idols’ Trump ‘Dancing’
text: In the battle of the Davids on Tuesday, Fox was the clear winner.

headline: Answers About New York’s Hidden Places
text: Following is the first set of answers from Michelle Haimoff, the author of “Secret New York: Exploring the City’s Hidden Neighborhoods.” This week Ms. Haimoff is answered readers’ questions about walking tours and the secret places and hidden gems of the city. (We are no longer taking questions for this feature.)

headline: Note to Conservatives: Think Small
text: Who needs big ideas? Stephen Bainbridge, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, reacts to a blog post by The Atlantic’s Megan McArdle that asks the question, “Are conservatives out of ideas?” His answer: Yes, and thank the stars.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, May 21:

headline: A High-Priced Voyage Home
text: The aircraft carrier Intrepid, the nautical museum being overhauled on Staten Island, has run into cost overruns.

headline: Ed’s Rant on Ramps
text: Regular Bitten contributor Ed Schneider found ramps the other day — often the first real sign of spring here in New York — and was off and running. –MB

headline: Slow Start Surprises Girardi
text: Manager Joe Girardi said on Sunday night that he never envisioned the Yankees starting with a 20-24 record. So, after they lost to the Baltimore Orioles, 12-2, in a brutal game on Tuesday night, we can safely reason that Girardi never saw 20-25 coming, either.

headline: Clinton Invokes 2000 Recount
text: In the wake of her romp in Kentucky last night, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton pivoted with a wheels-up for a trip to Florida, one of those two states she’s intent on seeing included in the delegate count as she uses her own magic math of 2210 delegates needed to become the Democratic nominee. (Not the 2026 the Obama campaign relies on, but the Clinton calculus that includes the Florida-Michigan seating.)She dialed in to the radio in Cleveland, Ohio, this morning, with Florida in mind, and reminding us all of oh, the 2000 nightmare that was a 36-day recount. Remember that? She’s not going to let us forget it soon; (at least not before the May 31 meeting of the Rules and Bylaws Committee of the Democratic National Committee).

headline: Flop Yourself Down, but Gently. Sleep Tight.
text: Video

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: The Lamentations of the Vanquished
text: In the days before the Stanley Cup final begins (weeks? months?), we spare a moment for a last look back at the two teams who stumbled at the penultimate hurdle, the fallen semifinalists Dallas and Philadelphia. And we take that look back through the eyes of their Hockey Night bloggers, starting with our correspondent in the Big D.

headline: Kevin Spacey on His Role in Recount
text: A promotional interview with Kevin Spacey on his role as Ron Klain, the senior adviser to Al Gore, and his thoughts on the election process.

headline: Help Desk | Pre-Fab Homes
text: A pre-fab house by WeeHouse. (Alchemy Architects)

headline: Clinton Presses Her Case in Florida
text: BOCA RATON — Striking a defiant tone, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday ratcheted up her argument that the Democratic Party should count the delegates from Florida and Michigan as it prepares to choose a presidential nominee.

headline: More Unintended Risks From Biofuels?
text: Much of the recent heat over biofuels has been focused on how much this booming business may have contributed to the international spike in food prices that has had an outsize impact on poor people. Defenders of farm-grown fuels point to studies showing the biofuels boom has had a minor impact on food prices compared to the surge in energy costs. They also say the eventual goal is to shift away from sources like corn toward plants harvested for their cellulose — ending competition with cropland or food markets.

headline: Reaction Abroad to the U.S. Election
text: A look at the Kentucky and Oregon primaries with Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

headline: In Dover, a Not Quite Grand Start
text: There are, I’ve long believed, two kinds of places in this world: destinations and way stations. Dover, England, is definitely the latter.

headline: ARM: Getting The Light Switches of the World to Chat Among Themselves
text: If you ever get the feeling that every heretofore ordinary object in your life is now beeping, flashing, counting, or otherwise hinting of intelligence — benign or maybe even malevolent — blame Warren East.

headline: Moody’s Computer Glitch Prompts Stock Tumble
text: How much can a computer glitch, a “mathematical typo,” cost?

headline: Contrarian Carbon-Cutters
text: Wired Magazine has a wonderfully contrarian list of strategies for cutting carbon in its 15th anniversary issue. “The war on greenhouse gases is too important to be left to the environmentalists,” the magazine announces, and proceeds to destroy some green sacred cows — including organic ones. Some of the recommendations:

headline: Giuliani Owes $3.1 Million
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York not only went through $58 million of other people’s money in his failed presidential bid. He’s also facing $3 million in campaign debt. And that is after he put $500,000 of his own money into his losing effort to win the Republican nomination — a campaign that ended shortly after his Florida-focused strategy failed.

headline: High School Blood Drives Pose Extra Risk
text: High school students who donate blood are more likely to experience complications like fainting and bruising than adult blood donors, according to a new study.

headline: Critic of Palestinian Video Wins French Case
text: A fierce debate over an iconic Palestinian image was jolted anew today by a French appeals court ruling.

headline: The Little Rally That Grew
text: The voting is over in Oregon, where Senator Barack Obama decisively won the primary on Tuesday. But people there and elsewhere are still buzzing about Mr. Obama’s Sunday rally in Portland, which drew 75,000 people — ­the largest crowd not just of Mr. Obama’s campaign but probably, according to local politicos, in Oregon campaign history.

headline: This Way to Brooklyn, This Way
text: The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, set the stage for the Brooklyn Bridge’s 125th anniversary celebration this afternoon by crooning “Happy Birthday” before joining other officials in unveiling the Brooklyn Bridge Pedestrian Walkway Project. This upgrade to its pedestrian walkway on the Brooklyn side includes new pedestrian signs and a permanent public-art lighting installation to welcome pedestrians exiting the bridge through the stairwell leading into Dumbo.

headline: Union Leader Has Advice for Obama
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s biggest supporter in the labor movement has some pointed advice for Barack Obama.

headline: The Price Wasn’t Right
text: Contestant has bad day on venerable game show:

headline: Player Ratings: Manchester United Triumph in Europe
text: After 120-plus minutes of soccer, the first all-English final in the UEFA Champions League came down to penalties. It was the first final played in Russia and the first final played on two surfaces: a much-maligned grass field (which like the game’s referee is from Slovakia) installed over the equally maligned artificial turf at Luzhniki Stadium. Chelsea came into the game without a loss in nine matches; United traveled to (wet and cool) Moscow after winning its second straight Premier League title.

headline: Bad News Hardly Dents Penn National Shares
text: Perhaps Barron’s stocks blog put it best: “Penn National Gaming (PENN) shareholders are doing their best ‘there’s a pony under here’ act of faith” that the buyout of the casino operator will go through as planned.

headline: Cell Phone Breakthroughs, Interrupted
text: Aside from a gigantic bill in Long Island, it seemed to be raining good news on one topic close to all of our hearts for a moment. Here are separate plans that emerged today for bringing cell phone freedom to Cuba and the U.S.:

headline: Vietnam: A Memorial Work
text: Six young men struggle to pedal and drag three pedicabs across the sandy and rocky bottom of a shallow sea.

headline: Lehman Creates Restructuring and Finance Group
text: Lehman Brothers said Wednesday that it is forming a restructuring and finance group, a new team aimed at capitalizing on an expected jump in bankruptcy filings and restructurings in the wake of the credit crunch.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Obama-Clinton Gap
text:
Robert Wright of Bloggingheads.tv, left, and former Senator Gary Hart discuss how economic change has split the Democratic electorate.

headline: Takeoff, but What Sort of Landing?
text: Some in India fear that a new airport in Bangalore is destined to become the latest example of India’s inability to plan for its future.

headline: A Setback for Public Toilets
text: There are lots of problems with public toilets in New York City, starting with the fact that there aren’t any.

text: Update below

headline: Peace Talks in the Middle East
text: Israel and Syria have said they are holding peace talks in Turkey, and factions in Lebanon have reached a deal, ending a political crisis.

headline: Big Brown Update: Wednesday
text: As expected, Big Brown returned to the track Wednesday, after a three-day break, following his easy Preakness win. Big Brown jogged a mile and a half around the track. He is scheduled to do a routine gallop Thursday.

headline: The Renovated Huntington Mansion
text: Images from the newly renovated Huntington Mansion in California after a three-year shutdown and a $20 million renovation.

headline: The Invisible War
text: Landing in Seattle after a long flight from Texas, I was about to join the exit scrum when the pilot informed us there were five soldiers on board, ending a three-day odyssey home from Iraq. Could we let them pass?

headline: McCain’s V.P. Search
text: Senator John McCain is planning to meet this weekend with at least three potential Republican running mates at a gathering at his ranch in Arizona, suggesting that he is stepping up his search for a vice president now that the Democratic contest appears basically decided, according to Republicans familiar with Mr. McCain’s plans, Adam Nagourney reports.

headline: Portrait of the Politico as a Young Man
text: Senator Barack Obama is usually the candidate known for stirring up youth enthusiasm. But Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has her own poster boy: Dalton Hatfield, who, as she reminded us during her victory speeches in both West Virginia and Kentucky, sold his bike and video games to donate more than $400 to her campaign.

headline: Peace Talks in the Middle East
text: Israel and Syria have said they are holding peace talks in Turkey, and Lebanonese factions have reached a deal, ending a political crisis.

headline: Your Comments on my Earthquake Column
text: My Thursday column is about the aftermath of the Sichuan earthquake, and what it says about China. I argue that the reaction to the quake shows some of the positive evolution in China over the years, away from a top-down authoritarianism to a less controlled model that isn’t a democracy but still is somewhat sensitive to public opinion.

headline: Quebec Court Blocks Bell Canada Deal
text: Is there any doubt now that the sale of Bell Canada is in trouble?

headline: Next ‘Idol’ Stop: Disney World
text: “David Archuleta and David Cook are no professional athletes, but one of them will be celebrating like one on tonight’s ‘American Idol’ finale,” the AP reports.

headline: Frank Rich to Be Consultant for HBO
text: “Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, has signed on with HBO as a creative consultant to help develop new programming, while still writing his weekly column,” Richard Perez-Pena reports.

headline: Barack Obama in Florida
text: At his first appearance in Florida since last fall, Senator Barack Obama made no mention of the the controversy over seating Florida's delegates.

headline: ‘Idol’ Viewers Set A Voting Record
text: The seventh season of “American Idol” recorded a record number of votes.

headline: Reducing Tensions in Abkhazia
text: The long military standoff in Abkhazia, where a separatist dispute has risked escalating this year to a renewed war, has entered a phase of quiet diplomacy.

headline: Open-Source File Format Is to Be a Part of Microsoft Office
text: Microsoft was set to announce Thursday that it would make the interchangeable document format of a competitor available in its own market-leading Office 2007 software during the first half of 2009.

headline: Police Are Out in Force as a Neighborhood Simmers With Tension Again
text: The streets of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, resembled an armed camp on Wednesday.

headline: Chamberlain Takes Step Toward Starting
text: As the questions started to dwindle late Wednesday night, Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, looked around at the reporters before him. “I guess that knocks Darrell Rasner off the back pages,” Cashman said, smiling.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An obituary on May 13 about Murray Jarvik, a psychopharmacologist who was among the first to study LSD, referred incorrectly to the chemical compound D-lysergic acid, which he studied in the 1950s. It is a precursor of LSD, not LSD itself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the publication history of The Village Voice, quoting an account Dr. Jarvik gave in a 2001 interview. The newspaper was founded in 1955; it did not exist in 1953, when, by Dr. Jarvik’s account, he placed an advertisement in the paper seeking subjects for an LSD study at Mount Sinai Hospital.

headline: Understanding and Outrage From Air Travelers
text: Daniel Rosenthal just finished classes at Yeshiva University, but he already expects that his expenses this fall will go up, thanks to American Airlines.

headline: Courage in Elm City
text: Last year, in an act of considerable political courage, New Haven began offering a municipal ID card to all residents, including illegal immigrants. The reaction from anti-immigrant forces was predictably ugly. Protesters disrupted hearings, heckled and threatened city officials and tried to intimidate businesses that supported the program, which is believed to be the first of its kind in the nation. The city has held firm.

headline: City Says Best Schools May Suffer
text: Some of New York City’s highest-performing schools could suffer “painful” budget cuts as high as 6 percent next year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said on Wednesday, blaming state rules that restrict how the city can spend state education money.

headline: A Surprise as Fans Pick a 7th ‘Idol’
text: LOS ANGELES  It was a winner by a knockout on Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of “American Idol,” but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow on the final night of competition one night earlier.

headline: Testimony Links Sprinter Pettigrew to Drugs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A drug adviser and distributor testified in federal court Wednesday that the sprinter Antonio Pettigrew obtained performance-enhancing drugs during a four-year period in which he competed on a record-setting 4x400-meter relay team.

headline: Two Choirs, and One Increasingly Busy Conductor
text: If the Department of Justice investigated conducting monopolies, its agents would be taking a close look at Kent Tritle. Just under two decades ago he started the Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola and quickly turned its resident choir into a finely polished, stylistically nimble ensemble. In 2005 he was appointed music director of the venerable Oratorio Society of New York, and this year he added Musica Sacra to his portfolio.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A jazz review on Wednesday about the Tomasz Stanko Quartet, at the Museum of Modern Art, referred incorrectly to the selection of music played. Three of the nine pieces were by Mr. Stanko; they were not all by the Polish film composer Krzysztof Komeda.

headline: Senate Panel Supports California Emissions Waiver
text: A Senate panel approved a measure to reverse a ruling by the Environmental Protection Agency and let California enforce auto emission standards that are tougher than federal law. The Committee on Environment and Public Works voted 10 to 9 to amend the Clean Air Act to grant California’s request for a waiver from E.P.A. rules that prohibit states from establishing their own pollution restrictions. Fourteen other states have adopted or are adopting the California standards and seek similar waivers from the federal rules.

headline: In the Spring Garden, Some Joys Just Won’t Wait
text: MY friend Rock and I have different attitudes about the garden.

headline: Police Dig Up Backyard in Futile Search for Body
text: Workers dug up a Queens backyard on Wednesday in a police search for human remains after a man imprisoned for murder suggested that he had left a body there, the authorities said.

headline: F.A.A. Bans Antismoking Drug, Citing Side Effects
text: The Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday it would no longer permit pilots or air traffic controllers to use the smoking cessation drug Chantix, citing potential side effects that could pose a threat to the safe operation of aircraft.

headline: Moscow Takes British Soccer Invasion in Stride
text: MOSCOW  Red Square felt more like Piccadilly Circus as thousands of English soccer fans swarmed the Russian capital for some quick sightseeing ahead of the first all-English final of the prestigious European Champions League later on Wednesday.

headline: A Phone to Match Your Swiss Army Knife
text: Road warriors who keep themselves electronically tethered to the office with a BlackBerry smartphone might be pestering the I.T. department for an upgrade. Research in Motion recently announced its new BlackBerry Bold model, which the company says has “the most vivid and bold display ever.”

headline: Small Businesses (and Their Customers) Feel Sting of Inflation
text: From 7 a.m., when Mark Roesner arrives at Copley Feed and Supply in Ohio and turns on the lights, until a little after 6 p.m., when his wife, Nancy Roesner, turns them off, the Roesners are reminded of the costs of inflation in ways big and small.

headline: Bell Canada Takeover Is Blocked
text: OTTAWA  An appeals court quashed approval for the $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of Bell Canada on Wednesday after siding with angry bondholders in a ruling.

headline: Steroids Dealer Provides the N.F.L. With Evidence
text: David Jacobs, a convicted steroids dealer from Plano, Tex., provided documentary evidence to N.F.L. officials on Wednesday that his lawyer said tied several players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Global Monitor Finds No Radioactive Leaks in Quake Zone
text: A global network of sensors has found no evidence that China’s complex of nuclear facilities in the earthquake zone let any radioactivity escape, its operator reported Wednesday.

headline: Berlusconi Moves to Tighten Immigration and Ease Trash Crisis
text: ROME  Beginning his third term as prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi on Wednesday pledged unusually forceful measures to solve Italy’s deep problems. These steps include new restrictions on illegal immigrants and the use of the military to tackle the longstanding garbage crisis in Naples.

headline: MP3 Players Without Cords
text: Q. Are there any wireless headphones that can be used with portable MP3 players? If so, do they have the same quality as the regular wired earphones?

headline: Gym Owner Questioned About Clemens
text: Federal agents have questioned another gym owner in Texas as part of their perjury investigation of Roger Clemens.

headline: Lakers Come on Strong and Pull Out Game 1
text: LOS ANGELES  When the Lakers gathered Monday night at a restaurant to watch Game 7 of the Spurs-Hornets series, Kobe Bryant presented each of his teammates with a $9,800 watch  a thank-you present for helping him earn the Most Valuable Player award.

headline: A Slap at the Dalai Lama
text: Last September, Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, courageously broke with her predecessors and met with the Dalai Lama. China predictably objected, soon joined by Mrs. Merkel’s vice chancellor and foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, who accused her of trying to “showcase” human rights.

headline: Chairs With Talking Points
text: AHMED KHOUJA’S Bean rocker is not exactly a precarious seat, but neither is it particularly stable. Shaped like a slatted lima bean, it requires your participation  to cross your legs just so and use your stomach muscles  to avoid tipping over.

headline: Safer Public Transportation
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Obama Heads to Florida, Many of Its Jews Have Doubts
text: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  At the Aberdeen Golf and Country Club on Sunday, the fountains were burbling, the man-made lakes were shining, and Shirley Weitz and Ruth Grossman were debating why Jews in this gated neighborhood of airy retirement homes feel so much trepidation about Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Google Says It Will Defend Competitive Rationale of a Yahoo Deal
text: How can Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, contend that teaming up with Yahoo in search ads would not invite an antitrust challenge?

headline: France Says Weak Dollar May Fuel Protections
text: PARIS  France’s finance minister on Wednesday urged central bankers to reduce the “misalignment” in the world’s major currencies, warning that a low American dollar was feeding an increasing trend toward protectionism in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: Breaking Impasse, European Nations Agree to Start Broad Talks With Russians
text: BRUSSELS  Ending an 18-month impasse, European Union countries agreed Wednesday to begin wide new negotiations with Russia.

headline: A Sly Brand of Relaxation That Doesn’t Involve Leisure
text: Al Foster pulls off a neat trick as a jazz drummer, and it’s hard to say exactly how he does it. Like a number of his peers, Mr. Foster, 64, places his beat on the forward lip of any tempo, creating an irresistible pull. And yet his playing exudes a laid-back feel, with plenty of room built in. To watch him in action, perched low to the ground behind several sharply angled cymbals, is to witness something like an expert golf swing.

headline: Oklahoma: University Gets $100 Million Donation
text: In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens, the university announced. Mr. Pickens, an alumnus of Oklahoma State and the founder and chairman of BP Capital Management, has already donated about $400 million to the university. Oklahoma law dictates that gifts like Mr. Pickens’s, given for endowed chairs, are to be matched by the state, bringing the amount the university will receive to $200 million.

headline: Protecting Animal Welfare
text: To the Editor:

headline: McCain Looks to Fill Ticket, and 3 Hopefuls Step Up
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona is set to meet with at least three potential running mates at a gathering at his ranch this weekend in Arizona, suggesting that he is stepping up his search for a vice-presidential candidate as the Democratic contest heads toward a conclusion, according to Republicans familiar with Mr. McCain’s plans.

headline: Shopping for Toile With Richard Saja
text: RICHARD SAJA is always on the lookout for toile, but not to buy a few yards for a dressing room armchair. He looks at the fabric as the basis for his art.

headline: Uranium Producer Warns of Lake Ontario Pollution
text: OTTAWA  Cameco, the world’s largest uranium producer, has told the Canadian nuclear regulator that its refinery might have leaked uranium, arsenic and fluorides into Lake Ontario.

headline: Names of the Dead
