text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,073 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: Europe’s Plan to Curb Tire Noise Exempts S.U.V.’s
text: BRUSSELS  Environmental advocates accused the European Commission on Wednesday of being soft on the auto industry by allowing a proposal to reduce noise from car and truck tires to exempt tires for sport utility vehicles.

headline: Americans Can Send Phones to Cuba
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush announced Wednesday that Americans would soon be allowed to give their relatives in Cuba cell phones to use. The move is intended to challenge Cuba’s new leader, Raul Castro, to make good on his promises of reform, by giving ordinary Cubans more freedom to communicate with one another and the outside world.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Wednesday about personnel issues confronting the Giants described incorrectly, in some editions, a big Super Bowl catch by Kevin Boss, the team’s promising young tight end. It was a 45-yard play, not a touchdown.

headline: At Table No. 3, Lunch With a Side of Schmooze
text: Joe Armstrong, who is otherwise known as the Mayor of Michael’s, took his usual perch at Table No. 3 on Tuesday as the suits began filling the room.

headline: Israel Holds Peace Talks With Syria
text: JERUSALEM  Israel and Syria announced on Wednesday that they were engaged in negotiations for a comprehensive peace treaty through Turkish mediators, a sign that Israel is hoping to halt the growing influence of Iran, Syria’s most important ally, which sponsors the anti-Israel groups Hezbollah and Hamas.

headline: Former Band Manager Is Sentenced
text: Lou Pearlman, right, the former manager of pop acts like the Backstreet Boys and ’N Sync, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Wednesday for running a decades-long investment scheme that defrauded investors of $300 million. In a sentencing hearing at Federal District Court in Orlando, Fla., Judge G. Kendall Sharp gave Mr. Pearlman an unusual incentive to pay back his investors, offering to reduce the sentence by one month for every $1 million he repays. Mr. Pearlman, 53, pleaded guilty in March to charges of conspiracy and money laundering in connection with a Ponzi scheme in which he used fake accounting documents to lure people to invest in two companies that existed only on paper. Mr. Pearlman fled the country early last year, once federal authorities began investigating him, and in June he was found at a hotel in Bali, registered under the name A. Incognito Johnson. Larry Rifken, a lawyer representing victims of the schemes, said in a statement: “The Creditors Committee is delighted with Judge Sharp’s ruling today on Mr. Pearlman’s sentence and believes that Judge Sharp did an excellent job in maximizing Mr. Pearlman’s incentive to cooperate with the Trustee and the Committee in identifying, locating and monetizing any remaining undisclosed assets.”

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on March 13 about the struggle among parents in the New York region over how to answer their children’s questions about the sex scandal that brought down Gov. Eliot Spitzer misstated the name of the 6-year-old daughter of Joy and Jeff Yagid of Maplewood, N.J.. She is Bella, not Della. Ms. Yagid left a note on an online bulletin board on March 14 alerting the reporter to the error, but the reporter did not see the note until Friday.

headline: A New Turn on Old Pots
text: Teco art pottery vases produced by William D. Gates in Illinois in the early 20th century, in dark blue, pale yellow and a popular subtle green, have been highly collectible since the 1980s. Now Prairie Arts, a company outside Chicago that makes and sells American Arts and Crafts accessories, is reproducing the vases in two new colors “that appeal to that younger demographic,” said Bryan Kelly, one of the owners.

headline: U.N. Leader Aims to Get More Aid in Myanmar
text: BANGKOK  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, flew on Thursday to Myanmar, where he hoped to pry open the door to more international aid at what he called a “critical moment” in the country’s slow recovery from the cyclone that left at least 100,000 people dead or missing.

headline: Britain: A New Look for Judges
text: Civil court judges in England are scheduled to ditch their traditional wigs and robes in October. The old, stuffy outfits  curly gray wigs made from horsehair, severe black robes with winged collars and stiff neckbands  are to be replaced by modern navy robes created by the fashion designer Betty Jackson. Ms. Jackson, who donated her services, is friends with the wife of a judge, a spokesman for the judiciary said. The changes will not apply to criminal court judges, nor to barristers, as lawyers who argue cases in court are known in Britain. Critics of the traditional wigs and robes have long complained that they alienate people in court and look hopelessly out of date.

headline: A Keyboard Invites Preschoolers to Play With the Computer. Mom and Dad Won’t Mind.
text: While custom keyboards for children are not new, Computer Cool School from Fisher-Price takes the genre up a notch, with light-up activity keys, a surprisingly sensitive touch pad and stylus and a software package that can manage settings for up to five children.

headline: When Two Davids Became Goliaths
text: As David Archuleta and David Cook competed for the title of “American Idol,” the second-to-last installment of the Fox show’s seventh season attracted 26.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That tally was up slightly from the same night a year ago (25.3 million). Fox dominated the night’s ratings over all, attracting 12.6 million with “Hell’s Kitchen” during the 9 o’clock hour after the final performances. ABC was runner up, as 19.9 million viewers tuned in for the finale of “Dancing With the Stars” from 9 to 11. CBS ranked third, earning a large audience for the two-hour finale of “NCIS” (16.4 million). At 10, CBS’s “Shark” delivered more modest ratings (10.5 million). NBC finished fourth over all, with mostly repeats.

headline: Pakistan and Taliban Agree to Army’s Gradual Pullback
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The government signed a deal with Taliban militants on Wednesday that calls for the Pakistani Army to withdraw gradually from Swat, a once popular resort area in North-West Frontier Province that has become a battleground.

headline: Sony Pictures to Release ‘Rent’
text: The Broadway production of “Rent” is headed to movie theaters. The final performance of the rock musical, which exits Broadway on Sept. 7 after 12 years, will be exhibited nationwide as part of a new business from Sony Pictures. The movie studio said on Wednesday that it would bring music concerts, stage shows and sporting events to multiplexes. Another early offering will be “Delirium,” a Cirque du Soleil show touring Europe. Exact dates for the limited engagements are still undecided. Programming theaters with nonmovie content has been gaining steam as multiplex owners seek ways to attract new ticket buyers. Sony is the first big studio to dip its toe into the arena, which until now has been left to niche players like Colorado-based Fathom Events, which simulcasts from the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Kennedy: A Little Like Everyone, a Lot Like No One Else
text: WASHINGTON  Congress is rife with types: the Serious Legislator, the Bomb Thrower, the Show Horse, the Workhorse, the Blowhard, the Orator, the Partisan, the Statesman, the Prima Donna, the Mentor, the Old-fashioned Pol and the Visionary.

headline: Clinton Signals She May Carry Fight to Convention
text: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  A day after Senator Barack Obama gathered a majority of pledged delegates in the Democratic presidential nominating contest, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defiantly sent out new signals Wednesday that she might take her fight for the nomination all the way to the party’s convention in August.

headline: Gun Dealer and Mayor Face Showdown
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood at City Hall two years ago to announce that he had just filed suit against several gun shop owners, mainly in the South, it was in a certain fashion the capstone of a signature campaign. Mr. Bloomberg had already bashed the industry in several angry speeches, gone to Washington to pressure congressmen and lobbyists, and made his war against illegal guns a personal crusade.

headline: With Mild Concussion, A Met Hopes to Return
text: ATLANTA  Ryan Church sauntered down the tunnel leading from the Mets’ clubhouse to the field, his bright blue hat on backward, concealing the tomato-size red welt on the right side of his forehead. The night before, he collided with Braves shortstop Yunel Escobar on the last play of the game and laid motionless, his head in the dirt next to second base.

headline: Swimsuits Make the Man
text: THERE is a sad deficiency of well-made men’s swimwear. Apart from classic surfer shorts from reliable suppliers like Birdwell, we are drowning in a sea of bunchy nylon, bad graphics and unfortunate cuts.

headline: U.S. Troops Kill 11 Shiite Militants
text: BAGHDAD  American troops killed 11 suspected Shiite militants in a series of clashes near Sadr City on Wednesday, one day after thousands of Iraqi troops moved onto the streets of the east Baghdad district.

headline: Diplomatic Effort Seeks to Ease Tensions and Lead to Talks in Georgian Enclave
text: SUKHUMI, Georgia  The long military standoff in Abkhazia, where a separatist dispute has threatened to escalate this year into a renewed war, has entered a phase of quiet diplomacy aimed at easing tensions and urging negotiations, officials on each side of the conflict said.

headline: Lion Who Made Players Roar Faces the Quiet
text: Marvin Miller transformed major league baseball players from sheep into lions.

headline: McCain Set to Release Health Data on Friday
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain is set to release 400 pages of medical records, including documents related to his melanoma surgery in August 2000, to a tightly controlled group of reporters on the Friday before Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Where Ralph Buys Blouses
text: AT 7 most mornings, including a lot of Saturdays and Sundays, Pat Capolupo is in his garment factory, Pat & Rose Dresses, on West 37th Street. Rose is Rose Panebianco, his sister, and for the last 40 years they have made the drive together from Cliffside Park, N.J., where they live two blocks apart.

headline: Return of the Scream
text: Bearing scars from a brazen theft, the Edvard Munch Expressionist masterwork “The Scream” went back on view on Wednesday in Oslo at the Munch Museum, where it was stolen in 2004, Agence France-Presse reported. “The Scream” and “Madonna,” another Munch painting seized at the same time, were presented to the news media and will go on public display from Friday through Sept. 26 under the title “Scream and Madonna  Revisited.” Then “Madonna” will undergo further restoration. The museum said its “Scream,” long thought to have been painted in 1893, as was another version, probably dates from 1910, although some doubts remain. Both paintings were scratched and torn and showed signs of humidity damage when they were recovered by the police in August 2006 under mysterious circumstances.

headline: Ways for Collectors and Dealers to Keep It Real
text: David H. Wilson, an antiques restorer in New Jersey who consults for Christie’s, offered these tips for spotting fakes.

headline: The Meaning of Mushrooms
text: Q. Mushrooms are growing around the stump of a fallen tree in my yard. Are they harmful to plants or other trees, or just signs that the stump is decomposing?

headline: Florida Pension Fund Is Suing A.I.G.
text: In another blow to the embattled American International Group, a Florida pension fund accused the insurance giant and a number of its top executives on Wednesday of understating the company’s exposure to the subprime mortgage crisis in order to inflate its stock price artificially.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on May 14 about a request to Congress for an infusion of $275 million for the Food and Drug Administration misstated the time frame for spending the money. Legislation is being written to allow the agency to spend the money through fiscal year 2009. A letter from the Food and Drug commissioner, Andrew C. von Eschenbach, to Senator Arlen Specter did not say that the agency could absorb the money in the next few months, nor did it give a specific time period.

headline: Quick Reminder to Speed Up Games
text: Baseball games are taking an extra minute out of the lives of fans, and team owners are concerned. On Tuesday, officials from the office of Commissioner Bud Selig held conference calls with club officials and umpires to remind them of rules designed to quicken games.

headline: Fewer Conflicts Involve Child Soldiers, Report Finds
text: DAKAR, Senegal  The number of conflicts in which children are used as soldiers has dropped sharply in the past four years, to 17 from 27, according to a research report released this week by the Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers.

headline: Where Children Fight the Wars, Innocence Dies First
text: CANNES, France  The brutal French-Belgian-Liberian movie “Johnny Mad Dog,” an assaultive fiction about Liberian child soldiers made with boys and girls who actually fought in that country’s recent war, left me wrung out  furious, confused, deep in thought. Shown Tuesday in Un Certain Regard, a section of the Cannes Film Festival reserved for younger and experimental filmmakers, the movie is the first fiction feature by Jean-Stéphane Sauvaire, a former assistant director who was born in 1968. Mr. Sauvaire previously made the documentary “Carlitos Medellin” (2004), about children who are surviving and dying from the violence that plagues Medellin, Colombia.

headline: Taliban Make Afghan Stability a Distant Goal
text: KHAKREZ, Afghanistan  Last fall, groups of Taliban fighters swarmed into every village in this district in southern Afghanistan. American forces arrived to sweep them out in January, people here say. By April, the Taliban were back, surrounding the district center in a show of force that froze villagers in their tracks. Then the insurgents melted away again.

headline: A Sketch From Spain and More Classic Fare
text: Countries with powerful popular cultures don’t produce many fugues. Abstraction and formal design have a hard time competing with musical impulses that seem to grow out of the ground, especially when the country is Spain and the melding of European and North African music remains so strong.

headline: Pirates, Pashas and Slaves in a Duel of Airborne Acrobatics
text: As war horses go, “Le Corsaire” is decidedly pretty and can still kick, a nice choice for the first week of American Ballet Theater’s season at the Metropolitan Opera House. What is rather lovable about this ballet, which opened on Tuesday night, is its utter lack of interest in Great Art. The story, originally inspired by Lord Byron’s 1814 poem “The Corsair,” now bears only the faintest of resemblances to that work, which blends ideas about slavery and liberation into the tale of the pirate Conrad, “that man of loneliness and mystery, scarce seen to smile.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Why a Fish Didn’t Show at a Festival in Its Honor
text: NYACK, N.Y.

headline: Deal for Lebanese Factions Leaves Hezbollah Stronger
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The agreement reached by Lebanese political factions early Wednesday amounted to a significant shift of power in favor of the militant Shiite group Hezbollah and its allies in the opposition, who won the power to veto any cabinet decision.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A capsule summary on Wednesday for an article about F.B.I. agents creating a “war crimes file” to document accusations against American military personnel misstated the year that the agents were told to close the file. It was 2003, not 2002.

headline: Web Site Sells Designers’ Discounted Samples
text: A Web site where decorators and designers can buy from hundreds of manufacturers and showrooms now has a sample-sale area open to the public. Discounted items change constantly, but those now on sale at decorati.com include a colored crystal chandelier in black, left, from NiBa Home in Miami for $8,438 (reduced from $9,375), a Hans Wegner Airport Chair from Dennis Miller in New York for $1,100 (it was $2,500) and a pair of Karl Springer chairs from Todd Hase Furniture for $1,900 (marked down from $2,879). Information: (415) 227-4558 or decorati.com.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Plants for a Japanese Garden

headline: Puerto Rico’s Moment in the Sun
text: PUERTO RICO, an afterthought trophy for the United States 110 years ago at the end of the Spanish-American War and an island in limbo since, has become an improbable player in the contest between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. Its primary on June 1 could bolster Mrs. Clinton’s claim to a majority of the popular vote  the combined tally for all the Democratic primaries and caucuses held across the country over the past six months.

headline: Frank Rich to Be Consultant for HBO
text: Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, has signed on with HBO as a creative consultant to help develop new programming, while still writing his weekly column, HBO and Times executives said Wednesday.

headline: Senators Sharply Question Oil Officials
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee vented their fury over high gasoline prices at executives of the nation’s five largest oil companies on Wednesday, grilling the oilmen over their multimillion-dollar pay packages and warning them that Congress was intent on taking action that could include a new tax on so-called windfall profits.

headline: A Quick Leap to Five Hearts, All in the Interest of Charity
text: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge event had its 45th running on May 14 at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan, with most of the top New York-area players competing. Organized by Marci Miron and Marion Madoff, the event raised more than $125,000 for the UJA-Federation of New York.

headline: The Senate Race in New Jersey: Watching the Debates
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Bronx, Dancer Does Right Thing
text: For 10 years the choreographer Arthur Aviles has been doing yeoman’s work in the Hunts Point neighborhood of the Bronx, where he and his partner, the writer Charles Rice-Gonzalez, founded the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance (BAAD!) in 1998. This work  maintaining a safe, welcoming space for performers and people of all stripes  is as much about activism as it is about art.

headline: Education Agency’s Plan Shores Up Market for Loans to College Students
text: Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings on Wednesday announced a plan committing the federal government to buy college loans for the coming school year from student lending companies and to take other measures to ensure that despite troubled credit markets, students will have access to college financing.

headline: Rock and Blue Eyes Top Billboards Chart
text: Two unlikely acts top this week’s Billboard album chart. Death Cab for Cutie, a bookish indie-rock quartet from Seattle, has reached No. 1 for the first time, and a Frank Sinatra compilation is No. 2. “Narrow Stairs” (Atlantic), Death Cab for Cutie’s seventh album, sold 144,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. “Nothing but the Best” (Reprise), released to coincide with the 10th anniversary of Sinatra’s death, moved 99,000 copies and is the highest-charting Sinatra album since his “Duets” reached No. 2 a dozen years ago. “We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things.” (Atlantic) by the singer Jason Mraz bowed at No. 3 with 73,000 sales, and another new album, “Rockferry” (A&M/Polydor) by the Welsh singer Duffy, is No. 4, moving 71,000.

headline: Rescue Ends One Ordeal for Young Chinese Pupils
text: CHENGDU, China  When the earth finally stopped bucking, only one building was left standing in the vicinity of the Yinxing Township Central Primary School, and that was the school itself.

headline: Three Dubliners’ Plain Poetry of Everyday Loss
text: Words are sharp, shiny hooks in the monologues of the Irish playwright Conor McPherson. They attract and snag the attention, snaring it at least until the language stops, and usually well after that. Give those words to actors who know how to cast a line, and you’ll find an audience helplessly captive.

headline: Nokia and France Télécom Form Partnership
text: Nokia and France Télécom said they had agreed to a partnership to provide Internet services over mobile telephones in nine European countries.

headline: A Laptop Straight From the Mothership
text: Alienware, a Dell subsidiary that makes amped-up desktops and laptops for gamers, just released the Area-51 m17x. True to its name, this futuristic-looking laptop, which starts at $2,199, looks as if it just floated out of an invading spacecraft.

headline: Theme Persists: Obama Outraises Clinton
text: Though Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised an impressive $21 million in April, her campaign ended the month $20 million in debt and with Senator Barack Obama more than $30 million ahead of her in cash on hand for the primary season, according to their latest campaign finance reports.

headline: Ex-Network Reporter Leaves Journalism to Join Obama’s Campaign
text: Linda Douglass, a longtime network news correspondent in Washington now working as a contributing editor to The National Journal, said Wednesday that she would leave the magazine to work for Senator Barack Obama’s campaign.

headline: Questions on Claim That Senator Was Target of Attacks
text: YONKERS  The staff of State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins says that her district office here has been the target of attacks and a break-in recently, but the police have raised questions about some parts of the staff’s account.

headline: Bush to Let Americans Send Cellphones to Cuban Relatives
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush announced Wednesday that Americans would soon be allowed to send cellphones to relatives in Cuba, a policy shift he said was intended to force the country’s new leader, Raúl Castro, to make good on promised reforms by giving his people the freedom to communicate.

headline: Making Opponents See Double
text: The Final Four on Saturday in Foxborough, Mass., will showcase a Duke team that is considered one of the best ever, a revitalized Syracuse club that did not qualify for the postseason last year and a Johns Hopkins team that overcame a five-game losing streak.

headline: Church Has Mild Concussion, but He Plans Quick Return
text: ATLANTA  Ryan Church sauntered down the tunnel leading from the Mets’ clubhouse to the field, his bright blue hat on backward, concealing the tomato-size red welt on the right side of his forehead. The night before, he collided with Braves shortstop Yunel Escobar on the last play of the game and laid motionless, his head in the dirt next to second base.

headline: House Votes to Override Bush’s Veto of Farm Bill
text: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday afternoon to override President Bush’s veto of the $307 billion farm bill, setting the stage for the second veto defeat of Mr. Bush’s presidency.

headline: More Questions Are Raised About Moody’s Ratings
text: The Moody’s Corporation is investigating whether it assigned top-flight credit ratings to certain securities because of computer errors, the company said Wednesday, raising new questions about the credibility of its assessments.

headline: It’s Still a Big City, Just Not Quite So Big
text: Somehow, Michael S. Miller resisted the temptation when he got home not long ago.

headline: In These Places, Old Age Becomes a Team Sport
text: For their new books, Dudley Clendinen and Andrew D. Blechman had different versions of the same idea: infiltrate the world of the not-young and study the native customs. But they took on similar projects for very different reasons. Mr. Clendinen cared deeply about his mother and wanted to understand the last years of her life. Mr. Blechman apparently liked the prospect of shooting geriatric fish in a barrel.

headline: Concerns From Fed Reverberate on Wall Street
text: The Federal Reserve’s aggressive rate-cutting campaign may be at an end.

headline: American, Cutting Back, Plans $15 Bag Fee
text: There’s an old saying about the best way to travel: bring half the clothes and twice the money.

headline: Top ETA Leader Is Seized in France
text: MADRID  Spanish and French authorities said on Wednesday they had arrested one of the highest-ranking members of ETA, dealing a blow to the Basque separatist group after a series of attacks in northern Spain.

headline: Minnesota Agency Faulted on Bridge Upkeep
text: Before the Interstate 35W bridge in downtown Minneapolis collapsed last year, state transportation officials had put off recommendations from experts to make it safer, failed to follow their own inspection policies and at times allowed financing concerns to affect how it was maintained, a team of investigators told Minnesota lawmakers in a report Wednesday.

headline: Donor Gives $20 Million to Revive a Historic Church
text: An anonymous donor has come to the rescue of St. Brigid’s Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, saving the building  which has presided over Tompkins Square Park since 1848  from demolition and making it possible for the structure to be reopened as a parish church.

headline: Zelma Henderson, Who Aided Desegregation, Dies at 88
text: Zelma Henderson, a Kansas beautician who was the sole surviving plaintiff in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, the landmark federal desegregation case of 1954, died on Tuesday in Topeka. She was 88 and had lived in Topeka all her adult life.

headline: Texas Seeks Stay of Polygamy Sect Custody Ruling
text: HOUSTON  The custody battle over 468 children seized from the ranch of a polygamist sect moved to the Texas Supreme Court on Friday, with the state insisting that the children were too endangered by sexual and emotional abuse to be returned to their families.

headline: Appeals Court Rules Against Texas in Polygamy Case
text: HOUSTON  A Texas appeals court ruled Thursday that state authorities and a lower court judge abused their authority by illegally seizing up to 468 children from their homes at a polygamist ranch in West Texas last month.

headline: Fashion’s Harlem Address
text: IN the self-aggrandizing nature of fashion speak, the term “emerging designer market” is often employed to mask what to the average mind would be called a “crafts fair,” where the only key to entry is a hot glue gun and a sack of beads.

headline: Zimbabwe: More Trouble for Anglicans
text: Despite a Supreme Court order requiring that the renegade Anglican bishop Nolbert Kunonga, a supporter of President Robert Mugabe, share dozens of churches in Harare, the capital, with followers of Bishop Sebastian Bakare, church officials and parishioners said the police had continued to harass and lock out the bulk of the city’s Anglicans. “The police have continued to brutalize our people, which is sad,” said Bishop Albert Chama, the dean of the Anglican Province of Central Africa. “This is political interference. I’m sure the police are getting orders from above. They’re protecting Kunonga.”

headline: Fund Manager Is to Refinance Stalled Auction-Rate Notes
text: Nuveen Investments, the largest American manager of closed-end funds, said on Wednesday that it had a commitment for up to $1.75 billion in liquidity support to help refinance the troubled auction-rate preferred shares its funds once issued.

headline: More Space, Delivered to You
text: NEARLY everyone needs more space for storage, but there’s an alternative to renting a truck and carting the excess to a rented unit: the storage space can come to you.

headline: Scientists See Supernova in Action
text: A star trembled on the brink of eternity. Outwardly all was serene, but its inside was falling into chaos.

headline: I Love What You Didn’t Do to Your Chipped Nails
text: PITY the mothers and grandmothers. Visible bra straps, glaringly obvious roots  these are but a few of the grooming no-nos that have become yes-yeses in recent years.

headline: ‘Unnecessary Distraction’ Brings Randolph Apology
text: ATLANTA  Willie Randolph’s pregame meeting with members of the news media in the manager’s office at Turner Field on Wednesday started with a question about the health of Ryan Church, who was injured the night before in a collision at second base.

headline: At One University, Tobacco Money Is a Secret
text: On campuses nationwide, professors and administrators have passionately debated whether their universities should accept money for research from tobacco companies. But not at Virginia Commonwealth University, a public institution in Richmond, Va.

headline: Costly in Alaska
text: To the Editor:

headline: From a World-Class Rower, Tips to Sharpen Technique
text: UNLIKE the teammates who power a quad or an eight-boat and rely on one another for rhythm and timing, a single sculler has no other rower to look to. He or she is a solitary person in a narrow shell of a boat no more than 12 inches across at its widest point.

headline: A Digital Picture Frame, Packaged With Your Images
text: If you wish you could skip the technical hurdle of loading your photos from a computer or memory card onto a digital picture frame, Kodak will happily do it for you.

headline: Voters Choose David Cook as ‘Idol’ Winner
text: LOS ANGELES  It was a winner by a knockout Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of “American Idol,” but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow during the final night of competition one night earlier.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption with an article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about foreign investors’ purchases of Manhattan office buildings reversed the identifications of the two buildings shown. The building at 31 West 52nd Street was shown in the top photograph and the Altria Building, at 120 Park Avenue, was below.

headline: Microsoft Offers Rebates to Shoppers Using Its Search
text: With its share of the Internet search market in steady decline and its pursuit of an alliance with Yahoo in doubt, Microsoft is taking a new approach to jump-starting its search engine: offering rebates to people who use it to find and buy some products.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An obituary by The Associated Press on April 4 about Rafael Azcona, the Spanish novelist and scriptwriter, misstated his date of death, relying on information from the Spanish Writers and Editors Society, and misstated his widow’s given name. He died on March 24, not March 23, and his widow is Susan Youdelman, not Susi. The Associated Press issued a correction on Wednesday.

headline: Charles Brenner, Psychoanalyst, Dies at 94
text: Dr. Charles Brenner, who reigned for nearly a half-century as the dean of American psychoanalysis, working to clarify, refine and fiercely defend its core principles, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: Physical Culture | At Trail’s End, There’s Nothing Like Happy Feet
text: DESPITE improvements in socks and shoes, blisters remain a sports injury that won’t go away. “It’s one of the most common minor injuries among outdoor enthusiasts,” said Dr. Christopher Van Tilburg, the author of “Mountain Rescue Doctor” and the editor of the magazine Wilderness Medicine. “It’s not often reported so we don’t have a lot of statistics, but it’s very, very common and can be extremely debilitating on a long hike.”

headline: Manchester United Wins Champions League Final
text: MOSCOW  A domestic rivalry splashed over international borders on Wednesday when England’s two best soccer clubs took their tenacious battle to the banks of the Moscow River to play for Europe’s most coveted athletic prize.

headline: House Override of Farm Bill Veto Is Only the 2nd in Bush’s Presidency
text: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to override President Bush’s veto of the $307 billion farm bill, just the second override in his presidency.

headline: Was Camerawork Negative? Sure, but Not in a Victory
text: I took the Willie Randolph Television Challenge.

headline: When Lightning Strikes a Modem
text: Q. The first time I used my Dell laptop after a heavy storm, the computer would not hold a dial tone when I tried to dial up to the Internet, and I still cannot get online with that computer. If this modem is fried, can I get an external modem for my laptop, or are there other options?

headline: Artisanal Offerings Are the Trend at Furniture Fair
text: MANY of the pieces at this year’s International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center this month felt more artisanal than manufactured, with less of the emphasis on new materials and technology that dominated the show in the last decade.

headline: Doctors Who Say They’re Sorry
text: The willingness of doctors at several major medical centers to apologize to patients for harmful errors is a promising step toward improving the quality of a medical system that kills tens of thousands of patients a year inadvertently.

headline: Make It Proud and Loud, With Strings
text: The New York Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Marvin Hamlisch demonstrated what might be called the First Law of Orchestration on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall in a 90-minute entertainment, “Broadway’s Greatest Showstoppers.”

headline: Police Officers Gather to Mourn and Wonder
text: ALBANY  Between the solemn invocations and bagpipe tributes on Wednesday afternoon, it was hard to overlook the fact that this year’s annual tribute to fallen New York police officers took place under unusually fraught circumstances.

headline: Headbangers From Iraq, Thrashing and Waiting
text: It was already an unlikely story: Around 2000, a group of Iraqi school friends weaned on bootleg Metallica and Slayer tapes formed their own metal band with an imposing name, Acrassicauda (derived from the name of a species of black scorpion), and an appropriately do-or-die attitude.

headline: A New Manhattan Park Teaches Children About Plants
text: Michael Van Valkenburgh, a landscape architect making his mark in New York with ambitious projects like Brooklyn Bridge Park, has created a more modest bit of greenery: the Toyota Children’s Learning Garden, a pocket park at 603 East 11th Street, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: At West Bank Conference, Dreams of Investment
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Hundreds of potential investors and dignitaries from the Middle East and beyond gathered here on Wednesday for the start of a vaunted conference under the slogan, “Palestine is open for business.”

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Friday about CBS’s $1.8 billion deal to buy CNet Networks misstated, in some copies, the color of the sneakers worn by Quincy Smith, president of CBS Interactive, in an appearance last week at the network’s upfront presentation for advertisers. As an accompanying picture showed, they were dark-colored  not his trademark white ones. And the caption for that photograph misstated, in some copies, the day of Mr. Smith’s appearance. It was Wednesday, May 14  not last Thursday.

headline: As Oil Prices Rise, Nations Revive Coal Mining
text: BIBAI, Japan  These rugged green mountains, once home to one of Asia’s most productive coal regions, are littered with abandoned mines and decaying towns  backwaters of an economy of bullet trains and hybrid cars.

headline: New Florida Law Allows Low-Cost Health Policies
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  With considerable fanfare, Gov. Charlie Crist traveled the length of his state on Wednesday to sign a bill aimed at providing low-cost health coverage to the uninsured by allowing the sale of stripped-down insurance policies.

headline: Hospital Releases Kennedy
text: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy was released from the hospital on Wednesday, a day after it was announced that he has a malignant brain tumor.

headline: Mets Lose in Nine, but Their Misery Goes Extra Innings
text: ATLANTA  The Mets have been able to fend off criticism of their wobbly start this season by declaring that the season is still young, but it may be difficult for the team to convince anyone it is a contender.

headline: Sizing Up the Cut of a Man
text: EVEN if you spend a lot of time around fashion and the endearing nut jobs who create it, this question comes up every so often: Who is that person?

headline: Kennedy Talked, Khrushchev Triumphed
text: IN his inaugural address, President John F. Kennedy expressed in two eloquent sentences, often invoked by Barack Obama, a policy that turned out to be one of his presidency’s  indeed one of the cold war’s  most consequential: “Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.” Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Kennedy’s special assistant, called those sentences “the distinctive note” of the inaugural.

headline: The Rain and the Minutes Pelt Down
text: First the calves cramp up, then the mind. How else to explain the pitty-pat slap that Didier Drogba administered in the final slogging minutes of the Champions League final on Wednesday?

headline: What the F.B.I. Agents Saw
text: Does this sound familiar? Muslim men are stripped in front of female guards and sexually humiliated. A prisoner is made to wear a dog’s collar and leash, another is hooded with women’s underwear. Others are shackled in stress positions for hours, held in isolation for months, and threatened with attack dogs.

headline: A Home Run, Umpire Says
text: For the second time in three games at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, umpires missed a home run call that could have been made correctly with the use of instant replay. On Sunday, they negated a homer by the Mets’ Carlos Delgado. This time, the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez was robbed.

headline: Correction
text: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about spa treatments using locally produced ingredients, referred incorrectly to the Maine Blueberry Pedicure at the Cliff House Resort and Spa in Ogunquit, Me. The pedicure was provided at no extra charge for guests booking a three- or four-night stay last July and August; it is not offered free with the purchase of a Maine Blueberry Body Wrap.

headline: Obama Declares Nomination Is ‘Within Reach’
text: Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday, amassing enough additional delegates to claim an all but insurmountable advantage in his race against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: An Indian Airport Hurries to Make the First Flight
text: BANGALORE, India  For years, frequent fliers in this technology hub complained bitterly about having to suffer the indignities of a tattered and tiny airport scrunched in the middle of a busy city neighborhood.

headline: Wang Says Strain Won’t Stop Next Start
text: Brian Cashman was in a meeting Wednesday when he took a call from the Yankees’ trainer’s room. That is rarely a good call for a general manager to take.

headline: The Democrats: Into the Homestretch
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pundits, Like Candidates, Find Themselves in Limbo
text: David Wright, the ABC News correspondent traveling with Senator Barack Obama in Iowa late Tuesday night, was interpreting the meaning of the senator’s primary performance in Kentucky  where he was “thumped again,” in the words of the ABC “Nightline” anchor Terry Moran.

headline: Beauvoir Trove Sold
text: In Paris on Wednesday Sotheby’s sold Simone de Beauvoir’s first completed novel, written when she was 18, along with tapes and other manuscripts of hers, all part of a rare trove of unpublished material compiled by one of her biographers, Fernande Gontier. “Départ,” (“Departure”) is a 351-page autobiographical novel that Beauvoir, above, finished in 1926; it brought about $56,260 and was sold to France’s National Library. Ms. Gontier, who collaborated with Beauvoir until she died in 1986, bought Beauvoir’s earliest manuscripts, including the novel, from a bookstore in Boston in 1980.

headline: Tip of the Week: Saving Your Cellphone From Water Damage
text: A bag of dry, uncooked rice can save your bacon if you accidentally drop your cellphone in a puddle or some other body of water. If your phone takes a splash, get it out of the water as soon as possible and take out the battery and SIM card (if it has one) immediately.

headline: Advice From White House Is Not Always Followed
text: WASHINGTON  Israel, America’s staunchest ally in the Middle East, just became the latest example of a country that has decided it is better to deal with its foes than to ignore them.

headline: Federal Court Reinstates Suit on Gays in Military
text: The federal appeals court in California on Wednesday reinstated a lawsuit challenging the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, which allows gay men and lesbians to serve in the armed forces so long as their sexual orientation remains private.

headline: Uploading Photos for You, With Longitude and Latitude
text: With a new memory card called the Explore, your camera can tell you where your photos were taken. The Explore is from Eye-Fi, which introduced a memory card with built-in Wi-Fi and automatic uploading last year.

headline: Author Examines the State of the Avant Garden Movement
text: What has happened to the avant garden since 1979, when Martha Schwartz burned a hole in the landscape world with her Bagel Garden? In “Avant Gardeners: 50 Visionaries of the Contemporary Landscape” (Thames & Hudson, $60), Tim Richardson, a British critic, examines gardens driven more by concept than plants or place, from Ms. Schwartz’s double row of varnished bagels in Cambridge, Mass. (he calls it “half Pop Art, half 17th-century parterre”), to more recent projects like Claude Cormier’s Lipstick Forest, 52 pink concrete tree trunks at a Montreal convention center, and Ron Lutsko’s minimalist landscapes in California. Mr. Richardson, who is as well-versed in 18th-century landscapes as he is in the primary colors of a Topher Delaney garden, matter-of-factly acknowledges that art must shed some blood to stay alive, which makes him a good Virgil for the journey into what he calls conceptualist landscape design.

headline: Raiding the Pantry to Add Sparkle and Shine
text: “MICHELLE, would you like to head up the creamy soft-scrub team?”

headline: The Further Adventures of the Fedora and Whip
text: CANNES, France  “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” is a movie for boomers of all ages, though you can bet the bank that plenty of tots will be tagging along with Mom and Dad, Granny and Gramps. Like the 1981 blockbuster “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” the first in a monster franchise that has spawned two previous movie sequels, a television series, comics, novels, video games and Disney theme-park attractions, this new one was directed by Steven Spielberg, cooked up and executive produced by George Lucas (with Kathleen Kennedy) and stars Harrison Ford as the archaeologist-adventurer-sexpot with the sardonic grin, rakish fedora and suggestive bullwhip.

headline: Which Came First, or Does It Even Matter?
text: IN the fast-food business, imitation isn’t just a form of flattery  it’s a proven way to increase sales.

headline: China Earthquake Pushes Tibet to Sidelines
text: As the Dalai Lama toured European capitals this week, the British prime minister closed the door to 10 Downing Street and agreed to meet him only as part of an “interfaith dialogue.” In Germany, most government officials declined to talk with him at all.

headline: Whipping Up a Batch of Furniture Polish
text: FOLLOWING are recipes for household cleaning products that use substances people tend to have around the house. The first one, for window cleaner, is from Consumer Reports. The others are those distributed by Women’s Voices for the Earth at parties it holds to encourage the use of homemade cleaners.

headline: Records Broken at Christies Auction
text: The monumental Thomas Moran landscape “Green River of Wyoming,” above, estimated at $3.5 million to $5 million, sold on Wednesday for $17.73 million at a Christie’s sale of American art in New York. The price set a record for a 19th-century American painting, surpassing that of John Singer Sargent’s “Robert Louis Stevenson and His Wife,” which fetched $8.8 million when it was sold at Sotheby’s in 2004 to the Las Vegas casino owner Stephen A. Wynn and his wife, Elaine. The buyer of the Moran was the Avery Galleries of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Another oil on canvas, Marsden Hartley’s “Lighthouse,” created in Berlin in 1915 and recently brought to light after its discovery in a museum in eastern Germany, sold for $6.31 million to an anonymous telephone bidder. Christie’s said the painting, with a estimate of $5 million to $7 million, set an auction record for an American Modernist painting, surpassing the $6.16 million for Georgia O’Keeffe’s “Calla Lilies With Red Anemone,” sold at Christie’s in 2001.

headline: Organize: It’s Your Civic Duty
text: THE jury summons said to go the courthouse the day I was supposed to drive the French horn car pool, write a 1,000-word column, take the dog to the vet and fax some supplementary tax records to my accountant (if I could find the slip of paper on which I wrote the fax number).

headline: 20 Seconds, and a Movie Has Arrived
text: Last year, the movie industry raked in more than $40 billion.

headline: Kennedy Leaves Hospital in Boston
text: BOSTON  One day after hearing the news that he has a malignant brain tumor, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, walked out of a hospital on Wednesday morning to a crowd of well wishers appearing strong and cheerful.

headline: The Blind Welcome a Ruling That May Help Them Count Their Cash
text: Harold Wenning, 69, remembers what he called “the one-for-five trick” from his days running a news kiosk in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Earthquake and Hope
text: BEIJING

headline: Lloyd Moore, Pioneering Nascar Driver, Dies at 95
text: Lloyd Moore, recognized by Nascar as its oldest living racecar driver, died Sunday at his home in Frewsburg, N.Y. He was 95.

headline: Fear of Troop Exodus Fuels Debate on G.I. Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Ever since the G.I.’s came home from World War II, it has been the nation’s policy to reward war veterans with college education. Now, a bipartisan proposal to expand that benefit significantly for today’s veterans has encountered a new complication: the military still needs its fighting men and women in uniform, not in classrooms.

headline: New From Wii: Not Much to Get Worked Up About
text: I hate working out. I’ve always thought the ideal solution would be for a workout enthusiast to telepathically connect with me and exercise my body while I slept, letting me avoid the discomfort and tedium of exercise.

headline: Hall Interior in Berlin Intact After Fire
text: A fire at the home of the Berlin Philharmonic will leave the orchestra homeless at least until June 2, forcing this weekend’s hefty program  Berlioz’s Te Deum and its 720 performers  into an open-air stadium, an orchestra spokesman said on Wednesday.

headline: Furniture Restorer’s Allegations of Deception Shake Antiques Trade
text: MICHAEL SMITH, a prominent decorator in Los Angeles, was staggered when a friend called from London in early April with the news: John Hobbs, a London antiques dealer known for superb English and Continental furniture, stratospheric prices and wealthy American clients, had been accused by his longtime restorer of selling fakes.

headline: Patrick Ireland, 36, Dies; Created to Serve Peace
text: DUBLIN  On Tuesday evening, here on a grassy terrace behind the old Royal Hospital Kilmainham, with the sun still high in the sky and his heart full of joy, Brian O’Doherty attended his own wake.

headline: Regulating the Net
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Finds Big Social Factor in Quitting Smoking
text: For years, smokers have been exhorted to take the initiative and quit: use a nicotine patch, chew nicotine gum, take a prescription medication that can help, call a help line, just say no. But a new study finds that stopping is seldom an individual decision.

headline: Spike Lee Plays Critic
text: Spike Lee is at the Cannes Film Festival to promote a new film, but he couldn’t resist taking a few swipes at his fellow directors Joel and Ethan Coen and Clint Eastwood. Speaking about his World War II drama, “Miracle at St. Anna,” Mr. Lee said that, unlike the Coens, he was respectful in the way he portrayed death.“I always treat life and death with respect, but most people don’t,” he said at a news conference on Tuesday, according to The Hollywood Reporter. “Look, I love the Coen brothers; we all studied at N.Y.U. But they treat life like a joke. Ha ha ha. A joke. It’s like: ‘Look how they killed that guy! Look how blood squirts out the side of his head!’ I see things different than that.”Speaking about the casting for his tale of four black American soldiers in Tuscany, Mr. Lee said that black actors appeared in war films too infrequently.“Clint Eastwood made two films about Iwo Jima that ran for more than four hours total, and there was not one Negro actor on the screen,” he said, adding, “There’s no way I know why he did that  that was his vision, not mine.” Mr. Lee also said that he was starting work on a documentary about Michael Jordan.

headline: Big Pictures, Now Suitable for E-Mail
text: ANN SAKAI has used a digital camera for eight years, but she has yet to conquer photo bloat. The oversized photo files she e-mails to friends and family strain the limits of their in-boxes.

headline: Food Fight: City Hall vs. Vendor
text: It was not the mayor’s birthday, nor had he even ordered in. But that did not stop concerned food vendors from coming to the defense of a colleague on Monday by delivering a large white cake to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg decorated with an unusual message in red, cherry-flavored icing: “$1,000 fine.”

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Public Lives column in some editions on Friday, about Nadine Strossen, who recently resigned as president of the American Civil Liberties Union, referred incorrectly to her tenure. She served for more than 17 years; she was not an “18-year” incumbent. And while she led the group for the longest period of time under the title of president  changed from “chairman” during the tenure of her immediate predecessor  she is not in fact the A.C.L.U.’s longest-serving leader. (That would be Harry Ward, who served as chairman for 20 years.) The article also misspelled the surname of one of Ms. Strossen’s debating partners over the years. She is Phyllis Schlafly, not Schlafley.

headline: Bach
text: The phrase “universal composer” is justifiably applied to Bach, Mozart and Beethoven. But the universality of Bach’s music is distinct in that many of his works can be effectively performed on different instruments, in a way that Beethoven’s “Moonlight” Sonata can’t. Bach “cannot die,” the pianist and harpsichordist Rosalyn Tureck said in 1961. “An instrument can die, but Bach can never die.”

headline: Students Questioned About Plot to Kill People
text: Three students at James Madison High School in Brooklyn were questioned by investigators on Wednesday after notes were discovered describing a plan to kill people in and around the school, the police said.

headline: Trainer Hints Belmont Isn’t End for Big Brown
text: With the Belmont Stakes still more than two weeks away, the trainer Rick Dutrow’s swagger over Big Brown is in full force.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: Small Steps in Talks on Kashmir
text: India and Pakistan agreed to give consular access to each other’s prisoners and increase cross-border bus service in the disputed region of Kashmir during talks between the countries’ foreign ministers. The small concessions were considered a sign of progress between the nuclear powers. Shah Mehmood Qureshi, foreign minister of Pakistan, said talks were “very frank,” while India’s foreign minister, Pranab Mukherjee, said the two countries “have to cover a long distance.” The governments plan to meet again in July.

headline: New York Fair Highlights Decorative Art Objects
text: Craft may be missing from the show’s name, but the annual Sculpture Objects and Functional Art New York fair will spotlight just that: one-of-a-kind, limited-edition and handmade objects in ceramics, glass, fiber, metal and wood. Starting May 29, more than 60 galleries from 11 countries will fill the Park Avenue Armory with modern and contemporary pieces like the hand-hammered metal Bis sculpture by Hervé Wahlen ($17,500 from Barry Friedman Ltd.), above; Michael Geertsen’s glazed earthenware Yellow Wall Object ($4,000 from Koppe Gallery); and Malene Müllertz’s ceramic White Burrs Basket ($3,200 from Lacoste Gallery), left. Mark Lyman, SOFA’s founding director, said he prefers to think of it not as craft, but as “unique work that celebrates quality of material and process while maintaining a connection to the intellect.” Through June 1 at the Park Avenue Armory at 67th Street, (800) 563-7632 or sofaexpo.com; admission is $25.

headline: Correction
text: An article on May 1 about biodegradable home products misstated the name of the university where researchers conducted the Garbage Project, which studied landfills for several decades beginning in the 1970s. It was the University of Arizona in Tucson, not the University of Tucson.

headline: Catherine Mulkerrin, Activist Boston Nun, Dies at 72
text: Sister Catherine E. Mulkerrin, who lobbied ardently but in vain to persuade Roman Catholic leaders in the Boston Archdiocese to warn parishioners about priests who had been accused of sexually molesting children, died on Saturday in Framingham, Mass. She was 72 and lived in Brighton, Mass.

headline: Yoo adds another big name designer to its roster
text: With developers around the world racing to enlist big name designers to add pizazz to their projects, Yoo—the design-centric company that helped power the trend—has added another A-lister to its design team.

headline: And The Winner Is…
text: “It was a winner by a knockout Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of ‘American Idol,’ but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow during the final night of competition one night earlier,” Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Yankees Make It Official: Chamberlain Will Start
text: The Yankees began Joba Chamberlain’s transition to the starting rotation on Wednesday, when he worked the final two innings — 35 pitches — of the Yankees’ 8-0 victory against the Orioles.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 99 Kent State
text: Location: Kent, Ohio

headline: Odds and Ends
text: In Thursday’s Times, Bill Finley takes a look at what the rest of Big Brown’s 3-year-old campaign could look like, culminating with a possible faceoff against Curlin in the Breeders’ Cup Classic.

headline: Shulman and Zatonskih Are U.S. Champions
So-Called Bridge Loans Can Take Many Forms
text: Q. What is a "bridge loan," and what is it used for?

headline: Special Assessments and Homeowners’ Taxes
text: Q. If a town or county imposes a special tax assessment against property owners for improvements like construction of streets, sidewalks, water mains, sewer lines, public parking facilities or similar things, is that assessment deductible on an income-tax return, as real estate taxes are?

headline: Weak Economy Bolsters Sales of Picture-Tube TVs
text: The slowing American economy has had an unexpected effect on the television business: a resurgence in the popularity of the standard picture-tube TV.

headline: When a Kiss is not A Kiss: Behaving Like a Local in Mumbai
text: This is the second installment of some insider-generated content on how to navigate Mumbai. Last week, three style shapers revealed how to dress for the city. This week, four Mumbaikars — native and adopted — share their advice on how to behave like an insider. Thanks to Rohan Gopaldas, Anuvab Pal, Shuchi Pandya and Priya Parker for these tips. They should know.

headline: Animated Discussions
text: From the Journal of Cartoon Over-Analyzations:

headline: Not So Fluffy Inside
More Deals for Enterprise Database Companies?
text: Sun Microsystems‘ acquisition of MySQL gave it a chunk of the huge enterprise database market. The 451 Group takes a look at how Oracle, IBM and Microsoft might respond with more deal activity of their own.

headline: Apollo Hires Former Morgan Banker to Lead Commodities Unit
text: Apollo Management has hired Morgan Stanley‘s ex-head of fixed income to develop a commodities business as more companies move into the sector to capitalize on rising prices and volatility.

headline: Simon Cowell Says ‘Sorry’ To ‘Idol’ Winner
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Sun Capital’s Jevic Files for Bankruptcy
text: Sun Capital Partners‘ Jevic Holding is seeking bankruptcy protection, as a nationwide decline in freight volumes has led the trucking company to look for a permanent rest stop.

headline: Pickens Donates $100 Million to Oklahoma State University
text: In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens, the university announced.

headline: Past Performance Is No Guarantee Of Future Results, Even on ‘Idol’
text: Under Simon Cowell’s deal with Fox, he has the rights to sign the winning singer and runner-up from each “American Idol” contest to a recording contract with his label, Sony BMG, a partnership between Sony Corp and Bertelsmann.

headline: Travel Basics: Beijing
text: By Donald Morrison

headline: L.S.E.’s Full-Year Profit Rises 58.6%
text: The London Stock Exchange Group reported Thursday that full-year profit rose 58.6 percent, boosted by its acquisition of Borsa Italiana.

headline: Dubai World Tees Off Deal for Starwood’s Scottish Resort
text: Dubai World, the state-owned investment group managing more than $100 billion, agreed to buy Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide‘s Turnberry golf resort in Scotland to expand its Leisurecorp sports unit.

headline: Adelphia Founder And Son to Be Re-Sentenced
text: A federal district court judge on Thursday will re-evaluate the prison sentences of Adelphia founder John Rigas and his son Timothy after an appeals court overturned one part of their convictions last year.

headline: China’s 51.com Raises $50 Million
text: 51.com, one of China’s largest social networks, is closing a $50 million round and plans to launch a platform for third party developers later this summer, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Fund Manager Is to Refinance Stalled Auction-Rate Notes
text: Nuveen Investments, the largest American manager of closed-end funds, said on Wednesday that it had a commitment for up to $1.75 billion in liquidity support to help refinance the troubled auction-rate preferred shares its funds once issued.

headline: Mexico Stock Exchange Plans to Raise $444 Million in I.P.O.
text: Mexico’s stock exchange operator says it’s ready to go public in its home market and in the U.S. next month in an offering that could raise as much as 4.6 billion pesos, or about $444 million.

headline: Handling, and Defending, Matt Walsh
text: An out-of-the-blue comment from a reader, Don Goldberg, who pointed us to his Web site, Damage Control 101:

headline: Philips Unloads Stake in MedQuist
text: Philips Electronics has agreed to sell its 69.5 percent stake in MedQuist to CBaySystems Holdings of the Virgin Islands for around $285 million.

headline: Harbinger and Salton Wrap Up Deal for Spectrum Unit
text: Spectrum Brands on Wednesday said it would sell its pet supply business to Salton in a deal worth up to $915 million, with financing from private equity firm and hedge fund Harbinger Capital Partners.

headline: Allianz in Deal Talks for Dresdner Bank
text: Allianz is in talks that might lead to a sale or merger of its Dresdner Bank unit and sees the “first apparently realistic possibility of a significant consolidation” in Germany’s banking market.

headline: Merrill Lynch Said to Be in Talks to Move Headquarters
text: Merrill Lynch is in renewed talks to move its headquarters to one of the new buildings which being built on the World Trade Center site, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Borders Jumps on Barnes & Noble Speculation
text: Borders, the bookstore chain put itself up for sale in March, saw its stock jump 9 percent on Wednesday as investors reacted to a report that Barnes & Noble was mulling a bid for its rival.

headline: Ex-Hedge Fund Manager Convicted of Fraud
text: A former hedge fund manager was convicted Wednesday of leading an investment scheme that caused clients, ranging from former NFL players to his mother, to lose millions of dollars while he spent the money on jewelry, real estate and a $500,000 wedding.

headline: Dyno Nobel Shareholders OK $2.5 Billion Deal
text: Shareholders in Australian firm Dyno Nobel, the world’s second-largest supplier of explosives, overwhelmingly approved a 2.6 billion Australian dollar ($2.5 billion) takeover by fertilizer maker Incitec Pivot, proxy votes showed Thursday.

headline: Florida Pension Fund Is Suing A.I.G.
text: In another blow to the embattled American International Group, a Florida pension fund accused the insurance giant and a number of its top executives on Wednesday of understating the company’s exposure to the subprime mortgage crisis in order to inflate its stock price artificially.

headline: Bear’s Mayer Turns Down JPMorgan Offer
text: Jeffrey Mayer, co-head of fixed income at Bear Stearns, has reportedly turned down an offer of $27 million from JPMorgan Chase to join the bank on completion of their merger, Financial News reported.

headline: Head of Citi’s Troubled Fund to Leave, Reports Say
text: The head of Citigroup‘s troubled Falcon Strategies hedge fund is leaving after spending nearly two decades at the company, Reuters said, citing an internal memo dated on Tuesday.

headline: What Should We Do About the Renaissance of Big Coal?
text: As the price of oil and gas shoots higher, Big Coal is making a big comeback. Countries from Britain to the United States to China are mining more coal – which is comparatively cheap – and building more coal-fired plants to generate electricity. Coal also enjoys more public acceptance than nuclear power, even though nuclear emits virtually no greenhouse gases.

headline: Hedge Fund Index Shows Gains in April
text: After a generally bruising March, hedge funds regained ground in April as global stock markets recovered, according to an industry index compiled by Eurekahedge.

headline: UBS Plans $15.55 Billion Rights Issue
text: UBS said Thursday that it is planning a deeply discounted rights issue worth 16 billion Swiss francs, or $15.55 billion.

headline: Google Says It Will Defend Competitive Rationale of a Yahoo Deal
text: How can Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, contend that teaming up with Yahoo in search ads would not invite an antitrust challenge?

headline: Twitter Said to Raise $15 Million in Fresh Funding
text: Twitter has raised a new $15 million round of funding, following a bidding war by venture cpitalists eager to get a slice of the micro-blogging start-up, according to an unsourced report from GigaOm.

headline: DealBook: Twitter Said to Raise $15 Million
text: Twitter has raised a new $15 million round of funding, following a bidding war by venture cpitalists eager to get a slice of the micro-blogging start-up, according to an unsourced report from GigaOm.  The publication, which previously reported that at least two V.C.'s were duking it out to get on board the latest round, said Twitter reached an agreement with investors Wednesday to raise $15 million in funding at around $80 million pre-money valuation.   According to GiagaOm, a new investor is leading the round with existing investor, Union Square Ventures also participating in this round. With this round, the company would have raised a little over $20 million in V.C. backing thus far.   Go to Article from GigaOm>>

headline: Saatchi to Advise Art Fund on Deals
text: The Art Trading Fund, a hedge fund that deals in fine art, said that Charles Saatchi, the British advertising magnate and art collector, will advise it on contemporary art purchases.

headline: NRG Makes $11 Billion Bid for Calpine

headline: Crown Heights Simmers Again
text: Crown Heights is experiencing racial tensions, as it has every so often since the 1991 unrest that erupted after a 7-year-old black boy was fatally struck by a Hasidic driver. The violence also left a Jewish man dead. The beating of a 20-year-old black college student last month and the robbery and beating of a Jewish teenager last week are the proximate causes of the latest unease.

headline: Still Not Too Late for Myanmar
text: Give Not Invading a Chance: This weekend, “one of the most grotesque events in the political history of the modern world” will take place in Myanmar, writes Timothy Garton Ash on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. “While dead children still lie face down in muddy flood waters after a devastating cyclone, while survivors get sick with life-threatening diarrhea, while international aid workers are prevented by the military regime from bringing in supplies that could save them, Burmese citizens will be herded into makeshift polling stations to approve by plebiscite a constitution that is designed to prevent the results of a democratic election held 18 years ago from ever being respected.”

headline: British PM Dealt Blow in By-Election Defeat
text: The main opposition Conservative Party won a key by-election victory in northwest England Friday, dealing a fresh blow to beleaguered Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

text: Scanning the financial press this morning, readers would have seen a disturbing yet familiar burst of oil news: rising prices, aghast lawmakers and protests in Europe. But another piece of bad news topped off the fray, one that was much less familiar to close observers of the oil market:

headline: The Flying Cuban
text: The scantily clad marvel soaring through the video above is the ballet star Carlos Acosta, whose memoir, “No Way Home,” I review in the Book Review this weekend. Acosta may not be that well known to casual observers of ballet in the States. He began dancing in Havana, and although he spent a few years in Houston early in his career, and has done a couple of stints as a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater, he’s spent most of his dancing life abroad, most prominently with the Royal Ballet, where he has been since 1998.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Brownies
text: The first time I made brownies without my mother was in the late 1960’s, using a recipe from Paula Peck, the cookbook writer. Over the years, I tinkered with that and a similar version by Marion Cunningham. As my daughters learned to cook, they experimented a bit further. But we never really strayed from the originals.

headline: ‘The Road to Heaven Is Too Dark’
text: Yumei Wang, who heads Oregon’s geohazards team, is dynamic and hard-bitten, as you might expect of someone facing the reality of a looming inevitable disaster (Oregon’s next great quake on the Cascadia fault) and inadequate preparation, with hundreds of schools, emergency-services buildings and vital water and power links still vulnerable.

headline: The Art of the Morning Gallop
text: Gallop boys, gallop girls, exercise riders, that’s who we are. I thought I would try to shed some light into the work done by those who ride racehorses during their morning exercises. Michelle Nevin exercises Big Brown. Andy Durnin did the same for Fusaichi Pegasus. They are the people reporters write about when their horses are in the limelight. But there are many of us who do the same thing on horses that are not quite so famous.

headline: Ahoy!  It's Fleet Week
text: Sailors take advantage of promotions at local bars near the seaport. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

text: This has been a frustrating time for bears, who see disaster all around them — except in stock prices.

headline: Randolph: No Excuses
text: All on his own, Mets Manager Willie Randolph apologized Wednesday for comments he made to Ian O’Connor of the Bergen Record suggesting that race had something to do with the way Randolph is portrayed or received in the media.

text: Calais had just enough beauty, and more than enough friendly faces, to make it the perfect introduction to France.

headline: The Starting Line: The Taint of Steroids, the Beauty of Olympic Art
text: The unending parade of banned-substance and doping stories has become as much of the Olympic narrative as sappy up-close-and-personal featurettes about athletes’ family dramas and uplifting moral tales about the unifying pull of the Olympic Spirit.

headline: Love Hurts, Part 2
text: I went to a small museum with my family this week, and in one of the galleries noticed a paperback copy of “The Professor of Desire” on a chair against the wall. “Are you reading that?” I asked the guard, who’d been keeping a wary eye on my two young children. He perked right up. “Philip Roth is my favorite author,” he said. We chatted a bit about academic concerns — David Kepesh as a narrator versus Nathan Zuckerman, and the playful cross-references between various novels — and as we talked the guard seemed to reach a decision. He leaned confidingly toward me, and his next sentences came all in a rush. “I’m rereading all of his breakup novels right now,” he said. “Because I’m going through one of my own, and they just really, really help.”

headline: Times Reader Beta for the Mac Now Available
text: Today our beta version of Times Reader for the Mac becomes available. The beta is free for all registered members of NYTimes.com to download and try.

headline: Fitting In After Iraq
text: Damien Cave covered Iraq between July 2006 and December 2007. He is now the Times’ Miami bureau chief and we asked him to explain what it’s been like readjusting to home.

headline: Scent Notes | David Yurman
text: The caste lines between perfumes — which are niche, which luxury and which mass passing as luxury (currently the industry’s greatest growth sector) — have become increasingly blurred, their defining cues both subtle and contradictory. The new David Yurman scent, which will be available at Yurman retail stores in late June followed by Neiman Marcus and Saks in July, provides an excellent example of how fuzzy it’s gotten. Perhaps this is because its perfumer, Harry Frémont, is one of the art form’s greatest masters at moving between styles and classes.

headline: Blame ‘Mr. Chelsea?’
text: Chelsea captain John Terry has endured “concussion, broken bones and painful wounds,” but now he seems overwrought by “emotional trauma” after missing Chelsea’s fifth spot kick in the penalty shootout in the Champions League final Wednesday against Manchester United.

headline: Karts for a Cause
text: LAKEVILLE, Conn. — The 2008 Karting Challenge, a four-hour endurance race to support the Special Olympics Connecticut, began Tuesday at Lime Rock Park here. At precisely 1 p.m., drivers from 16 teams dashed to their go-karts in a Le Mans-style start. Over the next four hours, the karts would lap the quarter-mile autocross course more than 300 times.

text: Wow.

headline: Port Authority Deal May Open Trade Center Door to Merrill
text: Updated, 4:37 p.m. | The Port Authority board met privately this morning to consider a deal that would allow Larry A. Silverstein, the developer of three of the future World Trade Center towers, to negotiate with Merrill Lynch as the tenant of the central building at the site. As it stands, under his agreement with the authority, Mr. Silverstein must complete the central building, known as Tower 3, by Dec. 31, 2011.

headline: The Ticket That Knows Who You Are
text: An estimated 16 million Olympic tickets to be used for this year’s Games are embedded with RFID (radio frequency identification) technology to “ensure security,” as the China’s People’s Daily Online reports.

headline: A Fitting End?
text: Manchester United and Chelsea pummeled each other through regulation time and two fatigue-inducing extra periods in the Champions League final before Man U finally prevailed on penalty kicks. Soccer has used penalties to decide tie matches in tournaments for more than three decades, often prompting criticism that it employs a manufactured endgame to settle its most important competitions. Does Wednesday’s thrilling finale validate the system as the best one available? And if not, what would?

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: An Opening Hints at a Reunion
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The summer festival season is beginning, and thank you, O Blog. It’s the perfect vehicle to log the panoply of events that can delight, bore and often overwhelm an ambitious attendee — and also to give a reader amuse-bouches of sounds and images (whatever of both can be pried out of protective festival organizers).

headline: The Morning Skate: Two Guys Named Stanley, and a Lousy Way to Win a Cup
text: Day 3 of the hockey world being held hostage by the Lords of Scheduling, and there’s no hope for an early end to the stalemate.

headline: ‘Idol’ Finale Matches Last Year’s Ratings
text: The Hollywood Reporter has the early Nielsen numbers: “The ‘American Idol’ seventh season finale Wednesday night managed to essentially match last year’s performance, with the coronation of David Cook watched by an estimated 31.7 million viewers. Last year, slightly fewer viewers — 30.8 million — tuned in to watch Jordin Sparks win Fox’s singing competition.”

headline: M.T.A. Might Bring Back Double-Decker Buses
text: Updated, 4:10 p.m. | Double-decker buses — a fixture of the streetscape in London and other international cities — could be making a comeback in New York City. Officials at New York City Transit said today that the agency was considering bringing back double-decker buses, similar to ones that used to run in the city decades ago.

headline: ‘Indians Actually Prefer Obama’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: This week, Barack Obama, true story, campaigned on an Indian reservation and the tribal chief adopted him. Yeah, the Indians actually prefer Obama to John McCain, because they still remember when McCain took their land.

headline: ‘Are You Excited? Do You Care?’
text: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Folks from all over the country are visiting here tonight. Good to have you with us. A lot of out-of-towners? That took a little too long, didn’t it? Listen to this: in New York City –- and maybe they do this in your home town, I doubt it –- there’s a restaurant downtown in the financial district, down on Wall Street, and I don’t know the name of it and I don’t even care. But you can go in there and you can order yourself a hamburger. Oh, that’s nice, you’re saying, “A hamburger –- jeez, I’d like a hamburger.” Who doesn’t like a hamburger? I’m not done here. How much do you pay for a hamburger? One hundred seventy-five dollars -– now, that seems to me like an incredible waste, especially when you can get a really good steak in New York City for only $250.

headline: ‘Like a Bad NBC Show’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: You know, on the news earlier tonight, they showed Barack Obama back in Iowa. And I got scared. I went, “Oh, no. We’re starting all over again!”

headline: A Deal in Peril
text: Wednesday’s decision by the Quebec Court of Appeals rejecting Bell Canada‘s “plan of arrangement” looks now like a very serious blow to the $51.8 billion buyout.

headline: Finding the Winner’s Circle in France
text: In a recent post, I lamented what to do with my 5-year-old sprinter in France, a country that favors distance over speed. Since my horse came from England, he wasn’t qualified to run handicaps in France, which left me with few choices. I managed to get him into a claiming race Thursday at St. Cloud racecourse outside Paris, and he won by half a length. We had a full field of 20, and Abwaab was a long shot: he paid 72.80 euros for the win and 18.40 for the place. The purse was 7,500 euros, which will pay for his oats for a bit. It certainly pales when compared with a Derby horse like Big Brown, but anybody involved in racing knows that no victory is inconsequential.

headline: An Aging ‘Idol?’
text: So how exactly did David Cook, age 25, win “American Idol?” His overwhelming victory “probably says as much about his soulful gaze and in-season makeover as it does about his chops as a rocker,” The Associated Press surmises. “Or maybe it says even more about who’s voting these days.” Derrik J. Lang writes:

headline: Frank Williams’s 600th Race
text: A vast and mighty milestone for Frank Williams today as he celebrated his 600th race in Formula One. Frank is always a popular man amongst journalists for his wisdom and experience, but today there was a huge gathering in the Williams motor home at 5 PM and Frank was in top form to celebrate his 600th race.

text: Stuck in New Delhi’s rush-hour traffic, my taxi driver finally gave up and turned off the engine. Cars, mopeds and auto-rickshaws were all at a dead stop, their horns continuing to blare as if the right amount of honking would get traffic moving again.

headline: Academic Faker
text: Ivory Tower | Kevin Kopelson, English professor at the University of Iowa, confesses to building his career on plagiarism. It all started in the fourth grade, when Kopelson had to write an essay on a conquistador. He cribbed from an ancient encyclopedia. “Clearly, then, my submission wasn’t the kind of thing an 8-year-old could devise. Even a precocious 8-year-old. Even a pretentious one. So imagine my – relief? surprise? indifference? contempt? – when this primal larceny came back marked ‘A.’ ” — London Review of Books

headline: Miller Undecided on Yahoo-Icahn Battle
text: Bill Miller, the star portfolio manager at Legg Mason Capital Management, said he has not yet decided whether to support a dissident board slate at Yahoo backed by billionaire investor Carl Icahn.

headline: Hangovers

I usually just hang out at a gate and wait, but it seems a shame that he will experience his first glimpse of the U.S. at an airport. Any suggestions?

headline: Partisan Preview of the Stanley Cup Final: Detroit vs. Pittsburgh
