The Red Wings, the Penguins, the Red Wings, the Penguins, Jim Rutherford, Nick Libett, Jim Rutherford, Nick Libett. … Yet surely new memories await. And they begin in the Motor City:

headline: He Sleeps With the Digits
text: Europe | Italy’s Mafia is updating killing for the new millennium, Umberto Eco writes. For example, a victim forced to swallow his mobile phone: “To make someone swallow a mobile phone is like making them swallow their genitals. The mobile is the most personal object a person possesses.” — Signandsight.com on a column in L’Espresso

headline: Hot Springs — and Life? — on Mars
text: A stuck wheel in the Martian dust turned out to be a lucky accident for the rover Spirit. As the crippled wheel was dragged along, it dug up a trench revealing a white layer of silica apparently produced by hydrothermal vents like the famous hot springs at Yellowstone. And where there was once hot water, there might have been life.

headline: A Fan's Dreamland
text: The secret desires of sports fans are playing out before your eyes in sports commercials.

headline: Microsoft Should Know Money Can’t Buy Love
text: The rap on Microsoft is that it copies everyone else’s good ideas. That may be too kind. I think it also copies a lot of proven bad ideas. To wit, Microsoft’s latest move to offer shopping rebates to people who use its Internet search service.

headline: The Saga of Skillet Flatbread
text: Kerri Conan, the Kansas-based food writer who has been my co-author on a number of projects and will contribute to Bitten whenever I can persuade her to do so, is as diligent and creative a cook as any I know. When I asked her why no one ever made socca — chickpea flatbread — with other flours, she immediately set about trying out alternatives and devised this whole wheat flatbread. I’ve made it — and you should too. It’s lovely, with heft and flavor — and easy. –MB

headline: A Farmer Switches to Mules
text: BRIEFS “Beat the rush . . . buy your pack mule now,” wrote one commenter on our post on soaring oil prices. But the joke had already turned into reality in McMinnville, Tenn., where a farmer told The Associated Press about his conversion from tractor to mules: “This fuel’s so high, you can’t afford it … We can feed these mules cheaper than we can buy fuel. That’s the truth.”

headline: Ellen Confronts McCain on Gay Marriage
text: “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” might be one of the most apolitical on television – except for one issue, which Senator John McCain had to confront head-on during his appearance today.

headline: And Paul Begala for Vice President?
text: “Tucker Carlson for president?” That’s the headline at the personal blog for Brendan Nyhan, a former Spinsanity editor who is now a graduate student in political science at Duke. Nyhan says that Carlson, the former “Crossfire” host and former writer for The Weekly Standard, among other magazines, may seek the nomination of the Libertarian Party, according to a rumor making the rounds among delegates to the Libertarian convention, which is being held in Denver this weekend.

headline: Who Else Could Bid For Calpine?
text: NRG Energy‘s roughly $11 billion unsolicited bid for Calpine has generated a lot of excitement in the normally sleepy power M&A space. There hasn’t been a major power generation hook-up in the United States in eons — or it sure feels that way — because of myriad internal industry struggles and regulatory roadblocks.

headline: ‘Idol’ By the Numbers: 97 Million Votes, 31.7 Million Viewers
text: This week’s final round of “American Idol” culminated in the announcement Wednesday night on Fox that David Cook, 25, had become the seventh winner of the series. A record 97 million votes were cast, according to the network, and ratings for the singing competition improved slightly over the show’s finale a year ago.

headline: Spitzer’s Downfall Inspires Performance Art
text: The performance artist Karen Finley has now turned her attention to the sex scandal that brought down former Gov. Eliot Spitzer. Ms. Finley will present a work in progress about the scandal tonight at the sixth annual meeting of the Cultural Studies Association at New York University. In a phone interview, she discussed her project with City Room and shared excerpts from the monologues.

headline: Should You Have an A.E.D. at Home?
text: Survivors of heart attacks have an elevated risk of sudden death from abnormal heart rhythms. The good news: Modern technology has brought us devices called automated external defibrillators, or A.E.D.’s, that can shock the heart back into a normal rhythm.

headline: McCain Rejects Hagee Backing as Nazi Remarks Surface

headline: Vegas Beckons
text: A new campaign for Las Vegas urges tourists not to think,  just come "right now."

headline: The Well Podcast: More on Wasted Food
text: One of my favorite posts this week was a slide show depicting the many ways we waste food. Whether it’s tossing out half a corn dog at a summer concert or letting lettuce wilt in our refrigerator, we are a nation of food wasters.

headline: A Top Republican Takes a Pass on Fossella’s Seat
text: There seems to be no end to the aftershocks following Representative Vito J. Fossella‘s decision not to run for reelection this year. The latest comes from Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, who announced today that he would not be a candidate for the congressional seat.

headline: Red Bulls’ Sniper Trying to Regain Form
text: There is no question that Juan Pablo Ángel, the Red Bulls’ veteran striker, makes everyone around him better.

headline: Do the N.H.L. Playoffs Drag On Too Long?
text: This year, it looked like it might be different. The Red Wings and Penguins were both up 3 games to 0 and seemingly on their way to semifinal sweeps. It seemed possible that the Stanley Cup final could start early and maybe — maybe — finish in May.

headline: Justice and the Stonehenge Vandals
text: Officials today revealed an incident last week at Stonehenge involving two men, a hammer and a screwdriver. They were chased off by security guards at the site, but not before leaving a scratch measuring two-and-a-half inches on the Heel Stone.

headline: Paterson Slips Into Past Tense on Clinton
text: Is Gov. David A. Paterson’s support for Hillary Clinton starting to cool? On a radio call-in show this afternoon, the governor insisted that he still supports Mrs. Clinton’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. But he sounded as if he is starting to have serious doubts about whether she can prevail against Barack Obama. “I would say that at this point,” Mr. Paterson said, “we’re starting to see a little, you know, desperation on the part of a woman who I supported, and woman who I’ll support until whatever time she makes a different determination.”

headline: N.Y. Governor Slips Into Past Tense on Clinton
text: Is Gov. David A. Paterson’s support for Hillary Rodham Clinton starting to cool? On a radio call-in show Thursday afternoon, the New York governor insisted that he still supports Mrs. Clinton’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. But he sounded as if he is starting to have serious doubts about whether she can prevail against Barack Obama.

headline: Transit Warning: The UK this Bank Holiday
text: Britain’s road and rail network is congested and getting around can be wearying at the best of times. Overcrowded trains and endless traffic jams are frustrating and stressful, but if you find yourself on a route that is undergoing engineering and structural improvements, your journey can make you lose the will to live.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: A Clash of Sensibilities, Now Resolved
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The 6-foot-wide, 20-foot-long house – actually, a work of sculpture by David Hammons – has been sitting in the run-down East Side neighborhood of Charleston for 17 years now. It has two stories, columns and a quietly satirical air about it, subtly mocking the city’s grand homes.

headline: The Top 20 Shows of the Season
text: The 2007-08 broadcast TV season came to a close on Wednesday, and Nielsen (and the networks) have been busy crunching the numbers since then.

headline: Fox Officially Takes the Gold This Broadcast Season
text: As expected, Fox was rated the No. 1 network for the 2007-08 broadcast season, attracting more total viewers than any other broadcaster for the first time in the 20-year history of the network.

headline: The V-22 Osprey
text: A close-up look at the the V-22 Osprey, an aircraft that flies like a plane but can land like a helicopter. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Friday’s Links: Can Blogging Revive a Stalled Start-Up?
text: Earlier this week, I recommended the site Brijit.com to a Times editor as a way to keep track of and keep up with all the long-form magazine articles worth reading. (I blogged about Brijit shortly after its introduction last fall.) Later that day, I visited Brijit myself and to my dismay, I saw this message:

headline: Convention Plans: The Power of Location
text: St. Paul is the host of this year’s Republican convention, and the city will have just a fraction of the hotel rooms that New York City had for the 2004 convention. So many delegates and news people will be staying in the sister city of Minneapolis or in the suburbs, with just a few lucky delegations staying within walking distance of the convention.

text: Designers at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair placed less emphasis on new materials and technology than in previous years.

headline: The Ear of the Beholder
text: I have a friend who has two grown children. She is estranged from her son, who has many egregious complaints about my friend, and vivid tales of childhood neglect and various other appalling maternal offenses. Her daughter, on the other hand, assures my heartbroken friend that the son has an overactive imagination combined with a need to blame everyone else for his own problems and that in fact, the stories of her failings as a parent never occurred. Who owns the truth?

headline: Celebrating an Engineering Marvel, Born in Tragedy
text: The Brooklyn Bridge: a marvel of engineering, or a death trap? Both, within the first week of its opening.

headline: Celebrating an Engineering Marvel, Born in Tragedy
text: The 125th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge is being marked with a series of celebrations, starting with a concert and lighting ceremony Thursday night. (Photo: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times) See the Slide Show  The Brooklyn Bridge: a marvel of engineering, or a death trap? Both, within the first week of its opening.  The  opening of the Brooklyn Bridge [pdf] on May 24, 1883, was a joyous occasion with "two great cities united." That 125th anniversary is being marked with a series of celebrations over the holiday weekend. But few remember that the bridge's public debut was marred days later by  a stampede [pdf] in which a dozen people were crushed to death, and 35 others injured. The May 30 mayhem was exacerbated by a false rumor that the bridge was going to collapse.  The traffic that surged onto the Brooklyn bridge as soon as it opened was overwhelming and dominated by pedestrians who were charged one cent to pass. There was room for 15,000 people on the footpaths at any one time (though overcrowding sometimes drove it to as high as 20,000).  On the second day, there was "a crush of foot passengers from 11 o'clock in the morning to 7 o'clock at night." The pedestrians "collected at the entrance, compressed themselves into a funnel about 15 feet in width and then ran the gantlet, one by one, of the tolltakers."  Until then, to cross the river, people had to take the ferry.  With subways now, it is rare to see such vast crowds on foot on the bridge, except in emergencies like Sept. 11 and blackouts.  The dense flow of people over the bridge made it fertile ground for pickpockets (newspaper accounts talk about a lot of men discovering that they were missing watches) and other hazards. Six days after the opening, the deadly stampede occurred.  According to the most commonly accepted account, one cited by The New-York Times, the stampede started when a woman fell down the wooden steps on the Manhattan side, and another woman screamed (perhaps because she saw the woman being dragged by a police office officer who had sprung to her aid)  But another version of the events, cited by The New York Tribune, and considered more credible by The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, starts with a German man descending the steps when a pickpocket tried to steal his watch. His wife screamed, and the thief's accomplices started yelling that the bridge was going to collapse, leading to a rumor-induced panic.  "Agonizing!" read the lead headine from The Eagle, which devoted an extra to the panic. It also highlighted "The Stairway that Led to Death."  As The Times described at the time [pdf]:  Those on the promenade above the stairway,knowing nothing of the fearful crush on the steps, surged ahead with irresistible force, and in a moment the whole stairway was packed with dead and dying men, women and children, piled upon another in a writhing, struggling mass. Cries, shrieks, yells, and groans filled the air at the stairway, while those on the promenade above yelled and shouted as they were pushed forward and rolled and tumbled over the poor unfortunates who were being crushed and trampled to death beneath them.  The situation was made worse by "a gang of New York toughs" who formed a dense line by putting their arms on each other's shoulders and charged.  The police officers on duty didn't have the ability to shut off the bridge on the other side. So for some time, the crowd kept pouring onto the bridge even as people were getting crushed on the other end. Officers were eventually stationed in the middle of the bridge to turn people back.  To relieve the strain of people, a bridge employee found a chisel and a hammer nearby and hammered at iron bolts and nuts until he broke away a section of the iron fence to relieve the crush. Also wood planks were laid so people could walk over the fence.  The Times reported the injuries in graphic detail [pdf]:  The first rescuers to reach the spot found the dead and dying wedged together in the narrow space as if they had fastened in a vise. So tightly were they packed and squeezed that from dozens of persons blood was oozing from ears and noses. The bodies were piled four or five deep at the foot of the stairway and most of those at the bottom were women.  The Brooklyn Daily Eagle wrote, "The sight was one that was never equaled for horror." The dead were laid in a row, their faces covered with hats or another article of clothing.  After the bodies and the crowds were cleared, all that was left was bloodstains on the steps, mens and women's hats, umbrellas and parasols, and a thousand steel pens lost by a peddler. But the clean-up was relatively speedy. As the Times described at the time [pdf]:  An hour after the disaster the only evidence that anything unusual had occurred at the stairway was the opening in the iron railing where a section of the latter was torn away in order that bodies might be more quickly taken from the mass in the stairway.  Among the proposals to advert future disasters: tripling the police force on the bridge, accelerating the plans for a telephone connection from one end of the bridge to another, and removing the stairs in favor of an inclined plane.  And of course, lawsuits were filed against the bridge trustees.  (Photo:  A bird's-eye view of fireworks at the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art))   Anniversary Events The Brooklyn Bridge lights will be turned on from 9 to 11 p.m. each night through Memorial Day. The celebrations and observances include lectures, dances, performances, a film series presented at the foot of the bridge, information tents, guided tours, and more. [Complete Schedule, NYCVisit.com.]

headline: A Soldier Remembers
text: A veteran of the Iraq war finds new meaning in Memorial Day. A video Op-Ed by filmmakers Peter Jordan and John Kane.

headline: Ex-Stock Trader Is Accused of Duping Friends Out of Millions
text: A former stock trader was charged on Thursday with duping friends out of $16 million over six years by luring them into various investments, most of which never existed, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said.

headline: Generals See Hope for Troop Reductions by Fall
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s nominees to serve as commander of forces in the Middle East and as the senior commander in Baghdad offered a cautiously optimistic picture of the situation in Iraq on Thursday. They said modest troop reductions may be possible in the fall, and that there was probably no need for the United States to take extra security steps for provincial elections now expected in November.

headline: A Fountain on Every Corner
text: WATER fountain season is here. New York City workers have turned on bubblers in the parks, and the Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson has begun to erect four enormous waterfalls in the harbor, each 90 to 120 feet high, that are scheduled to flow from July to October. The shimmering cascades will cost the city nothing (the $15 million cost is being paid by private donations to the Public Art Fund), but here’s a better idea for a civic-minded organization or person interested in celebrating water: sidewalk fountains in places outside the parks.

headline: F.A.A. Tests Ways to Detect Runway Junk
text: BOSTON  At the edge of Logan International Airport’s Runway 15-right, a technician watched a yellow sensor slowly scan back and forth across the pavement. He waited until it was pointed away from him and, like a man dodging a lawn sprinkler, he rushed to the middle of the 150-foot-wide runway, tossed a plastic pen onto the surface, and dashed back.

headline: Into the Louisiana Bayou
text: THERE are a lot of ways to hit the erase button on adult, workaday concerns on a quick trip to New Orleans.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: An Inquiry Into Interbank Loan Rate
text: LONDON  Each morning in London, a handful of banks quietly decide how much it costs to borrow money all over the world.

headline: Immigrants Fleeing Fury of South African Mobs
text: REIGER PARK, South Africa  Feneck Mgawa, a 39-year-old mechanic from Malawi, came to South Africa 18 months ago. He owned a box of tools and got work right away, living modestly in a hovel in a squatter’s camp and sending cash home each month to his wife and two children.

headline: German President Will Seek Reelection
text: BERLIN  President Horst Köhler announced Thursday that he would seek a second term, setting up a likely replay of the last election that would pit the government’s ruling coalition parties against each other.

headline: U.N. Chief Sees Myanmar Devastation
text: BANGKOK  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, had a firsthand look on Thursday at some of the damage caused by Myanmar’s cyclone, as a limited program of international aid gained momentum.

headline: What Ever Happened to (the Good Kind of) States’ Rights?
text: In February, the day after his infamous encounter at Washington’s Mayflower Hotel, Eliot Spitzer, then the governor of New York, published a remarkable opinion piece in The Washington Post.

headline: Farm Bill, in Part and in Full, Wins Passage
text: WASHINGTON  In following the legislative trail of the $307 billion farm bill, it is good to remember that the American system of checks and balances is not really designed for speed.

headline: Wilfrid Mellers, 94, Musicologist and Critic, Is Dead
text: Wilfrid Mellers, an English musicologist, composer, critic and teacher who published more than 20 books on subjects ranging from 17th-century English and French composers to the music of the Beatles and Bob Dylan, died on May 16 in Scrayingham, North Yorkshire. He was 94 and had homes in Scrayingham and the nearby city of York.

headline: One Word to You, Just One Word: Bakelite
text: REDDING, Conn.  What do bangles, billiard balls, radios and 78-r.p.m. records have in common?

headline: Bell Canada Shares Dive After Court Bars Buyout
text: OTTAWA  As shares in Bell Canada declined by the most in at least two decades on Thursday, many investors and analysts turned their attention to alternatives for the company should its $51.8 billion privatization fail.

headline: Silent Survivors of Afghanistan’s 4,000 Tumultuous Years
text: WASHINGTON  Art objects inspire many reactions, perhaps most crucially acts of preservation or destruction. From 1979 to late 2001, destruction had the upper hand in Afghanistan. The Soviet-Afghan war, the ensuing civil war and finally the pernicious rule of the Taliban inflicted incalculable losses on active archaeological sites and ancient monuments and artworks.

headline: Step to the Rear of the Bus, Please, or Take a Seat Upstairs
text: For decades, they were a fixture of New York life: double-decker buses swaying along Fifth Avenue. They disappeared in 1953 and made a brief and ill-fated return in the 1970s. But now they may be ready for a third act.

headline: Court Says Texas Illegally Seized Sect’s Children
text: HOUSTON  A Texas appeals court ruled on Thursday that the state had illegally seized up to 468 children from their homes at a polygamist ranch in West Texas. The decision abruptly threw the largest custody case in recent American history into turmoil.

headline: From Small Town to Big City, Desormeaux Comes Within Reach of Triple Crown
text: In front of an empty grandstand at Belmont Park, Kent Desormeaux spent Wednesday afternoon riding forgettable horses in forgettable races. There will be plenty of days like this between now and June 7, when Desormeaux and Big Brown tackle racing’s biggest challenge, completing the Triple Crown at the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Obama to Fill In for Kennedy at Ceremony
text: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy will not give the commencement address he was scheduled to deliver on Sunday at Wesleyan University and will be replaced as the speaker by Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Shield My Eyes, These Cubbies Are Good
text: Through all the unpredictability in the first month-and-a-half of this baseball season (the Yankees and Tigers are in last place, the Marlins are in first, and baseball's best pitcher might be Cliff Lee, of all people), one fact appears to be emerging: The Chicago Cubs are the best team in baseball. Let that sink in. Mull it over. Wrap it around your cerebral cortex. And imagine the terror that this has caused me and my fellow St. Louis Cardinals fans.

headline: Economic Toll Mounts From High Oil Prices
text: Oil prices leaped above $135 a barrel in overnight trading on Thursday, a new record that underscored the growing pressures that runaway energy prices are placing on some of the biggest names in global industry.

headline: Germany: Tribute to Nazis’ Gay Victims
text: A memorial dedicated to gay men and lesbians persecuted and killed under the Nazis will be inaugurated on May 27, the Lesbian and Gay Federation in Germany said. The $935,000 monument, designed by Michael Elmgreen of Denmark and Ingar Dragset of Norway, will be in Berlin on the edge of its Tiergarten park and near the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe. It features a concrete slab with a window that will allow visitors to view a looped video that will alternate every two years between a clip of men kissing and a clip of women kissing. Germany’s culture minister, Bernd Neumann, and Berlin’s mayor, Klaus Wowereit, who is gay, are expected to attend the ceremony.

headline: Iraq Spending Ignored Rules, Pentagon Says
text: A Pentagon audit of $8.2 billion in American taxpayer money spent by the United States Army on contractors in Iraq has found that almost none of the payments followed federal rules and that in some cases, contracts worth millions of dollars were paid for despite little or no record of what, if anything, was received.

headline: Dance Listings
text: Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.

headline: Obama Asks Jewish Voters to Judge Him on His Policies
text: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Senator Barack Obama sought to assure Jewish voters here on Thursday of his commitment to the security of Israel and implored them to disregard the false stories and rumors about his beliefs, background and foreign policy views toward the Middle East.

headline: Another Warsaw Skyscraper
text: Zaha Hadid will become the latest star architect to put her imprint on Warsaw. On Wednesday in the Polish capital she displayed her design, below, for a 790-foot residential skyscraper to be built in the heart of the city, Agence France-Presse reported. Called Lilium Tower, the sleek, glass-covered building, with floor space of 1.1 million square feet has a fleur-de-lis motif and is to house apartments, a condominium hotel and commercial and recreational facilities on a site facing the city’s Palace of Culture. Some planning permits are still needed; completion is expected in 2012. Last week, construction began on a futuristic residential skyscraper designed by Daniel Libeskind, and Norman Foster has designed a commercial center adjacent to the National Opera.

headline: Artisan Life in New York State, a Weekend at a Time
text: I will never complain about paying $200 for a handcrafted copper bowl again. That, at least, was the thought running through my head one Sunday morning last month as I found myself pounding a rigid sheet of copper into the silhouette of a delicate flower, using only a makeshift hammer and crude set of nails.

headline: Contenders Spar on Veterans’ Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain takes pride in his unwavering support for members of the armed forces. So when Senator Barack Obama criticized him on Thursday on the Senate floor, his response was scathing.

headline: UBS Moves to Raise $15 Billion
text: PARIS  The Swiss banking giant, UBS, said on Thursday that it would raise more than $15 billion by issuing sharply discounted shares as it tried to restore capital depleted by losses on mortgage securities.

headline: Giants Amid the Blooms
text: AS summer approaches and the euro and pound remain mightier than the dollar, New York City seems to have been recolonized by Europeans over the last few weeks. But one group of visitors that arrived recently from Britain for a brief change of scenery did not travel the normal way, slogging through the purgatory of airport customs. Most of them arrived at Port Elizabeth in New Jersey in the holds of cargo ships. And at least one made its way into the Bronx strapped to a low flatbed truck so big that it had to wait until the middle of the night to cross the George Washington Bridge, stopping traffic with its greenish biomorphic bulk, like something bound for a government lab at Area 51.

headline: Woman Troubles, in a Handy Musical Variety Pack
text: Victoria Clark as an 11-year-old? Victoria Clark, the gifted singing actress who won a Tony as a demure middle-aged mother in “The Light in the Piazza”? Who was so heartbreaking as a life-roughened Irish matron in the recent concert version of “Juno” at City Center Encores?

headline: Urgency Replaces Subtlety in Summer’s Struggle for Visitors
text: AS the crucial summer travel season starts, how much are tourism marketers scrambling to meet the challenges from fast-rising gasoline prices and airfares? Well, “What happens here stays here” is not staying around, at least for now.

headline: For Faneca, New Colors and a New Start With the Jets
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Alan Faneca leaned forward at left guard, same mop of red hair sneaking out of the helmet, same No. 66 stretched across the jersey, same physics lesson delivered after each snap: force = mass (x) acceleration.

headline: Murder, From Front to Back, in a Project in Queens
text: Mourning the murdered has become a familiar routine at the Redfern Houses in Far Rockaway, Queens. First there are the makeshift memorials, with flowers and candles and a smattering of personal items. Then, the dead often get more permanent epitaphs scrawled on the walls of the apartment house they called home, remembered by nicknames like “peanut” or “dimplez.”

headline: Two Are Charged in Attack on Teenager in Crown Heights
text: Two teenagers were arrested on Thursday in an attack on an Orthodox Jewish teenager in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, one of several recent cases that have stirred tensions between black and Jewish residents in a neighborhood with a volatile racial history.

headline: U.S. Airstrike Kills 8 Civilians in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  An American helicopter strike killed eight civilians, including two children, during an assault near the northern Iraqi town of Baiji, the Iraqi police said Thursday.

headline: Bacteria Thrive in Inner Elbow; No Harm Done
text: The crook of your elbow is not just a plain patch of skin. It is a piece of highly coveted real estate, a special ecosystem, a bountiful home to no fewer than six tribes of bacteria. Even after you have washed the skin clean, there are still one million bacteria in every square centimeter.

headline: Zimbabwe: Candidate Plans Return
text: The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai, who delayed his planned return last week to Zimbabwe to campaign for president because of fears he would be assassinated, said he would return on Saturday. Mr. Tsvangirai, a former trade union leader, faces a June 27 runoff against President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Tsvangirai has come under increasing pressure from allies to return to rally his supporters after more than a month outside the country. Hundreds of his supporters have been beaten in a brutal political crackdown since the March 29 election that pitted Mr. Tsvangirai against Mr. Mugabe. Election officials say Mr. Tsvangirai won 47.9 percent of the vote to Mr. Mugabe’s 42.3 percent; Mr. Tsvangirai contends he won outright. Mr. Tsvangirai left the country on April 8 because of what his spokesman called a credible death threat.

headline: Junta Offers Showcase Camps, but Most Burmese Lack Aid
text: HLINETHAYA RELIEF CAMP, Myanmar  The 68 blue tents are lined up in a row, with a brand-new water purifier and boxes of relief supplies, stacked neatly but as yet undelivered and not even opened. “If you don’t keep clean, you’ll be expelled from here,” a camp manager barked at families in some tents.

headline: Generals Tell Senate They Hope for Modest Cut in U.S. Troops in Iraq This Fall
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s nominees for commander of forces in the Middle East and senior commander in Baghdad told a Senate hearing on Thursday that modest troop reductions might be possible this fall and that the United States might not need to strengthen patrols for provincial elections now expected in November.

headline: Summer Sounds
text: SUMMER means music. It’s the season of the beach blanket jam, the prom song, the blockbuster movie soundtrack, the open-air amphitheater show.

headline: Auto Parts Workers Approve a Contract
text: DETROIT  The eighth-longest strike ever for the United Automobile Workers union ended Thursday as workers at American Axle and Manufacturing approved a four-year contract that the U.A.W.’s president had described as subpar but “the best we can do.”

headline: Most Days Are for Fishing and a Few for Nascar
text: AS Interstate 20 slices through the pines of central Alabama, it crosses a bridge over the silvery brown water of Logan Martin Lake about 40 miles east of downtown Birmingham. Fishermen are almost always out in their boats, and less affluent anglers cast from the edge of the bridge, much as they have since 1964, when the lake was created by the damming of the Coosa River.

headline: Financier Stands by a Firm Tainted by Heparin
text: Two years ago, a financier named Malon Wilkus spied what seemed like a good buy: Scientific Protein Laboratories, of Waunakee, Wis.

headline: Man Found for ‘All Seasons’
text: The three-time Tony Award-winning actor Frank Langella will star next season as Sir Thomas More in a Roundabout Theater Company revival of the Robert Bolt drama “A Man for All Seasons.” Doug Hughes, who directed the 2005 production of John Patrick Shanley’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “Doubt,” will stage “A Man for All Seasons,” opening in previews on Sept. 12 and officially on Oct. 7 for a limited engagement at the American Airlines Theater. ... After its annual spring hiatus, the summer edition of Gerard Alessandrini’s “Forbidden Broadway” will return under the title “Forbidden Broadway Dances With the Stars!” on June 28 at the 47th Street Theater. It features old favorites and new spoofs, including “South Pacific” and Patti LuPone in “Gypsy.”

headline: Correction: An ‘Our Town’ Stage for the Creative Set
text: The Havens column on May 9, about Three Oaks, Mich., described the area’s downtown business district incorrectly. There are a handful of empty storefronts; they are not all taken. The column also referred incorrectly to the Packer Schopf art gallery branch there. That branch has closed.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Saturday about Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s use of earmarks to finance pet projects in his district  a practice for which he has criticized the New York City Council  misidentified the borough that includes the Ryan Visitor Center of the Gateway National Recreation Area, for which Mr. Weiner secured about $66 million in improvements. The center is in Brooklyn, not Queens.

headline: Off Broadway ‘Love’ Story Ends
text: A closing notice for an Off Broadway show is not that newsworthy these days. But it is when the show is “I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change,” which opened in August 1996. When “I Love You” closes on July 27, it will have played 5,003 performances and 20 previews, an astonishingly long run by any measure, but downright historic for an Off Broadway musical (and second only to the run of “The Fantasticks”). Playing at the Westside Theater on 43rd Street, the show, a revue about love and marriage in the suburbs, has grossed more than $200 million, according to the producers, and productions have been mounted in more than 500 cities, including Taipei, Tel Aviv, Rio de Janeiro and Sydney. It has been translated into 12 languages; a Chinese version played in New York last year. Furthermore, producers said, there have been 61 wedding proposals at the show, all of which resulted in yeses. No word on how long those engagements lasted.

headline: Kentucky Speedway’s New Owner Promises a 2009 Sprint Cup Race
text: CONCORD, N.C.  Kentucky Speedway could be the next addition to Nascar’s Sprint Cup schedule now that the racetrack has been purchased by Speedway Motorsports Inc.

headline: 9 Airlines Face Threat of a Credit Downgrade
text: In the latest sign that the outlook for the airline industry is darkening, Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services on Thursday placed nine big airlines on CreditWatch with negative implications, meaning that it was likely to cut their debt ratings.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Congress Trims Bush’s Mexico Drug Plan
text: MEXICO CITY  The United States Congress has scaled back on President Bush’s anti-drug plans for Mexico and put human rights conditions on some of the aid, drawing fire from some Mexicans who accuse American lawmakers of meddling in their country’s internal affairs.

headline: Better Nursing Homes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Everglades Park Counts the Good and the Bad After a Blaze
text: REDLAND, Fla.  Rick Anderson, the fire management officer for Everglades National Park, stood in the burnt grass where the largest fire in 19 years began here last week and assessed the costs and benefits.

headline: Suggested Read: Wood’s Comeback
text: How fortunes can change. At the beginning of last season, Kerry Wood was, as Buzz Bissinger wrote for PLAY, "less a real ballplayer than a cautionary tale" whose flamethrower-turned-feeble story symbolized the "nightmarish possibilities for young pitchers." But after slogging through another rehab and trying his hand in the Cubs bullpen last year, Wood has emerged this season as one of the league's best closers. Wood has converted 10 of his first 13 save opportunities, using his fastball -- which is back in the upper 90s -- and nasty slider to strike out 22 in 22 2/3 innings.

headline: How to Rock in Iraq
text: Iraq documentary fatigue gets a rock-hard slap in the face with “Heavy Metal in Baghdad,” an intrepid, unlikely and altogether splendid feat of D.I.Y. reportage. The movie opens in the fall of 2006 as the filmmaker Suroosh Alvi, having sneaked into Baghdad via Germany and Kurdistan, dons a bulletproof vest under the watch of his $1,500-a-day security detail and prepares to interview the members of Acrassicauda, the only Iraqi heavy metal band.

headline: A School That Cost $20,000 Not to Go To
text: About six weeks ago, Michele Bender, a freelance writer who lives in SoHo, took out her checkbook. She wrote a $10,000 check for the balance of what she owed a desirable West Village private school, the Little Red School House, bringing the total she had paid to $20,000. She put it in the mail. Then she called her husband and cried.

headline: Potential Inheritor of a Staten Island Congressional Seat Says He Won’t Run
text: The political landscape in New York’s 13th Congressional District continued to shift on Thursday when Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, said that he would not run for the Congressional seat now held by Representative Vito J. Fossella.

headline: Medtronic Settles a Civil Lawsuit on Allegations of Medicare Fraud
text: A unit of Medtronic defrauded Medicare of hundreds of millions of dollars, according to a civil lawsuit that was unsealed Thursday and simultaneously settled with the Justice Department.

headline: Can We Find a New Way to Get Home?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Volumes to Go Before You Die
text: An odd book fell into my hands recently, a doorstopper with the irresistible title “1001 Books You Must Read Before You Die.” That sounds like a challenge, with a subtle insult embedded in the premise. It suggests that you, the supposedly educated reader, might have read half the list at best. Like one of those carnival strength-testers, it dares you to find out whether your reading powers rate as He-Man or Limp Wrist.

headline: Georgia Ruling Party Cements Power
text: MOSCOW  As vote counts were being tallied, the ruling party in Georgia had a commanding lead in the parliamentary elections held Wednesday, cementing President Mikheil Saakashvili and his party’s place as the nation’s pre-eminent political force.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the plan of a biotech company, BioArts, to use online auctions to sell chances to clone a dog misstated the percentage of embryo transfers that the company said resulted in a puppy. Lou Hawthorne, the chief executive of BioArts, said the success rate was 25 percent  not 1 percent to 4 percent.

headline: U.S. in Difficult Position Over Japan’s Rice Plan
text: HONG KONG  Japan is preparing to send at least 220,000 tons of rice to the Philippines, and possibly Africa. The Japanese government says the plan is meant to ease the suffering of poor nations punished by rising rice prices.

headline: Couples (Physical) Therapy, the Jerome Robbins Version
text: Here is the group, expanding and contracting in constant pulses of energy. And there is the couple, suddenly finding themselves alone, and still, in that crowd. It was a much-loved juxtaposition for Jerome Robbins, as demonstrated by Baroque to Jazz, the all-Robbins program performed Wednesday by New York City Ballet.

headline: The Sportsman’s Life in a ‘Bathtub Nash’
text: “YOU can sleep with the windows open,” Jim Dworschack said. “There aren’t any mosquitoes.” He was right, and that was the second-most miraculous thing about the evening. Most miraculous was that the windows were on a car  an antique S.U.V. of a car being used precisely as its maker intended.

headline: Girardi Angrily Departs, Then Has Reason to Smile
text: Hank Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ co-chairman, likes to say Joe Girardi is Billy Martin without the baggage. Like Martin, Girardi has a feisty side and does not take losing well. He also knows how to bark at an umpire, with a display of theatrics Thursday night at Yankee Stadium that would make Martin, Lou Piniella and Earl Weaver proud.

headline: Iraqi Symphony Performs
text: With a program of Arabic, Kurdish and classical Western music, the Iraqi National Symphony Orchestra gave a rare concert on Wednesday in Baghdad, Agence France-Presse reported. The performance, held in observance of World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development, was intended to “remind the world of what Iraqis can offer and to preserve the country’s cultural heritage,” said the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq. The performance, in the heavily fortified Green Zone, was attended by about 400 people, including United Nations officials, diplomats, military officers and Iraqi lawmakers, the mission said. Karim Wasfi, the orchestra’s director, and Oliver Gilmour, above, a British guest conductor, led the ensemble.

headline: Judge Says Bloomberg Cannot Testify at Trial of Gun Dealer
text: Saying that he did not want “a media show,” a federal judge ruled on Thursday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg cannot testify at the pending civil trial of a Georgia gun dealer accused of creating a public nuisance in New York by selling weapons that were later used to commit crimes in the city.

headline: 30 Former Officials Became Corporate Monitors
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has appointed at least 30 former prosecutors and other government officials as well-paid corporate monitors in arrangements that allow companies to avoid criminal prosecution, according to government data released Thursday by Congress.

headline: Admission of Doping Jeopardizes Relay Gold
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Olympic gold medalist and former world champion sprinter Antonio Pettigrew acknowledged in federal court Thursday that he used performance-enhancing drugs from 1997 to 2001.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Thursday about an investigation into the possibility that a computer error at the Moody’s Corporation led to incorrect credit ratings of securities paraphrased incorrectly a comment by Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, about his agency’s power in the inquiry. Mr. Cox said it was unclear if the S.E.C. had authority over the ratings, which were assigned in Europe. He did not say that the S.E.C. had no authority.

headline: Soderbergh and Che, Provocateurs
text: CANNES, France  On Wednesday morning festivalgoers  or at least the hordes of journalists who stumble into the Salle Lumière every day at 8:30 after a few hours’ sleep and a hasty café au lait  were given a bit of a break. In a departure, there was no competition press screening on the schedule, which provided some of us with an opportunity to glance at the trades, have a second café au lait and rest our eyes in anticipation of a long night of revolutionary struggle.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about a class-action lawsuit filed by a Florida pension fund against the American International Group misidentified the founder of A.I.G. It was founded by Cornelius Vander Starr  not by Maurice R. Greenberg, its former chief executive.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Detroit Wins to Square Up East Finals 1-1
text: BOSTON  The idea of a must-win game in Game 2 of a seven-game series seems absurd on its face. But given that the Detroit Pistons, losers of Game 1, had never won a series trailing, 2-0, or that the Celtics, winners of Game 1, had never lost a series when leading. 2-0, the second game of the Eastern Conference finals took on added importance for the hosts and the visitors Thursday night.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Encores
text: Starting with “Lucia di Lammermoor,” starring Natalie Dessay and Marcello Giordani, 20 live performances from the 2007-8 season of the Metropolitan Opera will be rebroadcast beginning Friday on Metropolitan Opera Radio on Sirius (Channel 85). The Summer Encore series, Fridays at 8 p.m., will continue until the weekend before next season’s opening night, Sept. 22.

headline: Embracing the Modern With a Shimmering Sound
text: Taka Kigawa is a pianist with a thoroughly contemporary sensibility. There were admirable aspects to his performances of works by Debussy and Stravinsky in his recital on Wednesday night at the Greenwich House Music School, where he is a respected faculty member. But it was in bracingly modern works of recent decades by Karen Tanaka and Tristan Murail that the Japanese-born Mr. Kigawa, a new-music champion, seemed at home.

headline: Veterans’ Benefits Bill Wins Approval in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  Twenty-five Republican senators broke with President Bush and voted Thursday for a major expansion of veterans’ benefits as part of a bill to finance another year of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Alou’s Calf Injury Adds to Randolph’s Troubles
text: ATLANTA  Willie Randolph has not had a good week. It got worse Thursday afternoon, when he learned that Moises Alou would go on the disabled list. And for the third straight day, he dealt with the repercussions of his ill-timed comments suggesting that criticism of him was laced with racial undertones.

headline: F.D.A. to Expand Scrutiny of Risks From Drugs After They’re Approved for Sale
text: WASHINGTON  Chastened by repeated instances in which popular medicines proved deadly, federal health officials announced a major effort on Thursday to use information on Medicare claims to assess the risks of drugs already on the market.

headline: Who’s Calling the Shots, the Yankees or Ortiz?
text: David Ortiz is a mammoth, powerful and gregarious left-handed hitter, the kind of slugger who would not need acting lessons to imitate Babe Ruth. Ortiz, the modern-day Ruth from the Boston Red Sox, will get that interesting chance at Yankee Stadium during the All-Star Game festivities  unless the Yankees succeed in an attempt to prevent it.

headline: Jazz, the Dead and a Musical Bridge
text: AT age 13, I loved malls, the latest New Kids on the Block album and tying satin ribbons in my hair to match my outfit. I’d just finished the seventh grade and was anticipating a summer backed by a Top 40 soundtrack. Yet here I was, packed into the back seat of the family Volvo, on the way to a concert by an outdated band I knew nothing about: the Grateful Dead.

headline: 74 City Schools Told to Expect 5% Budget Cut
text: The city’s Department of Education released a list on Thursday of 74 schools, including its most prestigious high schools, that are to have their budgets for next year cut by more than 5 percent.

headline: Merrill Lynch Weighs Putting Headquarters at Ground Zero
text: Merrill Lynch is negotiating a deal to build a 70-story headquarters at ground zero, a plan that would make it the first financial firm to return to the 16-acre former World Trade Center site since the terrorist attack destroyed the complex in 2001.

headline: A Home-Court Disadvantage
text: PARIS  Though he came close to winning the year’s first Grand Slam event in faraway Australia, there is no rush to claim that Jo-Wilfried Tsonga will flirt with victory on home soil at the French Open.

headline: Paris Bank’s Managers Are Blamed in a Scandal
text: PARIS  Serious management failures by immediate superiors allowed a rogue trader at Société Générale to commit the biggest fraud in financial history, according to an internal report to be released Friday.

headline: Soothing or Salting Wounds From Election 2000
text: “Every vote counts” is one of those platitudes, like “Watch your step,” that doesn’t have much meaning until that first really bad fall.

headline: The Master of the M.T.A.’s Hudson Yards Deal
text: GARY J. DELLAVERSON is in evident discomfort, almost cowering, as the stupendous squalor that engulfs his office at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is invaded and merrily scrutinized by a nosy reporter and photographer. “This is what I was afraid of,” grouses Mr. Dellaverson, the authority’s chief financial officer and chief negotiator of its excruciatingly complex $1.054 billion Hudson Yards redevelopment deal. “Stop looking around! You’re getting too personal!” Nice try. We had made an appointment.

headline: 3 Auditioning to Be McCain’s No. 2 Gain Qualified Backing
text: As Senator John McCain prepared to meet this weekend with three potential running mates, state Republican leaders across the country on Thursday gave a tentative nod of approval to those prospects while pointing to the possible suitability of others and emphasizing that Mr. McCain needed to please the party’s conservative base.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Tuesday about the potential dangers of plastic bottles and cups made with the chemical bisphenol-a, or BPA, incorrectly said that all baby bottles with the numeral 7 in the triangle stamp on the bottom contained BPA. Most plastic bottles and cups marked with a numeral 7 contain BPA, but not all do. Parents should not give those items to babies or young children unless the manufacturer guarantees that they are BPA-free.

headline: Invasion of the Heart
text: A Hollywood weepie snuggled inside a humanitarian tribute, “The Children of Huang Shi” molds the true story of the English reporter George Hogg (played by the Irish actor Jonathan Rhys Meyers) into a chaste love triangle given urgency by the Japanese invasion of China.

headline: California: Same-Sex Marriages
text: Lawyers for a group that opposes same-sex marriage have filed a motion asking the State Supreme Court to stay its recent decision effectively legalizing such marriages and rehear arguments on the issue. The Alliance Defense Fund, a group based in Arizona, said it wanted the court to wait to put its decision into effect until early November, when voters are expected to take up a ballot initiative that would define marriage as “between a man and a woman.” To allow the decision to take effect before then “risks legal havoc and uncertainty of immensurable magnitude,” the brief read. Shannon P. Minter, the legal director for the National Center for Lesbian Rights, which argued the original same-sex marriage case before the court, called the filing desperate. “We’re very confident the court will reject their motions,” Mr. Minter said. The court ruled on May 15 that two state laws defining marriage as between men and women were unconstitutional.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Shopkeeper Fatally Shot in Robbery
text: Wednesday was another slow day at Elgudzha Koyenishvili’s liquor store in a strip of shops on Lincoln Avenue in the small-town Staten Island neighborhood of Grant City.

headline: Italy Plans to Resume Building Atomic Plants
text: ROME  Italy announced Thursday that within five years it planned to resume building nuclear energy plants, two decades after a public referendum resoundingly banned nuclear power and deactivated all its reactors.

headline: Ace Can’t Stop Mets From Loss, Fourth of Its Kind
text: ATLANTA  If not Johan Santana, then who?

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: ‘Idol’ Finale: (Pop) Power to the People
text: Whether you embrace or scorn “American Idol,” the most efficient star-making phenomenon in entertainment history, can depend on the day. David Cook’s lopsided victory over David Archuleta on Wednesday night was an unexpected triumph of poise and maturity (Mr. Cook is 25) over ingenuousness and promise (Mr. Archuleta is 17). It reversed last season’s trend, when Jordin Sparks, an unformed talent with a bubbly personality and a big voice, won, and the older and less glamorous but far more talented Melinda Doolittle came in third.

headline: Suicide Bomber Attacks Gaza Crossing
text: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian suicide bomber detonated a truck packed with explosives early Thursday just short of the Erez crossing on the northern Gaza-Israel border, killing himself and causing damage, but no injuries, on the Israeli side.

headline: House Panel Subpoenas Rove in Inquiry Into Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON  The House Judiciary Committee pressed its investigation of possible political influence in Justice Department prosecutions on Thursday by issuing a subpoena to Karl Rove, the former chief political operative at the Bush White House.

headline: Children in Adult Jails
text: Children who are confined to adult jails are at greater risk of being raped, battered or pushed to suicide. They also are more likely to become violent criminals than children handled through the juvenile justice system. When Congress reauthorizes the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974, it should press the states to end this barbaric practice.

headline: Pettigrew Admits to Doping, Jeopardizing Relay Gold Medals
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Olympic gold medalist and former world champion sprinter Antonio Pettigrew acknowledged in federal court Thursday that he used performance-enhancing drugs from 1997 to 2001.

headline: Teach for America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lakers Know the Emotional Value of a Comeback Victory
text: LOS ANGELES  When San Antonio Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich, a wine connoisseur whose custom-built home cellar houses 3,000 bottles, sat down for a late dinner Wednesday and asked for a particular bottle of chardonnay and a pinot noir to accompany it, he was informed that the restaurant had neither.

headline: Her Father, His Secrets, Herself
text: Honor Moore was born in 1945, heir on both sides to old money, bad nerves and great literary material. From her mother, Jenny, she inherited artistic talent and a complicated, particularly female relationship to it, both of which she drew on in “The White Blackbird” (1996), her absorbing biography of her grandmother, the troubled and forgotten Modernist painter Margarett Sargent. From her father, Paul, the Episcopal bishop of the diocese of New York from 1972 to 1989, she inherited a certain melancholy appreciation for the mystery in things  and one heck of a story.

headline: As Koons Prices Balloon, His Dallas ‘Flower’ Will Be Sold
text: AS KOONS PRICES BALLOON,

headline: Putting Out a ‘Willkommen’ Mat
text: JOEL GREY’S tiny bungalow in Venice, Calif., a melting pot of artists, surfers and screenwriters, is 650 square feet of white walls, windows, ceiling and rafters. Sunlight pours through four windows onto honey-colored wood floors while cotton curtains rustle in the ocean breeze. A white slip-covered love seat nestles next to a low-slung coffee table, a television and a curved natural pine chair. Planks of sanded plywood serve as paneling on walls of the single bedroom. Within it, a double bed is dressed simply with a vintage patchwork quilt.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The Game Theory column in the Circuits pages on Thursday, reviewing Wii Fit from Nintendo, misstated the price for the product. It is $90, not $180.

headline: The Same Old Song on High Gas Prices
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz peered down at the executives from the nation’s biggest oil companies, arrayed before the House Judiciary Committee like five targets in a carnival dunk tank, wearing dark suits and ties instead of swim trunks.

headline: A Hit Man in a War Zone That Could Easily Be Iraq
text: “War, Inc.” is gonzo moviemaking with a bleeding heart. A satirical farce that wants to be “Dr. Strangelove” for the age of terrorism, it is a zany, nihilistic free-for-all that goes soft.

headline: Retrofitted for Revenge
text: The Japanese obsession with cavorting ninjas, cunning hardware and comely young avengers in abbreviated plaid skirts reaches some kind of climax with “The Machine Girl,” a riotous blend of arterial spray and grindhouse glee.

headline: J. C. Hurewitz, 93, Dies; Scholar of the Middle East
text: J. C. Hurewitz, a Columbia University professor whose voluminous research, belief in the importance of local histories and evenhanded scholarship contributed depth and complexity to the emerging field of Middle Eastern studies starting in 1950, died on May 16 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Keep It Near? Keep It Safe?
text: IT’S striking how often the idea of having a second home revolves around water. And a home on a Florida canal or on the Great Peconic Bay just isn’t complete without a boat at the dock.

headline: A New Détente Shakes Albany: Paterson-Bruno
text: ALBANY  The other day, the state’s top Republican, Joseph L. Bruno, stepped out of a meeting to take a phone call.

headline: Jan Pokorny, 93, Is Dead; Melded Architectural Styles
text: Jan Hird Pokorny, a Czech-born architect whose New York firm became known for restoring and adapting historic buildings for reuse, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Who Will Watch the Peacekeepers?
text: Bern, Switzerland

headline: Chamberlain Is Ready to Start, Father Says
text: Joe Girardi knows that Joba Chamberlain would do whatever the Yankees asked. So when he spoke with Chamberlain on Tuesday, he tried hard to find out exactly how much he wanted to shift to the rotation.

headline: Art in Review
text: ZHANG HUAN

headline: Anarchy With a Short Attention Span
text: Infantile, irreverent and boorish to the max, “Postal” explodes with bad attitude and lousy filmmaking. Opening with the sine qua non of tasteless 9/11 gags and closing with a shot of President Bush (Brent Mendenhall) skipping through a field of mushroom clouds hand in hand with “Sammy,” a k a Osama bin Laden (Larry Thomas), this idiot burlesque of American society manages to be both clueless and fearless.

headline: Idol Finale a Major Hit
text: The final round of “American Idol” culminated in the announcement on Wednesday night that David Cook, 25, had become the series’ seventh winner. A record 97 million votes were cast, according to the network, and ratings improved slightly over last year’s finale. According to Nielsen’s estimates the two-hour Fox finale averaged roughly 31.7 million viewers, a million more than last year. No other show came close to matching it that night. CBS trailed Fox in second place thanks to solid audiences for “Criminal Minds” at 9 (13 million) and “CSI: NY” at 10 (11.7 million), which led its time slot ahead of NBC’s “Law & Order” (8.5 million) and ABC’s “Boston Legal” (6.4 million). NBC ranked third, followed by ABC. Both networks broadcast reruns from 8 to 10 p.m.

headline: Tory Wins Labor Bastion, in Blow to Premier
text: CREWE, England  Voters in this old railway town in Britain’s industrial Midlands sent a powerful message to Prime Minister Gordon Brown and the governing Labor Party on Thursday, electing a Conservative candidate by a wide margin in a parliamentary constituency that had been a Labor bastion for decades.

headline: Bangladesh: Bird Flu Found in Child
text: Bangladesh announced its first known human case of bird flu, in a child who was infected in January. The child has already recovered, according to Mahmudur Rahman, director of the Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research. The government health department said that the child tested negative initially, but that tests of his virus culture by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention turned up positive this week. The news underscored the difficulty of proper surveillance and detection of the deadly virus, particularly dangerous in countries like Bangladesh where people live near poultry. Bird flu was first detected in Bangladesh last year, prompting widespread culling of chickens.

headline: For Naked Mummies, It’s a Wrap
text: The Manchester Museum in England has put some of its Egyptian mummies under wraps while it figures out what to do about visitor complaints that the naked remains should be treated with more respect and dignity, Agence France-Presse reported. The move toward modesty affected two unwrapped mummies and a partially wrapped one from the museum’s collection of 20,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts. Piotr Bienkowski, the museum’s deputy director, said, “This is an interim measure designed to find out public reaction because of the negative comments we have been getting.” Although some Egyptologists called the museum’s reaction “totally misguided,” “misinformed” and “a step backward,” Zahi Hawass, the secretary general of Egypt’s Supreme Council of Antiquities, said, “We don’t want people to see our naked bodies when we are dead, so why should we allow ourselves to view the bodies and expose them in this manner?”

headline: At Supreme Court, 5-to-4 Rulings Fade, but Why?
text: WASHINGTON  Where have all the 5-to-4 decisions gone?

headline: M.T.A. Approves a New Deal to Build at West Side Yards
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority unanimously approved a tentative billion-dollar deal with the Related Companies on Thursday to build a 26-acre, $15 billion enclave of office towers, residential buildings and parks over the West Side railyards.

headline: As Market Shifts, Ford Sees Profit Fleeing
text: DETROIT The budding turnaround at the Ford Motor Company has stalled amid rising gas prices and falling truck sales.

headline: California: Judge Rejects Gang Label
text: A San Diego Superior Court judge ruled that five men accused of killing a professional surfer should stand trial for second-degree murder, but rejected the prosecution’s claims that the accused men constituted a criminal street gang. The group, known as the Bird Rock Bandits, are accused of beating Emery Kauanui Jr., 24, to death last May after an altercation at a local bar. Judge John Einhorn said he had carefully deliberated the notion of the surfer groups as a gang but had concluded that such charges would be akin to putting “a round peg in a square hole.” The next hearing in the case is set for June 10; four of the five men are free on bail.

headline: McCain Cuts Ties to Pastors Whose Talks Drew Fire
text: Senator John McCain on Thursday rejected the endorsements of two prominent evangelical ministers whose backing he had sought to shore up his credentials with religious conservatives.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Release Schedule
text: Here is a selection of notable albums scheduled for summer-season release. (Dates are subject to change.)

headline: Stillness Returns, Sadness Lingers
text: DUJIANGYAN, China  The whoosh of the Min River, roiling through the valley below, drifted up the mountain. A breeze jostled the leaves of ancient ginkgoes. Here and there, the whine of a distant siren pierced the tranquillity.

headline: Jazz at a Fever Pitch, With Moments of Melody
text: Few jazz musicians have a keener sense of the heroic than the saxophonist James Carter. In his world, improvisation can only be a vigorous act, with every solo testing limits and flaunting extremes.

headline: When Driver’s Sponsor Disappears, Her Resolve Doesn’t
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Not long after word got out this month that the driver Sarah Fisher had lost her primary corporate sponsor, which is as bad as losing all of her tires, fans stopped her at Indianapolis Motor Speedway and offered more than sympathy.

headline: Earthquake Shifts Tone of Games
text: The Beijing tournament was a modest dress rehearsal for the Summer Olympic Games. Late last month, a women’s basketball team from the United States found itself in the final against the host Chinese.

headline: Federal Prosecutors Declare European Banker a Fugitive
text: A European banker indicted in a widening investigation of the Swiss banking giant UBS over its private banking business was declared to be a fugitive Thursday, putting further pressure on the bank’s operations.

headline: New Choice for Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON  It cannot be said that the Pentagon does not learn from its mistakes.

headline: Italy Embraces Nuclear Power
text: ROME  Italy announced Thursday that within five years it planned to resume building nuclear energy plants, two decades after a public referendum resoundingly banned nuclear power and deactivated all its reactors.

headline: More U.S. Legal Troubles for Figure in Israeli Case
text: Morris Talansky, the Long Island man at the heart of a corruption investigation in Israel that may topple Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, faces more legal problems when he finishes testifying and returns to New York.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The Lens feature in some editions on Wednesday, about the powerhouse and laundry building in United States Marine Hospital 43 on Ellis Island, misstated the name of the mainland medical institution with which the Ellis Island hospital was associated. It is the Long Island College Hospital, not the Long Island Medical Center.

headline: A Warning From the White House
text: WASHINGTON  Every once in a while, when President Bush or his advisers are particularly exercised by something a reporter writes or a Democrat says, the White House blasts an e-mail to hundreds of Washington opinion-makers under the headline “Setting the Record Straight.”

headline: And He Can Pitch, Too
text: As sports become ever more specialized, with left-handed relief specialists and second-down nickel backs rendering versatility downright quaint, few athletes should intrigue us as much as Micah Owings of the Arizona Diamondbacks.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Abroad column on Tuesday, about the future of Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, misstated the percentage of Berliners who voted in a nonbinding referendum on whether to keep the airport open, and misstated a requirement for the proposal’s approval. About 36 percent of eligible voters took part, not 22 percent. Approval required a “yes” vote from at least 25 percent of eligible voters, not a turnout of 25 percent of eligible voters. (While a large majority of those taking part, as the column noted, voted to keep it open, those votes came from only about 22 percent of eligible voters, short of the requirement.)

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A sports article on Wednesday about the N.B.A. draft lottery misstated, in some editions, the number of teams the Chicago Bulls leapfrogged to win the No. 1 pick. It was eight, not seven.

headline: A Businessman’s View of Mid-American Life
text: It’s not a fine-art photograph, but it looks as if it could be: a man stands in front of a new single-story brick and cinder-block building holding open one of its glass and metal doors as though to invite us in. Large paper letters on the inside of the storefront windows spell “Open.” Yet what this new business is open for remains a mystery. There are no other signs on the building, and no products are visible through the glass.

headline: Hints of Progress in Drugs Treating Brain Cancer
text: Robert A. Swanson, who co-founded Genentech and is considered a father of the biotechnology industry, was only 52 when he died in 1999, one year after a diagnosis of brain cancer.

headline: Alaska Governor Proposes $500 Million in Subsidies for a Gas Pipeline
text: Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska on Thursday proposed granting state subsidies to a Canadian company to build a long-sought natural gas pipeline.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Wednesday about the struggle to complete renovations to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in time for a scheduled fall reopening referred incorrectly to one of its exhibitions, a decommissioned submarine named the Growler. It was diesel powered and carried missiles with nuclear warheads; it was not nuclear powered.

headline: The Alpha Geeks
text: In 1950, Dr. Seuss published a book called “If I Ran the Zoo.” It contained the sentence: “I’ll sail to Ka-Troo, and bring back an IT-KUTCH, a PREEP, and a PROO, a NERKLE, a NERD, and a SEERSUCKER, too!” According to the psychologist David Anderegg, that’s believed to be the first printed use of the word “nerd” in modern English.

headline: Paying a Premium for a Wright Design
text: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT, who died in 1959 at the age of 92, completed more than 500 buildings in his lifetime. Of the 400 or so that still stand, most are residences. At any given time, 8 or 10 of these homes may be up for sale, and they are highly sought after.

headline: As Race Wanes, Talk of Clinton as No. 2 Grows
text: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her advisers insist that she is determined to win the Democratic nomination, friends of the couple say that former President Bill Clinton, for one, has begun privately contemplating a different outcome for her: As Senator Barack Obama’s running mate.

headline: A Fitting End?
text: Manchester United and Chelsea pummeled each other through regulation time and two fatigue-inducing extra periods in the Champions League final before Man U finally prevailed on penalty kicks. Soccer has used penalties to decide tie matches in tournaments for more than three decades, often prompting criticism that it employs a manufactured endgame to settle its most important competitions. Does Wednesday's thrilling finale validate the system as the best one available? And if not, what would?

headline: Rallying Round a Train That Gets No Respect
text: If you will excuse a biblical flourish, the G train is the Moses of New York mass transit. Like Moses, it never made it to the Promised Land. That is, if Manhattan is your idea of divine promise. With its nosebleed-inducing apartment prices and rents, some think of it as flowing not so much with milk and honey as with bilk and money.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fund Fees Revisited in Court
text: In 1970, Congress decided that there was too little price competition in the mutual fund industry and amended the law to allow fund investors to file suits claiming that management fees were excessive.

headline: Talking With the Enemy
text: Everybody knew President Bush was aiming at Senator Barack Obama last week when he likened those who endorse talks with “terrorists and radicals” to appeasers of the Nazis. But now we know what Mr. Bush knew then  that Israel is in indirect peace talks with Syria, a prominent member of Mr. Bush’s list of shunned nations  and it seems as if the president was going for a two-for-one in his crack about appeasement.

headline: Leaving Las Vegas
text: In Las Vegas, if it's action at the tables or sports books you're craving, stick with heart-of-the-Strip locales. For the best Sin City golf experiences, however, you've got to get out of town. Shadow Creek, a half-hour north of the Strip and the top golf venue for high-rolling MGM/Mirage whales, shut down last week for a seven-month refurbishment. Fortunately, a spectacular new layout opened in May to pick up the slack. The Chase at PGA Golf Club Coyote Springs may be awkwardly named, but the course is seamless from start to finish.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘THE ECCENTRICITIES OF A NIGHTINGALE’ Every season a handful of performances set the city’s theater watchers abuzz with excitement. This year has been unusually rich in quality work from actors on Broadway, from the fisticuffs of “August: Osage County” to the sweaty farcing of Mark Rylance and company in “Boeing-Boeing” to the filigreed performances in “South Pacific.” I’m sure they’ll linger long in the memory. But the less traveled byways of the city’s theater industry are home to performances no less powerful, no less indelible. Too often they pass unheralded; nobody can see everything, after all.

headline: Trouble in the Hudson
text: On the surface, the Hudson River is looking good. The sun on a spring morning glints off the water, off bridges and boats, off river bluffs groaning with new condominiums. The blue crabs are big, and the striped bass are bigger. If it weren’t for the PCB’s in the river mud, which General Electric might get around to dredging someday, you would think the Hudson was about as healthy as it has been since Indian times.

headline: Chip Off the Old Block
text: Wielding hammer and screwdriver in a nighttime attack, two men vandalized the central megalith at Stonehenge, a Unesco World Heritage site, Agence France-Presse reported. The incident last week was the first in decades, said officials of the conservation organization English Heritage. A chip of stone about the size of a large coin was removed, and a 2.5-inch-long scratch was left on a portion of the monument known as the Heel Stone. A spokeswoman for English Heritage said two men fled over a fence when spotted by security guards. “This is now a matter for the police,” she added. The 5,000-year-old ring of standing stones, near Salisbury in southwest England, draws about 850,000 visitors a year.

headline: Olmert Peace Effort Elicits Cynicism and Hope
text: JERUSALEM  In recent days, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert simultaneously began groundbreaking talks with Syria, discussed a possible truce with Hamas and facilitated a huge Palestinian investment conference in the West Bank  all while under serious criminal investigation on suspicion of bribery.

headline: Guantánamo Judge Won’t Delay Trials
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY NAVAL BASE, Cuba (AP)  A military judge on Thursday denied motions to delay the arraignments of five Guantánamo detainees suspected of mounting the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Violence in Rockaway
text: After a recent spate of violence in Far Rockaway, Queens, the New York Police Department has stepped up its presence in the area.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 98 Syracuse
text: Location: Syracuse, N.Y.

headline: Eight Bells for Eight Belles
text: Amanda Whitney needs some closure.

headline: The Insider | Tim Hamilton
text: The men’s-wear designer Tim Hamilton shares a few of his stylish essentials with The Moment. Hamilton, a veteran of Ralph Lauren and J.Crew, is a self-proclaimed “one-man show” who is nominated for the Swarovski Award for men’s wear from the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA). The CFDA winners will be announced June 2. Whatever happens, Hamilton’s fans have plenty to look forward to: he’s launching a tailoring line this fall and a range of men’s accessories next year.

headline: Afghanistan’s Hidden Treasures
text: At once revelatory and heart-rending, a show at the National Gallery of Art has much to tell about the country’s past and present.

headline: Moore in America
text: The New York Botanical Garden brings the museum outdoors with its exhibit of Henry Moore’s big, beloved bronze sculptures. Randy Kennedy reviews.

headline: ‘Clone Your Family Dog’
text: More “late night” jokes from you (send via the comment link below):

headline: ‘Indiana Jones’ and This Guy With a Tune
text: A theme song parody:

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Slave Trade in Charleston, This Time on Stage
text: We know fat happy Mambo,Simple lazy Sambo.

headline: Senna wins in Monaco
text: Bruno Senna carried on a family tradition today, taking victory in the GP2 support race in Monaco. His uncle Ayrton must have been hovering over him somewhere, especially at the start of the race. Senna started second and just leapt into first ahead of the pole sitter, Maldonado. This is Monaco, so the two drivers also finished the race 45 laps later in that same position. Maldonado pressured Senna a few laps before the end but it did no good. In Third was the Indian driver Chandhok, who started sixth. He should have finished fourth, but on the last lap Conway spun out….

headline: Flock Rounds Up $15 Million from V.C.s
text: Flock, the creator of a “social Web browser” that is fast gaining traction among devotees of cutting-edge Internet technology, has scored another $15 million in fresh funding, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Bernie Ecclestone’s letter to the FIA club presidents
text: I got a copy this morning of the letter that Bernie Ecclestone yesterday sent to the FIA club presidents as a response to a letter that Max Mosley had sent out earlier on to the club presidents. Here are a few relevant points/quotes from the letter:

headline: Space Exploration Quiz
text: In honor of the the Phoenix’s scheduled arrival on Mars this weekend, we have a space-exploration quiz and prize for you. If the NASA spacecraft survives its fiery descent — the “seven minutes of terror,” as my colleague Warren Leary reports— it will land on Sunday a little before 8 p.m. Eastern time on the arctic plain of Mars. [UPDATE: The Phoenix landed safely and is sending back photos, Ken Chang reports.]

headline: Brevan Howard Raises $1 Billion in I.P.O.
text: For Brevan Howard Asset Management it appears the second time was the charm.

headline: Defections Prompt Clear Channel to Sue Tribune
text: Trouble, it seems, is brewing between media companies, the Tribune Company and Clear Channel Communications.

headline: Moody’s Said to Have Shuffled Analysts After Banks’ Criticism
text: Moody’s credit rating unit, Moody’s Investors Service, moved analysts covering deals of particular investment banks in response to criticism by those banks, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Crisis? What Crisis? A Q&A With Don Goldberg
text: Don Goldberg, a crisis management expert for Qorvis Communications, says the N.F.L. and Bill Belichick have failed Damage Control 101.

headline: Halliburton Fires Up Counterbid for Expro
text: Halliburton, the world’s second-biggest oilfield contractor, offered 1.71 billion pounds ($3.4 billion) for Expro International Group, topping a bid by Candover Partners and Goldman Sachs, as record crude prices spur exploration.

headline: Austria’s Bawag May Go Public Sooner Than Anticipated
text: Austrian bank Bawag, which is owned by a consortium headed by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, said it is likely to be in shape for an initial public offering before its target of 2012.

headline: Advances in Merrill’s Deal for Ground Zero Headquarters
text: Merrill Lynch is negotiating a deal to build a 70-story headquarters at ground zero, a plan that would make it the first financial firm to return to the 16-acre former World Trade Center site since the terrorist attack destroyed the complex in 2001.

headline: Analyst Says Calpine Bid May Not Rise Much
text: Despite apparent market expectations that NRG may raise its $11 billion bid for Calpine, at least one analyst thinks a lengthy courtship between the two power generators is unlikely.

headline: Buyout Shop Stands by a Firm Tainted by Heparin
text: Two years ago, a financier named Malon Wilkus spied what seemed like a good buy: Scientific Protein Laboratories, of Waunakee, Wis.

headline: 9 Airlines Face Threat of a Credit Downgrade
text: In the latest sign that the outlook for the airline industry is darkening, Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services on Thursday placed nine big airlines on CreditWatch with negative implications, meaning that it was likely to cut their debt ratings.

headline: Delta and Northwest Win Approval for Transatlantic Cooperation
text: Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines, which last month announced plans to combine, on Thursday won final federal approval to share revenue and coordinate schedules across the Atlantic.

headline: Borders Chief Denies Holding ‘Substantial’ Sales Talks
