text: Borders Group has not had substantial discussions regarding a possible sale and was moving forward on efforts to improve its business, Chief Executive George Jones said Thursday.

headline: Atos Meeting Suspended As Hedge Funds Gain Support
text: Two hedge funds engaged in a proxy battle with Atos Origin got a surprise vote of support Thursday, but the outcome remained remained unclear as the French IT services firm suspended the annual meeting after an employee shareholder group said it would vote in support of board nominees proposed by rebel hedge fund shareholders.

headline: An Inquiry Into Interbank Loan Rate
text: Each morning in London, a handful of banks quietly decide how much it costs to borrow money all over the world.

headline: Ex-Stock Trader Is Accused of Duping Friends Out of Millions
text: A former stock trader was charged on Thursday with duping friends out of $16 million over six years by luring them into various investments, most of which never existed, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said.

headline: Nomura Hedge Fund Manger to Start New Firm
text: Makoto Haga, who in 1998 became the first hedge fund manager at Nomura Holdings, will start his own asset management firm with investments among Japan’s 800 largest companies.

headline: Mocana Ropes in $7 Million
text: Mocana, a maker of security software for non-PC devices like PDAs, has raised $7 million in its second round of venture funding.

headline: SmartSynch Puts $20 Million on the Meter
text: SmartSynch, which sells smart metering technology to the utility industry, has raised $20 million in new funding led by new investors Credit Suisse and Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance.

headline: Paris Bank’s Managers Are Blamed in a Scandal
text: Serious management failures by immediate superiors allowed a rogue trader at Société Générale to commit the biggest fraud in financial history, according to The New York Times which cited an internal report to be released Friday.

headline: China’s Haier Leads List of Possible Suitors for G.E. Unit
text: When General Electric announced it might sell its appliances unit, top bosses at Haier, G.E.’s rival in China, apparently jumped at what could be their last opportunity to buy a U.S. business with a household name.

headline: Linens ‘n Things Picks Stalking-Horse Bidders
text: Tiger Capital Group and SB Capital Group won a bidding war to become the joint stalking-horse bidders to lead a partial liquidation of Linens ‘n Things, paving the way for the May 29 auction of Apollo Management‘s bankrupt retailer.

headline: The Early Word: Veepstakes, Democrat Edition
text: As first lady, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spent eight years standing behind a president in the White House. And now, if she can’t get there on her own, former President Bill Clinton is said to be musing, perhaps she ought to do it again – as vice president. Though both campaigns have shrugged off such suggestions, some think the move would help unify the party. And, of course, Senator Barack Obama, assuming he becomes the Democratic nominee, has plenty of other choices.

headline: Heading for a Yahoo Showdown
text: Yahoo nominated 9 of its 10 existing directors for re-election to the company’s board on Thursday, setting the stage for a showdown with dissident shareholders at its annual shareholder meeting.

headline: Will Lehman Follow Bear into a Deal?
text: Can Lehman Brothers remain independent?

headline: Major Fallout as BCE Deal Falters
text: As shares in Bell Canada declined by the most in at least two decades on Thursday, many investors and analysts turned their attention to alternatives for the company should its $51.8 billion privatization fail.

headline: ‘The Cat in the Hat’ on the Couch
text: From a “Freudian” analysis of the Seuss classic (found on this parody page):

headline: Judicial Activism in Mutual Funds
text: My column today discusses a surprising decision by the chief judge of the Seventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, Frank Easterbrook, that essentially negates a section of the Investment Company Act allowing mutual fund shareholders to sue over management fees they deem to be too high.

headline: Trading in Silverjet Halted Amid Financing Troubles
text: Shares in Silverjet were suspended Friday as the company revealed a key funding deal had failed to materialize, prompting speculation that the British business-class airline is near collapse.

headline: Weill Admits Mistake in Citi Succession Planning
text: Sandford I. Weill, Citigroup‘s former chairman and chief executive, has acknowledged that the planning that led to the choice of Charles O. Prince as his successor in 2003 was flawed and turned out not to be the “right thing” for the company, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Weather Channel Bids Due Today
text: Wall Street Journal: “Time Warner Inc. and a partnership between General Electric Co.’s NBC Universal and Blackstone Group LP have emerged as leading contenders to win an auction for the Weather Channel, ahead of Friday’s deadline for a second round of bids.” Bids are due Friday.

headline: Dancin’ With the Sales Dude
text: Car stereo salesman gets down with customers groovin’ to his goods:

headline: Sue Simmons, Unscathed
text: WNBC is making another evening newscast change, and this one will install the channel’s two leading anchors, Chuck Scarborough and Sue Simmons, at 6 p.m.

headline: USA Renews ‘Criminal Intent’
text: “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” will remain on the case for another season on USA Network, the Associated Press reports.

headline: The Paterson-Bruno Détente
text: Gov. David A. Paterson has quietly declared a political truce with Joseph L. Bruno and his party in a shift that is turning Albany upside down and making some Democrats privately uneasy, Danny Hakim reports. Although the governor is committed to raising money for the state’s Democrats, he has been reluctant to recruit candidates to run against incumbent Republicans at a time when the Democrats appear tantalizingly close to taking over the Senate for the first time in more than 40 years.

headline: Giving Up the ‘Ugliest Skyscraper’ Title
text: There are people who say you have to stand next to the Verizon building at 375 Pearl Street to appreciate how ugly it is — its blank presence at street level, its disconnection from any human scale. There are others who say the offensiveness of the tower, built to house communications equipment, stems from the way it overshadows the Brooklyn Bridge when viewed from afar, acting as a drab, yet commercialized, backdrop (topped with a light-up Verizon sign ).

headline: More of the Same Old?
text: Was Obama’s hiring of Jim Johnson a sign of old Washington mentality?; Hillary Clinton’s popular vote lead.

headline: McCain’s Health Records
text: The status of Senator John McCain’s health over the course of the last eight years or so will be a primary topic of discussion today, as some of his medical records have been made available for the media to review.

headline: Not in My House
text: As if baseball’s Hatfields and McCoys (or their boisterous and loyal fans) needed another reason to get worked up: Major League Baseball is planning to cast Boston slugger David Ortiz in the role of Babe Ruth at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Nationwide predicts ‘single digit’ fall in U.K. housing prices
text: Another leading building industry company is forecasting declines in the U.K. housing market.

headline: Dynegy, a Dark Horse Again?
text: For people outside the power industry, Dynegy may be best remembered as the company that made a daring bid to buy Enron as that energy giant spiraled toward bankruptcy.

headline: Commander-in-Chief Tours Barracks
text: What a difference a few weeks make. At the end of April, a barracks at Fort Bragg, the North Carolina home of the Army’s 82nd Airborne Division, was a YouTube embarrassment replete with bad plumbing, mold and peeling paint. On Thursday, the commander-in-chief dropped by to witness a dramatically improved building. Freshly-painted walls were bright white, bathroom fixtures gleamed and everything seemed to be in tip-top shape.

headline: Surprise Stars Continue to Shine
text: Two players the average baseball fan may not have heard much about coming into the season are doing everything they can to make sure their names will be remembered by the end of it.

headline: Southwest's Kelleher on Airlines
text: CNBC interviews Herb Kelleher, founder of Southwest Airlines, about his company and the airline industry in the face of rising fuel prices.

headline: A True Racehorse
text: At first glance, the $16,000 claiming event carded as the seventh race at Churchill Downs on Friday doesn’t jump out as a tremendous event. It looks just like any other number of similar races around the country where you have a mix of all types of horses entered against one another, some dropping in class, some stepping up, but all for sale if you have 16 grand and an itch.

headline: Fox Welcomes The Total Viewer Win, But Wants To Stay Young
text: Fox’s historic victory — first place among all viewers for a full television season — left Kevin Reilly, the network’s entertainment president, “only mildly excited,” the Associated Press reports. Why?

headline: A Rare Bird of War Swoops In
text: Video

headline: Clinton Touting Popular Vote Projections
text: Senator Hillary Clinton is keeping hope alive today with a new assessment of the popular vote that says she is poised to finish the primary season on June 3 as the winner of the overall popular vote, at least by the most inclusive measure, which would include the tallies from all states.

headline: Rumors Fly About Big Beer Deal
text: The buzz is back: Speculation about a deal between Inbev and Anheuser Busch returned to Wall Street on Friday, when FT Alphaville reported that Inbev was considering a $46 billion takeover approach to its United States-based rival.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Swedish Pancakes
text: A rich pancake, like those often served in Sweden, takes the proportions of a standard pancake and skews them, boosting the proportion of eggs, butter and sugar at the expense of flour. As with brownies or cookies, when you increase fat and sweetness and decrease filler (a k a flour), the results are indisputably better, and — thanks to beaten egg whites — supremely light and airy.

headline: From China, Disaster Caught in a Wedding Lens
text: Some pretty amazing before-during-and-after photographs of the devastating May 12 earthquake in China have surfaced, photos that exist because of the timing of the quake — in midafternoon, when several newlywed couples happened to be having their wedding photos taken near the town of Bailu.

headline: Merrill Revs Up Its Lobbying Machine
text: John Thain, the new chief executive of Merrill Lynch, is is raising the volume of his firm’s voice in Washington. The New York investment bank replaced its chief in-house lobbyist in March and, according to a document made public late last week, hired a new outside lobbying firm in April. The moves come amid a deluge of legislative efforts aimed at the financial service industry.

headline: A Warning From the White House
text: In her column, Sheryl Gay Stolberg writes that the very public dust-up between the White House and NBC over the editing of an interview with President Bush, suggests the White House intends a more combative stance with the media in the twilight of the administration, as attention turns away from Mr. Bush and toward those trying to succeed him.

headline: A Weird Sort of Poetry, Indeed
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Krug on Mondavi
text: One last thought on Robert Mondavi. A few years ago I was in Champagne, meeting with Rémi Krug, then head of the Krug Champagne house, and he recalled in the course of our discussion something that Mondavi had said to him years before, back in 1983.

headline: Charity Begins at the Benefit Committee
text: Who among us who hasn’t flipped through the society pages and wondered how all these benefit balls and dinners get put together? And how do the women who do the putting together raise money in these uncertain times? With plenty of goosebumps, it turns out.

headline: Online Video’s Grave Consequences
text: For a decent sense of which organizations are still hellbent on hand-swatting every mosquito in the copyright-violation forest, the new site YouTomb provides a valuable service. It’s a video-sharing video watchdog joint, but only for videos that have been removed from YouTube — for supposed copyright violations. And other reasons.

headline: ‘$85 Worth of Gas’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Did you know that by staying home and watching this show tonight you are saving an average of $85 worth of gas? So you’re welcome, America.

headline: ‘Church Had a Portable Meth Lab’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Barack Obama was endorsed by 90-year-old Senator Robert Byrd. Yeah. Byrd said, “Obama will make a great president and if he doesn’t, I won’t be around anyway.”

headline: Testing the Strength of Chinese Walls
text: As part a global settlement in 2003, the top Wall Street firms agreed to shore up their “Chinese walls” in order to curb conflicts of interest among their various business arms. But many observers have remained cynical. Could the departments of big securities firms — stock research, investment banking and asset management — really separate themselves, with no breaches?

headline: Paterson Has Second Eye Procedure
text: Gov. David A. Paterson, who on Tuesday underwent surgery on his left eye to relieve sharp pain caused by glaucoma, had a second, similar procedure performed on his right eye on Friday morning. The governor’s office said in a statement:

headline: Songs in the Key of Life
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Awakening
text: T Magazine's Judith Puckett-Rinella cultivates one heck of rock garden.

headline: ‘Auditioning Candidates’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: John McCain is going to be the Republican nominee for president, so he is now auditioning candidates for vice president. And they’re visiting at his home in Arizona, which I believe is called the Lazy Artery. Wait, I believe it’s a ranch. I think it is the Double Hernia, or maybe it is called the Rancho Prostateo.

headline: Remembering Volleyball’s ‘Oriental Witches’
text: It just wouldn’t be a proper Olympic volleyball tournament if the Japanese women weren’t there. Today, this year’s tournament became a proper one as Japan and Serbia booked passage for the Beijing Games by winning their respective Olympic qualifying matches in Tokyo.

headline: At Danny Meyer’s, An Umbrella with Dinner
text: A full-service amenity at Eleven Madison Park restaurant. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

headline: ABC Allows Viewers To Embed Shows Online
text: Come fall, Web users will be able to embed “Lost” or “Desperate Housewives” on blogs and social networking sites.

headline: Sweeps Month Ends: Somebody Get A Broom
text: The May “sweeps” month and the September-to-May television season officially ended on Wednesday, and the broadcast networks would probably like to sweep the numbers under the rug.

headline: What Do You Miss Most About Old New York?
text: Here they come, chugging down Fifth Avenue, carrying their gleeful load of passengers: public double-decker buses in New York City! You can almost hear the violins bounce.

headline: Dispatch | The Other Bahamas
text: Order food off the chalk board at Tippy’s on Eleuthera.

headline: ‘Used Geo Metros’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Hey, congratulations to David Cook, the “American Idol,” who got so many votes, today Hillary offered him the V.P. spot.

headline: Britain’s Nimrod: Unsafe at Any Altitude?
text: The verdict from a British coroner today in the 2006 crash that killed 14 servicemen in Afghanistan is Ralph Naderesque in its harshness: The plane they were flying, known as a Nimrod, has “never been airworthy.”

headline: The Rules of Engagement
text: We are only midway through proxy season and change is already afoot. The litigation arising from the disputes between activist hedge-fund shareholders and their target companies is transforming strategies, tactics and the law.

headline: The Morning Skate: Any Day Now….
text: Day 4 of the hockey world being held hostage by the Lords of Scheduling. After negotiations for an early end to the standoff broke down early Wednesday morning when the NHL team’s of 183 lawyers walked out, after the Vera Wang Brigade descended on the NHL’s Sixth Avenue offices, pumping their fists yelling “Free the Stanley Cup final!!!” (see yesterday’s Morning Skate), Sean Avery returned to his xeroxing duties at Vogue.

headline: The Season for Gull’s Eggs
text: Ed Schneider, a regular Bitten contributor, checked in after a recent trip to London. –MB

headline: Wanna Buy A Home?
text: Back in Econ 101, I learned that if you cut the price of anything, the supply will shrink and demand will grow.

headline: The Starting Line: The Earthquake and the Changing Narrative of the Olympics
text: The Olympic torch relay reached Shanghai today, its tone more somber now with the death toll from the Sichuan earthquake at 55,000 and still climbing.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief on the Hot Seat
text: As the head of The Children’s Investment Fund, Christopher Hohn is used to putting powerful executives on the spot. His fund helped bring about the break-up and sale of ABN Amro and has agitated for change at other corporate giants.

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Individuality at Its Nuttiest and Finest’
text: Monday, May 19

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: The Freedom Schooner
text: Images of the Freedom Schooner Amistad and scenes from the opera production.

headline: Obama and the Preconditions Meme
text: As Senator Barack Obama speaks to the Cuban American National Foundation today, the Republicans are out in full force over his remarks time and again on whether he would meet with the leaders of rogue nations without preconditions.

headline: Historic Merc Library Will Move: Fiction, or Fact?
text: The Mercantile Library Center for Fiction, one of three private libraries in town that has survived since the early part of the 19th century, is in the process of selling its building at 17 East 47th Street in Manhattan, and will be shutting down in the coming weeks.

headline: Biofuels and Food Prices
text: Biofuels made from farm crops probably are the most controversial form of renewable energy. One reason is their supposed effect on food prices, which have shot up across the world in recent months and led to prortests and riots in some developing nations. Opinion leaders like Jeffrey Sachs of Columbia University are calling on governments to review their targets for biofuels, while many environmental and anti-poverty groups say crop fuels that compete with food should be abandoned entirely.In a new study, New Energy Finance, an energy consultancy in London, shows that biofuels do have an effect on food prices but that this effect may not be quite as significant as some people think.

headline: Bourn Doesn’t Need Average to Steal
text: Chipper Jones of the Braves may be making a run at a .400 batting average, but there are enough star players struggling mightily with the bat that 2008 could be called the Year of .215 or Below.

headline: Governor Pardons Hip-Hop Pioneer
text: Ricky Walters, a 43-year-old hip-hop pioneer known for the rap classic “The Great Adventures of Slick Rick” and was convicted of attempted murder in 1991, has received a full pardon from Gov. David A. Paterson. The governor said in a statement that he decided to pardon Mr. Walters, who was released from prison in 1997, to prevent him from being deported to Britain, where Mr. Walters was born and lived until the age of 11.

headline: The Art of Switching Leads
text: Yesterday I wrote about galloping horses and what I believe makes for a good exercise rider. Today I wanted to get into a little more technical detail and discuss lead changing.

headline: NBC Announces Fall Premiere Dates
text: NBC has announced the premiere dates for its fall programming slate. The highlights: a three-hour premiere of “Heroes” on Sept. 22; a new Thursday time slot for “Kath & Kim;” and an Oct. 17 berth for “Crusoe.” The Hollywood Reporter has details…

headline: Place Your Bets: Buyout Team or Big Red?
text: The battle between financial and strategic buyers has broken out on a new front: Expro, a relatively small oil-service firm based in the United Kingdom. On one side is a consortium of financial investors that includes Goldman Sachs and the British private equity firm Candover. On the other side sits the oil-service giant Halliburton, or “Big Red” as it is known in the trenches.

headline: Obama Takes 3 More Superdelegates
text: Senator Barack Obama added three superdelegates to his total today, a boost that comes after he saw just a trickle of delegates go to his side in recent days. Despite Mr. Obama’s triumphant speech in Iowa and the buzz about the vice presidential search, the Senator had not initially capitalized on his performance in Tuesday’s primaries, which gave him a majority of pledged delegates. (He received only two superdelegates on Wednesday and none on Thursday).

headline: Human Guinea Pig Seeking Cure for Jet Lag
text: This weekend, we’re running an article called “Coffee and naps not helping your jet lag? Try starving instead.” The snappy headline (thanks to yours truly, ahem), is not totally straightforward. If you read into the text from Reuters, it quotes a study showing that food deprivation, or a drastic change in meal times, can override a mouse‘s internal clock and its natural mechanism for coordinating waking and sleeping with periods of light and dark. “A period of fasting with no food at all for about 16 hours is enough to engage this new clock,” said Dr. Clifford Saper of Harvard Medical School, whose study appears in Science.

headline: Wanted: Better Data on Bad Subway Elevators
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority needs to do a better job informing the public about mechanical problems with elevators and escalators in the subway, an authority board member says.

headline: Sunscreen in Sea Water May Harm Coral
text: News today of one more way human activity might be helping wreck the planet: Research by Italian marine biologists, reported in Environmental Health Priorities, suggests that the sunscreen that washes off the skin of swimmers in the tropics may be contributing to coral bleaching.

headline: Photos by Cornell Capa, 1918-2008
text: Cornell Capa sought to produce images in which genuine human feeling predominated over commercial cynicism or disinterested formalism.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, May 23:

headline: J. C. Flowers Bids for Stake in Germany’s Hypo
text: J. C. Flowers, the private equity firm, on Friday unveiled a 1.1 billion euros ($1.7 billion) offer for a stake in German subprime-hit investment bank Hypo Real Estate.

headline: Hamm, Top U.S. Gymnast, May Miss Qualifiers
text: Gymnast Paul Hamm, who won a gold medal at the 2004 Athens Games and is the only American to win an all-around gold at an Olympics or world championship, has a broken bone in his hand that will probably force him to miss next month’s U.S. team trials. If he does miss the qualifiers, he’ll have to petition USA Gymnastics for a spot on the team.

headline: Tucker: The Man and His Dream, Deferred
text: Jake Tapper, a senior national correspondent for ABC News who calls himself a “good friend” of Tucker Carlson’s, regrets to report that Carlson will not be seeking the presidential nomination of the Libertarian Party.

headline: Lynn Hirschberg Talks to Tyra Banks
text: Tyra Banks on fame, her career and what every model should be equipped with.
From The Onion:

headline: What Have I Gotten Myself Into?
text: Not every major sporting event gives spectators a way to measure just how great the gap is between what they can achieve and what professional athletes can achieve under the most testing competitive conditions. Everyone who has ever watched the Masters on television, for instance, knows that the greens at Augusta are treacherous, but since no one has ever pulled a fan out of the gallery and asked him to knock in a putt to win the tournament, who knows how hard that really is?

headline: Before The Climb
text: Just so we’re clear on exactly how far I’ve got to go in these last six weeks before attempting to make it through the entire route of stage 10 of this year’s Tour de France, here is a quick summary of what I’ve done so far.

headline: Attack of the Midlife Hobby
text: About a year and a half ago I was doing some research for a video I made for this Web site about the poet Paul Muldoon’s rock band, Rackett, which he started after learning to play the guitar at age 48. I came across an article in which Muldoon’s “two-car garage band” was used as an example of a new phenomenon: the Midlife Hobby. According to Kate Muir, of The Times of London:

headline: More Reasons Not to Run for Congress
text: The field of Republican candidates interested in succeeding Vito J. Fossella is dwindling. Stephen J. Fiala, the county clerk and commissioner for jurors for Staten Island, announced today that he will not be a candidate for Congress.

headline: Why Guns Over Gas?
text: This Missouri used car dealership has a different kind of promotion, offering buyers a choice between a $250 gas card or a $250 check toward the purchase of a gun.

headline: Mexico: Crimes at the Border
text: A joint reporting project with Frontline World investigates smugglers along the Mexican border who are bribing American officials.

headline: Predicting The ‘Idol’ Winner
text: Ian Ayres of sis-blog Freakonomics asks: What’s the Best Way to Predict American Idol?

headline: New ‘Idol’ Tops iTunes Download Charts
text: Newly crowned “American Idol” David Cook is already topping the iTunes music download charts, Reuters reports.

headline: Answers About New York’s Hidden Places, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of answers from Michelle Haimoff, the author of “Secret New York: Exploring the City’s Hidden Neighborhoods.” Ms. Haimoff answered readers’ questions about walking tours and the secret places and hidden gems of the city. (We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.)

headline: The Digital Ramble | The Grand Tour
text: The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

headline: Ratings: ‘Grey’ Leads, ‘Dance’ Follows
text: The two-hour season finale of “Grey’s Anatomy” vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show’s fourth season conclusion declined nearly 5 million compared to a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal,” which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Narrow Minded
text: You don’t have to search very hard to find the excruciating online videos known as thinspiration, or thinspo. Photomontages of skeletal women, including some celebrities and models, play all over the Internet, uploaded from the United States, Germany, Holland and elsewhere. These videos are designed to “inspire” viewers — to fortify their ambitions. But exactly which ambitions? To lose weight, presumably. To stop losing weight, possibly. Thinspo videos profess a range of ideologies, often pressing morbid images into double service, as both goads and deterrents to anorexia.

headline: Navy Special Operations Watercraft
text: A ride on the Mark V, a 100,000 pound boat that travels at 47 knots. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Lacrosse: Final Four Weekend Arrives
text: Lacrosse purists may complain that there are no new teams in this weekend’s Final Four at Foxborough, Mass., but there will be no shortage of drama at Gillette Stadium.

headline: Astros Come on Strong in May
text: After losing 90 games in 2007 expectations were not particularly high for the 2008 Astros. So it was no particularly surprise when Houston finished the month of April three games under .500 and five games back of the division-leading Cubs.

headline: Queens Democrats Won’t Endorse Senator for Re-election
text: Democratic Party officials in Queens voted today not to endorse State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat who has been in office six years. Instead, they voted to back his challenger, City Councilman Hiram Monserrate.

headline: Rules That Rule
text: Bill Pennington learns that playing by the rules can save you some strokes.

headline: Yankees Voice Concern Over Ortiz Plan
text: The Yankees voiced their concerns with Major League Baseball about a plan to have David Ortiz, the Red Sox slugger, try to hit a home run to a designated spot at Yankee Stadium during the Home Run Derby part of All-Star Game festivities in July.

headline: Tracking China's Missing
text: Many survivors in Sichuan Province, China, continue to look for their missing relatives in the earthquake rubble.

headline: Worth Listening to: Obscure BBC Radio Podcasts
text: As a city resident who walks a lot, it’s not surprising I’ve become a big fan of podcasts.

headline: Tracking China's Missing
text: Many survivors in Sichuan Province, China, continue to look for their missing relatives in the earthquake rubble.

headline: He’s Got Algorithm
text: Education | Want to remember everything you’ll ever learn? That’s the goal behind SuperMemo, an educational software package that calculates when to review new information to help maximize study time. In an odd personal experiment, the Polish creator, Peter Wozniak, is living his life around the software. — Wired.

headline: Toys on a Marketing Tour
text: In this video provided by Spin Master, kids get a demonstration of the popular Bakugan Battle Brawlers game.

headline: Minaya to Join the Mets in Denver, Not for the Food
text: Omar Minaya is somewhere over middle America, on his way to Denver to either show support for the Mets or to see first-hand what has happened to his $140 million team. The Mets have a front-office representative — either Minaya, Tony Bernazard, the vice president of development, or the assistant general manager John Ricco — traveling with the team to every city, but I can’t recall Minaya making a trip out here since I took over the beat, in August 2005. Because he can, Minaya will usually pick cities like Miami, San Francisco or Washington, but I can guarantee you that he is not here, on Memorial Day weekend, because he wants to try the Vesta Dipping Grill.

headline: Clips From 'Date My House'
text: In an difficult real estate market, sellers are getting creative in how they market their property.

headline: Obama Discusses Cuba Policy
text: MIAMI – Senator Barack Obama on Friday called for greater engagement with Cuba and Latin America, saying the long policies of isolation have failed to advance the interests of the United States or help people who have suffered under oppressive regimes.

headline: Clips From "Flip This House"
text: In an difficult real estate market, sellers are getting creative in how they market their property.

headline: Toad-Venom ‘Love Stone’ Killed Man, City Says
text: A 35-year-old New York City man died after ingesting an illegal aphrodisiac derived from toad venom, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced on Friday.

headline: Wrigley Unwraps Big Fee for Goldman
text: Here’s a tasty morsel tucked in a late-Friday-before-the-holiday-weekend regulatory filing: Goldman Sachs stands to earn a mouth-watering $46 million in fees for its role as financial adviser to Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company in that company’s $23 billion sale to fellow candy company Mars. The fee was disclosed in a preliminary proxy statement that Wrigley filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday after the close of trading.

headline: Pollution 3.0
text: Environment | The growth of Internet-based “cloud computing” (services depicted as a “cloud” in many charts) means “the Internet could become as ungreen as aviation.” You might think computing happens in the Web ether, but it requires more and bigger data centers on earth — and “they are huge energy hogs.” [a href=”http://www.economist.com/opinion/displaystory.cfm?story_id=11412495″>Economist]

headline: The Book on Shopsin’s
text: What’s inside Kenny Shopsin’s mind has never been much of a mystery. He’s given a piece of it to his customers for years.

headline: For Australian Athletes, a Voice From the Grave
text: As the debate continues over whether athletes should speak out against China’s human rights record at the Summer Games, many members of Australia’s Olympic team will arrive in Beijing with the voice of an outspoken countryman fresh in their minds.

headline: Riding the Waves With the Navy Seals
text: Video

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 23
text: Here is a slide show that tells the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Brooklyn Bridge’s 125th birthday, a fashion show at Camden High School and the demolition of the Toy Tower in the East Village. Here are highlights from City Room and the most recent New York headlines.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Italians Looking to Welcome a Prodigal Offspring
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — There they sat, in the first row, in dark suits. The Italians are here. A delegation from Spoleto, Italy, attended a noon ceremony to inaugurate the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. and a rapprochement with the festival’s Italian parent, the Festival of Two Worlds.

headline: B-School Sendoffs: Moguls and Vodka
text: It’s graduation season at the top business schools, which brings with it the battle to claim the most prestigious keynote speaker. Captains of industry, government leaders and powerful financiers are usually the favorites to address departing students. But with the rocky economy and the rounds of layoffs on Wall Street, the best speaker this year may be the one that can do the most to lift students’ low spirits.

headline: Jozy Altidore: I’m Focused on the Fire
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore, who contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week, says he is eager to play the visiting Chicago Fire on Sunday.

headline: ‘America’s Toughest Job': I Dunno — Maybe Programming for NBC?
text: Thom Beers, the executive producer of “Deadliest Catch” and other cable hits, is bringing a series to NBC much earlier than expected.

headline: Say What? Hillary Clinton Does it Again
text: We have no idea what, exactly, Hillary Clinton was thinking when she referred to the assassination of Bobby Kennedy in explaining her decision to keep on campaigning when it looks like there is virtually no hope of her winning the Democratic nomination.

headline: Things We Learned This Season: The Big Issues and What They Meant
text: No matter what happens in the series, the Detroit-Pittsburgh Stanley Cup final stands as perhaps the biggest success for the National Hockey League in a season with many positive developments. Below, the writers and editors of the Slap Shot blog look back at the key issues, both good and bad, that defined the 2007-08 hockey season:

headline: Tidbits for the Long Weekend
text: With the Memorial Day holiday bearing down hard on a blog that thinks the season of taking your laptop out to a rocking chair on the porch with a cold lemonade handy, a ballgame on the transistor radio and the scent of barbecue wafting through the neighborhood to your eager nostrils can’t start soon enough, here are a few items we wish we’d gotten to today before the stampede out of Dodge took hold in earnest:

headline: Clinton, Discussing Nomination Battle, Invokes R.F.K. Assassination
text: Updated BRANDON, S.D. –Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defended staying in the Democratic nominating contests Friday by saying that her husband did not wrap up the nomination until June 1992 and that, “We all remember Bobby Kennedy was assassinated in June in California.”

headline: Eating Spring: Seasonal Vegetables in Italy
text: May is prime time for some of Italy’s most delicious and unusual vegetables. Hang on, I won’t name names just yet.

headline: UrbanEye: El Museo Del Barrio
text: El Museo Del Barrio holds its 15th anniversary "Quinceanero" gala. Melena Ryzik reports (con tiara).

headline: Bloggingheads: Hillary and Sexism
text:
Daniel Drezner of Tufts University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate how sexism and gender have affected Hillary Clinton's presidential run.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: If Girls Are Girly, What Are Boys?
text: This isn’t a tech post, just a linguistic musing.

headline: Paul Hamm Is Ailing but Not Quitting
text: The Olympic gold medalist Paul Hamm broke a bone in his right hand Thursday during the United States gymnastics nationals, but his goal of defending his all-around title at the Summer Olympics is far from doomed.

headline: Behind the Circuits
text: As high schoolers compete in a national robotics competition, the pressure brings team members together.

headline: Cheryl and Robert
text: Cheryl Bennett and Robert Davidowitz tell of being set up by Mr. Davidowitz's mother.

headline: Cheryl and Robert
text: Cheryl Bennett and Robert Davidowitz tell of being set up by Mr. Davidowitz's mother.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Music in Another Chamber
text: CHARLESTON, S.C — While the Dock Street Theater is undergoing renovations, the Spoleto Festival has moved its chamber music concerts — about 30 of them this year — to the newly renovated Memminger Auditorium. The first was on Friday afternoon. A sliding wall cut across the middle of the space, leaving roughly 350 seats facing the stage, which was angled into a corner.

headline: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse: Linked In
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — We’re winding down toward the first face-off of the lacrosse Final Four on Saturday. And in the interest of giving you the best coverage around, here are a few links from around the country to get you ready for Saturday’s games.

headline: U.S. seniors unite to build their own retirement ‘villages’
text: Retirees in the United States are banding together to create a novel solution to senior housing issues. And it seems like the type of concept that can translate to, say, a beach in Mexico as easily as a suburb in Texas

headline: Russia and Ukraine Lock Horns Over Naval Base
text: MOSCOW  They have bickered over NATO expansion, energy prices and how to commemorate a 1930s mass famine. Now, Russia and Ukraine are locked in a new dispute over a naval base in the Ukrainian city of Sevastopol.

headline: At Spoleto Festival, Revisiting a Fateful Chapter in Slavery
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Not so often do new American operas find life after birth. But Anthony Davis’s “Amistad,” a historically inspired exploration of slavery and freedom, has come back to the stage 11 years after its debut at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, and in a deeply resonant setting.

headline: A Flawed but Enduring Leader Returns to Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG

headline: The Killings in South Africa
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about efforts by the Swiss bank UBS to raise additional capital misstated several figures. The bank will issue 760 million new shares at 21 francs or $20.43 each, not $5.03. That price is 31 percent below the Wednesday closing price of 30.64 francs or $29.81, not $7.34. UBS’s shareholder equity fell to 16.4 billion francs or $15.96 billion, not $3.92 billion, at the end of March, from 51.3 billion francs or $49.9 billion, not $12.2 billion, a year earlier.

headline: Teeth Gritted, Drivers Adjust to $4 Gasoline
text: Hating every minute of it, Americans are slowly learning to live with high gasoline prices. For a nation accustomed to cheap fuel, big vehicles and sprawling suburbs, the adjustments are wrenching.

headline: Northwestern Keeps Hope Alive for 4th Title in a Row
text: TOWSON, Md.  Northwestern, trying for its fourth straight women’s lacrosse title, is still on course, but it got a scare before beating Syracuse, 16-8, on Friday night in the national semifinals.

headline: For Police, a Vacation Day Is Soon a Training Day, Too
text: For New York police officers, a day at the firing range has traditionally been a day away from the rigors of patrol. Officers shoot their guns, learn new techniques, meet colleagues and often get to go home a little early, a perquisite known in police jargon as “an early blow.”

headline: Survival Guide for New Hires
text: “NO matter how prepared you may be for the opportunity, entering a new job can be overwhelming,” Angeli R. Rasbury writes in Black Enterprise.

headline: Beyond Red State, Blue State: The Big Task Ahead
text: To the Editor:

headline: Franken-Coleman Race Is Going to the Blogs
text: EAGAN, Minn.  On a laptop at a kitchen table in this cheery Twin Cities suburb, headlines ripping into Al Franken, the satirist whose campaign for the United States Senate is seen as one of the most competitive in the nation, are written up day after day for “Minnesota Democrats Exposed,” a political blog created by a former Republican Party researcher.

headline: Composers of a Certain Age Receive a Makeover
text: Composers have long filtered their own ideas through a prism of older styles, adding contemporary flourishes to established forms. This theme of reinvention was the focus of an evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday by the pianists Stephen Gosling and Anthony Coleman that featured works reinventing older styles or techniques, in some cases the composers’ own.

headline: Cable Prices Keep Rising, and Customers Keep Paying
text: Americans discouraged by higher gas prices and airline fares may decide to spend more vacation time at home, perhaps watching television.

headline: ‘Idol’ Tries to Keep Viewers Guessing
text: LOS ANGELES  Even after seven seasons, with ratings down about 10 percent from last year and some of the teenage fans who helped build the franchise in its early years shunning the show for its un-hip ubiquity, “American Idol” demonstrated on Wednesday that it still has the capacity to surprise.

headline: Russia and China Attack U.S. Missile Shield Plan
text: BEIJING  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and President Hu Jintao of China met on Friday to conclude a deal on nuclear cooperation and together condemn American proposals for a missile shield in Europe. Both countries called the plan a setback to international trust that was likely to upset the balance of power.

headline: Doctors Say McCain Is in Robust Health and Free of Cancer
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Senator John McCain, 71, is in excellent health and shows no evidence of a recurrence of the melanoma skin cancer that led to extensive head and neck surgery in 2000, Mr. McCain’s doctors said on Friday.

headline: 270 Illegal Immigrants Sent to Prison in Federal Push
text: WATERLOO, Iowa  In temporary courtrooms at a fairgrounds here, 260 illegal immigrants were sentenced this week to five months in prison for working at a meatpacking plant with false documents.

headline: Using Movement to Thank a Champion of the Arts
text: In opening remarks on Thursday night for “Dancing for Micki,” a homage to the longtime arts supporter Micki Wesson, the theater director Ping Chong counted her among those who “help us transcend, however briefly, the mundane, and approach the divine.”

headline: Top Queens Democrats Shun Incumbent
text: Democratic Party officials in Queens voted on Friday not to endorse State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat who has been in office six years, for re-election. Instead, they voted to back his challenger, City Councilman Hiram Monserrate.

headline: Cornell Capa, Photographer, Is Dead at 90
text: Cornell Capa, who founded the International Center of Photography in New York after a long and distinguished career as a photojournalist, first on the staff of Life magazine and then as a member of Magnum Photos, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Georgia: Governing Party Wins
text: The governing party triumphed in parliamentary elections, official results showed, securing President Mikheil Saakashvili and his supporters as the nation’s pre-eminent political force. Citing the preliminary official results, the Central Elections Commission said Mr. Saakashvili’s United National Movement Party won 60 percent of the vote in Wednesday’s ballot. A leader of the opposition coalition, the United Opposition bloc, which had 18 percent of the vote, said it planned to boycott Parliament and stage demonstrations to protest what it called a rigged election, Reuters reported.

headline: Far From Always Being Right, the Customer Is on Hold
text: REMEMBER the days when, if something went wrong with a product you ordered, you picked up the phone and there was a live person on the other end? Wait, there is more. You asked for customer service and were transferred  to another human! And that person perhaps even solved your problem.

headline: Yankees Keep Stottlemyre Busy in Rout of Mariners
text: Mel Stottlemyre spent parts of four decades in the home dugout at Yankee Stadium, playing in the World Series and winning championships as a coach. This is his last weekend at the old ballpark, as the pitching coach for the Seattle Mariners.

headline: Georgia’s Ruling Party Victory Is Confirmed
text: The ruling party in Georgia triumphed in parliamentary elections, official results showed Friday, cementing President Mikheil Saakashvili and his followers as the nation’s pre-eminent political force.

headline: The Failures of Thabo Mbeki
text: Crackpot and dangerous theories on AIDS. Extreme and widening levels of income inequality. Enabling Zimbabwe’s Robert Mugabe and only belatedly trying to halt mob atrocities against desperate Zimbabwean and other African immigrants. This is the legacy of South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, who has one more year in his second term.

headline: Shoe Seller’s Secret of Success
text: HARVARD BUSINESS ONLINE posted a blog item on Monday morning praising the online shoe retailer Zappos. In short order, it spread around the Internet like kudzu.

headline: Prayers for the Invisible: Immigrants Who Die in Legal Limbo
text: Among the many rituals of the Roman Catholic Church, none specifically mention a Mass for the Invisible. Still, on Thursday, 12 people gathered at a church in Lower Manhattan to remember Boubacar Bah, a 52-year-old tailor from Guinea who overstayed a tourist visa and died in an immigration detention center.

headline: From a New Autobiography, a 1970 Breakthrough Revisited
text: Bobby Wolff has written his autobiography, “The Lone Wolff” (Master Point Press). Wolff has won 22 world championship medals: 11 gold, 7 silver and 4 bronze. He also has 44 national titles. What do you think the book is about?

headline: Wright Wants Mets to Take Losses Personally
text: DENVER  Back in the sanctuary of his Atlanta hotel room early Wednesday morning, about an hour after the Braves demolished the Mets while sweeping a doubleheader, David Wright dialed a familiar phone number. If anyone could understand his frustration, Wright thought, it was Paul Lo Duca, a former Met who is now a catcher with the Washington Nationals.

headline: R. Kelly Trial Continues
text: The trial of the R& B star R. Kelly, who is charged with 14 counts of child pornography stemming from a video in which, prosecutors say, he has sex with an under-age girl, wrapped up its first week on Friday in Chicago. In testimony this week Stephanie Edwards, a singer, identified the girl in the tape as her niece and said the girl was 13 or 14 when it was made. Mr. Kelly’s defense team filed a motion to call to the stand Jim DeRogatis, the pop music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times, who anonymously received the tape in 2002. Judge Vincent Gaughan said lawyers for The Sun-Times had until next Friday to respond. The trial is to resume on Tuesday. Mr. Kelly has pleaded not guilty, and the woman, now 23, said to be the girl on the tape, has denied that she is.

headline: Marines Won’t Charge 2 Officers Whose Men Killed Afghans After Car Bombing
text: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps will not bring criminal charges against two officers in command of a unit involved in the shooting deaths of as many as 19 civilians in northeastern Afghanistan last year after a car bomb struck the marines’ convoy, it was announced Friday.

headline: Tight Control on McCain Files and Shortened Question Period
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain released his medical records on Friday under tightly controlled circumstances, allowing them to be reviewed by a small group of reporters from news organizations that his campaign chose.

headline: Forecast Sends Pacific Sunwear Stock Price Tumbling
text: Pacific Sunwear of California fell the most in six years in Nasdaq trading on Friday after the clothing chain said annual earnings would be less than it previously forecast because of sluggish sales in states hit by the housing slump. Pacific Sunwear predicted profit of 59 to 64 cents a share, excluding some items, for the year through early 2009. In March, the retailer of surf-themed T-shirts, shorts and sweatshirts projected earnings of at least 73 cents. Analysts had expected 67 cents. About a quarter of the company’s 942 PacSun stores are in California, Florida and the Southwest, areas reeling from the housing decline.

headline: A Bidding War for Well Equipment Maker
text: LONDON  A group of private equity firms increased its offer for the Expro International Group, which makes deepwater well equipment, to more than £1.71 billion, or $3.4 billion, on Friday, entering into a bidding war with Halliburton amid record oil prices and rising exploration costs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cindy McCain Releases Summary of Taxes
text: Senator John McCain’s wife, Cindy, abruptly reversed course on Friday and released a summary of her 2006 income tax return after weeks of vowing not to do so. The form revealed that she took in more than $6 million in taxable income that year.

headline: Controversial Contractor’s Iraq Work Is Split Up
text: WASHINGTON  Sometime soon, a group of American corporate executives and military leaders will quietly sit down and divide Iraq into three parts.

headline: Microsoft Will Shut Down Book Search Program
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft said Friday that it was ending a project to scan millions of books and scholarly articles and make them available on the Web, a sign that it is retrenching in some areas of Internet search in the face of competition from Google, the industry leader.

headline: Hip-Hopper Is Pardoned by Governor
text: During a federal immigration hearing in 1995, Gov. David A. Paterson, then a New York State senator, testified on behalf of the hip-hop pioneer Ricky Walters, who was facing deportation to his native Britain for convictions on attempted murder and weapons charges.

headline: Neutra House Sale Won’t Take Place
text: The $16.8 million sale of a landmark Modernist house by Richard Neutra has been derailed, Christie’s said on Friday. An unidentified bidder bought the 1946 residence, the Kauffmann House in Palm Springs, Calif., above, at Christie’s auction of postwar and contemporary art in New York on May 13. But Marc Porter, president of Christie’s, said in a brief telephone interview on Friday that the deal had fallen apart. “The contract has been terminated by the seller by reason of a breach of its terms by the buyer,” he said. He declined to identify the buyer or to say whether that person had failed to deliver a payment. The sellers, Brent Harris and Beth Edwards Harris, who have divorced, could not immediately be reached for comment. The midcentury landmark of glass, steel and stone sold at the low end of its estimate of $15 million to $25 million at the auction. It was commissioned by the department store owner Edgar J. Kaufmann Sr., the same client who commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to build Fallingwater in Pennsylvania in the 1930s.

headline: Suicide Is the Second for the State Police in 9 Days
text: ALBANY  A State Police scientist hanged himself in his garage Friday, law enforcement officials said, the second time in a little over a week that someone with ties to the agency has killed himself.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Talking Business column last Saturday, about a sharp debate over the advantages and faults of investment instruments called fundamentally weighted index funds, misstated the name of the organization that publishes The Financial Analysts Journal, which prompted the feud by publishing an article on the funds. It is the CFA Institute, not the Chartered Financial Analysts Institute.

headline: Saudis Give $500 Million for Food
text: Saudia Arabia gave $500 million to the World Food Program, which Secretary General Ban Ki-moon described as “of unprecedented size and generosity.” The United Nations, in announcing the gift, said it would complete the program’s emergency appeal for $755 million to offset the rise in fuel and food prices around the world.

headline: From Thebes to Suburbia, in Dire Need of Therapy
text: The members of the doomed house of Oedipus have thrown together their own garage band. It’s part of a family therapy project, which they sorely need, and nobody’s quite in control. But, you know, they sound pretty good, especially considering that the lead vocalist has just gouged out his eyes, and the chief backup singer, who wears a noose around her neck, is dead.

headline: Merrill Trader Is Suspended After Derivatives Review
text: Merrill Lynch is investigating one of its trading desks in London and has suspended a trader after discovering that he may have overstated the value of some of the bank’s equity derivatives. “The firm routinely reviews the marks our traders set,” a Merrill spokesman, Jezz Farr, said Friday, referring to the values given to securities. ”Our preliminary review determined that one desk used marks that appear to be outside of our accepted policy.” Merrill declined to identify the trader.

headline: Switch to Nascar Brings Struggles but No Regrets
text: CONCORD, N.C.  The last two winners of the Indianapolis 500 will be miles from the starting grid Sunday when the green flag waves and the most prestigious open-wheel race in the country begins.

headline: Have We Got a Deal for You
text: Just when it appears that the New York State Legislature has hit bottom, we find a false floor. The Times’s Danny Hakim recently uncovered another appalling example of how a politically powerful group can order up laws in Albany, even skewing the estimates of how much it will cost taxpayers.

headline: Spotlight Recasts Church Leaders and Their Support
text: When George W. Bush ran for president in 2000, an influential megachurch pastor from Texas made an early endorsement that helped him win over skeptical evangelical conservatives.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An obituary and a headline on Friday about the architect and preservationist Jan Hird Pokorny misstated his age. As the obituary noted, he was born on May 25, 1914, and therefore was 93, not 83.

headline: When One-Man Bands Bend the Metal Clichés
text: “Hi,” Joe Preston announced. “We’re Thrones, from Salem, Oregon.”

headline: France’s Bright Shining Lie
text: Paris

headline: New York’s Past Beckons the Future
text: Here they come, chugging down Fifth Avenue with their cargo of gleeful passengers: public double-decker buses in New York City!

headline: Big Plans for Parks
text: The Leon Levy Foundation, run by Shelby White, a philanthropist, and named for her husband, a hedge fund pioneer who died in 2003, is giving $25 million to New York City parks in what the city has described as the biggest private “green” gift. The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will get $15 million to create a new native plant garden for the study and display of Northeast flora. In Brooklyn, Prospect Park will receive $10 million to finance the Lakeside Center, a new 36,000-square-foot building that will replace Wollman Rink and its surroundings. The 26-acre area will be restored to the original design of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, with a natural-habitat sanctuary and pedestrian pathways along the lake, and will be open year round.

headline: A Final Four That Is Filled With Talent and Tradition
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The teams participating in lacrosse’s Final Four weekend at Gillette Stadium took a walk through the stadium Thursday afternoon and craned their necks at the nearly 80,000 seats surrounding them.

headline: Lakers Take Two-Game Lead Without a Sweat
text: LOS ANGELES – Clutching, grabbing and just playing good defense, Bruce Bowen has had as much success as anyone defending Kobe Bryant. That is to say there are some nights he does not feel completely helpless.

headline: A Cantankerous Crowd in No Mood for Love
text: CANNES, France  The predictably cranky and impatient press audience offered little love to Philippe Garrel’s “Frontier of Dawn” at the Cannes Film Festival on Thursday, just a weak round of applause amid a chorus of jeers. One of the most significant and, in the United States, unknown of the post-New Wave French directors, Mr. Garrel employs poetic melancholia and unhurried rhythms that were, particularly at 8:30 in the morning, either too much or not nearly enough for a crowd that had stayed up late the previous night to take in and debate “Che,” Steven Soderbergh’s ambitious epic about the revolutions won and lost by Che Guevara. (The arguments continued hotly on Friday.)

headline: China’s Rush to Dispose of Dead Compounds Agony
text: BEICHUAN, China  The 30 bodies in plastic bags lay strewn outside the tea factory at the foot of the forensic scientist, flies buzzing all around. From some he had collected molars, and from others cartilage. He had worked quickly, 20 minutes per body.

headline: A Poll Finds Californians Still Oppose Gay Marriage
text: SAN FRANCISCO  More than half of Californians support a proposed ballot measure that would overturn a recent ruling that legalized same-sex marriage in the state, a poll has found.

headline: Cornell Capa, Photojournalist and Museum Founder, Dies at 90
text: Cornell Capa, who founded the International Center of Photography in New York after a long and distinguished career as a photojournalist, first on the staff of Life magazine and then as a member of Magnum Photos, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: U.N. Chief Says Myanmar Yields on Aid Workers
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar’s military junta promised on Friday to allow into the country “all aid workers” of any nationality, after three weeks of blocking most assistance to cyclone victims, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, announced.

headline: Israeli Police Question Olmert Again
text: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, was interrogated on Friday morning by the police for the second time this month in connection with a new and potentially serious corruption scandal. Meanwhile, his lawyers failed to delay by two weeks the early court deposition of an important witness in the case, the American fund-raiser and businessman Morris Talansky.

headline: Where to Catch the Sights, Sound and Smell of a Campaign
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  The man was persistent in demanding Senator Barack Obama’s tie.

headline: 20-Year Journey for 15-Minute Fall
text: He has spent two decades and nearly $20 million in a quest to fly to the upper reaches of the atmosphere with a helium balloon, just so he can jump back to earth again. Now, Michel Fournier says, he is ready at last.

headline: Corrections
text: Obituaries

headline: Boom Times for Brazil’s Consumers
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Consumers in the United States are tightening their belts; Brazilians are spending like there’s no word in Portuguese for recession.

headline: Surfing on a Big Wave of Enthusiasm
text: David Robertson has done great work with the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra in his three seasons there, both as an experienced and persuasive new-music conductor and as an insightful interpreter of the standard canon. He has an enthusiastic following among New York concertgoers as well, and his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening  the first concert in a two-week visit  offered ample reason for it.

headline: British Tory Leader Warns Against ‘Triumphalism’
text: CREWE, England  In the 30 months since he became the Conservative Party leader at the age of 39, and the fourth man to hold the job in eight years, David Cameron has had his fair share of showy, seemingly callow moments and policy pronouncements that raised doubts, in his own party and elsewhere, about his fitness to be the pretender to the keys of 10 Downing Street.

headline: Darfur Peacekeepers Robbed in Ambush
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Militiamen in Sudanese Army uniforms ambushed a convoy of Nigerian peacekeepers in Darfur, robbing them of cash and weapons, United Nations officials said Friday.

headline: Ortiz as Ruth? Yankees Say Not in Their House
text: The Yankees voiced their dismay to Major League Baseball on Friday about a promotion in which David Ortiz, the Red Sox slugger, will try to hit a home run to a designated spot at Yankee Stadium during the home run derby on July 14, the eve of the All-Star Game. It will be the fourth and last All-Star Game at the 85-year-old stadium.

headline: Djokovic’s Ascent Adds Intrigue to the French Open Draw
text: PARIS  Tennis draws are not nearly as suspenseful as tennis tournaments, but there was a buzz of anticipation as officials sifted through the seedings Friday at Roland Garros Stadium.

headline: A Passion for (and Against) Sarkozy
text: PARIS  Serge Hefez, a practicing psychiatrist, has identified a new mental illness among the French: obsessive Sarkosis, an unhealthy fascination with the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Existing Home Sales Fell in April to Another Low
text: Stocks took a dive on Friday after a report confirmed fears that the housing slump, which has weighed on nearly every corner of the nation’s economy, was nowhere near its end.

headline: Gymnast Breaks Hand, but Still Has Olympic Chances
text: The Olympic gold medalist Paul Hamm broke a bone in his right hand Thursday during the United States gymnastics nationals, but his goal of successfully defending his all-around title at the Beijing Olympics is far from doomed.

headline: 'Anatomy' Is Down but Still on Top
text: The two-hour season finale of “Grey’s Anatomy” vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show’s fourth-season conclusion declined by nearly 5 million from a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal,” which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBC finished third for the night, earning mediocre results from 9:30 to 11 with the start of the sixth edition of “Last Comic Standing” (5.9 million). Fox ranked second over all, thanks to the fourth-season premiere of “So You Think You Can Dance,” which averaged 8.6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Despite its modest number of total viewers, the Fox dancing contest fared particularly well among adults 18 to 49, winning the 8 o’clock hour in that demographic, ahead of ABC’s finale of “Ugly Betty,” which drew 8.8 million total viewers. CBS finished fourth with a lineup of all repeats.

headline: Tears for Teddy
text: My father was stricken with throat cancer back in the early 1990s, and I remember talking to his doctor (as clearly as if it was yesterday) about his prognosis.

headline: McCain’s Health Is Called Robust by His Doctors
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Senator John McCain, 71, is in excellent health and shows no evidence of the recurrence of the melanoma skin cancer that led to extensive head and neck surgery in 2000, Mr. McCain’s doctors said Friday.

headline: After Minaya Supports Randolph, Mets Lose in 13
text: DENVER – Omar Minaya, the Mets' general manager, can choose wherever and whenever to accompany his team. Coming here was not on Minaya's agenda until Thursday morning, after the third of four straight losses in Atlanta, when he decided to show support for his fading team and embattled manager.

headline: Parole Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Changing the Game With Innovations
text: CERTAINLY A. G. Lafley had his work cut out for him when he became Procter & Gamble’s chief executive eight years ago. Profits were lackluster and the stock was way down. New product introductions had slowed to a trickle, and no more than 15 percent of those wound up making money.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Crown Heights Journal article on Thursday, about racial tension between Jews and blacks in the Brooklyn neighborhood, omitted the name of the publication that first reported a comment by District Attorney Charles J. Hynes on accusations that Shmira, a Hasidic civilian patrol group, has been uncooperative with investigators. His comment, “You can’t have a group, whether it’s the Bloods, Crips or Shmira, acting like vigilantes,” was made to The Jewish Week of New York on April 29.

headline: 40 Million Acres of Rain Forest for the Greenest Bidder
text: The other day I went to a meeting to hear Harrison Ford talk about saving the rain forests and ended up listening to a man who has a rain forest to save: Guyana’s president, Bharrat Jagdeo.

headline: Snipes Is Granted Bail
text: Wesley Snipes can spend his Memorial Day weekend a free man. Last month in Ocala, Fla., he was sentenced to three years in prison for willfully failing to file his tax returns, one year for each misdemeanor conviction. He plans to appeal the conviction, handed down in February, and on Thursday Judge William Terrell Hodges granted his motion for bail, saying Mr. Snipes did not pose a flight risk, according to The Associated Press. At his sentencing, Mr. Snipes read a statement apologizing for some unspecified mistakes and failures; he did not mention taxes.

headline: Money for Museums
text: These have been good days for art lovers. In Colorado the Aspen Art Museum, home to contemporary art exhibitions, film and video series, has announced that starting on Thursday its admission will be free for the next 10 years, thanks to an undisclosed contribution by John and Amy Phelan. (The admission was previously $5 and under.) The Phelans are members of the museum’s council and part-time residents of Aspen. In New York, El Museo del Barrio, which showcases the art and cultured of Latin America, Puerto Rico and the rest of the Caribbean region, has received a $3 million gift from Carmen Ana Unanue, its chairwoman, and her family. The museum, at 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, is closed for a major renovation and is expected to re-open in September 2009.

headline: Ex-Worker in Child Care Is Sought in Smut Case
text: A former employee of a Manhattan company that provides emergency child care for workers at high-profile corporations is being sought by the authorities for possessing child pornography on his home computer, the police said on Friday.

headline: With Summer on the Way, Con Ed Girds Its Grid
text: Ah, spring. Season of baseball, budding trees and final exams. Or, for the engineers, planners and cable splicers at Con Edison, time to build new substations, overhaul thousands of breakers, feeders, switches and transformers and replace 1,900 miles of underground cables.

headline: Girardi Serves Penalty for Dirt-Kicking Tirade
text: It was three hours before game time on Friday when Joe Girardi read a distressing e-mail message from Major League Baseball. Girardi had been suspended for the game against Seattle for kicking dirt on the plate umpire, Chris Guccione, in a hat-kicking tirade in the ninth inning on Thursday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article last Saturday about a report on lapses at a Las Vegas endoscopy clinic linked to cases of hepatitis C misidentified the jobs of some of the health care workers who, according to the report, did not wear gloves when they administered intravenous medications. They were nurse anesthetists, not anesthesiologists.

headline: Heading Off New Account Fraud
text: One of the scariest types of identity crimes is something called new account fraud. This happens when a criminal steals your personal information, opens credit or other accounts in your name and goes on a spending spree. Here are a few things you can do on your own to prevent the crime.

headline: Ready to Charge Head-On Into Pain
text: Watching Bebe Neuwirth extract the scar tissue from the emotional viscera of Brecht-Weill songs at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening, I thought, “Here is the new Julie Wilson!” This woman is not afraid to face the painful truth and courageous enough to relive it onstage as completely as a performer can without crumbling into a mawkish heap. It is the same kind of surgery that Ms. Wilson recently performed in her Kabuki-like way at the Metropolitan Room, where she delivered the Brecht-Weill song lyrics as infuriated spoken monologues.

headline: IndyCar Chief Has Eye Ahead but Foot on Brake
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Ticket sales for Sunday’s Indianapolis 500 are up. The 33-car field is deep. Danica Patrick, the best-known driver in the race, is not only a drawing card, but also a threat to win. The forecast calls for a warm, sunny day.

headline: InBev Said to Consider Bid for Anheuser-Busch
text: The Belgian beer giant InBev is in the early stages of preparing what could be a $44.6 billion offer for Anheuser-Busch, the American maker of Budweiser beer, people briefed on the matter said Friday.

headline: Courage on Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Big Night in a Centenarian’s Big Year
text: It sometimes seems as if the yearlong international celebrations for the 100th birthday of the composer Elliott Carter were being spearheaded by James Levine, a longtime champion of Mr. Carter’s music.

headline: Cellphone Pioneer Struggles to Stay Relevant
text: Neeraj Choubey has not worked at the troubled cellphone maker Motorola for seven years. But from the number of calls and e-mail messages Mr. Choubey, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, has gotten in recent weeks, you would think he had never left his old colleagues.

headline: Immigration Officials Arrest 905 in California Sweep
text: LOS ANGELES  Federal immigration agents have arrested 905 people in California in the past three weeks after a statewide search for those who had violated orders to leave the country. The operation was the latest in a series of national sweeps by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.

headline: President and the Play
text: What can a popular ex-president do as a second act? Collaborate with his wife, of course  or try to. And in the former Czech leader Vaclav Havel’s case, return to his roots on the stage. Mr. Havel’s first new play in 20 years opened in the Archa Theater in Prague on Thursday. The play, “Odchazeni” (“Leaving”), is about a chancellor who must re-adjust to civilian life and the loss of power after being forced out by his former deputy. (Mr. Havel, now 71, whose last presidential term ended in 2003, has said he wrote most of the play before taking office.) It alludes to “King Lear” and “The Cherry Orchard” but has some postmodern touches: the playwright himself appears in a recorded voice-over. The play received mostly positive reviews in the Czech press. But this highly anticipated absurdist comedy was marred by some personal drama when Mr. Havel’s wife, Dagmar Havlova, who he said helped inspire the work, was barred from performing in it. The National Theater of Prague, which was originally scheduled to stage it, cited a policy against guest actors in rejecting Ms. Havlova for a role written for her. Mr. Havel responded by shopping the show to other theaters; citing health problems, Ms. Havlova eventually dropped out of the production altogether shortly before it opened at the Archa. In September the play is scheduled to run at the Orange Tree Theater in London.

headline: Obama, in Miami, Calls for Engaging With Cuba
text: MIAMI  Senator Barack Obama on Friday called for greater engagement with Cuba and Latin America, saying the long-standing policies of isolation have failed to advance the interests of the United States or help people who have suffered under oppressive governments.

headline: LifeLock Identity Fraud Service Finds Skeptics
text: It is, without a doubt, one of the great marketing stunts in recent memory.

headline: Carter Has Eye on Randolph’s Job
text: Willie Randolph got a vote of confidence Friday from General Manager Omar Minaya, but that did not stop the sharks from circling.

headline: Clinton Remark on Kennedy’s Killing Stirs Uproar
text: BRANDON, S.D.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defended staying in the Democratic nominating contest on Friday by pointing out that her husband had not wrapped up the nomination until June 1992, adding, “We all remember Bobby Kennedy was assassinated in June in California.”

headline: Cuba: U.S. Diplomat Is Accused of Delivering Cash to Opposition
text: Having accused a United States diplomat of carrying cash from Miami to Cuban opposition leaders, the government of Raúl Castro has pushed for an explanation from Washington. But the State Department has already shrugged off the e-mail messages, videos and audiotapes that Cuban leaders say show that Michael E. Parmly, head of the United States Interests Section in Havana, delivered the money. American officials say they have long provided humanitarian aid to Cuba’s opposition. But Cuba contends that the money in this case came from Fundación Rescate Jurídica, a group that advocates the overthrow of Cuba’s government.

headline: When Kennedy Met With Khrushchev
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawyer Accused of Making Improper Sexual Advances
text: A lawyer who has represented several of the city’s police unions was charged on Friday with inappropriately touching two female lawyers and making sexual advances toward them.

headline: California: Search for Remains in Manson Case Ends
text: The search for possible human remains near the remote ranch where Charles Manson was captured has ended, yielding only a bullet casing and some animal bones. The area around Barker Ranch, in the southwestern area of Death Valley National Park, was briefly closed this week for digging in five areas, overseen by the Inyo County Sheriff’s Office. A news release issued by the office said that “based on exploratory excavations, scientists and law enforcement personnel have determined that there are no human remains in or around the five areas of interest.” Rumors have persisted for years that remains are buried near the ranch. The search was prompted by the findings of a forensic technology team in March and subsequent soil research that were deemed inconclusive.

headline: N.H.L. Is Hoping Dream Matchup Gets Attention
text: After three seasons of trying to climb back to the top rung of American sports since its devastating lockout, the N.H.L. finally finds itself with a Stanley Cup finals it can brag about.

headline: Texas Tries to Reverse Court Ruling in Sect Case
text: HOUSTON  The custody battle over 468 children seized from the ranch of a polygamist sect in Eldorado, Tex., moved on Friday to the Supreme Court of Texas, where the state insisted that the children were too endangered by sexual and emotional abuse to be returned to their families.

headline: The Sinatra of Southwest Feels the Love
text: The Dallas-Fort Worth area is home to two of the country’s biggest airlines, American and Southwest, and for years, they’ve both held their annual meetings on the same day. This year was no exception: Wednesday was the big day.

headline: Authority Fires Official in Inquiry
text: The New York Power Authority fired its inspector general, Daniel Wiese, on Friday, according to a statement released by the authority.

headline: Sen. McCain’s Agents of Intolerance
text: It took a long time for him to do it, but Senator John McCain has finally rejected the endorsements of two evangelical ministers  one whose bizarre and hate-filled sermons deeply offended both Catholics and Jews and the other who has used his pulpit to attack Muslims.

headline: Rogue French Trader May Have Had Help, Audit Finds
text: PARIS  Weak management and insufficient internal risk controls at Société Générale made it possible for a 31-year-old trader to cause nearly 5 billion euros in losses at the French bank, a report from an internal investigation has concluded.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 16 through May 23:

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article last Saturday about steps taken by Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign to avoid potential conflicts of interest among his advisers misspelled the surname of a business partner of Craig Shirley, a public relations consultant whose ties to the campaign were severed. She is Diana Banister, not Bannister.

headline: Mortgages Without U.S. Backing Start to Rise
text: THE private mortgage market in the United States  almost moribund in the wake of the subprime crisis that bankrupted some lenders last year  is showing small signs of revival.

headline: Burger King Grants Raise to Pickers
text: After a contentious battle that included allegations of spying, Burger King announced on Friday that it had reached an agreement to improve the wages and working conditions of tomato pickers in Florida.

headline: 2 Inquiries Set on Pentagon Publicity Effort
text: The inspector general’s office at the Defense Department announced on Friday that it would investigate a Pentagon public affairs program that sought to transform retired military officers who work as television and radio analysts into “message force multipliers” who could be counted on to echo Bush administration talking points about Iraq, Afghanistan, Guantánamo and terrorism in general.

headline: Busy Students Get a New Required Course: Lunch
text: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y.  High school students in this well-to-do Westchester suburb pile on four, five, even six Advanced Placement classes to keep up with their friends. They track their grade-point averages to multiple decimal places and have longer résumés than their parents.

headline: Weighing Prospects for H.P.
text: SHAREHOLDERS of Hewlett-Packard reacted instantly and almost violently to their company’s plan to acquire Electronic Data Systems.

headline: Perceiving 2 Fallacies, a Secularist Faults His Fellows
text: Austin Dacey is a philosopher by training and an active secularist not only by conviction but by profession as well: He is a representative at the United Nations for the secularist Center for Inquiry.

headline: How to Stand Out in Times Square? Build a Bigger and Brighter Billboard
