text: They could be 212-foot-high, flat black stealth bomber wings studded with tiny jewels, soaring 17 stories above the crossroads of the world.

headline: Managers May Feel Heat, but TV Crews Sense Retribution
text: Willie Randolph’s squawking over negative visuals of him on SportsNet New York reminded Fox’s Tim McCarver of the reaction to his criticism of a previous manager and how he believed it prompted his firing as a Mets analyst after the 1998 season.

headline: Siegmund Nissel, 86, of Amadeus Group, Is Dead
text: Siegmund Nissel, the second violinist of the Amadeus Quartet, an internationally renowned ensemble that had its roots in the internment camps of wartime Britain, died on Wednesday at his home in London. He was 86.

headline: Footnote
text: Paul Newman has stepped down as the director of “Of Mice and Men” at the Westport Country Playhouse for health reasons. The production, scheduled for Oct. 7 through Nov. 1 at the Connecticut theater run by Mr. Newman’s wife, Joanne Woodward, was to be his directorial debut. Mark Lamos, who won a Tony Award for work with the Hartford Stage company, will fill in.

headline: LETTERS: The Readers Speak
text: Re “Information That Doesn’t Come Freely” (May 11):You write that “bad things can happen when a government tries to hide the records of its actions.” It is clear that this administration has no intention to serve the public’s best interest, but in fact is subjugating at all costs all that would counter its sole objective, namely the profits of its in-crowd.I have never had so many alarms going off in my head. America is in trouble! The only insights into the administration’s wrongdoings are the investigative and analytical reporting of the media.Thank you to the reporters Nina Bernstein and David Barstow, to David McCraw, a vice president and assistant general counsel for The Times, and to you. Robert PalmerCastro Valley, Calif., May 11, 2008 ● ●Re “The Preacher’s New Pulpit” (May 4):I strongly disagree with you on the question of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. and The Times’s coverage of his recent public and television appearances.I felt that the issue was covered ad nauseam everywhere and ran 24/7 on cable news channels. Yes, it was news, but it became the dominant news of the week at the expense of other more important stories.I appreciate that The Times showed some restraint while still covering the story well.Elizabeth KilroyNew York, May 5, 2008 ●Your column about the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. scandal should have also noted the failure of The Times to discuss the anti-American and outrageous statements of many men of the cloth, such as, but not limited to, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the Rev. Pat Robertson, Rev. John C. Hagee and even the Rev. Billy Graham.While The Times has provided article after article about Mr. Wright (and Senator Barack Obama), there’s been far less coverage of the other reverends who have made similar statements. In the Week in Review of May 4, we read about the “fiery theology” of black preachers, with no mention of the many other (white) preachers who have said far worse.Where is the balance?Vicki G. CheikesBoca Raton, Fla., May 6, 2008 ●I was interested in the difference between the coverage of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. in the paper and on The Caucus blog on the Web site.Perhaps you are right, and The Times should have reported more on the content of Mr. Wright’s recent speeches in the paper. But nothing substantial in the speeches had not been reported before, and nothing in them was not being reported endlessly on cable news. It seems that the story really was that Mr. Wright was saying these things again, which to me came through in the reporting in the paper.The Caucus blog, however, was all Wright all the time for at least three days that week. It was infuriating.The content of Mr. Wright’s speeches is available on television and on the Internet. How much of this do you want to put on the front page? The Wright story represents a great distraction from real issues, and it is entirely media-generated. Now, the media are a story, but they are becoming the main story. And that’s not good.Christopher WilsonMadison, Wis., May 4, 2008 ●While I very much appreciate your column about the paper’s coverage of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., The Times was hardly the first or only media outlet not to cover Mr. Wright in a proper sense. I don’t see why what Mr. Wright says in his crazy rants should be given the news attention that it has been given.What kind of impact will that have on the issues of the day? Does his hateful comments help a family with their bills, or help get us out of Iraq?I am a realist and know the news media will cover him because of his ties to Senator Barack Obama, though for the reasons I just stated, I wish it weren’t so.Steven M. ClaytonOcean, New Jersey May 4 2008

headline: ‘Any Country That’s Far, Far Away’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Time magazine says that former President Bill Clinton is pushing very hard for Barack Obama to choose Hillary as his vice president. Bill says, “Hillary would be a great vice president – or a great ambassador to any country that’s far, far away.”

headline: With the Patriots, It’s the Pattern
text: Last week, we linked to a Sports Illustrated article by a former player, Ross Tucker, who confirmed Matt Walsh’s accusations that the Patriots broke the rules by practicing with players who were supposed to be on injured reserve.

headline: Coulthard’s accident, Massa’s pole
text: No sooner did David Coulthard make it into the top 10 in today’s qualifying than his car slid out from under him and he ran into the guard rail on the tunnel exit and had a massive, high-speed crash at the fastest sector of the Monaco track. His rear wheel ran off down the track, his front right wheel rattled about on its tether, and Coulthard’s Red Bull came to a rest in the run-off area at the chicane. He got out of the car, looking terribly shaken, but unhurt.

headline: A Short History of the Sheepshead Bay
text: Over at Brooklyn Backstretch there is an interesting look at the origins of Saturday’s feature at Belmont, the Sheepshead Bay Handicap. For more history and archival photographs, read on.

headline: The Early Word: R.F.K. Fallout
text: In a campaign whose one-thing-after-another nature rivals that of any National Lampoon movie, the latest twist seems to have shocked even some of the most jaded observers.

headline: Eyeing Changes to ‘Idol’
text: Fox Broadcasting and Fremantle Media, the company that produces “American Idol,” “are now looking for more ways to change both the rules and the presentation of ‘Idol’ to keep ratings from taking what is by now a regular midseason sag,” Edward Wyatt reports in Saturday’s New York Times.

headline: We’ll Show You Our Cup Final Predictions if You’ll Show Us Yours
text: This is it: the Stanley Cup final. Who’ll win? Why even bother playing it — we’ll just tell you. Below, the results of our poll of the Slap Shot staff and their Hockey Night in Blogdom unpaid interns:

headline: Cities of the Dead
text: Like your average dreamy and morbid literary type, I love a good stroll through a cemetery (provided there’s no actual funeral involved, of course). So I was interested to pick up Marilyn Yalom’s new book “The American Resting Place: Four Hundred Years of History Through Our Cemeteries and Burials,” recently published by Houghton Mifflin. It’s perfect reading for Memorial Day, and not as somber as you might imagine.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: From Moral Challenge to Frothy Comedy

After the opening performance of “Amistad,” the musically and morally challenging opera about slavery composed in the 1990s, on Thursday, the festival introduced a production of Rossini’s frothy opera “La Cenerentola” on Friday night.

headline: A Track Ownership Solution
text: The breeding shed isn’t the only part of racing affected by the relentless logic of the market. Two of the three Triple Crown tracks — Churchill Downs and Pimlico — are owned by corporate empires, and, as we’ve begun to see in the last few years, what’s good for corporate management may not be so good for horsemen, racing fans, or, for that matter, even for the shareholders.

headline: ‘Moment of Truth’ Leads Last Year’s New Shows
text: Promoting the Fox lie detector test show “The Moment of Truth” last winter, the network’s reality guru Mike Darnell said viewers were “either going to love it or think it’s the end of Western civilization.”

headline: A Nudge From Obama?
text: Politics | What is “libertarian paternalism”? (And is it coming to an administration near you?) In a new book called “Nudge,” two informal advisers to Barack Obama, Richard Thaler and Cass Sunstein, argue that people need a government that can help them make better decisions. Otherwise, they save less than they intend to for retirement or use more energy than they need. Or other bad things. But the authors aren’t saying people are necessarily stupid. New York Review of Books

headline: Obama Campaigns in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. – The beats of salsa and reggaeton were pulsing, the sun was shining and the waves of the Atlantic were rippling in the distance when Senator Barack Obama walked into La Plaza del Quinto to greet supporters one week before the Democratic presidential primary here.

headline: Chinese Ask Why Schools Crumbled
text: Parents blame shoddy construction for the collapse of scores of schools during the May 12 earthquake, which killed thousands of children.

headline: Chinese Ask Why Schools Crumbled

headline: Macklowes Strike Deal to Sell G.M. Building
text: A group led by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the head of Boston Properties, a publicly traded real estate company, is buying the General Motors Building and three other Midtown towers from the financially troubled Macklowe family for $3.95 billion.

headline: Rocky Mountain Low
text: First off, for those of you back in New York who stayed up until 1:20 to watch the end of last night’s game, my condolences. Although there were encouraging signs – Carlos Delgado’s two-run homer, Fernando Tatis’s blast, their comeback from a 2-0 deficit – there were plenty of discouraging ones, too – Billy Wagner’s giving up his first earned run of the season, blowing a 5-4 ninth-inning lead, Marlon Anderson’s straining his left hamstring, Jose Reyes’s being picked off second – and we haven’t even gotten to Willie Randolph yet.

headline: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse: Syracuse Hangs On
text: FOXBORO, Mass. – When you cut through all the dazzling saves, near misses and jaw-dropping goals during Syracuse’s 12-11 double-overtime victory against Virginia on Saturday, one statistic jumps off the statistic sheet more than any.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Monkey’s Journey to the South
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Opera? Not exactly. Musical theater? Nope. Circus? Kinda. “Monkey: Journey to the West” is a hybrid spectacle with pop pedigree and ancient source material. Its composer, Damon Albarn, calls it simply a “new kind of thing.” Whatever it is, “it’s definitely changed my course,” Mr. Albarn said in an interview. “I love being the author of stuff now.”

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, May 25
text: While you’re priming the grill for Memorial Day festivities, Sunday’s talk shows will be dominated by figures who are, at this point, fairly accustomed to the hosts’ grilling.

headline: $50 Billion Bharti-MTN Deal Falls Apart
text: The world’s largest corporate deal in an emerging market, a tie-up worth nearly $50 billion between two telecommunication companies, Bharti Airtel in India and MTN Group in South Africa, came to a screeching halt Saturday.

headline: The Watch List
text: The Marlins’ rise to the top of the N.L. East coincides with Andrew Miller’s trading walks for strikeouts. Miller, below, struck out 18 and walked 13 in compiling a 9.12 E.R.A. over his first six starts. In four starts since, he is 3-1 with a 1.44 E.R.A., striking out 26 and walking 7. The Mets, who ripped Miller for five runs in his first start, will face the new Miller this week.

headline: Sichuan Athletes Get Back to Training
text: About 20 Chinese athletes bound for the Beijing Summer Games – including world champion diver Jia Tong – were training in Sichuan Province last week when a powerful earthquake hit southwestern China last week, killing more than 55,000 people.

headline: On the Road: Clinton’s Very Bad Day
text: Friday might have been one of the worst days of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s political career. Her campaign, as everyone knows, was already struggling. But on Friday, she made a reference to Bobby Kennedy’s assassination  a terrible choice of phrase in a presidential campaign that features an African-American candidate.

headline: Your Comments on my China Pollution Column
text: My Sunday column is about China’s pollution problems. One of the challenges will be how well China — and, behind it in a similar upward trajectory, India — handles the environmental costs of industrial revolution. Quite aside from the 300,000 Chinese who die prematurely each year from the consequences of air pollution, there are many who suffer from water pollution and overuse of water in the north. Some years the Yellow River doesn’t even reach the ocean in peak periods.

headline: Notes From the Yankees’ Clubhouse
text: Once again, there was rap music playing from a stereo in the middle of the Yankees’ clubhouse after Saturday’s victory. Such entertainment was rare during the era of Joe Torre, but things have changed in the first year under Joe Girardi.

headline: (Famous Name) Slept Here
text: NEW YORK CITY is full of famous people. And famous people, of course, need someplace to live.

headline: Logano, 18, to Make Nationwide Debut
text: CONCORD, N.C.  After 12 years of racing everything from quarter-midgets to late model stock cars, Joey Logano has finally reached the beginning of his career.

headline: When Nature Turns Savage, Like the Dogs of War
text: BEICHUAN, China — The doctor told the 10-year-old boy his legs would have to be sawed off. Although trapped in rubble, the boy refused. “If you have to cut off my legs, I want to die,” he said. “I don’t want to live without my legs.”

headline: Duke Falls Short in Comeback Bid, but Syracuse Succeeds
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Duke came to the men’s lacrosse final four to complete its program’s comeback. It had the top seed, a roster considered one of the most talented in college history and a swirling controversy after the N.C.A.A. granted 33 of its players an extra season of eligibility. The stage was set.

headline: Less, Yes, but Not by a Lot
text: THE BMW 3 Series has taken a page from the Marlon Brando playbook. As the legend increases, it grows more weighty, complicated and expensive.

headline: Amy Rosen, Alex Kontorovich
text: Amy Beth Rosen, a daughter of Barbara Rosen and Alvin Rosen of Valley Stream, N.Y., is to be married on Sunday to Alex Vladimir Kontorovich, a son of Alla Gil and Vladimir Kontorovich of East Windsor, N.J. Rabbi Steven M. Graber is to officiate at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

headline: Where Breathing Is Deadly
text: BADUI, China

headline: Gangsters Without Borders
text: Around the time the Soviet Union ceased to exist, I was waiting in the entry queue at Fiumicino Airport in Rome when I noticed a party of several dozen young Russian girls being fast-tracked past a freshly opened control window. By young I mean perhaps 15, and by Russian girls I mean beautiful adolescents with pale gold hair, perfect skin and the figures of child ballerinas. These wide-eyed coltish kids weren’t dancers or on a school trip. They were hustled along by a stocky middle-aged man with a short mustache and a stash of passports in his hairy hand. It was an unforgettable image of lambs to the slaughter  or, more precisely, of children to the brothel. You sometimes glimpse them, older now, dispersed around the world, and how they were engulfed by the criminal universe is one of the things Misha Glenny describes in “McMafia,” his dizzy tour of the forms of global crime born in the late ’80s, when finance capital shook off restraints and the Soviet Union collapsed.

headline: At Least a Start on Housing’s Revival
text: BY some accounts, now might be an opportune time to buy a new home. Interest rates are lower, a result of the Federal Reserve’s aggressive push to loosen credit, as are prices for many houses and condominiums. There is some optimism, too, that the federal government will eventually intercede with a housing bailout to halt the rise in foreclosures and help steady the market.

headline: Riding Out Downturn, Developers Adjust
text: HAMPERED by the broadening credit crisis, builders in Westchester, as elsewhere in the New York area and the country, are seeking ways to ride out what economists describe as the worst housing downturn since the late 1980s.

headline: In McCain Campaign, a Lobbying Labyrinth
text: Rick Davis, the manager of Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign, is a typical Washington insider in many ways, having long worked as both a lobbyist and a political operative along the intersection of politics, policy and money.

headline: Economy and All, Budgets Sail Through
text: LONG ISLAND school officials had worried about how the tight economy might affect the votes on district budgets last Tuesday. But in a low turnout on a rainy day, the voters generally supported them.

headline: Maya Stowe, Daniel Silver
text: Dr. Maya Kathryn Stowe and Daniel Stern Silver are to be married Sunday evening at Deerpark Restaurant on the Biltmore Estate in Asheville, N.C. Rabbi Darah R. Lerner is to officiate.

headline: Rare Bargain in a Burgundy
text: The weak dollar makes low-cost, high-quality red Burgundy virtually impossible to find. The spicy, cherrylike 2006 Bourgogne Rouge from Domaine Jessiaume, a little-known estate, is an exception.

headline: Fresh ‘Seagull’ Has Chekhov’s Essence
text: There’s an actress of a certain age, involved with a younger man, virtually ignoring her suicidal son, vacationing at her brother’s country place and demanding 100 percent of everyone’s attention 100 percent of the time.

headline: Zagat Offers a Beijing Olympics Guide
text: Westerners planning to attend the 2008 Summer Olympics (Aug. 8 to 24) in Beijing will be able to buy the first Zagat guide to the city. The guide, which was published earlier this month, has organized the opinions of 1,244 people surveyed into categories like favorite restaurants, hotels, nightspots, shops and tourist attractions. It also has helpful phrases, travel tips and fold-out maps of the city and the subway system. Most-popular restaurant accolades went to Alameda, a Brazilian place (Made in China, above, a Chinese restaurant popular with tourists, received top food honors, including raves for its Peking duck). The Peninsula Beijing was named the most popular hotel, and the Forbidden City won most popular tourist site. The guide is available in bookstores for $15.95 (addresses and phone numbers are available free at Zagat.com and on mobile devices at Zagat.mobi). A subscription to all online ratings and reviews costs $24.95 per year.

headline: Weddings and Dancing: Choreographed Ceremonies
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Children Wiggle, the Parents Worry
text: THE little girl with the pin-straight hair marched frenetically in place while the boy next to her in a blue and yellow striped shirt spun in circles. Heidi Betesh, an energetic dance teacher in black spandex and a wispy up-do, led a simple choreography of wiggles, claps and turns for the group of 25 children, most of them autistic.

headline: Dominican Crackdown Leaves Children of Haitian Immigrants in Legal Limbo
text: SAN PEDRO DE MACORIS, Dominican Republic  Two obsessions define this country: baseball and Haiti. Ángel Luis Joseph, a teenage outfielder with a hot bat, is caught between Dominicans’ devotion to the one and disdain for the other.

headline: Tsonga Is Out of French Open
text: PARIS  A tennis season that began in exhilarating fashion for the young Frenchman Jo-Wilfried Tsonga has turned into an ordeal, and he announced Saturday that he would miss this year’s French Open because of a knee injury.

headline: Never Mind the ‘Neo’
text: As the occupation of Iraq grinds through its sixth year, many who view American involvement there as a disaster are content to blame the neoconservatives, those operatives and intellectuals inside and outside the Bush administration who once believed they could democratize the Middle East at the point of a gun. Even some right-leaning critics have declared that the neoconservative project in Iraq was both utopian and imprudent, and therefore at odds with basic conservative principles.

headline: The Invisible Hand Is Shaking
text: ADAM SMITH’S modern disciples are far more enthusiastic about his celebrated invisible-hand idea than he ever was. In their account, Smith’s assertion was that purely selfish individuals are led by an invisible hand to produce the greatest good for all. Yet Smith himself was under no such illusion.

headline: Learning to Speak Olympics
text: Mocky is a naughty monkey. His friends Ken and Ann are humans. Together, they teach English in Beijing’s elementary schools. My students love Mocky. He and his pals are more fun than the characters in their previous textbook series, Ma Nan and her teacher Miss Zhang. Those primers could have been titled “Hectoring English.” A typical dialogue went:

text: This is how the world looked in the beginning, or perhaps how it will look in the end.

headline: Masters of Origami and Shapers of the Lifelike
text: Folded paper transcends mere craft in the Parrish Art Museum’s exhibition “Paper Transformed  Origami.” Here is an astonishing array of lifelike animals made of nothing but folded paper. Some of them are life-size, like a heron, its neck crooked, greeting visitors at the entrance to the show.

headline: Appeasement’s Taint Is All in Hindsight
text: In an era when much of the 20th century’s lexicon of geopolitical stock phrases  Iron Curtain, “collaborator,” “enemy within”  has lost the power to stir passions, the last 10 days have proven once again that cries of “appeasement” still resonate.

headline: Correction: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
text: The Green Traveler column on May 4, about the use of biofuels in air travel, summarized incorrectly a statement by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on the effect of jet exhaust. The panel said exhaust contributed to global warming by emitting carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides at high altitude and by forming condensation trails; it did not say jet engine exhaust depletes the ozone layer.

headline: A Chic Double-Wide
text: YOU can do a lot with a narrow town house, especially one on a private cobblestone street facing the East River and the Queensboro Bridge.

On Sunday evening, the Rev. K. Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at Studio 450, an event space in New York.

headline: The Tower That Has No Friends
text: PICTURE, if you will, the Brooklyn Bridge: the solid stone towers and the gentle arc of the roadbed over the river. Picture it from the Brooklyn side, where thousands gathered Thursday to celebrate the span’s 125th anniversary as one of the city’s most loved structures. If your picture is clear enough, you will also see, looming directly behind it in Manhattan, what may be the least loved: the 32-story, beige limestone monolith that is 375 Pearl Street.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Where Europe, Africa and the Mideast Meet in Tunisia
text: THE night air was cold and damp on the narrow, walled streets of Tunis’s medina, and the markets and stores all dark and locked up tight for the night. But all it took was a single rap of the iron knocker on the wooden door at 5, rue Dar El Jeld and in that instant a mystical world opened up.

text: FORT WORTH  With the 108th United States Open approaching, the two best golfers in the game are plotting very different courses toward their showdown at Torrey Pines on the cliffs above the Pacific in San Diego in three weeks.

headline: Chinese Are Left to Ask Why Schools Crumbled
text: This story was reported by Jim Yardley, Jake Hooker and Andrew C. Revkin, and was written by Mr. Yardley.

headline: ‘Poor, Obscure, Plain and Little’
text: Early in Queen Victoria’s reign, 30 percent of adult Englishwomen were single  and considered, as one social commentator put it, “redundant.” If of gentle birth and no means, without a family to care for, an extra woman naturally sought work as a governess. Living in another family’s home made romance unlikely and isolation inevitable, with poverty and unemployment always on the horizon. It was a grim life, grimmer still because it was the only choice open to many. As Charlotte Brontë’s Jane Eyre decides, “I want this because it is of no use wanting anything better.”

headline: Leanne Jochim, Aahren DePalma

headline: A Carrot? A Stick? No, a Cobra
text: IN 2001, our son, Tim, was a smart middle-schooler who, like many of his peers, wasn’t meeting his parents’ expectations. We thought he should be getting better grades, but distractions always seemed to get in the way: video games, roller hockey, Magic cards, girls, video games, TV and cars. Did I mention video games?

headline: The Prosecutor
text: Q: In 2001, you were tapped by President Bush for your dream job  U.S. attorney for New Mexico  only to end up as one of the eight federal prosecutors whose firing five years later set off an outcry. With your book “In Justice” about to come out, have you heard anything from President Bush? No, not even a little note of thanks. If somebody served honorably, you at least have your staff member send a form letter or something: thanks for your service.

headline: Divining a Lesson in Basra
text: BASRA, Iraq — On Basra’s Corniche, the boulevard past which the mingled waters of the Tigris and Euphrates flow into the Persian Gulf, there is a collective sense of relief these days.

headline: Letter: A Malian Festival
text: To the Editor: We were pleased to see The New York Times take note of the Festival au Desert in Mali (“In Mali, S.U.V.’s and Camels Deliver the Fans,” May 11). Unfortunately, the article flattened the richness and complexity of the festival, which combines entertainment with the functions of a county fair, town-hall meeting and community clinic. We heard great music, but also saw workshops on AIDS prevention, witnessed Doctors Without Borders at work and heard a discussion of “the duties of a good citizen” presented in French and Tamashek.

headline: Al Green Pays Tribute to the Old Al Green
text: ASK the Rev. Al Green about his gallant, groove-laden new album, “Lay It Down” (Blue Note), and you’re likely to hear a familiar phrase. “Love and Happiness,” Mr. Green said recently by phone from Memphis, where he has been the pastor of the Full Gospel Tabernacle for more than 30 years. “That’s the story that we are carrying. This whole theme is in the love zone, and in the happiness zone.”

headline: Jackson Reaches Out to Former Teammate Randolph
text: Reggie Jackson, a special consultant for the Yankees, has made three telephone calls recently to his former teammate Willie Randolph, the manager of the Mets.

headline: Boo! Boo! Boo! for the Home Team
text: At least one fan at Shea Stadium had to sadly pause over his $7.50 cup of beer as boos rained down from the supposed faithful on one of their own star hitters  merely for an unsuccessful at-bat. This in a city where the home-team breed from Brooklyn once prayed for divine intervention to deliver a long-ago Dodger slugger from an abysmal slump at the plate.

headline: Law Is the Law, but Producing Is His Life
text: JOHN BREGLIO’S shift from veteran theatrical lawyer to fledgling Broadway producer either took place gradually, over three decades, or in a split second, depending on how you look at it. And like the seasoned negotiator he is, Mr. Breglio maintains that both scenarios are arguable.

headline: Toughest Summer Job This Year Is Finding One
text: TULSA, Okla.  School is out, and Aaron Stallings, his junior year of high school behind him, wanders the air-conditioned cocoon of the Woodland Hills Mall in search of a job.

headline: Correction
text: An article on April 27 about commercial applications for hybrid vehicles described a bucket truck used by Florida Power and Light incorrectly. While the truck’s hybrid system can indeed power the bucket, it can also power the drive wheels.

headline: Earnhardt Refuses to Look Back
text: CONCORD, N.C.  A glass-encased wall of trophies greets visitors to the museum at Hendrick Motorsports, from the old Winston Cup and Nextel Cup championships to the many prizes for individual race wins over the 24-year history of the team. Jimmie Johnson’s No. 48 Chevrolet that clinched the 2007 Cup championship is prominently displayed on the floor nearby.

headline: Finding Potential for Debt in Distress
text: THE credit crisis and economic slowdown have sunk billions of dollars of debt into distressed status  deep in the junk-bond pile. Money managers have traditionally profited in such markets by buying debt on the cheap.

headline: Coffee Mated to Chocolate
text: Some food combinations are so natural, like strawberries and cream or beer and barbecue, you hardly give them a second thought. Coffee and chocolate may not coalesce on the tongue as readily, yet in the care of the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company, it’s a marriage that is likely to grow on you.

headline: With Steve Cauthen
text: Steve Cauthen, 48, is the last jockey to win the Triple Crown, which he did aboard Affirmed in 1978. In 1979, he moved to England, where jockeys can ride at slightly higher weights, and became one of Europe’s most successful ones. Cauthen retired after the 1992 racing season. Today, he operates Dreamfields, a breeding farm and training center in Verona, Ky.

headline: Gay, Punk and Ever the Provocateur
text: WITH each passing year the British artist and iconoclast Derek Jarman seems at once more important and more marginal. His place in history as a pioneering gay filmmaker is secure, but his work remains little seen, and the spirit in which it was made seems further away than ever.

headline: The Snare of Privilege
text: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton, Wellesley ’69, Yale Law ’73 and the first lady of the land for eight years, is suddenly a working-class heroine of guns and whiskey shots. Barack Obama, Columbia ’83 and Harvard Law ’91, visits bowling alleys and beer halls and talks about his single mother who lived on food stamps.

headline: Mozart’s Rivals Take the Stage Again

headline: Sheraton Expanding Lobby Computer Services
text: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts and Microsoft announced this month a partnership that will expand the communications hubs in many Sheraton lobbies. Called the Link @ Sheraton experienced with Microsoft, hubs will offer free Wi-Fi and Internet-enabled computer stations, where guests will be able to access their e-mail accounts, search the Web and print out materials like boarding passes.

headline: How Are Humans Unique?
text: Human beings do not like to think of themselves as animals. It is thus with decidedly mixed feelings that we regard the frequent reports that activities once thought to be uniquely human are also performed by other species: chimpanzees who make and use tools, parrots who use language, ants who teach. Is there anything left?

headline: Williams, Former Goat for Phillies, Is Now Fan Favorite
text: PHILADELPHIA  On his radio show “The Wild Pitch,” before Phillies games, Mitch Williams regularly reads a commercial for a plastic surgery clinic that promises to replace hair on men’s heads and remove their love handles.

headline: Partial Recall
text: Behind all the good-natured joking about “senior moments” lies real frustration and fear. How empowering, then, that we can do something to ward off normal, age-related memory loss: exercise. No, it’s not as easy as popping a pill. But as Sue Halpern reports in “Can’t Remember What I Forgot,” even a few brisk walks per week can have a measurable effect. Exercise promotes the birth of new neurons in the very part of the hippocampus (a brain structure crucial to forming new memories) that begins to malfunction with age. Exercise also counters age-related shrinking of the prefrontal cortex, an area involved in concentration and working memory (as in remembering a phone number long enough to dial).

headline: Kristen Silverberg, Paul Lettow
text: Kristen Silverberg and Paul V. Lettow were married on Saturday evening at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Lane Duncan, a Disciples of Christ minister and the bride’s brother-in-law, officiated.

headline: Addressing a Problem No Longer Discussed

headline: Russian Revolutionary
text: History has been spinning heads in Moscow for centuries, but there was a particularly dizzy moment just three weeks ago, during the May Day rally around the gray granite statue of Karl Marx. Marx gazes out at the Bolshoi Theater, where the hammer-and-sickle insignia that used to dominate the frieze over the front portico  back in the days when Stalin attended performances in his bulletproof box  has been swapped for the double-headed-eagle emblem of the Russian Federation. And lest there be any doubt about the economic principles prevailing in postrevolutionary Russia, a giant Samsung flat-screen-TV ad featuring two Bolshoi dancers is plastered on the Christo-like construction shroud that will wrap the theater throughout its four-year, $730 million renovation.

headline: The Ferry: Past, Present and Future
text: BRIDGES spelled the end of New York’s ferries a century ago; when you could zip over the Queensboro by trolley or car, why bother with poky boats?

headline: At the Top of His Game
text: I’M in eighth grade. I got the idea for the card game I’m marketing, Elementeo, at the end of fourth grade. I started working on it last year. I named my company Alchemist Empire because alchemists are always creating new things. For example, they try to make gold out of lead. I wanted to show that you can mix fun, education and action.

headline: Ukrainian Upstages His Hosts in Capturing Title in Bulgaria

headline: Gauging the Big Bets of a Hot Hand
text: COME hell, high water, credit crisis or asbestos claims, Fairfax Financial Holdings is that rarity  an insurance company whose shares have stood tall through it all. Even as the Standard & Poor’s insurance composite index has fallen 17.6 percent this year, Fairfax’s stock is down just 2.1 percent.

headline: If Mr. Big Is Buying

headline: Telling Stories in Many Shades of Delta Blue
text: WHEN the multi-instrumentalist Olu Dara ran out of money en route to Europe in 1963 and “got stranded,” as he likes to put it, in New York, he found a room in Brooklyn for $66 a month. Fresh out of the Navy and utterly lacking connections, he slowly began investigating his new world.

headline: Indian Point Contaminants May Stay for Now, N.R.C. Says
text: ENTERGY NUCLEAR’s operating policies since radioactive groundwater contamination from two of its reactors at Indian Point was discovered in 2005 have been “reasonable and technically sound,” the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Tuesday.

headline: Letters: Hurt Girls

text: AT the end of last year, when conventional wisdom said the economy was headed for recession  and a severe one at that a fixed-income strategy was simple: just shift into the lowest-risk investments you could find.

headline: A New Study Faults Plazas as Public in Name, Private in Look
text: MICHAEL KEANE is not sure if any New Yorker, however brash and ill-mannered, feels comfortable walking into a restaurant, past the host’s podium and into the outdoor seating area, sitting down at a table set with silverware and unwrapping a brown bag lunch.

headline: Learn French Cooking at Lessons in France
text: Languedoc, a region in southwest France, has long played second fiddle to its more glamorous neighbor, Provence. But sometimes overlooked areas keep delicious secrets.

headline: Attention, ‘Blue Boy’ Fans: Slow Down
text: San Marino, Calif.

headline: Spray of Gunfire Wounds 5 in Queens
text: Five people were wounded, one of them seriously, on Saturday when a gunman opened fire on a street in Jackson Heights, Queens, in what the police said they believed was a gang-related shooting. No arrests had been made by last night.

headline: Jill Rabin, Jonathan Steinberg
text: Jill Amanda Rabin and Jonathan Scott Steinberg are to be married on Sunday evening at the Yale Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Paula Jayne Winnig is to officiate.

headline: Madrid: Hospes Madrid
text: THE BASICS

headline: Boutonnieres in the City’s Lapel
text: THERE’S something about stumbling upon a manicured garden hidden somewhere in Manhattan. With the city raging just beyond the hedges, you claim a piece of bench or spot of grass and relax, let the perfume of flowers and a bumblebee or two drift over you with the breeze. It’s a stillness visitors rarely expect to find in the city (and one that New Yorkers with small apartments and roommates otherwise find only by locking themselves in the bathroom).

headline: Lauren Sunness, Bradley Bass
text: Lauren Anne Sunness, a daughter of Ellen and Bob Sunness of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in Miami on Saturday evening to Bradley Hunter Bass, a son of Renee and Harvey Bass of Long Grove, Ill. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated at the Mandarin Oriental hotel, with Rabbi Jonathan Blake taking part.

headline: Web Site Puts Focus on the Fix in Sports Bets
text: LONDON  With Internet gambling predicted to surpass $20 billion in 2008, and with illegal wagering accounting for $150 billion in the United States, by some estimates, the temptation for those seeking to influence the outcome of games has never been greater. Now, a raft of gambling scandals in sports, from cricket to soccer and most recently tennis, has raised an uncomfortable question: Are the games we watch fixed?

headline: Savoring a Patriotism That Endures
text: FAIRFIELD

headline: It’s Not a Campaign, It’s a Mission
text: A YEAR ago, Leon Lim, a 35-year-old doctoral student in Sanskrit from Dayton, Ohio, decided with his wife, Ranjani Powers, a yoga instructor, to head off to Bali, or India, or anywhere, really, just “somewhere very far away”  from the Iraq war, the Patriot Act and the tanking dollar, Mr. Lim said.

headline: High-Tech Devices Keep Elderly Safe From Afar
text: First thing every morning, Lynn Pitet, of Cody, Wyo., checks her computer to see whether her mother, Helen Trost, has gotten out of bed, taken her medication and whether she is moving around inside her house hundreds of miles away in Minnesota.

headline: Touring 10 Wineries, Sip by Sip
text: Westchester residents need not travel to Napa Valley or even the far reaches of Long Island to spend the day visiting wineries. Just north of the county lies the Shawangunk Wine Trail, an association of 10 Hudson Valley wineries covering 80 miles in Gardiner, Marlboro, New Paltz, Pine Bush, Washingtonville and Warwick.

headline: The Brickyard Is Patrick’s Backyard
text: INDIANAPOLIS  At one point Friday afternoon, 28 people stood at Danica Patrick’s infield souvenir truck, eyeing the merchandise. There were no shoppers at the next truck  until someone bought a disposable camera and briskly walked away.

headline: Raising the Dead
text: Some writers turn despair into humor as a way of making the world bearable, of discovering some glimmer of beauty or pleasure or, most important, humanity. In contrast, the gifted Bosnian writer Aleksandar Hemon has taken the formal structure of humor, the grammar of comedy, the rhythms and beats of a joke, and used them to reveal despair. His new novel, “The Lazarus Project,” is a remarkable, and remarkably entertaining, chronicle of loss and hopelessness and cruelty propelled by an eloquent, irritable existential unease. It is, against all odds, full of humor and full of jokes. It is, at the same time, inexpressibly sad.

headline: 36 Hours in Cartagena, Colombia
text: WITH its cocaine days in the past, the Colombian seaport of Cartagena has emerged as the belle of the ball. This tropical city on the Caribbean is pulsating like a salsa party, drawing well-heeled Latin Americans and European socialites to its restored colonial mansions, fancy fusion restaurants and Old World-style plazas. Other rhythms can be heard, too. Guitar players stroll through the cobblestone alleyways. Beauty pageants and dance festivals keep the city swinging after dark. And techno dance clubs keep Cartagena’s revelers up till dawn. But this stunningly beautiful city also has its quiet side. White sand beaches and crystal-clear water are just a short hop away.

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: An essay on May 11 about the American intellectual scene in 1958 referred incorrectly to Jack Kerouac’s “Dharma Bums,” published that year. It was his fourth novel, not the second. It followed “The Town and the City” (1950), “On the Road” (1957) and “The Subterraneans” (also 1958)

headline: The Kindness of Cronies
text: When Christopher J. Christie, New Jersey’s top federal prosecutor, gave a multimillion-dollar no-bid corporate monitoring contract to John Ashcroft, the former attorney general, it looked like an isolated case of favoritism. Now the Justice Department has revealed that at least 30 former government officials have been riding the same patronage train.

headline: The Sergeant Lost Within
text: “You want to wear this or this for therapy tomorrow?” Sgt. Shurvon Phillip’s mother asked, holding two shirts in front of him. On one wall of his bedroom hung a poster of a marine staring fiercely, assault rifle in hand and black paint beneath his narrow eyes. Shurvon’s eyes, meanwhile, are wide and soft brown. He sat upright, supported by the tilt of a hospital bed. He cannot speak and can barely emit sound or move any part of his body, and sometimes it’s as if the striking size of his eyes is a desperate attempt to let others understand who he is, to let them see inside his mind, because his brain can carry out so little in the way of communication.

headline: Name From London, People From Everywhere
text: FOR Maggie Tobin and Bob Mason, the last straw in Park Slope was the parking. The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual of driving around in search of a parking spot, sometimes for 40 minutes.

headline: Oysters on the Half Shell With Coconut Sauce
text: 1 stalk lemongrass

headline: Zimbabwe Opposition Leader Returns
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, who fled his homeland after winning the most votes in a presidential contest because of fears he would be assassinated, returned Saturday to Harare to campaign in the June 27 runoff against the incumbent, Robert Mugabe.

headline: Chetnashree Khemka, Matthew Chun
text: Chetnashree Khemka is to be married on Sunday evening to Matthew B. Chun at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York. Pandit Ashok Vyas, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

headline: Senate Race in Minnesota Shows Power of Bloggers
text: EAGAN, Minn.  On a laptop at a kitchen table in this cheery Twin Cities suburb, headlines ripping into Al Franken, the satirist whose campaign for the United States Senate is seen as one of the most competitive in the nation, are written up day after day for Minnesota Democrats Exposed, a political blog created by a former Republican Party researcher.

headline: Cultural Revaluation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jailed Teenager Suffers Critical Injury
text: A 16-year-old was taken to the hospital in critical condition with a head injury on Saturday after he was beaten up in a fight that broke out among prisoners while he was in a holding cell awaiting arraignment in Brooklyn Criminal Court, the police said.

headline: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Parking
text: WHEN the Department of Transportation recently put up several no-parking signs in Broad Channel, the signs quickly disappeared. When locals are questioned on the matter, it appears that nobody knows how this might have happened.

headline: Youth Is Slain on West Side in Possible Turf War
text: The boisterous crowd of teenagers gathered in front of the apartment building on the Upper West Side. It was after midnight on Saturday, and many had come from a party. Suddenly, some of the youths shouted, “East Side!” and others cried out, “West Side!”

headline: The Magnifying Glass Gets an Electronic Twist
text: PEOPLE who lose part of their sight to macular degeneration, diabetes or other diseases may now benefit from some new technology. Several portable video devices that enlarge print may help them make the most of their remaining vision.

headline: Seeking Solutions for People Adrift
text: The Homeless Go to a Place They Know

headline: Overstuffed Nod to Tradition
text: Set in a strip mall in Livingston, Irving’s Delicatessen is indisputably in the suburbs. But the taste of its juicy, yet lean, hand-sliced pastrami is worthy of an old-fashioned New York deli.

headline: Sheethal Rao, Tokumbo Shobowale
text: Sheethal Nagamma Rao and Olatokumbo Ezra Obafemi Shobowale were married on Saturday at The Times Center in Manhattan. Pandit Umesh K. Jois, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: The Dogs of 9/11
text: The Dogs of 9/11

headline: Hanging With a Fast Crowd
text: THEY will race today at Indianapolis, at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., and through the streets of Monaco, events that will draw hundreds of thousands of spectators and millions more television viewers.

headline: Letter: An Istanbul Mix
text: To the Editor: When I read “Istanbul’s Beat Is International” (May 11), I said to myself, no wonder. We can justify the new Turkish sound, as you refer to it, by the type of rock club/brewery/basement music joint I visited in December 2007. I was invited for a night out by two young Istanbul locals and we wound up at Balans, the kind of place where the entrance is a back door in an alley.

headline: Two Can Make History
text: New Haven

headline: Correction: Back to the City, for More Than Just Sex
text: An article on May 4 about Michael Patrick King, the head writer for the HBO series “Sex and the City” and the director of the movie version, misstated the number of seasons the show was on television. It was six seasons, not seven.

headline: Wooing Crowds, and Honoring Soldiers
text: WATERLOO, N.Y.  For many years, Memorial Day here evoked a mood only of sad reflection.

headline: Mrs. Corbett’s Request
text: Chapter 4: Five Shots in a Row

headline: India Clashes Over Caste Kill 2 Dozen
text: About two dozen protesters and two police officers have been killed in the past 48 hours during violent demonstrations in the northwestern state of Rajasthan, police officials said Saturday.

headline: Exposing the Wall Between the River and New York City
text: To the builders of the 21st-century World Trade Center it is both an obstacle and an engineering marvel of 19th-century New York: the massive granite river wall that opened Manhattan’s edges to a world of seagoing commerce.

headline: Pot Luck
text: Around 1979, when I was a child living in Russia, my teacher once assigned our class an essay: if a Magi promised to grant you a single wish, what would you ask for? I knew what I wanted, and I wrote about it with passion and sincerity. I thought it was a beautiful wish until my teacher read my essay and said she was appalled  she couldn’t believe anyone would waste a wish like that. She leaned close and whispered, “Wouldn’t you rather wish for world peace?”

headline: Roanoke Stands Out
text: “Brooklyn Uncorked,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, allows the public to compare the styles of Long Island wineries  30 this year. Sponsors of the tasting, on May 14, included the Long Island Wine Council and Edible East End and Edible Brooklyn, sister publications.

headline: Hope in the Unseen
text: Every once in a while as a journalist you see a scene that grips you and will not let go, a scene that is at once so uplifting and so cruel it’s difficult to even convey in words. I saw such a scene last weekend at the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore. It was actually a lottery, but no ordinary lottery. The winners didn’t win cash, but a ticket to a better life. The losers left with their hopes and lottery tickets crumpled.

headline: Passing Along the Cost of Landscaping
text: Q I live in Stuyvesant Town, where a massive landscaping project is being carried out on the grounds.

headline: A Children’s Art Project on a Pretty, Grand Scale
text: THROUGHOUT Westchester, children are creating Delftware-inspired tiles. An anticipated 2,000 to 3,000 elementary, middle and high schoolers from more than 30 school districts, Scout troops and summer camps will be participating in the Public Tile Project, the creation of a mile-long walkway in Peekskill lined with more than 500 Dutch-style ceramic tiles.

headline: Dick Sutcliffe, 90, Dies; Began ‘Davey and Goliath’
text: Dick Sutcliffe, whose idea to use animated characters to teach religious principles resulted in the cartoon show “Davey and Goliath,” died on May 11 in Dallas, where he lived. He was 90.

headline: Labor Pains
text: Eight years ago, Deborah Shank was seriously injured when a semitrailer rig struck the driver’s side of her minivan. Because Shank, then a shelf stocker at a Wal-Mart store in Cape Girardeau, Mo., had recently qualified for the company’s health plan, most of her immediate hospital expenses were covered. But because the accident left her in a wheelchair, with permanent brain damage, she continues to require full-time nursing care. To help pay for it, a court set up a $417,000 trust, using the proceeds of a lawsuit against the company whose driver caused the accident.

headline: Brazil Rainforest Analysis Sets Off Political Debate
text: SÃO JOSÉ DOS CAMPOS, Brazil  Gilberto Câmara, a scientist who leads Brazil’s national space agency, is more at ease poring over satellite data of the Amazon than being thrust into the spotlight.

headline: Monaco Grand Prix Is Glamorous and Grueling
text: Since its debut in 1929 as one of the earliest Grand Prix races, Monaco has captured the attention of even the least enthusiastic of motor-racing imaginations. There is no setting in the world quite like the cliffs, luxurious homes and buildings that form the race’s backdrop, the harbor filled with multimillion-dollar yachts, and the rich and glamorous crowd the race attracts every year, as it no doubt will again Sunday.

headline: For Shipbound Sailors, a Smiling Personal Shopper
text: EARLY one recent morning, Herb Reiss drove a blue minivan through a maze of idling 18-wheelers and shipping containers stacked high like giant Lego bricks, and pulled up to the dock of the New York Container Terminal at Howland Hook, Staten Island.

headline: Enjoy the Reunion. Skip the Check.
text: College students are headed home for the summer, leaving campuses to the alumni for a few days of remember-when revelry. Welcome to the annual ritual that has university development officers across the country sharpening their utensils. May I pour you another cocktail, sir?

headline: Puerto Rico Gets Its Moment in the Sun (the Political One) as Primary Nears
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Puerto Rico traditionally complains of being ignored by the rest of the United States, but that has just changed, if only for the moment. With a Democratic presidential primary to be held here on June 1, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton began their Memorial Day weekend on Saturday campaigning in the Spanish-speaking Caribbean.

headline: Inside a Museum, It’s Cool
text: Yonkers

headline: Twain Piece That Amuses in Antics, if Not Substance
text: Mark Twain, wherever he is, can rest easy.

headline: In W.N.B.A., a Little Traveling Music
text: Some W.N.B.A. fans go to great lengths to root for their favorite teams.

headline: When a Loan Is a Gift
text: My parents graciously offered to lend my wife and me the down payment for a home. While we can easily afford the mortgage payments, the bank wants all of us to sign a statement saying the money from my parents is a gift, not a loan, although the bank representative literally winked as he handed me the statement. I am reluctant to ask my parents to be dishonest, but isn’t everyone better off if this deal goes through?  M.S., BOSTON

headline: In Search of Buckley
text: In the late 1960s an assistant prosecutor friend of mine invited me to be his guest at a Jets game. He was a member of something called the Jets Club, which was located in an upper tier of Shea Stadium just behind the press box, with a lively bar scene and a perfect view of the field.

headline: ‘Black Flies’
text: "This is Camellia. Camellia, say hello. How old are you, Camellia? She says seven. When Camellia was two she stopped breathing. She has asthma. Her airway closed. Her heart stopped. She was lucky. We got to her on time. Did what we're trained to do. She's a success story. I want you all to look at her. Wave to them, Camellia. I bring her in on the last day at the academy. Once you're on the streets it's easy to forget Camellia."

headline: Comments Cast Shadow on Last Laps in Primaries
text: BAYAMÓN, P.R.  By this point in the Democratic presidential race  after endless hours of debates, 17 election nights and so many miles of campaigning  when both candidates arrived on Saturday in Puerto Rico, it seemed that surely everything had been said between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.

headline: Mets Win and Change the Subject for a Day
text: DENVER  About 12 hours after the Mets lost their fifth consecutive game, Willie Randolph wrote the names of Fernando Tatis, Nick Evans and Claudio Vargas on a lineup card. With his team playing poorly and his general manager, Omar Minaya, refusing to guarantee that he will not be fired this season, Randolph was, to an extent, putting his fate in a veteran with five career games of outfield experience, a 22-year-old recalled from Class AA Binghamton and a starting pitcher who was in the minor leagues 10 days ago.

headline: The Watch List
text: The Marlins’ rise to the top of the N.L. East coincides with Andrew Miller’s trading walks for strikeouts. Miller, below, struck out 18 and walked 13 in compiling a 9.12 E.R.A. over his first six starts. In four starts since, he is 3-1 with a 1.44 E.R.A., striking out 26 and walking 7. The Mets, who ripped Miller for five runs in his first start, will face the new Miller this week.

headline: War Zone Revisited
text: The title of John Gimlette’s “Panther Soup” refers to the mud that an American Army veteran of World War II, Putnam Flint, vividly remembers churning through in 1944 and ’45 with the 824th Tank Destroyer Battalion. Its members wore a panther patch on their uniforms as their towed antitank guns, later replaced by self-propelled tracked vehicles, moved from Marseille up the Rhone Valley to fight Hitler’s forces through the Vosges and Alsace into southern Germany and the Austrian Alps.

headline: Misreading the Arab Media
text: “ARABIC TV does not do our country justice,” President Bush complained in early 2006, calling it a purveyor of “propaganda” that “just isn’t right, it isn’t fair, and it doesn’t give people the impression of what we’re about.”

headline: $50 Billion Telecom Deal Falls Apart
text: NEW DELHI — The world's largest corporate deal in an emerging market, a tie-up worth nearly $50 billion between two telecommunication companies, Bharti Airtel in India and MTN Group in South Africa, came to a screeching halt Saturday.

headline: Dow Falls 507 Points as Oil Prices Soar
text: Rising energy costs and further declines in the troubled housing market led to steep losses in stocks last week.

headline: U.N. Leader Praises China’s Quake Response
text: CHENGDU, China  The secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-Moon, flew to the heart of China’s earthquake zone in Sichuan Province on Saturday to praise the nation’s response to the disaster and pledge his organization’s support.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: NETHERLAND, by Joseph O’Neill. (Pantheon, $23.95.) In the wittiest, angriest, most exacting and most desolate work of fiction yet about post-9/11 New York and London, the game of cricket provides solace to a man whose family disintegrates after the attacks.

headline: Step by Step, the Showgirl Must Go On
text: West Hollywood, Calif.

headline: Summer Arts in Connecticut and Westchester County
text: MAY 29 - JUNE 1

headline: Events in Westchester
text: FILM

headline: Worries in G.O.P. About McCain Camp Disarray
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign is in a troubled stretch, hindered by resignations of staff members, a lagging effort to build a national campaign organization and questions over whether he has taken full advantage of Democratic turmoil to present a case for his candidacy, Republicans say.

headline: Murder, She Once Wrote
text: AROUND 8 o’clock on a breezy evening in 1992, two private investigators stepped out of their car at the Christopher Street pier in Greenwich Village and approached a group of drunks and addicts huddled over a small fire. The investigators were soon joined by three Chinatown gang members who had information that the investigators needed. But the conversation was brief; the gang leader had a temper, and guns were drawn fast.

headline: Don’t Bother With the Hotel Pool
text: WHAT I remember most about a nighttime tour I took of Alcatraz a couple of years ago was the fact that  given the nearness of the island prison to downtown San Francisco, just a mile and a half offshore  inmates were often haunted by the sounds of life across the water. When city residents held New Year’s Eve parties and their reveling carried across the cold, current-roiled bay, the two shores seemed maddeningly close to the prisoners.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE RELUCTANT FUNDAMENTALIST, by Mohsin Hamid. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) Hamid was born in Pakistan and educated at Princeton and Harvard Law. The protagonist of his second novel is a lot like him — a cultivated young Pakistani, working in New York in 2001 after graduating from Princeton, who finds himself sympathizing with the attackers. “His resentment is at least in part self-loathing, directed at the American he’d been on his way to becoming,” our reviewer, Karen Olsson, said, calling the book “elegant and chilling.” Hamid told an interviewer that “this is a story of someone who is in love with America ... who finds he has to leave.”

headline: Emily’s Posts
text: OFFICE TATTOO FAQS

headline: ‘McMafia’
text: Introduction

headline: Colombian Guerrilla Leader Reported Dead
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombia’s defense minister revealed Saturday that officials were trying to corroborate an intelligence report claiming that Manuel Marulanda, the supreme leader of Colombia’s largest rebel group, died of natural causes in March.

headline: Asparagus-Tarragon Cocotte
text: Salt

headline: Amanda Viola, Peter Beuttenmuller
text: Amanda Emma Viola, a daughter of Mary Jayne Viola and Joseph Viola of New Fairfield, Conn., was married there on Friday to Lt. Peter Thomas Beuttenmuller, a son of Gail Darling and David Beuttenmuller, both of Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Martin P. Ryan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Edward the Confessor Church, where he is the pastor.

headline: ‘An Honor Beyond Words’ for New Hepburn Center Chief
text: OLD SAYBROOK

headline: Childhood Is the Mother of the Play
text: AH, sweet, blessed memories of childhood. Steaming herbal tea. Hippie language police. Friends who had same-sex parents. Feminism, politics and books debated around the kitchen table every night. Also, Annie Baker said she used to wonder, precisely why were the typewritten fliers, push-pinned up in the local health food shop, “always Xeroxed on purple paper with those little tear-off tabs at the bottom?”

headline: Narrow Minded
text: You don’t have to search very hard to find the excruciating online videos known as thinspiration, or thinspo. Photomontages of skeletal women, including some celebrities and models, play all over the Internet, uploaded from the United States, Germany, Holland and elsewhere. These videos are designed to “inspire” viewers  to fortify their ambitions. But exactly which ambitions? To lose weight, presumably. To stop losing weight, possibly. Thinspo videos profess a range of ideologies, often pressing morbid images into double service, as both goads and deterrents to anorexia.

headline: Where the Bargains Keep Rolling Along
text: LOOKING for a bargain in Europe this summer? Forget hotels, restaurants and most forms of entertainment  the costs of which are rising into the stratosphere with the dollar near its lows against the euro and still weak versus the pound.

headline: Flipped Out
text: The Flip

headline: Son of Speak-Easy
text: AFTER 400 years, the tides were due to turn. Here on New York’s harbor, roughnecked stevedores once toiled on grimy docks; then came piers-turned-parks, piers-turned-galleries and piers-turned-bowling alleys. Now, anchoring a trinity of luxury waterfront condo towers near West 11th Street designed by Richard Meier, is a seemingly out-of-place dive bar, the Rusty Knot.

headline: Lone Stumbling Block Stands in Front of Northwestern’s 4th Title
text: TOWSON, Md.  The measuring stick for excellence in women’s lacrosse is the Maryland team that won seven straight N.C.A.A. titles from 1995 to 2001. On Sunday night, when Northwestern plays Pennsylvania in this year’s championship game, those Maryland teams may find company.

headline: The Freedom Nonagenda
text: When John McCain talks about the world, he returns again and again to the subject that so preoccupies George Bush  democracy. McCain says that democracies share not only values but also interests that differ fundamentally from those of authoritarian states. In a major foreign-policy speech this past March, he spoke of “the great nations of India and Japan, Australia and Brazil, South Korea and South Africa, Turkey and Israel,” and proposed that the U.S. and Europe join with them in “a global coalition for peace and freedom” that he calls the “League of Democracies.”

headline: The Dogs of War
text: After the abuse of the prisoners at Abu Ghraib was exposed in April 2004 by The New Yorker and “60 Minutes,” the Bush administration sought to portray the reprehensible misconduct as the work of a few bad apples. Seeming to underscore that verdict was the fact that soldiers took pictures of themselves, smiling, holding thumbs up, with the naked, dead, abused and humiliated prisoners.

headline: The Kettle Boils, the Plot Thickens
text: AS any visitor from England will tell you, no one in the United States can make a proper cup of tea. But 234 years after the Boston Tea Party set a salty precedent for tea preparations here, some Americans can finally claim to make it up the steeping slope.

headline: From Italian and Latin Heritage: Artful Plates
text: BASSO CAFE in Norwalk took me by surprise. It looks like a modest little cafe on Route 23  trim, tidy and plain  but its “Mediterranean fusion cuisine,” salted with a few South American dishes, like empanadas and tres leches, belies its looks.

headline: U.S. Goalkeeper Faces Difficult Save
text: CARSON, Calif.  Eight months after the benching of goalkeeper Hope Solo and the corrosive fallout at the Women’s World Cup, no one is pretending that all wounds have healed as the Olympics approach. Close friendships have frayed. The telephone calls that used to come on days off  let’s go shopping, let’s go to the beach  no longer come.

headline: Entrees to Match the Course
text: IN 1947, Bing Crosby summoned his pals to Pebble Beach, Calif., for a boozy golf tournament by the bay. The event, officially the revival of the National Pro-Amateur Golf Championship, was called the Clambake. But no one came for the cuisine.

headline: Help for Struggling Homeowners
text: LENDERS are increasingly willing to change their loan terms for struggling borrowers, mortgage industry executives say, but the increased flexibility has not been enough to help many homeowners who wait too long before seeking help.

headline: Exposed
text: Back in 2006, when I was 24, my life was cozy and safe. I had just been promoted to associate editor at the publishing house where I’d been working since I graduated from college, and I was living with my boyfriend, Henry, and two cats in a grubby but spacious two-bedroom apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. I spent most of my free time sitting with Henry in our cheery yellow living room on our stained Ikea couch, watching TV. And almost every day I updated my year-old blog, Emily Magazine, to let a few hundred people know what I was reading and watching and thinking about.

headline: Charming Italian, and That’s the Truth
text: LIARS take their chances when they put their hands in the Bocca della Verità (“mouth of truth”) in the portico of the church of Santa Maria in Cosmedin in Rome. The open mouth on a giant face  the design thought to grace an ancient manhole cover  supposedly will clamp down on the hand of the dissembler.

headline: A Superhighway to Bliss
text: JILL BOLTE TAYLOR was a neuroscientist working at Harvard’s brain research center when she experienced nirvana.

headline: San Diego, Doing Fine
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Chief, a Little Skepticism Can Go a Long Way
text: A NEIGHBOR of mine has eyes in the back of her head. Sometimes she can tell without looking that her children are doing something off limits  eating cookies just before dinner, shedding backpacks on the kitchen floor  and she tells them to stop without even turning around.

headline: Diversity at the Office: Policy vs. Reality
text: MINORITY employees may flee workplaces even when employers have so-called diversity programs in place, says Natalie Holder-Winfield, an employment lawyer turned diversity consultant.

headline: In the Military, Finding Peace From a War at Home
text: I SPENT many a Memorial Day on the airfield at McGuire Air Force Base, N.J., watching the fighter jets do somersaults above us and leave a stream of red, white and blue smoke in their wakes. The show inspired both delight and terror. The jets shone like silver birds piercing the sky, but I worried that they would crash into the crowd, or one another.

headline: A Big Loss for Rutgers
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Tale of the Long-Suffering Wife, by Way of Queens
text: You can almost hear the thought processes behind this revival of “The Vows of Penelope Corelli” as you listen to the exaggerated Noo Yawk accents of the actors: it’s the Odyssey set in ethnic Queens and performed by the Sopranos. Richard Vetere’s goofy play, revised from his 1990s original, gives an Italian-American spin to the Homeric story of Penelope, who waited and waited and waited for Odysseus to return from his far-flung travels.

headline: A Spike in Screams Before Graduation
text: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.

headline: Seeing and Counting Salamanders Close-Up
text: Mystic

headline: Cloud Computing: So You Don’t Have to Stand Still
text: CLOUD computing is the jargon of the moment in the technology industry. Google, I.B.M., Microsoft and Yahoo are just some of the big companies talking up the cloud, and a bunch of smaller ones are, too.

Perhaps it’s a throwback to a childhood spent in Brooklyn-by-the-Sea, but eating places with views of rivers, lakes and oceans hold an immediate attraction, at least until the often disappointing food appears.

text: AS some of us know all too well, when we get older we tend to get quirkier. Radicchio, in downtown Ridgewood, is almost 16  a couple of lifetimes in restaurant years  and it has enough quirks for a Preston Sturges movie.

headline: Making the Call on a Home Run Promotion
text: David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox is scheduled to play the role of Babe Ruth in a Call Your Shot promotion that is part of the home run derby scheduled for the All-Star Game festivities on July 14 at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees were upset when they heard about the plan and said they would ask Major League Baseball for an explanation. Readers of Bats, The Times’s baseball blog, weighed in.

headline: Tears and Memories as Business Resumes at Dry Cleaners Where Woman Was Killed
text: Eden Dry Cleaners and Tailoring opened about 8:30 a.m. on Saturday. Kenneth Oh and a friend assisted the first customers. His younger brother, Daniel Oh, and some helpers arrived a few hours later.

headline: One-Slam Wonder Still Loved in France
text: PARIS  It is a nostalgic time in France, and the tennis world is in the same mood. Paris intellectuals have spent much of the year filling air and space with ruminations on the deeper meaning of the student demonstrations that peaked 40 years ago, in May 1968. But tennis has its own anniversary to analyze this spring with the French Open beginning Sunday.

headline: Mussina and Offense Among Signs of Hope
text: The Yankees are on a four-game winning streak, their best of the season, but there was more than just that for the home team to smile about after Saturday’s 12-6 victory over Seattle on a partly sunny day before 53,512 fans at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Minimal, but Not Radical, ‘Carousel’
text: There are many adjectives one can apply to the great musicals by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II. But a half-century or so after their creation, “fresh” is not typically the first, or even the last, word that springs to mind.

headline: Great Views, Priceless.
text: WHAT price glory? It could be more than $100 million.

headline: Indie Films, Coming to a Small Screen Near You
text: MORE than 3,600 independent features were submitted to the Sundance Film Festival this year, a record driven by inexpensive digital equipment and an abundance of film financing. But only a couple hundred of those movies will ever be distributed in theaters. Does that mean that almost 90 percent of indies have zero value?

headline: Jessica Lerer, Daniel Yunger

headline: A Promise Paid, or Not, for Housing
text: ON a recent Tuesday, thick ropes of rain slashed at the concrete and dripped off car tires in the parking lot of Harborview Terrace, a two-building public housing project on West 55th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. There was little indication that the forlorn lot, and the basketball court next to it, might be the site of a real estate battle.

headline: Trying to Right a Wrong Committed 20 Years Ago
text: Whatever happened to the boy and girl voted “cutest couple” in your senior class? In the case of the sweethearts in Craig Wright’s fuzzy but often touching class-reunion drama “The Pavilion,” now onstage at the Westport Country Playhouse, things haven’t gone well.

headline: Witness for the Transit
text: Raised in Fort Lee, N.J., long based in San Francisco and drawn by wanderlust or employment to Montreal, Lisbon, Auckland, Austin, Dubai and Berlin, August Kleinzahler is as much a travel writer as he is a poet: his sometimes bitter, sometimes astonished poems (several even entitled “Traveler’s Tales”) seek the distinctive qualities of each place, repellent or beautiful or (in places he loves best) both at once. In Vancouver, “the neon mermaid over the fish place / looks best that way, in the rain.” At Coney Island, “a cluster of hip-hop Lubavitch punks” watch Neil Diamond (yes, it’s really him) amble past on the sand; in the American South, the poet imagines “pecans suffering /their convoluted slumber in the heat.” The poet’s interest in places spans the globe now, but it began with his native New Jersey, where (an early poem called “Poetics” says) “I have loved the air outside Shop-Rite Liquor / on summer evenings/ better than the Marin hills at dusk.” Few poets since William Carlos Williams have done more for the Garden State, or rendered with such mixed feelings what they saw there.

headline: Balancing Art and Business
text: PETER C. SUTTON looked a little weary as he presided over a senior staff meeting at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. Dr. Sutton had just returned the night before from a business trip to Japan, where he had given a lecture on Vermeer and the Delft School, his specialty, and discussed loans of artworks for future shows at the Bruce. Now he was listening as Nancy Hall-Duncan, senior curator of art, reported on plans for a 2009 show devoted to the French Impressionist painter Alfred Sisley.

headline: Mexico Ties Rise in Killings to Its Crackdown on Drugs
text: MEXICO CITY  Killings related to an underworld war between drug cartels have increased sharply, up almost 50 percent from the same period last year, the attorney general said Friday.

headline: Voters Pass All but Two School Budgets

The cartoon depicting a FEMA executive commenting on Myanmar, on the bottom left, was by Signe Wilkinson of The Philadelphia Daily News, Washington Post Writers Group, and the cartoon about gas prices, on the bottom right, was by Rob Rogers of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, United Features Syndicate.

headline: A C.E.O. Hits ‘Reply,’ and Now It’s Regret
text: His multimillion-dollar compensation package and appearances at Congressional hearings have made Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financial’s chief executive, the public face of the subprime mortgage crisis. That face may have turned crimson after he mishandled an e-mail message from a Countrywide customer asking for an adjustment to the terms of his mortgage.

headline: Blood and Guts
text: In the early 1990s, lacking direction after a breakup with a girlfriend, Shannon Burke left New Orleans (where he’d been working in a bookstore), moved to New York and took a job on an ambulance crew. He was drawn to emergency medicine partly out of guilt, he later explained to a paramedic friend. Back in the French Quarter, he had come upon a tourist, shot in the head, and had been unable to help her. “I thought I should have known first aid,” he recalled. “Like I could have saved her.” Burke went to Manhattan as a kind of personal test because “I figured it would be the most extreme place to do it.” In the five years he served on city ambulances, first as an E.M.T., later as a paramedic at Station 18, on 136th Street across from Harlem Hospital, he saw unspeakable horrors. Unspeakable, but not inexpressible.

headline: On Shore, a Week to Release Stress but Also a Chance to Address It
text: For many service members, Fleet Week is a fun time to get some shore leave, explore New York and have a few  maybe free  drinks.

headline: Rendering Justice, With One Eye on Re-election
text: Last month, Wisconsin voters did something that is routine in the United States but virtually unknown in the rest of the world: They elected a judge.

headline: Citizen Pruners, on Deadwood Patrol
text: A CITY street tree has a rough life. Plumes of vehicular exhaust cloud trees’ spring blossoms, teenagers carve their trunks with the musings of adolescent love, and trucks barrel into their branches. And so at 8:30 on a recent morning, two citizen pruners, Peter Arndtsen and Bruce James, set out to care for some of the afflicted street trees in their Upper West Side neighborhood.

headline: Reviving a Dark Horse and His Revelation
text: IT doesn’t help your legacy as a composer to give the Nazi salute in 1938 at the premiere of your greatest work. Nor is it good for your cause to tell a young Herbert von Karajan that he has no future in conducting. So it may not be a total surprise that the Austrian composer Franz Schmidt is little known to the wider world, given his difficult character and distasteful political associations.

headline: Starting Salaries but New York Tastes
text: Laura Werkheiser knew she would have to make many sacrifices to live in Manhattan. Foremost among them was shopping for clothes.

headline: Now He’s Only Hunted by Cameras
text: The written record cannot be trusted in Salman Rushdie’s newest novel, “The Enchantress of Florence,” a story that roams from the red sandstone palace of the great Mughal emperor Akbar to the towered Palazzo in Machiavelli’s Florence. One character is erased from official history, a second is imagined into existence, a third is hopelessly mischaracterized.

headline: When They Were Around, the Ayes Had It
text: WASHINGTON — In the annals of Congressional history, Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas is remembered for the ignominious end to his long legislative career: a public display of inebriation during a dalliance with a stripper named Fanne Fox.

headline: Wall Street Exodus: Fear, Panic and Anger
text: THE mind wraps itself around losing a job, one of life’s great traumas, in jagged and swerving fits. When the call comes in, when rumor turns to reality, when it’s not the broker in the next cubicle but you who is presented with a stack of severance papers, the psyche takes over.

headline: Two Budget Airlines
text: While one budget airline tightens its belt, another one flexes its muscles. JetBlue (www.jetblue.com) recently announced that it would postpone its planned service between Los Angeles International Airport and Boston Logan and Kennedy Airport. The airline, which serves 53 destinations, was planning to offer three daily nonstop flights between Kennedy and Los Angeles International, and one between Los Angeles and Boston. The service was to have started last Wednesday.

Yet his latest movie places him in what may be his most improbable scenario to date.

headline: New Respect for White Brick Buildings

headline: Inside the List

As it happens, both books at No. 1 on these lists are new, too. On the nonfiction side, Barbara Walters’s memoir, “Audition,” knocks Ron Paul’s “Revolution” out of the top spot. On the fiction list, Stephenie Meyer’s “Host” displaces James Patterson’s “Sundays at Tiffany’s.”
