headline: The 54 of Us
text: Is Osama bin Laden a rebel against the Saudi Arabian ruling class or a model member of it? That question lurks behind “The Bin Ladens,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning New Yorker writer Steve Coll. The world’s most famous terrorist owes his fortune and his standing to a family business that Coll calls “the kingdom’s Halliburton.” Like Halliburton, the Saudi Binladin Group specializes in gigantic infrastructure projects. Government connections are the key to the family’s wealth. So you would assume they would react with unmixed horror to a radical son, like the duchess in the Noël Coward song:

headline: The Other Half
text: Today one of the last Bowery flophouses leans up against the futuristic steel facade of the New Museum, and a bed at the Bowery Hotel can run $750 a night. After such gentrification, it can be difficult to conjure up the squalid New York that Jacob Riis documented in his groundbreaking 1889 work of photojournalism, “How the Other Half Lives.” Riis was well aware that the “other half” in New York City had become the other three-quarters, with 1.2 million impoverished New Yorkers living in slums, 19th-century tenements that were a public health catastrophe, rife with typhus, diarrhea, cholera and tuberculosis. Employing unsentimental storytelling, reportage, social statistics and the latest advances in flash photography, Riis shed a stark light on the horrific living conditions of New York’s vast population of poor immigrants.

headline: A Conflict’s Buffer Zone: Rocks, and Inches
text: ON THE DJIBOUTIAN-ERITREAN BORDER  The distance between the rival armies is shorter than the barrel of a gun. Hundreds of opposing troops are lined up on the border, staring each other down, from just inches away.

headline: Things We Learned This Season
text: This article is by Dave Caldwell, Stu Hackel, Jeff Hale, Jeff Z. Klein, Mark Pargas, Nathan Sandals, Lew Serviss and Lynn Zinser.

headline: Energy Speculators Draw the Heat
text: FOR the energy industry and the financial players that have bet on surging oil prices, this should be a time of euphoria. Not only do prices keep hitting record highs, but trading volumes on contracts for everything from crude to gasoline to diesel have followed a similar arc, generating big profits for bourses like the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Intercontinental Exchange.

headline: From Break Dancing to Ballet
text: The day Carlos Acosta learned he was to study ballet, he climbed to the roof of his apartment, took a pigeon in his hands, stroked its feathers and sobbed. Today, Acosta is a star with the Royal Ballet whose name is not infrequently uttered in the same breath as Nureyev’s and Baryshnikov’s. That moment atop the pigeon roost, as he recounts in his memoir, “No Way Home,” marked his first step from indigence in Cuba to a life of fame and glamour. But here was the rub: The 9-year-old wanted to be Pelé, not a prince. And although this is a Cinderella story  ragamuffin running wild in the streets metamorphoses into ballet god  it is one in which the hero spends a dizzying amount of time pining for his position amid the squalor of the hearth.

headline: Memorial Day at ‘South Pacific’
text: NEW YORK is a ghost town on Memorial Day weekend. But two distinct groups are hanging tight: sailors delighting in the timeless shore-leave rituals of Fleet Week, and theatergoers clutching nearly impossible-to-get tickets for “South Pacific.”

headline: On the Reservation and Off, Schools See a Changing Tide
text: HARDIN, Mont.  One of the last traditional chiefs of the Crow Indian tribe, named Plenty Coups, had a vision as the Old West was fading. Education would be the way of the future, he said  a choice to be either the “the white man’s victim” or “the white man’s equal.”

headline: Letter: A Moroccan Lodging
text: To the Editor: What fun to read “Rockin’ the Casbah” (May 11) after having spent 10 days in Morocco last summer. I was surprised to read your endorsement of Villa Maroc as a place to stay in Essaouira. We and another couple stayed there only one night. We carried our bags up three flights of circuitous stairs to our rooms  small and musty with only one window that opened onto an alleyway, and noisy well into the night. The area around this riad is charming and quaint, but we should have stayed at the modern Sofitel overlooking the beautiful beach instead. Our memories would have been fonder.

headline: Instant Message, Instant Girlfriend
text: FOR several years I had a problem unusual among Internet geeks: I had too much success with women. I used the Internet as a means of communication with women I had already met offline in order to overcome my social awkwardness and forge romantic relationships.

headline: Lisa Rainwater and Andy Mele
text: TRUST an environmentalist to talk about love like it’s a natural resource. “It can’t be burned through like a flame,” Andy Mele said. “You need the flame, but there’s also sober, reflective and collaborative times. You can’t live on just fire or just water.”

headline: Mr. Chávez’s Unsavory Friends
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela has been caught. Despite his protestations of innocence, Interpol has corroborated the authenticity of thousands of computer files captured during a Colombian Army raid on a FARC rebel camp in Ecuador. Only a small share of this trove has been released, but it leaves little doubt that Venezuela has been aiding the guerrillas’ effort to overthrow Colombia’s democratically elected government.

headline: Driving Back Into Louisiana’s History
text: STRIDING across the rain-soaked field of an abandoned Louisiana plantation, Mitch Landrieu, the state’s lieutenant governor, waved his hands impatiently. “C’mon, you’ve got to see this,” he called out, sounding more P. T. Barnum than politician. Marching beside him was the Whitney Plantation’s owner, John Cummings, a wealthy Louisiana lawyer turned preservationist who, with Mr. Landrieu’s help, hopes to prove that the old Southern plantation, or at least this one, is still very much in business.

headline: Ferguson
text: A colleague dropped by on a recent day to tell me that it was the third anniversary of her son’s coming home from Iraq. That stopped me. It’s been 40 years since I stepped off the battlefield, and I’m not home yet. I can still feel the muck of rice paddies pulling on my boots, still hear the jungle hiss and snap in the dark. Even after the night dreams and day drifts have stopped and the loud noises no longer startle, you still press your chin against your shoulder and look back.

headline: ‘The Enchantress of Florence’
text: In the day's last light the glowing lake below the palace-city looked like a sea of molten gold. A traveler coming this way at sunset — this traveler, coming this way, now, along the lakeshore road — might believe himself to be approaching the throne of a monarch so fabulously wealthy that he could allow a portion of his treasure to be poured into a giant hollow in the earth to dazzle and awe his guests. And as big as the lake of gold was, it must be only a drop drawn from the sea of the larger fortune — the traveler's imagination could not begin to grasp the size of that mother-ocean! Nor were there guards at the golden water's edge; was the king so generous, then, that he allowed all his subjects, and perhaps even strangers and visitors like the traveler himself, without hindrance to draw up liquid bounty from the lake? That would indeed be a prince among men, a veritable Prester John, whose lost kingdom of song and fable contained impossible wonders. Perhaps (the traveler surmised) the fountain of eternal youth lay within the city walls — perhaps even the legendary doorway to Paradise on Earth was somewhere close at hand? But then the sun fell below the horizon, the gold sank beneath the water's surface, and was lost. Mermaids and serpents would guard it until the return of daylight. Until then, water itself would be the only treasure on offer, a gift the thirsty traveler gratefully accepted.

headline: Op-Classic, 1996: A Heartfelt Commemoration
text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: Herb Reiss carries goods and goodwill to mariners docked off Staten Island.

headline: Dick Martin, 1922-2008
text: Dick Martin, the comic who with his partner, Dan Rowan, redefined what could be done on television with their hyperactive 60’s and 70’s show “Rowan and Martin’s Laugh-In,” died Saturday at 86. (Before your time? Why don’t you Google your Funk & Wagnalls?) Here’s a “Laugh-In” sampler (that’s Martin on the right with Rowan in the show opener):

headline: Getting a Horse Ready to Race
text: Following up on the entries on exercise riding, I thought I would shed some light on what a training program to get a horse from the field to the races.

text: Martha Ann Overland writes from Hanoi:

headline: ‘A Huge Document’
text: Aired Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: John McCain made public his medical records. It was a huge document, with more than 84 pages on his ear hair alone.

headline: Bettman’s Bristling Defense of the Long N.H.L. Season
text: In his State of the NHL news conference yesterday, Gary Bettman presented the expected rosy picture of the league’s competitive and financial condition. But when asked a question about an actual problem the NHL faces, he showed the petulant side that has become so familiar to hockey fans in the 16 years since he took over and gave himself the newly minted title of commissioner.

headline: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse: Pride of the Blue Devils
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Duke Coach John Danoswki took a tone of pride when talking about his departing fifth-year seniors. Danowski came to Duke in the wake of the canceled 2006 season.

headline: Clinton Defends R.F.K. Remarks
text: The Clinton campaign is in full push-back mode this morning, trying to “set the record straight” and contain the damage from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s comments Friday about Bobby Kennedy.

headline: 30 Seconds With Steve Cauthen
text: Bill Finley interviewed jockey Steve Cauthen for Sunday’s New York Times.

headline: In Beijing, Learning to Speak Olympics
text: Today’s Times Book Review features a “Letter From Beijing” by Mike Meyer, author of “The Last Days of Beijing: Life in the Vanishing Backstreets of a City Transformed,” which will be published next month. Meyer, who has spent the last three years volunteering at an elementary school in a rundown neighborhood not far from Tiananmen Square, recounts China’s drive to have 35 percent of its population conversant with English by the start of the Olympics — part of an overall push that, as Meyer remembers from his first day at the school in 2005, led to his finding “blackboards decorated with chalked Olympic mascots, the five-colored rings and verses in Chinese:

headline: The Morning Skate: Sunday School Is in Session
text: Isn’t it fun when you watch a DVD of a really good film and there’s additional scenes and other extras? Or you get a CD by your favorite artist but some web site also lets you download bonus tracks? Well, today’s Times carries the Slap Shot contributors’ collective piece “Things We Learned This Season”, and thanks to digital technology and the miracle of the internet, Slap Shot presents the complete version of what we learned, which appeared on the blog late last week.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, May 25:

headline: The Shelley Duncan All-Stars
text: When Shelley Duncan was growing up, he and his brother, Chris, liked to take a stack of All-Star ballots and vote for the worst players at each position. So if you’ve ever wondered how no-name guys get thousands of votes, thank the Duncan brothers for starting the trend.

headline: Rent Adjustments While Elevators Are Replaced
text: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment. The landlord would like to replace our elevators this summer. I don’t believe this is necessary, as the elevators seem to work fine, but replacing them will allow him to raise our rents. The official letter from the landlord claims that the work is expected to take four to eight weeks. The full rent should include elevator use, and that will not be provided at this time.

headline: Passing Along the Cost of Landscaping
text: I live in Stuyvesant Town, where a massive landscaping project is being carried out on the grounds.

headline: Living in Kensington
text: The Kensington area of Brooklyn, with lower prices and a slower pace than “brownstone Brooklyn,” offers an increasingly popular alternative to the borough’s more gentrified neighborhoods.

headline: Engineers: Flaws in Chinese Schools Common Elsewhere
text: [UPDATED 5/25, 2:30 p.m.] Over the past week, I helped report and write a story with several of my colleagues who were on the front lines in quake-torn Sichuan province. The article focuses on the fate of a single shattered primary school, one of hundreds that fell around the region, many in areas where other buildings survived — including one school for the children of more privileged parents.

headline: Randolph Is Safe — For Now
text: At least that was the impression that Omar Minaya gave in speaking with reporters this morning. Calling his visit here a “productive weekend,” Minaya said the drama surrounding Randolph’s comments critical of SNY ended once he apologized and indicated that he is not in any imminent danger of being fired — something he did not do Friday.

headline: Nip and Tuck Them Into Bed
text: Books | A children’s book explains why Mom is getting a nose or boob job. It’s called “My Beautiful Mommy,” by Dr. Michael Salzhauer, a Miami plastic surgeon. “Why are you going to look different?” the girl asks. Mom responds: “Not just different, my dear—prettier!” — Newsweek.

headline: Water Polo Diary: How Do They Get the Horses in the Pool?
text: Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women’s water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She’ll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

headline: An Urban Tree House
text: Victoria Redel, a poet and novelist who thinks of herself as a country girl at heart, found an apartment close to Riverside Park.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Damon Albarn
text: Damon Albarn narrates an audio slide show about what inspired him to compose “Monkey: Journey to the West.”

headline: It’s a Blunderful World
text: It is no surprise that everyone makes mistakes, even grandmasters. But in recent tournaments, some of the top players in the world have made some blunders that even, well, ordinary players might make. Obviously, there is no causal relationship among the errors, but it is nice to be reminded that everyone is human. The first four positions are some of the worst (uh, best) mistakes from recent weeks. And, in the interest of balance, the next five puzzles are examples of excellent play.

headline: Fans of Ron
text: For Ron Paul supporters, it’s less about the campaign and more about libertarian ideals.

headline: Hope Solo, Still Working for Her Teammates’ Acceptance
text: In today’s Times Sports section, Jeré Longman writes about the continuing struggle of Hope Solo, the U.S. national team goalkeeper, to win back the trust of her teammates eight months after her angry outburst at being benched for the Women’s World Cup semifinal. But first, some background:

headline: David Bowie's Former Haunt
text: The Essex House, on Central Park South, the former apartment of David Bowie and his wife, Iman, is on the market.

headline: Spike Lee's Old Joint
text: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a 1930s firehouse that has been converted into two duplex lofts was leased to Spike Lee and his production company, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks, for the past 22 years.

headline: Clinton Soaks Up Warmth in Puerto Rico
text: With controversy still swirling around her following her remarks about the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, campaigning Sunday in Puerto Rico ahead of a primary there on June 1, did what people on the Caribbean island have traditionally done in times of trial. She went first to church, and then headed off to the beach.

headline: Frank Sinatra's Hangout
text: The listing for Sinatra’s penthouse apartment at 530 East 72nd Street reads: “The first owner was Old Blue Eyes. The new one must be someone with vision.”

headline: Ex-Fund Manager Convicted of Fraud Said to Commit Suicide
text: A man convicted in a multi-million dollar investment fraud whose victims included pro football players has committed suicide in jail, according to a law enforcement official.

headline: Patriots Are Safe; No One Will Go 17-0
text: The N.F.L. is considering adding a regular-season game (and subtracting a preseason one) as a possible solution to its dispute with the players union.

headline: Rating the Red Bulls vs. the Chicago Fire
text: The Red Bulls (3-2-3, 12 points) entered Sunday’s game against the Chicago Fire (6-2-1, 19 points) riding a five-game streak without a loss and were the only team in Major League Soccer with only one loss this season. So much for those statistics! The Fire had its three-game winning streak ended last week by the Houston Dynamo.

headline: This Green House
text: A day with the environmentally conscious students living in the sustainability house at Oberlin College.

headline: Tracking Young Talent
text: Many young racecar drivers hope to be noticed, but spotting talent is not an exact science.

headline: Lessons in Pitching From Mariano Rivera
text: Matt Franco had one at-bat for the Mets in the 2000 World Series. He took a third strike from Mariano Rivera to end Game 4.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 96 UTEP
text: Location: El Paso, Tex.

headline: Big Brown Has a Quarter Crack
text: Big Brown has a quarter crack in his left front hoof and has already missed two days of training, but his trainer, Rick Dutrow, says his colt is in little danger of missing the Belmont Stakes on June 7. (Full story and a multimedia graphic on remedies for the quarter crack can be found here.)

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Monkeys and Others
text: Video: The director and writer Chen Shi-Zheng talks about the North American premiere of his opera “Monkey: Journey to the West.”

headline: More Colorado Follies
text: I’ve just returned from New Zealand and find that in my absence the University of Colorado – the same one that earlier this year appointed as its president a Republican fund-raiser with a B.A. in mining and no academic experience – has gifted me again, this time with the announcement of plans to raise money for a Chair in Conservative Thought and Policy.

headline: Clinton Weighs In on Cuba
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Cuban independence week featured lengthy policy statements in Miami by John McCain and Barack Obama, but came and went without Hillary Rodham Clinton saying much on the topic. On Sunday night, however, speaking near San Juan at the “Casa de Cuba,” a community center for refugees from Cuba who have settled in Puerto Rico, she finally weighed in.

headline: The White Working Class: Forgotten Voters No More
text: Video

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Gingerbread Men Run Amok and Cats Dying 9 Ways
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — On the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.’s first weekend, already three productions consciously blur the line between moving images and real life. In Rossini’s “Cenerentola,” a huge video projection in the middle of the stage reflected offstage action. In the circus opera “Monkey: Journey to the West,” a cartoon projection on a scrim morphed into stage action or depicted animated scenes.

headline: Fleet Week
text: Sailors, marines and their vessels made New York City home for a week in a spring tradition.

headline: Does Randolph Stay or Does He Go?
text: Remember that last blog post? The one I wrote before Sunday’s 4-1 loss? That is how quickly things change in the Mets’ world. All of the optimism and hope that circulated through the clubhouse Sunday morning, filtering into Willie Randolph’s office and Omar Minaya’s words — it disappeared.

headline: The White Working Class: Forgotten Voters No More
text: Ruy Teixeira, a Democratic analyst of voting trends, wrote the book on the core issue in the endgame of the party’s nomination fight. Its title is “America’s Forgotten Majority: Why the White Working Class Still Matters.”

headline: Lebanon Elects President to Ease Divide
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After 18 months of grinding political conflict, Lebanon’s Parliament elected a new president on Sunday, in the first formal step toward enacting a new power-sharing pact among the country’s bitterly divided political factions.

headline: At Glittery Cannes, a Gritty Palme d’Or
text: CANNES, France  At the closing ceremony of the 61st Cannes Film Festival on Sunday, the red carpet was overrun by teenagers when the French film “The Class” (“Entre les Murs”) won the Palme d’Or. Directed by Laurent Cantet, this documentary-inflected drama follows a year in the life of a French schoolteacher working in a tough multicultural section of Paris. Based on a best-selling autobiographical novel by François Bégaudeau, who plays the main character, “The Class” is given great life by the performances of the nonprofessional actors playing the students. Mr. Cantet brought them onstage with him to accept the prize, and they brought the entire Palais des Festivals to its feet.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An Inside Pitch note with an article about the Yankees in some editions on Thursday referred imprecisely to a statistic from the Elias Sports Bureau in some copies. Jason Giambi, Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter are the three players who have been hit by the most pitches in the past 10 seasons in the American League, not in all of Major League Baseball.

headline: Indiana Jones Finds the Pot of Gold
text: Not all Indiana Jones quests bring home the archaeological bacon, but his latest adventure has reaped a treasure fit for Midas. As Harrison Ford returned to the title role after 19 years, “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” released by Paramount on Thursday, hauled in an estimated $126 million through Sunday and is expected to amass $25 million more on Monday, according to the box-office-tracking company Media by Numbers. If the numbers hold up, the film would be the second-best Memorial Day opening, after “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End” last year, according to Variety. The new Indiana Jones film’s gross was sufficient to wrest the No. 1 ranking from last week’s champion, “The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian” (Disney), which slipped to second place with $23 million. Paramount could derive additional joy from “Iron Man,” positioned in third place with a weekend take of $20.1 million to bring its four-week total to $252.3 million. Fourth place and $9 million in its third week went to the romantic comedy “What Happens in Vegas” (Fox), followed by “Speed Racer” (Warner Brothers), also in its third week, with $3.9 million.

headline: Medicare Marketing
text: To the Editor:

headline: World Bank, U.S., Britain and Japan Take on Warming
text: The World Bank will raise at least $5.5 billion with the United States, Britain and Japan this year for climate change funds that will help poor nations use clean technology and tackle global warming, a bank official said on Sunday.

headline: A Safe Landing, in a Familiar Place, for Johns Hopkins's Coach
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  While flying over Cayuga Lake in upstate New York a week ago, the Johns Hopkins men’s lacrosse coach, Dave Pietramala, and his offensive coordinator, Bobby Benson, heard a thud in their six-seat plane.

headline: Amid Calm in Sadr City, Officials and Cleric’s Backers Swap Charges of Weakness
text: BAGHDAD  As some semblance of normal life began to return to the Sadr City area on Sunday, the Iraqi government and followers of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr accused each other of being weak. The verbal sniping occurred despite a cease-fire that had finally brought calm to one of Baghdad’s most volatile areas.

headline: A New Twist on Balloon Sculpture
text: Most people associate balloon twisting with clowns, birthday parties, poodles and fanciful hats for children. But as it turns out, there are strong subcultures of balloon-twisters, and they do not always get along.

headline: Mets Lose Again; Wilpon Is Up Next
text: DENVER  Passing a trunk containing his No. 12 jersey, Willie Randolph wheeled a suitcase through the middle of a near-empty clubhouse Sunday afternoon. He knew he was flying to New York as the Mets’ manager, this much was certain. How much longer he retains his job may be in question after the Mets lost for the sixth time in seven games, 4-1 to the Colorado Rockies.

headline: Teenage Newshounds, It’s a Dog-Eat-Dog World
text: Before the television cameras rolled, Amanda Lorber was just one of 5,500 students at Cypress Bay High School in Weston, Fla. She was passionate about writing and musical theater, and possessed an intense desire to become the editor in chief of her school newspaper, The Circuit.

headline: Long March to an Apology
text: Washington

headline: Kuerten, a Three-Time French Open Champion, Bids Adieu
text: PARIS  Those searching for a last glimpse of vintage Gustavo Kuerten did not leave entirely unsatisfied on the first day of the French Open.

headline: Remember to Remember
text: Last Thursday, the soldiers of the Third United States Infantry Regiment (the Old Guard) placed a small American flag in front of each of the 260,000 or so grave markers in Arlington National Cemetery. The soldiers remained on duty throughout the weekend, replacing flags that had fallen or been removed, to ensure that each grave was appropriately decorated and honored on Memorial Day.

headline: Season Finale With a Florentine Touch
text: New York’s vibrant music scene is packed with ensembles of every type, but many worthy young musicians still struggle to find work. So the composer and conductor Salvatore Di Vittorio saw a niche for a professional orchestra for young players, offering regular performance opportunities to some of the many graduates who pour out of the country’s conservatories each year.

headline: More Monaco?
text: The names of the renowned architects Norman Foster and I. M. Pei have been associated with a secret plan by Prince Albert II of Monaco to enlarge his principality, which covers less than one square mile, by extending it out to sea on stilts, according to The Guardian of London. The new territory, with an estimated construction time of 10 years, would include apartments, shops, mooring for yachts and an architectural showpiece likely to be a museum. Some environmentalists along the Côte d’Azur are concerned about the project’s impact on marine life, but Robert Calcagno, Monaco’s councilor for the environment and a close associate of the prince, who regards himself as a champion of ecology, said, “Not only will we protect the ecosystem, but we will actually better the environment by putting in man-made reefs to allow species to thrive.”

headline: Donors Press Myanmar to Let Aid Workers In
text: BANGKOK  Delegates from 52 donor nations meeting on Sunday in Myanmar pressed its government to make good on a promise to give foreign aid workers free access to millions of isolated cyclone survivors.

headline: States Chafing at U.S. Focus on Terrorism
text: Juliette N. Kayyem, the Massachusetts homeland security adviser, was in her office in early February when an aide brought her startling news. To qualify for its full allotment of federal money, Massachusetts had to come up with a plan to protect the state from an almost unheard-of threat: improvised explosive devices, known as I.E.D.’s.

headline: Sydney Pollack, Film Director, Dies at 73
text: LOS ANGELES  Sydney Pollack, a Hollywood mainstay as director, producer and sometime actor whose star-laden movies like “The Way We Were,” “Tootsie” and “Out of Africa” were among the most successful of the 1970s and ’80s, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 73.

headline: Military Chief Warns Troops About Politics
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has written an unusual open letter to all those in uniform, warning them to stay out of politics as the nation approaches a presidential election in which the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan will be a central, and certainly divisive, issue.

headline: Mbeki Calls Harm to Migrants a Disgrace
text: JOHANNESBURG  After two weeks of only faint and infrequent condemnations of the anti-immigrant violence that has troubled South Africa, President Thabo Mbeki on Sunday described the wave of xenophobic attacks as an “absolute disgrace” that has blemished the country’s reputation.

headline: Deadly Infections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Starry Lineup of Female Choreographers: Vive la Différence
text: In his opening remarks for “Dancing Divas,” an evening for six female choreographers as part of the La MaMa Moves! festival, Nicky Paraiso, one of its curators, gushed, “I love this program.” Then why, after three years, doesn’t La MaMa give it more than one night?

headline: Safest Place Is in First; Dixon Wins Indy 500
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Scott Dixon won the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, but he said that on his final laps he was worried about everything that could go wrong with his racecar. It was a startling admission. Dixon is called the Iceman for good reason.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Unofficially, a New Season in the Air
Bringing TV Clips to Blogs, a Site Runs Afoul of Networks
text: In the bad old days of YouTube  before the site meticulously filtered out unauthorized content  the television and movie studios used to complain vociferously that their work was being posted to the site without permission.

headline: Footnotes
text: The filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki, below, whose credits include “Lights in the Dusk” and “The Man Without a Past,” has been granted an honorary title for Finns who have distinguished themselves in the arts, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Kaurismaki, 51, received the title of Academician from Tarja Halonen, president of Finland, on Friday at a ceremony in Helsinki. ... Eartha Kitt, the eternal femme fatale who opened the 2007-8 season at the renovated Café Carlyle in September, will close the season when she returns, June 4 to July 5, with an evening of standards and songs associated with her long career, including “C’est Si Bon,” “Monotonous” and “La Vie en Rose.” ... The Museum of Modern Art will remain open until 8:45 p.m. every Thursday in July and August. Visitors can tour the galleries and attend live music in two sets, at 5:30 and 7 p.m., in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden.

headline: A Star-Spangled Banner Yet Waves at Lord & Taylor
text: The dozen or so people in the folding chairs did not quite know what to do when 10 a.m. finally rolled around and the sound system stopped playing soft, up-tempo jazz and started playing “The Star-Spangled Banner.” Get up? Stay seated?

headline: The Right Yardage in Your Hands, Before You Even Grab a Club
text: If you ask me, there’s nothing like having a caddie by your side on the course. It can be one of golf’s great cosmic connections. Unfortunately, I haven’t yet persuaded a caddie to live in my guest room, which would be a real bonus for those situations when I want to dash out for a quick nine holes and need a caddie ready and waiting.

headline: Mets and Yankees Find Plenty of Ways to Be Preoccupied
text: It’s Memorial Day. Some of us can remember doubleheaders on this holiday, with radio broadcasters saying, “If you’re in the neighborhood, plenty of seats.” Instead, the Mets, currently by the twin furies of ineptitude and controversy, come home to a night game on Memorial Day. Bring the kiddies, bring the wife, indeed.

headline: Earth’s End Is Near Again: Crichton’s Brain Squad Is Back
text: “The Andromeda Strain,” Michael Crichton’s 1969 novel, written while he was still a medical student at Harvard, is like one of the mutations the book painstakingly describes. It can shape-shift into a dozen metaphors. At the time of its publication it spoke not only to cold war fears but also to more up-to-the-minute notions that lunar missions might result in the importation of perilous contaminants from the Moon.

headline: New CDs
text: USHER

headline: Answers for Any Question, on Any Rule, Any Time
text: The headquarters of the United States Golf Association are a dignified place ensconced on a manicured New Jersey estate that includes a long, winding driveway and clusters of stately trees. The offices are not open late on Sunday afternoons, but invariably at this time of year, the telephone at the main switchboard will ring.

headline: The Wars We Choose to Ignore
text: Gen. John A. Logan was a Union officer, a fierce Republican partisan, an early advocate of the kind of volunteer army the United States now fights wars with. He is also one of the people credited with coming up with the holiday that we celebrate today. A statue in Logan Circle in Washington shows the general on horseback flanked by two female figures said to represent America at war and America at peace.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review on Friday about “Afghanistan: Hidden Treasures From the National Museum, Kabul,” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and a picture caption misspelled the name of a satyr depicted on a bronze mask in the exhibition. He is Silenus, not Selenus.

headline: Abandoned Houses Are Keeping Contractors Busy
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The house on East 24th Street was the worst of the six that David Law and Trey McCallister worked on the other day here. The front door had been kicked in so many times that the dead bolt was exposed and bent. Trash littered the front and back yards. A copper pipe was gone.

headline: Ending a Long Drought, Kahne Wins the Longest Race
text: CONCORD, N.C.  If Kasey Kahne was somehow less deserving of a victory in the annual Nascar All-Star race a week ago after making the field on a fan vote, he surely earned his place in victory lane on Sunday night in the Coca-Cola 600.

headline: Aide Sees Obama Clinching Nomination in June
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama’s chief strategist said Sunday that he believed Mr. Obama would by the first week of June reach the absolute number of Democratic delegates needed to clinch the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: How Green Is the College? Time the Showers
text: OBERLIN, Ohio  Lucas Brown, a junior at Oberlin College here, was still wet from the shower the other morning as he entered his score on the neon green message board next to the bathroom sink: Three minutes, according to the plastic hourglass timer inside the shower. Two minutes faster than the morning before. One minute faster than two of his housemates.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the restoration of water service to a block of West 57th Street in Manhattan one day after a water main broke referred incorrectly at one point to the Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the sewer and water system. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is a city  not state  agency.

headline: Tenor Wins Competition
text: Triumphing over 72 singers from 29 countries in a competition that began in Brussels on May 8, the Hungarian tenor Szabolcs Brickner, 27, right, won the Queen Elisabeth Prize for singing, organizers said Sunday, Agence France-Presse reported. Given to up-and-coming classical musicians who seek an international career, the Belgian prize, established in 1937 for violinists by the Bavarian wife of the late King Albert I, now also honors pianists, composers and singers on a rotating basis.

headline: What to Say After a Medical Mistake?
text: To the Editor:

headline: NASA Spacecraft Lands on Mars
text: PASADENA, Calif.  NASA’s Phoenix spacecraft made a safe, flawless landing Sunday on Mars.

headline: Diarrheal Disease
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pit-Road Collision Ends Frustrating Day for Patrick
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Her helmet still on, Danica Patrick strode purposefully down pit road from her parked car toward Ryan Briscoe’s parked car, tugging off her black gloves as if she wanted to throw them down and challenge Briscoe to a fight.

headline: DVRs Lop Off End of (Gasp!) ‘American Idol’
text: Ever since NBC cut off the end of the 1968 Jets-Raiders football game in order to start the television movie “Heidi” on time, people who watch live television events have occasionally suffered emotional trauma over missing the end of a captivating contest.

headline: Barefoot in the Park? Watch Your Step
text: People have walked barefoot in the grass for thousands of years, and barefoot in New York City’s parks at least since the days of Olmsted and Vaux. Neil Simon wrote a play about it, and Robert Redford and Jane Fonda starred in the movie.

headline: The Obama Connection
text: It’s the networks, stupid.

headline: Browsers Are a Battleground Once Again
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The browser, that porthole onto the broad horizon of the Web, is about to get some fancy new window dressing.

headline: Sex Sells, So Legislator Urges State to Tax It
text: SACRAMENTO  Of all the proposals made by the government of California to help close the state’s $17 billion budget gap, only one drew a bevy of exotic dancers from San Francisco to speak against it.

headline: Veteran Tries to Get Back to Who He Was
text: HOLLIDAYSBURG, Pa.

headline: Radio’s ‘Fair Game’ to Be Canceled
text: “Fair Game,” the 17-month-old weeknight public-radio show hosted by Faith Salie, has been canceled for financial reasons, and its last broadcast will be on May 30, Public Radio International, the show’s producer, said on Friday. “We took a gamble on a show that was a departure for public radio, a little bit edgier,” Melinda Ward, P.R.I.’s senior vice president for content, said in an interview. “Unfortunately, the program didn’t catch fire fast enough, broadly enough to attract underwriting.” The program, which mixed newsmaker interviews and pop culture, was heard on about 25 stations, including WNYC-AM in New York, and had about 140,000 weekly listeners on average, P.R.I. said. Ms. Salie, 37, a former Rhodes Scholar and actress with a relaxed, often irreverent approach, called the show experience “wildly fulfilling.” Noting that “P.R.I. hired me to get a hipper, younger audience for public radio,” she said, “I think public radio is smart to recognize it needs to innovate in order to survive, and I hope that it will continue to actually allow for innovation rather than just recognize the need for it.” P.R.I. is exploring continuing “Fair Game” online; the show’s listeners downloaded about 100,000 podcasts each month, Ms. Ward said. Ms. Salie said that she was interested but was also exploring television hosting offers. WNYC-AM said it would expand “On Point” to fill the “Fair Game” time slot of 8 to 9 p.m.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the Frequent Flier column on Tuesday, about a malodorous flight taken by Greg Hanson, a software developer for Travelocity, referred incorrectly to the waterfall shown in a photograph of Mr. Hanson in Argentina. It is Iguazú Falls  not Iguaçu, as it is called on the other side of the waterfall in Brazil.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief art review on Friday about an exhibition of paintings and pastels by Joan Mitchell, at the Lennon, Weinberg gallery in Chelsea, misstated two words in a poem by James Schuyler that inspired a drawing on display. In the poem, “Sunset,” it is “The sun,” not “The man” that “just went behind the ridge,” and “turned it mauve, marked green by firs,” not “by fire.”

headline: Conflicts Hang Over Argentine Leader
text: BUENOS AIRES  These could be giddy times for Argentina and its first elected female president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner. Prices for agricultural commodities are soaring, consumer spending has been rising and foreign investment is flowing in.

headline: A Pause Before Summer
text: There is something wonderfully calming about standing on the edge of summer, here on Memorial Day, as though summer lay before us as undisturbed as a spring-fed mountain lake. We all know it’s not going to be like that. The heat and humidity will build, streets will melt, the presidential campaign will intensify, and the weeks will be no less crowded and worrying in June and July than they are any other time of year. But this morning, many Americans are quietly visiting cemeteries, thankful that Memorial Day comes just when spring blossoms are at their peak. Many more are simply savoring the pleasure of a day off in good weather.

headline: In Murderous Pursuit of Einstein’s Secrets
text: Q. What do Leonardo da Vinci and Albert Einstein have in common?

headline: Ginóbili Helps Breathe Life Into the Spurs
text: SAN ANTONIO  It is considered unbecoming of a San Antonio Spur to admit publicly to injuries, or at least to admit that crunched ankles sometimes make jump shots go sideways and make dribble drives go flat.

headline: Breast Milk Is Better
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Shoppers Head to Supercenters
text: The percentage of adult food shoppers who said they had shopped at a supermarket over the last month has fallen from to 86 percent from 93 percent since 2005, according to “U.S. Grocery Shopper Trends,” a survey of customers’ behavior prepared yearly by the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group.

headline: Rebel Death Raises Hope for Hostages in Colombia
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombia’s largest rebel group on Sunday confirmed the death of its senior leader, the legendary guerrilla Manuel Marulanda.

headline: Falun Gong Marchers Are Jeered in Chinatown
text: Anguish over the recent earthquake in China helped set off a small ideological disturbance in Chinatown on Sunday when a Falun Gong parade was jeered by supporters of the Chinese government who hurled water bottles and pieces of pastry at the marchers, as well as insults.

headline: Affordable Housing, at a Price
text: For years, officials in New Jersey have talked about the need for more affordable housing and then done almost nothing. The need is pressing, and the state may finally be ready to move. Unfortunately, this newfound resolve carries serious risks. Unless the state changes its current plan, some of the new housing will be built on the few parcels of undeveloped land that still remain. That must not be allowed to happen.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about Joe Armstrong, the New York bon vivant known as the Mayor of Michael’s, the West 55th Street restaurant popular with television and publishing executives, referred imprecisely to Paul Newman’s Hole in the Wall Gang camp in Connecticut, where Mr. Armstrong has volunteered as a cabin counselor. It is for children with cancer and other serious  but not necessarily terminal  illnesses.

headline: ‘Potter’ Actor Killed
text: An 18-year-old actor with a small role in the forthcoming film “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince” was fatally stabbed in a brawl outside a London bar on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. The actor, Rob Knox, who plays Marcus Belby, a student from Ravenclaw House at the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in the series’s sixth installment, to be released in November, was one of five young men taken to hospitals, the police said. Among them was a 21-year-old arrested on suspicion of murder. The killing brought to 14 the number of violent teenage deaths in London this year.

headline: Nuclear Gold Rush
text: If there’s one country where nuclear power would seem superfluous, it’s oil-rich Saudi Arabia. Yet a highlight of President Bush’s recent trip there was the signing of an agreement to cooperate on developing civilian nuclear energy. Saudi Arabia is only one of many nations in the Middle East suddenly eager for nuclear power.

headline: An Occasion to Wear ‘Empire State Burgundy’
text: Fifteen years after the movie “Sleepless in Seattle” gave his workplace even more fame, Robert Gross finally has a uniform that is camera worthy.

headline: Despite Much Adversity, Keeping the Music Alive
text: The Brazilian pianist and conductor João Carlos Martins has lived a life of renown, challenge, tenacity and triumph sufficient to fill a lively memoir. An acclaimed recitalist in the 1960s, he specialized in playing Bach with a Romantic subjectivity and intensity. When his concert career was derailed by injuries in the 1970s, Mr. Martins retreated to the studio for an extensive series of Bach recordings while reinventing himself as a successful entrepreneur and, briefly, a politician. A brutal 1995 mugging robbed him of his ability to play professionally.

headline: A Few Tremors in Oprahland
text: LOS ANGELES  Oprah Winfrey is still the queen of all media, but her crown is beginning to look a bit tarnished.

headline: Cable Networks Trying to Build on Their Gains in Ratings
text: If executives at VH1 starred in their own reality show, they could call it “Best Quarter Ever.”

headline: Caregivers on Strike Look to Labor Board for Relief
text: After three wearying months of walking the picket line, 220 nursing home workers at the Kingsbridge Heights Rehabilitation and Care Center in the west Bronx have had plenty of time to sharpen their message.

headline: Where History Is Always on Display
text: The United States Golf Association is more than just a governing national body of golf. Its headquarters, Golf House, also include a peerless museum of the game.

headline: Standing In for Kennedy, Obama Embraces Legacy
text: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  When Senator Edward M. Kennedy endorsed Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign in January, Mr. Kennedy passed the torch of Democratic liberalism, saying it was “time again for a new generation of leadership.”

headline: Three No-Trump, and on to Las Vegas
text: Each district of the American Contract Bridge League will send one team to play in the Championship Flight of the Grand National Teams at the Summer Nationals in Las Vegas, which start on July 16.

headline: Breathing Life Into Gods, and Into a Hindu Temple
text: In the new temple’s sanctum early Sunday morning, everything was in place: the coconuts, the red strings, the Post-It notes, all connected to the white marble statues of Shiva, Durga, Hanuman and the rest of the Hindu gods and goddesses lining the walls. All that remained was for the devotees to breathe life into them.

headline: Warner Tries a New Tactic to Revive Its DVD Sales
text: LOS ANGELES  Retail’s love affair with the DVD is on the rocks and Warner Brothers Entertainment would like to patch things up.

headline: In a Democratic District, a Former Firefighter Raises Republican Hopes
text: ALBANY  Tim Brown believes a Republican can win in the 26th State Senate District, which stretches from Gramercy Park to the Upper East Side. “It’s a district where people vote for the person, not along party lines,” Mr. Brown says.

headline: Tax Exemptions of Charities Face New Challenges
text: RED WING, Minn.  Authorities from the local tax assessor to members of Congress are increasingly challenging the tax-exempt status of nonprofit institutions  ranging from small group homes to wealthy universities  questioning whether they deserve special treatment.

headline: Kennedy Comment Sends Clinton Into Damage Control
text: The Clinton campaign began a concerted effort over the weekend to try to “set the record straight” and contain the damage from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s comments Friday about Robert F. Kennedy.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The San Isidro Tilantongo Journal article on May 13, about the successful use of old pre-Hispanic farming techniques in the barren Mixteca highlands of Mexico’s Oaxaca State, misstated the middle initial of a Duke University desertification expert who was quoted as saying the land’s agricultural potential was not high. He is James F. Reynolds, not James D. Reynolds.

headline: State Police Woes Prompted Trooper to Kill Himself, His Friends Say
text: Only in his last few weeks had Gary A. Berwick’s wife and daughters come home to find him sitting with the lights off. He had begun to retreat into himself, his usual cheer and ebullience melting into a despondent quiet. His friends knew he was saddened and worried, but little more. “There’s a lot of politics,” was all he would say.

headline: Learn to Play the Guitar at Your Local Newsstand
text: Sometimes success means seeing in advance, with absolute clarity, where you should go. And sometimes it’s more like, “Whoa, dude, check it out.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,074 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: A Glimpse of Weekend at McCain’s
text: SEDONA, Ariz.  James Wadsworth used to be a groundskeeper at Senator John McCain’s ranch near here. But on Sunday, he traded pruning shears for a digital camera, waiting for a glimpse of Mr. McCain, who spent the weekend entertaining a group of guests, including a few said to be potential running mates, at his secluded property.

headline: British U.F.O. Shocker! Government Officials Were Telling the Truth
text: LONDON — They were shaped like cigars, saucers, coffins and amorphous blinking blobs. They hovered in a menacing manner, traveled at impossible speeds and vanished into the netherworld, or, in one instance, a hedge in Cornwall.

headline: This Week’s Economic Reports
text: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY Reports this week will include new home sales for April, the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller index of home prices and the consumer confidence index (Tuesday); durable goods orders for April (Wednesday); the preliminary estimate of gross domestic product for the first quarter and Freddie Mac’s report on mortgage rates (Thursday); and personal income and spending for April (Friday).

headline: Toll Rises in China Quake
text: BEIJING  The official death toll from the May 12 earthquake in southwest China rose to more than 65,000, Chinese state media reported Monday, as rescuers prepared to dynamite and drain a lake caused by landslides.

headline: Hoof Issues Resurface, Hampering Big Brown
text: Big Brown’s smooth path to a potential Triple Crown sweep was spoiled Sunday when his trainer, Rick Dutrow, revealed that the colt had sustained a quarter crack on the inside of his left front hoof.

headline: China Orders 6 Telecoms to Merge Their Assets
text: China has told its six telecommunications companies to merge their assets, allowing fixed-line carriers to expand into wireless services and creating three operators that will offer phone and Internet connections to 1.3 billion people.

headline: 25-Mile Jump Set for Monday
text: Michel Fournier, a 64-year-old retired French army officer, is expected to attempt to parachute some 25 miles to earth early Monday in Saskatchewan. Fournier’s original plan was to jump on Sunday morning, but weather conditions were expected to be more favorable Monday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Foreign

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Tuesday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills, auctions of two-year notes and four-week bills on Wednesday and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

headline: An Online Swap Meet Where Ids and Superegos Mingle
text: Some enterprising Brooklynite was clearly inspired on Friday afternoon to host a really good Memorial Day weekend barbecue  the best kind of barbecue, in fact, the kind someone else pays for.

headline: Mexico’s War Against Drugs Kills Its Police
text: MEXICO CITY  The assassination was an inside job. The federal police commander kept his schedule secret and slept in a different place each night, yet the killer had the keys to the official’s apartment and was waiting for him when he arrived after midnight.

headline: Dick Martin, the Laid-Back Half of the ‘Laugh-In’ Duo, Is Dead at 86
text: Dick Martin, a veteran nightclub comic who with his partner, Dan Rowan, turned a midseason replacement slot at NBC in 1968 into a hit that redefined what could be done on television, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Malibu, Calif.

headline: This Is Funny Only if You Know Unix
text: FOR a certain subset of Internet users, “Sudo make me a sandwich” may as well be “Take my wife ... please.”

headline: In Game of Keep-Away, Northwestern Wins Title
text: TOWSON, Md.   It was slow, it was careful and it made history. Northwestern did all the right things Sunday night in frustrating and beating Pennsylvania, 10-6, to win its fourth consecutive N.C.A.A. women’s lacrosse title.

headline: Forecast: Dance With a Chance of Wit
text: It’s a little dangerous to call your company the Chase Brock Experience. It implies that an experience will be had. And that the said experience will somehow involve a quintessential Chase Brock-ness.

headline: Russia Triumphs at Eurovision Contest
text: Russia basked in joy on Sunday after Dima Bilan won that country’s first Eurovision Song Contest victory with a performance in English of the ballad “Believe,” produced by the American rapper Timbaland and written by Jim Beanz, another American, Agence France-Presse reported. More than 100 million television viewers worldwide watched the finale in Belgrade, Serbia, on Saturday as the 26-year-old Mr. Bilan, performing, above center, with Edvin Marton, left, and Evgeni Plushenko, received 272 points from voters in 43 countries, defeating Ani Lorak of Ukraine (230) and Kalomira of Greece (218). Mr. Bilan’s victory was hailed by President Dmitri A. Medvedev and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin. In a congratulatory message, Mr. Putin said, “This is not just a personal success for Dima Bilan but also another triumph for the whole of Russia.”

headline: Tip From Tiger: 2 Tees
text: Tiger Woods recently said his rehabilitation after knee surgery was going well enough that he had been able to work on his short game. You know that means a lot of putting. Here’s a practice drill I saw him do as he warmed up at last year’s Deutsche Bank Championship:

headline: Mr. Bush and the G.I. Bill
text: President Bush opposes a new G.I. Bill of Rights. He worries that if the traditional path to college for service members since World War II is improved and expanded for the post-9/11 generation, too many people will take it.

headline: Helping Israel Help Itself
text: To the Editor:

headline: Divided They Stand
text: It is, in a way, almost appropriate that the final days of the struggle for the Democratic nomination have been marked by yet another fake Clinton scandal  the latest in a long line that goes all the way back to Whitewater.

headline: For Women Warriors, Deep Wounds, Little Care
text: THIS Memorial Day, as an ever-increasing number of mentally and physically wounded soldiers return from Iraq, the Department of Veterans Affairs faces a pressing crisis: women traumatized not only by combat but also by sexual assault and harassment from their fellow service members. Sadly, the department is failing to fully deal with this problem.

headline: Health Risks Hiding in the Grass
text: Kicking off your shoes?

headline: O.K., People, Shake Those Hairy Swimsuits
text: At the start of “Champions of Dance: Make Millions!,” the choreographer Ashley Byler walks carefully into the studio space, hesitantly pushes back a curtain hiding a mirror and smooths an eyebrow.

headline: After Years of Turmoil, Newsday Prepares for Another Owner
text: Not so long ago, Newsday belonged to the front rank of American journalism. It reached far beyond its original role as chronicler of Long Island, covered news worldwide, undertook big reporting projects and even had the audacity to take on the New York City market.

headline: Beyond the Bossa Nova, Into a Realm of Reverie
text: Rosa Passos, the great Brazilian singer, has a pristine, delicate voice, and she puts it to spellbinding use. At the Allen Room on Friday night, she sang a number of sumptuous ballads in such a way that their melodies seemed lighted from within. She also flirted with samba, adopting a translucently airy cadence. Her concert was a study in small gestures and subtle touches, and she made it feel both natural and special.

headline: Closings for Memorial Day
text: The holiday, actually May 30, will be observed on Monday.

headline: Clinton Could Face an Uneasy Return to the Senate
text: WASHINGTON  When Hillary Rodham Clinton made a rare stop in the Senate last week, she spoke from a lonely outpost at the end of the Armed Services Committee dais, eight empty chairs emphasizing the gulf between her and real Senate power at the chairman’s spot.

headline: Dick Martin, ‘Laugh-In’ Host, Dies at 86
text: Dick Martin, a veteran nightclub comic who with his partner, Dan Rowan, turned a midseason replacement slot at NBC in 1968 into a hit that redefined what could be done on television, died Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Malibu, Calif.

headline: China Struggles to Shelter Millions of Quake’s Homeless
text: Two weeks after a powerful earthquake devastated parts of southwest China, the government is struggling to deal with a crisis that has left up to five million people homeless.

headline: Weeks After Cyclone in Myanmar, Even Farmers Wait for Food
text: PYAPON, Myanmar  The roads of the ravaged Irrawaddy Delta are lined these days with people hoping to be fed.

headline: Errant Throw Clears the Way for a Rare Comeback
text: Lying on the grass in the park on a sunny spring day is not supposed to be miserable. Tell that to J. J. Putz of the Seattle Mariners.

headline: Orphan Artworks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Modernism, Rapid-Fire or Dreamy
text: The word has been out for decades now: The bug-eyed monster of musical modernism is vanquished. Try telling that to the young, accomplished members of the Xanthos Ensemble of Boston, which came to Roulette in SoHo on Saturday night with a program featuring works by three uncompromising modernists: Pierre Boulez, Mario Davidovsky and Charles Wuorinen. And in the hands of musicians so copiously skilled and confident, this undeniably challenging music had genuine appeal.

headline: Opera Meets Animation to Tell a Chinese Tale
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The opening scene is a vast cartoon, projected on a scrim, with viewers zooming past clouds and mountain peaks to an egg, which falls, bursts and gives birth to Monkey. The scrim goes up, and the cartoon dissolves into a stage full of flipping acrobats, a monkey tribe flying from bamboo pole to bamboo pole. The score pulsates with an electronic beat.

headline: Manuel Marulanda, Top Commander of Colombia’s Largest Guerrilla Group, Is Dead
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Manuel Marulanda, the guerrilla tactician whose rise from peasant origins to top commander of Latin America’s largest rebel group was a mythical feature of Colombia’s long internal war, died on March 26 in a mountainous hideout in the Meta department in central Colombia. He was believed to be 76 years old.

headline: Valencia reviews ‘land grab’ laws; Surfers buying in Britain; actor Tom Conti talks houses
text: Headlines from the world of property:

headline: Still on the road
text: I won’t be able to post much for a while. But I have a suspicion that many people will have something to say about today’s column. So please put your comments here.

headline: Welcome to the Long, Hot Summer
text: Try to keep cool.

headline: ‘He Said Hillary Could Still Win’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Bringing Up Bison
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: The Toughest Mare
text: Let me introduce you to a horse that makes all the earlier debate about whether fillies can run against colts look just a little silly. Meet Princesse D’Anjou, a 7-year-old thoroughbred mare who on Sunday won the Grand Steeplechase de Paris for the second time. The event at Auteuil racecourse in Paris is the premiere steeplechase on the Continent, covering 5,800 meters, or just over three and a half miles, with 369,000 euros, or $582,000, going to the winner.

headline: The Early Word:  Memorial Day Edition
text: With the Memorial Day holiday as a backdrop, the presidential candidates are on the road in key areas today, with issues like veterans health care and the war in Iraq still themes on and off the campaign trail.

headline: Lessons in Quarter Cracks
text: This is from Ian McKinlay, Big Brown’s hoof specialist. He has posted an example of a quarter crack. It is not, however, Big Brown’s injury. McKinlay and Big Brown’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, remain confident the problem will be cleared up very soon.

headline: ‘His Senior Advisers?’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Hey, good news for John McCain. He announced this week he had his best fund-raising month ever — $18.5 million. That, plus what he gets from Social Security.

headline: Sacrifice, Security, and the Road Toward 9 Billion
text: I’m pausing to reflect on Memorial Day, which commemorates those who gave their lives in military service for the United States. Here’s a little background, in music and words, on Arlington National Cemetery, which was created in 1864 and now is slowly running out of room. Several years ago, I wrote a song about Arlington, performed by the band I’m in, Uncle Wade (I’m not sure I could be a journalist if I didn’t have music, too):

headline: Good Times, Bad Times
text: I’m writing this in a scant spare minute in Bordeaux, where I’ve parachuted in for a whirlwind weekend touring Pessac-Léognan and Graves. It’s a land of haves and have-nots, where I’ve seen both vineyards that have succumbed to neglect because the owners no longer had the money or energy to care for them and grand chateaux restored in full opulent detail by the prosperous elite. Incidentally, plenty of job opportunities must exist in chateau restoration as it seems to be a never-ending Bordeaux phenomenon.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Cast Parties
A Short History of the Met Mile
text: Teresa Genaro at brooklynbackstretch looks at a major race in New York, the Met Mile, which will be run for the 115th time on Monday at Belmont Park.

headline: SEED House Energy Saving Cheap Fixes List
The Obama Campaign in Transition
text: While he cannot yet declare himself the Democratic nominee, Barack Obama has largely turned his attention to John McCain.

headline: FIFA Suspends Iraq
text: FIFA announced today that it has suspended Iraq from all international soccer competitions for one year after last week’s decision by the Iraqi government to dissolve its national Olympic committee. Iraq was already facing a suspension from the International Olympic Committee that could prevent its athletes from going to Beijing.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, May 26:

headline: The Olympics and Darfur
text: Joey Cheek, the gold medalist speed skater and founder of Team Darfur, has a powerful essay in The Washington Post today, calling on Olympians to use their spotlight to push the case for Darfur. He doesn’t want a boycott, and he’s sensitive to the Chinese desire to host a great event, but he does want people to pressure China and the international community to put Darfur on the top of the international agenda.

headline: Iraq Briefing
text: A sample of Iraq-related articles in the news on Memorial Day.

headline: The Bunker Is Feeling Better Than the Memorial Cup
text: This just in: the Memorial Cup is not built for sharing. Just ask the Spokane Chiefs.

headline: The Morning Skate: Adjustments, Viewers, Memorials and Bettman vs. Dylan
text: Marc-Andre Fleury practiced his entrance yesterday so he could avoid doing this again.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 95 Arkansas State
text: Location: Jonesboro, Ark.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Dance of Two Worlds, Different Yet Vaguely Similar
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Nice contrast Sunday night at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., although one’s imagination could conjure up a similarity.

headline: The Starting Line: More Aftershocks, in China and Elsewhere
text: The grim aftermath of the Sichuan earthquake wears on, with the death toll now officially above 65,000 and a strong aftershock Sunday killing at least 8 and injuring as many as 1,000 more.

headline: The Team That Changed Lacrosse
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — At halftime of today’s national title game between Syracuse and Johns Hopkins, the N.C.A.A. will be honoring the 25th anniversary of Syracuse’s first national title. Players from the 1983 Orange will be trotted out at halftime, introduced and given their moment to wave to the crowd on this most resplendent spring day.

headline: Big Brown Healing
text: The trainer Rick Dutrow and the hoof specialist Ian McKinlay are encouraged by Big Brown’s recovery from a slight quarter crack, which is a stress fracture in the hoof, and they are not concerned that Big Brown will miss the Belmont Stakes on June 7.

headline: Jihad vs. Jihad
text: Terror | High-profile jihadists in the Muslim world are now criticizing Al Qaeda for targeting civilians. Two leading magazines feature “Dr. Fadl,” a central Qaeda figure whose writings were once used to indoctrinate recruits. He’s since published a book from prison repudiating the terrorist group. — New Yorker and New Republic.

headline: McCain Defends Stances on War and Veterans
text: ALBUQUERQUE — In a Memorial Day speech to veterans and their families here, Senator John McCain kept alive a debate about a new G.I. bill making its way through Congress, which he opposes, arguing that his own counter-proposal would be better for the military.

headline: 'At the Death House Door'
text: Video clips from the documentary on the Independent Film Channel.

headline: The Person Behind ‘The Paper’
text: New York Times: Meet Amanda Lorber, a subject and the unexpected star of the MTV reality series “The Paper.” “She became a role model to some viewers, an inadvertent villain to others and a case study in the perils that a young person faces when she becomes a reality-television star before she is old enough to vote,” Dave Itzkoff writes.

headline: Clinton Marks Memorial Day in Puerto Rico
text: BAYAMON, P.R. — Traditionally, Puerto Ricans have both served in the Armed Forces and died in combat in numbers disproportionate to their share of the population. So it rankles many on the island that, even as their sons and daughters are serving with distinction in Iraq and Afghanistan, they do not enjoy all of the same rights and privileges of citizenship as other Americans.

headline: The Ever-Rising Cost of Cable
text: Cable prices keep rising, and customers keep paying, Matt Richtel reported in Saturday’s New York Times.

headline: CNN, Newsweek Editor Starting International Show
text: “CNN is starting a weekly talk show on international issues led by Newsweek’s Fareed Zakaria that will debut next Sunday with former British Prime Minister Tony Blair as an interview subject,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Behind a Start-Up: One Family’s Choices
text: Many of the questions I get from readers have to do with money — specifically how people fund a career shift. I try to get these financial details as often as possible, and I recently heard from a reader, Nina Murphy, whose story of how her husband, Bart Ferris, left the corporate world to start a gourmet foods company with a partner touched on just this issue. It turns out that Ms. Murphy was a big part of the story herself since she is bringing her own skills to her husband’s venture by working as the company’s publicist. (Career reinvention is always a little easier with a supportive spouse in the wings. But that’s a subject for another post.) I asked Ms. Murphy to tell their story here in the blog, with a focus on how they managed the financial side of things. And now, I’ll leave it to Ms. Murphy:

headline: Oprah of the Masses
text: Oprah Winfrey’s audience is falling off, The Times reports today, but maybe what she’s losing in numbers is made up in, well, audience fervor. Or is that an understatement? You be the judge, as she announces her “favorite things” giveaway the other day:

headline: Congress Steps In
text: In light of recent, very public issues related to horse racing, Congress is beginning to take a closer look at the sport.

headline: U.S. vs. England: Pick Your Starting 11
text: Frankie Hejduk is back on the United States men’s national team 22-man roster, replacing Benny Feilhaber, for Wednesday’s friendly against England at Wembley Stadium in London. At 33, Hejduk is the team’s elder statesman.

headline: Lacrosse: Plenty to Talk About
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The crew is just about finished clearing the stands here at Gillette Stadium after the conclusion of the 2008 N.C.A.A. lacrosse tournament. Syracuse defeated Johns Hopkins, 13-10, and we figured we’d send you out with a few links before we leave the stadium.

headline: For Syracuse, A Victory With Feeling
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Sometimes things in sports transcend the final score, the statistic sheet and the midfield postgame celebration. Of all of the factors spurring Syracuse to the 2008 national lacrosse title with a 13-10 victory over Johns Hopkins on Monday, none may have loomed larger than the emotion of the team playing in honor of Aaron Guadagnolo.

headline: Belmont Update: 12 Days Away
text: Casino Drive, who after only two starts appears to be the strongest contender to upset Big Brown’s Triple Crown, is scheduled to have a work Wednesday. We will also learn Wednesday which jockey will be riding Casino Drive in the Belmont. Kent Desormeaux rode Casino Drive in his Peter Pan win, but he is Big Brown’s regular rider.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Racism Over?
text:
John McWhorter, left, of the Manhattan Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the problem of race for Barack Obama.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Decoding Oprah’s Ratings Declines
text: “The average audience for ‘The Oprah Winfrey Show’ has fallen nearly 7 percent this year, according to Nielsen Media Research — its third straight year of decline,” Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: On Cable: ‘Best Quarter Ever’
text: If executives at VH1 starred in their own reality show, they could call it “Best Quarter Ever.”

headline: Readers Respond to ‘Earthquake and Hope’
text: Nick’s recent column about China’s evolution toward greater freedom in the aftermath of the Sichuan earthquake generated numerous comments from Chinese readers. Some questioned the value of democracy for China, while others rallied to the defense of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao (温家宝). The support shown here for Mr. Wen is consistent with the outpouring of approval that can be found elsewhere on the Web, including Facebook and sites on the Chinese blogosphere. Readers’ response to the Communist Party was generally tempered, with neither heavy criticism nor praise for the government’s management of the earthquake and its handling of the news media.

headline: Castro Weighs In on Obama
text: Fidel Castro stepped aside as president of Cuba in February and has not been seen much since undergoing surgery in July 2006, but he is still very much a presence in the island nation he has turned over to his brother Raúl.

headline: Trump reportedly finds Russian buyer for his Florida estate
Third World Telecom Moves to the Front
text: The MTN Group, a small mobile operator in South Africa, attracted an investment in 1995 from SBC, an American telecommunications company. Now MTN is a sprawling company that spans 21 countries with 70 million customers, and it is attracting outside investors again.

headline: Lotus Therapy
text: The patient sat with his eyes closed, submerged in the rhythm of his own breathing, and after a while noticed that he was thinking about his troubled relationship with his father.

headline: Ex-Manager Tells of Bribery at Siemens
text: FRANKFURT  A former manager of Siemens, the European engineering company, testified Monday about an intricate system of slush funds and bribery at the company as the first trial on allegations of corporate corruption in Germany began.

headline: With Migrant Workers in Short Supply, a Farmer Looks to Machines
text: APPLETON, N.Y.  Scores of Jim Bittner’s cherry trees are now just heaps of roots and sticks, piled in his fields here along Route 18. Some of the branches lying on the ground are dotted with small blossoms, the season’s earliest evidence that sweet cherries were on their way. But for Mr. Bittner, having sweet cherries would have meant hiring someone to prune the trees and harvest the fruit, and he was not sure that he could do it this year. So he cut his trees down.

headline: Memo Pad
text: FARE INCREASES The six network airlines put in place another round of fare increases over the holiday, ranging up to $60 for a round-trip ticket, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of Farecompare.com. It was the 11th fare increase of the year that all six major carriers had joined in. Despite the wide-ranging fare increases, airlines have been “very cautious” about increasing fares on routes where there is competition from Southwest, JetBlue and other low-cost carriers, Mr. Seaney said. Additionally, he said, airlines are now frequently “firing out short-duration sales” on fares for certain routes, mostly to fill seats on off-peak business travel days.

headline: Glass and Rachmaninoff, With Percussion to Spare
text: The New York Youth Symphony closed its 45th season with what looked like a monster of a program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. Ryan McAdams, completing his first season as music director, devoted the first half of the program to a pair of contemporary percussion concertos by Lembit Beecher and Philip Glass, though only Mr. Glass called his piece a concerto explicitly. After intermission Mr. McAdams led his large ensemble of young instrumentalists (ages 12 to 22) in Rachmaninoff’s Second Symphony, a huge, broad-boned work full of structural pitfalls that must be overcome if the music is to sound coherent.

headline: The Running Mate Choice
text: My first thought on the running mate question is that to balance his ticket, Barack Obama should pick a really old white general. Therefore, he should pick Dwight Eisenhower. John McCain, on the other hand, needs to pick someone younger than himself. Therefore, he also should pick Dwight Eisenhower.

headline: Taiwanese Party Leader Visits Mainland China
text: HONG KONG  The chairman of Taiwan’s Nationalist Party left Monday for Beijing, the latest in a series of moves by officials on both sides of the Taiwan Straits to forge closer relations.

headline: Lakers’ G.M. Leaves the Drama in the Past
text: SAN ANTONIO  Kobe Bryant is smiling, his team is thriving and all of Los Angeles is back in full swoon for the Lakers. This might be a good time for Mitch Kupchak, the Lakers’ oft-maligned general manager, to exhale and perhaps take a figurative bow.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Deputy Managing Editor Jonathan Landman
text: Jonathan Landman, deputy managing editor of The New York Times, answered questions May 27-30, 2008.

headline: Glaciers in Antarctica May Be Releasing DDT Through Meltwater
text: Global use of the pesticide DDT has been sharply curtailed since the 1970s, so it’s natural to expect that over time, less of it would find its way into living creatures. And that has generally been the case: although many organisms still have detectable levels of DDT in fatty tissues, those levels have generally declined.

headline: Auto Industry Feels the Pain of Tight Credit
text: The auto industry is getting sideswiped by the housing crisis.

headline: Massive Floods May Have Formed Steep-Headed Canyons
text: With some canyons, it’s obvious how they formed: the river that is now at their base carved them over time. But the origin of others is less clear, particularly the kind that dead-end in steep headwalls, known as amphitheater-headed canyons.

headline: Spoleto U.S.A. Forecasts Higher Costs and Deficit
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The Spoleto Festival U.S.A., after a decade of economic health, has hit hard times.

headline: Taste for Quick Boost Tied to Taste for Risk
text: Health researchers have identified a surprising new predictor for risky behavior among teenagers and young adults: the energy drink.

headline: Spanish Company Buys Stake in Mexico Bank
text: Criteria CaixaCorp, the investment company owned by Spain’s biggest savings bank, agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank owned by the billionaire investor Carlos Slim, for 1.5 billion euros ($2.4 billion) to tap economic growth in Mexico. Criteria will pay 38.5 pesos ($3.71) a share for the holding, a premium of 8.6 percent above the Inbursa’s May 23 closing price, the Spanish company said Monday in a filing. Criteria, a unit of Barcelona-based La Caixa, which holds stakes in businesses worth about 24 billion euros, is buying the stock in Inbursa to diversify in a major Spanish-speaking country as the bank faces the increasing chance of a recession at home. The Mexican bank was set up in 1984 by Mr. Slim, the world’s second-richest man after Warren E. Buffett, according to Forbes magazine.

headline: Border Agents, Lured by the Other Side
text: SAN DIEGO  The smuggler in the public service announcement sat handcuffed in prison garb, full of bravado and shrugging off the danger of bringing illegal immigrants across the border.

headline: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Struggling, Jimmie Johnson Can Thank Sponsor
text: CONCORD, N.C.  Jimmie Johnson’s dominance at Lowe’s Motor Speedway used to raise suspicion among Nascar’s legion of conspiracy theorists. It was always just a little too coincidental for them that Johnson, who drives the No. 48 Lowe’s Chevrolet, won so often at a track with the same sponsor.

headline: Montana Dam Is Breached, Slowly, to Restore a Superfund Site
text: MILLTOWN, Mont.  Milltown Dam, a symbol of industrial progress that became a symbol of destruction, was recently breached, and two parts of the Clark Fork River were joined again.

headline: Risks: Study Ties Dirty Air to Blood Clots in Legs
text: Exposure to air pollution increases the risk for deep vein thrombosis, the blood clots that commonly occur in the leg veins. And the worse the air pollution, the higher the risk.

headline: Indy Jones Finds Gold at Global Box Office
