text: LOS ANGELES  The hard sell worked. “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” pushed by one of the biggest marketing campaigns in Hollywood history, sold an estimated $151.1 million in tickets in North American theaters over the five-day holiday weekend.

headline: Home as a Power Base and Balm to an Arid Heart
text: The vitamin-deficiency diseases, a longtime scourge in the impoverished corners of the world, are all but unknown in its well-nourished ones. The British novelist Margot Livesey, a shrewd diagnostician of Western mini-maladies, writes of two talented young women whose lives are malformed by what you might call emotional scurvy.

headline: $1.85 Fee to See a Doctor? Some Say It’s Too Much
text: PRAGUE  In the Czech Republic, you can now see a doctor for about $1.85. A day in the hospital can verge on $4. This is not cause for celebration.

headline: Experts Question Placebo Pill for Children
text: Jennifer Buettner was taking care of her young niece when the idea struck her. The child had a nagging case of hypochondria, and Ms. Buettner’s mother-in-law, a nurse, instructed her to give the girl a Motrin tablet.

headline: How a 2-Hour Flight Stretches Into 19
text: I’M a million-mile man. Despite all my flying time, I’ve had few mishaps. But the mishaps I’ve had are memorable.

headline: No Good News for Randolph as Mets Lose Again
text: A balmy breeze blew through Shea Stadium on Monday night, appropriate for Mets Manager Willie Randolph. Figuratively, he twisted slowly in the wind while his team lost to the Florida Marlins, 7-3, for its seventh defeat in eight games.

headline: Rockefellers Seek Change at Exxon
text: HOUSTON  The Rockefeller family built one of the great American fortunes by supplying the nation with oil. Now history has come full circle: some family members say it is time to start moving beyond the oil age.

headline: New Repellents Without DEET Show Promise in Tests on Humans
text: Researchers have found several new mosquito repellents that appear to work more than three times as long as DEET.

headline: Suddenly Without Stars, Belgian Tennis Fans Seek Someone to Cheer
text: PARIS  Out in the hinterlands at the French Open, Luc Vandaele, president of the Royal Belgian Tennis Federation, was trying and failing to get into the small grandstand in Court 8 to see his country’s best female player.

headline: Remind the Doctor
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Hot Seat With Room for Two
text: Infuriating as it plainly was for a proud, private man like Willie Randolph to hear his job status discussed as if he weren’t in the room, bristling as he was when he said, “I got to get on the field, man,” as the pregame news conference dragged on, the session was no Memorial Day picnic for Omar Minaya either.

headline: Talks Between United and US Airways Appear to Break Down
text: Talks between United Airlines and US Airways appear to have fallen apart, marking the second time in a month that United failed to reach a deal with a rival airline and putting the future of industry consolidation in question, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said Tuesday night.

headline: Governing Body Suspends Iraqi Soccer Association
text: BAGHDAD  Soccer’s world governing body suspended Iraq’s national soccer association on Monday, leaving the players on Iraq’s national team who had united a divided country fearing that they will not be able to participate in the 2010 World Cup.

headline: 2 American Soldiers Are Killed in Insurgent Attacks in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers were killed in Iraq over the weekend and early Monday, and a suicide bomber struck an American-backed Sunni militia just north of Baghdad, leaving two Iraqi police officers and three militia guards dead. A third soldier, identified only as being part of the American-led forces, was also killed Sunday in southern Iraq.

headline: Small Businesses on Discount
text: To all the usual reasons that small businesses are put up for sale  personal problems and personnel squabbles among them  add economic woes this year. But even as for-sale listings rise around the country, so is buyer interest.

headline: Those Singing Ice Dwellers (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Awash in Contributions, Campaigns Offer Tempting Targets for Thieves
text: In Republican circles, Christopher J. Ward was the go-to guy for politicians who needed help managing their campaign finances. As a staff member at the National Republican Congressional Committee and its treasurer since 2003, Mr. Ward was so valued that more than $360 million in donations to the committee passed through his hands  with few questions asked.

headline: Small-Business Books That Break the Mold
text: Books aimed at the small business and entrepreneur audience far too often fall into two categories.

headline: NASA Spacecraft Ready to Dig on Mars
text: PASADENA, Calif.  One day after a picture-perfect landing on Mars, NASA’s Phoenix lander seemed Monday to be in perfect health.

headline: Cigarettes and Addiction (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Artist Breathes New Life Into Renaissance Ways With Wood
text: On a recent spring morning, the artist Alison Elizabeth Taylor paced nervously around the second floor of an architectural woodworking firm in East Harlem, watching closely as three sinewy men prepared one of her delicate wood inlay compositions for the veneering press.

headline: Optimism Grows as Marines Push Against Taliban
text: GARMSER, Afghanistan  For two years British troops staked out a presence in this small district center in southern Afghanistan and fended off attacks from the Taliban. The constant firefights left it a ghost town, its bazaar broken and empty but for one baker, its houses and orchards reduced to rubble and weeds.

headline: Phone Giant in Germany Stirs a Furor
text: FRANKFURT  Germany was engulfed in a national furor over threats to privacy on Monday, after an admission by Deutsche Telekom that it had surreptitiously tracked thousands of phone calls to identify the source of leaks to the news media about its internal affairs.

headline: ‘Jewels’: Of Time and Non-Narrativity
text: For a work often described as the first full-length plotless ballet, George Balanchine’s “Jewels,” performed on Sunday by New York City Ballet, has plenty of pat explanations attached to it. These include its having been inspired by a visit to Van Cleef & Arpels, and representing, through the distinct sensibilities of each section, three different national styles of ballet.

headline: McCain Vows to Work With Russia on Arms
text: DENVER  Senator John McCain, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, distanced himself from the Bush administration on Tuesday by vowing to work more closely with Russia on nuclear disarmament and by calling for a reduction in tactical nuclear weapons in Europe.

headline: Asian Contemporary Art Sets a Record
text: “Mask Series 1996 No. 6,” above, a large oil-on-canvas diptych by the Chinese artist Zeng Fanzhi, sold for $9.7 million on Saturday at a Christie’s auction in Hong Kong, setting a record for Asian contemporary artwork, Reuters reported. The final price was more than triple the presale estimate of $1.9 million to $3.2 million. The piece depicts eight masked young people, arms linked, in what appears to be a friendly grouping. All of them are wearing red scarves reminiscent of Mao Zedong’s Communist guards, and the masks, each frozen in a grin, hide the emotion and identity of the characters beneath.

headline: Saliva and H.I.V.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Women Want to Wrestle; Small Colleges Oblige
text: Women’s wrestling teams are sprouting in the most unlikely places.

headline: 5 Men Are Killed in Separate Shootings in the Bronx
text: A 42-year-old man was killed after a family barbecue. A 51-year-old man was found shot in the head in a desolate spot people said they avoided after dark. They were but two of the five men killed during separate shootings in the Bronx over the long, warm holiday weekend, the police said.

headline: Randolph Is Still Mets’ Manager
text: When Mets Manager Willie Randolph sprinted onto the field for batting practice Monday, several dozens fans were behind the first-base dugout. One clapped. The others were silent. These days, Randolph is used to that kind of skeptical treatment.

headline: Bloomberg’s Temper
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tenants Roiled by Challenges on Residency
text: More than a year after buying Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan for a record-breaking $5.4 billion, Tishman Speyer Properties has accused hundreds of rent-stabilized tenants of living somewhere other than their apartments, a tactic that residents and their lawyers say is part of an aggressive attempt to drive out low-rent tenants to make way for high-rent ones.

headline: New DVDs: Action and Adventure
text: THE THIEF OF BAGDAD

headline: Curriculum Designed to Unite Art and Science
text: Senator Barack Obama likes to joke that the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination has been going on so long, babies have been born, and they’re already walking and talking.

headline: Hendrix on Display
text: An exhibition of the work of more than a dozen photographers who captured the rock star Jimi Hendrix between 1967 and 1970 will open on Thursday at the Celebrity Vault gallery in Beverly Hills. The show, “Hendrix Revealed: A Life through the Lens,” was presented in London earlier this year and has been organized in association with Raj Prem Fine Art Photography in London. A portion of proceeds from the opening-day sales will benefit the nonprofit arts organization Experience Music Project, in Seattle, where Hendrix was born. Among the images on display will be Ed Caraeff’s shot from the 1967 Monterey International Pop Music Festival of Hendrix setting fire to his Fender guitar.

headline: High Court Sets Date on Bell Canada Appeal
text: The Supreme Court of Canada said on Monday that it would accelerate its process to consider Bell Canada’s appeal of a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week. While the high court has yet to decide if it will hear Bell’s appeal, it issued a notice to both the company and its disgruntled bondholders indicating that June 17 is available for a hearing and setting a rapid timetable for filings. A Quebec appeals court sided with bondholders last week because Bell had not considered the impact of the buyout on their holdings. The buyout will add about 30 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in United States funds) in debt to the company, depressing the value of current bonds. Bell asked the court to rule by June 30, the closing date for the deal. The bondholders, in a separate court filing on Monday, rejected that idea and suggested that Bell and the buyout group, led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, should simply make the closing date later rather than expect the court to rush its decision.

headline: It’s the Genes, Stupid
text: Social scientists are stumped. Why do we bother to go to the polls when we know our individual vote has no chance of determining the result of a national election? Variations in turnout  by age, race, income or whatever  are hard to fit into a theory of human conduct that assumes that people are rational. But with time to spare before the November election, molecular biology is coming to the rescue. In the same way that researchers have teased out a role for genes in determining sexual orientation or the propensity to smoke, they are deploying genetics to understand our political choices.

headline: Eight Wounded in Harlem Shootings
text: Eight people were shot late Monday night along a stretch of Lenox Avenue north of 125th Street in Harlem, the police said.

headline: Learning How to Reflect (or Not)
text: A variety of meditative practices have been studied by Western researchers for their effects on mental and physical health.

headline: Mixed Outcomes in Laparoscopy for Prostates
text: Laparoscopic operations for prostate cancer, a minimally invasive surgery that is in rising demand, result in fewer immediate complications and quicker recovery than the more common open procedure, a new study reports. But the surgery increases the chance for longer term problems that require further therapy, the research says.

headline: Virginia Commonwealth’s Secret Deal
text: While most universities are struggling to ensure that any research supported by industry remains free of corporate control, it is shocking to find Virginia Commonwealth University going in the opposite direction. It has signed a contract to do research for Philip Morris that gives the company the final say over what results, if any, can be published.

headline: Soaring Fuel Prices Take a Withering Toll on Truckers
text: As his logging business expanded in the pine and hardwood forests of eastern Georgia, Jesse Hendley got into trucking. He scraped together the cash gradually to acquire seven tractor-trailers so that he could not only sell timber to mills in the south, but also charge the mills for delivery.

headline: An Advocate for Victims (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: G.O.P. Struggles to Replace a Favorite Son
text: Finding a candidate to replace Representative Vito J. Fossella, who will step down at the end of the year, is proving much harder than Republican Party leaders ever imagined.

headline: Turning Schools From Death Traps Into Havens
text: The potential for a modest school to survive a powerful earthquake is perhaps nowhere better illustrated than in Balakot, Pakistan, one of hundreds of communities near the border with India shattered by a devastating tectonic jolt on Oct. 8, 2005.

headline: Shuttle to Take Big Science Lab to Space Station
text: The space shuttle Discovery is set to deliver the International Space Station’s biggest room, in what its commander calls “a complicated, busy mission” that is scheduled to begin on Saturday.

headline: Cause of Fire at Berlin Philharmonic Is Found
text: German officials confirmed Monday that welding work was the cause of the recent fire at the Berlin Philharmonic’s landmark concert hall, The Associated Press reported. The fire broke out last Tuesday afternoon, just before a rehearsal was scheduled to begin, but there were neither injuries nor any serious damage to the structure or interior of the building, which is scheduled to reopen on June 2.

headline: The Torture Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Currency and the Blind
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. National Soccer Team Enters a Busy Season
text: The two-month hiatus for the United States men’s national team ends Wednesday, when Coach Bob Bradley takes the team to the sport’s rebuilt cathedral, Wembley Stadium in London, for a friendly match against England.

headline: Minnelli in London
text: Liza Minnelli performed at the London Coliseum on Sunday, marking the start of her first British concert tour in more than two decades. The audience thanked her with six standing ovations, The Times of London reported, which was all the more remarkable considering that the concert was nearly canceled. Ms. Minnelli, right, 62, was detained at Heathrow Airport in London on Saturday, when she and her entourage arrived following an appearance in Moscow last week. She did not have the proper work permit, The Daily Mail reported, and the British authorities told Ms. Minnelli she would have to cancel her Sunday concert. The British Home Office eventually smoothed things over, and she appeared on schedule. After her performance in London on Tuesday, Ms. Minnelli will sing in Nottingham, Manchester, Birmingham and Glasgow before heading on June 20 to Los Angeles, where she will be inducted into the Hollywood Bowl Hall of Fame.

headline: The Frenzy for Campaign Money
text: The power of money in politics has never been more pronounced or problematical as it is in this year’s presidential campaign  the costliest in the nation’s history.

headline: Syracuse Captures Lacrosse Title
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Syracuse men’s lacrosse program hit a generational low a year ago. The Orange, a perennial juggernaut, failed to make the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1982, and the team’s direction was uncertain.

headline: In Myanmar, Loss, Grief and, for Some, Resignation
text: THAT KYAR, Myanmar  One of Daw Then Khin’s grandsons has gone insane. He wanders day and night through the fields looking for his wife and son, both swept away by the furious floodwaters that came with the cyclone.

headline: Fast-Food Chain Advises Consumers to ‘Get Culverized’
text: Editors’ Note: This issue of In Advertising is coming to you today because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

headline: Helping Prisoners Re-enter Society
text: To the Editor:

headline: MTV’s Unscripted Show May Get a Dose of Gritty Brooklyn Reality
text: There is reality, like the reality-check, wake-up-call kind, the sorry-but-them’s-the-breaks kind, and there is “reality,” the kind in reality shows. The two may be sharing screen time this summer in “The Real World,” the great-grandfather of reality shows, filming in Brooklyn.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, referrred incorrectly to the length of her hair, which friends said she often did not curl until she was at work because she had risen so early to open the shop. Her hair was short, not long.

headline: Summer Entertainment in Bryant Park
text: Once again Bryant Park will provide a summer setting not only for lunchtime getaways or a chess game, but also for film and theater events. The HBO Bryant Park Summer Film Festival is to begin on June 16 with a screening of “Dr. No” (1962), the first James Bond film, starring Sean Connery, below. Subsequent Mondays will bring screenings of “Bride of Frankenstein,” “The Man Who Came to Dinner” and “Superman,” among others. Each week the lawn will open at 5 p.m. for blanket placement and picnics, and the film will start at dusk. For theater lovers, the annual Broadway in Bryant Park series, presented by the radio station 106.7 Lite FM, will be back for the seventh year, offering lunchtime concerts by cast members from Broadway and Off Broadway shows. The first show this year, on July 10, will include performances from “Chicago,” “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” “Cry-Baby” and “Stomp.” The series runs consecutive Thursdays through Aug. 14, from 12:30 to 1:30 p.m. The full schedules for both series are at bryantpark.org.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Julie Bertrand and Barbara Gillespie joined Concentric Pharma Advertising, New York, as group art supervisors. Both had worked at Draft FCB Healthcare, New York, part of the Draft FCB unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, where Ms. Bertrand had been a senior art director and Ms. Gillespie an art supervisor.

headline: BPA Plastic
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Blames Russia for Downed Drone
text: MOSCOW  A United Nations investigation has concluded that a remotely piloted Georgian reconnaissance aircraft that was destroyed last month was struck by an air-to-air missile fired from a Russian fighter jet.

headline: The Working Wounded
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: When Hostility Melted for the ‘Funny Accent’
text: It was 1:06 in the morning when I got the call from the emergency room. An 82-year-old required admission. Severe anemia. Stool test positive for blood.

headline: Atomic Monitor Signals Concern Over Iran’s Work
text: PARIS  The International Atomic Energy Agency, in an unusually blunt and detailed report, said Monday that Iran’s suspected research into the development of nuclear weapons remained “a matter of serious concern” and that Iran continued to owe the agency “substantial explanations.”

headline: Memorial Day Draws Two Messages on Iraq
text: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  Senator John McCain stood before hundreds of flag-waving veterans and their families on Monday and vowed not to waver in his support of the Iraq war. “Even,” he said, “if I must stand athwart popular opinion.”

headline: Vancouver Museum Reopens After Theft
text: The University of British Columbia’s Museum of Anthropology, in Vancouver, reopened Monday following an incident on Saturday, when a dozen works by the Canadian artist Bill Reid were stolen, The Globe and Mail and The Calgary Herald reported. Since most of the works are sculptures made from gold, museum authorities and the artist’s widow, Martine  Reid died in 1998  expressed concern that the thieves would melt the figures in order to cash in on the precious metal. “These pieces are Canadian treasures and belong to the Canadian people,” Jim Storie, the chairman of the Bill Reid Trust, said in a statement. “They’re all priceless.” Reid, who produced around 1,500 works, helped to popularize Canadian native art, and his work appears on the Canadian $20 bill.

headline: De-emphasis on Race in Adoption Is Criticized
text: WASHINGTON  Minority children in foster care are being ill-served by a federal law that plays down race and culture in adoptions, a report released on Tuesday said.

headline: At Yale, Another Honorific for Sir Paul
text: The former Beatle Paul McCartney, 65, was awarded an honorary doctor of music degree from Yale University at its commencement festivities Monday, The Associated Press reported. On Sunday the former British prime minister Tony Blair spoke at the university’s Class Day, advising students to “be prepared to fail as well as to succeed, and realize it is failure, not success, that defines character,” The Yale Daily News reported. “Sir Paul McCartney reminded me that the first record company the Beatles approached rejected them as a band no one would want to listen to,” Mr. Blair added, foreshadowing Mr. McCartney’s honor. Other recipients of honorary degrees on Monday included the former United States trade representative Carla Hills, the astronomer Martin Rees, the architect Cesar Pelli and the poet John Ashbery.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Treasures of a Nation, Not Fodder for an Ad
text: MEXICO CITY  Eager to bolster tourism, Hidalgo State came up with a novel idea: an advertising campaign featuring a well-known actress wearing Hidalgo’s most eye-popping sites on her flesh.

headline: Big Brown Could Return to Training Regimen Today
text: Big Brown’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, and the hoof specialist Ian McKinlay are encouraged by the colt’s recovery from a slight quarter crack (or stress fracture) on the inside of his left front hoof, and they say they are not concerned that Big Brown could miss the Belmont Stakes on June 7.

headline: Convicted Gambler Whose Lawyer Is His Son
text: Father and son shared little in common. There were no Little League games, no backpacking trips, no going to the movies together. The father, Raymond Marquez, was just too busy.

headline: China Mobile’s Shares Fall 8% in Hong Kong Trading
text: China Mobile, which counts more than two-thirds of the nation’s mobile phone users as customers, lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition. The shares fell 8.2 percent to close at 114.90 Hong Kong dollars ($14.93), the biggest drop in more than six years. China’s two biggest fixed-line companies will also provide wireless services under the government plan announced Saturday, threatening China Mobile’s dominance of a market with 583.5 million customers. “The government wants to balance the telecom industry instead of having just one dominant player,” said Teresa Chow, who helps manage $1.1 billion at RBC Investment Management Asia in Hong Kong, including China Mobile shares.

headline: Justices Favor Workers in Cases of Bias Retaliation
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday adopted a broad reading of two federal civil rights laws to protect employees from retaliation when they complain about discrimination in the workplace.

headline: Footnotes
text: Musical theater fans should take note: The original cast recordings of the Broadway production of “A Catered Affair” (PS Classics) and the current Lincoln Center revival of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s South Pacific” (Sony Classics) are to be released Tuesday. ... Tuesday night’s guests at Comic Book Club, the weekly talk show that takes place onstage at the People’s Improv Theater in Chelsea at 8 p.m., will include the comedian Selena Coppock and the comic artist Joe Infurnari, creator of “The Process” (theprocesscomic.com). Tickets for the event are $5 each (popcultureshock.com/cbclub).

headline: Lauder Steps Down as Whitney Museum Chairman
text: After 14 years in the post, Leonard A. Lauder stepped down on Tuesday as chairman of the board of trustees at the Whitney Museum of American Art. He remains a trustee and the chairman emeritus, with full voting rights.

headline: The Trouble With June 1992 as a Case for Pressing On
text: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told The Argus Leader of Sioux Falls, S.D., last week that efforts to “push” her out of the race before all the nominating contests were over was “unprecedented,” she offered a few historical references to support her argument.

headline: Verizon and the City: Digital Package (and Delays) Appear to Be Near
text: Michael and Susan Slutsky, who live with their two daughters in Tarrytown, N.Y., canceled Cablevision about two years ago when Verizon, which already provided their phone line, entered the television market in town. Last year, when their contract with AT&T for four cellphones expired, the Slutskys switched to Verizon Wireless, too, getting 10 percent off the monthly bill.

headline: Trying Again on a Coast That Defies Big Dreams
text: PACIFIC BEACH, Wash.  Big Bold Dream No. 1 arrived on the cloudy coast of Washington State in 1905. It was called the Moclips Beach Hotel, 270 grand rooms at its peak, with a railroad depot and waves crashing beyond the veranda. Then the ocean washed it all away.

headline: Prevention: Breast-Feeding Protects Against Arthritis
text: A Swedish study suggests yet another health advantage of breast-feeding, this time for the mother: it reduces the risk of rheumatoid arthritis.

headline: A Mind Geared to Physics, a Profile Set for Prime Time
text: It’s tempting to applaud “João Magueijo’s Big Bang,” a special on the Science Channel on Tuesday night, simply for existing. How often is an hour of prime-time television devoted to making the case for a radical but legitimate theory of cosmology?

headline: Mozart’s Soothing Sinfonia (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roads, High and Low
text: On Friday morning, Joe Biden gave us an example of a leading national politician exhibiting decency and class. Later in the day, Hillary Clinton gave us an example of something else.

headline: At World’s End, Honing a Father-Son Dynamic
text: ERIE, Pa.  Cormac McCarthy’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Road,” takes place in a world that, because of some unexplained catastrophe, has just about ended. The sky is gray, the rivers are black, and color is just a memory. The landscape is covered in ash, with soot falling perpetually from the air. The cities are blasted and abandoned. The roads are littered with corpses either charred or melted, their dreams, Mr. McCarthy writes, “ensepulchred within their crozzled hearts.”

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Wednesday about cutbacks in airline service to American cities erroneously included a city among those where scheduled service disappeared in the last year. New Haven, Conn., does indeed have regularly scheduled service. (US Airways has flights at Tweed New Haven Regional Airport.) The article also described incorrectly Myrtle Beach DirectAir’s thrice-weekly service at Plattsburgh, N.Y. The airline offers service to South Carolina, not North Carolina.

headline: The Bullpen’s Ineffectiveness Costs the Yankees and Rasner
text: BALTIMORE  In Darrell Rasner’s 21 major league games, few players have rattled him as thoroughly as the Baltimore Orioles’ Nick Markakis. Rasner had faced him only eight times before Monday’s game, but on seven of those occasions, Markakis wound up with a base hit.

headline: Scientists Document Bustling Community Far Below Ocean Floor
text: The lost civilization of Atlantis may just be legend, but way down below the ocean (to quote the folksinger Donovan) there are some things that are very real  namely, bacteria and archaea. By some estimates, sub-seafloor prokaryotes may account for two-thirds of the biomass of these types of organisms on Earth.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: Mars Lander Transmits Photos of Arctic Terrain
text: PASADENA, Calif.  The first pictures sent back by NASA’s Phoenix Mars lander from the northern arctic plains of Mars show a flat terrain marked by a polygonal pattern of shallow troughs and a few pebbles scattered about.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Saturday about Cindy McCain’s release of a summary of her 2006 income taxes misstated the greatest amount of income Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, reported in the seven years of tax returns they have released. It was $4.2 million in 2007, not $1.7 million in 2005.

headline: Jewish Voters and Barack Obama
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Court and on the Trail, One Aide Looms Over Obama
text: In the last year, Barack Obama has learned a thing or two about running for president, and Reggie Love has learned a thing or two about Barack Obama.

headline: Sydney Pollack, Director of High-Profile Hollywood Movies, Is Dead at 73
text: LOS ANGELES  Sydney Pollack, a Hollywood mainstay as director, producer and sometime actor whose star-laden movies like “The Way We Were,” “Tootsie” and “Out of Africa” were among the most successful of the 1970s and ’80s, died Monday at home here. He was 73.

headline: Mating Midges
text: Q. In May, near the Jerome Park Reservoir in the Bronx, my sister and I observed individual flies that sometimes clumped together in large swarms, which seemed to be attracted to people and animals passing by. The swarms then dissipated briefly, only to re-form. What kind of fly acts this way? Why are they swarming?

headline: The Claim: Dust Mites Make Allergies Worse
text: THE FACTS

headline: UBS Foresees More Subprime-Related Losses
text: UBS, the European bank hardest hit by the collapse of the subprime housing market in the United States, fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday after it said it may face more losses from mortgage securities. UBS declined 5.8 percent to 28.20 francs in Zurich, and has dropped 43 percent this year, cutting its market value to 61.4 billion francs ($59.9 billion). UBS, in a prospectus for a 16 billion-franc rights offer to shareholders, said the bank’s losses on residential and commercial real-estate securities outside the United States “could increase in the future.” UBS is seeking to replenish capital after about $38 billion in write-downs related to the subprime crisis.

headline: Thirty-Five Years of Rockefeller ‘Justice’
text: Enacted in 1973, New York’s Rockefeller drug laws penalized some first-time drug offenders more severely than murderers. Named for Nelson Rockefeller, who was governor at the time, the laws tied the hands of judges and mandated lengthy sentences for young offenders who often deserved a second chance. The laws, which were supposed to ensnare “kingpins,” have filled the prisons with drug addicts who would have been better dealt with through treatment programs. They also undermined faith in the fairness of the justice system by singling out poor and minority offenders while exempting wealthy ones.

headline: Taiwan: More Talks With Beijing
text: Wu Poh-Hsiung, the chairman of Taiwan’s Nationalist Party, began a six-day visit to the Chinese mainland intended to lay the groundwork for detailed talks on more charter flights across the Taiwan Strait and more mainland tourists on Taiwan.

headline: Amid Tremors, a City Trembles With Dread
text: CHENGDU, China  The teahouses are nearly empty, travel agents sit beside silent telephones and shopkeepers pass the day watching the continuing agony of their countrymen on television. The buildings in this usually teeming city of 10 million, about 50 miles east of the epicenter of the May 12 earthquake, may be unscathed, but its residents are living on edge.

headline: Rules for Reservoirs Pose Threat to Trout Population
text: HANCOCK, N.Y.  The West Branch of the Delaware River, when in good shape, is one of the great trout streams of North America. Like the more renowned Missouri and Henry’s Fork of Montana and Idaho, it is a tailwater fishery; that is, it owes its remarkable fecundity and its population of big wild trout to the cold-water outflow of reservoir impoundment.

headline: More Travelers, Costlier Oil and More Commotion
text: THE airlines are running out of ways to squeeze money out of passengers, now that they have jacked up fares all year and slapped extra charges on checked bags.

headline: Hezbollah Leader Plays Down Group’s Political Aims in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah’s leader sought to reassure the Lebanese about the Shiite militant group’s intentions in a speech on Monday, saying that its newly expanded political clout will not translate into greater control over the state, and that its top priority remains the fight against Israel.

headline: Myanmar Detention Overshadowed
text: BANGKOK  Almost lost in the clamor over Myanmar’s devastating cyclone, the house arrest of the charismatic pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, reaches a deadline for its annual renewal on Tuesday.

headline: 2 Colleges End Entrance Exam Requirement
text: Smith College, a women’s college in Northampton, Mass., and Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., will no longer require prospective students to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of their applications.

headline: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Threatens to Expel U.S. Envoy
text: President Robert Mugabe threatened to expel the American ambassador, William McGee, who has been outspoken about state-sponsored violence against the opposition party. Mr. Mugabe accused Mr. McGee of meddling in the country’s internal affairs and said, “Tall as he is, if he continues doing that, I will kick him out,” according to the state-run newspaper, The Herald. On Sunday, eight men carrying AK-47s intercepted a delivery of 60,000 copies of The Zimbabwean, a newspaper that opposes the president, and burned the newspapers, The Zimbabwean reported on its Web site.

headline: Emily Gould Responds to Readers
text: The author responds to readers' questions and comments on blogging about your private life. (Go to Original Article)

headline: At Center, BMXers Are Part of Team
text: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  Mike King started racing BMX bikes in 1975, 30 years before anyone envisioned the sport’s becoming part of the Olympics.

headline: Patterns: Vomiting Raises Risk of Irregular Periods
text: Teenage girls who vomit one to three times a month to control weight increase their risk of having irregular menstrual periods by 60 percent, a new study reports; those who vomit once a week or more triple their risk. When researchers restricted the analysis only to girls of normal weight, the association was even stronger.

headline: Contractors Are Kept Busy Maintaining Abandoned Homes
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The house on East 24th Street was the worst of the six that David Law and Trey McCallister worked on the other day here. The front door had been kicked in so many times that the dead bolt was exposed and bent. Trash littered the front and back yards. A copper pipe was gone.

headline: Lure of Olympics Prompts Return of a BMX Star
text: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  When Jill Kintner left BMX racing six years ago, she never planned to come back. She finished the 2002 season with typical dominance, adding a national pro title and a world championship to a racing résumé filled with more than 70 career wins.

headline: Red Flags for Hereditary Cancers
text: All cancers are genetic in origin. When genes are working properly, cell growth is tightly regulated, as if a stoplight told cells to divide only so many times and no more. A cancer occurs when something causes a mutation in the genes that limit cell growth or that repair DNA damage.

headline: Republican Senate Candidates in New Jersey Want You to Know Their Names
text: TRENTON  Depending on whom you ask, this is a story about Maverick Murray, Jersey Joe and the Liberal Loser Lobbyist. Others regard it simply as the Republican primary to choose a candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Saturday about Michel Fournier, the retired French army officer with plans to sky dive from a balloon gondola 25 miles above the earth’s surface, misstated the point during his journey at which he expects to experience weightlessness, and it misstated the altitude at which his parachute was designed to open. He would experience weightlessness during descent, not while in the balloon’s gondola. And his parachute is designed to open at around 5,000 feet, not 20,000 feet.

headline: Antiquities, the World Is Your Homeland
text: To what culture does the concept of “cultural property” belong? Who owns this idea?

headline: His Life With the Deaths That the State Carried Out
text: A lonely field of concrete crosses, engraved with dates and numbers and surrounded by weeds, is the first thing a viewer sees in the film “At the Death House Door.” Some of the graves in that field belong to inmates who were executed by the state at the prison in Huntsville, Tex.

headline: Some Pitfalls of Genetic Testing
text: The deciphering of the human genome has prompted a number of entrepreneurs to cash in on people’s genetic concerns. They offer DNA testing to look for aberrant genes associated with the risk of developing various diseases, especially cancer.

headline: One-Child Policy Lifted for Quake Victims’ Parents
text: CHENGDU, China  In response to inquiries from grieving relatives, local officials announced Monday that parents whose only child was killed or grievously injured in the May 12 earthquake would be exempt from the country’s one-child policy.

headline: In Move to Digital TV, Some Will Be Left Behind
text: NEARLY 25 million homes have at least one television set that will stop functioning in nine months, when the nation converts to digital over-the-air television.

headline: 8 Are Wounded in Shootings in Harlem
text: Eight people were shot and wounded late Monday night in Harlem, the police said. Most of the victims were found along a stretch of Lenox Avenue north of 125th Street.

headline: More Surgery Is Planned for Paterson, Official Says
text: After a painful eye ailment sent him to the hospital last week and led to two operations, Gov. David A. Paterson plans to have additional surgery this summer to remove a cataract from his left eye, his office said on Monday.

headline: S.E.C. Backs Health Care Balloting
text: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission, shifting its position, has told companies they must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal for universal health insurance coverage.

headline: U. Utah Phillips, Folk Troubadour, Dies at 73
text: Bruce Duncan Phillips, the itinerant folk singer, songwriter, storyteller and social activist who jokingly called himself U. Utah Phillips, “the Golden Voice of the Great Southwest,” died on Friday at his home in Nevada City, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Time Ebbs for the Heroes Who Saved the Harbor
text: His best day? For Seymour Wittek, it was the day he met the girl he would marry. There have been other significant days over his 87 years  when children were born and new jobs were begun, when grandchildren came along. One October day last year, death claimed Anne Wittek, his wife of 64 years. That was a most important day.

headline: Choreographers Intensely Personal and Absolutely Not
text: As titles of dance programs go, “Male Bonding” is pretty catchy. But this two-part event presented by the La MaMa Moves! festival had little to do with any affinities between the impressive lineup of choreographers taking part. Instead it showed a rich variety of intention and approach, from technically sophisticated to almost dance-free, intensely personal to determinedly neutral.

headline: Obama’s Likes and Dislikes: Hold the Mayo
text: As Senator Barack Obama’s body man, Reggie Love makes sure the candidate has plenty of the things he likes  and makes note of those things he would rather avoid. Here is a partial list, provided by Mr. Love.

headline: Polishing for the Inauguration
text: A half dozen or so hotels in Washington are undergoing extensive renovations, in part to take advantage of business related to Inauguration Day. This is good news for executives visiting the city, for any reason.

headline: Going With the Grain
text: Images of works by Alison Elizabeth Taylor, whose “Room” is the highlight of her second solo show at James Cohan Gallery in Chelsea. Carol Kino reports.

headline: Same Joke, More Regret
text: Note to pundits and politicians: Assassination jokes just don’t go over well.

headline: The Body Man
text: Reggie Love, who played football and basketball at Duke, is now Senator Barack Obama's right-hand man, the personal aide who shadows the senator and anticipates everything he needs.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 94 San Diego State
text: Location: San Diego

headline: Grammer to Play Bad Dad in ABC Pilot
text: The Hollywood Reporter: “Kelsey Grammer, whose latest sitcom ‘Back to You’ was recently axed by Fox after just one season, is eyeing a quick return to primetime with a starring role on ABC’s comedy pilot ‘Roman’s Empire.'”

headline: ‘Signal Moment’ In Broadcast TV Slump?
text: Los Angeles Times: The double-digit declines of the 2007-08 broadcast season “may be no temporary hiccup,” Scott Collins writes. “Increasingly, the shutdown and aftermath of the writers strike that ended in February is beginning to look like a signal moment in the slow, painful meltdown of the broadcast-TV industry.” Read more…

headline: Nine Months Before the Digital TV Transition, 25 Million Homes Are Unready
text: Nearly 25 million homes have at least one television set that will stop functioning in nine months, when the nation converts to digital over-the-air television.

headline: The Best of YouTube: Montreal 1976
text: The 1976 Olympics left Montreal saddled with more than a billion dollars in debt that took 30 years to pay off. But what a small price to pay for all the tremendous sporting memories, many of them documented on YouTube.

headline: GlassLab
text: Images from the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum.

headline: $10 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in New York, Washington and Colorado.

headline: Paris ahoy! Commuter boats ready for sail
text: Savvy Paris commuters are constantly on the look-out for alternative forms of transportation when train strikes loom and Metro lines rumble to a halt because of mysterious unexplained “incidents.”

headline: Time With ‘the Boss’
text: Reggie Love, Barack Obama’s personal aide, keeps a photo journal of the campaign, and has more than 10,000 pictures so far. Here are some of them.

headline: Are Talks About Greenhouse Gas Targets Enough?
text: The dynamism of 2007 — when the world woke up to climate change — has transformed this year into something more familiar to longtime observers of policies on global warming: talks about targets.

headline: Sydney Pollock, as Talent Agent in ‘Tootsie’
text: The director and sometime actor Sydney Pollock died Monday at 73. In perhaps his most memorable acting scene, from his cross-dressing comedy “Tootsie,” he played the agent to Dustin Hoffman’s struggling actor before he (Hoffman) decides to become a “she” (language advisory):

headline: Asparagus, Asparagus Everywhere
text: You have a little more time to enjoy asparagus in Germany, a spring specialty that has popped up on most menus in Frankfurt since mid-April. Spargel, Spargel everywhere.

headline: ‘In Bed With the Saudis’
text: More of your “late night” humor (send via the comment link below):

headline: Eni in Exclusive Taks to Buy $3.9 Billion Stake in Distrigaz
text: Eni confirmed exclusive talks to buy Suez‘s 2.5 billion euro ($3.9 billion) majority stake in Belgian natural gas distributor Distrigaz, as Italy’s largest oil company seeks clients and access to the fuel.

headline: Daylight Snaps Up Cadence Energy for $304 Million
text: Daylight Resources Trust has struck a deal to acquire Cadence Energy, a Calgary company formerly known as Kereco Energy, in a cash and unit transaction valued at 301 million Canadian dollars ($304.1 million).

headline: Ex-Manager Tells of Bribery at Siemens
text: A former manager of Siemens, the European engineering company, testified Monday about an intricate system of slush funds and bribery at the company as the first trial on allegations of corporate corruption in Germany began.

headline: Ontario Teachers’ Gives RailPower $20.2 Million Injection
text: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, which injected a lifesaving 35 million ($35.4 million) Canadian dollars into hybrid locomotive maker RailPower Technologies in January, has ponied up another 20 million Canadian dollars to help the company build a new factory in Quebec.

headline: Cott Shares Rise on Hedge Fund Push
text: Struggling Canadian soft-drink maker Cott saw its shares rise Monday following a push from a U.S. hedge fund to shake up its leadership.

headline: Murchison Mettals Trumps Sinosteel’s Midwest Bid
text: Murchison Metals said Monday that it had offered shares worth 1.65 billion Australian dollars for rival Midwest, trumping a bid by Sinosteel, in an effort to secure valuable iron-ore reserves in Australia.

headline: Spain’s Caixa Takes Stale in Mexico’s Inbursa
text: Grupo Financiero Inbursa, the bank controlled by billionaire Carlos Slim, rose to a record in Mexico City trading after Spain’s largest savings bank said it would buy a stake to jointly move into other Latin American countries.

headline: Shell Ponies Up $3.1 Billion for Nigerian Joint Ventures
text: Nigeria signed a $3.1 billion deal with the local arm of Royal Dutch Shell on Monday to plug a funding gap in their joint venture projects, the country’s state oil firm NNPC said.

headline: S.E.C. Backs Health Care Balloting
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission, shifting its position, has told companies they must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal for universal health insurance coverage.

headline: Infineon Chief Resigns Over Disagreement With Board
text: Infineon Technologies, one of the largest semiconductor makers in Europe, said Monday that its chief executive, Wolfgang Ziebart, had resigned after almost four years in the role because of a disagreement with the board.

headline: Web Sites Before the Internet
text: Cracked.com asked its readers to imagine what the Web might look like if it were around in pre-Internet times. Here are a few of the pages they came up with (more here, but discretion advised):

headline: MTN’s Iran Ties Could Complicate Financing
text: Having broken off talks with one suitor and quickly found another, the South African mobile phone operator MTN Group could still face obstacles to any deal from an unlikely corner: U.S. regulators, who prevent American companies from facilitating business in Iran, one of MTN’s fastest growing markets.

headline: Kleiner Said Dole Out iFund Cash to Pelago
text: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is reportedly leading a $15 million round for Pelago, the first company to tap iFund, the $100 million cash pool Apple launched in partnership with the V.C. firm to fund iPhone applications.

headline: Linens ‘n Things May Shutter More Stores, Report Says
text: Apollo Management‘s bankrupt retailer Linens ‘n Things may close additional stores beyond the 20 percent of its chain that it has already pledged to shutter, The New York Post reported.

headline: I.P.O. Market Sputters Along
text: After a modest uptick following Visa‘s stock debut in March, the market for initial public offerings is back in the doldrums.

headline: Kerkorian Borrows Another $100 Million for Ford Investment
text: Billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has added $100 million in financing as part of his bid to increase his stake in the Ford Motor Company.

headline: Quickoffice Scores $3 Million
text: Quickoffice, a company that makes mobile office document software for smart phones, has raised $3 million to help it expands at a time when users are expected to start using their phones for more tasks.

headline: Wall Street Exodus: Fear, Panic and Anger
text: Since August, banks worldwide have announced plans to eliminate as many as 65,000 jobs. Many losing their jobs now have lived through other crises on Wall Street – the 1987 market crash, the widespread layoffs of the early 1990s and the financial upheaval of 1998.

headline: MTN in New Deal Talks, Again in India
text: The MTN Group, a small mobile operator in South Africa, attracted an investment in 1995 from SBC, an American telecommunications company. Now MTN is a sprawling company that spans 21 countries with 70 million customers, and it is attracting outside investors again.

headline: Rags to Riches, One Year Later
text: As Casino Drive prepares for this year’s Belmont Stakes, it seems like a good time for an update on his half sister, Rags to Riches, the 2007 Belmont winner.

headline: Deutsche Bahn Said to Tap 4 Banks for I.P.O.
text: Four investment banks were reportedly given the mandate for one of the year’s biggest flotation: the 8 billion euro initial public offering of Deutsche Bahn, Europe’s biggest rail and logistics group.

headline: Blackstone and Apollo Said to Weigh Chemical Buyout
text: The Blackstone Group and Apollo Management, the private equity groups, are reportedly in talks to buy Chemtura, a manufacturer and marketer of specialty chemicals, in what would be one of the bigger U.S. buyouts this year.

headline: Borders Book Chain Turns a Page on the Web
text: The Web site for the preservation of the Borders Group, the country’s second-largest book chain, goes live today at www.borders.com.

headline: The Early Word: A Week to Go
text: Let the countdown begin. With just a week between now and the final primaries in South Dakota and Montana on June 3 and a few days until Puerto Rico holds its contest, the Democratic nominating fight may be coming to an end.

headline: Battle Between TCI and J-Power Heats Up
text: The acrimonious battle between J-Power, one of Japan’s biggest energy producers, and The Children’s Investment Fund has escalated after J-Power published an open letter to shareholders.

headline: Court to Fast-Track BCE Buyout Appeal
text: BCE won its request for an expedited process as the Supreme Court of Canada considers whether or not it will hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that threatened the phone company’s buyout deal. The court suggested on Monday it may hear an appeal in three weeks.

headline: CSX’s Hedge-Fund Struggle Puts Swaps in Focus
text: A looming decision in a heated lawsuit brought by railroad giant CSX could shut down a loophole used by activist hedge funds to hide their stake from the market, The New York Post reported.

headline: Designing for Resilience in Seismic Hot Zones
text: An important theme of Dot Earth is limiting losses from inevitable disasters — what I call “hard knocks.” As the human population heads toward 9 billion, more or less, with most of the growth coming in struggling places, unless more is done to boost resilience to known hazards — earthquakes included — there will be ever more wrenching imagery like that out of China (and Myanmar, as well).

headline: Rockefellers Seek Change at ExxonMobil
text: The Rockefeller family built one of the great American fortunes by supplying the nation with oil. Now history has come full circle: some family members say it is time to start moving beyond the oil age.

headline: Renters Forced Out of Stuyvesant Town
text: More than a year after buying Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan for a record-breaking $5.4 billion, Tishman Speyer Properties has accused hundreds of rent-stabilized tenants of living somewhere other than their apartments, The Times reports. Residents and their lawyers say that tactic is part of an aggressive attempt to drive out tenants paying lower rents to turn their units into market rate rentals.

headline: Volvo, Biofuels, and Sewage in Sweden
text: The race is on to commercialize eco-friendly transport fuels that avoid deforestation and higher food prices. The Swedes have been working with one such solution for years: Sludge from city sewage systems.

headline: The Deals Bear Stearns Didn’t Do
text: Bear Stearns tried at least six times to raise billions of dollars in the months before its dramatic collapse — and considered selling a stake to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts — but the efforts fizzled each time, according to an article in The Wall Street Journal that recounts the firm’s missed opportunities in that fateful period. Those opportunities, the article said, “might have been able to save the 85-year-old brokerage.”

headline: Ask About Fighting Poverty in New York
text: This week, David R. Jones, the president of the Community Service Society of New York, will be answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Roast Salmon With Spicy Soy Oil
text: If you can get wild salmon — and it is the season — its flavor is almost always better than that of farmed.

headline: Axcelis and the Future of Majority Voting
text: The Friday before Memorial Day is a good day for a company to disclose information that it would otherwise prefer to keep quiet. Most of the press and the investment community is already physically — if not mentally — out of town. So, by the time the markets re-open Tuesday, the news is already stale and apt to be lost in the mix.

headline: Readers Respond: Help With a 50th Wedding Anniversary
text: The following is a very detailed question from Linda Plaut of Golden, Colo. She’s looking for a great location for a wedding anniversary that fulfills a long list of criteria. Based on your own trips and travel experiences, do you have any advice that helps meet this tall order? We put this question to you, readers.

headline: Cannes, Monaco, Yeah-yeah
text: After finishing the piece about Pat Capolupo of Pat & Rose last week, I went to Monaco to see the Grand Prix—hence my recent silence. Pat’s last word to me as I left the factory was “Ferrari.” I laughed. Pat likes to keep things simple: pick a great name. On the plane to Nice I saw Tory Burch, who was going to visit some friends near Monaco, though probably wasn’t going to stay for the Grand Prix. Later, the next day, the sun shining as it’s meant to, we got together for lunch on the beach at Cap d’Ail. She introduced me to her friends, who invited me to a cocktail party at their home that night, where I met some more people who I would see throughout the weekend at various places. Monaco, I guess, is like that during the GP.

headline: Big Brown Returns to the Track
text: The hoof specialist Ian McKinlay was giddy Monday night about how quickly Big Brown was healing from a quarter crack, or stress fracture, in his left front hoof. He basically declared him cured, and predicted he would be on the track this morning.

headline: New Teen Health Worry: Energy in a Can
text: With names like Rock Star, Full Throttle and Monster, it’s no wonder new super-caffeinated energy drinks appeal to teens.

headline: ‘Fire Willie’ Chants at Shea Stadium
text: The first boisterous fan tried to start a “Fire Willie” chant in the eighth inning on Monday night. It did not last long; 20 seconds, at the most. The fan couldn’t find any vocal allies in his call for Willie Randolph, the Mets’ manager, to lose his job.

headline: NBC Prepares Horror Anthology Series
text: NBC is premiering a new horror anthology series, ”Fear Itself,” on June 5 at 10 p.m. The Associated Press reports:

headline: Braves Hope the Road Leads to the Playoffs
text: Between the surprise start by the Florida Marlins and the stunning struggles of the Mets, the Atlanta Braves carved out a spot for themselves in second place in the National League East, tied with the Philadelphia Phillies at two and a half games back. But this is all about to change, according to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution’s Mark Bradley.

headline: Not Digging It
text: Indiana Jones and the Ivory Tower: The newest Indiana Jones movie has raked in more than $150 million already, but not all archaeologists like to dream about themselves in a whip-and-fedora ensemble. Neil Asher Silberman, the former director of the Ename Center for Public Archaeology and Heritage Presentation in Belgium, explains in The Washington Post why he dislikes “the world’s most famous fictional archaeologist.” He writes:

headline: Inquiry Finds Port Security Lacking
text: The attacks of Sept. 11 transformed ports of entry into points of anxiety, but the job itself didn’t get any easier — just as illegal drugs slipped through loopholes, so did potential security threats. While no attacks have originated at the ports, reminders that they are vulnerable are frequent — from the Sept. 11 Commission’s final report to the uproar over a proposal to allow a Dubai company manage some operations at U.S. ports.

headline: Renewable Energy Appeal Is Newest Twist on Old E-Mail Scheme
text: It was only a matter of time before those e-mail scammers purporting to be Nigerian oil ministers who need your financial help to embezzle cash switched to a more green appeal: renewable energy.

headline: End to ‘Soccer Apartheid’
text: A day after FIFA decided to boot last year’s darlings of international soccer, the world soccer governing body announced a more welcome decision, lifting a confrontational ban on international matches played at high altitude.

headline: The Electric Computers Are Here
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: McCain Calls for a Harder Line on North Korea
text: DENVER—Senator John McCain kept up his attacks on Senator Barack Obama on Tuesday as naïve in foreign policy and appeared critical of the Bush administration’s diplomatic engagement in North Korea. Both positions were precursors of a speech on nuclear security policy that Mr. McCain gave today at the University of Denver.

headline: A Freemason Returns to the Albany Helm
text: Here is a little-known fact about New York’s accidental governor, David A. Paterson: He is the first Freemason to hold that office in more than 60 years. He joined the fraternal order in 2002, his office confirmed. In fact, he is actually the 20th New York governor to be a member, according to the Grand Lodge of New York (which is still on a public-relations binge to demystify itself).Having governors on the membership rolls hasn’t necessarily helped the Freemasons fend off the conspiracy theories swirling around them, ranging from possession of the Holy Grail, the founding of Atlantis and the hiding of secret symbols in Washington architecture and United States currency.

headline: Super Sunday: Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500
text: Once again, there was considerable heartbreak for some very well known names (and some not so well known) at the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indy 500 (both held on Sunday). Let’s go in chronological order:

headline: Previews of a Potential Cable Deal
text: Now that Time Warner Cable is to be spun off from parent company Time Warner, questions have emerged about what it will do with its newfound freedom. Richard Greenfield, an analyst at Pali Research, said in a report Tuesday that he thinks it may move to swallow a smaller rival.

headline: Mexican Navy vs. Sharks
text: BRIEFS We’ve seen navies take on pirates and green pirates take on whale hunters. But a navy hunting sharks? That’s a new one. After a series of rare attacks that left two swimmers dead, the Mexican Navy is searching for the feared beast by helicopter, boat and binoculars.

headline: Memorial Day in Mosul
text: Updated MOSUL – The closest thing to a Memorial Day barbecue for soldiers at Combat Outpost Rabiy came when one of their Bradley fighting vehicles, rumbling along a rubble-strewn street in Mosul, hit a sheep.

headline: Retired Thoroughbreds: Athletes for All Occasions
text: As people are becoming more aware of the fate of racehorses after they finish running, it is important to highlight those horses that have successfuly transitioned from the racetrack to a second career. To show that our stars have other options. And as more people become aware of the qualities thoroughbreds can bring to other equestrian disciplines, we can expand the “adopter pool” for Off Track Thoroughbreds (OTTBs) and increase the numbers that can then avoid the miserable fate of horse slaughter.

headline: Rockefellers Take on ExxonMobil
text: CNBC's Larry Kudlow discusses the Rockefellers' call for ExxonMobil to move into alternative energy with a panel of analysts and reporters.

headline: Another World
text: Peter Cooper is building a 16,000-square-foot family house on four acres in New Zealand.

headline: Inside the Candy Factory
text: Late Friday, Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company filed the preliminary proxy statement for its shareholders to approve Wrigley’s acquisition by Mars. The heart of this document is the background to the transaction section — the company’s disclosure, mandated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, of the events leading up to Wrigley’s agreement to be bought for about $23 billion.

headline: Culver's: Value Basket
text: Culver's is urging the hungry to "Get Culverized" in a humorous campaign by the Chicago office of Marc USA.

headline: Google Fights for the Right to Hide Its Privacy Policy
text: What’s one way that Google is different from AOL, Yahoo and Microsoft? It’s the only one of the big Internet companies that doesn’t put a link to its privacy policy on its home page.

text: Following is a transcript of John McCain's remarks at the University of Denver.

text: Hillary Clinton’s recent comments about the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy have gotten a lot of attention. A far more offensive assassination reference on Fox News has largely gone under the radar, since it happened over a slow Memorial Day weekend.

headline: The Starting Line: Smog in Beijing and a London Stadium to Take Away
text: With Beijing’s air quality plummeting because of a sandstorm blowing in today from Mongolia, the municipal government has declared an air quality emergency and advised people with respiratory problems to stay indoors. (The Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau’s Chinese-language site is here, and translated into English here and is here.)

headline: Networks to Show Joint Cancer Research Telethon in September
text: “ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

text: Things are tough all over. Take formerly Communist Central Europe:

headline: A Busy Period for Chess
text: As the weather has warmed, tournament and match activity has picked up. Last week, began with Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, ranked No. 2 in the world, winning the CEZ Chess Trophy, a rapid-play match in the Czech Republic against David Navarra, that country’s top-ranked player (No. 50 over all). Kramnik got off to a blistering start with 3.5 out of 4 points; the final score was 5.5-2.5.

headline: All Summer Long
text: I have a problem. These days I’m in school most of the year, which means my own reading list takes a back seat to whatever’s on the syllabus. As the fall, winter and spring wear on, I collect books the way a chipmunk does seeds and nuts for the winter. This has made for a daunting pile — and kept me feeling woefully behind.

headline: Culinary Tourism in Iowa?
text: That’s what the Iowa Arts Council is pushing and, while I am not jumping into the jalopy or logging on to book a ticket, I do find this little presentation  a convincing bundle of evidence that wonderful eating is possible wherever there is good land and decent weather. (Hat tip to Mike at www.notionscapital.com.)

headline: The Morning Skate: Red-Faced Penguins
text: Is this what the Stanley Cup final has come to, these words from Pittsburgh Post-Gazette columnist Gene Collier?

headline: What’s Next for Securitization?
text: The word “securitization” has taken on a sinister tone since the subprime mortgage debacle poked holes in the balance sheets of some of the world’s biggest banks. But this kind of Wall Street alchemy isn’t going away, an article from the Investment Dealers’ Digest suggests.

headline: Fillies in France
text: Sometimes taking on the guys is easier than tangling with one tough broad. That’s the reasoning behind the trainer Pascal Bary’s decision to run his top filly, Natagora, in the French Derby at Chantilly on Sunday rather than in the Oaks a week later.

headline: Ask the Locals, Yes, but Which Ones?
text: You know you’re onto something when even Brooklynites extend a compassionate hand to their mainland rivals in the Bronx. Yet that is what happened after my City Room post in mid-May about hotels, tourism and the Bronx. Boosters of both boroughs know they are often seen as provincial outposts that could never rival the imperial majesty of Manhattan Island.

headline: Obama and the White Working Class
text: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC analyzes Barack Obama's standing with a constituency that is the core issue in the Democratic endgame.

headline: Free 41-day ‘Visit’ to the North Pole in 44 Seconds
text: You can experience 41 days of conditions around the North Pole in 44 seconds, thanks to the web cams left behind by an international research team (funded by the National Science Foundation) that annually ventures northward to install and retrieve instruments on and under the drifting sea ice at the top of the world. The view is not as extreme, perhaps, as that provided by the Phoenix lander on Mars, but it’s pretty neat, nonetheless.

headline: Gas Prices Rise, Buses Crowd
text: BRIEFS Last month, our sibling blog Freakonomics asked Will Drivers Learn to Stop Worrying and Love the Bus? The answer just arrived from North Carolina: “The surge in gas prices this spring — a 65-cent rise in two months to a record average of $3.92 per gallon for regular on Monday — has driven Triangle commuters in unprecedented numbers to park their cars and board the buses.” [The News & Observer]

headline: That Beijing Air; those Olympic Women
text: After my Sunday column about China’s pollution problem, a belated peg: Beijing declared an air emergency today in part because of dust storms rolling in from Mongolia. The authorities told people with respiratory problems to stay inside. That’s from a new Olympics blog, Rings, that the Times has started.

headline: The Headwinds of War
text: This isn’t the blogging equivalent of Walter Cronkite saying that Vietnam was an unwinnable war, but it’s close. Byron York, the White House correspondent for National Review, calls the Iraq war a “mistake” in a post at The Corner, National Review’s staff blog.

headline: M.B.A’s Still Love Google and Goldman
text: Business school graduates are getting ready to hit the work force — if they are lucky — and it seems that nearly a quarter of them want to work for Google.

headline: A Bearish Outlook for Lehman
text: CNBC's David Faber reviews a negative report by Bank of America about Lehman Brothers, whose stock has been battered by pessimists.

headline: Questioning the Wisdom of Crowds
text: “Sometimes Crowds Aren’t That Wise,” wrote a smart blogger on the shortcomings of Digg, the news hub run by the masses. Inevitably, Digg linked to the story, packaging it with a warning that “this story contains information that may not be accurate.” The particular inaccuracies were not immediately apparent, but another Digg user was hardly surprised by the overall point: “Was this article written by Captain Obvious?”

headline: Liberty Pulls Back from Vongo Internet Movie Service
text: UPDATED | 5/27 4:45 PM Mr. Southwick writes to say he speaks for Starz, not Liberty Media, its owner.

headline: An Officer and a Beekeeper
text: When they join the Police Department, new officers tell their employer about their other life skills and interests. Anthony Planakis, who joined in 1994, listed masonry and cement work. And beekeeping. So it was that about 4:30 p.m. on Monday, Officer Planakis, the son of a beekeeper who now works in the police’s Building Maintenance Department, got a call asking whether he could help contain a swarm of bees that had attached itself to the side of an apartment building in the Bronx. He grabbed his gear, and hopped into his car.

headline: Another Bearish Call on Lehman
text: Lehman Brothers‘ stock has taken it on the nose over the past week, falling more than 14 percent after a new wave of criticism struck the securities firm.

headline: Cheever’s the M.V.P. on Indy TV
text: The currently popular definition of a Most Valuable Player is someone who makes the teammates around him better. If true, give Eddie Cheever Jr. the M.V.P. trophy for Sunday’s Indianapolis 500 telecast on ABC.

headline: O.K., Ban Racing … But Then What?
text: Depending on which recent poll you believe, anywhere from 10 to 38 percent of Americans support a ban on horse racing. Debate lingers over how much the emotionally charged aftermath of the death of Eight Belles in the Kentucky Derby swayed public opinion on this matter. But for the sake of argument, let’s grant the extremists their wish, in theory. What would happen if thoroughbred racing — as of this instant — suddenly became illegal in the United States?

text: They had been saving their anger ever since the trading scandal at the French bank Société Générale broke in January. On Tuesday, shareholders were given their first chance to challenge management on a loss of 4.9 billion euros or $7.1 billion – and there was no more holding back.

headline: Protests Planned for Rules Committee Meeting
text: The Democratic National Committee is bracing itself for protests outside its Rules and Bylaws Committee meeting on Saturday in Washington, where the fates of the Florida and Michigan primaries could finally be decided.

headline: Jeter Envy
text: The synonym, presumably, would be “to favrerate”: Joe Posnanski is a sports columnist for The Kansas City Star who, in his spare time, produces one of the finest blogs on The Series of Tubes. In a post over the weekend, Posnanski coined the word “Jeterate,” a verb meaning “to praise someone for something of which he or she is entirely unworthy of praise” in the course of a post explaining why fans of Derek Jeter, the Yankees shortstop, drive him “batty.”
