Actually, though, this post applies to Detroit and Pittsburgh equally, because it involves … Zurich.

headline: Willie Randolph, Blowing in the Wind
text: Maybe that’s not exactly how the Bob Dylan tune goes, but it is appropriate for the Mets manager. Randolph is still the manager today. Tomorrow, too. But if the Mets keep losing, how much longer will he be commuting to Shea?

headline: Feeling For … Malcolm McLaren
text: Malcolm McLaren, 1980 (Stuart Nicol/Evening Standard/Getty Images).

headline: The Finer Points of Catching, at Age 6
text: I have a feeling Dante Girardi, even at 6 years old, knows he’s getting a special kind of baseball instruction. On the field at Camden Yards, while his dad chatted with Orioles Manager Dave Trembley, Dante was getting pointers from Tony Pena.

headline: Wireless Broadband Bolsters Economy
text: Wireless technology will continue to have a huge impact on the economy as it becomes easier for businesses and their employees to access the Internet on their cell phones and other wireless devices, according to a study to be released Wednesday by the CTIA, a trade group for the wireless industry.

headline: Spray-Painting Brighter (and More Lawful) Swashes of Graffiti
text: A love of graffiti has gained Steve Powers notoriety as an outlaw artist, plus a Fulbright scholarship.

headline: A Tailor Who Caters to a Certain Taste
text: Memorial Day has come and gone and summer stretches out languidly before him; now is the time that a certain kind of Northeastern dandy, when in polite company, may safely revel in a certain kind of highly coded casual wear.So I stopped by the fifth-floor atelier of Paul Winston, the proprietor of Winston Tailors (a k a Chipp 2). Chipp, which is what most people still call it, is a family-owned business at 11 East 44th Street. It has occupied various locations near this same spot in Midtown, between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, since it was started by Mr. Winston’s father, Sidney, in 1945.

headline: Nascar Wins Ratings
text: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No.1 on Sunday.

headline: Pens Find Turnabout Is Fair Play
text: How odd near the end of a playoff run where nearly all their previous opponents were reduced to whining about the officiating and accusing the Penguins of diving that the Penguins have resorted to just that after falling behind 2-0 to Detroit in the Stanley Cup final.

headline: Working Toward Safer Bombs: 2 Tracks
text: It rained in Dublin today, and at least one person was happy about that. Marc Garlasco, a senior military analyst at Human Rights Watch, has been trying to move nations closer to an international ban on cluster munitions — arms that critics blame for preventable civilian casualties.

headline: McCain on Nuclear Disarmament
text: In a speech at the University of Denver in which he was interrupted by hecklers, Senator John McCain vowed to work with Russia on arms.

headline: Pasta With Soft-Shell Crabs
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to cook pasta with soft-shell crabs.

headline: Edamame Salad
text: Mark Bittman turns a familiar Japanese appetizer into something new.

headline: Smoke Clears. Dust Does Not.
text: These pre-Olympic mornings, when the air is thick with the scent of jasmine and roses, I gaze out the window of my high-rise apartment in northwest Beijing and see, alas, not much. That’s because the air is also thick with oxides of many colors and complex carbon chains yet unclassified.

headline: Live From New York . . . It’s the World Science Festival!
text: The World Science Festival opens this week in New York. When I first heard about this new event, I was a bit surprised, because I’d never thought of New York as even the national science center, let alone the world hub. In 1994, when the Times Magazine put out a special issue asking, “What’s New York the Capital of Now?” I wrote the introductory essay and came up with about two dozen answers ranging alphabetically from advertising and art to restaurants and theater. It never occurred to me to put science on the list.

headline: Will Lieberman Skip Hagee Event?
text: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut is scheduled to appear as the featured speaker at a July conference in Washington for a group run by the Rev. John C. Hagee, the televangelist whose controversial statements led Senator John McCain to disavow Mr. Hagee’s endorsement of his presidential campaign.

headline: Gravel Exits, Stage Left
text: As Bob Barr, a former Republican, reignited his political career by taking the Libertarian presidential nomination at the party’s convention in Denver on Sunday, the political career of Mike Gravel came to a close. It was the former Democrat’s second loss of a party’s presidential nomination in a single year.

headline: Campaign Mementos
text: In 1952, Adlai Stevenson ran for president on the Democratic ticket against Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower and was labeled “egg-head” for being an intellectual. But worse, he was saddled with the ignominious distinction of being too frugal. During a campaign stop, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph by William M. Gallagher of The Flint Journal revealed a hole in the sole of Governor Stevenson’s right shoe, and this quickly became a trademark. The shoe was made into metallic lapel pins, proudly worn by supporters in both the ’52 and ’56 elections.

headline: Obama’s Staff Corrects WWII Story
text: LAS VEGAS – The family tree of Senator Barack Obama has been the subject of much discussion – and inspection – since he arrived on the national political stage four years ago.

headline: Home Prices Rise (Somewhere)
text: The economic numbers today were dreadful. Consumer confidence is down, again. New home sales are still horrid. And the S.&P./Case-Shiller indexes show home prices falling further.

headline: Blog Roll: Superfecta
text: On the day we launched The Rail, I said it was part of our mission to reflect the eclectic mix of folks who are passionate about horse racing. We have also tried to be as democratic as the game itself by offering a platform to a wide variety of voices.

headline: Why Walter Bender Left One Laptop Per Child
text: When Microsoft joined the One Laptop Per Child project earlier this month, I wrote an article noting the change in heart by both sides. The O.L.P.C. project, intended to bring cheap computers to children in poorer nations, had been committed to using the freely distributed Linux operating system, an open-source alternative to Microsoft’s Windows. And Microsoft had resisted joining anything that promoted open-source software.

headline: Clinton’s Grand Design
text: The campaigns have become fond of those teaser e-mail messages. They make you think they’re making some big announcement (like, say, suspending their campaigns), but then it’s just some silly pitch.

headline: Riding a Flavor Trip
text: At "flavor tripping" parties, guests eat a berry known as miracle fruit that temporarily rewires taste buds, turning sour flavors sweet.

headline: Donnie Baseball Visits Baseball Shrine
text: Don Mattingly has played in or coached in more than 2,000 major league games, but he had never visited Wrigley Field. That finally changed on Monday after Mattingly, a special assignment coach with the Los Angeles Dodgers, saw the famous ivy on the outfield walls and heard the Bleacher Bums.“My mom always wanted me to play here,” Mattingly said. “It was day baseball. It was five hours from my home. You were close enough so that you could get home, but not so close that you would have people bothering you all the time.”When Mattingly, who played his entire career with the Yankees, was asked if he ever came close to playing for the Chicago Cubs, he said that he had not. Then Mattingly laughed and added, “Well, not that I know of.”As Mattingly and Manager Joe Torre drove to Wrigley on Monday, he told Torre that he had never seen the Friendly Confines. The Yankees played here in 2003, but Mattingly, who lives in Evansville, Ind., did not became a Yankees coach until 2004.Mattingly was supposed to be the Dodgers’ batting coach, but he assumed a lesser role so he could be home with Jordon, his youngest son. Mattingly and his wife, Kim, filed for divorce last November. Jordon is in high school.Although Joe Girardi beat out Mattingly for the Yankees’ manager position, Mattingly said he still wanted to manage. Mattingly said he would renew his quest once his family situation was stabilized. He will not travel to Shea Stadium with the Dodgers for the series starting Thursday because he is taking Jordon to compete in a horse jumping show.

headline: No Midges, but the Rain and the Umps are Bugging Girardi
text: Flash back to Game 2 of the playoffs in Cleveland last October. The field is infested with midges off Lake Erie, and Joe Torre makes no move to confront the umpires or pull his team off the field. Later, after losing his job as Yankees manager, Torre would cite that as a regret.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Paris, France
text: The Frugal Traveler falls in love with a bourgeois bohemian neighborhood and throws a frugal housewarming party.

headline: Famed architect Richard Meier on his new project in Tel Aviv and the state of tower design
text: “There should be a purpose to building a tower other than making sure it’s taller than the last one,” says Richard Meier, the designer of some of the world’s most recognizable buildings.

headline: Compared to Other Liquids, Gasoline is Cheap
text: In five years of writing this blog, I’ve generally resisted passing along some of those great little tidbits that get passed around by e-mail—jokes, quotes, factoids, and stuff like that. Most of the sob stories are bogus, most of the jokes aren’t funny, and so on.

headline: Musings Inspired By a Quagga
text: The hall is hushed, like a church. No one else is here. The only sound is the clicking of the heels of my shoes. I walk up and down, looking at the animals. They make no noise, for they are dead.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, included an erroneous age from the police for the victim. She was 62, not 52. The error was repeated on May 19 in an article in some editions about an arrest in the case.

headline: When Doctors Go to Court
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hint of Hope as Child Obesity Rate Hits Plateau
text: Childhood obesity, rising for more than two decades, appears to have hit a plateau, a potentially significant milestone in the battle against excessive weight gain among children.

headline: J. R. Simplot, Farmer Who Developed First Frozen French Fries, Dies at 99
text: J. R. Simplot, a billionaire who grew up in a sod-roofed log cabin and dropped out of school at 14, then marshaled luck, spunk and inventiveness to fashion an entrepreneurial career that included developing the first commercial frozen French fry, died on Sunday at his home in Boise, Idaho. He was 99.

headline: With Bold Steps, Fed Chief Quiets Some Criticism
text: WASHINGTON  Over a frantic weekend in mid-March, Ben S. Bernanke rewrote the rule book as chairman of the Federal Reserve. Like a military commander applying overwhelming force, he took steps then and over the next two months that some at the central bank are now calling the Bernanke Doctrine.

headline: Al Qaeda Warrior Uses Internet to Rally Women
text: BRUSSELS  On the street, Malika El Aroud is anonymous in an Islamic black veil covering all but her eyes.

headline: Drawn by Nature to New Zealand
text: “Another world at the edge of the world” is how Peter Cooper likes to refer to his isolated beachhead on the remote northern coast of New Zealand.

headline: After Seven Years Away, His Return Is Filled With Rage
text: Free advice for playwrights: If you’re going to leave the antagonist of your story unseen, you should make doubly sure that his loathsome qualities are clear. It’s a test that “Blink,” an intense drama in the Brits Off Broadway Festival at the 59E59 Theaters, doesn’t quite pass. The result is that a lot of well-acted rage by the three-member cast feels as if it’s bouncing off the walls rather than striking a target.

headline: Three Remain in Running for Newark Schools Post
text: NEWARK  After nearly four dozen job applications over the past six months, the search for a new superintendent in Newark, New Jersey’s largest school system, has been narrowed to three candidates.

headline: For Coors Light, a Night Out That Begins on MySpace
text: BEER has long been marketed as a sociable beverage, from a campaign for Budweiser that carried the theme “When gentlemen agree” to the Löwenbräu jingle that began, “Here’s to good friends.” Now, another beer brand, Coors Light, is extending its presence in the new media with efforts on the social networking Web sites Facebook and MySpace.

headline: Parents’ Grief Turns to Rage at Chinese Officials
text: DUJIANGYAN, China  Bereaved parents whose children were crushed to death in their classrooms during the earthquake in Sichuan Province have turned mourning ceremonies into protests in recent days, forcing officials to address growing political repercussions over shoddy construction of public schools.

headline: Study Links Caesareans With Births Before Term
text: Premature single births have been increasing in the United States, mostly among infants delivered by Caesarean section, researchers are reporting. And they say some of the increase may be due to Caesareans that are not medically necessary.

headline: Fearing Floods, Chinese Order Evacuations in Quake Area
text: SHANGHAI  The Chinese authorities are evacuating 150,000 people threatened by possible flooding from a lake in southwestern China formed by landslides following this month’s earthquake, and military engineers struggled Tuesday to dig sluiceways to drain the water safely.

headline: Realtors Agree to Stop Blocking Web Listings

But Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has jumped into the online social networking world with a page on Facebook, one of the most popular sites of its kind.

headline: Earle Hagen, Who Composed Noted TV Tunes, Dies at 88
text: Earle H. Hagen, a onetime big-band trombonist who wrote some of the most famous theme songs in television history, died Monday in Rancho Mirage, Calif., near Palm Springs. He was 88 and lived in Rancho Mirage.

headline: Move From Bullpen Gives Chamberlain a New View
text: BALTIMORE  His first four months of major league service have been a whirlwind for Joba Chamberlain, so the process of converting him to a starting role does not exactly feel weird.

headline: Designers Teach Glass (and Themselves) New Tricks
text: Summer hadn’t quite arrived in the city over the Memorial Day weekend, but in the garden of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, on upper Fifth Avenue, it was several hundred degrees in the shade. Onstage in the Corning Museum GlassLab, four sweat-beaded men in black T-shirts rotated elongated rods  tipped with molten glass hot enough to ignite anything it touched, whether metal, wood or flesh  with the nonchalance of baton twirlers.

headline: Penguins Look for Way to Relocate Their Offense
text: PITTSBURGH  The Penguins spent the regular season and the first three rounds of the playoffs as a puck-possession team, with enough offensive firepower to score seemingly whenever necessary.

headline: A Specialist’s Sole Focus Is Trying to Repair Hooves
text: OCEANPORT, N.J.  There was more good news from the Big Brown camp Tuesday morning. His foot problem on the mend, Big Brown returned to training, jogging a mile and a half at Belmont Park. All signs indicate that he is on track to make the Belmont Stakes, which can only mean that Ian McKinlay has done his job well.

headline: Yankees Lose Kennedy, Then Things Get Worse
text: BALTIMORE, May 27 – For Ian Kennedy, Tuesday's game was his major league career in microcosm. It started flawlessly and spiraled quickly into shambles in the Yankees' wild 10-9 loss to the Baltimore Orioles in 11 innings.

headline: Ex-Governor, Now in Prison, Sees Case End
text: CHICAGO  The United States Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would not hear an appeal by former Gov. George Ryan of Illinois of his 2006 racketeering and fraud conviction.

headline: Canada: Hollinger Control of Sun-Times Ends
text: The Sun-Times Media Group, the newspaper publisher once led by Conrad M. Black, won Canadian court approval of the settlement of a four-year dispute that will end control over the company by Hollinger Inc. Hollinger, Mr. Black’s former Toronto-based holding company, will convert its supervoting shares in Sun-Times to common stock under an agreement approved by Ontario Superior Court Judge Colin L. Campbell. Mr. Black, convicted of fraud last year and sent to prison, helped build Sun-Times, formerly called Hollinger International, into the world’s third-largest publisher of English-language newspapers, before selling most of its properties in a $3 billion strip-down of assets from 1998 to 2001.

headline: In Ex-Spokesman’s Book, Harsh Words for Bush
text: PHOENIX  President Bush “convinces himself to believe what suits his needs at the moment,” and has engaged in “self-deception” to justify his political ends, Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, writes in a critical new memoir about his years in the West Wing.

headline: The Tension in the Democrats’ Camp
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the Public Tile Project in Peekskill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for information about an event that is being held on Friday to benefit the project. It is (914) 461-3275.

headline: Mayor of Orange Resigns and Pleads Guilty to Extortion
text: NEWARK  A prominent New Jersey Democrat who had served simultaneously as the mayor of Orange and a state assemblyman pleaded guilty in federal district court Tuesday to one count of attempted extortion.

headline: The First Step for Woods Is Negotiating 18 Stairs
text: BETHESDA, Md.  Walking down the 18 stairs from a hallway above the ballroom at the Congressional Country Club was like a tap-in putt for Tiger Woods on Tuesday. He moved fluidly, almost gliding into the room and onto the elevated platform before a room full of reporters, photographers, TV cameras, talking heads, club members and tournament officials.

headline: Ricotta Crostini With Fresh Thyme and Dried Oregano
text: Adapted from A Voce

headline: Red Snapper Tacos With Tomatillo Salsa
text: Time: At least 45 minutes plus at least 30 minutes’ resting

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about a warning from the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to all troops that they should not become involved in partisan politics referred incorrectly to the length of the Iraq war. It has not lasted longer than World War II. ( The Second World War began in September 1939 with the invasion of Poland and ended in August 1945 with Japan’s surrender. The Iraq war began in March 2003. The United States’ five-year involvement in Iraq, however, has indeed been longer than its four-year involvement in World War II.)

headline: Making Age an Issue
text: PRODUCER Campaign Group

headline: Mexico: 7 Federal Police Officers Killed in Shootout With Drug Cartel
text: Seven federal police officers were killed in Culiacán during a gun battle with three men working for a drug cartel, the police said. The officers were the latest victims in a conflict between the cartels and the police that has claimed the lives of more than 30 federal agents and 170 local police officers in the last 18 months. The officers were trying to enter a house where they believed that drug dealers were hiding and were met with a hand grenade and machine-gun fire, the police said. One of the gunmen died in the exchange of fire, and a second man and a teenage boy were arrested.

headline: End Runs on Medicaid
text: A federal district judge has slapped down a sneaky attempt by the Bush administration to impose an onerous Medicaid regulation despite the clear intent of Congress that it be deferred. Once again, the administration has been caught in a flagrant attempt to ignore the will of Congress and unilaterally chart its own path.

headline: 2 Voter Rights Cases, One Gripping a College Town, Stir Texas
text: PRAIRIE VIEW, Tex.  “Vote or Die,” exhorts the faded slogan on a roadway at Prairie View A&M University, where black students once marched for the right to vote here in the town where they attend school, on a former cotton plantation about 50 miles northwest of Houston.

headline: A Sunni Bloc Pulls Back on Rejoining Iraqi Cabinet
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s largest Sunni political bloc suspended its return to the Shiite-dominated government on Tuesday, saying Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki had refused to give it the cabinet ministries it wanted.

headline: A Court Full of Chaos, a Trial Crammed With Questions
text: The 1916 trial of Sir Roger Casement had everything a dramatist could want: salacious revelations, media manipulation, star cameos (George Bernard Shaw and Arthur Conan Doyle were among those appealing for clemency), political intrigue and a central character wrapped in mystery.

headline: Trinity Loses, but Wins Title
text: Trinity College started Tuesday hoping to become the first undefeated team in modern N.C.A.A. baseball history. It had to settle for a national championship.

headline: A Not-So-Old Standby
text: “I haven’t had anything I didn’t like,” said one of my tablemates as she reflected on the meal we were just finishing at the Harrison, and her tone communicated surprise and significant regard. What sounded in one sense like faint praise was actually a major compliment.

headline: Germany and Poland Find That Trying to Get Along Has Its Benefits
text: BERLIN  It’s springtime in Europe and something like love is in the air again for an unlikely pair. Germany and Poland have finally patched things up again.

headline: Soft-Shell Crabs Take a Turn With Pasta
text: I’M forever looking for new ways to cook soft-shell crabs. So when the splendid Los Angeles chef (Angeli Caffe) and radio host (KCRW’s “Good Food” show) Evan Kleiman mentioned to me that she served soft-shells on top of pasta, I thought, “Yes, well, that’s obvious enough  once a good cook mentions it to you!” Then I got to work.

headline: U.S. Businessman Testifies He Gave Olmert $150,000 Over 13 Years
text: JERUSALEM  A Long Island businessman at the heart of a corruption case involving Prime Minister Ehud Olmert told an Israeli court on Tuesday that he gave about $150,000, mostly in cash stuffed into envelopes, to Mr. Olmert over the course of 13 years.

headline: In an Uncertain Market, Hotels May Be Ripe Buys
text: A $200 million resort hotel does not exactly resemble a suburban home. But scratch the surface of the sales market for each property category, and they look remarkably similar today.

headline: Truth or Consequences
text: Imagine for a minute, just a minute, that someone running for president was able to actually tell the truth, the real truth, to the American people about what would be the best  I mean really the best  energy policy for the long-term economic health and security of our country. I realize this is a fantasy, but play along with me for a minute. What would this mythical, totally imaginary, truth-telling candidate say?

headline: Pennsylvania: Scouts Group Sues City
text: The Philadelphia city government said it would fight a lawsuit by the local Boy Scouts organization that seeks to block the city’s efforts to evict it from rent-free premises because of alleged anti-gay policies. City officials say the policies violate a city ordinance and have told the Cradle of Liberty group to renounce its ban on gay Scouts, start paying $200,000 a year in rent or vacate its headquarters by May 31. “We are not going to subsidize the violation of our ordinance,” said Shelley Smith, the city solicitor. “It’s still our intention to take the legal action necessary to evict them.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Celtics Look for Shots, and a Sense of Urgency
text: WALTHAM, Mass.  A mere 12 hours after touching down in the wee hours Tuesday morning, the Boston Celtics were back at work. Late afternoon practice/film sessions at home after playoff losses on the road have become a staple of the Celtics’ postseason. They have won only once in eight road games.

headline: A Return Home May Place Torre in a Tough Spot
text: CHICAGO  Joe Torre was talking recently to his wife, Ali, about Willie Randolph’s perilous status as manager of the Mets. They lamented how difficult it must be for Randolph to endure the percolating speculation that he may lose his job.

headline: Connecting Philosophy, Sondheim and Seurat
text: The topic of the day’s seminar was “Kripke on Philosophy of Mind and Wittgenstein,” and the first couple of philosophers on the docket began speaking of the seeming possibility of the falsity of necessity and how it can be epistemologically possible to conceive of a metaphysical impossibility. As this was being discussed, a reporter discovered that it is very possible to contract a throbbing headache, and quickly.

headline: If a Terrace Is Unusable, Is the Rent Reduced?
text: Q. I rent a penthouse studio with a large terrace. There is major construction on the exterior of the building, making the terrace impossible to use. This was not a problem in January, when construction began and I wasn't using the terrace. But now that the weather is warming, they are telling me that they don't anticipate completion until July.

headline: Moose Gain Ground but Keep a Low Profile
text: McKENZIE MOUNTAIN WILDERNESS, N.Y.  Here in the boreal forests of the Adirondack Mountains, moose are seemingly everywhere and nowhere.

headline: ‘Devil May Care’
text: THE WATCHER WATCHED

headline: Justices Say Law Bars Retaliation Over Bias Claims
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that employees are protected from retaliation when they complain about discrimination in the workplace, adopting a broad interpretation of workers’ rights under two federal civil rights laws.

headline: A City Tailor Who Revels in the Boldest Sportswear
text: Memorial Day has come and gone, and summer stretches out languidly before him; now is the time that a certain kind of Northeastern dandy, when in polite company, may safely revel in a certain kind of highly coded casual wear.

headline: Brazil: Oil Company Planning to Sell Shares
text: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, betting the country’s recent oil finds will lure investors who snubbed other offerings this year. Mr. Batista founded Rio de Janeiro-based OGX less than a year ago. He paid $800 million in November to buy his first oil-exploration licenses off Brazil’s coast. Francisco Gros, vice president of the OGX board and former chief executive, said in an interview April 4 that OGX might have oil reserves of 4.8 billion barrels, according to a study by DeGolyer and MacNaughton, an oil-reserve appraisal firm based in Dallas.

headline: A Few Aid Workers Reach Into Myanmar
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar is allowing some foreign aid workers to enter remote areas hard hit by the May 3 cyclone in what relief agencies said Tuesday appeared to be the beginning of a new policy that fulfills a pledge made last week to the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

headline: A Tour of Bitters for the Summer
text: YOU have to hand it to the British for their engaging skill at understatement. How else to explain their predilection for taking something refreshing and delicious and saddling it with a name like “ordinary”?

headline: Home Village Exerts Pull, Even Amid the Rubble
text: SHENXI VILLAGE, China  Since returning to this mountain village a few days after fleeing from the earthquake that devastated this region of Sichuan Province, Xiong Fuquan has made two or three daily round trips to the nearest town for supplies.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,075 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: Nothing Says Summer Like Icing
text: I WAS recently at a lunch where the birthday girl ordered flourless chocolate cake. Someone else ordered chocolate mousse. The mousse looked like mousse. The cake did, too, only darker and wetter, like a floor tile gone horribly wrong.

headline: Pairings: Red Snapper Tacos With Tomatillo Salsa
text: Alex Hall, an English guest at our tasting of English and American bitter ales, told us that the typical partner for a pint of bitters was a pub lunch: a sandwich of Cheddar or Stilton with pickles on whole-grain bread.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the convictions of illegal immigrants who worked in an Iowa meat-packing plant misstated the sentence or crime for some of them. Of the 270 immigrants who were sent to prison, 260 were sentenced to five months for using false work documents; 2 were sentenced to 12 months and 1 day for that crime; and 8 received five-month sentences for re-entering the United States illegally after deportation. All 270 immigrants were not sentenced to five months for using false documents.

headline: Charity Finds Child Sexual Abuse by Peacekeepers and Aid Workers
text: A British charity, Save the Children UK, said it had uncovered evidence of sexual abuse of children, some as young as 6, by United Nations peacekeepers and by workers from other international aid groups. The finding was based on field research in southern Sudan, Ivory Coast and Haiti. United Nations officials said the report reflected a continuing problem, despite efforts in recent years to establish conduct and discipline units in all the missions.

headline: Nascar Wins Ratings
text: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Fox’s live broadcast of the Coca-Cola 600 drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBS’s regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by “Two and a Half Men” at 9, the night’s most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for “The Bachelorette” from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBC’s “American Gladiators” delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of “Dateline,” which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour “So You Think You Can Dance” premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

headline: Glitch Hinders a Second Day on Mars
text: A communications glitch kept the Phoenix lander from getting instructions for its second day on Mars, mission officials said. But the problem was fixed later in the day, The Associated Press quoted NASA officials as saying. The spacecraft is equipped to send and receive data via radio from two satellites, the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter and the Mars Odyssey. But the Reconnaissance Orbiter spontaneously turned off its UHF radio, preventing transmission of the day’s instructions. “Phoenix is healthy; everything is fine,” Fuk Li, the manager of the Mars exploration program for the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said at a news conference.

headline: Tilting at the Bocuse d’Or
text: WITH all the chef competitions, you wouldn’t think there was a cooking contest in which Americans were underrepresented.

headline: A Tiny Fruit That Tricks the Tongue
text: CARRIE DASHOW dropped a large dollop of lemon sorbet into a glass of Guinness, stirred, drank and proclaimed that it tasted like a “chocolate shake.”

headline: Santana Provides Relief for Mets
text: Johan Santana was entrusted with more than just rescuing the Mets from their tailspin Tuesday night. At stake, in no particular order, was their peace of mind, their manager’s job security and the support of a fan base that has grown increasingly vociferous with its discontent.

headline: Sydney Pollack, Filmmaker New and Old
text: Sydney Pollack’s career as a director blossomed in the 1960s and ’70s, but in many ways he was a throwback to an earlier era in American movies.

headline: Resources Scarce, Homelessness Persists in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS  Mayor C. Ray Nagin recently suggested a way to reduce this city’s post-Katrina homeless population: give them one-way bus tickets out of town.

headline: Defamation Case: Clemens Responds
text: Lawyers for Roger Clemens responded Tuesday to a two-month-old motion by his former trainer Brian McNamee that asked for the dismissal of a defamation lawsuit brought by Clemens.

headline: Please, Is This $1 or $100?
text: In most countries, it is fairly easy for people to tell how many euros or pounds or yen they are holding in their hands. Different denominations can come in different sizes and colors. Some have filaments or other characteristics that make it easy to recognize their value by touch. The all-American “greenback” is an exception, but it should not be.

headline: Major San Francisco Development Faces a Ballot Test
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It is difficult to imagine a tougher place to undertake a major redevelopment than the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard here.

headline: Giving the Corkscrew a New Twist
text: Inspiration for the Wine Ratchet Magnum came from the toolbox. This sleek new wine opener operates like a ratchet wrench, which is what the people at Built, a New York company, were thinking of when they designed it.

headline: South Africa: Notorious White Dorm Converted Into Diversity Center
text: The University of the Free State in Bloemfontein announced that it will close down the Reitz Residence, which became a symbol of white racist resistance to integration of campus housing, and convert it to an institute for the study of diversity. Four students who lived there made an infamous video that humiliated black cleaning women through mock initiation rites into the residence. The university called the closing “an important gesture of reconciliation towards all South Africans who had been offended.”

headline: A Tomboy in Malaysia Is Introduced to Hormones
text: The Malaysian filmmaker Yasmin Ahmad tells deeply personal and intensely humanistic stories based largely on her own experiences. For her fourth film, “Mukhsin,” she revisits the loving and liberal family of her previous features, continuing her portrait of one woman’s journey from childhood through adolescence and marriage.

headline: Delgado Benched as Slump Deepens
text: The Mets were losing by three runs in the fifth inning Monday night but showed signs of life: no outs, runners on first and second, and Carlos Delgado striding to the plate. On the fourth pitch of the at-bat, though, Delgado fouled out.

headline: In Vermont, a Debate Swirls Around an Aging Nuclear Plant
text: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  After part of a cooling tower collapsed last August at Vermont’s only nuclear power plant, the company that runs it blamed rotting wooden timbers that it had failed to inspect properly. The uproar that followed rekindled environmental groups’ hopes of shutting down the aging plant.

headline: Some Foes of a Floundering German Far-Right Party Want to Try Again to Ban It
text: BERLIN  Germany’s leading extreme right-wing party is on the ropes because of financial mismanagement, criminal investigations and fierce competition from the left for the populist protest vote. The debate among the authorities here is whether to try to ban it or to allow it to quietly self-destruct.

headline: Can He Take a Frisk?
text: After “Rahmbo” Emanuel, the Illinois congressman dubbed “the hostage negotiator” by the Obama forces, fails to talk Hillary down, Barack Obama knows that he is left with one final roll of the dice. He sets up a secret meeting with Bill Clinton in neutral territory at Rahm’s hideaway office in the Capitol.

headline: Grotesquerie and Ecstasy, on Both Street and Stage
text: Sometimes Butoh, the outré, avant-garde dance movement that developed in mid-20th-century Japan, seems tailor made for New York.

headline: An Annual Holiday Celebration Still Resonates Inside a Cathedral
text: Over the years the annual free concert on Memorial Day by the New York Philharmonic at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has become a very meaningful holiday event for music-loving New Yorkers. Before the cathedral began its extensive renovations several years ago, it used to be possible for more than 2,500 people to attend these concerts.

headline: Harlem’s Bloody Past Is Reluctantly Revisited
text: When the gunfire started, Donald Banks crouched behind a parked car on Lenox Avenue, not sure where the bullets were coming from and not caring, as long as they did not get too close.

headline: Calendar
text: Party From 1988

headline: New Climate Report Foresees Big Changes
text: The rise in concentrations of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from human activities is influencing climate patterns and vegetation across the United States and will significantly disrupt water supplies, agriculture, forestry and ecosystems for decades, a new federal report says.

headline: Big Bangs Don’t Always Require Long Fuses
text: Some people think Neil LaBute should write only one-acts  and it’s easy to see why. His lean, economical dialogue is usually built around a savvy concept that can stretch thin by the second hour of a full-length play. But Mr. LaBute, who polarizes critics like few other playwrights, excels at shorthand, as demonstrated by “The Great War,” a bruising, comically nasty portrait of a broken marriage directed by Andrew McCarthy. Call it “Virginia Woolf” Lite.

headline: Stark Contrasts Between McCain and Obama in Judicial Wars
text: WASHINGTON  The presidential election, lawyers and scholars agree, will offer voters a choice between two sharply different visions for the ideological shape of the nation’s federal courts.

headline: Footnotes
text: Featuring 170 works, a $7.1 million museum dedicated to the Belgian Surrealist René Magritte is to open in Brussels on June 9, 2009, the director of Belgium’s fine arts museums, Michel Draguet, announced on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported.  ... Al Jaffee, above, the veteran Mad magazine cartoonist, received the Reuben Award as cartoonist of the year at the National Cartoonists Society’s annual ceremony in New Orleans, according to the group’s Web site (reuben.org). Mr. Jaffee, 87, who lives in Manhattan, created the Mad Fold-In in 1964 and still draws it. He is also known for Mad’s “Snappy Answers to Stupid Questions.” Also nominated for the award, often called the profession’s top honor, were Dave Coverly, who draws “Speed Bump,” and Dan Piraro, who draws “Bizarro.” ... The Brooklyn Philharmonic, led by a guest conductor, George Garrett Keast, and featuring the violinist Tim Fain, will present a free concert in Central Park at 7:30 p.m. on June 24 as part of the 103rd season of the Naumburg Orchestral Concert Series. The performance, in the Naumburg Bandshell, will include works by Mozart, Stravinsky and Beethoven. ... Carl Reiner will be saluted by the National Yiddish Theater Folksbiene at a gala benefit concert on June 17 at Town Hall, where Brian Williams, a self-described Yiddish enthusiast, will serve as host, and featured guests will include Mary Tyler Moore, Theodore Bikel, Fyvush Finkel, Jerry Stiller  and Anne Meara and Renée Taylor. ... Running from mid-January to mid-April, an exhibition devoted to the life of the Danish-American entertainer Victor Borge will be presented at Scandinavian House to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth.

headline: In Rare Move, 3 Candidates Join in Pledge on Darfur
text: WASHINGTON  The three senators who would be president have agreed to a rare joint statement accusing the Sudanese government of atrocities against civilians in Darfur and warning it not to try to run out the clock on the Bush administration, which has called the killings in Darfur genocide.

headline: Chancellor Talks of Cuts for Schools, Amid Hissing
text: If Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein were looking for allies in his latest battle with state officials over education funding, he would have found few in the City Council chamber on Tuesday.

headline: Caught in Sting, Mayor and Ex-Lawmaker Pleads Guilty in 2 Courts
text: NEWARK  A prominent New Jersey Democrat who had served simultaneously as the mayor of Orange and a state assemblyman pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Tuesday to one count of attempted extortion, and in state court to another count of official misconduct.

headline: Using the President, but Carefully Going Only So Far
text: PHOENIX  The last time the two met  83 days ago  President Bush promised that he would do whatever Senator John McCain asked him to do to help elect him the 44th president.

headline: Ballerina Is Injured
text: Diana Vishneva is injured and will not dance as scheduled in American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake” on Thursday night at Lincoln Center. (Her replacement, one of Ballet Theater’s other Russian stars, Nina Ananiashvili, will dance with Marcelo Gomes.) Ms. Vishneva’s manager, Sergei Danilian, said the dancer originally hurt her ankle in April, while performing with the Kirov Ballet during its New York season. Ms. Vishneva did dance a short solo, “The Dying Swan,” at Ballet Theater’s opening-night gala, but Mr. Danilian said that her injury has worsened. Kelly Ryan, a Ballet Theater spokeswoman, said that Ms. Vishneva would not appear in Twyla Tharp’s new “Rabbit and Rogue,” which opens next week. “We are hopeful that she will be able to perform in ‘Don Quixote’ on June 11, and in ‘Giselle’ on July 11,” Ms. Ryan said. In addition to her Ballet Theater commitments, Ms. Vishneva is scheduled to appear on June 15 in Moscow, at a gala arranged in honor of the Bolshoi ballerina Marina Semonova, and in St. Petersburg, Russia, on June 22 in her own show, “Beauty in Motion.”

headline: What You Get for ... $10 Million
text: Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: New Challenge for Space Station Crew: A Broken Toilet
text: Four words you don’t want to hear in space:

headline: Terror and the Internet: Senator Lieberman Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Odom’s Finishing Touch Helps Lakers Hold On
text: SAN ANTONIO – A rivalry layered with big shots, big stars and tension that often stretches deep into May added a new chapter Tuesday night. A 3-pointer that went wide at the buzzer. An apparent foul that wasn't called. And a superstar with nerves of steel admitting to a minor anxiety attack.

headline: Defining Two Years of Residency
text: Q. I understand that in order to qualify for the $250,000 or $500,000 capital gains tax exclusion on the sale of a principal residence, the taxpayer must use the home as his or her principal residence for two of the five years preceding the sale.

headline: Russia: Court Dismisses Charges Against Media Advocate
text: The Constitutional Court threw out smuggling charges against the head of a Western-backed independent media organization last year. Manana A. Aslamazyan, the director of the Educated Media Foundation, had been charged with failing to declare about $13,000 in cash upon arrival in Russia in January 2007. The authorities confiscated documents and computers from her organization, forcing it to shut down. Human rights advocates said the incident was part of a broader government crackdown on independent media.

headline: When It Comes to Politics, Burmese Say, Government Is All Too Helpful
text: MEE LAUNG KWIN, Myanmar  As the fisherman sat mending cyclone-damaged nets in his riverside hut here on Saturday, he said he had not known it was the day he and other residents of the Irrawaddy Delta were supposed to vote on the new military-backed Constitution.

headline: Democrats Miss Marks to Finance Convention
text: The Democratic Party is struggling to raise money for its convention in Denver on Aug. 25-28, with fund-raising by the host committee falling far short of the party’s goals and lagging behind the Republicans’ efforts for their convention in Minneapolis-St. Paul.

headline: The ‘Endangered’ Lower East Side
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pasta With Soft-Shell Crabs
text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: Paris Chooses Tower by Jean Nouvel for La Défense
text: The French architect Jean Nouvel has been selected to design a high-rise building that will strikingly alter the skyline in La Défense business district on the outskirts of Paris, officials announced on Tuesday. His project was chosen from among those of five finalists, among them Norman Foster and Daniel Libeskind. The building, dubbed the Signal Tower, is part of an ambitious plan to revitalize La Défense that was conceived in 2006 when Nicolas Sarkozy, who is now France’s president, led a public body dedicated to that goal. Patrick Devedjian, who succeeded him, said the tower would be the “most important architectural act since the Eiffel Tower.” Comprising four segments that resemble stacked cubes, the tower will have apartments on the upper floors, as well as a hotel, offices and a business plaza. (Above, an artist’s rendering of an interior view, and, right, of the tower, shown with the Grande Arche.) It is to be completed by 2015. Mr. Nouvel, who captured the Pritzker Prize, architecture’s top honor, this year, also designed the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which opened in 2006, and is at work on a satellite of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Nude Photos Ignite Australian Debate
text: Cate Blanchett joined forces on Tuesday with prominent people in the arts to protest plans by the police to initiate an obscenity prosecution over images by Bill Henson, an eminent photographer, that feature nude 12- and 13-year-olds, Agence France-Presse reported. An open letter signed by Ms. Blanchett, who, with her husband, the playwright Andrew Upton, is a joint artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, declared that the potential prosecution “does untold damage to our cultural reputation.” The signers included Elizabeth Ann Macgregor, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney, and the writer Larissa Behrendt.  Last week, responding to a complaint from a member of the public, the police raided and closed the Henson exhibition at the Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery in Sydney and seized 20 works. They said they were likely to bring charges in connection with the images, described by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd as “absolutely revolting.” All the signers of the protest letter took part last month in Canberra in Mr. Rudd’s national summit on future directions. The letter said that Mr. Henson’s “work itself is not pornographic, even though it includes depictions of naked human beings. It is more justly seen in a tradition of the nude in art that stretches back to the ancient Greeks, and which includes painters such as Caravaggio and Michelangelo.”

headline: Suddenly, Ricotta’s a Big Cheese
text: “Bland can be wonderful,” said Gabe Thompson, the chef at dell’Anima in the West Village. “Bland is important.” Mr. Thompson was talking about the role of fresh ricotta in his kitchen.

headline: Canadian Official Quits Ahead of Ex-Lover’s Interview
text: OTTAWA  First Maxime Bernier lost his girlfriend. Then he lost his job as Canada’s minister of foreign affairs.

headline: Solid Foundation vs. Quick Renovation
text: “Don’t brag about your lightning pace, for Slow and Steady won the race!”

headline: It’s Spring, and Many Honeybees Choose to Call New York Home
text: Thousands of years of evolution and cultivation have led honeybees to seek certain qualities in a home  the ideal being something like a hollowed-out wooden tree limb.

headline: Chief of Vodafone Unexpectedly Resigns
text: The chief executive of Vodafone, Arun Sarin, who steered the cellphone operator in a sometimes tempestuous five-year pursuit of growth, will resign at the end of July, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Anchors to Stage Live Cancer Benefit
text: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, representatives for the networks said in interviews. Among those who encouraged the networks to put aside their competitive instincts, albeit temporarily, was Katie Couric, anchor of the “CBS Evening News,” who will appear on the fund-raiser alongside her principal rivals, Brian Williams of NBC and Charles Gibson of ABC. All three have had immediate family members die of the disease, and another principal, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC and Ms. Couric’s former boss, is a colon cancer survivor.

headline: 007 Runs Full-Throttle Through a New Book
text: It’s the big day: the 100th anniversary of the birth of Ian Fleming. Without Fleming, who died in 1964 at 56, we would never have had the debonair company of James Bond, the creative sadism of Goldfinger and Dr. No or the pet octopus named Octopussy. Without the benefit of Fleming, however, we’ve had Octopussy as a cinematic Bond Girl in 1983, part of a movie franchise that is miraculously resuscitated (most recently by Daniel Craig as Bond in “Casino Royale”) each time it falters, and a string of ersatz Bond books by fill-in writers. To this shaky bibliography we can now add “Devil May Care.”

headline: Germany Remembers Persecuted Gays
text: A monument featuring two men kissing was unveiled by Germany in Berlin on Tuesday in memory of thousands of homosexuals who were persecuted, tortured and killed by the Nazis, Agence France-Presse reported. Designed by the Danish-born Michael Elmgreen and the Norwegian-born Ingar Draset, both based in Berlin, the memorial, situated in the Tiergarten park, near the Brandenburg Gate and the Holocaust memorial, consists of a gray concrete slab about 13 feet high. Inside, at eye level, is a gap filled by a television screen that shows the kissing men, above. Bernd Neumann, Germany’s minister of culture,  evoked the present when he said the monument was “also first and foremost an expression of our conviction that in our country there is no place for the discrimination of homosexuals, of people who think and live differently.” On hand for the unveiling was Berlin’s openly gay mayor, Klaus Wowereit, but no survivors. The last known survivor, Pierre Seel, died in November 2005. Homosexuality was illegal in Germany until 1969 and not formally decriminalized until 1994.

headline: Corrections: For the Record

headline: Hit Shows in Britain Suffer Body Blow
text: Out-of-context theater reviews in advertisements that make a theatrical turkey sound like the second coming of “Hamlet” are now subject to criminal prosecution in Britain, Variety has reported. Enacted in response to European Union regulations, a consumer protection law that took effect on Monday to combat misleading or aggressive marketing practices empowers prosecutors to defend the hoodwinked. The prosecutors must prove that theatergoers were misled. Guilty theater operators could be fined as much as $9,900 and sent to prison for two years.

headline: From Belgium, Sweetened for Americans
text: The specialties at Le Petit Belge, a tiny takeout shop at 22 East 14th Street, are thick, round Belgian Liège-style waffles and poffys, puffy silver-dollar-size pancakes that come piled in a paper cone. Either indulgence ($3.50 a portion, plain) can be ordered with toppings including caramel, strawberries, chocolate, whipped cream, granola and banana. Plain frozen yogurt is the only topping that is not sweet.

headline: Geometries | Fort Tompkins
text: Fort Tompkins, which dates to the 17th century and began to assume its current masonry form in 1807, was for decades a vital element in the defense of New York Harbor. In the 19th-century fortification on the north coast of Staten Island, opposing walls, the scarp and counterscarp, are faced with granite and have rifle slits in them, which enabled troops to create a cross-fire to fend off attackers in the ditch between the walls.

headline: The Call of the Meat Eater

headline: If a Terrace Is Unusable, Is the Rent Reduced?
text: I rent a penthouse studio with a large terrace. There is major construction on the exterior of the building, making the terrace impossible to use. text: Ahead of this year’s Tony Awards, to be presented live on CBS on Sunday, June 15, Bobby Cannavale, who is nominated for his performance in “Mauritius,” and Martha Plimpton, who is nominated for her role in “Top Girls,” took readers’ questions on their shows, their acting careers and being Tony nominees.

headline: Defining Two Years of Residency
text: I understand that in order to qualify for the $250,000 or $500,000 capital gains tax exclusion on the sale of a principal residence, the taxpayer must use the home as his or her principal residence for two of the five years preceding the sale.

headline: Tattoos of the High Seas
text: Sailors roll up their sleeves (and shirts) to reveal their tattoos. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: The Starting Line: Smog, Golf, Stadiums and Banned Swimmers
text: The Wednesday pollution reading in Beijing reached “hazardous,” the second-worst of the eight air quality categories used by the municipal government. The conditions in the capital evoked the spectre of event cancellations at the Games, which the International Olympic Committee promised it would do if the smog is too thick in August.

headline: What Your Eyes Say About Your Mood
text: Has anyone ever told you that you looked sad or tired when you weren’t? If the problem isn’t your mood, it might be your face, according to a study in the medical journal Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery.

headline: M.T.A. Board Will Fight for Its Free E-ZPass Tags
text: Updated, 5:26 p.m. | For years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has given its board members free passes to drive across its bridges and tunnels without paying tolls and to ride the subways, buses and commuter railroads without paying a fare. And when the board members retire, they are allowed to keep the passes for life.On Wednesday the authority said it will go to court to defend the practice in the face of a challenge by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that giving E-ZPass tags to board members violates a law that they must serve without compensation.

headline: Changing Islam From the Inside
text: New York University has just started up a potentially important program called the Moral Courage Project, run by a spiky-haired dynamo named Irshad Manji (I’ve said more about her, as well as Ayaan Hirsi Ali, here). The program seeks to encourage and promote maverick scholars and writers who dissent from the orthodoxies of their own communities without giving up their particular identities or affiliations. Fittingly, its first speaker was the Sudanese scholar Abdullahi Ahmed An-Na’im, the author of a remarkable book, “Islam and the Secular State.”

headline: Packing Up Alexander Hamilton’s Country Home
text: Alexander Hamilton’s country home, the Grange, has been sitting on Convent Avenue and 141st Street for 119 years; long enough for neighbors to get well used to it. On Monday, however, it drew all kinds of astonished stares.

headline: Prado to Ride Casino Drive
text: ELMONT, N.Y. — The two-time Belmont Stakes winner Edgar Prado will ride undefeated Casino Drive in the test of the champion, Nobutaka Tada, racing manager for owner Hidetoshi Yamamot, announced Wednesday.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, May 28:

headline: Even Without ‘Idol,’ Fox Leads the Ratings
text: On Tuesday night — the first Tuesday in months that Fox has not had “American Idol” to lift it to the top of the ratings — “Hell’s Kitchen” did the trick instead, as 9.4 million viewers tuned in to the cooking competition at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although CBS’s “NCIS” repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), the Fox reality series remained far and away the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Q&A: Matt Answers Readers’ Comments
text: Hundreds of readers’ comments have streamed in, ranging from congratulatory (“Can’t wait to read your blogs and see your pics!” wrote JCurtis) and hospitable (“Send me a note and we’ll treat you to a low-cost beer!” offered Matt Moore of Frankfurt), to downright hostile. My bluejeans were a popular target, which made me realize I had to answer a few questions and clear up some misconceptions.

headline: Fire Damages Vacant Bronx Factory
text: People walking around East Harlem and the Upper East Side this afternoon may have noticed black smoke billowing in the air, visible from quite a distance. The Fire Department says the smoke is from a vacant factory, under construction, that caught fire in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx. No injuries were reported in the fire, at 80 Bruckner Boulevard, near the Willis Avenue Bridge, and the authorities said the fire has not posed any danger to residents or workers.

headline: LifeLock CEO’s Identity Wasn’t So Secure After All
text: I just read Dan Tynan’s awesome review of identity-theft protection services in PC World.

headline: Clarke and McClellan: 2004 and Now
text: Earlier today, Richard A. Clarke noted that Scott McClellan’s adventure in memoir writing was much like his own — they both criticized the Bush administration and in turn faced harsh attacks. But a statement from Mr. McClellan in 2004, dug up by Karen Tumulty of Time magazine, demonstrated a connection so direct that it seemed a little eerie.

headline: Show Us Your Tattoos, Sailor
text: Video

headline: Answers About Fighting Poverty in New York
text: Following is the first set of answers from David R. Jones, the president of the Community Service Society of New York. This week, he is answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy.

headline: McCain Raps Obama Again on Iraq, Preconditions
text: Updated RENO, Nev. — Senator John McCain intensified his criticism of Senator Barack Obama today as a leader willing to meet with the president of Iran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, but not the top American commander in Baghdad, General David H. Petraeus.

headline: China’s Dams Under Pressure
text: Engineers, construction workers and soldiers were racing Wednesday to relieve pressure on the  dammed Bai He River in Sichuan Province that threatens millions of people who live downstream -- most of them survivors of the devastating May 12 earthquake.

headline: Honestly? | Ali Lohan Channeling Blair Waldorf
text: Spotted: Little Lohan playing dress up. (Getty Images)

headline: Park the Car, Part 2
text: Late in the afternoon on Memorial Day, I drove from Putnam County, north of New York, to Manhattan, a trip I often take on Sunday afternoons. The weather was glorious. But I cannot recall a day when there was less traffic.

headline: Border Dispute Risks Red Sea Trade
text: A border conflict between Djibouti and Eritrea could disrupt a vital international trade route.

headline: 'Black Watch'
text: An excerpt from the production by the National Theater of Scotland.

headline: Game 3 Warm-up: Sydor in for Pens; Messier Anoints Sundin
text: As expected, the Red Wings were in the quiet hum of their routine at Wednesday’s pre-game skate, and the Penguins felt the need to change something — anything — to jar themselves from a scoreless funk. So defenseman Darryl Sydor is in, despite not having played a game since March, and Kris Letang is out.

headline: Dancing, Dating, Joking Among Summer TV Options
text: As the September-to-May television season wrapped up last week, “summer series were quick to appear on the schedule, and no immediate excitement was obvious” from viewers, the Associated Press reports.

headline: Are Sumo Wrestlers Sexy?
text: After many years of selling the responsibility of all-wheel drive and safety, Subaru wants to make more of an emotional connection between the brand and its buyers.

headline: Pattern Recognition: Hey, That’s Levittown
text: CHICAGO — Say what you will about New York City’s suburbs, but kaleidoscopic ornamentation usually does not come to mind.

headline: Exxon’s Texas-Size War Chest
text: The oil industry is known to be very conservative. And Exxon Mobil, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, may be the most conservative of the bunch. It refuses to invest in projects that would lower its industry-leading return on capital employed, which is now around 35 percent. Rather than use its phenomenal cash flow for huge, dilutive acquisitions, it prefers to spend billions of dollars to buy back its own stock.

headline: Making Friends (and Dinner) in Paris
text: Paris—city of light! capital of romance! home to epicures and bon vivants!—has always been, for me, something of a lonely city. I’ve visited several times before, and though I wasn’t always solo (one trip was with my family, another was to visit the woman who would eventually become my wife), I would end up pacing the streets by myself for hours, unsure of what to do and where to go and how to find someone, anyone, to connect with.

headline: A Catchy Title and Contagious Formula for Leadership
text: This week’s Shifting Careers column for the Small Business section focuses on a popular class taught by Stewart Friedman at the Wharton School. Mr. Friedman teaches a model of management that he calls “total leadership,” which basically means leadership that is informed by a person’s values and is reflected in all aspects of life, not just work.

headline: For Chinese Star, Just Another Race
text: Chinese track star and Olympic hopeful, Liu Xiang, speaks to the media at the Empire State Building.

headline: A Football Scientist Looks at the Jets
text: As ESPN’s “Football Scientist,” K.C. Joyner uses statistics to analyze the N.F.L.

headline: A Few Things to Think About
text: I must admit that I am still a bit too sun-dried after Memorial Day weekend to focus on events in the market.

headline: Don’t Text and Drive. Play it Safe: Name a Designated Texter
text: Laws against drunk driving will never be passe, but they are not the cutting edge in car safety these days. That would be anti-texting laws.

headline: Obama Says He Is Considering Iraq Trip
text: THORNTON, Colo. – Senator Barack Obama said today that he is considering visiting American troops and commanders in Iraq this summer. He declined an invitation from Senator John McCain to take a joint trip to Iraq, saying, “I just don’t want to be involved in a political stunt.”

headline: For Cup on NBC, Even a Tiny Audience Would Count as Huge
text: Tonight the 2008 Stanley Cup final makes its U.S. broadcast network debut, moving to NBC from the quiet niche of Versus. There have been a number of breathless stories over the last couple of days about the relatively large audience the Detroit-Pittsburgh final has drawn on Versus, which invariably include the phrase “second only to Lance Armstrong’s final ride in the 2005 Tour de France for the highest-rated in the network’s history.” There has also been a lot of talk about how this year’s ratings are way up, like 275 percent up, over those of the 2006 and 2005 finals.

headline: TiVo Posts A First Quarter Profit
text: Associated Press: “Digital video recorder pioneer TiVo reported Wednesday that its first-quarter net income more than quadrupled as operating costs, most notably for marketing and research, declined.”

headline: Viacom Sees Ad Growth Slowing In 2nd Quarter

text:
Chris Hayes of The Nation, left, and Matthew Continetti of The Weekly Standard question the McCain campaign's competency.

headline: Penny Pinching Looks Great
text: The men’s style landscape has reached a price point that is, even for the overdrawn 2008 wallet, affordable. And men are responding.

headline: Player Ratings: England 2, U.S. 0
text: The United States now has a 2-7 record against England after Wednesday’s defeat at Wembley in a series that dates to 1950 (if you do not know what happened then, it is time to do some research).

headline: Who’s Smarter: Bill Gates or Mark Zuckerberg?
text: A variety of legends have grown up around Bill Gates’ brief career at Harvard. (He dropped out halfway through and co-founded Microsoft). On Tuesday night, during an interview at the “D: All Things Digital” conference in Carlsbad, Calif., Mr. Gates regaled the audience with his strategy of not bothering to attend classes and then catching up in a single intense burst during a separate reading period at the end of the term.

headline: Restoration Row
text: (Photo: A bison in Theodore Roosevelt National Park, in North Dakota. (Credit: Dan Koeck for The New York Times)) PAWHUSKA, Okla. – It is hard to love a land you don't understand, and for most of my life I had no idea why anyone would ever live in the Great Plains – let alone love the place.   Flat, featureless, boring. Those were the words I heard growing up whenever someone would mention the plains. My view was informed by Dorothy's Kansas, which looked scary and Gothic even before the twister took her house and Toto, too.  But then I spent some time here, mostly listening to people in the twilight of their lives tell about the land when it turned on them, during the Dust Bowl of the 1930s. At the end of a long day of hearing stories, I would go for a run in the wind, and sometimes get a glimpse of the magic of the place — a pronghorn antelope in a sprint, a sky blushing pink, the quiet when the air finally settles.   There are people with us still who remember the Great Plains in its birthday suit, grass as far as the eye could see, what Walt Whitman called, "that delicate miracle, the ever-recurring grass."   That land is gone to us, now. Once, the grassland in our midsection spanned at least 14 states, from Minnesota to Texas, the second biggest ecosystem in North America. It's gone because the grass was overturned and the bison were chased off the land and the riot of biodiversity that evolved over 10,000 years was replaced by a few commodity crops to feed us.   It's not worth arguing over whether this was a good or a bad thing, because most of the intentions were good, even if the excesses were bad. But it's always worthwhile to wonder whether humans can fix what they screwed up.   And here, just north of this little town in Osage Indian country, I saw some evidence that the land can be healed. I saw shaggy-headed bison and their calves, several thousand of them, in a setting that was neither park nor zoo. I saw grass stretching almost to the horizon, flowering in parts, combed by the wind. I saw the sun dip behind the lilt of the Flint Hills, closing out a day with a burst of color.   This miracle of restoration is the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve, nearly 40,000 acres run by the Nature Conservancy. It is the largest protected remnant of tallgrass prairie left on earth, according the stewards of this land – cowboys with advanced botany degrees.   The conservancy bought this land in 1989 and then set out to bring it back. The two biggest missing elements – fire and bison – were returned. Both renew the grass, distribute seeds, and keep the carpet of big bluestem, wild rye and other species healthy.   The result is somewhat astonishing. Over 300 species of forbs, grasses and flowers are here. And while this preserve is just a patch, an anchored Noah's Ark of what used to cover much of the continent, it says something about restoration. Bit by bit, maybe some of what we lost can be brought back.   I say this at a time when nearly all commercial salmon fishing has been halted on the West Coast. What used to be a rite of the season – a taste of the wild, spring Chinook returning to the Columbia River, the richest salmon on earth – is almost a memory this year.   But look also at bald eagles that fly in all 50 states, a byproduct of strong laws and far-sighted bird lovers. From my house in a metro area of nearly 3 million people, I can see a pair of nesting bald eagles.   We restore things to the wild, and in time, they return the favor. Think of Nick Adams, the psychically wounded veteran coming home to the nurturing water in Hemingway's "Big Two-Hearted River."   So even with the sky here in Oklahoma rumbling and clacking, menaced by twisters rolling down Tornado Alley, there is just enough of the original plains at the Tallgrass Preserve to make flatland believers out of skeptics.   You can see in the remains of a day the reason why people who came here a hundred years ago were so lonely — and, also, why they fell in love with the place.

headline: Restoration Row
text: PAWHUSKA, Okla. – It is hard to love a land you don’t understand, and for most of my life I had no idea why anyone would ever live in the Great Plains – let alone love the place.

headline: Affordable Classics
text: The cost of gasoline and eggs may be soaring, but most clothing has gotten cheaper in the last decade.

headline: On Location
text: An artist-designer and her son live in a Pennsylvania home that is an experiment in art, design and communal creativity.

headline: Ready… Set… Joba!
text: Pettitte, 6.2 innings … Chamberlain 1.1 innings … Rivera 1 inning.

headline: Global Demand Squeezing Natural Gas Supply
text: CAMERON PARISH, La.  The cost of a gallon of gas gets all the headlines, but the natural gas that will heat many American homes next winter is going up in price as fast or faster.

headline: Kennedy Is Put on Disabled List, But He May Throw in a Week
text: BALTIMORE  The Yankees were encouraged to learn on Wednesday that Ian Kennedy could be throwing in a week or two. Then again, with Joba Chamberlain increasing his pitch count and Kennedy struggling, it is not known where Kennedy will pitch when he returns.

headline: Shopping for Wedding Gifts With Gregory Krum
text: WEDDING season is upon us, and with it the perpetual question of what to give to the newlyweds.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Garden Benefit

headline: Chamberlain Helps Out in Possible Relief Finale
text: BALTIMORE  As the Yankees’ manager, Joe Girardi tries to win every game while implementing the long-term vision of the front office. He studied industrial engineering at Northwestern, but he probably never attempted an experiment like this.

headline: Do I Detect a Hint of ... Joe?
text: THOUGH wine tastings seem to have become less pretentious in recent years, it’s still rare to hear a top varietal compared to Cinnamon Toast Crunch cereal. But at coffee tastings  known to aficionados as cuppings  there is no prescribed lexicon, and a lot more room for whimsy.

headline: Tip of the Week: Using Autofill for Your Spreadsheet
text: The autofill feature of your spreadsheet program is a great way to save your hands from having to type common sets of data like the days of the week or months of the year. In Microsoft Excel, for example, type “January” into a cell and press the Enter key. Select the cell and drag the small square handle down 11 more cells to fill in the rest of the months. Illustrated instructions are at snipurl.com/2a4zt. You can do the same thing with Google Spreadsheets, as explained at snipurl.com/2a4zz. J. D. BIERSDORFER

headline: Ruling Near on Boeing-Airbus Dispute
text: FRANKFURT  Airbus and Boeing have packed a decade’s worth of drama into the nearly four years since the United States and Europe began a battle over state aid for their aircraft industries.

headline: An 18th-Century Satire Gets a 21st-Century Spin
text: Why stage a 229-year-old play by Frances Burney that went unseen for a couple of centuries? To make some scholarly point, perhaps, about a woman who was ahead of her time, or about the stifling of the feminine voice throughout history?

headline: Texas Suit Over Voting Is Settled
text: HOUSTON  A voting-rights lawsuit accusing the Texas attorney general of harassing Democratic and minority activists who were helping elderly or disabled voters mail in their ballots was settled on Wednesday, with state officials agreeing to clarify antifraud measures.

headline: Human Rights Report Assails U.S.
text: PARIS  Sixty years after the United Nations adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, governments in scores of countries still torture or mistreat their people, Amnesty International said Wednesday in a report that again urged the United States to close down the Guantánamo Bay detention camp in Cuba.

headline: Ex-Aide Turns Critic; Chorus Strikes Back
text: WASHINGTON  As President Bush’s press secretary, Scott McClellan was a dutiful practitioner of the swift, efficient and highly coordinated strategy the White House typically employs to take on Mr. Bush’s critics.

headline: Lottery Numbers
France: Sarkozy Pulls Down European Labor Rules
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy announced that France would open its borders on July 1 to all workers from eight former Communist countries that joined the European Union four years ago. The move, announced in Poland, abolishes restrictions a year earlier than planned. The eight countries  Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia  have faced labor market restrictions in several Western European countries.

headline: Aid to the Burmese Cyclone Victims
text: To the Editor:

headline: British Leader Warns of Global Oil Price Shock
text: PARIS  As protests against the soaring cost of fuel threatened to widen in Europe, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain warned on Wednesday that the world confronted a global shock caused by skyrocketing oil prices.

headline: Sharapova Survives Wind and Swirling Clay
text: PARIS  Perhaps Paris in the spring is not so idyllic after all. After the rain and lightning on Monday and Tuesday came high winds on Wednesday to stir up the clay and the top seed at the French Open.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about a gift to New York City parks from the Leon Levy Foundation referred incorrectly to a project for which the New York Botanical Garden received $15 million. It is to create a native plant garden for the study and display of Northeastern flora, not a native plant bed.

headline: Rival to Iran’s President Is Elected Speaker
text: TEHRAN  A rival to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was elected by an overwhelming majority as speaker of the Iranian Parliament on Wednesday, a strong signal of growing impatience with the president’s economic policies and a possible sign of a political shift in the country.

headline: Durable Goods Show a Smaller Dip Than Was Forecast
text: A crucial measure of business spending declined less than expected in April, a sign that businesses might be breathing easier about the economy, although orders for cars and computer equipment still dipped, the government said Wednesday.

headline: Recalling Ancient Times: Say, 10 or 20 Years Ago
text: Research involves risky leaps forward, and as Somewhere Out There, Movement Research’s spring festival, continues to unfold through June 8 with discussions, workshops, performances and various strange outings, the area in and around Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village promises to be full of experimentation. If you want to see where dance is headed, start here.

headline: Racial Shift in a Progressive City Spurs Talks
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Not every neighborhood in this city is one of those Northwest destinations where passion for espresso, the environment and plenty of exercise define the cultural common ground. A few places are still described as frontiers, where pioneers move because prices are relatively reasonable, the location is convenient and, they say, they “want the diversity.”

headline: A Restless Couple at Rest
text: PETER MOORE’S first real estate venture lasted only 48 hours. He was 19, in the middle of a year off from Columbia, and living with his family in their town house on East 84th Street when he signed a lease on a 5,000-square-foot loft on Lispenard Street, borrowing the deposit money for the $800-a-month space from his parents.

headline: Pre-K System Faulted as Confusing to Parents
text: A new application process intended to simplify pre-kindergarten enrollment has left parents confused and angry about options for their children, New York City’s public advocate said on Wednesday.

headline: City Revises Safety Rules on Cranes
text: City inspectors will no longer be present every time a construction crane is erected or made taller, officials said on Wednesday, as they continued to modify safeguards put in place after the collapse of a crane 10 weeks ago that killed seven people on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about the breaching of a dam on the Clark Fork River in Montana as part of a toxic waste cleanup misstated the reason that arsenic-laden waste is found in the river. The waste comes from naturally occurring arsenic in the ore minerals that have been mined in the area over the years; arsenic was not used by miners to separate metal from rock.

headline: Old Meters Mean Double the Price at the Pump
text: For a brief moment on Wednesday morning, the gas pump at Gary Staiano’s Texstar service station in Bellerose, Queens, turned into a time machine. After 11.3 gallons was pumped into a Pontiac Grand Am, the meter read $23, or $2.03 a gallon, a price not seen in more than three years.

headline: Sony Taps Into Photo Archive as a Resource During Hard Times
text: Some of Sony’s music executives believe there is a gold mine under the company’s New York headquarters on Madison Avenue. It doesn’t look like much: just a small room, three floors below ground level, with a wall full of the sliding shelves you’d find in a law firm or university library.

headline: Democrats Are Advised to Seat Half of 2 States’ Delegations
text: Democratic Party lawyers have determined that no more than half the delegates from Florida and Michigan can be seated at the party’s August convention, dealing a blow to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s efforts to seat the full delegations from those states.

headline: In Her Own World
text: BEACH Lake, Pa.

headline: Staten Island Democrats Choose a Councilman as Their Candidate for Fossella’s Seat
text: The Staten Island Democratic Party voted on Wednesday night to endorse City Councilman Michael E. McMahon as its choice for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican.

headline: In Dispute on Free Transit Passes, It’s New York Agency vs. State’s Top Lawyer
text: It is a contrast that has often galled some commuters: While they have to pay their way on trains, buses and bridges, members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board, many of them quite wealthy, travel free.

headline: New Life for an Old PC
