headline: Bullfighting is Dead! Long Live Bullfighting!
text: "As Spain goes, so goes toreo, or bullfighting, Michael Kimmelman writes in PLAY. In today's Spain, though, a curious divide exists between indifference to and fascination with bullfighting. While the country apparently cares less than ever about what bullfighters do, it is loathe to have people from the outside demand that it's time to do away with this centuries-old tradition. Even as it is ignored by a new generation of Spaniards and attacked by animal rights activists, it persists as a complex part of the national consciousness. There are more bullfights now than ever, and as Kimmelman writes, "Spaniards tell their children to be nice to the dog, but they talk bullfighting with their friends."

headline: Each Experience Speaks Its Own Language
text: “Glossolalia: Languages of Drawing” is the most exciting exhibition of drawings the Museum of Modern Art has produced in years. Organized by Connie Butler, the museum’s chief curator of drawings, it presents a delightfully unpredictable mix of about 100 works by two distinct groups: self-taught outsider artists and idiosyncratic but conventionally trained professionals, many of whom have been inspired by outsider art.

headline: Charges of Insider Trading for a Wall Street Luminary
text: John F. Marshall spent decades teaching at business schools and watching his students parlay his lessons into fortunes on Wall Street. But when he and another professor reached for some of those riches themselves, events took a startling turn, the authorities say.

headline: Riding the Road to Beijing Aboard the U.S.A. Local
text: ROHNERT PARK, Calif.  Just where in the world was the United States Olympic softball team? It should not take eight hours to get here from Visalia, even with a McDonald’s stop in Madera and an out-of-the-way detour through Palo Alto.

They could have fretted over allowing the previously overmatched Penguins to gain confidence. They could have started obsessing over Saturday’s Game 4.

headline: Off the Grid, but Plugged In
text: SOMETIMES you just want to get away from it all. And that doesn’t mean simply turning the phone off. For some second-home owners it means escaping everyday stress by going off-grid  living life more or less unplugged.

headline: Where Have All the Paintings Gone? To the National Academy
text: If you emerged from the Whitney Biennial wondering where all the painting went, don’t despair. An alternative view of the state of contemporary art can be found at the National Academy’s annual exhibition. This year’s show is a non-member affair (alternate years are members-only), which means that it is about as lively as a juried exhibition organized by committee can be.

headline: Was Press a War ‘Enabler’? 2 Offer a Nod From Inside
text: In his new memoir, “What Happened,” Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, said the national news media neglected their watchdog role in the run-up to the invasion of Iraq, calling reporters “complicit enablers” of the Bush administration’s push for war.

headline: Sculptor as Magician
text: BOSTON  The Indian-born, London-based sculptor Anish Kapoor has always been a kind of magician, which cuts two ways. Whether with blazingly reflective metal surfaces or dark, plush, seemingly infinite interiors, his pieces dispense multiple visual thrills and mysteries. But the same effects can make his work appear tricky, decorative and shallow. It hasn’t helped that they seem to have been concocted by playing fast and slick with the innovations of his Minimalist and Post-Minimalist predecessors.

headline: What to Ask About Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

headline: Lesser Lights Get Chance to Shine at French Open
text: PARIS  After an early whiff of trouble and another rain delay, it turned into a fine day for Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer, but then it is usually a fine day for those two in the early stages of the French Open.

headline: A New Life, but the Same Old Family
text: The dream for Harry Bernstein’s mother, raising six children in poverty in England after the First World War, was America. It will surprise no one that this dream sours. But for the Bernsteins, who arrived in Chicago in 1922, the new world’s disappointments were nothing compared with the harm they did each other. The immigrant’s hell, in this wise, unsentimental memoir, is what they carry with them.

headline: A Step Closer to Justice
text: New Yorkers should be proud of Gov. David Paterson’s efforts to assure basic civil rights for same-sex couples married outside the state. Now, the State Legislature should prove its own commitment to equality and justice by granting gay couples the right to marry in New York State.

headline: McClellan Responds to White House Criticism
text: Former White House press secretary Scott McClellan continued to press his case Thursday that the Bush administration manipulated intelligence to justify the war in Iraq, and responded to a growing chorus of criticism from other former administration officials.

headline: A Lesson for Randolph From Torre
text: As the failed former manager of the Mets, Joe Torre returned to Shea Stadium on Thursday night at the helm of another presently mediocre National League team.

headline: Help Russia Help Us
text: IN a campaign speech this week, John McCain cited the “special responsibility” of the United States and Russia to cooperate to prevent the spread and use of nuclear weapons. There is a remarkable consensus among the presidential candidates about this imperative. But we must not wait until a new administration in 2009 to advance this vital work. An agreement the Bush administration signed with Russia earlier this month is an essential step for this cooperation. That agreement is now before Congress.

headline: Forget the Ibuprofen, Recover Through Your Stomach
text: You've just finished a hard workout, satisfied from a personal best in a 10-mile run or additional reps with free weights. Your attitude is "You'll do it again tomorrow, for sure," Gretchen Reynolds writes in her Phys Ed column "Swallow This." "But then it hits - the aftermath" -- soreness from strained or tired muscles that usually settles in roughly 12-24 hours after a workout. So how can you best repair and refresh those muscles? Start with a postworkout meal full of glucose and protein (no carbo-loading allowed!)

headline: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome No Longer Seen as 'Yuppie Flu'
text: For decades, people suffering from chronic fatigue syndrome have struggled to convince doctors, employers, friends and even family members that they were not imagining their debilitating symptoms. Skeptics called the illness “yuppie flu” and “shirker syndrome.”

headline: Climate Enters Debate Over Nuclear Power
text: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  After part of a cooling tower collapsed last August at Vermont’s only nuclear power plant, the company that runs it blamed rotting wooden timbers that it had failed to inspect properly. The uproar that followed rekindled environmental groups’ hopes of shutting down the aging plant.

headline: South Africa Plans Shelters for Foreigners Who Fled Attacks
text: JOHANNESBURG  The South African government decided Thursday to set up small, temporary shelters rather than large refugee camps for thousands of foreigners driven from their homes in widespread xenophobic violence that hit Johannesburg and Cape Town hardest.

headline: Tough Questions for China on Schools and Japan Aid
text: BEIJING  Japan on Thursday decided against using military aircraft to deliver aid to earthquake victims in China after Chinese officials reportedly expressed concerns about what would have been the first Japanese military deployment to China since the two countries were enemies during World War II.

headline: Wildlife Areas in Balkans to Expand
text: The governments of Albania, Bosnia, Croatia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia agreed to increase cross-border conservation efforts in an area of Southeastern Europe especially rich in wildlife, including bears, lynxes, wolves and golden jackals. The nations said they would create 13 new protected areas and extend 9 others in the Dinaric Arc, an area that stretches from Trieste in Italy to Tirana in Albania. The area, with large areas of undamaged forest, also has some of the richest freshwater ecosystems in the Mediterranean, according to environmentalists.

headline: Obama’s Doctor, Praising His Health, Sees No Obstacles to Service
text: Senator Barack Obama, 46, was in “excellent health” at the time of his last examination more than a year ago and has no known medical problems that would affect his ability to serve as president, according to a letter by his physician released on Thursday.

headline: An Inconvenient Truth, the Opera, for La Scala
text: Al Gore’s “Inconvenient Truth,” first a film and then a book, is now becoming an opera. Officials of the Milan opera house La Scala say the Italian composer Giorgio Battistelli has been commissioned to write it for the 2011 season, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Battistelli is currently the artistic director of the Arena in Verona.

headline: It Sure Sounds Like That Other Vienna Guy, You Know, a Tough Act to Follow
text: Domenico Cimarosa’s comic opera “Il Matrimonio Segreto” had its premiere in Vienna in February 1792, two months after Mozart’s death. The public reception was ecstatic. Mozart never had this kind of success in the city.

headline: For Soldiers, a Fringe Fighting Sport Finds Mainstream Appeal
text: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  When his turn came to fight, Pfc. Carl Miller tied a red karate belt over his camouflage fatigues. Tattooed across his thumbs were the Latin words for “lesson learned.”

headline: First a TV Series, Then Off to Jail
text: The Atlanta rapper T. I., below, in true lemons-to-lemonade fashion, is turning his legal problems into an eight-episode MTV series, Reuters reported. The series will follow him as he performs more than 1,000 hours of community service before starting a one-year sentence on weapons convictions next spring. T. I. (real name: Clifford Harris) has previous convictions. He was arrested in October and charged with possession of unregistered machine guns and possession of firearms by a convicted felon. He is working on a new album, “Paper Trail,” due out Aug. 12. His single “No Matter What” is No. 10 on the Billboard Hot Rap Tracks chart.

headline: Theater Listings
text: TEATROSTAGEFEST 2008 For the second year, several New York City theater companies will team up with colleagues from Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain to present a two-week celebration of Latino performance at several locations around the city. The festival, which includes plays, concerts, comedy, panel discussions and even a high school playwriting competition, starts on Monday, when Bianca Marroquin, Broadway’s current Roxie Hart in “Chicago,” performs a solo evening at Joe’s Pub, offering a mix of her original songs, show tunes and Mexican standards.

headline: Sorry, Your Body’s in My Windshield
text: There are no supernatural happenings, just people under extreme stress succumbing to their worst instincts, in Stuart Gordon’s grim, expert little thriller “Stuck.” Mr. Gordon has enjoyed a cult following since his 1985 horror hit, “Re-Animator.” And “Stuck,” while not strictly a horror film, is steeped in gore and carries a seam of mocking gallows humor as relentless as that of “Sweeney Todd.”

headline: Stonehenge Used as Cemetery From the Beginning
text: At least part of the mystery of Stonehenge may have now been solved: It was from the beginning a monument to the dead.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an editorial on May 25 about Venezuela’s support for the FARC rebel group misstated the location of a FARC camp raided by the Colombian Army. It was in Ecuador, not Venezuela.

headline: NATO Chief in Afghanistan Says Pakistan’s Tack on Militants Is Not as Expected
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The departing American commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan, Gen. Dan K. McNeill, raised concerns on Thursday that Pakistan had not followed through on promises to tackle militancy on its side of the border, and in recent months had even stopped its cooperation with NATO and Afghan counterparts on border issues.

headline: In New York City, Two Versions of End-of-Life Care
text: There are two starkly different paths toward death in New York City’s hospitals, one for patients at elite private institutions, another for those at public hospitals, according to new data compiled as part of a consumer rating system.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on May 11 about veterans’ mental health problems incorrectly described how the Department of Veterans Affairs released data on veterans’ suicide attempts. The information was given to CBS News in reply to a Freedom of Information Act request, not in Congressional testimony by an official.

headline: Agency Sounds an Alarm on Banks’ Shaky Outlooks
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned Thursday that the nation’s ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further.

headline: A Knack for Putting Feminism on Film
text: THE more fanatical a feminist she becomes, the more mascara (mad hot eyelashes) and peroxide (mad hot hair highlights) she piles on: nice contrast to bare feet, jeans, and her “lucky shirt,” a black Harley Davidson tank top.

headline: Sears Holdings Reports an Unexpected Loss
text: The Sears Holdings Corporation, the parent of Sears and Kmart, reported an unexpected $56 million first-quarter loss on Thursday, dealing another setback to Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge fund manager who has struggled to turn the company around.

headline: First-Quarter Economic Growth Stronger Than Estimated
text: The economy grew at a faster pace than originally estimated in the first quarter, the government said Thursday, but the nation remained mired in its most stagnant period of growth in five years.

headline: Shorts at Full Length
text: There are several advantageous contexts for the screening of short films: as a complement to a main feature, at film festivals, in classrooms, as DVD supplements, streaming online. But the feature-length, omnibus program for theatrical release? Not so much.

headline: Courts Reject Two Major Vioxx Verdicts
text: Two major court victories for Merck on Thursday pushed the litigation over the painkiller Vioxx closer to conclusion and highlighted the increasing difficulty that plaintiffs’ lawyers were having in winning lawsuits against big drug companies.

headline: Leaders in Congress Seek to Settle on Nominee
text: WASHINGTON  Hoping to bring their party’s presidential nomination fight to an end, the two top Democrats in Congress said they were pressing superdelegates who had yet to declare a preference in the race to make their choice public by the middle of next week.

headline: New York’s Tap Water
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turning a Century in California
text: A DOZEN miles north of Berkeley, Calif., on a windy day in early May, I stopped by the side of the road and watched a seemingly endless parade of cyclists glide by.

headline: Chateau’s Monkey Room Is Lovingly Restored
text: PARIS  There is something about monkeys, many antiques dealers say, that people find irresistible. Any piece of furniture, candlestick, sculpture or picture with a monkey tends to sell right away. “I’m always looking for monkeys everywhere I go, and they fly out of the shop,” said Phyllis Washington, a dealer based in Palm Desert, Calif. “I can never find enough.”

headline: States of Great: The Starlet
text: If Tiger Woods is the royalty in the current realm of sports greatness, then Floyd Mayweather is the Hollywood entertainer. Too bad he's in an Indie production. Widely regarded as the world's best pound-for-pound boxer, Mayweather is a star in a fringe sport -- famous, but, as Carlo Rotella writes for PLAY, not famous enough to satisfy him. So he's taken control of his career and, while at the top of his profession, is "pursuing mainstream fame and money a la Paris Hilton more strenuously than he's chasing Sugar Ray Robinson and all-time greatness as a boxer."

headline: Mounting Costs Slow the Push for Clean Coal
text: WASHINGTON  For years, scientists have had a straightforward idea for taming global warming. They want to take the carbon dioxide that spews from coal-burning power plants and pump it back into the ground.

headline: At Bear, an Apology Is Met With Silence
text: DROPPING the curtain on 85 years of Wall Street history, shareholders of Bear Stearns voted Thursday to support the troubled investment bank’s controversial, government-backed merger with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,078 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Secretary Gates Visits Guam Military Base
text: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam  Dipping low over this tropical island in a Navy helicopter on Friday, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates gazed out over one of the largest American military construction projects in decades.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Two picture captions on Thursday with an article about efforts in Portland, Ore., to encourage black and white residents to talk about gentrification misstated, in some editions, the name of a street there that was once predominantly black. As the article correctly noted, it is Alberta Street, not Albert.

headline: Going to the Mat to Welcome a Sport to Broadcast TV
text: Gus Johnson’s physical commitment to being CBS’s first choke-by-choke announcer of the EliteXC mixed martial arts card Saturday night found him engaged in ground combat Tuesday night with a partner on the blue mat of Renzo Gracie’s Brazilian jiu-jitsu academy in Manhattan.

headline: Pitcher Used to the Shadows Is a Bright Spot for the Yanks
text: Darrell Rasner won just once for the Yankees last season, and hardly anybody noticed. It was the day a burly Texan burst into the press box at Yankee Stadium and told the crowd he was coming back. Rasner did not mind being overshadowed; it is the story of his career, and besides, he was excited to see Roger Clemens.

headline: A Roller-Coaster Career Takes a Winning Turn
text: When the Mets played the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium on Thursday night, Fernando Tatis was in the starting lineup, just as he was nine years ago, when he had the best inning of his life  perhaps the best inning of any batter’s life.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: The Basics column on Tuesday, about academic programs that combine approaches of both the sciences and the humanities, misstated the title of a book by David Sloan Wilson. It is “Evolution for Everyone,” not “Evolution for Everybody.”

headline: The Pentagon and Me
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harvey Korman of ‘Burnett Show’ Dies at 81
text: Harvey Korman, the award-winning comedic actor who rose to fame playing second banana to Carol Burnett on her television variety series and who starred in hit movies like “Blazing Saddles” and “High Anxiety,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: DNA Offers Clues to Greenland’s First Inhabitants
text: A swatch of hair, so thick and tangled it could have belonged to man or bear, has provided answers about a mysterious culture and its origins half a world away.

headline: Wine Takes Over a Town, and Prosperity Follows
text: WALLA WALLA has always been best known for its sweet onions, wheat fields and a penitentiary. It was a punch line of a town with the funny name that wasn’t on the road to anywhere. Outsiders hardly ever came unless they were attending a college graduation or visiting relatives.

headline: Martin Levin, Prolific Book Reviewer, Dies at 89
text: Martin Levin, a writer, humorist and prolific book critic for whom reading and reviewing five books a week for The New York Times for decades on end was as reasonable, natural and essential as breathing, died on May 21 in Manhattan. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Lustrous, Glittering, Monied Dysfunction
text: “Savage Grace,” Tom Kalin’s long-awaited second feature (after “Swoon”), swoons through a number of lovely, storied places on its way to a sad and sordid end. Narrated by Tony Baekeland (played in young adulthood by Eddie Redmayne), it begins in the post-World War II Manhattan of late-night dinners at the Stork Club and moves on to Paris in the ’50s and then to Spain (Cadaqués and Majorca, to be precise) in the late 1960s and London after that.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Art in Review
text: CHRISTOPHER WOOL

headline: Scott McClellan’s Memoir: If Only ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cut Out the Theatrics: N.B.A. Devises Penalties for ‘Floppers’
text: LOS ANGELES  The N.B.A. likes its players to be entertainers, but when it comes to fouls, the league would like to see a little less dramatic flair.

headline: ‘Recount,’ the Movie: Reliving the 2000 Election
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Honor for Smokey Robinson
text: Smokey Robinson, above, will be inducted into the Apollo Legend Hall of Fame and the actor Denzel Washington and his wife, Pauletta Washington, will receive the Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis Arts and Humanitarian Award Monday evening during the fourth annual spring benefit at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. The event will be hosted by the comedian and actress Wanda Sykes, with a performance featuring Earth, Wind & Fire, Nnenna Freelon and India.Arie. The event will raise money for the Apollo Theater Foundation, which has programs for education, community outreach and performing artists. Mr. Robinson’s Hall of Fame predecessors are Gladys Knight, James Brown, Ella Fitzgerald and Little Richard. Ticket information is available at (800) 618-3444.

headline: Under Pressure, White House Issues Climate Change Report
text: The Bush administration, bowing to a court order, has released a fresh summary of federal and independent research pointing to large, and mainly harmful, impact of human-caused global warming in the United States.

headline: Irate Europeans Protest the Soaring Price of Gasoline
text: PARIS  Marie Schneberger has always been thrifty about gasoline. The high price of filling up made it prohibitively expensive for Ms. Schneberger, a middle-income airline employee, to own anything bigger than a Fiat subcompact.

headline: ‘The Dream’
text: Dreams played an important part in our lives in those early days in England. Our mother invented them for us to make up for all the things we lacked and to give us some hope for the future. Perhaps, also, it was for herself, to escape the miseries she had to endure, which were caused chiefly by my father, who cared little about his family.

headline: Victory Puts Focus Back on the Field
text: All of a sudden, the Mets have changed the tone and the topic at Shea Stadium, all for the better. The week began with recriminations about their shabby Western trip and debate about the employment of Manager Willie Randolph.

headline: M.T.A. Does About-Face on Free E-ZPass Travel
text: It did not take long for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to reverse itself on the issue of free travel perks for its former and current board members.

headline: Insurgents Hide in Tanker to Attack Iraqi Police
text: BAGHDAD  An American marine guarding a checkpoint on the western outskirts of Falluja handed out coins with an Arabic translation of a biblical verse to Iraqis entering the city, angering residents and city leaders who denounced it as a serious affront to Islam and an attempt to convert them to Christianity.

headline: Eagles Say Goodbye, Again and Again
text: What comes after a farewell tour? For the Eagles the sequel to their coyly named “Farewell I” tour in 2005 was nothing less than their first studio album since 1979, “Long Road Out of Eden” (ERC II), a 20-track, two-CD set that has sold nearly four million copies in the United States since its release last year. That led in turn to one more tour, which came to Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, to be repeated on Friday and Saturday.

headline: Steroid Myth, Scandals and Dreams
text: Just when Christopher Bell’s documentary, “Bigger, Stronger, Faster*,” seems content to be an entertaining exploration of his and his two brothers’ use of anabolic steroids, it turns a corner and plunges into deeper waters. It happens when Mr. Bell, who narrates the film in the jocular first-person style of Michael Moore or Morgan Spurlock, reflects on steroid use as a metaphor for modern American life. Are steroids un-American, as Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. is heard to say? Or are they as American as apple pie?

headline: Adding One More Work to Hals’s Portfolio
text: ADDING ONE MORE WORK

headline: ‘Bodies’ Exhibitors Admit Corpse Origins Are Murky
text: After more than two years of assurances that the cadavers on display in a popular South Street Seaport exhibit were legally obtained in China, the company that runs the exhibit admitted on Thursday that it could not prove that the bodies were not those of prisoners who might have been tortured or executed. The company promised refunds to people who have seen the exhibit.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the leadership of Ben S. Bernanke as Federal Reserve chairman misattributed comments about the Fed’s new lending programs for financial institutions. The quotations  “These new facilities are Ben’s initiatives” and “He has been willing to take a fresh look at how the system works and press the boundaries in a thoughtful way”  were by Richard W. Fisher, president of the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank  not by Charles I. Plosser, president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank.

headline: Big Number for G.M.: 19,000 Take a Buyout
text: DETROIT  General Motors on Thursday said that 19,000 hourly workers  a quarter of a unionized work force that already has been drastically pared down  have accepted buyouts.

headline: Latin American Painting Sets a Record
text: A record price for a Latin American artwork sold at auction was set at Christie’s on Wednesday night when “Troubadour,” left, a 1945 painting by the Mexican artist Rufino Tamayo, was bought by a telephone bidder for $7.2 million. Officials at Christie’s declined to identify the buyer, who paid more than twice the $3 million high estimate, saying only that he was “an American collector who was very private.” The painting, which depicts a musician strumming a guitar, was sold by Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va., which is trying to raise $50 million for its endowment.

headline: Advocacy and Nonprofits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside Voice, Please, Even at the Gym
text: Dustin Vye could not believe what he was hearing: off-color language that cannot be printed here, sputtered by another man struggling to do squats at Mr. Vye’s favorite gym.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: For Five Days, New York Will Be Science City
text: Relax. There won’t be any exam. The only test is whether you are curious.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on May 19 about an exhibition on Ian Fleming, the creator of James Bond, at the Imperial War Museum in London misidentified the area of England where he played golf shortly before he died. It was in Kent, not Oxfordshire. The article also misidentified a gun used by Bond in the novel “Dr. No.” It was a Smith & Wesson .38 Centennial Airweight, not a Smith & Wesson .357 Magnum. And the article misstated the size of the large naval guns outside the museum. They are 15-inch guns, not 18-inch guns.

headline: Beverly Hills Cop No. 4
text: Eddie Murphy will be back as the smart-talking, fast-thinking Detroit detective Axel Foley in the fourth installment of “Beverly Hills Cop,” Variety reported. Paramount is aiming for a summer 2010 release of the film, with Brett Ratner as director, according to the article, which also said that Mr. Murphy had approached the studio about reviving the franchise, which helped make him a huge star and grossed $712.8 million worldwide. Released in 1984, the original “Beverly Hills Cop” made $316 million worldwide. The last installment was in 1994.

headline: The Reality Situation
text: Dear Senators Obama and McCain,

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: The Entrepreneurial Edge column in Business Day on May 15, about the development of biomedical companies in Orange County, Calif., misidentified the developer of a stent used to prevent glaucoma. He is Dr. Rick Hill, an ophthalmologist formerly with the University of California, Irvine  not Dr. Richard Little, who is still an ophthalmologist there.

headline: Artists and Writers? They'll Take Brooklyn
text: It’s no surprise that Brooklyn is crawling with artists, musicians and writers, but now one nonprofit arts group says it has the numbers to prove it. On Friday the New York Foundation for the Arts will announce its annual grants to New Yorkers in an array of creative fields. This year 137 prizes of $7,000 each will be distributed for painting, photography, music composition, choreography, architecture, fiction writing, video, and writing plays and screenplays. And for the second consecutive year, the foundation says, applicants and winners who live in Brooklyn outnumber those from Manhattan. “For artists, Brooklyn is the new Manhattan,” said Michael L. Royce, the foundation’s executive director. “It features low-cost spaces to work, exhibit and perform, and it is a community in which the exchange of ideas and creativity is commonplace.” The prizes, which have been given for 23 years and are financed largely by the New York State Council on the Arts, go to artists throughout the state, but most of the winners are in New York City.

headline: Ultimate Fighting Recruits Military to Its Ranks
text: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  The United States military is embracing a combat sport commonly called ultimate fighting that a decade ago was called human cockfighting and largely outlawed.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: For Dunkin’, a Tempest in an Iced-Coffee Cup
text: IT was a peculiarly Internet-age controversy.

headline: Location Gives Tiny State Prime Access to Big Riches
text: DJIBOUTI  For centuries, nomads have dropped down from the rocky hills around here to carve bricks of salt from an ancient lake and haul them away on the backs of camels.

headline: A Political Hot Potato, Literally, Between Latin Neighbors
text: LIMA, Peru  They have quarreled over the 1880’s pillaging of Peru’s national library by Chilean troops. They have squabbled over who has the naming rights to pisco, the fiery grape brandy. Now, Peru and Chile are arguing over another hot-button issue: the origins of the potato.

headline: Republicans Back Ex-Wall Street Executive to Run for Fossella’s Seat
text: Republican leaders in Staten Island on Thursday night endorsed Francis H. Powers, a retired Wall Street executive, as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella.

headline: High Spirits for a Battler Who Is Low on Delegates
text: MADISON, S.D.  She might be lacking in delegates, money and avenues to the Democratic nomination, but if nothing else, Hillary Rodham Clinton has clearly solidified her front-running position as the presidential candidate to have cocktails with.

headline: When Doctors Apologize
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suicide Bomb Kills 4 in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomb exploded near a convoy of international forces here on the eastern side of Kabul, killing four civilian bystanders and wounded 14 others Thursday, police officials said.

headline: Texas Loses Court Ruling Over Taking of Children
text: HOUSTON  Bringing polygamist families closer to regaining custody of their children, a divided Supreme Court of Texas agreed Thursday that the state had illegally seized 468 girls and boys from a West Texas ranch last month on unproven grounds of physical and sexual abuse.

headline: 2 Men Long Confined as Insane Regain Their Right to Vote
text: BOSTON  The Rhode Island Board of Elections has restored the voting rights of two men who were stripped of them last year because they were found two decades ago to be not guilty of murder by reason of insanity.

headline: Iraqi Soccer Team Cleared to Play
text: BAGHDAD  Soccer’s world governing body abruptly lifted the suspension of Iraq’s soccer association on Thursday, easing concerns that Iraq’s team, a rare symbol of national unity, would be banned from the 2010 World Cup.

headline: Learning Firsthand About Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: Leonard Jason is a professor of psychology at DePaul University in Chicago and the director of the university’s Center for Community Research. He is on the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Advisory Committee to the federal Department of Health and Human Services and is a board member of the International Association for CFS/ME, an advocacy group.

headline: Classic Patti Austin, Newly Focused on Swing and Jazz
text: For years Patti Austin has struggled with the mixed blessing of having a voice that is too perfect. Strong and flexible, with a velvety texture and immaculately rounded tones complemented by impeccable enunciation, it is a quintessential session singer’s voice because it is not instantly identifiable when heard singing backup vocals or commercials. On Wednesday evening at the Rose Theater, where Ms. Austin headlined Jazz at Lincoln Center’s annual spring gala benefit, all the hallmarks of her musical personality were in place  but with a difference.

headline: Police Review Finds Shooting in Condo Lobby Justified
text: An off-duty detective was justified in shooting two men, one fatally, after they attacked him and a woman on Wednesday night in Chinatown, the police said on Thursday after a first review.

headline: West Coast Cool Suits Serene Torre
text: Joe Torre slept about two and a half hours in a Midtown hotel before spending part of his second day in New York since February sitting with some kindergartners. Torre, the old Yankees manager, the older Mets manager and the current manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, had a crucial appointment with an aspiring actress.

headline: Fight Over Land Use at Valley Forge
text: EAGLEVILLE, Pa.  A local planning board has approved a proposal to build a $250 million visitor center and conference facilities on privately owned land in Valley Forge National Historical Park. Opponents say the decision increases the risk of commercial development in other scenic and historic national parks.

headline: Bookstore for Sale
text: The Harvard Book Store, a family-owned landmark near Harvard Yard, was put up for sale this week, the store’s owner, Frank Kramer, said Thursday. Mr. Kramer, 66, said that it was time to move on after 46 years of running the business, which his father started in 1932. “I’m not sure what, but I’d like to try something new,” he said. His decision, reported on Wednesday in The Boston Globe, comes at a time when big chain bookstores like Barnes & Noble and Borders have forced thousands of independent bookstores to close their doors. But Mr. Kramer said Thursday that his store was profitable, and that he would like the new owner to continue the tradition of “great bookselling,” which offers quality books as well as perks like talks and readings by authors.

headline: Best Is the New Worst
text: PITY the poor word “elite,” which simply means “the best” as an adjective and “the best of a group” as a noun. What was once an accolade has turned poisonous in American public life over the past 40 years, as both the left and the right have twisted it into a code word meaning “not one of us.” But the newest and most ominous wrinkle in the denigration of all things elite is that the slur is being applied to knowledge itself.

headline: Fighting Same-Sex Policy Seems to Be Uphill Battle
text: Legal challenges to Gov. David A. Paterson’s plan to recognize same-sex marriages from other jurisdictions are likely to come thick and fast. But they face an uphill fight, legal experts said on Thursday, given New York’s unusual legal terrain.

headline: U.S. Withdraws Fulbright Grants to Gaza
text: GAZA  The American State Department has withdrawn all Fulbright grants to Palestinian students in Gaza hoping to pursue advanced degrees at American institutions this fall because Israel has not granted them permission to leave.

headline: Donnell Library Closes This Week, So a Hotel Can Be Built
text: After 52 years as one of the most heavily used branches of the New York Public Library system, the Donnell Library Center, on West 53rd Street, will all but close at the end of this week. A small circulating collection will remain open, in the basement, through the end of August. Then the building will be razed to make way for an 11-story hotel.

headline: George Garrett, 78, Southern Novelist, Is Dead
text: George Garrett, a highly regarded Southern novelist who never received the wide literary renown that his decades of glowing reviews would suggest, died on Monday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 78.

headline: Yes He (and We) Can
text: When Chip Brown went to Florida for two weeks in March for an up-close look at the Tiger Woods phenomenon, he left knowing that Woods, still just 32, was one of the most written-about athletes of all time, the subject of many millions of words, including some 85 books. He also knew Woods tended to avoid saying anything very revealing.

headline: Lose Homes, Pay More Tax
text: Some of the biggest losers in the real estate slump are not purchasers of mansions they could not afford. They are buyers of second homes  or third ones, for that matter  who are sitting on a tax time bomb.

headline: After the Shock of an Earthquake, Thousands Now Huddle in Fear of a Flood
text: QINGLIAN, China  It is a simple strand of red plastic hanging between two trees, but for residents of this battered town, it is the line between life and potential death.

headline: How Governor Set His Stance on Gay Rights
text: When David A. Paterson was growing up and his parents would go out of town, he and his little brother would stay in Harlem with family friends they called Uncle Stanley and Uncle Ronald.

headline: A Puppet Who Dances Like a Real Boy
text: Nami Yamamoto’s new dance, “a howling flower,” is a work for six stellar performers and a puppet named Tony, an enchanting creature both for the way he looks and for the way he compels the others to act.

headline: Mixing Art and Science to Get Doomsday
text: “There is no stable matter, and as in Buddhism, there is no stable anything,” muses the director Peter Sellars, as he reflects on the implications of splitting the atom in Jon Else’s enthralling documentary “Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic.”

headline: Your Room Is Ready
text: AT the Malyn Resort, a pink stucco mid-century motel in Treasure Island, Fla., a barrier island community near St. Petersburg, guests in plastic lounge chairs talk in low, lazy tones as ripples form on the crystal blue water in the swimming pool. The aroma of sizzling hot dogs wafts from beneath the thatched roof of the poolside cabana, as a tropical breeze off the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway rustles the palm trees. Children chase other children, leaving a trail of wet footprints. And a clunk from the ice machine indicates cocktail hour is about to begin.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Louisiana Tries Again
text: Two years have passed since the federal courts relinquished control of Louisiana’s notoriously troubled juvenile justice system. The state regained its autonomy by reducing the number of children held in detention and by promising to embrace reforms based on Missouri’s system, which long ago abandoned sprawling, prison-style facilities in favor of small, regional facilities that focus on rehabilitation.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Foodies on the Hudson
text: BEFORE the post-9/11 influx of second-home owners to the Hudson Valley, sophisticated restaurants taking advantage of the region’s bounty were scarce. Christine Jones and Bert Goldfinger, New Yorkers who have owned a farmhouse in bucolic Ghent, N.Y., in Columbia County, since 1993, remember the way it was.

headline: Taste of Senate Set Capt. McCain on a New Path
text: WASHINGTON  At a meeting in his Pentagon office in early 1981, Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman told Capt. John S. McCain III that he was about to attain his life ambition: becoming an admiral.

headline: A Slow Crescendo of Intimidation
text: From Sam Peckinpah’s “Straw Dogs” to Michael Haneke’s “Funny Games,” the home-invasion thriller has proved adept at eliciting the fear and dislocation that accompany the violation of our most sacred space.

headline: Tycoons in Russia Want to Create World’s Largest Mining Concern
text: MOSCOW  Two Russian metals tycoons, Vladimir O. Potanin and Alisher B. Usmanov, are moving to merge their companies with the goal of creating the world’s largest mining concern.

headline: Bryant in Charge, Lakers Back on Top
text: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant wanted a team to call his own, a locker room to lead, a city singing his name and a championship that would bear his image. With four more victories, he will have it all.

headline: Clamor for Memoir Leads to Early Release in Stores
text: The explosive reaction to the new memoir by Scott McClellan, former White House press secretary, prompted his publisher to allow sales of the book on Wednesday, several days ahead of the original publication date of Monday.

headline: Food Report Criticizes Biofuel Policies
text: Agriculture Secretary Edward T. Schafer is preparing to walk into a buzzsaw of criticism over American biofuels policy when he meets with world leaders to discuss the global food crisis next week.

headline: Olmert Aide Puts New Pressure on Him to Quit
text: JERUSALEM  Pressure on Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to step down increased Thursday when Tzipi Livni, his foreign minister and a senior member of the same political party, urged preparations for new elections.

headline: China Says It Will Accept Aid From Japan’s Military
text: SHANGHAI  China acknowledged Thursday that it was willing to receive disaster relief assistance from Japan’s Self-Defense Forces in what would be the first Japanese military air mission to China since the end of World War II.

headline: Potter Was Still Magical, but Not All Books Rose
text: J. K. Rowling may have given a much needed jolt to the publishing industry last July when the final installment in her celebrated series about the boy wizard, “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” sold 8.3 million copies in the United States in 24 hours, but publishers still struggled to sell more books overall than they did in 2006, according to the Book Industry Study Group, a publishing trade association.

headline: 428 Wolves
text: Until March 28, the fate of the gray wolf in the Rocky Mountains was in the hands of the federal government because the wolf was listed as an endangered species. But once it was removed from the list  a decision that is being challenged in court by a dozen conservation groups  the gray wolf fell under the protection of individual states. That is turning out to mean almost no protection at all.

headline: Universal Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cheney Tells New York’s G.O.P. He Sees Success in Iraq War
text: At a Midtown hotel ballroom on Thursday, Vice President Dick Cheney declared that the United States was “succeeding brilliantly” in Iraq and assailed Democrats on taxes, gas prices, and national security.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article on Saturday about electoral gains by the opposition Conservative Party of Britain under the leadership of David Cameron referred incorrectly to the honing of his oratory skills. While Mr. Cameron is known for his quick repartee in parliamentary debates with Prime Minister Gordon Brown, the Labor Party leader, he never participated in the debates of the Oxford Union as a student.

headline: Hockey Shows Up N.B.A. in Detroit
text: The N.H.L. chalked up a small victory Wednesday night in its battle with the N.B.A. for the attention of sports viewers in Detroit.

headline: Peru Guards Its Guano as Demand Soars Again
text: ISLA DE ASIA, Peru  The worldwide boom in commodities has come to this: Even guano, the bird dung that was the focus of an imperialist scramble on the high seas in the 19th century, is in strong demand once again.

headline: Graham Found Guilty of Lying in Balco Case
text: With the conviction Thursday of the former track coach Trevor Graham on one of three felony charges for making false statements to drug investigators, antidoping authorities are expected to review new evidence against several former Olympic sprinters as federal prosecutors move on to a perjury case against Barry Bonds.

headline: Merger Talks Appear Over for 2 Airlines
text: United Airlines told US Airways on Thursday that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, people with direct knowledge of the situation said.

headline: Corrections: Putting Out a ‘Willkommen’ Mat
text: An article on May 23 about Joel Grey’s house in California referred incorrectly to Venice, the community in which he lives. It is a district in Los Angeles, not a separate town. The article also misspelled a word in a French phrase spoken by Mr. Grey as a greeting to a neighbor. It is “Tout va bien?” (“How are you?”) not “Tu.”

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Crash Kills Chile’s Top Police Official
text: PANAMA  Chile’s top police official and at least 14 other people were killed Thursday afternoon when a Panamanian Air Force helicopter crashed on top of a building in the heart of the city.

headline: Study Finds Disparities in Mortgage Fees
text: Minorities and people without college degrees pay more in mortgage fees than do white applicants and those with a higher education, according to a study released Thursday.

headline: The Girls Are Back in Town
text: A little Botox goes a long way in “Sex and the City,” but a little decent writing would have gone even further. A dumpy big-screen makeover of that much-adored small-screen delight, the movie was written and directed by Michael Patrick King, one of the guiding lights and bright wits of the original series, based on Candace Bushnell’s newspaper columns and subsequent book. Once again, Sarah Jessica Parker has stepped into the dizzyingly high heels of Carrie Bradshaw, that postmodern Lorelei Lee  a hardly working New York writer with a passion for men and Manolos  but this time she’s taken a terrible tumble.

headline: Some Looking for Seat Belt After First Day of Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  As a general rule, green speeds on the PGA Tour range anywhere from quick to fast to really fast. Every now and then, they get seriously fast, which is quicker than a thought. Once in a great while, they get where they were during Thursday’s first round of the Memorial Tournament.

headline: Sex and the Rest of the City
text: There are neighborhoods in the far reaches of New York City, from Tottenville on Staten Island to Bushwick in Brooklyn, that have about as much in common with the glimmering, candy-coated Manolo Blahnik world of “Sex and the City” as, say, East Texas.

headline: Harry Potter Prequel for Charity
text: J. K. Rowling, below, has written a short prequel to her Harry Potter books for her contribution to a charity auction at Waterstone Ltd. in London on June 10. The 800-word work (on a paper slightly bigger than a postcard) is one of 13 works submitted by a group of authors that includes Doris Lessing, Tom Stoppard, Margaret Atwood and Nick Hornby, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Rowling used both sides of her card to handwrite the prequel to her seven-book Potter series. All 13 card-size works will go on sale at an auction called “What’s Your Story?” at Waterstone’s flagship store in central London.

headline: Housing Cuts Are Proposed to Help Close Budget Gap
text: The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority painted a bleak financial picture of the agency at a City Council hearing on Thursday, saying that without increased government aid the authority would raise rents for some tenants and eliminate hundreds of community centers and resident programs.

headline: Through a Peephole: Woman on a Quest
text: Giuseppe Tornatore’s sleazy Hitchcockian thriller, “The Unknown Woman,” keeps you glued to the screen despite your increasingly nagging doubts about its integrity. Just under two hours, sumptuously photographed in noirish shades and slathered in spine-tingling music by Ennio Morricone, it twists every which way to sustain suspense until the final frame.

headline: Power and Tenacity Collide in a Singapore Courtroom
text: SINGAPORE  “Mr. Lee, we get to meet at last.”

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with an obituary about the film director Sydney Pollack misidentified the film from which a scene was shown and misidentified the actress in it in some editions. The scene was from “Out of Africa,” not “The Way We Were,” and the actress, shown kissing Robert Redford, was Meryl Streep, not Barbra Streisand. The obituary also omitted part of the name of the Indiana high school Mr. Pollack attended. It was South Bend Central High School, not South Bend High School.

headline: Another Book Deal Loosens Another Tongue
text: A large and noisy crowd filled Rockefeller Plaza soon after sunrise Thursday outside the NBC studio where the “Today” show is broadcast. Which of the following guests on “Today” would you say was the reason that so many people summoned so much screaming energy at an hour when most New Yorkers had yet to have their first cup of coffee?

headline: Coping With the Reality of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: Researchers, doctors and patient advocates all agree that managing and coping with chronic fatigue syndrome is a major challenge for patients as well as their families. Here are some important factors they say are necessary to keep in mind.

headline: Notebook Sales Help Dell to Surpass Forecasts
text: Dell delivered the goods on Thursday.

headline: China and Taiwan Discuss Direct Flights
text: After a break of almost a decade, China and Taiwan agreed Thursday to resume discussions on issues such as visits by mainland Chinese to the island and the introduction of regular direct charter flights between them, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

headline: Selected Studies: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: 142-Match Streak, Not Always With Ease
text: It has been 10 years since the girls tennis team at St. Francis Prep of Queens last lost. In that time, the program has compiled a 142-match winning streak, captured 10 Catholic High School Athletic Association state championships and claimed 8 Mayor’s Cup titles.

headline: Fox Tops Ratings
text: Fox ranked first in the ratings on Wednesday, as a two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” averaged 9.3 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. CBS, with repeats, finished second over all, as “Criminal Minds” at 9 p.m. and “CSI: NY” at 10 p.m. delivered the night’s largest audiences, 9.7 million and 9.4 million viewers. During the 8 p.m. hour, a prime-time rerun of CBS’s game show “The Price Is Right” drew 7.9 million viewers. Despite CBS’s solid performance in total viewers, the network was third among adults 18 to 49 behind Fox and ABC, which broadcast new episodes of “Wife Swap” at 8 (5.8 million), “Supernanny” at 9 (6.6 million) and “Men in Trees” at 10 (5.3 million). NBC was fourth over all; its coverage of Game 3 of the Stanley Cup Finals from 8 to 11 p.m., drew approximately 4.5 million viewers.

headline: Con Ed Suit Blames City in Explosion in Midtown
text: Consolidated Edison sued New York City and a contractor on Thursday, contending that they contributed to the explosion of one of the utility’s steam pipes in Midtown Manhattan last summer that killed one person, injured dozens of others and displaced thousands more.

headline: On the Front Porch
text: WHO Jessica Chalker, 22, and her sister Hannah, 19, from Marietta, Ga. WHAT 4-bedroom house WHERE St. Simons Island, Ga.

headline: Attitude and a Badge (You Know the Drill)
text: “You don’t know me,” Mary Shannon (Mary McCormack), a United States marshal, says dismissively. “Really?” a handsome but irritated F.B.I. agent replies. “Let’s see,” he says. “Typical relationship has a shelf life of, oh, I’d say about a month  tops. No real friends, can’t always figure out why you’re on the outside looking in, nobody gets you, but ‘Hey, that’s their problem.’ ”

headline: Life in Iran, Etched With Suspicion and Humor
text: Decades before Marjane Satrapi drew the first frame of her celebrated comic book memoir “Persepolis,” the Iranian satirist Ardeshir Mohassess, now 69, was making black-and-white drawings whose blend of humor and reportage made him a cult figure for artists and intellectuals in his country. With rich allusions to Persian miniatures, Western artists like Goya and episodes in Iranian history, Mr. Mohassess has depicted life in Iran before, during and after the Islamic Revolution of 1979. The drawings have a fanciful yet descriptive line quality, comically exaggerating facial expressions while giving full weight to bullet holes and severed limbs. Some of the meanings may be lost on American viewers, but the artist’s deep suspicion of religious and political authority comes across clearly.

headline: Tales of a Goofball Guru
text: Fred Simmons (Danny McBride) is the type of blustery, provincial narcissist who is always putting his foot in his mouth and absolutely loving how it tastes. By day this goofball guru of a suburban tae kwon do studio teaches his disciples how to bust cinder blocks according to a five-step code of honor (“self-control, courtesy, perseverance, integrity, indomitable spirit”). By night he flops on the couch and pretends to care about his wife, Suzie (Mary Jane Bostic), and her day at work. Her new job as a dental office assistant apparently entails little more than compiling lists of co-workers “most likely to go on a killing spree” and photocopying her breasts.

headline: Church Says He Does Not Regret Helping Out Mets
text: Before reporters were permitted into the Mets’ clubhouse Thursday afternoon, Brian Schneider asked his teammates to lower the volume of the music blasting from the computer. Ryan Church was coming in soon and, because of his concussion, he may not have appreciated the loud noise.

headline: Black Group Turns Away From Bill on Smoking
text: A bill to regulate tobacco products has lost the support of a black antismoking group, which said Thursday that the legislation failed to adequately protect the health of African-Americans because it would not ban menthol flavorings from cigarettes.

headline: U.S. Regulators Push to Strengthen Oversight of Energy Markets
text: Faced with enormous political pressure to tighten the oversight of energy trading, federal regulators said Thursday that they have been investigating oil and derivative markets for six months to look into potential price manipulation.

headline: Gay Marriage Opponents Consider Ways to Fight New Policy
text: Opponents of same-sex unions were pondering a range of legal and legislative challenges to Gov. David A. Paterson’s new policy of having state agencies honor same-sex marriages that have been performed outside New York.

headline: Bruno Weighs Gay Marriage Directive
text: ALBANY  As New York lawmakers pondered a new directive from Gov. David A. Paterson that state agencies begin revising their policies to honor same-sex marriages conducted outside New York, the Legislature’s top Republican said he had yet to decide whether to challenge the governor.

headline: The Giants Receive Their Super Bowl Rings
text: The Giants waited nearly four months for this moment. Patience was rewarded during a lavish ceremony Thursday night at Tiffany and Co. at which the Giants received their Super Bowl rings.

headline: Dior Drops Actress From Ads After China Remarks
text: PARIS  Christian Dior, the French fashion brand, has become the latest global company to learn a hard lesson about the danger of offending Chinese pride.

headline: Sticker Shock and Awe at the Pentagon
text: A lot more spending and far too little oversight, those are the bottom lines of two disturbing new reports on the Pentagon’s flawed-to-broken budgeting process. The Pentagon’s inspector general plaintively reported this week that his staff is overwhelmed. For good reason. The Pentagon’s budget has doubled since 2000, while the number of auditors has remained static.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article last Friday about a federal effort to use information on Medicare claims to assess the risks of drugs already on the market misstated the number of prescription purchases by Americans. The average among all Americans is 16 a year  not 13, the average among Americans younger than 65.

headline: Longtime Anti-Beijing Protests Provoke a Sudden and Angry Backlash
text: In many respects, the scene on Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, this week was familiar to those who live and work in the neighborhood: a group of men and women holding up banners that read “Gods Eliminate Chinese Communist Party” and “Falun Dafa Is Good.”

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Expected to Plead Guilty and Cooperate With Investigation
text: A banker indicted in a tax inquiry of the Swiss giant UBS is expected to enter a guilty plea next month and cooperate with investigators.

headline: States of Great: The Sub-Cult Hero
text: Vladimir Galchenko is one of the world's best jugglers. Penn Jillette, of Penn & Teller fame, explains Galchenko's talent this way: "It couldn't be simpler. He can throw more things in the air and catch them in order." As Jason Fagone writes in PLAY, Galchenko's YouTube clips are inspiring kids who have started to change the face of juggling, "evolving a culture whose values - speed, numbers, athleticism, technique - are distinct from the traditional juggling values of balance, expression, and showmanship." But as Fagone also notes, Galchenko, known as Vova, has a career problem: once you've reached the pinnacle of an endeavor few people care about, where do you go next?

headline: A Friendly Vibe, Made Up of Shared Sensibilities and Common Repertory
text: Wednesday night at Smalls in the West Village was a friends-of-friends gig, an intersection of two circles. Aaron Parks, the young pianist who led the band, played with the bassist Ben Street and the drummer Jeff Ballard. The Parks-Street alliance comes from a current version of the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel’s band; the Street-Ballard alliance comes from years of playing together in various rhythm sections, including one from an earlier Rosenwinkel band.

headline: Rule Change Would Permit Weapons in National Parks
text: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.  The federal government is considering a proposal to allow visitors to carry loaded, concealed weapons in some national parks, wildlife refuges and monuments.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 91 Toledo
text: Location: Toledo, Oh.

headline: Peru's Guano Trade
text: Amid surging prices for synthetic fertilizers and organic food, guano, bird droppings found on islands off the coast of Peru, has become a niche fertilizer sought around the world.

headline: The Return of Schoeneweis
text: Basking in the afterglow of a Mets victory Wednesday night, Scott Schoeneweis got to talking about Duaner Sanchez’s solid bunt in the 11th inning. Earlier, Willie Randolph had complimented Guy Conti and Sandy Alomar Sr. for working on pitchers with their bunting, so I asked Schoeneweis how his skills compared.

headline: The Wing Luke Asian Museum
text: As the Wing Luke Asian Museum reopens in Seattle, the celebrations are about more than mere institutional accomplishments.

headline: Giants-Patriots Super Bowl: Was It Not Real?
text: I was an admirer of Ken Burns’s Civil War documentary, shown on PBS in 1990. As the last program wound down, I remember thinking: How will he put a bow on it — and do the series justice?

headline: U.S.A. Softball Team on the Road
text: The Olympians are playing local all-stars on a nationwide tour.

headline: ‘Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano’
text: The gala presentation of “Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano” (“Michelangelo: The Wise Hand”), a volume of photographs of this Renaissance master’s sculptures, may well have been the most lavish book debut in history.

headline: The Girls of Summer
text: The U.S. women's softball team goes for the gold in what could be its last Olympic campaign.

headline: Back, sort of
text: I’m still on the road (just talked at the Trento Festival in Italy, Barcelona next) — and mysteriously unable to post images to this blog. But I have a bit more time now. I assume that most readers have gotten over their Two Minutes Hate; anyway, I expect to be posting a few pieces about economics over the weekend.

headline: Nassau County Legislative Grants
Iranian Life, Wryly Drawn
text: Illustrations by Ardeshir Mohassess at the Asia Society. Karen Rosenberg reviews.

headline: Suffolk County Legislative Grants
From Seattle Slew to Our Stable
text: Right now, Bill Turner is the only living trainer of a Triple Crown winner. His horse, the great Seattle Slew, was undefeated in nine races, a streak that ended with his Belmont Stakes win in 1977. Bill might lose that distinction June 7, if Big Brown takes the Belmont, but for now the reporters are still dropping by his barn in the mornings, asking whether he thinks Big Brown will win, or just collecting memories of that past Triple Crown campaign.

headline: Quebecor Sells Assets to Dutch Investment Firm
text: Six months after a deal to sell its European operations fell through, Quebecor World has found another buyer for the assets, but at a much lower price than initially sought.

headline: Why Baseball Really Is a Game of Inches
text: Several journalists I really respect (Pat Jordan, Dan Shaughnessy, Selena Roberts) have written or talked lately about shrinking access to players. I won’t pretend to know what it was like before I started in this business, in 1990, but in the role of beat writer, I rarely end the day thinking I did not have enough access.

headline: Australia’s Origin Rejects BG’s $13 Billion Offer
text: Origin Energy of Australia rejected on Friday a revised $13 billion takeover bid from the British gas producer BG Group and upped the ante by doubling its own gas reserves estimate.

headline: Belon of Russia Said to Plan London I.P.O.
text: Belon Group, a Russian coal mining company, is planning to float at least 15 percent of its shares on the London Stock Exchange in the second half of 2009, a business daily reported on Friday.

headline: As Profits Soar, Man Group Loses a Leader
text: The Man Group posted a 60 percent gain in earnings last year, but said it is losing the man that helped turn it into the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund manager.

headline: Norway’s Fund to Seek Larger Equity Deals
text: Norway’s $400 billion oil fund is close to owning more than 1 percent of the entire European stock market as it takes advantage of market turmoil to buy more equities, and has set up a division that will seek larger stakes in companies, similar to a private equity investor.

headline: Russian Moguls Seek to Form Mining Giant
text: Two Russian metals tycoons, Vladimir O. Potanin and Alisher B. Usmanov, are moving to merge their companies with the goal of creating the world’s largest mining concern.

headline: Is Google Violating a California Privacy Law?
text: UPDATED 5/30, 8:45 AM After I wrote about Google’s spat with an advertising trade group over the company’s refusal to put a link to its privacy policy on the home page of Google.com, I discovered that there is actually a California law on the subject.

headline: Noble’s I.P.O.: A Mixed Bag?
text: Noble Environmental Power‘s planned initial public offering brings “good news and bad news” for investors interested in the alternative energy sector, according to TheStreet.com.

headline: U.S. Regulators Seek More Oversight of Energy Markets
text: Faced with enormous political pressure to tighten the oversight of energy trading, federal regulators said Thursday that they have been investigating oil and derivative markets for six months to look into potential price manipulation.

headline: Former EADS Chief Faces Insider Trading Charges
text: French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Noël Forgeard, the former co-chief executive of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europe’s largest aerospace group, his lawyer said Friday. The charges relate to delays in the program to build the A380 superjumbo.

headline: Deutsche Mulls Revamp of Bonus Structure
text: Deutsche Bank‘s chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said his firm is considering the possibility of a “multi-year” bonus system, where less would depend on an employee’s performance in the previous 12 months. The move comes amid mounting criticism of a bonus culture at investment banks that some say encourages excessive risk-taking.

headline: Former Deutsche Banker Said to Be in Talks to Join Providence
text: Tommy Gahan, who helped build Deutsche Bank‘s securities business in the United States, is in discussions to join Providence Equity Partners, a private equity firm that specializes in media and telecommunications deals, The New York Post reported.

headline: Trump Casino to Go ‘Margaritaville’ in $316 Million Deal
text: Under a new deal to bring that Margaritaville flavor further north, those living in the Northeast may now only have to travel as far as the Jersey Shore to find Jimmy Buffett blowing out his flip flop or searching for that lost shaker of salt.

headline: Sopogy Soaks Up $9.1 Million
text: Sopogy, a small-scale solar thermal start-up, has closed a $9.1 million round from investors including the investment vehicle of eBay founder Pierre Omidyar, Ohana Holdings, New Energy Finance reported.

headline: Sears’ Surprise Loss Is Another Blow to Lampert
text: The Sears Holdings Corporation, the parent of Sears and Kmart, reported an unexpected $56 million first-quarter loss on Thursday, dealing another setback to Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge fund manager who has struggled to turn the company around.

headline: Did Goldman Overreach With Its Spac?
text: Goldman Sachs usually doesn’t have trouble taking its clients public.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Expected to Plead Guilty
text: A banker indicted in a tax inquiry of the Swiss giant UBS is expected to enter a guilty plea next month and cooperate with investigators.

headline: Yahoo-Microsoft: The Parlor Game
text: Microsoft and Yahoo seem to hang out in all the same places but somehow keep missing each other. That’s turned speculation over what it will take to get the two of them together into something of a C.E.O. parlor game.

headline: Harvey Korman, Straight Man Without a Straight Face
text: Harvey Korman, the comedic actor who rose to fame playing second banana to Carol Burnett on her TV variety series and who starred in hit movies like “Blazing Saddles” and “High Anxiety,” died on Thursday at 81. One of his favorite roles was the dastardly Hedley Lamarr in Mel Brooks’s “Blazing Saddles” from 1974:

headline: Hedges in Focus Ahead of Banks’ Quarterly Reports
text: The effectiveness of hedges against mortgage- and credit-related losses will be a major focus as investment banks such as Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs report quarterly results in coming weeks, analysts say. MarketWatch reports that some hedging strategies have been showing cracks, raising concerns about more write-downs on top of an already weak environment for big brokerages.

headline: Agency Sounds Alarm on Banks’ Shaky Outlooks
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned Thursday that the nation’s ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further. The F.D.I.C. said the combined profit of the financial institutions it regulates plunged 46 percent, to $19.3 billion, during the first three months of the year.

headline: Charges of Insider Trading for a Wall St. Luminary
text: John F. Marshall spent decades teaching at business schools and watching his students parlay his lessons into fortunes on Wall Street. But when he and another professor reached for some of those riches themselves, events took a startling turn, the authorities say.

headline: Panties for Peace
text: Who needs “Sex and the City” anyway? Relinquish your panties for a cause (well, a different cause). From the Canadian Press:

headline: Sex and the Golden Girl
text: The reviews for the new “Sex and the City” flick are less than ecstatic, so you could do worse than this TV Land parody with Bea Arthur and Sally Struthers from a few years back. Here’s Metamucil in your Cosmopolitan!

headline: Divorce Turns Ugly for Nevada’s Governor
text: LAS VEGAS — The governor of the state made famous in part for its quick, private divorces is now embroiled in a breakup so tawdry, so publicly spectacular and so potentially grueling that how it plays out could have implications from Carson City to the White House.

headline: The Early Word: Iraq On the Agenda
text: As economic issues have come to dominate the national dialogue over the last few months, the war in Iraq has taken a backseat. But on the campaign trail in recent days, Senator John McCain has been sounding foreign policy and national security themes, and hitting Senator Barack Obama hard on Iraq.

headline: United-US Airways Merger Talks Appear Over
text: United Airlines told US Airways on Thursday that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, The New York Times reported.

headline: Latest Updates on Fatal Crane Collapse
text: Updated, 7:40 p.m. | The city’s Office of Emergency Management has provided an update about the deadly crane collapse on the Upper East Side. City officials have confirmed that two construction workers were killed in the 8 a.m. collapse, at East 91st Street and First Avenue, and that two other people were injured. A total of eight buildings with 212 apartments were evacuated for much of the day, but residents and businesses were being allowed to return this evening to all but the most heavily damaged building, 354 East 91st Street.

headline: Report Sees Fewer-Than-Expected Wall St. Layoffs
text: New York City’s financial sector might only slice 15,000 to 25,000 jobs in the current downturn, which could prove shorter than the mayor has predicted, the city comptroller said on Thursday.

headline: Algae-to-Fuel Venture Announces Funding
text: Sapphire Energy, which says it’s producing the chemical equivalent of gasoline from algae, has come out of stealth mode, announcing that it raised $50 million from ARCH Venture Partners, Venrock, and the Wellcome Trust.

headline: A Commuter Pain Survey
text: Gas prices, apparently, are still not high enough to convince some people to get out of their cars, according to a new Commuter Pain Survey released by I.B.M. Friday.

headline: Couric Speaks About War Pressure
text: In his new memoir, “What Happened,” Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, said the national news media neglected their watchdog role in the run-up to the invasion of Iraq, calling reporters “complicit enablers” of the Bush administration’s push for war.

headline: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
text: Iraqi women answer questions from readers.

headline: NBC, Blackstone Seen As Leading Bidder For The Weather Channel
text: Reuters: “A consortium including NBC Universal and Blackstone Group bidding for the Weather Channel is offering about $1.8 billion in equity for their bid, or roughly half the total offer, a source familiar with the matter said.”

headline: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
text: Iraqi women answer questions from readers.

headline: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
text: Iraqi women answer questions from readers.

headline: How a Governor’s Views on Gay Rights Were Shaped
text: Gov. David A. Paterson discusses how he arrived at his stance on gay rights in an interview with Jeremy Peters and Danny Hakim.

headline: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
text: Iraqi women answer questions from readers.

headline: A Letter to Facebook’s Founder
text: Memo

headline: Quién es Más Macho?
text: There’s been a lot of chatter in blogville about the merits of Jim Webb, the Democratic senator from Virginia, as Barack Obama’s running mate: antiwar, veteran, Reagan Democrat. Ezra Klein of the American Prospect understands Webb’s appeal, but he also thinks Webb would be the wrong choice.

headline: You Can’t Get There From Here
text: Greetings from Beaune, center of the Burgundy wine region, where I’ve been touring about for the last few days.

headline: What L’Etape Looks Like
text: As part of the blog he did about his (successful) attempt to ride L’Etape last summer, Matt Smith, the Web master at Cervelo, was filmed by the bike manufacturer’s videographer. So those of you who want to get a better handle on just what it looks like when 8,000 amateurs pit themselves against a mountain stage of the Tour de France, can check out the video of Matt’s ride in the 2007 edition of L’Etape.

headline: Stray Questions for: Nathaniel Rich
text: Nathaniel Rich is an editor at The Paris Review. His first novel, “The Mayor’s Tongue,” was published this spring.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Cold Eggplant Salad With Sesame Dressing
text: A different kind of eggplant salad in every way, from cooking method to seasoning.

headline: Casino Drive Is Not Really a Pioneer
text: Ray Paulick, the former editor and chief of The Blood-Horse, has a good column about Japanese horse racing on ESPN.com. He says no on should be surprised that Casino Drive is here for the Belmont Stakes and, in fact, we should be prepared for the colt to win.

headline: A Surfeit of Advice!
text: 37 Days to L’Etape. On the training schedule: last night after work I did a one-hour recovery ride of light intensity (that following a one-hour session of intense interval training the night before, overseen by my coach, with the bike on an indoor trainer hooked up to a machine that allowed me to gauge the power in watts of every pedal stroke).

headline: US Airways: No Pretzels, No Mergers
text: Earlier this week, passengers with tickets on US Airways learned there would be no more pretzels and peanuts on domestic flights. On Friday, the airline’s employees were told that there’s no merger rolling down the aisle either.

headline: Coney Island Is Spruced Up and Waiting for the Crowds
text: The stretch of Stillwell Avenue between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, like most of Coney Island, has seen a lot of change over the years. Once home to amusements like Stauch’s Baths (featured prominently in “The Warriors”) and the Tornado and Bobsled roller coasters, the street emptied over the years as attractions burned down or went out of business, and property owners bulldozed land for redevelopment that never materialized.

headline: Almost 80, and Still Zabar’s Big Fish
text: Saul Zabar, the president and co-owner of the Upper West Side’s culinary epicenter, discusses his reluctant path into the family business.

headline: When a Founder Becomes a Footnote
text: He put the ‘Gomez’ in Gomez Inc., but now an Internet entrepreneur finds himself relegated to the fine print.

headline: Boffo Box Office for Science Festival
text: New York is a tough town to open a show in, but the World Science Festival already looks like a smash. The first day’s events were sold out on Thursday. Of the 46 events in the four-day festival, all but five are either sold out or virtually sold out (meaning there are a few single tickets left), says Adam Pockriss, a spokesman for the festival.

headline: Republicans on Defense Over G.I. Bill
text: In his column today, Carl Hulse writes Democrats have been encouraged to emphasize the veterans education program developed by Senator James Webb of Virginia as a political rallying cry this summer.

headline: Ferraro Wants Study on Racism, Sexism in 2008 Race
text: Geraldine Ferraro, who has been making headlines for months over what she contends is the sexist treatment of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in this presidential cycle, has penned an Op-Ed in the Boston Globe.

headline: Torre Followed Orders While Quietly Getting His Players’ Backs
text: Mariano Duncan played under Joe Torre for two years with the Yankees and is now Torre’s first base coach on the Los Angeles Dodgers. Duncan batted .340 in 1996 and helped the Yankees secure a World Series title. He also coined the phrase that the team wore on T-Shirts: “We play today, we win today. Dassit.”

headline: A weekly roundup of the latest from the T Web site
text: BY JORDAN HRUSKA

headline: Shotgun in a Rally Car, Fun or Scary?
text: I’ll never forget the first time I sat shotgun in a rally car. It was a 1999 Ford Focus WRC, driven by Thomas Radstrom, a snow specialist. While rally cars might not have the crazy horsepower of other top-level racecars, nothing can prepare you for the amount of low-end torque they have. The Focus WRC was equipped with a six-speed sequential gearbox, so the acceleration was just insane.
