headline: Presidential Libraries
text: Recently in this space, Dwight Garner offered photographic evidence that Barack Obama has been working his way through Fareed Zakaria’s new book, “The Post-American World,” and wondered out loud what John McCain should read.

headline: Progress on a Budget. How Would You Spend?
text: Bjorn Lomborg, excoriated by some and lionized by others for being a best-selling promoter of free-market problem-solving, has teamed with eight leading economists and other experts in Copenhagen to produce a “Copenhagen Consensus” — a menu for getting the most advancement of the human condition out of an extra (hypothetical) $75 billion over four years. Whichever of the above-mentioned groups you may be in, the resulting list of investments, sorted mainly through a cost-benefit analysis (a process some would reject out of hand), is worth exploring.

headline: Quote: Alien vs. Presidential Contender
text: Who doesn’t love a good U.F.O. tale? As the city of Denver and the rest of the world await a local activist’s proof of alien life — footage of a living extraterrestrial — City Councilman Charlie Brown is frowning. From The Rocky Mountain News:

headline: Will the Next U.S. President Act on Emissions?
text: President George W. Bush declines to commit the United States to fixed, binding targets on reducing emissions. But other major developed nations — including those formerly led by climate change skeptics, like Australia — regard tough regulatory action as the surest way to transform their energy systems. That’s something that all three candidates for the U.S. presidency seem to agree on, too.

headline: Calpine Snubs NRG, Sort of
text: Calpine‘s rejection Friday of an unsolicited, $11 billion takeover offer from rival power generator NRG Energy wasn’t exactly a shock. Calpine’s shares have consistently traded about $1 above the value of NRG’s all-stock offer since NRG’s overture was made public two weeks ago.

headline: Q&A: Florida and Michigan Delegates
text: Updated Democrats have been wrestling for months over whether to reconsider seating the large swath of delegates from Florida and Michigan. The party stripped them of their delegates because they broke party rules by leap-frogging over the Feb. 5 primary date set for most other states.

headline: Prado Won’t Ride Casino Drive Until Belmont
text: So Edgar Prado has the mount on Casino Drive, and he has won the Belmont and ruined previous Triple Crown bids. A solid choice for Casino Drive’s jockey for sure.

text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Signs of Life for Megadeals?
text: Five months into a tough year for deal-making, a few statistics confirm what practitioners in the trenches already knew. The volume of announced mergers around the world is down from last year’s heady levels: It declined about 35 percent through May 29 compared with the equivalent period in 2007, according to Dealogic’s numbers. And the value of leveraged buyout deals has positively plunged, down 76 percent from a year ago.

headline: FIFA’s New Way of Counting to 11
text: As the 58th FIFA congress draws to a close, the most controversial development was one that was entirely expected. By a vote of 155 to five, with 40 abstentions, soccer’s governing body backed further discussion of Sepp Blatter’s “6+5″ plan limiting the number of foreign players on club teams.

headline: The Morning Skate: Doc’s Honor, Orpik’s Shift, Wings’ Teeth and Memories of Luc

text: Yes, it’s a hit at the box office, but are the critics happy with the World Science Festival? Well, I liked what I’ve seen so far, and the the early reviews from my Times colleagues have been good, too. More reviews from Lab readers are welcome.

headline: Clinton Camp’s Argument: No Michigan Delegates for You
text: Updated Senator Hillary Clinton’s campaign says that the Democratic party cannot award any of the “uncommitted” delegates from Michigan to any specific candidate, setting up a potentially major battle with the campaign of Senator Barack Obama.

headline: The Starting Line: The Olympics — for Older Folks?
text: The results of a very telling survey gauging interest among German adults in the Olympics vs. interest in the European Nations Football Championship are in. Surprisingly, Germans are about equally interested in both, even though Euro 2008 begins in June and the 2008 Beijing Games begin in August.

headline: What’s the Rush?
text: One argument we hear against synthetic tracks in the debate which has been raging long before Eight Belles is that they — or at least some of them — take the emphasis off early speed. In pulling his horses out of Del Mar, where last year’s initial Polyseason featured slow times and an end to the speed bias which has been a part of the game in California for so long, his owner Ahmed Zayat said: “You need a surface that is both safe and maintains the integrity of racing. … You can’t take the speed out.”

headline: An Anonymous Blogger, Revealed
text: BRIEFS Abu Muqawama, an anonymous blogger we’ve mentioned several times in The Lede’s posts on Iraq, has revealed himself as Andrew Exum, an Iraq War veteran and military scholar with a few New York Times op-eds under his belt. He also decided to hand the blog over to other contributors in order to pursue his academic work in Lebanon, not that everyone took him that seriously. “I figure it’s a Jay-Z-style retirement,” Spencer Ackerman, another blogger on security issues, wrote in response.

headline: Comcast Tries to Break Some Windows
text: As more and more video is available on the Internet, one question moves sharply into focus: What will happen to cable and satellite television providers? Do we really need specialized networks for our TV, or will the Internet be enough once someone figures out an easy way to get Internet video onto our TV screens?

headline: Floyd Mayweather: Beyond the Ring
text: Boxing's biggest star yearns to be even bigger.

Above: Anja Frejya’s portrait of Gudrun Gut in 1977 (Gut later co-founded Berlin post-punk band Malaria); punk merchandise for sale in the gift shop.

headline: Vova Galchenko: Juggler in Action
text: He has juggling tricks no one else has. And 30-foot-high ceilings.

headline: Students Protest ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Policy
text: Two students were arrested for trespassing at the Armed Forces recruiting station in Times Square today as part of a series of sit-in protests in the Northeast against the Pentagon’s “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” policy. About 20 people took part in the protest, organized by the Harvard Right to Serve Campaign; most left the scene when the police arrived.

headline: A King Receives an Eviction Notice
text: Nepal’s long path from monarchy to republic has come to this: an eviction notice for Gyanendra, the world’s last Hindu king. He has two weeks to leave the palace. Luckily, he also has a private residence in Katmandu, above.

headline: Bourdon’s Death Hits Pens’ Letang Hard
text: Penguins defenseman Kris Letang was enjoying an off day on Wednesday when a call from his agent delivered the horrible news that Luc Bourdon, one of Letang’s best friends, had been killed in a motorcycle accident.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, May 30:

headline: That Animal Look
In This Week’s Magazine: Personalize This
text: Not so long ago, even rank amateurs pretended to be sound engineers when listening to jazz or Journey. Just like a real audiophile, you furrowed your brow over graphic equalizers and studied up on reference speakers and multi-CD changers. If your life was going to include a party or seduction, you needed a stereo — and your choice of equipment made a statement. Then the iPod and iTunes changed that; for all but the fanatics, they took the art out of playing music in the car or at home. And then came that unromantic iPod dock: no longer did your choice of Harman/Kardon or a scuffed boombox say anything about you except that that you were lugging around some antiquated junk. What a comedown. The old rarefied knowledge — and finesse with the levers and knobs and high-stacked component systems — suddenly seemed worthless.

headline: Bob Barr: The Libertarians Find a (Surprising) Nominee
text: It’s been barely two years since former Representative Bob Barr of Georgia renounced the Republican party, after having made his name as the scathing orator who led Congress’s campaign to impeach President Bill Clinton. “Let’s do it!” was his passionate rallying cry.

headline: Ratings: Jack Has To Return To the Island But He Must Take All the Harlem Globetrotters
text: Thursday’s two-hour finale of “Lost” attracted 12.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, lifting ABC to No. 1 in the night’s ratings. Although the show’s fourth season conclusion drew 1.7 million viewers less than the final episode a year ago, it still easily led with the night with the highest ratings, outperforming Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10 p.m. (9.4 million).

headline: ‘Do You Like This Sort of Thing?’
text: This Sunday’s jumbo Summer Reading issue of the Book Review is the usual embarrassment of riches, but let me heartily recommend Nicholson Baker’s delightful review of “The Flash Press: Sporting Male Weeklies in 1840s New York,” written by Patricia Cline Cohen, Timothy J. Gilfoyle and Helen Lefkowitz Horowitz, in association with the American Antiquarian Society.

headline: Red Carpet
Want to Buy an iPhone? Wait a Few Weeks
text: Everybody keeps asking me if they should hold off on buying an iPhone, since the rumors of an iPhone 2.0 are running rampant.

headline: McCain, Obama Campaigns Feud Over Iraq Troop Reductions
text: MILWAUKEE — A fierce debate erupted today between the campaigns of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama over whether Mr. McCain misspoke in a town hall meeting on Thursday when he said American troops in Iraq have now been drawn down to “pre-surge levels.”

headline: More Reviews for McClellan
text: Scott McClellan’s book continues to reverberate in Washington, where new criticisms sprung today from both sides of the aisle and the fourth estate. But there was also at least one fence mended as well. In the last item, an unusual exchange of emotions for this story: forgiveness.

headline: Radical Pique
text: Michael Kinsley, writing in his column for Time magazine, reflects on a controversy that’s sure to revive this summer after Barack Obama secures the presidential nomination of the Democratic Party — Obama’s relationship with Bill Ayers and Bernardine Dohrn, two former members of the Weather Underground.

headline: Remembering the Ghosts of Wall Street
text: At 12:01 a.m. on Saturday, Bear Stearns will cease to exist as a standalone firm, swallowed into J.P. Morgan Chase after the most turbulent period of the investment bank’s 85-year history.

headline: Extra Innings Could Cost Reds
text: In a game that stretched 18 innings and nearly six hours, the Cincinnati Reds used 10 pitchers in a loss last Sunday to the San Diego Padres. They ended up losing on a three-run homer by Adrian Gonzalez in the bottom of the 18th, but the ramifications of having to use so much of the team’s pitching staff in a single game could end up outweighing the loss.

headline: Soft Serve | Carbonated Vodka, A Seaworthy Prius, Deflation Chic
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Fine Print | ‘The Purple Anthology’
text: Purple Anthology, Rizzoli, 2008 (Katja Rahlwes).

headline: A New High for Bush
text: The University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey for May is out, and in one way it sets a record. Asked if the government’s economic policy is good, only fair, or poor, 55 percent now answer poor.

headline: New Group Pressures D.N.C. in Ads
text: A group headed by donors to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hastily formed a new political action committee this week and began running a television advertisement in the Washington, D.C. area on Friday imploring the Democratic National Committee to seat the entire delegations from both Florida and Michigan.

headline: Injury Bugs the Red Wings
text: It seemed that Red Wings Coach Mike Babcock was worried more about having to talk about the injury to forward Tomas Holmstrom than he was about the injury itself. Babcock said he expects Holmstrom to play in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup final on Saturday despite an injured hamstring.

headline: Scarlett Johansson reportedly moving up to New York penthouse
text: Actress Scarlett Johansson was a no-show in Cannes, but she has tongues wagging in real estate circles. According to the blood hounds of the celeb-estate beat, the hour-glass-bodied star is set to pay $2.1 million for a two-bedroom, two-bath penthouse in midtown Manhattan. Real Estalker has all the details.

headline: DISH, EchoStar Sue TiVo
text: Reuters reports: “DISH Network Corp. and EchoStar Corp. said on Friday they had filed a lawsuit against TiVo Inc. and asked a Delaware court to find that their new DVR software does not infringe a TiVo patent.”

headline: Saturday Night on CBS: A Mixed Martial Arts Debut
text: This Saturday, CBS will become the first legacy network to show full mixed martial arts matches in prime time, the Associated Press reports.

headline: Kerry Criticizes McCain’s Use of Petraeus Photo
text: On the heels of a directive to soldiers from America’s top military official to stay out of politics, Senator John McCain acknowledged that his use of Gen. David H. Petraeus’s picture in a fund-raising pitch was not appropriate.

headline: A Fast Train Wins the Mayor’s Support
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that he strongly supported the idea of two-hour train service between New York and Washington contained in a bill cosponsored by Rep. John L. Mica of Florida, the ranking Republican on the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. The mayor made his statement after meeting with Mr. Mica.The legislation would require the secretary of transportation to solicit proposals for the financing, design, construction and operation of a high-speed rail system between the two cities, with the goal of “achieving less than two-hour express service.” The proposal was described in The New York Sun today. Amtrak’s Acela express trains currently make the trip in 2 hours 45 minutes.

headline: Upfronts: Has ABC Taken An Early Lead?
text: The upfront market for the broadcast networks to sell commercial time during their prime-time shows for the 2008-9 season may already be under way.

headline: $8.50 a Pack! Why Not Quit?
text: On Tuesday, the state tax on cigarettes will rise by $1.25 a pack — to $2.75 from $1.50 — driving up the cost of a typical pack in New York City to around $8.50. The city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which has waged a relentless campaign against smoking since 2002, is promoting that fact, telling smokers that they could save about $3,000 a year if they quit a pack-a-day habit. They could use that money, the city says, to buy season Major League Baseball tickets ($2,025), a quarter-carat diamond engagement ring ($2,799) or a 10-day Caribbean cruise ($1,750).

headline: Surfing: A History
text: In Tahiti, writing in his journal after having watched surfing for the first time, Capt. James Cook “could not help concluding that this man felt the most supreme pleasure while he was driven on so fast and so smoothly by the sea.” Other newcomers to Polynesia in the 18th and 19th century — explorers, traders, missionaries — also noted the powerful effect surfing had on natives, particularly in Hawaii: entire villages stood empty during a good run of surf, island priests tried to conjure up better waves by thrashing the water with vines and chanting invocations, and the local mythology included tales of surfing-based romance, conquest and treachery.

headline: Candidates’ Statement on Darfur Ignites Debate
text: The Sudanese Embassy in the United States has challenged a joint statement issued earlier this week by all three presidential candidates in which they blamed the government of Sudan for atrocities against civilians in Darfur.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Memorial Day celebrations, a makeover at the Empire State Building and Fleet Week festivities. Here are highlights from City Room and the most recent New York headlines.

headline: Sewing the Energy Loopholes Shut
text: With gasoline prices bubbling up toward a once-unthinkable $5 a gallon, lawmakers in Washington are running franticly to do something – anything – to halt the steep rise in the price of oil.

headline: A Sichuan Family and Tibet’s Future
text: One sign that life in China is getting back to normal after the catastrophic earthquake in Sichuan is that the Olympics and Tibet are again attracting the world’s attention — though it’s hard to know what “normal” means in China these days.

headline: Fear of Flying
text: No one who has flown in the past year will be at all surprised to hear that in a recent survey by the University of Michigan, customers gave airline service the worst grades since 2001, with the industry’s overall scores dropping for the third straight year. What I think all of us poor passengers are continually amazed at (or maybe it’s just really disheartening) is how low the airlines are willing to go — and I’m not talking prices. First punctuality was all but eliminated, then food, then the pillows and blankets. I was recently charged on Air Canada for seat selection. Now American is charging not only for the second piece of luggage (as many airlines have already done) but for the first. Still, a recent short hop I took on Horizon Air set a new dismal standard for cost efficiency.

headline: Belmont News: Friday
text: Nick Zito is considering a second entry in the Belmont with the Barbaro Stakes runner-up Da’ Tara. He already plans to run Anak Nakal, the seventh-place finisher in the Kentucky Derby. Da’ Tara had an encouraging work at Saratoga on Thursday, going a half in 49.67.

headline: California Privacy Chief Says Google Should Improve Disclosure
text: UPDATE 6/3 5:45PM: Four privacy groups have sent a letter to Google asking it to place a link to its privacy policy on hits home page. Coverage from CNet and ComputerWorld.

headline: Valentín Misses the Mets and Thinks He Can Help
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The pain in José Valentín’s right elbow won’t do anything to speed his return to the Mets. And it has been similarly frustrating for Valentín to watch, from a distance, as the Mets try to right themselves.

headline: Friday Happy Hour: Caribbean Breeze
text: The islands breeze in Puerto Rico clearly helped soften even the most polished of candidates. Or was it that Presidente beer? With the commonwealth’s Democratic primary coming up Sunday, the campaign took on a Latin flavor.

headline: Chamberlain Will Start on Tuesday
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Joba Chamberlain will make his highly anticipated first major league start on Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium against Toronto. Manager Joe Girardi said he made the decision after weighing “a ton of factors,” among them keeping Andy Pettitte on normal rest.

headline: The World Science Festival: Oliver Sacks at the MET
text: What can you see with your eyes closed? As it turns out a lot more than you might think, as the writer and neurologist Oliver Sacks discovered in 2005 when he developed cancer in his right eye. Speaking at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Friday night to a standing room only crowd, Sacks detailed in words and drawings from his journals (think preschool art) what it is looks like when your eyes deceive you. His talk was part of the World Science Festival, which was founded by the husband and wife team, Columbia physicist Brian Greene and television producer Tracy Day.

headline: Mixed Martial Arts and the Military
text: Soldiers at Fort Bragg, N.C., competed in fights blending jiu-jitsu, boxing and wrestling techniques.

headline: Relief on the Range
text: Mets relief pitcher Scott Schoeneweis gets a golf lesson.

headline: In Training
text: Women inmates at a New York prison are training puppies to help the disabled and returning war veterans.

headline: Debra and Michael
text: Debra Waxman and Michael Pilla decided to get married after dating for 5 years, but it took a Florida trip to unite their families.

headline: Debra and Michael
text: Debra Waxman and Michael Pilla decided to get married after dating for 5 years, but it took a Florida trip to unite their families.

headline: Campaigning in Old San Juan
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held a rally at a waterside plaza in Old San Juan Friday night, arriving three hours late, speaking for nine minutes and dancing  on stage for three minutes during a brief performance afterwards by local reggaeton artists, Rakim and Ken Y. (Note to self: Hillary Clinton is not in South Dakota anymore.)

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: What George Forgot
text: So there’s the loyalty tradeoff for you: On the one hand, Bernard Kerik did a terrible job in a critical assignment in Iraq and showed a stupendous disinterest in ethical considerations when he served in New York City. On the other, he will never, ever write a tell-all memoir about any of the great men he has known.

headline: Judge Approves Credit Bureau’s Settlement Plan
text: TransUnion, the credit reporting agency, won preliminary court approval to pay $75 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of as many as 150 million people accusing it of improperly selling consumer credit information. The company would allow qualified consumers six months of unlimited free access to their credit reports and an as-yet undetermined cash award, under the terms of the accord approved by a Federal District Court judge, Robert Gettleman, in Chicago. The lawsuits accuse the company of selling marketing lists grouping consumers by their credit profiles, in violation of the federal law. TransUnion admits no wrongdoing in the settlement.

headline: Gunman Kills 8 Worshipers at Mosque in Yemen
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A gunman opened fire in a mosque in northern Yemen on Friday, killing at least eight people as they knelt for prayer and wounding dozens of others in the latest of a string of violent episodes across the country.

headline: The Human Toll of a Building Binge
text: Once again, death by crane has come to the East Side of Manhattan. As stadiums are built, a new subway line is dug and office towers soar, one anonymous apartment house development on 91st Street has provided another flash look at the vulnerability of life in a crowded city. While people across the street were getting ready for work on Friday morning, a crane fell and ripped open their homes.

headline: What George Forgot
text: “DISLOYAL, SICKENING AND DESPICABLE DISLOYAL, SICKENING AND DESPICABLE,” wrote Bernard Kerik in an e-mail that he was circulating around this week. Kerik, you may remember, was the former New York City police commissioner who George W. Bush once tried to make chief of Homeland Security. This was during Kerik’s happier, preindictment era.

headline: Deal to Return Children to Sect Breaks Down
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Negotiations for the state’s release of more than 460 children who were removed from a polygamist sect in April broke down Friday in a scene of chaos and bitterness in a courtroom in this West Texas city.

headline: Hossa and Penguins Regain Postseason Touch
text: PITTSBURGH  With nine goals in three rounds of playoffs, Marian Hossa seemed to put the doubts that have dogged him during his career to rest. He helped his new team, the Penguins, storm to the Stanley Cup finals, making their trade for him at the deadline look brilliant, not risky. A talented but always mercurial winger, Hossa seemed to find a home.

headline: Germany to Sell Part of Rail Company
text: FRANKFURT  Ending years of wrangling, the German Parliament on Friday voted to sell a stake in Deutsche Bahn, the former state railroad monopoly that is now a logistics company.

headline: Farnsworth Escapes in Eighth as the Yankees Piece Together a Victory
text: MINNEAPOLIS  With Joba Chamberlain finally and officially placed in the rotation Friday  he will start Tuesday in New York  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi now must find someone he trusts to replace Chamberlain as the bridge to closer Mariano Rivera.

headline: Growing Opposition to Iraq Security Pact
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is facing growing opposition to a proposed security agreement that would set out how long American forces and military bases stayed in Iraq.

headline: Administration Moves to Avert a Late Rules Rush
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration has told federal agencies that they have until June 1 to propose any new regulations, a move intended to avoid the rush of rules issued by previous administrations on their way out the door.

headline: Former EADS Chief Faces Preliminary Charges
text: PARIS  French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Noël Forgeard, a former chief executive of EADS, as they investigate stock sales executed ahead of the announcement of major delays in building the A380 superjumbo.

headline: Richard Lower Dies at 78; Transplanted Animal and Human Hearts
text: Dr. Richard R. Lower, whose daring heart surgeries on animals in the 1950s helped pave the way for the first successful transplant of a human heart in 1967, died on May 17 in Twin Bridges, Mont. He was 78.

headline: Putin Maintains Presidential Air in Paris Trip
text: PARIS  It is Vladimir V. Putin’s first trip abroad as Russia’s prime minister, but he might as well still be its president.

headline: An Accident Fuses Two Workers’ Lives Forever
text: Donald Leo, a sturdy 30-year-old crane operator, was looking forward to a June wedding and then a honeymoon in Greece. Ramadan Kurtaj, a 27-year-old émigré who had fought for his life in Kosovo, worked long hours on water and sewer lines so that he could send money home to his parents.

headline: Investigators Look at Equipment, Not Crane’s Operators
text: This article was reported by Charles V. Bagli,  Ken Belson and  William Neuman, and written by Mr. Neuman.

headline: United and US Airways End Merger Talks
text: US Airways and United Airlines told their employees on Friday that they would not reach a merger agreement with another airline for the time being, and said they were evaluating further steps.

headline: A Night of Dance, Face Paint and Social Commentary
text: The last place you might expect to see a new ballet is at La MaMa, a theater that is virtually a synonym for all things avant-garde. Of course, there is no rule that a new ballet can’t be avant-garde; it just almost never is. And sadly, it wasn’t on Thursday night, when Christopher Caines presented “Exquisite Hour” as part of “An Evening of Dance Works,” the final program, in the Annex, of the “La MaMa Moves!” dance festival.

headline: Crew of Discovery
text: Don’t call them rookies.

headline: Celtics Oust Pistons to Return to N.B.A. Finals
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  The N.B.A.’s best basketball team in the regular season has not made anything look easy in the playoffs.

headline: Is Tiger Woods the Best Athlete Ever?
text: Watch Play Magazine writers Charles McGrath and Michael Sokolove debate the question, and share your own thoughts.

headline: Riding the Emotions of a Ratmansky Ballet
text: As “Concerto DSCH,” the new ballet by Alexei Ratmansky for New York City Ballet, unfolded at its premiere on Thursday night, you could feel wave upon wave of emotion sweeping across the audience. Wonder, excitement, admiration, affection, hilarity, surprise, exhilaration.

headline: Basking in a World Where Anything Goes
text: “Is it to rescue or is it to wreck?/Is it an ache in the heart/Or just a pain in the neck?” So wrote Cole Porter about serial infatuation in his 1938 song “At Long Last Love.” To hear such delicious turns of phrase delivered with meaningful hesitations and a raised eyebrow by Jeff Harnar, who completes a four-night tribute to Porter at the Metropolitan Room on Saturday, is to find yourself grinning with pleasure.

headline: A Specialist Over 200 Meters Becomes a Favorite in the 100
text: By his own admission, Usain Bolt has some bad running habits.

headline: A Serial Killer’s Evolution as Seen From a Marriage
text: Although television has provided a broad outlet for documentaries in recent years, there is still obviously enough competition for scheduling on the most prestigious networks that even someone like the producer and director Barbara Kopple  of “Harlan County U.S.A.,” “Wild Man Blues” and “Shut Up & Sing” isn’t necessarily guaranteed to show up on HBO or PBS.

headline: Shuttle on Schedule for Saturday Launch
text: Both weather and technology seem to be cooperating for launching the space shuttle Discovery on Saturday to begin a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle, with its crew of seven astronauts, is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 Saturday afternoon to bring a tour-bus-sized science laboratory to the station, the $1 billion “Kibo” module.

headline: Commodity Policies Set for Revision
text: The chief regulator of the nation’s commodity markets will unveil early next week a set of policy changes to address public and political concerns that market malfunctions may be contributing to rising food and energy prices, according to people who have been briefed about the agency’s plans.

headline: Court Upholds Key Provision of the Voting Rights Act
text: WASHINGTON  A special three-judge court ruled Friday that Congress acted constitutionally when it extended the law requiring sections of the country with a history of racial discrimination to get federal approval for any changes in voting procedures.

headline: Portraying Spirituality of Messiaen as Organist
text: The works of Olivier Messiaen that have traveled best are chamber, vocal and orchestral scores. But Messiaen was an organist, and he composed an imposing body of works for his instrument. This year several organists have taken the occasion of Messiaen’s centenary to make that point. Gail Archer began a six-concert tour of the major Messiaen works in January, and undertook a tour of Manhattan’s organs while she was at it, playing each concert in a different church. For her finale, on Thursday evening, she performed the huge “Livre du Saint Sacrement” (1984) at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: 2 Campaigns Flare Up Over Iraq Troop Levels
text: MILWAUKEE  A fierce debate erupted on Friday between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama over whether Mr. McCain misspoke at a town-hall-style meeting the previous day when he said that American troops in Iraq had been reduced to “pre-surge levels.”

headline: Jesters of Different Faiths Use Laughs to Bridge the Divide
text: MADISON, N.J.  The Jewish comedian began with a routine about raising adolescents. “There was a reason Abraham was asked to sacrifice Isaac at 12 and not 13,” he said. “At 13, it wouldn’t have been a sacrifice.”

headline: Monks Succeed in Cyclone Relief as Junta Falters
text: KUN WAN, Myanmar  They paddle for hours on the stormy river, or carry their sick parents on their backs through the mud and rain, traveling for miles to reach the one source of help they can rely on: Buddhist monks.

headline: Looking Skyward in Lower Manhattan
text: New York has never been very nice to the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry.

headline: Springtime in Paris Is Cruel to the Williamses
text: PARIS  A day that started badly for the Williams family in morning sunlight ended badly for the Williams family in near darkness with flashbulbs going off in the stands.

headline: British Banker Group to Strengthen Libor Oversight
text: LONDON  The British Bankers’ Association said on Friday that it planned to strengthen the oversight of the London interbank offered rate after questions arose about the veracity of the 22-year-old benchmark used to set borrowing costs around the world.

headline: A Spider’s High Price
text: A four-foot-high metal and fabric sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois sold for $4.5 million, a record price for the artist, at Christie’s International in Paris, Bloomberg News reported. The sculpture by Ms. Bourgeois, 96, was bought by a European collector on the telephone, competing against three other bidders on Tuesday, the auction house said. Works by Ms. Bourgeois, known for her spider sculptures, already commanded the highest prices for a living female artist. Her most expensive sculpture, an eight-foot-high arachnid, fetched $4 million with fees at Christie’s New York in November 2006, according to Artnet.

headline: The Old Family Tea Business Gets a New-Media Spin
text: TEA is the second most popular beverage among consumers around the world after water, according to the Tea Association of the United States of America, and is found in almost 80 percent of American homes. Sales of tea have increased every year for more than 15 years and show no signs of slowing. R. C. Bigelow, a family-owned company in Fairfield, Conn., is one of the country’s biggest tea producers. Cindi Bigelow is the third generation of the family to take the reins.

headline: Berio’s ‘Love Letter’ to Schubert, Inspired by Sketches for an Unwritten Symphony
text: The dynamic conductor David Robertson was almost certainly on the short list during the New York Philharmonic’s search for a music director to succeed Lorin Maazel. Though Alan Gilbert wound up with the job, on Thursday night Mr. Robertson conducted the orchestra in a concert that suggested what qualities he might have brought to the position.

headline: Martínez Is Back in Mets’ Dugout, Bringing His Upbeat Attitude With Him
text: Pedro Martínez was back with the Mets at Shea Stadium on Friday, which meant he was throwing, smiling, joking and trying to bring some stability to a team that has been wobbly without him. Martínez says he believes he can still make a difference, and believes the Mets have to make a difference.

headline: Errors Lead Serena Williams to Exit in Paris
text: PARIS  On a gorgeous spring day in the French capital, one where it was easy to forget all the storm clouds of the past week, Serena Williams ended up in a dark and disappointed mood after one of the most surprising defeats of her career.

headline: South Africa: Attacks on Immigrants Decline
text: After more than two weeks of attacks on Zimbabweans, Malawians, Mozambicans and other immigrants living in poor townships, the government said that calm was returning and that there had been no additional incidents in the past three days. More than 1,300 people have been arrested for crimes related to the violence in Johannesburg, Pretoria, Cape Town and elsewhere. Thousands of displaced victims will be sheltered in small tents and provided with clean water and toilets.

headline: Loss of a Backer Grounds a Business-Class Airline
text: LONDON  Silverjet, the business-class-only airline, on Friday became the third such carrier to cease operations in the last six months, unable to cope with rising fuel costs or to attract new financing.

headline: Crane Collapse, 2nd Since March, Kills 2 Workers
text: This time, it was the top of the crane that fell. The huge pieces smashed into the penthouse of a nearby building, then tore off a row of balconies and plummeted to the street in a shower of bricks, dust and debris. Two men, both workers, were killed.

headline: City Opera Plans Different Programs for a Shrinking Season
text: While its home is closed for renovations, New York City Opera will shrink its main dramatic offerings next season to one lonely opera: Samuel Barber’s “Antony and Cleopatra.” For two performances. Unstaged.

headline: Army Judge Is Replaced for Trial of Detainee
text: The chief judge at Guantánamo replaced the military judge in one of the most closely watched war crimes cases on Thursday, creating a new controversy in the military commission system and the potential for new delays.

headline: Job Climate for the Class of 2008 Is a Bit Warmer Than Expected
text: Given that the economy is flagging, this would seem an inauspicious time to be graduating from college and looking for full-time employment.

headline: McEwan Opera Delayed
text: The world premiere of the first opera by the novelist Ian McEwan (“Atonement”), a collaboration with the composer Michael Berkeley, has been postponed because the leading man has voice problems, Media Wales reported. The opera, “For You,” was to be staged in a partnership with the Hay Festival at Theatr Brycheiniog in Brecon on Saturday and Sunday, before embarking on a tour. But Eric Roberts, a Welsh baritone who sings the role of a womanizing composer, has been told by doctors that he must rest. Music Theater Wales, which is staging the opera, has also been forced to cancel a performance at Clwyd Theatr Cymru in Mold on Thursday.

headline: Group Is Said to Bid $3.5 Billion for Weather Channel
text: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, people briefed on the matter said. NBC, the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital were offering about $3.5 billion including debt, these people said. About $1.8 billion of that was in cash, which would be split equally among the three investors. Other bidders for the channel include Time Warner, these people said. A winner may be announced as soon as next week. Landmark Communications, the privately held owner of the Weather Channel, is putting the weather-news heavyweight up for sale as part of a break-up of itself. Landmark originally sought to fetch $5 billion for the Weather Channel.

headline: Text of Message Sent to United Employees
text: Following is the text of a message from the chief executive of United Airlines, Glenn F. Tilton, that was sent Friday to airline employees.

headline: Mets Give Their Fans Reasons to Boo
text: The Mets left Shea Stadium in a hurry Friday night.

headline: The Nucleus Remains, but Changes Await the Spurs
text: LOS ANGELES  Late Thursday night, in a cramped Staples Center locker room, Manu Ginóbili talked about pain, Bruce Bowen mused on missed opportunities and R. C. Buford rifled through boxes of stale pepperoni pizza.

headline: China’s Push to Avert Quake Flood Nears End
text: CHENGDU, China  After five days of nonstop digging, engineers said Friday night that they were nearly finished carving a channel they hoped would relieve pressure on a swelling lake that threatens more than a million people already coping with the aftermath of the May 12 earthquake.

headline: Coming Late to the Table
text: I guess it’s official now since we have a Bush administration insider, Scott McClellan, telling us that the war in Iraq was a monumental strategic blunder, and that it was sold cynically and deceitfully to a craven Congress and to a public still traumatized by the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: It’s Easier to Be Green if It Also Saves Money
text: PRICE matters, and suddenly Americans are seeking to conserve energy in ways forgotten since the early 1980s.

headline: Push for New Direction Leads to Sudden Dead End for a 40-Year Naval Career
text: FLORENCE, Italy

headline: A Premonition Fulfilled, in a City That Lives With Cranes
text: They knew what it was as soon as they heard the noise.

headline: Isolated in Amazon, Visible From the Air
text: Aerial photographs of an isolated community of indigenous people in the Amazon basin, near the border shared by Brazil and Peru, were released this week to show that they exist but may be endangered by illegal logging.

headline: Vengeance Revisited, With Singing
text: ARLINGTON, Va.  The macabre and the misty-eyed vie uneasily for supremacy in “The Visit,” a musical adaptation of Friedrich Dürrenmatt’s 1956 tragicomedy about vengeance and venality, at the Signature Theater here.

headline: Billboards That Look Back
text: In advertising these days, the brass ring goes to those who can measure everything  how many people see a particular advertisement, when they see it, who they are. All of that is easy on the Internet, and getting easier in television and print.

headline: Baltimore Bids to Ban Selling Small Cigars Individually
text: Hoping to curb the increase in the number of young people who smoke small, inexpensive cigars, Baltimore plans to bar shops from the common practice of breaking open packages to sell them individually.

headline: Musharraf Denies He Is Stepping Down
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pressed by a swirl of rumors that he was about to be ousted, President Pervez Musharraf insisted this week that he was staying, and President Bush on Friday confirmed his continued support with a reassuring phone call to Mr. Musharraf, the White House said.

headline: Police Told to Give Street-Stop Data
text: A state judge in Manhattan has ordered the Police Department to release its database on hundreds of thousands of civilians stopped by officers.

headline: Charles Ober for City Council
text: There will be a special election on Tuesday in the 30th City Council District in Queens, which includes Ridgewood, Middle Village and Glendale. The seat became vacant after the resignation of City Councilman Dennis Gallagher, who admitted to sexually abusing a woman in his district office. Voters in this election, to fill the seat for the rest of the year, should seize the chance to force some much-needed change.

headline: A Vote to Ease Executive Changes at Alcatel-Lucent
text: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman. The new rules allow board members to make such changes by a simple majority instead of the two-thirds majority previously required. “Good governance is clearly moving to majority voting, rather than super-majority voting,” said Patricia F. Russo, left, who has been chief executive since the company was created by a merger in 2006. Ms. Russo repeated a forecast that sales for telecommunications equipment will fall this year because of the dollar’s decline against the euro and possible spending delays at some clients.

headline: TV Spotlight Shines on Celebrated Street Brawler
text: Kevin Ferguson, who goes by the name Kimbo Slice, has fought in only two professional mixed martial arts matches, and he has a long way to go before he is considered a polished, well-rounded fighter.

headline: Climbing Down Off the Screen, Getting Up Onstage
text: Sean (Diddy) Combs has held many jobs over the course of his career: record-label owner, rapper, restaurateur, actor, fashion mogul. On Wednesday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, he took on another: epistemologist.

headline: The Huge Hybrid: a New Twist on S.U.V.’s Finds Few Takers
text: DETROIT  They’ve been criticized as gas hogs, dinosaurs and land yachts.

headline: Strong Backing for Ex-Governor’s Appeal
text: Fifty-four former state attorneys general filed a brief Friday supporting the appeal of former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama, convicted two years ago on bribery and corruption charges in a prosecution depicted by his supporters as politically motivated.

headline: Corrections
text: Front Page

headline: States Seek Delay in California Marriage Ruling
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Concerned about the national ramifications of same-sex marriages in California, attorneys general from 10 states have asked the California Supreme Court to stay its decision legalizing the marriages, which are set to begin on June 17.

headline: Alvin M. Marks, Inventor With 122 Patents, Dies at 97
text: Alvin M. Marks, a prolific inventor who held patents on polarized film for sunglasses, a 3-D moviemaking process, a generator the size of a grapefruit that could produce enough electricity for a house, a windmill with no moving parts and a trillion-dollar “space train,” died Sunday in Gardner, Mass. He was 97 and lived in Athol, Mass.

headline: In Disclosure, North Korea Contradicts U.S. Intelligence on Its Plutonium Program
text: WASHINGTON  An 18,000-page declaration submitted by North Korea to the United States is stirring debate about whether American intelligence agencies previously overstated how much plutonium the Pyongyang government might have produced for its nuclear weapons program.

headline: Michelangelo for Readers With Deep Pockets
text: BOLOGNA, Italy  The gala presentation of “Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano” (“Michelangelo: The Wise Hand”), a volume of photographs of this Renaissance master’s sculptures, may well have been the most lavish book debut in history.

headline: Double-Decker Memories
text: To the Editor:

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 23 through May 30:

headline: Nine Restless Dancers and One Slippery Creature
text: Like many New York choreographers, Susan Rethorst was forced to give up her studio space for financial reasons, but unlike many, she did  or rather, made  something about it. A resulting dance, “208 East Broadway, Part 2: Suitcase Dreams,” is a continuation of a work she created in her living room; in its latest incarnation it moves far beyond those four walls.

headline: Gaza Strip: Rice Surprised Student Grants Withheld
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she was surprised the State Department had withdrawn Fulbright fellowships to study in the United States from seven Palestinians living in Gaza, and department officials were working to press Israel to reverse its decision not to give the students exit visas. Once students have been selected for the prestigious fellowships, said Tom Casey, a State Department spokesman, “It ought to be falling off a log for them to be able to do this.”

headline: Career Bureaucrat Rises to Prominence in Housing Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  The phone calls have been streaming into the Federal Housing Administration for months now  from White House budget officials, Democratic lawmakers and the occasional cable television news producer  all asking for a few minutes with the man in charge.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies on Friday about the comic actor Harvey Korman, who appeared for 10 seasons on “The Carol Burnett Show,” misstated the history of the ending of the show. Ms. Burnett chose to end it after the 11th season; it was not canceled because it was failing. The obituary also misstated the title of the skit in which Mr. Korman and Ms. Burnett played a combative married couple raising the wife’s teenage sister. It was called “Carol and Sis,” not “Old Folks at Home.”

headline: Chamberlain Will Make His First Start on Tuesday
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Joba Chamberlain will make his highly anticipated first major league start Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium against the Toronto Blue Jays. Manager Joe Girardi said he made the decision after weighing “a ton of factors,” among them keeping Andy Pettitte on normal rest.

headline: Ford to Build More Fiestas to Offset Falling Truck Sales
text: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company, struggling with tumbling sales of its bigger vehicles, revealed plans on Friday to build its new subcompact car, the Fiesta, at a Mexican factory that assembles full-size pickup trucks.

headline: Drug Massacre Leaves a Mexican Town Terrorized
text: VILLA AHUMADA, Mexico  A massacre here two weeks ago has turned this once sleepy town into a ghostly emblem of the drug violence that has swept Mexico over the last year and a half, gutting local police forces, terrifying citizens and making it almost impossible for the authorities to assert themselves.

headline: Extra Powerful Role Model Will Return to Weight Lifting’s Biggest Stage
text: ATLANTA  At first, all Cheryl Haworth sought through weight lifting was an extra layer of muscle to help smack a softball farther. Then, before she could legally drive, she awakened as the nation’s mightiest woman, an overnight sensation bearing the burden of XX-sized role model.

headline: Shake-Up at French Bank After Trading Scandal
text: PARIS Société Générale, the French banking giant, announced Friday that it would replace its head of investment banking, Jean-Pierre Mustier, in its latest effort to restore a reputation bruised by a trading scandal.

headline: Text of Message to US Airways Employees
text: Following is the text of a message from W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive at US Airways, that was sent Friday to airline employees.

headline: Troubled Oceans
text: Five years have elapsed since the Pew Oceans Commission’s seminal report urging prompt action to arrest the alarming decline of this country’s ocean resources. Four years have elapsed since a blue-ribbon presidential commission said much the same thing, urging special attention to problems like overfishing and the deterioration of coastal wetlands and estuaries. Despite an occasional burst of energy, however, the Bush administration and Congress have left much to be done. And time is running out.

headline: The Worst Way of Farming
text: In the past month, two new reports have examined how farm animals are raised in this country. The report funded by the Pew Charitable Trusts calls the prevailing system “industrial farm animal production.” The report from the Union of Concerned Scientists prefers the term “confined animal feeding operations.”

headline: Q. & A. on Democrats and Disputed Delegates
text: A potentially fierce political showdown is in the offing on Saturday as Democratic Party officials meet to try to resolve one of the most contentious issues of their presidential primary process: whether to seat the delegations from Florida and Michigan at the party’s August convention, and if so, how.

headline: Frank Shattuck II, Who Helped Guide Schrafft’s, Dies at 89
text: Frank G. Shattuck II, the last president of the company that owned Schrafft’s restaurants, a New York City-based chain that for decades offered home-style food in genteel surroundings to secretaries, errand boys, court clerks and others watchful of their wallets, died Saturday near his home in Bennington, Vt. He was 89.

headline: Hudson River Water
text: To the Editor:

headline: An International Dispute Over a Humble Tuber
text: LIMA, Peru  They have quarreled over the 1880s pillaging of Peru’s national library by Chilean troops. They have squabbled over who has the naming rights to pisco, the fiery grape brandy. Now, Peru and Chile are arguing over another hot-button issue: the origins of the potato.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an appraisal of the career of the film director Sydney Pollack, who died on Monday, misspelled the surname of the actor shown with Jane Fonda in a film that Mr. Pollack directed, “They Shoot Horses, Don’t They?” He is Michael Sarrazin, not Serrazin.

headline: Seattle Asian Museum Moves Around the Corner and Into Its Identity
text: SEATTLE  As the Wing Luke Asian Museum reopens on Saturday, the celebrations here are about more than mere institutional accomplishments. The move of this 42-year-old museum around the corner (after raising $23.2 million for its new home), the size of that new home (60,000 square feet or eight times the size of the old), its expanded ambitions (projecting 60,000 annual visitors instead of 15,000)  all this is a considerable achievement for an institution that used to be housed in an old garage and that now hopes to be an anchor for revitalizing Seattle’s Chinatown (now part of the city’s International District).

headline: Colombia’s Chance
text: Colombia’s president, Álvaro Uribe, may be sorely tempted to begin a final, killing offensive against rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. The rebels are weakened, and Mr. Uribe is eager to capitalize politically on their defeat.

headline: Former EADS Chief Faces Insider Trading Charges
text: PARIS — French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Noël Forgeard, the former co-chief executive of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europe’s largest aerospace group, his lawyer said Friday. The charges relate to delays in the program to build the A380 superjumbo.

headline: Dancing for Dollars (10,000, to Be Exact)
text: Critics may not be able to vote during the four nights of “The A.W.A.R.D. Show!” choreography competition, but it’s nice to think that we have a voice in what the event’s artist director, Neta Pulvermacher, described as “an exercise in democracy and in seeing.” Think of us as dance superdelegates, surveying the bigger picture from afar.

headline: As Iowa Job Surplus Grows, Workers Call the Shots
text: DES MOINES  On a recent evening here, Greg Tew, 28, considered the question: What is it like to work in a state that is creating more jobs than workers? He was sitting in the lobby of a new hotel in downtown Des Moines, part of an extensive redevelopment investment to attract workers to Iowa.

headline: Gates Warns China Not to Bully Region on Energy
text: SINGAPORE  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a set of thinly veiled warnings to China on Saturday, cautioning that it could risk its share of further gains in Asia’s economic prosperity if it bullied its neighbors over natural resources in contested areas like the South China Sea.

headline: Alexander Courage, ‘Star Trek’ Composer, Dies at 88
text: Alexander Courage, an Emmy-winning Hollywood composer whose most famous work was the strange, soaring and instantly recognizable theme from “Star Trek,” died on May 15 in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 88 and until recently lived in Malibu.

headline: Fuel Costs Incite Protests by Fishermen in Europe
text: PARIS  Commercial fishermen across Europe carried out new protests on Friday against soaring fuel bills, blockading ports and refineries in France and handing out fresh fish in Madrid.

headline: Paterson Faces Suit Over Order on Marriage
text: ALBANY  An Arizona-based conservative Christian group said on Friday that it planned to sue Gov. David A. Paterson to block his directive to state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside New York.

headline: Fox News Employee Sues Over Infestation
text: Two months after Fox News said it had wiped out a bedbug infestation in its Midtown Manhattan newsroom, a network employee who says she was bitten on three occasions has filed a negligence suit against the building’s owners and managing agent and two cleaning companies. In a suit filed Thursday, the employee, Jane Clark, a coordinator in the department that transmits the channel’s satellite feeds around the world, seeks unspecified damages for “pain, shock, mental anguish,” which she says resulted from bites on her arms, leg and neck. Ms. Clark is on medical leave. Fox News is not named in the suit. A statement by one of the building owners and Cushman & Wakefield, its managing agent, said tenants were responsible for providing extermination services. Still, the statement added, “As a prudent step, we are bringing in outside, independent experts to review the situation.” On March 17 a Fox executive said that the infestation appeared to have originated in the home of another employee.

headline: Bureaucrats and the Cloven-Hoofed
text: As if there’s not enough on its smorgasbord of potential threats, the Department of Homeland Security is studying whether the government’s contagious animal disease lab can be moved to mainland farm country from its longtime island outpost off the coast of New York. Members of Congress are properly alarmed at the news that the agency is already considering five possible sites onshore, even though there have been no risk assessments yet on potential relocation dangers to the livestock industry from foot-and-mouth disease and other contagious threats.

headline: Crane Collapse Kills Two and Unsettles New Yorkers
text: The collapse of a crane at an Upper East Side construction site on Friday morning killed two workers and severely damaged several high-rise apartments. And it left many New Yorkers pondering an unsettling question: This again?

headline: At Exxon’s Can’t-Miss Meeting
text: There were storms around New York on Tuesday evening, and we sat on the runway for hours. I was heading to Dallas for Exxon Mobil’s annual meeting, which had become this year’s “can’t-miss” meeting, especially if you are a reporter.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on May 22 about the questioning of three Brooklyn high school students after notes describing a murder plot were discovered included erroneous information from the police about the McDonald’s restaurant where one of the named targets worked. It is in Brooklyn but not “across the street” from the school, James Madison High. The article also misidentified the school’s neighborhood. It is in Midwood, not Marine Park.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on May 22 about the impressions of Jewish voters in Florida of Senator Barack Obama paraphrased incorrectly from a statement by Rabbi David Saperstein of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism in Washington, who commented on those views. He said that among the concerns Jews have about Mr. Obama are his past associations and his support for Israel. Rabbi Saperstein did not say Jews are concerned about the senator’s patriotism.

headline: Barcelona Will Play at Chicago and New York
text: F.C. Barcelona will make its third trip to the United States in the last five years and play two exhibition games in August, including one against the Red Bulls, Major League Soccer announced Friday.

headline: Pakistani Nuclear Scientist Denies Selling Secrets
text: PARIS  Abdul Qadeer Khan, the founder of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons program, was reported on Friday to have withdrawn an admission that he sold nuclear technology to Iran, North Korea and Libya, saying that he had made it under pressure from President Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Strong Winds Can’t Knock the Memorial Leaders Down
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  The second round of the Memorial turned into an all-day survival test Friday, with 25-mile-per-hour wind gusts buffeting the late starters and sending the field’s stroke average soaring to almost 76.

headline: Farewell, Fair Weather
text: We are now firmly ensconced in the Age of Extreme Weather.

headline: Phoenix to Earthlings: I’ve Landed! Awesome!
text: @infoholic Yup, I can dig into frozen ground as hard as concrete. The scoop has special blades and a powered “rasp” to scrape ice. Cool!

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Wednesday about climate change cited the wrong year for the most recent Senate vote on the McCain-Lieberman bill. The Senate last voted on the proposal in 2005, not 2003.

headline: Footnote
text: “Natasha,” a story written by Vladimir Nabokov around 1924 as his career began, will be published for the first time in English in the summer fiction issue of The New Yorker, on sale Monday. The story, which was part of Nabokov’s archives at the Library of Congress, was translated by his son, Dmitri Nabokov. It tells of a young woman who cares for her father in Berlin as he mourns their exile from Russia.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the difficulties of importing natural gas misstated the name of a company that builds import facilities. It is Sempra LNG, a division of Sempra Energy  not Sempra LNGE.

headline: Earl Eaton, a Founder of the Vail Skiing Resort, Is Dead at 85
text: Earl Eaton, a dreamer who grew up glorying in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado as a hunter, a hiker, a prospector and a skier, then looked anew at a nameless 11,570-foot-high mountain and envisioned what became Vail, one of America’s most popular ski resorts, died on May 25 at his home in Eagle, Colo. He was 85.

headline: Former EADS Chief Faces Insider Trading Charges
text: PARIS  French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Noël Forgeard, a former chief executive of EADS, as they investigate stock sales executed ahead of the announcement of major delays in building the Airbus A380 superjumbo.

headline: Go Ahead, Go Barefoot. The Grass Is Fine.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan to Send China Aid on Civilian, Not Military, Planes
text: BEIJING  Japan on Thursday decided against using military aircraft to deliver aid to earthquake victims in China after Chinese officials reportedly expressed concerns about what would have been the first Japanese military deployment to China since the two countries were enemies during World War II.

headline: Blair Charity to Enlist Religion as a Positive Force
text: Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, formally unveiled plans in New York City on Friday for an ambitious new charity that he hopes will enlist religion as a force for economic development and conflict resolution, rather than violence and strife.

headline: Mocking of Clinton at Obama’s Church Reverberates
text: CHICAGO  Reverberations from the Sunday sermon of a Roman Catholic priest who mocked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at Senator Barack Obama’s home church here continued to spread Friday, after the priest offered an apology and the archbishop of Chicago gave him a public reprimand for “partisan campaigning.”

headline: Columbia Takes an Early Lead, but Loses Its N.C.A.A. Opener
text: CONWAY, S.C.  Mike Malfettone hit his first home run of the season Friday in the third inning of a scoreless game in N.C.A.A. Division I regional play here. Columbia, which had not played in the tournament since 1976, was leading Coastal Carolina, the top seed in this double-elimination regional.

headline: Vatican Asserts Rule That Bars Female Priests
text: ROME  The Vatican on Friday reaffirmed a ban on ordaining women as priests, warning that the consequences of any such ordination would be the automatic excommunication of anyone involved.

headline: Negotiating for a House? Start With ‘Dear Seller’
text: A few years ago, when multiple bidders would show up at a real estate open house, the truly desperate resorted to writing love letters to the sellers.

headline: Berlioz by the Tarmac
text: A week and a half after a fire damaged its concert hall, the Berlin Philharmonic moved on to playing an airport. The orchestra performed Berlioz’s “Symphonie Fantastique” and “Mort de Cleopatre” in a hangar at the Tempelhof Airport on Thursday night as planes landed nearby, including one during the quietest moment of the symphony, The Associated Press reported. It was the second temporary facility for the orchestra; after a fire caused by welding work tore through the roof of the Philharmonic on May 20, it also performed in an open-air stadium used for rock concerts. The Philharmonic hopes to return to its home, whose interior was not severely damaged, by Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Music Critic Must Testify About R. Kelly Sex Tape
text: A music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times who gave the police the tape that prosecutors say shows R. Kelly, having sex with an under-age female must testify at Mr. Kelly’s child pornography trial, a judge ruled Friday. Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court ruled that the defense can question the critic, Jim DeRogatis, about what he did with the VHS cassette between the time he received it and the time he gave it to the authorities, The Chicago Tribune reported. Lawyers for Mr. Kelly, the R&B singer who won a Grammy in 1997 and is known for his raunchy ballads, contend that their client is not on the tape and that Mr. DeRogatis has a personal bias against him. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. The trial continues Monday.

headline: The Generic Washington Memoir
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Advice of Youth
text: BABY boomers are facing a new generation gap. But this time, they are the ones on the older side of the divide, at least when it comes to planning their financial futures.

headline: Five Diamonds, and Headed to World Mind Sports Games
text: The trial to select the women’s team to represent the United States in the first World Mind Sports Games ended on Tuesday in Raleigh, N.C.

headline: Legitimizing Marijuana
text: JANE WELLS of CNBC keeps a blog called Funny Business, but her recent reports on California’s medical marijuana industry are about a business that is increasingly being taken seriously. They amount to a short primer on how the business works and how the operators of the state’s estimated 500 dispensaries deal with the high risks and high costs of working in a legal gray area (cnbc.com).

headline: Before the Hunt, a Lesson With a High Flier
text: I WADED into the pitiless mid-May sun with a falconer and one of her favorite birds of prey. The grassy meadow in front of the British School of Falconry at the Equinox resort in Manchester Village, Vt., bloomed with yellow dandelions.

headline: Rift Develops Among Investors in Russian Gas Venture
text: MOSCOW  BP, the huge British oil company, on Friday rejected demands from a group of Russian billionaires to fire the head of the lucrative TNK-BP natural gas venture, deepening a confrontation between shareholders as the country’s biggest state-controlled oil companies seek a stake in the venture.

headline: From Britain, a Trove of Glittering Prizes
text: Not every exhibition has to be more than the sum of its parts, especially when the parts are as gratifying as those making up “Medieval and Renaissance Treasures From the Victoria and Albert Museum” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a ruling by the Texas Supreme Court against the seizure of 468 children from a polygamist ranch misspelled the name of an elder and spokesman of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. He is Willie Jessop, not Jessup.

headline: Kicking Back With Kiss
text: It is unclear whether they discussed makeup, but on Thursday in Stockholm, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice had a late-night meeting with the rock group Kiss. Ms. Rice was in Sweden for an international conference concerning Iraq; the band was there to play a sold-out concert and asked to meet her. After a dinner with Carl Bildt, the Swedish foreign minister, Ms. Rice joined Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley, Eric Singer and Tommy Thayer in the executive lounge of the Sheraton Hotel, where they signed autographs and gave T-shirts to her staff. “It was really fun” to meet them, Ms. Rice said, according to The Associated Press, adding that they seemed well informed about politics. Though she said she had never seen the band perform, she named “Rock and Roll All Nite” as her favorite Kiss song.

headline: Democrats Debate Seating Delegates From Two States
text: WASHINGTON  A Democratic Party committee tried Saturday to resolve the disputes over primary votes in Florida and Michigan, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign calling for the delegations to be seated essentially as if there had been no questions about the validity of the contests and Senator Barack Obama’s campaign for the first time laying out its proposal for a portion of the delegates to be seated.

headline: Norway: Teachers and Health Workers Strike
text: Nearly 5,000 Norwegian teachers and health workers walked off the job, joining 3,300 others who had been on strike since Monday in a dispute over pay. What began as a narrowly focused action is likely to escalate further next week, according to Anders Folkestad, head of the Confederation of Unions for Professionals, about half of whose 270,000 members are teachers. The teachers’ strike has already affected nearly 30,000 students.

headline: Paying Off the Debts That Seem Unshakeable
A Lifetime Amid the Lox and Rugelach
text: Nowadays, most tales of longstanding and beloved family businesses in New York seem to end with a sniff and a final mop of the floor. But as Zabar’s, the venerable West Side purveyor of New York noshes, approaches its 75th anniversary next year, it is flourishing and still very much in the family. Overseeing aisles of smoked fish, a United Nations worth of cheeses, and the iconic coffee and rugelach is the firm’s president, Saul Zabar, who will celebrate the 75th anniversary of his 5th birthday next week.

headline: Profiles of Speed and Power
text: In Saturday’s Times, Joshua Robinson profiles Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt, who has come out of nowhere this year and established himself as perhaps the fastest man in the world. Also, Mike Tierney looks at how Cheryl Haworth, no longer a media novelty, remains a brute force on the lifting stage.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 90 Stanford
text: Location: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Football Is War! (George Carlin’s Routine)
text: A couple of days ago, we posted a well-written and sharply argued comment from a reader: Football Is Not War

headline: Getting to Know … Graham Motion
text: Inspired by the clever American Express print ads featuring celebrities such as Tina Fey and Larry David, I thought we’d try a low-budget version for The Rail. First up is Graham Motion, trainer of the Belmont contender and third-place Preakness finisher Icabad Crane. Motion, 44, was born into a racing family (his father a bloodstock agent; his mother an amateur jockey) in Cambridge, England, and now resides in Fair Hill, Md., with his wife, Anita, and his two children, Jane and Marcus. He is ranked 13th on the 2008 earning’s list ($2,542,037), with 50 wins in 237 starts.

headline: How I Spent My Stimulus Check
text: Some of the odder postings at howispentmystimulus.com (names withheld here; site includes accompanying photos):

headline: Bark Lark
text: Fun with trees found here.

headline: The Early Word: All Eyes on the D.N.C.
text: The Rules and Bylaws Committee of the Democratic Party meets today in Washington to consider a question that has loomed large over the primary season – what to do about the Democratic delegates from the states of Florida and Michigan.

headline: Democrats Meet Over Fla., Mich. in Late-Night Session
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic Party officials met privately for five and a half hours late Friday night to discuss the Michigan and Florida delegations to the party’s convention but did not resolve their differences.

headline: A Local Immigration Crackdown
text: Sheriff Wendell Hall of Santa Rosa County, Fla., uses false-documentation laws to round up illegal immigrants.

headline: Outside the D.N.C. Meeting
text: WASHINGTON — A raucous crowd of several hundred gathered outside a Washington hotel where the rules committee of the Democratic Party is poised to make a decision about the seating of delegates from Florida and Michigan.

headline: Frowning on Big Brown
text: Not everybody in thoroughbred racing is giddy over the prospect of a Big Brown Triple Crown.

headline: Where have I seen that dress before?
text: This week for the New York premiere of “Sex and the City,” Sarah Jessica Parker wore a strapless Nina Ricci gown designed by Olivier Theyskens. It was one of 40 outfits that Parker planned for the movie’s premieres in London and Berlin, and the press junkets. She looked glamorous and happy in the dress and was asked several times by reporters on the red carpet if it was the sort of dress that Carrie Bradshaw would have worn. New Yorkers have no trouble seeing SJP as Carrie, and given the TV show’s name-dropping familiarity with the fashion world, what she wore to the opening was bound to get attention. It had to be stand-out.

headline: The Morning Skate: Sour Grapes, Melrose Place and Oilers=Man U?
text: Tonight one of the largest Canadian TV audiences of the year will scurry back from their refrigerators and bathroom breaks during the first intermission of Stanley Cup final Game 4 to absorb the words of Don Cherry. His Coach’s Corner segment on Hockey Night in Canada remains hugely popular and has made Cherry probably the most recognizable person in the country.

headline: Blog Roll: Things We Should Know
text: Our friends in the Thoroughbred Bloggers Alliance have first-rate posts up about the past, the present and the future.

headline: Embedded vs. non-embedded inflation
text: The big economic debate of the moment is whether the Fed and its peers have made a terrible mistake by focusing on staving off financial crisis while more or less ignoring the rise of inflation. “Inflation is rising and it seems the world’s central banks have critically misjudged the situation,” says Wolfgang Munchau in the FT. I’ve heard even more apocalyptic views from some serious people in the last couple of weeks.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 31:

headline: The World Science Festival: Behind Disney’s Magic
text: Disney teamed up with the World Science Festival on Saturday with a show about the science that goes into that old Disney magic. Like most Disney productions, it was very professional and very kid-friendly. Of course the show also doubled as a giant advertisement for Disney theme parks, but I guess that comes with the territory.

headline: ‘One Big Puerto Rican Day Parade’
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — “Campaigning in Puerto Rico is like one big Puerto Rican Day parade,” Hillary Rodham Clinton told an audience at a San Juan clinic Saturday. (And as the senator from New York, Mrs. Clinton knows her Puerto Rican Day parades — a festive mega-party up Fifth Avenue every year that attracts New York City’s population of Puerto Ricans by the thousands.)

headline: It’s Latin to Us
text: Laugh Lines’s knowledge of Latin is limited to time daydreaming in the pews (the old joke: What’s God’s phone number? Et cum spiri 2-2-0). So we cannot vouch for the translations below (found here):

headline: Some Missions Are Just Funnier Than Others
text: Much has been made of the need to fix a malfunctioning toilet aboard the International Space Station. Toilets are, of course, comedy gold. And space toilets? More golden still. So news organizations have had a great deal of fun at NASA’s expense lately.

headline: On the Road: Obama at Rushmore, Too
text: Late Friday evening, Barack Obama had a perhaps strategic change of tourist heart. A bus full of campaign reporters had decided to pay an end of the day visit to Mount Rushmore and the candidate was rumored to be a no-show.

headline: Art and Glitz in Moscow
text: Moscow’s glitterati, dripping in oil wealth, were at it again this week, celebrating art with a big party, this time at the Manezh exhibition hall at the foot of the Kremlin wall.

headline: Obama Quits His Church
text: WASHINGTON – Senator Barack Obama is ending his membership at Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago, a congregation he has belonged to for about two decades and one that had become a lightning rod in his Democratic presidential bid.

headline: Casino Drive Has Big Brown in His Sights
text: In an article for Sunday’s Times, Joe Drape writes that many expect Casino Drive, a chestnut colt whose stamina has been leisurely built, to be a formidable obstacle on Big Brown’s path to become the 12th Triple Crown champion.

headline: Belmont News: Saturday
text: Big Brown’s left front foot continues to progress. It is now equipped with a new set of stainless steel wires that are holding together the quarter crack. Big Brown galloped this morning at Belmont Park.

headline: D.N.C. Cuts Fla., Mich. Votes in Half
text: 7:45 p.m. | Rules Wrap Up: After a nearly 10-hour marathon meeting of the Democratic party’s rules committee, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton came away with a total of 24 more pledged delegates, but today’s decisions on the seating of Florida and Michigan delegates fell far short of what her campaign had hoped.
